{"plague": [{"archive_id": "7926602", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Congo DR (11): (IT)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7926602", "date": "2020-11-08 18:39:49", "main_text": "PLAGUE - CONGO DR (11): (ITURI)\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 8 Nov 2020\nFrom: Anne Laudisoit <laudisoit@ecohealthalliance.org> [edited]\n\n\nA new outbreak of suspected bubonic plague was reported on 29 Oct 2020 from the Aungba health zone located in the Mahagi territory, Ituri province, in northeastern DR Congo. The area is located in the most active endemic plague focus in continental Africa and borders the West Nile plague endemic focus in Uganda.\n\nOn 29 Oct 2020, the head nurse of the health area of Avari alerted the central office of the chief medical doctor of Aungba about 4 community deaths in the village Amoli, close to the Ugandan border. On 30 Oct 2020, the supervision team of the Aungba health zone carried out an outbreak investigation and recorded 7 cases of bubonic plague including 4 deaths.\n\nThe index cases appear to be 2 boys aged 13 and 10 years old from the same family residing in Amoli, who died between 26 and 27 Oct 2020; both presented a clinical prognosis consistent with the definition of bubonic plague, i.e. high fever with sudden onset, headache and painful swelling in the armpits. The other 2 deceased persons are 2 girls, aged 14 and 13 years belonging to another family from a household located close to the presumed index cases.\n\nThe inhabitants of Amoli have reported domestic and peri-domestic murine epizootics (rat falls) in the week preceding the appearance of the 1st human cases.\n\nThe investigation team searched for other cases in the area, which led to the discovery of 3 other active suspected bubonic plague cases, which were treated at the nearest health center. In addition, 26 contacts were treated preventively with doxycycline (100 mg), and the 2 houses where the deaths occurred were dusted with deltamethrin to control potentially infected fleas.\n\nThis is the 8th plague outbreak reported in less than a year from the plague endemic focus in the DR Congo.\n\n--\nPascal Adroba, MD\nProvincial Division of Health\nIturi, DR Congo\n\nDelphonse Unenall, MD\nAungba Health Zone Chief MD\nIturi, DR Congo\n\nAnne Laudisoit, PhD\nEcohealth Alliance\n<laudisoit@ecohealthalliance.org>\n\n[Most cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. The swollen gland is called a bubo. Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2 to 6 days after being bitten.\n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. The bacteremia can also occur as an initial event. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antibiotic therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. - Mod.LL]\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr. Anne Laudisoit and colleagues for sending this report. - Mod.ML\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map:\nIturi, DR Congo: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/34771]", "summary": "\n\n--\nPascal Adroba, MD\nProvincial Division of Health\nIturi, DR Congo\n\nDelphonse Unenall, MD\nAungba Health Zone Chief MD\nIturi, DR Congo\n\nAnne Laudisoit, PhD\nEcohealth Alliance\n< A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The index cases appear to be 2 boys aged 13 and 10 years old from the same family residing in Amoli, who died between 26 and 27 Oct 2020; both presented a clinical prognosis consistent with the definition of bubonic plague, i.e. high fever with sudden onset, headache and painful swelling in the armpits. \n\nThe investigation team searched for other cases in the area, which led to the discovery of 3 other active suspected bubonic plague cases, which were treated at the nearest health center. laudisoit@ecohealthalliance.org>\n\n[Most cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. \n\nThis is the 8th plague outbreak reported in less than a year from the plague endemic focus in the DR Congo. \n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. On 30 Oct 2020, the supervision team of the Aungba health zone carried out an outbreak investigation and recorded 7 cases of bubonic plague including 4 deaths. Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2020-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the DR Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "DR", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Adroba", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Amoli", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "8250540", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Madagascar: bubonic", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=8250540", "date": "2021-03-20 20:00:42", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR: BUBONIC\n****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 15 Mar 2021 12:56 p.m. UTC\nSource: Garda World [edited]\nhttps://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/455181/madagascar-plague-activity-reported-in-multiple-districts-of-madagascar-through-march\n\n\nFrom 1 Jan 2021-11 Mar 2021, at least 21 confirmed cases of bubonic plague have been confirmed in Madagascar; 8 of these cases were reported since 1 Mar 2021 in Amoron'i Mania (Ambositra and Manandriana). Since the start of the year [2021], 37 suspected cases have been reported, affecting multiple regions, including Alaotra-Mangoro, Analamanga, Haute Matsiatra, and Itasy. Roughly 9 deaths have been associated with this disease activity. This represents the most complete data available as of 12 Mar 2021.\n\nPlague is endemic to Madagascar, where 200-700 cases are reported each year, primarily the bubonic form. The risk of plague spreading to humans is elevated in Madagascar, where the fleas that transmit the disease are highly resistant to insecticide. The poor state of Madagascar's public health system and limited access to healthcare in rural areas may also facilitate the spread of the disease.\n\nPlague is caused by a bacterium that is usually transmitted through the bite of an infected flea. However, an infection can also occur through direct contact with tissues or fluids from infected animals, such as a scratch or bite. Bubonic plague occurs when the bacteria infect a person's lymph nodes. This form of plague is not easily transmissible from person to person. However, when the bacteria spread through the bloodstream to the lungs, pneumonic plague can transmit directly from person to person via respiratory droplets containing the plague bacteria. Symptoms of plague generally develop 1-7 days after exposure. All forms of plague cause nondescript symptoms, such as fever, chills, and extreme weakness. Symptoms of bubonic plague also include swollen, tender, and painful lymph nodes and symptoms of pneumonic plague include pneumonia with shortness of breath, chest pain, and cough.\n\nConsult a travel medicine provider before departure regarding plague vaccination. Practice basic health precautions. Avoid flea bites. Seek medical attention if symptoms develop within a week of being in affected areas.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague infections in Madagascar have been relatively quiet since the dramatic outbreak in 2017.\n\nThe following paragraph is from Chanteau S, Ratsifasoamanana L, Rasoamanana B, et al.: Plague, a reemerging disease in Madagascar. Emerg Infect Dis. 1998; 4(1): 101-4; PMID: 9452403; available at http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/4/1/98-0114_article.htm:\n\n'Human cases of plague, which had virtually disappeared in Madagascar after the 1930s, reappeared in 1990 with more than 200 confirmed or presumptive cases reported each year since. In the port of Mahajanga, plague has been reintroduced, and epidemics occur every year. In Antananarivo, the capital, the number of new cases has increased, and many rodents are infected with Yersinia pestis. Despite surveillance for the sensitivity of Y. pestis and fleas to drugs and insecticides and control measures to prevent the spread of sporadic cases, the elimination of plague has been difficult because the host and reservoir of the bacillus, Rattus rattus, is both a domestic and a sylvatic rat.'\n\nFatalities related to plague usually are caused by spread of the organism from the bubo (the very painful infected lymph node that drains the area where the flea bite occurred) to the bloodstream. The bacteremia can cause a coagulopathy, producing the purpura seen in the 'black plague,' and also may spread to the lungs causing a hemorrhagic pneumonia. It is the pneumonia that can facilitate person-to-person transmission.\n\nMadagascar was the location of the isolation of multi-antimicrobial resistant _Yersinia pestis_ in 1995 (Galimand M, Guiyoule A, Gerbaud G, et al.: Multidrug resistance in _Yersinia pestis_ mediated by a transferable plasmid. N Engl J Med. 1997; 337(10): 677-80, PMID: 9278464; http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJM199709043371004). The strain was resistant to chloramphenicol, streptomycin, and tetracycline but sensitive to fluoroquinolones and trimethoprim as well as other aminoglycosides. This was an ominous observation; however, it is not clear whether this naturally occurring strain has persisted or spread. - Mod.LL\n\nMaps of Madagascar: https://www.worldometers.info/maps/madagascar-political-map/ and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/181]", "summary": "Emerg Infect Dis. 1998; 4(1): 101-4; PMID: 9452403; available at http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/4/1/98-0114_article.htm:\n\n'Human cases of plague, which had virtually disappeared in Madagascar after the 1930s, reappeared in 1990 with more than 200 confirmed or presumptive cases reported each year since. From 1 Jan 2021-11 Mar 2021, at least 21 confirmed cases of bubonic plague have been confirmed in Madagascar; 8 of these cases were reported since 1 Mar 2021 in Amoron'i Mania (Ambositra and Manandriana). However, when the bacteria spread through the bloodstream to the lungs, pneumonic plague can transmit directly from person to person via respiratory droplets containing the plague bacteria. Symptoms of bubonic plague also include swollen, tender, and painful lymph nodes and symptoms of pneumonic plague include pneumonia with shortness of breath, chest pain, and cough. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nFatalities related to plague usually are caused by spread of the organism from the bubo (the very painful infected lymph node that drains the area where the flea bite occurred) to the bloodstream. Despite surveillance for the sensitivity of Y. pestis and fleas to drugs and insecticides and control measures to prevent the spread of sporadic cases, the elimination of plague has been difficult because the host and reservoir of the bacillus, Rattus rattus, is both a domestic and a sylvatic rat.' Plague is endemic to Madagascar, where 200-700 cases are reported each year, primarily the bubonic form. PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR: BUBONIC\n****************************\n The bacteremia can cause a coagulopathy, producing the purpura seen in the 'black plague,' and also may spread to the lungs causing a hemorrhagic pneumonia. Bubonic plague occurs when the bacteria infect a person's lymph nodes. This form of plague is not easily transmissible from person to person. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague infections in Madagascar have been relatively quiet since the dramatic outbreak in 2017.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1997-03-25 00:00:00", "1998-03-25 00:00:00", "1990-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "1995-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Rasoamanana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Analamanga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mahajanga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mania", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "8189569", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (01): (NM) cat", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=8189569", "date": "2021-02-13 22:13:42", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (01): (NEW MEXICO) CAT\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 11 Feb 2021\nSource: Los Alamos Reporter [edited]\nhttps://losalamosreporter.com/2021/02/11/cat-diagnosed-with-plague-in-los-alamos-county/\n\n\nThe New Mexico Department of Health (NMDOH) reports a cat has been diagnosed with plague in Los Alamos County, making it the 1st plague case in New Mexico this year [2021].\n\n'NMDOH staff will conduct an environmental investigation to ensure the safety of the immediate family and neighbors,' said Secretary-Designate Dr. Tracie Collins. 'We also offer a friendly reminder: even in the midst of a global pandemic, other diseases still occur in New Mexico, and there are steps people can take to keep themselves and their pets safe.'\n\nThe cat, which became ill in early January [2021], has now recovered following veterinary treatment.\n\nPlague is a bacterial disease in wildlife and is generally transmitted to pets through the bites of infected fleas or after eating an infected animal. Humans can also contract plague via infected fleas or direct contact with infected animals.\n\nSymptoms of plague in humans include sudden onset of fever, chills, headache, and weakness. In most cases there is a painful swelling of the lymph node in the groin, armpit, or neck area. Plague symptoms in cats and dogs are fever, lethargy, and loss of appetite; there may be swelling in the lymph nodes under the jaw. With prompt diagnosis and appropriate antibiotic treatment, the probability of death in people and pets can be greatly reduced. Physicians or veterinarians who suspect plague should promptly report to NMDOH.\n\nTo prevent plague,\n- avoid sick or dead rodents and rabbits, as well as their nests and burrows;\n- prevent your pets from roaming and hunting;\n- talk to your veterinarian about using an appropriate flea control product on your pets;\n- have any sick pets examined promptly by a veterinarian;\n- contact your medical provider about any unexplained illness involving a sudden and severe fever;\n- clean up areas near the home where rodents could live, such as woodpiles, brush piles, junk, and abandoned vehicles;\n- place hay, wood, and compost piles as far as possible from your home;\n- avoid leaving pet food and water where rodents and wildlife can access it.\n\nFor more information, including fact sheets in English and Spanish, go to the Department of Health's website at https://nmhealth.org/about/erd/ideb/zdp/plg.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations. Surveillance efforts testing fleas are very important to detect circulation of _Y. pestis_ and risk of infection.\n\nPlague may infect human beings through several routes: 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals (mentioned previously); 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues, generally from an animal; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals.\n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under the jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front leg (the armpit, if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever (or chills). These clinical signs may be present in the dog as well. Swelling under the jaw in cats is frequently mistaken as a cat-fight abscess. When this mistake occurs and the caregiver or veterinarian does not take precautions, such as exam gloves, the swelling may rupture on palpation and possibly expose the owner or the veterinarian though even small scratches on the hands or cuticles of the fingers.\n\nThis cat is clearly an indication that the _Y. pestis_ bacteria is circulating in the area's fleas.\n\nIf your pets are not on flea prevention, please ask your veterinarian about the best flea prevention. Bathing your pet in dishwashing soap is not sufficient to help your pet avoid diseases carried by fleas. Some of the over-the-counter flea prevention products may be harmful to your pet, so please check with your veterinarian. It is also a good time to make sure your pet is current on a rabies shot.\n\nKeeping your pets inside is best, and being inside a yard will help diminish your pet's ability to consume a dead animal and will further reduce the risk of plague to both you and your animal. - Mod.TG\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map:\nLos Alamos County, New Mexico, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/7430]", "summary": "\n\nTo prevent plague,\n- avoid sick or dead rodents and rabbits, as well as their nests and burrows;\n- prevent your pets from roaming and hunting;\n- talk to your veterinarian about using an appropriate flea control product on your pets;\n- have any sick pets examined promptly by a veterinarian;\n- contact your medical provider about any unexplained illness involving a sudden and severe fever;\n- clean up areas near the home where rodents could live, such as woodpiles, brush piles, junk, and abandoned vehicles;\n- place hay, wood, and compost piles as far as possible from your home;\n- avoid leaving pet food and water where rodents and wildlife can access it. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. Plague may infect human beings through several routes: 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals (mentioned previously); 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues, generally from an animal; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals. \n\nKeeping your pets inside is best, and being inside a yard will help diminish your pet's ability to consume a dead animal and will further reduce the risk of plague to both you and your animal. \n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under the jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front leg (the armpit, if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever (or chills). Plague is a bacterial disease in wildlife and is generally transmitted to pets through the bites of infected fleas or after eating an infected animal. \n\nIf your pets are not on flea prevention, please ask your veterinarian about the best flea prevention. (NEW MEXICO) CAT\n***********************************\n TG\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map:\nLos Alamos County, New Mexico, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/7430] \n\nSymptoms of plague in humans include sudden onset of fever, chills, headache, and weakness. \n\n--\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "rabies"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2021-02-11 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Los Alamos County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7820677", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Mongolia (08): (HD) bubonic, marmot exposure", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7820677", "date": "2020-09-28 21:25:29", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MONGOLIA (08): (HOVD) BUBONIC, MARMOT EXPOSURE\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 27 Sep 2020\nSource: XinHuaNet [edited]\nhttp://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2020-09/27/c_139401224.htm\n\n\nA suspected case of bubonic plague in western Mongolia's Khovd (or Hovd) province has been confirmed by lab test results, the country's National Center for Zoonotic Diseases (NCZD) said on Sun 27 Sep 2020.\n\nThe 25-year-old female patient from the province and 19 people in close contact with her are now under isolation at a local hospital, the NCZD said in a statement. The center said the woman was found to have eaten marmot meat last week. While hunting marmots is illegal in Mongolia, many Mongolians regard the rodent as a delicacy and ignore the law.\n\nSince the beginning of 2020, the Asian country has reported 22 suspected cases, 6 of which were confirmed by laboratory tests. Three of the 6 patients have died. 17 out of all the 21 Mongolian provinces are now at risk of the bubonic plague, the NCZD said, urging the public to avoid eating marmot meat.\n\nThe bubonic plague is a bacterial disease spread by fleas living on wild rodents such as marmots and can kill an adult in less than 24 hours if not treated in time, according to the WHO.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is caused by _Yersinia pestis_. Plague appears to be more prevalent this year (2020) in Mongolia. It is not clear that person-to-person spread has occurred.\n\nMost cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea, causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. The swollen gland is called a 'bubo.' Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2-6 days after being bitten.\n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated or sometimes without having a preceding bubo, plague bacteria can invade the bloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antimicrobial therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. At this stage, person-to-person spread can occur, causing other cases of 'primary' plague pneumonia. A quarantine would be required with contact tracing and even prophylactic antimicrobials if the index case or cases actually had plague pneumonia.\n\nPlague is endemic in Mongolia. Marmots such as the Tarvaga, the Tarbagan or Mongolian marmot, _Marmota sibirica_, a large rodent related to the American woodchuck (_M. monax_), are thought to be significant zoonotic reservoirs for _Y. pestis_ in Eastern Asia. The name marmot comes from French marmotte, from Latin _mures monti_ 'mountain mouse'.\n\nWhile foodborne transmission of _Y. pestis_ has been described (such as Leslie T, et al. Outbreak of gastroenteritis caused by _Yersinia pestis_ in Afghanistan. Epidemiol Infect. 2011; 139(5): 728-35; https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20663260), it is far more likely that the bubonic plague cases were acquired via the bites of infected fleas. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map:\nMongolia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. \n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated or sometimes without having a preceding bubo, plague bacteria can invade the bloodstream. \n\nMost cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea, causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. PLAGUE - MONGOLIA (08): (HOVD) BUBONIC, MARMOT EXPOSURE\n*******************************************************\n A suspected case of bubonic plague in western Mongolia's Khovd (or Hovd) province has been confirmed by lab test results, the country's National Center for Zoonotic Diseases (NCZD) said on Sun 27 Sep 2020. The bubonic plague is a bacterial disease spread by fleas living on wild rodents such as marmots and can kill an adult in less than 24 hours if not treated in time, according to the WHO. 2011; 139(5): 728-35; https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20663260), it is far more likely that the bubonic plague cases were acquired via the bites of infected fleas. At this stage, person-to-person spread can occur, causing other cases of 'primary' plague pneumonia. 17 out of all the 21 Mongolian provinces are now at risk of the bubonic plague, the NCZD said, urging the public to avoid eating marmot meat. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2-6 days after being bitten.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2020-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Tarbagan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Afghanistan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mongolia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "8211886", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Congo DR: (IT) fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=8211886", "date": "2021-02-25 13:08:39", "main_text": "PLAGUE - DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF CONGO: (ITURI) FATAL\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 19 Feb 2021\nSource: Barron's, Agence France-Presse (AFP) report [edited]\nhttps://www.barrons.com/news/31-dead-in-dr-congo-plague-outbreak-01613736004\n\n\nHealth officials and experts said on Friday [19 Feb 2021]. 31 people have died in an outbreak of plague that erupted in northeastern Congo DR 3 months ago, 'We have more than 520 cases... of which more than 31 have been fatal,' Patrick Karamura, health minister in Ituri province, where plague is endemic, told AFP. The cases are the bubonic form of the disease, except for 5 cases of pneumonic plague and 2 of septicaemic plague, he said.\n\nAnne Laudisoit, an epidemiologist with a New York-based NGO called Ecohealth Alliance, said the cases had surfaced between [15 Nov 2020] and [13 Dec 2020] in Biringi, in Ituri's Aru Territory. The average age of patients was 13, but this varied between 3 months and 73 years, she said. The WHO issued an alert in July 2020 of a plague outbreak in Rethy, also in Ituri.\n\nPlague has persisted in the province since it was first confirmed there in 1926. A long-feared disease with biblical connotations, but treatable today with antimicrobials, the plague is caused by a bacterium called _Yersinia pestis_.\n\nLaudisoit, who is in the area with a team of researchers, said an early sign of the latest outbreak came with the mass death of rats. Germ-carrying fleas which live in the rats' fur then look for other hosts in proximity, which are humans. The bacterium is then transmitted through flea bites.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED Rapporteur Kunihiko Iizuka\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea, causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. The swollen gland is called a bubo. Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2-6 days after being bitten.\n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. The bacteremia can also occur as an initial event. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antibiotic therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map of Congo DR: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/34771]", "summary": "31 people have died in an outbreak of plague that erupted in northeastern Congo DR 3 months ago, 'We have more than 520 cases... of which more than 31 have been fatal,' Patrick Karamura, health minister in Ituri province, where plague is endemic, told AFP. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The cases are the bubonic form of the disease, except for 5 cases of pneumonic plague and 2 of septicaemic plague, he said. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea, causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. \n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. A long-feared disease with biblical connotations, but treatable today with antimicrobials, the plague is caused by a bacterium called _Yersinia pestis_. \n\nAnne Laudisoit, an epidemiologist with a New York-based NGO called Ecohealth Alliance, said the cases had surfaced between [15 Nov 2020] and [13 Dec 2020] in Biringi, in Ituri's Aru Territory. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2-6 days after being bitten. If plague patients are not given specific antibiotic therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. It is caused by a fungus _Aphanomyces astaci_ that was brought into Europe by the introduction of _Procambarus clarkii_, a freshwater crayfish species from Louisiana, USA, which is naturally infected by this pathogen although it does not develop clinical disease.\n\nThe white-clawed crayfish, or European freshwater crayfish (_Austropotamobius pallipes_), is an endangered species. positive\n\nFuture reporting\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2020-09-02 00:00:00", "2020-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Italy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Udine", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Padova", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rome", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Friuli - Venezia Giulia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cavazzo Carnico", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7772408", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (06): (CO) human, cat exposure", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7772408", "date": "2020-09-12 17:36:50", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (06): (COLORADO) HUMAN, CAT EXPOSURE\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 8 Sep 2020\nSource Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/colorado-reports-2nd-human-plague-case-of-2020/\n\n\nThe Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment is reporting the 2nd case of human plague in the state during this summer [2020]. The case, reported to the department on 3 Sep [2020], is a resident from a rural county in Colorado. The 1st case was diagnosed earlier this summer in a resident from southwest Colorado. The cases are unrelated. Both cases had exposure to sick animals: a squirrel and a cat [respectively]. Neither case is suspected of having spread the infection to other people or animals. These are the 1st cases of human plague reported in the state since 2015. In the past 10 years, there have been 14 cases of human plague in Colorado.\n\nEarlier this year [2020], plague bacteria were confirmed in rodents in Broomfield, Jefferson, and Adams counties as well as a cat in Elbert County.\n\nCDPHE reminds residents that it is not uncommon for plague to be seen this time of year, but it can also be found in rodents year-round. It sometimes spills over into other wildlife species as well as domestic cats and dogs.\n\nPeople should take the following precautions to protect themselves and their pets:\n- Do not directly handle any wildlife.\n- Keep pets away from wildlife, especially dead rodents and rabbits.\n- Don't let dogs or cats hunt prairie dogs, squirrels, voles, other rodents, or rabbits.\n- Don't allow pets to roam freely.\n- Treat all pets for fleas according to a veterinarian's advice.\n- If your pet develops a sudden illness after contact with wildlife, call a veterinarian immediately.\n- Do not feed wildlife. This attracts them to your property, brings them in close contact, and increases the risk of disease transmission.\n- Do not attempt to remove or kill prairie dogs. This may increase the risk of plague for you and your domestic animals.\n- Be aware of rodent and rabbit populations in your area and report sudden die-offs or multiple dead animals to your local health department.\n\nPlague is most commonly spread to people by the bite of an infected flea but also may be transmitted by infected animal tissues, fluids, or respiratory droplets. Infected fleas may be found near areas where multiple rodents or rabbits have died; avoiding these areas and not allowing pets or other animals to explore these areas will decrease the risk of getting plague. Citizens with direct exposure to fleas or wildlife in the affected areas may be at risk. People who think they have been exposed should contact a healthcare provider immediately. Symptoms include sudden fever, headache, chills, weakness, and tender, painful lymph nodes. While there are no publicly available vaccines to prevent plague in people, if caught early, it can be successfully treated with antimicrobials in both people and pets.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The typical sign of the most common form of human plague is a swollen and very tender lymph gland, accompanied by pain. The swollen gland is called a 'bubo.' Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2-6 days after being infected.\n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated or occurring without a bubo (which makes the diagnosis more difficult to make initially), plague bacteria invade the bloodstream (septicemic plague). As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antimicrobial therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. About 14% (one in 7) of all plague cases in the United States are fatal (https://portal.ct.gov/-/media/Departments-and-Agencies/DPH/dph/communications/CERC/PlagueFSwebpdf.pdf).\n\nThe clinical manifestations of the human case and those of the cat are not stated here. Clinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under the jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front leg (the armpit, if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever. These clinical signs may be present in the dog as well. Swelling under the jaw in cats is frequently mistaken as a cat-fight abscess. If one lives in a plague-endemic area, please take your pet to a veterinarian if you notice any abnormalities.\n\nBe sure to consult your veterinarian if you find a lump on your pet, as well as to get the best flea prevention treatment for your pet. It may be necessary to have your yard and/or home treated for fleas. Vacuum your home, including any bedding and furniture, and immediately upon finishing take the vacuum back outside, seal it in a plastic bag, and dispose of it. This type of cleaning will have to be repeated every week for 4-6 weeks to break the cycle of the flea in the home. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map:\nColorado, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/209]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The typical sign of the most common form of human plague is a swollen and very tender lymph gland, accompanied by pain. \n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated or occurring without a bubo (which makes the diagnosis more difficult to make initially), plague bacteria invade the bloodstream (septicemic plague). Infected fleas may be found near areas where multiple rodents or rabbits have died; avoiding these areas and not allowing pets or other animals to explore these areas will decrease the risk of getting plague. From [11 Jun to 9 Aug 2020], a total of 73 cases with 10 deaths (CFR 13.6%) were notified in 5 out of 22 health areas of Rethy health zone.\n\nPlague is endemic in Ituri province. Since the beginning of 2020 to date [Tue 20 Oct 2020], Ituri Province has reported a total of 124 cases and 17 deaths (CFR 18.7%) in 5 health zones, namely Aungba, Linga, Rethy, Aru, Logo and Kambala. In 2019, from week 1 to 52, a total of 48 cases of bubonic plague including 8 deaths have been reported in the country.\n\nPlague is an infectious disease caused by the bacterium, _Yersinia pestis_. It is found in animals throughout the world, most commonly rats but other rodents like ground squirrels, prairie dogs, chipmunks, rabbits and, in China, marmots. Fleas typically serve as the vector for plague. People can also get infected through direct contact with an infected animal, through inhalation and in the case of pneumonic plague, person to person.\n\n_Yersinia pestis_ is treatable with antimicrobials if started early enough.\n\nThere are 3 forms of human plague; bubonic, septicemic and pneumonic.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. The swollen gland is called a bubo. Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2 to 6 days after being bitten.\n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. The bacteremia can also occur as an initial event. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antibiotic therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map:\nDR Congo: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/194]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. People can also get infected through direct contact with an infected animal, through inhalation and in the case of pneumonic plague, person to person. Local government activated a Level IV public health emergency response.\n\nAccording to reports, a village that is a 3-hour drive from the Menghai County seat recently found 3 rodents dead of unknown cause. The township government immediately reported to the county disease prevention and control center. The provincial level disease prevention and treatment institute and the state level disease control center's on-site epidemiological survey and lab results led to preliminary conclusions on 21 Sep 2020 that rodent plague had occurred in Xiding.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Dan Silver\n\n[The specific rodent involved is not stated.\n\nPlague is caused by _Yersinia pestis_. Plague appears to be more prevalent this year (2020) in Mongolia. It is not clear that person-to-person spread has occurred.\n\nMost cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea, causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. The swollen gland is called a 'bubo.' Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2-6 days after being bitten. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nYunnan Province, China: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/351]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n\nOn 25 Sep 2020, the Plague Command Post of Yunnan's Menghai County reported an outbreak of plague among rodents in a remote village of Xiding Township, and following a proactive search, a suspected case of bubonic plague was found in a 3-year-old child who is now undergoing treatment. The provincial level disease prevention and treatment institute and the state level disease control center's on-site epidemiological survey and lab results led to preliminary conclusions on 21 Sep 2020 that rodent plague had occurred in Xiding. Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. \n\nMost cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea, causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. Date: Fri 25 Sep 2020 22:58 CST\nSource: China News [in Chinese, translated DG, abridged, edited]\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2020-09-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2020-03-25 00:00:00", "2020-09-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yunnan Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "YUNNAN", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CHINA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Xiding", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yunnan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Menghai County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Xiding Township", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "8061711", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Congo DR (12): (IT)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=8061711", "date": "2020-12-31 17:00:02", "main_text": "PLAGUE - DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF CONGO (12): (ITURI)\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 31 Dec 2020\nFrom: Anne Laudisoit <laudisoit@ecohealthalliance.org> [edited]\n\n\nDR Congo confirmed bubonic plague (more than 200 cases)\n-------------------------------------------------------\nBetween 15 Nov 2020 and 13 Dec 2020, the Biringi health zone, located in the territory of Aru, Ituri province, DR Congo, reported 151 suspected cases of bubonic plague with 5 deaths (case fatality rate [CFR] 3.3%).\n\nOn 22 Nov 2020, the head nurse of the Kumbuku health center (trained in plague outbreak investigation while working in Aru health zone) diagnosed plague in an 11 year old boy brought in as an emergency to the health center by his family in an altered general status (coma, high fever, and bilateral swelling of axillary lymph nodes). The boy passed away a couple of minutes later. Alerted by this event, the head nurse visited the household of the deceased patient in the Onuoyia village (N 02 deg 48'13.1', E 030 deg 29'33.2'') to investigate further. He found that the 6 year old brother of the patient had similar symptoms without complication (consistent with the case definition for suspected bubonic plague - see further) and recovered after a 10-day treatment with trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole. However, a member of the network of volunteer community relay (RECO, or relais communautaire) notified the head nurse that on 15 Nov 2020 an 11 year old girl from the same family living in a neighboring household also died in a clinical picture of chills, headache, and painful lymph node swelling behind the ear. The parents treated the child for malaria, with no improvement. The girl identified as the index case died in the community on 15 Nov 2020.\n\nOn 27 Nov 2020, a 3 year old girl of the mother's family, who attended the funeral wake of the index case, presented with fever, painful swelling of the left axillary lymph node, and abdominal pain. She was treated at home for malaria, again, by the parent, with no improvement. The girl died on the 29 Nov 2020. The experienced head nurse of Kumbuku health area then organized an active case-tracing and surveillance in the community with the help of the RECOs. However, the information did not reach the central bureau of the health zone before 14 Dec 2020.\n\nSuspected plague is defined -- according to WHO -- in any person with a rapid onset of fever, chills, severe malaise, and prostration accompanied by the following: 1. for bubonic plague, very painful swelling of the lymph nodes (bubo); 2. for pneumonic plague, coughing with blood-stained sputum, chest pain, and breathing difficulties. In view of the increased number of people affected through active surveillance, the health center nurse issued an alert to the health zone central bureau for further investigation.\n\nAs soon as they were able to investigate, on 21 Dec 2020, the Biringi and Aru health zone medical team, consisting of the Biringi zone chief medical officer, the nurse supervisor of the Aru health zone, and the laboratory technician from Aru General Hospital, investigated 58 cases and 5 community deaths reported at the Azumba and Kumbuku health centers. They took 9 samples of bubo aspirate, which were sent to the national reference laboratory (Institut National de Recherche Biomedicale, INRB), 6 of which tested positive with a rapid diagnostic test for plague. The team visited the villages of Azumba and Onu Oyia (Biringi health zone), where 41 additional cases were identified among the population with the help of the RECO. In addition, rat epizootics were reported in the immediate vicinity of the outbreak areas around the beginning of November 2020 in the Onu Ayia, Odhu, Linya, and Ayaya villages. Moreover, according to the zone chief medical officer, access to drinking water for the entire health zone is only 2%, which is an additional public health problem for ensuring sound hygiene. With the degrading situation, the Biringi health zone medical team called on Malteser International NGO for support. The financial and logistical intervention of Malteser International allowed to implement chemoprophylaxis and treat about 86 suspected cases and 2129 contacts with doxycycline (100 mg), while 152 sick patient's homes were dusted with deltamethrin.\n\nDue to the high number of cases (more than 200) and the proximity of refugee camps and internally displaced people, a 2nd mission was carried out by the Ituri Provincial Division of Health (DPS) team with the financial support of UNICEF and WHO. Between 18 and 26 Dec 2020, they conducted an in-depth rapid outbreak investigation mission (semi-structured interviews, flea collection, and dead rodent sampling, following an original protocol developed in collaboration with international colleagues) in the Biringi health zone and brought 9 tons of UNICEF equipment to the Biringi, Aru, and Aungba health zones, which regularly notify plague (PPE [personal protective equipment], WASH [water, sanitation and hygiene], sanitation material).\n\nFlea traps (light traps) were also placed for 3 consecutive nights in 10 houses (21-24 Dec 2020) in the affected villages (Onu Ayia, Odhu, Linya, and Ayaya), and 7 houses had been dusted (insecticide) between 8 and 10 Dec 2020 by the Biringi health zone team. A total of 27 fleas were collected, namely _Ctenocephalides felis strongylus_ (26) and _Ctenocephalides canis_ (1). It is worth noting that DNA of _Yersinia pestis_ had been detected in the former species further south within the Ituri endemic plague focus in 2007 (Leulmi, et al., PLOS NTD, 2014; https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pntd.0003152).\n\nSix RDT [rapid diagnostic test] for plague were also tested on dead rats (_Rattus rattus_) found in the house and vicinity of patients' households; one was positive for plague.\n\nAs of 31 Dec 2020, the Biringi health zone has reported 256 cases of bubonic plague with 7 deaths. Overall, women (51.2%) and men (48.7%) are equally affected; however, adolescents (under 17 years old) seem the most at risk, representing 78.9% of the sick people. The behavioral risk factors of exposure for this observation have not been solved.\n\nIn this region, where there are nearly 47 000 internally displaced refugees from South Sudan, with some moving freely between the 2 countries, the risk of a regional flare-up is to be considered if the epidemic also reaches this camp. The NGO ADES, which manages the closest camp (7000 people), has been asked to reinforce hygiene and sanitation measures. The medical staff of the affected health zones, the RECO, the DPS, WHO, and UNICEF are monitoring the situation.\n\ncommunicated by:\nCleophas Ntumba Jalwiny\nPascal Adroba\nGustave Losa Lona\nJean Baptiste Shuli Tchomba\nMichel Mandro\nAlex Nyakabasa Murhula\nBunia, Ituri, DR Congo\nAnne Laudisoit, Ecohealth Alliance\n<laudisoit@ecohealthalliance.org>\n\n[Most cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea, causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. The swollen gland is called a bubo. Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2-6 days after being bitten.\n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. The bacteremia can also occur as an initial event. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antibiotic therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death.\n\nProMED-mail thanks Dr Anne Laudisoit and colleagues for sending this report. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of DR Congo: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/194.]", "summary": "On 22 Nov 2020, the head nurse of the Kumbuku health center (trained in plague outbreak investigation while working in Aru health zone) diagnosed plague in an 11 year old boy brought in as an emergency to the health center by his family in an altered general status (coma, high fever, and bilateral swelling of axillary lymph nodes). \n\nAs soon as they were able to investigate, on 21 Dec 2020, the Biringi and Aru health zone medical team, consisting of the Biringi zone chief medical officer, the nurse supervisor of the Aru health zone, and the laboratory technician from Aru General Hospital, investigated 58 cases and 5 community deaths reported at the Azumba and Kumbuku health centers. \n\nSuspected plague is defined -- according to WHO -- in any person with a rapid onset of fever, chills, severe malaise, and prostration accompanied by the following: 1. for bubonic plague, very painful swelling of the lymph nodes (bubo); 2. for pneumonic plague, coughing with blood-stained sputum, chest pain, and breathing difficulties. Between 18 and 26 Dec 2020, they conducted an in-depth rapid outbreak investigation mission (semi-structured interviews, flea collection, and dead rodent sampling, following an original protocol developed in collaboration with international colleagues) in the Biringi health zone and brought 9 tons of UNICEF equipment to the Biringi, Aru, and Aungba health zones, which regularly notify plague (PPE [personal protective equipment], WASH [water, sanitation and hygiene], sanitation material). Alex Nyakabasa Murhula\nBunia, Ituri, DR Congo\nAnne Laudisoit, Ecohealth Alliance\n<laudisoit@ecohealthalliance.org>\n\n[Most cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea, causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. Between 15 Nov 2020 and 13 Dec 2020, the Biringi health zone, located in the territory of Aru, Ituri province, DR Congo, reported 151 suspected cases of bubonic plague with 5 deaths (case fatality rate [CFR] 3.3%). \n\nFlea traps (light traps) were also placed for 3 consecutive nights in 10 houses (21-24 Dec 2020) in the affected villages (Onu Ayia, Odhu, Linya, and Ayaya), and 7 houses had been dusted (insecticide) between 8 and 10 Dec 2020 by the Biringi health zone team. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n As of 31 Dec 2020, the Biringi health zone has reported 256 cases of bubonic plague with 7 deaths. Moreover, according to the zone chief medical officer, access to drinking water for the entire health zone is only 2%, which is an additional public health problem for ensuring sound hygiene. In view of the increased number of people affected through active surveillance, the health center nurse issued an alert to the health zone central bureau for further investigation. However, a member of the network of volunteer community relay (RECO, or relais communautaire) notified the head nurse that on 15 Nov 2020 an 11 year old girl from the same family living in a neighboring household also died in a clinical picture of chills, headache, and painful lymph node swelling behind the ear. \n\nSix RDT [rapid diagnostic test] for plague were also tested on dead rats (_Rattus rattus_) found in the house and vicinity of patients' households; one was positive for plague. \n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. On 27 Nov 2020, a 3 year old girl of the mother's family, who attended the funeral wake of the index case, presented with fever, painful swelling of the left axillary lymph node, and abdominal pain. He found that the 6 year old brother of the patient had similar symptoms without complication (consistent with the case definition for suspected bubonic plague - see further) and recovered after a 10-day treatment with trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole. Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. \n\ncommunicated by:\nCleophas Ntumba Jalwiny\nPascal Adroba\n [edited]\n\n\nDR Congo confirmed bubonic plague (more than 200 cases)\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "malaria", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2129-03-25 00:00:00", "2020-03-25 00:00:00", "2020-12-14 00:00:00", "2020-12-21 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2020-12-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "DR", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ayaya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kumbuku", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Aru", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Linya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Leulmi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Onuoyia village", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ituri", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Odhu", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Sudan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7689128", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (04): (NM) septicemic, fatal, comment", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7689128", "date": "2020-08-18 09:10:34", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (04): (NEW MEXICO) SEPTICEMIC, FATAL, COMMENT\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 10 Aug 2020\nFrom: Gregory Mertz <gmertz@salud.unm.edu> [edited]\n\n\nProMED has had 2 recent posts regarding plague, including China Plague - China (03): (NM) 20200809.7660510 and Plague - USA (03): (NM) septicemic, fatal 20200808.7658204. In each case, ProMED has used boilerplate language from moderator LL describing bubonic plague, which incorrectly implies that septicemic plague is a complication of bubonic plague. Septicemic plague, which refers to sepsis without presence of a bubo, is the 2nd most common presentation of plague. These recent ProMED posts are misleading and miss important teaching points, including the clinical presentation of plague syndromes other than bubonic plague and the need for empiric coverage for plague in persons with sepsis without buboes in areas where plague is in the differential diagnosis.\n\n--\nGregory J Mertz\nCenter for Global Health\nUniversity of New Mexico Health Sciences Center\nAlbuquerque, NM\n<gmertz@salud.unm.edu>\n\n[ProMED thanks Gregory Mertz for his comments. My comments were not meant to imply that all cases of septicemic plague occur following the bubonic form as this is not the case. The ProMED comments are not meant to be comprehensive, but we would invite Dr. Mertz to provide further commentary on septicemic plague, 'intestinal' plague and the clear need for empiric coverage for potential _Yersinia pestis_ septicemic infection in endemic areas. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "These recent ProMED posts are misleading and miss important teaching points, including the clinical presentation of plague syndromes other than bubonic plague and the need for empiric coverage for plague in persons with sepsis without buboes in areas where plague is in the differential diagnosis. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7688535", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Mongolia (06): (HD) bubonic, marmot exp", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7688535", "date": "2020-08-18 11:12:09", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MONGOLIA (06): (HOVD) BUBONIC, MARMOT EXPOSURE\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 16 Aug 2020\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/mongolia-plague-another-human-case-this-one-in-tsetseg-soum-khovd-province-32075/\n\n\nThe Mongolia National Center for Zoonotic Disease reported on their Facebook page [https://www.facebook.com/nczd.gov/?fref=ts] of an additional suspected human bubonic plague case in western Mongolia. The case is a 37-year-old man from Tsetseg soum, Khovd province and is currently hospitalized in critical condition.\n\nIt is reported the patient ate marmot meat. Since the beginning of 2020, 13 human plague cases have been reported (9 suspect and 4 confirmed).\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is caused by _Yersinia pestis_. Plague appears to be more prevalent this year (2020) in Mongolia. It is not clear that person-to-person spread has occurred.\n\nMost cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea, causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. The swollen gland is called a 'bubo'. Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2-6 days after being bitten.\n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream, which can occur even without a clear bubo. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antimicrobial therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. At this stage, person-to-person spread can occur, causing other cases of 'primary' plague pneumonia. A quarantine would be required with contact tracing and even prophylactic antimicrobials if the index case or cases actually had plague pneumonia.\n\nPlague is endemic in Mongolia. Marmots such as the Tarvaga, the Tarbagan or Mongolian marmot, _Marmota sibirica_, a large rodent related to the American woodchuck (_M. monax_), are thought to be significant zoonotic reservoirs for _Y. pestis_ in Eastern Asia. The name marmot comes from French 'marmotte', from Latin _mures monti_ 'mountain mouse'.\n\nWhile foodborne transmission of _Y. pestis_ has been described (such as Leslie T, et al. Outbreak of gastroenteritis caused by _Yersinia pestis_ in Afghanistan. Epidemiol Infect. 2011; 139(5): 728-35; https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20663260), it is far more likely that the bubonic plague cases were acquired via the bites of infected fleas. - Mod.LL\n\nMaps of Mongolia: http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/asia/political-map-of-Mongolia.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/67210]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream, which can occur even without a clear bubo. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is caused by _Yersinia pestis_. Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. \n\nMost cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea, causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The Mongolia National Center for Zoonotic Disease reported on their Facebook page [https://www.facebook.com/nczd.gov/?fref=ts] of an additional suspected human bubonic plague case in western Mongolia.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2020-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Mongolia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Afghanistan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Khovd", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tarbagan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7670859", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, animal - Russia: (TU) ground squirrel, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7670859", "date": "2020-08-12 13:07:32", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - RUSSIA: (TUVA) GROUND SQUIRREL, ALERT\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 11 Aug 2020 10:20 PM MSK\nSource: UrduPoint News/Sputnik [edited]\nhttps://www.urdupoint.com/en/world/russian-watchdog-registers-plague-outbreaks-a-998939.html\n\n\nPlague was detected in ground squirrels in the Russian southeastern Republic of Tuva last month [July 2020], the country's consumer rights and human welfare watchdog [Rospotrebnadzor] said on Tuesday [11 Aug 2020], adding that the entire population engaged in livestock breeding in the area was subject to vaccination.\n\n'There is an epizootic activity of Tuva mountain natural plague foci recorded almost every year since 1964. In July 2020, local epizootics in the habitat of long-tailed ground squirrels were registered on the territory of Mongun-Tayginskiy and Ovyursky [districts] of the Republic of Tuva. An active epizootic process was registered at one of the sites,' Rospotrebnadzor said.\n\nThe watchdog added that as many as 4810 people had been vaccinated in the republic's affected areas.\n\n'Field deratization has been carried out on 3.9 hectares [9.6 acres] of land. Medical institutions' epidemic readiness has been checked and training sessions to identify patients with plague have been carried out. Health education is also underway,' Rospotrebnadzor noted.\n\nIn early July [2020], the republic's Agriculture Ministry called on the residents to observe preventive measures in connection with the bubonic plague outbreak in Mongolia. Since 2016, Russia has registered no cases of plague in humans.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-SoAs from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed-SoAs@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_ which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. Humans are at risk of becoming infected if they are exposed to rodent fleas.\n\nIn the natural foci of Tuva, the vector is the flea _Citellophilus tesquorum altaicus_ and the mammal host is the long-tailed ground squirrel (_Urocitellus undulatus_). For a picture see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Long-tailed_ground_squirrel#/media/File:Spermophilus_undulatus1.jpg. - Mod.PMB\n\nMaps of Russia: https://www.usrbc.org/site/resources/russianmap and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/409]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n\nPlague was detected in ground squirrels in the Russian southeastern Republic of Tuva last month [July 2020], the country's consumer rights and human welfare watchdog [Rospotrebnadzor] said on Tuesday [11 Aug 2020], adding that the entire population engaged in livestock breeding in the area was subject to vaccination. Date: Tue 11 Aug 2020 10:20 PM MSK\nSource: UrduPoint News/Sputnik [edited]\n Communicated by:\nProMED-SoAs from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed-SoAs@promedmail.org>\n\n \n\n'There is an epizootic activity of Tuva mountain natural plague foci recorded almost every year since 1964.
