In past years, chipmunks with plague have been found near the Taylor Creek, Kiva Beach, Tallac Historic Site and Fallen Leaf Lake, among others. \n- Wear long pants tucked into boot tops and spray insect repellent containing DEET on socks and pant cuffs to reduce exposure to fleas.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1908-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "1905-03-25 00:00:00", "1909-03-25 00:00:00", "1907-03-25 00:00:00", "1906-03-25 00:00:00", "1903-03-25 00:00:00", "1897-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "1900-03-06 00:00:00", "1894-03-25 00:00:00", "1904-02-29 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00", "1970-03-25 00:00:00", "1898-03-25 00:00:00", "1901-04-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Francisco", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canton", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Concord", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Highway", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "El Dorado County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Orleans", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kiva Beach", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7622263", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (02): (NM) bubonic", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7622263", "date": "2020-07-29 08:22:16", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (02): (NEW MEXICO) BUBONIC\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 27 Jul 2020 11:30 AM MDT\nSource: KOB.com [edited\nhttps://www.kob.com/albuquerque-news/new-mexico-reports-first-2020-human-bubonic-plague-case/5808212/\n\n\nThe New Mexico Department of Health [NMDOH] is reporting the state's 1st human plague case of 2020. Officials said a Santa Fe County man in his 60s has been diagnosed with bubonic plague.\n\n'This is a reminder that even during a pandemic, other infectious diseases are out that that can still put your health at risk,' NMDOH Secretary Kathy Kunkel said. 'All New Mexicans need to be aware of the risks for contracting diseases like plague and take the necessary precautions to avoid them.'\n\nAccording to the health department, the man is recovering at a local hospital while officials investigate any ongoing risks to immediate family members, neighbors, and others in the surrounding community.\n\nTo prevent plague, the NMDOH issued the following recommendations:\n- avoid sick or dead rodents and rabbits, and their nests and burrows;\n- prevent pets from roaming and hunting;\n- talk to your veterinarian about using an appropriate flea control product on your pets as not all products are safe for cats, dogs, or your children;\n- clean up areas near the home where rodents could live, such as woodpiles, brush piles, junk and abandoned vehicles;\n- have sick pets examined promptly by a veterinarian;\n- see your doctor about any unexplained illness involving a sudden and severe fever;\n- put hay, wood, and compost piles as far as possible from your home;\n- don't leave your pet's food and water where rodents and wildlife can get to it.\n\nSymptoms include the sudden onset of fever, chills, headache, and weakness. Health officials said in most cases there is a painful swelling of the lymph node in the groin, armpit, or neck area. Plague symptoms in dogs and cats are fever, lethargy, and loss of appetite. A dog in Santa Fe County was also diagnosed with the plague in 2020. In New Mexico, there was one human plague case in 2019 and none in 2018. With prompt diagnosis and antibacterial treatment, the fatality rate in people and pets can be greatly reduced.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n['The typical sign of the most common form of human plague is a swollen and very tender lymph gland, accompanied by pain. The swollen gland is called a 'bubo'. Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2-6 days after being infected.\n\n'When bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream (septicemic plague). As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antimicrobial therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. About 14% (one in 7) of all plague cases in the United States are fatal.' (https://portal.ct.gov/-/media/Departments-and-Agencies/DPH/dph/communications/CERC/PlagueFSwebpdf.pdf)\n\nIn recent decades, an average of 7 human plague cases have been reported each year in the United States (range: 1-17 cases per year) (https://www.cdc.gov/plague/maps/index.html). Most cases of _Yersinia pestis_ infections in the USA occur in the area of the 'Four Corner' states: Colorado, Arizona, New Mexico, and Utah, although California and, to a lesser extent, Oregon also may have cases. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map of New Mexico, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4529\nNew Mexico County map: https://www.mapsofworld.com/usa/states/new-mexico/new-mexico-county-map.html]", "summary": "To prevent plague, the NMDOH issued the following recommendations:\n- avoid sick or dead rodents and rabbits, and their nests and burrows;\n- prevent pets from roaming and hunting;\n- talk to your veterinarian about using an appropriate flea control product on your pets as not all products are safe for cats, dogs, or your children;\n- clean up areas near the home where rodents could live, such as woodpiles, brush piles, junk and abandoned vehicles;\n- have sick pets examined promptly by a veterinarian;\n- see your doctor about any unexplained illness involving a sudden and severe fever;\n- put hay, wood, and compost piles as far as possible from your home;\n- don't leave your pet's food and water where rodents and wildlife can get to it. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n'When bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream (septicemic plague). PLAGUE - USA (02): (NEW MEXICO) BUBONIC\n***************************************\n Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. In recent decades, an average of 7 human plague cases have been reported each year in the United States (range: 1-17 cases per year) (https://www.cdc.gov/plague/maps/index.html). promed@promedmail.org>\n\n['The typical sign of the most common form of human plague is a swollen and very tender lymph gland, accompanied by pain. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. Date: Mon 27 Jul 2020 11:30 AM MDT\nSource: KOB.com [edited\nhttps://www.kob.com/albuquerque-news/new-mexico-reports-first-2020-human-bubonic-plague-case/5808212/\n\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2018-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2020-03-25 00:00:00", "2019-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mexico County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santa Fe County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7658204", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (03): (NM) septicemic, fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7658204", "date": "2020-08-08 17:05:28", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (03): (NEW MEXICO) SEPTICEMIC, FATAL\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 7 Aug 2020\nSource: Los Alamos Reporter [edited]\nhttps://losalamosreporter.com/2020/08/07/rio-arriba-county-man-dies-from-human-plague/\n\n\nThe New Mexico Department of Health (NMDOH) reports the death of a man in his 20s from Rio Arriba County of septicemic plague, the 1st human plague death in New Mexico in 2020, and the 2nd human plague case overall. The Rio Arriba County man died after being hospitalized. An environmental investigation will take place at the person's home to look for ongoing risk to immediate family members, neighbors, and others in the surrounding community.\n\nPlague is a bacterial disease of rodents and is generally transmitted to humans through the bites of infected fleas but can also be transmitted by direct contact with infected animals, including rodents, wildlife, and pets. Pets that are allowed to roam and hunt can bring infected fleas from dead rodents back into the home, putting household members at risk.\n\n'Plague activity in New Mexico is usually highest during the summer months, so it is especially important now to take precautions to avoid rodents and their fleas, which can expose you to plague,' said Department of Health Secretary Kathy Kunkel.\n\nTo prevent plague, the Department of Health recommends the following:\n- Avoid sick or dead rodents and rabbits, and their nests and burrows.\n- Prevent pets from roaming and hunting.\n- Talk to your veterinarian about using an appropriate flea control product on your pets, as not all products are safe for cats, dogs, or your children.\n- Clean up areas near the home where rodents could live, such as woodpiles, brush piles, junk, and abandoned vehicles.\n- Have sick pets examined promptly by a veterinarian.\n- See your doctor about any unexplained illness involving a sudden and severe fever.\n- Put hay, wood, and compost piles as far as possible from your home.\n- Don't leave your pet's food and water where rodents and wildlife can get to it.\n\nSymptoms of plague in humans include sudden onset of fever, chills, headache, and weakness. In most cases there is a painful swelling of the lymph node in the groin, armpit, or neck areas. Plague symptoms in cats and dogs are fever, lethargy, and loss of appetite. There may be a swelling in the lymph node under the jaw. With prompt diagnosis and appropriate antibiotic treatment, the fatality rate in people and pets can be greatly reduced. Physicians who suspect plague should promptly report to the New Mexico Department of Health.\n\nThis is the 1st human plague-related death in New Mexico since 2015. There was a single human plague case in 2019 in a 72-year-old man from Torrance County, and no human plague cases in 2018.\n\nThere have been 2 animal plague cases in New Mexico in 2020: 1 dog and 1 cat, both Santa Fe County. There were 2 animal plague cases in 2019 (a dog from Quay County and a cat from Santa Fe County) and 3 animal plague cases in 2018 (2 dogs from Santa Fe County and 1 dog from Torrance County).\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The typical sign of the most common form of human plague is a swollen and very tender lymph gland, accompanied by pain. The swollen gland is called a 'bubo.' Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2-6 days after being infected.\n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream (septicemic plague). As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antimicrobial therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. About 14% (one in 7) of all plague cases in the United States are fatal (https://portal.ct.gov/-/media/Departments-and-Agencies/DPH/dph/communications/CERC/PlagueFSwebpdf.pdf).\n\nIn recent decades, an average of 7 human plague cases have been reported each year in the United States (range: 1-17 cases per year) (https://www.cdc.gov/plague/maps/index.html). Most cases of _Yersinia pestis_ infections in the USA occur in the area of the 'Four Corners' states -- Colorado, Arizona, New Mexico, and Utah -- although California and, to a lesser extent, Oregon also may have cases. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nRio Arriba County, New Mexico, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/17672]", "summary": "The New Mexico Department of Health (NMDOH) reports the death of a man in his 20s from Rio Arriba County of septicemic plague, the 1st human plague death in New Mexico in 2020, and the 2nd human plague case overall. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The typical sign of the most common form of human plague is a swollen and very tender lymph gland, accompanied by pain. There were 2 animal plague cases in 2019 (a dog from Quay County and a cat from Santa Fe County) and 3 animal plague cases in 2018 (2 dogs from Santa Fe County and 1 dog from Torrance County). A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream (septicemic plague). There was a single human plague case in 2019 in a 72-year-old man from Torrance County, and no human plague cases in 2018. \n\n'Plague activity in New Mexico is usually highest during the summer months, so it is especially important now to take precautions to avoid rodents and their fleas, which can expose you to plague,' said Department of Health Secretary Kathy Kunkel. \n\nIn recent decades, an average of 7 human plague cases have been reported each year in the United States (range: 1-17 cases per year) (https://www.cdc.gov/plague/maps/index.html). Plague is a bacterial disease of rodents and is generally transmitted to humans through the bites of infected fleas but can also be transmitted by direct contact with infected animals, including rodents, wildlife, and pets. \n\nTo prevent plague, the Department of Health recommends the following:\n- Avoid sick or dead rodents and rabbits, and their nests and burrows. Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. \n\nThere have been 2 animal plague cases in New Mexico in 2020: 1 dog and 1 cat, both Santa Fe County. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. \n\nSymptoms of plague in humans include sudden onset of fever, chills, headache, and weakness.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2019-03-25 00:00:00", "2020-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2018-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rio Arriba County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santa Fe County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Quay County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Torrance County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7688534", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Congo DR (08): (IT) human, rodent", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7688534", "date": "2020-08-18 08:37:17", "main_text": "PLAGUE - DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF CONGO (08): (ITURI) HUMAN, RODENT\n*****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 16 Aug 2020\nFrom: Anne Laudisoit <laudisoit@ecohealthalliance.org> [edited]\n\n\nPlague in Congo DR: follow up, epizootic and new outbreak\n---------------------------------------------------------\nThis is a follow up of the WHO summary statement on plague in Congo DR (Plague - Congo DR (07): (IT) clusters, fatal, WHO 20200725.7606707) posted on ProMED 25 Jul 2020 (posted on the WHO website on 23 Jul 2020). As stated in the WHO article, since 12 Jun 2020, an upsurge of plague cases has been noted in the Rethy Health zone, Ituri province where response has been hampered by the insecurity due to the presence of the CODECO [Cooperative for the Development of Congo] armed group in the region. The COVID-19 pandemics and the rise in cases in Bunia town are further complicating the response team interventions in the area. Other health zones have since then been affected and the case number in Rethy health zone is still increasing with 62 cases reported to date of which 6 bubonic plague cases since 1 Aug 2020. It strongly suggests that plague is actively circulating in the rodent and flea population in the whole region. Indeed, 2 additional events are worth reporting.\n\nOn 22 Jul 2020, the central office of the Aru health zone (BCZ [Health Zone Central Office]), Ituri Province, Congo DR received an alert from the Titular Nurse of the Oronzi Health Area reporting a large rat fall around and inside houses in the Burenga village (N2.81114, E30.79158). This village is located 90 km [56 mi] north from the on-going Rethy outbreak area and 10 km [6.2 mi] west to the Uganda border. This information was relayed by the RECO (Community Relay Network) network who are volunteers trained in community monitoring and surveillance.\n\nOn 23 Jul 2020, a team composed of the technician from Aru General Reference Hospital (HGR) and the Chief Physician of Aru HGR -- who is the focal point for plague surveillance in this plague endemic zone -- was sent to the field to carry out an investigation. Upon arrival, the team observed a mass die-off of a single Muridae rodent species, the black rat (_Rattus rattus_). 3 blood samples were taken on freshly dead rat carcasses and the rapid diagnostic tests performed on fresh rat carcasses were positive for plague. No human cases have been reported to date.\n\nThe team has instructed the RECO to carry out insecticidal dusting of houses (as a measure to prevent flea borne plague transmission) by spraying them with a deltamethrin-based solution, to raise awareness among the population and finally to go to the Health Centre as soon as symptoms consistent with either forms of plague appear. This rapid response highlights the success of recent community awareness campaigns that followed the Rethy Area outbreak reported on 14 Jun 2020 (ProMED archive no. 20200617.7480784) and updated on 25 Jul 2020 by WHO (ProMED archive no. 20200725.7606707).\n\nOn 31 Jul 2020 a new plague outbreak was noted in the Logo Health Zone in the Kanga Health Area sharing a border with the Wala health area, in Jupanjaya village (N2.05394, E30.94094, 1985m asl [above sea level]). Rat falls have also been reported in several villages of the health area and in particular in Juparima village (N2.08094, E30.95742, 1977m asl) where _R. rattus_ have been dying in houses and peri-domestic bushes.\n\nSo far 4 human cases have been reported and confirmed microbiologically at the Logo General Reference Hospital (Wayson staining of bubo aspirate). The index case is a 23 month old female from Jupanjaya village. Since 30 Jul 2020, the child had had chills and fever. On 31 Jul 2020, the child's condition worsened with impaired breathing, high fever, which prompted her mother to seek treatment at the health center. At her admission, the child presented with fever at 38 deg C [100.4 deg F], and dyspnea. The nurse excluded malaria with a negative RDT [rapid diagnostic test] and confirmed the pneumonia which he treated with amoxicillin and paracetamol. Slight improvements were observed, that is, fever and dyspnea regressed, however in the morning of 1 Aug 2020, the presence of left axillary bubo was noted and the child condition relapsed. 3 more of bubonic plague cases have been reported: an 8 year old boy was reported on 2 Aug 2020 from Moo village (N2.06797 E30.97878, 1555m asl), 21 year old female on 11 Aug 2020 from Raa village (N2.07814 E30.92981, 2044m asl) and a 24 month female on 14 Aug 2020 from Kanga village (N2.07428 E30.95431, 1955m asl).\n\nGiven that this area has experienced pneumonic plague in recent years, the RECOs are leading an awareness campaign to broadcast preventive measures, and are actively searching for cases in the communities to refer them to the health centres. Household insecticidal dusting with deltamethrin is on-going. While the medical staff of the Ituri Province is well trained and prepared to respond to plague outbreaks, the underfunding of plague response teams, the lack of research on the origin of infected rodents and fleas, the gaps in our understanding on the factors triggering plague reemergence, and the current sanitary and security realms should be emphasized. The evolution of these multiple outbreaks should be closely monitored and dealt with.\n\nThis is the 7th outbreak of human plague (epidemiological threshold is 1 to declare an outbreak, according to the country's plague response guidance manual) in the region in less than a year.\n\nThe frequency of the rat falls is an early alert signal that plague may be circulating and there is an urgent need for communication and outreach campaigns throughout the whole plague endemic area.\n\nInterestingly since June 2020, plague has also reemerged in China (ProMED archive nos: 20200809.7660510 and 20200706.7543168), the USA (ProMED archive nos: 20200808.7658204 and 20200729.7622263), Mongolia (ProMED archive no. 20200720.7591590), and Russia (ProMED archive no. 20200812.7670859) raising even more questions on the conditions prevailing in these areas and the factors triggering plague reemergence in animal populations worldwide.\n\n--\nFrancoise Nyisi, Rethy General Reference hospital, DR Congo\nDr Phocas Kasereka, General Hospital of Aru, DR Congo\nDr Pascal Adroba, Centre for Surveillance and Control of Plague, Bunia, DR Congo\nDr Michel Mandro, Ituri Provincial Division of health, Bunia, DR Congo\nDr Justin Wathum, Kanga Health zone Chief Medical doctor, DR Congo\nDr Anne Laudisoit, EcoHealth Alliance, New York, USA\n<laudisoit@ecohealthalliance.org>\n\n[ProMED thanks Dr Laudisoit and her colleagues for their continued contributions regarding _Yersinia pestis_ infection in the Ituri province of Congo DR. - Mod.LL\n\nMaps of Congo DR: http://goo.gl/DM2AT8 and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/194]", "summary": "\n\n--\nFrancoise Nyisi, Rethy General Reference hospital, DR Congo\nDr Phocas Kasereka, General Hospital of Aru, DR Congo\nDr Pascal Adroba, Centre for Surveillance and Control of Plague, Bunia, DR Congo\nDr Michel Mandro, Ituri Provincial Division of health, Bunia, DR Congo\nDr Justin Wathum, Kanga Health zone Chief Medical doctor, DR Congo\nDr Anne Laudisoit, EcoHealth Alliance, New York, USA\n<laudisoit@ecohealthalliance.org>\n\n[ProMED thanks Dr Laudisoit and her colleagues for their continued contributions regarding _Yersinia pestis_ infection in the Ituri province of Congo DR. 3 more of bubonic plague cases have been reported: an 8 year old boy was reported on 2 Aug 2020 from Moo village (N2.06797 E30.97878, 1555m asl), 21 year old female on 11 Aug 2020 from Raa village (N2.07814 E30.92981, 2044m asl) and a 24 month female on 14 Aug 2020 from Kanga village (N2.07428 E30.95431, 1955m asl). On 31 Jul 2020 a new plague outbreak was noted in the Logo Health Zone in the Kanga Health Area sharing a border with the Wala health area, in Jupanjaya village (N2.05394, E30.94094, 1985m asl [above sea level]). \n\nThe team has instructed the RECO to carry out insecticidal dusting of houses (as a measure to prevent flea borne plague transmission) by spraying them with a deltamethrin-based solution, to raise awareness among the population and finally to go to the Health Centre as soon as symptoms consistent with either forms of plague appear. While the medical staff of the Ituri Province is well trained and prepared to respond to plague outbreaks, the underfunding of plague response teams, the lack of research on the origin of infected rodents and fleas, the gaps in our understanding on the factors triggering plague reemergence, and the current sanitary and security realms should be emphasized. This is a follow up of the WHO summary statement on plague in Congo DR (Plague - Congo DR (07): (IT) clusters, fatal, WHO 20200725.7606707) posted on ProMED 25 Jul 2020 (posted on the WHO website on 23 Jul 2020). This rapid response highlights the success of recent community awareness campaigns that followed the Rethy Area outbreak reported on 14 Jun 2020 (ProMED archive no. 20200617.7480784) and updated on 25 Jul 2020 by WHO (ProMED archive no. 20200725.7606707). \n\nThis is the 7th outbreak of human plague (epidemiological threshold is 1 to declare an outbreak, according to the country's plague response guidance manual) in the region in less than a year. On 23 Jul 2020, a team composed of the technician from Aru General Reference Hospital (HGR) and the Chief Physician of Aru HGR -- who is the focal point for plague surveillance in this plague endemic zone -- was sent to the field to carry out an investigation. On 22 Jul 2020, the central office of the Aru health zone (BCZ [Health Zone Central Office]), Ituri Province, Congo DR received an alert from the Titular Nurse of the Oronzi Health Area reporting a large rat fall around and inside houses in the Burenga village (N2.81114, E30.79158). A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n As stated in the WHO article, since 12 Jun 2020, an upsurge of plague cases has been noted in the Rethy Health zone, Ituri province where response has been hampered by the insecurity due to the presence of the CODECO Interestingly since June 2020, plague has also reemerged in China (ProMED archive nos: 20200809.7660510 and 20200706.7543168), the USA (ProMED archive nos: 20200808.7658204 and 20200729.7622263), Mongolia (ProMED archive no. 20200720.7591590), and Russia (ProMED archive no. The frequency of the rat falls is an early alert signal that plague may be circulating and there is an urgent need for communication and outreach campaigns throughout the whole plague endemic area. Given that this area has experienced pneumonic plague in recent years, the RECOs are leading an awareness campaign to broadcast preventive measures, and are actively searching for cases in the communities to refer them to the health centres. Rat falls have also been reported in several villages of the health area and in particular in Juparima village (N2.08094, E30.95742, 1977m asl) where _R. rattus_ have been dying in houses and peri-domestic bushes. 6 bubonic plague cases since 1 Aug 2020. 3 blood samples were taken on freshly dead rat carcasses and the rapid diagnostic tests performed on fresh rat carcasses were positive for plague. [edited]\n\n\nPlague in Congo DR: follow up, epizootic and new outbreak\n Slight improvements were observed, that is, fever and dyspnea regressed, however in the morning of 1 Aug 2020, the presence of left axillary bubo was noted and the child condition relapsed. On 31 Jul 2020, the child's condition worsened with impaired breathing, high fever, which prompted her mother to seek treatment at the health center. Other health zones have since then been affected and the case number in Rethy health zone is still increasing with 62 cases reported to date of which PLAGUE - DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF CONGO (08): (ITURI) HUMAN, RODENT\n* \n\nSo far 4 human cases have been reported and confirmed microbiologically at the Logo General Reference Hospital (Wayson staining of bubo aspirate). This village is located 90 km [56 mi] north from the on-going Rethy outbreak area and 10 km [6.2 mi] west to the Uganda border. It strongly suggests that plague is actively circulating in the rodent and flea population in the whole region. Date: Sun 16 Aug 2020\n raising even more questions on the conditions prevailing in these areas and the factors triggering plague reemergence in animal populations worldwide. The COVID-19 pandemics and the rise in cases in Bunia town are further complicating the response team interventions in the area. Since 30 Jul 2020, the child had had chills and fever. Upon arrival, the team observed a mass die-off of a single Muridae rodent species, the black rat (_Rattus rattus_). The index case is a 23 month old female from Jupanjaya village. No human cases have been reported to date. At her admission, the child presented with fever at 38 deg C [100.4 deg F], and dyspnea.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "malaria", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2020-06-14 00:00:00", "2020-08-14 00:00:00", "2020-08-01 00:00:00", "2020-03-25 00:00:00", "2020-07-31 00:00:00", "2020-06-12 00:00:00", "1985-03-25 00:00:00", "1555-03-25 00:00:00", "1977-03-25 00:00:00", "2020-06-25 00:00:00", "2038-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the Ituri Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "rethy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Raa village", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jupanjaya village", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Logo Health Zone", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Adroba", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Moo village", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ituri Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kanga village", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Congo DR", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Rethy Health", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bunia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Juparima village", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kanga Health", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Plague - Congo DR", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Kanga Health Area", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7591590", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Mongolia (05): (HD) bubonic, marmot exposure", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7591590", "date": "2020-07-20 11:24:22", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MONGOLIA (05): (HOVD) BUBONIC, MARMOT EXPOSURE\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 19 Jul 2020 01:06 PM BST\nSource: Xinhua News Agency/United News of Bangladesh (UNB) [edited]\nhttp://unb.com.bd/category/World/bubonic-plague-case-reported-in-western-mongolia/54848\n\n\nA 6-year-old child in Uyench soum (administrative subdivision) of Khovd [Hovd] Province in Mongolia was reported to be infected with bubonic plague in Western Mongolia, according to the country's National Center for Zoonotic Diseases (NCZD).\n\nThe child is now under isolation at a local hospital, said Nyamdorj Tsogbadrakh, director of the NCZD on Fri 17 Jul 2020. The child showed symptoms of high-grade fever and skin rashes after playing with a dead marmot, the official added.\n\nA total of 7 suspected cases of bubonic plague have been reported across the country so far in 2020. 3 of which had been confirmed by laboratory test results. 2 cases of bubonic plague have been confirmed in Tsetseg soum in Khovd Province earlier in July 2020. A 15-year-old boy in Govi-Altai province died from bubonic plague last week. Up to 17 out of all 21 provinces in Mongolia are now at risk for the bubonic plague, according to the NCZD.\n\nHealth Minister Togtmol Munkhsaikhan has ordered all relevant officials to ensure that health organizations are ready, including training health workers in high-risk provinces and raising public awareness about the infectious disease.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is caused by _Yersinia pestis_. Plague appears to be more prevalent this year (2020) in Mongolia. It is not clear that person-to-person spread has occurred.\n\nMost cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea, causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. The swollen gland is called a 'bubo'. Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2-6 days after being bitten.\n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antimicrobial therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. At this stage, person-to-person spread can occur, causing other cases of 'primary' plague pneumonia. A quarantine would be required with contact tracing and even prophylactic antimicrobials if the index case or cases actually had plague pneumonia.\n\nPlague is endemic in Mongolia. Marmots such as the Tarvaga, the Tarbagan or Mongolian marmot, _Marmota sibirica_, a large rodent related to the American woodchuck (_M. monax_), are thought to be significant zoonotic reservoirs for _Y. pestis_ in Eastern Asia. The name marmot comes from French marmotte, from Latin _mures monti_ 'mountain mouse'. - Mod.LL\n\nMaps of Mongolia: http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/asia/political-map-of-Mongolia.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/59547]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nMost cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea, causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. \n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. \n\nA total of 7 suspected cases of bubonic plague have been reported across the country so far in 2020. PLAGUE - MONGOLIA (05): (HOVD) BUBONIC, MARMOT EXPOSURE\n*******************************************************\n A 6-year-old child in Uyench soum (administrative subdivision) of Khovd [Hovd] Province in Mongolia was reported to be infected with bubonic plague in Western Mongolia, according to the country's National Center for Zoonotic Diseases (NCZD). At this stage, person-to-person spread can occur, causing other cases of 'primary' plague pneumonia. 2 cases of bubonic plague have been confirmed in Tsetseg soum in Khovd Province earlier in July 2020. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2020-03-25 00:00:00", "2020-07-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Govi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mongolia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Khovd Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uyench", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bangladesh", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tarbagan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7606707", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Congo DR (07): (IT) clusters, fatal, WHO", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7606707", "date": "2020-07-25 17:26:40", "main_text": "PLAGUE - DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF CONGO (07): (ITURI) CLUSTERS, FATAL, WHO\n************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 23 Jul 2020\nSource: WHO Disease Outbreak News [edited]\nhttps://www.who.int/csr/don/23-july-2020-plague-drc/en/\n\n\nPlague -- Democratic Republic of the Congo\n-----------------------------------------\nThe health zone of Rethy in Ituri Province, the Democratic Republic of the Congo, has seen an upsurge of plague cases since June 2020. The 1st case, a 12-year-old girl, reported to a local health center on 12 Jun 2020 experiencing a headache, fever, cough, and an enlarged lymph node. She died on the same day, and further deaths from the community due to suspected cases of plague were subsequently reported. From 11 Jun 2020 through 15 Jul 2020, 6 of 22 health areas have been affected within Rethy health zone (11 villages), with a total of 45 cases including 9 deaths (case fatality rate: 20%). All 9 cases who died presented with signs of headache, high fever, and painful nodes; 4 of the 9 cases had cough.\n\nThe health zone team carried out an investigation resulting in 5 positive rapid diagnostic tests (RDTs). Nine additional samples were taken and shipped to the National Institute for Biomedical Research [Institut National de Recherche Biomedicale (INRB)] laboratory in Kinshasa. Of the 45 cases reported, 2 showed signs of septicemic plague; all the other cases were diagnosed as having bubonic plague. According to the available information, it is likely that all 3 types of plague clinical presentation (bubonic, septicemic and pneumonic) are present.\n\nThe distribution by sex shows 58% (26/45) are male and 93% (42/45) are greater than 5 years old. Of the 45 cases reported, 9 including 4 who died, had cough among the symptoms -- a sign indicating a potential progression from bubonic plague to pulmonary plague. This was specifically noticed among the deceased.\n\nPlague is endemic in Ituri province. Since the beginning of 2020, Ituri Province has reported a total of 64 plague cases and 14 deaths (CFR: 21.8%) in 5 health zones, namely, Aungba, Linga, Rethy, Aru and Kambala health zones. This compares against 10 cases and 5 deaths (lethality, 50.0%) during the same period in 2019, all in a single zone.\n\nThe current COVID-19 epidemic affects 7 of 26 provinces in the country. Ituri has also reported cases of COVID-19 that may further interrupt response activities due to lockdown (as of 16 Jul 2020, there have been 8162 confirmed COVID-19 cases including 191 deaths in the DRC). These are in addition to longstanding public health response challenges identified in the region, including a lack of resources and insecurity. Although it has been reported that there is no significant impact of the COVID-19 context on activities taking place in this area, there is limited information available on the current access to health care. This includes whether there is a need for the population of Ituri to seek care in Uganda, as well as the availability of human resources, drugs, and personal protective equipment (PPE). Furthermore, the reference laboratory in Bunia, Ituri province is currently not functional, which might delay the confirmation of suspected cases and response efforts.\n\nPublic health response\n- A national rapid response team (RRT) has been deployed to the affected health zone to conduct an outbreak investigation and implement initial response activities.\n- UNICEF is on the ground responding to the humanitarian situation at Bunia, working on community engagement and safe and dignified burial practices.\n- The WHO guideline for plague, including case definitions, has been disseminated to health facilities to improve the detection of cases.\n- The WHO is supporting plague-endemic areas with surveillance, investigation of cases, and training of health workers and community relays in the prevention, early detection and case management of plague.\n- Doxycycline prophylaxis has been administrated to the listed contacts.\n- Intrahousehold spraying with deltamethrin has been used in some villages.\n- Safe and dignified burials (SDB) have been performed by the health district team.\n- Sensitization of the population on plague prevention measures in the affected villages through local radio.\n\nWHO risk assessment\nInfection with plague can cause severe disease resulting in high mortality in humans, particularly if not identified early. Plague can exhibit in 3 forms: bubonic, septicemic and pneumonic. If untreated, bubonic plague can evolve to pneumonic plague. Early diagnosis and treatment are essential for survival and reduction of complications.\n\nRethy health zone is endemic for plague and regularly registers cases of enzootic variants of _Yersinia pestis_ in much of the wild rodent population. Its 1st outbreak was reported in February 2020 with cases imported from Linga health zone, based in the Godjoka health area.\n\nOn the security level, there are reports of atrocities and violence linked to the militia CODECO, which continues to impact the population of this territory (Djugu and its surroundings). There have been mass population displacements within Djugu and Mahagi territories. Currently, the Rethy health zone has received approximately 112 714 internally displaced persons (IDPs), most of whom have come from the Jiba and Linga health zone. The growing insecurity impacts traffic flow between the villages and the willingness of the population to either stay or work in that area. There has also been a deterioration of water, hygiene and sanitation conditions in the reception areas and in the IDP sites.\n\nThe early detection and reporting of the current outbreak by healthcare workers demonstrate that a functioning surveillance system is in place. Ituri province had a reference laboratory in Bunia that is no longer functional. The INRB laboratory based in Kinshasa/DRC has the ability to conduct laboratory testing for suspected cases. However, delays in shipping samples from Rethy to Bunia and then to Kinshasa, and delays in testing in Kinshasa INRB due to high workload and backload related to COVID-19 samples to be tested, might jeopardize the surveillance and response. Ongoing efforts are required to ensure that any other cases are promptly detected, isolated, and investigated to avoid the establishment of local transmission.\n\nThe risk at the national level is considered to be moderate given the evolution of the current situation is in danger of deteriorating rapidly (case fatality rate: 20%), the notification of cases of pulmonary plague, the challenges with the surveillance system and delays between sample collection and laboratory confirmation, and the volatile security situation and the existence of other epidemics in progress in the country, which prevents the setting up of a more comprehensive response. Furthermore, the health zone currently does not have enough PPE, body bags and materials needed for decontamination. Malteser International, an NGO that supplies the health zone with drugs, has had difficulty getting the products into the zone because of insecurity on the RN27 road.\n\nThe principles of control are known and have been implemented (early treatment with the recommended antibiotics, isolation of the pneumonic cases, chemoprophylaxis given to the close contacts of the latest ones, rodent and flea control, safe and dignified burials, and the prevention of nosocomial transmission), but the means are limited and the health system is unable to manage the cases in the most appropriate way. The antibiotics used for the treatment of the cases are doxycycline, ciprofloxacin and cotrimoxazole. For the pulmonary or septicemic form case, gentamycin was administrated. The lack of laboratory confirmation is worrying, but the use of rapid diagnostic tests (RDT) in the field ensures a minimum of confirmation among the suspected cases. The RDTs are especially reliable to confirm bubonic plague suspected forms.\n\nThe risk at the regional level is considered low because the epidemic seems to be contained in the Rethy health zone and that it is an isolated region. The risk is considered low globally.\n\nWHO advice\nBubonic plague is the most common form of plague and is caused by the bite of an infected flea. The plague bacillus, _Y. pestis_, enters at the bite site and travels through the lymphatic system to the nearest lymph node, where it replicates. At advanced stages of the infection, the inflamed lymph nodes can turn into suppurating open sores. There is no interhuman transmission of bubonic plague.\n\nUntreated, bubonic plague can advance and spread to the lungs, which is the more severe type of plague called pneumonic plague, the most virulent form of plague. The incubation period can be as short as 24 hours. Any person with pneumonic plague may transmit the disease via droplets to other humans. Untreated pneumonic plague, if not diagnosed and treated early, is almost always fatal. However, the probability of recovery is high if detected and treated in time (within 24 hours of onset of symptoms).\n\nEarly diagnosis and treatment are essential for survival and reduction of complications. Appropriate diagnostic samples include blood cultures, lymph node aspirates if possible, and/or sputum, if indicated. Drug therapy should begin as soon as possible after the laboratory specimens are taken. Post-exposure prophylaxis is indicated in persons with known exposure to plague, such as close contact with a pneumonic plague patient or direct contact with infected body fluids or tissues. Duration of post-exposure prophylaxis to prevent plague is 7 days.\n\nPreventive measures include informing people when zoonotic plague is present in their environment and advising them to take precautions against flea bites and not to handle animal carcasses. People, especially health workers, should also avoid direct contact with infected tissues such as buboes, or close exposure to patients with pneumonic plague.\n\nRecommended response measures for all forms of plague:\n\n- Obtain specimens, which should be carefully collected using appropriate infection, prevention and control procedures and sent to labs for testing. Confirmation of plague requires lab testing. The best practice is to identify _Y. pestis_ from a sample of pus from a bubo, blood or sputum. A specific _Y. pestis_ antigen can be detected by different techniques.\n\n- Ensure correct treatment: Prompt treatment with the correct medications is critical to prevent complications. Verify that patients are being given appropriate antimicrobial treatment such as aminoglycosides, fluoroquinolones, chloramphenicol, tetracyclines, sulfonamides and supportive therapy. The antibacterial treatment may need to be adjusted depending on a patient's age, medical history, underlying health conditions, or allergies. Duration of treatment is 10 to 14 days, or until 2 days after fever subsides.\n\n- Protect health workers: Inform and train them on infection prevention and control. Workers in direct contact with pneumonic plague patients must wear a full personal protective equipment and use standard precautions for respiratory diseases. Depending on the circumstances, they can also take a chemoprophylaxis with antibiotics such as doxycycline for the duration of 7 days or at least as long as they are exposed to infected patients. However, the chemoprophylaxis cannot replace the use of PPE and the individual physical precautions.\n\n- Isolate patients with pneumonic plague: Patients with confirmed or suspected pneumonic plague should be isolated so as not to infect others via air droplets. Provide masks for pneumonic patients.\n\n- Contact follow-up: Identify, inform and monitor close contacts of pneumonic plague patients and provide them with a 7-day chemoprophylaxis.\n\n- Ensure safe burial practices: Optimal infection prevention and control measures are to be observed during funeral and burial ceremonies. Funeral ceremonies in the houses of plague victims that may involve assembly of people should be discouraged.\n\n- To effectively and efficiently manage plague outbreaks it is crucial to have an informed and vigilant healthcare work force (and community) to quickly diagnose and manage patients with infection, to identify risk factors, to conduct ongoing surveillance, to control vectors and hosts, to confirm diagnosis with laboratory tests, and to communicate findings with appropriate authorities.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea, causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. The swollen gland is called a 'bubo.' Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2-6 days after being bitten.\n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antimicrobial therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. At this stage, person-to-person spread can occur, causing other cases of 'primary' plague pneumonia. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nIturi, Democratic Republic of the Congo: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/64029]", "summary": "\n\nUntreated, bubonic plague can advance and spread to the lungs, which is the more severe type of plague called pneumonic plague, the most virulent form of plague. Source: WHO Disease Outbreak News [edited]\nhttps://www.who.int/csr/don/23-july-2020-plague-drc/en/\n\n\nPlague -- Democratic Republic of the Congo\n She died on the same day, and further deaths from the community due to suspected cases of plague were subsequently reported. \n\nPreventive measures include informing people when zoonotic plague is present in their environment and advising them to take precautions against flea bites and not to handle animal carcasses. \n\n- Isolate patients with pneumonic plague: PLAGUE - DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF CONGO (07): (ITURI) CLUSTERS, FATAL, WHO\n************************************************************************\n Workers in direct contact with pneumonic plague patients must wear a full personal protective equipment and use standard precautions for respiratory diseases. \n- Sensitization of the population on plague prevention measures in the affected villages through local radio. All 9 cases who died presented with signs of headache, high fever, and painful nodes; 4 of the 9 cases had cough.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2020-03-25 00:00:00", "2019-03-25 00:00:00", "2020-06-25 00:00:00", "2020-02-25 00:00:00", "2020-07-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bunia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rethy in Ituri Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Democratic Republic of the", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ituri Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kinshasa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kambala", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Linga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ituri province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of the Congo", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7557341", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Mongolia (03): marmot meat consumption", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7557341", "date": "2020-07-09 16:30:03", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MONGOLIA (03): MARMOT MEAT CONSUMPTION\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 7 Jul 2020\nSource: CNN WORLD [edited]\nhttps://edition.cnn.com/2020/07/07/asia/russia-marmot-hunting-plague-scli-intl/index.html\n\n\nRussian authorities have warned people near the country's border with Mongolia not to hunt or eat marmots after an outbreak of bubonic plague.\n\nTwo cases of the plague were recorded in the Khovd province in western Mongolia, reported Russian state media agency TASS on [Tue 7 Jul 2020].\n\nOfficials from the Republican Ministry of Agriculture and Food told citizens in the border area not to hunt marmots or eat marmot meat, and take preventive measures against insect bites.\n\nMarmots are large ground squirrels, a type of rodent, that have historically been linked to plague outbreaks in the region. Rodents are the main [reservoir] of plague transmission from animals to humans, and the disease can also be passed on through flea bites. Bubonic plague, which is one of plague's 3 forms, causes painful, swollen lymph nodes, as well as fever, chills, and coughing.\n\nPlague killed an estimated 50 million people in Europe during the Black Death pandemic in the Middle Ages, but modern antibiotics can prevent complications and death if administered quickly enough.\n\nMongolia quarantined its region near the Russian border last week [1 Jul 2020] after lab tests showed 2 cases of bubonic plague linked to the consumption of marmot meat, the country's health officials said.\n\nMongolia's National Center for Zoonotic Diseases said last week it had identified and tested 146 people who had come into contact with the 2 infected people. The center also identified 504 people of secondary contact in the Khovd province.\n\nThe Russian Embassy in Mongolia said 'there are no grounds for serious concern' as the Mongolian authorities have imposed travel restrictions and isolated infected individuals, according to Russian state-run news agency RIA Novosti.\n\nThe embassy also cited Sergei Diorditsu, a World Health Organization (WHO) representative in Mongolia, who reportedly said the province sees seasonal outbreaks of the plague, according to RIA Novosti. 'There are natural foci of plague in Mongolia and the disease is spread by tarbagans [Mongolian marmots],' said the embassy. 'The problem is that local residents who, despite all prohibitions and recommendations of local authorities, continue to hunt them and eat them, as this is a local delicacy.'\n\nAuthorities in the Chinese region of Inner Mongolia have also confirmed a case of the plague. The case in the city of Bayannur, northwest of Beijing, was confirmed [Tue 7 Jul 2020], according to state-run Xinhua news agency.\n\nIn 2019 a couple in Mongolia died after eating a raw marmot kidney, triggering a quarantine that left several tourists stranded in the region.\n\nAnywhere from 1000 to 2000 people get the plague every year, according to the WHO, but that estimate does not account for unreported cases.\n\n[Byline: Jack Guy and Mary Ilyushina]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Siberian marmot (_Marmota sibirica_) is a commonly hunted wildlife species in Mongolia, for their meat and skin.\n\nPlague, caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, is enzootic in wild rodent populations (mainly marmots) over large rural areas of Mongolia. Natural plague foci have occurred over 28.3% of Mongolia, and 47.1% of these foci are highly active. Highly active plague foci exist mainly in the western part of Mongolia. A total of 27% of all plague cultures were isolated from ectoparasites of 12 species of endemic mammals and 1 species of bird.\n\nMost plague cultures isolated from ectoparasites of mammals were from fleas (91.5%). The majority of cultures isolated from fleas were from marmot fleas (64.5% of all fleas). The marmot flea (_Oropsylla silantiewi_) is considered the primary vector of plague. [Portions of this comment were extracted from https://doi.org/10.1089/vbz.2009.0047]. - Mod.PMB\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map:\nMongolia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1]", "summary": "\n\nMongolia quarantined its region near the Russian border last week [1 Jul 2020] after lab tests showed 2 cases of bubonic plague linked to the consumption of marmot meat, the country's health officials said. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The problem is that local residents who, despite all prohibitions and recommendations of local authorities, continue to hunt them and eat them, as this is a local delicacy.'\n\nAuthorities in the Chinese region of Inner Mongolia have also confirmed a case of the plague. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Siberian marmot (_Marmota sibirica_) is a commonly hunted wildlife species in Mongolia, for their meat and skin. \n\nTwo cases of the plague were recorded in the Khovd province in western Mongolia, reported Russian state media agency TASS on [Tue 7 Jul 2020]. \n\nMarmots are large ground squirrels, a type of rodent, that have historically been linked to plague outbreaks in the region. Anywhere from 1000 to 2000 people get the plague every year, according to the WHO, but that estimate does not account for unreported cases.\n\n PLAGUE - MONGOLIA (03): MARMOT MEAT CONSUMPTION\n***********************************************\n \n\nMongolia's National Center for Zoonotic Diseases said last week it had identified and tested 146 people who had come into contact with the 2 infected people. \n\nOfficials from the Republican Ministry of Agriculture and Food told citizens in the border area not to hunt marmots or eat marmot meat, and take preventive measures against insect bites. \n\n\nRussian authorities have warned people near the country's border with Mongolia not to hunt or eat marmots after an outbreak of bubonic plague. Bubonic plague, which is one of plague's 3 forms, causes painful, swollen lymph nodes, as well as fever, chills, and coughing.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2019-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Khovd", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bayannur", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mongolia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7586178", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA: (CO) septicemic", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7586178", "date": "2020-07-18 05:57:27", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA: (COLORADO) SEPTICEMIC\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 17 Jul 2020\nSource: New York Post [edited]\nhttps://nypost.com/2020/07/17/first-human-case-of-bubonic-plague-since-2015-reported-in-colorado/\n\n\nA Colorado resident was infected with the plague after a squirrel in the state tested positive for the bubonic plague, the first human case in the state since 2015, according to a report. The unnamed person, who lives in the south west section of the state, contracted septicemic plague earlier this summer and has since recovered, officials confirmed to the Denver Post. The person had had contact with sick squirrels.\n\nSepticemic plague is one of the 3 main forms of plague, the other forms being bubonic and pneumonic. All are caused by bacteria called _Yersinia pestis_ that live in some animals -- mostly rodents -- and their fleas. Septicemic is the rarest of the plague varieties and is an infection in the blood, which can cause tissues to turn black and die, whereas the bubonic form causes swollen and painful lymph nodes, and the pneumonic form is a severe lung infection. The bubonic plague is the commonest type.\n\nThe disease doesn't spread easily to other people, and nobody else was infected, health officials said. However, experts warned of an 'increase of reported plague activity' and cautioned people to avoid handling or feeding rodents and other wildlife. 'While we see most plague activity during the summer, the disease can be found in rodents year-round, and [it] sometimes spills over into other wildlife species as well as domestic cats and dogs,' Dr Jenifer House, Colorado's public health veterinarian, said in a statement. 'Plague has been present in Colorado since at least the 1940s, and cases in wild rodents in Colorado are reported most years.'\n\nWhile the infection can be deadly if left untreated, most people recover when given antibacterial treatment promptly. Household pets like cats and dogs can also catch plague from infected wildlife, so the health department advised not allowing pets to roam or to hunt rodents, according to the outlet.\n\nEarlier this summer, a squirrel in Jefferson County tested positive for the bubonic plague, which killed more than 50 million people across Africa, Asia, and Europe in the Middle Ages and came to be known as 'black death'.\n\n[byline: Natalie O'Neill]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n['The typical sign of the most common form of human plague is a swollen and very tender lymph gland, accompanied by pain. The swollen gland is called a 'bubo'. Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2-6 days after being infected.\n\n'When bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream (septicemic plague). As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antimicrobial therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. About 14% (one in 7) of all plague cases in the United States are fatal.' (https://portal.ct.gov/-/media/Departments-and-Agencies/DPH/dph/communications/CERC/PlagueFSwebpdf.pdf?la=en)\n\nIn recent decades, an average of seven human plague cases have been reported each year in the United States (range: 1-17 cases per year) (https://www.cdc.gov/plague/maps/index.html). Most cases of _Y. pestis_ infections in the USA occur in the area of the 'Four Corner' states: Colorado, Arizona, New Mexico, and Utah, although California and, to a lesser extent, Oregon also may have cases. - Mod.LL\n\nA further factsheet is available from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention at https://www.cdc.gov/plague/resources/235098_Plaguefactsheet_508.pdf. - Mod.SH\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Colorado, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/209.]", "summary": "\n\n'When bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream (septicemic plague). \n\n\nA Colorado resident was infected with the plague after a squirrel in the state tested positive for the bubonic plague, the first human case in the state since 2015, according to a report. \n\nSepticemic plague is one of the 3 main forms of plague, the other forms being bubonic and pneumonic. Septicemic is the rarest of the plague varieties and is an infection in the blood, which can cause tissues to turn black and die, whereas the bubonic form causes swollen and painful lymph nodes, and the pneumonic form is a severe lung infection. Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. The National Centre for Zoonotic Diseases (NCZD) said the teenager from the western province of Govi-Altai (also spelled Altay) had died from eating marmot meat. A quarantine has now been put in place on 5 districts in the province, which shares a border with China. 'The result of a polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test revealed on Monday night [13 Jul 2020] that bubonic plague caused the death of a 15 year old boy,' Dorj Narangerel, a spokesperson for the health ministry, told a press conference.\n\nThe death follows the news earlier in July 2020 of 2 people testing positive for the disease in the neighboring province of Khovd. The NCZD is currently organizing a nationwide immunization program to stop the spread of the disease.\n\nIn 2019, a lockdown was imposed in the Mongolian province of Bayan-Olgii after reports that a couple had died from the bubonic plague after reportedly eating raw marmot meat.\n\nRussia has increased patrols in an attempt to stop people hunting marmots near its border with Mongolia. China issued a warning last week after a suspected case of bubonic plague was discovered in the autonomous region of Inner Mongolia.\n\n[byline: Carl McQueen]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is caused by _Yersinia pestis_.\n\nMost cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea, causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. The swollen gland is called a 'bubo' .Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2-6 days after being bitten.\n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antimicrobial therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. At this stage, person-to-person spread can occur, causing other cases of 'primary' plague pneumonia. A quarantine would be required with contact tracing and even prophylactic antimicrobials if the index case or cases actually had plague pneumonia.\n\nPlague is endemic in Mongolia. Marmots such as the Tarvaga, the Tarbagan or Mongolian marmot, _Marmota sibirica_, a large rodent related to the American woodchuck (_Marmota monax_), are thought to be significant zoonotic reservoirs for _Y. pestis_ in Eastern Asia. The name marmot (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marmot) comes from French marmotte, from Latin _mures monti_ 'mountain mouse'.\n\nWhile foodborne transmission of _Y. pestis_ has been described (for example, Leslie T, et al. Outbreak of gastroenteritis caused by _Yersinia pestis_ in Afghanistan. Epidemiol Infect. 2011; 139(5): 728-35; https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20663260), it is far more likely that the case was acquired via the bites of infected fleas.\n\nA vaccination program is reported to be under way. As discussed by Oyston and Titball (see Plague. In Beyond anthrax. Edited by Lutwick LI, Lutwick SM. Springer Science; 2008: pp. 55-76), historically both killed whole-cell plague vaccines and live attenuated ones (particularly strain EV) have been used in parts of the world. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Govi-Altay, Mongolia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/18050.]", "summary": "\n\n[byline: Carl McQueen]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is caused by _Yersinia pestis_. The result of a polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test revealed on Monday night [13 Jul 2020] that bubonic plague caused the death of a 15 year old boy,' Dorj Narangerel, a spokesperson for the health ministry, told a press conference. Most cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea, causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. At this stage, person-to-person spread can occur, causing other cases of 'primary' plague pneumonia. \n\nThe death follows the news earlier in July 2020 of 2 people testing positive for the disease in the neighboring province of Khovd.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2020-07-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2019-03-25 00:00:00", "2008-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Marmota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Afghanistan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mongolia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Khovd", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tarbagan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7543168", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - China (02): (NM) bubonic", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7543168", "date": "2020-07-06 10:43:24", "main_text": "PLAGUE - CHINA (02): (INNER MONGOLIA) BUBONIC\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 5 Jul 2020\nSource: Sohu [in Chinese, machine trans., edited]\nhttps://www.sohu.com/a/405898689_114988\n\n\nAccording to the Bayannur City Health Commission, on 5 Jul 2020, a herdsman in Wengen Town, Wulatezhongqi, Bayannur City [Inner Mongolia], was diagnosed as a case of bubonic plague by the expert team during the consultation in the Wulatezhongqi People's Hospital. Before the onset of the disease, the patient had been active in the plague epidemic area. At present, the patient has been isolated and is being treated in a local hospital and his condition is stable. Party committees and local governments attach great importance to epidemic prevention and control, and relevant prevention and control measures have been implemented.\n\nExperts reminded the general public to strictly follow the 'Three nos' and, 'Three reports' requirements for the prevention and control of plague, to effectively implement personal protection, and improve self-protection awareness and ability.\n\n1. 'Three no's': unauthorized hunting of epidemic animals, non-deprivation of epidemic animals, and unauthorized carrying of epidemic animals and their products out of the epidemic area.\n\n2. 'Three reports': marmots and other animals found to be sick (or dead) should be reported, patients with suspected plague should be reported, and patients with high fever and unexplained death should be reported.\n\n3. Maintain good personal hygiene habits, try to avoid going to crowded places, go to a medical institution for medical treatment, or wear a mask in time when the person has fever, cough, or other related symptoms.\n\n4. If you suspect that you have been in contact with the case, you can take the initiative to report to the local disease control department and obtain professional guidance. If you have fever, cough, lymph node pain, hemoptysis, or bleeding, you should see a doctor as soon as possible.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED Rapporteur Kunihiko Iizuka\n\n[Plague is caused by _Yersinia pestis_.\n\nMost cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea, causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. The swollen gland is called a 'bubo.' Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2-6 days after being bitten.\n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antimicrobial therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. At this stage, person-to-person spread can occur, causing other cases of 'primary' plague pneumonia. A quarantine would be required with contact tracing and even prophylactic antimicrobials if the index case or cases actually had plague pneumonia. - Mod.LL\n\nMaps of China: https://www.chinadiscovery.com/china-maps/china-provincial-map.html and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/37804]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. \n\nExperts reminded the general public to strictly follow the 'Three nos' and, 'Three reports' requirements for the prevention and control of plague, to effectively implement personal protection, and improve self-protection awareness and ability.
