Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. At this stage, person-to-person spread can occur, causing other cases of 'primary' plague pneumonia. Communicated by:\nProMED Rapporteur Kunihiko Iizuka\n\n[Plague is caused by _Yersinia pestis_.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2020-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bayannur City", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7546991", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Congo DR (06): (IT) bubonic, clusters, fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7546991", "date": "2020-07-07 09:30:04", "main_text": "PLAGUE - DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF CONGO (06): (ITURI) BUBONIC, CLUSTERS, FATAL\n****************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Mon 6 Jul 2020\nFrom: Anne Laudisoit <laudisoit@ecohealthalliance.org> [edited]\n\n\nOn 4 Jul 2020, 3 suspected cases (including one death) of bubonic plague were reported to the Ituri Provincial Health Division by the Kumudhu Health Centre head nurse (Aru Health District), Ituri Province, Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). These cases are reported from a region geographically disjunct from the ongoing epidemic in the health zone of Rethy (Plague - Congo DR (05): (IT) bubonic, septicemic, fatal 20200626.7513771).\n\nOn 5 Jul 2020, a team composed of the chief doctor and the head nurse supervisor of the Aru health zone, the chief physician and the laboratory technician from Aru General Hospital and the head nurses of Kumudu and Odranyi health centres investigated the site of the outbreak. They noted the presence of 2 suspected, active cases of bubonic plague originating from the Odranyi health area.\n\nThe reported patient (F, 60 years old) was admitted to the Kumudhu health centre but comes from Trangala village located in the Odranyi health area (N2\u00b0 47' 04.8' E30\u00b0 37' 05.0'), and presented with fever (39C/102.2F), intense headache, diarrhoea, and an inguinal bubo. A rapid diagnostic test performed on this patient's bubo aspirate was positive for plague. A 2nd case (M, 2 years old) was admitted to the Odranyi health centre on 5 Jul 2020 with fever and vomiting. He also was coming from the village of Trangala in a household that had experienced the death of a 1st patient (index case) who died of suspected bubonic plague on 3 Jul 2020. Upon arrival, the investigation team was notified of the death of a 1st 10-year-old child with high fever, repeated vomiting, and an inguinal lymph node in that household. The child had been treated with an indigenous treatment before succumbing to the disease. In addition, an epizootic of rats called 'edro' in the local language (Lugbara) was reported in the immediate vicinity of this household around 1 Jul 2020.\n\nA total of 18 contacts -- including those who attended the funeral wake of the deceased 10 year old boy -- were traced, doxycycline (100mg) was administered as a preventive measure, and 6 households were disinfected with deltamethrin.\n\n--\nPhocas Kasereka, Hopital General de Aru, DR Congo\nPascal Adroba, Provincial Health Division, Bunia, DR Congo; Technical Assistant at the Plague surveillance and control centre, Bunia, DR Congo\nMichel Mandro, Provincial Health Division, Bunia, DR Congo\nGustave Losa Lona, Plague surveillance and control centre , Bunia, DR Congo\nAnne Laudisoit, EcoHealth Alliance, New York, USA\nhttp://www.ecohealthalliance.org\n\n*****\n[2]\nDate: Mon 6 2020\nSource: Sohu [in Chinese, trans., edited]\nhttps://www.sohu.com/a/406021949_260616\n\n\nNews from a WeChat notice from China's embassy in Congo on 6 Jul 2020. On 3 Jul 2020, the Ituri Provincial Government announced that bubonic plague has occurred in the province's Djugu region. 36 cases have been confirmed with 8 deaths. According to a report from the World Health Organization, Ituri Province is the world's most active region for plague with about 1000 cases per year. Bubonic plague can be spread by infected fleas. Clinical manifestations are swelling of lymph nodes, fever, chills, headache, exhaustion, muscle aches, etc. The main treatment method is by antibiotics.\n\nChina's embassy to the DRC cautions Chinese citizens not to visit the outbreak region and take thorough personal precautions to avoid contact with rodents. If symptoms such as fever, chills, hemoptysis, or swelling of lymph nodes occur, seek medical attention right away.\nAffiliation:\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Dan Silver\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is caused by _Yersinia pestis_.\n\nMost cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea, causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. The swollen gland is called a 'bubo.' Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2-6 days after being bitten.\n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antimicrobial therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. At this stage, person-to-person spread can occur, causing other cases of 'primary' plague pneumonia. A quarantine would be required with contact tracing and even prophylactic antimicrobials if the index case or cases actually had plague pneumonia. - Mod.LL\n\nFor more information see: https://actualite.cd/2020/07/05/rdc-ituri-la-peste-bubonique-fait-8-deces (in French). - Mod.JH\n\nMaps of Congo DR: http://goo.gl/DM2AT8 and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/64029]", "summary": "\n\n--\nPhocas Kasereka, Hopital General de Aru, DR Congo\nPascal Adroba, Provincial Health Division, Bunia, DR Congo; Technical Assistant at the Plague surveillance and control centre, Bunia, DR Congo\nMichel Mandro, Provincial Health Division, Bunia, DR Congo\nGustave Losa Lona, Plague surveillance and control centre , Bunia, DR Congo\nAnne Laudisoit, EcoHealth Alliance, New York, USA\nhttp://www.ecohealthalliance.org\n\n*****\n A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n [edited]\n\n\nOn 4 Jul 2020, 3 suspected cases (including one death) of bubonic plague were reported to the Ituri Provincial Health Division by the Kumudhu Health Centre head nurse (Aru Health District), Ituri Province, Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). Affiliation:\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Dan Silver\n< \n\nThe reported patient (F, 60 years old) was admitted to the Kumudhu health centre but comes from Trangala village located in the Odranyi health area (N2\u00b0 47' 04.8' E30\u00b0 37' 05.0'), and presented with fever (39C/102.2F), intense headache, diarrhoea, and an inguinal bubo. Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. He also was coming from the village of Trangala in a household that had experienced the death of a 1st patient (index case) who died of suspected bubonic plague on 3 Jul 2020. \n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. These cases are reported from a region geographically disjunct from the ongoing epidemic in the health zone of Rethy (Plague - Congo DR (05): (IT) bubonic, septicemic, fatal 20200626.7513771). They noted the presence of 2 suspected, active cases of bubonic plague originating from the Odranyi health area. Most cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea, causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. \n\nA total of 18 contacts -- including those who attended the funeral wake of the deceased 10 year old boy -- were traced, doxycycline (100mg) was administered as a preventive measure, and 6 households were disinfected with deltamethrin. PLAGUE - DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF CONGO (06): (ITURI) BUBONIC, CLUSTERS, FATAL\n On 5 Jul 2020, a team composed of the chief doctor and the head nurse supervisor of the Aru health zone, the chief physician and the laboratory technician from Aru General Hospital and the head nurses of Kumudu and Odranyi health centres investigated the site of the outbreak. A 2nd case (M, 2 years old) was admitted to the Odranyi health centre on 5 Jul 2020 with fever and vomiting. According to a report from the World Health Organization, Ituri Province is the world's most active region for plague with about 1000 cases per year. At this stage, person-to-person spread can occur, causing other cases of 'primary' plague pneumonia. On 3 Jul 2020, the Ituri Provincial Government announced that bubonic plague has occurred in the province's Djugu region. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2-6 days after being bitten. Upon arrival, the investigation team was notified of the death of a 1st 10-year-old child with high fever, repeated vomiting, and an inguinal lymph node in that household. A quarantine would be required with contact tracing and even prophylactic antimicrobials if the index case or cases actually had plague pneumonia. Date: Mon 6 Jul 2020\n Date: Mon 6 2020\n Bubonic plague can be spread by infected fleas. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is caused by _Yersinia pestis_. If plague patients are not given specific antimicrobial therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. \n\nChina's embassy to the DRC cautions Chinese citizens not to visit the outbreak region and take thorough personal precautions to avoid contact with rodents. A rapid diagnostic test performed on this patient's bubo aspirate was positive for plague. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. In addition, an epizootic of rats called 'edro' in the local language (Lugbara) was reported in the immediate vicinity of this household around 1 Jul 2020. Clinical manifestations are swelling of lymph nodes, fever, chills, headache, exhaustion, muscle aches, etc. If symptoms such as fever, chills, hemoptysis, or swelling of lymph nodes occur, seek medical attention right away. Preliminary test results revealed on Monday [29 Jun 2020] that he... (had contracted) the bubonic plague,' the NCZD said in a statement, adding that the official result of the test will be released on Tuesday evening [30 Jun 2020].\n\nThe man is in critical condition, the NCZD added, urging citizens not to eat marmot meat. A couple died of bubonic plague in the western Mongolian province of Bayan-Ulgii in April 2019 after eating raw marmot meat.\n\nThe bubonic plague is a bacterial disease that is spread by fleas living on wild rodents such as marmots.\n\n[Byline: Bernama]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is caused by _Yersinia pestis_.\n\nMost cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea, causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. The swollen gland is called a 'bubo.' Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2-6 days after being bitten.\n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antimicrobial therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. At this stage, person-to-person spread can occur, causing other cases of 'primary' plague pneumonia.\n\nPlague is endemic in Mongolia. Marmots such as the Tarvaga, the Tarbagan or Mongolian marmot, _Marmota sibirica_, a large rodent related to the American woodchuck (_Marmota monax_), are thought to be significant zoonotic reservoirs for _Y. pestis_ in Eastern Asia. The name marmot (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marmot) comes from French marmotte, from Latin _mures monti_ 'mountain mouse.'\n\nWhile foodborne transmission of _Y. pestis_ has been described (e.g., Leslie T, et al. Outbreak of gastroenteritis caused by _Yersinia pestis_ in Afghanistan. Epidemiol Infect. 2011; 139(5): 728-35; https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20663260), it is far more likely that the bubonic plague cases [current case plus 2 from April 2019] were acquired via the bites of infected fleas. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nKhovd [Hovd] Province, Mongolia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/44622]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is caused by _Yersinia pestis_. The men, from Mongolia, are said to have contracted the deadly disease from marmots, in a country where consuming the innards of the animals is traditionally believed to be good for your health. A 27-year-old and his brother, 17, are being treated in separate hospitals in Khovd province in western Mongolia. The older brother is in a 'critical' condition.\n\nThe cases have now sparked urgent checks on 146 people with whom they were in contact. Health officials now face a big task ahead of them as it is believed 500 people may already be affected, say reports. Major security precautions have been put into operation amid fears of a spread.\n\nThe plague is spread by fleas living on wild rodents such as marmots, a large type of squirrel. The country's National Centre for Zoonotic Diseases confirmed that bubonic plague had been diagnosed, and emergency meetings have been set up.\n\nIt is a recurrent problem in the East Asian nation. A couple died of bubonic plague in the western Mongolian province of Bayan-Ulgii in April 2019 after eating raw marmot meat. It prompted authorities to warn against eating raw marmot because it can carry _Yersinia pestis_, the plague bacillus. The plague is spread by marmots coughing or through the bite of the tarbagan flea they carry, or through consumption of their meat.\n\n[Byline: Anna Savva]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Thu 2 Jul 2020\nSource: Moscow Times [edited]\nhttps://www.themoscowtimes.com/2020/07/02/mongolia-quarantines-russian-border-region-over-bubonic-plague-suspicion-a70756\n\n\nMongolia has quarantined its western region near the border with Russia after identifying 2 suspected cases of the black plague linked to the consumption of marmot meat, health officials said Wed 1 Jul 2020. Lab tests confirmed that 2 unidentified individuals had contracted the 'marmot plague' in the region of Khovd, Mongolia's National Center for Zoonotic Disease (NCZD) said in a statement.\n\nThe NCZD said it moved to quarantine the provincial capital and one of the region's districts about 500 km [311 mi] south of the southern Siberian republics of Tyva and Altai. Vehicles are temporarily banned from entering the region, the state-run TASS news agency cited Mongolian media as saying.\n\nThe NCZD said it has analyzed samples taken from 146 people who it said had contacts with the 2 infected persons and identified 504 2nd-contact individuals. Media reports suggested that the victims were a 27-year-old male and a young woman of an unknown age.\n\nMongolia closed a key border crossing with Russia in May 2019 on suspicion that it may have played a role in an outbreak of the plague, stranding several Russian tourists. A husband and wife had died after eating marmot meat in that incident. Experts say the direct descendants of the same bubonic plague that killed 50 million people in the 14th century still exist today, killing around 2000 people a year.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[One report states that a 2nd case was the brother of the primary case, but the other report states that it was a woman.\n\nPlague is caused by _Yersinia pestis_.\n\nMost cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea, causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. The swollen gland is called a 'bubo.' Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2-6 days after being bitten.\n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antimicrobial therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. At this stage, person-to-person spread can occur, causing other cases of 'primary' plague pneumonia. A quarantine would be required with contact tracing and even prophylactic antimicrobials if the index case or cases actually had plague pneumonia.\n\nPlague is endemic in Mongolia. Marmots such as the Tarvaga, the Tarbagan or Mongolian marmot, _Marmota sibirica_, a large rodent related to the American woodchuck (_Marmota monax_), are thought to be significant zoonotic reservoirs for _Y. pestis_ in Eastern Asia. The name marmot (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marmot) comes from French marmotte, from Latin _mures monti_ 'mountain mouse.'\n\nWhile foodborne transmission of _Y. pestis_ has been described (e.g., Leslie T, et al. Outbreak of gastroenteritis caused by _Yersinia pestis_ in Afghanistan. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2019-04-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2020-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2019-05-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Afghanistan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tarbagan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mongolia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Khovd", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Marmota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tyva", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7343777", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Congo DR (03): bubonic, fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7343777", "date": "2020-05-16 18:49:16", "main_text": "PLAGUE - DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF CONGO (03): BUBONIC, FATAL\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 4 May 2020\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/plague-cases-reported-again-in-drc-99496/\n\n\nAfter going several weeks without a reported human plague case in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), new cases were reported between mid-February and mid-March [2020]. Since the beginning of the year [2020], a total of 20 suspected bubonic plague cases with 7 deaths (case fatality ratio 35%) were notified in 5 health zones: Aungba (4 cases and 2 deaths), Linga (7 cases and 5 deaths), Rethy (6 cases and no deaths), Aru (2 cases and no deaths), and Kambala (1 case and no deaths). From week 1 to 52 of 2019, a total of 48 cases of bubonic plague including 8 deaths have been reported in the country.\n\nPlague is an infectious disease caused by the bacterium, _Yersinia pestis_. It is found in animals throughout the world, most commonly rats but other rodents like ground squirrels, prairie dogs, chipmunks, rabbits, and voles. Fleas typically serve as the vector of plague. People can also get infected through direct contact with an infected animal, through inhalation, and, in the case of pneumonic plague, person to person. _Yersinia pestis_ infection is treatable with antimicrobials if started early enough.\n\nThere are 3 forms of human plague; bubonic, septicemic, and pneumonic. Bubonic plague is the most common form. In this form, the bacteria enter the body through the bite of an infected flea or rodent. Here the bacteria infect the lymphatic system. After a few days to a week, the person will experience fever, chills, weakness, and swollen lymph glands. These are called buboes.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The bacterium that causes plague is _Yersinia pestis_. Most cases of plague are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. The swollen gland is called a 'bubo.' Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2-6 days after being bitten. At this point in the illness, there is no risk of person-to-person spread, so if this was indeed a case of bubonic plague, no isolation or quarantine is necessary.\n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may produce bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antimicrobial therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. At this stage, as appears to have happened in this case, person-to-person spread can occur, causing other cases of 'primary' plague pneumonia.\n\nPatients with primary pneumonic plague generate large quantities of infectious aerosols that pose a significant risk to close contacts.\n\nCDC (US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) guidelines identify contacts within 2 meters (6.5 ft) as being at greatest risk and do not consider the organism likely to be carried through air ducts or vents. Persons who have been in contact with pneumonic plague patients or handling potentially infectious body fluids or tissues without appropriate protection should receive preventive antimicrobial therapy. The preferred antimicrobial agents for prophylaxis include tetracyclines and fluoroquinolones. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nDR Congo: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/194]", "summary": "Since the beginning of the year [2020], a total of 20 suspected bubonic plague cases with 7 deaths (case fatality ratio 35%) were notified in 5 health zones: Aungba (4 cases and 2 deaths), Linga (7 cases and 5 deaths), Rethy (6 cases and no deaths), Aru (2 cases and no deaths), and Kambala (1 case and no deaths). Most cases of plague are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. People can also get infected through direct contact with an infected animal, through inhalation, and, in the case of pneumonic plague, person to person. _ \n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. At this stage, as appears to have happened in this case, person-to-person spread can occur, causing other cases of 'primary' plague pneumonia. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The bacterium that causes plague is _Yersinia pestis_. At this point in the illness, there is no risk of person-to-person spread, so if this was indeed a case of bubonic plague, no isolation or quarantine is necessary. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. From week 1 to 52 of 2019, a total of 48 cases of bubonic plague including 8 deaths have been reported in the country. After going several weeks without a reported human plague case in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), new cases were reported between mid-February and mid-March [2020]. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2-6 days after being bitten. Persons who have been in contact with pneumonic plague patients or handling potentially infectious body fluids or tissues without appropriate protection should receive preventive antimicrobial therapy. \n\nThere are 3 forms of human plague; bubonic, septicemic, and pneumonic. Patients with primary pneumonic plague generate large quantities of infectious aerosols that pose a significant risk to close contacts. PLAGUE - DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF CONGO (03): BUBONIC, FATAL\n As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. If plague patients are not given specific antimicrobial therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. Plague is an infectious disease caused by the bacterium, _Yersinia pestis_. Bubonic plague is the most common form. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may produce bloody sputum. After a few days to a week, the person will experience fever, chills, weakness, and swollen lymph glands. LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nDR Congo: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/194] Fleas typically serve as the vector of plague. These are called buboes.\n\n--\n In this form, the bacteria enter the body through the bite of an infected flea or rodent. guidelines identify contacts within 2 meters (6.5 ft) as being at greatest risk and do not consider the organism likely to be carried through air ducts or vents.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of the", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kambala", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7513771", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Congo DR (05): (IT) bubonic, septicemic, fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7513771", "date": "2020-06-26 21:52:15", "main_text": "PLAGUE - DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF CONGO (05): (ITURI) BUBONIC, SEPTICEMIC, FATAL\n******************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 26 Jun 2020\nFrom: Anne Laudisoit <laudisoit@ecohealthalliance.org> [edited]\n\n\nSince 11 Jun 2020, a total of 29 plague cases have been reported in the Ituri endemic focus of Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), Djugu territory.\n\nOn 17 Jun 2020, 10 cases were reported, including 4 deaths (CFR = 0.4), from 4 villages. As of 26 Jun 2020, the number of cases has risen to 29 (17 female, 12 male) with 6 deaths (CFR = 0.2), and patients are now reported from 10 villages in 5 health areas (Kpandroma 2 cases, Lokpa 23, Ngri Balo 1, Rassia 2 and Uketha 1) located within the Rethy Health zone.\n\nThe investigation team composed of the chief medical doctor of the Rethy Health zone, the nurses from the Rethy General Reference Hospital and the Center for Neglected Tropical Diseases (Rethy HGR-CRMT), sanitation officers, and community relay have been pursuing contact tracing, ensuring dignified and safe burials, and taking care of chemoprophylaxis distribution.\n\nHowever, because of the presence of militia in the region, the insecurity has increased, limiting movements and preventing support response teams access to the outbreak site, consequently affecting drug provision. Added to this crisis situation, the COVID-19 pandemic's stigma and the lack of resources locally have slowed down and impaired a swift response. This situation is to be monitored as the bubonic cases emerge in several localities, and the report of multiple rat die-offs suggests that the situation may worsen and -- if not treated promptly -- may evolve into a pneumonic plague outbreak.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nFrancoise Ngave Nyisi, Rethy General Reference Hospital, Congo DR\nJean de Dieu Dheda Bulo, Rethy Health Zone, Congo DR\nPascal Adroba, Provincial Division of Health, Bunia, Congo DR\nMichel Mandro, Provincial Division of Health, Bunia, Congo DR\nAnne Laudisoit, Ecohealth Alliance, New York, USA\n<laudisoit@ecohealthalliance.org>\n\n[ProMED thanks the contributors for this follow-up post of a new outbreak of plague in the endemic area of Congo DR.\n\nThe bacterium that causes plague is _Yersinia pestis_. Most cases of plague are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. The swollen gland is called a 'bubo'. Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2-6 days after being bitten. At this point in the illness, there is no risk of person-to-person spread, so if this was indeed a case of bubonic plague, no isolation or quarantine is necessary.\n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may produce bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antimicrobial therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. At this stage, as appears to have happened in this case, person-to-person spread can occur, causing other cases of 'primary' plague pneumonia.\n\nPatients with primary pneumonic plague generate large quantities of infectious aerosols that pose a significant risk to close contacts.\n\nCDC (US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) guidelines identify contacts within 2 meters (6.5 ft) as being at greatest risk and do not consider the organism likely to be carried through air ducts or vents. Persons who have been in contact with pneumonic plague patients or handling potentially infectious body fluids or tissues without appropriate protection should receive preventive antimicrobial therapy. The preferred antimicrobial agents for prophylaxis include tetracyclines and fluoroquinolones. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nIturi, Democratic Republic of the Congo: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/64029]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Francoise Ngave Nyisi, Rethy General Reference Hospital, Congo DR\nJean de Dieu Dheda Bulo, Rethy Health Zone, Congo DR\nPascal Adroba, Provincial Division of Health, Bunia, Congo DR\nMichel Mandro, Provincial Division of Health, Bunia, Congo DR\nAnne Laudisoit, Ecohealth Alliance, New York, USA\n< Most cases of plague are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. As of 26 Jun 2020, the number of cases has risen to 29 (17 female, 12 male) with 6 deaths (CFR = 0.2), and patients are now reported from 10 villages in 5 health areas (Kpandroma 2 cases, Lokpa 23, Ngri Balo 1, Rassia 2 and Uketha 1) located within the Rethy Health zone. This situation is to be monitored as the bubonic cases emerge in several localities, and the report of multiple rat die-offs suggests that the situation may worsen and -- if not treated promptly -- may evolve into a pneumonic plague outbreak. \n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. At this stage, as appears to have happened in this case, person-to-person spread can occur, causing other cases of 'primary' plague pneumonia. At this point in the illness, there is no risk of person-to-person spread, so if this was indeed a case of bubonic plague, no isolation or quarantine is necessary. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. Persons who have been in contact with pneumonic plague patients or handling potentially infectious body fluids or tissues without appropriate protection should receive preventive antimicrobial therapy. laudisoit@ecohealthalliance.org>\n\n[ProMED thanks the contributors for this follow-up post of a new outbreak of plague in the endemic area of Congo DR. PLAGUE - DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF CONGO (05): (ITURI) BUBONIC, SEPTICEMIC, FATAL\n [edited]\n\n\nSince 11 Jun 2020, a total of 29 plague cases have been reported in the Ituri endemic focus of Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), Patients with primary pneumonic plague generate large quantities of infectious aerosols that pose a significant risk to close contacts. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2-6 days after being bitten. \n\nThe investigation team composed of the chief medical doctor of the Rethy Health zone, the nurses from the Rethy General Reference Hospital and the Center for Neglected Tropical Diseases (Rethy HGR-CRMT), sanitation officers, and community relay have been pursuing contact tracing, ensuring dignified and safe burials, and taking care of chemoprophylaxis distribution. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. \n\nThe bacterium that causes plague is _Yersinia pestis_. If plague patients are not given specific antimicrobial therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nIturi, Democratic Republic of the Congo: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/64029] \n\n--\n On 17 Jun 2020, 10 cases were reported, including 4 deaths (CFR = 0.4), from 4 villages. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may produce bloody sputum. guidelines identify contacts within 2 meters (6.5 ft) as being at greatest risk and do not consider the organism likely to be carried through air ducts or vents. Date: Fri 26 Jun 2020\n However, because of the presence of militia in the region, the insecurity has increased, limiting movements and preventing support response teams access to the outbreak site, consequently affecting drug provision. **\n Communicated by:\n Added to this crisis situation, the COVID-19 pandemic's stigma and the lack of resources locally have slowed down and impaired a swift response. \n\nCDC (US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) \n\n \n\n \n\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2020-06-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2020-06-11 00:00:00", "2020-06-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bunia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "DR", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Democratic Republic of Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Adroba", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Democratic Republic of the", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lokpa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rethy Health Zone", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ecohealth Alliance", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7224404", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, animal - USA: (WY) cougar", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7224404", "date": "2020-04-14 18:27:28", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA: (WYOMING) COUGAR\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 9 Apr 2020\nSource: Belleville News Democrat [edited]\nhttps://www.bnd.com/news/nation-world/national/article241909026.html\n\n\nIn Yellowstone, cougars are facing an epidemic of their own: Bubonic plague.\n\nThe flea-borne disease, most famous for killing half of Europe during the medieval ages, is showing up in the cougar population inhabiting the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem [GYE], according to a recent study.\n\nFindings suggest it could be widespread. Of the 28 big cats researchers tested, 12 were infected or had been infected, according to the study published in Environmental Conservation.\n\n'This suggests that: (bubonic plague) may be present at higher levels in the GYE than previously assumed,' it said, also adding that plague may be a 'significant' cause of death for the animals.\n\nResearchers carried out the study over the course of 9 years, following the discovery of 2 dead cougars, a mother and her cub, in Wyoming, the Smithsonian Magazine said.\n\nThe deaths weren't in and of themselves surprising, lead researcher Mark Elbroch told Livescience.\n\nIt was the winter, and so starvation was the presumed culprit, but when the true cause of death was discovered, it 'was a shocker,' he told the outlet.\n\nResearchers said it's very unlikely the average person would ever catch plague from a mountain lion, but given that the disease is capable of animal-to-human transmission, they recommended warnings for some.\n\n'We would also emphasize that hunters and others handling pumas in this region should be made aware of the possibility of exposure,' the study said.\n\nCougar behavior makes them a poor means of transferring diseases to people, but as Elbroch's team points out, their high rate of infection means the Yellowstone ecosystem itself could be a hotbed of plague.\n\nA Boy Scout came down with plague in 2008 following a camping trip in Yellowstone National Park, the Jackson Hole News & Guide reported.\n\n'Plague is very much a part of the landscape in the western U.S., and wild animals are frequently exposed to it,' a USDA researcher Sarah Bevins told National Geographic. 'Human plague infections are still relatively rare ... but untreated plague infections are still just as deadly as they were 500 years ago.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations. Small rodents such as deer mice and grasshopper mice are suggested to act as the reservoirs. Larger species like squirrels, chipmunks and prairie dogs are considered to be more vulnerable to infection.\n\nCarnivores (like cougars) may be infected through fleabite or ingestion of infected rodents. Studies of black bears (another carnivore) in California found plague antibody prevalence from 15% to 36%.\n\nThe study referred to can be accessed at https://doi.org/10.1017/S0376892920000065. The abstract reads: 'We tested for plague (_Yersinia pestis_) in a puma population in the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem (GYE) over 9 years, overlapping a case when a boy in the area became infected with plague. Antibodies to _Y. pestis_ were detected in 8 of 17 (47%) pumas tested by complementenzyme-linked immunosorbent assay, and the organism itself was detected in 4 of 11 (36%) pumas tested after necropsy. Neither puma sex nor age was significantly associated with _Y. pestis_ exposure or mortality, although our sample size was small. The overall prevalence of exposure we recorded was similar to that found along the western slope of Colorado, which is adjacent to the Four Corners region, a known plague hotspot in the USA. This suggests that: (1) _Y. pestis_ may be present at higher levels in the GYE than previously assumed; (2) plague is a significant source of mortality for local pumas (6.6% of sub-adult and adult mortality); and (3) pumas may be a useful sentinel for potential risk of plague exposure to humans throughout the West. We would also emphasize that hunters and others handling pumas in this region should be made aware of the possibility of exposure.' - Mod.PMB\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nWyoming, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/251]", "summary": "This suggests that: (1) _Y. pestis_ may be present at higher levels in the GYE than previously assumed; (2) plague is a significant source of mortality for local pumas (6.6% of sub-adult and adult mortality); and (3) pumas may be a useful sentinel for potential risk of plague exposure to humans throughout the West. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Human plague infections are still relatively rare ... but untreated plague infections are still just as deadly as they were 500 years ago.'\n\n--\n \n\n'This suggests that: (bubonic plague) may be present at higher levels in the GYE than previously assumed,' it said, also adding that plague may be a 'significant' cause of death for the animals. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. The abstract reads: 'We tested for plague (_Yersinia pestis_) in a puma population in the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem (GYE) over 9 years, overlapping a case when a boy in the area became infected with plague. \n\n'We would also emphasize that hunters and others handling pumas in this region should be made aware of the possibility of exposure,' the study said. \n\nCougar behavior makes them a poor means of transferring diseases to people, but as Elbroch's team points out, their high rate of infection means the Yellowstone ecosystem itself could be a hotbed of plague. \n\n'Plague is very much a part of the landscape in the western U.S., and wild animals are frequently exposed to it,' a USDA researcher Sarah Bevins told National Geographic. ' PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA: (WYOMING) COUGAR\n**************************************\n \n\nCarnivores (like cougars) may be infected through fleabite or ingestion of infected rodents. Researchers said it's very unlikely the average person would ever catch plague from a mountain lion, but given that the disease is capable of animal-to-human transmission, they recommended warnings for some.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-04-11 00:00:00", "2008-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "National Park", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Livescience", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yellowstone", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7026580", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Congo DR: (IT) pneumonic, fatal, susp, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7026580", "date": "2020-02-25 23:51:45", "main_text": "PLAGUE - DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF CONGO: (ITURI) PNEUMONIC, FATAL, SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n***************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 25 Feb 2020\nFrom: Anne Laudisoit <laudisoit@ecohealthalliance.org> [edited]\n\n\nA suspect plague outbreak cluster has been noted in the Godjoka health area as of 19 Feb 2020. The chief medical officer of the Rethy Health zone, the head nurse and the laboratory team from the Rethy General reference hospital investigated the outbreak site. The Godjoka village is located in the Linga health zone, Djugu territory, Ituri province, in the Congo DR (N 02.01'47.9'' and E030.44'56.6'', 1940m) in the plague endemic area.\n\nThere have been 6 suspected cases of plague, including 5 deaths and 1 recovering patient. The index case is a young boy who died on 19 Feb 2020. His mother, the neighbour and her child all died on 21 Feb 2020 and were buried the night of 24 Feb 2020, under pressure from the villagers. Finally, the traditional healer ['tradipraticien'] who took care of the mother (who was the 2nd case) died in turn on 25 Feb 2020, and samples were taken that same day. The rapid diagnostic test was positive for plague. Because of their rapidly fatal course, pneumonic plague is suspected for one or more of the 5 fatal cases.\n\nThe only survivor has been under treatment at the Godjoka Health center since 22 Feb; he is the 20-year-old brother of the index case. The test on the sputum of this patient was negative.\n\n--\nFrancoise Ngave Nyisi, Rethy General Reference Hospital, DR Congo\nMandro Michel, Provincial Division of Health, Bunia, DR Congo\nAdroba Pascal, Provincial Division of Health, Bunia, DR Congo\nLaudisoit Anne, Ecohealth Alliance, New York, USA\n<laudisoit@ecohealthalliance.org>\n\n\n\n[ProMED thanks Dr Laudisoit and her hardworking Congolese colleagues for this important report. Thus far the diagnosis of plague rests on the single positive diagnostic test obtained from the traditional healer, as it appears that the first 4 fatal cases were buried before diagnostic tests could be obtained. Following this logic, It is possible that the sole survivor thus far has the bubonic form of the disease, and thus a negative sputum result. We seek and hope to obtain further information on all of these cases, including age, nature, and duration of symptoms, presence or absence of buboes, etc.\n\nThis putative plague cluster is in a known historic plague-endemic region, where there were 31 cases and 8 deaths between Jan - Oct 2019, as previously reported by ProMED (Plague - Congo DR (02): (IT) fatal 20191016.6731137). The Ituri district, of course, has also been affected by the still smouldering North Kivu-Ituri Ebola outbreak that began in July 2018. This district has also been, and continues to be, a region of great civil unrest, with multiple armed insurgency groups operating near and across the Ugandan border.\n\nThe following background information on plague by Mod.LL is copied from our most recent ProMED post on plague [see below under See Also]:\n\n'The bacterium that causes plague is _Yersinia pestis_. Most cases of plague are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. The swollen gland is called a 'bubo.' Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2-6 days after being bitten. At this point in the illness, there is no risk of person-to-person spread, so if this was indeed a case of bubonic plague, no isolation or quarantine is necessary.\n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antimicrobial therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. At this stage, as appears to have happened in this case, person-to-person spread can occur, causing other cases of 'primary' plague pneumonia. - Mod.LL\n\nA ProMED/HealthMap of DR Congo is available at: DR Congo: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/194. - Mod.LXL]", "summary": "This putative plague cluster is in a known historic plague-endemic region, where there were 31 cases and 8 deaths between Jan - Oct 2019, as previously reported by ProMED (Plague - Congo DR (02): (IT) fatal 20191016.6731137). Most cases of plague are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. \n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Thus far the diagnosis of plague rests on the single positive diagnostic test obtained from the traditional healer, as it appears that the first 4 fatal cases were buried before diagnostic tests could be obtained. LL is copied from our most recent ProMED post on plague [see below under See Also]:\n\n'The bacterium that causes plague is _Yersinia pestis_. Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. At this stage, as appears to have happened in this case, person-to-person spread can occur, causing other cases of 'primary' plague pneumonia. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. At this point in the illness, there is no risk of person-to-person spread, so if this was indeed a case of bubonic plague, no isolation or quarantine is necessary. \n\nThere have been 6 suspected cases of plague, including 5 deaths and 1 recovering patient. Francoise Ngave Nyisi, Rethy General Reference Hospital, DR Congo\nMandro Michel, Provincial Division of Health, Bunia, DR Congo\nAdroba Pascal, Provincial Division of Health, Bunia, DR Congo\nLaudisoit Anne, Ecohealth Alliance, New York, USA\n< Because of their rapidly fatal course, pneumonic plague is suspected for one or more of the 5 fatal cases.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2020-02-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2018-07-25 00:00:00", "2020-02-21 00:00:00", "2020-02-19 00:00:00", "2020-02-24 00:00:00", "2019-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Mod", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Congo DR", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Kivu - Ituri", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Linga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ecohealth Alliance", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "DR", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bunia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7480784", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Congo DR (04): (IT) bubonic, septicemic, fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7480784", "date": "2020-06-17 17:04:58", "main_text": "PLAGUE - DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF CONGO (04): (ITURI) BUBONIC, SEPTICEMIC, FATAL\n******************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 16 Jun 2020\nFrom: Anne Laudisoit <laudisoit@ecohealthalliance.org> [edited]\n\n\nA bubonic and septicemic plague cluster has been noted in the Ituri endemic focus of Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), Djugu territory, on 14 Jun 2020 by the Lokpa health center nurse (N 2 deg 01' 34.0' E 30 deg 54' 35.4', 2082 m).\n\nOn 15 Jun 2020, a team composed of 2 laboratory technicians, the head nurse of the Rethy General Reference Hospital and the Center for Neglected Tropical Diseases (Rethy HGR-CRMT) and a sanitation officer of the Rethy health zone, investigated the outbreak site and tested 6 patients for plague with a rapid diagnostic test. As of 16 Jun 2020, of the 10 cases (of which 4 deaths were reported), 8 were diagnosed with bubonic plague and 2 were diagnosed with septicemic plague.\n\nThree suspect patients came from Bbala village (N 02 deg 01' 53.4' E 030 deg 54' 32.9', 2093 m asl), 5 from Zambi village (N 02 deg 02' 21.7' E 030 deg 54' 30.2', 1993 m asl), 1 from Dzavikpa village (N 02 deg 01' 16.3' E 030 deg 54' 53.4', 2083 m) and 1 from Kpagboma village (N 2 deg 00' 38.7' E 30 deg 54' 35.7', 2066 m asl).\n\nThe index case seems to be a 4 year old boy coming from Zambi village (Lokpa health area) who died on 11 Jun 2020; samples were not taken. On 14 Jun 2020, his 41 year old father also succumbed to the disease, which prompted the head nurse of the Lokpa health centre to alert the heath authorities of the Rethy health zone. The saliva sample tested positive for plague with a rapid diagnostic test performed on the deceased on 15 Jun 2020.\n\nIn total, the investigation team tested 6 patients (2 deceased), and 4 (2 from Bbala and 2 from Zambi) were positive for plague (blood, saliva or bubo aspirate). All contacts who had attended the funeral wake of the deceased and from active cases' households were administered chemoprophylaxis (doxycycline or cotrimoxazole according to age), and houses of the patients were disinfected. People have confirmed recent rat die-off in Bbala and Zambi villages.\n\nThe investigation team is monitoring the outbreak despite the insecurity in the region and the lockdown measures due to COVID-19.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nFrancoise Ngave Nyisi, Rethy General Reference Hospital, Congo DR\nMichel Mandro, Provincial Division of Health, Bunia, Congo DR\nPascal Adroba, Provincial Division of Health, Bunia, Congo DR\nAnne Laudisoit, Ecohealth Alliance, New York, USA\n<laudisoit@ecohealthalliance.org>\n\n[ProMED thanks the contributors for this post of a new outbreak of plague in the endemic area of Congo DR.\n\nThe bacterium that causes plague is _Yersinia pestis_. Most cases of plague are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. The swollen gland is called a 'bubo'. Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2-6 days after being bitten. At this point in the illness, there is no risk of person-to-person spread, so if this was indeed a case of bubonic plague, no isolation or quarantine is necessary.\n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may produce bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antimicrobial therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. At this stage, as appears to have happened in this case, person-to-person spread can occur, causing other cases of 'primary' plague pneumonia.\n\nPatients with primary pneumonic plague generate large quantities of infectious aerosols that pose a significant risk to close contacts.\n\nCDC (US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) guidelines identify contacts within 2 meters (6.5 ft) as being at greatest risk and do not consider the organism likely to be carried through air ducts or vents. Persons who have been in contact with pneumonic plague patients or handling potentially infectious body fluids or tissues without appropriate protection should receive preventive antimicrobial therapy. The preferred antimicrobial agents for prophylaxis include tetracyclines and fluoroquinolones. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Ituri, Democratic Republic of the Congo: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/64029.]", "summary": "\n\nThree suspect patients came from Bbala village (N 02 deg 01' 53.4' E 030 deg 54' 32.9', 2093 m asl), 5 from Zambi village (N 02 deg 02' 21.7' E 030 deg 54' 30.2', 1993 m asl), 1 from Dzavikpa village (N 02 deg 01' 16.3' E 030 deg 54' 53.4', 2083 m) and 1 from Kpagboma village (N 2 deg 00' 38.7' E 30 deg 54' 35.7', 2066 m asl). [edited]\n\n\nA bubonic and septicemic plague cluster has been noted in the Ituri endemic focus of Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), Djugu territory, on 14 Jun 2020 by the Lokpa health center nurse (N 2 deg 01' 34.0' E 30 deg 54' 35.4', 2082 m). As of 16 Jun 2020, of the 10 cases (of which 4 deaths were reported), 8 were diagnosed with bubonic plague and 2 were diagnosed with septicemic plague. On 15 Jun 2020, a team composed of 2 laboratory technicians, the head nurse of the Rethy General Reference Hospital and the Center for Neglected Tropical Diseases (Rethy HGR-CRMT) and a sanitation officer of the Rethy health zone, investigated the outbreak site and tested 6 patients for plague with a rapid diagnostic test. In total, the investigation team tested 6 patients (2 deceased), and 4 (2 from Bbala and 2 from Zambi) were positive for plague (blood, saliva or bubo aspirate). All contacts who had attended the funeral wake of the deceased and from active cases' households were administered chemoprophylaxis (doxycycline or cotrimoxazole according to age), and houses of the patients were disinfected. guidelines identify contacts within 2 meters (6.5 ft) as being at greatest risk and do not consider the organism likely to be carried through air ducts or vents. \n\nThe investigation team is monitoring the outbreak despite the insecurity in the region and the lockdown measures due to COVID-19. Date: Tue 16 Jun 2020\n The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may produce bloody sputum. LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Ituri, Democratic Republic of the Congo: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/64029.] \n\nCDC (US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) **\n \n\n \n\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1993-03-25 00:00:00", "2066-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2020-06-11 00:00:00", "2020-06-14 00:00:00", "2020-06-16 00:00:00", "2020-06-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Zambi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lokpa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Democratic Republic of Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bunia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Democratic Republic of the", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ecohealth Alliance", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bbala", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "DR", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Adroba", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "kpagboma", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6814943", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - China (04): (NM) pneumonic", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6814943", "date": "2019-11-30 17:26:05", "main_text": "PLAGUE - CHINA (04): (INNER MONGOLIA) PNEUMONIC\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 28 Nov 2019\nSource: XinhuaNet [edited]\nhttp://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2019-11/28/c_138590117.htm\n\n\nA new pneumonic plague case has been confirmed in Ulanqab, northern China's Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region, after a herdsman was diagnosed on Wed 27 Nov 2019. The city is over 500 km [about 311 mi] away from Xilingol League in the region, where the other 3 pneumonic plague cases were previously found.\n\nThe patient, who had visited a region where plague sources were identified, was being treated in isolation and was in a stable condition at the Siziwang Banner People's Hospital in Ulanqab, according to the hospital on Thu 28 Nov 2019. Four people who had close contact with the patient have been isolated for medical observation as required. None of them have shown symptoms such as fever at present.\n\nSiziwang Banner has completed comprehensive disinfection and sterilization of the patient's house and the surrounding pastoralists' dwellings. Local authorities are implementing rodent and flea control and publicity work. After the plague cases, the health department in Inner Mongolia has carried out investigations and rodent extermination.\n\n[byline: Xuxin]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Previous posts reported that only 2 of the recent cases were pneumonic. This post appears to report the 3rd Inner Mongolia case of pneumonic plague. The epidemiology of this case is not stated.\n\nThe bacterium that causes plague is _Yersinia pestis_. Most cases of plague are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. The swollen gland is called a 'bubo'. Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2-6 days after being bitten. At this point in the illness, there is no risk of person-to-person spread, so if this was indeed a case of bubonic plague, no isolation or quarantine is necessary.\n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antimicrobial therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. At this stage, as appears to have happened in this case, person-to-person spread can occur, causing other cases of 'primary' plague pneumonia. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region, China: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/356.]", "summary": "\n\n[byline: Xuxin]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Previous posts reported that only 2 of the recent cases were pneumonic. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Most cases of plague are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. \n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. At this stage, as appears to have happened in this case, person-to-person spread can occur, causing other cases of 'primary' plague pneumonia. Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. At this point in the illness, there is no risk of person-to-person spread, so if this was indeed a case of bubonic plague, no isolation or quarantine is necessary. \n\nThe patient, who had visited a region where plague sources were identified, was being treated in isolation and was in a stable condition at the Siziwang Banner People's Hospital in Ulanqab, according to the hospital on Thu 28 Nov 2019.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2019-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ulanqab", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CHINA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Inner Mongolia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7028683", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Congo DR (02): (IT) bubonic, pneumonic, fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7028683", "date": "2020-02-26 13:39:07", "main_text": "PLAGUE - DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF CONGO (02): (ITURI) BUBONIC, PNEUMONIC, FATAL\n*****************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 26 Feb 2020\nFrom: Anne Laudisoit <laudisoit@ecohealthalliance.org> [edited]\n\n\n[1] Bubonic plague investigation - RFI\n--------------------------------------\nOn 22 Feb 2020, the Aungba Health Zone chief medical doctor was alerted that suspect bubonic plague cases were reported in the Ugunzu-Makangi village of the Aterlembe health area, Djugu territory, Ituri Province, DR Congo. Murine epizootics were also mentioned in the Makangi village. On 23 Feb 2020, the chief medical doctor of the Aungba health Zone (Lat 2 33' 00'' Long 30 30' 00'') was appointed to visit the health center of Aterlembe for 2 days to investigate suspect bubonic plague cases. The head doctor Dr Delphonse Unen Ali reported on the same day (23 Feb 2020) on the outbreak. The nurse of the Aterlembe health center notified 2 suspected cases of bubonic plague. He reported that the index cases were 2 family members who presented with fever, headache, and painful buboes on 22 Feb 2020 at 2 health centers. After self-medicating for 6 days (16-22 Feb 2020), they consulted as ambulatory patients the Kpese health post and then the Yuku health center, both in the Aru health zone. A 2-year-old boy died on 21 Feb 2020 with symptoms consistent with that of bubonic plague (fever, painful buboes), the 2nd patient -- the 12 year old brother of the co-primary case -- tested positive for plague with the RDT [rapid diagnostic test] and is recovering. He presented with fever, painful buboes, and headaches. So far 16 contacts have been traced and treated with doxycycline, 27 households were dusted.\n\n[2] Pneumonic plague - follow up to: PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Congo DR: (IT) pneumonic, fatal, susp, RFI 20200225.7026580\n--------------------\nBetween 19 Feb 2020 and 25 Feb 2020, the health area of Godjoka has experienced an outbreak of suspected pneumonic plague. Symptoms reported were headache, painful cough, dyspnea, hemoptysis, and diarrhea lasting 3 days followed by death. On 25 Feb 2020, the traditional healer's body, positive for plague with the rapid diagnostic test, was transported by relatives to a small locality near Kpandruma (Lat. 2\u00b0 03' 15.3' Long. 30\u00b0 50' 58.2', alt 2804m) in the Rethy Health Zone, Djugu territory, Ituri Province DR Congo. She was buried there. The transport by relatives increases the risk of plague spread to relatives and mourning villagers. It should be noted that the city of Kpandruma is the major commercial center of the region . On 25 Feb 2020, the intervention team treated over 300 contacts with doxycycline, and disinfected the houses where the bodies were laid prior to burial. Children under 10 years old and pregnant women have received cotrimoxazole [trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole] on the morning of 26 Feb 2020.\n\n--\nFrancoise Ngave Nyisi, Rethy General Reference Hospital, DR Congo\nMichel Mandro, Provincial Division of Health, Bunia, DR Congo\nPascal Adroba, Provincial Division of Health, Bunia, DR Congo\nGustave Losa Lona, Coordinator of the Plague Surveillance center in Ituri (CSLP)\nAnne Laudisoit, EcoHealth Alliance, New York, USA\n<laudisoit@ecohealthalliance.org>\n\n[ProMED thanks our colleagues in the Democratic Republic of the Congo and at the EcoHealth Alliance for this report.\n\nThe bacterium that causes plague is _Yersinia pestis_. Most cases of plague are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. The swollen gland is called a 'bubo.' Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2-6 days after being bitten. At this point in the illness, there is no risk of person-to-person spread, so if this was indeed a case of bubonic plague, no isolation or quarantine is necessary.\n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may produce bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antimicrobial therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. At this stage, as appears to have happened in this case, person-to-person spread can occur, causing other cases of 'primary' plague pneumonia.\n\nPatients with primary pneumonic plague generate large quantities of infectious aerosols that pose a significant risk to close contacts.\n\nCDC (US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) guidelines identify contacts within 2 meters (6.5 ft) as being at greatest risk and do not consider the organism likely to be carried through air ducts or vents. Persons who have been in contact with pneumonic plague patients or handling potentially infectious body fluids or tissues without appropriate protection should receive preventive antimicrobial therapy. The preferred antimicrobial agents for prophylaxis include tetracyclines and fluoroquinolones. - Mod.LL\n\nMaps of Congo DR: http://goo.gl/DM2AT8 and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/64029]", "summary": "A 2-year-old boy died on 21 Feb 2020 with symptoms consistent with that of bubonic plague (fever, painful buboes), the 2nd patient -- the 12 year old brother of the co-primary case -- tested positive for plague with the RDT [rapid diagnostic test] and is recovering.
