PMB]\n\n******\n Date: Sun 6 Oct 2019\n Date: Sun 6 Oct 2019\n The guinea pig, _C. porcellus_ is one of the few species domesticated by pre-Columbian civilizations (the other 2 are llamas and alpacas).", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2000-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2019-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00", "2019-10-06 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Anses", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tanzania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Blukwa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ecuador", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "DR", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Microcavia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Guinea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mbulu", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Galea", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6622982", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Madagascar (02): (AV) bubonic", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6622982", "date": "2019-08-14 21:22:48", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (02): (ANTANANARIVO) BUBONIC\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 9 Aug 2019\nSource: RFI [in French, machine trans. edited]\nhttp://www.rfi.fr/afrique/20190809-madagascar-peste-bubonique-saison-pesteuse-premiers-cas\n\n\nIn Madagascar, the plague season has started. The 1st 3 cases of bubonic plague have just been recorded 50 km west of the capital. No deaths have occurred for the moment, but the Ministry of Health is watching. As every year, awareness campaigns have started. The goal: to prevent the spread of epidemics like that of 2017, the black year, which had more than 200 victims and 2400 people infected by the bacterium throughout the Malagasy territory.\n\n'Do not repeat the mistakes of the past' is the stated ambition of the Ministry of Health. Contacted by telephone, the Director General of Preventive Medicine, Dr. Fidiniaina Randriatsarafara, said that 'information and awareness activities have started. Radio clips are being broadcast on local radio stations to remind the public that the appearance of swelling, sudden fever, or chest pains require an immediate visit to the nearest health center. Clinics are sometimes several hours walking distance away, and patients more easily consult traditional healers.\n\nAt present, health centers in plague-endemic areas are all expected to be provided with drugs, since treatment exists to treat both forms of plague on the island. However, some clinics are still awaiting them, according to a ministry official.\n\nAnother important preventive measure is the requirement for road transport companies to register the name and telephone number of all passengers during the plague season. In 2017, it was a sick traveler who transmitted the pneumonic plague to other passengers, extending the epidemic to Tamatave. However, according to a regional carrier, many companies do not register passengers and are not sanctioned.\n\n--\nCommunicated by\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nfrom\nProMED-FRA\n\n[Plague infections in Madagascar have been relatively quiet since the dramatic outbreak in 2017.\n\nThe following paragraph is from Chanteau S, Ratsifasoamanana L, Rasoamanana B, et al. Plague, a reemerging disease in Madagascar. Emerg Infect Dis 1998;4(1):101-4, PMID: 9452403; available at http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/4/1/98-0114_article.htm:\n\n'Between 1930 and 1990, bubonic plague had 'virtually disappeared' on the island due to efficient pest-control and good health management. However, since 1990, an annual 200 cases are being reported, and bubonic plague takes on epidemic form, especially in the port of Mahajanga, each year. In the capital city of Antananarivo, more cases are being notified each year since 1990. Madagascar (pop. 13 million) has accounted for 45% of all the cases of plague in Africa.'\n\nFatalities related to plague usually are caused by spread of the organism from the bubo (the very painful infected lymph node that drains the area where the flea bite occurred) to the bloodstream. The bacteremia can cause a coagulopathy, producing the purpura seen in the 'black plague,' and also may spread to the lungs causing a hemorrhagic pneumonia. It is the pneumonia that can facilitate person-to-person transmission.\n\nMadagascar was the location of the isolation of multi-antimicrobial resistant _Yersinia pestis_ in 1995 (Galimand M, Guiyoule A, Gerbaud G, et al. Multidrug resistance in _Yersinia pestis_ mediated by a transferable plasmid. N Engl J Med. 1997;337(10):677-80, PMID: 9278464; available at http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJM199709043371004). The strain was resistant to chloramphenicol, streptomycin, and tetracycline but sensitive to fluoroquinolones and trimethoprim as well as other aminoglycosides. This was an ominous observation; however, it is not clear whether this naturally occurring strain has persisted or spread. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nAntananarivo, Analamanga, Madagascar: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/9420]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nAt present, health centers in plague-endemic areas are all expected to be provided with drugs, since treatment exists to treat both forms of plague on the island. Emerg Infect Dis 1998;4(1):101-4, PMID: 9452403; available at http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/4/1/98-0114_article.htm:\n\n'Between 1930 and 1990, bubonic plague had 'virtually disappeared' on the island due to efficient pest-control and good health management. from\nProMED-FRA\n\n[Plague infections in Madagascar have been relatively quiet since the dramatic outbreak in 2017. LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nAntananarivo, Analamanga, Madagascar: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/9420] The bacteremia can cause a coagulopathy, producing the purpura seen in the 'black plague,' and also may spread to the lungs causing a hemorrhagic pneumonia.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1995-03-25 00:00:00", "1990-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-01-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Analamanga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mahajanga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rasoamanana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6602703", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (03): (CO) prairie dogs", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6602703", "date": "2019-08-02 17:15:26", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (03): (COLORADO) PRAIRIE DOGS\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 1 Aug 2019\nSource: KDVR Fox Denver [edited]\nhttps://kdvr.com/2019/08/01/plague-detected-in-commerce-city-prairie-dogs/\n\n\nPlague-infested fleas are affecting prairie dog colonies throughout the Commerce City region and prompted the closure of multiple heavily trafficked areas nearby. The Tri-County Health Department released a statement regarding the plague on Thursday [1 Aug 2019], saying the disease is common and can be dealt with using insecticide to kill the fleas (http://www.tchd.org/271/Animal-Related-Zoonotic-Diseases).\n\nWhile there are no reported cases of the plague detected in humans in Commerce City, the Rocky Mountain Arsenal National Wildlife Refuge, Commerce City open space areas, and unpaved parking areas at Dick's Sporting Goods Park have all voluntarily closed in order to protect people and pets (https://www.fws.gov/refuge/rocky_mountain_arsenal/).\n\nSigns have been posted and insecticide is being used to mitigate the problem.\n\nWhile the plague does not usually cause dogs [and cats] to fall ill, they can transport the fleas. Common symptoms of the plague in humans include fever, swollen and tender lymph nodes, chills, and extreme exhaustion. If you believe you may have the plague, contact your doctor.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Domestic pets, and especially cats, can bring infected fleas into the house. This is not uncommon. So make sure your animals are routinely treated for fleas to keep down the risk. Even better, keep your cats indoors.\n\nPlague may infect humans through several routes: (1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals (mentioned previously); (2) direct contact with contaminated tissues, generally from an animal; or (3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals.\n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under the jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front leg (the armpit, if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever. These clinical signs may be present in the dog as well. Swelling under the jaw in cats is frequently mistaken as a cat fight abscess. Please take your pet to a veterinarian if you notice any abnormalities. Be sure to consult your veterinarian if you find a lump on your pet, as well as to get the best flea prevention treatment for your pet. It may be necessary to have your yard and/or home treated for fleas. Vacuum your home, including any bedding and furniture, and immediately upon finishing, take the vacuum back outside, seal it in a plastic bag, and dispose of it. This type of cleaning will have to be repeated every week for 4-6 weeks to break the cycle of the flea in the home. This disease should be taken seriously, so please be sure your pet is on some form of flea prevention.\n\nTo find Commerce City, go to http://fallingrain.com/world/US/CO/Commerce_City.html. - Mod.MHJ\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nColorado, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/209]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Domestic pets, and especially cats, can bring infected fleas into the house. Plague may infect humans through several routes: (1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals (mentioned previously); (2) direct contact with contaminated tissues, generally from an animal; or (3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals. Source: KDVR Fox Denver [edited]\nhttps://kdvr.com/2019/08/01/plague-detected-in-commerce-city-prairie-dogs/\n\n\nPlague-infested fleas are affecting prairie dog colonies throughout the Commerce City region and prompted the closure of multiple heavily trafficked areas nearby. \n\nWhile there are no reported cases of the plague detected in humans in Commerce City, the Rocky Mountain Arsenal National Wildlife Refuge, Commerce City open space areas, and unpaved parking areas at Dick's Sporting Goods Park have all voluntarily closed in order to protect people and pets (https://www.fws.gov/refuge/rocky_mountain_arsenal/). \n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under the jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front leg (the armpit, if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever. \n\nWhile the plague does not usually cause dogs [and cats] to fall ill, they can transport the fleas. MHJ\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nColorado, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/209] The Tri-County Health Department released a statement regarding the plague on Thursday [1 Aug 2019], saying the disease is common and can be dealt with using insecticide to kill the fleas (http://www.tchd.org/271/Animal-Related-Zoonotic-Diseases).", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Commerce City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6714191", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (04): (NM)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6714191", "date": "2019-10-07 23:52:07", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (04): (NEW MEXICO)\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 4 Oct 2019\nSource: New Mexico (USA) Department of Health [edited]\nhttps://nmhealth.org/news/disease/2019/10/?view=805\n\n\nThe New Mexico Department of Health's (NMDOH) Scientific Laboratory Division has confirmed a case of plague in a 72-year-old man from Torrance County, the 1st human case of plague in New Mexico this year [2019].\n\nPlague is a disease caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is generally transmitted to humans from the bites of infected fleas that live among rodents and rabbits. Plague can also be transmitted by direct contact with infected animals. Pet dogs and cats can become infected with plague when they eat an infected rodent or when they are bitten by an infected flea.\n\nNMDOH staff have gone door-to-door in the affected area to inform neighbors about plague and provided them with education to reduce their risks.\n\n'No matter where you call home in New Mexico, you can reduce the risk of plague by avoiding contact with rodents or their fleas, or outdoor pets by providing appropriate flea prevention for pets year-round,' said Secretary of Health Kathy Kunkel.\n\nSymptoms of plague in humans include sudden onset of a fever, chills, headache, and weakness usually within one to 7 days of becoming infected. There may be a painful swelling of the lymph node in the neck, armpit or groin areas, referred to as bubonic plague. The infection can also spread to the blood, causing septicemic plague, or to the lungs, causing pneumonic plague.\n\nWith prompt diagnosis and appropriate antibiotic treatment, the fatality rate in people and pets can be greatly reduced. Physicians who suspect plague should promptly report all cases to the New Mexico Department of Health.\n\nTo prevent plague, the Department of Health recommends that residents:\n\n- Avoid sick or dead rodents and rabbits, and their nests and burrows.\n- Clean up areas near the house where rodents could live, such as woodpiles, brush piles, junk and abandoned or un-used vehicles.\n- See a healthcare provider about any unexplained illness involving a sudden and severe fever. Inform your healthcare provider about any flea bites, contact with rodents, or burrows during the previous couple of weeks.\n- Wear protective clothing to prevent flea bites while working outside.\n- Provide safe and effective flea control for pets as recommended by a veterinarian.\n- Sick pets should be examined promptly by a veterinarian.\n\nThis is the 1st human plague case in New Mexico since 2017, a year where there was a total of 4 human cases. There has been one animal plague case in a dog in Quay County in 2019 (see Department of Health Reports Plague Case in Quay County). There were 3 cases of animal plague in dogs in 2018, and 28 animal plague cases in 2017 in New Mexico.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Earlier comment from Mod.LL (archive number 20180614.5856107):\n'The manifestations of _Yersinia pestis_ infection in this case are not stated in the report but it is likely to have been bubonic plague. Of late, 2015 was a 'banner year' for _Y. pestis_ infections in the USA with 15 cases and 4 deaths. In recent decades, an average of 7 human plague cases have been reported each year (range: 1-17 cases per year) with 0-2 deaths.\n\nThe following was extracted from: Prentice MB, Rahalison L. Plague. Lancet. 2007; 369(9568): 1196-207, with the citations removed:\n\n'Some plague cases (10-25 per cent) present with primary septicemia (hypotension, shock) without lymph nodes being obviously affected and these patients have higher mortality than those with bubonic plague. The term septicemic plague can be confusing, since most patients with buboes have detectable bacteremia at some stage and can also have high-density bacteremia with systemic signs of sepsis. Debate about whether septicemic plague is always secondary to frank or subclinical bubonic or pneumonic disease continues, but work in mice lends support to the existence of a syndrome of septicemic disease without histological changes in lymph nodes in a few animals infected by flea bites.'\n\nEarlier comment of Mod.TG (archive number 20190413.6421127):\n\n'Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations. Surveillance efforts testing fleas are very important to detect circulation of _Y. pestis_ and risk of infection.\n\nPlague may infect human beings through several routes: 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals (mentioned previously; 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues, generally from an animal; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals.\n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under the jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front leg (the armpit, if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever (or chills). These clinical signs may be present in the dog as well. Swelling under the jaw in cats is frequently mistaken as a cat-fight abscess.\n\nIf your pets are not on flea prevention, please ask your veterinarian about the best flea prevention. Bathing your pet in dishwashing soap is not sufficient to help your pet avoid diseases carried by fleas. Some of the over the counter flea preventions may be harmful to your pet, so please check with your veterinarian. It is also a good time to make sure your pet is current on a rabies shot.\n\nKeeping your pets inside is best, and being inside a yard will help diminish the ability to consume a dead animal and further reduce the risk of plague to your animal and to yourself.' - Mod.LM\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nNew Mexico, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/233]", "summary": "Plague may infect human beings through several routes: 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals (mentioned previously; 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues, generally from an animal; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals. \n\n'No matter where you call home in New Mexico, you can reduce the risk of plague by avoiding contact with rodents or their fleas, or outdoor pets by providing appropriate flea prevention for pets year-round,' said Secretary of Health Kathy Kunkel. 2007; 369(9568): 1196-207, with the citations removed:\n\n'Some plague cases (10-25 per cent) present with primary septicemia (hypotension, shock) without lymph nodes being obviously affected and these patients have higher mortality than those with bubonic plague. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n In recent decades, an average of 7 human plague cases have been reported each year (range: 1-17 cases per year) with 0-2 deaths.\n\n \n\nPlague is a disease caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is generally transmitted to humans from the bites of infected fleas that live among rodents and rabbits. Debate about whether septicemic plague is always secondary to frank or subclinical bubonic or pneumonic disease continues, but work in mice lends support to the existence of a syndrome of septicemic disease without histological changes in lymph nodes in a few animals infected by flea bites.' There were 3 cases of animal plague in dogs in 2018, and 28 animal plague cases in 2017 in New Mexico. Scientific Laboratory Division has confirmed a case of plague in a 72-year-old man from Torrance County, the 1st human case of plague in New Mexico this year [2019]. \n\nKeeping your pets inside is best, and being inside a yard will help diminish the ability to consume a dead animal and further reduce the risk of plague to your animal and to yourself.' \n\nThis is the 1st human plague case in New Mexico since 2017, a year where there was a total of 4 human cases. \n\nTo prevent plague, the Department of Health recommends that residents:\n\n- Avoid sick or dead rodents and rabbits, and their nests and burrows. Pet dogs and cats can become infected with plague when they eat an infected rodent or when they are bitten by an infected flea. LL (archive number 20180614.5856107):\n'The manifestations of _Yersinia pestis_ infection in this case are not stated in the report but it is likely to have been bubonic plague. \n\nSymptoms of plague in humans include sudden onset of a fever, chills, headache, and weakness usually within one to 7 days of becoming infected. There has been one animal plague case in a dog in Quay County in 2019 (see Department of Health Reports Plague Case in Quay County). PLAGUE - USA (04): (NEW MEXICO)\n*******************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "rabies"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2019-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-10-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Quay County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mod", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Torrance County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6710185", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Congo DR: (IT) fatal, human, rodent", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6710185", "date": "2019-10-06 07:31:26", "main_text": "PLAGUE - DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF CONGO: (ITURI) FATAL, HUMAN, RODENT\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 4 Oct 2019\nFrom: Dr. Pascal Adroba, Dr. Anne Laudisoit, and Dr. William Karesh [edited]\n\n\nOn 25 Sep 2019, a rodent and guinea pig die-off was reported to the health authorities of the Aru Health Zone, Ituri Province, DRC, in the village of Omeyi in the Ongoyi health area. Subsequently a family cluster of 4 cases with the clinical symptoms consistent with the definition of bubonic plague was reported. Symptoms were high fever in 3 patients and high fever with a painful inguinal swollen lymph node in the 15-year-old patient. This family was admitted at the health center of Ekanga on 25 Sep 2019; unfortunately, the 15-year-old boy died on 26 Sep 2019. The other 3 patients were treated with doxycycline (200 mg/day for 5 days).\n\nThe DRC health zone team arrived on 27 Sep 2019 to spray the houses with deltamethrin, take human and wildlife samples, and raise community awareness of the measures to be taken. In response to this situation, the head of the Health Center of Ekanga alerted the Central Office of the health zone, and 225 villagers were given doxycycline preventively (single 200-mg dose for adults and children ). A plague rapid diagnostic test (RDT) was performed on the 3 other patients but only one was weakly positive, possibly due to antibiotic treatment. Two samples taken on the dying guinea pigs (lymph node aspirate) were strongly positive with the same RDT.\n\nIn total, 12 suspected plague cases (4 male, 8 female) and 3 deaths have been reported since 27 Sep 2019: 7 cases and 3 deaths from Omeyi, 3 cases from Ongoyi, 1 case from Doro and 1 case from Alembele village.\n\nThe provincial division of health is closely monitoring the situation and should send a team to the outbreak site on 7 Oct 2019. Rodent samples have been stored in ethanol for PCR diagnostic confirmation of bubonic plague.\n\nThe location of the village in proximity with the Ugandan border (20 km [12.4 mi] maximum) and with people seeking treatment in Uganda presents an additional risk of transborder outbreak as earlier this year [2019]. In March 2019, a 35-year-old woman died of pneumonic plague in Uganda after spending time in Atungulei village in DRC's Ituri province, and where her 4-year-old child had died days before. Further investigation revealed that finding her sick at her child's burial, her relatives took her to Uganda for treatment.\n\n--\nDr. Pascal Adroba\nCaritas, Bunia, Ituri Province, DRC\nwith additional details from\nDr. Anne Laudisoit\nEcoHealth Alliance\n<laudisoit@ecohealthalliance.org>\nWilliam B. Karesh, DVM\nExecutive Vice President for Health and Policy\nEcoHealth Alliance\n<karesh@ecohealthalliance.org>\n\n[ProMED is grateful to Drs. Adroba, Laudisoit, and Karesh for reporting this cluster of rodent and human plague occurring in Ituri, DRC. Although rodents and their fleas are the source of human plague, we don't often identify ill and dying animals in proximity and in advance of human cases.\n\nFrom Mod.LL: 'Most cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. The swollen gland is called a 'bubo'. Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2 to 6 days after being bitten.\n\n'When bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antibiotic therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death.'\n\nPlague is endemic in this region of DRC, and this outbreak adds to the woes of a region where Ebola virus disease and measles have been occurring. Moreover, symptoms and signs of plague may overlap with those of Ebola and complicate diagnosis and provision of appropriate medical care. ProMED reported plague in an adjacent region of Uganda in March 2019 (Archive number 20190312.6363171). - Mod.LM\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nDR Congo: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/194\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nIturi, Democratic Republic of the Congo: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/64029]", "summary": "In total, 12 suspected plague cases (4 male, 8 female) and 3 deaths have been reported since 27 Sep 2019: 7 cases and 3 deaths from Omeyi, 3 cases from Ongoyi, 1 case from Doro and 1 case from Alembele village. Although rodents and their fleas are the source of human plague, we don't often identify ill and dying animals in proximity and in advance of human cases. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The other 3 patients were treated with doxycycline (200 mg/day for 5 days).", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2019-09-25 00:00:00", "2019-09-27 00:00:00", "2019-03-25 00:00:00", "2019-09-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Adroba", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Atungulei", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bunia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ituri Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ekanga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Democratic Republic of the", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Laudisoit", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ongoyi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Omeyi", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6454287", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Mongolia (02): (BO) bubonic, marmot, fatal, quarantine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6454287", "date": "2019-05-03 20:16:31", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MONGOLIA (02): (BAYAN-OLGIY) BUBONIC, MARMOT, FATAL, QUARANTINE\n************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 3 May 2019\nSource: Mirror [edited]\nhttps://www.mirror.co.uk/news/world-news/bubonic-plague-outbreak-plane-passengers-14987444\n\n\nA married couple has died, leaving their 4 children orphaned after an outbreak of the bubonic plague, which sparked plane panic.\n\nThe man, 38, named only as Citizen T, and his pregnant wife, 37, are thought to have fallen ill after hunting and eating contaminated marmot, a large species of squirrel, in Mongolia. The man died on 27 Apr [2019], and the woman died 3 days later, reports the Siberian Times.\n\nThe highly contagious bacterial disease is spread by fleas living on wild rodents. It has sparked fears of an outbreak, and urgent measures and precautions have been put in place to stop the infection spreading. Around 158 people have been put under intensive medical supervision after coming into contact directly or indirectly with the couple.\n\nThere were dramatic scenes when a flight from Bayan, Ulgii and Khovd in Mongolia -- the area where the couple fell ill -- was met by workers in white anti-contamination suits as [the plane] landed in the country's capital of Ulaanbaatar.\n\nEleven passengers from the west of the country were held at the airport and sent immediately for hospital checks. Others were examined in a special facility at the airport. Paramedics in anti-contamination boarded the flight as soon as it landed.\n\nSome frontier checkpoints with Russia are reported to have been closed, leading to foreign tourists being stranded in Mongolia.\n\nDr N. Tsogbadrakh, director of National Centre for Zoonotic Dermatology and Medicine, said, 'Despite the fact that eating marmots is banned, Citizen T hunted marmot. He ate the meat and gave it to his wife, and they died because the plague affected his stomach. Four children are orphaned.'\n\nBubonic plague is believed to be the cause of the Black Death that spread through Asia, Europe, and Africa in the 14th century, killing an estimated 50 million people.\n\nThe plague is a bacterial disease that is spread by fleas living on wild rodents such as marmots. The disease can kill an adult in less than 24 hours if not treated in time, according to the World Health Organisation.\n\n[Byline: Will Stewart and Amber Hicks]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Kunihiko Iizuka\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nBayan-Olgiy Aymag, Bayan-Olgiy, Mongolia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/34282]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nThere were dramatic scenes when a flight from Bayan, Ulgii and Khovd in Mongolia -- the area where the couple fell ill -- was met by workers in white anti-contamination suits as [the plane] landed in the country's capital of Ulaanbaatar. [Byline: Will Stewart and Amber Hicks]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\n \n\nThe plague is a bacterial disease that is spread by fleas living on wild rodents such as marmots. ProMED-mail Rapporteur Kunihiko Iizuka\n\n[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nBayan-Olgiy Aymag, Bayan-Olgiy, Mongolia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/34282] PLAGUE - MONGOLIA (02): (BAYAN-OLGIY) BUBONIC, MARMOT, FATAL, QUARANTINE\n************************************************************************\n \n\nBubonic plague is believed to be the cause of the Black Death that spread through Asia, Europe, and Africa in the 14th century, killing an estimated 50 million people. \n\nThe highly contagious bacterial disease is spread by fleas living on wild rodents.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2038-03-25 00:00:00", "2037-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ulaanbaatar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mongolia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6452212", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Mongolia: (BO) bubonic, susp, fatal, quarantine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6452212", "date": "2019-05-02 12:38:38", "main_text": "PLAGUE - PLAGUE - MONGOLIA: (BAYAN-OLGIY) BUBONIC, SUSPECTED, FATAL, QUARANTINE\n*******************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 1 May 2019 15:46:16 ULAT\nSource: Xinhua News Agency [edited]\nhttp://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2019-05/01/c_138027120.htm\n\n\nA district of the western Mongolian province of Bayan-Olgiy has been quarantined after 2 people died of suspected bubonic plague, local media reported Wed 1 May 2019. A couple died in suspicious circumstances in Ulgii district of the western province in late April 2019, news website <gogo.mn> quoted the province's emergency management department as saying.\n\n'Preliminary test results show that bubonic plague likely caused the deaths of the 2 people. The province's office has declared an indefinite quarantine in Ulgii soum,' the department said in a statement, adding that further investigation of the case is still underway.\n\nPlague is a bacterial disease that is spread by fleas living on wild rodents such as marmots. The disease can kill an adult in fewer than 24 hours if not treated in time, according to the WHO.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is caused by _Yersinia pestis_.\n\nMost cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. The swollen gland is called a 'bubo.' Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2 to 6 days after being bitten.\n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antibiotic therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. At this stage, as appears to have happened in the report above, person-to-person spread can occur, causing other cases of 'primary' plague pneumonia.\n\nPlague is endemic in Mongolia. Marmots such as the Tarvaga, the Tarbagan or Mongolian marmot, _Marmota sibirica_, a large rodent related to the American woodchuck (_M. monax_), are thought to be significant zoonotic reservoirs for _Y. pestis_ in Eastern Asia. The name marmot (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marmot) comes from French marmotte, from Latin _mures monti_ 'mountain mouse.'\n\nMaps of Mongolia can be found at http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/mongolia.pdf and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/34282. The province of Bayan-Olgiy is in the extreme western part of the country. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n PLAGUE - PLAGUE - MONGOLIA: (BAYAN-OLGIY) BUBONIC, SUSPECTED, FATAL, QUARANTINE\n*******************************************************************************\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is caused by _Yersinia pestis_. Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2019-05/01/c_138027120.htm\n\n\nA district of the western Mongolian province of Bayan-Olgiy has been quarantined after 2 people died of suspected bubonic plague, local media reported Wed 1 May 2019. \n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. \n\n'Preliminary test results show that bubonic plague likely caused the deaths of the 2 people. Most cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. At this stage, as appears to have happened in the report above, person-to-person spread can occur, causing other cases of 'primary' plague pneumonia.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2019-05-25 00:00:00", "2019-05-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/34282", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ulgii", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tarbagan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6421127", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (02): (NM) dog", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6421127", "date": "2019-04-13 20:59:46", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (02): (NEW MEXICO) DOG\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 12 Apr 2019\nSource: KOB [edited]\nhttps://www.kob.com/new-mexico-news/quay-county-first-case-of-plague/5314839/\n\n\nThe New Mexico Department of Health has reported the 1st case of plague this year [2019], in Quay County. Health officials say a ranch dog was reported with the illness but has since recovered, thanks to treatment from his veterinarian.\n\nPlague is an infectious disease caused by bacteria usually transmitted through the bite of an infected flea. Animals can also be infected through the eating of other animals who are infected.\n\nHumans can contract the plague through contact with tissues of infected animals and rarely through inhalation of coughed droplets from a sick pet. [Humans may also acquire the disease by being bitten by infected fleas. - Mod.TG]\n\n'Plague can be deadly for pets and people if not promptly treated with antibiotics,' said Kathy Kunkel, cabinet secretary for the New Mexico Department of Health (NMDOH). 'We encourage pet owners to discuss with their veterinarians the best way to protect their animals from fleas.'\n\nSymptoms [in people] of the plague include sudden onset of fever, chills, headache, and weakness. Signs in animals include fever, tiredness, and loss of appetite.\n\nPhysicians in New Mexico who suspect plague should immediately call 505-827-0006.\n\nHere are other recommendations from the Department of Health in order to avoid the plague:\n\n- Avoid sick or dead rodents and rabbits and their nests and burrows.\n- Clean up areas near the home where rodents could live, such as woodpiles, brush or junk piles, outbuildings, sheds, and abandoned vehicles.\n- Since pets who enjoy the outdoors can inadvertently carry infected fleas home, it is recommended they be on a flea-prevention product year-round.\n- Prevent pets from roaming and hunting.\n- Sick pets should be examined promptly by a veterinarian.\n- See your doctor about any unexplained illness involving a sudden and high fever, and be sure to describe to your provider if you've had contact with fleas, sick animals, or rodents.\n\n[Byline: Marian Camacho]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations. Surveillance efforts testing fleas are very important to detect circulation of _Y. pestis_ and risk of infection.\n\nPlague may infect human beings through several routes: 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals mentioned previously; 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues, generally from an animal; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals.\n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under the jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front leg (the armpit, if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever (or chills). These clinical signs may be present in the dog as well as the cat. Swelling under the jaw in cats is frequently mistaken as a cat-fight abscess. Contact with the fluid from such an abscess carries a high risk of infection for the person contacting it.\n\nPlease take your pet to a veterinarian if you notice any abnormalities. Be sure to consult your veterinarian if you find a lump on your pet, as well as to get the best flea-prevention treatment for your pet, regardless of whether it is a cat, dog, or even a rabbit. It may be necessary to have your yard and/or home treated for fleas. Vacuum your home, including any bedding and furniture, and immediately upon finishing, take the vacuum bag outside, seal it in a plastic bag, and dispose of it. This type of cleaning will have to be repeated every week for 3-6 weeks to break the cycle of the flea in the home. This disease should be taken seriously, so please be sure your pet is on some form of flea-prevention year around.\n\nIf your pets are not on flea prevention, please ask your veterinarian about the best flea prevention. Bathing your pet in dishwashing soap is not sufficient to help your pet avoid diseases carried by fleas. Some of the over-the-counter flea preventions may be harmful to your pet, so please check with your veterinarian. It is also a good time to make sure your pet is current on a rabies shot.\n\nKeeping your pets inside is best, and being inside a yard will help diminish the ability to consume a dead animal and will further reduce the risk of plague to your animal and to yourself. - Mod.TG\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nQuay County, New Mexico, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/11455]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Plague may infect human beings through several routes: 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals mentioned previously; 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues, generally from an animal; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals. \n\nHumans can contract the plague through contact with tissues of infected animals and rarely through inhalation of coughed droplets from a sick pet. \n\nIf your pets are not on flea prevention, please ask your veterinarian about the best flea prevention. Be sure to consult your veterinarian if you find a lump on your pet, as well as to get the best flea-prevention treatment for your pet, regardless of whether it is a cat, dog, or even a rabbit. \n\nHere are other recommendations from the Department of Health in order to avoid the plague:\n\n- Avoid sick or dead rodents and rabbits and their nests and burrows. \n\nKeeping your pets inside is best, and being inside a yard will help diminish the ability to consume a dead animal and will further reduce the risk of plague to your animal and to yourself. Since pets who enjoy the outdoors can inadvertently carry infected fleas home, it is recommended they be on a flea-prevention product year-round. \n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under the jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front leg (the armpit, if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever (or chills). PLAGUE - USA (02): (NEW MEXICO) DOG\n***********************************\n - See your doctor about any unexplained illness involving a sudden and high fever, and be sure to describe to your provider if you've had contact with fleas, sick animals, or rodents. TG]\n\n'Plague can be deadly for pets and people if not promptly treated with antibiotics,' said Kathy Kunkel, cabinet secretary for the New Mexico Department of Health (NMDOH). TG\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nQuay County, New Mexico, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/11455] \n\nSymptoms [in people] of the plague include sudden onset of fever, chills, headache, and weakness. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "rabies"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Quay County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6363171", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Uganda: Congo DR border, pneumonic, fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6363171", "date": "2019-03-12 13:09:14", "main_text": "PLAGUE - UGANDA: DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF CONGO BORDER, PNEUMONIC, FATAL\n**********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 12 Mar 2019\nSource: AFP [edited]\nhttps://www.9news.com.au/2019/03/12/10/54/deadly-plague-on-uganda-congo-border-who\n\n\nA deadly form of plague has broken out on Uganda's border with the Democratic Republic of Congo, and several people are thought to have died of the disease, WHO has said. The agency praised Ugandan health workers for vigilance and prompt action in spotting a suspected outbreak of pneumonic plague, which WHO says is usually fatal unless detected early and treated with antimicrobials.\n\nUganda's Health Ministry reported 2 probable cases of the illness in Zombo district on 5 Mar 2019 after a 35 year old woman died and her 23 year old cousin reported similar symptoms, WHO said in a report on [Mon 11 Mar 2019]. Further investigation revealed the dead woman had lived in Atungulei village in Congo's Ituri province, and her 4 year old child had died days beforehand. Finding her sick at her child's burial, her relatives took her to Uganda for treatment.\n\nThe cousin's symptoms raised suspicions of plague, and a preliminary rapid diagnostic test was positive for the disease. Results on additional specimens sent to Uganda's Plague Laboratory in Arua were pending. The patient was steadily improving, the WHO report said.\n\nSome 55 people, including 11 health workers and people who took part in the dead woman's funeral, had been identified as high-risk contacts and were being followed up. An additional 3 other people reportedly died of similar symptoms in Congo, WHO said, and Congolese authorities were investigating.\n\nPneumonic plague is caused by the _Yersinia pestis_ bacterium, usually found in small mammals and their fleas. Humans can be infected through flea bites, unprotected contact with bodily fluids or contaminated materials, and the inhalation of droplets or small particles from a patient with pneumonic plague.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. The swollen gland is called a 'bubo'. Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2 to 6 days after being bitten.\n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antibiotic therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. At this stage, as appears to have happened in this case, person-to-person spread can occur, causing other cases of 'primary' plague pneumonia. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail maps:\nUganda: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/97\nDR Congo: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/194]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nUganda's Health Ministry reported 2 probable cases of the illness in Zombo district on 5 Mar 2019 after a 35 year old woman died and her 23 year old cousin reported similar symptoms, WHO said in a report on [Mon 11 Mar 2019]. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Source: AFP [edited]\nhttps://www.9news.com.au/2019/03/12/10/54/deadly-plague-on-uganda-congo-border-who\n\n\nA deadly form of plague has broken out on Uganda's border with the Democratic Republic of Congo, and several people are thought to have died of the disease, WHO has said. Finding her sick at her child's burial, her relatives took her to Uganda for treatment. The swollen gland is called a 'bubo'.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2019-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Atungulei", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Zombo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of Congo", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6456511", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Mongolia (03): (BO) bubonic, marmot, fatal, quarantine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6456511", "date": "2019-05-06 22:24:49", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MONGOLIA (03): (BAYAN-OLGIY) BUBONIC, MARMOT, FATAL, QUARANTINE\n************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 4 May 2019\nSource: Siberian Times [edited]\nhttps://siberiantimes.com/other/others/news/town-in-mongolia-closed-for-quarantine-after-bubonic-plague-claimed-two-lives/\n\n\nThe Mongolian Ministry of Health confirmed 2 people -- a 38-year-old man and his pregnant wife, 37 -- died from plague after consuming raw meat and internal organs of a marmot. Their deaths left 4 children as orphans aged from 2 to 13. Dramatic pictures have shown at least one aircraft being met by anti-contamination emergency workers in a bid to prevent spread of the disease.\n\nThe local town of Ulgii (or Olgii) on the border with Russia was shut for quarantine by Mongolian health authorities and army. Several dozen tourists from all over the world had to alter their holiday plans and are now waiting to hear when they might be allowed to leave the town.\n\n'Did you think that the plague was something from the Dark Ages? Us too!! We were just about to leave Ulgii to go deeper into Mongolia, but all exits of the town were shut and we were not allowed to leave. Half of the city is closed due to some plague-contaminated marmots!' wrote one traveler from Kemerovo [Siberia, Russia] who is marooned on the border with her husband. With a big group of fellow travelers from the US, Netherlands, Sweden, Switzerland, South Korea, and Germany, the Russians were besieging the authorities, desperate to leave the town.\n\nThe tragic family that died from plague got infected after eating raw kidneys of a marmot. An old Mongolian tradition says that a raw meat and internal organs of freshly killed marmot strengthens health, local media reported.\n\nThe Mongolian Ministry of Health stressed they did not think that the situation with the plague was critical or anywhere near epidemic. Yet there was no deadline announced for the quarantine which in the worst case scenario can last as long as 21 days.\n\nSanitary and epidemiological services in Russia's Altai and Tuva republics, which neighbour the Bayan-Uglii province of Mongolia, are on high alert since news broke of the plague outbreak.\n\nIn Uglii a total of 158 people who came directly or indirectly into contact with the couple are 'under supervision'.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Plague is caused by _Yersinia pestis_.\n\nMost cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. The swollen gland is called a 'bubo.' Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2 to 6 days after being bitten.\n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antibiotic therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. At this stage, as appears to have happened in the report above, person-to-person spread can occur, causing other cases of 'primary' plague pneumonia. As it is only pneumonic plague that spreads person-to-person and close contact is required, if the tourists were not exposed to the couple, quarantine seems not needed.\n\nPlague is endemic in Mongolia. Marmots such as the Tarvaga, the Tarbagan or Mongolian marmot, _Marmota sibirica_, a large rodent related to the American woodchuck (_M. monax_), are thought to be significant zoonotic reservoirs for _Y. pestis_ in Eastern Asia. The name marmot (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marmot) comes from French marmotte, from Latin _mures monti_ 'mountain mouse.'\n\nMaps of Mongolia: http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/mongolia.pdf and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/34282. The province of Bayan-Olgiy is in the extreme western part of the country. - Mod.LL\n\nWhile foodborne transmission of _Yersinia pestis_ has been described (e.g, Leslie T, et al. Outbreak of gastroenteritis caused by _Yersinia pestis_ in Afghanistan. Epidemiol Infect. 2011 May; 139(5): 728-35. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20663260), it is far more likely that these bubonic plague cases were acquired via the bites of infected fleas. - Mod.LM]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. The Mongolian Ministry of Health confirmed 2 people -- a 38-year-old man and his pregnant wife, 37 -- died from plague after consuming raw meat and internal organs of a marmot. Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. PLAGUE - MONGOLIA (03): (BAYAN-OLGIY) BUBONIC, MARMOT, FATAL, QUARANTINE\n************************************************************************\n As it is only pneumonic plague that spreads person-to-person and close contact is required, if the tourists were not exposed to the couple, quarantine seems not needed. At this stage, as appears to have happened in the report above, person-to-person spread can occur, causing other cases of 'primary' plague pneumonia. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. Most cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. \n\nSanitary and epidemiological services in Russia's Altai and Tuva republics, which neighbour the Bayan-Uglii province of Mongolia, are on high alert since news broke of the plague outbreak. \n\nThe Mongolian Ministry of Health stressed they did not think that the situation with the plague was critical or anywhere near epidemic. The tragic family that died from plague got infected after eating raw kidneys of a marmot. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2 to 6 days after being bitten. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20663260), it is far more likely that these bubonic plague cases were acquired via the bites of infected fleas. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. \n\n'Did you think that the plague was something from the Dark Ages?", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2037-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Afghanistan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kemerovo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tarbagan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/34282", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sweden", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Korea", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6147679", "headline": "PRO/AH> Crayfish plague - Ireland: (WH) white-clawed crayfish", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6147679", "date": "2018-11-15 12:17:42", "main_text": "CRAYFISH PLAGUE - IRELAND: (WESTMEATH) WHITE-CLAWED CRAYFISH\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 14 Nov 2018\nSource: Afloat [edited]\nhttps://afloat.ie/marine-environment/marine-wildlife/item/41091-water-users-called-on-to-help-limit-crayfish-plague-outbreak-in-athlone\n\n\nAll water users along the River Shannon are being urged to take precautions after confirmation of an outbreak of crayfish plague on a stretch of the Al River. This river is one of the main tributaries to the River Shannon in Athlone [County Westmeath] and flows westerly, entering the Shannon downstream of the weir. A small number of dead freshwater crayfish were reported on the river last week [week of 5 Nov 2018]. DNA analysis by the Marine Institute has now confirmed that crayfish were infected with the fungus-like organism responsible for causing crayfish plague. Further analysis is still ongoing to establish if there may be any links between this and previous outbreaks of crayfish plague.\n\nCrayfish plague only impacts native white-clawed crayfish. Fish and other freshwater animals are not affected. The disease infects species of crayfish and experience elsewhere indicates the disease can cause up to 100% mortality in white-clawed crayfish species. Agencies including the National Parks and Wildlife Service, Westmeath Municipal and County Councils will be working together to erect signage along the Al River and information will be on the Westmeath County Council website. Crayfish plague is recognised as a very significant threat to the survival of the globally threatened white-clawed crayfish in Ireland.\n\nThe disease is considered fatal to all infected native crayfish and the experience in other countries is that where outbreaks occur there is complete extermination of white-clawed crayfish populations. It is spread invisibly in water and the infectious stage may be moved to other river and lake systems on equipment, boats and machinery.\n\nThe crayfish plague comes from the North American species of crayfish, which are now widespread in the UK and on the continent of Europe. To date there are no known records of these American species in Ireland and it is against the law to bring them into Ireland, to sell them, distribute them or release them.\n\nThis is the 7th confirmed outbreak of the disease in the whole of Ireland since it was first found in 2015 in Co Cavan, followed by four separate confirmed outbreaks in 2017 and one confirmed outbreak in Northern Ireland earlier this year [2018]. The closest known previous outbreak to this was one in the Lorrha in Co Tipperary and it is not known how the disease could have spread to the River Al at this time.\n\nAnyone involved in activities in the Al River and River Shannon should observe the 'Check, Clean, and Dry' protocol once they leave the river and before visiting any waterway again. This includes community and local authority clean-up groups, survey work, as well as anglers and all recreational water uses. All wet gear (boats, clothing, and equipment) should be checked for any silt or mud, plant material, or animals before being thoroughly cleaned and finally dried. Disinfectant or hot water (over 40 deg Celsius [105 deg F]) should be used to clean all equipment and this should be followed by a minimum 48-hour drying period (preferably longer, up to a week).\n\nMembers of the public who see any dead or dying crayfish should report this to National Parks and Wildlife Service, Westmeath County Council, or Colette O'Flynn at the National Biodiversity Data Centre, Waterford at <coflynn@biodiversityireland.ie>. Anyone who suspects they have seen a non-native species of crayfish are asked to take a picture of it showing the underside of the claws and submit via the National Biodiversity Data Centre's invasive species record form or direct to Colette O'Flynn.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Crayfish fungal plague, fatal to many crayfish species, has affected many European countries. It is caused by a fungus _Aphanomyces astaci_ that was brought into Europe by the introduction of _Procambarus clarkii_, a freshwater crayfish species of Louisiana, USA, which is naturally infected by this pathogen, although it does not develop clinical disease.\n\nThe white-clawed crayfish, _Austropotamobius pallipes_ is an endangered European freshwater crayfish, and the only species of crayfish native to the British Isles. A picture can be seen at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Austropotamobius_pallipes#/media/File:Austropotamobius_pallipes.jpg.\n\nFor detailed information about the disease caused by this fungus see http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/aahm/current/chapitre_aphanomyces_astaci.pdf. - Mod.PMB\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Ireland: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/64658.]", "summary": "Anyone who suspects they have seen a non-native species of crayfish are asked to take a picture of it showing the underside of the claws and submit via the National Biodiversity Data Centre's invasive species record form or direct to Colette O'Flynn.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nThe white-clawed crayfish, _Austropotamobius pallipes_ is an endangered European freshwater crayfish, and the only species of crayfish native to the British Isles. \n\nThe disease is considered fatal to all infected native crayfish and the experience in other countries is that where outbreaks occur there is complete extermination of white-clawed crayfish populations. The disease infects species of crayfish and experience elsewhere indicates the disease can cause up to 100% mortality in white-clawed crayfish species. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Crayfish fungal plague, fatal to many crayfish species, has affected many European countries. \n\nCrayfish plague only impacts native white-clawed crayfish. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n CRAYFISH PLAGUE - IRELAND: (WESTMEATH) WHITE-CLAWED CRAYFISH\n Crayfish plague is recognised as a very significant threat to the survival of the globally threatened white-clawed crayfish in Ireland. DNA analysis by the Marine Institute has now confirmed that crayfish were infected with the fungus-like organism responsible for causing crayfish plague. The crayfish plague comes from the North American species of crayfish, which are now widespread in the UK and on the continent of Europe. It is caused by a fungus _Aphanomyces astaci_ that was brought into Europe by the introduction of _Procambarus clarkii_, a freshwater crayfish species of Louisiana, USA, which is naturally infected by this pathogen, although it does not develop clinical disease. \n\n\nAll water users along the River Shannon are being urged to take precautions after confirmation of an outbreak of crayfish plague on a stretch of the Al River. This is the 7th confirmed outbreak of the disease in the whole of Ireland since it was first found in 2015 in Co Cavan, followed by four separate confirmed outbreaks in 2017 and one confirmed outbreak in Northern Ireland earlier this year [2018]. \n\nMembers of the public who see any dead or dying crayfish should report this to National Parks and Wildlife Service, Westmeath County Council, or Colette O'Flynn at the National Biodiversity Data Centre, Waterford at <coflynn@biodiversityireland.ie>. Further analysis is still ongoing to establish if there may be any links between this and previous outbreaks of crayfish plague. A small number of dead freshwater crayfish were reported on the river last week Disinfectant or hot water (over 40 deg Celsius [105 deg F]) should be used to clean all equipment and this should be followed by a minimum 48-hour drying period (preferably longer, up to a week). The closest known previous outbreak to this was one in the Lorrha in Co Tipperary and it is not known how the disease could have spread to the River Al at this time. It is spread invisibly in water and the infectious stage may be moved to other river and lake systems on equipment, boats and machinery. Anyone involved in activities in the Al River and River Shannon should observe the 'Check, Clean, and Dry' protocol once they leave the river and before visiting any waterway again. All wet gear (boats, clothing, and equipment) should be checked for any silt or mud, plant material, or animals before being thoroughly cleaned and finally dried. To date there are no known records of these American species in Ireland and it is against the law to bring them into Ireland, to sell them, distribute them or release them. PMB\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Ireland: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/64658.] Date: Wed 14 Nov 2018\n This includes community and local authority clean-up groups, survey work, as well as anglers and all recreational water uses. This river is one of the main tributaries to the River Shannon in Athlone [County Westmeath] and flows westerly, entering the Shannon downstream of the weir. For detailed information about the disease caused by this fungus see http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/aahm/current/chapitre_aphanomyces_astaci.pdf. Source: Afloat [edited]\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2018-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Northern Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6361715", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Madagascar", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6361715", "date": "2019-03-12 12:54:11", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR\n*******************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 9 Mar 2019\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/madagascar-plague-cases-top-100/\n\n\nPlague is endemic in Madagascar, and a seasonal upsurge, predominantly of the bubonic form, usually occurs yearly between September and April. According to the general secretary of the Madagascar Ministry of Health, between 300 and 600 suspected cases are reported each year, with about 30 cases of pulmonary plague and 10 to 70 deaths.\n\nSince August 2018, Madagascar health officials have reported 105 human plague cases. Of these, 91 cases were identified as bubonic plague, while 14 were pneumonic plague. Of the bubonic plague cases reported to date, 19 people have died; 12 of the 14 pneumonic plague cases also perished.\n\nThe districts that include confirmed cases of plague are Manandriana, Tsiroanomandidy, Ambositra, Midongy Atsimo, Ambalavao, Befotaka, Ambatofinandrahana, Miarinarivo, Anjozorobe, Faratsiho, Fianarantsoa, Moramanga, Ankazobe, Arivonimamo, Betafo, and Mandoto.\n\nPlague is an infectious disease caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_. It is found in animals throughout the world, most commonly rats but also other rodents like ground squirrels, prairie dogs, chipmunks, rabbits, and voles. Fleas typically serve as the vector of plague. Human cases have been linked to the domestic cats and dogs that bring infected fleas into the house.\n\nPeople can also get infected through direct contact with an infected animal, through inhalation, and, in the case of pneumonic plague, person to person. _Y. pestis_ [infection] is treatable with antimicrobials if started early enough.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\nvia\nProMED-EAFR\n<promed-eafr@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague infections on Madagascar have been relatively quiet since the dramatic outbreak in 2017.\n\nThe following paragraph is from Chanteau S, Ratsifasoamanana L, Rasoamanana B, et al. Plague, a reemerging disease in Madagascar. Emerg Infect Dis 1998;4(1):101-4, PMID: 9452403; available at http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/4/1/98-0114_article.htm.\n\n'Between 1930 and 1990, bubonic plague had 'virtually disappeared' on the island due to efficient pest-control and good health management. However since 1990, an annual 200 cases are being reported and bubonic plague takes on epidemic form, especially in the port of Mahajanga, each year. In the capital city of Antananarivo, more cases are also being notified each year since 1990. Madagascar (pop. 13 million) has accounted for 45% of all the cases of plague in Africa.'\n\nFatalities related to plague usually are caused by spread of the organism from the bubo (the very painful infected lymph node that drains the area where the flea bite occurred) to the bloodstream. The bacteremia can cause a coagulopathy, producing the purpura seen in the 'black plague', and also may spread to the lungs causing a hemorrhagic pneumonia. It is the pneumonia that can facilitate person-to-person transmission.\n\nMadagascar was the location of the isolation of multi-antimicrobial resistant _Yersinia pestis_ in 1995 (Galimand M, Guiyoule A, Gerbaud G, et al. Multidrug resistance in _Yersinia pestis_ mediated by a transferable plasmid. N Engl J Med. 1997;337(10):677-80, PMID: 9278464; available at http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJM199709043371004). The strain was resistant to chloramphenicol, streptomycin, and tetracycline but sensitive to fluoroquinolones and trimethoprim as well as other aminoglycosides. This was an ominous observation; however, it is not clear whether this naturally occurring strain has persisted or spread. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Madagascar: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/181.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n promed@promedmail.org>\nvia\nProMED-EAFR\n<promed-eafr@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague infections on Madagascar have been relatively quiet since the dramatic outbreak in 2017. Of the bubonic plague cases reported to date, 19 people have died; 12 of the 14 pneumonic plague cases also perished. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< According to the general secretary of the Madagascar Ministry of Health, between 300 and 600 suspected cases are reported each year, with about 30 cases of pulmonary plague and 10 to 70 deaths. Of these, 91 cases were identified as bubonic plague, while 14 were pneumonic plague. \n\nPeople can also get infected through direct contact with an infected animal, through inhalation, and, in the case of pneumonic plague, person to person. However since 1990, an annual 200 cases are being reported and bubonic plague takes on epidemic form, especially in the port of Mahajanga, each year. \n\n'Between 1930 and 1990, bubonic plague had 'virtually disappeared' on the island due to efficient pest-control and good health management. PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR\n*******************\n \n\nThe districts that include confirmed cases of plague are Manandriana, Tsiroanomandidy, Ambositra, Midongy Atsimo, Ambalavao, Befotaka, Ambatofinandrahana, Miarinarivo, Anjozorobe, Faratsiho, Fianarantsoa, Moramanga, Ankazobe, Arivonimamo, Betafo, and Mandoto.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1990-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-09-25 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-04-25 00:00:00", "1995-03-25 00:00:00", "2019-03-25 00:00:00", "2018-08-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rasoamanana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mahajanga", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6250448", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA: (WY) feline", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6250448", "date": "2019-01-09 20:05:22", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA: (WYOMING) FELINE\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 7 Jan 2019\nSource: Jackson Hole Radio [edited]\nhttp://jacksonholeradio.com/2019/01/plague-found-in-wyoming-cat/\n\n\nLaboratory testing at the University of Wyoming has recently confirmed a Johnson County cat was infected with plague, according to the Wyoming Department of Health. No human cases have been identified at this time.\n\nThe cat's home is in Kaycee, and the animal is known to wander outdoors. The illness was confirmed by the Wyoming State Veterinary Laboratory in Laramie. State health officer Dr. Alexia Harrist points out plague is a serious bacterial infection which can be deadly for pets and people if not promptly treated with antibiotics. However, it is treatable, and if treated it does not spell certain death as it did during the Black Plague.\n\nThis is the 3rd plague-infected cat identified in Wyoming over the past 6 months; the others were in Sheridan and Campbell counties. Only 6 human cases of plague have been exposed in Wyoming since 1978 with the last investigated in 2008. There is an average of 7 human plague cases each year in the United States.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations. Surveillance efforts testing fleas are very important to detect circulation of _Y. pestis_ and risk of infection.\n\nPlague may infect human beings through several routes: 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals (mentioned previously; 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues, generally from an animal; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals.\n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under the jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front leg (the armpit, if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever (or chills). These clinical signs may be present in the dog as well. Swelling under the jaw in cats is frequently mistaken as a cat-fight abscess.\n\nPlease take your pet to a veterinarian if you notice any abnormalities. Be sure to consult your veterinarian if you find a lump on your pet, as well as to get the best flea prevention treatment for your pet. It may be necessary to have your yard and/or home treated for fleas. Vacuum your home, including any bedding and furniture, and immediately upon finishing, take the vacuum bag outside, seal it in a plastic bag, and dispose of it. This type of cleaning will have to be repeated every week for 3-6 weeks to break the cycle of the flea in the home. This disease should be taken seriously, so please be sure your pet is on some form of flea prevention.\n\nIf your pets are not on flea prevention, please ask your veterinarian about the best flea prevention. Bathing your pet in dishwashing soap is not sufficient to help your pet avoid diseases carried by fleas. Some of the over the counter flea preventions may be harmful to your pet, so please check with your veterinarian. It is also a good time to make sure your pet is current on a rabies shot.\n\nKeeping your pets inside is best, and being inside a yard will help diminish the ability to consume a dead animal and further reduce the risk of plague to your animal and to yourself. - Mod.TG\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nWyoming, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/251]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Plague may infect human beings through several routes: 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals (mentioned previously; 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues, generally from an animal; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals.
