31(42) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=28224\n\n\nCrayfish plague (_Aphanomyces astaci_), United Kingdom\n------------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 15 Oct 2018 from Dr Christine Middlemiss, Chief Veterinary Officer, DEFRA, Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs, London, United Kingdom\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 31 Aug 2018\nDate of confirmation of the event: 14 Sep 2018\nReason for notification: recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: Jun 2018\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: _Aphanomyces astaci_\nNature of diagnosis: clinical\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak location: Headwater of the River Blackwater, near Aughentaine, Blackwater, Tyrone, Northern Ireland\nDate of start of the outbreak: 31 Aug 2018\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: river system\nWater type: fresh water\nPopulation type: wild\nProduction system: open\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Morbidity / Mortality / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nWhite clawed crayfish (_Austropotamobius pallipes_) / 100 percent / 100 percent / - / 20 / 20 / 0 / 0 /\nAffected population: 20 dead white-clawed crayfish, which were found during routine field surveys, have subsequently tested positive for crayfish plague. The location where the crayfish were found was at the headwater of the River Blackwater, near Aughentaine. This section of the river was enhanced for salmon habitat during the 1990's and 2000's. Surveillance is on-going. No further reports to date.\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed in percentages], expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nWhite clawed crayfish (_Austropotamobius pallipes_) / ** / ** / 100 / **\n* Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter\n** Not calculated because of missing information\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists); no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nMarine Institute (regional reference laboratory) / White clawed crayfish (_Austropotamobius pallipes_) / polymerase chain reaction / 14 Sep 2018 / positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n['Crayfish plague is a highly infectious disease of all crayfish of non-North American origin. The aetiological agent is an oomycete fungus, _Aphanomyces astaci_, which is now widespread in Europe as well as in North America.\n\n'The disease first occurred in Europe in the 3rd quarter of the 19th century in the Franco-German border region. From there, a steady spread of infection occurred, principally in 2 directions, down the Danube into the Balkans and towards the Black Sea, and across the north German plain into Russia and from there south to the Black Sea and north-west to Finland and finally, in 1907, to Sweden. In the 1960s the 1st outbreaks in Spain were reported and in the 1980s further spread of infection to the British Isles, Turkey, Greece, and Norway was reported.\n\n'The European crayfish species, the noble crayfish _Astacus astacus_ of north-west Europe, the stone crayfish _Austropotamobius pallipes_ of south-west and west Europe, the related _Austropotamobius torrentium_ (mountain streams of south-west Europe), and the slender clawed or Turkish crayfish _Astacus leptodactylus_ of eastern Europe and Asia Minor are all highly susceptible.' (https://thefishsite.com/disease-guide/crayfish-plague). - Mod.CRD\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Northern Ireland, United Kingdom: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/36315]", "summary": "Population type: wild\nProduction system: open\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Morbidity / Mortality / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nWhite clawed crayfish (_Austropotamobius pallipes_) / 100 percent / 100 percent / - / 20 / 20 / 0 / 0 /\n A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed in percentages], expressed as percentages]\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nWhite clawed crayfish (_Austropotamobius pallipes_) / ** / ** / 100 / **\n Measures applied: vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists); 31(42) [edited]\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1990-03-25 00:00:00", "2018-09-14 00:00:00", "2000-03-25 00:00:00", "1907-03-25 00:00:00", "2018-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Turkey", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Northern Ireland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sweden", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Greece", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Finland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "London", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Norway", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6094752", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Anthrax and plague: novel dual vaccine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6094752", "date": "2018-10-16 17:58:30", "main_text": "ANTHRAX AND PLAGUE: NOVEL DUAL VACCINE\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Tue 16 Oct 2018\nSource: Medical Press, an American Society for Microbiology report [edited]\nhttps://medicalxpress.com/news/2018-10-dual-vaccine-anthrax-plague.html\n\n\nA team of researchers has now engineered a virus nanoparticle vaccine against _Bacillus anthracis_ and _Yersinia pestis_, tier 1 agents that pose serious threats to national security of the United States.\n\n_B. anthracis_ and _Y. pestis_ are the pathogens that cause anthrax and plague, respectively. Using bacteriophage T4, the scientists developed the vaccine by incorporating key antigens of both _B. anthracis_ and _Y. pestis_ into one formulation.\n\nTwo doses of this vaccine provided complete protection against both inhalational anthrax and pneumonic plague in animal models. Even when animals were threatened with lethal doses of both anthrax lethal toxin and _Y. pestis_ CO92 bacteria, the vaccine was shown to be effective.\n\nThe study is published in mBio, an open-access journal of the American Society for Microbiology.\n\n'This dual anthrax-plague vaccine is a strong candidate for stockpiling against a potential bioterror attack involving either one or both of these biothreat agents,' the researchers noted in the study. Their results demonstrate that T4 nanoparticle is a novel platform for developing multivalent vaccines against pathogens of high public health concern.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue 16 Oct 2018, 8:20 AM EDT\nSource: Daily Mail [edited]\nhttps://www.dailymail.co.uk/health/article-6281597/Vaccine-protects-against-anthrax-plague-developed-amid-fears-terror-threats.html\n\n\nScientists have created a vaccine that protects against both anthrax and plague amid fears of terror threats. The bacteria behind anthrax and the pneumonic plague are 2 of the deadliest pathogens that could be used in warfare. Researchers from The Catholic University of America therefore created a single vaccine that could provide complete protection against the 2 diseases. Tests on animals showed the vaccine worked, even if they were infected with a deadly dose of either of the 2 killer pathogens.\n\n'This dual anthrax-plague vaccine is a strong candidate for stockpiling against a potential bioterror attack involving either one or both of these biothreat agents,' scientists led by Dr. Pan Tao said. The Washington DC-based team combined toxins from the bacteria _Bacillus anthracis_ and _Yersinia pestis_, which cause anthrax and the pneumonic plague, respectively. These toxins are known to stimulate an immune response when a person becomes infected.\n\nWhen given to mice, rats and rabbits, the vaccine gave complete protection against both diseases, even when the animals were infected with doses that are known to [be] deadly. The [vaccination] is thought to stimulate immune cells to clear the bacteria from the body. It is unclear when it may be available. The study was published in the journal of the American Society for Microbiology.\n\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) classes' anthrax and plague [bacteria] as the pathogens that pose the greatest threat to the national security of the US. Both anthrax and plague can kill in as little as 3 days.\n\nThe most deadly form of anthrax is inhaled (pneumonic), which can quickly cause sufferers to cough up blood and even fall into coma. If spores enter a person's lymph nodes, they can multiply and produce deadly toxins that spread throughout the body. This can lead to life-threatening internal bleeding, as well as the death of tissues and [failure of] major organs. Although there is an FDA-approved anthrax vaccine, it can cause the airways to collapse and general circulation failure.\n\nThere is no approved vaccine for plague; however, an experimental one is sometimes used in the military. It is unclear what the potential side effects of the newly-developed dual vaccine may be. The pneumonic form of plague is the most dangerous, which can cause patients to cough up blood and suffer sudden cardiac arrest. The bacteria for both diseases are most often inhaled as infected droplets.\n\nAs well as protecting against a potential terror threat, the researchers believe the plague vaccine could be used globally. The disease killed 209 people in Madagascar in an outbreak last year [2017].\n\n[Byline: Alexandra Thompson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: October, 2018\nSource: American Society for Microbiology Research Article, Therapeutics and Prevention [edited]\nhttps://mbio.asm.org/content/9/5/e01926-18\n\n\nCitation\n--------\nA Bacteriophage T4 Nanoparticle-Based Dual Vaccine against Anthrax and Plague\nTao P, Mahalingam M, Zhu J, et al, 2018 mBio DOI: 10.1128/mBio.01926-18. Available in PDF at:\nhttps://mbio.asm.org/content/mbio/9/5/e01926-18.full.pdf\n\nAbstract\n--------\n_Bacillus anthracis_ and _Yersinia pestis_, the causative agents of anthrax and plague, respectively, are 2 of the deadliest pathogenic bacteria that have been used as biological warfare agents. Although Biothrax is a licensed vaccine against anthrax, no Food and Drug Administration-approved vaccine exists for plague. Here, we report the development of a dual anthrax-plague nanoparticle vaccine employing bacteriophage (phage) T4 as a platform. Using an in vitro assembly system, the 120- by 86-nm heads (capsids) of phage T4 were arrayed with anthrax and plague antigens fused to the small outer capsid protein Soc (9\u2009kDa). The antigens included the anthrax protective antigen (PA) (83\u2009kDa) and the mutated (mut) capsular antigen F1 and the low-calcium-response V antigen of the type 3 secretion system from _Y. pestis_ (F1mutV) (56\u2009kDa). These viral nanoparticles elicited robust anthrax- and plague-specific immune responses and provided complete protection against inhalational anthrax and/or pneumonic plague in 3 animal challenge models, namely, mice, rats, and rabbits. Protection was demonstrated even when the animals were simultaneously challenged with lethal doses of both anthrax lethal toxin and _Y. pestis_ CO92 bacteria. Unlike the traditional subunit vaccines, the phage T4 vaccine uses a highly stable nanoparticle scaffold, provides multivalency, requires no adjuvant, and elicits broad T-helper 1 and 2 immune responses that are essential for complete clearance of bacteria during infection. Therefore, phage T4 is a unique nanoparticle platform to formulate multivalent vaccines against high-risk pathogens for national preparedness against potential bioterror attacks and emerging infections.\n\nImportance\n----------\nFollowing the deadly anthrax attacks of 2001, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) determined that _Bacillus anthracis_ and _Yersinia pestis_ that cause anthrax and plague, respectively, are 2 Tier 1 select agents that pose the greatest threat to the national security of the United States. Both cause rapid death, in 3 to 6\u2009days, of exposed individuals. We engineered a virus nanoparticle vaccine using bacteriophage T4 by incorporating key antigens of both _B. anthracis_ and _Y. pestis_ into one formulation. Two doses of this vaccine provided complete protection against both inhalational anthrax and pneumonic plague in animal models. This dual anthrax-plague vaccine is a strong candidate for stockpiling against a potential bioterror attack involving either one or both of these biothreat agents. Further, our results establish the T4 nanoparticle as a novel platform to develop multivalent vaccines against pathogens of high public health significance.\n\nDiscussion, Comment\n-------------------\nIt is significant that the dual anthrax-plague vaccine, unlike the traditional subunit vaccines, elicited robust immune responses against both antigens in the absence of an adjuvant. In fact, addition of adjuvants such as Alhydrogel and/or liposomes to the nanoparticles did not enhance the immune responses (data not shown). We speculate that this might be because the viral nanoparticles, mimicking the PAMPs of a natural pathogen, engage with the TLRs and robustly stimulate the innate and adaptive immune systems of the host and do not need an external adjuvant (46) [see URL for references]. Consistent with this hypothesis, the T4 dual vaccine elicited both TH1- and TH2-mediated antibody responses against both antigens. This seems to be a signature characteristic of the phage T4 nanoparticle platform, one that is highly desirable for clearance of pathogenic organisms during natural infection. However, further studies are needed to understand the mechanisms.\n\nIn conclusion, our studies highlight some unique properties of the T4 phage nanoparticle that are distinct from the traditional subunit vaccines, which could facilitate formulation of multivalent vaccines against high-risk pathogens. Potentially, additional antigens from other biothreat agents and/or from emerging pathogens could be incorporated using the same principle, and these formulations can be customized to address different threats in different geographical regions of the world. Additional advantages of phage T4 platform include the following: highly stable structure, scalability, cost-effectiveness, safety, and lack of preexisting immunity in humans. Together, these factors could accelerate the streamlining of clinical trials, manufacture, and deployment at a much reduced cost, time, and effort. Phage T4, thus, is a good candidate to develop as a 'universal' platform for creating and stockpiling multivalent vaccines as part of our national preparedness against potential future biothreats and emerging infections. With some more refinement, this platform may have the most desirable target product profile for licensure.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This apparently very successful vaccine worked for mice, rats, and rabbits. It is still a long way away from trials in humans. But from this account it may well be a winner. It is quick. It is effective. It is efficient. People ask me whether I have fears working with _Bacillus anthracis_. Frankly no because humans are hard to infect and antibiotics are effective.\n\nWhat does frighten me is exposure to _Yersinia pestis_ as we have no effective vaccine: the French have a vaccine which they use but I can see delays if it were needed in a hurry. It is a horrible death and it is not called the 'Black Death' for nothing. So while this joint vaccine may be promulgated as a defence in case of a biowarfare attack, which is not every day events, split into its components they have a place for protection for those exposed to these pathogens occupationally. The reservoir for _Y. pestis_ is field rodents in Arizona. Anthrax is increasingly sporadic in cattle but it has its favorite spots, but otherwise we see it in deer in west Texas, in Wood Bison, and in northern cattle. The 'Hot Shot' men burning those infected bison carcasses, which average around 2500 lbs each, deserve some immunity protection. And from this account of this experimental dual vaccine, 2 shots are enough. A significant improvement over the present human anthrax vaccine. - Mod.MHJ]\n\n.................................................mhj/ao/jh", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n \n\n'This dual anthrax-plague vaccine is a strong candidate for stockpiling against a potential bioterror attack involving either one or both of these biothreat agents,' the researchers noted in the study. \n\n'This dual anthrax-plague vaccine is a strong candidate for stockpiling against a potential bioterror attack involving either one or both of these biothreat agents,' scientists led by Dr. Pan Tao said. Following the deadly anthrax attacks of 2001, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) determined that _Bacillus anthracis_ and _Yersinia pestis_ that cause anthrax and plague, respectively, are 2 Tier 1 select agents that pose the greatest threat to the national security of the United States. \n_Bacillus anthracis_ and _Yersinia pestis_, the causative agents of anthrax and plague, respectively, are 2 of the deadliest pathogenic bacteria that have been used as biological warfare agents. These viral nanoparticles elicited robust anthrax- and plague-specific immune responses and provided complete protection against inhalational anthrax and/or pneumonic plague in 3 animal challenge models, namely, mice, rats, and rabbits. Source: Medical Press, an American Society for Microbiology report [edited]\nhttps://medicalxpress.com/news/2018-10-dual-vaccine-anthrax-plague.html\n\n\nA team of researchers has now engineered a virus nanoparticle vaccine against _Bacillus anthracis_ and _Yersinia pestis_, tier 1 agents that pose serious threats to national security of the United States. \n\nTwo doses of this vaccine provided complete protection against both inhalational anthrax and pneumonic plague in animal models. A Bacteriophage T4 Nanoparticle-Based Dual Vaccine against Anthrax and Plague\n It is significant that the dual anthrax-plague vaccine, unlike the traditional subunit vaccines, elicited robust immune responses against both antigens in the absence of an adjuvant. This dual anthrax-plague vaccine is a strong candidate for stockpiling against a potential bioterror attack involving either one or both of these biothreat agents. ANTHRAX AND PLAGUE: NOVEL DUAL VACCINE\n************************************** Unlike the traditional subunit vaccines, the phage T4 vaccine uses a highly stable nanoparticle scaffold, provides multivalency, requires no adjuvant, and elicits broad T-helper 1 and 2 immune responses that are essential for complete clearance of bacteria during infection. Here, we report the development of a dual anthrax-plague nanoparticle vaccine employing bacteriophage (phage) T4 as a platform. Two doses of this vaccine provided complete protection against both inhalational anthrax and pneumonic plague in animal models. \n\n_B. anthracis_ and _Y. pestis_ are the pathogens that cause anthrax and plague, respectively. Although Biothrax is a licensed vaccine against anthrax, no Food and Drug Administration-approved vaccine exists for plague. \n\nWhat does frighten me is exposure to _Yersinia pestis_ as we have no effective vaccine: the French have a vaccine which they use but I can see delays if it were needed in a hurry. The Washington DC-based team combined toxins from the bacteria _Bacillus anthracis_ and _Yersinia pestis_, which cause anthrax and the pneumonic plague, respectively. Even when animals were threatened with lethal doses of both anthrax lethal toxin and _Y. pestis_ CO92 bacteria, the vaccine was shown to be effective. \n\nWhen given to mice, rats and rabbits, the vaccine gave complete protection against both diseases, even when the animals were infected with doses that are known to [be] deadly. \n\nAs well as protecting against a potential terror threat, the researchers believe the plague vaccine could be used globally. https://www.dailymail.co.uk/health/article-6281597/Vaccine-protects-against-anthrax-plague-developed-amid-fears-terror-threats.html\n\n\nScientists have created a vaccine that protects against both anthrax and plague amid fears of terror threats. The bacteria behind anthrax and the pneumonic plague are 2 of the deadliest pathogens that could be used in warfare. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) classes' anthrax and plague [bacteria] as the pathogens that pose the greatest threat to the national security of the US. \n\nThere is no approved vaccine for plague; however, an experimental one is sometimes used in the military. Therefore, phage T4 is a unique nanoparticle platform to formulate multivalent vaccines against high-risk pathogens for national preparedness against potential bioterror attacks and emerging infections. Using an in vitro assembly system, the 120- by 86-nm heads (capsids) of phage T4 were arrayed with anthrax and plague antigens fused to the small outer capsid protein Soc (9\u2009kDa). The antigens included the anthrax protective antigen (PA) (83\u2009kDa) and the mutated (mut) capsular antigen F1 and the low-calcium-response V antigen of the type 3 secretion system from _Y. pestis_ (F1mutV) (56\u2009kDa). \n\nThe most deadly form of anthrax is inhaled (pneumonic), which can quickly cause sufferers to cough up blood and even fall into coma. We engineered a virus nanoparticle vaccine using bacteriophage T4 by incorporating key antigens of both _B. anthracis_ and _Y. pestis_ into one formulation. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2018-10-25 00:00:00", "2046-03-25 00:00:00", "2001-03-25 00:00:00", "2018-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wood Bison", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "TH1-", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "F1mutV", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington DC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6065963", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Madagascar (06)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6065963", "date": "2018-10-02 12:14:33", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (06)\n************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 28 Sep 2018\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/plague-reported-10-madagascar-districts-82760/\n\n\nMadagascar health officials reported in an update [of] Wed 26 Sep 2018 that the plague case count has now risen to 22 cases in 10 districts from 1 Aug 2018 to 24 Sep 2018. To date, 5 deaths have been reported.\n\nThe 10 districts include Ambalavo, Ambatofinandrahana, Ambatolampy, Ambositra, Ankazobe, Antananarivo, Antsirabe, Arivonimamo, Fandriana, and Miarinarivo.\n\nPlague is known to be endemic in Madagascar and a seasonal upsurge (predominantly the bubonic form) usually occurs early every year between September and April.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[From the last update, on 22 Sep 2018, there were 4 deaths and a total of 16 cases. When these new cases first developed is not clear.\n\n2017 was indeed a 'banner' season for plague in the island nation of Madagascar. The outbreak was notable not only for the large number of cases but also for the high percentage of cases of pneumonic plague in urban settings and in areas where the infection generally does not occur.\n\nThe following paragraph is from Chanteau S, Ratsifasoamanana L, Rasoamanana B, et al. Plague, a reemerging disease in Madagascar. Emerg Infect Dis. 1998; 4(1): 101-4, PMID: 9452403; available at http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/4/1/98-0114_article.htm.\n\n'Between 1930 and 1990, bubonic plague had 'virtually disappeared' on the island due to efficient pest-control and good health management. However since 1990, an annual 200 cases are being reported and bubonic plague takes on epidemic form, especially in the port of Mahajanga, each year. In the capital city of Antananarivo, more cases are also being notified each year since 1990. Madagascar (pop. 13 million) has accounted for 45 per cent of all the cases of plague in Africa.'\n\nFatalities related to plague usually are caused by spread of the organism from the bubo (the very painful infected lymph node which drains the area where the flea bite occurred) to the bloodstream. The bacteremia can cause a coagulopathy, producing the purpura seen in the 'black plague' and also spread to the lungs causing a hemorrhagic pneumonia. It is the pneumonia that can facilitate person-to-person transmission.\n\nMadagascar was the location of the isolation of multi-antimicrobial resistant _Yersinia pestis_ in 1995 (Galimand M, Guiyoule A, Gerbaud G, et al. Multidrug resistance in _Yersinia pestis_ mediated by a transferable plasmid. N Engl J Med. 1997; 337(10): 677-80, PMID: 9278464; available at http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJM199709043371004). The strain was resistant to chloramphenicol, streptomycin, and tetracycline but sensitive to fluoroquinolones and trimethoprim as well as other aminoglycosides. This was an ominous observation; however, it is not clear whether this naturally occurring strain has persisted or spread. - Mod.LL\n\nMaps of Madagascar: http://www.madacamp.com/Regions,_Districts_and_Communes_of_Madagascar and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/181.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n http://outbreaknewstoday.com/plague-reported-10-madagascar-districts-82760/\n\n\nMadagascar health officials reported in an update [of] Wed 26 Sep 2018 that the plague case count has now risen to 22 cases in 10 districts from 1 Aug 2018 to 24 Sep 2018. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< The outbreak was notable not only for the large number of cases but also for the high percentage of cases of pneumonic plague in urban settings and in areas where the infection generally does not occur. \n\n'Between 1930 and 1990, bubonic plague had 'virtually disappeared' on the island due to efficient pest-control and good health management. 'We have recorded from [1 Aug to 17 Sep 2018], 13 suspected cases of plague, 3 of which are confirmed and caused 2 deaths,' Rantomalala said.\n\nThe 1st fatality was recorded in Fiadanana, north of the capital Antananarivo, while the 2nd was reported in Ambalavao in the Indian Ocean island's interior. 'For the moment, the situation is under control, we are on the right track,' he told reporters.\n\nIn 2017, more than 200 people were killed before bubonic and pneumonic plague epidemics were brought under control in November 2017. The disease spread to urban centres including the capital in 2017, taking the authorities by surprise. 'We learnt the lessons of that epidemic,' the minister added. 'Last year in September 2017 we had already had 54 confirmed cases'.\n\n'For now, there is no need to talk of an epidemic or to restrict public meetings,' said Charlotte Ndiaye, local representative of the WHO.\n\nMadagascar has suffered bubonic plague outbreaks almost every year since 1980. The disease tends to make a comeback each hot rainy season, from September to April. On average, 300-600 infections are recorded annually among a population approaching 25 million people, according to UN estimates.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The previous report, just 2 days before, noted a total of 8 cases. This post raises the number of suspected cases to 13. PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (04)\n The distribution of cases between bubonic, pneumonic and septicemic forms is not noted.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1980-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-11-25 00:00:00", "2021-04-25 00:00:00", "2021-09-25 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00", "2018-09-17 00:00:00", "2017-09-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fiadanana", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5995755", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (03): (WY) feline", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5995755", "date": "2018-08-29 17:22:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (03): (WYOMING) FELINE\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 29 Aug 2018\nSource: Casper Star Tribune [edited]\nhttps://bit.ly/2LzeT8k\n\n\nA cat in Big Horn has been confirmed to have been infected with plague, the state Department of Health announced [Wed 29 Aug 2018].\n\nThere are no known human cases in that area or in Wyoming as a whole. There hasn't been a confirmed case since 2008, according to a department press release. The cat 'is known to wander outdoors,' the release said.\n\nThe case comes a little over a year after the plague was found in prairie dogs in the Thunder Basin National Grassland, the 1st time the disease popped up there in more than 15 years.\n\n'Plague is a serious bacterial infection that can be deadly for pets and for people if not treated as soon as possible with antibiotics,' Alexia Harrist, state health officer and epidemiologist, said in a statement. 'The disease can be transmitted to humans from ill animals and by fleas coming from infected animals.'\n\nDepartment spokeswoman Kim Deti did not immediately return a request for comment late [Wed 29 Aug 2018] morning.\n\nThere have been just 6 cases of plague in humans here since 1978, according to the department. The United States overall averages 7 human cases a year.\n\nSigns in pets include swelling in the neck, face or ears; lack of energy; fever; chills; coughing; vomiting; diarrhea; and dehydration. Humans have similar symptoms, along with difficulty breathing, headaches and abdominal pain.\n\nThe department recommends using insect repellent on boots and pants in areas possibly having fleas; using flea repellent on pets; properly disposing of rodents brought home by pets; avoid exposure and contact to rodents dead or alive; and avoid areas with 'unexplained rodent die-offs.' [Please use pet specific flea repellant as some repellants not intended for cats can cause death. - Mod.TG]\n\n[Byline: Seth Klamann]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations. Surveillance efforts testing fleas are very important to detect circulation of _Y. pestis_ and risk of infection.\n\nPlague may infect human beings through several routes: 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals (mentioned previously; 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues, generally from an animal; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals.\n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under the jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front leg (the armpit, if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever. These clinical signs may be present in the dog as well. Swelling under the jaw in cats is frequently mistaken as a cat fight abscess.\n\nPlease take your pet to a veterinarian if you notice any abnormalities. Be sure to consult your veterinarian if you find a lump on your pet, as well as to get the best flea prevention treatment for your pet. It may be necessary to have your yard and/or home treated for fleas. Vacuum your home, including any bedding and furniture, and immediately upon finishing take the vacuum back outside, seal it in a plastic bag, and dispose of it. This type of cleaning will have to be repeated every week for 3-6 weeks to break the cycle of the flea in the home. This disease should be taken seriously, so please be sure your pet is on some form of flea prevention.\n\nIf your pets are not on flea prevention, please ask your veterinarian about the best flea prevention. Bathing your pet in dishwashing soap is not sufficient to help your pet avoid diseases carried by fleas. Some of the over the counter flea preventions may be harmful to your pet so please check with your veterinarian. It is also a good time to make sure your pet is current on a rabies shot.\n\nKeeping your pets inside is best and inside a yard will help diminish the ability to consume a dead animal and further reduce the risk of plague to your animal and to yourself. - Mod.TG\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nWyoming, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/251]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The department recommends using insect repellent on boots and pants in areas possibly having fleas; using flea repellent on pets; properly disposing of rodents brought home by pets; avoid exposure and contact to rodents dead or alive; and avoid areas with 'unexplained rodent die-offs.' Plague may infect human beings through several routes: 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals (mentioned previously; 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues, generally from an animal; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals. \n\nIf your pets are not on flea prevention, please ask your veterinarian about the best flea prevention. \n\nKeeping your pets inside is best and inside a yard will help diminish the ability to consume a dead animal and further reduce the risk of plague to your animal and to yourself. TG]\n\n[Byline: Seth Klamann]\n\n--\n Be sure to consult your veterinarian if you find a lump on your pet, as well as to get the best flea prevention treatment for your pet. \n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under the jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front leg (the armpit, if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever. \n\nSigns in pets include swelling in the neck, face or ears; lack of energy; fever; chills; coughing; vomiting; diarrhea; and dehydration. \n\nThe case comes a little over a year after the plague was found in prairie dogs in the Thunder Basin National Grassland, the 1st time the disease popped up there in more than 15 years. \n\nThere have been just 6 cases of plague in humans here since 1978, according to the department. Bathing your pet in dishwashing soap is not sufficient to help your pet avoid diseases carried by fleas. TG\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nWyoming, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/251] \n\nPlease take your pet to a veterinarian if you notice any abnormalities.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "rabies"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2008-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "1978-03-25 00:00:00", "2018-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6039244", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Madagascar (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6039244", "date": "2018-09-19 16:54:17", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (03)\n************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 18 Sep 2018, 4:01 PM\nSource: News 24 [edited]\nhttps://www.news24.com/Africa/News/plague-outbreak-kills-two-in-madagascar-20180918\n\n\nAn outbreak of plague in Madagascar has killed 2 people, a health official said on [Tue 18 Sep 2018], marking the official start of the season when the disease is considered to be at its deadliest. Last year, in 2017, more than 200 people were killed before epidemics of bubonic and pneumonic plague were brought under control in November [2017].\n\nThe WHO has warned that 2018's strain could be even more virulent. 'According to counts undertaken between [1 Aug 2018] and [13 Sep 2018], we recorded 8 suspected plague cases, 6 of whom recovered and 2 died in their villages,' said health ministry official Manitra Rakotoarivony. The 1st fatality was recorded in Fiadanana, north of the capital Antananarivo, while the 2nd was reported in Ambalavao in the Indian Ocean island's interior, added Rakotoarivony.\n\nMadagascar has suffered bubonic plague outbreaks almost every year since 1980, often caused by rats fleeing forest fires. The disease tends to make a comeback each hot rainy season, from September to April. On average, between 300 and 600 infections are recorded every year among a population approaching 25 million people, according to a UN estimate.\n\nLast year [2017], cases sprang up far earlier than usual and, instead of being confined to the countryside, the disease infiltrated towns. The authorities recorded more than 2000 cases.\n\nThe plague bacterium _Yersinia pestis_ is typically transmitted to humans from infected rats via fleas. It can also be transmitted from human to human through cough droplets expelled by a person with a pneumonic form of the disease. Pneumonic plague can prove fatal between 24 to 72 hours while the bubonic form is less dangerous.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[2017 was indeed a 'banner' season for plague in the island nation of Madagascar. The outbreak was notable not only for the large number of cases but also for the high percentage of cases of pneumonic plague in urban settings and in areas where the infection generally does not occur.\n\nThe following paragraph is from Chanteau S, Ratsifasoamanana L, Rasoamanana B, et al: Plague, a reemerging disease in Madagascar. Emerg Infect Dis. 1998;4(1):101-4, PMID: 9452403 (available at http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/4/1/98-0114_article.htm.\n\n'Between 1930 and 1990, bubonic plague had 'virtually disappeared' on the island due to efficient pest-control and good health management. However since 1990, an annual 200 cases are being reported and bubonic plague takes on epidemic form, especially in the port of Mahajanga, each year. In the capital city of Antananarivo, more cases are also being notified each year since 1990. Madagascar (pop. 13 million) has accounted for 45 percent of all the cases of plague in Africa.'\n\nFatalities related to plague usually are caused by spread of the organism from the bubo (the very painful infected lymph node which drains the area where the flea bite occurred) to the bloodstream. The bacteremia can cause a coagulopathy, producing the purpura seen in the 'black plague' and also spread to the lungs causing a hemorrhagic pneumonia. It is the pneumonia that can facilitate person-to-person transmission.\n\nMadagascar was the location of the isolation of multi-antimicrobial resistant _Y. pestis_ in 1995 (Galimand M, Guiyoule A, Gerbaud G, et al: Multidrug resistance in _Yersinia pestis_ mediated by a transferable plasmid. N Engl J Med. 1997;337(10):677-80, PMID: 9278464; available at, http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJM199709043371004). The strain was resistant to chloramphenicol, streptomycin, and tetracycline but sensitive to fluoroquinolones and trimethoprim as well as other aminoglycosides. This was an ominous observation; however, it is not clear whether this naturally occurring strain has persisted or spread. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nMadagascar: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/181]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n According to counts undertaken between [1 Aug 2018] and [13 Sep 2018], we recorded 8 suspected plague cases, 6 of whom recovered and 2 died in their villages,' said health ministry official Manitra Rakotoarivony. An outbreak of plague in Madagascar has killed 2 people, a health official said on [Tue 18 Sep 2018], marking the official start of the season when the disease is considered to be at its deadliest. \n\n'Between 1930 and 1990, bubonic plague had 'virtually disappeared' on the island due to efficient pest-control and good health management. However since 1990, an annual 200 cases are being reported and bubonic plague takes on epidemic form, especially in the port of Mahajanga, each year. \n\nMadagascar has suffered bubonic plague outbreaks almost every year since 1980, often caused by rats fleeing forest fires. Last year, in 2017, more than 200 people were killed before epidemics of bubonic and pneumonic plague were brought under control in November [2017]. The outbreak was notable not only for the large number of cases but also for the high percentage of cases of pneumonic plague in urban settings and in areas where the infection generally does not occur. \n\nLast year [2017], cases sprang up far earlier than usual and, instead of being confined to the countryside, the disease infiltrated towns. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[2017 was indeed a 'banner' season for plague in the island nation of Madagascar. Pneumonic plague can prove fatal between 24 to 72 hours while the bubonic form is less dangerous.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1990-03-25 00:00:00", "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "2018-08-01 00:00:00", "2021-11-25 00:00:00", "2021-09-25 00:00:00", "2021-04-25 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00", "2018-09-18 00:00:00", "1980-03-25 00:00:00", "1995-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Fiadanana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mahajanga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rasoamanana", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6048975", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR>  Plague - Madagascar (05)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6048975", "date": "2018-09-24 15:33:23", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (05)\n************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 22 Sep 2018\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/plague-reported-eight-madagascar-districts-46345/\n\n\nPlague reported in 8 Madagascar districts\n-----------------------------------------\nIn an update on the plague situation in Madagascar, the Ministry of Health is now reporting plague has affected 8 districts in the country-Central Highlands, Ambalavao, Ambatofinandrahana, Ambositra, Ankazobe, Fandriana, Miarinarivo and Antisirabe. In these 8 districts, 16 suspect cases have been reported in a month, including 4 fatalities. A total of 5 of the cases have been laboratory confirmed. Of the 5 confirmed cases, 2 were classified as bubonic plague and 3 as pulmonary plague.\n\nPlague is known to be endemic in Madagascar and a seasonal upsurge (predominantly the bubonic form) usually occurs early every year between September and April.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[From the last update, 2 days before this, there were 2 deaths and a total of 13 cases. When these new cases first developed is not clear.\n\n2017 was indeed a 'banner' season for plague in the island nation of Madagascar. The outbreak was notable not only for the large number of cases but also for the high percentage of cases of pneumonic plague in urban settings and in areas where the infection generally does not occur.\n\nThe following paragraph is from Chanteau S, Ratsifasoamanana L, Rasoamanana B, et al: Plague, a reemerging disease in Madagascar. Emerg Infect Dis. 1998; 4(1): 101-4, PMID: 9452403, available at\nhttp://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/4/1/98-0114_article.htm.\n\n'Between 1930 and 1990, bubonic plague had 'virtually disappeared' on the island due to efficient pest-control and good health management. However since 1990, an annual 200 cases are being reported and bubonic plague takes on epidemic form, especially in the port of Mahajanga, each year. In the capital city of Antananarivo, more cases are also being notified each year since 1990. Madagascar (pop. 13 million) has accounted for 45 percent of all the cases of plague in Africa.'\n\nFatalities related to plague usually are caused by spread of the organism from the bubo (the very painful infected lymph node which drains the area where the flea bite occurred) to the bloodstream. The bacteremia can cause a coagulopathy, producing the purpura seen in the 'black plague' and also spread to the lungs causing a hemorrhagic pneumonia. It is the pneumonia that can facilitate person-to-person transmission.\n\nMadagascar was the location of the isolation of multi-antimicrobial resistant _Y. pestis_ in 1995 (Galimand M, Guiyoule A, Gerbaud G, et al: Multidrug resistance in _Yersinia pestis_ mediated by a transferable plasmid. N Engl J Med. 1997; 337(10): 677-80, PMID: 9278464; available at, http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJM199709043371004). The strain was resistant to chloramphenicol, streptomycin, and tetracycline but sensitive to fluoroquinolones and trimethoprim as well as other aminoglycosides. This was an ominous observation; however, it is not clear whether this naturally occurring strain has persisted or spread. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nMadagascar: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/181]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Of the 5 confirmed cases, 2 were classified as bubonic plague and 3 as pulmonary plague. The outbreak was notable not only for the large number of cases but also for the high percentage of cases of pneumonic plague in urban settings and in areas where the infection generally does not occur. However since 1990, an annual 200 cases are being reported and bubonic plague takes on epidemic form, especially in the port of Mahajanga, each year. \n\n'Between 1930 and 1990, bubonic plague had 'virtually disappeared' on the island due to efficient pest-control and good health management. \n\n\nPlague reported in 8 Madagascar districts\n In an update on the plague situation in Madagascar, the Ministry of Health is now reporting plague has affected 8 districts in the country-Central Highlands, Ambalavao, Ambatofinandrahana, Ambositra, Ankazobe, Fandriana, Miarinarivo and Antisirabe. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[From the last update, 2 days before this, there were 2 deaths and a total of 13 cases. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Fatalities related to plague usually are caused by spread of the organism from the bubo (the very painful infected lymph node which drains the area where the flea bite occurred) to the bloodstream. LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\n Plague is known to be endemic in Madagascar and a seasonal upsurge (predominantly the bubonic form) usually occurs early every year between September and April.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1997-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-04-25 00:00:00", "1990-03-25 00:00:00", "1995-03-25 00:00:00", "1998-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-09-25 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Rasoamanana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mahajanga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ambositra", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ambatofinandrahana", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5905474", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Peru: (LB) septicemic, fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5905474", "date": "2018-07-14 21:47:15", "main_text": "PLAGUE - PERU: (LAMBAYEQUE) SEPTICEMIC, FATAL\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Thu 12 Jul 2018 11:08 a.m.\nSource: RPP Noticias [in Spanish, machine trans., edited]\nhttp://rpp.pe/peru/lambayeque/confirman-la-primera-muerte-por-peste-bubonica-en-lambayeque-noticia-1136024\n\n\nA 42-year-old man died from bubonic plague in the Lambayeque [Peru] region. He had contracted the disease in the Salas district, as confirmed by the Regional Health Management.\n\nThe head of Epidemiology, Dafne Moreno Paico, indicated that the Peruvian citizen likely acquired the disease by the bite of a flea infected with the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_ in the Moistures Alto de Salas sector on [Fri 29 Jun 2018]. Moreno noted that the patient, who had been living in the USA for 7 years, was admitted to the Regional Hospital of Lambayeque, where doctors confirmed bubonic plague, which later developed into septicemic plague. The specialist said that the citizen had high fever and malaise, which complicated his health, leading to his death.\n\nDafne Moreno said that, for 20 years, no deaths from this disease were reported in this region following the outbreak of plague occurring in several areas of Morrope; several people died in that outbreak.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Lambayeque is a region in northwestern Peru known for its rich Moche and Chimu historical past. The region's name originates from the ancient pre-Inca civilization of the Lambayeque. It can be seen on a map at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lambayeque_Region. - Mod.LL]\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Thu 12 Jul 2018 4:46 p.m.\nSource: RPP Noticias [in Spanish, machine trans., edited]\nhttp://rpp.pe/peru/lambayeque/ciento-veinte-personas-bajo-vigilancia-por-peste-en-la-region-noticia-1136106\n\n\nA relative of the deceased and a patient of the Regional Hospital presented some symptoms, but the immediate analysis ruled out the disease. A total of 120 people from the Lambayeque [Peru] region remain under surveillance after having had contact with the 42-year-old patient, who died after presenting symptoms of bubonic and septicemic plague.\n\nThe head of the Epidemiological Area of the Regional Health Management, Dafne Moreno, said that after a census of the patient's contacts, 89 people in the Regional Hospital, 16 relatives, and 15 in the clinic, where [the patient] was initially attended, were identified. He said that all were evaluated by specialists, and each person will receive the corresponding week-long treatment to prevent the disease. A relative of the deceased and a patient of the Regional Hospital presented fever, but the immediate analysis ruled out the disease; this is expected to be reconfirmed by the National Institute of Health.\n\n'The probabilities of transmission (due to septicemic plague) are few, given that the patient has not had major respiratory manifestations that could allow him to exhale the bacterium. Obviously, all precautions must be taken, and that is why all of them are given the corresponding treatment,' he explained. Moreno also indicated that surveillance and vector-control actions are continuing in different parts of the region in order to prevent the spread of the _Yersinia pestis_ bacteria, which causes bubonic plague, a disease usually transmitted by the bite of fleas from sick rodents.\n\nOn [Thu 12 Jul 2018], representatives of the Regional Health Management met with professionals from the National Health Institute and the National Health Strategy of Zoonosis of Minsa, who will provide technical assistance to strengthen these preventative activities.\n\nThe Regional Health Management confirmed on [Thu 12 Jul 2018] the death of a Peruvian patient, who for 7 years had been living in the USA. He arrived in Lima [Peru] and then visited the Salas district. There he was apparently bitten by a flea from a rodent. On [Wed 4 Jul 2018], he went to a clinic, which referred him to the Regional Hospital Lambayeque for his acute condition. However, one day later he died.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[_Yersinia pestis_ is endemic in parts of South America. Most cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea, causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. The swollen gland is called a 'bubo.' Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2-6 days after being bitten.\n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antimicrobial therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. Only if spread to the lungs occurs can the infection spread from person to person. However, if one acquires the infection by the respiratory route, this pneumonia is infectious as well. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nLambayeque, Peru: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/53696\n]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n Moreno also indicated that surveillance and vector-control actions are continuing in different parts of the region in order to prevent the spread of the _Yersinia pestis_ bacteria, which causes bubonic plague, a disease usually transmitted by the bite of fleas from sick rodents. \n\nDafne Moreno said that, for 20 years, no deaths from this disease were reported in this region following the outbreak of plague occurring in several areas of Morrope; several people died in that outbreak. Moreno noted that the patient, who had been living in the USA for 7 years, was admitted to the Regional Hospital of Lambayeque, where doctors confirmed bubonic plague, which later developed into septicemic plague. Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. \n\n'The probabilities of transmission (due to septicemic plague) are few, given that the patient has not had major respiratory manifestations that could allow him to exhale the bacterium. \n\nThe head of Epidemiology, Dafne Moreno Paico, indicated that the Peruvian citizen likely acquired the disease by the bite of a flea infected with the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_ in the Moistures Alto de Salas sector on [Fri 29 Jun 2018]. \n\nThe head of the Epidemiological Area of the Regional Health Management, Dafne Moreno, said that after a census of the patient's contacts, 89 people in the Regional Hospital, 16 relatives, and 15 in the clinic, where [the patient] was initially attended, were identified. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Most cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea, causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Morrope", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lima", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lambayeque", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chimu", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Peru", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5780275", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Madagascar (02): 2017-2018", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5780275", "date": "2018-05-02 21:02:49", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (02): 2017-2018\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 28 Apr 2018\nSource: Outbreaks News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/madagascar-huge-plague-season-ends-latest-numbers-10337/\n\n\nPlague is endemic in Madagascar, with hundreds of cases reported annually. Plague season typically lasts from Sept to April each year and the 2017-2018 season was quite remarkable. By the end of April 2018, some 2671 cases of the plague had been recorded since the 1st case of the plague season was reported in August 2017, including at least 239 deaths.\n\nThe number of cases in the 2017-2018 season is at least 6 times the annual average of around 400 cases, the outbreak began earlier than usual, and the predominance of pneumonic plague in urban areas this season differs from the usual trend of bubonic plague in rural areas.\n\nSince the official announcement of the containment of the urban pneumonic plague outbreak on 27 November 2017, 194 cases of plague, bubonic (60) and pneumonic (128), have been reported, including 23 deaths.\n\nPlague is an infectious disease caused by the bacterium, _Yersinia pestis_. It is found in animals throughout the world, most commonly rats but other rodents like ground squirrels, prairie dogs, chipmunks, rabbits and voles. Fleas typically serve as the vector of plague. Human cases have been linked to the domestic cats and dogs that brought infected fleas into the house. People can also get infected through direct contact with an infected animal, through inhalation and in the case of pneumonic plague, person to person.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This was indeed a 'banner' season for plague in the island nation of Madagascar. The outbreak was notable not only for the large number of cases but also for the high percentage of cases of pneumonic plague in urban settings and in areas where the infection generally does not occur.\n\nThe following paragraph is from Chanteau S, Ratsifasoamanana L, Rasoamanana B, et al: Plague, a reemerging disease in Madagascar. Emerg Infect Dis. 1998;4(1):101-4, PMID: 9452403 (available at http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/4/1/98-0114_article.htm.\n\n'Between 1930 and 1990, bubonic plague had 'virtually disappeared' on the island due to efficient pest-control and good health management. However since 1990, an annual 200 cases are being reported and bubonic plague takes on epidemic form, especially in the port of Mahajanga, each year. In the capital city of Antananarivo, more cases are also being notified each year since 1990. Madagascar (pop. 13 million) has accounted for 45 percent of all the cases of plague in Africa.'\n\nFatalities related to plague usually are caused by spread of the organism from the bubo (the very painful infected lymph node which drains the area where the flea bite occurred) to the bloodstream. The bacteremia can cause a coagulopathy, producing the purpura seen in the 'black plague' and also spread to the lungs causing a hemorrhagic pneumonia. It is the pneumonia that can facilitate person-to-person transmission.\n\nMadagascar was the location of the isolation of multi-antimicrobial resistant _Y. pestis_ in 1995 (Galimand M, Guiyoule A, Gerbaud G, et al: Multidrug resistance in _Yersinia pestis_ mediated by a transferable plasmid. N Engl J Med. 1997;337(10):677-80, PMID: 9278464; available at, http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJM199709043371004). Human cases have been linked to the domestic cats and dogs that brought infected fleas into the house.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-11-27 00:00:00", "1995-03-25 00:00:00", "1990-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-08-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mahajanga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rasoamanana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5856107", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (02): (ID)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5856107", "date": "2018-06-14 12:37:33", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (02): (IDAHO)\n**************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 12 Jun 2018\nSource: Idaho Central District Health Department [edited]\nhttp://www.cdhd.idaho.gov/pdfs/News/2018/06-12-18-human-plague-case.pdf\n\n\nPlague was confirmed this week in an Elmore county child. The child is recovering after receiving antimicrobial treatment. 'Plague is spread to humans through a bite from an infected flea. People can decrease their risk by treating their pets for fleas and avoiding contact with wildlife,' said Sarah Correll, DVM, Central District Health Department epidemiologist. 'Wear insect repellant, long pants, and socks when visiting plague affected areas.'\n\nIt is not known whether the child was exposed to plague in Idaho or during a recent trip to Oregon. Plague has historically been found in wildlife in both states. Since 1990, 8 human cases were confirmed in Oregon and 2 were confirmed in Idaho.\n\nPlague in humans is rare, but occurs naturally in some rodent populations, including ground squirrels in Idaho. Fleas spread the disease between animals. The disease can also be transmitted to humans by direct contact with infected animals or their fleas. Person-to-person transmission is extremely rare and this case was not a risk to others.\n\nSymptoms of plague usually occur within 2 to 6 days of exposure and include sudden onset of fever, chills, headache, and weakness. In most cases, there is also a painful swelling of the lymph node [called a bubo - Mod.LL] in the groin, armpit, or neck. Plague signs in cats and dogs include fever, lethargy and loss of appetite. There may be a swelling in the lymph nodes under the jaw of pets. Prompt diagnosis and appropriate antibiotic treatment can greatly reduce the risk of death in people and pets.\n\nPlague was identified in 2015 and 2016 in ground squirrels in both Elmore and south Ada counties. However, this season [2018], no ground squirrel die offs or unusual behavior has been reported by state wildlife officials.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The manifestations of _Yersinia pestis_ infection in this case are not stated in the report but it is likely to have been bubonic plague. Of late, 2015 was a 'banner year' for _Y. pestis_ infections in the USA with 15 cases and 4 deaths. In recent decades, an average of 7 human plague cases have been reported each year (range: 1-17 cases per year) with 0-2 deaths.\n\nThe following was extracted from: Prentice MB, Rahalison L. Plague. Lancet. 2007; 369(9568): 1196-207, with the citations removed:\n\n'Some plague cases (10-25 per cent) present with primary septicemia (hypotension, shock) without lymph nodes being obviously affected and these patients have higher mortality than those with bubonic plague. The term septicemic plague can be confusing, since most patients with buboes have detectable bacteremia at some stage and can also have high-density bacteremia with systemic signs of sepsis. Debate about whether septicemic plague is always secondary to frank or subclinical bubonic or pneumonic disease continues, but work in mice lends support to the existence of a syndrome of septicemic disease without histological changes in lymph nodes in a few animals infected by flea bites.'\n\nElmore county, Idaho which was named after the Ida Elmore mines, producer of silver and gold in the 1860s is located south of Boise and in the southwestern part of the state. Its location can be found on a map at: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elmore_County,_Idaho. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Idaho, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/3482]", "summary": "Debate about whether septicemic plague is always secondary to frank or subclinical bubonic or pneumonic disease continues, but work in mice lends support to the existence of a syndrome of septicemic disease without histological changes in lymph nodes in a few animals infected by flea bites.'\n\nElmore county, Idaho which was named after the Ida Elmore mines, producer of silver and gold in the 1860s is located south of Boise and in the southwestern part of the state. 2007; 369(9568): 1196-207, with the citations removed:\n\n'Some plague cases (10-25 per cent) present with primary septicemia (hypotension, shock) without lymph nodes being obviously affected and these patients have higher mortality than those with bubonic plague. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n In recent decades, an average of 7 human plague cases have been reported each year (range: 1-17 cases per year) with 0-2 deaths.\n\n \n\nSymptoms of plague usually occur within 2 to 6 days of exposure and include sudden onset of fever, chills, headache, and weakness. PLAGUE - USA (02): (IDAHO)\n**************************\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The manifestations of _Yersinia pestis_ infection in this case are not stated in the report but it is likely to have been bubonic plague. \n\nPlague was identified in 2015 and 2016 in ground squirrels in both Elmore and south Ada counties. Source: Idaho Central District Health Department [edited]\nhttp://www.cdhd.idaho.gov/pdfs/News/2018/06-12-18-human-plague-case.pdf\n\n\nPlague was confirmed this week in an Elmore county child. The term septicemic plague can be confusing, since most patients with buboes have detectable bacteremia at some stage and can also have high-density bacteremia with systemic signs of sepsis. \n\nIt is not known whether the child was exposed to plague in Idaho or during a recent trip to Oregon.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1990-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-10-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Boise", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Idaho", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Elmore county", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5721677", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA: (NM) canine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5721677", "date": "2018-03-31 20:41:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA: (NEW MEXICO) CANINE\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 30 Mar 2018\nSource: NH Register [edited]\nhttps://www.nhregister.com/news/article/Health-agency-reports-case-of-plague-in-Santa-Fe-12793684.php\n\n\nState health officials report a case of plague in a dog from Santa Fe County, making it the 1st diagnosed case of plague in New Mexico this year [2018].\n\nThe Department of Health says it's checking the home of the dog's owner for risks to others and sending personnel around the neighborhood to inform residents and provide information on reducing risks.\n\nPlague is a bacterial disease of wildlife and is generally transmitted to humans and pets through the bites of infected fleas. Pet animals also can be exposed after eating an infected animal. Plague can be transmitted to humans by direct contact with infected animals, including rodents, wildlife and pets.\n\nThe department says New Mexico had 4 human cases of plague in 2017 and that those people all survived the illness.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations. Surveillance efforts testing fleas are very important to detect circulation of _Y. pestis_ and risk of infection.\n\nPlague may infect human beings through several routes: 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals (mentioned previously; 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues, generally from an animal; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals.\n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under the jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front leg (the armpit, if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever. These clinical signs may be present in the dog as well. Swelling under the jaw in cats is frequently mistaken as a cat fight abscess. Please take your pet to a veterinarian if you notice any abnormalities. Be sure to consult your veterinarian if you find a lump on your pet, as well as to get the best flea prevention treatment for your pet. It may be necessary to have your yard and/or home treated for fleas. Vacuum your home, including any bedding and furniture, and immediately upon finishing take the vacuum back outside, seal it in a plastic bag, and dispose of it. This type of cleaning will have to be repeated every week for 4-6 weeks to break the cycle of the flea in the home. This disease should be taken seriously, so please be sure your pet is on some form of flea prevention.\n\nIf your pets are not on a flea prevention, please ask your veterinarian about the best flea prevention. Bathing your pet in dishwashing soap is not sufficient to help your pet avoid diseases carried by fleas. Some of the over the counter flea preventions may be harmful to your pet so please check with your veterinarian. It is also a good time to make sure your pet is current on a rabies shot.\n\nKeeping your pets inside a yard will help diminish the ability to consume a dead animal and further reduce the risk of plague to your animal and to yourself. - Mod.TG\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of New Mexico, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/233]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Plague may infect human beings through several routes: 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals (mentioned previously; 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues, generally from an animal; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. \n\nIf your pets are not on a flea prevention, please ask your veterinarian about the best flea prevention. Be sure to consult your veterinarian if you find a lump on your pet, as well as to get the best flea prevention treatment for your pet. \n\nThe Department of Health says it's checking the home of the dog's owner for risks to others and sending personnel around the neighborhood to inform residents and provide information on reducing risks. Plague is a bacterial disease of wildlife and is generally transmitted to humans and pets through the bites of infected fleas. \n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under the jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front leg (the armpit, if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever. Plague can be transmitted to humans by direct contact with infected animals, including rodents, wildlife and pets. Bathing your pet in dishwashing soap is not sufficient to help your pet avoid diseases carried by fleas. \n\nThe department says New Mexico had 4 human cases of plague in 2017 and that those people all survived the illness. This disease should be taken seriously, so please be sure your pet is on some form of flea prevention.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "rabies"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2017-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santa Fe County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5752357", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Bolivia: (LP) bubonic, fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5752357", "date": "2018-04-17 12:44:43", "main_text": "PLAGUE - BOLIVIA: (LA PAZ) BUBONIC, FATAL\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 16 Apr 2018 17:48 BOT\nSource: La Raz\u00f3n Digital, Bolivia [in Spanish, machine trans., summ., edited]\nhttp://www.la-razon.com/sociedad/Caso-peste-bubonica-anciana-muere-norte-Paz-raton-roedor-Apolo_0_2911508872.html\n\n\nThe Departmental Health Service (SEDES) of La Paz reported that an 81-year-old woman in the municipality of Apolo, north of La Paz, died on 26 Feb 2018, due to bubonic plague, confirming the 1st case of this type of disease in 2018. The head of the Epidemiology Unit of that health division, Alejandra Salas, indicated that the positive case was confirmed after a laboratory examination that led to the activation of an operation in the area, in order to interrupt the chain of transmission. 'They proceeded to perform the active search for rodents that were near the houses, because these animals are usually those that have fleas and through their bite the bubonic plague is transmitted,' Salas said, according to an institutional note.\n\nThe health contingent evaluated homes in the communities of Machua, Los Altos, Alto Humaca, and Suturi, where they also trained residents on the symptoms of the disease, its consequences and how to disinfect vulnerable areas with insecticides.\n\n[Byline: Rub\u00e9n Ari\u00f1ez]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-ESP\n<promed-esp@promedmail.org>\n\n[_Yersinia pestis_ is endemic in parts of South America including the La Paz department of Bolivia.\n\nMost cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. The swollen gland is called a 'bubo.' Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2 to 6 days after being bitten.\n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antibiotic therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. At this stage, as appears to have happened in the report above, person-to-person spread can occur, causing other cases of 'primary' plague pneumonia. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nApolo, La Paz, Bolivia: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/13357]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. \n\nMost cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. \n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. The Departmental Health Service (SEDES) of La Paz reported that an 81-year-old woman in the municipality of Apolo, north of La Paz, died on 26 Feb 2018, due to bubonic plague, confirming the 1st case of this type of disease in 2018.
