The inhabitants of this Analamanga region district [Antananarivo province], located 100 km [62 mi] from Antananarivo have been in a panic since the beginning of this week. Anguish following the existence of a suspected case of plague affecting a cook with the clergy of the Saint-Jean school.\n\n'This 40-year-old man presented all the symptoms of bubonic plague, including fever, fatigue, and swollen lymph glands. Since his consultation at Ankazobe level II health center last Tue 16 Jan 2018, the patient is being treated in the isolation ward,' says Andriamanantena Rakotoarivony, technical assistant in the Ankazobe Public Health District Service (Sdsp).\n\nAnkazobe constitutes one of the plague foci in Madagascar, that is to say, cases of bubonic or pulmonary plague often appear there during the season between August and April. Since the beginning of the season, this District has recorded 9 cases, including 4 deaths. The 1st case that appeared in August 2017 would have been a foreigner passing through this locality. Currently, 13 districts are still considered as usual plague foci, including Tsiroanomandidy, Andilamena, Arivonimamo, etc. 'Despite the declaration of the end of the epidemic of urban pneumonic plague, new cases of bubonic plague continue to appear this season. However, no deaths have been recorded since the inhabitants were able to assimilate sensitization, including immediate consultation of health centers in the event of the appearance of suspicious signs,' said Dr Manitra Rakotoarivony, Director of Health Promotion at the supervisory ministry. In all cases, the population must remain cautious to better prevent and cope with new cases.\n\nAt this time, the mobilization of community outreach workers is continuing, as is the capacity building of health personnel, including physicians.\n\n[Byline: Patricia Ramavonirina]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[This case appears to be a sporadic case of bubonic plague, unrelated to the very large outbreak occurring earlier in this plague season in Madagascar.\n\nMaps of Madagascar: http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/madagascar/mar2582r/madagascar_pol.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/63640. However, the country this fall experienced a steep rise in pneumonic cases, especially in urban areas. Since August 2017, officials have reported 2575 confirmed, probable, or suspected cases, including 221 deaths. Of the total, 1985 cases have been classified as the more serious pneumonic form.\n\nOver the most recent reporting week Analamanga region has been most affected, and active surveillance and health worker training are under way in the area's private and public health facilities.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There is a continued downward trend in cases. With so many cases of pneumonic plague, the case fatality rate seems low.\n\nDate / Cases / Deaths / Average new cases per day\n-------------------------------------------------\n14 Sep 2017 / 28 / PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (37): FATAL\n*******************************\n 14 Sep 2017 / 28 / 5\n30 Dec 2017 / 2575 / 221 / 12\n- Mod.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2037-03-25 00:00:00", "2575-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-04-25 00:00:00", "2021-09-25 00:00:00", "2017-08-25 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00", "1985-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "week Analamanga", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5506305", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - China : (GS) septicemic, fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5506305", "date": "2017-12-15 16:26:06", "main_text": "PLAGUE - CHINA: (GANSU) SEPTICEMIC, FATAL\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 15 Dec 2017\nSource: China.org [edited]\nhttp://www.china.org.cn/china/2017-12/15/content_50105165.htm\n\n\nHealth authorities in Gansu province have confirmed the death of a patient from septicemic plague -- a rare disease in China -- and strict control and prevention measures are being imposed. The patient, a herder from Jiuquan's Subei Mongolian autonomous county, died on [Tue 12 Dec 2017] afternoon, despite efforts by medical personnel, according to a statement by the Gansu Health and Family Planning Commission on [Wed 13 Dec 2017].The patient's gender was not disclosed. Experts said tests had confirmed at 11 pm that the patient died of septicemic plague that evolved from bubonic plague, which was reported as a suspected plague case at 5:30 pm.\n\nAuthorities said they had placed 12 people who had close contact with the patient under quarantine, and no abnormalities had been found. The Jiuquan government also imposed quarantine measures at Subei People's Hospital and at the patient's residence in Subei to prevent the spread of the disease, the statement said. The National Health and Family Planning Commission, China's top health authority, and the Gansu commission sent experts to Subei to guide disease control and prevention, the statement said.\n\nPlague, a virulent microbe that can be transmitted to humans from wild animals, is classed as a Category A infectious disease -- meaning extremely dangerous -- under Chinese law. The only other disease falling into the category is cholera. The law requires that authorities adopt strict measures for control and prevention, including immediately reporting suspected cases, keeping infected people under quarantine during treatment and sterilizing the bodies of the deceased and cremating them.\n\nOnly one plague case was reported on the Chinese mainland in 2016 and the person didn't die, according to the national health commission. No cases were reported on the mainland between January and June 2017.\n\nTuesday's case was the 1st reported in Gansu since 2014, according to the provincial health commission. Three cases were reported in the province that year [2014], and all 3 people died. In July 2017, Gansu became the 1st provincial region in China to adopt strict measures for the control and prevention of plague. Governments at the county level and higher that are in, or near, places prone to the disease were asked to establish institutions to prevent and control the disease.\n\nResidents were advised to avoid contact with sick animals that might be infected with the disease -- marmots, for example -- and told not to eat them.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most plague cases are due to the bubonic form following the bite of an infected rodent flea causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. The swollen gland is called a 'bubo.' Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2 to 6 days after being bitten.\n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, the _Yersinia pestis_ organism can invade the bloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition 'septicemic plague'. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antibiotic therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. At this stage, as appears to have happened in this case, person-to-person spread can occur, causing cases of 'primary' plague pneumonia.\n\nThe marmot is the most common reservoir for _Yersinia pestis_ in eastern Asia. The etymology of the term 'marmot' is uncertain (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marmot). It may have arisen from the Gallo-Romance prefix marm-, meaning to mumble or murmur (an example of onomatopoeia). Another possible origin is post-classical Latin, mus montanus, meaning 'mountain mouse.' - Mod.LL\n\nGansu is a province of the People's Republic of China, located in the northwest of the country and can be found on a map at\nhttps://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gansu. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "Experts said tests had confirmed at 11 pm that the patient died of septicemic plague that evolved from bubonic plague, which was reported as a suspected plague case at 5:30 pm. \n\n\nHealth authorities in Gansu province have confirmed the death of a patient from septicemic plague -- a rare disease in China -- and strict control and prevention measures are being imposed. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nPlague, a virulent microbe that can be transmitted to humans from wild animals, is classed as a Category A infectious disease -- meaning extremely dangerous -- under Chinese law. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most plague cases are due to the bubonic form following the bite of an infected rodent flea causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. \n\nOnly one plague case was reported on the Chinese mainland in 2016 and the person didn't die, according to the national health commission. Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. The law requires that authorities adopt strict measures for control and prevention, including immediately reporting suspected cases, keeping infected people under quarantine during treatment and sterilizing the bodies of the deceased and cremating them. \n\nResidents were advised to avoid contact with sick animals that might be infected with the disease -- marmots, for example -- and told not to eat them. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition 'septicemic plague'. At this stage, as appears to have happened in this case, person-to-person spread can occur, causing cases of 'primary' plague pneumonia. The patient, a herder from Jiuquan's Subei Mongolian autonomous county, died on [Tue 12 Dec 2017] afternoon, despite efforts by medical personnel, according to a statement by the Gansu Health and Family Planning Commission on [Wed 13 Dec 2017].The patient's gender was not disclosed. In July 2017, Gansu became the 1st provincial region in China to adopt strict measures for the control and prevention of plague. The National Health and Family Planning Commission, China's top health authority, and the Gansu commission sent experts to Subei to guide disease control and prevention, the statement said. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The Jiuquan government also imposed quarantine measures at Subei People's Hospital and at the patient's residence in Subei to prevent the spread of the disease, the statement said. \n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, the _Yersinia pestis_ organism can invade the bloodstream. \n\nTuesday's case was the 1st reported in Gansu since 2014, according to the provincial health commission. Governments at the county level and higher that are in, or near, places prone to the disease were asked to establish institutions to prevent and control the disease. If plague patients are not given specific antibiotic therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. PLAGUE - CHINA: (GANSU) SEPTICEMIC, FATAL\n A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2 to 6 days after being bitten. \n\n--\n Authorities said they had placed 12 people who had close contact with the patient under quarantine, and no abnormalities had been found.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "cholera", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2017-07-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Jiuquan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the People 's Republic of China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gansu", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5504809", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (15) (CO): canine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5504809", "date": "2017-12-15 10:33:48", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (15) (COLORADO): CANINE\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 12 Dec 2017\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/colorado-dog-plague-euthanized-csu-notifies-faculty-students-33776/\n\n\nA dog that was being treated at Colorado State University (CSU) was diagnosed with plague and euthanized on Friday [8 Dec 2017]. The CSU Veterinary Teaching Hospital notified faculty, staff, and students on Monday [11 Dec 2017].\n\nLocal media reports that this was the 7th case of plague in a domestic animal in Colorado this year [2017].\n\nOfficials say they have taken all of the steps to directly notify anyone who may have been exposed to the bacteria, either directly at the hospital or who had animals that were also patients at the time the infected dog was hospitalized.\n\nFor those who were in contact with the infected dog, early detection of infections with this bacteria are very treatable with an antibiotic. Those who are at risk have been provided with information about how to monitor for symptoms.\n\nA limited number of people were exposed, but as a precaution, anyone with concerns about exposure should consult with their medical care provider. If you have not received a direct contact from the Veterinary Teaching Hospital VT(H), you or your pet were not identified as being at risk for potential exposure.\n\nThis was a complex case because some of the dog's symptoms were atypical for plague. As soon as tests confirmed late Friday [8 Dec 2017] that the dog was infected with the bacteria that causes plague, the hospital took immediate steps to notify people who may have been exposed. Those steps were:\n\n- We immediately identified and directly notified students, staff and faculty who were potentially exposed to the dog. We provided specific information about the case and proactive next steps these individuals should take.\n- We immediately identified and then directly notified the owners of 59 animals (48 dogs, 10 cats and a rabbit) at the hospital that were potentially exposed via sharing space with the infected dog. We provided information about proactive next steps and best practices, which include giving these pets an antibiotic, and are providing that medication for free to these clients.\n- We cleaned and disinfected the treatment areas where the dog was receiving care, following best practices recommended by experts at CSU and the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment.\n- We notified the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment, Larimer County Department of Public Health, and other regulatory agencies, and began collaborating on a response, following public health best practices and recommendations.\n- Before the test confirmed the infection, the dog had been placed on a drug that would treat this infection, and would greatly reduce exposure to others after the 1st 48 hours. After the infection was confirmed, veterinarians began treating all other pets who had been in close proximity to the infected dog that were at the VTH.\n\nFacts about _Yersinia pestis_ and plague:\n- This bacterium is commonly found in rodents in Colorado, including the Fort Collins area.\n- Plague is an extremely rare diagnosis in a dog.\n- The timeframe for showing symptoms of illness after exposure are up to 7 days but can occur in a much shorter time frame, such as 2-3 days.\n- The bacteria most commonly spread via a bite from an infected flea. Less commonly, they can spread through direct contact with body fluids or tissue from an infected person or animal, or by breathing in infected droplets from the cough of an infected person, generally limited to those with close contact.\n- Plague is most common in the area during the warm months of May to September. Freezing temperatures often greatly diminish the spread.\n- Public health officials have advised that the chance of infection is limited to those with direct contact with the infected animal. They recommend as a precaution that all of those potentially exposed consult with their medical care provider to discuss monitoring for fever and other signs of infection, and potential prophylactic antibiotic treatment.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague may infect human beings through several routes: 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals (mentioned previously; 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues, generally from an animal; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals.\n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under the jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front leg (the armpit, if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever. These clinical signs may be present in the dog as well. Swelling under the jaw in cats is frequently mistaken as a cat fight abscess. Please take your pet to a veterinarian if you notice any abnormalities. Be sure to consult your veterinarian if you find a lump on your pet, as well as to get the best flea prevention treatment for your pet. It may be necessary to have your yard and/or home treated for fleas. Vacuum your home, including any bedding and furniture, and immediately upon finishing take the vacuum back outside, seal it in a plastic bag, and dispose of it. This type of cleaning will have to be repeated every week for 4-6 weeks to break the cycle of the flea in the home. This disease should be taken seriously, so please be sure your pet is on some form of flea prevention. - Mod.TG\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nColorado, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/209]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague may infect human beings through several routes: 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals (mentioned previously; 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues, generally from an animal; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Less commonly, they can spread through direct contact with body fluids or tissue from an infected person or animal, or by breathing in infected droplets from the cough of an infected person, generally limited to those with close contact. As soon as tests confirmed late Friday [8 Dec 2017] that the dog was infected with the bacteria that causes plague, the hospital took immediate steps to notify people who may have been exposed. - We immediately identified and then directly notified the owners of 59 animals (48 dogs, 10 cats and a rabbit) at the hospital that were potentially exposed via sharing space with the infected dog. Officials say they have taken all of the steps to directly notify anyone who may have been exposed to the bacteria, either directly at the hospital or who had animals that were also patients at the time the infected dog was hospitalized. Those steps were:\n\n- We immediately identified and directly notified students, staff and faculty who were potentially exposed to the dog. \n- Plague is an extremely rare diagnosis in a dog. They recommend as a precaution that all of those potentially exposed consult with their medical care provider to discuss monitoring for fever and other signs of infection, and potential prophylactic antibiotic treatment. After the infection was confirmed, veterinarians began treating all other pets who had been in close proximity to the infected dog that were at the VTH. \n\nA limited number of people were exposed, but as a precaution, anyone with concerns about exposure should consult with their medical care provider. For those who were in contact with the infected dog, early detection of infections with this bacteria are very treatable with an antibiotic. \n\nFacts about _Yersinia pestis_ and plague:\n- - Public health officials have advised that the chance of infection is limited to those with direct contact with the infected animal. TG\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nColorado, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/209] Before the test confirmed the infection, the dog had been placed on a drug that would treat this infection, and would greatly reduce exposure to others after the 1st 48 hours. \n\nThis was a complex case because some of the dog's symptoms were atypical for plague.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5482572", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Madagascar (36): fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5482572", "date": "2017-12-05 10:48:23", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (36): FATAL\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 4 Dec 2017\nSource: WHO [edited]\nhttps://reliefweb.int/report/madagascar/madagascar-plague-outbreak-external-situation-report-14-4-december-2017\n\n\nExternal Situation Report 14: 04 December 2017\n-----------------------------------------------\nDue to concerted national and international response the current and unprecedented outbreak of plague in Madagascar, which started on [Tue 1 Aug 2017], has been contained.\n\nOn [Mon 27 Nov 2017] the Ministry of Health of Madagascar officially announced the containment of the acute urban pneumonic plague outbreak. However, because plague is endemic in Madagascar and the plague season lasts from September to April, more cases of bubonic and sporadic pneumonic plague are expected to be reported until April 2018. WHO and other stakeholders will continue to support the Ministry of Health of Madagascar to maintain vigilance and to sustain a strong alert and response system to rapidly detect and respond to new plague cases as they emerge.\n\nFrom [Mon 20 to Sun 26 Nov 2017], 72 cases of plague (one confirmed, 6 probable and 65 suspect) were reported to WHO. The date of onset of the last confirmed bubonic case was [Sat 18 Nov 2017] and the date of onset of the last case of secondary pneumonic plague (primary bubonic form) was [Sun 19 Nov 2017].\n\nFrom [Tue 1 Aug to Sun 26 Nov 2017], a cumulative total of 2417 confirmed, probable and suspected cases of plague, including 209 deaths (case fatality rate 9 percent), have been reported from 57 of 114 (50 percent) districts in Madagascar. Analamanga Region in central Madagascar has been the most affected, with 68 percent of all recorded cases. Since the beginning of this outbreak, the vast majority of cases have been treated and have recovered. As of [Sun 26 Nov 201], only 13 people were hospitalized for plague. There has been no international spread outside the country.\n\nThe majority of the reported cases (1854, 77 percent) have been clinically classified as pneumonic plague, 355 have been classified as bubonic plague (15 percent), one was septicemic, and 207 have not yet been classified (further classification of cases is in process). Up to 81 healthcare workers have had illness compatible with plague, none of whom have died.\n\nOf the 1854 clinical pneumonic cases, 390 (21 percent) have been confirmed, 618 (33 percent) are probable and 846 (46 percent) remain suspected (additional laboratory results are in process). Up to 33 isolates of _Yersinia pestis_ have been cultured and are sensitive to all antimicrobials recommended by the National Plague Control Program.\n\nA total of 7318 contacts identified during this outbreak have been put under a course of prophylactic antibiotics, including 11 contacts who developed symptoms compatible with plague and were classified as suspect cases. On [Sun 26 Nov 2017], 24 of 29 (83 percent) contacts were followed.\n\nPlague is endemic on the Plateaux of Madagascar, including Ankazobe District, where the current outbreak originated. A seasonal upsurge, predominantly of the bubonic form, usually occurs yearly between September and April. This year [2017], the plague season began earlier than usual. The current outbreak is predominantly pneumonic and is affecting both endemic and non-endemic areas, including major urban centres such as Antananarivo (the capital city) and Toamasina (a port city).\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There is a continued downward trend in cases. With so many cases of pneumonic plague, the case fatality rate seems low.\n\nDate / Cases / Deaths / Average new cases per day\n-------------------------------------------------\n14 Sep 2017 / 28 / 5\n30 Sep 2017 / 73 / 17 / 3\n3 Oct 2017 / 194 / 30 / 40\n5 Oct 2017 / 258 / 36 / 32\n7 Oct 2017 / 343 / 42 / 43\n8 Oct 2017 / 387 / 45 / 44\n9 Oct 2017 / 449 / 48 / 62\n10 Oct 2017 / 500 / 54 / 51\n11 Oct 2017 / 561 / 57 / 61\n13 Oct 2017 / 684 / 57 / 61\n16 Oct 2017 / 805 / 74 / 40\n17 Oct 2017 / 878 / 80 / 44\n18 Oct 2017 / 1032 / 89 / 164\n19 Oct 2017 / 1153 / 94 / 121\n20 Oct 2017 / 1297 / 102 / --\n23 Oct 2017 / 1192 / 124 / 10\n25 Oct 2017 / 1309 / 93 / 58\n27 Oct 2017 / 1554 / 113 / 122\n30 Oct 2017 / 1801 / 127 / 82\n1 Nov 2017 / 1836 / 133 / 17\n3 Nov 2017 / 1947 / 143 / 55\n10 Nov 2017 / 2119 / 171 / 25\n13 Nov 2017 / 2158 / 174 / 13\n17 Nov 2017 / 2267 / 195 / 27\n22 Nov 2017 / 2348 / 202 / 16\n26 Nov 2017 / 2417 / 209 / 15.\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map\nMadagascar: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/181. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "Sep 2017 / 73 / 17 / 3\n3 Oct 2017 / 194 / 30 / 40\n5 Oct 2017 / 258 / 36 / 32\n7 Oct 2017 / 343 / 42 / 43\n8 Oct 2017 / 387 / 45 / 44\n9 Oct 2017 / 449 / 48 / 62\n10 Oct 2017 / 500 / 54 / 51\n11 Oct 2017 / 561 / 57 / 61\n13 Oct 2017 / 684 / 57 / 61\n16 Oct 2017 / 805 / 74 / 40\n17 Oct 2017 / 878 / 80 / 44\n18 Oct 2017 / 1032 / 89 / 164\n19 Oct 2017 / 1153 / 94 / 121\n20 Oct 2017 / 1297 / 102 / --\n 23 Oct 2017 / 1192 / 124 / 10\n25 Oct 2017 / 1309 / 93 / 58\n27 Oct 2017 / 1554 / 113 / 122\n30 Oct 2017 / 1801 / 127 / 82\n1 Nov 2017 / 1836 / 133 / 17\n3 Nov 2017 / 1947 / 143 / 55\n10 Nov 2017 / 2119 / 171 / 25\n13 Nov 2017 / 2158 / 174 / 13\n17 Nov 2017 / 2267 / 195 / 27\n22 Nov 2017 / 2348 / 202 / 16\n26 Nov 2017 / 2417 / 209 / 15. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< 14 Sep 2017 / 28 / 5\n30 \n\n\nExternal Situation Report 14: 04 December 2017\n Date: Mon 4 Dec 2017\n \n\nOf the 1854 clinical pneumonic cases, 390 (21 percent) have been confirmed, 618 (33 percent) are probable and 846 (46 percent)", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2017-12-25 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00", "1854-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-09-25 00:00:00", "2021-04-25 00:00:00", "2417-03-25 00:00:00", "2036-03-25 00:00:00", "2018-04-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Analamanga Region", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ankazobe District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5501299", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (14): (CA) bear, exposure", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5501299", "date": "2017-12-13 17:20:55", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (14): (CALIFORNIA) BEAR, EXPOSURE\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 8 Dec 2016, 7:03 AM\nSource: The Mercury News [edited]\nhttp://www.mercurynews.com/2017/12/08/bears-exposed-to-plague-found-in-northern-california/\n\n\nTwo black bears exposed to the plague were found in Paradise, according to the California Department of Public Health. The department collected blood in September [2017] from 2 bears killed under depredation permits, and the samples tested positive for antibodies to _Yersinia pestis_, the bacterium that causes plague.\n\nThe California Department of Fish and Wildlife issued the depredation permits. Tanya Espinosa, spokesperson for U.S. Department of Agriculture's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, said she could not reveal the location the bears were found because they were not on public lands.\n\nThey were removed by Animal and Plant Health Inspection Services because they were damaging private lands and an agricultural resource, Espinosa said.\n\nThe U.S. Department of Agriculture Wildlife Services routinely submits blood samples from bears and other predators it encounters in wildlife management activities. This is, in part, to determine whether they have been exposed to plague in the past.\n\nPlague is a flea-borne disease spread through contact with infected animals, dead or alive, and flea bites. In the 1300s, it killed millions in Europe, and took on the name of the Black Death. Symptoms include fever, nausea, headaches, weakness and swollen, tender lymph nodes. If caught early, it's treatable in the modern age with antibiotics.\n\nPredators like bears often prey on rodents, which are the primary carriers of plague, according to the state Public Health Department. When bears scavenge a plague-infected rodent, they are exposed to plague bacteria and develop antibodies. These bears were infected with the bacterium that causes plague, but unlike humans, bears do not become ill from plague infection, according to the state.\n\nThe public health department can get an indication of plague activity in a geographic area by testing bear blood samples and finding plague antibodies. Positive samples help identify areas where the state department or local agencies can focus rodent surveillance activities to determine the risk to humans and if there is increased plague activity.\n\nPlague routinely occurs in the Sierra Nevada, where the state public health department suspects the bears were most likely exposed, in the mountains east of Paradise. It's hard to pin down exactly where the plague exposure occurred because bears have large home ranges, according to the department.\n\nHistorically, about 12 percent of bear samples have tested positive for plague antibodies, according to California Department of Public Health. Positive bear samples have been found in 32 counties in California.\n\n[Byline: Ashiah Scharaga]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_ which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations. Small rodents such as deer mice and grasshopper mice are suggested to act as the reservoirs. Larger species like squirrels and chipmunks are considered to be more vulnerable to infection.\n\nThe pathogen occurs in California most commonly in chipmunks, ground squirrels, and other rodents, where infection can be subclinical or contribute to mass die-offs. Carnivores (like bears) may be infected through fleabite or ingestion of infected rodents. Studies of black bears in California found plague antibody prevalence from 15 percent to 36 percent. - Mod.PMB\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map: California, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/204>]", "summary": "These bears were infected with the bacterium that causes plague, but unlike humans, bears do not become ill from plague infection, according to the state. Historically, about 12 percent of bear samples have tested positive for plague antibodies, according to California Department of Public Health.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-09-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5481202", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Peru: (LL) infected fleas", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5481202", "date": "2017-12-04 10:02:14", "main_text": "PLAGUE - PERU: (LA LIBERTAD) INFECTED FLEAS\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 2 Dec 2017\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/peru-plague-infected-fleas-found-sewer-rats-la-libertad-96669/\n\n\nOfficials in La Libertad, Peru are carrying out a fumigation campaign in the District Municipality of Chocope, Ascope province, after the presence of the agent of plague, _Yersinia pestis_, was confirmed in fleas found on sewer rodents, according to a El Comercio report (computer translated). In addition, the National Institute of Health (INS) issued a report stating that in a sample extracted in the sector known as Panamericana Norte, in Chocope, '18 percent of fleas in sewer rodents are infected with the bacterium.'\n\nGiven this situation, the district mayor, Rolando Luj\u00e1n, met with the head of the local health center and other competent authorities to take measures to prevent the epidemic outbreak of bubonic plague in Chocope, a district considered endemic area for plague. The authorities decided to develop a fumigation campaign in 160 homes located in the Panamericana Norte sector. The fumigation will be in charge of qualified personnel of the Ministry of Health (Minsa).\n\n'We ask for the cooperation of the families and owners so that they allow the fumigators to enter their buildings and we can avoid the resurgence of the disease, whose last case was presented some 2 years ago, 'said the mayor. Luj\u00e1n also explained why killing the rats was not the answer-'What is infected is the flea, not the rodent. If we kill the rodent the flea will jump and possibly infect other animals.'\n\nPlague is an infectious disease caused by the bacterium, _Yersinia pestis_. It is found in animals throughout the world, most commonly rats, but also in other rodents like ground squirrels, prairie dogs, chipmunks, rabbits, and voles. Fleas typically serve as the vector of plague. Human cases have been linked to domestic cats and dogs that brought infected fleas into the house. People can also get infected through direct contact with an infected animal, [or person to person through inhalation, as in the case of pneumonic plague].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague continues to occur sporadically in South America, especially the La Libertad region of Peru. - Mod.LL\n\nMaps of Peru: http://www.geographicguide.com/pictures/peru-map.jpg (regions) and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/30540]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague continues to occur sporadically in South America, especially the La Libertad region of Peru. http://outbreaknewstoday.com/peru-plague-infected-fleas-found-sewer-rats-la-libertad-96669/\n\n\nOfficials in La Libertad, Peru are carrying out a fumigation campaign in the District Municipality of Chocope, Ascope province, after the presence of the agent of plague, _Yersinia pestis_, was confirmed in fleas found on sewer rodents, according to a El Comercio report (computer translated). PLAGUE - PERU: (LA LIBERTAD) INFECTED FLEAS\n*******************************************\n In addition, the National Institute of Health (INS) issued a report stating that in a sample extracted in the sector known as Panamericana Norte, in Chocope, '18 percent of fleas in sewer rodents are infected with the bacterium.'\n\n Given this situation, the district mayor, Rolando Luj\u00e1n, met with the head of the local health center and other competent authorities to take measures to prevent the epidemic outbreak of bubonic plague in Chocope, a district considered endemic area for plague.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2017-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Chocope", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "La Libertad", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Peru", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "El Comercio", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5453966", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Madagascar (34): fatal, decreasing caseload", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5453966", "date": "2017-11-20 17:36:03", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (34): FATAL, DECREASING CASELOAD\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Fri 20 Nov 2017\nSource: Reliefweb, a WHO report [edited]\nhttps://reliefweb.int/report/madagascar/madagascar-plague-outbreak-external-situation-report-12-20-november-2017\n\n\nMadagascar plague outbreak: external situation report no.12 - [20 Nov 2017]\n---------------------------------------------------------------------\nWHO continues to support the Ministry of Public Health and other national authorities in Madagascar to monitor and respond to the outbreak of plague. From [6 to 17 Nov 2017], 216 cases of plague (1 confirmed, 20 probable and 195 suspected) were reported to WHO. The date of onset of the last case of bubonic plague was [7 Nov 2017] and the last confirmed case of pneumonic plague was reported on [14 Nov 2017].\n\nFrom [1 Aug to 17 Nov 2017], a cumulative total of 2267 confirmed, probable and suspected cases of plague, including 195 deaths (case fatality rate 9 per cent), have been reported from 55 of 114 (48 per cent) districts in Madagascar.\n\nAnalamanga Region in central Madagascar has been the most affected, with 68 per cent of all recorded cases. Since the beginning of this outbreak, the vast majority of cases have been treated and recovered. As of [17 Nov 2017], only [no number is given - Mod.LL] people were hospitalized for plague. There has been no international spread outside the country.\n\nMost of the reported cases (1732, 76 per cent) have been clinically classified as pneumonic plague, 327 have been classified as bubonic plague (14 per cent); 1 was septicemic; and 207 have not yet been classified (further classification of cases is in process). A total of 81 health care workers have had illness compatible with plague, none of whom have died.\n\nOf the 1732 clinical pneumonic cases, 389 (22 per cent) have been confirmed, 612 (35 per cent) are probable and 731 (42 per cent) remain suspected (additional laboratory results are in process). Thirty isolates of _Yersinia pestis_ have been cultured and are sensitive to all antimicrobials recommended by the National Plague Control Program.\n\nOf the 7270 contacts identified during this outbreak, about 99 per cent (7166) have completed their 7-day follow up and a course of prophylactic antimicrobials, and 11 contacts have developed symptoms compatible with plague and became suspected cases. On [17 Nov 2017], all 33 contacts currently under follow-up were reached and provided with prophylactic antimicrobials.\n\nPlague is endemic on the Plateaux of Madagascar, including Ankazobe District, where the current outbreak originated.\n\nA seasonal upsurge, predominantly of the bubonic form, usually occurs yearly between September and April. In 2017, the plague season began earlier than usual. The current outbreak is predominantly pneumonic and is affecting both endemic and non-endemic areas, including major urban centres such as Antananarivo (the capital city) and Toamasina (a port city).\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There is a continued downward trend in cases. With so many cases of pneumonic plague, the case fatality rate seems low.\n\nDate / Cases / Deaths / Average new cases per day\n-------------------------------------------------\n14 Sep 2017 / 28 / 5\n30 Sep 2017 / 73 / 17 / 3\n3 Oct 2017 / 194 / 30 / 40\n5 Oct 2017 / 258 / 36 / 32\n7 Oct 2017 / 343 / 42 / 43\n8 Oct 2017 / 387 / 45 / 44\n9 Oct 2017 / 449 / 48 / 62\n10 Oct 2017 / 500 / 54 / 51\n11 Oct 2017 / 561 / 57 / 61\n13 Oct 2017 / 684 / 57 / 61\n16 Oct 2017 / 805 / 74 / 40\n17 Oct 2017 / 878 / 80 / 44\n18 Oct 2017 / 1032 / 89 / 164\n19 Oct 2017 / 1153 / 94 / 121\n20 Oct 2017 / 1297 / 102 / --\n23 Oct 2017 / 1192 / 124 / 10\n25 Oct 2017 / 1309 / 93 / 58\n27 Oct 2017 / 1554 / 113 / 122\n30 Oct 2017 / 1801 / 127 / 82\n1 Nov 2017 / 1836 / 133 / 17\n3 Nov 2017 / 1947 / 143 / 55\n10 Nov 2017 / 2119 / 171 / 25\n13 Nov 2017 / 2158 / 174 / 13\n17 Nov 2017 / 2267 / 195 / 27\n- Mod.LL]\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat 18 Nov 2017\nSource: L'Express Madagascar [in French, machine trans., edited]\nhttp://www.lexpressmada.com/blog/actualites/andranomena-un%E2%80%88eleve%E2%80%88contracte%E2%80%88-la%E2%80%88peste%E2%80%88bubonique/\n\n\nA student from public elementary primary school (EPP) in Andranomena Antananarivo-city reportedly has bubonic plague. The Ministry of National Education published the information on its Facebook page yesterday, [Fri 17 Nov 2017], around 22 hours (10 pm). 'The health staff confirmed the disease. He is already under treatment in a hospital,' said the ministry. A disinfection and disinfestation operation was to be organized at this facility today [Sat 18 Nov 2017]. People who have been in contact with the patient will also have to undertake contact prophylaxis, to prevent the spread of the disease. If all these procedures are followed, the plague should not affect other students or school staff. Moreover, every school, private and public, has a device, like an isolation room, and can monitor the health of each pupil, under the control of the state, making it possible to detect a probable case of plague at school level.\n\nThis is the latest new case notified to Antananarivo-city, after a few days of silence about the plague epidemic. A total of 12 patients are being treated in hospitals of the Big Island; 6 of them are in Antananarivo, 3 in the Upper Matsiatra region, 1 in the Bongolava region and 1 in Itasy. A notable fact of this latest plague situation is, also, the existence of a patient in the region of Atsimo-Andrefana.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Atsimo-Andrefana region is in south eastern Madagascar, not in the endemic areas for plague. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/181.]", "summary": "Sep 2017 / 73 / 17 / 3\n3 Oct 2017 / 194 / 30 / 40\n5 Oct 2017 / 258 / 36 / 32\n7 Oct 2017 / 343 / 42 / 43\n8 Oct 2017 / 387 / 45 / 44\n9 Oct 2017 / 449 / 48 / 62\n10 Oct 2017 / 500 / 54 / 51\n11 Oct 2017 / 561 / 57 / 61\n13 Oct 2017 / 684 / 57 / 61\n16 Oct 2017 / 805 / 74 / 40\n17 Oct 2017 / 878 / 80 / 44\n18 Oct 2017 / 1032 / 89 / 164\n19 Oct 2017 / 1153 / 94 / 121\n20 Oct 2017 / 1297 / 102 / --\n 23 Oct 2017 / 1192 / 124 / 10\n25 Oct 2017 / 1309 / 93 / 58\n27 Oct 2017 / 1554 / 113 / 122\n30 Oct 2017 / 1801 / 127 / 82\n1 Nov 2017 / 1836 / 133 / 17\n3 Nov 2017 / 1947 / 143 / 55\n10 Nov 2017 / 2119 / 171 / 25\n13 Nov 2017 / 2158 / 174 / 13\n17 Nov 2017 / 2267 / 195 / 27\n- Mod. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< From [1 Aug to 17 Nov 2017], a cumulative total of 2267 confirmed, probable and suspected cases of plague, including 195 deaths (case fatality rate 9 per cent), have been reported from 55 of 114 (48 per cent) districts in Madagascar. The date of onset of the last case of bubonic plague was [7 Nov 2017] and the last confirmed case of pneumonic plague was reported on [14 Nov 2017]. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n Most of the reported cases (1732, 76 per cent) have been clinically classified as pneumonic plague, 327 have been classified as bubonic plague (14 per cent); 1 was septicemic; and 207 have not yet been classified (further classification of cases is in process). \n\n\nMadagascar plague outbreak: external situation report no.12 - [20 Nov 2017]\n PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (34): FATAL, DECREASING CASELOAD\n****************************************************\n From [6 to 17 Nov 2017], 216 cases of plague (1 confirmed, 20 probable and 195 suspected) were reported to WHO. \n\nOf the 7270 contacts identified during this outbreak, about 99 per cent (7166) have completed their 7-day follow up and a course of prophylactic antimicrobials, and 11 contacts have developed symptoms compatible with plague and became suspected cases. 14 Sep 2017 / 28 / 5\n30 \n\nOf the 1732 clinical pneumonic cases, 389 (22 per cent) have been confirmed, 612 (35 per cent) are probable and 731 (42 per cent) remain suspected (additional laboratory results are in process). Date: Fri 20 Nov 2017\n Date: Sat 18 Nov 2017\n Date / Cases / Deaths / Average new cases per day\n LL]\n\n******\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-09-25 00:00:00", "2021-04-25 00:00:00", "1732-03-25 00:00:00", "2034-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Analamanga Region", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Reliefweb", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ankazobe District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5450599", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Madagascar (33): fatal, WHO", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5450599", "date": "2017-11-17 17:32:40", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (33): FATAL, WHO\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 16 Nov 2017\nSource: WHO, UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs, Government of Madagascar [edited]\nhttps://reliefweb.int/report/madagascar/madagascar-plague-epidemic-joint-situation-report-no-5-16-november-2017\n\n\nMadagascar: Plague Epidemic - Joint Situation Report No. 5 as of 16 Nov 2017\n----------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\nHighlights\n----------\n- The epidemic remains active in 09 health districts.\n- A total of 2158 cases have been recorded from 1 August to 13 November 2017, of which 76 percent of were pneumonic.\n- About 60 percent of the 174 total deaths occurred at community level.\n- 1180 patients have been cured since the beginning of this epidemic, 28 others are receiving treatment in hospitals.\n- There has been a marked decrease in new cases, from 502 cases the week of 2 to 8 October 2017 to 70 cases the week of 6 to 12 November 2017.\n- Up to 7166 people who had contact with patients with pneumonic plague completed their prophylactic treatment, out of 7270 identified people.\n- Up to 8 international airports and one port have established sanitary control posts.\n\nSituation Overview\n------------------\nAlthough plague is endemic in Madagascar, this season has been uncharacteristic: it started a month early, has been predominately of the pneumonic form, and has most affected the largest urban centers of Madagascar (Antananarivo, Toamasina, Fianarantsoa and Antsirabe). Many of the district's current affected have no experience of the disease, which represents another challenge in addition to the difficulties in controlling the epidemic in urban areas.\n\nThe total number of cases (2158) is already 5 times higher than the average annual total of 400 (September to April). However, there is a clear decrease in plague cases, from 502 cases during epidemiological week 40 (2-8 Oct 2017) to 70 cases during week 45 (6-12 Nov 2017).\n\nThe spread of pneumonic plague in high-density urban areas is faster, with a risk of large-scale epidemics, while the implementation of health and non-health responses is confronted with access problems (difficulty in tracing contacts, especially in slums) and the frequent moving of people. The capital city of Antananarivo, the country's trade and transport hub, is most affected by this epidemic.\n\nPneumonic plague due to person-to-person transmission by air poses a high health risk for all actors involved in the response, including health service providers in hospitals and health centers, social workers, health workers security and defense forces, journalists, hygienists, communicators, volunteers, etc. Since the beginning of the epidemic, 82 health personnel have been infected (with no deaths).\n\nThe epidemic has had consequences for tourism with the cancellation of cruises, but the situation is being addressed with the direct involvement of the World Tourism Organization. School has been suspended for one month.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[There is a continued downward trend in cases. With so many cases of pneumonic plague, the case fatality rate seems low.\n\nDate / Cases / Deaths / Average new cases per day\n-------------------------------------------------\n14 Sep 2017 / 28 / 5\n30 Sep 2017 / 73 / 17 / 3\n3 Oct 2017 / 194 / 30 / 40\n5 Oct 2017 / 258 / 36 / 32\n7 Oct 2017 / 343 / 42 / 43\n8 Oct 2017 / 387 / 45 / 44\n9 Oct 2017 / 449 / 48 / 62\n10 Oct 2017 / 500 / 54 / 51\n11 Oct 2017 / 561 / 57 / 61\n13 Oct 2017 / 684 / 57 / 61\n16 Oct 2017 / 805 / 74 / 40\n17 Oct 2017 / 878 / 80 / 44\n18 Oct 2017 / 1032 / 89 / 164\n19 Oct 2017 / 1153 / 94 / 121\n20 Oct 2017 / 1297 / 102 / --\n23 Oct 2017 / 1192 / 124 / 10\n25 Oct 2017 / 1309 / 93 / 58\n27 Oct 2017 / 1554 / 113 / 122\n30 Oct 2017 / 1801 / 127 / 82\n1 Nov 2017 / 1836 / 133 / 17\n3 Nov 2017 / 1947 / 143 / 55.\n10 Nov 2017 / 2119 / 171 / 25.\n13 Nov 2017 / 2158 / 174 / 13. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/181.]", "summary": "Sep 2017 / 73 / 17 / 3\n3 Oct 2017 / 194 / 30 / 40\n5 Oct 2017 / 258 / 36 / 32\n7 Oct 2017 / 343 / 42 / 43\n8 Oct 2017 / 387 / 45 / 44\n9 Oct 2017 / 449 / 48 / 62\n10 Oct 2017 / 500 / 54 / 51\n11 Oct 2017 / 561 / 57 / 61\n13 Oct 2017 / 684 / 57 / 61\n16 Oct 2017 / 805 / 74 / 40\n17 Oct 2017 / 878 / 80 / 44\n18 Oct 2017 / 1032 / 89 / 164\n19 Oct 2017 / 1153 / 94 / 121\n20 Oct 2017 / 1297 / 102 / --\n 23 Oct 2017 / 1192 / 124 / 10\n25 Oct 2017 / 1309 / 93 / 58\n27 Oct 2017 / 1554 / 113 / 122\n30 Oct 2017 / 1801 / 127 / 82\n1 Nov 2017 / 1836 / 133 / 17\n3 Nov 2017 / 1947 / 143 / 55. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n However, there is a clear decrease in plague cases, from 502 cases during epidemiological week 40 (2-8 Oct 2017) to 70 cases during week 45 (6-12 Nov 2017). - There has been a marked decrease in new cases, from 502 cases the week of 2 to 8 October 2017 to 70 cases the week of 6 to 12 November 2017. Plague Epidemic - Joint Situation Report No. 5 as of 16 Nov 2017\n---------------------------------------------------------------------------- WHO\n************************************\n \n13 Nov 2017 / 2158 / 174 / 13. - Mod. 14 Sep 2017 / 28 / 5\n30 \n10 Nov 2017 / 2119 / 171 / 25. Date: Thu 16 Nov 2017\n Pneumonic plague due to person-to-person transmission by air poses a high health risk for all actors involved in the response, including health service providers in hospitals and health centers, social workers, health workers security and defense forces, journalists, hygienists, communicators, volunteers, etc. Date / Cases / Deaths / Average new cases per day\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2017-11-13 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00", "2158-03-25 00:00:00", "2033-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-08-01 00:00:00", "1180-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5467648", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Madagascar (35): fatal, WHO", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5467648", "date": "2017-11-27 13:56:49", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (35): FATAL, WHO\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 27 Nov 2017\nSource: WHO Emergencies preparedness, response, Disease Outbreak News (DONs) [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/csr/don/27-november-2017-plague-madagascar/en/\n\n\nPlague - Madagascar\n-------------------\nFrom 1 Aug 2017 through 22 Nov 2017, a total of 2348 confirmed, probable and suspected cases of plague, including 202 deaths (case fatality rate 8.6 percent), were reported by the Ministry of Health of Madagascar to WHO. There were 1791 cases of pneumonic plague, of which 22 percent were confirmed, 34 percent were probable, and 44 percent were suspected. In addition to pneumonic cases, there were reports of 341 cases of bubonic plague, one case of septicemic plague and 215 cases with type unspecified. In total, 81 healthcare workers have had illness compatible with plague, none of whom have died.\n\nSince the beginning of the outbreak, cases of pneumonic and bubonic plague have been detected in 55 out of 114 districts (48 percent), including non-endemic areas and major cities. Analamanga region has been the most affected, with 68 percent of the cumulative reported cases. All contacts identified (7289) during this outbreak have completed their course of prophylactic antis. 11 contacts developed symptoms compatible with plague and were classified as suspect cases. All contacts had completed their follow up.\n\nThe Institut Pasteur Madagascar has cultured 33 isolates of _Yersinia pestis_, which were all sensitive to the antimicrobials recommended by the National Program for the Control of Plague.\n\nPlague is endemic in some areas of Madagascar and additional cases of plague may occur, at least until the end of the plague season in April 2018. It is therefore important that control measures continue through the end of the plague season.\n\nPublic health response\n----------------------\nThe Ministry of Public Health of Madagascar is coordinating the response, with the support of WHO, the Institute Pasteur Madagascar, and other agencies, stakeholders, and partners. The Ministry of Public Health of Madagascar activated crisis units in Antananarivo and Toamasina to coordinate the outbreak response efforts. All cases and contacts have been provided treatment or prophylactic antimicrobials at no cost to themselves.\n\nThe public health response measures have included:\n- strengthened epidemiological surveillance in the all affected districts, and enhanced case finding;\n- rapid investigation of new cases;\n- sample collection, referral, and testing;\n- isolation and treatment of all pneumonic cases, as well as treatment of bubonic cases;\n- active finding, tracing, and monitoring of contacts and provision of free prophylactic antibiotics;\n- disinsection, including rodent and vector control\n- raising public awareness on prevention for bubonic and pneumonic plague;\n- raising awareness among health care workers and providing information to improve case detection, infection control measures, and protection from infection;\n- providing information about infection control measures during burial practices.\n\nWHO has coordinated and mobilised regional and global partners in the Global Outbreak Alert and Response Network (GOARN) to support the outbreak response and will continue work with partners to ensure further rapid response support as needed. Working together, the Ministry of Health, WHO, GOARN, and other partners have trained more than 1800 community health workers for contact tracing, about 300 doctors as contact tracing supervisors and has established rapid response teams for case investigation. The IFRC, UNICEF, and USAID have supported case management, including establishment of plague treatment centres. Laboratory confirmation of plague cases is conducted by the Institute Pasteur of Madagascar (IPM). WHO and IPM established a system for specimen collection and referral from peripheral areas to the IPM laboratory to strengthen laboratory capacity for testing and confirmation.\n\nEnhanced measures for exit screening have been implemented at the International Airports in Antananarivo and Nocib\u00e9, to avoid the international spread of pneumonic plague cases. These measures included: filling a special departure form at the airport (to identify passengers at risk); temperature screening of departing passengers, and referring passengers with fever to airport physicians for further consultation; passengers with symptoms compatible with pneumonic plague are immediately isolated at the airport and investigated using a rapid diagnostic test and notified according to the response alert protocol. Symptomatic passengers are not allowed to travel. A WHO GOARN team, consisting of US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and L'Institut de veille sanitaire/Sant\u00e9 publique France (InVS/SPF), provided technical support at the airport to establish exit screening. WHO and partners will support the MOH to re-evaluate the need for continuity of the exit screening and will implement appropriate recommendations.\n\n9 countries and overseas territories in the African region (Comoros, Ethiopia, Kenya, Mauritius, Mozambique, La R\u00e9union (France), Seychelles, South Africa, and Tanzania) had been identified as priority countries for plague preparedness and readiness by virtue of their trade and travel links to Madagascar. These countries have been implementing readiness activities, including increased public awareness of plague, enhancing surveillance for the disease (particularly at points of entry), and prepositioning of equipment and supplies. WHO will support these countries to integrate the plague preparedness and operational readiness activities into their overall multi-hazard preparedness and readiness functions.\n\nWHO risk assessment\n-------------------\nNo new cases of confirmed bubonic plague have been notified after 8 Nov 2017 and no new cases of confirmed pneumonic have been notified since 14 Nov 2017. All contacts finished follow up on 19 Nov 2017. However, plague in Madagascar is seasonal and WHO expects additional reports of cases. It is therefore important for the Ministry of Health, WHO, and partners to sustain prevention and response activities until April 2018. A longer term strategy will be needed for plague prevention, preparedness, and response.\n\nBased on the current epidemiology and response capacity, WHO estimates the risk of plague at the national level is moderate. The risk at the regional and global levels is low.\n\nWHO travel advice\n-----------------\nTo date, there are no reported cases related to international travel. WHO advises against any restriction on travel or trade on Madagascar. WHO recommends that travel measures put in place by neighboring countries in relation to this outbreak be discontinued, given the containment of the pneumonic plague outbreak.\n\nInternational travelers arriving in Madagascar should be informed that plague is endemic in Madagascar, and about the recent plague outbreak. Travelers should protect themselves against flea bites, avoid contact with dead animals, infected tissues or materials, and avoid close contact with patients with pneumonic plague. In case of sudden symptoms of fever, chills, painful and inflamed lymph nodes, or shortness of breath with coughing and/or blood-tainted sputum, travelers should immediately contact a medical service. Travelers should avoid self-medication, even if for prophylaxis. Prophylactic treatment is only recommended for persons who have been in close contact with cases, or with other high risk exposures (such as bites from fleas or direct contact with body fluids or tissues of infected animals). Upon return from travel to Madagascar, travelers should be on alert for the above symptoms. If symptoms appear, travellers should seek medical care and inform their physician about their travel history to Madagascar.\n\nFollowing the visit of the Secretary General of the World Tourism Organization (UNWTO) on 3 Nov 2017, the UN body expressed confidence on tourism in Madagascar and echoed the WHO advice against any travel or trade restrictions against Madagascar.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There is a continued downward trend in cases as can be seen in Figure 1 in the source URL above. With so many cases of pneumonic plague, the case fatality rate seems low.\n\nDate / Cases / Deaths / Average new cases per day\n-------------------------------------------------\n14 Sep 2017 / 28 / In addition to pneumonic cases, there were reports of 341 cases of bubonic plague, one case of septicemic plague and 215 cases with type unspecified. These measures included: filling a special departure form at the airport (to identify passengers at risk); temperature screening of departing passengers, and referring passengers with fever to airport physicians for further consultation; passengers with symptoms compatible with pneumonic plague are immediately isolated at the airport and investigated using a rapid diagnostic test and notified according to the response alert protocol. Plague is endemic in some areas of Madagascar and additional cases of plague may occur, at least until the end of the plague season in April 2018. Date / Cases / Deaths / Average new cases per day\n \n\nEnhanced measures for exit screening have been implemented at the International Airports in Antananarivo and Nocib\u00e9, to avoid the international spread of pneumonic plague cases.
