Madagascar (31): fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5438233", "date": "2017-11-11 16:47:05", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (31): FATAL\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 9 Nov 2017 8:33\nSource: L'Express Madagascar [machine transl, edited]\nhttp://www.lexpressmada.com/blog/actualites/antananarivo-ville-un-malade-dans-la-rue-succombe-a-la-peste/\n\n\nThe epidemic of plague is still being talked about in the city of Antananarivo. A man reportedly entered a large hospital in Antananarivo with pulmonary plague, according to the result of a rapid diagnostic test (RDT). It was the Municipal Health Bureau (BMH) of Antananarivo City Council that reported 'Some people brought this man to our service this morning [Wed 8 Nov 2017]. They found him in the street, sick. We did first aid; he was then taken to a big hospital for further treatment. He succumbed sometime after,' says our source.\n\nBefore this last case, the Minister of Public Health, Professor Mamy Lalatiana Andriamanarivo, welcomed the 'Zero deaths for 10 days in Toamasina and for 5 days in Antananarivo'. In the last report of the general plague situation, sent by the National Office of Risk and Disaster Management (BNGRC), yesterday [Wed 8 Nov 2017], there were no deaths reported, despite the rise in deaths from 131 to 132 between 8 and 9 November [2017]. The 132nd case on the balance sheet was not recent, according to a source at the ministry. Counting this man who died the number of plague deaths increased to 133. This man was buried by BMH agents in the Anjanahary mass grave.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[A previous death count had been reported to be 143. I have not found any new updates regarding case numbers of this outbreak since the last report. Additionally, it is still difficult to see how the case fatality rate could be as low as it is with over 60 percent of the cases said to be pneumonic plague.\n\nDate / Cases / Deaths / Average new cases per day\n-------------------------------------------------\n14 Sep 2017 / 28 / 5\n30 Sep 2017 / 73 / 17 / 3\n3 Oct 2017 / 194 / 30 / 40\n5 Oct 2017 / 258 / 36 / 32\n7 Oct 2017 / 343 / 42 / 43\n8 Oct 2017 / 387 / 45 / 44\n9 Oct 2017 / 449 / 48 / 62\n10 Oct 2017 / 500 / 54 / 51\n11 Oct 2017 / 561 / 57 / 61\n13 Oct 2017 / 684 / 57 / 61\n16 Oct 2017 / 805 / 74 / 40\n17 Oct 2017 / 878 / 80 / 44\n18 Oct 2017 / 1032 / 89 / 164\n19 Oct 2017 / 1153 / 94 / 121\n20 Oct 2017 / 1297 / 102 / --\n23 Oct 2017 / 1192 / 124 / 10\n25 Oct 2017 / 1309 / 93 / 58\n27 Oct 2017 / 1554 / 113 / 122\n30 Oct 2017 / 1801 / 127 / 82\n1 Nov 2017 / 1836 / 133 / 17\n3 Nov 2017 / 1947 / 143 / 55. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/181.]", "summary": "Sep 2017 / 73 / 17 / 3\n3 Oct 2017 / 194 / 30 / 40\n5 Oct 2017 / 258 / 36 / 32\n7 Oct 2017 / 343 / 42 / 43\n8 Oct 2017 / 387 / 45 / 44\n9 Oct 2017 / 449 / 48 / 62\n10 Oct 2017 / 500 / 54 / 51\n11 Oct 2017 / 561 / 57 / 61\n13 Oct 2017 / 684 / 57 / 61\n16 Oct 2017 / 805 / 74 / 40\n17 Oct 2017 / 878 / 80 / 44\n18 Oct 2017 / 1032 / 89 / 164\n19 Oct 2017 / 1153 / 94 / 121\n20 Oct 2017 / 1297 / 102 / --\n 23 Oct 2017 / 1192 / 124 / 10\n25 Oct 2017 / 1309 / 93 / 58\n27 Oct 2017 / 1554 / 113 / 122\n30 Oct 2017 / 1801 / 127 / 82\n1 Nov 2017 / 1836 / 133 / 17\n3 Nov 2017 / 1947 / 143 / 55. - Mod. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n [Wed 8 Nov 2017], there were no deaths reported, despite the rise in deaths from 131 to 132 between 8 and 9 November [2017]. PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (31): FATAL\n*******************************\n 14 Sep 2017 / 28 / 5\n30 Date: Thu 9 Nov 2017 8:33\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[A previous death count had been reported to be 143.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Toamasina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5427532", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Madagascar (30): fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5427532", "date": "2017-11-06 17:59:10", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (30): FATAL\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 6 Nov 2017\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/plague-outbreak-update-1947-cases-143-deaths-madagascar-69245/\n\n\nPlague outbreak update: 1947 cases, 143 deaths in Madagascar\n------------------------------------------------------------\nIn an update on the plague outbreak in Madagascar, UN officials now put the ever changing case tally in the epidemic that began on [1 Aug 2017] at 1947 confirmed, probable and suspected cases of plague through [3 Nov 2017]. Of these, 1437 (74 percent) were clinically classified as pulmonary plague, 295 (15 percent) were bubonic plague, one was septicemic, and 211 were not yet classified (further classification of cases is in process). The death count has risen to 143.\n\nOfficials have been saying recently that the number of new cases of pulmonary plague is declining across the country. However, while the decline in the incidence is encouraging, more cases of plague are expected to be reported in Madagascar until the typical plague season ends in April 2018.\n\nTo that effect, sustaining ongoing operations during the outbreak and through the plague season is crucial to minimize the current human-to-human transmission of pneumonic plague and the bubonic plague infections. The key control measures that need to continue to the end of April 2018 include active case finding and treatment, comprehensive contact identification, follow-up and antibiotic treatment, rodent and flea control, and safe and dignified burials.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There continues to be substantial variation in the numbers reported in this significant outbreak of plague, making interpretations of control difficult to make. Additionally, it is still difficult to see how the case fatality rate could be as low as it is with over 60 percent of the cases said to be pneumonic plague.\n\nDate / Cases / Deaths / Average new cases per day\n-------------------------------------------------\n14 Sep 2017 / 28 / 5\n30 Sep 2017 / 73 / 17 / 3\n3 Oct 2017 / 194 / 30 / 40\n5 Oct 2017 / 258 / 36 / 32\n7 Oct 2017 / 343 / 42 / 43\n8 Oct 2017 / 387 / 45 / 44\n9 Oct 2017 / 449 / 48 / 62\n10 Oct 2017 / 500 / 54 / 51\n11 Oct 2017 / 561 / 57 / 61\n13 Oct 2017 / 684 / 57 / 61\n16 Oct 2017 / 805 / 74 / 40\n17 Oct 2017 / 878 / 80 / 44\n18 Oct 2017 / 1032 / 89 / 164\n19 Oct 2017 / 1153 / 94 / 121\n20 Oct 2017 / 1297 / 102 / --\n23 Oct 2017 / 1192 / 124 / 10\n25 Oct 2017 / 1309 / 93 / 58\n27 Oct 2017 / 1554 / 113 / 122\n30 Oct 2017 / 1801 / 127 / 82\n1 Nov 2017 / 1836 / 133 / 17\n3 Nov 2017 / 1947 / 143 / 55\n\nFor any budding pathophysiologists interesting in plague virulence, the following is reproduced here:\nFitts EC, Andersson JA, Kirtley ML, et al: New Insights into Autoinducer-2 signaling as a virulence regulator in a mouse model of pneumonic plague. mSphere. 2016;1(6). pii: e00342-16. eCollection 2016 Nov-Dec, available at:\nhttps://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5156673/\n\nAbstract:\n'The Enterobacteriaceae family members, including the infamous _Yersinia pestis_, the causative agent of plague, have a highly conserved interbacterial signaling system that is mediated by the autoinducer-2 (AI-2) quorum-sensing molecule. The AI-2 system is implicated in regulating various bacterial virulence genes in diverse environmental niches. Deletion of the gene encoding the synthetic enzyme for the AI-2 substrate, luxS, leads to either no significant change or, paradoxically, an increase in in-vivo bacterial virulence. We showed that deletion of the rbsA and lsrA genes, components of ABC transport systems that interact with AI-2, synergistically disrupted AI-2 signaling patterns and resulted in a more-than-50-fold decrease in _Y. pestis_ strain CO92 virulence in a stringent pneumonic plague mouse model. Deletion of luxS or lsrK (encoding AI-2 kinase) from the ArbsA AlsrA background strain or complementation of the ArbsA AlsrA mutant with the corresponding gene(s) reverted the virulence phenotype to that of the wild-type _Y. pestis_ CO92. Furthermore, the administration of synthetic AI-2 in mice infected with the ArbsA AlsrA AluxS mutant strain attenuated this triple mutant to a virulence phenotype similar to that of the ArbsA AlsrA strain in a pneumonic plague model. Conversely, the administration of AI-2 to mice infected with the ArbsA AlsrA AluxS AlsrK mutant did not rescue animals from lethality, indicating the importance of the AI-2-LsrK axis in regulating bacterial virulence. By performing high-throughput RNA sequencing, the potential role of some AI-2-signaling-regulated genes that modulated bacterial virulence was determined. We anticipate that the characterization of AI-2 signaling in _Y. pestis_ will lead to reexamination of AI-2 systems in other pathogens and that AI-2 signaling may represent a broad-spectrum therapeutic target to combat antibiotic-resistant bacteria, which represent a global crisis of the 21st century.\n\n'_Yersinia pestis_ is the bacterial agent that causes the highly fatal disease plague. The organism represents a significant concern because of its potential use as a bioterrorism agent, beyond the several thousand naturally occurring human infection cases occurring globally each year. While there has been development of effective antibiotics, the narrow therapeutic window and challenges posed by the existence of antibiotic-resistant strains represent serious concerns. We sought to identify novel virulence factors that could potentially be incorporated into an attenuated vaccine platform or be targeted by novel therapeutics. We show here that a highly conserved quorum-sensing system, autoinducer-2, significantly affected the virulence of _Y. pestis_ in a mouse model of pneumonic plague. We also identified steps in autoinducer-2 signaling which had confounded previous studies and demonstrated the potential for intervention in the virulence mechanism(s) of autoinducer-2. Our findings may have an impact on bacterial pathogenesis research in many other organisms and could result in identifying potential broad-spectrum therapeutic targets to combat antibiotic-resistant bacteria, which represent a global crisis of the 21st century.' - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/181.]", "summary": "Sep 2017 / 73 / 17 / 3\n3 Oct 2017 / 194 / 30 / 40\n5 Oct 2017 / 258 / 36 / 32\n7 Oct 2017 / 343 / 42 / 43\n8 Oct 2017 / 387 / 45 / 44\n9 Oct 2017 / 449 / 48 / 62\n10 Oct 2017 / 500 / 54 / 51\n11 Oct 2017 / 561 / 57 / 61\n13 Oct 2017 / 684 / 57 / 61\n16 Oct 2017 / 805 / 74 / 40\n17 Oct 2017 / 878 / 80 / 44\n18 Oct 2017 / 1032 / 89 / 164\n19 Oct 2017 / 1153 / 94 / 121\n20 Oct 2017 / 1297 / 102 / --\n 23 Oct 2017 / 1192 / 124 / 10\n25 Oct 2017 / 1309 / 93 / 58\n27 Oct 2017 / 1554 / 113 / 122\n30 Oct 2017 / 1801 / 127 / 82\n1 Nov 2017 / 1836 / 133 / 17\n3 Nov 2017 / 1947 / 143 / 55\n\nFor any budding pathophysiologists interesting in plague virulence, the following is reproduced here:\nFitts EC, Andersson JA, Kirtley ML, et al: New Insights into Autoinducer-2 signaling as a virulence regulator in a mouse model of pneumonic plague. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n In an update on the plague outbreak in Madagascar, UN officials now put the ever changing case tally in the epidemic that began on [1 Aug 2017] at 1947 confirmed, probable and suspected cases of plague through [3 Nov 2017]. PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (30): FATAL\n*******************************\n To that effect, sustaining ongoing operations during the outbreak and through the plague season is crucial to minimize the current human-to-human transmission of pneumonic plague and the bubonic plague infections. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\n\nPlague outbreak update: 1947 cases, 143 deaths in Madagascar\n We showed that deletion of the rbsA and lsrA genes, components of ABC transport systems that interact with AI-2, synergistically disrupted AI-2 signaling patterns and resulted in a more-than-50-fold decrease in _Y. pestis_ strain CO92 virulence in a stringent pneumonic plague mouse model. Furthermore, the administration of synthetic AI-2 in mice infected with the ArbsA AlsrA AluxS mutant strain attenuated this triple mutant to a virulence phenotype similar to that of the ArbsA AlsrA strain in a pneumonic plague model. Of these, 1437 (74 percent) were clinically classified as pulmonary plague, 295 (15 percent) were bubonic plague, one was septicemic, and 211 were not yet classified (further classification of cases is in process). 14 Sep 2017 / 28 / 5\n30 We show here that a highly conserved quorum-sensing system, autoinducer-2, significantly affected the virulence of _Y. pestis_ in a mouse model of pneumonic plague. Date: Mon 6 Nov 2017\n We anticipate that the characterization of AI-2 signaling in _Y. pestis_ will lead to reexamination of AI-2 systems in other pathogens and that AI-2 signaling may represent a broad-spectrum therapeutic target to combat antibiotic-resistant bacteria, which represent a global crisis of the 21st century.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2018-04-25 00:00:00", "1947-03-25 00:00:00", "1437-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5422504", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Madagascar (29): fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5422504", "date": "2017-11-04 11:29:29", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (29): FATAL\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Fri 3 Nov 2017\nSource: CNN [edited]\nhttp://www.cnn.com/2017/11/03/health/madagascar-plague-outbreak-bn/index.html\n\n\nThe spread of a plague outbreak in Madagascar may finally be slowing down.\nThe epidemic, which began in August 2017, has taken the lives of 133 people and resulted in 1836 suspected or confirmed cases. However, the occurrence of new cases is finally decreasing, according to a report released [Wed 1 Nov 2017] by the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs.\n\nThe week of 9 Oct 2017, there were 477 new cases, compared with 161 during the week of 23 Oct 2017. The report says 1044 patients have been cured, and 83 others are receiving treatment. The number of hospitalizations because of the plague has also decreased, according to the WHO. Although the number of total cases has continued to increase, this is because of 'enhanced surveillance and ongoing investigations,' the WHO said; some of the cases were not actually infected, upon inspection.\n\nThe epidemic remains active in 12 districts, and among the total cases reported, 61 percent are said to be the pneumonic plague, according to the UN office. This is faster-spreading and more transmittable than bubonic plague, noted Tarik Jasarevic, a spokesman for the WHO; 'compared with past outbreaks, this year [2017] there is a higher portion of pneumonic plague cases.'\n\nSince plague is endemic (or regularly found) in Madagascar, its 'spread to non-endemic areas which were not used to handling plague cases, including densely populated cities,' may have caused a more severe outbreak, according to Jasarevic. The unusual spread of pneumonic plague in this outbreak was due to one infected person who traveled to find care early in the outbreak, infecting people along the way. These individuals infected others, leading to several chains of transmission, added Nyka Alexander, a representative of the WHO Health Emergencies Programme.\n\nOngoing efforts to control the spread of bubonic and pneumonic plague include seeking out and treating new cases, identifying the method of disease contact, disease follow-up and antibiotic treatment, rodent and flea control, and 'safe and dignified burials,' the WHO said in a statement.\n\n[Byline: Victoria Larned]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Thu 2 Nov 2017 8:34\nSource: L'Express Madagascar [machine transl, edited]\nhttp://www.lexpressmada.com/blog/actualites/antananarivo-trois-morts-suspects-de-peste-dans-la-communaute/\n\n\nThe calm of the plague has been broken by the suspicious death of 3 people in Antananarivo, [Tue 31 Oct and Wed 1 Nov 2017]. Unlike the cases reported recently, they all died at the community level with a rapid diagnostic test (RDT) positive for plague, as reported by the Municipal Bureau of Health (BMH) of the Urban Commune of Antananarivo (AUC), which supports the deceased outside health facilities and burial of plague victims in the city of Antananarivo. These deaths were recorded in Andohamandry Manjakamiadana at Andrainarivo and Ampahibe. The first 2 were on [Tue 31 Oct 2017], and the last [Wed 1 Nov 2017]. The Ministry of Health has not yet confirmed cases in Andrainarivo and Amparibe.\n\nOne of Andrainarivo victims was homeless. 'He bowed out on the street,' reports a source at the BMH. It would, thus, the 1st homeless victim of the plague in the capital. 'If the response is not reinforced, the disease will spread quickly to his family and all those who came into contact with him,' says a doctor. The BMH took his body for burial in the grave of Anjanahary last night [Wed 1 Nov 2017].\n\nThe deaths at community level should be alarming indicators for the Department of Public Health. People probably think that the danger is past, with the decline of the victims. So, they will not join the health facilities, despite the presence of symptoms, namely high fever, chills, fatigue, chest pain, cough with sputum streaked with blood. The active case, awareness and all response activities should be strengthened.\n\nYesterday, [Wed 1 Nov 2017], the Secretary General of Public Health, Dr. Jos\u00e9a Ratsirarson emphasized that the plague patient who escaped the anti-plague hospital in Ambohimiandra (CHAPA), last [Thu 26 Oct 2017], has not been found. 'We do not know what has become of him. The last time we joined him on the phone, he agreed to come back to the hospital for treatment, so far he has not showed up, 'he says. We do not know until yesterday [Wed 1 Nov 2017], if it is one of those who died in Antananarivo.\n\nOn [Tue 31 Oct 2017], 83 people were under treatment at the facility level, a thousand people have been cured since the beginning of the epidemic and 7 new cases were recorded throughout Madagascar. With these 3 cases, the number of deaths would amount to 129 (now 133).\n\n[Byline: Miangaly\u2008Ralitera]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[There continues to be substantial variation in the numbers reported in this significant outbreak of plague, making interpretations of control difficult to make. This posting reports 'more than 1800 suspected, probable and confirmed' cases, yet the post from 3 days earlier reported 1554 cases. These up and down numbers make it quite difficult to assess the state of this unique outbreak. Additionally, it is still difficult to see how the case fatality rate could be as low as it is with over 60 percent of the cases said to be pneumonic plague.\n\nDate / Cases / Deaths / Average new cases per day\n-------------------------------------------------\n14 Sep 2017 / 28 / 5\n30 Sep 2017 / 73 / 17 / 3\n3 Oct 2017 / 194 / 30 / 40\n5 Oct 2017 / 258 / 36 / 32\n7 Oct 2017 / 343 / 42 / 43\n8 Oct 2017 / 387 / 45 / 44\n9 Oct 2017 / 449 / 48 / 62\n10 Oct 2017 / 500 / 54 / 51\n11 Oct 2017 / 561 / 57 / 61\n13 Oct 2017 / 684 / 57 / 61\n16 Oct 2017 / 805 / 74 / 40\n17 Oct 2017 / 878 / 80 / 44\n18 Oct 2017 / 1032 / 89 / 164\n19 Oct 2017 / 1153 / 94 / 121\n20 Oct 2017 / 1297 / 102 / --\n23 Oct 2017 / 1192 / 124 / 10\n25 Oct 2017 / 1309 / 93 / 58\n27 Oct 2017 / 1554 / 113 / 122\n30 Oct 2017 / 1801 / 127 / 82\n1 Nov 2017 / 1836 / 133 / 17. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/181.]", "summary": "Sep 2017 / 73 / 17 / 3\n3 Oct 2017 / 194 / 30 / 40\n5 Oct 2017 / 258 / 36 / 32\n7 Oct 2017 / 343 / 42 / 43\n8 Oct 2017 / 387 / 45 / 44\n9 Oct 2017 / 449 / 48 / 62\n10 Oct 2017 / 500 / 54 / 51\n11 Oct 2017 / 561 / 57 / 61\n13 Oct 2017 / 684 / 57 / 61\n16 Oct 2017 / 805 / 74 / 40\n17 Oct 2017 / 878 / 80 / 44\n18 Oct 2017 / 1032 / 89 / 164\n19 Oct 2017 / 1153 / 94 / 121\n20 Oct 2017 / 1297 / 102 / --\n 23 Oct 2017 / 1192 / 124 / 10\n25 Oct 2017 / 1309 / 93 / 58\n27 Oct 2017 / 1554 / 113 / 122\n30 Oct 2017 / 1801 / 127 / 82\n1 Nov 2017 / 1836 / 133 / 17. - Mod. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n [Byline: Victoria Larned]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Yesterday, [Wed 1 Nov 2017], the Secretary General of Public Health, Dr. Jos\u00e9a Ratsirarson emphasized that the plague patient who escaped the anti-plague hospital in Ambohimiandra (CHAPA), last [Thu 26 Oct 2017], has not been found. This is faster-spreading and more transmittable than bubonic plague, noted Tarik Jasarevic, a spokesman for the WHO; 'compared with past outbreaks, this year [2017] there is a higher portion of pneumonic plague cases.' \n\nOngoing efforts to control the spread of bubonic and pneumonic plague include seeking out and treating new cases, identifying the method of disease contact, disease follow-up and antibiotic treatment, rodent and flea control, and 'safe and dignified burials,' the WHO said in a statement. PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (29): FATAL\n*******************************\n \n\nSince plague is endemic (or regularly found) in Madagascar, its 'spread to non-endemic areas which were not used to handling plague cases, including densely populated cities,' may have caused a more severe outbreak, according to Jasarevic. On [Tue 31 Oct 2017], 83 people were under treatment at the facility level, a thousand people have been cured since the beginning of the epidemic and 7 new cases were recorded throughout Madagascar. The first 2 were on [Tue 31 Oct 2017], and the last [Wed 1 Nov 2017]. Unlike the cases reported recently, they all died at the community level with a rapid diagnostic test (RDT) positive for plague, as reported by the Municipal Bureau of Health (BMH) of the Urban Commune of Antananarivo (AUC), which supports the deceased outside health facilities and burial of plague victims in the city of Antananarivo. The calm of the plague has been broken by the suspicious death of 3 people in Antananarivo, [Tue 31 Oct and Wed 1 Nov 2017]. Date / Cases / Deaths / Average new cases per day\n However, the occurrence of new cases is finally decreasing, according to a report released [Wed 1 Nov 2017] by the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs. 14 Sep 2017 / 28 / 5\n30 Date: Fri 3 Nov 2017\n Date: Thu 2 Nov 2017 8:34\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1554-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-08-25 00:00:00", "1836-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00", "1044-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5448645", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Madagascar (32): fatal, WHO", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5448645", "date": "2017-11-16 19:20:45", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (32): FATAL, WHO\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 15 Nov 2017\nSource WHO Disease Outbreak News [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/csr/don/15-november-2017-plague-madagascar/en/\n\n\nPlague - Madagascar\n-------------------\nSince [Tue 1 Aug 2017], Madagascar has been experiencing a large outbreak of plague. As of [Fri 10 Nov 2017], a total of 2119 confirmed, probable and suspected cases of plague, including 171 deaths (case fatality rate: 8 percent), have been reported by the Ministry of Health of Madagascar to WHO.\n\nFrom 1 Aug through 10 Nov 2017, 1618 (76 percent) cases and 72 deaths have been clinically classified as pneumonic plague, including 365 (23 percent) confirmed, 573 (35 percent) probable and 680 (42 percent) suspected cases. In addition to the pneumonic cases, 324 (15 percent) cases of bubonic plague, one case of septicemic plague, and 176 unspecified cases (8 percent), have been reported to WHO (Figure 1 [for Figures, see original URL - Mod.LL]). Up to 82 healthcare workers have had illness compatible with plague, none of whom have died.\n\nFrom 1 Aug through 10 Nov, 16 (out of 22) regions of Madagascar have reported cases. Analamanga Region has been the most affected, reporting 72 percent of the overall cases (Figures 2 and 3).\n\nAs of [Fri 10 Nov 2017], 218 out of 243 (90 percent) contacts under follow-up were reached and provided with prophylactic antimicrobials. Since the beginning of the outbreak, a total of 7122 contacts were identified, 6729 (95 percent) of whom have completed their 7-day follow up and a course of prophylactic antimicrobials. Only 9 contacts developed symptoms and became suspected cases.\n\nLaboratory confirmation of plague is being conducted by the Institut Pasteur of Madagascar, National WHO Collaborating Center for plague in Madagascar. Up to 25 isolates of _Yersinia pestis_ have been cultured and all are sensitive to antimicrobials recommended by the National Program for the Control of Plague.\n\nThe number of new cases and hospitalizations of patients due to plague is declining in Madagascar. The last confirmed bubonic case was reported on [Tue 24 Oct 2017] and the last confirmed pneumonic case was reported on [Sat 28 Oct 2017].\n\nSince plague is endemic to parts of Madagascar, WHO expects more cases to be reported until the end of the typical plague season in April 2018. It is therefore important that control measures continue through to the end of the plague season.\n\nPublic health response\n----------------------\n- The Ministry of Public Health of Madagascar is coordinating the health response, with the support of WHO and other agencies and partners.\n- The Ministry of Public Health of Madagascar has activated crisis units in Antananarivo and Toamasina and all cases and contacts have been provided access to treatment or prophylactic antibiotics at no cost to themselves.\n\nPublic health response measures include:\n- Investigation of new cases\n- Isolation and treatment of all pneumonic cases\n- Enhanced case finding\n- Active finding, tracing and monitoring of contacts and provision of free prophylactic antibiotics\n- Strengthened epidemiological surveillance in the all affected districts\n- Disinsection, including rodent and vector control\n- Raising public awareness on prevention for bubonic and pneumonic plague\n- Raising awareness among health care workers and providing information to improve case detection, infection control measures and protection from infection\n- Providing information about infection control measures during burial practices.\n- Enhanced measures for exit screening have been implemented at the International Airport in Antananarivo. These measures include: filling a special departure form at the airport (to identify passengers at risk); temperature screening of departing passengers, and referring passengers with fever to airport physicians for further consultation; passengers with symptoms compatible with pneumonic plague are immediately isolated at the airport and investigated using a rapid diagnostic test and notified according to the response alert protocol. Symptomatic passengers are not allowed to travel. A WHO GOARN team, consisting of US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and L'Institut de veille sanitaire/ Sant\u00e9 publique France (InVS/SPF), is providing technical support at the airport.\n\nA total of 9 countries and overseas territories in the African region (Comoros, Ethiopia, Kenya, Mauritius, Mozambique, La R\u00e9union (France), Seychelles, South Africa, and Tanzania) have been identified as priority countries for plague preparedness and readiness by virtue of their trade and travel links to Madagascar. These countries are implementing readiness activities, including increased public awareness of plague, enhancing surveillance for the disease (particularly at points of entry), and prepositioning of equipment and supplies.\n\nWHO risk assessment\n-------------------\nSince mid-October 2017, the number of new cases of plague, the number of hospitalizations of patients due to plague, and the number of geographic districts reporting plague has decreased. While the declining trend in new plague case reports and reduction in hospitalizations due to plague are encouraging signs, WHO expects more cases of plague to be reported from Madagascar until the typical plague season ends in April 2018.\n\nThe decline in case reports suggest that the epidemic phase of the outbreak is ending, however sustaining ongoing operations is critical to minimize bubonic plague infections and human-to-human transmission of pneumonic plague.\n\nThe trend in the number of new cases of plague has been declining for more than a month, indicating that measures taken to contain the outbreak have been effective. WHO is working with the Ministry of Health in Madagascar and other partners to maintain ongoing outbreak control efforts, including active case finding and treatment, comprehensive contact identification, follow-up and antibiotic treatment, rodent and flea control, and safe and dignified burials through this outbreak and the plague season into 2018, and to outline a longer term strategy for plague preparedness and control.\n\nSince the beginning of this outbreak, the vast majority of cases, and more than 7000 contact persons, have been treated and have recovered. As of 15 November 2017, only 12 people are hospitalized for plague. There has been no international spread outside the country.\n\nBased on available information and response measures implemented to date, WHO estimates the risk of potential further spread of the plague outbreak at national level remains high. The risk of international spread is mitigated by the short incubation period of pneumonic plague, implementation of exit screening measures and advice to travellers to Madagascar, and scaling up of preparedness and operational readiness activities in neighbouring Indian Ocean islands and other southern and east African countries. The overall global risk is considered to be low. WHO is re-evaluating the risk assessment based on the evolution of the outbreak and information from response activities.\n\nAdvice on prevention and control measures and treatment options has been provided to Madagascar and to priority countries in the region.\n\nWHO travel advice\n-----------------\nBased on the available information to date, the risk of international spread of plague appears very low. WHO advises against any restriction on travel or trade on Madagascar. To date, there are no reported cases related to international travel.\n\nInternational travellers arriving in Madagascar should be informed about the current plague outbreak and the necessary protection measures. Travellers should protect themselves against flea bites, avoid contact with dead animals, infected tissues or materials, and avoid close contact with patients with pneumonic plague. In case of sudden symptoms of fever, chills, painful and inflamed lymph nodes, or shortness of breath with coughing and/or blood-tainted sputum, travellers should immediately contact a medical service. Travellers should avoid self-medication, even if for prophylaxis. Prophylactic treatment is only recommended for persons who have been in close contact with cases, or with other high risk exposures (such as bites from fleas or direct contact with body fluids or tissues of infected animals). Upon return from travel to Madagascar, travellers should be on alert for the above symptoms. If symptoms appear, travellers should seek medical care and inform their physician about their travel history to Madagascar.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[With so many cases of pneumonic plague, the case fatality rate seems low.\n\nDate / Cases / Deaths / Average new cases per day\n-------------------------------------------------\n14 Sep 2017 / 28 / 5\n30 Sep 2017 / 73 / 17 / 3\n3 Oct 2017 / 194 / 30 / 40\n5 Oct 2017 / 258 / 36 / 32\n7 Oct 2017 / 343 / 42 / 43\n8 Oct 2017 / 387 / 45 / 44\n9 Oct 2017 / 449 / 48 / 62\n10 Oct 2017 / 500 / 54 / 51\n11 Oct 2017 / 561 / 57 / 61\n13 Oct 2017 / 684 / 57 / 61\n16 Oct 2017 / 805 / 74 / 40\n17 Oct 2017 / 878 / 80 / 44\n18 Oct 2017 / 1032 / 89 / 164\n19 Oct 2017 / 1153 / 94 / 121\n20 Oct 2017 / 1297 / 102 / --\n23 Oct 2017 / 1192 / 124 / 10\n25 Oct 2017 / 1309 / 93 / 58\n27 Oct 2017 / 1554 / 113 / 122\n30 Oct 2017 / 1801 / 127 / 82\n1 Nov 2017 / 1836 / 133 / 17\n3 Nov 2017 / 1947 / 143 / 55.\n10 Nov 2017 / 2119 / 171 / 25. - Mod.MPP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/181.]", "summary": "Sep 2017 / 73 / 17 / 3\n3 Oct 2017 / 194 / 30 / 40\n5 Oct 2017 / 258 / 36 / 32\n7 Oct 2017 / 343 / 42 / 43\n8 Oct 2017 / 387 / 45 / 44\n9 Oct 2017 / 449 / 48 / 62\n10 Oct 2017 / 500 / 54 / 51\n11 Oct 2017 / 561 / 57 / 61\n13 Oct 2017 / 684 / 57 / 61\n16 Oct 2017 / 805 / 74 / 40\n17 Oct 2017 / 878 / 80 / 44\n18 Oct 2017 / 1032 / 89 / 164\n19 Oct 2017 / 1153 / 94 / 121\n20 Oct 2017 / 1297 / 102 / --\n \n\nPublic health response measures include:\n- Investigation of new cases\n- Isolation and treatment of all pneumonic cases\n- Enhanced case finding\n- Active finding, tracing and monitoring of contacts and provision of free prophylactic antibiotics\n- Strengthened epidemiological surveillance in the all affected districts\n- Disinsection, including rodent and vector control\n- Raising public awareness on prevention for bubonic and pneumonic plague\n- 23 Oct 2017 / 1192 / 124 / 10\n25 Oct 2017 / 1309 / 93 / 58\n27 Oct 2017 / 1554 / 113 / 122\n30 Oct 2017 / 1801 / 127 / 82\n1 Nov 2017 / 1836 / 133 / 17\n3 Nov 2017 / 1947 / 143 / 55. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n While the declining trend in new plague case reports and reduction in hospitalizations due to plague are encouraging signs, WHO expects more cases of plague to be reported from Madagascar until the typical plague season ends in April 2018. In addition to the pneumonic cases, 324 (15 percent) cases of bubonic plague, one case of septicemic plague, and 176 unspecified cases (8 percent), have been reported to WHO (Figure 1 [for Figures, see original URL - Mod. From 1 Aug through 10 Nov 2017, 1618 (76 percent) cases and 72 deaths have been clinically classified as pneumonic plague, including 365 (23 percent) confirmed, 573 (35 percent) probable and 680 (42 percent) suspected cases. Since mid-October 2017, the number of new cases of plague, the number of hospitalizations of patients due to plague, and the number of geographic districts reporting plague has decreased. WHO is working with the Ministry of Health in Madagascar and other partners to maintain ongoing outbreak control efforts, including active case finding and treatment, comprehensive contact identification, follow-up and antibiotic treatment, rodent and flea control, and safe and dignified burials through this outbreak and the plague season into 2018, and to outline a longer term strategy for plague preparedness and control. As of [Fri 10 Nov 2017], a total of 2119 confirmed, probable and suspected cases of plague, including 171 deaths (case fatality rate: 8 percent), have been reported by the Ministry of Health of Madagascar to WHO. \n\nSince plague is endemic to parts of Madagascar, WHO expects more cases to be reported until the end of the typical plague season in April 2018. These measures include: filling a special departure form at the airport (to identify passengers at risk); temperature screening of departing passengers, and referring passengers with fever to airport physicians for further consultation; passengers with symptoms compatible with pneumonic plague are immediately isolated at the airport and investigated using a rapid diagnostic test and notified according to the response alert protocol. The last confirmed bubonic case was reported on [Tue 24 Oct 2017] and the last confirmed pneumonic case was reported on [Sat 28 Oct 2017]. The decline in case reports suggest that the epidemic phase of the outbreak is ending, however sustaining ongoing operations is critical to minimize bubonic plague infections and human-to-human transmission of pneumonic plague. Date / Cases / Deaths / Average new cases per day\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[With so many cases of pneumonic plague, the case fatality rate seems low. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< The risk of international spread is mitigated by the short incubation period of pneumonic plague, implementation of exit screening measures and advice to travellers to Madagascar, and scaling up of preparedness and operational readiness activities in neighbouring Indian Ocean islands and other southern and east African countries. WHO\n************************************\n The trend in the number of new cases of plague has been declining for more than a month, indicating that measures taken to contain the outbreak have been effective. \n10 Nov 2017 / 2119 / 171 / 25. - Mod. \n\nLaboratory confirmation of plague is being conducted by the Institut Pasteur of Madagascar, National WHO Collaborating Center for plague in Madagascar. Based on available information and response measures implemented to date, WHO estimates the risk of potential further spread of the plague outbreak at national level remains high. \n\nAs of [Fri 10 Nov 2017], 218 out of 243 (90 percent) contacts under follow-up were reached and provided with prophylactic antimicrobials. \n\nInternational travellers arriving in Madagascar should be informed about the current plague outbreak and the necessary protection measures.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2018-04-25 00:00:00", "2017-11-10 16:18:00", "2119-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00", "2018-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-11-15 00:00:00", "2032-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Analamanga Region", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "symptomatic", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kenya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ethiopia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tanzania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Comoros", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5417971", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Madagascar (27): fatal, revised numbers", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5417971", "date": "2017-11-01 10:22:38", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (27): FATAL, REVISED NUMBERS\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 30 Oct 2017\nSource: UNICEF (United Nations Children's Fund) [edited]\nhttps://reliefweb.int/report/madagascar/madagascar-plague-outbreak-situation-report-30-october-2017\n\n\nMadagascar: plague outbreak situation report, 30 Oct 2017\n---------------------------------------------------------\nHighlights\n----------\n- The number of new notified cases have begun to decline following 6 weeks of intensive outbreak response by the Madagascar Government and partners to the dual epidemics of pneumonic and bubonic plague. While the number of patients decrease, 978 people have been cured, 122 are currently on treatment, and 113 deaths have been reported.\n- Between 1 Aug 2017 and 27 Oct 2017, a total of 1554 cases have been notified, out of which 985 are pneumonic plague, 230 bubonic plague, and 339 unknown. Out of these total reported cases, 332 cases are confirmed, 495 cases are probable, and 727 cases suspected. It is noteworthy that only 27 per cent of pneumonic cases have been confirmed so far, while 34 per cent remaining probable and 35 per cent suspect. Considering the current situation and the fact that the plague season in Madagascar runs through April, continued vigilance of the response is required.\n- Treatment and referral capacity, data management, contact tracing, and communication and sensitization have been significantly reinforced. The current focus is on rumour management, addressing stigmatization, safe and respectful burial, and clarifying diagnosis of very young children who are unable to go through regular testing.\n- To facilitate the reopening of schools and the return to school for 415 000 children in affected areas on 6 Nov 2017 (following the precautionary closure of schools on 2 Oct 2017), UNICEF has been working with the Ministry of Education on plague detection and referral protocol and related special training for more than 15 000 teachers and administrative staff to ensure that children with symptoms are properly referred to treatment centres without causing stigmatization or panic.\n- UNICEF's support to the response is focused on improving the health case management in treatment centres, including hygiene and wash provisions; facilitating food provision for patients and families in hospitals and a continuously evolving communication response aimed at sensitizing communities on the dangers of the epidemic; advice on how to prevent and access treatment, as well as address rumours; reduce stigma and facilitate work at community level (tracing, referral, burials).\n\nData as of 27 Oct 2017:\n- 1554 total cases notified, of which 985 cases of pneumonic plague, 230 cases of bubonic plague, and 339 unknown cases, notably in the urban areas of Tamatave and Antananarivo\n- 978 recoveries\n- 113 deaths reported\n- 40 out of 114 districts have been affected with the highest number of cases detected in the capital\n\nSituation overview & humanitarian response\n------------------------------------------\nMadagascar is experiencing 2 concurrent outbreaks of plague: a flea-transmitted bubonic plague outbreak that has spread beyond the usual rural areas where the plague is endemic, into new rural, as well as urban areas; and a 2nd highly-contagious human to human transmitted pneumonic plague outbreak which has been spreading rapidly predominantly in the 3 main urban areas of the country. The number of reported cases has been steadily rising although appears to have tapered somewhat in the past 10 days. To date, 1554 cases have been reported and the number of deaths recently exceeded 100.\n\nThe response is now in place following intense work over the past few weeks on (1) developing the necessary technical protocols for this unprecedented situation, with WHO leading the epidemiological surveillance, treatment, contact, and tracing part of this work and UNICEF leading protocol development for schools, WASH [Water, Sanitation and Hygiene] and C4D [Communication for Development] (including safe and culturally appropriate burials), and (2) setting up previously non-existent treatment and care services at hospitals including antibiotics provision, triage and isolation capacity set up, proper hygiene and waste disposal, training of staff amongst other activities.\n\nNevertheless, several factors continue to make this dual epidemic outbreak very complex to manage:\n- a steadily increasing demand to assist in setting up new treatment centres given the rapid overflow of existing hospitals and the emergence of the outbreak in new areas;\n- the lack of capacity of some existing centres to provide adequate isolation and hygiene;\n- complexity of data systems, with an over-estimate of 'suspected' cases, irregular or incomplete data coming from the peripheral level and a constantly evolving situation;\n- complexity of tracing contacts in urban, often informal, settings;\n- false rumours causing panic and creating dangerous behaviours;\n- strong pressure on Ministry of Education to re-open schools.\n\nUNICEF is supporting the national response alongside the Ministry of Health, World Health Organization (WHO), National Office for Disaster Prevention and Control (BNGRC), USAID, Government of France, Institut Pasteur, International Federation of the Red Cross, Medecins du Monde, Action contre la Faim, and M\u00e9decins Sans Fronti\u00e8res (MSF). Significant surge capacity from these international organisations has arrived from abroad in recent weeks.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There continues to be substantial variation in the numbers reported in this significant outbreak of plague, making interpretations of control difficult to make.\n\nDate / Cases / Deaths / Average new cases per To facilitate the reopening of schools and the return to school for 415 000 children in affected areas on 6 Nov 2017 (following the precautionary closure of schools on 2 Oct 2017), UNICEF has been working with the Ministry of Education on plague detection and referral protocol and related special training for more than 15 000 teachers and administrative staff to ensure that children with symptoms are properly referred to treatment centres without causing stigmatization or panic. PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (27): FATAL, REVISED NUMBERS\n************************************************\n The response is now in place following intense work over the past few weeks on (1) developing the necessary technical protocols for this unprecedented situation, with WHO leading the epidemiological surveillance, treatment, contact, and tracing part of this work and UNICEF leading protocol development for schools, WASH [Water, Sanitation and Hygiene] and C4D [Communication for Development] (including safe and culturally appropriate burials), and (2) setting up previously non-existent treatment and care services at hospitals including antibiotics provision, triage and isolation capacity set up, proper hygiene and waste disposal, training of staff amongst other activities. \n\n\nMadagascar: plague outbreak situation report, 30 Oct 2017\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-04-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "1554-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Monde", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5415688", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Madagascar (26): fatal, revised numbers, transportation", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5415688", "date": "2017-10-31 20:20:05", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (26): FATAL, REVISED NUMBERS, TRANSPORTATION\n****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Down-revised WHO numbers\n[2] Possibly higher numbers\n[3] South African case NOT imported\n[4] ECDC guidelines regarding ships and aircraft\n\n******\n[1] Down-revised WHO numbers\nDate: Thu 26 Oct 2017\nSource: WHO, Health Emergency Information and Risk Assessment [edited]\nhttp://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/10665/259372/1/Ex-PlagueMadagascar26102017.pdf\n\n\nExternal situation report 06\n----------------------------\nWHO continues to support the Ministry of Public Health and other national authorities in Madagascar to monitor and respond to the outbreak of plague. The number of new cases of pulmonary plague has continued to decline in all active areas across the country. In the past 2 weeks, 12 previously affected districts reported no new confirmed or probable cases of pulmonary plague. From 1 Aug 2017 to 24 Oct 2017, a total of 1309 suspected cases of plague, including 93 deaths (7 percent), were reported. The figures in this report are based on a rigorous data cleaning, verification and analysis process aimed to give a better understanding of the dynamics of the epidemic. Of these, 882 (67 percent) were clinically classified as pulmonary plague, 221 (17 percent) were bubonic plague, 1 was septicemic, and 186 were unspecified (further classification of cases is in process). Since the beginning of the outbreak, 71 healthcare workers (with no deaths) have been affected.\n\nOf the 882 clinical cases of pneumonic plague, 235 (27 percent) were confirmed, 300 (34 percent) were probable and 347 (39 percent) remain suspected (additional laboratory results are in process). 14 strains of Yersinia pestis have been isolated and were sensitive to antimicrobials recommended by the National Program for the Control of Plague.\n\nBetween 1 Aug 2017 and 24 Oct 2017, 29 districts have reported confirmed and probable cases of pulmonary plague. The number of districts that reported confirmed and probable cases of pulmonary plague during the last 2 weeks reduced to 17. About 70 percent (3467) of 4990 contacts identified have completed their 7-day follow-up and a course of prophylactic antibiotics. A total of 7 contacts developed symptoms and became suspected cases. On 24 Oct 2017, 1165 out of 1239 (94 percent) contacts were followed up and provided with prophylactic antimicrobials.\n\nPlague is endemic on the Plateaux of Madagascar, including Ankazobe district, where the current outbreak originated. A seasonal upsurge, predominantly of the bubonic form, usually occurs yearly between September and April. In 2017, the plague season began earlier and the current outbreak is predominantly pneumonic and is affecting both endemic and non-endemic areas, including major urban centres such as Antananarivo (the capital city) and Toamasina (the port city).\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The overall numbers of cases and deaths, as noted in this report, have been lessened based on 'a rigorous data cleaning, verification and analysis process aimed to give a better understanding of the dynamics of the epidemic' although the Outbreak News report from 30 Oct 2017 gives higher numbers from perhaps a different source. There have been moderate discordance in numbers from Madagascar and WHO sources previously.\n\nDate / Cases / Deaths / Average new cases per day\n-------------------------------------------------\n14 Sep 2017 / 28 / 5\n30 Sep 2017 / 73 / 17 / 3\n3 Oct 2017 / 194 / 30 / 40\n5 Oct 2017 / 258 / 36 / 32\n7 Oct 2017 / 343 / 42 / 43\n8 Oct 2017 / 387 / 45 / 44\n9 Oct 2017 / 449 / 48 / 62\n10 Oct 2017 / 500 / 54 / 51\n11 Oct 2017 / 561 / 57 / 61\n13 Oct 2017 / 684 / 57 / 61\n16 Oct 2017 / 805 / 74 / 40\n17 Oct 2017 / 878 / 80 / 44\n18 Oct 2017 / 1032 / 89 / 164\n19 Oct 2017 / 1153 / 94 / 121\n20 Oct 2017 / 1297 / 102 / --\n23 Oct 2017 / 1192 / 124 / 10\n25 Oct 2017 / 1309 / 93 / 58\n\nDiscordance in overall numbers makes interpretation of number of new cases difficult. It does seem to appear that a downswing in the outbreak may be occurring. Overall, however, the low case fatality rate seems inconsistent with the number of cases of pneumonic plague. - Mod.LL]\n\n******\n[2] Possibly higher numbers\nDate: Mon 30 Oct 2017\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/madagascar-plague-situation-improving-beginning-end-epidemic-maintain-vigilance-48693/\n\n\nWhile plague cases continue to be reported in Madagascar, health officials say the situation is improving as evidenced by 16 previously affected districts reported no new confirmed or probable cases of pulmonary plague during the past 2 weeks, which is creating some optimism.\n\n'This is the beginning of the end of the epidemic if we maintain vigilance,' said Dr Mahery Ratsitorahana, Director of Health Surveillance and Epidemiological Surveillance (DVSSE) within the Ministry of Public Health, during a press conference, according to L'Express de Madagascar report.\n\nThe WHO said something similar in a report today, 30 Oct 2017:\n'While progress has been made in response to the plague outbreak in Madagascar, sustainability of ongoing operations (during the outbreak and through the plague season usually from September to April) remains critical. Funds for operations are running low, given the fact that only 26 percent of the multisector response plan has been funded. Additional response logistics such as temperature monitoring equipment (infrared thermometers), rapid diagnostic tests, personal protective equipment, infection prevention and control supplies, and medicines (antibiotics) need to be provided. Efforts to strengthen outbreak control measures should continue.'\n\nFrom 1 Aug 2017 to 27 Oct 2017, a total of 1554 suspected cases of plague, including 113 deaths (case fatality rate 7 percent), were reported. Of these, 985 (63 percent) were clinically classified as pulmonary plague, 230 (15 percent) were bubonic plague, 1 was septicemic, and 338 were unspecified (further classification of cases is in process). Since the beginning of the outbreak, 71 healthcare workers (with no deaths) have been affected.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The overall number of cases from this report and the deaths are higher than the latest WHO data which I could find. - Mod.LL]\n\n******\n[3] South African case NOT imported\nDate: Tue 31 Oct 2017\nSource: Eyewitness News [edited]\nhttp://ewn.co.za/2017/10/31/nicd-sa-man-who-contracted-plague-in-madagascar-back-home-healthy\n\n\nThe National Institute for Communicable Diseases (NICD) has confirmed that a South African man who visited Madagascar contracted a plague formerly known as black death, but he has been successfully treated and is now back home. The plague has only been detected in Madagascar with 93 deaths reported since August 2017.\n\nThe NICD's Lucille Blumberg says that the man was treated in hospital in Madagascar earlier in October 2017 after he was in contact with a man who died from the plague. He was put on antimicrobials for a week, which Blumberg says were extremely effective.\n\n'He is in good health and there's absolutely no risk. We need to be vigilant, the risks are low. But it is absolutely necessary that we have systems in place.'\n\nBlumberg says that the man has tested negative after numerous follow-up tests.\n\n[Byline: Mia Lindeque]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is now clear that the South African case was not imported from Madagascar but rather diagnosed and treated in Madagascar proper. At this point, there are no documented _Y. pestis_ cases exported outside of Madagascar. - Mod.LL]\n\n******\n[4] ECDC guidelines regarding ships and aircraft\nDate: Mon 30 Oct 2017\nSource: European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) [edited]\nhttps://ecdc.europa.eu/en/publications-data/guidance-management-suspected-bubonic-plague-cases-identified-aircraft-and-ships\n\n\nGuidance for the management of suspected bubonic plague cases identified on aircraft and ships\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nKey messages:\n- The common route of transmission of bubonic plague to humans is the bite of an infected flea. The disease can be transmitted between humans by contact with infected bodily fluids; humans can be also infected by touching or skinning infected animals.\n- The infection can cause a severe disease in humans but can be successfully treated with early administration of antimicrobials. If bubonic form is not treated, the infection can spread through the bloodstream to the lungs, resulting in pneumonic or septicemic form of plague.\n- A case of bubonic plague can be suspected on aircraft or ships when a passenger or a crew member leaving an affected area has a fever associated with swollen lymph nodes.\n- The presence of trained crew members and their awareness of the disease could help reduce the risk of onboard transmission.\n- The main risk of transmission on aircraft and ships lies in infected fleas infesting a passenger and/or his/her belongings. The transmission by bodily fluids (such as the fluid from the buboes) requires exposure to infected material through a break in the skin; this can be considered unlikely on aircraft and ships, but it cannot be excluded.\n- Members of the cabin crew assisting an ill passenger should wear gloves; the ill passenger and the crew member assisting him/her should follow standard infection control precautions.\n- Local authorities at the arrival airport/mooring port of call should be informed immediately after the identification of a suspected case of bubonic plague on board so they can plan mitigation measures aimed at reducing the risk of further spread.\n- If there is a suspected plague case on board, passengers should be informed about how to self-monitor for plague-compatible symptoms; the collection of passenger contact details is crucial for further contact tracing.\n- Physicians should consider early post-exposure prophylaxis for passengers and crew members who have come in direct contact with body fluids of the ill passenger.\n- Arrangements for post-event disinfection and disinsection procedures for the aircraft and the ill passenger's belongings should be considered after disembarking.\n- On a ship, the WHO's International medical guide for ships suggests that the patient's quarters and all other passenger quarters should be treated with insecticide powder in order to ensure the extermination of fleas.\n- After disembarking from a ship, the sickbay and/or the cabin where the ill passenger was isolated should be disinfected and disinsected. All biohazard materials should be disposed of properly and in accordance with the relevant national and international rules and recommendations.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The full text of the ECDC document can be found at the source URL above. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/181.]", "summary": "Sep 2017 / 73 / 17 / 3\n3 Oct 2017 / 194 / 30 / 40\n5 Oct 2017 / 258 / 36 / 32\n7 Oct 2017 / 343 / 42 / 43\n8 Oct 2017 / 387 / 45 / 44\n9 Oct 2017 / 449 / 48 / 62\n10 Oct 2017 / 500 / 54 / 51\n11 Oct 2017 / 561 / 57 / 61\n13 Oct 2017 / 684 / 57 / 61\n16 Oct 2017 / 805 / 74 / 40\n17 Oct 2017 / 878 / 80 / 44\n18 Oct 2017 / 1032 / 89 / 164\n19 Oct 2017 / 1153 / 94 / 121\n20 Oct 2017 / 1297 / 102 / --\n A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The overall numbers of cases and deaths, as noted in this report, have been lessened based on 'a rigorous data cleaning, verification and analysis process aimed to give a better understanding of the dynamics of the epidemic' although the Outbreak News report from 30 Oct 2017 gives higher numbers from perhaps a different source. Source: European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) [edited]\nhttps://ecdc.europa.eu/en/publications-data/guidance-management-suspected-bubonic-plague-cases-identified-aircraft-and-ships\n\n\nGuidance for the management of suspected bubonic plague cases identified on aircraft and ships\n 23 Oct 2017 / 1192 / 124 / 10\n25 Oct 2017 / 1309 / 93 / 58\n\nDiscordance in overall numbers makes interpretation of number of new cases difficult. The WHO said something similar in a report today, 30 Oct 2017:\n'While progress has been made in response to the plague outbreak in Madagascar, sustainability of ongoing operations (during the outbreak and through the plague season usually from September to April) remains critical. PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (26): FATAL, REVISED NUMBERS, TRANSPORTATION\n****************************************************************\n From 1 Aug 2017 to 27 Oct 2017, a total of 1554 suspected cases of plague, including 113 deaths (case fatality rate 7 percent), were reported. \n\nBetween 1 Aug 2017 and 24 Oct 2017, 29 districts have reported confirmed and probable cases of pulmonary plague. From 1 Aug 2017 to 24 Oct 2017, a total of 1309 suspected cases of plague, including 93 deaths (7 percent), were reported. Source: WHO, Health Emergency Information and Risk Assessment [edited]\nhttp://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/10665/259372/1/Ex-PlagueMadagascar26102017.pdf\n\n\nExternal situation report 06\n While plague cases continue to be reported in Madagascar, health officials say the situation is improving as evidenced by 16 previously affected districts reported no new confirmed or probable cases of pulmonary plague during the past 2 weeks, which is creating some optimism. \n- A case of bubonic plague can be suspected on aircraft or ships when a passenger or a crew member leaving an affected area has a fever associated with swollen lymph nodes. In this update:\n[1] Down-revised WHO numbers\n \n- Local authorities at the arrival airport/mooring port of call should be informed immediately after the identification of a suspected case of bubonic plague on board so they can plan mitigation measures aimed at reducing the risk of further spread. \n\nOf the 882 clinical cases of pneumonic plague, 235 (27 percent) were confirmed, 300 (34 percent) were probable and 347 (39 percent) remain suspected (additional laboratory results are in process). Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Of these, 882 (67 percent) were clinically classified as pulmonary plague, 221 (17 percent) were bubonic plague, 1 was septicemic, and 186 were unspecified (further classification of cases is in process). ----------------------------------------------------------------------\nKey messages:\n- Of these, 985 (63 percent) were clinically classified as pulmonary plague, 230 (15 percent) were bubonic plague, 1 was septicemic, and 338 were unspecified (further classification of cases is in process). \n- Members of the cabin crew assisting an ill passenger should wear gloves; the ill passenger and the crew member assisting him/her should follow standard infection control precautions. Date / Cases / Deaths / Average new cases per day\n 14 Sep 2017 / 28 / 5\n30 \n- Physicians should consider early post-exposure prophylaxis for passengers and crew members who have come in direct contact with body fluids of the ill passenger. \n\nThe NICD's Lucille Blumberg says that the man was treated in hospital in Madagascar earlier in October 2017 after he was in contact with a man who died from the plague. Date: Mon 30 Oct 2017\n Date: Mon 30 Oct 2017\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The full text of the ECDC document can be found at the source URL above. Date: Thu 26 Oct 2017\n If there is a suspected plague case on board, passengers should be informed about how to self-monitor for plague-compatible symptoms; the collection of passenger contact details is crucial for further contact tracing. In 2017, the plague season began earlier and the current outbreak is predominantly pneumonic and is affecting both endemic and non-endemic areas, including major urban centres such as Antananarivo (the capital city) and Toamasina (the port city). Date: Tue 31 Oct 2017\n \n- Arrangements for post-event disinfection and disinsection procedures for the aircraft and the ill passenger's belongings should be considered after disembarking.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2017-10-25 00:00:00", "4990-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-04-25 00:00:00", "1309-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-09-25 00:00:00", "3467-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-08-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5394246", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Madagascar (23): fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5394246", "date": "2017-10-20 21:56:41", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (23): FATAL\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 20 Oct 2017 7:37 AM\nSource: Reuters [edited]\nhttps://uk.reuters.com/article/us-health-who-africa/plague-kills-94-in-madagascar-who-says-working-to-prevent-spread-idUKKBN1CP1FK\n\n\nA plague epidemic has killed 94 people on the island of Madagascar and could spread further, the WHO said on [Fri 20 Oct 2017].\n\nWHO's Africa emergencies director, Ibrahima Soce Fall, told reporters in Geneva the organization was racing to stop both the Madagascar plague and an outbreak of the Ebola-like Marburg virus in Uganda that it was confident it could contain.\n\nPlague is endemic in Madagascar, but the outbreak that has caused 1153 suspected cases since August 2017 is especially worrying because it started earlier in the season than usual, it has hit towns rather than rural areas, and it is mainly causing pneumonic plague, the most deadly form of the disease. The outbreak already looks big when compared with the 3248 cases and 584 deaths reported worldwide from 2010 to 2015. Fall said the risk to Madagascar remained very high, although the international risk was very low.\n\nWHO has delivered antimicrobials to Madagascar to treat up to 5000 patients and as a prophylactic dose for up to 100 000 people who might be at risk, as well as 150 000 sets of personal protective equipment. About 2000 health workers are tracing people who have had contact with plague sufferers, which should allow the disease to be controlled relatively quickly, Fall said.\n\n'I'm confident that with the strong team we have on the ground, combined with more partners coming and health workers, we will be able very quickly to reverse the trend.'\n\n[Byline: Tom Miles]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The plague epidemic in Madagascar continues to grow dramatically with a majority of cases being pneumonic plague which is easily passed from person-to-person and has involved healthcare workers as well.\n\nDate / Cases / Deaths / Average new cases per day\n-------------------------------------------------\n14 Sep 2017 / 28 / 5\n30 Sep 2017 / 73 / 17 / 3\n3 Oct 2017 / 194 / 30 / 40\n5 Oct 2017 / 258 / 36 / 32\n7 Oct 2017 / 343 / 42 / 43\n8 Oct 2017 / 387 / 45 / 44\n9 Oct 2017 / 449 / 48 / 62\n10 Oct 2017 / 500 / 54 / 51\n11 Oct 2017 / 561 / 57 / 61\n13 Oct 2017 / 684 / 57 / 61\n16 Oct 2017 / 805 / 74 / 40\n17 Oct 2017 / 878 / 80 / 44\n18 Oct 2017 / 1032 / 89 / 164\n19 Oct 2017 / 1153 / 94 / 121. - Mod.LL\n\nMaps of Madagascar can be seen at http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/madagascar/mar2582r/madagascar_pol.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/181. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "Sep 2017 / 73 / 17 / 3\n3 Oct 2017 / 194 / 30 / 40\n5 Oct 2017 / 258 / 36 / 32\n7 Oct 2017 / 343 / 42 / 43\n8 Oct 2017 / 387 / 45 / 44\n9 Oct 2017 / 449 / 48 / 62\n10 Oct 2017 / 500 / 54 / 51\n11 Oct 2017 / 561 / 57 / 61\n13 Oct 2017 / 684 / 57 / 61\n16 Oct 2017 / 805 / 74 / 40\n17 Oct 2017 / 878 / 80 / 44\n18 Oct 2017 / 1032 / 89 / 164\n19 Oct 2017 / 1153 / 94 / 121. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The plague epidemic in Madagascar continues to grow dramatically with a majority of cases being pneumonic plague which is easily passed from person-to-person and has involved healthcare workers as well. Plague is endemic in Madagascar, but the outbreak that has caused 1153 suspected cases since August 2017 is especially worrying because it started earlier in the season than usual, it has hit towns rather than rural areas, and it is mainly causing pneumonic plague, the most deadly form of the disease. PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (23): FATAL\n*******************************\n 14 Sep 2017 / 28 / 5\n30 \n\n[Byline: Tom Miles]\n\n--\n Date: Fri 20 Oct 2017 7:37 AM\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2017-03-25 00:00:00", "1153-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-08-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Uganda", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Geneva", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5392390", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Madagascar (22): fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5392390", "date": "2017-10-20 11:15:02", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (22): FATAL\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Thu 19 Oct 2017 2:50 PM\nSource: Voice of America (VOA) News [edited]\nhttps://www.voanews.com/a/un-says-madagascar-plague-cases-top-1000-mark/4077923.html\n\n\nThe number of cases of plague in Madagascar has doubled during the past 5 days, according to the UN. UN spokesperson Stephane Dujarric said [Thu 19 Oct 2017] as of [Wed 18 Oct 2017], 1032 cases were reported, 67 percent of which are pneumonic, which is more serious than bubonic plague. So far 89 deaths have been recorded, including 13 on [Tue 17 Oct 2017]. Dujarric said the spread was 'highly challenging' to control.\n\nMedical teams in the country have stepped up efforts to combat the spread of the plague, but experts have said the situation will worsen if not rapidly funded. Only 26 percent of the USD 9.5 million requested has been contributed, Dujarric said.\n\nPneumonic plague is a lung infection, transmitted through flea bites or from person to person through droplets in the air when someone coughs or sneezes. A person can die within 48 hours of the disease's onset if not treated with antibiotics. Symptoms of pneumonic plague include coughing, fever, chest pain and difficulty breathing.\n\nWhile plague is a recurring problem in Madagascar, this particular outbreak has triggered a nationwide panic because it has moved from remote rural areas into the cities, including the capital, Antananarivo.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Thu 19 Oct 2017\nSource: BNGRC (National Office for the Management of Risks and Crises) [in French. trans., edited]edited]\nhttp://www.bngrc-mid.mg/images/document/Peste2017/Bulletin_Flash_19_10_2017_20h00_vff6.pdf\n\n\nCurrently, 39 districts in 17 Regions of Madagascar are affected by the plague epidemic. To date, 911 cases have been reported, of which 612 are pneumonic, 175 are bubonic, and 124 are unspecified. The overall results show 554 people who have already recovered and left the hospital, 262 people undergoing treatment, and 95 deaths.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[These separate reports from the same day show quite different numbers; the VOA report cites UN data with 1032 cases and 89 deaths and the Madagascar generated data cites 911 cases (121 fewer cases) but 95 deaths (6 more deaths). These are different sources of data and, as with the Yemeni cholera epidemic, numbers can vary. Whichever set of numbers is correct is less important than that the outbreak is still growing. It is still early in the plague season but the number of cases has surpassed most recent years.\n\nDate / Cases / Deaths / Average new cases per day\n-------------------------------------------------\n14 Sep 2017 / 28 / 5\n30 Sep 2017 / 73 / 17 / 3\n3 Oct 2017 / 194 / 30 / 40\n5 Oct 2017 / 258 / 36 / 32\n7 Oct 2017 / 343 / 42 / 43\n8 Oct 2017 / 387 / 45 / 44\n9 Oct 2017 / 449 / 48 / 62\n10 Oct 2017 / 500 / 54 / 51\n11 Oct 2017 / 561 / 57 / 61\n13 Oct 2017 / 684 / 57 / 61\n16 Oct 2017 / 805 / 74 / 40\n17 Oct 2017 / 878 / 80 / 44\n18 Oct 2017 / 1032 / 89 / 164\n- Mod.
