While the last report shows 610 cases and 63 deaths in Madagascar [the latest numbers I have seen from Madagascar are 687 and 57 deaths. - Mod.LL], 2 cases including one death in the Seychelles, it is now the turn of Mauritius to record its 1st case of suspected plague. A man was placed in quarantine in Mauritius because of a suspicion of plague. The patient was admitted on [Mon 16 Oct 2017] at Souillac Hospital, a town located in the south of the island.\n\nAccording to the protocol established in Mauritius, this hospital is empowered to take care of this type of patients. Analyzes have been carried out and the results are expected, says the newspaper L'Express de Maurice. Recall that the countries of the Indian Ocean zone are concerned of the spread of plague that is currently prevalent in Madagascar.\n\nUnlike the Seychelles whose government has decided to suspend its air links with Madagascar, Mauritius or R\u00e9union have decided to call for more vigilance of the 1st signs of plague in any person returning from this destination.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] EpiCore response\nDate: Tue 17 Oct 2017\nSource: Source: EpiCore Global Surveillance Project [edited]\n\n\nAll passengers arriving from Madagascar are being followed up by Public Health department. This patient reported having fever, malaise, and sore throat after returning from Madagascar. After examination, he was thought to have an upper respiratory tract infection but was admitted to the isolation unit and started on doxycycline as precautionary measures, pending results of investigations. His throat swab culture on _Yersinia_ selective medium was negative. Since admission he has not had fever and has remained well. His blood culture has remained negative after 5 days incubation and he is expected to be discharged today, 17 Oct 2017. This was more a case under investigation than a suspect case, and it is considered that plague has now been excluded in this patient.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nEpiCore Global Surveillance Project\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED thanks the EpiCore Global Surveillance Project member for this report. The case was imported from Madagascar and appears not to have been a _Y. pestis_ infection. If it had been the case, this would have been the 3rd country (the others being Seychelles, with any 2nd case not clearly documented, and South Africa) with imported cases. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/182.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Communicated by:\nEpiCore Global Surveillance Project\n< [2] EpiCore response\n\n******\n [1] Mauritius: plague concern\n [1] Mauritius: plague concern\n \n\n--\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n \n\n--\n PLAGUE - MAURITIUS: ex MADAGASCAR, NOT\n************************************* Date: Tue 17 Oct 2017\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2017-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Seychelles", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5379530", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Seychelles (04): poss. local spread", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5379530", "date": "2017-10-13 18:31:44", "main_text": "PLAGUE - SEYCHELLES (04): POSSIBLE LOCAL SPREAD\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 13 Oct 2017\nSource: Medical Xpress [edited]\nhttps://medicalxpress.com/news/2017-10-seychelles-schools-plague.html\n\n\nThe Seychelles government ordered schools to close [Fri 13 Oct 2017], after the discovery of 2 suspected cases of plague thought to have been brought from Madagascar where the disease has killed scores. The health ministry has also put under surveillance 320 people who have come into contact with the 2 patients. A total of 12 people showing plague-like symptoms have been admitted to hospital and given antimicrobials.\n\nPanic gripped parents on the Indian Ocean archipelago after some students developed fevers in recent days, leading to the school closures.\n\n'We made this decision as a precautionary measure to reassure parents,' said Merida Delcy, an adviser to the education ministry, noting that they would not reopen until [Wed 18 Oct 2017], at the earliest.\n\nPreliminary tests on the 2 people, including a Seychellois who returned from Madagascar a week ago, showed they could have plague, the health ministry said.\n\n'It has not yet been confirmed that the 2 people are sick due to plague, samples will be sent this weekend to the Institut Pasteur (in France),' said public health commissioner Jude Gedeon. The results are expected next week [week of Sun 15 Oct 2017].\n\nThe sick include a student at Anse Boileau Elementary School on the main island of Mahe where all students have since been given antimicrobials.\n\nAs fear of plague spreads, there has been a run on surgical masks which people hope will offer protection against the highly infectious disease. Plague outbreaks are common on Madagascar, 1800 kilometres (1120 miles) to the south, where the disease is endemic. But this year [2017] both bubonic plague, spread by infected rats via flea bites, and the pneumonic type, spread person-to-person, have hit urban areas, including the capital Antananarivo, leaving at least 54 dead.\n\nA Seychellois basketball coach who was visiting Madagascar is among the victims. The Seychelles government has begun to quarantine people who have arrived from Madagascar in the last week [week of Sun 1 Oct 2017]. The latest Madagascar health ministry report this week says 500 cases and 54 deaths [now 561 and 57 - Mod.LL] have so far been recorded, with around half of each occurring in the capital.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There is no confirmation about any cases acquired on Seychelles on the Ministry of Health facebook page https://www.facebook.com/mohseychellesofficial/. PLAGUE - SEYCHELLES (04): POSSIBLE LOCAL SPREAD\n***********************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2017-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5382291", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Seychelles (05)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5382291", "date": "2017-10-15 15:58:20", "main_text": "PLAGUE - SEYCHELLES (05)\n************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 15 Oct 2017\nSource: Seychelles Ministry of Health Facebook Page [edited]\nhttps://www.facebook.com/mohseychellesofficial/posts/\n\n\nToday, Sun 15 Oct 2017 at 10:00 am, the 12 family members (11 on Mahe and 1 on Praslin) of the 1st index probable case were discharged home after completing the stipulated 7 days' post exposure to a probable plague case. They have remained well and without symptoms. Meanwhile, the outbreak in Madagascar continues and remains uncontrolled.\n\nSuspected Case update:\n- A total of 13 people remain admitted in isolation in hospital. The index patient (probable case) is still admitted on the hospital ward and has no symptoms and is stable. Today is the 7th day of treatment, and, as per clinical guidelines, the patient is no longer infectious. He remains to complete his antibiotic course. The other patients in the hospital are stable on treatment and asymptomatic. These include the foreign national.\n\nContact tracing and surveillance:\n- The total number of people admitted at the Perseverance military academy for active surveillance are now 6. None of them have developed any symptoms. 11 family members of the 1st probable case were discharged to go home today, 15 Oct 2017, as they did not develop any symptoms during their stay. This confirms that they did not contract plague. Minister Jean Paul Adam along with other senior health officials were there to talk with them before they took their transport home.\n\n- 1 family member on active surveillance at Baie Ste Anne Praslin hospital is also being discharged today, Sun 15 Oct 2017.\n- 3 Seychellois nationals returned from Madagascar via Nairobi on Thu 12 Oct 2017. They remain well and are receiving prophylaxis.\n- 2 Australians who arrived on Fri 13 Oct 2017 from Mauritius after having spent time in Madagascar will remain in active surveillance for 7 days before being released on 20 Oct 2017, if they do not develop any symptoms.\n- The Japanese and 2 Italians left Seychelles last night.\n\nA total of 577 children and 63 teachers at Anse Boileau Primary School and cr\u00e8che have been given antimicrobial prophylaxis. This is a precautionary measure in view of a potential contact with an admitted child. By Tue 17 Oct 2017, they will have spent 7 days after contact with the admitted child. While they have to finish their antibiotics course, they will come off passive surveillance.\n\nRegional Health facilities (Beau Vallon, English River, Les Mamelles, Anse Boileau health centres and Anse Royale and Baie Ste Anne Hospitals) are being used to assess contact and provide prophylaxis.\n\nThe Public Health Authority (PHA) is reinforcing the advisory to discourage people from traveling to Madagascar for the time being.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Ministry of Health here has done an excellent job in managing the importation of pneumonic plague from Madagascar. There have been no documented cases transmitted to Seychelles as of now. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/183.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n- 2 Australians who arrived on Fri 13 Oct 2017 from Mauritius after having spent time in Madagascar will remain in active surveillance for 7 days before being released on 20 Oct 2017, if they do not develop any symptoms. Today, Sun 15 Oct 2017 at 10:00 am, the 12 family members (11 on Mahe and 1 on Praslin) of the 1st index probable case were discharged home after completing the stipulated 7 days' post exposure to a probable plague case. \n\nSuspected Case update:\n- A total of 13 people remain admitted in isolation in hospital. 11 family members of the 1st probable case were discharged to go home today, 15 Oct 2017, as they did not develop any symptoms during their stay. \n\n- 1 family member on active surveillance at Baie Ste Anne Praslin hospital is also being discharged today, Sun 15 Oct 2017. PLAGUE - SEYCHELLES (05)\n************************\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nContact tracing and surveillance:\n- The index patient (probable case) is still admitted on the hospital ward and has no symptoms and is stable. \n- 3 Seychellois nationals returned from Madagascar via Nairobi on Thu 12 Oct 2017.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2017-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Nairobi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Praslin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "seychelle", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Seychelles", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5380658", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Madagascar (19): Seychelles ex Madagascar cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5380658", "date": "2017-10-14 13:33:49", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (19): SEYCHELLES ex MADAGASCAR CASES\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 13 Oct 2017\nSource: CIDRAP [edited]\nhttp://www.cidrap.umn.edu/news-perspective/2017/10/plague-total-grows-madagascar-response-builds\n\n\nThe World Health Organization (WHO) said today [13 Oct 2017] in an update on Madagascar's plague outbreak that the number of infections as of 12 Oct 2017 has climbed to 684, an increase of 297 cases since its last update on 9 Oct 2017. Also, health officials in Seychelles are closely monitoring 11 people in hospital isolation, a step that follows the announcement 3 days ago of a probable imported case in a man who had traveled to Madagascar.\n\nOf Madagascar's new cases, 197 are pneumonic, putting that total at 474. 12 more deaths have been reported, lifting that number to 57. The WHO said the latest totals reflect an overall reduction in the case-fatality rate, which over the past few days has dropped from 11.6% to 8.3%.\n\nIllnesses have now been reported in 35 of Madagascar's 114 districts, 8 more since the previous update, the WHO said. The hardest-hit area is Antananarivo Renivohitra District, a large urban area surrounding the country's capital.\n\nOf the 684 cases, 63 are confirmed, 271 are probable, and 350 are suspected. In addition to the 474 pneumonic cases, 156 are bubonic, 1 is septicemic, and 54 are unspecified. So far 11 _Yersinia pestis_ strains have been isolated, and tests show that all are sensitive to antimicrobials recommended for treatment.\n\nThe WHO has said that the overall threat of disease spread within Madagascar is high, while the regional risk is moderate, and the overall global risk is low. Madagascar and its global health partners have scaled up surveillance and contact tracing, and the Pasteur Institute has sent 1918 rapid diagnostic tests to outbreak hot spots and to the health ministry.\n\nThe International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC) announced on 13 Oct 2017 that it is deploying its 1st-ever plague treatment center in Madagascar. It said the 50-bed facility will include a full medical team, using national health staff to isolate and treat patients sick with plague. It is also releasing about USD 1 million from its disaster relief emergency fund to scale up the local Red Cross medical treatment capacity. Fatoumata Nafo-Traore, MD, IFRC regional director for Africa, said in a statement: 'Our past experience in outbreak response had underlined the importance of responding quickly and effectively.'\n\nMedicine du Monde is setting up 5 isolation and treatment centers, and Doctors without Borders has deployed 70 people to help support the response in Toamasina, another hot spot that is also Madagascar's main seaport. The WHO has delivered personal protective equipment (PPE) and antimicrobials, and the United States Agency for International Development (USAID) has donated PPE and vehicles to help the country's health officials.\n\nIn a Facebook update, the Seychelles Ministry of Health (MOH) said there have been a few more hospital admissions linked directly or indirectly to the initial probable case. One is a foreign national who had not had contact with any other known cases and presented with fever and mild respiratory symptoms on 10 Oct 2017, which prompted isolation. The rapid screening test was weakly positive for plague, but the finding hasn't been confirmed yet by the Pasteur Institute.\n\nYesterday, 12 Oct 2017, a 26-year-old woman was transferred to the hospital with symptoms, where she was isolated and put on antimicrobials while testing is underway. The ministry said a total of 12 people have been admitted and are receiving treatment as a precaution. One is a child who may have had contact with some children at a school, and health officials will offer the students antimicrobial prophylaxis. The MOH said all of the patients, apart from the index case, are stable and are on treatment with no respiratory distress. More than 320 people who had contact with the imported probable case have been prescribed antimicrobial prophylaxis.\n\nEarlier this week, Air Seychelles cancelled all flights to and from Madagascar, and health officials there are isolating everyone entering from Madagascar and are temporarily advising against travel to Madagascar. The WHO has said it advises against any restriction on travel or trade to Madagascar, is aware of the Seychelles measure restricting travel from Madagascar, and is in contact with authorities to confirm the information and learn the public health rationale and scientific evidence, based on the International Health Regulations.\n\n[Byline: Lisa Schnirring]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The rapid rise of cases of _Yersinia pestis_ infection with a predominance of pneumonic plague is quite worrisome.\n\nDate / Cases / Deaths\n---------------------\n14 Sep 2017 / 28 / 5\n30 Sep 2017 / 73 / 17\n3 Oct 2017 / 194 / 30\n5 Oct 2017 / 258 / 36\n7 Oct 2017 / 343 / 42\n8 Oct 2017 / 387 / 45\n9 Oct 2017 / 449 / 48\n10 Oct 2017 / 500 / 54\n11 Oct 2017 / 561 / 57\n13 Oct 2017 / 684 / 57\n\nCases and deaths of plague reported by the WHO for Madagascar 2010-2015 http://www.who.int/wer/2016/wer9108.pdf?ua=1:\n\nYear / 2010 / 2011 / 2012 / 2013 / 2014/ 2015\nCases 324 / 392 / 256 / 675 / 482 / 275\nDeaths / 30 / 93 / 60 / 118 / 112 / 63\n\nThe Seychelles portion of the post confirms yesterday's [13 Oct 2017] post, but it remains unclear whether additional imported cases of _Y. pestis_ infection have occurred and if local transmission has occurred there. - PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (19): SEYCHELLES ex MADAGASCAR CASES\n********************************************************\n Madagascar and its global health partners have scaled up surveillance and contact tracing, and the Pasteur Institute has sent 1918 rapid diagnostic tests to outbreak hot spots and to the health ministry.\n\n \n\nYesterday, 12 Oct 2017, a 26-year-old woman was transferred to the hospital with symptoms, where she was isolated and put on antimicrobials while testing is underway. The Seychelles portion of the post confirms yesterday's [13 Oct 2017] post, but it remains unclear whether additional imported cases of _Y. pestis_ infection have occurred and if local transmission has occurred there. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n< The WHO has said it advises against any restriction on travel or trade to Madagascar, is aware of the Seychelles measure restricting travel from Madagascar, and is in contact with authorities to confirm the information and learn the public health rationale and scientific evidence, based on the International Health Regulations. 14 Sep 2017 / 28 / 5\n30 Also, health officials in Seychelles are closely monitoring 11 people in hospital isolation, a step that follows the announcement 3 days ago of a probable imported case in a man who had traveled to Madagascar. \n\nMedicine du Monde is setting up 5 isolation and treatment centers, and Doctors without Borders has deployed 70 people to help support the response in Toamasina, another hot spot that is also Madagascar's main seaport. A total of 561 reported cases of plague were recorded, including 415 pulmonary forms, 145 bubonic forms, and another unspecified case. In general, there are 57 deaths with a national case fatality rate of 10.2% (the ratio of deaths to the total number of cases reported). The following figures show the distribution of case numbers by district (above) and region (below) [The numbers for each district and region can be seen at the original URL. - Mod.LL]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nMelissa Dudley\nSenior Health Intelligence Analyst\n<mlsdudley@gmail.com>\n\n[ProMED thanks Melissa Dudley for this posting.\n\nThe rapid rise of cases of _Yersinia pestis_ infection with a predominance of pneumonic plague (415/561 - 74%) is quite worrisome.\n\nDate / Cases / Deaths\n---------------------\n14 Sep 2017 / 28 / 5\n30 Sep 2017 / 73 / 17\n3 Oct 2017 / 194 / 30\n5 Oct 2017 / 258 / 36\n7 Oct 2017 / 343 / 42\n8 Oct 2017 / 387 / 45\n9 Oct 2017 / 449 / 48\n10 Oct 2017 / 500 / 54\n11 Oct 2017 / 561 / 57\n\nThe dates above are the day before each report was released. The number of new cases per day, which appears to be increasing, starting on 5 Oct 2017 is:\n\n5 Oct 2017 - 32\n7 Oct 2017 - 43\n8 Oct 2017 - 44\n9 Oct 2017 - 62\n10 Oct 2017 - 51\n11 Oct 2017 - 61\n- Mod.LL\n\n******\n[2] Antimicrobial Sensitivities of Current _Y. pestis_ Isolates\nDate: Fri 13 Oct 2017\nSource: Pasteur Institute Madagascar [machine trans. edited]\nhttp://www.pasteur.mg/synthese-resultats-biologiques-peste-mise-a-jour-6-octobre-2017/\n\n\nMonitoring the susceptibility of strains of _Yersinia pestis_ to different antimicrobials is a priority for the success of the National Program for the Control of Plague. It detects the emergence of strains of reduced susceptibility or resistance to streptomycin and sulfonamides, antimicrobials recommended and used in the National Program, and evaluates other alternatives (tetracycline, ciprofloxacin, and chloramphenicol) for treatment.\n\nSince the beginning of the season, the 11 isolated strains are sensitive to these antimicrobials. They have been isolated from Miarinarivo, Moramanga, Mahajanga, Tsiroanomandidy and Andramasina.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nAmanda Walsh\nPublic Health England\n<amanda.walsh@phe.gov.uk>\n\n[ProMED thanks Amanda Walsh for a source to the antimicrobial sensitivity data for strains in the current outbreak, which appear to be fully sensitive. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/181.]", "summary": "Sep 2017 / 73 / 17\n3 Oct 2017 / 194 / 30\n5 Oct 2017 / 258 / 36\n7 Oct 2017 / 343 / 42\n8 Oct 2017 / 387 / 45\n9 Oct 2017 / 449 / 48\n10 Oct 2017 / 500 / 54\n The number of new cases per day, which appears to be increasing, starting on 5 Oct 2017 is:\n\n5 Oct 2017 - 32\n7 Oct 2017 - 43\n8 Oct 2017 - 44\n9 Oct 2017 - 62\n10 Oct 2017 - 51\n11 Oct 2017 - 61\n- Mod. Speaking to several media houses, he addressed the case of pneumonic plague that was confirmed yesterday, 10 Oct 2017. He also stressed on current and additional measures being taken by the Ministry of Health to prevent this from spreading.\n\nNew measures being implemented against pneumonic plague:\n- everyone entering Seychelles from Madagascar will immediately be referred to the isolation centre in Perseverance [Perseverance Island is an artificial island in Seychelles, lying 2 km (1.3 mi) from the capital Victoria. - Mod.LL]\n- no foreigners coming to Seychelles from Madagascar will be granted entry. Only Seychelles citizens will be allowed to enter the country.\n- a Travel Advisory has been issued, in collaboration with Seychelles Tourism Board requesting all transiting points (Mauritius, Kenya, and Reunion) to redirect all passengers who are not a citizen of Seychelles.\n- cargo ships will continue to be monitored as before. If anyone presents with symptoms within less than 7 days of leaving Madagascar, the ship will remain in isolation at sea. If anyone on board is sick, they will receive treatment;\n- cruise ships are advised to remain at sea for at least 7 days before entering the port after visiting Madagascar. If it is less than 7 days (incubation period) all passengers and crew will remain under surveillance for the recommended time before entering the country.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed 11 Oct 2017 12:59 SCT\nSource: Seychelles News Agency [edited]\nhttps://goo.gl/YDGzyc\n\n\nVisitors to Seychelles who have visited Madagascar or transited through that island nation in the last 7 days will be placed under observation by health officials upon arrival to Mahe.\n\nThe Minister of Health, Jean-Paul Adam, made the statement in the National Assembly on [Wed 11 Oct 2017] when answering an urgent question from the Leader of the Opposition, Wavel Ramkalawan. Adam was called to the National Assembly after the 1st case of pneumonic plague in Seychelles was confirmed on Tue 10 Oct 2017. The patient is a man who returned to Mahe, the main island, last [Fri 6 Oct 2017], on board the last Air Seychelles flight from Madagascar.\n\nThe health minister also confirmed that 258 people are currently under observation and receiving treatment after the case of pneumonic plague was detected. 'The 258 includes 41 passengers and 7 crew from the flight, 12 close family members, and 18 staff and patients from the Anse Boileau health centre where the man went when he fell ill.'\n\nThe man disobeyed instructions given upon his arrival to remain at home for a period of time and attended a party that same evening. The minister explained that the result of the tests conducted on the infected man was sent to the Pasteur Institute in Paris, which confirmed the pneumonic plague.\n\nAdam said that 'all the 170 people who were at the party including the 13 staff working at the venue are also under passive surveillance. We were already putting Seychellois and tourists under active observation at their homes or at hotels. But as from today [11 Oct 2017], all those arriving from Madagascar will be put in isolation for 6 days,' the Minister said.\n\nAdam added that the authority will be using the Seychelles Coast Guard military academy as the isolation centre located at Perseverance, a reclaimed island on the outskirts of Victoria.\n\nThe national airline -- Air Seychelles -- had suspended all flights to Madagascar, following guidance and requests of the Seychelles' Public Health Authority amid concerns over the outbreak of the plague in Madagascar. To date, there are 449 cases confirmed in Madagascar and 48 people have died [now 500 cases and 54 deaths - Mod.LL]. Air Seychelles is the only airline in the region to suspend all its flights to the island.\n\nThe health ministry has also liaised with the Seychelles Fishing Authority to get fishermen who may have travelled to Madagascar recently to report their trips and if necessary to seek advice from health professionals. 'We are also in contacts with boats, and we want to urge those who may have travelled to Madagascar informally to stop this practice and to report to their nearest health centres.' Adam said this is important for assessment and also 'for us to decide if they need to be placed under surveillance for treatment. We are also liaising with travel agents to discourage people from visiting the island.'\n\nSeychelles, a group of 115 islands in the western Indian Ocean, is on high alert ever since it was confirmed that a Seychellois basketball coach, who died in a hospital in Madagascar in September 2017, had contracted the plague.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Seychelles seems to have responded in appropriate ways related to the single importation (so far) of a person who developed pneumonic plague after returning from Madagascar. It is not clear if this case had any relationship to the basketball tournament that had occurred on Madagascar. Since there is no comment in this report regarding institution of antimicrobial prophylaxis to any of the contacts. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail maps can be accessed at\nSeychelles: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/183\nMadagascar: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/181]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n \n\nNew measures being implemented against pneumonic plague:\n- everyone entering Seychelles from Madagascar will immediately be referred to the isolation centre in Perseverance [Perseverance Island is an artificial island in Seychelles, lying 2 km (1.3 mi) from the capital Victoria. - Mod. '", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2017-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2017-09-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Seychelles", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kenya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Perseverance", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Victoria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Paris", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5369168", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Madagascar (15): fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5369168", "date": "2017-10-09 20:30:52", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (15): FATAL\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 9 Oct 2017\nSource: WHO [edited]\nhttps://reliefweb.int/report/madagascar/plague-outbreak-madagascar-external-situation-report-02-9-october-2017\n\n\nPlague outbreak - Madagascar - External Situation Report 02 - 9 October 2017\n------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\nSituation update\n----------------\nThe outbreak of plague in Madagascar continues to evolve. Since the last report on [Wed 4 Oct 2017], a total of 230 new suspected cases including 17 deaths (case fatality rate 7.4 percent) were reported. Between 1 Aug 2017 and 8 Oct 2017, a total of 387 cases (suspected, probable and confirmed) including 45 deaths (case fatality rate 11.6 percent) have been reported from 27 out of 114 districts in the country. Of these, 277 cases (71.6 percent) had the pneumonic form of the disease, 106 were bubonic plague, one case was septicemia plague, and 3 cases were unspecified. Of 279 cases reported to the Central Plague Laboratory of the Institut Pasteur of Madagascar, 38 were confirmed by polymerase chain reaction (PCR), 113 were classified as probable cases after testing positive on rapid diagnostic tests (RDT) and 123 remain suspected cases, pending results. A total of 14 (64 percent) out of 22 regions in the country (including the North and South-east Regions that are considered non-endemic) have been affected. At least 8 healthcare workers from one district health hospital have contracted plague since [Sat 30 Sep 2017].\n\nPlague is known to be endemic on the Plateaux of Madagascar (including Ankazobe District where the current outbreak originated) and a seasonal upsurge (predominantly the bubonic form) usually occurs early every year between September and April. Unlike the usual endemic pattern, the plague season begun early this year [2017], and the current outbreak has affected major urban centres, including Antananarivo (the capital city) and Toamasina (the port city).\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n\n[The rapid rise of cases with a predominance of pneumonic plague and infection in health care workers are all very worrisome.\n\nDate / Cases / Deaths\n14 Sep 2017 / 28 / 5\n30 Sep 2017 / 73 / 17\n3 Oct 2017 / 194 / 30\n5 Oct 2017 / 258 / 36\n7 Oct 2017 / 343 / 42\n8 Oct 2017 / 387 / 45. - Mod.LL\n\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/181.]", "summary": "Sep 2017 / 73 / 17\n3 Oct 2017 / 194 / 30\n5 Oct 2017 / 258 / 36\n7 Oct 2017 / 343 / 42\n8 Oct 2017 / 387 / 45. - Mod. According to Today in Seychelles, a Seychellois basketball coach died from the disease in September 2017 in a hospital in Antananarivo, the capital of Madagascar, where 42 people have died from the 'Black Death.'\n\nThe coach was assisting the Seychelles men's reigning champion of the Beau Vallon Heat in Madagascar during the Indian Ocean Club Championship. The government of Madagascar over the weekend [7-8 Oct 2017] confirmed that the death was due to the pneumonic plague. The other members of the Seychellois basketball delegation, who were in close contact with [the coach], have been under observation since they returned to the country, [Jude Gedeon, Seychelles' public health commissioner] said. They are now at the military academy at Perseverance, a reclaimed island on the outskirts of Victoria.\n\nAccording to the Seychelles News Agency, the Seychelles' Ministry of Health on [Wed 3 Oct 2017] advised all airlines and travel agents to discourage people from traveling to Madagascar due to the plague outbreak. Additional health measures at Seychelles' main airport have also been put in place.\n\nGedeon said that officials have put in place walk-through and temperature scanners at the international airport to detect cases. A form is also being given to disembarked passengers to state if they have any symptoms similar to those brought on by the plague. Additionally, as a precaution, all schools in Seychelles are closed for the next 6 days as it is not yet confirmed that contact was made with any of the teachers.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This report claims that 3 individuals in the Seychelles have tested positive for _Yersinia pestis_. Yesterday's posting (Plague - Seychelles: ex Madagascar, RFI 20171010.5371382) reported on an imported case of plague (from Madagascar) as well as an ill contact. It is not clear if the contact had been in Madagascar.\n\nProMED would appreciate more information in this regard. The Seychelles Ministry of Health has denied that other cases existed on its Facebook page (https://www.facebook.com/mohseychellesofficial/posts/747073488827118). The Ministry of Health did confirm that the case imported from Madagascar was pneumonic plague.\n\nSeychelles, officially the Republic of Seychelles, is an archipelago and country in the Indian Ocean. The 115-island country, whose capital is Victoria, lies 1500 km (approx 932 mi) east of mainland East Africa. Other nearby island countries and territories include Comoros, Mayotte (region of France), Madagascar, R\u00e9union (region of France), and Mauritius to the south. With a population of roughly 94 228, it has the smallest population of any sovereign African country.\n\nA map showing the location of Seychelles and Madagascar can be seen at http://i.huffpost.com/gen/276402/SEYCHELLES-MAP.jpg. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/183.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Source: eTurbo News [edited]\nhttps://eturbonews.com/167377/plague-spreading-madagascar-seychelles\n\n\nHealth officials in Seychelles have confirmed that 3 people have tested positive for plague. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< According to the Seychelles News Agency, the Seychelles' Ministry of Health on [Wed 3 Oct 2017] advised all airlines and travel agents to discourage people from traveling to Madagascar due to the plague outbreak. Yesterday's posting (Plague - Seychelles: ex Madagascar, RFI 20171010.5371382) reported on an imported case of plague (from Madagascar) as well as an ill contact. \n\nGedeon said that officials have put in place walk-through and temperature scanners at the international airport to detect cases. The other members of the Seychellois basketball delegation, who were in close contact with [the coach], have been under observation since they returned to the country, [Jude Gedeon, Seychelles' public health commissioner] said. \n\n--\n According to Today in Seychelles, a Seychellois basketball coach died from the disease in September 2017 in a hospital in Antananarivo, the capital of Madagascar, where 42 people have died from the 'Black Death.'", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2017-09-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Victoria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Republic of Seychelles", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Seychelles", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "East Africa", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5371382", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Seychelles: ex Madagascar, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5371382", "date": "2017-10-10 17:56:43", "main_text": "PLAGUE - SEYCHELLES: ex MADAGASCAR, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n***********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Tue 10 Oct 2017\nSource: Seychelles Ministry of Health, Facebook post [edited]\nhttps://www.facebook.com/mohseychellesofficial/posts/747073488827118\n\n\nMan tests positive for plague following presentation of symptoms\n----------------------------------------------------------------\nIn interview today [Tue 10 Oct 2017], Dr Jude Gedeon, Public Health Commissioner confirmed that a 34 year old man has been infected with the plague. The man who traveled to Madagascar, arrived in Seychelles on [Fri 6 Oct 2017], at which point he was placed under passive surveillance.\n\n'He presented with symptoms yesterday, [Mon 9 Oct 2017]. He was not feeling well and reported to a health center. Because he was under surveillance, he was immediately put in isolation at the Seychelles Hospital,' Dr Gedeon said. Several tests were done, some of which had normal results. 'We also conducted a rapid plague test which produced a weakly positive result,' Dr Gedeon added. Following this, the result was sent to L'institut Pasteur in France for cross-checking, at which point it was confirmed to be a positive plague result.\n\nThe man has been immediately given antimicrobial treatment and all people who came into direct contact with him have also been put under active surveillance. These include his partner who also presented with symptoms today [Tue 10 Oct 2017], but has not been confirmed to be infected, and a child who resides with them.\n\nDr Gedeon has reassured that there is no reason to panic and that the Public Health Authority is continuing to enforce measures to prevent an outbreak within the country. 'We continue to monitor passengers who enter the country from Madagascar. There are currently 42 people who are under passive surveillance,' he stated. Moreover, 15 people who have been identified to have come into contact with the man have also been put on antimicrobial treatment to prevent infection.\n\n'Plague can easily be treated with antimicrobials when detected early. And, our objective is to have early diagnosis and identification of points of contact, so we can administer treatment early,' Dr Gedeon further added with regards to strategies being implemented by the Ministry of Health.\n\nAt the moment, Air Seychelles has cancelled all flights to and from Madagascar as a further preventative measure. All members of the basketball delegation who were put under active surveillance at a center have also been discharged following no presentation of symptoms.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue 10 Oct 2017\nSource: Seychelles Ministry of Health, Facebook post [edited]\nhttps://www.facebook.com/pg/mohseychellesofficial/posts/?ref=page_internal\n\n\nNew isolation unit setup as additional measure to deal with plague\n------------------------------------------------------------------\nDr Danny Louange, CEO of Health Care Agency, has confirmed that a new isolation unit is being setup at the Seychelles Hospital. He said this during an interview with the media today [Tue 10 Oct 2017]. The new unit will be temporarily located on the 2nd floor of the Seychelles Hospital on Hermitte Ward. The Hermitte Ward is being moved to the antenatal ward. Thus, the 2 maternity wards will be merged until further notice.\n\nThis measure is being taken by the Ministry of Health in the event that more cases of plague are diagnosed. 'We need to provide a facility for patients who will be put under isolation and the best place to properly do this is Hermitte Ward,' Dr Louange explained. 'The unit requires 2 separate sections and Hermitte ward already allows for this to be done. In addition it has 2 different doorways.' This will permit staff to have different entrances based on their stations.\n\nIt is important that people with symptoms of plague are put in the correct environment. They need to be in a facility where they can get the right care and treatment. Dr Louange reassures the public that the Health Care Agency has enough resources to treat patients in case of more plague diagnosis.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The manifestations of plague in this case exported to Seychelles are not reported and ProMED would like more information in this regard.\n\n_Yersinia pestis_, the etiological agent of human plague, is transmitted from person-to-person via the respiratory route from a patient with plague pneumonia. Primary pneumonic plague arises as a result of inhalation of plague bacilli in infectious aerosols, such as would be produced when there are 2ary pneumonic complications in bubonic/septicemic plague.\n\nPrimary plague pneumonia has a short incubation period of 1-3 days, after which there is sudden onset of flu-like symptoms including fever, chills, headache, generalized body pains, weakness and chest discomfort. A cough develops with sputum production, which may be bloody, and increasing chest pain and difficulty in breathing. As the disease progresses, hypoxia (low oxygen concentration in the blood) and hemoptysis (coughing up blood) are prominent. The disease is invariably fatal unless antimicrobial therapy commences within 24 hours of onset of symptoms.\n\nPatients with primary pneumonic plague generate large quantities of infectious aerosols that pose a significant risk to close contacts. CDC guidelines identify contacts within 2 meters [6.6 feet] as being at greatest risk and do not consider the organism likely to be carried through air ducts or vents. Persons who have been in contact with pneumonic plague patients or handling potentially infectious body fluids or tissues without appropriate protection should receive preventive antimicrobial therapy. The preferred antimicrobial agents for prophylaxis are tetracyclines, quinolones, or chloramphenicol.\n\nSeychelles, officially the Republic of Seychelles, is an archipelago and country in the Indian Ocean. The 115-island country, whose capital is Victoria, lies 1500 km (approx 932 mi) east of mainland East Africa. Other nearby island countries and territories include Comoros, Mayotte (region of France), Madagascar, R\u00e9union (region of France) and Mauritius to the south. With a population of roughly 94 228, it has the smallest population of any sovereign African country. Its location can be found on a map at: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seychelles. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/181.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n Source: Seychelles Ministry of Health, Facebook post [edited]\nhttps://www.facebook.com/pg/mohseychellesofficial/posts/?ref=page_internal\n\n\nNew isolation unit setup as additional measure to deal with plague\n Primary pneumonic plague arises as a result of inhalation of plague bacilli in infectious aerosols, such as would be produced when there are 2ary pneumonic complications in bubonic/septicemic plague. \n\nPrimary plague pneumonia has a short incubation period of 1-3 days, after which there is sudden onset of flu-like symptoms including fever, chills, headache, generalized body pains, weakness and chest discomfort. https://www.facebook.com/mohseychellesofficial/posts/747073488827118\n\n\nMan tests positive for plague following presentation of symptoms\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nThe man has been immediately given antimicrobial treatment and all people who came into direct contact with him have also been put under active surveillance. \n\nIt is important that people with symptoms of plague are put in the correct environment. Date: Tue 10 Oct 2017\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "East Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Victoria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Republic of Seychelles", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "seychelle", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5375932", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Madagascar (17): South Africa (ex Madagascar) RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5375932", "date": "2017-10-12 12:46:43", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (17): SOUTH AFRICA (EX MADAGASCAR) REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n******************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] Madagascar: new case numbers\n[2] South Africa ex Madagascar\n[3] Antimicrobial susceptibility question\n\n******\n[1] Madagascar: new case numbers\nDate: Wed 11 Oct 2017\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/madagascar-plague-outbreak-case-count-reaches-500/\n\n\nIn a follow-up on the Madagascar plague outbreak, the [Ministry of Public Health] reported an additional 51 news plague cases today, 11 Oct 2017, bringing the total cases since August 2017 to 500. On 11 Oct 2017, 29 new pneumonic plague cases were reported, while and additional 12 bubonic plague cases were reported. 10 suspect cases were also recorded. In addition, 6 additional deaths have been reported, bringing the total to 54. The capital city of Antananarivo saw an additional 37 cases, mostly pneumonic, and 4 deaths.\n\nIn a message from Minister of Communication and Relations with the Institutions, Harry Laurent Rahajason writes:\n'This epidemic is our common enemy, we must defeat it. Immediately, the government mobilized all means of response. We worked in close cooperation with the World Health Organization, as well as multiple partners, international organizations and countries. The Malagasy specialists in epidemiology and those of the Institut Pasteur are actively present in support of the Crisis Staff. The national plan of action against plague has been adapted to the present situation, with the support of national and international partners.\n\nFirst, we pay close attention to inpatients, and protect persons who have come into contact with them. In the affected areas, our teams are on the ground 24 hours a day. Secondly, teams of international experts and doctors have been on the ground for several days and more are expected. We have also strengthened airport controls. In order to protect our children, and in order not to expose them to allergies following the disinfection of the buildings, the return to school is postponed by one week on 16 Oct 2017.\n\nWe have temporarily suspended gatherings to the general public in places where the traceability of the participants is difficult if not impossible (stadiums, sports palaces, gymnasiums ...).\n\nThe most important is to present yourself to the health services if you have symptoms such as sudden onset of fever, headache, cough, difficulty breathing, or sputum with some blood. The health services will take care of you immediately and apply the appropriate treatment.'\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The rapid rise of cases of _Yersinia pestis_ infection with a predominance of pneumonic plague is quite worrisome.\n\nDate / Cases / Deaths\n---------------------\n14 Sep 2017 / 28 / 5\n30 Sep 2017 / 73 / 17\n3 Oct 2017 / 194 / 30\n5 Oct 2017 / 258 / 36\n7 Oct 2017 / 343 / 42\n8 Oct 2017 / 387 / 45\n9 Oct 2017 / 449 / 48\n10 Oct 2017 / 500 / 54\n\nIt is frightening to monitor substantial outbreaks of infectious diseases in 2017. Although the specter of emerging zoonoses such as influenza H7N9 is worrisome (the pandemic clock is ticking, we just do not know what time it is), this year some of the old favorites are back on the front page:\n\n- Plague in Madagascar with urban cases and a predominance of pneumonic involvement with large numbers relatively early in plague season on the island and at least one case exported to Seychelles and one to South Africa;\n\n- Cholera in horrific numbers in Yemen, already in almost 6 months approaching 6 years of cases in Haiti, occurring in not just drought or flooding but in the midst of overt military conflict;\n\n- Hepatitis A in the USA, in southern California and eastern Michigan, occurring in substantial numbers not related to a contamination food but rather a product of unsanitary living conditions in homeless and illicit drug user population.\n\nWith global warming and climate change, continued warfare throughout the world, and the widening societal gaps in both the 1st and 3rd worlds, those of us involved in both public health and Public Health must remain ever vigilant to adapt our roles and change our paradigms to deal with these changes resulting in old and new pathogens. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/181.]\n\n******\n[2] South Africa ex Madagascar\nDate: Thu 12 Oct 2017 12:59 SAST\nSource: TimesLIVE [edited]\nhttps://goo.gl/vkvNwh\n\n\nA South African basketball player who had contracted plague in Madagascar has been successfully treated. The player has returned to South Africa and the National Institute for Communicable Diseases (NICD) on Thu 12 Oct 2017, issued a statement saying the player does not pose any health risk. Details about the player and the team have not been established yet by TimesLIVE but the NICD is in contact with the group and has mentioned that it will follow up on them.\n\nThe NICD warned South Africans traveling to Madagascar to be highly cautious of their surroundings as the country is experiencing an outbreak.\n\nAccording to the NICD statement\u201a the number of reported cases is 449 and 48 deaths have been recorded so far [now 500 cases and 54 deaths]. 'The outbreak is primarily located in the middle 1/3 of the island\u201a centred around the capital\u201a Antananarivo and Toamasina province on the east coast. A single area on the northern coast is affected. The majority of cases are presenting as pneumonic plague\u201a' reads the statement.\n\nThe NICD said plague is a zoonotic disease caused by a bacterium _Yersinia pestis_. Where plague is endemic\u201a it is usually found in rodents and is spread by fleas from rodent or to other mammals. 'South African travelers to Madagascar are advised to avoid highly populated areas\u201a avoid close contact with ill persons\u201a wear surgical masks while in transit\u201a avoid contact with rodents and dead animals\u201a' said the NICD statement.\n\n[Byline: Bafana Nzimande]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is the 1st report regarding the case of plague exported to South Africa from Madagascar. It is not stated what form of plague the individual had but like the fatal case in a Seychelles man who died in Madagascar, this case was related to the basketball tournament held in Madagascar. It has not been stated that the Seychelles pneumonic plague case imported from Madagascar was related to the same tournament. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/179.]\n\n******\n[3] Antimicrobial susceptibility question\nDate: Wed 11 Oct 2017\nFrom: Allen Lenoir <alenoir165@aol.com> [edited]\n\n\nWhat is known of the antimicrobial susceptibility profile of the organisms isolate in this outbreak? I recall a report many years ago of a strain isolated in Madagascar that was only sensitive to trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.\n\n--\nAllen Lenoir, MD\nMiami, FL\nUSA\n<alenoir165@aol.com>\n\n[Indeed, as Dr Lenoir points out, Madagascar was the location of the isolation of multi-antimicrobial resistant _Y. pestis_ in 1995 (Galimand M, Guiyoule A, Gerbaud G, et al: Multidrug resistance in _Yersinia pestis_ mediated by a transferable plasmid. N Engl J Med. 1997;337(10):677-80, PMID: 9278464; available at http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJM199709043371004). The strain was resistant to chloramphenicol, streptomycin, and tetracycline but sensitive to fluoroquinolones and trimethoprim as well as other aminoglycosides. This was an ominous observation; however, it is not clear whether this naturally occurring strain has persisted or spread and it has not clearly been stated that the outbreak strain is anything but fully drug sensitive. ProMED would like information about the drug sensitivities of the outbreak isolates. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "Sep 2017 / 73 / 17\n3 Oct 2017 / 194 / 30\n5 Oct 2017 / 258 / 36\n7 Oct 2017 / 343 / 42\n8 Oct 2017 / 387 / 45\n9 Oct 2017 / 449 / 48\n10 Oct 2017 / 500 / 54\n\n \n\n--\nAllen Lenoir, MD\nMiami, FL\nUSA\n<alenoir165@aol.com>\n\n[Indeed, as Dr Lenoir points out, Madagascar was the location of the isolation of multi-antimicrobial resistant _Y. pestis_ in 1995 (Galimand M, Guiyoule A, Gerbaud G, et al: Multidrug resistance in _Yersinia pestis_ mediated by a transferable plasmid. Although the specter of emerging zoonoses such as influenza H7N9 is worrisome (the pandemic clock is ticking, we just do not know what time it is), this year some of the old favorites are back on the front page:\n\n- Plague in Madagascar with urban cases and a predominance of pneumonic involvement with large numbers relatively early in plague season on the island and at least one case exported to Seychelles and one to South Africa;\n\n- Cholera in horrific numbers in Yemen, already in almost 6 months approaching 6 years of cases in Haiti, occurring in not just drought or flooding but in the midst of overt military conflict;\n\n- Hepatitis A in the USA, in southern California and eastern Michigan, occurring in substantial numbers not related to a contamination food but rather a product of unsanitary living conditions in homeless and illicit drug user population.
