The bacterium is not native to North America.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5251542", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (13): (AZ) bubonic, infected fleas, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5251542", "date": "2017-08-15 12:41:12", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (13): (ARIZONA) BUBONIC, INFECTED FLEAS, ALERT\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 11 Aug 2017\nSource: Arizona Daily Sun [edited]\nhttp://azdailysun.com/news/local/plague-found-in-doney-park-fleas/article_7dfd6c7b-5878-5da5-afd4-40890956abb7.html\n\n\nCoconino County Public Health Services District (CCPHSD) officials confirmed that fleas collected in the Doney Park area, northeast of Flagstaff, have tested positive for plague (_Yersinia pestis_).\n\nLast week, fleas collected in the Red Lake area, approximately 5 miles northeast of Williams, tested positive for plague. The tests were conducted by the Center for Pathogen and Microbiome Institute at Northern Arizona University.\n\nCCPHSD is notifying area residents, and the rodent burrows, which are located on private property, will be treated. The area will be closely monitored to determine whether further action is required.\n\nBecause the disease is endemic in Coconino County, there are likely additional locations with infected fleas. CCPHSD Environmental Health staff will continue to collect and test flea samples from locations throughout the county.\n\nCCPHSD is urging the public to take precautions to reduce their risk of exposure to this serious disease, which can be present in fleas, rodents, rabbits and predators that feed upon these animals. The disease can be transmitted to humans and other animals by the bite of an infected flea or by direct contact with an infected animal. To limit possible exposure, people are encouraged to avoid rodent burrows and keep dogs on a leash as required by Arizona State law.\n\nAn abundance of active prairie dogs doesn't indicate disease is present. However, a sudden die-off of prairie dogs and rodents may be an indicator of plague. Persons noticing a sudden die-off of rodents or rabbits are urged to contact CCPHSD Environmental Services at 679-8750.\n\nSymptoms of plague in humans generally appear within 2 to 6 days following exposure and include the following: fever, chills, headache, weakness, muscle pain, and swollen lymph glands (called 'buboes') in the groin, armpits or limbs. The disease can become septicemic (spreading throughout the bloodstream) and/or pneumonic (affecting the lungs) but is curable with proper antibiotic therapy if diagnosed and treated early.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations. Surveillance efforts testing fleas are very important to detect circulation of _Y. pestis_ and risk of infection. - Mod.PMB\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/207.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. \n\nCCPHSD is urging the public to take precautions to reduce their risk of exposure to this serious disease, which can be present in fleas, rodents, rabbits and predators that feed upon these animals. \n\nSymptoms of plague in humans generally appear within 2 to 6 days following exposure and include the following: fever, chills, headache, weakness, muscle pain, and swollen lymph glands (called 'buboes') in the groin, armpits or limbs. PLAGUE - USA (13): (ARIZONA) BUBONIC, INFECTED FLEAS, ALERT\n*******************************************************************\n \n\nLast week, fleas collected in the Red Lake area, approximately 5 miles northeast of Williams, tested positive for plague. http://azdailysun.com/news/local/plague-found-in-doney-park-fleas/article_7dfd6c7b-5878-5da5-afd4-40890956abb7.html\n\n\nCoconino County Public Health Services District (CCPHSD) officials confirmed that fleas collected in the Doney Park area, northeast of Flagstaff, have tested positive for plague (_Yersinia pestis_). \n\nBecause the disease is endemic in Coconino County, there are likely additional locations with infected fleas.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Coconino County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ARIZONA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5313580", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Iraq: (Baghdad) MOH, denied, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5313580", "date": "2017-09-13 13:45:01", "main_text": "PLAGUE - IRAQ: (BAGHDAD) MINISTRY OF HEALTH, DENIED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n****************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 12 Sep 2017\nSource: Alghad Press [in Arabic, trans. Mod.NS, edited]\nhttp://bit.ly/2fgiCKH\n\n\nThe Ministry of Health denied on [Tue 12 Sep 2017] what has been circulated in some social media sites and other media sources about the occurrence of plague cases. The spokesman for the Ministry of Health, Saif Al-Bader, said in a statement that 'after communicating with the relevant authorities and departments, it has been found that no deaths due to plague have occurred.' He indicated that 'this disease was eliminated from Iraq a long time ago and the health departments, whether in Baghdad or the other governorates, have not registered any cases in the whole country.'\n\n'The Ministry of Health is carrying out intensive campaigns to combat vectors of diseases, under the supervision and follow-up of the Communicable Diseases Control Center,' Al-Bader added.\n\nThe director of the Communicable Diseases Control Center, Sabah Abdul-A'ayma, said that 'the center continues to supervise all the teams from the different units of the center that are involved in the ongoing campaigns to fight disease carriers, especially in the areas that were mentioned in the rumors such as Al-Rusafa, Al-Saadoun, and Al-Batawin.'\n\nAbdul-A'ayma added that 'the last campaign was carried out today [Tue 12 Sep 2017] as a team from the Communicable Diseases Control Center conducted an intensive rodent control campaign in the area of Al-Batawin, through the distribution of toxic baits and carrying out fumigation of rodent burrows in the region.'\n\nAbdul-A'ayma stressed that 'these measures taken by the Communicable Diseases Control Center are aimed to reduce the spread of rodents, which are hard to control due to rapid reproduction as well as the presence of a poor environment from the accumulation of wastes and sewage that contributes to the spread of rodents.'\n\nAl-Bader pointed out that 'the ministry calls on people not to believe these rumors that are aimed at spreading panic in society.' He called on the media to adhere to the scientific standards and accuracy in the dissemination of any information affecting the health of the country, without reference to specialists particularly under the circumstances of the country's fight against terrorism.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-MENA\n<promed-mena@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED would appreciate more information regarding whether plague cases have occurred in Iraq. If plague is present there, a program to eradicate rodents alone will not be effective in preventing human cases as the infected flea vector will seek other blood sources such as humans.\n\nThis publication regarding the history of _Y. pestis_ in Iran also reviews the history of plague in other countries in the Middle East including Iraq:\n\nHashemi Shahraki A, Carniel E, Mostafavi E: Plague in Iran: its history and current status. Epidemiol Health. 2016 Jul 24; 38: e2016033; available at https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5037359/\n\n'Throughout its history, Iraq has experienced multiple epidemics of plague. In 716 and 717 CE, a large outbreak known as al-Ashraf (the Notables) was recorded in Iraq and Syria. In an epidemic of bubonic plague in 1772 and 1773, many victims died in cities such as Basra (with 250 000 deaths) and Mosul. In 1801 CE, a large plague epidemic occurred in Mosul and Baghdad. A plague epidemic occurred again in Baghdad in 1908. From 1923 to 1924, approximately 90 cases of pneumonic plague were reported in Baghdad, and some plague outbreaks were reported in Basra.' - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/89.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-MENA\n<promed-mena@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED would appreciate more information regarding whether plague cases have occurred in Iraq. \n\nThis publication regarding the history of _Y. pestis_ in Iran also reviews the history of plague in other countries in the Middle East including Iraq:\n\nHashemi Shahraki A, Carniel E, Mostafavi E: \n\nThe director of the Communicable Diseases Control Center, Sabah Abdul-A'ayma, said that 'the center continues to supervise all the teams from the different units of the center that are involved in the ongoing campaigns to fight disease carriers, especially in the areas that were mentioned in the rumors such as Al-Rusafa, Al-Saadoun, and Al-Batawin.' \n\nAbdul-A'ayma stressed that 'these measures taken by the Communicable Diseases Control Center are aimed to reduce the spread of rodents, which are hard to control due to rapid reproduction as well as the presence of a poor environment from the accumulation of wastes and sewage that contributes to the spread of rodents.' The Ministry of Health denied on [Tue 12 Sep 2017] what has been circulated in some social media sites and other media sources about the occurrence of plague cases. From 1923 to 1924, approximately 90 cases of pneumonic plague were reported in Baghdad, and some plague outbreaks were reported in Basra.' If plague is present there, a program to eradicate rodents alone will not be effective in preventing human cases as the infected flea vector will seek other blood sources such as humans. \n\n'The Ministry of Health is carrying out intensive campaigns to combat vectors of diseases, under the supervision and follow-up of the Communicable Diseases Control Center,' Al-Bader added. Jul 24; 38: e2016033; available at https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5037359/\n\n'Throughout its history, Iraq has experienced multiple epidemics of plague.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1908-03-25 00:00:00", "1772-03-25 00:00:00", "1801-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "1773-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Baghdad", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mosul", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Syria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iraq", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "IRAQ", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Basra", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iran", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "BAGHDAD", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5311663", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Madagascar (03): fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5311663", "date": "2017-09-12 22:08:03", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (03): FATAL\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 12 Sep 2017, 8:36 AM\nSource: L'Express Madagascar [in French, machine trans., edited]\nhttp://www.lexpressmada.com/blog/actualites/epidemie-la-peste-refait-surface/\n\n\nAround 5 pm yesterday [Mon 11 Sep 2017], a 40 year old woman suspected to have died from pneumonic plague, according to a source within the (BMH), was buried at the cemetery of Anjanahary. She died at the Respiratory Diseases Service of the hospital in Antananarivo-city, after being admitted on [ Sun 10 Sep 2017], according to concordant sources.\n\nThe victim had contracted the disease during a holiday in the east of the Big Island. 'She was staying with her family in Toamasina, when 4 of the family, including the husband and wife, died suddenly. It was suspected plague,' reported a relative.\n\nThe eastern part of the island is, however, not a plague area. It is feared that those deaths are connected to that of a person who came from Moramanga and was traveling in Toamasina. Sources reveal that the latter would have joined Toamasina by bush taxi, starting from Moramanga, following a suspected pneumonic plague outbreak. It is believed that a young man sitting next to him in the public transport was then infected, and also died.\n\nAsked about these facts, the responsible service of the fight against the plague in the Ministry of Public Health at the hospital, preferred to remain silent. The same happened with the director of health surveillance and epidemiological surveillance of the Ministry, who is currently on a mission to Toamasina\n\nAnother source in the ministry who would urge everyone to take precautions against these suspected cases of plague, revealed the existence of 5 suspicious deaths and 10 patients since the beginning of the plague season. They were listed in Toamasina, Moramanga and Miarinarivo excluding that recorded in Antananarivo. She also stressed that members of the family of the deceased in Toamasina would have already returned home to Mahajanga and Voh\u00e9mar.\n\nHowever, there is no risk of transmission of the disease to those who have been in contact with the victim. The team of the Ministry of Public Health and of the BMH had been rushed to the hospital to distribute plague prevention drugs to his family and relatives and the hospital staff. They have also conducted a service disinfection operation where the deceased was admitted and the mortuary. Despite this, consulting a doctor is highly recommended in case of suspicious symptoms, namely high fever, painful glands, cough with bloody sputum. Bush fires are to be avoided and the sanitation of the neighborhoods is indicated, to prevent the rats from entering in the village.\n\n[Byline: Miangaly Ralitera]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The exact circumstances regarding the etiology of these deaths and the epidemiology of transmission are not entirely clear. ProMED would like more information about this reported outbreak of pneumonic plague, the only form of human _Yersinia pestis_ infection that transmits from person-to-person. The ProMED report from January 2017 (Plague - Madagascar: fatalities 20170110.4754927) also reported cases of plague in the east of the island, also in an non-endemic area for plague.\n\nThe following paragraph of this posting is from Chanteau S, Ratsifasoamanana L, Rasoamanana B, et al: Plague, a Reemerging Disease in Madagascar. Emerg Infect Dis 1998;4: 101-4. Available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2627662/pdf/9452403.pdf:\n\nBetween 1930 and 1990, bubonic plague had 'virtually disappeared' on the island due to efficient pest-control and good health-management. However since 1990, an annual 200 cases are being reported and bubonic plague takes on epidemic form especially in the port of Mahajanga each year. In the capital city of Antananarivo more cases are also being notified each year since 1990. Madagascar (pop. 13 million) [pop. 22.92 million, 2013] has accounted for 45 percent of all the cases of plague in Africa.\n\nFatalities related to plague usually are caused by spread of the organism from the bubo (the very painful infected lymph node which drains the area where the flea bite occurred) to the bloodstream. The bacteremia can cause a coagulopathy producing the purpura seen in the 'Black Plague' and also spread to the lung causing a hemorrhagic pneumonia that can facilitate person-to-person transmission. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/181.]", "summary": "The same happened with the director of health surveillance and epidemiological surveillance of the Ministry, who is currently on a mission to Toamasina\n\nAnother source in the ministry who would urge everyone to take precautions against these suspected cases of plague, revealed the existence of 5 suspicious deaths and 10 patients since the beginning of the plague season. The ProMED report from January 2017 (Plague - Madagascar: fatalities 20170110.4754927) also reported cases of plague in the east of the island, also in an non-endemic area for plague. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2627662/pdf/9452403.pdf:\n\nBetween 1930 and 1990, bubonic plague had 'virtually disappeared' on the island due to efficient pest-control and good health-management. [Mon 11 Sep 2017], a 40 year old woman suspected to have died from pneumonic plague, according to a source within the (BMH), was buried at the cemetery of Anjanahary. ProMED would like more information about this reported outbreak of pneumonic plague, the only form of human _Yersinia pestis_ infection that transmits from person-to-person. The bacteremia can cause a coagulopathy producing the purpura seen in the 'Black Plague' and also spread to the lung causing a hemorrhagic pneumonia that can facilitate person-to-person transmission. However since 1990, an annual 200 cases are being reported and bubonic plague takes on epidemic form especially in the port of Mahajanga each year. It is caused by a fungus _Aphanomyces astaci_ that was brought into Europe by the introduction of _Procambarus clarkii_, a freshwater crayfish species of Lousiana, USA, which is naturally infected by this pathogen, although it does not develop clinical disease.\n\nFor a picture of a white-clawed crayfish go to "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5194895", "date": "2017-07-21 17:16:19", "main_text": "PLAGUE - CANADA: (SASKATCHEWAN) PRAIRIE DOGS, SUSPECTED\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 20 Jul 2017\nSource: Regina Leader-Post [edited]\nhttp://leaderpost.com/news/local-news/prairie-dog-dies-from-sylvatic-plague-at-grasslands-national-park\n\n\nThe Broken Hills prairie dog colony at Grasslands National Park is being closed off to visitors after a prairie dog recently died from sylvatic plague. The park is located just outside of Val Marie in southwest Saskatchewan. Two dead ground squirrels were also discovered and have been sent for testing.\n\nSylvatic plague is a rare, but naturally occurring disease that affects wildlife in the region. Sylvatic plague is in the same bacterium that causes bubonic and pneumonic plague in humans [_Yersinia pestis_], but it poses very low risk to human health. It is extremely rare for humans to contract the disease. The last confirmed case of human infection in Canada was in 1939 and was not fatal.\n\n'The safety of visitors and staff is Parks Canada's top priority. Grasslands National Park is collaborating with the appropriate provincial and federal government agencies to address this situation and ensure public safety,' said a press release issued by Parks Canada.\n\nParks Canada staff are dusting burrows in the Broken Hills colony with the insecticide DeltaDust (deltamethrin) to mitigate the potential spread of the disease. The insecticide kills fleas that could carry the sylvatic plague. Parks Canada says it will be closely monitoring the prairie dog population and conduct further disease surveillance within the park.\n\nThe park itself will remain open. Other prairie dog colonies in the park are still accessible.\n\nSince 2010, all prairie dog colonies in the Grasslands National park have been closed to domestic animals to prevent the possibility of pets carrying infected fleas back to their owners.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Grasslands National Park is in SW Saskatchewan and close to the border with the US: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grasslands_National_Park. Check out Val Marie, SK, on the FallingGrain map: http://www.fallingrain.com/world/CA/11/Val_Marie.html\n\nThe 2010 outbreak in the park was at the Larsen colony. Presumably the Broken Hills colony was _Yersinia pestis_ naive and when the infection found its way there, it found a ready home and announced itself with significant prairie dog deaths, though its presence has yet to be confirmed. We look forward to the results of the park surveillance.\n\nNormally prairie dog sylvatic plague presents few risks to humans but if you see a dead prairie dog do not pick it up, keep your dog well away from it. As we know from affected states in the US cats can bring the fleas into the house so make sure that your cats have regular flea medicine to prevent any infestation. Plague is not called the 'black death' for nothing. It is not a fun disease though it responds well to antibiotics. - Mod.MHJ\n\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/262.]", "summary": "\n\nNormally prairie dog sylvatic plague presents few risks to humans but if you see a dead prairie dog do not pick it up, keep your dog well away from it. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The Broken Hills prairie dog colony at Grasslands National Park is being closed off to visitors after a prairie dog recently died from sylvatic plague. Since 2010, all prairie dog colonies in the Grasslands National park have been closed to domestic animals to prevent the possibility of pets carrying infected fleas back to their owners. Presumably the Broken Hills colony was _Yersinia pestis_ naive and when the infection found its way there, it found a ready home and announced itself with significant prairie dog deaths, though its presence has yet to be confirmed. PLAGUE - CANADA: (SASKATCHEWAN) PRAIRIE DOGS, SUSPECTED\n*******************************************************\n Parks Canada says it will be closely monitoring the prairie dog population and conduct further disease surveillance within the park. \n\nSylvatic plague is a rare, but naturally occurring disease that affects wildlife in the region. Sylvatic plague is in the same bacterium that causes bubonic and pneumonic plague in humans [_Yersinia pestis_], but it poses very low risk to human health. \n\nParks Canada staff are dusting burrows in the Broken Hills colony with the insecticide DeltaDust (deltamethrin) to mitigate the potential spread of the disease.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-25 00:00:00", "1939-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the Broken Hills", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Broken Hills", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "colony", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5150405", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (09): (TX) prairie dog, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5150405", "date": "2017-07-04 19:56:26", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (09): (TEXAS) PRAIRIE DOG, ALERT\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 3 Jul 2017\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/texas-plague-confirmed-muleshoe-national-wildlife-refuge-44802/\n\n\nMuleshoe National Wildlife Refuge near Muleshoe, Texas, is informing the public that plague has been confirmed on the Refuge and is currently confined to 2 populations of prairie dogs. For public safety, Paul's Lake and the access road to the lake are temporarily closed to all public access.\n\nPlague is widespread across the western United States and outbreaks are fairly common. Caused by a bacterium called _Yersinia pestis_, plague can be transmitted from animal to animal and from animal to human by the bites of infective fleas.\n\n'To protect our visitors, we have voluntarily closed the area where plague has been found. It is well marked and we are asking the public to respect all signs and closures for their own safety,' stated Refuge Manager Jude Smith. 'We understand this closure may be an inconvenience to our visitors, however we expect this outbreak to pass fairly soon.'\n\nThe Refuge is safe to visit and continues to welcome visitors. There are additional ways the public can protect themselves and their pets:\n- Keep pets leashed and use flea powder or a flea collar.\n- People should avoid animals with fleas and not camp or rest near animal burrows. - Do not touch wild, sick, or dead animals.\n- Wear insect repellant when outdoors.\n\nPlague is rare, but can be a serious disease if contracted by humans.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_ which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations, with prairie dogs one of the main species contributing to its maintenance. Humans are at risk of becoming infected if they are exposed to rodent fleas. - Mod.PMB\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/245.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. PLAGUE - USA (09): (TEXAS) PRAIRIE DOG, ALERT\n*********************************************\n There are additional ways the public can protect themselves and their pets:\n- Keep pets leashed and use flea powder or a flea collar. Caused by a bacterium called _Yersinia pestis_, plague can be transmitted from animal to animal and from animal to human by the bites of infective fleas. \n- People should avoid animals with fleas and not camp or rest near animal burrows. \n\n--\n For public safety, Paul's Lake and the access road to the lake are temporarily closed to all public access.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-09 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "TEXAS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Muleshoe", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5233248", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (11): (AZ) bubonic, prairie dog, die-off", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5233248", "date": "2017-08-07 12:26:07", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (11): (ARIZONA) BUBONIC, PRAIRIE DOG, DIE-OFF\n******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 4 Aug 2017\nSource: White Mountain Independent [edited]\nhttp://www.wmicentral.com/news/apache_county/report-bubonic-plague-in-prairie-dogs-spreads-to-old-concho/article_82afccd4-ad86-5cce-8109-c578ed0f40d0.html\n\n\nThe Apache County [Arizona] Health Department recently notified the public about a new prairie dog die-off in Concho. A previous die-off was reported in early July [2017].\n\nA notice posted on the Apache County website states: 'The Health Department has received an additional report of another prairie dog die-off in Old Concho.'\n\nThe notice bluntly states that 'Old Concho is now considered a plague-positive area.' The die-off occurred earlier in July [2017].\n\nFleas, and the rodents they commonly live on and feed off of, act as hosts for the life cycle of the bubonic plague bacteria, _Yersinia pestis_. Prairie dogs are quite susceptible to the disease and die quickly. Since their hosts are dead and the fleas can no longer get a meal of blood from them, the insects abandon their hosts who die deep in their burrows. They climb up and hang out near the entrance of the burrow, hoping to catch a ride and a meal on another passing animal, usually another rodent.\n\nThe new area of infestation is on the opposite side of Highway 61 northwest from the original infestation. A map of the affected area has been posted on the Apache County website.\n\n'They both happened during the same time period. If it was the same mode of transmission, I don't know,' said Apache County Public Health Director Chris Sexton. Sexton said he could not be sure if rodents or some other type of animal is moving the fleas around Concho.\n\nThe most recent die-off occurred on vacant land in an area with a smaller number of prairie dog burrows. Sexton said it was about 300 feet [about 91.5 m] to the nearest residence. He did not say who reported the die-off.\n\nThe property where the previous prairie dog die-off occurred was recently treated for fleas. A crew from Coconino County Public Health dusted the affected burrows with an insecticide to kill any fleas that were still alive.\n\nOn [13 Jul 2017], Dr Joe Busch, a staff scientist with the Pathogen and Microbiome Institute at Northern Arizona University, took samples of fleas from burrows where the die-off occurred at the property. 10 percent of the fleas sampled tested positive for the bubonic plague bacteria.\n\nSexton said that the burrows in the area of the most recent die-off will not be dusted because the property owners cannot be reached. He said the dusting crew must have the owner's permission before entering their property. Apache County does not conduct insecticide dusting of prairie dog burrows -- they contract with Coconino County for that work. Sexton said Coconino County staffers were unable to reach the property owners. No one from Apache County has attempted to contact them, he said.\n\nSexton was not concerned about the bacteria spreading from the untreated burrows, noting that no die-offs had been reported in Concho Valley. 'If this was something highly transmissible, like measles or flu, we would take more precautions,' he said.\n\nThe US averages about 7 cases of plague in humans annually, according to the Centers for Disease Control, although the disease did cause 4 deaths in 2015. Most US cases are in Arizona and New Mexico, according to a map on the CDC website.\n\nJeff Nafziger, an environmental health specialist with Navajo County, confirmed [Tue 1 Aug 2017] that a prairie dog die-off had occurred somewhere near Taylor, but he did not give a specific location. Nafziger said the situation was under investigation and that plague bacteria had not been confirmed at that site. A crew from Northern Arizona University may take flea samples from the area for testing next week.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_ ,which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations, with prairie dogs one of the main species contributing to its maintenance. Humans and their companion animals are at risk of becoming infected if they are exposed to rodent fleas. - Mod.PMB\n\nThe state of Arizona can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62015. A county map can be seen at http://geology.com/county-map/arizona-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nSexton said that the burrows in the area of the most recent die-off will not be dusted because the property owners cannot be reached. \n\nJeff Nafziger, an environmental health specialist with Navajo County, confirmed [Tue 1 Aug 2017] that a prairie dog die-off had occurred somewhere near Taylor, but he did not give a specific location. PLAGUE - USA (11): (ARIZONA) BUBONIC, PRAIRIE DOG, DIE-OFF\n******************************************************************\n \n\nA notice posted on the Apache County website states: 'The Health Department has received an additional report of another prairie dog die-off in Old Concho.' Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. The most recent die-off occurred on vacant land in an area with a smaller number of prairie dog burrows. The property where the previous prairie dog die-off occurred was recently treated for fleas. On [13 Jul 2017], Dr Joe Busch, a staff scientist with the Pathogen and Microbiome Institute at Northern Arizona University, took samples of fleas from burrows where the die-off occurred at the property. \n\nSexton was not concerned about the bacteria spreading from the untreated burrows, noting that no die-offs had been reported in Concho Valley. ' \n\nFleas, and the rodents they commonly live on and feed off of, act as hosts for the life cycle of the bubonic plague bacteria, _ Since their hosts are dead and the fleas can no longer get a meal of blood from them, the insects abandon their hosts who die deep in their burrows. \n\nThe US averages about 7 cases of plague in humans annually, according to the Centers for Disease Control, although the disease did cause 4 deaths in 2015. \n\nThe notice bluntly states that 'Old Concho is now considered a plague-positive area.' The Apache County [Arizona] Health Department recently notified the public about a new prairie dog die-off in Concho. \n\nThe new area of infestation is on the opposite side of Highway 61 northwest from the original infestation.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-07-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Coconino County Public Health", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Navajo County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Coconino County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Concho", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ARIZONA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Apache County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Concho Valley", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5132081", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (08): (NM)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5132081", "date": "2017-06-26 22:35:42", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (08) : (NEW MEXICO)\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Mon 26 Jun 2017\nSource: New Mexico Department of Health [edited]\nhttps://nmhealth.org/news/disease/2017/6/?view=574\n\n\nThe New Mexico Department of Health (NMDOH) is reporting 2 recent confirmed plague cases in 52-year-old and 62-year-old females from Santa Fe County. With the addition of these cases, there have been 3 human plague cases from Santa Fe County in 2017. All 3 cases required hospitalization. There have been no deaths from plague in 2017.\n\nNMDOH conducted environmental investigations around the homes of the patients to look for ongoing risk and to ensure the safety of the immediate family and neighbors.\n\nPlague is a bacterial disease of rodents and is generally transmitted to humans through the bites of infected fleas, but can also be transmitted by direct contact with infected animals, including rodents, wildlife and pets. Plague can be present in fleas that infest wild rodents in Santa Fe County, including the city limits of Santa Fe, and several other New Mexico counties.\n\n'Pets that are allowed to roam and hunt can bring infected fleas from dead rodents back into the home, putting you and your children at risk,' said Dr. Paul Ettestad, public health veterinarian for the Department of Health. 'Keeping your pets at home or on a leash and using an appropriate flea control product is important to protect you and your family.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nPaul Ettestad DVM, MS\nState Public Health Veterinarian\nInfectious Disease Epidemiology Bureau\nEpidemiology and Response Division\nNew Mexico Department of Health\n<Paul.Ettestad@state.nm.us>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Mon 26 June 2017\nFrom: Paul Ettestad <Paul.Ettestad@state.nm.us> [edited]\n\n\nThese cases all come from various locations in Santa Fe County so there is no single focal point of plague activity. New Mexico has had laboratory confirmed plague cases in 5 cats and 12 dogs from various counties in North Central New Mexico (Santa Fe, Torrance, Los Alamos, Sandoval, Bernalillo, Rio Arriba, and Taos counties) so plague activity is fairly widespread in this area.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nPaul Ettestad DVM, MS\nState Public Health Veterinarian\nInfectious Disease Epidemiology Bureau\nEpidemiology and Response Division\nNew Mexico Department of Health\n<Paul.Ettestad@state.nm.us>\n\n[The manifestations of _Yersinia pestis_ infection in this case, the 2nd and 3rd for 2017, are not stated in the report but it is likely to have been bubonic plague.\n\n2015 was a 'banner year' for _Y. pestis_ infections in the USA with 15 cases and 4 deaths. In recent decades, an average of 7 human plague cases have been reported each year (range: 1-17 cases per year) with 0-2 deaths.\n\nThe following was extracted from: Prentice MB, Rahalison L. Plague. Lancet. 2007; 369(9568): 1196-207, with the citations removed:\n\n'Some plague cases (10-25 percent) present with primary septicemia (hypotension, shock) without lymph nodes being obviously affected and these patients have higher mortality than those with bubonic plague. The term septicemic plague can be confusing, since most patients with buboes have detectable bacteremia at some stage and can also have high-density bacteremia with systemic signs of sepsis. Debate about whether septicemic plague is always secondary to frank or subclinical bubonic or pneumonic disease continues, but work in mice lends support to the existence of a syndrome of septicemic disease without histological changes in lymph nodes in a few animals infected by flea bites.' - Mod.LL\n\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/233.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n New Mexico has had laboratory confirmed plague cases in 5 cats and 12 dogs from various counties in North Central New Mexico (Santa Fe, Torrance, Los Alamos, Sandoval, Bernalillo, Rio Arriba, and Taos counties) so plague activity is fairly widespread in this area.'\n\n--\n 2007; 369(9568): 1196-207, with the citations removed:\n\n'Some plague cases (10-25 percent) present with primary septicemia (hypotension, shock) without lymph nodes being obviously affected and these patients have higher mortality than those with bubonic plague. In recent decades, an average of 7 human plague cases have been reported each year (range: 1-17 cases per year) with 0-2 deaths.\n\n New Mexico Department of Health\n<Paul.Ettestad@state.nm.us>\n\n[The manifestations of _Yersinia pestis_ infection in this case, the 2nd and 3rd for 2017, are not stated in the report but it is likely to have been bubonic plague. PLAGUE - USA (08) : (NEW MEXICO)\n********************************\n New Mexico Department of Health\n<Paul.Ettestad@state.nm.us>\n\n******\n Infectious Disease Epidemiology Bureau\nEpidemiology and Response Division\n Infectious Disease Epidemiology Bureau\nEpidemiology and Response Division\n Debate about whether septicemic plague is always secondary to frank or subclinical bubonic or pneumonic disease continues, but work in mice lends support to the existence of a syndrome of septicemic disease without histological changes in lymph nodes in a few animals infected by flea bites.' - Mod. Plague is a bacterial disease of rodents and is generally transmitted to humans through the bites of infected fleas, but can also be transmitted by direct contact with infected animals, including rodents, wildlife and pets.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Torrance", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Los Alamos", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santa Fe County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5197563", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (10): (AZ,TX) bubonic, prairie dogs, fleas", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5197563", "date": "2017-07-23 09:04:18", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (10): (ARIZONA, TEXAS) BUBONIC, PRAIRIE DOGS, FLEAS\n****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] Arizona\n[2] Texas\n\n******\n[1] Arizona\nDate: Fri 21 Jul 2017\nSource: The Independent [edited]\nhttp://www.wmicentral.com/news/apache_county/bubonic-plague-found-in-concho-prairie-dogs/article_a0ac6eab-efc7-5532-9602-28484d776317.html\n\n\nBubonic plague, the disease that killed millions of people in Europe in the 1300s, is thankfully, a lot more deadly to prairie dogs and other rodents than it is to people in 2017. But [sylvatic plague is] still out there.\n\nThe bacterium that causes the disease, _Yersinia pestis,_ was found in fleas collected from prairie dog burrows earlier this month [July 2017]. The burrows are located on the south side of Highway 61, on ranch land in Concho [Apache County]. The disease caused a die-off in several prairie dog colonies in the area. [MM] was the first to notice there was something wrong with the prairie dogs. 'I watch prairie dogs from my porch when I drink my coffee in the morning,' she said, noting that she can also see their burrows from other locations on her property.\n\nIn late June and early July [2017], MM noticed the burrows were strangely silent. No prairie dogs scurrying around in the cool of the morning, barking and calling to each other. She asked her husband, who runs cow-calf pairs at a ranch, to watch other burrows on the property. He also found some of them were silent, seemingly deserted. Knowing something was amiss, MM began calling state and local agencies, trying to get someone to check it out.\n\nOn [13 Jul 2017], Dr Joe Busch, a staff scientist with the Pathogen and Microbiome Institute at Northern Arizona University [NAU], arrived in Concho with some student assistants. MM didn't know how they had heard about the problem with prairie dogs in Concho, but she was glad to see them. MM wasn't aware that her chain of telephone calls had activated a state network that includes the Arizona Department of Health Services and the Arizona Game and Fish Department.\n\nThe network, which includes county health departments, keeps an eye on plague outbreaks in the state. Northeastern Arizona's prairie dog populations are the primary hosts for the disease in the state. 'She did all the right things, she was very proactive,' Busch said in a telephone interview.\n\nBusch and his student team came to Concho to take samples of fleas from the silent burrows outside MM's home. Wearing gloves taped to their long sleeves and pants taped at the ankle, the scientists placed 4-inch square pieces of white flannel into the entrances of a number of the burrows, after breathing onto the little squares of cloth. 'The carbon dioxide from their breath is what attracts the fleas.' Busch said.\n\nWhy collect fleas? Fleas, and the rodents they commonly live on and feed off of, act as hosts for the biological lifecycle of the bacteria. 'Plague can replicate and grow in fleas,' Busch said. The infected fleas then bite the rodents they live on and infect them with plague bacteria. Prairie dogs are quite susceptible to the disease and die quickly. Since their hosts are dead and the fleas can no longer get a meal of blood from them, the insects abandon their hosts who expire deep in their burrows. They climb up and hang out near the entrance of the burrow, hoping to catch a ride and a meal on another passing animal, usually another rodent.\n\nThe team spent about 6 hours in Concho, collecting samples from different burrows. 'We might get one flea from a burrow, we might get 30 fleas,' he said. After the fleas jump onto the fabric, the students promptly placed it inside a zipper baggie, noting the GPS location of each burrow that was sampled.\n\nBack in the lab at NAU, the fleas are frozen overnight to kill them, then they are mashed up and their DNA extracted from the mashed cells. The scientists look for the bacteria in the flea's DNA. 10 percent of the fleas from the sampled burrows in Concho tested positive for plague bacteria. Apache County Health Department director Chris Sexton said the county has contracted with Coconino County to visit Concho and dust the affected prairie dog burrows to kill the fleas.\n\nThis is not the 1st time a prairie dog die-off from the plague has occurred in Concho. Busch visited the area to take samples from burrows in 2012 as well.\n\nThe risk of infection for pets and humans is minimal.\n\nSince the plague has such a deadly reputation, it can be alarming. MM said that her husband has taken precautions, wearing insect repellent, and they have also treated their dog for fleas as a preventive measure. These are all good steps to take, according to Busch, because people and pets can get the plague if they are bitten by infected fleas.\n\nIn 2017, however, the risk of infection is low and the disease is readily treated with antibiotics; drugs that were far beyond the imagination of people who suffered with the disease in the 1300s.\n\nThe US averages about 7 cases of plague in humans annually, according to the Centers for Disease Control, although the disease did cause 4 deaths in 2015. Most US cases are in Arizona and New Mexico, according to a map on the CDC website.\n\nSexton said the best way to protect yourself and your pets is to stay away from burrows where a die-off has occurred. If you live in proximity to these burrows, use flea preventive products on your pets and keep them confined away from burrows if they run loose. People should wear insect repellent, tight-fitting clothes and hats if they venture near burrows, or if they work, camp, or hike outdoors. Don't let pets sleep in your bed.\n\nPlague symptoms are similar to the flu -- aches, fever, nausea, lack of energy. Symptoms usually occur within 2 to 7 days after a flea bite. People infected with the plague can also develop black, swollen boils near lymph nodes in the neck, underarms and groin -- the symptom that led to the name 'Black Death.' See your doctor promptly if you develop flu symptoms and you think you may have been bitten by a flea.\n\nMM feels authorities took too long to alert people to the potential threat, so she took steps herself to notify neighbors and people in the area. 'I felt like I'm sort of ground zero on this. I felt like if somebody got sick and I didn't tell people, I would feel responsible,' she said.\n\nFor more information about plague and how to prevent it, see the Public Health Notice on the homepage of the Apache County website at http://www.co.apache.az.us/apache-county-public-health-services-public-notice-07192017/ or visit the CDC webpage about the plague at https://www.cdc.gov/plague/index.html.\n\n[Byline: Trudy Balcom]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Arizona can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62015. Apache County can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/arizona-county-map.gif.\nTo find Concho, go to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Concho,_Arizona. - Mod.MHJ]\n\n*****\n[2] Texas\nDate: Fri 21 Jul 2017 9:53 AM CDT\nSource: Rare Houston [edited]\nhttp://rare.us/local/houston/the-same-plague-virus-that-caused-the-black-death-just-showed-up-in-a-weird-place-in-west-texas/\n\n\nThe same plague virus that wiped out 60 percent of the European population during the black death is now sweeping through West Texas prairie dogs. Muleshoe National Wildlife Refuge [Bailey County] released a statement confirming the plague outbreak.\n\nAs a safety measure, the refuge has closed down 2 areas in the park, including Paul's Lake. 'To protect our visitors, we have voluntarily closed the area where plague has been found. It is well marked and we are asking the public to respect all signs and closures for their own safety,' the park's manager Jude Smith explained in the statement. The outbreak is currently limited to 2 prairie dog populations.\n\nWhile the plague can be transferred from the infected animals to humans or other animals through infected flea bites, park officials ensure the public that it is still safe to visit the open areas. If they bring pets with them to the park, they should take measures to protect their pets from fleas.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Texas can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/61484. Bailey County can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/texas-county-map.gif.\nTo find Muleshoe National Wildlife Refuge, go to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Muleshoe_National_Wildlife_Refuge.\n\nOne always needs stimulating field exercises to educate one's graduate students, and collecting fleas from prairie dog colonies is good, with an extra dimension of instilling sound biosecurity. I have done this with _Mycobacterium leprae_ infected armadillos, _Vibrio cholerae_ in frozen frog legs, lead content in Spanish Moss on trees next to roads and car exhaust, and a large number of others. Believe me, the students learn and remember. Plus over the years I saw a good publication rate from these student exercises. - Mod.MHJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Texas can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/61484. Source: The Independent [edited]\nhttp://www.wmicentral.com/news/apache_county/bubonic-plague-found-in-concho-prairie-dogs/article_a0ac6eab-efc7-5532-9602-28484d776317.html\n\n\nBubonic plague, the disease that killed millions of people in Europe in the 1300s, is thankfully, a lot more deadly to prairie dogs and other rodents than it is to people in 2017. PLAGUE - USA (10): (ARIZONA, TEXAS) BUBONIC, PRAIRIE DOGS, FLEAS\n****************************************************************\n \n\nWhile the plague can be transferred from the infected animals to humans or other animals through infected flea bites, park officials ensure the public that it is still safe to visit the open areas. The bacterium that causes the disease, _Yersinia pestis,_ was found in fleas collected from prairie dog burrows earlier this month [July 2017]. \n\nThe US averages about 7 cases of plague in humans annually, according to the Centers for Disease Control, although the disease did cause 4 deaths in 2015. \n\nSexton said the best way to protect yourself and your pets is to stay away from burrows where a die-off has occurred. \n\nBusch and his student team came to Concho to take samples of fleas from the silent burrows outside MM's home. \n\nThis is not the 1st time a prairie dog die-off from the plague has occurred in Concho. [Byline: Trudy Balcom]\n\n--\n \n\n--\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Arizona can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62015. MHJ]\n\n*****\n The infected fleas then bite the rodents they live on and infect them with plague bacteria. In this posting:\n[1] Arizona\n CDT\nSource: Rare Houston [edited]\n Since their hosts are dead and the fleas can no longer get a meal of blood from them, the insects abandon their hosts who expire deep in their burrows. For more information about plague and how to prevent it, see the Public Health Notice on the homepage of the Apache County website at http://www.co.apache.az.us/apache-county-public-health-services-public-notice-07192017/ or visit the CDC webpage about the plague at https://www.cdc.gov/plague/index.html.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "cholera", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-07-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Coconino County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ARIZONA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bailey County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Apache County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "TEXAS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Concho", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Apache County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5056046", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Crayfish plague - Ireland: white-clawed crayfish", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5056046", "date": "2017-05-23 14:01:25", "main_text": "CRAYFISH PLAGUE - IRELAND: WHITE-CLAWED CRAYFISH\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 18 May 2017\nSource: Inland Fishers Ireland [edited]\nhttps://tinyurl.com/ksoxvae\n\n\nAll water users are being urged to take precautions after confirmation of an outbreak of crayfish plague on a stretch of the River Suir downstream of Clonmel to Carrick-on-Suir. It comes after large numbers of dead freshwater crayfish were reported on the river earlier this month [May 2017]. DNA analysis has now confirmed that the cause of death was crayfish plague.\n\nThe kill has only impacted white-clawed crayfish and other freshwater animals are not affected. This is a characteristic feature of the disease which only infects species of crayfish but causes 100 percent mortality. All agencies, including the National Parks and Wildlife Service, Inland Fisheries Ireland, and Tipperary County Council will be working to contain the outbreak to this stretch of the River Suir. Given the experience of outbreaks elsewhere, a total kill of the population is expected which will have major consequences for the ecology of the river. Crayfish are very common in the Suir and are important in maintaining its ecology.\n\nAnyone using the river is being urged to observe the 'check, clean, and dry' protocol once they leave the river and before using it again. This means that all wet gear (boats, clothing, and equipment) should be checked for any silt or mud, plant material, or animals before being cleaned and finally dried. Disinfectant or hot water (over 40 deg C [104 deg F]) should be used to clean all equipment and this should be followed by a 24 hour drying period.\n\nThe drying period is especially important in ensuring that all equipment is clear of infectious organism, including the removal of any water inside the boat. The crayfish plague organism can be carried on wet equipment to new sites and containment of the outbreak is essential to prevent spread to other unaffected populations in Ireland.\n\nThis is the 2nd confirmed outbreak of the disease in Ireland following one in County Cavan in 2015. There is no indication of how the disease reached the Suir although a link to the Cavan outbreak is considered unlikely as the disease there appears to have run its course. This outbreak on the River Suir is of great concern as the stretch of river affected is popular with anglers and canoeists.\n\nThe white-clawed crayfish is a globally threatened species and Ireland holds one of the largest surviving population. It is the only freshwater crayfish species found in Ireland and is present in lakes, rivers, and streams over much of the island. Throughout its European range, this species has been decimated by the impact of crayfish plague which spread to Europe with the introduction of North American species of crayfish.\n\nUntil 2015, Ireland was considered free of the disease and it remains the only European country without any established non-native crayfish species.\n\nIf crayfish plague becomes established there is a high probability that the white-clawed crayfish, which is currently protected under Irish Law and the EU Habitats Directive, will be eliminated from much of Ireland. If non-native crayfish are found to be established in Ireland, this could have a severe impact on habitats as they can destabilise canal and river banks by burrowing. It could also impact other freshwater species, such as salmon and trout fisheries. At this time however, there is no evidence that non-native freshwater crayfish have been introduced in this country.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[_Austropotamobius pallipes_, the white-clawed crayfish of Western European streams, has become restricted in distribution over the past century.\n\nCrayfish fungal plague, fatal to white-clawed crayfish, has affected many European countries. It is caused by a fungus _Aphanomyces astaci_ that was brought into Europe by the introduction of _Procambarus clarkii_, a freshwater crayfish species of Louisiana, USA, which is naturally infected by this pathogen, although it does not develop clinical disease.\n\nFor a picture of a white-clawed crayfish go to http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Austropotamobius_pallipes#mediaviewer/File:Austropotamobius_pallipes.jpg. - Mod.PMB\n\nMaps of Ireland can be seen at http://www.vidiani.com/maps/maps_of_europe/maps_of_ireland/administrative_map_of_ireland.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/60540. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "\n\nIf crayfish plague becomes established there is a high probability that the white-clawed crayfish, which is currently protected under Irish Law and the EU Habitats Directive, will be eliminated from much of Ireland. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[_Austropotamobius pallipes_, the white-clawed crayfish of Western European streams, has become restricted in distribution over the past century. \n\nCrayfish fungal plague, fatal to white-clawed crayfish, has affected many European countries. Throughout its European range, this species has been decimated by the impact of crayfish plague which spread to Europe with the introduction of North American species of crayfish. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n CRAYFISH PLAGUE - IRELAND: WHITE-CLAWED CRAYFISH\n \n\nUntil 2015, Ireland was considered free of the disease and it remains the only European country without any established non-native crayfish species. \n\nThe white-clawed crayfish is a globally threatened species and Ireland holds one of the largest surviving population. \n\nThe kill has only impacted white-clawed crayfish and other freshwater animals are not affected. It is caused by a fungus _Aphanomyces astaci_ that was brought into Europe by the introduction of _Procambarus clarkii_, a freshwater crayfish species of Louisiana, USA, which is naturally infected by this pathogen, although it does not develop clinical disease. \n\n\nAll water users are being urged to take precautions after confirmation of an outbreak of crayfish plague on a stretch of the River Suir downstream of Clonmel to Carrick-on-Suir. The crayfish plague organism can be carried on wet equipment to new sites and containment of the outbreak is essential to prevent spread to other unaffected populations in Ireland. If non-native crayfish are found to be established in Ireland, this could have a severe impact on habitats as they can destabilise canal and river banks by burrowing. It is the only freshwater crayfish species found in Ireland and is present in lakes, rivers, and streams over much of the island. This is a characteristic feature of the disease which only infects species of crayfish but causes 100 percent mortality. It comes after large numbers of dead freshwater crayfish were reported on the river earlier this month \n\nThe drying period is especially important in ensuring that all equipment is clear of infectious organism, including the removal of any water inside the boat. At this time however, there is no evidence that non-native freshwater crayfish have been introduced in this country. \n\nAnyone using the river is being urged to observe the 'check, clean, and dry' protocol once they leave the river and before using it again. For a picture of a white-clawed crayfish go to http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Austropotamobius_pallipes#mediaviewer/File:Austropotamobius_pallipes.jpg. \n\nThis is the 2nd confirmed outbreak of the disease in Ireland following one in County Cavan in 2015. DNA analysis has now confirmed that the cause of death was crayfish plague. This outbreak on the River Suir is of great concern as the stretch of river affected is popular with anglers and canoeists. There is no indication of how the disease reached the Suir although a link to the Cavan outbreak is considered unlikely as the disease there appears to have run its course. Crayfish are very common in the Suir and are important in maintaining its ecology. \n\n--\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2017-05-18 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-05-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5087671", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (06): (NM)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5087671", "date": "2017-06-06 22:56:29", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (06): (NEW MEXICO)\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 5 Jun 2017 5:24pm\nSource: Associated Press [edited]\nhttps://www.abqjournal.com/1013490/plague-case-reported-in-santa-fe-county.html\n\n\nThe state Department of Health has reported the 1st human case of plague in New Mexico in 2017. Health officials say a 63-year-old Santa Fe County man is currently hospitalized with the bacterial disease. They are conducting an environmental investigation at the man's home to look for ongoing risk and ensure the health of his immediate family and neighbors.\n\nHealth Department staff also is going door-to-door near the man's home to inform them about plague found in the area and educate them on reducing their risk.\n\nPlague generally is transmitted to humans through the bites of infected fleas, but can be transmitted by direct contact with infected animals including rodents, wildlife and pets. So far there have been 10 dogs and 5 cats with confirmed plague in New Mexico in 2017.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The manifestations of _Yersinia pestis_ infection in this case, the 1st for 2017, are not stated in the report but it is likely to have been bubonic plague.\n\n2015 was a 'banner year' for _Y. pestis_ infections in the USA with 15 cases and 4 deaths. In recent decades, an average of 7 human plague cases have been reported each year (range: 1-17 cases per year) with 0-2 deaths.\n\nThe following was extracted from: Prentice MB, Rahalison L. Plague. Lancet. 2007; 369(9568): 1196-207, with the citations removed:\n\n'Some plague cases (10-25 percent) present with primary septicemia (hypotension, shock) without lymph nodes being obviously affected and these patients have higher mortality than those with bubonic plague. The term septicemic plague can be confusing, since most patients with buboes have detectable bacteremia at some stage and can also have high-density bacteremia with systemic signs of sepsis. Debate about whether septicemic plague is always secondary to frank or subclinical bubonic or pneumonic disease continues, but work in mice lends support to the existence of a syndrome of septicemic disease without histological changes in lymph nodes in a few animals infected by flea bites.' - Mod.LL]\n\n[Plague may infect human beings through several routes: 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals (mentioned previously; 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues, generally from an animal; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals.\n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under the jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front leg (the armpit, if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever. These clinical signs may be present in the dog as well. Swelling under the jaw in cats is frequently mistaken as a cat fight abscess. Please take your pet to a veterinarian if you notice any abnormalities. Be sure to consult your veterinarian if you find a lump on your pet, as well as to get the best flea prevention treatment for your pet. It may be necessary to have your yard and/or home treated for fleas. Vacuum your home, including any bedding and furniture, and immediately upon finishing take the vacuum back outside, seal it in a plastic bag, and dispose of it. This type of cleaning will have to be repeated every week for 4-6 weeks to break the cycle of the flea in the home. This disease should be taken seriously, so please be sure your pet is on some form of flea prevention. - Mod.TG\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/233.]", "summary": "LL]\n\n[Plague may infect human beings through several routes: 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals (mentioned previously; 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues, generally from an animal; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The manifestations of _Yersinia pestis_ infection in this case, the 1st for 2017, are not stated in the report but it is likely to have been bubonic plague. 2007; 369(9568): 1196-207, with the citations removed:\n\n'Some plague cases (10-25 percent) present with primary septicemia (hypotension, shock) without lymph nodes being obviously affected and these patients have higher mortality than those with bubonic plague. Debate about whether septicemic plague is always secondary to frank or subclinical bubonic or pneumonic disease continues, but work in mice lends support to the existence of a syndrome of septicemic disease without histological changes in lymph nodes in a few animals infected by flea bites.' - Mod. Source: Associated Press [edited]\nhttps://www.abqjournal.com/1013490/plague-case-reported-in-santa-fe-county.html\n\n\nThe state Department of Health has reported the 1st human case of plague in New Mexico in 2017.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santa Fe County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5108564", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (07): (CO) feline", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5108564", "date": "2017-06-15 17:44:03", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (07): (COLORADO) FELINE\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 14 Jun 2017 1:59 p.m. MT\nSource: Coloradoan [edited]\nhttp://www.coloradoan.com/story/news/local/colorado/2017/06/14/pet-cat-near-larimer-weld-county-line-contracts-plague/397035001/\n\n\nA domestic cat in rural northwest Weld County has tested positive for plague.\nThe cat became sick in early June [2017] and is receiving treatment, according to a Wednesday news release from the Weld County Department of Public Health and Environment. The cat is expected to make a full recovery, and the owner is taking preventive antibiotics. Weld County has taken the lead on the case, but the home is near the Larimer-Weld county line.\n\nThe Larimer County Department of Health and Environment has one key message for residents: Don't panic. Larimer and Weld counties have instances of plague in rodents nearly every year, especially in more rural areas. Prairie dogs test positive for plague fairly regularly, and family pets occasionally contract the disease. Larimer County health department spokeswoman Katie O'Donnell said 3 cats and a dog have been infected in Larimer County in the past 2 years.\n\nPlague is treatable, both in people and animals, as long as it's caught early, O'Donnell said.\n\nThe most common strain in the area is bubonic plague, which is not contagious person to person but is carried by infected fleas and rodents. People most commonly contract plague from the bite of an infected flea, but they can also get the disease from direct contact with an infected animal. O'Donnell said the department sees the bulk of its cases between spring and the 1st freeze in the fall.\n\nSymptoms include a sudden onset of fever, headache, chills, weakness, nausea, vomiting and diarrhea, as well as swollen and painful lymph nodes near the flea bite.\n\nPeople can help prevent infection by applying insect repellent on themselves and flea-prevention treatments on their animals, O'Donnell said.\n\nIn 2015, TG, a 16-year-old Poudre High School student, died after he contracted septicemic plague, a rare and highly fatal strain. He was Larimer County's 1st confirmed plague death since 1999.\n\nPlague is largely concentrated in the western United States, and an average of 7 people contract the disease nationwide each year, according to the Centers for Disease Control.\n\nPrevent plague and other animal-borne diseases [Source: Weld County Department of Public Health and Environment]\n- Avoid flea bites: Stay away from rodents, and consider wearing repellent when in areas where rodents are present.\n- Keep fleas off your pets by applying flea-control products.\n- Do not allow cats or dogs that roam and hunt to sleep in your bed, as they can carry fleas.\n- Reduce rodent habitat around your home. Remove brush, trim vegetation and keep the area clear.\n- Do not feed or handle wildlife. If you must dispose of a carcass, wear gloves or use a shovel.\n\n[Byline: Cassa Niedringhaus]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Domestic cats present a risk because they can bring infected fleas into the house. Also you don't want an infected pet cat nuzzling and breathing into your mouth. But _Yersnia pestis_ responds well to antibiotics if taken early, and preferably prophylacticly if exposure is suspected. If you can it is worth watching and listening to the video clip in this report. - Mod.MHJ\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/209.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nPrevent plague and other animal-borne diseases [Source: Weld County Department of Public Health and Environment]\n- Avoid flea bites: Stay away from rodents, and consider wearing repellent when in areas where rodents are present. \n\nThe most common strain in the area is bubonic plague, which is not contagious person to person but is carried by infected fleas and rodents. Plague, Animal - USA (05): (Colorado) feline, bubonic, alert 20170505.5014699\n--------------------------------------------------------------\nThe following was added into the article: [This is actually a vectorborne disease, as it is transmitted from fleas not from the animal itself. The fleas may get off the animal onto another animal or a human being. But the affected animals do not transmit the disease. The infected animal is only the vehicle for the fleas. - Mod.TG]\n\nIt should be noted that cats (feline in general) can transmit the bacterium via the respiratory route, rather effectively. Several cases have been described of primary pneumonic plague in humans after exposure to a _Y.pestis_ infected cat (see references below).\n\nSomeone else might be able to quantify the transmission efficiency, but it is important to note that plague infected cats are a risk factor for human exposure even without fleas present.\n\nResources:\nWerner SB, et al. Primary plague pneumonia contracted from a domestic cat at South Lake Tahoe, Calif. JAMA. 1984; 251(7): 929-931.\nGage KL, et al. Cases of cat-associated human plague in the Western US, 1977-1998. Clin Infect Dis. 2000; 30(6): 893-900.\nDoll JM, et al. Cat-transmitted fatal pneumonic plague in a person who traveled from Colorado to Arizona. Am J Trop Med Hyg. 1994; 51(1): 109-114.\nEidson M, et al. Feline plague in New Mexico: risk factors and transmission to humans. Am J Public Health. 1988; 78(10): 1333-1335.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nBieneke Bron\nDVM | PhD candidate Comparative Biomedical Sciences\nUniversity of Wisconsin\n1656 Linden Dr,\nMadison, WI, 53706\n<gmbron@gmail.com>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri 5 May 2017\nFrom: Gurfield, Nikos <Nikos.Gurfield@sdcounty.ca.gov> [edited]\n\n\nTo clarify moderator TG's comments that a cat infected with plague cannot infect another animal or person may not always be true. If the cat is shedding plague via a draining abscess or has the pneumonic form, then the cat itself becomes the vector, and quite capable of transmitting the bacterium without a flea intermediary. Thanks for your postings!\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nGurfield, Nikos\n<Nikos.Gurfield@sdcounty.ca.gov>\n\n[Dear Readers,\nYears ago when I started with ProMED-mail, a dear friend said be ready on some occasions to eat some 'crow', the only question was did I prefer it baked or fried.
