Date: Fri 5 May 2017\n Date: Fri 5 May 2017\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1984-03-25 00:00:00", "2000-03-25 00:00:00", "1988-03-25 00:00:00", "1656-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "1994-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Calif.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4965194", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (03): (NM) feline, canine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4965194", "date": "2017-04-12 05:46:48", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (03): (NEW MEXICO) FELINE, CANINE\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 10 Apr 2017 6:39 PM MDT\nDate: Albuquerque Journal [edited]\nhttps://www.abqjournal.com/985771/second-animal-plague-case-confirmed-in-north-albuquerque-acres.html\n\n\nA stray cat found in North Albuquerque Acres was confirmed to have died of plague, marking the 2nd recent death of an animal found in that area from the bacterial disease, city officials said today [10 Apr 2017]. The cat's death, after the recent death of a dog from plague, could indicate the reemergence of plague in a part of the city where it has not been observed since the late 1990s, said Dr Mark DiMenna, deputy director of the city's Environmental Health Department.\n\nNorth Albuquerque Acres is in far Northeast Albuquerque west of Tramway NE, including neighborhoods both north and south of Paseo del Norte NE. The agency warned residents to call 311 to report sick or dead animals found in the area.\n\nCats are particularly susceptible to plague, which can spread among colonies of feral cats, the agency said in a written statement. People who work with free-roaming cats need to watch for plague symptoms in both animals and humans, it said.\n\nPlague is a potentially deadly bacterial disease cycling between rodents and fleas. People usually get the disease from the bites of infected fleas, but it can also be transmitted by direct contact with infected animals, including rodents and pets.\n\n[Signs] of plague in cats can include swollen lymph nodes, vomiting, diarrhea, loss of appetite, and the presence of abscesses, discharge or bloody sputum, the statement said. Symptoms of plague in humans include sudden onset of fever, chills, headache, weakness, and painful swelling of the lymph node in the groin, armpit or neck areas.\n\n[byline: Olivier Uyttebrouck]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is transmitted by fleas. There are several forms of plague in human beings: bubonic, septicemic, and pneumonic.\n\nPlague, caused by _Yersinia pestis_, is enzootic among rodents in the western United States. Humans can be infected through 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals; 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals.\n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under the jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front leg (the armpit, if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever. These clinical signs may be present in the dog as well. Swelling under the jaw in cats is frequently mistaken as a cat fight abscess. Please take your pet to a veterinarian if you notice any abnormalities.\n\nBe sure to consult your veterinarian if you find a lump on your pet, as well as to get the best flea prevention treatment for your pet. It may be necessary to have your yard and/or home treated for fleas. Vacuum your home, including any bedding and furniture, and immediately upon finishing take the vacuum back outside, seal it in a plastic bag, and dispose of it. This type of cleaning will have to be repeated every week for 4-6 weeks to break the cycle of the flea in the home.\n\nThis disease should be taken seriously, so please be sure your pet is on some form of flea prevention. If you are hiking/biking/trekking/walking in the mountains or trails, then you will need some collars for your ankles and to check yourself carefully for fleas as well as note any abnormalities in your health. - Mod.TG\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6643.]", "summary": "\n\n[byline: Olivier Uyttebrouck]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is transmitted by fleas. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n\nA stray cat found in North Albuquerque Acres was confirmed to have died of plague, marking the 2nd recent death of an animal found in that area from the bacterial disease, city officials said today [10 Apr 2017]. Humans can be infected through 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals; 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals. The cat's death, after the recent death of a dog from plague, could indicate the reemergence of plague in a part of the city where it has not been observed since the late 1990s, said Dr Mark DiMenna, deputy director of the city's Environmental Health Department. \n\nCats are particularly susceptible to plague, which can spread among colonies of feral cats, the agency said in a written statement. People usually get the disease from the bites of infected fleas, but it can also be transmitted by direct contact with infected animals, including rodents and pets. \n\nPlague is a potentially deadly bacterial disease cycling between rodents and fleas. \n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under the jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front leg (the armpit, if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Albuquerque Acres", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5014699", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (05): (CO) feline, bubonic, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5014699", "date": "2017-05-05 11:38:52", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (05): (COLORADO) FELINE, BUBONIC, ALERT\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[There is a correction of this report: Plague - USA (06): (CO) feline, bubonic, alert: correction 20170506.5017288]\n\nDate: Tue 2 May 2017 05:55:35 PM MDT\nSource: Times Call [edited]\nhttp://www.timescall.com/longmont-local-news/ci_30961641/longmont-cat-diagnosed-bubonic-plague-first-confirmed-boulder\n\n\nBoulder County [Colorado] Public Health is reminding people to take precautions against animalborne diseases after the pet cat of a family from Longmont tested positive for plague, according to a news release. [This is actually a vectorborne disease, as it is transmitted from fleas not from the animal itself. The fleas may get off of the animal onto another animal or a human being. But the affected animals does not transmit the disease. The infected animal is only the vehicle for the fleas. - Mod.TG]\n\nThe cat's owners noticed that the cat was lethargic and had swollen lymph nodes on Easter Sunday [16 Apr 2017]. The cat tested positive for bubonic plague on 21 Apr 2017. The cat was given antibiotics and has improved, while the family is taking post-exposure plague medications and has not shown any symptoms, according to the news release. [Post exposure plague medication? This is only true in the sense that we typically do not take the necessary antibiotics until we have a reason, but this is a statement that is a bit out of the norm. - Mod.TG]\n\nThe cat is the 1st instance of confirmed plague in Boulder County this season. Plague occurs naturally in Colorado and is spread through fleas to wild rodents and small mammals such as squirrels, rats, prairie dogs and rabbits. Plague can spread to humans if they are bitten by an infected flea.\n\nCarol McInnes, Boulder County Public Health environmental health specialist, said in the news release that people should limit their exposure to fleas to reduce the risk of plague spreading. 'Keeping cats indoors is the best way to protect them from getting plague,' McInnes said. 'Pet owners should also discuss the best way to protect pets from fleas with their veterinarians.'\n\nRain and warmer weather typically mark the beginning of spring migration season for many rodents and small mammals throughout the Front Range. This migration season can increase the risk of other animal-borne diseases such as rabies, tularemia, hantavirus and West Nile virus, according to the news release.\n\nPeople should keep their property tidy and clear any areas where rodents or rabbits can hide and breed as well as storing bird and pet food away from areas that rodents could access. Stop pets from eating wild rodents and wear closed [toed] shoes in areas where animals have been sick or died. Do not mow over animal carcasses. Make sure pets are vaccinated against rabies. People should see a health care professional if they or their pet becomes sick after spending time near wildlife.\n\nBubonic plague\n--------------\nWhat is it? The commonest form of plague caused by the bacteria _Yersinia pestis_. It is an infection of the lymph nodes.\n\nHow does it spread? It spreads primarily through bites from infected fleas, which travel on small mammals and rodents. In some cases, the plague can be transmitted to humans from sick animals.\n\nIs it treatable? People with plague need immediate antibiotic treatment in the 1st 24 hours that symptoms occur. Without treatment, about 50 per cent of people with bubonic plague die. With treatment, about 13 per cent of people infected with bubonic plague die.\n\nWhat are the symptoms? Symptoms usually show up between 2 and 6 days after being infected. Chills, fever, fatigue or malaise, headache, muscle pain, seizures, and painful lymph gland swelling in the groin, armpits, or neck.\n\nHow do I avoid it? Protect pets from fleas and ticks and keep pets on a leash and out of wild rodent habitats. If you enter a wild rodent habitat, wear insect repellent and tuck pants cuffs into socks to prevent flea bites. Do not touch or feed wild rodents. Do not touch dead or sick animals. Prevent rodents in and around your home by clearing plants from outside walls, storing food properly and setting traps. Treat rodent sites with flea powder.\n\n[byline: Karen Antonacci]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Colorado can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4519. Boulder County can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/colorado-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ\n\nPlague is transmitted by fleas. There are several forms of plague in human beings: bubonic, septicemic, and pneumonic.\n\nPlague, caused by _Yersinia pestis_, is enzootic among rodents in the western United States. Humans can be infected through 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals; 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals.\n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under the jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front leg (the armpit, if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever. These clinical signs may be present in the dog as well. Swelling under the jaw in cats is frequently mistaken as a cat fight abscess. Please take your pet to a veterinarian if you notice any abnormalities.\n\nBe sure to consult your veterinarian if you find a lump on your pet, as well as to get the best flea prevention treatment for your pet. It may be necessary to have your yard and/or home treated for fleas. Vacuum your home, including any bedding and furniture, and immediately upon finishing take the vacuum back outside, seal it in a plastic bag, and dispose of it. This type of cleaning will have to be repeated every week for 4-6 weeks to break the cycle of the flea in the home.\n\nThis disease should be taken seriously, so please be sure your pet is on some form of flea prevention. If you are hiking/biking/trekking/walking in the mountains or trails, then you will need some collars for your ankles and to check yourself carefully for fleas as well as note any abnormalities in your health. - Mod.TG]", "summary": "\n\n[byline: Karen Antonacci]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Colorado can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4519. ' Humans can be infected through 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals; 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals. \n\nPeople should keep their property tidy and clear any areas where rodents or rabbits can hide and breed as well as storing bird and pet food away from areas that rodents could access. \n\n\nBoulder County [Colorado] Public Health is reminding people to take precautions against animalborne diseases after the pet cat of a family from Longmont tested positive for plague, according to a news release. \n\nBe sure to consult your veterinarian if you find a lump on your pet, as well as to get the best flea prevention treatment for your pet. Plague occurs naturally in Colorado and is spread through fleas to wild rodents and small mammals such as squirrels, rats, prairie dogs and rabbits. \n\nBubonic plague\n PLAGUE - USA (05): (COLORADO) FELINE, BUBONIC, ALERT\n************************************************************\n The cat was given antibiotics and has improved, while the family is taking post-exposure plague medications and has not shown any symptoms, according to the news release. \n\nThe cat is the 1st instance of confirmed plague in Boulder County this season. USA (04): (NM) feral cat, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4980169", "date": "2017-04-19 14:09:32", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (04): (NEW MEXICO) FERAL CAT, ALERT\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 17 Apr 2017 11:45 pm MDT\nSource: Albuquerque Journal [edited]\nhttps://www.abqjournal.com/989331/plagueinfected-cat-prompts-warning.html\n\n\nThe discovery of a plague-infected cat this month [April 2017] in far Northeast Albuquerque prompted a city health official to warn people not to feed feral animals, and to take precautions against disease when handling strays.\n\nThe cat's death, after the death of a pet dog from plague in March [2017], has raised concerns about the re-emergence of plague in North Albuquerque Acres, where the bacterial illness had not been observed since the late 1990s.\n\nNorth Albuquerque Acres is in far Northeast Albuquerque, west of Tramway NE, including neighborhoods both north and south of Paseo del Norte NE.\n\nMark DiMenna, deputy director of the city's Environmental Health Department, said city officials have trapped about 30 stray cats in the area and are testing the animals for plague. Test results were not complete on [Mon 17 Apr 2017].\n\nDiMenna said he doesn't expect the city to alter its trap-neuter-return program for feral cats in response to the infected animals. Under trap-neuter-return, cats living in feral colonies are trapped, sterilized, vaccinated, and returned to the area where they were found.\n\n'We are not trying to leverage this to make any changes' to trap-neuter-return, DiMenna said in an interview. 'I think the city is pretty committed to this program.'\n\nDiMenna urged groups and individuals who work with feral cats to take precautions, such as wearing gloves when they handle cats, and seeking prompt treatment for bites and scratches.\n\nHe also urged people not to put out food for feral cats, which can attract wild animals, such as skunks and raccoons, that can carry plague, in addition to predators such as coyotes that prey on cats.\n\nPeople also need to be aware of clinical signs of plague in both cats and people, which in cats can include swollen lymph nodes, vomiting, diarrhea, loss of appetite, and the presence of abscesses, discharge, or bloody sputum. In humans include sudden onset of fever, chills, headache, weakness, and painful swelling of the lymph nodes in the groin, armpit, or neck areas.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations. Some species are particularly susceptible. Free-ranging carnivores, including feral cats, are particularly exposed to plague as they pray on its reservoir. - Mod.PMB\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/59671.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nDiMenna urged groups and individuals who work with feral cats to take precautions, such as wearing gloves when they handle cats, and seeking prompt treatment for bites and scratches.\n\n \n\nPeople also need to be aware of clinical signs of plague in both cats and people, which in cats can include swollen lymph nodes, vomiting, diarrhea, loss of appetite, and the presence of abscesses, discharge, or bloody sputum. \n\nMark DiMenna, deputy director of the city's Environmental Health Department, said city officials have trapped about 30 stray cats in the area and are testing the animals for plague. \n\nDiMenna said he doesn't expect the city to alter its trap-neuter-return program for feral cats in response to the infected animals. 'It is important to avoid touching any sick or dead animals and to take safety measures to protect your family and pets.'\n\nPlague is easily treated in humans with antibiotics if recognized early. If infected, people will show a sudden onset of high fever, muscle pain, extreme fatigue, and painful swollen nodes, according to officials.\n\nHealth officials recommend the following measures to avoid becoming infected with the plague:\n- Avoid contact with any sick or dead wild animals.\n- Use insect repellant that contains DEET to prevent flea bites.\n- Tuck pant cuffs into socks to prevent flea bites.\n- Protect your pets by using preventive flea treatments.\n- Keep your dogs under direct supervision and on a leash when outside.\n- Contact your veterinarian if your pet becomes ill.\n- Prevent rodent infestations around your house by clearing away debris and trash.\n- Seek medical attention if you become ill with a high fever and/or swollen lymph nodes.\n\nYou are asked to report any unusual wild animal activity to Broomfield Animal Services at (303) 438-6400.\n\n[Byline: Oscar Contreras]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is transmitted by fleas. There are several forms of plague in human beings: bubonic, septicemic, and pneumonic.\n\nThe organism _Yersinia pestis_, causes plague. Primarily in the western portion of the United States, plague is enzootic among rodents. Humans can be infected through 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals; 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals.\n\nDomestic cats and dogs can also contract plague from infective fleas. They may carry infected fleas home to their owners. Cats may serve as a direct source of infection. These clinical signs may be present in the dog as well. Swelling under the jaw in cats is frequently mistaken as a cat fight abscess. People are also prone to the respiratory infection.\n\nThere are many flea treatments and repellents appropriate for pets available. Some products may be suitable for dogs but not cats, or may be suitable for an adult but not a younger animal. There were also 4 cases in 2015, but one resulted in death.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is transmitted by fleas. There are several forms of plague in human beings: bubonic, septicemic, and pneumonic.\n\nPlague, caused by _Yersinia pestis_, is enzootic among rodents in the western United States. Humans can be infected through 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals; 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals.\n\nPlague is a potential bioterrorism agent. Human infections are rare but can be life-threatening. The case fatality rate of plague depends on the clinical presentation (that is, bubonic, septicemic, or pneumonic) and timing of initiation of antibiotic therapy; if untreated, the case fatality rate is over 50 percent for bubonic plague and approaches 100 percent for pneumonic plague. Rapid laboratory identification can help guide therapy.\n\nDomestic cats and dogs can also contract plague from infective fleas. They may carry infected fleas home to their owners. Cats may serve as a direct source of infection. There are many flea treatments and repellents appropriate for pets available. Some products may be suitable for dogs but not cats, or may be suitable for an adult but not a younger animal. Be sure to consult your veterinarian, as some products may be toxic to cats, kittens, and puppies, even resulting in fatalities.\n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under the jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front leg (the armpit, if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever. These clinical signs may be present in the dog as well. Swelling under the jaw in cats is frequently mistaken as a cat fight abscess. Please take your pet to a veterinarian if you notice any abnormalities.\n\nVeterinarians should protect themselves by wearing gloves when examining these swellings. A bubo that ruptures may infect the veterinarian or even the pet owner if the pet owner is the one palpating the swelling.\n\nAnother form of the disease is the respiratory form. Cats may acquire this form and can spread it to their owners or the veterinarians through infected expiratory droplets. People are also prone to the respiratory infection.\n\nYou should also be aware that the fleas that hitchhike into the home via a pet vehicle can also transmit disease to you, the owner, or caretaker of the pet. Sleeping in the same bed with dogs has been associated with plague in enzootic areas. Plague patients with no history of exposure to rodents can be infected by _Y. pestis_ if their pets carry infected rodent fleas into the home. Veterinarians always should recommend flea control to dog and cat owners.\n\nPlague is infamous for killing millions of people in Europe during the Middle Ages. Today, modern antibiotics are effective in treating plague, but without prompt treatment, the disease can cause serious illness or death. Presently, human plague infections continue to occur in the western United States, but significantly more cases occur in parts of Africa and Asia.\n\nParts of this comment have been excerpted from CDC. Notes from the field: two cases of human plague -- Oregon, 2010. MMWR 2011; 60(07): 214; http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6007a4.htm and from http://www.cdc.gov/plague/. - Mod.TG\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/233.]", "summary": "The case fatality rate of plague depends on the clinical presentation (that is, bubonic, septicemic, or pneumonic) and timing of initiation of antibiotic therapy; if untreated, the case fatality rate is over 50 percent for bubonic plague and approaches 100 percent for pneumonic plague. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is transmitted by fleas. Humans can be infected through 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals; 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals. Presently, human plague infections continue to occur in the western United States, but significantly more cases occur in parts of Africa and Asia.\n\n Plague patients with no history of exposure to rodents can be infected by _Y. pestis_ if their pets carry infected rodent fleas into the home. \n\nYou should also be aware that the fleas that hitchhike into the home via a pet vehicle can also transmit disease to you, the owner, or caretaker of the pet. \n\nDomestic cats and dogs can also contract plague from infective fleas. \n\nNew Mexico saw 4 human plague cases in 2016, although nobody died. \n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under the jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front leg (the armpit, if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever. \n\nThe department says in a news release that the dogs were several miles from Edgewood and were confirmed to have plague this year. Plague is a bacterial disease that can be fatal but in most cases causes fever, chills, headache and weakness. \n\nAnother form of the disease is the respiratory form. \n\n--\n \n\nIt can be passed from animals to people by direct contact.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://www.cdc.gov/plague/. - Mod", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6007a4.htm", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4846917", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Uganda: 2011-2014, ciprofloxacin efficacy", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4846917", "date": "2017-02-17 16:48:56", "main_text": "PLAGUE - UGANDA: 2011-2014, CIPROFLOXACIN EFFICACY\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 17 Feb 2017\nSource: Emerging Infectious Diseases 2017 23:553-555 [edited]\nhttps://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/23/3/16-1212_article\n\n\nSuccessful Treatment of Human Plague with Oral Ciprofloxacin\n------------------------------------------------------------\nPlague is a life-threatening zoonotic disease caused by _Yersinia pestis_. Zoonotic foci exist on several continents; however, resource-poor areas in sub-Saharan Africa account for most human cases (1). The pathogenesis of plague involves facultative intracellular infection of host macrophages, followed by fulminant extracellular growth and bacteremia (2). In the absence of effective antimicrobial drug treatment, bubonic plague is fatal in about 50 percent of cases and pneumonic plague in greater than 90 percent [of cases] (1,3).\n\nDrugs approved by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for treatment of plague include streptomycin and doxycycline. Streptomycin is bactericidal but rarely used because of limited availability and serious toxicities. Doxycycline is bacteriostatic and lacks concentration-dependent activity or a post-antibiotic effect, which might limit its efficacy for serious _Y. pestis_ infections (4). Nevertheless, low cost and oral dosing have made doxycycline a 1st-line treatment in several countries (5,6). Fluoroquinolones, include ciprofloxacin, have recently been approved by the FDA for treatment of plague based on animal and in vitro studies (4,7,8). Clinical experience with these agents, however, is limited (1,5).\n\nDuring 2011-2014, patients with suspected plague seen at 6 clinics and 2 hospitals in the West Nile region of Uganda were offered enrollment in an open-label study evaluating the safety and efficacy of ciprofloxacin for treatment of plague. Patients were excluded if they were pregnant, less than 8 years of age, considered too ill to receive oral treatment, or had received antimicrobial drug treatment in the preceding 7 days. After written consent was obtained, diagnostic samples were collected and oral ciprofloxacin administered for 10 days at a weight-calibrated dosage of approximately 15 mg/kg [0.00052 oz] twice daily (range 13-17 mg/kg)[0.00045-0.00059 oz], with a maximum dose for adults of 750 mg [0.026 oz] twice daily. Diagnostic samples were cultured on sheep blood agar and suspect isolates confirmed by bacteriophage lysis (9). Patients were monitored daily during treatment, and clinical outcome was assessed 14-21 days after initial evaluation. Because of simultaneous prevention efforts and lower than expected enrollment, the study was terminated early. The study was approved by Institutional Review Boards at the Uganda Virus Research Institute, the Uganda National Council for Science and Technology, and the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nA total of 5 patients with culture-confirmed plague were enrolled and treated with oral ciprofloxacin (Table [for table, see original URL. - Mod.LL]). Median patient age was 27 years (range 10-52 years); median time between illness onset and enrollment was 4 days (range 1-7 days). Up to 4 patients had bubonic plague, with _Y. pestis_ isolated from bubo aspirates or blood cultures. The fifth patient, a 13-year-old boy, had pneumonic plague as indicated by hemoptysis, patchy bilateral infiltrates on chest radiograph, and _Y. pestis_ isolated from sputum. The illness had evolved over 6 days, a clinical course suggestive of secondary rather than primary pneumonic plague (3); the primary focus of infection was not identified. Three patients were admitted and 2 treated as outpatients. In addition to ciprofloxacin, all received acetaminophen, and 2 received a bolus of normal saline. All became afebrile within 2 days. At 14 days, all had been discharged and returned to their normal activities. The 13-year-old boy with culture-confirmed pneumonic plague reported mild, nonproductive cough, but no complications were identified.\n\nFluoroquinolones have pharmacokinetic properties that make them attractive for treatment of plague, including bactericidal activity, good oral bioavailability, excellent tissue penetration, and an established safety record (8,10). In vitro assays suggest that ciprofloxacin is comparable to streptomycin and superior to doxycycline or gentamicin for killing of intracellular _Y. pestis_ (4), and efficacy has been demonstrated in rodent and nonhuman primate models (8). Along with FDA approval, our results add to growing clinical experience (5) and support the broader use of oral ciprofloxacin for treatment of human plague, especially in resource-poor areas where [access to] intravenous treatment is limited.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Butler T: Plague gives surprises in the first decade of the 21st century in the United States and worldwide. Am J Trop Med Hyg. 2013;89:788-793.\n2. Zhou D, Han Y, Yang R: Molecular and physiological insights into plague transmission, virulence and etiology. Microbes Infect. 2006;8:273-284.\n3. Pollitzer R: Plague. Mwengee W, Butler T, Mgema S, et al: Treatment of plague with gentamicin or doxycycline in a randomized clinical trial in Tanzania. Clin Infect Dis. 2006;42:614-621.\n7. National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases. Treatment of pneumonic plague: medical utility of ciprofloxacin [cited Mon 13 Jun 2016]. http://www.fda.gov/downloads/AdvisoryCommittees/CommitteesMeetingMaterials/Drugs/Anti-InfectiveDrugsAdvisoryCommittee/UCM297865.pdf\n9. New York: Elsevier; 2015. p. 419-439\n\n[Authors: Apangu T, Griffith K, Abaru J]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is a small report underscoring the efficacy of the fluoroquinolone in _Y. pestis_ infection. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/97.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Source: Emerging Infectious Diseases 2017 23:553-555 [edited]\nhttps://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/23/3/16-1212_article\n\n\nSuccessful Treatment of Human Plague with Oral Ciprofloxacin\n During 2011-2014, patients with suspected plague seen at 6 clinics and 2 hospitals in the West Nile region of Uganda were offered enrollment in an open-label study evaluating the safety and efficacy of ciprofloxacin for treatment of plague. Along with FDA approval, our results add to growing clinical experience (5) and support the broader use of oral ciprofloxacin for treatment of human plague, especially in resource-poor areas where [access to] intravenous treatment is limited. [Authors: Apangu T, Griffith K, Abaru J]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< In the absence of effective antimicrobial drug treatment, bubonic plague is fatal in about 50 percent of cases and pneumonic plague in greater than 90 percent [of cases] (1,3). \n\nFluoroquinolones have pharmacokinetic properties that make them attractive for treatment of plague, including bactericidal activity, good oral bioavailability, excellent tissue penetration, and an established safety record (8,10). Patients were excluded if they were pregnant, less than 8 years of age, considered too ill to receive oral treatment, or had received antimicrobial drug treatment in the preceding 7 days. \n\nA total of 5 patients with culture-confirmed plague were enrolled and treated with oral ciprofloxacin (Table [for table, see original URL. PLAGUE - UGANDA: 2011-2014, CIPROFLOXACIN EFFICACY\n************************************************* Median patient age was 27 years (range 10-52 years); median time between illness onset and enrollment was 4 days (range 1-7 days). The illness had evolved over 6 days, a clinical course suggestive of secondary rather than primary pneumonic plague (3); the primary focus of infection was not identified. The fifth patient, a 13-year-old boy, had pneumonic plague as indicated by hemoptysis, patchy bilateral infiltrates on chest radiograph, and _Y. pestis_ isolated from sputum. Treatment of pneumonic plague: medical utility of ciprofloxacin [cited Mon 13 Jun 2016]. \n\nDrugs approved by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for treatment of plague include streptomycin and doxycycline. Fluoroquinolones, include ciprofloxacin, have recently been approved by the FDA for treatment of plague based on animal and in vitro studies (4,7,8). In vitro assays suggest that ciprofloxacin is comparable to streptomycin and superior to doxycycline or gentamicin for killing of intracellular _Y. pestis_ (4), and efficacy has been demonstrated in rodent and nonhuman primate models (8). The 13-year-old boy with culture-confirmed pneumonic plague reported mild, nonproductive cough, but no complications were identified. After written consent was obtained, diagnostic samples were collected and oral ciprofloxacin administered for 10 days at a weight-calibrated dosage of approximately 15 mg/kg Up to 4 patients had bubonic plague, with _Y. pestis_ isolated from bubo aspirates or blood cultures. Mwengee W, Butler T, Mgema S, et al: Treatment of plague with gentamicin or doxycycline in a randomized clinical trial in Tanzania. In vitro efficacy of antibiotics commonly used to treat human plague against intracellular Yersinia pestis. [0.00052 oz] twice daily (range 13-17 mg/kg)[0.00045-0.00059 oz], with a maximum dose for adults of 750 mg [0.026 oz] twice daily. The pathogenesis of plague involves facultative intracellular infection of host macrophages, followed by fulminant extracellular growth and bacteremia (2). Patients were monitored daily during treatment, and clinical outcome was assessed 14-21 days after initial evaluation. \n\nReferences\n---------- Doxycycline is bacteriostatic and lacks concentration-dependent activity or a post-antibiotic effect, which might limit its efficacy for serious _Y. pestis_ infections (4). Plague is a life-threatening zoonotic disease caused by _Yersinia pestis_.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-06-13 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "1954-03-25 00:00:00", "2000-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tanzania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4784059", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Madagascar (02): 2nd cluster", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4784059", "date": "2017-01-22 19:35:16", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (02): SECOND CLUSTER\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 18 Jan 2017\nSource: VOA News [edited]\nhttp://www.voanews.com/a/plague-outbreak-hits-remote-part-of-madagascar/3681279.html\n\n\nEven for Madagascar, this is no ordinary bubonic plague outbreak. The African nation has the world's highest incidence of the bacterial infection that earned the grim name 'The Black Death' after it killed an estimated 50 million people in the 14th century. The rat- and flea-borne illness hits the island nation every year from about December to April.\n\nBut 2017 is different, says the WHO's Dr. Eric Bertherat. This latest outbreak has popped up in a completely new area. The mountainous area of Befotaka in southeastern Madagascar has seen 68 cases -- of which 27 have died -- since the end of 2016, according to WHO estimates.\n\nBertherat said there also are unconfirmed reports of a nearby 2nd cluster of some 30 cases. 'This outbreak occurred in a place where they had no plague case reported since 1950,' he told VOA from Geneva, after returning from a recent visit to Madagascar to assess the situation.\n\nEven more alarming, he says, is the fact that 'it occurred in a very remote and insecure place where it's very difficult to go. And that's the main problem, for the time being. There is no one to control the outbreak, because we are still trying to organize a kind of rescue operation to go there.'\n\nBertherat says plague is impossible to entirely eradicate. To do so, he said, would mean killing every plague-carrying wild animal, which is an impossible task, and very likely would disrupt a delicate ecological balance. Some developed nations like the USA experience plague. The CDC reported 16 cases in 2015. Four of those cases ended in death.\n\nBertherat says Madagascar is exceptionally susceptible, however, because of its persistent poverty. The spread of plague is often aided by poor sanitation and a lack of health care. But why, with modern medicine and new rapid tests available in Madagascar, does this 14th century affliction appear to be growing? The answer, Bertherat says, may lie in a very modern trend: deforestation. Madagascar has seen massive deforestation because of illegal logging and as subsistence farmers continue to push into wild habitats.\n\n'Our hypothesis,' he said, 'is that this re-emergence in fact is due to the further extension of the natural focus of the migration of the rats, and also the fact that there is more and more contact between the local population and the forest area.'\n\n[Byline: Anita Powell]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following paragraph is from Chanteau S, Ratsifasoamanana L, Rasoamanana B, et al: Plague, a reemerging disease in Madagascar. Emerg Infect Dis. 1998;4(1):101-4, PMID: 9452403 (available at, http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/4/1/98-0114_article.htm):\n\n'Between 1930 and 1990, bubonic plague had 'virtually disappeared' on the island due to efficient pest-control and good health management. However, since 1990, an annual 200 cases are being reported, and bubonic plague takes on epidemic form, especially in the port of Mahajanga, each year. In the capital city of Antananarivo, more cases are also being notified each year since 1990. Madagascar (pop. 13 million) has accounted for 45 percent of all the cases of plague in Africa.'\n\nFatalities related to plague usually are caused by spread of the organism from the bubo (the very painful infected lymph node which drains the area where the flea bite occurred) to the bloodstream. The bacteremia can cause a coagulopathy, producing the purpura seen in the 'black plague' and also spread to the lungs causing a hemorrhagic pneumonia. It is the pneumonia that can facilitate person-to-person transmission.\n\nMadagascar was the location of the isolation of multi-antimicrobial resistant _Y. pestis_ in 1995 (Galimand M, Guiyoule A, Gerbaud G, et al: Multidrug resistance in _Yersinia pestis_ mediated by a transferable plasmid. N Engl J Med. 1997;337(10):677-80, PMID: 9278464; available at http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJM199709043371004). The strain was resistant to chloramphenicol, streptomycin, and tetracycline but sensitive to fluoroquinolones and trimethoprim as well as other aminoglycosides. This was an ominous observation; however, it is not clear whether this naturally occurring strain has persisted or spread.\n\nThe regions of Madagascar can be found on a map at: http://www.ngw.nl/heraldrywiki/images/c/cd/Madregions.jpg. The affected regions are in the southern part of the island nation. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/181.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n 1998;4(1):101-4, PMID: 9452403 (available at, http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/4/1/98-0114_article.htm):\n\n'Between 1930 and 1990, bubonic plague had 'virtually disappeared' on the island due to efficient pest-control and good health management. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following paragraph is from Chanteau S, Ratsifasoamanana L, Rasoamanana B, et al: \n\n[Byline: Anita Powell]\n\n--\n \n\n'Our hypothesis,' he said, 'is that this re-emergence in fact is due to the further extension of the natural focus of the migration of the rats, and also the fact that there is more and more contact between the local population and the forest area.' However, since 1990, an annual 200 cases are being reported, and bubonic plague takes on epidemic form, especially in the port of Mahajanga, each year. PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (02): SECOND CLUSTER\n****************************************\n Fatalities related to plague usually are caused by spread of the organism from the bubo (the very painful infected lymph node which drains the area where the flea bite occurred) to the bloodstream. \n\nBertherat says plague is impossible to entirely eradicate. \n\nMadagascar was the location of the isolation of multi-antimicrobial resistant _Y. pestis_ in 1995 (Galimand M, Guiyoule A, Gerbaud G, et al: Multidrug resistance in _Yersinia pestis_ mediated by a transferable plasmid. \n\nEven more alarming, he says, is the fact that 'it occurred in a very remote and insecure place where it's very difficult to go. \n\nBertherat said there also are unconfirmed reports of a nearby 2nd cluster of some 30 cases. The mountainous area of Befotaka in southeastern Madagascar has seen 68 cases -- of which 27 have died -- since the end of 2016, according to WHO estimates.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1990-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-03-25 00:00:00", "1995-03-25 00:00:00", "1950-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-01-18 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Rasoamanana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mahajanga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Befotaka", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Geneva", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4754927", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Madagascar: fatalities", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4754927", "date": "2017-01-10 15:56:11", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR: FATALITIES\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 9 Jan 2017\nSource: WHO Emergencies preparedness, response, Disease Outbreak News (DONs) [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/csr/don/09-january-2017-plague-mdg/en/\n\n\nPlague \u00ad Madagascar\n-------------------\nOn 6 Dec 2016, the Ministry of Health (MoH) in Madagascar alerted WHO of a suspected plague outbreak in Befotaka district, Atsimo Atsinanana region in the southeastern part of the country. The district is outside the area known to be endemic in Madagascar. No plague cases have been reported in this area since 1950.\n\nAs of 27 Dec 2016, 62 cases (6 confirmed, 5 probable, 51 suspected) including 26 deaths (case fatality rate of 42 percent) have been reported in 2 adjacent districts in 2 neighboring regions of the country. As many as 28 cases, including 10 deaths, have been reported from Befotaka District in Atsimo-Atsinanana Region and 34 cases, including 16 deaths, have been reported from Iakora district in Ihorombe Region. Of the 11 samples tested, 5 were positive for plague on rapid diagnostic test and 6 are now confirmed at Institut Pasteur laboratory. Of the total reported cases, 5 are classified as pneumonic plague cases and the remaining as bubonic plague.\n\nRetrospective investigations carried out in those 2 districts showed that it is possible that the outbreak might have started in mid-August 2016. The investigation in neighbouring villages is still ongoing. On 29 Dec 2016, an investigation carried out within 25 km [approx. 15.5 mi] of the initial foci in Befotaka district has reported 3 deaths and is being investigated further for possible linkage to the outbreak. The affected zone is located in a very remote, hard to reach and highly insecure area (classified as red zone due to local banditry). Despite arrangements made with the local authorities, insecurity slows down the investigations and response activities. In addition, a helicopter has been made available but its use has been limited due to bad weather and financial limitations.\n\nPublic Health Response\n----------------------\nOn 6 Dec 2016, a 15 member multidisciplinary team from MoH, Institute Pasteur including public health professional, epidemiologist, entomologist and laboratory professional visited the affected area for epidemiological investigation and response activities. Key response activities already implemented include:\n\n- Epidemiological investigations including active case finding and rapid diagnostic testing\n- Training of community health workers on community-based surveillance and early detection of cases\n- Clinical management of suspected cases\n- Identification, follow up and chemoprophylaxis of contacts\n- Vector and reservoir control through the use of Kartman boxes\n- Sensitization of the population\n- Strengthening the community based surveillance\n- Free treatment of other diagnosed disease such as malaria\n- Strengthening early detection in neighboring districts\n- Laboratory confirmation\n\nWHO Risk Assessment\n-------------------\nBased on the available information to date, the risk of international spread appears unlikely, especially as it is occurring in a very remote area. However, the difficulty to reach the affected area hampered prompt investigation and therefore at this stage the real magnitude of the outbreak is still to be defined, and the risk of further spread in the area and sustained transmission cannot be formally ruled out. WHO continues supporting the ongoing investigation and response activities.\n\nWHO Advice\n----------\nFurther ecological investigations will be needed to understand the occurrence of a plague outbreak in an area which has not reported any cases of plague since 1950 in order to adapt long term surveillance and control measures.\n\nThe outbreak impacts rural communities which have already suffered from remoteness and inadequate access to health services. Staff from the MoH is supported by the Pasteur Institute of Madagascar, who are all experienced on control measures. However, local conditions make their implementation complex.\n\nDue to the remoteness of the affected area and the conditions for getting infected by the disease, the current outbreak does not represent a significant risk for travelers.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is caused by the _Yersinia pestis_ bacillus, carried by rat fleas. At the start of the rainy season, currently, rats flee the sewers of Madagascar in massive numbers and take refuge in people's cottages. Care must be taken in any rodent eradication program to ensure that a flea-killing compound is part of the plan. Just as in a natural rodent die-off from _Y. pestis_, the fleas will seek alternate hosts, that is, humans.\n\nIt is interesting that no cases had been reported from this remote area in almost 70 years. The areas remoteness is likely to be partly responsible for this, rather than no sporadic cases occurring.\n\nThe following paragraph is from Chanteau S, Ratsifasoamanana L, Rasoamanana B, et al: Plague, a reemerging disease in Madagascar. Emerg Infect Dis. 1998;4(1):101-4, PMID: 9452403 (available at, http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/4/1/98-0114_article.htm).\n\n'Between 1930 and 1990, bubonic plague had 'virtually disappeared' on the island due to efficient pest-control and good health management. However since 1990, an annual 200 cases are being reported and bubonic plague takes on epidemic form, especially in the port of Mahajanga, each year. In the capital city of Antananarivo, more cases are also being notified each year since 1990. Madagascar (pop. 13 million) has accounted for 45 percent of all the cases of plague in Africa.'\n\nFatalities related to plague usually are caused by spread of the organism from the bubo (the very painful infected lymph node which drains the area where the flea bite occurred) to the bloodstream. The bacteremia can cause a coagulopathy, producing the purpura seen in the 'black plague' and also spread to the lungs causing a hemorrhagic pneumonia. It is the pneumonia that can facilitate person-to-person transmission.\n\nMadagascar was the location of the isolation of multi-antimicrobial resistant _Y. pestis_ in 1995 (Galimand M, Guiyoule A, Gerbaud G, et al: Multidrug resistance in _Yersinia pestis_ mediated by a transferable plasmid. N Engl J Med. 1997;337(10):677-80, PMID: 9278464; available at, http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJM199709043371004). The strain was resistant to chloramphenicol, streptomycin, and tetracycline but sensitive to fluoroquinolones and trimethoprim as well as other aminoglycosides. This was an ominous observation; however, it is not clear whether this naturally occurring strain has persisted or spread.\n\nThe regions of Madagascar can be found on a map at: http://www.ngw.nl/heraldrywiki/images/c/cd/Madregions.jpg. The affected regions are in the southern part of the island nation. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/181.]", "summary": "Key response activities already implemented include:\n\n- Epidemiological investigations including active case finding and rapid diagnostic testing\n- Training of community health workers on community-based surveillance and early detection of cases\n- Clinical management of suspected cases\n- Identification, follow up and chemoprophylaxis of contacts\n- Vector and reservoir control through the use of Kartman boxes\n- Sensitization of the population\n- Strengthening the community based surveillance\n- Free treatment of other diagnosed disease such as malaria\n- Strengthening early detection in neighboring districts\n- Laboratory confirmation\n\nWHO Risk Assessment\n A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Source: WHO Emergencies preparedness, response, Disease Outbreak News (DONs) [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/csr/don/09-january-2017-plague-mdg/en/\n\n\nPlague \u00ad Madagascar\n Further ecological investigations will be needed to understand the occurrence of a plague outbreak in an area which has not reported any cases of plague since 1950 in order to adapt long term surveillance and control measures. As of 27 Dec 2016, 62 cases (6 confirmed, 5 probable, 51 suspected) including 26 deaths (case fatality rate of 42 percent) have been reported in 2 adjacent districts in 2 neighboring regions of the country. As many as 28 cases, including 10 deaths, have been reported from Befotaka District in Atsimo-Atsinanana Region and 34 cases, including 16 deaths, have been reported from Iakora district in Ihorombe Region. Of the total reported cases, 5 are classified as pneumonic plague cases and the remaining as bubonic plague. On 6 Dec 2016, a 15 member multidisciplinary team from MoH, Institute Pasteur including public health professional, epidemiologist, entomologist and laboratory professional visited the affected area for epidemiological investigation and response activities. However, the difficulty to reach the affected area hampered prompt investigation and therefore at this stage the real magnitude of the outbreak is still to be defined, and the risk of further spread in the area and sustained transmission cannot be formally ruled out. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nIt is interesting that no cases had been reported from this remote area in almost 70 years. \n\nPublic Health Response\n \n\n'Between 1930 and 1990, bubonic plague had 'virtually disappeared' on the island due to efficient pest-control and good health management. However since 1990, an annual 200 cases are being reported and bubonic plague takes on epidemic form, especially in the port of Mahajanga, each year. No plague cases have been reported in this area since 1950. \n\n--\n Fatalities related to plague usually are caused by spread of the organism from the bubo (the very painful infected lymph node which drains the area where the flea bite occurred) to the bloodstream. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is caused by the _Yersinia pestis_ bacillus, carried by rat fleas. On 6 Dec 2016, the Ministry of Health (MoH) in Madagascar alerted WHO of a suspected plague outbreak in Befotaka district, Atsimo Atsinanana region in the southeastern part of the country. Due to the remoteness of the affected area and the conditions for getting infected by the disease, the current outbreak does not represent a significant risk for travelers. \n\nMadagascar was the location of the isolation of multi-antimicrobial resistant _Y. pestis_ in 1995 (Galimand M, Guiyoule A, Gerbaud G, et al: Multidrug resistance in _Yersinia pestis_ mediated by a transferable plasmid.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "malaria", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1950-03-25 00:00:00", "1990-03-25 00:00:00", "1995-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-12-25 00:00:00", "2016-12-06 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2017-01-09 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Iakora", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rasoamanana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ihorombe Region", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Befotaka", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mahajanga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Atsimo - Atsinanana Region", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4698685", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Madagascar (02): (AS) fatalities", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4698685", "date": "2016-12-14 16:27:41", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASGAR (02): (ATSINANANA) FATALITIES\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Tue 6 Dec 2016, 6:09 PM\nSource: Africa Review [edited]\nhttp://www.africareview.com/news/Bubonic-plague-kills-scores-in-southern-Madagascar/979180-3477216-format-xhtml-3mnm8z/index.html\n\n\nBubonic plague has killed at least 31 people in Madagascar's southern district of Befotaka Atsimo, an official said. 'The victims are from 2 adjacent rural communes: 25 in one and 6 in another one,' said local lawmaker Col Maroriky. The lawmaker said the affected areas were remote and prone to diseases and insecurity.\n\nReports of a mysterious disease outbreak first emerged last week but it has now been confirmed as bubonic plague. Bush fires, blamed on persistent drought, have reportedly driven disease carrying rodents into villages, where they have transmitted the disease to humans. The outbreak has been aggravated by the poor local health infrastructure.\n\nMedical experts from the Health Ministry and the Institut Pasteur de Madagascar in Antananarivo were deployed to the affected area on Mon 5 Dec 2016. However, the bad roads from the regional capital city of Vangaindrano were reportedly impeding access to the affected populations.\n\n[Byline: Rivonala Razafison]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Mon 5 Dec 2016, 8:35 AM\nSource: L'Express de Madagascar [in French, machine trans., edited]\nhttp://www.lexpressmada.com/blog/actualites/befotaka-atsimo-des-suspicions-de-peste\n\n\nIt is suspected that plague could have caused deaths in Befotaka Atsimo. Elements of the Ministry of Public Health have been dispatched to this non-plague area. Authorities in the Befotaka Atsimo district and the Midongy Atsimo district have reported suspicious deaths in Inosy Ambalarano commune, Befotaka Atsimo district, in the Atsimo Atsinanana region this weekend. The victims had the same symptoms, namely [swollen] lymph nodes, such as those of bubonic plague. The exact statistics of the deceased escape from these sources. The brigade commander of the Befotaka gendarmerie Atsimo, a reliable source, reported 2 deaths. 'Our people did not see these bodies,' said a source from the police.\n\nAnother source in Midongy Atsimo, the district closest to the scene of the drama, reported dozens of deaths in 2 months. 'We have heard about people who died for unknown causes in Ambalarano 2 months ago. The inhabitants of this commune who come to shop in Midongy Atsimo speak of it, but they believe that it is due to the sorcery', it is explained.\n\nMaroriky, deputy of the district of Befotaka Atsimo, meanwhile, reported a dozen deaths. These figures came from the elements of the civil security of this small town which informed him of this drama, 4 days before. For now, everything is unclear as to the cause of the disease and the exact number of deaths.\n\nTeams from the Ministry of Public Health and the Pasteur Institute of Madagascar were dispatched to the site. They left the central office on with all the necessary inputs to diagnose the causes of death and to treat the sick. 'It is a very inaccessible area. These teams, composed of about 20 people, will have to travel about 30 kilometers on foot before arriving at the site, in this district classified [as] red zone, 'explains Dr. Maherisoa Ratsitorahina, director of the Health Watch and epidemiological surveillance of the Ministry of Public Health.\n\n[Byline: Miangaly Ralitera]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is caused by the _Yersinia pestis_ bacillus, carried by rat fleas. At the start of the rainy season, currently, rats flee the sewers of Madagascar in massive numbers and take refuge in people's cottages. Care must be taken in any rodent eradication program to ensure that a flea-killing compound is part of the plan. Just as in a natural rodent die-off from _Y. pestis_, the fleas will seek alternate hosts, that is, humans.\n\nThe following paragraph is from 1998 (Chanteau S, Ratsifasoamanana L, Rasoamanana B, et al: Plague, a reemerging disease in Madagascar. Emerg Infect Dis. 1998;4(1):101-4, PMID: 9452403; http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/4/1/98-0114_article.htm).\n\n'Between 1930 and 1990, bubonic plague had 'virtually disappeared' on the island due to efficient pest-control and good health management. However since 1990, an annual 200 cases are being reported and bubonic plague takes on epidemic form, especially in the port of Mahajanga, each year. In the capital city of Antananarivo, more cases are also being notified each year since 1990. Madagascar (pop. 13 million) has accounted for 45 percent of all the cases of plague in Africa.'\n\nFatalities related to plague usually are caused by spread of the organism from the bubo (the very painful infected lymph node which drains the area where the flea bite occurred) to the bloodstream. The bacteremia can cause a coagulopathy, producing the purpura seen in the 'black plague' and also spread to the lungs causing a hemorrhagic pneumonia. It is the pneumonia that can facilitate person-to-person transmission.\n\nMadagascar was the location of the isolation of multi-antimicrobial resistant _Y. pestis_ in 1995 (Galimand M, Guiyoule A, Gerbaud G, et al: Multidrug resistance in _Yersinia pestis_ mediated by a transferable plasmid. N Engl J Med. 1997;337(10):677-80, PMID: 9278464; http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJM199709043371004). The strain was resistant to chloramphenicol, streptomycin, and tetracycline but sensitive to fluoroquinolones and trimethoprim as well as other aminoglycosides. This was an ominous observation; however, it is not clear whether this naturally occurring strain has persisted or spread.\n\nAtsimo-Atsinanana (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atsimo-Atsinanana) is a region in Madagascar. The region used to be part of the Fianarantsoa Province. The region extends along the southern part of the east coast of Madagascar. It is bordered by Vatovavy-Fitovinany and Haute Matsiatra (North), Ihorombe (West) and Anosy (South). It can be seen on a map of the island country at: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atsimo-Atsinanana#/media/File:Madagascar-Atsimo_Atsinanana_Region.png. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/181.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n \n\nAnother source in Midongy Atsimo, the district closest to the scene of the drama, reported dozens of deaths in 2 months. ' PLAGUE - MADAGASGAR (02): (ATSINANANA) FATALITIES\n*************************************************\n Date: Tue 6 Dec 2016, 6:09 PM\nSource: Africa Review [edited]\nhttp://www.africareview.com/news/Bubonic-plague-kills-scores-in-southern-Madagascar/979180-3477216-format-xhtml-3mnm8z/index.html \n\n'Between 1930 and 1990, bubonic plague had 'virtually disappeared' on the island due to efficient pest-control and good health management. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is caused by the _Yersinia pestis_ bacillus, carried by rat fleas. \n\nMadagascar was the location of the isolation of multi-antimicrobial resistant _Y. pestis_ in 1995 (Galimand M, Guiyoule A, Gerbaud G, et al: Multidrug resistance in _Yersinia pestis_ mediated by a transferable plasmid. Authorities in the Befotaka Atsimo district and the Midongy Atsimo district have reported suspicious deaths in Inosy Ambalarano commune, Befotaka Atsimo district, in the Atsimo Atsinanana region this weekend. [Byline: Rivonala Razafison]\n\n--\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n [Byline: Miangaly Ralitera]\n\n--\n \n\nMaroriky, deputy of the district of Befotaka Atsimo, meanwhile, reported a dozen deaths. \n\n\nBubonic plague has killed at least 31 people in Madagascar's southern district of Befotaka Atsimo, an official said. ' \n\nMedical experts from the Health Ministry and the Institut Pasteur de Madagascar in Antananarivo were deployed to the affected area on Mon 5 Dec 2016. Fatalities related to plague usually are caused by spread of the organism from the bubo (the very painful infected lymph node which drains the area where the flea bite occurred) to the bloodstream. However since 1990, an annual 200 cases are being reported and bubonic plague takes on epidemic form, especially in the port of Mahajanga, each year.
