Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Humans are infected from the animal reservoir by being fed upon by the mammal's infested fleas or from direct contact with an infected animal.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Marmota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "America", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Altai Republic", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4322943", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, animal - USA (07): (CA) squirrel", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4322943", "date": "2016-07-02 17:25:48", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (07): (CALIFORNIA) SQUIRREL\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 28 Jun 2016\nSource: KESQ.com [edited]\nhttp://www.kesq.com/news/campground-squirrels-test-positive-for-plague-in-san-jacinto-mountains/40262400\n\n\nSquirrels at 2 campgrounds in the San Jacinto Mountains have tested antibody-positive for plague this month [June 2016], according to Riverside County [California] health officials.\n\nNow the Riverside County Environmental Health Vector Control Program wants to make sure visitors and campers are taking the proper precautions to stay safe and healthy while having fun in the mountains.\n\nThe squirrels were in the Dark Canyon Campground and Marion Mountain Campground.\n\nThe Riverside County Environmental Health Vector Control Program was notified about the positive blood tests by the California Department of Public Health, which were collected on 8 and 13 Jun [2016]. The U.S. Forest Service district rangers and safety officer have also been notified.\n\nThe antibody-positive test means the squirrels had been exposed to the disease sometime in the past. All campgrounds are continuously posted to remind campers that plague has been found in the area in the past.\n\nAccording to the release, plague is a rare bacterial disease in rodents that can be transmitted through the bite of infected rodent fleas. The disease has been detected in ground squirrels, chipmunks, and other wild rodents throughout many mountain regions in Southern California. The last positive plague samples in the San Jacinto Mountain Range were in 2012 and 2002.\n\n[Byline: Patrick Edgell]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations. Some species are particularly susceptible. For example, _Y. pestis_ caused the extinction of entire colonies of black-tailed prairie dogs. Small rodents such as deer mice and grasshopper mice are suggested to act as the reservoirs. Larger species like squirrels and chipmunks are considered to be more vulnerable to infection. - Mod.PMB\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/204.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. \n\n\nSquirrels at 2 campgrounds in the San Jacinto Mountains have tested antibody-positive for plague this month [June 2016], according to Riverside County [California] health officials. \n\nThe Riverside County Environmental Health Vector Control Program was notified about the positive blood tests by the California Department of Public Health, which were collected on 8 and 13 Jun [2016]. \n\nNow the Riverside County Environmental Health Vector Control Program wants to make sure visitors and campers are taking the proper precautions to stay safe and healthy while having fun in the mountains. According to the release, plague is a rare bacterial disease in rodents that can be transmitted through the bite of infected rodent fleas. [Byline: Patrick Edgell]\n\n--\n The disease has been detected in ground squirrels, chipmunks, and other wild rodents throughout many mountain regions in Southern California. The antibody-positive test means the squirrels had been exposed to the disease sometime in the past.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-06-25 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2002-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Riverside County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4295323", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (03): (NM)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4295323", "date": "2016-06-18 09:33:51", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (03): (NEW MEXICO)\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 17 Jun 2016\nSource: New Mexico Department of Health [edited]\nhttps://nmhealth.org/news/disease/2016/6/?view=437\n\n\nThe New Mexico Department of Health [NMDH] has confirmed a case of plague in a 16-year-old boy from Rio Arriba County who is currently hospitalized. Confirmatory testing was conducted at the Scientific Laboratory Division. This is the 1st human case of plague in New Mexico and in the USA in 2016.\n\n'We will conduct an environmental investigation at the teen's home to look for ongoing risk and to ensure the health of the immediate family and neighbors,' said Department of Health Secretary Designate Lynn Gallagher. 'Staff will go door-to-door to neighbors near the patient's home to inform them about plague found in the area and educate them on reducing their risk.'\n\nPlague is a bacterial disease of rodents and is generally transmitted to humans through the bites of infected fleas, but can also be transmitted by direct contact with infected animals, including rodents, wildlife and pets.\n\n'Late spring and summer are when we see most cases of plague, though they can occur throughout the year in New Mexico,' said Dr Paul Ettestad, public health veterinarian for the Department of Health. 'Sick or dead rodents and rabbits are being reported from many areas in the state so it is very important to take precautions to avoid rodents and their fleas which can expose you to plague. Pets that are allowed to roam and hunt can bring plague-infected fleas from dead rodents back into the home, putting you and your children at risk.'\n\nTo prevent plague, the Department of Health recommends:\n- avoid sick or dead rodents and rabbits, and their nests and burrows;\n- keep your pets from roaming and hunting;\n- talk to your veterinarian about using an appropriate flea control product on your pets as not all products are safe for cats, dogs, or your children;\n- clean up areas near the house where rodents could live, such as woodpiles, brush piles, junk, and abandoned vehicles;\n- sick pets should be examined promptly by a veterinarian;\n- see your doctor about any unexplained illness involving a sudden and severe fever;\n- put hay, wood, and compost piles as far as possible from your home; and\n- don't leave your pet's food and water where rodents can get to it.\n\nSymptoms of plague in humans include sudden onset of fever, chills, headache, and weakness. In most cases there is a painful swelling of the lymph node in the groin, armpit, or neck areas. Plague symptoms in cats and dogs are fever, lethargy, and loss of appetite. There may be a swelling in the lymph node under the jaw. Prompt diagnosis and appropriate antibiotic treatment can greatly reduce the risk of death. Physicians who suspect a patient may have plague should promptly report it to the Department of Health.\n\nIn New Mexico, there were 4 human plague cases in 2015 with one death.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nPaul Ettestad DVM\nPublic Health Veterinarian\nNew Mexico Department of Health\nUSA\n<Paul.Ettestad@state.nm.us>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Ettestad for this post. The manifestations of _Yersinia pestis_ in this case are not stated in the NMDH report.\n\n2015 was a 'banner year' for _Y. pestis_ infections in the USA with 15 cases and 4 deaths. In recent decades, an average of 7 human plague cases have been reported each year (range: 1-17 cases per year) with 0-2 deaths.\n\nThe following was extracted from Prentice MB, Rahalison L: Plague. Lancet. 2007; 369(9568): 1196-207, with the citations removed:\n\n'Some plague cases (10-25 percent) present with primary septicemia (hypotension, shock) without lymph nodes being obviously affected and these patients have higher mortality than those with bubonic plague. The term septicemic plague can be confusing, since most patients with buboes have detectable bacteremia at some stage and can also have high-density bacteremia with systemic signs of sepsis. Debate about whether septicemic plague is always secondary to frank or subclinical bubonic or pneumonic disease continues, but work in mice lends support to the existence of a syndrome of septicemic disease without histological changes in lymph nodes in a few animals infected by flea bites.'\n\nThe state of New Mexico can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/17672. Rio Arriba County can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/new-mexico-county-map.gif. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "\n\nTo prevent plague, the Department of Health recommends:\n- avoid sick or dead rodents and rabbits, and their nests and burrows;\n- keep your pets from roaming and hunting;\n- talk to your veterinarian about using an appropriate flea control product on your pets as not all products are safe for cats, dogs, or your children;\n- clean up areas near the house where rodents could live, such as woodpiles, brush piles, junk, and abandoned vehicles;\n- sick pets should be examined promptly by a veterinarian;\n- see your doctor about any unexplained illness involving a sudden and severe fever;\n- put hay, wood, and compost piles as far as possible from your home; and\n- don't leave your pet's food and water where rodents can get to it. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n 2007; 369(9568): 1196-207, with the citations removed:\n\n'Some plague cases (10-25 percent) present with primary septicemia (hypotension, shock) without lymph nodes being obviously affected and these patients have higher mortality than those with bubonic plague. \n\nPlague is a bacterial disease of rodents and is generally transmitted to humans through the bites of infected fleas, but can also be transmitted by direct contact with infected animals, including rodents, wildlife and pets. In recent decades, an average of 7 human plague cases have been reported each year (range: 1-17 cases per year) with 0-2 deaths.\n\n New Mexico Department of Health\nUSA\n<Paul.Ettestad@state.nm.us>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Ettestad for this post. Debate about whether septicemic plague is always secondary to frank or subclinical bubonic or pneumonic disease continues, but work in mice lends support to the existence of a syndrome of septicemic disease without histological changes in lymph nodes in a few animals infected by flea bites.' \n\n'Late spring and summer are when we see most cases of plague, though they can occur throughout the year in New Mexico,' said Dr Paul Ettestad, public health veterinarian for the Department of Health. ' Sick or dead rodents and rabbits are being reported from many areas in the state so it is very important to take precautions to avoid rodents and their fleas which can expose you to plague. Pets that are allowed to roam and hunt can bring plague-infected fleas from dead rodents back into the home, putting you and your children at risk.' Communicated by:\nPaul Ettestad DVM\n \n\nSymptoms of plague in humans include sudden onset of fever, chills, headache, and weakness.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Rio Arriba County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4267825", "headline": "PRO/AH> Plague, animal - USA (04): (CO) feral cat, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4267825", "date": "2016-06-06 12:29:06", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (04): (COLORADO) FERAL CAT, ALERT\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 2 Jun 2016\nSource: KJCT8 [edited]\nhttp://www.kjct8.com/content/news/381664531.html\n\n\nThe [Colorado] Delta County Health Department is warning residents of plague after a feral cat tested positive for the disease over the Memorial Day [30 May 2016] weekend. Health officials said the cat was found on Hanson Road near Cedaredge, then taken to Surface Creek Veterinary Center where it tested positive for plague before being euthanized.\n\nOfficials said this is the 1st plague activity detected this season [2016]. 'Plague is commonly transmitted by fleas, so taking steps to avoid fleas will help prevent spread of the disease,' said Ken Nordstrom, Delta County Health Department environmental health director.\n\nPublic health officials recommend the following steps to reduce being exposed to plague:\n- avoid fleas. Protect pets with flea control products and keep them on a leash and out of wild rodent habitats;\n- stay out of areas with wild rodents. If you must enter areas with wild rodents, wear insect repellent. You may also tuck pants cuffs into socks to prevent flea bites;\n- avoid all contact with wild rodents, including squirrels and chipmunks; do not feed or handle them;\n- do not touch sick or dead animals;\n- prevent rodents living around your house: clear plants and materials away from outside walls, prevent access to pet food and trash, and set traps.\n\nCats and dogs that roam and hunt can carry infected fleas home to their owners. In rare instances pets that contract plague can transmit the disease to people. 'Keeping pets from roaming and hunting, and using flea control on them is the best way to protect them from getting plague,' said Nordstrom. 'Pet owners should ask their veterinarian to recommend a flea control product to use on their pet.'\n\nThe plague is an infectious disease, occurring naturally in Colorado; it is spread by flea bites among small wild animals such as squirrels, chipmunks, and rabbits.\n\nBubonic plague is the commonest form of plague and occurs after a bite from an infected flea. Plague can be spread to humans when infected fleas bite a human.\n\nSymptoms of plague include a sudden, high fever, extreme fatigue, and sometimes, but not always, painful swollen lymph nodes (called buboes). About half of the people infected with plague will also have gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and/or abdominal pain.\n\nAnyone who observes these symptoms in a person or pet should contact their healthcare provider or veterinarian immediately. Plague can be treated with common antibiotics, and treatment is most successful when begun early.\n\nContact the Delta County Health Department, 970-874-2165, if you find dead rabbits, squirrels, or prairie dogs in this area.\n\n[byline: Jay Greene]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations. Some species are particularly susceptible. Free-ranging carnivores, including feral cats, are particularly exposed to plague as they prey on its reservoir.\n\nThe state of Colorado can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/20511. Delta County can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/colorado-county-map.gif. - Mod.PMB]", "summary": "You may also tuck pants cuffs into socks to prevent flea bites;\n- avoid all contact with wild rodents, including squirrels and chipmunks; do not feed or handle them;\n- do not touch sick or dead animals;\n- prevent rodents living around your house: clear plants and materials away from outside walls, prevent access to pet food and trash, and set traps. \n\n[byline: Jay Greene]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. About half of the people infected with plague will also have gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and/or abdominal pain. Date: Thu 2 Jun 2016\n It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. Source: KJCT8 [edited]\nhttp://www.kjct8.com/content/news/381664531.html\n\n\n Plague can be treated with common antibiotics, and treatment is most successful when begun early.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Delta County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/20511", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4290356", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, animal - USA (06): (ID) cat recovering, ground squirrel", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4290356", "date": "2016-06-16 10:01:05", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (06): (IDAHO) CAT RECOVERING, GROUND SQUIRREL\n******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] Ada County: cat recovering\n[2] Elmore County: domestic cats, ground squirrels\n\n******\n[1] Ada County: feline recovering\nDate: Tue 14 Jun 2016 3:32 PM MDT\nSource: Kivi TV [edited]\nhttp://www.kivitv.com/news/plague-infected-boise-cat-recovering\n\n\nInitial tests on a south Boise [Ada County] cat have come back as positive for the plague, said Central District Health Department [CDHD] officials.\n\n'The cat is being treated and is recovering,' said CDHD spokeswoman Christine Myron. The cat lived within the known area of impact in the desert south of Boise.\n\n'Previously, 2 Elmore County cats contracted plague and died. We want to remind people to take steps to keep themselves and animals safe,' Myron said.\n\n[Byline: Steve Bertel]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Elmore County: domestic cats, ground squirrels\nDate: Tue 14 Jun 2016\nSource: Idaho Central District Health Department [edited]\nhttp://www.cdhd.idaho.gov/news/current/2016-Ground-Squirrel-Plague.htm\n\n\nTo date, plague has been found in dead ground squirrels and was confirmed in the deaths of 2 pet cats who resided in Elmore County.\n\nMost recently, initial test results show that an Ada County cat has plague. However, the cat is being treated and is recovering. More details on these cases can be found among News Releases, located under the Resources section of this page [see source URL above].\n\nPublic health officials are asking area residents and public to take precautions if they live or recreate in any area with known ground squirrels, even if they are outside the known area of impact.\n\nGround squirrels typically hibernate in early July, at which time the threat of plague will significantly decrease. It is important to note that 3 squirrels or fox squirrels, which often live in residential areas, are not of concern.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is great news to hear this cat is being successfully treated. This is a great success story.\n\nPlague is transmitted by fleas. There are several forms of plague in human beings: bubonic, septicemic, and pneumonic.\n\nPlague, caused by _Yersinia pestis_, is enzootic among rodents in the western United States. Humans can be infected through 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals; 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals.\n\nPlague is a potential bioterrorism agent. Human infections are rare but can be life-threatening. The case fatality rate of plague depends on the clinical presentation (that is, bubonic, septicemic, or pneumonic) and timing of initiation of antibiotic therapy; if untreated, the case fatality rate is over 50 per cent for bubonic plague and approaches 100 per cent for pneumonic plague. Rapid laboratory identification can help guide therapy.\n\nDomestic cats and dogs can also contract plague from infective fleas. They may carry infected fleas home to their owners. Cats may serve as a direct source of infection. There are many flea treatments and repellents appropriate for pets available. Some products may be suitable for dogs but not cats, or may be suitable for an adult but not a younger animal. Be sure to consult your veterinarian, as some products may be toxic to cats, kittens, and puppies, even resulting in fatalities.\n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under the jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front leg (the armpit, if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever. These clinical signs may be present in the dog as well. Swelling under the jaw in cats is frequently mistaken as a cat fight abscess. Please take your pet to a veterinarian if you notice any abnormalities.\n\nVeterinarians should protect themselves by wearing gloves when examining these swellings. A bubo that ruptures may infect the veterinarian or even the pet owner if the pet owner is the one palpating the swelling.\n\nAnother form of the disease is the respiratory form. Cats may acquire this form and can spread it to their owners or the veterinarians through infected expiratory droplets. People are also prone to the respiratory infection.\n\nYou should also be aware that the fleas that hitchhike into the home via a pet vehicle can also transmit disease to you, the owner, or caretaker of the pet. Sleeping in the same bed with dogs has been associated with plague in enzootic areas. Plague patients with no history of exposure to rodents can be infected by _Y. pestis_ if their pets carry infected rodent fleas into the home. Veterinarians always should recommend flea control to dog and cat owners.\n\nPlague is infamous for killing millions of people in Europe during the Middle Ages. Today, modern antibiotics are effective in treating plague, but without prompt treatment, the disease can cause serious illness or death. Presently, human plague infections continue to occur in the western United States, but significantly more cases occur in parts of Africa and Asia.\n\nParts of this comment have been excerpted from CDC. Notes from the field: two cases of human plague -- Oregon, 2010. MMWR, 25 Feb 2011; 60(07): 214; http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6007a4.htm and from http://www.cdc.gov/plague/. - Mod.TG\n\nThe state of Idaho can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/215. A county map can be seen at http://geology.com/county-map/idaho-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The case fatality rate of plague depends on the clinical presentation (that is, bubonic, septicemic, or pneumonic) and timing of initiation of antibiotic therapy; if untreated, the case fatality rate is over 50 per cent for bubonic plague and approaches 100 per cent for pneumonic plague. [2] Elmore County: domestic cats, ground squirrels\n\n******\n \n\n[Byline: Steve Bertel]\n\n--\n \n\nPublic health officials are asking area residents and public to take precautions if they live or recreate in any area with known ground squirrels, even if they are outside the known area of impact. Humans can be infected through 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals; 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals. PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (06): (IDAHO) CAT RECOVERING, GROUND SQUIRREL\n Presently, human plague infections continue to occur in the western United States, but significantly more cases occur in parts of Africa and Asia.\n\n \n\nGround squirrels typically hibernate in early July, at which time the threat of plague will significantly decrease. \n\n'Previously, 2 Elmore County cats contracted plague and died. Date: Tue 14 Jun 2016 3:32 PM MDT\nSource: Kivi TV [edited]\n \n\nYou should also be aware that the fleas that hitchhike into the home via a pet vehicle can also transmit disease to you, the owner, or caretaker of the pet. To date, plague has been found in dead ground squirrels and was confirmed in the deaths of 2 pet cats who resided in Elmore County. \n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under the jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front leg (the armpit, if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever. \n\nMost recently, initial test results show that an Ada County cat has plague. [2] Elmore County: domestic cats, ground squirrels\n Plague patients with no history of exposure to rodents can be infected by _Y. pestis_ if their pets carry infected rodent fleas into the home. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\n--\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-02-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-06-14 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Idaho", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Boise", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Elmore County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6007a4.htm", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ada County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://www.cdc.gov/plague/. - Mod", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4289092", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, tularemia - USA (NM) alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4289092", "date": "2016-06-15 14:41:39", "main_text": "PLAGUE, TULAREMIA - USA (NEW MEXICO): ALERT\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 13 June 2016\nSource: Albuquerque Journal [edited]\nhttp://www.abqjournal.com/791345/tularemia-plague-in-pets-higher-than-average.html\n\n\nThe New Mexico Department of Health has confirmed 10 cases of plague and 19 cases of tularemia in dogs and cats - 'higher than average' this year - in multiple counties.\n\nPlague-positive pets have been reported in Los Alamos, Rio Arriba, Sandoval, Santa Fe, Taos and Torrance counties; while pet positive tests for tularemia have been reported in Bernalillo, Los Alamos, Sandoval and Santa Fe counties.\n\nPlague and tularemia are bacterial diseases of rodents and rabbits. Human contraction of plague is generally from flea bites, while human contraction of tularemia is from deer fly bites, Department of Health veterinarian Dr. Paul Ettestad said Mon [14 Jun 2016]. These illnesses also can be transmitted by direct contact with infected animals, including pets.\n\nEttestad said the contraction rate of both plague and tularemia this year 'is higher than average, but not on a record pace.' In New Mexico, plague and tularemia are more prevalent in the spring and early summer.\n\n'We are seeing recent die-offs of rabbits in several areas of New Mexico from both plague and tularemia,' Ettestad said. 'People can be exposed to plague when pets bring infected fleas back into the home, by caring for a sick pet without proper precautions, or by contact with rodents or fleas outdoors. Exposure to tularemia can occur from bites from deer flies or handling infected animals or pets which have been exposed,' he said.\n\nSymptoms of plague and tularemia in humans are similar and include sudden onset of fever, chills, headache, weakness, swollen lymph nodes and possible infection at the bite site, Ettestad said. Likewise, he noted, signs of plague and tularemia in cats and dogs are similar, and include fever, lethargy, loss of appetite and possible swelling in the lymph node under the jaw.\n\nThe only sure way to distinguish the difference between these is through laboratory testing, he said. With prompt diagnosis and appropriate antibiotic treatment, the fatality rate in people and pets can be greatly reduced. According to statistics compiled by the Department of Health for 2015, 4 people in New Mexico contracted plague, with 1 fatality in Santa Fe County, and 8 cases of tularemia were confirmed, with no fatalities. There were also 63 confirmed cases of tularemia in dogs and cats in 2015, and 18 confirmed pet plague cases.\n\n[Byline: Rick Nathanson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Fleas and ticks are the guilty party in spreading these diseases to other animals, including our pets and us. Protecting our pets and ourselves from fleas and ticks is primary. Flea and tick collars around your ankles when hiking these areas can be helpful. For pets there are generally once-a-month treatments available that work very well.\n\nPlague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations, with some species being particularly susceptible. Free-ranging carnivores, including feral cats, are particularly exposed to plague as they prey on its reservoir.\n\nTularemia is a bacterial septicemia that affects, aside from people, more than 250 species of wild and domestic mammals, birds, reptiles and fish. It is listed as a category A bioterrorism agent because of the potential for fatality, airborne dissemination, and societal disruption if released. The causative bacterium, _Francisella tularensis_, is a nonspore-forming, Gram-negative coccobacillus antigenically related to _Brucella_ spp.\n\nTularemia can be transmitted by aerosol, direct contact, ingestion, or arthropods. Inhalation of aerosolized organisms (in the laboratory or as an airborne agent in an act of bioterrorism) can produce a pneumonic form. Direct contact with, or ingestion of, infected carcasses of wild animals (such as cottontail rabbit) can produce the ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, oropharyngeal (local lesion with regional lymphadenitis), or typhoidal form. Immersion in or ingestion of contaminated water can result in infection in aquatic animals. Ticks can maintain infection transstadially [pathogen remains with the vector from one life stage ('stadium') to the next] and transovarially [transmission of a pathogen from an organism (as a tick) to its offspring by infection of eggs in its ovary], making them efficient reservoirs and vectors.\n\nThe commonest source of infection for people and herbivores is the bite of an infected tick, but people who prepare or eat improperly cooked wild game are also at increased risk. Dogs, cats, and other carnivores may acquire infection from ingestion of an infected carcass. Case reports have implicated cats as a source of infection in people. - Mod.TG\n\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/233.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nSymptoms of plague and tularemia in humans are similar and include sudden onset of fever, chills, headache, weakness, swollen lymph nodes and possible infection at the bite site, Ettestad said. 'People can be exposed to plague when pets bring infected fleas back into the home, by caring for a sick pet without proper precautions, or by contact with rodents or fleas outdoors. \n\nThe commonest source of infection for people and herbivores is the bite of an infected tick, but people who prepare or eat improperly cooked wild game are also at increased risk. The New Mexico Department of Health has confirmed 10 cases of plague and 19 cases of tularemia in dogs and cats - 'higher than average' this year - in multiple counties. There were also 63 confirmed cases of tularemia in dogs and cats in 2015, and 18 confirmed pet plague cases. \n\nEttestad said the contraction rate of both plague and tularemia this year 'is higher than average, but not on a record pace.' Human contraction of plague is generally from flea bites, while human contraction of tularemia is from deer fly bites, Department of Health veterinarian Dr. Paul Ettestad said Mon [14 Jun 2016]. \n\n'We are seeing recent die-offs of rabbits in several areas of New Mexico from both plague and tularemia,' Ettestad said. Likewise, he noted, signs of plague and tularemia in cats and dogs are similar, and include fever, lethargy, loss of appetite and possible swelling in the lymph node under the jaw. According to statistics compiled by the Department of Health for 2015, 4 people in New Mexico contracted plague, with 1 fatality in Santa Fe County, and 8 cases of tularemia were confirmed, with no fatalities. \n\nTularemia is a bacterial septicemia that affects, aside from people, more than 250 species of wild and domestic mammals, birds, reptiles and fish. Plague-positive pets have been reported in Los Alamos, Rio Arriba, Sandoval, Santa Fe, Taos and Torrance counties; while pet positive tests for tularemia have been reported in Bernalillo, Los Alamos, Sandoval and Santa Fe counties. Exposure to tularemia can occur from bites from deer flies or handling infected animals or pets which have been exposed,' he said.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-06-14 00:00:00", "2016-06-13 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Sandoval", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bernalillo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Los Alamos", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santa Fe", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santa Fe County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4287888", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, animal - USA (05): (ID) domestic cat, ground squirrel", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4287888", "date": "2016-06-15 10:48:22", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (05): (IDAHO) DOMESTIC CAT, GROUND SQUIRREL\n****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 10 Jun 2016\nSource: KMVT.com [edited]\nhttp://www.kmvt.com/content/news/Plague-area-in-southwest-Idaho-expands-officials-warn-of-threat-382505451.html\n\n\nPreliminary laboratory tests indicate a 2nd cat from Elmore County likely died of plague. This is the 2nd cat death within the last week thought to be connected to the bacterial infection, though the cats were owned by separate families. The most recent cat lived both indoors and outdoors, and had contact with ground squirrels before becoming ill. Family members and other household pets are being monitored to ensure the cat did not spread the infection. Final lab results will be available next week.\n\nThe cat lived approximately 2 miles [3.2 km] from Mountain Home in an area not previously identified with confirmed plague. 'We want to emphasize that plague is likely present at some level in ground squirrel populations throughout the sagebrush habitat in southern Idaho. With the known confirmed cases in these areas we want to people to be aware and be able to take appropriate steps to protect themselves and their pets from plague,' said State Wildlife Veterinarian Dr Mark Drew.\n\nPlague is transmitted through the bites of infected fleas and can cause serious illness to people and pets if not treated quickly. It also can be transmitted to people by direct contact with infected animals, including rodents, rabbits and pets. Common rodents that can become infected include ground squirrels, rats, voles, and mice. Tree squirrels in Idaho are not known to carry plague.\n\nPublic health officials urge everyone to take proper precautions to protect themselves and their pets against plague regardless of where they live in proximity to the latest area of impact. To prevent plague in humans:\n- see your doctor immediately about any unexplained illness with a severe fever if you have been in the affected area;\n- avoid picking up or touching dead animals; wear gloves if you must handle dead animals;\n- do not let pets sleep in bed with you. This has been shown to increase your risk of getting plague;\n- clean up areas near the house where rodents could live, such as woodpiles, brush piles, junk and abandoned vehicles;\n- put hay, wood, and compost piles as far as possible from your home;\n- wear long-sleeved shirts and long pants;\n- use DEET on clothing in accordance with label instructions or wear clothing pre-treated with permethrin;\n- use DEET on exposed skin, in accordance with label instructions.\n\nPlague prevention in pets:\n- do not let your pets hunt or roam in the affected area;\n- talk to your veterinarian about using an appropriate flea control product on your pets;\n- sick pets should be examined promptly by a veterinarian;\n- don't leave your pet's food and water where rodents can get to it.\n\nSymptoms of plague in humans\n----------------------------\nSymptoms of plague in humans include sudden onset of fever, chills, headache, and weakness. In most cases there is a painful swelling of the lymph node in the groin, armpit or neck areas. Physicians who suspect plague should promptly report it to their local public health district.\n\nSigns of plague in animals\n--------------------------\nPlague signs in cats and dogs are fever, lethargy, and loss of appetite. There may be a swelling in the lymph node under the jaw. With prompt diagnosis and appropriate antibiotic treatment, the fatality rate in people and pets can be greatly reduced.\n\nAmong pets, cats are highly susceptible to plague and may be an indicator that plague is in the area. If plague is suspected, any type of animal or human should be treated by a health professional immediately.\n\nBackground\n----------\nIn late May [2016], the Idaho Department of Fish and Game collected dead ground squirrels from several areas in Ada County and submitted them to public health laboratories for testing. The laboratory found the plague bacterium. Ground squirrel populations with plague can experience high mortality, sometimes evidenced by large numbers of carcasses. At this time, plague has been detected in ground squirrels -- not tree squirrels. Subsequently, a cat in neighboring Elmore County died of plague.\n\nPlague activity can increase in the spring and summer months when rodents are more active. However, wildlife experts say ground squirrels begin hibernating in late June/early July, at which time the threat of plague will decrease.\n\nArea of impact where plague has been identified in ground squirrels to date. Please note that rodents outside of this area may carry plague and prevention efforts should be heeded.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague, caused by _Yersinia pestis_, is enzootic among rodents in the western United States. Humans can be infected through 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals; 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals.\n\nPlague is a potential bioterrorism agent. Human infections are rare but can be life-threatening. The case fatality rate of plague depends on the clinical presentation (that is, bubonic, septicemic, or pneumonic) and timing of initiation of antibiotic therapy; if untreated, the case fatality rate is over 50 per cent for bubonic plague and approaches 100 per cent for pneumonic plague. Rapid laboratory identification can help guide therapy.\n\nDomestic cats and dogs can also contract plague from infective fleas. They may carry infected fleas home to their owners. Cats may serve as a direct source of infection. There are many flea treatments and repellents appropriate for pets available. Some products may be suitable for dogs but not cats, or may be suitable for an adult but not a younger animal. Be sure to consult your veterinarian, as some products may be toxic to cats, kittens, and puppies, even resulting in fatalities.\n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under the jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front leg (the armpit, if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever. Please take your pet to a veterinarian if you notice any abnormalities.\n\nVeterinarians should protect themselves by wearing gloves when examining these swellings. A bubo that ruptures may infect the veterinarian or even the pet owner if the pet owner is the one palpating the swelling.\n\nAnother form of the disease is the respiratory form. Cats may acquire this form and can spread it to their owners or the veterinarians through infected expiratory droplets. People are also prone to the respiratory infection.\n\nYou should also be aware that the fleas that hitchhike into your home via a pet vehicle can also transmit disease to you, the owner, or caretaker of the pet. Sleeping in the same bed with dogs has been associated with plague in enzootic areas. Plague patients with no history of exposure to rodents can be infected by _Y. pestis_ if their pets carry infected rodent fleas into the home. Veterinarians always should recommend flea control to dog and cat owners.\n\nParts of this comment have been excerpted from: CDC. Notes from the field: 2 cases of human plague -- Oregon, 2010. MMWR, 25 Feb 2011; 60(07);214 and the above referenced article http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6007a4.htm. - Mod.TG\n\nThe state of Idaho can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/3055. A county map can be seen at http://geology.com/county-map/idaho-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "Plague prevention in pets:\n- do not let your pets hunt or roam in the affected area;\n- talk to your veterinarian about using an appropriate flea control product on your pets;\n- sick pets should be examined promptly by a veterinarian;\n- don't leave your pet's food and water where rodents can get to it. This has been shown to increase your risk of getting plague;\n- clean up areas near the house where rodents could live, such as woodpiles, brush piles, junk and abandoned vehicles;\n- put hay, wood, and compost piles as far as possible from your home;\n- wear long-sleeved shirts and long pants;\n- use DEET on clothing in accordance with label instructions or wear clothing pre-treated with permethrin;\n- use DEET on exposed skin, in accordance with label instructions. To prevent plague in humans:\n- see your doctor immediately about any unexplained illness with a severe fever if you have been in the affected area;\n- avoid picking up or touching dead animals; wear gloves if you must handle dead animals;\n- do not let pets sleep in bed with you. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The case fatality rate of plague depends on the clinical presentation (that is, bubonic, septicemic, or pneumonic) and timing of initiation of antibiotic therapy; if untreated, the case fatality rate is over 50 per cent for bubonic plague and approaches 100 per cent for pneumonic plague. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague, caused by _Yersinia pestis_, is enzootic among rodents in the western United States. Among pets, cats are highly susceptible to plague and may be an indicator that plague is in the area. \n\nSigns of plague in animals\n Humans can be infected through 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals; 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals. With the known confirmed cases in these areas we want to people to be aware and be able to take appropriate steps to protect themselves and their pets from plague,' said State Wildlife Veterinarian Dr Mark Drew. \n\nSymptoms of plague in humans\n \n\nThe cat lived approximately 2 miles [3.2 km] from Mountain Home in an area not previously identified with confirmed plague. ' \n\nArea of impact where plague has been identified in ground squirrels to date. Plague is transmitted through the bites of infected fleas and can cause serious illness to people and pets if not treated quickly. \nSymptoms of plague in humans include sudden onset of fever, chills, headache, and weakness. \n\nDomestic cats and dogs can also contract plague from infective fleas. \n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under the jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front leg (the armpit, if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever. At this time, plague has been detected in ground squirrels -- not tree squirrels. It also can be transmitted to people by direct contact with infected animals, including rodents, rabbits and pets. However, wildlife experts say ground squirrels begin hibernating in late June/early July, at which time the threat of plague will decrease. \n\nYou should also be aware that the fleas that hitchhike into your home via a pet vehicle can also transmit disease to you, the owner, or caretaker of the pet. \n\n--\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2011-02-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Background", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Elmore County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ada County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Idaho", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4182029", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (02): (WA) pneumonic, NOT", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4182029", "date": "2016-04-25 12:45:12", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (02): (WASHINGTON) PNEUMONIC, NOT\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 23 Apr 2016\nSource: KEPR [edited]\nhttp://keprtv.com/news/local/benton-franklin-health-district-possible-plague-case-detected-in-patient\n\n\nPlague tests come back negative\n-------------------------------\nBenton-Franklin Health District was notified that a local resident was being tested for a possible case of pneumonic plague. Test results received today, 23 Apr 2016, from the Washington State Department of Health were negative.\n\nPlague occurs naturally in the western USA; the last case in Washington State was in 1984. The plague bacterium (_Yersinia pestis_) is transmitted by fleas and cycles naturally among wild rodents. Plague can also infect humans and their pets. Plague can be treated successfully with antimicrobials, but an infected person must be treated promptly.\n\n[byline: Kristi Paulus]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although there are no details regarding this case, if it were seemingly a zoonotic pneumonia with Gram negative bacilli, then _Francisella tularensis_ also needs to be considered. Tularemia pneumonia can also be fatal but, unlike pneumonic plague, does not* spread from person to person. - Mod.LL\n\nProMED-mail would be pleased to hear of the definitive diagnosis, when it is made. - Mod.SH\n*The word 'not' was unfortunately omitted from the original posting. - Mod.SH\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/248.]", "summary": "\n\n[byline: Kristi Paulus]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although there are no details regarding this case, if it were seemingly a zoonotic pneumonia with Gram negative bacilli, then _Francisella tularensis_ also needs to be considered. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n PLAGUE - USA (02): (WASHINGTON) PNEUMONIC, NOT\n**********************************************\n \nBenton-Franklin Health District was notified that a local resident was being tested for a possible case of pneumonic plague. Plague tests come back negative\n Date: Sat 23 Apr 2016\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1984-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Washington State", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WASHINGTON", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4265294", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, animal - USA (03): (ID) ground squirrel, domestic cat, susp", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4265294", "date": "2016-06-04 21:09:55", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (03): (IDAHO) GROUND SQUIRREL, DOMESTIC CAT, SUSPECTED\n***************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this report:\n[1] Ground squirrels\n[2] Domestic cat\n\n******\n[1] Ground squirrels\nDate: Fri 27 May 2016\nSource: Idaho Fish and Game news release [edited]\nhttp://fishandgame.idaho.gov/public/media/viewNewsRelease.cfm?newsID=8199\n\n\nPreliminary tests of ground squirrels found dead in desert areas of Ada and Elmore counties have come back positive for plague. Idaho public health and Idaho Fish and Game officials are asking people to take precautions as outdoor summer activities shift into high gear over the long Memorial Day [30 May 2016] weekend.\n\nLast year [2015], plague was confirmed in ground squirrels in the same general areas of southern Idaho. Plague can circulate in wild animal populations every year. Confirmatory laboratory tests are being conducted, with results expected next week [week of 1 Jun 2016].\n\nPlague is a bacterial disease of rodents that is transmitted through the bites of infected fleas and can cause serious illness to people and pets if not treated quickly. It also can be transmitted to people by direct contact with infected animals, including rodents, rabbits and pets. Common rodents that can become infected include ground squirrels, rats, voles and mice. Tree squirrels in Idaho are not known to carry plague.\n\n'Just like last year [2015], our investigation began in May after hearing reports from people finding dead ground squirrels in the desert southeast of Boise,' State Wildlife Veterinarian Dr Mark Drew said. 'We hope to have confirmation of these results soon and will keep the public up to date as we learn more.'\n\nPeople can greatly reduce their risk of becoming infected with plague by taking simple precautions, including avoiding contact with wild rodents, their fleas and rodent carcasses. Health officials recommend:\n- do not feed rodents in picnic or campground areas and never handle sick or dead rodents;\n- keep your pets from roaming and hunting ground squirrels or other rodents in affected desert areas;\n- talk to your veterinarian about using an appropriate flea control product on pets as not all products are safe for cats, dogs or children;\n- clean up areas near your home where rodents can live, such as woodpiles;\n- sick pets should be examined promptly by a veterinarian, especially if they may have had contact with sick or dead rodents in the desert areas south and east of Boise;\n- see your doctor if you have any unexplained illness involving a sudden and severe fever after being in a plague-impacted area;\n- put hay, wood, and compost piles as far as possible from your home;\n- don't leave pet food and water where rodents or other wild animals can access them.\n\nSymptoms of plague in humans include sudden onset of fever, chills, headache, and weakness. In most cases there is a painful swelling of the lymph node in the groin, armpit, or neck areas. Plague clinical signs in cats and dogs are fever, lethargy, and loss of appetite, with possible swelling in the lymph node under the jaw. With prompt diagnosis and appropriate antibiotic treatment, the fatality rate in people and pets can be greatly reduced. Physicians who suspect plague should promptly report it to their local public health district.\n\nIdaho Fish and Game is interested in reports of multiple (greater than 5) dead ground squirrels, yellow-bellied marmots (aka 'rock-chucks'), voles, cottontail rabbits, or jackrabbits. Please do not report single mortalities; observations of multiple mortalities are a greater indicator of possible plague activity. If people find groups of 5 or more dead animals listed above, they should not touch them, but should report the location to the Idaho Department of Fish and Game at https://idfg.idaho.gov/plague. All reports are reviewed and appropriately handled, however, not all people submitting reports will be contacted for follow-up.\n\nSince 1940, only 5 human cases of plague have been reported in Idaho. The last 2 cases reported in Idaho occurred in 1991 and 1992, with both patients fully recovering. In 2015, a dog tested positive for plague after ground squirrel exposure. The dog recovered after medical treatment.\n\nFor more information:\n- General overview: http://www.cdc.gov/plague/\n- FAQs: http://www.cdc.gov/plague/faq/index.html\n- Protect yourself from plague fact sheet: http://www.cdc.gov/plague/resources/235098_Plaguefactsheet_508.pdf\n- Idaho Department of Fish and Game: http://fishandgame.idaho.gov\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Domestic cat\nDate: Fri 3 Jun 2016\nSource: Idaho Elmore County Health Department Announcement\nhttp://www.cdhd.idaho.gov/pdfs/News/2016/06-03-16%20Pet-Cat-Likely-Died-of-Plague.pdf\n\n\nElmore County [Idaho] Cat Likely Died of Plague\nGround Squirrel Plague Area of Impact Expanded to the East\n----------------------------------------------------------\nLaboratory tests indicate an Elmore County cat likely died from plague. The cat had contact with ground squirrels, also known as 'whistle pigs,' before becoming ill. Family members and other household pets are being monitored to ensure the cat did not spread the infection.\n\nThe cat lived outside of the initial area of impact identified in the [27 May 2016] press release about plague in ground squirrels; the cat resided approximately 3 miles west of the City of Mountain Home. Given the positive initial tests for plague in the cat, the area of impact has been expanded eastward into Elmore County (see enclosed map). People living or recreating in the area should take precautions.\n\nPlague is transmitted through the bites of infected fleas and can cause serious illness to people and pets if not treated quickly. It also can be transmitted to people by direct contact with infected animals, including rodents, rabbits and pets. Common rodents that can become infected include ground squirrels, rats, voles and mice. Tree squirrels in Idaho are not known to carry plague.\n\n'This is a reminder that whether you live in the area of impact or recreate there, it is very important to take precautions to avoid contact with ground squirrels and their potentially infected fleas. Make sure your pets have proper flea control. Do not let your pets touch ground squirrels in the affected area. People can be exposed to plague when pets bring infected fleas back into the home, by caring for a sick pet without proper precautions, or by contact with rodents carrying fleas,' said Sarah Correll, Epidemiologist for Central District Health Department.\n\nEarlier this week, official lab tests confirmed plague infection in ground squirrel die-offs found in desert areas south of Boise and west of Mountain Home.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations. Some species are particularly susceptible. For example, _Y. pestis_ caused the extinction of entire colonies of black-tailed prairie dogs. Small rodents such as deer mice and grasshopper mice are suggested to act as the reservoirs. Larger species like squirrels and chipmunks are considered to be more vulnerable to infection.\n\nThe state of Idaho can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/215. A county map can be seen at http://geology.com/county-map/idaho-county-map.gif. - Mod.PMB\n\nThe presence of plague in domestic animals increases the risk of transmission to humans. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "Health officials recommend:\n- do not feed rodents in picnic or campground areas and never handle sick or dead rodents;\n- keep your pets from roaming and hunting ground squirrels or other rodents in affected desert areas;\n- talk to your veterinarian about using an appropriate flea control product on pets as not all products are safe for cats, dogs or children;\n- clean up areas near your home where rodents can live, such as woodpiles;\n- sick pets should be examined promptly by a veterinarian, especially if they may have had contact with sick or dead rodents in the desert areas south and east of Boise;\n- see your doctor if you have any unexplained illness involving a sudden and severe fever after being in a plague-impacted area;\n- put hay, wood, and compost piles as far as possible from your home;\n- don't leave pet food and water where rodents or other wild animals can access them. For more information:\n- General overview: http://www.cdc.gov/plague/\n- FAQs: http://www.cdc.gov/plague/faq/index.html\n- Protect yourself from plague fact sheet: http://www.cdc.gov/plague/resources/235098_Plaguefactsheet_508.pdf\n- Idaho Department of Fish and Game: http://fishandgame.idaho.gov\n\n--\n A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (03): (IDAHO) GROUND SQUIRREL, DOMESTIC CAT, SUSPECTED\n***************************************************************************\n People can be exposed to plague when pets bring infected fleas back into the home, by caring for a sick pet without proper precautions, or by contact with rodents carrying fleas,' said Sarah Correll, Epidemiologist for Central District Health Department. Source: Idaho Elmore County Health Department Announcement\nhttp://www.cdhd.idaho.gov/pdfs/News/2016/06-03-16%20Pet-Cat-Likely-Died-of-Plague.pdf\n\n\nElmore County [Idaho] Cat Likely Died of Plague\n \n\nPeople can greatly reduce their risk of becoming infected with plague by taking simple precautions, including avoiding contact with wild rodents, their fleas and rodent carcasses. \n\nThe cat lived outside of the initial area of impact identified in the [27 May 2016] press release about plague in ground squirrels \n\n'This is a reminder that whether you live in the area of impact or recreate there, it is very important to take precautions to avoid contact with ground squirrels and their potentially infected fleas. \n\nEarlier this week, official lab tests confirmed plague infection in ground squirrel die-offs found in desert areas south of Boise and west of Mountain Home. \n\nPlague is transmitted through the bites of infected fleas and can cause serious illness to people and pets if not treated quickly. \n\n'Just like last year [2015], our investigation began in May after hearing reports from people finding dead ground squirrels in the desert southeast of Boise,' State Wildlife Veterinarian Dr Mark Drew said. ' Plague is a bacterial disease of rodents that is transmitted through the bites of infected fleas and can cause serious illness to people and pets if not treated quickly. \n\nLast year [2015], plague was confirmed in ground squirrels in the same general areas of southern Idaho. \n\nIdaho Fish and Game is interested in reports of multiple (greater than 5) dead ground squirrels, yellow-bellied marmots (aka 'rock-chucks'), voles, cottontail rabbits, or jackrabbits. Ground Squirrel Plague Area of Impact Expanded to the East\n \n\n\nPreliminary tests of ground squirrels found dead in desert areas of Ada and Elmore counties have come back positive for plague. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< ----------------------------------------------------------\nLaboratory tests indicate an Elmore County cat likely died from plague. It also can be transmitted to people by direct contact with infected animals, including rodents, rabbits and pets. It also can be transmitted to people by direct contact with infected animals, including rodents, rabbits and pets.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-05-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "1991-03-25 00:00:00", "1992-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00", "1940-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-05-25 00:00:00", "2016-05-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Boise", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Idaho", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the City of Mountain Home", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Elmore County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4178118", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, animal - USA (02): (WY) feline", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4178118", "date": "2016-04-23 12:19:05", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (02): (WYOMING) FELINE\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 21 Apr 2016\nSource: Wyoming Department of Health [edited]\nhttp://www.health.wyo.gov/News.aspx?NewsID=892\n\n\nThree Park County cats have recently been confirmed as infected with plague, according to the Wyoming Department of Health (WDH). No human cases have been identified. All 3 cats lived in Cody, off the South Fork Road. The illness was confirmed in the 1st pet by the Wyoming State Veterinary Laboratory in Laramie on 12 Apr 2016, with confirmation of the 3rd on 20 Apr 2016.\n\n'Plague is a serious bacterial infection that can be deadly for pets and for people if not treated promptly with antibiotics,' said Dr Karl Musgrave, state public health veterinarian with WDH. 'The disease can be transmitted to humans from ill animals and by fleas coming from infected animals. We want people to know of the potential threat in the area the cats were from as well as across the state. Dogs can also become ill and transmit the disease.'\n\n'While the disease is rare in humans, it's safe to assume that the risk for plague exists all around Wyoming,' Musgrave said. Six human cases of plague have been confirmed in Wyoming since 1978 with the last one reported in 2008. There are an average of 7 human cases across the nation each year.\n\nPrecautions Musgrave recommends to help prevent plague infections include:\n- avoid unnecessary exposure to rodents;\n- avoid contact with rodent carcasses;\n- avoid areas with unexplained rodent die-offs;\n- use insect repellent on boots and pants when in areas that might have fleas;\n- use flea repellent on pets, and properly dispose of rodents pets may bring home.\n\nPlague signs in animals can include enlarged lymph glands; swelling in the neck, face or around the ears; fever; chills; lack of energy; coughing; vomiting; diarrhea and dehydration. Ill animals should be taken to a veterinarian.\n\nPlague symptoms in people can include fever, swollen and tender lymph glands, extreme exhaustion, headache, chills, coughing, difficulty breathing, abdominal pain, vomiting and diarrhea. People who are ill should seek professional medical attention.\n\nMore information about plague is available online from the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention at http://www.cdc.gov/plague/.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is transmitted by fleas. There are several forms of plague in human beings: bubonic, septicemic and pneumonic.\n\nPlague, caused by _Yersinia pestis_, is enzootic among rodents in the western United States. Humans can be infected through 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals; 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals.\n\nPlague is a potential bioterrorism agent. Human infections are rare but can be life-threatening. The case fatality rate of plague depends on the clinical presentation (that is, bubonic, septicemic, or pneumonic) and timing of initiation of antibiotic therapy; if untreated, the case fatality rate is over 50 per cent for bubonic plague and approaches 100 per cent for pneumonic plague. Rapid laboratory identification can help guide therapy.\n\nDomestic cats and dogs can also contract plague from infective fleas. They may carry infected fleas home to their owners. Cats may serve as a direct source of infection. There are many flea treatments and repellents appropriate for pets available. Some products may be suitable for dogs but not cats, or may be suitable for an adult but not a younger animal. Be sure to consult your veterinarian, as some products may be toxic to cats, kittens, and puppies, even resulting in fatalities.\n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under the jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front leg (the armpit, if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever. These clinical signs may be present in the dog as well. Swelling under the jaw in cats is frequently mistaken as a cat fight abscess. Please take your pet to a veterinarian if you notice any abnormalities.\n\nVeterinarians should protect themselves by wearing gloves when examining these swellings. A bubo that ruptures may infect the veterinarian or even the pet owner if the pet owner is the one palpating the swelling.\n\nAnother form of the disease is the respiratory form. Cats may acquire this form and can spread it to their owners or the veterinarians through infected expiratory droplets. People are also prone to the respiratory infection.\n\nYou should also be aware that the fleas that hitchhike into the home via a pet vehicle can also transmit disease to you, the owner, or caretaker of the pet. Sleeping in the same bed with dogs has been associated with plague in enzootic areas. Plague patients with no history of exposure to rodents can be infected by _Y. pestis_ if their pets carry infected rodent fleas into the home. Veterinarians always should recommend flea control to dog and cat owners.\n\nPlague is infamous for killing millions of people in Europe during the Middle Ages. Today, modern antibiotics are effective in treating plague. Without prompt treatment, the disease can cause serious illness or death. Presently, human plague infections continue to occur in the western United States, but significantly more cases occur in parts of Africa and Asia.\n\nParts of this comment have been excerpted from: CDC. Notes from the field: two cases of human plague -- Oregon, 2010. MMWR, 25 Feb 2011; 60(07);214 http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6007a4.htm. And from http://www.cdc.gov/plague/. - Mod.TG\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/14420.]", "summary": "Precautions Musgrave recommends to help prevent plague infections include:\n- avoid unnecessary exposure to rodents;\n- avoid contact with rodent carcasses;\n- avoid areas with unexplained rodent die-offs;\n- use insect repellent on boots and pants when in areas that might have fleas;\n- use flea repellent on pets, and properly dispose of rodents pets may bring home.\n\n More information about plague is available online from the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention at http://www.cdc.gov/plague/.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The case fatality rate of plague depends on the clinical presentation (that is, bubonic, septicemic, or pneumonic) and timing of initiation of antibiotic therapy; if untreated, the case fatality rate is over 50 per cent for bubonic plague and approaches 100 per cent for pneumonic plague. Humans can be infected through 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals; 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals. Plague patients with no history of exposure to rodents can be infected by _Y. pestis_ if their pets carry infected rodent fleas into the home. \n\nYou should also be aware that the fleas that hitchhike into the home via a pet vehicle can also transmit disease to you, the owner, or caretaker of the pet. Presently, human plague infections continue to occur in the western United States, but significantly more cases occur in parts of Africa and Asia.\n\n \n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under the jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front leg (the armpit, if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever. \n\nDomestic cats and dogs can also contract plague from infective fleas. Plague signs in animals can include enlarged lymph glands; swelling in the neck, face or around the ears; fever; chills; lack of energy; coughing; vomiting; diarrhea and dehydration. \n\n'While the disease is rare in humans, it's safe to assume that the risk for plague exists all around Wyoming,' Musgrave said. Plague symptoms in people can include fever, swollen and tender lymph glands, extreme exhaustion, headache, chills, coughing, difficulty breathing, abdominal pain, vomiting and diarrhea. Plague is a serious bacterial infection that can be deadly for pets and for people if not treated promptly with antibiotics,' said Dr Karl Musgrave, state public health veterinarian with WDH. ' promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is transmitted by fleas. The disease can be transmitted to humans from ill animals and by fleas coming from infected animals. http://www.health.wyo.gov/News.aspx?NewsID=892\n\n\nThree Park County cats have recently been confirmed as infected with plague, according to the Wyoming Department of Health (WDH). \n\nAnother form of the disease is the respiratory form. Test results are expected on Saturday [23 Apr 2016] from the Washington State Department of Health. The case has not been confirmed and there is no immediate risk to the general public, the health district said. The health district will continue to investigate the case, as it does with all reportable conditions.\n\nPlague occurs naturally in the western United States; the last case in Washington State was in 1984. The plague bacterium (_Yersinia pestis_) is transmitted by fleas and cycles naturally among wild rodents. Plague can also infect humans and their pets. Plague can be treated successfully with antimicrobials, but an infected person must be treated promptly. Anyone who has been exposed to the illness can be treated with antibiotics before developing symptoms.\n\nPlague is most often transmitted through bites of infected fleas. It can also be contracted by touching or skinning infected animals (coyotes, squirrels, rats, prairie dogs, and rabbits) or inhaling droplets from the cough of an infected person or animal (especially sick cats). The last reported human-to-human transmission in the US occurred in the 1920s.\n\n[byline: Dawn J. Sagert]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail awaits additional information about this case. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/248.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n[byline: Dawn J. The dogs were treated and recovered.\n\nThe city did not release further information but warned not to touch or let your pet come into contact with sick or dead animals and to make sure they are treated for fleas.\n\nContact your veterinarian if your pet is sick and call a doctor if you become ill.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nPromed mail from Healthmap alerts\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n[Plague is transmitted by fleas.
