Notes from the field: two cases of human plague -- Oregon, 2010.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-01-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-02-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-01-14 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3920609", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Madagascar", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3920609", "date": "2016-01-08 16:12:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR\n*******************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 7 Jan 2016\nSource: The Hamilton Spectator [edited]\nhttp://www.thespec.com/news-story/6222323-bubonic-plague-outbreak-kills-63-in-madagascar/\n\n\nThe latest outbreak of bubonic plague on the Indian Ocean island of Madagascar has killed 63 people since August 2015, the Health Ministry said. At least 174 cases of the disease have been detected, Maherisoa Ratsitorahina, head of disease surveillance at the ministry, said in a statement Thursday [7 Jan 2016] in the capital, Antananarivo. Madagascar notified the WHO of the current outbreak in September 2015.\n\nAt least 79 people died after an outbreak in 2014 that continued into early 2015, when at least 335 cases were reported, according to the WHO. The bacterial disease is spread to people who have been bitten by infected rodent fleas, the WHO says.\n\nEfforts to curb the spread of the disease are being impeded by a build-up of garbage in Antananarivo amid a dispute between the municipality and the national government over who is responsible for waste management in the city.\n\n[Byline: Fanja Razafimahatratra]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is caused by the _Yersinia pestis_ bacillus, carried by rat fleas. At the start of the rainy season, currently, rats flee the sewers of Madagascar in massive numbers and take refuge in people's cottages. Care must be taken in any rodent eradication program to ensure that a flea-killing compound is part of the plan. Just as in a natural rodent die-off from _Y. pestis_, the fleas will seek alternate hosts, that is, humans.\n\nThe following paragraph is from 1998 (Chanteau S, Ratsifasoamanana L, Rasoamanana B, et al: Plague, a Reemerging Disease in Madagascar. Emerg Infect Dis 1998; 4(1): 101-4; http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/4/1/98-0114_article.htm).\n\n'Between 1930 and 1990, bubonic plague had 'virtually disappeared' on the island due to efficient pest-control and good health management. However since 1990, an annual 200 cases are being reported, and bubonic plague takes on epidemic form, especially in the port of Mahajanga, each year. In the capital city of Antananarivo, more cases are also being notified each year since 1990. Madagascar (pop. 13 million) has accounted for 45 percent of all the cases of plague in Africa.'\n\nFatalities related to plague usually are caused by spread of the organism from the bubo (the very painful infected lymph node which drains the area where the flea bite occurred) to the bloodstream. The bacteremia can cause a coagulopathy, producing the purpura seen in the 'black plague' and also spread to the lungs causing a hemorrhagic pneumonia. It is the pneumonia that can facilitate person-to-person transmission.\n\nMadagascar was the location of the isolation of multi-antimicrobial resistant _Y. pestis_ in 1995 (Galimand M, Guiyoule A, Gerbaud G, et al: Multidrug resistance in _Yersinia pestis_ mediated by a transferable plasmid. N Engl J Med 1997; 337(10): 677-81; http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJM199709043371004). The strain was resistant to chloramphenicol, streptomycin, and tetracycline but sensitive to fluoroquinolones and trimethoprim as well as other aminoglycosides. This was an ominous observation; however, it is not clear whether this naturally occurring strain has persisted or spread. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/181.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is caused by the _Yersinia pestis_ bacillus, carried by rat fleas. \n\nAt least 79 people died after an outbreak in 2014 that continued into early 2015, when at least 335 cases were reported, according to the WHO. \n\nEfforts to curb the spread of the disease are being impeded by a build-up of garbage in Antananarivo amid a dispute between the municipality and the national government over who is responsible for waste management in the city. \n\n'Between 1930 and 1990, bubonic plague had 'virtually disappeared' on the island due to efficient pest-control and good health management. \n\nMadagascar was the location of the isolation of multi-antimicrobial resistant _Y. pestis_ in 1995 (Galimand M, Guiyoule A, Gerbaud G, et al: Multidrug resistance in _Yersinia pestis_ mediated by a transferable plasmid. Fatalities related to plague usually are caused by spread of the organism from the bubo (the very painful infected lymph node which drains the area where the flea bite occurred) to the bloodstream. PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR\n*******************\n The latest outbreak of bubonic plague on the Indian Ocean island of Madagascar has killed 63 people since August 2015, the Health Ministry said. However since 1990, an annual 200 cases are being reported, and bubonic plague takes on epidemic form, especially in the port of Mahajanga, each year.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-25 00:00:00", "1998-03-25 00:00:00", "1990-03-25 00:00:00", "1995-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-09-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-08-25 00:00:00", "2016-01-07 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mahajanga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rasoamanana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3801914", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Madagascar (05): (IT) fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3801914", "date": "2015-11-18 17:48:22", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (05): (ITASY REGION) FATAL\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 12 Nov 2015\nSource: L'express de Madagascar [machine trans. edited]\nhttp://www.lexpressmada.com/blog/actualites/miarinarivo-deux-personnes-succombent-a-la-peste-48173/\n\n\nTwo people from 2 different municipalities of the Miarinarivo district died on 31 Oct 2015, reported Dr. Bruno Randrema Marcellin, communications manager of the Division of the Plague Ministry of Health yesterday, 11 Nov 2015.\n\n'These individuals have died following a bubonic plague,' he said. The cause of death has been confirmed by the Pasteur Institute of Madagascar, according to the report of the Ministry of Public Health. No other facts have been detected in these 2 municipalities to date.\n\nIn addition, close monitoring continues for other cases. Since August 2015, the number of victims of the plague in Madagascar continues. 20 deaths were recorded so far in 2015. Tsiroanomandidy and Moramanga are the most affected cities.\n\nThe Ministry of Public Health called for vigilance by all. Delay of treatment of the plague is fatal.\n\n[Byline: Miangaly Ralitera]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-FRA\n<promed-fra@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is caused by the _Yersinia pestis_ bacillus, which in Madagascar is carried by rat fleas. At the start of the rainy season, currently, rats flee the sewers of Madagascar in massive numbers and take refuge in people's cottages.\n\nThe following paragraph of this posting is from Chanteau S, Ratsifasoamanana L, Rasoamanana B, et al: Plague, a Reemerging Disease in Madagascar. Emerg Infect Dis 1998; 4(1): 101-4; http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2627662/pdf/9452403.pdf:\n\nBetween 1930 and 1990, bubonic plague had 'virtually disappeared' on the island due to efficient pest-control and good health-management. However since 1990, an annual 200 cases are being reported and bubonic plague takes on epidemic form especially in the port of Mahajanga each year. In the capital city of Antananarivo more cases are also being notified each year since 1990. Madagascar (pop. 13 million) [pop. 22.92 million, 2013] has accounted for 45 percent of all the cases of plague in Africa.\n\nThe circumstances related to the deaths of these cases is not stated. Fatalities related to plague usually are caused by spread of the organism from the bubo (the very painful infected lymph node which drains the area where the flea bite occurred) to the bloodstream. The bacteremia can cause a coagulopathy producing the purpura seen in the 'Black Plague' and also spread to the lung causing a hemorrhagic pneumonia. It is the pneumonia that can facilitate person-to-person transmission.\n\nMiarinarivo is a city in Itasy Region, in the Central Highlands of Madagascar. It is located 100 km (62 miles) from Antananarivo and is the capital of Itasy Region as well as of its district and can be found on a map of the island nation at:\nhttp://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/madagascar/mar2582r/madagascar_pol.jpg. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/181.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-FRA\n<promed-fra@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is caused by the _Yersinia pestis_ bacillus, which in Madagascar is carried by rat fleas. Emerg Infect Dis 1998; 4(1): 101-4; http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2627662/pdf/9452403.pdf:\n\nBetween 1930 and 1990, bubonic plague had 'virtually disappeared' on the island due to efficient pest-control and good health-management. http://www.lexpressmada.com/blog/actualites/miarinarivo-deux-personnes-succombent-a-la-peste-48173/\n\n\nTwo people from 2 different municipalities of the Miarinarivo district died on 31 Oct 2015, reported Dr. Bruno Randrema Marcellin, communications manager of the Division of the Plague Ministry of Health yesterday, 11 Nov 2015. PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (05): (ITASY REGION) FATAL\n**********************************************\n However since 1990, an annual 200 cases are being reported and bubonic plague takes on epidemic form especially in the port of Mahajanga each year. \n\n'These individuals have died following a bubonic plague,' he said. It is located 100 km (62 miles) from Antananarivo and is the capital of Itasy Region as well as of its district and can be found on a map of the island nation at:\nhttp://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/madagascar/mar2582r/madagascar_pol.jpg. Fatalities related to plague usually are caused by spread of the organism from the bubo (the very painful infected lymph node which drains the area where the flea bite occurred) to the bloodstream. [Byline: Miangaly Ralitera]\n\n--\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1990-03-25 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00", "1998-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-08-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mahajanga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rasoamanana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Itasy Region", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4052792", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Plague: worldwide, 2010-2015", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4052792", "date": "2016-02-26 13:57:17", "main_text": "PLAGUE: WORLDWIDE, 2010-2015\n****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 26 Feb 2016\nSource: WHO, Weekly Epidemiological Record (WER) 20168: 89-104 [edited]\nhttp://www.who.int/entity/wer/2016/wer9108.pdf?ua=1\n\n\nPlague around the world, 2010-2015\n----------------------------------\nPlague is a bacterial infection mainly affecting small mammals and transmitted by fleas. The geographical distribution of the disease is very focalized. Occasionally, the pathogen _Yersinia pestis_ can infect humans through infected flea bites. Human plague is a serious disease, particularly in its septicaemic and pneumonic forms. The pneumonic form, invariably fatal unless treated early, is especially contagious and can trigger terrifying epidemics through direct person-to-person contact. In these circumstances, plague is simultaneously a medical and a public health emergency.\n\nBetween 1 Jan 2010 and 31 Dec 2015, 3248 cases of plague in humans were reported, resulting in 584 deaths (Table 1) [for Table, see source URL above. - Mod.LL]. The principal animal reservoir (which differs from region to region) and local socioeconomic conditions are determinants of the epidemiological characteristics of the disease and the risk of transmission to humans. Plague is a disease of poverty in Africa, South America, and India, where the animal reservoir essentially comprises commensal rodents, but tends to be a sporadic disease associated with outdoor occupations in the other endemic regions.\n\nAfrica\n------\nIn Africa, 4 countries still regularly report cases.\n\nMadagascar is the most seriously affected country in the world. The surveillance system is relatively effective, thanks to the support of the national Pasteur Institute. Thus, specimens are taken from 95 percent of suspected cases and nearly 55 percent of these are confirmed as plague cases. Incidence has declined in the last 2 years but there has been an increase in the overall case fatality rate (23 percent in 2015) associated with the higher frequency of pneumonic forms (23.3 percent). This increase in serious forms of the disease is symptomatic of the deteriorating fabric of the health system as a result of the recent social and political crisis in the country. In 2014, one case of pneumonic plague (with a subsequently fatal outcome) was confirmed in the capital, Antananarivo. The rapid response of the health authorities fortunately prevented the emergence of any secondary cases.\n\nThe Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) has seen incidence rates collapse in recent years, but it is unlikely that this indicates a decrease in real terms. The 2 endemic health districts with a population of 1.9 million are located in the north-east of the country, a troubled region where the surveillance system is coming under increasing strain. In addition to sporadic cases, the region is regularly affected by epidemics affecting dozens of people: in 2014, for example, there was an epidemic of bubonic plague with a case-fatality rate of 8.7 percent and another of pneumonic plague with a case-fatality rate of more than 41 percent.\n\nUganda shares the same plague focus as the DRC and reports cases every year in Arua region. 30 percent of these cases are confirmed by laboratory diagnosis.\n\nAt the end of 2014, an epidemic of bubonic plague occurred in Mbule district in the Manyara region of the United Republic of Tanzania, resulting in the deaths of 5 of the 38 people affected. None of the cases were confirmed using international standards, however.\n\nIt should be noted that no cases have been reported in North Africa, a region that witnessed several re-emergent outbreaks in the previous decade.\n\nThe Americas\n------------\nIn the Americas, Peru regularly reports cases in 4 regions in the north-west of the country, where new foci emerged in 2013. These are essentially sporadic cases of bubonic plague associated with farming activities in rural areas. The return of the El Nino weather pattern in 2016 might go hand in hand with a recrudescence of plague, as has been noted on previous occasions.\n\nIn the western United States of America (USA), plague circulates among wild rodents in rural and semi-rural areas, resulting in several cases every year. Humans are regularly infected through contact with domestic animals (cats or dogs). In 2014, 3 people in Colorado developed pneumonic plague following exposure to a sick animal and a fourth person might have been infected through contact with one of these patients, making this the first possible case of person-to-person transmission recorded in the USA since 1924.\n\nAsia\n----\nIt is thought that plague originated in Central Asia, and this region is still the biggest natural focus of the disease. However, the at-risk population is restricted to breeders and hunters because the reservoirs consist mainly of gerbils in the steppe and marmots in mountainous areas. Consequently, the risk of transmission to humans is very low and outbreaks of the disease in people are totally sporadic.\n\nTwo marmot hunters contracted bubonic plague, one in Kyrgyzstan in 2013, the other in the Russian Federation in 2014. Kyrgyzstan had seen no cases of human plague since 1981, and in the Gorno-Altaisk mountains in the Russian Federation, this was the 1st case since 1961.\n\nMongolia and China sporadically report similar cases.\n\nDiscussion\n----------\nBy simply monitoring the incidence of human plague cases, we can only get a partial picture of the true extent of circulation of the microorganism in nature, and hence of the risk to people. Among endemic countries that have reported no cases in the period 2010-2015, some, for example India or Kazakhstan, carry out planned and regular entomological and zoological surveillance activities. But this surveillance is expensive and complicated to maintain, and is very often neglected in the absence of any human cases.\n\nIn many endemic countries, it is hard to obtain detailed knowledge about the status or development of natural foci. The interpretation that should be given to the sudden emergence of a case of human plague, in some places decades after the most recent outbreak, can therefore present special challenges.\n\nSurveillance of circulating strains of _Y. pestis_ has revealed no evidence of new resistance to antibiotics.\n\nThe challenge in 2015 remains that of ensuring early treatment and hence diagnosis of plague, both clinically and in terms of laboratory testing. The use of rapid diagnostic tests has made laboratory confirmation much easier, but this method is still not being routinely employed. Some of the cases reported in Africa might not fit the definition of probable or confirmed cases, but the information that would enable us to make a determination is not available.\n\nMoreover, given that total incidence does not exceed a few hundred cases and as the endemic areas are highly localized, minor changes in surveillance in a particular administrative region or even in a particular health district can significantly affect national and even global data.\n\nAnnual variations in incidence should be treated with caution.\n\nTo what extent is the reported global incidence a reflection of the actual plague situation?\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nA number of countries have demonstrated their capacity to detect and confirm isolated and completely unexpected cases following decades of epidemiological silence (Kyrgyzstan in 2013 and the Russian Federation in 2014). It is not unlikely that some cases escape surveillance, particularly in Africa and South America. Yet it is scarcely probable that these cases would have a significant impact on the rate of global incidence: human plague is still a rare and serious disease which, in its pneumonic form, triggers epidemics that make headlines because of their high case-fatality rate.\n\nThe downward trend in global incidence observable in recent years therefore appears to mirror the reality. In the absence of systematic global surveillance of natural foci, it is not possible to say that this development is related to changes in the way that the microorganism is circulating in the environment. Moreover, there has been no significant improvement in prevention.\n\nThe role of improved living conditions cannot be ruled out, but it could also be a natural cyclical development as already seen in the past. Whatever the explanation, the human plague burden cannot be gauged solely by the number of cases or deaths. In the past 15 years, violent epidemics of pneumonic plague and the emergence and re-emergence of the disease in urban areas have continually fuelled public anxiety and mobilized the international community.\n\nIn the collective unconscious and beyond the epidemiological reality, plague is still seen as a scourge of humanity in 2016.\n\n[Byline: E Bertherat]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[2015 was a 'banner year' for _Yersinia pestis_ infections in the USA, with now 16 cases and 4 deaths. In recent decades, an average of 7 human plague cases have been reported each year (range: 1-17 cases per year) with 0-2 deaths. These were all the cases in 2015 reported from the Americas. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "In addition to sporadic cases, the region is regularly affected by epidemics affecting dozens of people: in 2014, for example, there was an epidemic of bubonic plague with a case-fatality rate of 8.7 percent and another of pneumonic plague with a case-fatality rate of more than 41 percent. In recent decades, an average of 7 human plague cases have been reported each year (range: 1-17 cases per year) with 0-2 deaths. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Yet it is scarcely probable that these cases would have a significant impact on the rate of global incidence: human plague is still a rare and serious disease which, in its pneumonic form, triggers epidemics that make headlines because of their high case-fatality rate. Thus, specimens are taken from 95 percent of suspected cases and nearly 55 percent of these are confirmed as plague cases. Some of the cases reported in Africa might not fit the definition of probable or confirmed cases, but the information that would enable us to make a determination is not available.\n\n Moreover, given that total incidence does not exceed a few hundred cases and as the endemic areas are highly localized, minor changes in surveillance in a particular administrative region or even in a particular health district can significantly affect national and even global data. These are essentially sporadic cases of bubonic plague associated with farming activities in rural areas. In the past 15 years, violent epidemics of pneumonic plague and the emergence and re-emergence of the disease in urban areas have continually fuelled public anxiety and mobilized the international community. [Byline: E Bertherat]\n\n--\n The 2 endemic health districts with a population of 1.9 million are located in the north-east of the country, a troubled region where the surveillance system is coming under increasing strain.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-03-25 00:00:00", "1981-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-12-31 00:00:00", "1961-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00", "1924-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the United Republic of Tanzania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Peru", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States of America", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Russian Federation", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of the", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kyrgyzstan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3781747", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, animal - USA (15): (CO) prairie dog, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3781747", "date": "2015-11-10 16:23:26", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (15): (COLORADO) PRAIRIE DOG, ALERT\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 4 Nov 2015\nSource: ReporterHerald.com [edited]\nhttp://www.reporterherald.com/news/larimer-county/ci_29072097/prairie-dog-plague-idd-at-bobcat-ridge\n\n\nA prairie dog found at Bobcat Ridge Natural Area is believed to have been infected with plague, prompting officials to urge residents to take caution.\n\nThe trail at the Fort Collins Natural Area remains open, but signs have been posted letting residents know about the animal and offering safety advice.\n\nAran Meyer, wildlife biologist, said officials do not want to cause people to panic but also want to make people aware. 'It's important to protect yourself,' said Meyer. 'We need to find that balance ... I wouldn't say it's unsafe; just have a heightened awareness, a situational awareness, just like you would to avoid West Nile.'\n\nA visitor to the natural area noticed a prairie dog that appeared to be ill last weekend [31 Oct - 1 Nov 2015] and alerted a ranger. Initial testing revealed that the rodent was likely infected with plague, though officials are still awaiting final confirmation.\n\nPlague can spread to pets and humans, often through the bite of an infected flea or through close contact with an infected animal. The condition can be fatal unless it is diagnosed and treated quickly.\n\nColorado has reported 20 total cases of plague in humans between 2005 and 2015, including 4 cases this year [2015] and 8 cases in 2014, according to the Colorado Department of Health and Environment. The plague caused at least 2 deaths this year, including one in Pueblo County as well as the death of 16-year-old TG in Larimer County in June 2015.\n\nTG died just days after his 16th birthday after suffering flu-like symptoms. Health officials believe the teen was bitten by an infected flea somewhere near his family's rural property in Red Feather Lakes. His was the 1st human case of plague in Larimer County since 1999.\n\nSymptoms of plague include sudden onset of high fever, chills, headache, muscle aches and weakness. Residents who become ill with these symptoms within 7 days of visiting a plague-infected area are urged to consult their doctor.\n\nOfficials also urge residents to take preventative measures, including using insect repellant on their skin and clothing and using a flea and tick preventative on dogs and cats. Cats are particularly susceptible to plague, and residents are warned not to let them or dogs roam free. (Neither is allowed at Bobcat Ridge.)\n\nOther advice includes: do not camp near rodent nests or burrows; avoid sick or dead animals; and, if you are a hunter or trapper, wear gloves when handling your prey.\n\n[Byline: Pamela Johnson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations. Humans are at risk of becoming infected if they are exposed to rodent fleas.\n\nA map of the affected area can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/awL4. - Mod.PMB\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/209.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nColorado has reported 20 total cases of plague in humans between 2005 and 2015, including 4 cases this year [2015] and 8 cases in 2014, according to the Colorado Department of Health and Environment. Date: Wed 4 Nov 2015\n Humans are at risk of becoming infected if they are exposed to rodent fleas. \n\n \n\n Source: ReporterHerald.com [edited]\nhttp://www.reporterherald.com/news/larimer-county/ci_29072097/prairie-dog-plague-idd-at-bobcat-ridge His was the 1st human case of plague in Larimer County since 1999.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1999-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-06-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Larimer County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pueblo County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3668691", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (16): (NM) septicemic", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3668691", "date": "2015-09-24 16:21:50", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (16): (NEW MEXICO) SEPTICEMIC\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 23 Sep 2015\nSource: New Mexico Department of Health [edited]\nhttp://nmhealth.org/news/disease/2015/9/?view=313\n\n\nHuman Plague Case Confirmed in Santa Fe County\n----------------------------------------------\nThe New Mexico Department of Health announced today, 23 Sep 2015, a laboratory-confirmed case of plague in a 73-year-old woman from Santa Fe County. The case was confirmed at the Department of Health's Scientific Laboratory Division. This is the 4th human case of plague in New Mexico in 2015 and the 2nd in Santa Fe County. The woman was hospitalized and is back home recovering. The other cases in the state occurred in a 52-year-old woman from Santa Fe County, who died from the illness, and in a 65-year-old man and a 59-year-old woman, both from Bernalillo County, who have recovered.\n\n'This is the 4th case of plague in New Mexico with the patient presenting clinical signs of septicemic plague,' said Department of Health Secretary Retta Ward, MPH. 'Though septicemic plague is less common and harder to recognize than the more common form of bubonic plague, health care providers need to consider plague in their diagnosis when the patient has a fever of unknown origin and when the patient is from plague endemic areas of the state.'\n\nSepticemic plague accounts for approximately 20-25 percent of New Mexico cases. No detectable swollen lymph node (bubo) is found.\n\nPlague is a potentially fatal illness in people that occurs in many parts of New Mexico. It is caused by a bacterium found in rodents, especially ground squirrels, rabbits and pack rats. Most human cases of plague are acquired through the bite of infected fleas. Dogs and cats are also susceptible to plague and are infected either through bites of infected fleas or by eating an animal that has died from the disease.\n\n'Several of our plague cases in 2015 have most likely been exposed to plague-infected rodent fleas brought into the home and bedroom by dogs and cats that are allowed to roam and hunt and aren't treated with a flea control product, said Paul Ettestad, state public health veterinarian with the Department of Health.\n\nIn addition to the 4 human cases, there have been 8 cases of plague in 2015 in dogs and cats, including pets from Bernalillo, Santa Fe, and Torrance counties.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This continues to be a 'banner year' for _Yersinia pestis_ infections in the USA with 15 cases and 4 deaths. In recent decades, an average of 7 human plague cases have been reported each year (range: 1-17 cases per year) with 0-2 deaths.\n\nThe following was extracted from Prentice MB, Rahalison L: Plague. Lancet. 2007; 369(9568): 1196-207, with the citations removed:\n\n'Some plague cases (10-25 percent) present with primary septicemia (hypotension, shock) without lymph nodes being obviously affected and these patients have higher mortality than those with bubonic plague. The term septicemic plague can be confusing, since most patients with buboes have detectable bacteremia at some stage and can also have high-density bacteremia with systemic signs of sepsis. Debate about whether septicemic plague is always secondary to frank or subclinical bubonic or pneumonic disease continues, but work in mice lends support to the existence of a syndrome of septicemic disease without histological changes in lymph nodes in a few animals infected by flea bites.'\n\nThe state of New Mexico can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/233. A county map can be seen at http://geology.com/county-map/new-mexico-county-map.gif. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "Though septicemic plague is less common and harder to recognize than the more common form of bubonic plague, health care providers need to consider plague in their diagnosis when the patient has a fever of unknown origin and when the patient is from plague endemic areas of the state.' \n\n'Several of our plague cases in 2015 have most likely been exposed to plague-infected rodent fleas brought into the home and bedroom by dogs and cats that are allowed to roam and hunt and aren't treated with a flea control product, said Paul Ettestad, state public health veterinarian with the Department of Health. 2007; 369(9568): 1196-207, with the citations removed:\n\n'Some plague cases (10-25 percent) present with primary septicemia (hypotension, shock) without lymph nodes being obviously affected and these patients have higher mortality than those with bubonic plague. In recent decades, an average of 7 human plague cases have been reported each year (range: 1-17 cases per year) with 0-2 deaths.\n\n A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n'This is the 4th case of plague in New Mexico with the patient presenting clinical signs of septicemic plague,' said Department of Health Secretary Retta Ward, MPH. ' Debate about whether septicemic plague is always secondary to frank or subclinical bubonic or pneumonic disease continues, but work in mice lends support to the existence of a syndrome of septicemic disease without histological changes in lymph nodes in a few animals infected by flea bites.' The other cases in the state occurred in a 52-year-old woman from Santa Fe County, who died from the illness, and in a 65-year-old man and a 59-year-old woman, both from Bernalillo County, who have recovered. In addition to the 4 human cases, there have been 8 cases of plague in 2015 in dogs and cats, including pets from Bernalillo, Santa Fe, and Torrance counties. The New Mexico Department of Health announced today, 23 Sep 2015, a laboratory-confirmed case of plague in a 73-year-old woman from Santa Fe County. \n\nSepticemic plague accounts for approximately 20-25 percent of New Mexico cases. Dogs and cats are also susceptible to plague and are infected either through bites of infected fleas or by eating an animal that has died from the disease.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "plague"], "syndromes": ["fever of unknown origin"], "event_date": ["2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2015-09-23 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bernalillo County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santa Fe", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santa Fe County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3755255", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (17): (OR) bubonic", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3755255", "date": "2015-10-30 11:27:29", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (17): (OREGON) BUBONIC\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 29 Oct 2015\nSource: Oregon Health Authority News and Information [edited]\nhttp://www.oregon.gov/oha/news/Pages/Bubonic%20plague%20confirmed%20in%20Crook%20Co.%20teen%20after%20hunting%20trip.aspx\n\n\nThe Oregon Health Authority's Public Health Division is confirming a case of bubonic plague in a teenage Crook County girl. The girl is believed to have acquired the disease from a flea bite during a hunting trip near Heppner in Morrow County on 18 Oct 2015. She reportedly fell ill 3 days later and was hospitalized in Bend the same day. She is recovering in the hospital's intensive care unit.\n\nOregon Public Health and the CDC epidemiologists are working with health officials in Crook, Deschutes, and Morrow counties to investigate the illness. No other persons are believed to have been infected.\n\n'Many people think of the plague as a disease of the past, but it's still very much present in our environment, particularly among wildlife,' said Emilio DeBess, DVM, state public health veterinarian in the Public Health Division's Acute and Communicable Disease Prevention Section. 'Fortunately, plague remains a rare disease, but people who may come in contact with wildlife still need to take precautions to keep it that way.'\n\nDeBess recommends people avoid any contact with wild rodents. They should never feed squirrels, chipmunks, or other rodents in picnic or campground areas, and never touch sick or dead rodents. Pets also should be protected from fleas and kept away from wild animals.\n\nPlague is rare in Oregon and is treatable with antimicrobials if caught early. Only 8 human cases have been diagnosed in the state since 1995.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nEmilio DeBess DVM, MPH\nState Public Health Veterinarian\nClinical Epidemiologist, Acute and Communicable Disease\nFoodborne and Zoonotic Disease Manager\nOregon Health Authority\nPortland, Oregon\nUSA\n<emilio.e.debess@state.or.us>\n\n[This continues to be a 'banner year' for _Yersinia pestis_ infections in the USA, with now 16 cases and 4 deaths. In recent decades, an average of 7 human plague cases have been reported each year (range: 1-17 cases per year) with 0-2 deaths. - Mod.LL\n\nThe state of Oregon can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/13119. He died on Thu 9 Sep 2015, in the Karakol regional hospital, the ministry stated in a press release.\n\n'He was diagnosed with bubonic plague,' according to a statement. His body was cremated and the remains have been buried with particular precautions.\n\n'We suspect that the affected person was infected with the plague by means of the bite of a flea,' Tolo Isakov, a ministry official who heads the sanitation division, stated at a briefing in Bishkek Mon, 13 Sep 2015. He added that the last recorded case of bubonic plague in\nKyrgyzstan occurred 30 years ago.\n\nHealth Minister Dinara Saginbayeva aimed to dispel fears of an epidemic. 'There won't be a bubonic plague epidemic,' she stated. 'The type of the illness which infected the teenager is just not conducive to a plague epidemic. So there are not any grounds for closing the borders.'\n\nOfficers have hospitalized and quarantined 105 individuals who had contact with the deceased, together with doctors and medical employees who treated the boy, the minister stated. Doctors have been additionally administered antimicrobials, she stated.\n\n[Byline: Barney Henderson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although the posting reports that the last case of plague in Kyrgyzstan was 30 years ago, ProMED posted (Plague - Kyrgyzstan: (YK) fatal 20130829.1909839) 1 case in a 15-year-old boy (is this the same case?) and also several other presumptive cases.\n\nAs outlined by the CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) and quoted in ProMED-mail post 20120601.1153277: 'Death from bubonic plague occurs after the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_ escapes from the infected bubo into the bloodstream (septicemic plague) causing the manifestations of the sepsis syndrome. Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) with subsequent cutaneous hemorrhage may well have been what was called the 'Black Death' in the Middle Ages. The bacterium can spread to the lungs, causing a secondary plague pneumonia (secondary to the bacteremia), or to the meninges, causing a plague meningitis. Both of these events have a high case fatality rate and the secondary plague pneumonia is the way the infection spreads (by aerosol) from person to person.\n\n'The typical sign of the most common form of human plague is a swollen and very tender lymph gland, accompanied by pain. The swollen gland is called a 'bubo.' Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2-6 days after being infected.\n\n'When bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antibiotic therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death.' - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/28670.]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although the posting reports that the last case of plague in Kyrgyzstan was 30 years ago, ProMED posted (Plague - Kyrgyzstan: (YK) fatal 20130829.1909839) 1 case in a 15-year-old boy (is this the same case?) and also several other presumptive cases. \n\nAs outlined by the CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) and quoted in ProMED-mail post 20120601.1153277: 'Death from bubonic plague occurs after the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_ escapes from the infected bubo into the bloodstream (septicemic plague) causing the manifestations of the sepsis syndrome. The dead animal was found at the Kiva picnic area on 17 Aug [2015]. So far, health officials are not aware of any human contact with the infected squirrel.\n\n'It's something that we don't see in large pandemics in the modern era of antibiotics,' explained Dr Randall Todd of the Washoe County Health District. 'But we do still worry about it a little bit in the western and southwestern states because it lives endemically in some of the rodent populations.' Doctor Todd referred to a map from the CDC, which shows where human cases of plague have been reported between 1970 and 2012. Several were right here in northern Nevada.\n\nThe disease is carried by fleas, and spread by rodents, and other small animals like rabbits and prairie dogs. Dr. Todd said that if one of these animals allows you to get close, that's unusual behavior. They may be sick. He said don't touch it, and don't let your dogs get close either.\n\n'If you have pets like dogs or cats that are allowed to roam free where they might be exposed to fleas, then you would probably want to take some steps to do flea prevention on your pets, and you probably would not want them to sleep on or in your bed,' he says. According to information from the CDC, human infection is rare. Fewer than 20 cases have been reported per year over the past 15 years, but it can be fatal.\n\nIf you are exposed, you may have a fever, headache, and painful swollen lymph nodes. Seek medical attention right away.\n\nTo reduce your chances of catching the disease, El Dorado County health officials say don't feed squirrels or other wild rodents. Never touch sick, injured, or dead rodents. Eliminate nesting places for rodents around homes, sheds and garages.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations. Some species are particularly susceptible. For example, _Y. pestis_ caused the extinction of entire colonies of black-tailed prairie dogs. Small rodents such as deer mice and grasshopper mice are suggested to act as the reservoirs. Larger species like squirrels and chipmunks are considered to be more vulnerable to infection. - Mod.PMB\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/204.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. \n\n'If you have pets like dogs or cats that are allowed to roam free where they might be exposed to fleas, then you would probably want to take some steps to do flea prevention on your pets, and you probably would not want them to sleep on or in your bed,' he says. \n\nThe disease is carried by fleas, and spread by rodents, and other small animals like rabbits and prairie dogs. The woman, a resident of Marquette, Michigan, contracted plague while visiting family in Salida during the Gentlemen of the Road Music Festival weekend, 22-23 Aug 2015.\n\nAfter the music festival, she flew back to Michigan that Tuesday, 25 Aug 2015, and the next morning she awoke with a high fever, said her father. She spent 2 days with a 103-degree fever and then went to the hospital. While she was in the hospital, she displayed textbook plague symptoms, her father said. The CDC soon came for exhaustive questioning. The patient said her fever kept spiking until the doctors administered the antimicrobials recommended by the CDC.\n\nThe CDC confirmed plague in a biopsy of one of Plescher's lymph nodes late last week at the Michigan hospital.\n\nThere were a few days' lag in word getting back to Chaffee County [Colorado] Public Health because the diagnosis was from an out-of-state hospital, said Andrea Carlstrom, county health director.\n\nThe patient has been released from the hospital, but her recovery is slow. She said her fever has subsided and much of her swelling has gone down, but her lymph nodes are still 'huge' and she still can't walk or even sit up. While in the area she hiked a portion of the Little Rainbow trail around CR 108. This is the 2nd case of plague contracted by a person, likely while hiking in the Methodist Mountain Trail System. 'There seems to be a clear common denominator of the Little Rainbow area (in these cases),' said Carlstrom.\n\n[Byline: Ryan Summerlin]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This has been a 'banner year' for _Yersinia pestis_ infections in the USA with 14 cases and 4 deaths. In recent decades, an average of 7 human plague cases have been reported each year (range: 1-17 cases per year) with 0-2 deaths.\n\nThis may well be the 1st case of plague diagnosed in the state of Michigan and was certainly acquired in Colorado. This case seems parallel to the case in Georgia earlier in 2015 which was acquired in California. The city of Marquette is located in the Upper Peninsula of Michigan. People living there are usually called 'Yuppers' (pronounced U-pers).\n\nThe typical sign of the most common form of human plague is a swollen and very tender lymph gland, accompanied by pain. The swollen gland is called a 'bubo.' Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2-6 days after being infected.\n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antibiotic therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. About 14 per cent (1 in 7) of all plague cases in the USA are fatal - Mod.LL\n\n'There were a few days' lag in word getting back to Chaffee County [Colorado] Public Health because the diagnosis was from an out-of-state hospital'... PLAGUE - USA (15): (MICHIGAN) ex COLORADO, BUBONIC\n**************************************************\n \n\nThere were a few days' lag in word getting back to Chaffee County [Colorado] Public Health because the diagnosis was from an out-of-state hospital, said Andrea Carlstrom, county health director. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2-6 days after being infected. LL\n\n'There were a few days' lag in word getting back to Chaffee County [Colorado] Public Health because the diagnosis was from an out-of-state hospital'...", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2015-09-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2015-09-06 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-08-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Salida", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chaffee County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Marquette", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3631683", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Madagascar (04): (AO) pneumonic, fatal, WHO", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3631683", "date": "2015-09-08 19:35:59", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (04): (ALAOTRA-MANGORO) PNEUMONIC, FATAL, WHO\n*****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 6 Sep 2015\nSource: WHO, Emergencies preparedness, response, Disease Outbreak News (DONs) [edited]\nhttp://who.int/csr/don/06-september-2015-plague/en/\n\n\nPlague - Madagascar\n-------------------\nThe Ministry of Health of Madagascar has notified WHO of an outbreak of plague. The 1st case was identified on 17 Aug 2015 in a rural township in Moramanga district [Alaotra-Mangoro region, Toamasina province]. The case passed away on 19 Aug 2015. As of 30 Aug 2015, 14 cases, including 10 deaths, were reported. All confirmed cases are of the pneumonic form. Since 27 Aug 2015, no new cases have been reported from the affected or neighboring districts.\n\nPublic health response\n----------------------\nThe national task force has been activated to manage the outbreak. With support from partners -- including WHO and the Pasteur Institute of Madagascar -- the government of Madagascar is implementing thorough public health measures, including active case and contact finding, provision of chemoprophylaxis, case and contact management, enhanced epidemiologic surveillance, infection prevention and control (house disinfection), vector control activities, social mobilization, coordination and resource mobilization.\n\nWHO risk assessment\n-------------------\nWHO does not recommend any travel or trade restriction based on the current information available. In urban areas, such as Antananarivo, the surveillance of epidemic risk indicators is highly recommended for the implementation of preventive vector control activities.\n\nBackground\n----------\nPlague is a bacterial disease caused by _Yersinia pestis_, which primarily affects wild rodents. It is spread from one rodent to another by fleas. Humans bitten by an infected flea usually develop a bubonic form of plague, which produces the characteristic plague bubo (a swelling of the lymph node). If the bacteria reach the lungs, the patient develops pneumonia (pneumonic plague), which is then transmissible from person to person through infected droplets spread by coughing. If diagnosed early, bubonic plague can be successfully treated with antibiotics. Pneumonic plague, on the other hand, is one of the most deadly infectious diseases; patients can die 24 hours after infection. The mortality rate depends on how soon treatment is started, but is always very high.\n\nThe current outbreak follows another plague outbreak that occurred in Madagascar between 2014 and 2015, with a peak in November 2014 when over 335 cases and 79 deaths were reported.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is caused by the _Yersinia pestis_ bacillus, which in Madagascar is carried by rat fleas. At the start of the rainy season, currently, rats flee the sewers of Madagascar in massive numbers and take refuge in people's cottages.\n\nThe following paragraph of this posting is from Chanteau S, Ratsifasoamanana L, Rasoamanana B, et al: Plague, a Reemerging Disease in Madagascar. Emerg Infect Dis 1998; 4(1): 101-4; http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2627662/pdf/9452403.pdf:\n\nBetween 1930 and 1990, bubonic plague had 'virtually disappeared' on the island due to efficient pest-control and good health-management. However since 1990, an annual 200 cases are being reported and bubonic plague takes on epidemic form especially in the port of Mahajanga each year. In the capital city of Antananarivo more cases are also being notified each year since 1990. Madagascar (pop. 13 million) [pop. 22.92 million, 2013] has accounted for 45 percent of all the cases of plague in Africa.\n\nFatalities related to plague usually are caused by spread of the organism from the bubo (the very painful infected lymph node which drains the area where the flea bite occurred) to the bloodstream. The bacteremia can cause a coagulopathy producing the purpura seen in the 'Black Plague' and also spread to the lung causing a hemorrhagic pneumonia. It is the pneumonia that can facilitate person-to-person transmission.\n\nMadagascar was the location of the isolation of multi-antimicrobial resistant _Y. pestis_ in 1995 (Galimand M, Guiyoule A, Gerbaud G, et al: Multidrug resistance in _Yersinia pestis_ mediated by a transferable plasmid. N Engl J Med 1997; 337(10): 677-80; http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJM199709043371004). The strain was resistant to chloramphenicol, streptomycin, and tetracycline but sensitive to fluoroquinolones and trimethoprim as well as other aminoglycosides. This was an ominous observation; however, it is not clear if this naturally occurring strain has persisted or spread.\n\nMoramanga (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moramanga) is a city in Madagascar between the capital city Antananarivo and the east coast. The name Mora-manga literally means 'easy to beautify'. The city of Moramanga has an important place in the history of Madagascar. It was in Moramanga, on the night of 29 Mar 1947 that the Malagasy Uprising against French colonial rule started. Moramanga is also the capital city of the Bezanozano people (one of the 18 Ethnic groups of Madagascar). Moramanga is in the Alaotra-Mangoro region.\n\nMaps of Madagascar can be seen at http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/madagascar/mar2582r/madagascar_pol.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/2483. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/2483.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n With support from partners -- including WHO and the Pasteur Institute of Madagascar -- the government of Madagascar is implementing thorough public health measures, including active case and contact finding, provision of chemoprophylaxis, case and contact management, enhanced epidemiologic surveillance, infection prevention and control (house disinfection), vector control activities, social mobilization, coordination and resource mobilization. \n\nThe current outbreak follows another plague outbreak that occurred in Madagascar between 2014 and 2015, with a peak in November 2014 when over 335 cases and 79 deaths were reported. Emerg Infect Dis 1998; 4(1): 101-4; http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2627662/pdf/9452403.pdf:\n\nBetween 1930 and 1990, bubonic plague had 'virtually disappeared' on the island due to efficient pest-control and good health-management. PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (04): (ALAOTRA-MANGORO) PNEUMONIC, FATAL, WHO\n*****************************************************************\n Humans bitten by an infected flea usually develop a bubonic form of plague, which produces the characteristic plague bubo (a swelling of the lymph node). Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< However since 1990, an annual 200 cases are being reported and bubonic plague takes on epidemic form especially in the port of Mahajanga each year. Fatalities related to plague usually are caused by spread of the organism from the bubo (the very painful infected lymph node which drains the area where the flea bite occurred) to the bloodstream. If the bacteria reach the lungs, the patient develops pneumonia (pneumonic plague), which is then transmissible from person to person through infected droplets spread by coughing. \n\nPublic health response\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is caused by the _Yersinia pestis_ bacillus, which in Madagascar is carried by rat fleas. \n\nMadagascar was the location of the isolation of multi-antimicrobial resistant _Y. pestis_ in 1995 (Galimand M, Guiyoule A, Gerbaud G, et al: Multidrug resistance in _Yersinia pestis_ mediated by a transferable plasmid. \n\nWHO risk assessment\n \n\n--\n http://who.int/csr/don/06-september-2015-plague/en/\n\n\nPlague - Madagascar\n The bacteremia can cause a coagulopathy producing the purpura seen in the 'Black Plague' and also spread to the lung causing a hemorrhagic pneumonia. Source: WHO, Emergencies preparedness, response, Disease Outbreak News (DONs) [edited]\n Date: Sun 6 Sep 2015\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2015-08-19 00:00:00", "1995-03-25 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-11-25 00:00:00", "2015-08-27 00:00:00", "1998-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00", "1990-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-08-17 00:00:00", "1947-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Rasoamanana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Background", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Moramanga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mahajanga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Toamasina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3622887", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (14): (NM) septicemic", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3622887", "date": "2015-09-04 10:56:32", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (14): (NEW MEXICO) SEPTICEMIC\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 3 Sep 2015\nSource: KOAT [edited]\nhttp://www.koat.com/news/nm-officials-confirm-another-human-case-of-plague/35087504\n\n\nThis year's [2015] 3rd human case of the plague in New Mexico was confirmed by health officials [Thu 3 Sep 2015]. The case was confirmed in a 59-year-old woman from Bernalillo County, who is recovering. The other cases in the state occurred in a 52-year-old woman from Santa Fe County, who died from the illness and in a 65-year-old man from Bernalillo County who recovered.\n\n'All 3 of New Mexico's human plague cases in 2015 have been septicemic plague, which is less common and more difficult to recognize,' said Department of Health Secretary Retta Ward, MPH. 'I urge all health care providers who see patients with a fever of unknown origin, and who are presenting from plague endemic areas of the state to consider plague in their diagnosis.' Septicemic plague accounts for as much as 25 percent of New Mexico cases.\n\nSepticemic plague has no specific features or detectable swollen lymph node, by which it can be distinguished from other infectious diseases, although abdominal pain, vomiting, and diarrhea are common.\n\nPlague is a potentially fatal illness in people that occurs in many parts of New Mexico. It is caused by bacteria found in rodents, especially ground squirrels, rabbits, and hares. Most human cases of plague are acquired through the bite of infected fleas. Dogs and cats are also susceptible to plague and are infected either through bites of infected fleas or by eating an animal that has died from the disease.\n\nSymptoms of plague in people usually develop 2 to 8 days after exposure. Typical symptoms include sudden fever, chills, headaches, and swelling of the lymph nodes in the neck, armpit, or groin areas. As stated earlier, no detectable swollen lymph node is found in cases of primary septicemic plague. In addition to the 3 human cases, there have been 7 cases of plague this year [2015] in dogs and cats, including pets from Bernalillo, Santa Fe, and Torrance counties.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following was extracted from Prentice MB, Rahalison L: Plague. Lancet. 2007; 369(9568): 1196-207 with the citations removed:\n\nSome plague cases (10-25 percent) present with primary septicemia (hypotension, shock) without lymph nodes being obviously affected and these patients have higher mortality than those with bubonic plague. The term septicemic plague can be confusing, since most patients with buboes have detectable bacteraemia at some stage and can also have high-density bacteraemia with systemic signs of sepsis. Debate about whether septicemic plague is always secondary to frank or subclinical bubonic or pneumonic disease continues, but work in mice lends support to the existence of a syndrome of septicemic disease without histological changes in lymph nodes in a few animals infected by flea bites. - Mod.LL\n\nThe state of New Mexico can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/233. A county map can be seen at http://geology.com/county-map/new-mexico-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "2007; 369(9568): 1196-207 with the citations removed:\n\nSome plague cases (10-25 percent) present with primary septicemia (hypotension, shock) without lymph nodes being obviously affected and these patients have higher mortality than those with bubonic plague. \n\n'All 3 of New Mexico's human plague cases in 2015 have been septicemic plague, which is less common and more difficult to recognize,' said Department of Health Secretary Retta Ward, MPH. ' A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Debate about whether septicemic plague is always secondary to frank or subclinical bubonic or pneumonic disease continues, but work in mice lends support to the existence of a syndrome of septicemic disease without histological changes in lymph nodes in a few animals infected by flea bites. In addition to the 3 human cases, there have been 7 cases of plague this year [2015] in dogs and cats, including pets from Bernalillo, Santa Fe, and Torrance counties. The other cases in the state occurred in a 52-year-old woman from Santa Fe County, who died from the illness and in a 65-year-old man from Bernalillo County who recovered. 28(36) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=18547\n\n\nCrayfish plague (_Aphanomyces astaci_), Ireland\n-----------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 1 Sep 2015 from Dr Martin Blake, Chief Veterinary Officer, Department of Agriculture, Food and the Marine, Agriculture House, Dublin, Ireland\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification (final report)\nDate of start of the event: 10 Jul 2015\nDate of confirmation of the event: 30 Aug 2015\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 1987\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: _Aphanomyces astaci_\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks:\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: River Erne, Cavan\nDate of start of the outbreak: 10 Jul 2015\nOutbreak status: resolved (1 Sep 2015)\nEpidemiological unit: river system\nWater type: fresh water\nPopulation type: wild\nProduction system: open\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Morbidity / Mortality / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nWhite clawed crayfish (_Austropotamobius pallipes_) (kg) / 5 (scale 0 to 5) / 5 (scale 0 to 5) / - / - / - / - / - /\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: there were approximately 700 carcasses observed in a 10 km [6.2 mi] stretch of the river. The total population of the area is unknown but only a few live crayfish could be found. These have since died in captivity.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country; no vaccination; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: screening; official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; zoning\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type:\nInstitute of Environmental Sciences, University of Kolbenz-Lawdau, Siebeldingen (Germany) (foreign laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nWhite clawed crayfish (_Austropotamobius pallipes_) / gene sequencing/ 30 Aug 2015/ Positive\nWhite clawed crayfish (_Austropotamobius pallipes_) / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 10 Aug 2015 / Positive\nWhite clawed crayfish (_Austropotamobius pallipes_) / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 30 Aug 2015 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This immediate notification officially confirms the information communicated in the ProMED-mail report archive number 20150820.3591203. Although the outbreak was resolved, the event is still continuing. New outbreaks could be detected.\n\nThe aetiological agent of crayfish plague is _Aphanomyces astaci_, a member of a group of organisms commonly known as the water moulds. Although long regarded to be fungi, this group, the Oomycetida, are now considered protists and are classified with diatoms and brown algae in a group called the Stramenopiles or Chromista.\n\nFor the above and additional background information, including diagnostic methods, and references please refer to the OIE Aquatic Manual 2015, Chapter 2.2.1 Crayfish plague (_Aphanomyces astaci_) at http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/aahm/current/2.2.01_CRAYFISH_PLAGUE.pdf\n\nOIE's internationally agreed requirements pertaining to crayfish plague (_A astaci_) are spelled out in chapter 9.1 of OIE's Aquatic Animal Health Code, available at http://www.oie.int/index.php?id=171&L=0&htmfile=chapitre_aphanomyces_astaci.htm\n\nInfected animals may show clinical signs; however, infection may be present in the absence of any signs. Pictures of lesions of crayfish plague can be seen at http://library.enaca.org/Health/FieldGuide/html/cp001cra.htm\n\nFor background on crayfish plague, see also commentaries in ProMED-mail archive nos. 20131216.2118609 and 20131022.2013248.\n\nMaps of Ireland are available at http://www.headrambles.com/wp-content/uploads/2008/02/map-ireland.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/47506. - Mod.CRD]", "summary": "Population type: wild\nProduction system: open\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Morbidity / Mortality / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nWhite clawed crayfish (_Austropotamobius pallipes_) (kg) / 5 (scale 0 to 5) / 5 (scale 0 to 5) / - / - / - / - / - /\n\nEpidemiology\n A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \nInformation received on [and dated] 1 Sep 2015 from Dr Martin Blake, Chief Veterinary Officer, Department of Agriculture, Food and the Marine, Agriculture House, Dublin, Ireland\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification (final report)\n Measures to be applied: screening;
