28(36) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=18547", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1987-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-08-10 00:00:00", "2015-09-01 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Dublin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WAHID", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chromista", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3603984", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Madagascar (03): (AO) pneumonic, fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3603984", "date": "2015-08-27 19:45:05", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (03): (ALAOTRA-MANGORO) PNEUMONIC\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 26 Aug 2015\nSource: France 24, Agence France-Presse (AFP) report [edited]\nhttp://www.france24.com/en/20150826-pneumonic-plague-kills-eight-madagascar\n\n\nA health ministry official said Wed 26 Aug 2015, 8 people have died of pneumonic plague in 2 days on the Indian Ocean island of Madagascar which is hit by deadly outbreaks almost every year.\n\nPneumonic plague is rare and more vicious than the commonly-known bubonic strain as it gives antimicrobials little time to act and can kill within 24 hours.\n\n'12 cases of pneumonic plague have been identified,' out of which 8 people have died in 2 days, Maherisoa Ratsitorahina, the health ministry's chief epidemiologist, told AFP. He said the disease was confined to Antsahatsihanarina village, which is less than 20 kilometers (12 miles) from the city of Moramanga [Alaotra-Mangoro region, Toamasina province] in the east of the island.\n\nPlague is endemic in Madagascar where outbreaks have resurfaced often since 1980 and are blamed mainly on rats and flea infestation due to unbridled deforestation. Pneumonic plague can be spread from person to person through coughing.\n\nThe WHO warned early in 2015 that the number of plague cases has steadily increased over the last 3 years, making Madagascar the world's most affected country. In 2013, the country registered 86 cases and 39 deaths while between September 2014 to February 2015, a total of 263 people were infected cases and at least 71 killed.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is caused by the _Yersinia pestis_ bacillus, which in Madagascar is carried by rat fleas. At the start of the rainy season, currently, rats flee the sewers of Madagascar in massive numbers and take refuge in people's cottages.\n\nThe following paragraph of this posting is from Chanteau S, Ratsifasoamanana L, Rasoamanana B, et al: Plague, a Reemerging Disease in Madagascar. Emerg Infect Dis 1998; 4(1): 101-4; http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2627662/pdf/9452403.pdf:\nBetween 1930 and 1990, bubonic plague had 'virtually disappeared' on the island due to efficient pest-control and good health-management. However since 1990, an annual 200 cases are being reported and bubonic plague takes on epidemic form especially in the port of Mahajanga each year. In the capital city of Antananarivo more cases are also being notified each year since 1990. Madagascar (pop. 13 million) [pop. 22.92 million, 2013] has accounted for 45 percent of all the cases of plague in Africa.\n\nFatalities related to plague usually are caused by spread of the organism from the bubo (the very painful infected lymph node which drains the area where the flea bite occurred) to the bloodstream. The bacteremia can cause a coagulopathy producing the purpura seen in the 'Black Plague' and also spread to the lung causing a hemorrhagic pneumonia. It is the pneumonia that can facilitate person-to-person transmission.\n\nMadagascar was the location of the isolation of multi-antimicrobial resistant _Y. pestis_ in 1995 (Galimand M, Guiyoule A, Gerbaud G, et al: Multidrug resistance in _Yersinia pestis_ mediated by a transferable plasmid. N Engl J Med 1997; 337(10): 677-80; http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJM199709043371004). The strain was resistant to chloramphenicol, streptomycin, and tetracycline but sensitive to fluoroquinolones and trimethoprim as well as other aminoglycosides. This was an ominous observation; however, it is not clear if this naturally occurring strain has persisted or spread.\n\nMaps of Madagascar can be seen at http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/madagascar/mar2582r/madagascar_pol.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/2483.\nMoramanga (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moramanga) is a city in Madagascar between the capital city Antananarivo and the east coast. The name Mora-manga literally means 'easy to beautify'. The city of Moramanga has an important place in the history of Madagascar. It was in Moramanga, on the night of 29 Mar 1947 that the Malagasy Uprising against French colonial rule started. Moramanga is also the capital city of the Bezanozano people (one of the 18 Ethnic groups of Madagascar. Moramanga is in the Alaotra-Mangoro region.\n- Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Source: France 24, Agence France-Presse (AFP) report [edited]\nhttp://www.france24.com/en/20150826-pneumonic-plague-kills-eight-madagascar\n\n\nA health ministry official said Wed 26 Aug 2015, 8 people have died of pneumonic plague in 2 days on the Indian Ocean island of Madagascar which is hit by deadly outbreaks almost every year. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is caused by the _Yersinia pestis_ bacillus, which in Madagascar is carried by rat fleas. \n\n'12 cases of pneumonic plague have been identified,' out of which 8 people have died in 2 days, Maherisoa Ratsitorahina, the health ministry's chief epidemiologist, told AFP. Emerg Infect Dis 1998; 4(1): 101-4; http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2627662/pdf/9452403.pdf:\nBetween 1930 and 1990, bubonic plague had 'virtually disappeared' on the island due to efficient pest-control and good health-management. PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (03): (ALAOTRA-MANGORO) PNEUMONIC\n*****************************************************\n \n\nPneumonic plague is rare and more vicious than the commonly-known bubonic strain as it gives antimicrobials little time to act and can kill within 24 hours. In 2013, the country registered 86 cases and 39 deaths while between September 2014 to February 2015, a total of 263 people were infected cases and at least 71 killed. However since 1990, an annual 200 cases are being reported and bubonic plague takes on epidemic form especially in the port of Mahajanga each year. \n\nMadagascar was the location of the isolation of multi-antimicrobial resistant _Y. pestis_ in 1995 (Galimand M, Guiyoule A, Gerbaud G, et al: Multidrug resistance in _Yersinia pestis_ mediated by a transferable plasmid. The WHO warned early in 2015 that the number of plague cases has steadily increased over the last 3 years, making Madagascar the world's most affected country. Fatalities related to plague usually are caused by spread of the organism from the bubo (the very painful infected lymph node which drains the area where the flea bite occurred) to the bloodstream.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1947-03-25 00:00:00", "1980-03-25 00:00:00", "1990-03-25 00:00:00", "1995-03-25 00:00:00", "1998-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Rasoamanana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Antsahatsihanarina village", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Moramanga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Toamasina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mahajanga", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3608570", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (13): (UT) fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3608570", "date": "2015-08-28 12:11:27", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (13) : (UTAH) FATAL\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 27 Aug 2015\nSource: Utah Department of Health [edited]\nhttp://udohnews.blogspot.com/2015/08/utah-resident-dies-from-plague.html\n\n\nUtah public health officials have confirmed that an elderly resident died from plague in August 2015. This is the 1st Utah resident to be diagnosed with plague since 2009.\n\nPlague is a rare, life-threatening, flea-borne illness that is maintained in a rodent-flea transmission cycle. Species such as prairie dogs, black footed-ferrets, squirrels, and rabbits are especially susceptible and experience high mortality upon infection. Plague is naturally occurring in Utah, and typically seen in the prairie dog populations each year.\n\nSince 1 Apr 2015, a total of 12 cases of human plague have been reported in residents of 7 states: Arizona (2), California (1), Colorado (4), Georgia (1), New Mexico (2), Oregon (1), and Utah (1). The 2 cases in Georgia and the California resident have been linked to exposures at or near Yosemite National Park in California.\n\nThe investigation continues into the circumstances surrounding the Utah [resident's] illness. The patient may have contracted the disease from a flea, or contact a dead animal. At this time, public health officials believe there was no travel history indicating that the Utah resident traveled anywhere else where plague is common.\n\nHuman plague occurs in areas where the bacteria are present in wild rodent populations. The risks are generally highest in rural and semi-rural areas, including campsites and homes that provide food and shelter for various ground squirrels, chipmunks, and wood rats, or other areas where you may encounter rodents.\n\nPlague is a very serious illness, but it is treatable with commonly available antimicrobials. The earlier a patient seeks medical care and receives treatment that is appropriate for plague, the better the chance for a full recovery. Some common symptoms may include fever, headache, chills, and weakness. If you are experiencing symptoms, seek immediate medical attention.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[During 2001-2012, the annual number of human plague cases reported in the USA ranged from 1-17 (median = 3 cases). A map of the location of plague cases in the USA from 1970-2012 can be found at http://www.cdc.gov/plague/maps/. Most case reports are around the Four Corners area of the southwest where Utah, Colorado, New Mexico, and Arizona come together. This seems clear in New Mexico and Arizona where most cases occur in the northern parts of the states but somewhat in Colorado and clearly in Utah, the cases are less concentrated in the southern parts.\n\nAs outlined by the CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) and quoted in ProMED-mail post 20120601.1153277: 'Death from bubonic plague occurs after the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_ escapes from the infected bubo into the bloodstream (septicemic plague) causing the manifestations of the sepsis syndrome. Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) with subsequent cutaneous hemorrhage may well have been what was called the 'Black Death' in the Middle Ages. The bacterium can spread to the lungs, causing a secondary plague pneumonia (secondary to the bacteremia), or to the meninges, causing a plague meningitis. Both of these events have a high case fatality rate and the secondary plague pneumonia is the way the infection spreads (by aerosol) from person to person.\n\n'The typical sign of the most common form of human plague is a swollen and very tender lymph gland, accompanied by pain. The swollen gland is called a 'bubo.' Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2-6 days after being infected.\n\n'When bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antibiotic therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. About 14 per cent (1 in 7) of all plague cases in the United States are fatal.' - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/246.]", "summary": "Since 1 Apr 2015, a total of 12 cases of human plague have been reported in residents of 7 states: Arizona (2), California (1), Colorado (4), Georgia (1), New Mexico (2), Oregon (1), and Utah (1). As outlined by the CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) and quoted in ProMED-mail post 20120601.1153277: 'Death from bubonic plague occurs after the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_ escapes from the infected bubo into the bloodstream (septicemic plague) causing the manifestations of the sepsis syndrome. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[During 2001-2012, the annual number of human plague cases reported in the USA ranged from 1-17 (median = 3 cases). A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The bacterium can spread to the lungs, causing a secondary plague pneumonia (secondary to the bacteremia), or to the meninges, causing a plague meningitis. \n\n'When bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. Source: Utah Department of Health [edited]\nhttp://udohnews.blogspot.com/2015/08/utah-resident-dies-from-plague.html\n\n\nUtah public health officials have confirmed that an elderly resident died from plague in August 2015. \n\n'The typical sign of the most common form of human plague is a swollen and very tender lymph gland, accompanied by pain. \n\nHuman plague occurs in areas where the bacteria are present in wild rodent populations. Both of these events have a high case fatality rate and the secondary plague pneumonia is the way the infection spreads (by aerosol) from person to person. About 14 per cent (1 in 7) of all plague cases in the United States are fatal.' At this time, public health officials believe there was no travel history indicating that the Utah resident traveled anywhere else where plague is common. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2-6 days after being infected. Plague is a rare, life-threatening, flea-borne illness that is maintained in a rodent-flea transmission cycle. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. A map of the location of plague cases in the USA from 1970-2012 can be found at http://www.cdc.gov/plague/maps/. PLAGUE - USA (13) : (UTAH) FATAL\n The earlier a patient seeks medical care and receives treatment that is appropriate for plague, the better the chance for a full recovery. If plague patients are not given specific antibiotic therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. Plague is naturally occurring in Utah, and typically seen in the prairie dog populations each year.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-01-17 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-08-25 00:00:00", "2015-04-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "National Park", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3596108", "headline": "PRO/AH> Plague - USA (11): (GA) ex CA, comments", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3596108", "date": "2015-08-22 23:38:45", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (11): (GEORGIA) ex CALIFORNIA, COMMENTS\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Sat 22 Aug 2015\nFrom: Harry F Hull <hfhullmd@gmail.com> [edited]\n\n\nThe recent plague case diagnosed in Georgia serves as a reminder that physicians throughout the country should be alert for the possibility of plague occurring in travelers coming from the western USA. In addition to the Georgia case, a 13-year-old girl died from plague in South Carolina in 1983 and a couple were hospitalized with plague in New York in 2002. All of these people resided in Santa Fe, New Mexico and informed the treating physician that they had the symptoms of plague. The death occurred because the potential diagnosis of plague was discounted by the physician. There is a high degree of awareness of the symptoms of plague among residents of northern New Mexico due to educational efforts by the state health department. However, travelers to the West and residents of other states are probably much less likely to recognize the symptoms of plague. Rapid diagnosis and treatment with effective antimicrobials is essential to survival. State health departments can arrange for diagnostic testing and provide recommendations for treatment.\n\n--\nHarry F. Hull, MD\nFormer New Mexico State Epidemiologist\nReno, Nevada\n<hfhullmd@gmail.com>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri 21 Aug 2015\nFrom: Allen Lenoir <alenoir165@aol.com> [edited]\n\n\nAn alternative explanation for a case of plague in someone who had not traveled to an endemic area would be exposure to someone who developed pneumonic plague after traveling to such an area. In that situation, the secondary case(s) would also have pneumonic plague.\n\n--\nAllen Lenoir, MD\nMiami, Florida\n<alenoir165@aol.com>\n\n[ProMED thanks our colleagues Dr. Lenoir and Dr. Hull for their comments. Certainly pneumonic plague can be acquired in a non-endemic area from another person who has pneumonic plague where the infection was acquired in an endemic area. Clearly, as well, a comprehensive travel history can be needed to suspect plague as well as a variety of infectious diseases including malaria, leishmaniasis and coccidioidomycosis. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n \n\n--\nAllen Lenoir, MD\nMiami, Florida\n<alenoir165@aol.com>\n\n[ProMED thanks our colleagues Dr. Lenoir and Dr. Hull for their comments. Certainly pneumonic plague can be acquired in a non-endemic area from another person who has pneumonic plague where the infection was acquired in an endemic area. The recent plague case diagnosed in Georgia serves as a reminder that physicians throughout the country should be alert for the possibility of plague occurring in travelers coming from the western USA. \n\n--\nHarry F. Hull, MD\n In addition to the Georgia case, a 13-year-old girl died from plague in South Carolina in 1983 and a couple were hospitalized with plague in New York in 2002.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "malaria", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-03-25 00:00:00", "1983-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nevada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santa Fe", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Reno", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Florida", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Carolina", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Miami", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3595447", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (10): (NM)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3595447", "date": "2015-08-22 23:29:33", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (10): (NEW MEXICO)\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 20 Aug 2015\nSource: KRQE [edited]\nhttp://krqe.com/2015/08/20/65-year-old-man-diagnosed-with-plague-in-bernalillo-county/\n\n\n65-year-old man diagnosed with plague in Bernalillo County [New Mexico]\n-----------------------------------------------------------------------\nA Bernalillo County [New Mexico] man has been infected with the plague. Health officials say infected fleas are spreading the disease. A New Mexican has already died this year [2015] after being infected.\n\nAnd with this new case there is growing concern. Health officials say the latest patient is an East Mountain man. That area would be more susceptible because of the rabbit and rodent population there. The plague infects those animals and then the fleas on them carry it elsewhere, including to pets and people.\n\nHealth officials say people in town are at less of risk but there's still a risk. They say the best advice is to make sure your animals have a year-round flea treatment to keep the bugs away. There's also a chance your pet can get infected if they eat an animal that has died from the disease. This year officials say the risk is greater.\n\nThe other case this year was of a 52-year-old woman from Santa Fe County. She died from the illness.\n\nAlong with the 2 human cases this year, there have been 7 confirmed cases in animals.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This has been a prominent year for _Yersinia pestis_ infections in the USA, with 8 reported cases including 3 fatalities, and with one of the cases presenting in Georgia (the 1st case reported in that state) but acquired in California. The manifestations of _Yersinia pestis_ infection in this case are not stated, although overall 95 percent of cases are bubonic in nature. Deaths from plague generally occur from septicemic or pneumonic plague. Only pneumonic plague can be spread from person to person.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED map of Bernalillo County, New Mexico, United States can be found at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1843 - Mod.LL]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This has been a prominent year for _Yersinia pestis_ infections in the USA, with 8 reported cases including 3 fatalities, and with one of the cases presenting in Georgia (the 1st case reported in that state) but acquired in California. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n http://krqe.com/2015/08/20/65-year-old-man-diagnosed-with-plague-in-bernalillo-county/\n\n\n65-year-old man diagnosed with plague in Bernalillo County [New Mexico]\n PLAGUE - USA (10): (NEW MEXICO)\n*******************************\n \n\nThe other case this year was of a 52-year-old woman from Santa Fe County. Along with the 2 human cases this year, there have been 7 confirmed cases in animals. \n\n--\n They say the best advice is to make sure your animals have a year-round flea treatment to keep the bugs away. The manifestations of _Yersinia pestis_ infection in this case are not stated, although overall 95 percent of cases are bubonic in nature.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-10 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bernalillo County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santa Fe County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3602201", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (12)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3602201", "date": "2015-08-26 03:28:43", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (12)\n*****************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 25 Aug 2015\nSource: MMWR 2015;64 (Early Release): 1-2 [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm64e0825a1.htm?s_cid=mm64e0825a1_w\n\n\nSince 1 Apr 2015, a total of 11 cases of human plague have been reported in residents of 6 states: Arizona (2), California (1), Colorado (4), Georgia (1), New Mexico (2), and Oregon (1). The cases in Georgia and California residents have been linked to exposures at or near Yosemite National Park in the southern Sierra Nevada Mountains of California. Nine of the 11 patients were male; median age was 52 years (range = 14-79 years). Three patients aged 16, 52, and 79 years died.\n\nPlague is a rare, life-threatening, flea-borne zoonosis caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_. During 2001-2012, the annual number of human plague cases reported in the USA ranged from 1-17 (median = 3 cases) (1). It is unclear why the number of cases in 2015 is higher than usual. Plague circulates among wild rodents and their fleas in rural and semirural areas in the western USA (2). Transmission to humans occurs through the bite of infected fleas, direct contact with infected body fluids or tissues, or inhalation of respiratory droplets from ill persons or animals, including ill domesticated cats and dogs (3). The usual incubation period between exposure and illness onset is 2-6 days.\n\nIn humans, plague is characterized by the sudden onset of fever and malaise, which can be accompanied by abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. There are 3 main forms of plague, depending upon the route of infection. Bubonic plague, resulting from the bite of an infected flea, accounts for approximately 80-85 percent of cases; patients develop a 'bubo,' a painful swelling of one or several lymph nodes that progresses during the 1st few days of illness. Septicemic plague, accounting for approximately 10 percent of cases, can occur from a flea bite or from direct contact with infectious fluids; infection spreads directly through the bloodstream with no localizing signs. Primary pneumonic plague, occurring in approximately 3 percent of plague patients, results from aerosol exposure to infective droplets and is characterized by a fulminant primary pneumonia. Secondary pneumonic plague can result from the spread of _Y. pestis_ to the lungs in patients with untreated bubonic or septicemic infection.\n\nThe mortality rate for untreated plague has ranged from 66 percent to 93 percent; however, in the antimicrobial era, mortality has been reduced to approximately 16 percent (4). Prompt treatment with antimicrobials such as aminoglycosides, fluoroquinolones, or doxycycline greatly improves outcome (4).\n\nHealth care providers should consider the diagnosis of plague in any patient with compatible signs or symptoms, residence or travel in the western USA, and recent proximity to rodent habitats or direct contact with rodents or ill domestic animals. Suspicion of plague should prompt 1) collection of blood, bubo aspirate, or sputum samples for _Y. pestis_ diagnostic testing; 2) implementation of isolation and respiratory droplet precautions for patients with respiratory involvement; 3) immediate antimicrobial treatment (before laboratory confirmation); and 4) notification of public health officials. _Y. pestis_-specific testing is available at state health laboratories. Recommendations for diagnostic testing and antibiotic treatment are available at http://www.cdc.gov/plague/healthcare/clinicians.html. Misidentification of _Y. pestis_ as _Pseudomonas luteola_ and other organisms through the use of automated bacterial identification systems has been reported (5).\n\nPersons engaging in outdoor activities in areas where plague is endemic should wear long pants when possible and use insect repellent on clothing and skin. Persons also should avoid direct contact with ill or dead animals and never feed squirrels, chipmunks, or other rodents. In addition, pet owners should regularly use flea control products on their pets and consult a veterinarian if their pet is ill. Rodent habitat can be reduced around the home by removing brush, clutter, and potential rodent food sources such as garbage or pet food. Additional information on prevention of plague is available at http://www.cdc.gov/plague/prevention/index.html.\n\nReferences\n--------\n1. Adams DA, Jajosky RA, Ajani U, et al: Summary of notifiable diseases--United States, 2012. Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 2014;61: 1--121.\n2. CDC: Plague. Atlanta, GA: US Department of Health and Human Services, CDC; 2015. Available at http://www.cdc.gov/plague/.\n3. Runfola JK, House J, Miller L, et al: Outbreak of human pneumonic plague with dog-to-human and possible human-to-human transmission--Colorado, June-Jul y 2014. Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 2015;64: 429-34.\n4. Kugeler KJ, Staples JE, Hinckley AF, Gage KL, Mead PS: Epidemiology of human plague in the United States, 1900-2012. Emerg Infect Dis 2015;21: 16-22.\n5. CDC: Notes from the field: two cases of human plague--Oregon, 2010. Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 2011;60:214.\n\n[Authors: Kwit N, Nelson C, Kugeler K, et al]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is the up to date CDC report on this year's [2015] cases of _Yersinia pestis_ infection in the USA. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106.]", "summary": "Since 1 Apr 2015, a total of 11 cases of human plague have been reported in residents of 6 states: Arizona (2), California (1), Colorado (4), Georgia (1), New Mexico (2), and Oregon (1). A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Suspicion of plague should prompt 1) collection of blood, bubo aspirate, or sputum samples for _Y. pestis_ diagnostic testing; 2) implementation of isolation and respiratory droplet precautions for patients with respiratory involvement; 3) immediate antimicrobial treatment (before laboratory confirmation); and 4) notification of public health officials. During 2001-2012, the annual number of human plague cases reported in the USA ranged from 1-17 (median = 3 cases) (1). [Authors: Kwit N, Nelson C, Kugeler K, et al]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Primary pneumonic plague, occurring in approximately 3 percent of plague patients, results from aerosol exposure to infective droplets and is characterized by a fulminant primary pneumonia. Bubonic plague, resulting from the bite of an infected flea, accounts for approximately 80-85 percent of cases; patients develop a 'bubo,' a painful swelling of one or several lymph nodes that progresses during the 1st few days of illness. Runfola JK, House J, Miller L, et al: Outbreak of human pneumonic plague with dog-to-human and possible human-to-human transmission--Colorado, June-Jul y 2014. Septicemic plague, accounting for approximately 10 percent of cases, can occur from a flea bite or from direct contact with infectious fluids; infection spreads directly through the bloodstream with no localizing signs. \n\nHealth care providers should consider the diagnosis of plague in any patient with compatible signs or symptoms, residence or travel in the western USA, and recent proximity to rodent habitats or direct contact with rodents or ill domestic animals. The mortality rate for untreated plague has ranged from 66 percent to 93 percent; however, in the antimicrobial era, mortality has been reduced to approximately 16 percent (4). An unidentified Georgia resident was infected while hiking in California. The California Department of Public Health said that the 'presumptive positive case' occurred when the tourist visited in early August 2015.\n\nThe Georgia Public Health Laboratory confirmed later Wednesday, 19 Aug 2015, that the patient did test positive for bubonic plague. The CDC is also conducting tests to confirm the diagnosis. The person was hospitalized in Georgia and released Tuesday night, 18 Aug 2015.\n\nDoctors caution travelers to western states, where plague is naturally occurring, to prevent flea bites and get immediate medical care if they start to feel symptoms.\n\n'Antimicrobials are effective in treating plague, but without prompt treatment, the disease can cause serious illness or death,' Patrick O'Neal, M.D., director of health protection for the Georgia Department of Public Health, said in a press release.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is the same case initially reported as acquired in California (Plague - USA (08): (CA) 20150819.3589079), but this report confirms that the diagnosis was made in Georgia. PLAGUE - USA (09): (GEORGIA) \n\n The CDC is also conducting tests to confirm the diagnosis.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-08-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 {"archive_id": "3591203", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Crayfish plague - Ireland: white-clawed crayfish mortality", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3591203", "date": "2015-08-20 14:54:44", "main_text": "CRAYFISH PLAGUE - IRELAND: WHITE-CLAWED CRAYFISH MORTALITY\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 17 Aug 2015\nSource: RTE News [edited]\nhttp://www.rte.ie/news/2015/0817/721791-crayfish-plague/\n\n\nInvestigations are under way after 600 crayfish were killed by crayfish plague in a [County] Cavan river.\n\nPreliminary results indicate the cause of deaths in the River Bruskey, near Ballinagh, to be the incurable, waterborne, fungus type disease.\n\nIf this plague becomes established, there is a high probability that white-clawed crayfish, Ireland's only freshwater crayfish species, will be eliminated from much of the island.\n\nThe disease may have been accidentally introduced from contaminated equipment that was previously used in affected waters in another country.\n\nHowever, if the disease was caused by the introduction of non-native crayfish, then it is likely to become established with a severe and probably irreversible ecological impact.\n\nMany US crayfish species are resistant to the plague but can act as a carrier of the disease, and can also out-compete Ireland's smaller native crayfish.\n\nThe introduction of non-native species is illegal and the white-clawed crayfish has already been completely eliminated from much of its European range.\n\nUntil now, Ireland has been free of crayfish plague and is the only European country without any established non-native crayfish species.\n\nThe only means of protecting native crayfish stocks is to prevent the introduction and spread of the disease, and this is possible if the disease was accidentally introduced from contaminated equipment.\n\nThe disease has no direct threat to human, fish, or other animal life.\n\nNon-native crayfish can also destabilise canal and river banks by burrowing, and have a severe impact on other freshwater species such as salmon and trout.\n\nWhile non-native crayfish may be a potential cause, there is no evidence to date that they have been introduced to Ireland.\n\nMembers of the public are asked to alert the authorities to any reports of mass mortalities of crayfish as well as sightings of unusual crayfish, and in particular to disinfect boots or angling equipment before moving from one body of water to another.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[_Austropotamobius pallipes_, the white-clawed crayfish of Western European streams, has become restricted in distribution over the past century.\n\nCrayfish fungal plague, fatal to white-clawed crayfish, has affected many European countries. It is caused by a fungus _Aphanomyces astaci_ that was brought into Europe by the introduction of _Procambarus clarkii_, a freshwater crayfish species of Louisiana, USA, which is naturally infected by this pathogen, although it does not develop clinical disease.\n\nFor a picture of a white-clawed crayfish go to http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Austropotamobius_pallipes#mediaviewer/File:Austropotamobius_pallipes.jpg.\n\nMaps of Ireland can be seen at http://www.vidiani.com/maps/maps_of_europe/maps_of_ireland/administrative_map_of_ireland.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/47506. - Mod.PMB]", "summary": "\n\nIf this plague becomes established, there is a high probability that white-clawed crayfish, Ireland's only freshwater crayfish species, will be eliminated from much of the island. \n\nMany US crayfish species are resistant to the plague but can act as a carrier of the disease, and can also out-compete Ireland's smaller native crayfish. \n\nUntil now, Ireland has been free of crayfish plague and is the only European country without any established non-native crayfish species. \n\nThe only means of protecting native crayfish stocks is to prevent the introduction and spread of the disease, and this is possible if the disease was accidentally introduced from contaminated equipment. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[_Austropotamobius pallipes_, the white-clawed crayfish of Western European streams, has become restricted in distribution over the past century. \n\nCrayfish fungal plague, fatal to white-clawed crayfish, has affected many European countries. \n\nMembers of the public are asked to alert the authorities to any reports of mass mortalities of crayfish as well as sightings of unusual crayfish, and in particular to disinfect boots or angling equipment before moving from one body of water to another. \n\nThe introduction of non-native species is illegal and the white-clawed crayfish has already been completely eliminated from much of its European range.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ballinagh", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ireland", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3566831", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (07): (CO)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3566831", "date": "2015-08-08 21:49:53", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (07): (COLORADO)\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 5 Aug 2015\nSource: CBS4 [edited]\nhttp://denver.cbslocal.com/2015/08/05/boulder-resident-tests-positive-for-plague/http://denver.cbslocal.com/2015/08/05/boulder-resident-tests-positive-for-plague/\n\n\nA Boulder, Colorado resident has tested positive for plague, the 1st human case in Boulder in more than 20 years. The Boulder resident had found a dead chipmunk on his/her property and a few days later went to the doctor after experiencing fever, chills, muscle pain, weakness, loss of appetite and confusion. The person received antimicrobial treatment and went home to recover.\n\nThis is the 1st person to test positive for the plague in Boulder County since 1993. 3 other Colorado residents have become ill from the disease as far in 2015, 2 of them did not survive.\n\n'In Boulder County, we so often see plague in prairie dogs,' said Jamie Feld, Communicable Disease Control program epidemiologist, in a statement. 'This is a good reminder that plague-infected fleas are also found on many other wild rodents.'\n\nIn 2014, 8 people tested positive for plague in Colorado.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[So far in 2015, there have been 6 cases of _Y. pestis_ infection in the western USA with 3 fatalities. USA (13): (CA) squirrel", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3588477", "date": "2015-08-19 11:44:50", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (13): (CALIFORNIA) SQUIRREL\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 16 Aug 2015\nSource: Newsmax.com [edited]\nhttp://www.newsmax.com/Health/Health-News/plague-yosemite-squirrels-camp/2015/08/16/id/670329/\n\n\nOfficials at Yosemite National Park said [Fri 14 Aug 2015] they will temporarily close a popular campsite after 2 squirrels died of plague in the area.\n\nTuolumne Meadows Campground will close from noon Monday through noon Friday [17-21 Aug 2015] so authorities can treat the area with a flea-killing insecticide.\n\nCampers had their reservations canceled at the 304-site campground so the insecticide can be sprayed into rodent 'burrow holes,' the California Department of Health said.\n\nPlague is carried by rodents and is spread by fleas, but transmission between people is rare.\n\n'Although this is a rare disease, and the current risk to humans is low, eliminating the fleas is the best way to protect the public from the disease,' said Dr Karen Smith, director of the state Health Department. 'By eliminating the fleas, we reduce the risk of human exposure and break the cycle of plague in rodents at the sites.'\n\nSince 1970, 42 people in California have contracted plague, resulting in 9 deaths. Health officials find plague-infected animals every year, mostly in the state's mountains and foothill regions.\n\nLast year [2014], plague was found in the counties of El Dorado, Mariposa, Modoc, Plumas, San Diego, Santa Barbara, and Sierra.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations. Some species are particularly susceptible. For example, _Y. pestis_ caused the extinction of entire colonies of black-tailed prairie dogs. Small rodents such as deer mice and grasshopper mice are suggested to act as the reservoirs. Larger species like squirrels and chipmunks are considered to be more vulnerable to infection. - Mod.PMB\n\nThe state of California an be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/29430. A county map can be seen at http://geology.com/county-map/california-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. Source: Newsmax.com [edited]\nhttp://www.newsmax.com/Health/Health-News/plague-yosemite-squirrels-camp/2015/08/16/id/670329/\n\n\nOfficials at Yosemite National Park said [Fri 14 Aug 2015] they will temporarily close a popular campsite after 2 squirrels died of plague in the area. \n\nPlague is carried by rodents and is spread by fleas, but transmission between people is rare. Although this is a rare disease, and the current risk to humans is low, eliminating the fleas is the best way to protect the public from the disease,' said Dr Karen Smith, director of the state Health Department. ' \n\nCampers had their reservations canceled at the 304-site campground so the insecticide can be sprayed into rodent 'burrow holes,' the California Department of Health said. The California Department of Public Health announced 'a presumptive positive case of plague' involving someone from Georgia who had spent time in early August 2015 in the state.\n\nBefore feeling sick, this person visited Yosemite, the Sierra National Forest, and nearby areas. No other details were given, including who the person is, their current medical condition, and where exactly he or she stayed overnight. Nor is it certain this person contracted the plague while in California.\n\nStill, the report suggests that 2 people recently in California have a disease best known for killing millions centuries ago, which, despite all the advances of modern science, remains a real, present-day problem. In addition to the California cases, 2 people contracted the plague this year [2015] in Colorado. Both of them, a teenager in Larimer County and the other an adult in Pueblo County, died of the disease.\n\nNews of the latest probable plague case in California comes just after Yosemite National Park shut down its Tuolumne Meadows Campground after authorities determined 2 dead squirrels had the plague. The campground will be closed from Mon 17 Aug - Fri 21 Aug 2015. It is one of 13 around Yosemite, which, with about 4 million visitors, is the 3rd most visited U.S. national park. Staff will treat the Tuolumne Meadows site with deltamethrin, a chemical that kills fleas that spread the plague, according to the park.\n\nThe 1st Yosemite campground to get the once over was Crane Flat, which is where a child -- after visiting nearby Stanislaus National Forest -- had stayed in mid-July 2015. In that case, an insecticide that contained deltamethrin was used on rodent burrows on 10-11 Aug 2015. That child is recovering from the plague, and no other members of the camping party have reported any related symptoms, according to authorities.\n\nUntil now, California hadn't had an instance of human plague since 2006, when there were 3 cases in Mono, Los Angeles and Kern counties, according to state health officer Dr. Karen Smith. There have been 42 cases in the state since 1970, of which 9 proved fatal. 'Although this is a rare disease, people should protect themselves from infection by avoiding any contact with wild rodents,' Smith said.\n\n[Byline: Greg Botelho]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most cases of _Yersinia pestis_ infections in the USA are reported from the Four Corners area of the USA, where the states of Colorado, Utah, Arizona, and New Mexico come together.\n\nAs outlined by the CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) at http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvbid/plague/diagnosis.htm: 'Death from bubonic plague occurs after the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_ escapes from the infected bubo into the bloodstream (septicemic plague) causing the manifestations of the sepsis syndrome. Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) with subsequent cutaneous hemorrhage may well have been what was called the 'Black Death' in the Middle Ages. The bacterium can spread to the lungs, causing a secondary plague pneumonia (secondary to the bacteremia), or to the meninges, causing a plague meningitis. Both of these events have a high case fatality rate, and the secondary plague pneumonia is the way the infection spreads (by aerosol) from person to person.\n\n'The typical sign of the most common form of human plague is a swollen and very tender lymph gland, accompanied by pain. The swollen gland is called a 'bubo.' Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2 to 6 days after being infected.\n\n'When bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antibiotic therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. About 14 per cent (1 in 7) of all plague cases in the United States are fatal.' - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/204.]", "summary": "\n\nNews of the latest probable plague case in California comes just after Yosemite National Park shut down its Tuolumne Meadows Campground after authorities determined 2 dead squirrels had the plague. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most cases of _Yersinia pestis_ infections in the USA are reported from the Four Corners area of the USA, where the states of Colorado, Utah, Arizona, and New Mexico come together. \n\n'The typical sign of the most common form of human plague is a swollen and very tender lymph gland, accompanied by pain.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-08-18 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00", "1970-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2010-08-11 20:15:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Los Angeles", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mono", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pueblo County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Larimer County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3537026", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (04): (NM) pneumonic, fatality", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3537026", "date": "2015-07-26 20:14:05", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (04): (NEW MEXICO), PNEUMONIC, FATALITY\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 24 Jul 2015\nSource: KRWG [edited]\nhttp://krwg.org/post/plague-likely-cause-death-santa-fe-county-woman\n\n\nThe New Mexico Department of Health (NMDoH) is investigating a probable case of plague in a 52-year-old woman from Santa Fe County who died of her illness. Confirmatory testing is being conducted at the NMDoH's Scientific Laboratory Division. This would be the 1st human case of plague in New Mexico in 2015. An environmental investigation will take place at the woman's home to look for ongoing risk to others in the surrounding area.\n\n'Department of Health staff will go door-to-door to neighbors near the case to inform them about plague found in the area and educate them on reducing their risk,' said Department of Health Secretary Retta Ward, MPH. 'Because the patient had pneumonia, health care providers and other close contacts of the patient who have been determined to have been exposed are taking preventive antimicrobial therapy.'\n\nPlague is a bacterial disease of rodents and is generally transmitted to humans through the bites of infected fleas, but it can also be transmitted by direct contact with infected animals, including rodents, wildlife and pets.\n\nPlague cases can occur at any time of the year in New Mexico, but most cases occur during the summer months. It is especially important now given the warm temperatures to take precautions to avoid rodents and their fleas, which can expose people to plague. Pets that are allowed to roam and hunt can bring infected fleas from dead rodents back into the home, putting household members at risk.\n\nIn New Mexico, there were 2 human plague cases in 2014, 4 human plague cases in 2013 with one fatality, one human plague case in 2012, 2 human cases of plague in 2011, and no cases in 2010.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As outlined by the CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) and quoted in ProMED-mail post 20120601.1153277: 'Death from bubonic plague occurs after the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_ escapes from the infected bubo into the bloodstream (septicemic plague) causing the manifestations of the sepsis syndrome. Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) with subsequent cutaneous hemorrhage may well have been what was called the 'Black Death' in the Middle Ages. The bacterium can spread to the lungs, causing a secondary plague pneumonia (secondary to the bacteremia), or to the meninges, causing a plague meningitis. Both of these events have a high case fatality rate and the secondary plague pneumonia is the way the infection spreads (by aerosol) from person to person.\n\n'The typical sign of the most common form of human plague is a swollen and very tender lymph gland, accompanied by pain. The swollen gland is called a 'bubo.' Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2 to 6 days after being infected.\n\n'When bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antibiotic therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. About 14 per cent (1 in 7) of all plague cases in the United States are fatal.' - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map showing New Mexico can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/233.]", "summary": "In New Mexico, there were 2 human plague cases in 2014, 4 human plague cases in 2013 with one fatality, one human plague case in 2012, 2 human cases of plague in 2011, and no cases in 2010. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As outlined by the CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) and quoted in ProMED-mail post 20120601.1153277: 'Death from bubonic plague occurs after the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_ escapes from the infected bubo into the bloodstream (septicemic plague) causing the manifestations of the sepsis syndrome. \n\nPlague is a bacterial disease of rodents and is generally transmitted to humans through the bites of infected fleas, but it can also be transmitted by direct contact with infected animals, including rodents, wildlife and pets. The bacterium can spread to the lungs, causing a secondary plague pneumonia (secondary to the bacteremia), or to the meninges, causing a plague meningitis. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n'When bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. \n\n'Department of Health staff will go door-to-door to neighbors near the case to inform them about plague found in the area and educate them on reducing their risk,' said Department of Health Secretary Retta Ward, MPH. ' \n\n'The typical sign of the most common form of human plague is a swollen and very tender lymph gland, accompanied by pain.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santa Fe County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3540232", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, animal - USA (11): (CO) squirrel", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3540232", "date": "2015-07-27 20:40:35", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (11): (COLORADO), SQUIRREL\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 24 Jul 2015\nSource: Gould for Golden [edited]\nhttp://gouldforgolden.com/2015/07/24/important-information-tree-squirrels-confirmed-to-have-plague-in-parfet-park-in-golden/\n\n\nJefferson County Public Health (JCPH) received confirmation today [24 Jul 2015] that squirrels located in Parfet Park have tested positive for bubonic plague.\n\nPostings are being placed around the area with information reminding citizens to take simple precautions to avoid exposure. Plague is a highly infectious bacterial disease carried by various types of wild rodents and is transmitted primarily by flea bites. Squirrels, prairie dogs and other mammals, such as rabbits and cats are susceptible to plague because they carry fleas.\n\n'The risk of residents contracting plague is extremely low,' said Jefferson County Public Health Director Dr. Mark Johnson. 'We want people to be aware that summer marks the beginning of the plague season, and just a few simple precautions will further reduce that risk.'\n\nJCPH and the City of Golden Animal Control are working together to investigate the cases and to determine the extent of the die-off in the area.\n\nWhen plague appears in an area, there is usually a die-off of the rodents and rabbits. When the animal dies, the fleas leave to find another host, thus spreading the disease. Most human plague cases result from infected flea bites. Less commonly, people are infected by direct contact (i.e. through a bite) with blood or tissues of infected animals.\n\nThe best way to prevent plague is to control the presence of rodents and fleas in and around the home. In addition, people should avoid contact with any species of wild rodents, especially sick or dead rodents. If a dead rodent is found, do not handle the animal directly, use gloves and place it in a plastic bag. Dogs and cats should be confined so they cannot prey on infected rodents and then bring the disease home with them. Pet owners who live close to rodent populations should use flea control products recommended by their veterinarian. Controlling fleas on pets will prevent the transfer of fleas to humans. If these reasonable precautions are taken, the probability of contracting plague is extremely low.\n\nPlague is easily treated in humans with antibiotics when recognized early. Two to 6 days after being infected with plague, people become ill with the following symptoms: sudden onset of high fever; muscle pain; malaise, or a general feeling of being ill; nausea and vomiting. Anyone experiencing these symptoms should consult a physician immediately.\n\nJefferson County Public Health will continue its plague surveillance of rodent populations in the county. Citizens are requested to report any unusual rodent die-offs to City of Golden Animal Control 303-384-8045.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations. Some species are particularly susceptible. For example, _Y. pestis_ caused the extinction of entire colonies of black-tailed prairie dogs. Small rodents such as deer mice and grasshopper mice are suggested to act as the reservoirs. Larger species like squirrels and chipmunks are considered to be more vulnerable to infection.\n\nA map of the affected area can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/awKA. - Mod.PMB\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/209.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. \n\nThe best way to prevent plague is to control the presence of rodents and fleas in and around the home. \n\nWhen plague appears in an area, there is usually a die-off of the rodents and rabbits. Plague is a highly infectious bacterial disease carried by various types of wild rodents and is transmitted primarily by flea bites. Two to 6 days after being infected with plague, people become ill with the following symptoms: sudden onset of high fever; muscle pain; malaise, or a general feeling of being ill; nausea and vomiting. PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (11): (COLORADO), SQUIRREL\n***********************************************\n In addition, people should avoid contact with any species of wild rodents, especially sick or dead rodents. If these reasonable precautions are taken, the probability of contracting plague is extremely low.\n\n \n\nJefferson County Public Health will continue its plague surveillance of rodent populations in the county. \n\n'The risk of residents contracting plague is extremely low,' said Jefferson County Public Health Director Dr. Mark Johnson. Squirrels, prairie dogs and other mammals, such as rabbits and cats are susceptible to plague because they carry fleas.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-11 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Parfet Park", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the City of Golden Animal Control", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3562691", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (05): (CO) fatality", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3562691", "date": "2015-08-06 20:15:41", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (05): (COLORADO) FATALITY\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 5 Aug 2015\nSource: The Denver Post [edited]\nhttp://www.denverpost.com/news/ci_28589498/pueblo-county-plague-death-becomes-2nd-colorado-this\n\n\nPueblo County plague death becomes 2nd in Colorado this year [2015]\n-------------------------------------------------------------------\nPueblo County health officials on Wednesday, 5 Aug 2015, announced a plague death, the 2nd such death in Colorado in 2015. The Pueblo City-County Health Department identified the person only as an adult. Authorities did not say which form of the plague was responsible for the death.\n\nThe person is the 4th in Colorado to contract the plague in 2015, including a 16-year-old Poudre High School student in Larimer County who was killed by a form of the bacterial infection known as septicemic plague. The other 2 cases were in Boulder County and Denver, according to the Colorado Department of Health and Environment.\n\nHealth officials say the public should avoid dead animals -- specifically rodents -- and report any large die-offs to county health departments or the state.\n\n[Byline: Jesse Paul]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As outlined by the CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) and quoted in ProMED-mail post 20120601.1153277: 'Death from bubonic plague occurs after the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_ escapes from the infected bubo into the bloodstream (septicemic plague) causing the manifestations of the sepsis syndrome. Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) with subsequent cutaneous hemorrhage may well have been what was called the 'Black Death' in the Middle Ages. The bacterium can spread to the lungs, causing a secondary plague pneumonia (secondary to the bacteremia), or to the meninges, causing a plague meningitis. Both of these events have a high case fatality rate and the secondary plague pneumonia is the way the infection spreads (by aerosol) from person to person.\n\n'The typical sign of the most common form of human plague is a swollen and very tender lymph gland, accompanied by pain. The swollen gland is called a 'bubo.' Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2 to 6 days after being infected.\n\n'When bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antibiotic therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. About 14 per cent (1 in 7) of all plague cases in the United States are fatal.' - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/903.]", "summary": "promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As outlined by the CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) and quoted in ProMED-mail post 20120601.1153277: 'Death from bubonic plague occurs after the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_ escapes from the infected bubo into the bloodstream (septicemic plague) causing the manifestations of the sepsis syndrome. \n\nThe person is the 4th in Colorado to contract the plague in 2015, including a 16-year-old Poudre High School student in Larimer County who was killed by a form of the bacterial infection known as septicemic plague. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Source: The Denver Post [edited]\nhttp://www.denverpost.com/news/ci_28589498/pueblo-county-plague-death-becomes-2nd-colorado-this\n\n\nPueblo County plague death becomes 2nd in Colorado this year [2015]\n -------------------------------------------------------------------\nPueblo County health officials on Wednesday, 5 Aug 2015, announced a plague death, the 2nd such death in Colorado in 2015. The bacterium can spread to the lungs, causing a secondary plague pneumonia (secondary to the bacteremia), or to the meninges, causing a plague meningitis. \n\n'When bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the Pueblo City - County Health Department", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pueblo County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Boulder County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Larimer County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denver", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3552460", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, animal - USA (12): (CO) feline", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3552460", "date": "2015-08-02 09:29:46", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (12): (COLORADO), FELINE\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 30 Jul 2015\nSource: Denver CBS Local [edited]\nhttp://denver.cbslocal.com/2015/07/30/cat-in-grand-county-tests-positive-for-the-plague/\n\n\nThe state health department has confirmed that a cat in Grand County has tested positive for the plague. State Public Health Veterinarian Jennifer House says 3 cats in Colorado have tested positive for the plague so far this year [2015].\n\nThe plague can be transmitted to people through a flea bite and direct contact with infected animals. Typical symptoms include sudden onset of fever and chills, severe headache, muscle aches, nausea, vomiting and a general feeling of systemic illness.\n\nOne person has died from the plague in 2015. Taylor Gaes of Larimer County died on 8 Jun 2015 after coming down with what he thought was a bad case of the flu, but tests confirmed it was a rare form of the plague.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague, caused by _Yersinia pestis_, is enzootic among rodents in the western United States. Humans can be infected through 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals; 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals.\n\nPlague is a potential bioterrorism agent. Human infections are rare but can be life-threatening. The case fatality rate of plague depends on the clinical presentation (that is, bubonic, septicemic, or pneumonic) and timing of initiation of antibiotic therapy; if untreated, the case fatality rate is over 50 per cent for bubonic plague and approaches 100 per cent for pneumonic plague. Rapid laboratory identification can help guide therapy.\n\nDomestic cats and dogs can also contract plague from infective fleas. They may carry infected fleas home to their owners. Cats may serve as a direct source of infection. There are many flea treatments and repellents appropriate for pets available. Some products may be suitable for dogs but not cats, or may be suitable for an adult but not a younger animal. Be sure to consult your veterinarian, as some products may be toxic to cats, kittens, and puppies, even resulting in fatalities.\n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under the jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front leg (the armpit, if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever. Please take your pet to a veterinarian if you notice any abnormalities.\n\nVeterinarians should protect themselves by wearing gloves when examining these swellings. A bubo that ruptures may infect the veterinarian or even the pet owner if the pet owner is the one palpating the swelling.\n\nAnother form of the disease is the respiratory form. Cats may acquire this form and can spread it to their owners or the veterinarians through infected expiratory droplets. People are also prone to the respiratory infection.\n\nYou should also be aware that the fleas that hitchhike into your home via a pet vehicle can also transmit disease to you, the owner, or caretaker of the pet. Sleeping in the same bed with dogs has been associated with plague in enzootic areas. Plague patients with no history of exposure to rodents can be infected by _Y. pestis_ if their pets carry infected rodent fleas into the home. Veterinarians always should recommend flea control to dog and cat owners.\n\nAlthough plague is relatively rare in wild ungulates, this report (J Wildl Dis. 2008 Oct;44(4):983-7. Ocular plague (_Yersinia pestis_) in mule deer (_Odocoileus hemionus_) from Wyoming and Oregon. Edmunds DR1, Williams ES, O'Toole D, Mills KW, Boerger-Fields AM, Jaeger PT, Bildfell RJ, Dearing P, Cornish TE) describes ocular lesions associated with _Yersinia pestis_ infection in 3 free-ranging mule deer (_Odocoileus hemionus_) from Wyoming and Oregon, USA. All deer were observed antemortem and seemed to be blind. Post-mortem examination revealed gross lesions of bilateral keratoconjunctivitis and/or panophthalmitis in the 1st 2 deer, but only partial retinal detachment in the 3rd deer. Microscopically, all deer had moderate-to-severe necrotizing and fibrinopurulent endophthalmitis and varying degrees of keratoconjunctivitis with abundant intralesional coccobacilli. The lesions in the 1st (D1) and 3rd deer (D3) suggested an acute course, whereas those in the 2nd deer (D2) were subacute to chronic. _Yersinia pestis_ was isolated from ocular tissue swabs or ocular fluids of D1 and D2, and it was demonstrated by immunohistochemistry within ocular lesions of D1 and D3. Although plague does not seem to be a major cause of morbidity or mortality in free-ranging mule deer, keratoconjunctivitis or pinkeye is relatively common in these animals, and plague should be considered as a differential diagnosis in such cases, with appropriate precautions taken to protect human and animal health.\n\nParts of this comment have been excerpted from: CDC. Notes from the field: 2 cases of human plague -- Oregon, 2010. MMWR, 25 Feb 2011; 60(07);214 and the above referenced article http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6007a4.h. - Mod.TG\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/209.]", "summary": "The case fatality rate of plague depends on the clinical presentation (that is, bubonic, septicemic, or pneumonic) and timing of initiation of antibiotic therapy; if untreated, the case fatality rate is over 50 per cent for bubonic plague and approaches 100 per cent for pneumonic plague. Although plague does not seem to be a major cause of morbidity or mortality in free-ranging mule deer, keratoconjunctivitis or pinkeye is relatively common in these animals, and plague should be considered as a differential diagnosis in such cases, with appropriate precautions taken to protect human and animal health. Humans can be infected through 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals; 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals.
