Ocular plague (_Yersinia pestis_) in mule deer (_Odocoileus hemionus_) from Wyoming and Oregon. \n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under the jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front leg (the armpit, if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-12 00:00:00", "2011-02-25 00:00:00", "2015-06-08 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Grand County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Larimer County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3513063", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, animal - USA (10): (UT) sylvatic, prairie dog, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3513063", "date": "2015-07-15 14:16:07", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (10): (UTAH) SYLVATIC, PRAIRIE DOG, ALERT\n*************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n[In the original email version of this post, the outbreak was erroneously referred to as bubonic plague rather than sylvatic plague. ProMED-mail apologizes for the error. - Mods.MHJ/MPP]\n\n\nDate: Tue 14 Jul 2015\nSource: KSL.com [edited]\nhttp://www.ksl.com/?nid=148&sid=35498521\n\n\n[Sylvatic] plague wiped out a colony of Utah prairie dogs in a remote area of the Uintah Basin, and health officials are urging residents to refrain from handling any of the dead rodents they may find. The plague outbreak, which is not uncommon in prairie dogs, was discovered last week [week of 6 Jul 2015] in an area called Coyote Basin, southeast of Vernal, said Dax Mangus, wildlife program manager in the northeastern region for the Utah Division of Wildlife Resources. The outbreak killed a colony of between 60 and 80 prairie dogs.\n\nMangus said the outbreak occurred in an area under monitoring because it is a site for the reintroduction of the black footed ferret, which prey on the dogs. The black footed ferret, North America's only native wild ferret species, has been listed as endangered since 1967 and 90 percent of its diet is prairie dogs.\n\nPlague outbreaks are not uncommon in prairie dog populations and cycles through as the colonies of animals become more dense. The disease wipes out that particular 'town,' and then new populations later establish. The disease can be transmitted to humans and can be treated with antibiotics.\n\nA statement by the TriCounty Health Department -- which serves Daggett, Duchesne, and Uintah counties -- advises people to take proper precautions and refrain from handling any carcasses of the animals. In addition, wild carnivores may become infected by eating the remains of any infected animal, which can include mice and chipmunks as well.\n\nPeople usually become infected when they are bitten by a rodent flea that is carrying the plague bacterium or by handling an infected animal without taking precautions. Symptoms include: sudden onset of fever, headache, chills, weakness, and swollen, tender, and painful lymph nodes (generally near the site where bacteria entered the body). People typically become ill within 2 to 6 days after being infected. The health department advised that the sooner treatment is obtained, the better chance of a full recovery. There are no plague vaccines that are available in the United States.\n\nMangus said the agency is currently involved in an ongoing study to develop and administer a possible vaccine to the rodents to prevent outbreaks like these. The agency will continue to monitor prairie dog populations with an eye to maintaining its efforts to bolster the reintroduction of black footed ferrets in the area. 'Our primary concern is if their food source goes away,' Mangus said.\n\nThe Utah Division of Wildlife Resources can be reached to answer questions regarding plague infestations by calling 435-781-WILD (9453). For information regarding disposal of dead animals, call TriCounty Health Department at 435-247-1177 (Vernal), 435-722-6300 (Roosevelt) or 1-866-275-0246 (toll-free).\n\n[Byline: Amy Joi O'Donoghue]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This article is worth accessing for the clear graphics on actual risks. Click on 'Photo Gallery' to see the unobstructed diagrams.\n\nThe state of Utah can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/40593. For a map of the state, go to http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/united_states/utah_90.jpg. Uintah County is in the north east corner of the state. - Mod.MHJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This article is worth accessing for the clear graphics on actual risks. [In the original email version of this post, the outbreak was erroneously referred to as bubonic plague rather than sylvatic plague. The plague outbreak, which is not uncommon in prairie dogs, was discovered last week For information regarding disposal of dead animals, call TriCounty Health Department at 435-247-1177 (Vernal), 435-722-6300 (Roosevelt) or 1-866-275-0246 (toll-free). [Byline: Amy Joi O'Donoghue]\n\n--\n \n\nThe state of Utah can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/40593. [week of 6 Jul 2015] in an area called Coyote Basin, southeast of Vernal, said Dax Mangus, wildlife program manager in the northeastern region for the Utah Division of Wildlife Resources. The outbreak killed a colony of between 60 and 80 prairie dogs. Symptoms include: sudden onset of fever, headache, chills, weakness, and swollen, tender, and painful lymph nodes (generally near the site where bacteria entered the body). Source: KSL.com [edited]\nhttp://www.ksl.com/?nid=148&sid=35498521\n\n\n \n\n\nDate: Tue 14 Jul 2015\n **\n People typically become ill within 2 to 6 days after being infected. The disease wipes out that particular 'town,' and then new populations later establish. The health department advised that the sooner treatment is obtained, the better chance of a full recovery. \n\n Our primary concern is if their food source goes away,' Mangus said.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1967-03-25 00:00:00", "9453-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Vernal", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uintah County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3563153", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (06): (CA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3563153", "date": "2015-08-07 10:22:16", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (06): (CALIFORNIA)\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 6 Aug 2015\nSource: California Department of Public Health [edited]\nhttp://www.cdph.ca.gov/Pages/NR15-056.aspx\n\n\nCalifornia Department of Public Health (CDPH) Director and State Health Officer Dr Karen Smith today, 6 Aug 2015, announced the department is investigating a case of human plague in California, and conducting an environmental evaluation in the Stanislaus National Forest, Yosemite National Park, and the surrounding areas.\n\nThe department began investigating this incident after a child from Los Angeles County became ill and was hospitalized after visiting the Stanislaus National Forest and camping at Crane Flat Campground in Yosemite National Park in mid-July 2015. No other members of the camping party reported symptoms and health officials are continuing to monitor the child's family and treatment providers. The child is recovering.\n\n'Human cases of plague are rare, with the last reported human infection in California occurring in 2006,' Dr. Smith said. 'Although this is a rare disease, people should protect themselves from infection by avoiding any contact with wild rodents. Never feed squirrels, chipmunks, or other rodents in picnic or campground areas, and never touch sick or dead rodents. Protect your pets from fleas and keep them away from wild animals,' Dr Smith added.\n\nCDPH is working closely with the Los Angeles County Department of Public Health (LACDPH), US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Yosemite National Park and the US Forest Service to investigate the source of the infection, and the patient's travel history and activities during the incubation period.\n\nAs a precaution, Yosemite National Park will provide additional information to visitors about steps to prevent plague exposure, and post caution signs at the Crane Flat campground and nearby campgrounds. Steps the public can take to avoid exposure to human plague include:\n- never feed squirrels, chipmunks or other rodents and never touch sick or dead rodents;\n- avoid walking, hiking or camping near rodent burrows;\n- wear long pants tucked into socks or boot tops to reduce exposure to fleas;\n- spray insect repellent containing DEET on socks and pant cuffs to reduce exposure to fleas;\n- keep wild rodents out of homes, trailers, and outbuildings and away from pets.\n\nIn California, plague-infected animals are most likely to be found in the foothills and mountains and to a lesser extent, along the coast. Desert and Central Valley areas are considered low risk for plague. State and local health officials regularly monitor plague-prone areas by testing animals and their fleas. In 2014, non-human plague activity was detected in animals in 7 counties: El Dorado, Mariposa, Modoc, Plumas, San Diego, Santa Barbara, and Sierra.\n\nPlague is not transmitted from human to human, unless a patient with plague also has a lung infection and is coughing. There have been no known cases of human-to-human infection in California since 1924. LACDPH and CDPH believe the risk of human-to-human transmission is similarly low in this case. The last reported cases of human plague in California occurred in 2005 and 2006 in Mono, Los Angeles, and Kern counties and all 3 patients survived following treatment with antibiotics. Since 1970, 42 human cases of plague have been confirmed in California, of which 9 were fatal.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is a short history of the introduction of _Yersinia pestis_ into the USA (http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/aso/databank/entries/dm00bu.html):\n\nIn the summer of 1899, a ship sailing from Hong Kong to San Francisco had had 2 cases of plague on board. Because of this, although no passengers were ill when the ship reached San Francisco, it was to be quarantined on Angel Island. When the boat was searched, 11 stowaways were found -- the next day 2 were missing. Their bodies were later found in the Bay, and autopsy showed they contained plague bacilli. Despite this scare, there was no immediate outbreak of disease. But rats from the ship probably had something to do with the epidemic that hit San Francisco 9 months later.\n\nOn 6 Mar 1900, a city health officer autopsied a deceased Chinese man and found organisms in the body that looked like plague. In 1894, 2 research physicians had simultaneously and independently identified the bacillus that causes bubonic plague. Shibasaburo Kitasato published his findings in Japanese and English; Alexandre Yersin published in French. People in different parts of the world credited one or the other with the discovery, depending which journals they had read. (Since 1970 the bacillus has been known as _Yersinia pestis_.) That the plague had an identifiable 'germ' was known. But other recent findings had not been disseminated -- or believed. Most people felt that the germ infected humans through food or open wounds. Disinfection campaigns were the order of the day. In some places they ran carbolic acid through sewers, actually spreading the disease faster because it flushed out rats that had lived there.\n\nBack in San Francisco, however, political issues vied with scientific efforts. Anti-Chinese feeling ran strong in the city then, and the 1st step taken was to quarantine Chinatown. The Chinese objected, and so did the business community. Not because they wanted to protect the rights of the Chinese, but it was bad for business to have people thinking there was plague in their city or state. The quarantine was lifted but health officials ran house-to-house inspections of Chinatown. People resisted, hiding their dead and locking their doors. But 2 more plague victims turned up. The city Board of Health officially announced that plague was present in the city. The governor refused to believe it or to do anything to help in the antiplague effort. The Surgeon General got permission from President McKinley to pass antiplague regulations. Others still denied the existence of plague, although more and more states in the country were stopping trade with California.\n\nCommissions and boards formed, fought with the governor, and were disbanded, underfunded, and reformed. Meanwhile, more plague cases were found. In April 1901, a clean-up campaign of Chinatown was undertaken, scouring almost 1200 houses and 14 000 rooms. In 1903, a new governor took office and vowed to help the boards of health in every way. On 29 Feb 1904, a woman in the town of Concord, California, died of plague, its last victim -- for a while. There had been 121 cases in San Francisco and 5 outside, with 122 deaths.\n\nKnowledge, like illness, spreads. In the next few years, information about the plague's causes and transmission would be clarified. In 1894, physician Mary Miles in Canton, China, had reported the widespread death of rats in plague epidemics. But people assumed the rats caught the disease from humans. In 1897, Japanese physician Masanori Ogata wrote 'one should pay attention to insects like fleas for, as the rat becomes cold after death, they leave their host and may transmit the plague virus directly to man.' Paul Louis Simmond put all the accumulated observations together, made his own observations (societal and microscopic), and experimented with the bacillus, rats, and fleas. He proved that rat fleas bit people (which went against received wisdom), and that a sick animal could not transmit the disease if it didn't have fleas. Simmond published his conclusions in 1898 and was roundly ridiculed. But in 1905, a British commission published some of the same findings and in 1908, issued a report confirming all of Simmond's conclusions (though not crediting him).\n\nIn 1906, an earthquake of record proportions devastated San Francisco. The ruin of the city's buildings made not just people, but rats, homeless. The subsequent year or 2 of living in refugee camps while rebuilding was highly conducive to rat and flea infestations. In 1907, cases of plague were reported. But with hindsight on the last epidemic and new knowledge from research, officials launched a new kind of campaign. They offered a bounty on rats. A similar rat-catching campaign had been used successfully to fight plague in New Orleans. It worked as well in San Francisco, and though this 2nd epidemic was stronger than the 1st, it was brought to halt in 1909. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/29430.]", "summary": "Steps the public can take to avoid exposure to human plague include:\n- never feed squirrels, chipmunks or other rodents and never touch sick or dead rodents;\n- avoid walking, hiking or camping near rodent burrows;\n- wear long pants tucked into socks or boot tops to reduce exposure to fleas;\n- spray insect repellent containing DEET on socks and pant cuffs to reduce exposure to fleas;\n- keep wild rodents out of homes, trailers, and outbuildings and away from pets. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n'Human cases of plague are rare, with the last reported human infection in California occurring in 2006,' Dr. Smith said. ' promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is a short history of the introduction of _Yersinia pestis_ into the USA (http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/aso/databank/entries/dm00bu.html):\n\nIn the summer of 1899, a ship sailing from Hong Kong to San Francisco had had 2 cases of plague on board. Plague is not transmitted from human to human, unless a patient with plague also has a lung infection and is coughing. The last reported cases of human plague in California occurred in 2005 and 2006 in Mono, Los Angeles, and Kern counties and all 3 patients survived following treatment with antibiotics. \n\nAs a precaution, Yosemite National Park will provide additional information to visitors about steps to prevent plague exposure, and post caution signs at the Crane Flat campground and nearby campgrounds. Dr Karen Smith today, 6 Aug 2015, announced the department is investigating a case of human plague in California, and conducting an environmental evaluation in the Stanislaus National Forest, Yosemite National Park, and the surrounding areas. PLAGUE - USA (06): (CALIFORNIA)\n*******************************\n In 1897, Japanese physician Masanori Ogata wrote 'one should pay attention to insects like fleas for, as the rat becomes cold after death, they leave their host and may transmit the plague virus directly to man.' State and local health officials regularly monitor plague-prone areas by testing animals and their fleas. On 6 Mar 1900, a city health officer autopsied a deceased Chinese man and found organisms in the body that looked like plague. Since 1970, 42 human cases of plague have been confirmed in California, of which 9 were fatal. In 2014, non-human plague activity was detected in animals in 7 counties: El Dorado, Mariposa, Modoc, Plumas, San Diego, Santa Barbara, and Sierra. The city Board of Health officially announced that plague was present in the city. Not because they wanted to protect the rights of the Chinese, but it was bad for business to have people thinking there was plague in their city or state. In 1894, physician Mary Miles in Canton, China, had reported the widespread death of rats in plague epidemics. In 1894, 2 research physicians had simultaneously and independently identified the bacillus that causes bubonic plague. \n\nCDPH is working closely with the Los Angeles County Department of Public Health (LACDPH), US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Yosemite National Park and the US Forest Service to investigate the source of the infection, and the patient's travel history and activities during the incubation period. In California, plague-infected animals are most likely to be found in the foothills and mountains and to a lesser extent, along the coast. He proved that rat fleas bit people (which went against received wisdom), and that a sick animal could not transmit the disease if it didn't have fleas. A similar rat-catching campaign had been used successfully to fight plague in New Orleans. There have been no known cases of human-to-human infection in California since 1924. In 1907, cases of plague were reported. Meanwhile, more plague cases were found.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1909-03-25 00:00:00", "1905-03-25 00:00:00", "1900-03-06 00:00:00", "1897-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "1901-04-25 00:00:00", "1908-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "1904-02-29 00:00:00", "1903-03-25 00:00:00", "1906-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "1898-03-25 00:00:00", "1907-03-25 00:00:00", "1894-03-25 00:00:00", "1924-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-08-06 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "1970-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Francisco", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Los Angeles County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mono", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Modoc", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mariposa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Concord", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Diego", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canton", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "El Dorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "National Park", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santa Barbara", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Orleans", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Los Angeles", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3526149", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (03): (CO) bubonic", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3526149", "date": "2015-07-21 19:26:55", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (03): (COLORADO) BUBONIC\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 20 Jul 2015\nSource: Chaffee County Times [edited]\nhttp://www.chaffeecountytimes.com/news/plague-confirmed-in-chaffee-county/article_26bc4908-2f01-11e5-9c23-1b90ac501fdd.html\n\n\nChaffee County Health Department reported Fri 17 Jul 2015 that bubonic plague has been confirmed in a Chaffee County resident recently. The unidentified individual was hospitalized and has survived following intravenous antimicrobial treatment, Susan Ellis, county health director, wrote in a press release. Identification of the disease was made by the state public health laboratory 10 Jul 2015.\n\nColorado Department of Public Health reports that 17 human plague cases have been confirmed in Colorado since 2005. This would make the 18th case. Investigation revealed that the family dog became ill with symptoms consistent with plague a few days prior to the onset of illness in the dog's owner. The dog has recovered and test results from the dog are pending.\n\nThe incubation period for the bubonic plague is 1-6 days. Ellis said the infected individual was in Chaffee County during that time period, which made it clear she was in the county when she contracted the disease. The health department is conducting surveillance for rodent die-off and has posted warning signs about plague in the vicinity of the Little Rainbow Trailhead off CR 110.\n\nA 16-year old boy from the Cherokee Park area in northern Colorado died from the septicemic form of the plague on 8 Jun 2015.\n\n[Byline: Paul J. Goetz]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As compared to cats, dogs are not considered to be significant in the transmission of _Yersinia pestis_ to humans. However, as underscored by the following paper, cases in canines do occur:\n\nOrloski KA, Eidson M: Yersinia pestis infection in three dogs. J Am Vet Med Assoc. 1995;207: 316-318\nAbstract:\n'_Yersinia pestis_ infection was diagnosed in 3 dogs. Clinical signs included lethargy (3 dogs), pyrexia (2 dogs), and a purulent skin lesion in the cervical region (2 dogs). _Yersinia pestis_ infection is a potentially fatal zoonotic disease of human beings. Human cases have resulted from contact with infected domestic cats; however, the risk of human infection from contact with infected domestic dogs is unknown. Dogs frequently are exposed to _Y. pestis_ in areas in which there are plague epizootics; however, clinical illness in dogs is rare. In the western United States, where _Yersinia pestis_ is endemic, plague should be considered in the differential diagnosis when examining dogs with nonspecific fever and lethargy.'\n\nIndeed, a cluster of canine-related human cases of pneumonic plague with possible human to human spread occurred in Colorado in 2014 (Plague - USA: (CO) pneumonic, canine source, poss. human-to-human spread, 2014: 20150501.3335475). - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/209.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Indeed, a cluster of canine-related human cases of pneumonic plague with possible human to human spread occurred in Colorado in 2014 (Plague - USA: (CO) pneumonic, canine source, poss. Human cases have resulted from contact with infected domestic cats; however, the risk of human infection from contact with infected domestic dogs is unknown. Clinical signs included lethargy (3 dogs), pyrexia (2 dogs), and a purulent skin lesion in the cervical region (2 dogs). \n\nColorado Department of Public Health reports that 17 human plague cases have been confirmed in Colorado since 2005. Dogs frequently are exposed to _Y. pestis_ in areas in which there are plague epizootics; however, clinical illness in dogs is rare. However, as underscored by the following paper, cases in canines do occur:\n\nOrloski KA, Eidson M: Yersinia pestis infection in three dogs. Abstract:\n'_Yersinia pestis_ infection was diagnosed in 3 dogs. In the western United States, where _Yersinia pestis_ is endemic, plague should be considered in the differential diagnosis when examining dogs with nonspecific fever and lethargy.' promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As compared to cats, dogs are not considered to be significant in the transmission of _Yersinia pestis_ to humans.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2015-06-08 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chaffee County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3470704", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, animal - USA (09): (CO) mule deer, prairie dog", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3470704", "date": "2015-06-28 21:15:46", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (09): (COLORADO), MULE DEER, PRAIRIE DOG\n*************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: 26 Jun 2015\nSource: The Denver Post [edited]\nhttp://www.denverpost.com/news/ci_28391254/el-paso-county-confirms-mule-deer-carried-first\n\n\nEl Paso County Public Health officials Friday [26 Jun 2015] confirmed the area's 1st case of the plague this year [2015], saying a mule deer found on 19 Jun 2015 tested positive for the disease.\n\nOfficials are cautioning residents in the Pleasant Valley neighborhood, on Colorado Springs' west side, to take precautions. Notification of the positive test came Friday [26 Jun 2015].\n\nThe El Paso County case comes on the heels of at least 2 other incidents of plague in recent days; a 16-year-old high school baseball player from Poudre High School died on 8 Jun 2015 after contracting a rare strain of the disease. Also on Friday [26 Jun 2015], a parking area in Lakewood's Bear Creek Lake Park was shut down by plague connected to a prairie dog colony.\n\nPlague is a bacterial disease transmitted to humans by the bite of an infected flea, or by handling an infected animal. Taking steps to avoid flea exposure will help prevent spread of the disease.\n\nIn humans, the symptoms of plague infection are high fever, chills, headache, extreme fatigue and tender or swollen lymph glands. If you experience these symptoms, contact your physician.\n\nPlague is endemic in El Paso County, and precautions to prevent plague should always be taken. El Paso County's last reported human case occurred in 1991; officials said they will monitor plague activity in the neighborhood and respond as appropriate.\n\n[Byline: Anthony Cotton]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: 26 Jun 2015\nSource: The Denver Post [edited]\nhttp://www.denverpost.com/news/ci_28390231/prairie-dog-plague-shuts-down-part-bear-creek\n\n\nA parking area in Lakewood's Bear Creek Lake Park has been shut down by plague connected to a prairie dog colony. The unpaved, overflow parking lot at the park, 15 600 W. Morrison Road, has been closed the past week, according to a Lakewood media release.\n\nJefferson County Public Health confirmed the presence of plague in the popular park. Crews have dusted prairie dog holes in the area to kill fleas, which carry and transmit the plague, the release said.\n\nThe city is not aware of any humans who have contracted the plague from the park's prairie dog colonies.\n\nPark visitors are urged to follow posted directions and closures, and to keep dogs on a leash and away from marked areas.\n\n[Byline: Kieran Nicholson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Joe Dudley\n\n[Plague, caused by _Yersinia pestis_, is enzootic among rodents in the western United States. Humans can be infected through 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals; 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals.\n\nPlague is a potential bioterrorism agent. Human infections are rare but can be life-threatening. The case fatality rate of plague depends on the clinical presentation (that is, bubonic, septicemic, or pneumonic) and timing of initiation of antibiotic therapy; if untreated, the case fatality rate is over 50 per cent for bubonic plague and approaches 100 per cent for pneumonic plague. Rapid laboratory identification can help guide therapy.\n\nDomestic cats and dogs can also contract plague from infective fleas. They may carry infected fleas home to their owners. Cats may serve as a direct source of infection. There are many flea treatments and repellents appropriate for pets available. Some products may be suitable for dogs but not cats, or may be suitable for an adult but not a younger animal. Be sure to consult your veterinarian, as some products may be toxic to cats, kittens, and puppies, even resulting in fatalities.\n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under the jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front leg (the armpit, if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever. Please take your pet to a veterinarian if you notice any abnormalities.\n\nVeterinarians should protect themselves by wearing gloves when examining these swellings. A bubo that ruptures may infect the veterinarian or even the pet owner if the pet owner is the one palpating the swelling.\n\nAnother form of the disease is the respiratory form. Cats may acquire this form and can spread it to their owners or the veterinarians through infected expiratory droplets. People are also prone to the respiratory infection.\n\nYou should also be aware that the fleas that hitchhike into your home via a pet vehicle can also transmit disease to you, the owner, or caretaker of the pet. Sleeping in the same bed with dogs has been associated with plague in enzootic areas. Plague patients with no history of exposure to rodents can be infected by _Y. pestis_ if their pets carry infected rodent fleas into the home. Veterinarians always should recommend flea control to dog and cat owners.\n\nAlthough plague is relatively rare in wild ungulates, this report (J Wildl Dis. 2008 Oct;44(4):983-7. Ocular plague (_Yersinia pestis_) in mule deer (_Odocoileus hemionus_) from Wyoming and Oregon. Edmunds DR1, Williams ES, O'Toole D, Mills KW, Boerger-Fields AM, Jaeger PT, Bildfell RJ, Dearing P, Cornish TE) describes ocular lesions associated with _Yersinia pestis_ infection in 3 free-ranging mule deer (_Odocoileus hemionus_) from Wyoming and Oregon, USA. All deer were observed antemortem and seemed to be blind. Post-mortem examination revealed gross lesions of bilateral keratoconjunctivitis and/or panophthalmitis in the 1st 2 deer, but only partial retinal detachment in the 3rd deer. Microscopically, all deer had moderate-to-severe necrotizing and fibrinopurulent endophthalmitis and varying degrees of keratoconjunctivitis with abundant intralesional coccobacilli. The lesions in the 1st (D1) and 3rd deer (D3) suggested an acute course, whereas those in the 2nd deer (D2) were subacute to chronic. _Yersinia pestis_ was isolated from ocular tissue swabs or ocular fluids of D1 and D2, and it was demonstrated by immunohistochemistry within ocular lesions of D1 and D3. Although plague does not seem to be a major cause of morbidity or mortality in free-ranging mule deer, keratoconjunctivitis or pinkeye is relatively common in these animals, and plague should be considered as a differential diagnosis in such cases, with appropriate precautions taken to protect human and animal health.\n\nParts of this comment have been excerpted from: CDC. Notes from the field: 2 cases of human plague -- Oregon, 2010. MMWR, 25 Feb 2011; 60(07);214 and the above referenced article http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6007a4.htm. - Mod.TG\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/209.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n The case fatality rate of plague depends on the clinical presentation (that is, bubonic, septicemic, or pneumonic) and timing of initiation of antibiotic therapy; if untreated, the case fatality rate is over 50 per cent for bubonic plague and approaches 100 per cent for pneumonic plague. Although plague does not seem to be a major cause of morbidity or mortality in free-ranging mule deer, keratoconjunctivitis or pinkeye is relatively common in these animals, and plague should be considered as a differential diagnosis in such cases, with appropriate precautions taken to protect human and animal health. \n\nThe El Paso County case comes on the heels of at least 2 other incidents of plague in recent days; a 16-year-old high school baseball player from Poudre High School died on 8 Jun 2015 after contracting a rare strain of the disease. [26 Jun 2015] confirmed the area's 1st case of the plague this year [2015], saying a mule deer found on 19 Jun 2015 tested positive for the disease. PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (09): (COLORADO), MULE DEER, PRAIRIE DOG\n*************************************************************\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Joe Dudley\n\n[Plague, caused by _Yersinia pestis_, is enzootic among rodents in the western United States. Humans can be infected through 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals; 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals. Source: The Denver Post [edited]\nhttp://www.denverpost.com/news/ci_28390231/prairie-dog-plague-shuts-down-part-bear-creek\n\n\nA parking area in Lakewood's Bear Creek Lake Park has been shut down by plague connected to a prairie dog colony. Plague patients with no history of exposure to rodents can be infected by _Y. pestis_ if their pets carry infected rodent fleas into the home. \n\nThe city is not aware of any humans who have contracted the plague from the park's prairie dog colonies. Plague is a bacterial disease transmitted to humans by the bite of an infected flea, or by handling an infected animal. \n\nDomestic cats and dogs can also contract plague from infective fleas. Also on Friday [26 Jun 2015], a parking area in Lakewood's Bear Creek Lake Park was shut down by plague connected to a prairie dog colony. \n\nYou should also be aware that the fleas that hitchhike into your home via a pet vehicle can also transmit disease to you, the owner, or caretaker of the pet. \n\nJefferson County Public Health confirmed the presence of plague in the popular park. Crews have dusted prairie dog holes in the area to kill fleas, which carry and transmit the plague, the release said. Post-mortem examination revealed gross lesions of bilateral keratoconjunctivitis and/or panophthalmitis in the 1st 2 deer, but only partial retinal detachment in the 3rd deer. Plague is endemic in El Paso County, and precautions to prevent plague should always be taken. \n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under the jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front leg (the armpit, if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1991-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-06-08 00:00:00", "2011-02-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-06-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2015-06-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "El Paso County 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lakewood", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "El Paso County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "El Paso County Public Health", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado Springs '", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3458401", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (02): (CO) fatality", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3458401", "date": "2015-06-23 10:45:57", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (02): (COLORADO) FATALITY\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 21 Jun 2015\nSource: CBS News, Associated Press (AP) report [edited]\nhttp://www.cbsnews.com/news/in-rare-case-colorado-teen-dies-of-plague/\n\n\nA young man has died in Larimer County, [Colorado], in the county's 1st confirmed plague case since 1999. Authorities are still investigating the 8 Jun 2015 death. CBS Denver reports that the teenager acquired the infection most likely from fleas on a dead rodent or other animal on the family acreage. He was a 16-year-old high school athlete who played quarterback on the football team and was a starting pitcher in baseball.\n\nThe Larimer County Health Department said this is the 1st county resident confirmed to have contacted the plague since 1999. The agency is leading the investigation with help from experts from the CDC, the State Health Department and the coroner's office. Officials say the family is reaching out to people who visited the home before the cause of death was known. There is a small chance that others could have been bitten by infected fleas.\n\nPlague can spread through rodent populations in a localized area often resulting in mass animal 'die-offs.' The only animals with confirmed plague so far in 2015 in Larimer County were in an area of Soapstone Natural area that is not open to the public, according to CBS Denver.\n\nThe plague killed millions of people in Europe in the Middle Ages in a series of outbreaks known as the Black Death. 'Now, it's very rare, especially in the USA. There are only about 7 to 10 cases a year, but it still exists,' medical contributor Dr Holly Phillips told 'CBS This Morning.' 'Think of rodents in very rural states -- western states, southwest, ranches, farms -- that's likely what happened here.'\n\nThe plague can be treated with antimicrobials, but Phillips said that because it's so rare and early symptoms can resemble the flu, it may not be recognized in time. The most common form of the disease, bubonic plague, accounts for about 80 percent of cases in humans. It causes painful swelling of the lymph nodes, fever, and muscle aches, and as the bacteria multiply they can spread to the respiratory system and bloodstream.\n\nA 7-year-old girl recovered from the plague after contracting it while camping in southwest Colorado in 2015. Her mother said may have been infected by insects near a dead squirrel she wanted to bury.\n\nIn recent decades, an average of 7 human plague cases are reported each year nationwide according to the CDC. Most human cases in the United States are scattered in rural areas and occur predominantly in northern New Mexico, northern Arizona, and southern Colorado, California, southern Oregon, and far western Nevada.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nChanel Schwartzentruber\n<cschwart@mail.uoguelph.ca>\n\n[Another report of this case was submitted by Adrienne LeBailly, MD, MPH, Director, Larimer County Dept. of Health & Environment. ProMED-mail thanks both submitters.\n\nThere was no report of a bubo in this case, only that the young man had a 'flu-like' illness. This appears to be a case of primary septicemic plague.\n\nAs outlined by the CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) and quoted in ProMED-mail post 20120601.1153277: 'Death from bubonic plague occurs after the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_ escapes from the infected bubo into the bloodstream (septicemic plague) causing the manifestations of the sepsis syndrome. Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) with subsequent cutaneous hemorrhage may well have been what was called the 'Black Death' in the Middle Ages. The bacterium can spread to the lungs, causing a secondary plague pneumonia (secondary to the bacteremia), or to the meninges, causing a plague meningitis. Both of these events have a high case fatality rate and the secondary plague pneumonia is the way the infection spreads (by aerosol) from person to person.\n\n'The typical sign of the most common form of human plague is a swollen and very tender lymph gland, accompanied by pain. The swollen gland is called a 'bubo.' Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2 to 6 days after being infected.\n\n'When bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antibiotic therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. About 14 per cent (1 in 7) of all plague cases in the United States are fatal.' - Mod.LL\n\nThe state of Colorado can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1298. Larimer County can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/colorado-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "As outlined by the CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) and quoted in ProMED-mail post 20120601.1153277: 'Death from bubonic plague occurs after the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_ escapes from the infected bubo into the bloodstream (septicemic plague) causing the manifestations of the sepsis syndrome. \n\n'When bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. The bacterium can spread to the lungs, causing a secondary plague pneumonia (secondary to the bacteremia), or to the meninges, causing a plague meningitis. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. \n\n'The typical sign of the most common form of human plague is a swollen and very tender lymph gland, accompanied by pain. \n\nA 7-year-old girl recovered from the plague after contracting it while camping in southwest Colorado in 2015. Both of these events have a high case fatality rate and the secondary plague pneumonia is the way the infection spreads (by aerosol) from person to person. \n\nPlague can spread through rodent populations in a localized area often resulting in mass animal 'die-offs.' \n\nThe Larimer County Health Department said this is the 1st county resident confirmed to have contacted the plague since 1999. \n\nThe plague can be treated with antimicrobials, but Phillips said that because it's so rare and early symptoms can resemble the flu, it may not be recognized in time. PLAGUE - USA (02): (COLORADO) FATALITY\n**************************************\n Communicated by:\nChanel Schwartzentruber\n<cschwart@mail.uoguelph.ca>\n\n[Another report of this case was submitted by Adrienne LeBailly, MD, MPH, Director, Larimer County Dept. of Health & Environment. In recent decades, an average of 7 human plague cases are reported each year nationwide according to the CDC. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. The only animals with confirmed plague so far in 2015 in Larimer County were in an area of Soapstone Natural area that is not open to the public, according to CBS Denver.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["1999-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2015-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Larimer County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Larimer County Dept", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nevada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3443480", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, animal - USA (08): (ID) vole, susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3443480", "date": "2015-06-17 08:55:45", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (08):(IDAHO) VOLE, SUSPECTED\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 15 Jun 2015\nSource: KTVB [edited]\nhttp://www.ktvb.com/story/news/health/2015/06/15/rodents-plague-southwest-idaho/71269628/\n\n\nThere is another possible case of the plague in southwest Idaho. This one was found near Highway 19, immediately west of Caldwell [Canyon County]. This possible case is not connected to the plague found southeast of Boise[Ada County] last month [May 2015] [see archive list below.] The plague found in the desert southeast of Boise involved ground squirrels. This new potential case of the plague is tied to voles. Voles are also commonly called meadow mice.\n\nState health officials say they tested dead voles found in the area near Highway 19 west of Caldwell and initial results indicate possible plague.\nThey say the case appears to be localized and not widespread. However, people are urged to take precautions.\n\nPlague is a bacterial disease of rodents that can cause serious illness to people and pets, if not treated quickly. Plague is generally transmitted to humans and animals through bites of infected fleas. People can be exposed to plague when pets have contact with rodents or fleas outdoors, or when pets bring infected rodents or fleas back into the home. [Or when people approach dead wildlife when the fleas are in the process of abandoning ship. Mod.JW]\n\n'Don't let your pets sleep with you in your bed. If your pets roam free or they may hunt some of these rodents that may be a risk for plague. They may bring these infected fleas home and if they sleep in your bed they may have a chance to bite you as well,' said epidemiologist Raemi Nolevanko with Southwest District Health. People can also become infected by caring for a sick pet without proper precautions.\n\nPeople are urged to keep their pets from roaming or hunting voles or other rodents. Sick pets should be examined promptly by a veterinarian. Plague symptoms in cats and dogs are fever, lethargy, and loss of appetite.\n\nPeople are encouraged to avoid contact with wild rodents. Clean up areas near your home where rodents can live -- like wood piles or tall grass. Put hay, wood, and compost piles as far away as possible from your home.\n\nSymptoms of plague in humans include sudden onset of fever, chills, headache, and weakness. If you experience any of the symptoms, get medical help right away.\n\n[Paul Boehlke, Kim Fields]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Idaho can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/8132.\nCanyon and Ada counties can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/idaho-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ\n\nPlague was diagnosed recently in Idaho in a dog -- see archives listed below.\n\nPlague is transmitted by fleas. There are several forms of plague in human beings: bubonic, septicemic, and pneumonic.\n\nGround squirrels, and other rodents are frequently the source of the bacteria. This suspected case is in a vole, a rodent with a short tail, short legs and short nose. They are really very charming little creatures. A photo may be viewed at http://www.arkive.org/field-vole/microtus-agrestis/.\n\nPlague, caused by _Yersinia pestis_, is enzootic among rodents in the western United States. Humans can be infected through\n1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals;\n2) direct contact with contaminated tissues; or\n3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals.\n\nFor a more complete comment on plague in animals, readers are encouraged to read the moderator's comments on ProMED-mail post 20150608.3417597. - Mod.TG]", "summary": "Humans can be infected through\n1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals;\n2) direct contact with contaminated tissues; or\n3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n People can be exposed to plague when pets have contact with rodents or fleas outdoors, or when pets bring infected rodents or fleas back into the home. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Idaho can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/8132. \n\nState health officials say they tested dead voles found in the area near Highway 19 west of Caldwell and initial results indicate possible plague. \n\nPlague is a bacterial disease of rodents that can cause serious illness to people and pets, if not treated quickly. PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (08):(IDAHO) VOLE, SUSPECTED\n*************************************************\n \n\nPeople are urged to keep their pets from roaming or hunting voles or other rodents. A photo may be viewed at http://www.arkive.org/field-vole/microtus-agrestis/.\n\nPlague, caused by _Yersinia pestis_, is enzootic among rodents in the western United States. \n\nSymptoms of plague in humans include sudden onset of fever, chills, headache, and weakness. \n\nPeople are encouraged to avoid contact with wild rodents. [Paul Boehlke, Kim Fields]\n\n--\n Plague is generally transmitted to humans and animals through bites of infected fleas. MJ\n\nPlague was diagnosed recently in Idaho in a dog -- see archives listed below. This possible case is not connected to the plague found southeast of Boise[Ada County] last month [May 2015] [see archive list below.]", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2015-05-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Idaho", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canyon County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Boise", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Boise[Ada County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Highway", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3394344", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, animal - USA (05): (ID) ground squirrel, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3394344", "date": "2015-05-29 13:57:14", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (05): (IDAHO) GROUND SQUIRREL, ALERT\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed, 27 May 2015\nSource: Kuna Melba News [edited]\nhttp://www.kunamelba.com/2015/05/plague-found-south-kuna/\n\n\nThe Idaho Department of Health and Welfare said that ground squirrels south of Kuna in the Morley Nelson Birds of Prey Conservation Area have tested positive for plague and that humans and pets should avoid the area. The bacterial disease responsible for the deaths of an estimated 50 million people in the 14th century, or nearly 60 percent of Europe, was found by Idaho Fish and Game officials, testing positive in 7 dead squirrels sent to the U.S. Center for Disease Control and Prevention. Officials said they found 24 die-off sites. Ground squirrels are routinely tested, as plague has appeared in ground squirrel populations before.\n\nThe plague area of approximately circular shape extends just south of Kuna to the Snake River, bordering Interstate I-84 to the north and nearly to Mountain Home eastward.\n\nClinical signs of plague in humans include headache, weakness, fever and chills. 2 cases of plague in Idaho among humans happened in 1991 and 1992. Both recovered.\n\nDogs or cats with clinical signs of fever, vomiting or loss of appetite should see a veterinarian immediately. Protect pets with flea repellent products and do not allow them to roam free. Rolling in or picking up a dead squirrel by dogs should not be permitted.\n\nPlague has not been detected in any other animals at this time.\n\n[Byline: Mark Barnes]\n\n---\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations. Some species are particularly susceptible. For example, _Y. pestis_ caused the extinction of entire colonies of black-tailed prairie dogs. Small rodents such as deer mice and grasshopper mice are suggested to act as the reservoirs. Larger species like squirrels and chipmunks are considered to be more vulnerable to infection.\n\nA map of the affected area can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/awKj. - Mod.PMB]\n\n[Plague, caused by _Yersinia pestis_, is enzootic among rodents in the western USA. Humans can be infected through 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals; 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals.\n\nPlague is a potential bioterrorism agent. Human infections are rare but can be life-threatening. The plague case-fatality rate depends on the clinical presentation (that is, bubonic, septicemic, or pneumonic) and timing of initiation of antibiotic therapy; if untreated, the case-fatality rate is over 50 per cent for bubonic plague and approaches 100 per cent for pneumonic plague. Rapid laboratory identification can help guide therapy.\n\nDomestic cats and dogs can also contract plague from infective fleas. They may carry infected fleas home to their owners. Cats may serve as a direct source of infection. There are many flea treatments and repellents appropriate for pets available. Some products may be suitable for dogs but not cats, or may be suitable for an adult but not a younger animal. Be sure to consult your veterinarian, as some products may be toxic to cats, kittens, and puppies, even resulting in fatalities.\n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under the jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front leg (the armpit if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever. Please take your pet to a veterinarian if you notice any abnormalities.\n\nVeterinarians should protect themselves by wearing gloves when examining these swellings. A bubo that ruptures may infect the veterinarian or even the pet owner if the pet owner is the one palpating the swelling.\n\nAnother form of the disease is the respiratory form. Cats may acquire this form and can spread it to their owners or the veterinarians through infected expiratory droplets. People are also prone to the respiratory infection.\n\nYou should also be aware that the fleas that hitchhike into your home via a pet vehicle can also transmit disease to you, the owner, or caretaker of the pet. Sleeping in the same bed with dogs has been associated with plague in enzootic areas. Plague patients with no history of exposure to rodents can be infected by _Y. pestis_ if their pets carry infected rodent fleas into the home. Veterinarians always should recommend flea control to dog and cat owners.\n\nParts of this comment have been excerpted from: Notes from the Field: Two Cases of Human Plague -- Oregon, 2010, CDC. MMWR, 25 Feb 2011; 60(07);: 214 http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6007a4.htm. - Mod.TG]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The plague case-fatality rate depends on the clinical presentation (that is, bubonic, septicemic, or pneumonic) and timing of initiation of antibiotic therapy; if untreated, the case-fatality rate is over 50 per cent for bubonic plague and approaches 100 per cent for pneumonic plague. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. Humans can be infected through 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals; 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals. Plague patients with no history of exposure to rodents can be infected by _Y. pestis_ if their pets carry infected rodent fleas into the home. \n\nYou should also be aware that the fleas that hitchhike into your home via a pet vehicle can also transmit disease to you, the owner, or caretaker of the pet. \n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under the jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front leg (the armpit if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever. \n\nDomestic cats and dogs can also contract plague from infective fleas. \n\nDogs or cats with clinical signs of fever, vomiting or loss of appetite should see a veterinarian immediately. \n\nClinical signs of plague in humans include headache, weakness, fever and chills. PMB]\n\n[Plague, caused by _Yersinia pestis_, is enzootic among rodents in the western USA. The Idaho Department of Health and Welfare said that ground squirrels south of Kuna in the Morley Nelson Birds of Prey Conservation Area have tested positive for plague and that humans and pets should avoid the area. The bacterial disease responsible for the deaths of an estimated 50 million people in the 14th century, or nearly 60 percent of Europe, was found by Idaho Fish and Game officials, testing positive in 7 dead squirrels sent to the U.S. Center for Disease Control and Prevention. \n\nParts of this comment have been excerpted from: Notes from the Field: Two Cases of Human Plague -- Oregon, 2010, CDC. \n\nAnother form of the disease is the respiratory form. [Byline: Mark Barnes]\n\n---\n PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (05): (IDAHO) GROUND SQUIRREL, ALERT\n The plague area of approximately circular shape extends just south of Kuna to the Snake River, bordering Interstate I-84 to the north and nearly to Mountain Home eastward. Ground squirrels are routinely tested, as plague has appeared in ground squirrel populations before. A bubo that ruptures may infect the veterinarian or even the pet owner if the pet owner is the one palpating the swelling. Cats may acquire this form and can spread it to their owners or the veterinarians through infected expiratory droplets. \n\nA map of the affected area can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/awKj. \n\nVeterinarians should protect themselves by wearing gloves when examining these swellings. 2 cases of plague in Idaho among humans happened in 1991 and 1992. They may carry infected fleas home to their owners. Some products may be suitable for dogs but not cats, or may be suitable for an adult but not a younger animal. Sleeping in the same bed with dogs has been associated with plague in enzootic areas. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. For example, _Y. pestis_ caused the extinction of entire colonies of black-tailed prairie dogs. Be sure to consult your veterinarian, as some products may be toxic to cats, kittens, and puppies, even resulting in fatalities. \n\n Protect pets with flea repellent products and do not allow them to roam free.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1991-03-25 00:00:00", "1992-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-02-25 00:00:00", "2015-05-27 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Idaho", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kuna", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3417597", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, animal - USA (07): (ID) canine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3417597", "date": "2015-06-08 04:16:51", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (07): (IDAHO) CANINE\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 4 Jun 2015\nSource: KTVB.com [edited]\nhttp://www.ktvb.com/story/news/health/2015/06/04/health-department-ada-county-dog-likely-has-plague/28484481/\n\n\nAn Ada County dog likely contracted the plague after it came into contact with ground squirrels south of Boise last month [May 2015], health officials said. According to Central District Health Department (CDHD), the dog became ill at the end of May 2015. Plague was confirmed in ground squirrels in an area south of Boise to the Snake River and from Kuna to Mountain Home nearly 2 weeks ago.\n\nThe dog's owner took it to a veterinarian where a sample was taken and submitted to the State Public Health Laboratory for testing. Preliminary tests indicate the dog likely has the disease. CDHD spokesperson Christine Myron said final results are expected in a week. The dog was treated for the plague and is now recovering. Those who handled the dog while it was ill are being monitored and provided preventative medication if needed, Myron said.\n\nPlague is a bacterial disease of rodents and is generally transmitted to humans through the bites of infected fleas. It can also be transmitted by direct contact with infected animals, including rodents, wildlife and pets. 'This is a reminder that people who live and recreate in the area of impact need to take precautions to avoid contact with ground squirrels and their potentially infected fleas. Do not let your dog touch ground squirrels in the affected area. People can be exposed to plague when pets bring infected fleas back into the home, by caring for a sick pet without proper precautions, or by contact with rodents carrying fleas,' said Sarah Correll, epidemiologist for Central District Health Department.\n\nTo prevent plague, the public health department recommends the following:\n\n- see your doctor about any unexplained illness with a severe fever if you have been in the affected area;\n- avoid picking up or touching dead animals; wear gloves if you must handle dead animals;\n- do not let pets sleep in bed with you. This has been shown to increase your risk of getting plague;\n- do not let your pets hunt or roam in the affected area;\n- talk to your veterinarian about using an appropriate flea control product on your pets;\n- clean up areas near the house where rodents could live, such as woodpiles, brush piles, junk and abandoned vehicles;\n- sick pets should be examined promptly by a veterinarian;\n- put hay, wood, and compost piles as far as possible from your home;\n- don't leave your pet's food and water where rodents can get to it;\n- If you enter the identified Area of Impact, take the proper precautions:\n- wear long-sleeved shirts and long pants;\n- use DEET on clothing in accordance with label instructions or wear clothing pre-treated with permethrin;\n- use DEET on exposed skin, in accordance with label instructions.\n\nSymptoms of plague in humans include sudden onset of fever, chills, headache, and weakness. In most cases, there is a painful swelling of the lymph node in the groin, armpit, or neck areas. Plague signs in cats and dogs are fever, lethargy, and loss of appetite. There may be a swelling in the lymph node under the jaw. With prompt diagnosis and appropriate antibiotic treatment, the fatality rate in people and pets can be greatly reduced.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is transmitted by fleas. There are several forms of plague in human beings: bubonic, septicemic and pneumonic.\n\nThis article leads us to believe the contact with ground squirrel, or fleas from the ground squirrel, transmitted plague to the dog.\n\nPlague, caused by _Yersinia pestis_, is enzootic among rodents in the western United States. Humans can be infected through 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals; 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals.\n\nPlague is a potential bioterrorism agent. Human infections are rare but can be life-threatening. The case fatality rate of plague depends on the clinical presentation (that is, bubonic, septicemic, or pneumonic) and timing of initiation of antibiotic therapy; if untreated, the case fatality rate is over 50 per cent for bubonic plague and approaches 100 per cent for pneumonic plague. Rapid laboratory identification can help guide therapy.\n\nDomestic cats and dogs can also contract plague from infective fleas. They may carry infected fleas home to their owners. Cats may serve as a direct source of infection. There are many flea treatments and repellents appropriate for pets available. Some products may be suitable for dogs but not cats, or may be suitable for an adult but not a younger animal. Be sure to consult your veterinarian, as some products may be toxic to cats, kittens, and puppies, even resulting in fatalities.\n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under the jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front leg (the armpit, if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever. Please take your pet to a veterinarian if you notice any abnormalities.\n\nVeterinarians should protect themselves by wearing gloves when examining these swellings. A bubo that ruptures may infect the veterinarian or even the pet owner if the pet owner is the one palpating the swelling.\n\nAnother form of the disease is the respiratory form. Cats may acquire this form and can spread it to their owners or the veterinarians through infected expiratory droplets. People are also prone to the respiratory infection.\n\nYou should also be aware that the fleas that hitchhike into your home via a pet vehicle can also transmit disease to you, the owner, or caretaker of the pet. Sleeping in the same bed with dogs has been associated with plague in enzootic areas. Plague patients with no history of exposure to rodents can be infected by _Y. pestis_ if their pets carry infected rodent fleas into the home. MMWR, 25 Feb 2011; 60(07);214 http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6007a4.htm. - Mod.TG\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/215.]", "summary": "This has been shown to increase your risk of getting plague;\n- do not let your pets hunt or roam in the affected area;\n- talk to your veterinarian about using an appropriate flea control product on your pets;\n- clean up areas near the house where rodents could live, such as woodpiles, brush piles, junk and abandoned vehicles;\n- sick pets should be examined promptly by a veterinarian;\n- put hay, wood, and compost piles as far as possible from your home;\n- don't leave your pet's food and water where rodents can get to it;\n- \n\nTo prevent plague, the public health department recommends the following:\n\n- see your doctor about any unexplained illness with a severe fever if you have been in the affected area;\n- avoid picking up or touching dead animals; wear gloves if you must handle dead animals;\n- do not let pets sleep in bed with you. If you enter the identified Area of Impact, take the proper precautions:\n- wear long-sleeved shirts and long pants;\n- use DEET on clothing in accordance with label instructions or wear clothing pre-treated with permethrin;\n- use DEET on exposed skin, in accordance with label instructions. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n People can be exposed to plague when pets bring infected fleas back into the home, by caring for a sick pet without proper precautions, or by contact with rodents carrying fleas,' said Sarah Correll, epidemiologist for Central District Health Department. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< The case fatality rate of plague depends on the clinical presentation (that is, bubonic, septicemic, or pneumonic) and timing of initiation of antibiotic therapy; if untreated, the case fatality rate is over 50 per cent for bubonic plague and approaches 100 per cent for pneumonic plague. An Ada County dog likely contracted the plague after it came into contact with ground squirrels south of Boise last month", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2011-02-25 00:00:00", "2015-05-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ada County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Boise", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3354008", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, animal - USA (03): (AZ) feline, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3354008", "date": "2015-05-11 18:57:44", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (03): (ARIZONA) FELINE, ALERT\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 8 May 2015\nSource: The Daily Courier [edited]\nhttp://dcourier.com/main.asp?SectionID=1&SubSectionID=1&ArticleID=145035\n\n\nYavapai County [Arizona] Community Health Service issued a warning to residents and visitors of the Mingus Mountain area to take extra precautions after the discovery of plague in a sick cat from Jerome.\n\n'Educating the public about the symptoms of plague and avoiding dead animals is what we need to do right now,' Public Health Protection Manager Cecil Newell said. 'Plague is one of those diseases that naturally circulate in wildlife from time to time.'\n\nPlague can bring on severe and sometimes fatal breathing problems if left untreated. The bacteria live in the bloodstream and saliva of infected animals and can spread to other animals or humans through flea bites or when people are bitten or scratched by the infected animal.\n\n'While it is possible, it would be extremely rare for someone to get plague by inhaling the drops of saliva sprayed into the air when an animal coughed,' health service epidemiologist Stephen Everett said.\n\nRespiratory plague cases will have flu-like symptoms plus a cough and may develop rapidly advancing pneumonia. Bubonic plague symptoms, which develop from 1 to 6 days after exposure, include a sudden onset of flu-like symptoms such as chills, breathing problems, fever, headache and extreme exhaustion or painful, swollen glands in the groin, neck or armpit areas.\n\nYavapai County Community Health Service took 2 additional cats from the Jerome area for testing.\n\nSince 2000 there have been 2 cases of plague diagnosed in Arizona residents. The most recent Yavapai County resident case was in 1991.\n\n'If residents see an unexplainable large die-off in local wildlife, we would like to hear about it,' Newell said. Call 928-771-3122 if you notice large numbers of dead squirrels, chipmunks, rodents or other wildlife.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague, caused by _Yersinia pestis_, is enzootic among rodents in the western USA. Humans can be infected through 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals; 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals.\n\nPlague is a potential bioterrorism agent. Human infections are rare but can be life-threatening. The plague case-fatality rate depends on the clinical presentation (that is, bubonic, septicemic, or pneumonic) and timing of initiation of antibiotic therapy; if untreated, the case-fatality rate is over 50 per cent for bubonic plague and approaches 100 per cent for pneumonic plague. Rapid laboratory identification can help guide therapy.\n\nDomestic cats and dogs can also contract plague from infective fleas. They may carry infected fleas home to their owners or, especially cats, serve as a direct source of infection. There are many flea treatments and repellents appropriate for pets and available. Some products may be suitable for dogs but not cats, or may be suitable for an adult but not a younger animal. Be sure to consult your veterinarian, as some products may be toxic to cats, kittens, and puppies, even resulting in fatalities.\n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under the jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front leg (the armpit if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever. Please take your pet to a veterinarian if you notice any abnormalities in your pet.\n\nVeterinarians should protect themselves by wearing gloves when examining these swellings. A bubo that ruptures may infect the veterinarian or even the pet owner if the pet owner is the one palpating the swelling.\n\nAnother form of the disease is the respiratory form. Cats may acquire this form and can spread it to their owners or the veterinarians through infected expiratory droplets. People are also prone to the respiratory infection.\n\nYou should also be aware that the fleas that hitchhike into your home via a pet vehicle can also transmit disease to you, the owner, or caretaker of the pet. Sleeping in the same bed with dogs has been associated with plague in enzootic areas. Plague patients with no history of exposure to rodents can be infected by _Y. pestis_ if their pets carry infected rodent fleas into the home. Veterinarians always should recommend flea control to dog and cat owners.\n\nParts of this comment have been excerpted from: Notes from the Field: Two Cases of Human Plague -- Oregon, 2010, CDC. MMWR, 25 Feb 2011; 60(07);: 214 http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6007a4.htm. - Mod.TG\n\nThe state Arizona of can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/17068. County can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/arizona-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The plague case-fatality rate depends on the clinical presentation (that is, bubonic, septicemic, or pneumonic) and timing of initiation of antibiotic therapy; if untreated, the case-fatality rate is over 50 per cent for bubonic plague and approaches 100 per cent for pneumonic plague. Humans can be infected through 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals; 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals. Bubonic plague symptoms, which develop from 1 to 6 days after exposure, include a sudden onset of flu-like symptoms such as chills, breathing problems, fever, headache and extreme exhaustion or painful, swollen glands in the groin, neck or armpit areas. Plague patients with no history of exposure to rodents can be infected by _Y. pestis_ if their pets carry infected rodent fleas into the home. \n\nRespiratory plague cases will have flu-like symptoms plus a cough and may develop rapidly advancing pneumonia. \n\n'While it is possible, it would be extremely rare for someone to get plague by inhaling the drops of saliva sprayed into the air when an animal coughed,' health service epidemiologist Stephen Everett said. \n\n'Educating the public about the symptoms of plague and avoiding dead animals is what we need to do right now,' Public Health Protection Manager Cecil Newell said.
