Some products may be suitable for dogs but not cats, or may be suitable for an adult but not a younger animal.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2000-03-25 00:00:00", "1991-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-02-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yavapai County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3400360", "headline": "PRO/AH> Plague, animal - USA (06): (NE) prairie dog, spread", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3400360", "date": "2015-06-01 12:20:58", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (06): (NEBRASKA) PRAIRIE DOG, SPREAD\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 29 May 2015\nSource: Chadrad.com [edited]\nhttp://www.chadrad.com/newsstory.cfm?story=37554\n\n\nThe US Forest Service says that sylvatic plague has been confirmed in black tailed prairie dog colonies on the Oglala National Grassland [NG] north west of Crawford [Nebraska].\n\nActing Pine Ridge district ranger Geri Mason says die-offs of prairie dogs led to the collection of fleas from several prairie dog colonies on the Oglala NG in October and November [2014]. They were tested by the University of South Dakota and results recently came back positive for the bacterium that causes plague.\n\nThe same bacterium that causes bubonic and pneumonic plague in humans causes sylvatic plague in wildlife. Only about 10 to 20 human cases of plague are reported in the United States each year, generally contracted in prairie settings.\n\nMason says it was 1st detected in the Nebraska National Forests and Grasslands in 2004 on both the Buffalo Gap and Fort Pierre National Grasslands in South Dakota, and has since spread to the adjacent Badlands National Park and to the Lower Brule Indian Reservation. The initial outbreak posed a serious threat to the black-footed ferret, which was successfully reintroduced over 20 years ago in the Conata Basin area of the Buffalo Gap NG and has since been introduced in other locations around the region.\n\nThe Forest Service and other agencies began an aggressive campaign of dusting the entrances of prairie dog colonies with a contact insecticide to kill fleas and keep the plague from spreading, but Mason says there are no plans at this time to extend that into the Oglala NG. As for the threat of plague spreading to humans, Mason says prevention is the best remedy. She says to avoid any contact with wild rodents such as prairie dogs, dead or alive, that may have infected fleas, never feed wildlife. She also recommends keeping pets away from prairie dog colonies or dead rodents and to be sure outdoor pets are wearing flea collars to prevent them from bringing in infected fleas.\n\nMore information about the plague can be found at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's website at http://www.cdc.gov.\n\n[byline: Chris Fankhauser]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague was not previously documented in Nebraska, although it was nearby in Wyoming.\n\nPlague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations.\n\nFor a picture of a black tailed prairie dog, go to http://fc07.deviantart.net/fs71/i/2011/220/a/6/black_tailed_prairie_dog_by_dingo84dogs-d45wnep.jpg.\n\nA map of the affected area can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/229. - Mod.PMB]", "summary": "\n\n[byline: Chris Fankhauser]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague was not previously documented in Nebraska, although it was nearby in Wyoming. Plague is generally transmitted to humans through the bites of infected fleas.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague, caused by _Yersinia pestis_, is enzootic among rodents in the western USA. Humans can be infected through 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals; 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals.\n\nPlague is a potential bioterrorism agent. Human infections are rare but can be life-threatening. The plague case-fatality rate depends on the clinical presentation (that is, bubonic, septicemic, or pneumonic) and timing of initiation of antibiotic therapy; if untreated, the case-fatality rate is over 50 per cent for bubonic plague and approaches 100 per cent for pneumonic plague. Rapid laboratory identification can help guide therapy.\n\nDomestic cats and dogs can also contract plague from infective fleas. They may carry infected fleas home to their owners. Cats may serve as a direct source of infection. There are many flea treatments and repellents appropriate for pets available. Some products may be suitable for dogs but not cats, or may be suitable for an adult but not a younger animal. Be sure to consult your veterinarian, as some products may be toxic to cats, kittens, and puppies, even resulting in fatalities.\n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under the jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front leg (the armpit if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever. Please take your pet to a veterinarian if you notice any abnormalities.\n\nVeterinarians should protect themselves by wearing gloves when examining these swellings. PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (04): (NEW MEXICO), FELINE, CANINE\n*******************************************************\n \n\nParts of this comment have been excerpted from: Notes from the Field: Two Cases of Human Plague -- Oregon, 2010, CDC. \n\n--\n A bubo that ruptures may infect the veterinarian or even the pet owner if the pet owner is the one palpating the swelling.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-01-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2011-02-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santa Fe County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bernalillo County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3280037", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, animal - USA (02): (AZ) prairie dogs, fleas", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3280037", "date": "2015-04-06 19:41:22", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (02): (ARIZONA) PRAIRIE DOGS, FLEAS\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon, 6 Apr 2015\nSource: DailyMail.co.uk [edited]\nhttp://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3027403/Fleas-Arizona-test-positive-PLAGUE-disease-begins-decimating-prairie-dog-population.html\n\n\nFleas in Arizona have tested positive for the plague and could spread the deadly disease to humans, according to officials.\n\nThe plague, which famously killed millions of Europeans during the Black Death, is most commonly carried by fleas and rodents. Prairie dog deaths at Picture Canyon in Arizona alerted officials to the possibility of an outbreak.\n\nFleas from the preserve near a water treatment plant in Flagstaff were found to carry the illness.\n\nHuman cases have developed from close contact with cats who have preyed on infected vermin, and residents in the Southwest have been warned about dangers of the disease while camping.\n\nThe Southwestern US is similar to the plains of Central Asia where plague began, Professor David Wagner of Northern Arizona University told the Arizona Daily Sun.\n\nPlague is still contracted by as many as 2000 people a year, according to the World Health Organization, though the vast majority of cases are in sub-Saharan Africa and Madagascar.\n\nPrairie dogs are particularly susceptible to illness because they live in social burrows, and 90 percent of the furry creatures' colony can eventually be wiped out if plague infects one member. The disease's rodent host dies, when fleas will look for more blood to feed on, including from people.\n\nInsecticide has been sprayed in prairie dog burrows in Picture Canyon to halt the plague's spread.\n\nClinical signs in humans include fever, chills and muscle pain. At later stages the disease causes gangrene and a large amount of pustules, or buboes, on the skin. The incubation period could be up to 7 days.\n\nModern medications are effective in fighting bacterium that causes plague, _Yersinia pestis_, though it can be deadly if left untreated.\n\nThe last plague epidemic in the United States was in Los Angeles between 1924 and 1925, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nPlague originally came to North America via rodents on steamships from Asia.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is mainly spread by the bites of infected fleas. Though the bacterium is not native to North America, when it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations. Some species are particularly susceptible. For example, _Y. pestis_ caused the extinction of entire colonies of black-tailed prairie dogs. Small rodents such as deer mice and grasshopper mice have been suggested as reservoirs. Larger species like squirrels and chipmunks are considered to be more vulnerable to infection. Dogs and cats may bring infected fleas to their homes, so flea control is advised for pets and the house environment.\n\nFor more information on plague go to http://www.cdc.gov/plague/.\n\nFor a picture of a prairie dog go to http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/0d/Prairie_Dog_Washington_DC_1.jpg.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/207. - Mod.PMB]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. \n\nPrairie dogs are particularly susceptible to illness because they live in social burrows, and 90 percent of the furry creatures' colony can eventually be wiped out if plague infects one member. PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (02): (ARIZONA) PRAIRIE DOGS, FLEAS\n**********************************************************\n \n\nInsecticide has been sprayed in prairie dog burrows in Picture Canyon to halt the plague's spread. \n\nHuman cases have developed from close contact with cats who have preyed on infected vermin, and residents in the Southwest have been warned about dangers of the disease while camping. \n\nThe last plague epidemic in the United States was in Los Angeles between 1924 and 1925, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Zambia: (ES) bubonic, susp", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3305202", "date": "2015-04-17 21:29:40", "main_text": "PLAGUE - ZAMBIA: (EASTERN PROVINCE) BUBONIC, SUSPECTED\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 16 Apr 2015\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/plague-outbreak-kills-three-in-zambia-24623/\n\n\nA outbreak, likely of bubonic plague, in Nyimba District in Eastern Province, Zambia, has resulted in at least 3 deaths, according to a Times of Zambia report.\n\nEastern Province Permanent Secretary Chanda Kasolo disclosed during the Provincial Epidemics Preparedness Prevention Control and Management meeting in Chipata yesterday [15 Apr 2015] that the outbreak of the suspected plague had so far affected 13 people from Kavyeni Village.\n\nMr Kasolo said in a speech read on his behalf by assistant secretary Beenzu Chikuba that health workers from Nyimba District health office and some from the provincial health office had already been dispatched to address the situation.\n\nBlood samples have also been collected from patients and sent to Lusaka awaiting confirmation of the disease.\n\nPlague is an infectious disease caused by the bacterium, _Yersinia pestis_. It is found in animals throughout the world, most commonly rats, but other rodents like ground squirrels, prairie dogs, chipmunks, rabbits, and voles. Fleas typically serve as the vector of plague.\n\nHuman cases have been linked to the domestic cats and dogs that brought infected fleas into the house. People can also get infected through direct contact with an infected animal, through inhalation and in the case of pneumonic plague, person to person.\n\n_Yersinia pestis_ [plague] is treatable with antimicrobials if started early enough.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDr Tony Ellam\nConsultant in Communicable Disease Control (ret)\n<tonypj@meadlane.freeserve.co.uk>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Ellam for submitting this post.\n\nEndemic in a number of African countries including Madagascar, Congo DR, Uganda, and Zambia, _Yersinia pestis_ is a category A potential bioterrorism agent. Human infections are rare but can be life-threatening. The plague case-fatality rate depends on the clinical presentation (that is, bubonic, septicemic, or pneumonic) and timing of antibiotic therapy initiation; if untreated, the case fatality rate is over 50 percent for bubonic plague and approaches 100 percent for pneumonic plague. Rapid laboratory identification can help guide therapy. - Mod.LL\n\n[Readers please note there are no prairie dogs or chipmunks in Zambia -- those are North American species. - Mod.JW]\n\nMaps of Zambia can be seen at http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/zambia.pdf and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/45380. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The plague case-fatality rate depends on the clinical presentation (that is, bubonic, septicemic, or pneumonic) and timing of antibiotic therapy initiation; if untreated, the case fatality rate is over 50 percent for bubonic plague and approaches 100 percent for pneumonic plague. Communicated by:\nDr Tony Ellam\nConsultant in Communicable Disease Control (ret)\n<tonypj@meadlane.freeserve.co.uk>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Ellam for submitting this post. PLAGUE - ZAMBIA: (EASTERN PROVINCE) BUBONIC, SUSPECTED\n******************************************************\n \n\nEastern Province Permanent Secretary Chanda Kasolo disclosed during the Provincial Epidemics Preparedness Prevention Control and Management meeting in Chipata yesterday [15 Apr 2015] that the outbreak of the suspected plague had so far affected 13 people from Kavyeni Village. People can also get infected through direct contact with an infected animal, through inhalation and in the case of pneumonic plague, person to person. [Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\n \n\nHuman cases have been linked to the domestic cats and dogs that brought infected fleas into the house. Mr Kasolo said in a speech read on his behalf by assistant secretary Beenzu Chikuba that health workers from Nyimba District health office and some from the provincial health office had already been dispatched to address the situation. LL\n\n[Readers please note there are no prairie dogs or chipmunks in Zambia -- those are North American species.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "Kavyeni Village", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nyimba District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Congo DR", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chipata", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Zambia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3097674", "date": "2015-01-16 18:41:26", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA: (NEW MEXICO) MULTIPLE ANIMALS\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 15 Jan 2015\nSource: Albuquerque Journal [edited]\nhttp://www.abqjournal.com/526832/abqnewsseeker/five-recent-animal-plague-cases-reported-in-south-santa-fe.html\n\n\nA total of 5 plague cases have been found in animals in south Santa Fe since November [2014], according to the [New Mexico] state Department of Health.\n\n3 cats, 1 dog and 1 mouse were confirmed with the bacterial disease, all associated with residences along the Interstate 25 corridor between Cerrillos Road and Old Las Vegas Highway.\n\nThe disease is carried by fleas often found on rodents, but the fleas can transmit plague when they hop to a person or pet and bite it looking for a blood meal.\n\nYou also can catch plague through direct contact with diseased animals.\n\n'We are seeing die-offs of rabbits, squirrels, pack rats and various rodents in several areas of New Mexico from both plague and tularemia,' said Dr. Paul Ettestad, public health veterinarian, in a news release.\n\nPeople are advised to prevent their pets from roaming, consider appropriate flea control, clean up areas such as wood and brush piles that attract rodents, have any sick pets promptly examined by a veterinarian, and see their own doctor about any suspicious illness.\n\nSymptoms of plague in humans include sudden and severe fever, chills, headache and weakness, as well as painful lymph node swelling in the groin, armpit or neck.\n\nIn animals, plague can be signaled through fever, lethargy and loss of appetite, along with swelling under the jaw.\n\nIn 2014, 17 cases of plague were reported in dogs and cats in New Mexico and 2 cases were reported in humans, both of whom recovered. The previous year saw 4 human plague cases in New Mexico, with 1 person dying.\n\n[Byline: Jackie Jadrnak]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The location of Santa Fe, New Mexico, can be seen on the map at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1612.\n\nPlague, caused by _Yersinia pestis_, is enzootic among rodents in the western USA. Humans can be infected through 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals; 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals.\n\nPlague is a potential bioterrorism agent. Human infections are rare but can be life-threatening. The case fatality rate of plague depends on the clinical presentation (that is, bubonic, septicemic, or pneumonic) and timing of initiation of antibiotic therapy; if untreated, the case fatality rate is over 50 per cent for bubonic plague and approaches 100 per cent for pneumonic plague (1). Rapid laboratory identification can help guide therapy.\n\nDomestic cats and dogs can also contract plague from infective fleas. They may carry infected fleas home to their owners or, especially with cats, serve as a direct source of infection. There are many flea treatments and repellents appropriate for pets available. Some products may be suitable for dogs but not cats or may be suitable for an adult but not a younger animal. Be sure to consult your veterinarian, as some products may be toxic to cats, kittens, and puppies, even resulting in fatalities.\n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under the jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front leg (the armpit, if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever. Please take your pet to a veterinarian if you notice any abnormalities.\n\nVeterinarians should protect themselves by wearing gloves when examining these swellings. A bubo that ruptures may infect the veterinarian or even the pet owner if the pet owner is the one palpating the swelling.\n\nAnother form of the disease is the respiratory form. Cats may acquire this form and can spread it to their owners or the veterinarians through infected expiratory droplets. People are also prone to the respiratory infection.\n\nYou should also be aware that the fleas that hitchhike into your home on a pet can also transmit disease to you, the owner or caretaker of the pet. Sleeping in the same bed with dogs has been associated with plague in enzootic areas (2). Plague patients with no history of exposure to rodents can be infected by _Y. pestis_ if their pets carry infected rodent fleas into the home. Veterinarians always should recommend flea control to dog and cat owners.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. CDC. Human plague -- four states, 2006. MMWR 2006; 55(34): 940-3; available at http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5534a4.htm.\n2. Gould LH, Pape J, Ettestad P, et al. Dog-associated risk factors for human plague. Zoonoses Public Health 2008; 55(8-10): 448-54; abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18489541.\n\nParts of the above comment have been extracted from: CDC. Notes from the field: two cases of human plague -- Oregon, 2010. MMWR 2011; 60(7): 214 http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6007a4.htm. - Mod.TG]", "summary": "The case fatality rate of plague depends on the clinical presentation (that is, bubonic, septicemic, or pneumonic) and timing of initiation of antibiotic therapy; if untreated, the case fatality rate is over 50 per cent for bubonic plague and approaches 100 per cent for pneumonic plague (1). A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nThe disease is carried by fleas often found on rodents, but the fleas can transmit plague when they hop to a person or pet and bite it looking for a blood meal. Humans can be infected through 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals; 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals. \n\nPeople are advised to prevent their pets from roaming, consider appropriate flea control, clean up areas such as wood and brush piles that attract rodents, have any sick pets promptly examined by a veterinarian, and see their own doctor about any suspicious illness. \n\n'We are seeing die-offs of rabbits, squirrels, pack rats and various rodents in several areas of New Mexico from both plague and tularemia,' said Dr. Paul Ettestad, public health veterinarian, in a news release. \n\nSymptoms of plague in humans include sudden and severe fever, chills, headache and weakness, as well as painful lymph node swelling in the groin, armpit or neck. Plague patients with no history of exposure to rodents can be infected by _Y. pestis_ if their pets carry infected rodent fleas into the home. \n\n3 cats, 1 dog and 1 mouse were confirmed with the bacterial disease, all associated with residences along the Interstate 25 corridor between Cerrillos Road and Old Las Vegas Highway. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The location of Santa Fe, New Mexico, can be seen on the map at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1612. \n\nDomestic cats and dogs can also contract plague from infective fleas. \n\nYou should also be aware that the fleas that hitchhike into your home on a pet can also transmit disease to you, the owner or caretaker of the pet. \n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under the jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front leg (the armpit, if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever. In 2014, 17 cases of plague were reported in dogs and cats in New Mexico and 2 cases were reported in humans, both of whom recovered. PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA: (NEW MEXICO) MULTIPLE ANIMALS\n***************************************************\n \n\nYou also can catch plague through direct contact with diseased animals. The previous year saw 4 human plague cases in New Mexico, with 1 person dying.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2015-01-15 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-11-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3335475", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA: (CO) pneumonic, canine source, poss. human-to-human spread, 2014", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3335475", "date": "2015-05-01 21:31:29", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA: (COLORADO) PNEUMONIC, CANINE SOURCE, POSSIBLE HUMAN-TO-HUMAN SPREAD, 2014\n***************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 30 Apr 2015\nSource: CDC. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 2015; 64(16): 429-34 [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6416a1.htm?s_cid=mm6416a1_w\n\n\nOutbreak of human pneumonic plague with dog-to-human and possible human-to-human transmission -- Colorado, June-July 2014\n-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n[Authors: Runfola JK, House J, Miller K, et al]\n\nOn 8 Jul 2014, the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment (CDPHE) laboratory identified _Yersinia pestis_, the bacterium that causes plague, in a blood specimen collected from a man (patient A) hospitalized with pneumonia. The organism had been previously misidentified as _Pseudomonas luteola_ by an automated system in the hospital laboratory. An investigation led by Tri-County Health Department (TCHD) revealed that patient A's dog had died recently with hemoptysis. 3 other persons who had contact with the dog, 1 of whom also had contact with patient A, were ill with fever and respiratory symptoms, including 2 with radiographic evidence of pneumonia. Specimens from the dog and all 3 human contacts yielded evidence of acute _Y. pestis_ infection. 1 of the pneumonia cases might have resulted through human-to-human transmission from patient A, which would be the first such event reported in the USA since 1924.\n\nThis outbreak highlights 1) the need to consider plague in the differential diagnosis of ill domestic animals, including dogs, in areas where plague is endemic; 2) the limitations of automated diagnostic systems for identifying rare bacteria such as _Y. pestis_; and 3) the potential for milder plague illness in patients taking antimicrobial agents. Hospital laboratorians should be aware of the limitations of automated identification systems, and clinicians should suspect plague in patients with clinically compatible symptoms from whom _P. luteola_ is isolated.\n\nInvestigation and results\n-------------------------\nPatient A, a previously healthy middle-aged man, developed fever and cough on 28 Jun 2014. Over the next 24 hours his condition worsened with increasing cough and the production of bloody sputum. He was admitted to a local hospital where he was diagnosed with pneumonia (Figure [for figure and tables see source URL above URL. - Mod.LL]). Blood cultures collected on [30 Jun 2014] grew a Gram negative rod that was initially identified as _P. luteola_ using an automated identification system. Over the next 6 days patient A's respiratory status deteriorated, and he was transferred to another facility where he required intubation. Because of the severity of his illness and previous reports of misidentification of _Y. pestis_ as _P. luteola_ (1,2), the isolate was sent to the CDPHE laboratory for further testing. On 8 Jul 2014, the specimen was correctly identified as _Y. pestis_, and patient A received a diagnosis of pneumonic plague. Patient A was treated with broad-spectrum antimicrobials, including levofloxacin and streptomycin, and recovered after hospitalization for 23 days.\n\nTCHD initiated an investigation, consisting of interviews with patient A's family, evaluation of potential exposures to the patient, and an environmental assessment to determine the risk for further disease transmission. The investigation revealed that patient A's dog, a male American pit bull terrier aged 2 years, became ill with fever, jaw rigidity, drooling, and right forelimb ataxia on 24 Jun 2014 (Table). The dog was kept overnight at a veterinary clinic and humanely euthanized the following day after developing dyspnea and bloody sputum. Patient A had close contact with the dog during euthanasia. Necropsy revealed gastric and pulmonary hemorrhage. Samples tested negative for evidence of rabies virus infection and anticoagulants; histopathologic examination of the tissues was declined by patient A. Following patient A's diagnosis with plague, liver and lung tissues from the dog were tested for _Y. pestis_, and results were positive by both polymerase chain reaction assay and culture. Archived formalin-fixed tissues from the dog were processed for histopathology, revealing severe acute bronchopneumonia with intra-alveolar bacteria. The investigation also identified 3 other persons who had been in close contact with the ill dog, one of whom who also had contact with patient A. All 3 subsequently received diagnoses of plague, and all 3 recovered (Table, Figure).\n\nOn 30 Jun 2014, 2 days after patient A became ill, patient B, a female veterinary clinic employee, developed a fever and cough and visited an urgent care facility, where bronchitis was diagnosed. She reported close contact with the ill dog on 24-25 Jun 2014. After her symptoms failed to improve with self-initiated amoxicillin/clavulanic acid, patient B visited an emergency department on 5 Jul 2014, received a diagnosis of pneumonia, and was treated with azithromycin, with improvement over the next several days. After notification on 10 Jul 2014 of her exposure to plague, she visited a health care provider and was treated with oral levofloxacin. A polymerase chain reaction test on a sputum specimen was positive for _Y. pestis_. Subsequent testing of paired acute and convalescent serum specimens demonstrated a 4-fold increase in antibody titers to _Y. pestis_, indicative of recent infection (Table).\n\nPatient C, a female veterinary clinic employee, also had close contact with the dog on 24-25 Jun 2014 and self-initiated a 6-day course of oral doxycycline on 25 Jun 2014. On 4 Jul 2014, she experienced fever, chills, myalgia, and fatigue; symptoms progressed to chest tightness and cough. Following notification of the exposure to plague on 9 Jul 2014, patient C self-initiated a second course of doxycycline and was medically evaluated later that day. Crackles were heard during chest auscultation; however, results of a chest radiograph were normal. A full course of oral doxycycline was continued with resolution of symptoms. Initial and follow-up serum specimens tested positive for antibody to _Y. pestis_, with a greater than fourfold decrease in antibody titers at follow-up 6 months later (Table).\n\nOn 4 Jul 2014, patient D, a woman who was a close contact of patient A, experienced chest tightness, dyspnea, and fever. She was evaluated at an emergency department, received a diagnosis of pneumonia, and was treated with oral levofloxacin. Patient D handled the body of the dog on 25 Jun 2015 after it died, at one point getting blood on her hands. She also had extended close contact with patient A on 29-30 Jun 2014 while he was coughing bloody sputum. On 8 Jul 2014, after patient A was identified with pneumonic plague, patient D was hospitalized and treated with levofloxacin and streptomycin. Paired acute and convalescent serum specimens for patient D demonstrated a greater than 4-fold increase in antibody titers to _Y. pestis_ (Table).\n\nPublic health response\n----------------------\nTCHD evaluated potential exposures from each patient and conducted an environmental assessment to determine the risk for further disease transmission. Case status was assigned according to case definitions developed by the Council of State and Territorial Epidemiologists for CDC's National Notifiable Diseases Surveillance System.\n\nMedical personnel and personal contacts of all 4 patients were notified of their possible exposure to plague. A total of 114 persons had close contact with the dog or one or more of the human patients: 36 in veterinary settings, 58 in human health care settings, and 20 as close personal contacts. Antimicrobial prophylaxis was recommended for 88 persons interviewed within 7 days of exposure. The remaining 26 were advised to monitor for fever for 7 days and to seek medical attention immediately if symptoms occurred.\n\nOn 9 Jul 2014, TCHD surveyed patient A's property for evidence of plague. Live rabbits were observed on the property but no other wildlife. Inactive prairie dog burrows were present; however, it was reported that the prairie dog colony had been intentionally eradicated in October 2013.\n\nCDPHE issued press releases for public awareness and Health Alert Network notifications to health care providers and veterinarians on 9, 10, and 18 Jul 2014. Medical facilities were instructed to use droplet precautions for persons with suspected plague. TCHD staff members distributed information on plague symptoms and transmission risk to homes in the vicinity of the index patient. No further cases have been identified.\n\nDiscussion\n----------\nPlague is a rare but life-threatening zoonosis caused by _Y. pestis_. A median of 8 cases of human plague are reported annually in the USA (3), primarily among residents of semirural areas in New Mexico, Arizona, Colorado, and California. Normally a pathogen of rodents, _Y. pestis_ is transmitted to humans through the bite of infected rodent fleas or direct contact with the tissues or secretions of infected animals.\n\nBubonic plague, characterized by fever and painful regional lymphadenopathy, results from percutaneous exposure and accounts for approximately 85 percent of reported cases. Pneumonic plague occurs as either a complication of untreated bubonic plague (10-13 percent of all cases) or as a primary pneumonia following inhalation of infectious droplets (2 percent of all cases) (4). Untreated pneumonic plague has a fatality rate of 93 percent or more and can be spread from person to person through aerosols generated during coughing. A 3rd clinical form, septicemic plague, is characterized by fever and shock without localizing signs or symptoms. Laboratory diagnosis of plague is based on culture or polymerase chain reaction assays of blood, sputum, or lymph node aspirates, or on serology. Effective therapy includes aminoglycosides and doxycycline. In addition, the fluoroquinolones levofloxacin and ciprofloxacin have been approved recently by the Food and Drug Administration based on animal studies. The advent of antimicrobial therapy has reduced overall plague mortality from more than 60 percent to approximately 16 percent (3,5,6).\n\nIn this outbreak, all 4 patients had laboratory-confirmed plague, including 3 patients (A, B, and D) with clinical and radiographic evidence of pneumonia. The 4th patient (C) had an atypical presentation with respiratory symptoms but no radiographic evidence of pneumonia, possibly as a result of partial treatment immediately after exposure. 3 patients (A, B and C) became ill shortly after exposure to an ill infected dog. The source of infection for patient D is less certain because she had exposure to both the dog on 25-26 Jun 2014 (an incubation period of 9-10 days) and to patient A on 29-30 Jun 2014 while he had hemoptysis (an incubation period of 5-6 days). The shorter incubation period is more typical of plague and therefore supports human-to-human transmission (6). Nevertheless, transmission from the dog cannot be excluded given the animal's role in the other 3 infections and because incubation periods of up to 10 days have been reported, although rarely (7). Primary pneumonic plague is rare in the USA with only 74 cases reported during 1900-2012, and this event represents the largest outbreak and the 1st instance of possible human-to-human transmission since an outbreak in Los Angeles in 1924 (3,5).\n\n_Y. pestis_ infection in dogs generally is either asymptomatic or the cause of only a mild, self-limiting febrile illness (8). Dogs can play a role in human infection through transport of rodent fleas into the home (8,9). This outbreak began with illness in a pet dog, a previously unrecognized source of plague exposure in the USA. The only previously published case of direct transmission of plague from a dog to a human was reported from China in 2009 (10). Although symptomatic plague in dogs is rare, veterinarians should consider the possibility of _Y. pestis_ infection in ill dogs with wildlife exposure in areas where plague is endemic.\n\nThis outbreak is notable for the several factors that delayed its recognition. First, patient A's bacterial isolate initially was identified as _P. luteola_ by an automated blood culture system, and the correct identification of _Y. pestis_ was only made 7 days later. This delay resulted in the exposure of numerous medical personnel. Misidentification and a resulting delayed diagnosis have been previously reported, reinforcing the need for critical evaluation of results from automated systems and education of hospital microbiologists regarding this limitation (1,2). Among 12 _Y. pestis_ isolates obtained from patients in the USA during 2010-2013, at least 3 (25 percent) were originally misidentified by automated systems (Division of Vector-borne Diseases, National Center for Emerging and Zoonotic Infectious Diseases, CDC, unpublished data, 2015). Second, the spectrum of disease was broader than usual for pneumonic plague (7), with 2 of the 4 patients not requiring hospitalization. The clinical course of the milder cases might have been modified by self-administration of antimicrobials or medical prescription of azithromycin, an antibiotic not recommended for plague. Pneumonia is the only form of plague with the potential for human-to-human transmission. Delayed recognition because of inaccurate laboratory test results and atypical clinical presentations can lead to high numbers of potential exposures to health care workers, laboratory workers, and other close contacts.\n\nAlthough human plague is rare in North America, it remains a public health concern in the western USA where _Y. pestis_ circulates among wild rodent populations. The risk for plague can be minimized by avoidance of possibly infected rodents (such as prairie dogs) and their fleas. All suspected or confirmed plague cases and rodent die-offs in areas where plague is endemic should be reported immediately to public health officials so that exposures can be minimized to prevent additional transmission. Once plague is suspected, appropriate precautions and treatment should be initiated immediately, and clinical specimens should be collected and tested as soon as possible. Early recognition of plague, especially the pneumonic form, is critical to effective clinical management and a timely public health response. Veterinarians should consider plague in the differential diagnosis of ill domestic animals, including dogs, in areas where plague is endemic.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Tourdjman M, Ibraheem M, Brett M, et al: Misidentification of Yersinia pestis by automated systems, resulting in delayed diagnoses of human plague infections -- Oregon and New Mexico, 2010-2011. Clin Infect Dis 2012; 55(7): e58-60; [available at http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/55/7/e58.long].\n2. CDC: Notes from the field: two cases of human plague -- Oregon, 2010. Emerg Infect Dis 2015; 21(1): 16-22; available at [http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/21/1/14-0564_intro].\n4. CDC: Plague. Atlanta, GA: US Department of Health and Human Services, CDC; 2015. Available at http://www.cdc.gov/plague/.\n5. Hinckley AF, Biggerstaff BJ, Griffith KS, Mead PS: Transmission dynamics of primary pneumonic plague in the USA. Epidemiol Infect 2012; 140(3): 554-60; [abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21733272].\n6. Kool JL: Risk of person-to-person transmission of pneumonic plague. Clin Infect Dis 2011; 52(2): 185-90; [available at http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/52/2/185.long].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The state of Colorado can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4477. Adams County in northern Colorado can be seen on the map at http://geology.com/county-map/colorado-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ\n\nThis detailed description of the mid-2014 outbreak of pneumonic plague in Adams County, Colorado, just north and east of the Denver metropolitan area, was covered by ProMED when it was occurring. It is particularly important for several points:\n- the number of cases that occurred\n- the source being a canine\n- the initial misidentification of the isolate using an automated diagnostic system, and\n- the possibility of the 1st human-to-human transmission of pneumonic plague in the USA since 1924.\n\nTo understand the pneumonic plague outbreak in Los Angeles in 1924, the reader is referred to a detailed description (Viseltear AJ: The pneumonic plague epidemic of 1924 in Los Angeles. Yale J Biol Med 1974; 1: 40-54; available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2595158/pdf/yjbm00152-0044.pdf). The outbreak affected 28 Hispanics and 2 Caucasians during a 2 week period in the fall of 1924, during clearly the pre-antimicrobial era although plague anti-serum was used in the outbreak. The source of the outbreak, although initially blamed on flea-infected rats from the Los Angeles harbor, was thought to be 2 cases of bubonic plague, one of which was associated with secondary plague pneumonia, that occurred earlier in the month of October 1924 was probably of endemic origin like the Oakland, California cluster in 1919.\n\nIt is interesting that Viseeltear reports that 'City health officers who released the story already had a confirmed diagnosis of pneumonic plague but chose for obvious reasons to refer to the disease, from 1 to 5 Nov 1924, as the 'strange malady,' 'pneumonia,' 'virulent pneumonia,' or 'malignant pneumonia.' Not until 6 Nov 1924, when the epidemic appeared to have run its course, did Los Angeles newspapers refer to the disease properly as pneumonic plague and even then justified this evasion by adding that pneumonic plague was the 'technical term' for 'malignant pneumonia.'\n\n'The New York Times and the Washington Post, however, were quick to headline that pneumonic plague had erupted in Los Angeles. Indeed, the news blackout was confined to Los Angeles as most major California newspapers reported the epidemic correctly.' - Mod.LL]", "summary": "\n\nThis outbreak highlights 1) the need to consider plague in the differential diagnosis of ill domestic animals, including dogs, in areas where plague is endemic; 2) the limitations of automated diagnostic systems for identifying rare bacteria such as _Y. pestis_; and 3) the potential for milder plague illness in patients taking antimicrobial agents. It is particularly important for several points:\n- the number of cases that occurred\n- the source being a canine\n- the initial misidentification of the isolate using an automated diagnostic system, and\n- the possibility of the 1st human-to-human transmission of pneumonic plague in the USA since 1924. http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6416a1.htm?s_cid=mm6416a1_w\n\n\nOutbreak of human pneumonic plague with dog-to-human and possible human-to-human transmission -- Colorado, June-July 2014\n Pneumonic plague occurs as either a complication of untreated bubonic plague (10-13 percent of all cases) or as a primary pneumonia following inhalation of infectious droplets (2 percent of all cases) (4). [Authors: Runfola JK, House J, Miller K, et al]\n\nOn 8 Jul 2014, the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment (CDPHE) laboratory identified _Yersinia pestis_, the bacterium that causes plague, in a blood specimen collected from a man (patient A) hospitalized with pneumonia. The source of infection for patient D is less certain because she had exposure to both the dog on 25-26 Jun 2014 (an incubation period of 9-10 days) and to patient A on 29-30 Jun 2014 while he had hemoptysis (an incubation period of 5-6 days). Primary pneumonic plague is rare in the USA with only 74 cases reported during 1900-2012, and this event represents the largest outbreak and the 1st instance of possible human-to-human transmission since an outbreak in Los Angeles in 1924 (3,5). The source of the outbreak, although initially blamed on flea-infected rats from the Los Angeles harbor, was thought to be 2 cases of bubonic plague, one of which was associated with secondary plague pneumonia, that occurred earlier in the month of October 1924 was probably of endemic origin like the Oakland, California cluster in 1919. The investigation also identified 3 other persons who had been in close contact with the ill dog, one of whom who also had contact with patient A. All 3 subsequently received diagnoses of plague, and all 3 recovered (Table, Figure). Not until 6 Nov 1924, when the epidemic appeared to have run its course, did Los Angeles newspapers refer to the disease properly as pneumonic plague and even then justified this evasion by adding that pneumonic plague was the 'technical term' for 'malignant pneumonia.' Although symptomatic plague in dogs is rare, veterinarians should consider the possibility of _Y. pestis_ infection in ill dogs with wildlife exposure in areas where plague is endemic. \n\nIt is interesting that Viseeltear reports that 'City health officers who released the story already had a confirmed diagnosis of pneumonic plague but chose for obvious reasons to refer to the disease, from 1 to 5 Nov 1924, as the 'strange malady,' 'pneumonia,' 'virulent pneumonia,' or 'malignant pneumonia.' All suspected or confirmed plague cases and rodent die-offs in areas where plague is endemic should be reported immediately to public health officials so that exposures can be minimized to prevent additional transmission. \n\nPatient C, a female veterinary clinic employee, also had close contact with the dog on 24-25 Jun 2014 and self-initiated a 6-day course of oral doxycycline on 25 Jun 2014. PLAGUE - USA: (COLORADO) PNEUMONIC, CANINE SOURCE, POSSIBLE HUMAN-TO-HUMAN SPREAD, 2014\n On 8 Jul 2014, after patient A was identified with pneumonic plague, patient D was hospitalized and treated with levofloxacin and streptomycin. Madagascar", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3076901", "date": "2015-01-08 10:39:14", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR\n*******************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 7 Jan 2015\nSource: L'Express Madagascar [edited]\nhttp://www.lexpressmada.com/blog/actualites/sante-treize-cas-suspects-de-peste-dans-la-capitale-24794\n\n\nThe capital, Antananarivo, is no longer immune to the epidemic of the plague; 10 suspected cases were identified according to arrivals information at Compte-Gouttes.\n\nThe progress of the plague epidemic becomes increasingly worrying. The districts around the capital do not seem to be the only ones infected. According to information gathered from the Ministry of Health yesterday [6 Jan 2015], 13 suspected cases were registered in the urban commune of Antananarivo, from 4 Aug 2014 to 29 Dec 2014. The disease has infected several neighborhoods, including Anosibe, Anosimahavelona, Anosizato, Manjakaray, Antanimora and Ankasina.\n\nFaced with this situation, a source from the Public Health Service District reacted, stating that: 'The situation is now under control; all these people were registered as suspects, as they presented the symptoms of this disease, namely high fever and buboes. Only 3 cases have been confirmed after laboratory analysis,' the source said.\n\nNdranto Rakotonanahary, director of population and health at the town hall of Antananarivo, has not confirmed these 13 suspected cases. 'There is only one case, in the district of Ankasina, which was treated by the municipal health service. We are not aware of other cases,' he said.\n\nSince the 'beginning' of the plague season, between 4 Aug 2014 and 29 Dec 2014, 224 cases of plague were reported in the Big Island. 58 of the cases have died. The meeting between the WHO and the Ministry of Public Health, on 10 Dec 2014 in Anosy, reported 47 deaths. The number of people identified as infected with the disease was 189 at that time.\n\n[Byline: Vonjy Radasimalala and Michella Raharisoa]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is caused by the _Yersinia pestis_ bacillus, carried by rat fleas. At the start of the rainy season, currently, rats flee the sewers of Madagascar in massive numbers and take refuge in people's cottages. Care must be taken in any rodent eradication program to ensure that a flea-killing compound is part of the plan. Just as in a natural rodent die-off from _Y. pestis_, the fleas will seek alternate hosts, that is, humans.\n\nThe following paragraph is from 1998 (Chanteau S, Ratsifasoamanana L, Rasoamanana B, et al: Plague, a Reemerging Disease in Madagascar. Emerg Infect Dis 1998; 4(1): 101-4; http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/4/1/98-0114_article.htm).\n\n'Between 1930 and 1990, bubonic plague had 'virtually disappeared' on the island due to efficient pest-control and good health management. However since 1990, an annual 200 cases are being reported, and bubonic plague takes on epidemic form, especially in the port of Mahajanga, each year. In the capital city of Antananarivo, more cases are also being notified each year since 1990. Madagascar (pop. 13 million) has accounted for 45 percent of all the cases of plague in Africa.'\n\nFatalities related to plague usually are caused by spread of the organism from the bubo (the very painful infected lymph node which drains the area where the flea bite occurred) to the bloodstream. The bacteremia can cause a coagulopathy, producing the purpura seen in the 'Black Plague' and also spread to the lungs causing a hemorrhagic pneumonia. It is the pneumonia that can facilitate person-to-person transmission.\n\nMadagascar was the location of the isolation of multi-antimicrobial resistant _Y. pestis_ in 1995 (Galimand M, Guiyoule A, Gerbaud G, et al: Multidrug resistance in _Yersinia pestis_ mediated by a transferable plasmid. N Engl J Med 1997; 337(10): 677-81; http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJM199709043371004). The strain was resistant to chloramphenicol, streptomycin, and tetracycline but sensitive to fluoroquinolones and trimethoprim as well as other aminoglycosides. This was an ominous observation; however, it is not clear whether this naturally occurring strain has persisted or spread. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/181.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is caused by the _Yersinia pestis_ bacillus, carried by rat fleas. Madagascar's Health Ministry made the announcement on Mon 24 Nov 2014, and warned that the toll would probably rise over the coming months as it spreads towards the capital Antananarivo. They added that 138 suspect cases have been recorded since the beginning of 2014. The ministry went on to say that it is attempting to contain the outbreak by disinfection of residents' homes. The WHO has confirmed the dispatch of health workers to sanitize slums in the capital.\n\nAccording to Philemon Tafangy, the health ministry's secretary general, '200 households have been disinfected' this month [November 2014]. He added that in an attempt to arrest the spread of the disease, antimicrobials have been given to all those who had come in contact with the infected.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This report increases the total number of cases by 19 and the death toll by 7 since the ProMED posting on 22 Nov 2014. Rappt.DS, edited]\nhttp://news.xmnn.cn/a/gnxw/201410/t20141017_4142844.htm\n\n\nGansu Health and Family Planning Commission officially reported on 17 Oct 2014 that the Gansu Subei Mongolian Autonomous County People's Hospital confirmed a case of plague. The patient was from Sangewa Ranch in Machang Village of Dangchengwan Township in Subei County. The patient had fever and shortness of breath before passing away.\n\nThe report stated that on 15 Oct 2014, Jiuquan City Health Bureau reported [the case as] suspected plague. The patient was a male, Han Chinese, 50-year old rancher. On 16 Oct 2014, experts from national, provincial, city, and county levels confirmed pneumonic plague based on clinical symptoms, epidemiological history, and lab test results. No abnormalities have been observed in 22 contacts.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Dan Silver\n\n[Most plague cases are due to the bubonic form following the bite of an infected rodent flea causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. The swollen gland is called a 'bubo.' Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2 to 6 days after being bitten.\n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, the _Yersinia pestis_ organism can invade the bloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antibiotic therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. At this stage, as appears to have happened in this case, person-to-person spread can occur, causing cases of 'primary' plague pneumonia.\n\nThe marmot is the most common reservoir for _Yersinia pestis_ in eastern Asia. The etymology of the term 'marmot' is uncertain (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marmot). It may have arisen from the Gallo-Romance prefix marm-, meaning to mumble or murmur (an example of onomatopoeia). Another possible origin is post-classical Latin, mus montanus, meaning 'mountain mouse.' - Mod.LL\n\nMaps of China can be seen at http://www.sacu.org/maps/provmap.png and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/333. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Dan Silver\n\n[Most plague cases are due to the bubonic form following the bite of an infected rodent flea causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. DS, edited]\nhttp://news.xmnn.cn/a/gnxw/201410/t20141017_4142844.htm\n\n\nGansu Health and Family Planning Commission officially reported on 17 Oct 2014 that the Gansu Subei Mongolian Autonomous County People's Hospital confirmed a case of plague. At this stage, as appears to have happened in this case, person-to-person spread can occur, causing cases of 'primary' plague pneumonia. On 16 Oct 2014, experts from national, provincial, city, and county levels confirmed pneumonic plague based on clinical symptoms, epidemiological history, and lab test results. PLAGUE - CHINA (03): (GANSU) PNEUMONIC, FATALITY\n************************************************\n Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. \n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, the _Yersinia pestis_ organism can invade the bloodstream. The report stated that on 15 Oct 2014, Jiuquan City Health Bureau reported [the case as] suspected plague.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Machang Village", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Subei County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3027826", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Madagascar (04)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3027826", "date": "2014-12-12 09:36:07", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (04)\n************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 11 Dec 2014\nSource: L'Express de Madagascar [in French, trans. CopyEd.LMI, edited]\nhttp://www.lexpressmada.com/blog/actualites/sante-le-nombre-de-deces-de-la-peste-atteint-cinquante-deux-23285\n\n\nThe number of people dying from plague continues to rise. 52 deaths were reported at the meeting with the WHO and the Ministry of Public Health, held yesterday, 10 Dec 2014, in Ambohidahy. The latest November 2014 statistics reported 47 deaths from plague. The number of people reported infected with the disease to date, is 189 in Madagascar. 179 of these patients are suffering from bubonic plague. 5 people have been infected with pneumonic plague. The other 5 cases remain unclear. However, a source at the Ministry of Public Health remains cautious. '96 cases have now been confirmed with the Pasteur Institute in Madagascar. The number of people affected by this disease could be close to 100,' confirmed the source.\n\nOut of the 44 districts with plague, the remaining currently infected districts in the Big Island are Amparafaravola, Miarinarivo, Tsiroanomandidy, and Ankazobe. 'A locality is described as an area at the end of plague when there are no cases reported 12 days after the registration of the last case,' said a doctor at the Ministry of Public Health. The short-term eradication of plague in a plague outbreak remains a great challenge. 'There needs to be a comprehensive plan to exterminate rodents in these districts to prevent this disease. Environmental protection such as the fight against burning bushes and forest is also crucial. But all these actions should not only be the prerogative of the Ministry of Public Health. Everyone in the country must be mobilized', the doctor suggested.\n\nDespite the rising number of deaths, WHO is reassuring on its website. 'WHO, as already pointed out in its initial statement, does not recommend any travel restrictions or fewer trade goods to and from Madagascar'. According to its statement, WHO wishes to stress that all public health facilities in the country are able to support any suspected or confirmed case of plague.\n\n[Byline: Vonjy Radasimalala]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is caused by the _Yersinia pestis_ bacillus, carried by rat fleas. At the start of the rainy season, currently, rats flee the sewers of Madagascar in massive numbers and take refuge in people's cottages. Care must be taken in any rodent eradication program to ensure that a flea-killing compound is part of the plan. Just as in a natural rodent die-off from _Y. pestis_, the fleas will seek alternate hosts, that is, humans.\n\nThe following paragraph is from 1998 (Chanteau S, Ratsifasoamanana L, Rasoamanana B, et al: Plague, a Reemerging Disease in Madagascar. Emerg Infect Dis 1998; 4(1): 101-4; http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/4/1/98-0114_article.htm).\n\n'Between 1930 and 1990, bubonic plague had 'virtually disappeared' on the island due to efficient pest-control and good health management. However since 1990, an annual 200 cases are being reported and bubonic plague takes on epidemic form especially in the port of Mahajanga each year. In the capital city of Antananarivo more cases are also being notified each year since 1990. Madagascar (pop. 13 million) has accounted for 45 percent of all the cases of plague in Africa.'\n\nFatalities related to plague usually are caused by spread of the organism from the bubo (the very painful infected lymph node which drains the area where the flea bite occurred) to the bloodstream. The bacteremia can cause a coagulopathy producing the purpura seen in the 'Black Plague' and also spread to the lungs causing a hemorrhagic pneumonia. It is the pneumonia that can facilitate person-to-person transmission.\n\nMadagascar was the location of the isolation of multi-antimicrobial resistant _Y. pestis_ in 1995 (Galimand M, Guiyoule A, Gerbaud G, et al: Multidrug resistance in _Yersinia pestis_ mediated by a transferable plasmid. N Engl J Med 1997; 337(10): 677-81; http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJM199709043371004). The strain was resistant to chloramphenicol, streptomycin, and tetracycline but sensitive to fluoroquinolones and trimethoprim as well as other aminoglycosides. This was an ominous observation; however, it is not clear if this naturally occurring strain has persisted or spread. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/181.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is caused by the _Yersinia pestis_ bacillus, carried by rat fleas. \n\n'Between 1930 and 1990, bubonic plague had 'virtually disappeared' on the island due to efficient pest-control and good health management. A locality is described as an area at the end of plague when there are no cases reported 12 days after the registration of the last case,' said a doctor at the Ministry of Public Health. However since 1990, an annual 200 cases are being reported and bubonic plague takes on epidemic form especially in the port of Mahajanga each year. Fatalities related to plague usually are caused by spread of the organism from the bubo (the very painful infected lymph node which drains the area where the flea bite occurred) to the bloodstream. The short-term eradication of plague in a plague outbreak remains a great challenge. ' \n\nMadagascar was the location of the isolation of multi-antimicrobial resistant _Y. pestis_ in 1995 (Galimand M, Guiyoule A, Gerbaud G, et al: Multidrug resistance in _Yersinia pestis_ mediated by a transferable plasmid. According to its statement, WHO wishes to stress that all public health facilities in the country are able to support any suspected or confirmed case of plague. Out of the 44 districts with plague, the remaining currently infected districts in the Big Island are Amparafaravola, Miarinarivo, Tsiroanomandidy, and Ankazobe. ' The latest November 2014 statistics reported 47 deaths from plague. The bacteremia can cause a coagulopathy producing the purpura seen in the 'Black Plague' and also spread to the lungs causing a hemorrhagic pneumonia. 5 people have been infected with pneumonic plague. Madagascar (pop. 13 million) has accounted for 45 percent of all the cases of plague in Africa.' PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (04)\n The number of people dying from plague continues to rise. The number of people reported infected with the disease to date, is 189 in Madagascar. [Byline: Vonjy Radasimalala]\n\n--\n \n\nDespite the rising number of deaths, WHO is reassuring on its website. ' The number of people affected by this disease could be close to 100,' confirmed the source. 179 of these patients are suffering from bubonic plague. 52 deaths were reported at the meeting with the WHO and the Ministry of Public Health, held yesterday, 10 Dec 2014, in Ambohidahy.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1990-03-25 00:00:00", "1995-03-25 00:00:00", "1998-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-11-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ambohidahy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rasoamanana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mahajanga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2981993", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Madagascar (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2981993", "date": "2014-11-22 11:48:51", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (02)\n************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 21 Nov 2014\nSource: NPR [edited]\nhttp://www.npr.org/blogs/goatsandsoda/2014/11/21/365798616/plague-outbreak-in-madagascar-spreads-to-its-capital\n\n\nAn outbreak of the plague has sickened at least 119 people and killed 40 in Madagascar, the WHO reports Friday, 21 Nov 2014. The outbreak started back in August 2014 in a rural village, WHO said. Then it spread to 7 of Madagascar's 22 regions. 2 cases have occurred in the country's capital of Antananarivo.\n\n'There is now a risk of a rapid spread of the disease due to the city's high population density and the weakness of the health care system,' the WHO writes.\n\nThe plague is not new to Madagascar. The disease re-emerged in the country in the 1990s. And now Madagascar reports more cases than any other country -- about 300 to 600 each year. People catch the plague bacteria, _Yersinia pestis_, from fleas that live on rodents. So the disease thrives in cities with poor sanitation.\n\nAfter a coup d'etat in 2009, Antananarivo's health and sanitation systems collapsed, Aaron Ross wrote on the Pulitzer Center's website in January 2014. 'Trash can go weeks, even months, without being collected and rats have become a common sight along the narrow alleyways that coil around the city's steep hillsides,' Ross wrote.\n\nThe plague's signature symptom is large, swollen lymph nodes. This form of the disease is called bubonic plague. And it's not very contagious. When the infection moves to the lungs, it's called pneumonic plague, a form that's more dangerous. It kills quickly, and it spreads from person to person through coughs. In the current outbreak, so far, only 2 percent of the cases are pneumonic, WHO says.\n\nBoth forms of the plague are easily cured with antimicrobials when the disease is caught early.\n\n[Byline: Michaeleen Doucleff]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nSara Volk de Garcia\nChicago, Illinois\nUSA\n<sara.m.volk@gmail.com>\n\n[Plague is caused by the _Yersinia pestis_ bacillus, carried by rat fleas. At the start of the rainy season, currently, rats flee the sewers of Madagascar in massive numbers and take refuge in people's cottages.\n\nThe following paragraph is from 1998 (Chanteau S, Ratsifasoamanana L, Rasoamanana B, et al: Plague, a Reemerging Disease in Madagascar. Emerg Infect Dis 1998; 4(1): 101-4; http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/4/1/98-0114_article.htm).\n\n'Between 1930 and 1990, bubonic plague had 'virtually disappeared' on the island due to efficient pest-control and good health management. However since 1990, an annual 200 cases are being reported and bubonic plague takes on epidemic form especially in the port of Mahajanga each year. In the capital city of Antananarivo more cases are also being notified each year since 1990. Madagascar (pop. 13 million) has accounted for 45 percent of all the cases of plague in Africa.'\n\nFatalities related to plague usually are caused by spread of the organism from the bubo (the very painful infected lymph node which drains the area where the flea bite occurred) to the bloodstream. The bacteremia can cause a coagulopathy producing the purpura seen in the 'Black Plague' and also spread to the lungs causing a hemorrhagic pneumonia. It is the pneumonia that can facilitate person-to-person transmission.\n\nMadagascar was the location of the isolation of multi-antimicrobial resistant _Y. pestis_ in 1995 (Galimand M, Guiyoule A, Gerbaud G, et al: Multidrug resistance in _Yersinia pestis_ mediated by a transferable plasmid. N Engl J Med 1997; 337(10): 677-80; http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJM199709043371004). The strain was resistant to chloramphenicol, streptomycin, and tetracycline but sensitive to fluoroquinolones and trimethoprim as well as other aminoglycosides. This was an ominous observation; however, it is not clear if this naturally occurring strain has persisted or spread. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/181.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n'Between 1930 and 1990, bubonic plague had 'virtually disappeared' on the island due to efficient pest-control and good health management.
