[Plague is caused by the _Yersinia pestis_ bacillus, carried by rat fleas. \n\nThe following paragraph is from 1998 (Chanteau S, Ratsifasoamanana L, Rasoamanana B, et al", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2014-01-25 00:00:00", "2014-08-25 00:00:00", "1998-03-25 00:00:00", "1990-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "1995-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Rasoamanana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mahajanga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2821046", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Crayfish plague - UK: (England) white-clawed crayfish", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2821046", "date": "2014-10-01 23:44:45", "main_text": "CRAYFISH PLAGUE - UK: (ENGLAND) WHITE-CLAWED CRAYFISH\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 27 Sep 2014\nSource: BBC News Dorset [edited]\nhttp://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-dorset-29381685\n\n\nAn appeal has been launched to safeguard one of the last remaining white-clawed crayfish habitats after the outbreak of a killer disease. More than 100 of the rare native crayfish species have so far died as a result of crayfish plague on Dorset's River Allen.\n\nThe disease, carried by non-native American signal crayfish, was first discovered on the river in July [2014]. Dorset Wildlife Trust has launched a GBP 33 000 river restoration work appeal. Until recently the River Allen had been identified as a stronghold of the native species. The trust said the cash would bolster a GBP 60 000 [USD 53 500] project set up in 2013 to help native crayfish thrive on the river.\nThe Environment Agency has urged anglers to disinfect their fishing tackle and clothing to try to prevent its spread.\n\nIt is not clear how the fungal infection reached the River Allen but it can be spread on damp equipment that has come from water containing signal crayfish.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[_Austropotamobius pallipes_, the white-clawed crayfish of Western European streams, has become restricted in distribution over the past century. Crayfish fungal plague, fatal to white-clawed crayfish, has affected many European countries. It is caused by a fungus _Aphanomyces astaci_ that was brought into Europe by the introduction of _Procambarus clarkii_, a freshwater crayfish species of Louisiana, USA, which is naturally infected by this pathogen, although it does not develop clinical disease.\n\nFor a picture of a white-clawed crayfish go to http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Austropotamobius_pallipes#mediaviewer/File:Austropotamobius_pallipes.jpg.\nA map of affected area can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/40. - Mod.PMB]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[_Austropotamobius pallipes_, the white-clawed crayfish of Western European streams, has become restricted in distribution over the past century. CRAYFISH PLAGUE - UK: (ENGLAND) WHITE-CLAWED CRAYFISH\n More than 100 of the rare native crayfish species have so far died as a result of crayfish plague on Dorset's River Allen. Crayfish fungal plague, fatal to white-clawed crayfish, has affected many European countries. \n\nThe disease, carried by non-native American signal crayfish, was first discovered on the river in July [2014]. \n\nIt is not clear how the fungal infection reached the River Allen but it can be spread on damp equipment that has come from water containing signal crayfish. An appeal has been launched to safeguard one of the last remaining white-clawed crayfish habitats after the outbreak of a killer disease. It is caused by a fungus _Aphanomyces astaci_ that was brought into Europe by the introduction of _Procambarus clarkii_, a freshwater crayfish species of Louisiana, USA, which is naturally infected by this pathogen, although it does not develop clinical disease. [USD 53 500] project set up in 2013 to help native crayfish thrive on the river. \n\n--\n For a picture of a white-clawed crayfish go to http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Austropotamobius_pallipes#mediaviewer/File:Austropotamobius_pallipes.jpg. Date: Fri 27 Sep 2014\n Source: BBC News Dorset [edited]\n **\n Until recently the River Allen had been identified as a stronghold of the native species. \n \n Dorset Wildlife Trust has launched a GBP 33 000 river restoration work appeal. The Environment Agency has urged anglers to disinfect their fishing tackle and clothing to try to prevent its spread. The trust said the cash would bolster a GBP 60 000 \n\n A map of affected area can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/40.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-07-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2832636", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - China (02): (GS) fatality", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2832636", "date": "2014-10-05 18:30:32", "main_text": "PLAGUE - CHINA (02): (GANSU), FATALITY\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 4 Oct 2014\nSource: DNA India [edited]\nhttp://www.dnaindia.com/world/report-man-dies-of-plague-in-china-2023525\n\n\nA 45-year-old man in northwest China's Gansu province has died of plague, the 2nd death of its kind in 2014, official media reported on Sat 4 Oct 2014. The case was reported in Subei County under the jurisdiction of Jiuquan City. The man, a herder, died on Wednesday, 1 Oct 2014, in hospital.\n\nThe provincial health and family planning commission confirmed the case after lab reports were released, state-run Xinhua news agency reported. The man grazed his sheep in a pasture where widespread plague has been reported among marmots in recent years.\n\nA total of 41 people who had close contact with the man have been put in quarantine under medical observation. None have shown any symptoms so far. His home village has also been isolated and thoroughly disinfected. It is the 2nd plague death in Jiuquan in 2014. The other fatality was also marmot-related.\n\nThe National Health and Family Planning Commission has sent specialists to the county to prevent the plague from spreading. Plague is categorized as a Class A infectious disease, the most serious under China's Law on the Prevention and Treatment of Infectious Diseases.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[No specific information is available. Most deaths from _Yersinia pestis_ human infection relates to bacteremic complications or the primary or secondary development of pneumonic plague. It is that form of infection that can result in person-to-person transmission. Given the isolation precautions, it might be assumed that the gentleman had developed pneumonic plague.\n\nPrimary pneumonic plague (one percent of natural plague presentations) arises as a result of inhalation of plague bacilli in infectious aerosols, such as would be produced when there are secondary pneumonic complications in bubonic/septicemic plague.\n\nPrimary plague pneumonia has a short incubation period of 1-3 days, after which there is sudden onset of flu-like symptoms including fever, chills, headache, generalized body pains, weakness, and chest discomfort. A cough develops with sputum production, which may be bloody, and increasing chest pain and difficulty in breathing. As the disease progresses, hypoxia (low oxygen concentration in the blood) and hemoptysis (coughing up blood) are prominent. The disease is invariably fatal unless antimicrobial therapy commences within 24 hours of exposure.\n\nPatients with primary pneumonic plague generate large quantities of infectious aerosols that pose a significant risk to close contacts. CDC (US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) guidelines identify contacts within 2 meters (6.5 ft) as being at greatest risk and do not consider the organism likely to be carried through air ducts or vents. Persons who have been in contact with pneumonic plague patients or handling potentially infectious body fluids or tissues without appropriate protection should receive preventive antimicrobial therapy. The preferred antimicrobial agents for prophylaxis are tetracyclines, quinolones, or chloramphenicol.\n\nThe marmot is the most common reservoir for _Yersinia pestis_ in eastern Asia. The etymology of the term 'marmot' is uncertain (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marmot). It may have arisen from the Gallo-Romance prefix marm-, meaning to mumble or murmur (an example of onomatopoeia). Another possible origin is post-classical Latin, mus montanus, meaning 'mountain mouse'. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/333.]", "summary": "\n\nPrimary pneumonic plague (one percent of natural plague presentations) arises as a result of inhalation of plague bacilli in infectious aerosols, such as would be produced when there are secondary pneumonic complications in bubonic/septicemic plague. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nPrimary plague pneumonia has a short incubation period of 1-3 days, after which there is sudden onset of flu-like symptoms including fever, chills, headache, generalized body pains, weakness, and chest discomfort. \n\n\nA 45-year-old man in northwest China's Gansu province has died of plague, the 2nd death of its kind in 2014, official media reported on Sat 4 Oct 2014. Persons who have been in contact with pneumonic plague patients or handling potentially infectious body fluids or tissues without appropriate protection should receive preventive antimicrobial therapy. Patients with primary pneumonic plague generate large quantities of infectious aerosols that pose a significant risk to close contacts. The man grazed his sheep in a pasture where widespread plague has been reported among marmots in recent years.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Jiuquan City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gansu", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Subei County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jiuquan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2757605", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (06): (CO) septicemic", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2757605", "date": "2014-09-08 14:40:58", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (06): (COLORADO) SEPTICEMIC\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 8 Sep 2014\nSource: Pagosa Daily Post [edited]\nhttp://www.pagosadailypost.com/news/26698/Plague_Case_Confirmed_in_La_Plata_County/\n\n\nSan Juan Basin Health (SJBH) in coordination with the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment (CDPHE) has identified a human case of septicemic plague in a La Plata County resident. An investigation is underway to determine the source of exposure. The patient is currently receiving treatment. This is the 2nd case of plague in La Plata County this year [2014].\n\nSince 1957, Colorado has identified 65 cases of human plague, 9 (14 percent) of which were fatal.\n\n157 samples have been tested for plague in 2014 at public health laboratories. 2 rodents, a rabbit, a dog and a cat have all tested positive for plague in Colorado. 14 flea samples have also tested positive for plague. Since domestic cats and dogs can carry infected fleas into the home, it is important to consult your veterinarian about how to effectively control fleas on your pets.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is the 6th case of plague in Colorado in 2014. There was a cluster of 4 cases in Adams County related to an infected dog and this is the 2nd of La Plata County.\n\nThe state of Colorado can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6666. A map of the counties in Colorado can be found at http://www.maps.com/ref_map.aspx?pid=11663. La Plata county is in southwestern Colorado, bordering New Mexico, and Adams county is in northeast Colorado, close to Denver. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is the 6th case of plague in Colorado in 2014. \n\nSince 1957, Colorado has identified 65 cases of human plague, 9 (14 percent) of which were fatal. \n\n157 samples have been tested for plague in 2014 at public health laboratories. http://www.pagosadailypost.com/news/26698/Plague_Case_Confirmed_in_La_Plata_County/\n\n\nSan Juan Basin Health (SJBH) in coordination with the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment (CDPHE) has identified a human case of septicemic plague in a La Plata County resident. PLAGUE - USA (06): (COLORADO) SEPTICEMIC\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1957-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "San Juan Basin Health", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Adams County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Adams county", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denver", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "La Plata County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2666637", "headline": "PRO/AH> Plague, animal - USA (06): comment", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2666637", "date": "2014-08-07 09:42:54", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (06): COMMENT\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 5 Aug 2014\nFrom: Harry Hull <hfhullmd@gmail.com> [edited]\n\n\n[Re: ProMED-mail Plague, animal - USA (05): (CA) squirrel 20140804.2656788]\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nWhile the moderator correctly points out that dogs usually do not become ill with plague and rarely transmit the disease to humans, dogs can serve as passive vectors for plague by bringing infected fleas into the home. Flea collars reduce, but do not eliminate the risk. CDC advises the use of flea control products for free-roaming dogs and cats in plague endemic areas and not allowing these animals to sleep in your bed.\n\n--\nHarry F Hull, MD\n<hfhullmd@gmail.com>\nFormer New Mexico state epidemiologist\n\n[Dr Hull is correct. Fleas on dogs can serve as a vector bringing plague into the house.\n\nRecently, a dog in Colorado did die of plague (ProMED-mail post 20140719.2621418) and people in the household were also infected with the pneumonic form of plague. It is believed the people got the plague from the dog and not the fleas, but I think it would difficult to prove that with fleas already present in the home.\n\nThis moderator wishes to thank Dr Hull for his comment. - Mod.TG\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/787.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n While the moderator correctly points out that dogs usually do not become ill with plague and rarely transmit the disease to humans, dogs can serve as passive vectors for plague by bringing infected fleas into the home. PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (06): COMMENT\n**********************************\n Recently, a dog in Colorado did die of plague (ProMED-mail post 20140719.2621418) and people in the household were also infected with the pneumonic form of plague. [Re: ProMED-mail Plague, animal - USA (05): (CA) squirrel 20140804.2656788]\n Harry F Hull, MD\n<hfhullmd@gmail.com>\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2643587", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, animal - USA: (NM) zoo", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2643587", "date": "2014-07-29 21:32:31", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA: (NEW MEXICO) ZOO\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 25 Jul 2014\nSource: krqe.com [edited]\nhttp://krqe.com/2014/07/25/new-cases-of-plague-found-in-east-mountains/\n\n\nThe plague appears to be spreading in Albuquerque's east mountains [in New Mexico].\n\nAccording to the Department of Game and Fish, the latest plague infection was of a mountain lion and coati at the Wildlife West Nature Park (http://www.wildlifewest.org/).\n\nA coati is a small raccoon-like animal; both it and the cougar died.\n\nThe plague is a bacterial disease of rodents which can be transmitted to humans through bites of infected fleas and contact with infected animals.\n\nIndications of the disease are flu-like symptoms.\n\nThe Department of Game and Fish is applying insecticides in rodent burrows to kill fleas and posting signs to warn people to stay on designated trails.\n\nPlague is usually more prevalent in mountain areas, so keep an eye on your pets.\n\n[Byline: Kim Vallez]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations. Some species are particularly susceptible. For example, _Y. pestis_ caused the extinction of entire colonies of black-tailed prairie dogs. Small rodents such as deer mice and grasshopper mice are suggested to act as the reservoirs. Larger species like squirrels and chipmunks are considered to be more vulnerable to infection.\n\nA map of the affected area can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/233. - Mod.PMB]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. \n\nThe plague is a bacterial disease of rodents which can be transmitted to humans through bites of infected fleas and contact with infected animals. \n\nThe Department of Game and Fish is applying insecticides in rodent burrows to kill fleas and posting signs to warn people to stay on designated trails. PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA: (NEW MEXICO) ZOO\n**************************************\n [Byline: Kim Vallez]\n\n--\n \n\nA coati is a small raccoon-like animal; both it and the cougar died.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2720056", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, animal - USA (07): (CO) prairie dog, rabbit", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2720056", "date": "2014-08-25 19:07:14", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (07): (COLORADO) PRAIRIE DOG, RABBIT\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Thu 21 Aug 2014\nSource: Yahoo News [edited]\nhttp://news.yahoo.com/plague-boulder-colorado-124423854.html\n\n\nHealth officials in Colorado have issued a warning to residents in Boulder County that the bubonic plague has been found in fleas taken from a prairie dog. Notices posted on fence posts around a 44-acre open-space property say that 'wild rodents and other small mammals' including squirrels, prairie dogs and rabbits 'may be infected with plague.' The signs recommend people treat their pets with anti-flea medication, avoid open spaces where the plague has been confirmed and avoid contact 'with all sick or dead rodents.'\n\nOther advice:\n\n- Avoid fleas. Protect pets with flea powder or drops, or a new flea collar. Keep pets on a leash and out of wild rodent habitats.\n\n- Avoid all contact with wild rodents, including squirrels; do not feed or handle them.\n\n- Prevent rodent infestations around your house. Clear plants and material away from outside walls, reduce access to food items and set rodent traps.\n\n- Treat known rodent sites around your home with flea powder or a suitable insecticide.\n\nAccording to KUSA-TV, it is the 1st confirmed case of plague in Boulder County since 2011, when a domesticated cat and a dead squirrel tested positive for it. According to the Boulder County Public Health Department, 2 squirrels had been tested for plague earlier this year [2014], but those tests came back negative.\n\n'The fleas don't travel large distances, so it's nothing we're seeing spread or becoming an epidemic,' Lane Drager, consumer protection coordinator for Boulder County Public Health, told the Daily Camera. 'It's confined to that one area. But if pets are going into these areas, they are risking exposure for themselves and for those pet owners.'\n\nStill, locals should be on the lookout for signs of plague ('sudden onset of fever and chills, severe headache, muscle aches, nausea, vomiting, general feeling of systemic [whole body] illness, extreme pain and swelling in the lymph node') and seek immediate treatment.\n\nPlague can be treated with antibiotics, the officials added, but treatment is 'most successful when the disease can be diagnosed quickly.'\n\n[Byline: Dylan Stableford]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri 22 Aug 2014\nSource: KOAA 5 [edited]\nhttp://www.koaa.com/news/wild-rabbit-near-yoder-dies-from-plague/\n\n\nA wild rabbit in eastern El Paso County [Colorado] died as a result of contracting bubonic plague, the El Paso County Health Department announced Friday [22 Aug 2014]. It is the 1st confirmed presence of plague in El Paso County this season, the department said. The rabbit was found dead near a prairie dog burrow on private property near Yoder. Testing was completed on the animal Thursday [21 Aug 2014] and confirmed the rabbit had plague.\n\nThe health department says a public health specialist went door-to-door to notify area residents of the presence of plague. The department warns the public not to try to catch, feed, handle, or kill prairie dogs, squirrels, chipmunks, rabbits, or any other type of wild animal. Plague can be transmitted to humans by the bite of an infected flea.\n\n[Byline: Zach Taxon]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations. Some species are particularly susceptible. For example, _Y. pestis_ caused the extinction of entire colonies of black-tailed prairie dogs. Small rodents such as deer mice and grasshopper mice are suggested to act as the reservoirs. Larger species like squirrels and chipmunks are considered to be more vulnerable to infection. Dogs and cats may bring infected fleas to their homes, so flea control is advised for dogs and the house environment. - Mod.PMB\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/209.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (07): (COLORADO) PRAIRIE DOG, RABBIT\n*********************************************************\n \n\n[Byline: Dylan Stableford]\n\n--\n \n\nStill, locals should be on the lookout for signs of plague ('sudden onset of fever and chills, severe headache, muscle aches, nausea, vomiting, general feeling of systemic [whole body] illness, extreme pain and swelling in the lymph node') and seek immediate treatment. Notices posted on fence posts around a 44-acre open-space property say that 'wild rodents and other small mammals' including squirrels, prairie dogs and rabbits 'may be infected with plague.' \n\nThe health department says a public health specialist went door-to-door to notify area residents of the presence of plague. The signs recommend people treat their pets with anti-flea medication, avoid open spaces where the plague has been confirmed and avoid contact 'with all sick or dead rodents.' \n\nOther advice:\n\n- Avoid fleas. \n\n- Avoid all contact with wild rodents, including squirrels; do not feed or handle them. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\n\nA wild rabbit in eastern El Paso County [Colorado] died as a result of contracting bubonic plague, the El Paso County Health Department announced Friday [22 Aug 2014]. The department warns the public not to try to catch, feed, handle, or kill prairie dogs, squirrels, chipmunks, rabbits, or any other type of wild animal. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n [Byline: Zach Taxon]\n\n--\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Boulder County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "El Paso County Health Department", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yoder", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "El Paso County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2656788", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, animal - USA (05): (CA) squirrel", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2656788", "date": "2014-08-04 00:07:20", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (05): (CALIFORNIA), SQUIRREL\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 2 Aug 2014\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/san-diego-county-mouse-tests-positive-for-hantavirus-squirrels-positive-for-plague-50343/\n\n\nSan Diego County officials issued an alert last week after 2 squirrels trapped in routine monitoring at an empty outdoor school on Palomar Mountain have tested positive for plague. The squirrels were trapped on property at Camp Palomar Outdoor School, which was undergoing summer maintenance and not scheduled to be used by campers until 25 Aug 2014.\n\nThis prompted officials to remind people to take simple steps to protect themselves when camping and hiking. 'When you're enjoying the outdoors, just remember, don't feed or play with squirrels; don't play near squirrel burrows or set up your tents around them; and report dead squirrels to camp rangers,' said San Diego County Environmental Health Director Liz Pozzebon.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague, caused by _Yersinia pestis_, is enzootic among rodents in the western USA. Humans can be infected through 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals; 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals.\n\nPlague is a potential bioterrorism agent. Human infections are rare but can be life-threatening. The case fatality rate of plague depends on the clinical presentation (that is, bubonic, septicemic, or pneumonic) and timing of initiation of antibiotic therapy; if untreated, the case fatality rate is over 50 per cent for bubonic plague and approaches 100 per cent for pneumonic plague (1). Rapid laboratory identification can help guide therapy.\n\nDomestic cats and dogs can also contract plague from infective fleas. They may carry infected fleas home to their owners or, especially with cats, serve as a direct source of infection. There are many flea treatments and repellents appropriate for pets available. Some products may be suitable for dogs but not cats or may be suitable for an adult but not a younger animal. Be sure to consult your veterinarian, as some products may be toxic to cats, kittens, and puppies, even resulting in fatalities.\n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under the jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front leg (the armpit, if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever. Please take your pet to a veterinarian if you notice any abnormalities.\n\nVeterinarians should protect themselves by wearing gloves when examining these swellings. A bubo that ruptures may infect the veterinarian or even the pet owner if the pet owner is the one palpating the swelling.\n\nAnother form of the disease is the respiratory form. Cats may acquire this form and can spread it to their owners or the veterinarians through infected expiratory droplets. People are also prone to the respiratory infection.\n\nYou should also be aware that the fleas that hitchhike into your home on a pet can also transmit disease to you, the owner or caretaker of the pet. Sleeping in the same bed with dogs has been associated with plague in enzootic areas (2). Plague patients with no history of exposure to rodents can be infected by _Y. pestis_ if their pets carry infected rodent fleas into the home. Veterinarians always should recommend flea control to dog and cat owners.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. CDC. Human plague -- four states, 2006. MMWR 2006; 55(34): 940-3; available at http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5534a4.htm.\n\n2. Gould LH, Pape J, Ettestad P, et al. Dog-associated risk factors for human plague. Zoonoses Public Health 2008; 55(8-10): 448-54; abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18489541.\n\nParts of the above comment have been extracted from: CDC. Notes from the field: two cases of human plague - Oregon, 2010. MMWR 2011; 60(7): 214 http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6007a4.htm.\n\nCalifornia may be found on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/787. - Mod.TG]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The case fatality rate of plague depends on the clinical presentation (that is, bubonic, septicemic, or pneumonic) and timing of initiation of antibiotic therapy; if untreated, the case fatality rate is over 50 per cent for bubonic plague and approaches 100 per cent for pneumonic plague (1). Humans can be infected through 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals; 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals. Plague patients with no history of exposure to rodents can be infected by _Y. pestis_ if their pets carry infected rodent fleas into the home. PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (05): (CALIFORNIA), SQUIRREL\n*************************************************\n \n\nYou should also be aware that the fleas that hitchhike into your home on a pet can also transmit disease to you, the owner or caretaker of the pet. \n\nDomestic cats and dogs can also contract plague from infective fleas. \n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under the jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front leg (the armpit, if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague, caused by _Yersinia pestis_, is enzootic among rodents in the western USA. They may carry infected fleas home to their owners or, especially with cats, serve as a direct source of infection. [Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nReferences\n---------- \n\nThis prompted officials to remind people to take simple steps to protect themselves when camping and hiking. '", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hantavirus", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-08-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Diego County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2684621", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (05): (CO) bubonic", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2684621", "date": "2014-08-13 10:09:36", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (05): (COLORADO) BUBONIC\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 11 Aug 2014\nSource: The Denver Post [edited]\nhttp://www.denverpost.com/news/ci_26317922/bubonic-plague-confirmed-la-plata-county-woman\n\n\nA La Plata County woman has contracted bubonic plague, according to the San Juan Basin Health Department. The woman was hospitalized Sat 9 Aug 2014, before she was released to recover at home, Flannery O'Neil, a spokeswoman for the department, said Mon 11 Aug 2014. O'Neil said the department is investigating how the woman was exposed to the plague.\n\nThe last case of bubonic plague in La Plata County, which lies in a region of the nation that predominantly sees the disease, was in 2006. A case was also confirmed in nearby Archuleta County in 2012, O'Neil said.\n\n'In recent decades, an average of 7 human plague cases have been reported each year nationwide,' the department said. 4 other cases of plague, specifically pneumonic plague, have been reported in Colorado in 2014. All of those sickened lived in Adams County, according to state health officials. There have been 64 cases of human plague in Colorado since 1957, 9 of which were fatal.\n\n[Byline: Jesse Paul]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The bubo, of bubonic plague, is an extremely painful lymph node swelling in the area draining from the flea bite that introduced the bacillus. - Mod.LL\n\nThe state of Colorado can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6666. A county map can be seen at http://geology.com/county-map/colorado-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n PLAGUE - USA (05): (COLORADO) BUBONIC\n*************************************\n \n\n'In recent decades, an average of 7 human plague cases have been reported each year nationwide,' the department said. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The bubo, of bubonic plague, is an extremely painful lymph node swelling in the area draining from the flea bite that introduced the bacillus. 4 other cases of plague, specifically pneumonic plague, have been reported in Colorado in 2014. \n\nThe last case of bubonic plague in La Plata County, which lies in a region of the nation that predominantly sees the disease, was in 2006. The woman was hospitalized Sat 9 Aug 2014, before she was released to recover at home, Flannery O'Neil, a spokeswoman for the department, said Mon 11 Aug 2014.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "1957-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "La Plata County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Archuleta County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Adams County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2621418", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (03): (CO) cluster from canine exposure", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2621418", "date": "2014-07-19 16:44:37", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (03): (COLORADO) CLUSTER FROM CANINE EXPOSURE\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 19 Jul 2014\nSource: Bloomberg News [edited]\nhttp://www.bloomberg.com/news/2014-07-18/four-cases-of-life-threatening-plague-found-in-colorado.html\n\n\n3 more plague cases were found in Colorado, a week after the 1st infection of the deadliest form of the disease was reported in the state in a decade. The man initially reported with pneumonic plague on 11 Jul 2014 is [still] hospitalized; 2 of the new cases also had pneumonic plague, while the 3rd had a milder form. All 4 cases may be linked to the original man's dog, which died from the illness, state health officials said.\n\nThe people newly found to be infected were treated with antimicrobials, recovered, and are no longer contagious. Health officials suspect the dog that died may been exposed to plague-infected fleas from a prairie dog or rabbit, said Jennifer House, a spokeswoman for the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment department. 'We've had quite a number of cases this year [2014],' House said in a telephone interview. 'We do believe the outbreak itself to be over.'\n\nColorado has had 60 cases of all types of plague since 1957, and 9 people have died. 12 cases of plague have occurred in the past decade in the state. The state's investigation is ongoing, House said.\n\n'While this is not a daily, weekly, or monthly occurrence, it isn't without precedence,' said Jim Siedlecki, director of public information of Adams County, where the original victim lives, in a telephone interview. 'A case of plague where fleas and prairie dogs are involved isn't earth shattering for Colorado.'\n\n[Byline: Sonali Basak and Jennifer Oldham]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As compared to cats, dogs are not considered to be significant in the transmission of _Yersinia pestis_ to humans, as underscored by the following paper. Clearly, however, since this paper, cases from canine exposure have occurred.\n\nOrloski KA, Eidson M: Yersinia pestis infection in three dogs. J Am Vet Med Assoc. 1995;207: 316-318\n\nAbstract:\n'_Yersinia pestis_ infection was diagnosed in 3 dogs. Clinical signs included lethargy (3 dogs), pyrexia (2 dogs), and a purulent skin lesion in the cervical region (2 dogs). _Yersinia pestis_ infection is a potentially fatal zoonotic disease of human beings. Human cases have resulted from contact with infected domestic cats; however, the risk of human infection from contact with infected domestic dogs is unknown. Dogs frequently are exposed to _Y. pestis_ in areas in which there are plague epizootics; however, clinical illness in dogs is rare. In the western United States, where _Yersinia pestis_ is endemic, plague should be considered in the differential diagnosis when examining dogs with nonspecific fever and lethargy.' - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/209.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n 1995;207: 316-318\n\nAbstract:\n'_Yersinia pestis_ infection was diagnosed in 3 dogs. Clinical signs included lethargy (3 dogs), pyrexia (2 dogs), and a purulent skin lesion in the cervical region (2 dogs). Human cases have resulted from contact with infected domestic cats; however, the risk of human infection from contact with infected domestic dogs is unknown. The man initially reported with pneumonic plague on 11 Jul 2014 is [still] hospitalized; 2 of the new cases also had pneumonic plague, while the 3rd had a milder form. Dogs frequently are exposed to _Y. pestis_ in areas in which there are plague epizootics; however, clinical illness in dogs is rare. Health officials suspect the dog that died may been exposed to plague-infected fleas from a prairie dog or rabbit, said Jennifer House, a spokeswoman for the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment department. \n\n\n3 more plague cases were found in Colorado, a week after the 1st infection of the deadliest form of the disease was reported in the state in a decade. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As compared to cats, dogs are not considered to be significant in the transmission of _Yersinia pestis_ to humans, as underscored by the following paper. \n\nColorado has had 60 cases of all types of plague since 1957, and 9 people have died.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1957-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Adams County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2656232", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (04): (NM)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2656232", "date": "2014-08-03 14:56:21", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (04): (NEW MEXICO)\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 21 Jul 2014\nSource: New Mexico Department of Health [edited]\nhttp://nmhealth.org/news/disease/2014/7/?view=97\n\n\nThe New Mexico Department of Health is reporting a case of plague in a 43-year-old woman from Rio Arriba County who is currently hospitalized. Confirmatory testing was conducted at the Department's Scientific Laboratory Division.\n\nThe 1st plague case in New Mexico in 2014 was reported in April 2014 in a 57-year-old man from Torrance County who is still recovering. An environmental investigation will take place at the woman's home to look for ongoing risk to others in the surrounding area.\n\n'Plague activity in New Mexico is usually highest during the summer months, so it is especially important now to take precautions to avoid rodents and their fleas, which can expose you to plague,' said Department of Health Secretary Retta Ward, MPH. 'This person was most likely exposed to plague when her dogs brought infected fleas back into the home.'\n\nPlague is a bacterial disease of rodents and is generally transmitted to humans through the bites of infected fleas but can also be transmitted by direct contact with infected animals, including rodents, wildlife and pets.\n\n'We are seeing die offs of rabbits, squirrels, pack rats and various rodents in several areas of New Mexico from both plague and tularemia,' said Dr. Paul Ettestad, public health veterinarian for the Department of Health. 'Pets that are allowed to roam and hunt can bring infected fleas from dead rodents back into the home, putting you and your children at risk.'\n\nIn New Mexico, there were 4 human plague cases in 2013 with one fatality, one human plague case in 2012, 2 human cases of plague in 2011, no cases in 2010, and 6 human cases of plague in 2009, one of them fatal.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The manifestations of _Yersinia pestis_ infection in this case are not stated, although overall 95 percent of cases are bubonic in nature. As in the previous 2014 cluster of 4 human cases of plague in Colorado, this NM case seems to be related to a dog exposure, but this time, the canine was not reported to be ill. As compared to cats, dogs are not considered to be significant in the transmission of _Yersinia pestis_ to humans, as underscored by the following paper. Clearly, however, since this paper, cases from canine exposure have occurred.\n\nOrloski KA, Eidson M: _Yersinia pestis_ infection in three dogs. J Am Vet Med Assoc. 1995;207: 316-318.\n\nAbstract:\n'_Yersinia pestis_ infection was diagnosed in 3 dogs. Clinical signs included lethargy (3 dogs), pyrexia (2 dogs), and a purulent skin lesion in the cervical region (2 dogs). _Yersinia pestis_ infection is a potentially fatal zoonotic disease of human beings. Human cases have resulted from contact with infected domestic cats; however, the risk of human infection from contact with infected domestic dogs is unknown. Dogs frequently are exposed to _Y. pestis_ in areas in which there are plague epizootics; however, clinical illness in dogs is rare. In the western United States, where _Yersinia pestis_ is endemic, plague should be considered in the differential diagnosis when examining dogs with nonspecific fever and lethargy.'\n\nA map of the USA showing the origin location of plague cases in the USA between 1970 and 2012 shows that in New Mexico, most cases are found in the northwestern part of the state (http://www.cdc.gov/plague/maps/). Rio Arriba County is in this high distribution area. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/233.]", "summary": "\n\nIn New Mexico, there were 4 human plague cases in 2013 with one fatality, one human plague case in 2012, 2 human cases of plague in 2011, no cases in 2010, and 6 human cases of plague in 2009, one of them fatal. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Human cases have resulted from contact with infected domestic cats; however, the risk of human infection from contact with infected domestic dogs is unknown. \n\n'Plague activity in New Mexico is usually highest during the summer months, so it is especially important now to take precautions to avoid rodents and their fleas, which can expose you to plague,' said Department of Health Secretary Retta Ward, MPH. ' Plague is a bacterial disease of rodents and is generally transmitted to humans through the bites of infected fleas but can also be transmitted by direct contact with infected animals, including rodents, wildlife and pets. \n\nA map of the USA showing the origin location of plague cases in the USA between 1970 and 2012 shows that in New Mexico, most cases are found in the northwestern part of the state (http://www.cdc.gov/plague/maps/). As in the previous 2014 cluster of 4 human cases of plague in Colorado, this NM case seems to be related to a dog exposure, but this time, the canine was not reported to be ill. Clinical signs included lethargy (3 dogs), pyrexia (2 dogs), and a purulent skin lesion in the cervical region (2 dogs). Dogs frequently are exposed to _Y. pestis_ in areas in which there are plague epizootics; however, clinical illness in dogs is rare. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The manifestations of _Yersinia pestis_ infection in this case are not stated, although overall 95 percent of cases are bubonic in nature. \n\n'We are seeing die offs of rabbits, squirrels, pack rats and various rodents in several areas of New Mexico from both plague and tularemia,' said Dr. Paul Ettestad, public health veterinarian for the Department of Health. '", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-04-25 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Torrance County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rio Arriba County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2620341", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - China: (GS) pneumonic, fatality", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2620341", "date": "2014-07-18 17:53:49", "main_text": "PLAGUE - CHINA: (GANSU) PNEUMONIC, FATALITY\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Thu 17 Jul 2014\nSource: CRI [edited]\nhttp://english.cri.cn/12394/2014/07/17/3241s836529.htm\n\n\nAn outbreak of plague has killed a man in northwest China's Gansu Province. Local authorities say the man's remains have been properly disposed of and 151 people who had close contact with him are now quarantined.\n\nThe victim was said to have been hospitalized before he died on Wednesday, 16 Jul 2014. An autopsy found he died of plague, an infection which has largely died out in China.\n\nAuthorities have isolated several villages nearby and activated a 3rd-degree epidemic alert in the region.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri 18 Jul 2014\nSource: South China Morning Post [edited]\nhttp://www.scmp.com/news/china/article/1556119/man-38-dies-pneumonic-plague-while-herding-gansu\n\n\nA 38-year-old man in the northwestern province of Gansu died of pneumonic plague on Wednesday, 16 Jul 2014, state media reported. More than 150 people who were in contact with the man have been quarantined, the provincial public health authority said in a news bulletin on its website. None of the quarantined has had any symptoms so far.\n\nThe man was diagnosed with the plague on Thursday, 17 Jul 2014. He became ill after having had close contact with a dead marmot while herding [livestock], the bulletin and Xinhua reported. The patient was taken to hospital in Yumen on Tuesday afternoon, 15 Jul 2014, after developing a high fever.\n\nYumen city, where the patient was being treated, and the man's home village and town along with the pasture where he worked were also in quarantine. Experts have been sent to the affected area. The patient's body was cremated, according to media reports.\n\nIn August 2009, China reported an outbreak of pneumonic plague in western Qinghai province after a herdsman died of high fever and hemoptysis (coughing up of blood from the respiratory tract), according to WHO records. The source of the outbreak in 2009 was also a wild marmot, the epidemiological investigation showed.\n\n[Byline: Kathy Gao]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following was taken from the moderator comment by JW in ProMED-mail post Plague, pneumonic, 2009 - China: (QH) follow up 20110109.0100:\n'The 2009 outbreak in Qinghai Province was reported in the literature in 2011 (Hu Wang et al: A dog-associated primary pneumonic plague in Qinghai Province, China. Clin Infect Dis. 2011;52: 185-190).\n\nThe outbreak was reported by ProMED in 2009 in a thread (see ProMED archives below) that ended with the report from WHO and a comment by ProMED that no further information regarding the patient, who was in critical condition, was available. This paper reports that the patient survived and that the index patient contracted pneumonic plague after carrying his dead dog on his shoulders around his neck for 400 meters to bury it [presumably bitten by infected fleas abandoning the dead dog. - Mod.JW]\n\nIt also clarifies statements in the WHO report that could have been misunderstood to mean that plague had been transmitted from the index case's corpse. To quote WHO: 'The 1st case was a 32-year-old male herdsman who developed fever and hemoptysis on 26 Jul 2009. He was referred to a hospital but died en route and was buried the following day. On 30 Jul 2009, 11 people who had close contact with the case (mainly relatives who attended the funeral) developed fever and cough and were all hospitalized. On 1 Aug 2009, specimens taken from all these 12 people, including the 1st case, tested positive for plague. On 2 Aug 2009, both the 64-year-old father-in-law of the index case and a 37-year-old male neighbor of the 1st case (who helped to bury the corpse) also died.'\n\nThe Chinese authors defined a close contact as 'a person who lived with or had face-to-face contact (within one meter) with the patient, and a direct contact as a person who once was together with a patient in the same room or in the same car with closed windows.'\n\nOnly the 11 close contacts became infected; none of 61 direct contacts became infected, and nobody who attended the funeral but had not previously been a close contact became infected. They also reported that most of the patients (6 of 11, excluding the index case) in this outbreak developed septicemic plague complicated with shock; 2 of 11 developed multiple organ failure, and 1 of 11 developed meningitis in addition to the plague pneumonia.'\n\nThe marmot is the most common reservoir for _Yersinia pestis_ in eastern Asia. The etymology of the term 'marmot' is uncertain (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marmot). It may have arisen from the Gallo-Romance prefix marm-, meaning to mumble or murmur (an example of onomatopoeia). Another possible origin is post-classical Latin, mus montanus, meaning 'mountain mouse.' - Mod.LL\n\nA photo of a Western child tourist with marmots (ground squirrels) in China is at\nhttp://english.peopledaily.com.cn/mediafile/201208/29/F201208290951362644423139.jpg - Mod.JW\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/333.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following was taken from the moderator comment by JW in ProMED-mail post Plague, pneumonic, 2009 - China: (QH) follow up 20110109.0100:\n'The 2009 outbreak in Qinghai Province was reported in the literature in 2011 ( They also reported that most of the patients (6 of 11, excluding the index case) in this outbreak developed septicemic plague complicated with shock; 2 of 11 developed multiple organ failure, and 1 of 11 developed meningitis in addition to the plague pneumonia.' Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n \n\nThe Chinese authors defined a close contact as 'a person who lived with or had face-to-face contact (within one meter) with the patient, and a direct contact as a person who once was together with a patient in the same room or in the same car with closed windows.' On 2 Aug 2009, both the 64-year-old father-in-law of the index case and a 37-year-old male neighbor of the 1st case (who helped to bury the corpse) also died.' This paper reports that the patient survived and that the index patient contracted pneumonic plague after carrying his dead dog on his shoulders around his neck for 400 meters to bury it [presumably bitten by infected fleas abandoning the dead dog. \n\nOnly the 11 close contacts became infected; none of 61 direct contacts became infected, and nobody who attended the funeral but had not previously been a close contact became infected. In August 2009, China reported an outbreak of pneumonic plague in western Qinghai province after a herdsman died of high fever and hemoptysis (coughing up of blood from the respiratory tract), according to WHO records. http://www.scmp.com/news/china/article/1556119/man-38-dies-pneumonic-plague-while-herding-gansu\n\n\nA 38-year-old man in the northwestern province of Gansu died of pneumonic plague on Wednesday, 16 Jul 2014, state media reported. \n\nThe outbreak was reported by ProMED in 2009 in a thread (see ProMED archives below) that ended with the report from WHO and a comment by ProMED that no further information regarding the patient, who was in critical condition, was available. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< To quote WHO: 'The 1st case was a 32-year-old male herdsman who developed fever and hemoptysis on 26 Jul 2009. On 1 Aug 2009, specimens taken from all these 12 people, including the 1st case, tested positive for plague.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-08-25 00:00:00", "2021-06-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-08-01 00:00:00", "2009-08-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Qinghai Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gansu", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yumen", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gansu Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Qinghai", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Plague", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2600593", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (02): (CO) pneumonic", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2600593", "date": "2014-07-10 13:31:38", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (02): (COLORADO) PNEUMONIC\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Wed 9 Jul 2014\nSource: 9NEWS, KUSA [edited]\nhttp://www.9news.com/story/news/local/2014/07/09/new-case-of-pneumonic-plague-in-colorado/12439709/\n\n\nIt's a disease carved into human history, with a deadly reputation. 'The plague is basically what's been here for centuries,' said 9NEWS Medical Expert Dr. John Torres. 'It's what caused the Black Death back in the Middle Ages.'\n\nEven though it doesn't kill people in large numbers like it once did, it is a serious disease. One man from Adams County [Colorado] is in the hospital recovering from a form of plague. The disease is part of the fabric of nature in Colorado now, found in rodents -- mainly prairie dogs. It's transmitted through the fleas they carry.\n\n'When the prairie dogs actually die, the fleas need somewhere to go. So once there is a prairie dog die-off, the fleas are out looking for somewhere to get a meal from,' said Jennifer House of the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment.\n\nIn the latest case, doctors discovered the owner of a dog contracted plague. Tests later showed the dog, which had died unexpectedly, also had the disease.\n\nThere are 3 types of plague; all can be potentially deadly, if not treated. The 1st is bubonic, which causes lymph nodes to swell. There is also septicemic, which comes about when the plague gets into the bloodstream. Finally, there is pneumonic, which is the kind the patient in Colorado has. Doctors said it can be especially worrisome. 'It's a type of pneumonia,' Dr. John said. 'It can be spread from person to person, and that's what makes it kind of scary and kind of dangerous.'\n\nThe Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment said there have been 12 cases of plague in Colorado in the past decade [2004-2014]. The last case of pneumonic plague was in 2004. 'In humans, it's actually become fairly rare,' House said. 'We don't see a lot of cases.'\n\nStill, experts said to protect yourself, insect repellent with DEET helps. They also recommend staying away from wildlife and making sure your pets do as well. The key is to make sure fleas that carry plague don't land on you.\n\nTo treat the plague, doctors give patients specific antimicrobial agents. As for how exactly the latest patient and the dog contracted the plague, the department of health said that was still under investigation.\n\n[Byline: Maya Rodriguez]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: 9 Jul 2014\nSource: Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment\nhttps://www.colorado.gov/pacific/cdphe/news-release-pneumonic-plague-found-colorado-resident-and-pet-dog\n\n\nThe Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment laboratory yesterday [8 Jul 2014] identified pneumonic plague in a Colorado resident. Investigation revealed the family dog had recently died unexpectedly. The carcass was recovered and tested at the Colorado State University Veterinarian Diagnostic Laboratory, where tests were positive for plague.\n\nTri-County Health Department officials and the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment are working together to investigate the source of exposure and to identify those who may have been exposed through close contact with the individual. Any individuals exposed will be recommended for antibiotic treatment.\n\nThe patient and the dog may have been exposed in eastern Adams County. Plague is spread from fleas on rodents, most commonly prairie dogs. People walking in open spaces and trails should avoid contact with rodents.\n\nDr. Jennifer House, public health veterinarian at the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment, encourages people take the following precautions to prevent plague exposure:\n\n- Do not directly handle any dead rodents.\n- Keep pets away from wildlife, especially dead rodents.\n- Don't let dogs or cats hunt prairie dogs or other rodents.\n- Don't allow pets to roam freely.\n- Treat all pets for fleas according to a veterinarian's advice.\n- Do not feed prairie dogs or other rodents - this attracts them to your property, brings them in close contact with other rodents and increases the risk of disease transmission.\n- Be aware of rodent populations in your area and report sudden die-offs or multiple dead animals to your local health department.\n\nContact your physician if you develop a high fever and other plague symptoms following a fleabite or direct contact with dead rodents. Symptoms of plague include a sudden onset of high fever, muscle pain, malaise, nausea and vomiting, or a general feeling of being ill. Individuals with bubonic plague will develop a large, swollen, painful lymph node in the area of a flea bite, usually in the groin or armpit. If untreated, the disease can enter the bloodstream or lungs, which are severe, life-threatening complications. Individuals with pneumonic plagues (the lung form) develop fever, headache, weakness, shortness of breath, chest pain, cough which can lead to respiratory failure. Pneumonic plague is the most serious form of the disease and is the only form of plague that can be spread from person to person (by infectious droplets from coughing). Although human cases occur infrequently, plague is severe and potentially life-threatening if not detected and quickly treated with common antibiotics.\n\nPlague often is identified when there is an unusual die-off of prairie dogs in an area. When an infected animal dies, the fleas leave the carcass to find another host, thus spreading the disease. Most human plague cases occur when humans are bitten by infected fleas. Less commonly, people are infected by direct contact with blood or tissues from an infected animal or from pets that become infected and transmit the disease. Since 1957, Colorado has identified 60 cases of human plague, 9 (15 percent) of which were fatal.\n\nAdditional information on plague can be found at: http://www.cdc.gov/plague\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most cases of _Yersinia pestis_ infections in the USA are reported from the 4 Corners area of the USA where the states of Colorado, Utah, Arizona, and New Mexico come together.\n\nAs outlined by the CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) and quoted in ProMED-mail post 20120601.1153277: 'Death from bubonic plague occurs after the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_ escapes from the infected bubo into the bloodstream (septicemic plague), causing the manifestations of the sepsis syndrome. Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) with subsequent cutaneous hemorrhage may well have been what was called the 'Black Death' in the Middle Ages. The bacterium can spread to the lungs, causing a secondary plague pneumonia (secondary to the bacteremia), or to the meninges, causing a plague meningitis. Both of these events have a high case fatality rate, and the secondary plague pneumonia is the way the infection spreads (by aerosol) from person to person.\n\n'The typical sign of the most common form of human plague is a swollen and very tender lymph gland, accompanied by pain. The swollen gland is called a 'bubo.' Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2 to 6 days after being infected.\n\n'When bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antibiotic therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. About 14 per cent (1 in 7) of all plague cases in the United States are fatal.'\n\nAdams County is the 5th most populous of the 64 counties of the US state of Colorado. As of the 2010 census, the population was 441 603. The county seat is Brighton. The county is named for Alva Adams, Governor of the State of Colorado.\n\nAdams County is part of the Denver-Aurora-Lakewood, CO Metropolitan Area and can be found on a map at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Map_of_Colorado_highlighting_Adams_County.svg. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4477.]", "summary": "\n\nAdditional information on plague can be found at: http://www.cdc.gov/plague\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n As outlined by the CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) and quoted in ProMED-mail post 20120601.1153277: 'Death from bubonic plague occurs after the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_ escapes from the infected bubo into the bloodstream (septicemic plague), causing the manifestations of the sepsis syndrome. \n\nDr. Jennifer House, public health veterinarian at the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment, encourages people take the following precautions to prevent plague exposure:\n\n- Do not directly handle any dead rodents. Pneumonic plague is the most serious form of the disease and is the only form of plague that can be spread from person to person (by infectious droplets from coughing). \n\n'When bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. \n\nContact your physician if you develop a high fever and other plague symptoms following a fleabite or direct contact with dead rodents. Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. The bacterium can spread to the lungs, causing a secondary plague pneumonia (secondary to the bacteremia), or to the meninges, causing a plague meningitis. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. Although human cases occur infrequently, plague is severe and potentially life-threatening if not detected and quickly treated with common antibiotics. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2 to 6 days after being infected. Individuals with bubonic plague will develop a large, swollen, painful lymph node in the area of a flea bite, usually in the groin or armpit. As for how exactly the latest patient and the dog contracted the plague, the department of health said that was still under investigation.
