The alert was declared to take action in the area and 'avoid there being more victims and to keep the illness from leading to pneumonic plague,' which, unlike bubonic plague, can be transmitted from person to person, Barrientos said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[_Yersinia pestis_ is endemic in parts of South America including the La Paz department of Bolivia.\n\nMost cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. The swollen gland is called a 'bubo.' Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2 to 6 days after being bitten.\n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antibiotic therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. At this stage, as appears to have happened in this posting, person-to-person spread can occur, causing other cases of 'primary' plague pneumonia. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6754.]", "summary": "The alert was declared to take action in the area and 'avoid there being more victims and to keep the illness from leading to pneumonic plague,' which, unlike bubonic plague, can be transmitted from person to person, Barrientos said. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. \n\nMost cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. \n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. \n\n\nBolivia's public health authorities declared the province [department] of La Paz on epidemiological alert owing to an outbreak of bubonic plague detected in communities along the border with Peru, the government said Tuesday, 1 Jul 2014.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Apolo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bolivia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Peru", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2430602", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA: (NM) pneumonic", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2430602", "date": "2014-04-25 20:39:23", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA: (NEW MEXICO) PNEUMONIC\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 25 Apr 2014\nFrom: Paul Ettestad <Paul.Ettestad@state.nm.us> [edited]\n\n\nBelow is the New Mexico Department of Health's press release that went out today, 25 Apr 2014. This is the 1st known human plague case in the USA in 2014. The case developed right axillary bubonic plague which progressed to secondary septicemic plague and then to secondary pneumonic plague. Potentially exposed friends, family members and hospital staff are being evaluated and offered antibiotic prophylaxis if indicated. An environmental investigation will be done to look for possible rodent die off in the area due to plague.\n\n'The New Mexico Department of Health (NMDOH) is reporting a case of plague in a 57-year-old man from Torrance County who is currently hospitalized in critical condition. Confirmatory testing is being conducted at the NMDOH's Scientific Laboratory Division. This is the 1st human case of plague in New Mexico and in the USA in 2014. An environmental investigation will take place at the man's home to look for ongoing risk to others in the surrounding area.\n\n'An epidemiologic investigation and an environmental investigation around the home of the plague case are being conducted by NMDOH staff to look for ongoing risk and to ensure the safety of the immediate family and neighbors,' said Department of Health Secretary Retta Ward, MPH. 'Staff will go door-to-door to neighbors near the case to inform them about plague found in the area and educate them on reducing their risk. Health care providers and others close to the patient who have been determined to have been exposed are taking preventive antibiotic therapy.'\n\nPlague is a bacterial disease of rodents and is generally transmitted to humans through the bites of infected fleas, but can also be transmitted by direct contact with infected animals, including rodents, wildlife and pets.\n\n'Plague cases have occurred every month of the year in New Mexico, but most cases usually occur in the summer months,' said Dr. Paul Ettestad, public health veterinarian for the Department of Health. 'It is especially important now that it is warming up to take precautions to avoid rodents and their fleas which can expose you to plague. Pets that are allowed to roam and hunt can bring infected fleas from dead rodents back into the home, putting you and your children at risk.'\n\nTo prevent plague, the Department of Health recommends:\n- Avoid sick or dead rodents and rabbits, and their nests and burrows.\n- Keep your pets from roaming and hunting\n- Talk to your veterinarian about using an appropriate flea control product on your pets as not all products are safe for cats, dogs, or your children.\n- Clean up areas near the house where rodents could live, such as woodpiles, brush piles, junk and abandoned vehicles.\n- Sick pets should be examined promptly by a veterinarian.\n- See your doctor about any unexplained illness involving a sudden and severe fever.\n- Put hay, wood, and compost piles as far as possible from your home.\n- Don't leave your pet's food and water where mice can get to it.\n\nSymptoms of plague in humans include sudden onset of fever, chills, headache, and weakness. In most cases there is a painful swelling of the lymph node in the groin, armpit or neck areas. Plague symptoms in cats and dogs are fever, lethargy and loss of appetite. There may be a swelling in the lymph node under the jaw. With prompt diagnosis and appropriate antibiotic treatment, the fatality rate in people and pets can be greatly reduced. Physicians who suspect plague should promptly report to NMDOH.\n\nIn New Mexico, there were 4 human plague cases in 2013 with 1 fatality, 1 human plague case in 2012, 2 human cases of plague in 2011, no cases in 2010, and 6 human cases of plague in 2009, 1 of them fatal.'\n\n--\nPaul Ettestad DVM, MS\nState Public Health Veterinarian\nEpidemiology and Response Division\nNew Mexico Department of Health\n<Paul.Ettestad@state.nm.us>\n\n[ProMED thanks Dr. Ettestad for this report.\n\nIndeed, the development of secondary pneumonic plague caused by _Yersinia pestis_ disseminating to the lungs causes the distinct potential of human-to-human transmission of the infection. Direct airborne spread of the plague bacillus to another human causes primary pneumonic plague with a high case fatality rate. As noted by Dr. Ettestad, appropriate chemoprophylaxis is indicated in exposed individuals. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/18327.]", "summary": "In New Mexico, there were 4 human plague cases in 2013 with 1 fatality, 1 human plague case in 2012, 2 human cases of plague in 2011, no cases in 2010, and 6 human cases of plague in 2009, 1 of them fatal.'\n\n--\nPaul Ettestad DVM, MS\n A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The case developed right axillary bubonic plague which progressed to secondary septicemic plague and then to secondary pneumonic plague. \n\n'An epidemiologic investigation and an environmental investigation around the home of the plague case are being conducted by NMDOH staff to look for ongoing risk and to ensure the safety of the immediate family and neighbors,' said Department of Health Secretary Retta Ward, MPH. Direct airborne spread of the plague bacillus to another human causes primary pneumonic plague with a high case fatality rate. \n\nTo prevent plague, the Department of Health recommends:\n- Avoid sick or dead rodents and rabbits, and their nests and burrows. Plague is a bacterial disease of rodents and is generally transmitted to humans through the bites of infected fleas, but can also be transmitted by direct contact with infected animals, including rodents, wildlife and pets. Indeed, the development of secondary pneumonic plague caused by _Yersinia pestis_ disseminating to the lungs causes the distinct potential of human-to-human transmission of the infection. \n\n'The New Mexico Department of Health (NMDOH) is reporting a case of plague in a 57-year-old man from Torrance County who is currently hospitalized in critical condition. Plague cases have occurred every month of the year in New Mexico, but most cases usually occur in the summer months,' said Dr. Paul Ettestad, public health veterinarian for the Department of Health. ' 'Staff will go door-to-door to neighbors near the case to inform them about plague found in the area and educate them on reducing their risk. - Keep your pets from roaming and hunting\n- Talk to your veterinarian about using an appropriate flea control product on your pets as not all products are safe for cats, dogs, or your children. State Public Health Veterinarian\nEpidemiology and Response Division\n \n\nSymptoms of plague in humans include sudden onset of fever, chills, headache, and weakness.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Torrance County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2151808", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Peru: (LL) bubonic", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2151808", "date": "2014-01-04 20:13:01", "main_text": "PLAGUE - PERU: (LA LIBERTAD) BUBONIC\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 3 Jan 2014\nSource: RPP, Peru [in Spanish, machine trans., edited]\nhttp://www.rpp.com.pe/2014-01-03-la-libertad-confirman-nuevo-caso-de-peste-bubonica-en-ascope-noticia_659216.html\n\n\nThe regional manager of health of La Libertad region, Jose Evangelista, reported a new case of bubonic plague in an adult woman who became infected in her house in the district of Casa Grande, in the province of Ascope.\n\nThe authority indicated that the woman is stable after receiving specialized care in the city of Trujillo. With this case, there are 6 confirmed cases of plague in La Libertad region. Among those infected there are 2, a doctor and a 9-year-old, infected with pneumonic plague, a 7-year-old who died for septicemic plague, and 2 other cases of bubonic plague detected in Ascope province.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague continues to occur sporadically in South America, especially the La Libertad region of Peru. - Mod.LL\n\nMaps of Peru can be seen at http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/americas/peru_pol91.jpg and http://healthmap.org/r/3ZKy. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Among those infected there are 2, a doctor and a 9-year-old, infected with pneumonic plague, a 7-year-old who died for septicemic plague, and 2 other cases of bubonic plague detected in Ascope province. PLAGUE - PERU: (LA LIBERTAD) BUBONIC\n************************************\n \n\n\nThe regional manager of health of La Libertad region, Jose Evangelista, reported a new case of bubonic plague in an adult woman who became infected in her house in the district of Casa Grande, in the province of Ascope. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "Peru", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "La Libertad", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ascope province", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2290976", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Madagascar", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2290976", "date": "2014-02-22 21:07:41", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR\n*******************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 20 Feb 2014\nSource: L'Express de Madagascar [in French, transl, edited]\nhttp://www.lexpressmada.com/blog/actualites/un-cas-de-peste-detecte-chaque-semaine-5286\n\n\nIs the plague outbreak on hold in Madagascar? Christophe Rogier, director of the Pasteur Institute in Madagascar, revealed information that was not reassuring in his progress report for the fight against the plague in prisons launched by the Ministry of Public Health, by the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) and by the prison administration.\n\n'The plague remains sporadic but is much more deadly than malaria. The disease can emerge in a locality where the epidemic has not yet hit, as was the case in Ambilobe in 2011. This sporadic case that was not contained can thus turn into an epidemic. We must be very careful because we get a case of plague each week all over the island,' said Christophe Rogier.\n\nThe main cause of the resurgence of the disease is not very clear. Some doctors argue that the bush fires are pushing the rats to seek refuge in the homes. They carry fleas infected by the plague, then transmit the disease to humans. This theory is in part true, says Christophe Rogier, but the people infected by the plague in Ambilobe lived in the forest in a mining site far from bush fires.\n\nOn the other hand, prisons which usually get a lot of cases of plague have not reported any cases yet. In 2012, thanks to the pest control campaign carried out by the ICRC in the prison of Antanimora, 1600 rats were caught. The short film, made by the ICRC to alert people to the fight against this disease, was a moving testimony for a different reason. The prisoners did not get infected by the plague, but the son of the district chief of Miari\u00adnarivo, Justin Tata.\n\n'Plague can infect the whole world. The change in behavior must be priority number one,' emphasized Christoph Vogt, regional head of delegation of the ICRC in the Indian Ocean.\n\nFaced with this situation, Philemon Tafangy, general secretary of the ministry of public health, accused other entities. 'Let's not only accuse the ministry of public health, but let's ask the right questions: Who should collect the trash so as not to attract the rats? Who is responsible for the lack of drugs in the health centers? Who is in charge of prohibiting bush fires in order not to disturb the natural habitat of rodents? Who should encourage people to go to health centers when they are sick?' he asked.\n\n[Byline: Vonjy Radasimalala]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague continues to occur on the island of Madagascar at a slow rate. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1kSe.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR\n*******************\n Christophe Rogier, director of the Pasteur Institute in Madagascar, revealed information that was not reassuring in his progress report for the fight against the plague in prisons launched by the Ministry of Public Health, by the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) and by the prison administration. This theory is in part true, says Christophe Rogier, but the people infected by the plague in Ambilobe lived in the forest in a mining site far from bush fires. \n\nOn the other hand, prisons which usually get a lot of cases of plague have not reported any cases yet. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague continues to occur on the island of Madagascar at a slow rate. \n\n'The plague remains sporadic but is much more deadly than malaria. [Byline: Vonjy Radasimalala]\n\n--\n \n\n'Plague can infect the whole world.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "malaria", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ambilobe", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Antanimora", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2370079", "headline": "PRO/AH> Plague - Europe: Medieval times, mode of transmission", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2370079", "date": "2014-03-31 20:08:29", "main_text": "PLAGUE - EUROPE: MEDIEVAL TIMES, MODE OF TRANSMISSION\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 29 Mar 2014\nSource: The Guardian/The Observer [edited]\nhttp://www.theguardian.com/science/2014/mar/29/black-death-not-spread-rat-fleas-london-plague\n\n\nArchaeologists and forensic scientists who have examined 25 skeletons unearthed in the Clerkenwell area of London a year ago [2013] believe they have uncovered the truth about the nature of the Black Death that ravaged Britain and Europe in the mid-14th century. Analysis of the bodies and of wills registered in London at the time has cast doubt on 'facts' that every schoolchild has learned for decades: that the epidemic was caused by a highly contagious strain spread by the fleas on rats. Now evidence taken from the human remains found in Charterhouse Square, to the north of the City of London, during excavations carried out as part of the construction of the Crossrail train line, have suggested a different cause: only an airborne infection could have spread so fast and killed so quickly.\n\nThe Black Death arrived in Britain from central Asia in the autumn of 1348 and by late spring the following year it had killed 6 out of every 10 people in London. Such a rate of destruction would kill 5 million now. By extracting the DNA of the disease bacterium, _Yersinia pestis_, from the largest teeth in some of the skulls retrieved from the square, the scientists were able to compare the strain of bubonic plague preserved there with that which was recently responsible for killing 60 people in Madagascar. To their surprise, the 14th-century strain, the cause of the most lethal catastrophe in recorded history, was no more virulent than today's disease. The DNA codes were an almost perfect match.\n\nAccording to scientists working at Public Health England in Porton Down, for any plague to spread at such a pace it must have got into the lungs of victims who were malnourished and then been spread by coughs and sneezes. It was therefore a pneumonic plague rather than a bubonic plague. Infection was spread human to human, rather than by rat fleas that bit a sick person and then bit another victim. 'As an explanation [rat fleas] for the Black Death in its own right, it simply isn't good enough. It cannot spread fast enough from one household to the next to cause the huge number of cases that we saw during the Black Death epidemics,' said Dr Tim Brooks from Porton Down, who will put his theory in a Channel 4 documentary, Secret History: The Return of the Black Death.\n\nTo support his argument, Brooks has looked at what happened in Suffolk in 1906 when plague killed a family and then spread to a neighbor who had come to help. The culprit was pneumonic plague, which had settled in the lungs of the victims and was spread through infected breath.\n\nThe skeletons at Charterhouse Square reveal that the population of London was also in generally poor health when the disease struck. Crossrail's archaeology contractor, Don Walker, and Jelena Bekvalacs of the Museum of London found evidence of rickets, anemia, bad teeth and childhood malnutrition.\n\nIn support of the case that this was a fast-acting, direct contagion, archaeologist Dr Barney Sloane found that in the medieval City of London all wills had to be registered at the Court of Hustings. These led him to believe that 60 percent of Londoners were wiped out.\n\nAntimicrobial agents can today prevent the disease from becoming pneumonic. In the spring of 1349, the death rate did not ease until Pentecost on 31 May.\n\n[Byline: Vanessa Thorpe]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nM. Randolph Kruger\n<memphisservices@bellsouth.net>\n\n[Given what I have read regarding the Black Death, it has always been my opinion that, although an epidemic of rodent flea-associated bubonic plague with septicemic plague occurred, many of the cases must have been transmitted from person to person by the respiratory route. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6010.]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nM. Randolph Kruger\n<memphisservices@bellsouth.net>\n\n[Given what I have read regarding the Black Death, it has always been my opinion that, although an epidemic of rodent flea-associated bubonic plague with septicemic plague occurred, many of the cases must have been transmitted from person to person by the respiratory route. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n By extracting the DNA of the disease bacterium, _Yersinia pestis_, from the largest teeth in some of the skulls retrieved from the square, the scientists were able to compare the strain of bubonic plague preserved there with that which was recently responsible for killing 60 people in Madagascar. \n\nTo support his argument, Brooks has looked at what happened in Suffolk in 1906 when plague killed a family and then spread to a neighbor who had come to help. Now evidence taken from the human remains found in Charterhouse Square, to the north of the City of London, during excavations carried out as part of the construction of the Crossrail train line, have suggested a different cause: only an airborne infection could have spread so fast and killed so quickly. According to scientists working at Public Health England in Porton Down, for any plague to spread at such a pace it must have got into the lungs of victims who were malnourished and then been spread by coughs and sneezes. Analysis of the bodies and of wills registered in London at the time has cast doubt on 'facts' that every schoolchild has learned for decades: that the epidemic was caused by a highly contagious strain spread by the fleas on rats. Infection was spread human to human, rather than by rat fleas that bit a sick person and then bit another victim. ' It cannot spread fast enough from one household to the next to cause the huge number of cases that we saw during the Black Death epidemics,' said Dr Tim Brooks from Porton Down, who will put his theory in a Channel 4 documentary, Secret History: The Return of the Black Death. The culprit was pneumonic plague, which had settled in the lungs of the victims and was spread through infected breath. http://www.theguardian.com/science/2014/mar/29/black-death-not-spread-rat-fleas-london-plague\n\n\nArchaeologists and forensic scientists who have examined 25 skeletons unearthed in the Clerkenwell area of London a year ago [2013] believe they have uncovered the truth about the nature of the Black Death that ravaged Britain and Europe in the mid-14th century. [Byline: Vanessa Thorpe]\n\n--\n It was therefore a pneumonic plague rather than a bubonic plague. \n\nAntimicrobial agents can today prevent the disease from becoming pneumonic. To their surprise, the 14th-century strain, the cause of the most lethal catastrophe in recorded history, was no more virulent than today's disease. PLAGUE - EUROPE: MEDIEVAL TIMES, MODE OF TRANSMISSION\n In the spring of 1349, the death rate did not ease until Pentecost on 31 May.\n\n In support of the case that this was a fast-acting, direct contagion, archaeologist Dr Barney Sloane found that in the medieval City of London all wills had to be registered at the Court of Hustings. LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6010.] Crossrail's archaeology contractor, Don Walker, and Jelena Bekvalacs of the Museum of London found evidence of rickets, anemia, bad teeth and childhood malnutrition. Date: Sat 29 Mar 2014\n The skeletons at Charterhouse Square reveal that the population of London was also in generally poor health when the disease struck. The Observer [edited]\n **\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1906-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "1348-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Charterhouse Square", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Britain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the City of London", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Suffolk", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "London", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Porton Down", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2257050", "headline": "PRO> Plague (02): genetic analysis, Justinian plague bacillus, comment", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2257050", "date": "2014-02-05 17:08:08", "main_text": "PLAGUE (02): GENETIC ANALYSIS, JUSTINIAN PLAGUE BACILLUS, COMMENT\n*****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Mon 3 Feb 2014\nFrom: Wendy Orent-Goldman <orentw@bellsouth.net> [edited]\n\n\nReality is not as that described. That the genetics of the Justinian plague were different from the Black Death proves nothing, except that more than one plague strain has the power to provoke -- under the right circumstances -- a pandemic. Nothing new in that. Plague with pandemic potential has been out there in Central Asia for centuries. There were 3 separate huge outbreaks of pneumonic plague in Manchuria in the early 20th century, which killed a total of 85 000 people. But a worldwide pandemic never broke out, even without antibiotics, because the intelligent doctors who rushed into Manchuria imposed ultimately successful quarantines. Otherwise, at least one of those outbreaks could have reached Peking [Beijing], and that could have been nasty indeed, though a worldwide pandemic on the scale of the Black Death still would have been most unlikely. As the great plague doctor Wu Lien-teh said, no disease is so susceptible to quarantine as plague. And he was speaking of the worst form of plague, pneumonic plague.\n\nThe Justinian plague, unlike the Black Death, was probably never very communicable -- there is no evidence of contagion from any of the primary sources. The Prophet Muhammad, who witnessed later stages of the pandemic, noted its random pattern -- that plague appeared to strike out of nowhere -- and concluded that the disease was God's gift. During the Black Death, Muslim physicians who witnessed contagion and insisted the disease spread through contact got into serious trouble for contradicting the Prophet. But they were observing a different disease pattern altogether than the one Muhammad saw. The Justinian plague seems to have rat- and rat-flea-borne bubonic plague, which was fostered by the immense storehouses of grain erected by Emperor Justinian, and by the grain trade across the Mediterranean from the great grain-growing regions of North Africa, from where it 1st burst into humanity. The Central Asian origins of the Justinian plague remain quite likely -- though there is nothing new in this observation: to gerbils and grass rats, Asia and Africa are one long habitat. The Justinian plague was most parallel to the plague outbreak in India in the early 20th century, which followed the same pattern: random 'strikes' not shared in households, and no evidence of contagion. This is what the late plague expert Robert Pollitzer called 'zoonotic plague' as opposed to the 'demic' plague of the Black Death and the Manchurian outbreaks, which is human-to-human borne.\n\nAnyone studying the Justinian plague and the Black Death would have realized that, given the pattern of transmission alone, these were very different outbreaks, and therefore had to be very different genetically. Proving this tells us nothing, since the researchers cannot possibly pinpoint which genetic changes signal human-to human transmission.\n\nThe most important point is that social conditions on earth have changed so dramatically that it is impossible to imagine, except in the case of a bioterrorist using the right plague strain with the genetic potential to transmit immediately lung-to-lung (and good luck with that -- the Soviets knew how to identify those strains, but at this point the likelihood of a bioterrorist repeating their discoveries seems vanishingly small) and then adding in antibiotic resistance. But that sort of plague outbreak could be handled with quarantine.\n\nA natural Black Death? Seriously -- does anybody believe this? People would be immediately isolated and treated with antibiotics, as happens in Central Asia all the time. It's also important to remember that the Black Death wasn't just pneumonic, it was bubonic also. And this wouldn't be the rat-rat-flea pattern seen in the Justinian Plague. This was 'demic' bubonic plague, spread by the so-called human flea, _Pulex irritans_. Both those conditions, uncontrolled pneumonic plague and human-to-human flea-borne transmission via _P. irritans_, were necessary to produce the Black Death. So was ignorance, and filth, and the updated Mongolian Silk Road, which provided rapid transportation out of Central Asia.\n\nAnother Black Death? Most unlikely.\n\nOh, and by the way, the Athenian plague (as even a cursory look at Thucydides would reveal) was not, and could not have been, the plague; that outbreak -- complete with secondary outbreaks of Brill-Zinsser's -- disease was almost certainly typhus. And the Antonine plague -- probably smallpox or measles -- wasn't caused by _Yersinia pestis_ either.\n\n_Y. pestis_ is still out there in rodents, as it has been for millennia. I wouldn't lose any sleep over it.\n\n--\nWendy Orent-Goldman\nLecturer, Emory University\nAtlanta, Georgia\nUSA\n<orentw@bellsouth.net>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue 4 Feb 2014\nFrom: Hugh Baker <drhugh@sympatico.ca> [edited]\n\n\nAt the beginning of the 20th century, the prevailing epidemiology was that the Mongol hoards brought the plague with them, the famine that stimulated the Mongol migration west having driven together the various grain-hungry vectors required for a pandemic of _Yersinia pestis_. This point of view was partly driven by anti-Chinese politics of the time.\n\nToward the end of the 20th century, there was some thought that the Romans imported the plague accidentally into the Mediterranean area by their incessant exploration of central Africa looking for ivory. The deeper into the forest the searches penetrated, the more they were exposed to the wild rodent vector of the bacillus, thus allowing the ship-board rats to acquire the fleas of the rodents of the deep forest. Due to the habit of burying at sea crew or passengers that died in transit, it took a while for human cases to manifest in Roman cities. If this scenario is true, it is probable that the Mongols took the plague BACK to the Far East, thus introducing it to a naive population.\n\nThat the Justinian strain and the Hong Kong strain are so significantly different may be an example of isolation of a population and allowing it to diverge by rapid expansion into a new niche.\n\n--\nHugh J Baker, DVM\nEtobicoke, Ontario\nCanada\n<drhugh@sympatico.ca>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks the authors for their comments. The thread is cut. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "\nWendy Orent-Goldman\nLecturer, Emory University\nAtlanta, Georgia\nUSA\n<orentw@bellsouth.net>\n\n******\n A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n This is what the late plague expert Robert Pollitzer called 'zoonotic plague' as opposed to the 'demic' plague of the Black Death and the Manchurian outbreaks, which is human-to-human borne. \n\nThe most important point is that social conditions on earth have changed so dramatically that it is impossible to imagine, except in the case of a bioterrorist using the right plague strain with the genetic potential to transmit immediately lung-to-lung (and good luck with that -- the Soviets knew how to identify those strains, but at this point the likelihood of a bioterrorist repeating their discoveries seems vanishingly small) and then adding in antibiotic resistance. That the genetics of the Justinian plague were different from the Black Death proves nothing, except that more than one plague strain has the power to provoke -- under the right circumstances -- a pandemic. Oh, and by the way, the Athenian plague (as even a cursory look at Thucydides would reveal) was not, and could not have been, the plague; that outbreak -- complete with secondary outbreaks of Brill-Zinsser's -- disease was almost certainly typhus. PLAGUE (02): GENETIC ANALYSIS, JUSTINIAN PLAGUE BACILLUS, COMMENT\n*****************************************************************\n The Justinian plague was most parallel to the plague outbreak in India in the early 20th century, which followed the same pattern: random 'strikes' not shared in households, and no evidence of contagion. The Prophet Muhammad, who witnessed later stages of the pandemic, noted its random pattern -- that plague appeared to strike out of nowhere -- and concluded that the disease was God's gift. As the great plague doctor Wu Lien-teh said, no disease is so susceptible to quarantine as plague. \n\nAnyone studying the Justinian plague and the Black Death would have realized that, given the pattern of transmission alone, these were very different outbreaks, and therefore had to be very different genetically. \n\n--\nHugh J Baker, DVM\n and rat-flea-borne bubonic plague, which was fostered by the immense storehouses of grain erected by Emperor Justinian, and by the grain trade across the Mediterranean from the great grain-growing regions of North Africa, from where it 1st burst into humanity. Both those conditions, uncontrolled pneumonic plague and human-to-human flea-borne transmission via _P. irritans_, were necessary to produce the Black Death. At the beginning of the 20th century, the prevailing epidemiology was that the Mongol hoards brought the plague with them, the famine that stimulated the Mongol migration west having driven together the various grain-hungry vectors required for a pandemic of _Yersinia pestis_. And the Antonine plague -- probably smallpox or measles -- wasn't caused by _Yersinia pestis_ either. And he was speaking of the worst form of plague, pneumonic plague. Etobicoke, Ontario\nCanada\n<drhugh@sympatico.ca>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks the authors for their comments.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "measles", "plague", "smallpox"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2014-02-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "North Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Manchuria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2242145", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague: Genetic analysis, Justinian plague bacillus", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2242145", "date": "2014-02-02 23:42:22", "main_text": "PLAGUE: GENETIC ANALYSIS, JUSTINIAN PLAGUE BACILLUS\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 28 Jan 2014\nSource: The Mirror [edited]\nhttp://www.mirror.co.uk/news/technology-science/bubonic-plague-deadly-black-death-3068411\n\n\nA strain of bubonic plague as deadly as that which caused the Black Death could make a reappearance on Earth, scientists have said in a stark warning. Research into one of the most devastating pandemics in human history - the Plague of Justinian, where half the world's population died - found evidence that such an episode could happen again. Scientists who isolated genetic traces of the plague from the teeth of 2 1500-year-old victims found it was caused by a distinctly different bacterial strain from that responsible for the later Black Death.\n\nBoth scourges were triggered by the bubonic plague bacterium, _Yersinia pestis_, which can be spread from rats [or other infected rodents - Mod. LL] to humans by fleas. The new research shows that the 2 infectious organisms were distinct strains. While the Justinian strain vanished from the Earth, the Black Death strain gave rise to another pandemic in the late 1800s. The discovery suggests that a new deadly strain of plague could strike again without warning.\n\nDr Dave Wagner, a member of the international team of scientists from Northern Arizona University in the USA, said: 'We know the bacterium _Y. pestis_ has jumped from rodents into humans throughout history and rodent reservoirs of plague still exist today in many parts of the world.\n\n'If the Justinian plague could erupt in the human population, cause a massive pandemic, and then die out, it suggests it could happen again. Fortunately we now have antibiotics that could be used to effectively treat plague, which lessens the chances of another large-scale human pandemic.' The Plague of Justinian struck in the 6th century and is estimated to have killed between 30 million and 50 million people as it spread across Asia, North Africa, the Middle East and Europe - virtually half the world's population at the time. Some 800 years later, the Black Death wiped out 50 million Europeans between 1347 and 1351.\n\nThe scientists managed to recover tiny DNA fragments of the bacterium from the teeth of two Justinian plague victims buried in Bavaria, Germany. From these short remnants they reconstructed the genome of the Justinian strain of _Y. pestis_ and compared it with a database of more than 100 contemporary strains.\n\nThe findings, published online in the journal The Lancet Infectious Diseases, revealed that the strain responsible for the Justinian plague was an evolutionary 'dead end'. It came, did its damage, and disappeared from the Earth, having no connection with the later Black Death.\n\nThe 19th century pandemic which spread across the globe from Hong Kong was a likely descendant of the more successful Black Death strain, said the scientists.\n\nExperts now think the Justinian strain of _Y. pestis_ originated in Asia, not in Africa as originally thought. But there was no molecular evidence of a link with earlier smaller epidemics such as the Plague of Athens in 430 BC and the Antonine Plague between the years 165 and 180.\nThese outbreaks could also represent separate, independent emergences of Y. pestis strains capable of infecting humans, it is believed.\n\n'This study raises intriguing questions about why a pathogen that was both so successful and so deadly died out,' said Australian co-author Dr Edward Holmes, from the University of Sydney. 'One testable possibility is that human populations evolved to become less susceptible.'\n\n[Byline: Jessica Best]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED Rapporteur Kunihiko Iizuka\n\n\n\n[The paper highlighted is : Wagner DM, lunkheads J, Harbeck M, et al: Yersinia pestis and the Plague of Justinian 541--543 AD: a genomic analysis. Lancet Infectious Diseases.doi:10.1016/S1473-3099(13)70323-2; [Abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24480148:]\n\nBackground\n----------\n_Yersinia pestis_ has caused at least three human plague pandemics. The second (Black Death, 14--17th centuries) and third (19--20th centuries) have been genetically characterised, but there is only a limited understanding of the first pandemic, the Plague of Justinian (6--8th centuries). To address this gap, we sequenced and analysed draft genomes of _Y. pestis_ obtained from two individuals who died in the first pandemic.\n\nMethods\n-------\nTeeth were removed from two individuals (known as A120 and A76) from the early medieval Aschheim-Bajuwarenring cemetery (Aschheim, Bavaria, Germany). We isolated DNA from the teeth using a modified phenol-chloroform method. We screened DNA extracts for the presence of the _Y. pestis_ specific pla gene on the pPCP1 plasmid using primers and standards from an established assay, enriched the DNA, and then sequenced it. We reconstructed draft genomes of the infectious _Y. pestis_ strains, compared them with a database of genomes from 131 _Y. pestis_ strains from the second and third pandemics, and constructed a maximum likelihood phylogenetic tree.\n\nFindings\n-------\nRadiocarbon dating of both individuals (A120 to 533 AD [plus or minus 98 years]; A76 to 504 AD [plus or minus 61 years]) places them in the timeframe of the first pandemic. Our phylogeny contains a novel branch (100 percent bootstrap at all relevant nodes) leading to the two Justinian samples. This branch has no known contemporary representatives, and thus is either extinct or unsampled in wild rodent reservoirs. The Justinian branch is interleaved between two extant groups, 0.ANT1 and 0.ANT2, and is distant from strains associated with the second and third pandemics.\n\nInterpretation\n------------\nWe conclude that the _Y. pestis_ lineages that caused the Plague of Justinian and the Black Death 800 years later were independent emergences from rodents into human beings. These results show that rodent species worldwide represent important reservoirs for the repeated emergence of diverse lineages of _Y. pestis_ into human populations.\n\nOnce again, this is another study that underscores how Mother Nature remains the World's best bioterrorist. with MERS-CoV, influenza H5N1 and H7N9, and others, she continues to challenge us. This moderator hopes that a more virulent plague strain will not be part of her handiwork.- mod. LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n We reconstructed draft genomes of the infectious _Y. pestis_ strains, compared them with a database of genomes from 131 _Y. pestis_ strains from the second and third pandemics, and constructed a maximum likelihood phylogenetic tree. We conclude that the _Y. pestis_ lineages that caused the Plague of Justinian and the Black Death 800 years later were independent emergences from rodents into human beings. \n\nBoth scourges were triggered by the bubonic plague bacterium, _Yersinia pestis_, which can be spread from rats [or other infected rodents - Mod. Scientists who isolated genetic traces of the plague from the teeth of 2 1500-year-old victims found it was caused by a distinctly different bacterial strain from that responsible for the later Black Death. said: 'We know the bacterium _Y. pestis_ has jumped from rodents into humans throughout history and rodent reservoirs of plague still exist today in many parts of the world. \n\n[Byline: Jessica Best]\n\n--\n \n\n'If the Justinian plague could erupt in the human population, cause a massive pandemic, and then die out, it suggests it could happen again. Lancet Infectious Diseases.doi:10.1016/S1473-3099(13)70323-2; [Abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24480148:]\n\nBackground\n Research into one of the most devastating pandemics in human history - the Plague of Justinian, where half the world's population died - found evidence that such an episode could happen again. \n\nExperts now think the Justinian strain of _Y. pestis_ originated in Asia, not in Africa as originally thought. PLAGUE: GENETIC ANALYSIS, JUSTINIAN PLAGUE BACILLUS\n \n\n\nA strain of bubonic plague as deadly as that which caused the Black Death could make a reappearance on Earth, scientists have said in a stark warning. From these short remnants they reconstructed the genome of the Justinian strain of _Y. pestis_ and compared it with a database of more than 100 contemporary strains. The Plague of Justinian struck in the 6th century and is estimated to have killed between 30 million and 50 million people as it spread across Asia, North Africa, the Middle East and Europe - virtually half the world's population at the time. Methods\n-------\n The second (Black Death, 14--17th centuries) and third (19--20th centuries) have been genetically characterised, but there is only a limited understanding of the first pandemic, the Plague of Justinian (6--8th centuries). Yersinia pestis_ has caused at least three human plague pandemics. These results show that rodent species worldwide represent important reservoirs for the repeated emergence of diverse lineages of _Y. pestis_ into human populations. Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nRedclaw crayfish (_Cherax quadricarinatus_) / 224017 / 160017 / 148217 / 0 / 0\nOutbreak statistics:\nSpecies / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nRedclaw crayfish (_Cherax quadricarinatus_) / 71.43 percent / 66.16 percent / 92.63 percent / 66.16 percent\n* Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and / or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: the crayfish plague infection, which is notifiable to the OIE, was detected on 5 crayfish farms in the process of passive surveillance (reported cases) and identified as _Aphanomyces astaci_ infection. Movement restriction was implemented on the infected farms. The clinical and epidemiological investigations of surrounding crayfish farms were conducted. No other case or evidence of crayfish plague infection was detected.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: quarantine; movement control inside the country; disinfection of infected premises / establishment (s); surveillance outside containment and / or buffer zone; no vaccination; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results:\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNational Pingtung University of Science and Technology (local laboratory) / Redclaw crayfish (_Cherax quadricarinatus_) / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 6 Dec 2013 / Positive\nNational Pingtung University of Science and Technology (local laboratory) / Redclaw crayfish (_Cherax quadricarinatus_) / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 9 Dec 2013 / Positive\nNational Pingtung University of Science and Technology (local laboratory) / Redclaw crayfish (_Cherax quadricarinatus_) / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 9 Jan 2014 / Positive\nAnimal Health Research Institute (AHRI) (national laboratory) / Redclaw crayfish (_Cherax quadricarinatus_) / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 17 Feb 2014 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is resolved. No more reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of the outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The aetiological agent of crayfish plague is _Aphanomyces astaci_, a member of a group of organisms commonly known as the water moulds. Although long regarded to be fungi, this group, the Oomycetida, are now considered protists and are classified with diatoms and brown algae in a group called the Stramenopiles or Chromista.\n\nFor the above and additional background information, including diagnostic methods, and references please refer to the OIE Aquatic Manual 2013, Chapter 2.2.1 Crayfish plague (_Aphanomyces astaci_) at http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/aahm/current/2.2.01_CRAYFISH_PLAGUE.pdf.\n\nOIE's internationally agreed requirements pertaining to crayfish plague (_Aphanomyces astaci_) are spelled out in chapter 9.1 of OIE's Aquatic Animal Health Code, available at http://www.oie.int/index.php?id=171&L=0&htmfile=chapitre_1.9.1.htm.\n\nFor background on crayfish plague see also commentaries in ProMED-mail archive nos. 20131216.2118609 and 20131022.2013248.\n\nRedclaw (_Cherax quadricarinatus_) is a freshwater crayfish native to parts of northern Australia and Papua New Guinea. Redclaw has also been grown in New Zealand, Southeast Asia, Africa, Central and South America, and the US.\n\nThey are often called 'freshwater lobsters' for their physical resemblance and large size -- red claw can grow to over one pound (454 g; http://www.ncagr.gov/markets/aquaculture/aussieredclawcrayfish.pdf and http://www.dpi.nsw.gov.au/fisheries/pests-diseases/freshwater-pests/species/redclaw).\n\nRedclaw are tolerant of a broad range of environmental conditions, have a simple reproductive cycle and fast growth rates which has generated interest in the species for commercial aquaculture and ornamental aquarium use.\n\nThe name 'redclaw' comes from the fact that mature male specimens display distinctive red patches on the claws. The male is larger than the female reaching a maximum of 25 cm (9.8 in) in length and weight up to 600 g (1.3 lb). In their native range, redclaw inhabit a diversity of freshwater habitats including still ponds, small creeks, isolated rock pools, and fast flowing rivers (http://www.dpi.nsw.gov.au/fisheries/pests-diseases/freshwater-pests/species/redclaw).\n\nRedclaw (_Cherax quadricarinatus_) photos can be seen at http://www.fao.org/fishery/culturedspecies/Cherax_quadricarinatus/en#tcNA003F.\n\nMaps of Taiwan are available at http://www.ephotopix.com/taiwan_admin_map.html and http://healthmap.org/r/1ob5. - ["2014-01-28 00:00:00", "2014-01-08 00:00:00", "2014-01-09 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2014-02-18 00:00:00", "2014-02-17 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Changhua City", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2130918", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Madagascar (04)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2130918", "date": "2013-12-23 18:24:10", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (04)\n************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 20 Dec 2013\nSource: UN Integrated Regional Information Networks (IRIN) News [edited]\nhttp://www.irinnews.org/report/99370/plague-in-madagascar\n\n\nThe bubonic plague season arrived in Madagascar earlier than usual in 2013, and with it an apparently greater prevalence of a more deadly manifestation of the disease.\n\nBetween September and December 2013, the health ministry reported 42 known deaths and 84 cases from the illness in 4 of the country's 112 districts. The cases have been recorded at various geographical locations: Mandritsara in the north, Soanierana Ivongo in the [northeast], Ikongo in the southwest, and Tsiroanomandidy in the central highlands.\n\nDr Voahangy Ravaoalimalala, vice-director of the Malagasy Institut Pasteur, which performs pathogen tests for the health ministry in Antananarivo, told IRIN: 'Bubonic plague can be treated easily with antibiotics, but this time some cases of pneumonic plague have also been identified. This form of plague is harder to treat, as it can kill people within 3 days.'\n\nMost cases of the 3 common plague forms are bubonic. Between 2 and 8 days after exposure, the patient develops fever and chills, as well as the [painful] swelling of lymph nodes -- the buboes -- to which the bacteria move and where they multiply. The 2nd is septicemic plague, with a fatality rate of 50 percent -- higher than bubonic --, and the 3rd is pneumonic plague, which is fatal in all cases unless the patient is given antibiotics as soon as the symptoms appear.\n\nThe health ministry notes that between 300 and 600 cases of bubonic plague occur annually in Madagascar, usually between October and March. Despite some anxiety in the capital, Antananarivo, and local media reports that there was a suspected case of plague in Manjakandriana, 20 km [12.4 mi] from the densely populated city, the cases and fatalities have occurred in fairly isolated areas. 2 weeks ago, officials announced Antananarivo's coffers were empty and there was no money to spare for rubbish collection. Refuse has been piling up in the city, encouraging the spread of rats and mice. The UN Development Programme (UNDP) and the European Union (EU) have donated money and equipment, and have mobilized volunteers to assist in clearing the city of garbage.\n\nAccording to the WHO, 21 725 persons were infected with plague worldwide in the 1st decade of the 21st century, accounting for 1612 deaths and a case fatality rate of 7.4 percent.\n\nIn many countries the disease has retreated as a result of access to medication, rodent-proof housing and better urban hygiene, but living conditions in Madagascar's highland villages -- where people often store their rice crops in their homes -- attract rats and make the country more prone to plague outbreaks. According to WHO, bubonic plague is endemic in many parts of Africa, and 'the most heavily affected African countries are the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Madagascar, Mozambique, Uganda and Tanzania.'\n\nPlague is thought to have arrived in Madagascar in 1898, carried by infected rats on ships from India. As a result of vaccination campaigns, improved housing and public hygiene, and the discovery of streptomycin and the use of insecticides, plague was brought under control in the 1950s.\n\nDuring the next 30 years, only 20 to 50 cases per year were reported in Madagascar, but since 1989 the number of suspected cases has increased steadily.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The numbers in this UN IRIN report differ slightly from previous reports of the current _Yersinia pestis_ infection situation on the island nation of Madagascar. The report does contribute some background information about plague there. - Mod.LL\n\nMaps of Madagascar can be seen at http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/madagascar/mar2582r/madagascar_pol.jpg and http://healthmap.org/r/1kSe. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "The 2nd is septicemic plague, with a fatality rate of 50 percent -- higher than bubonic --, and the 3rd is pneumonic plague, which is fatal in all cases unless the patient is given antibiotics as soon as the symptoms appear. \n\nDr Voahangy Ravaoalimalala, vice-director of the Malagasy Institut Pasteur, which performs pathogen tests for the health ministry in Antananarivo, told IRIN: 'Bubonic plague can be treated easily with antibiotics, but this time some cases of pneumonic plague have also been identified. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n In many countries the disease has retreated as a result of access to medication, rodent-proof housing and better urban hygiene, but living conditions in Madagascar's highland villages -- where people often store their rice crops in their homes -- attract rats and make the country more prone to plague outbreaks. \n\nThe health ministry notes that between 300 and 600 cases of bubonic plague occur annually in Madagascar, usually between October and March. Despite some anxiety in the capital, Antananarivo, and local media reports that there was a suspected case of plague in Manjakandriana, 20 km [12.4 mi] from the densely populated city, the cases and fatalities have occurred in fairly isolated areas. \n\nDuring the next 30 years, only 20 to 50 cases per year were reported in Madagascar, but since 1989 the number of suspected cases has increased steadily. \n\nMost cases of the 3 common plague forms are bubonic. \n\nBetween September and December 2013, the health ministry reported 42 known deaths and 84 cases from the illness in 4 of the country's 112 districts. According to the WHO, 21 725 persons were infected with plague worldwide in the 1st decade of the 21st century, accounting for 1612 deaths and a case fatality rate of 7.4 percent. According to WHO, bubonic plague is endemic in many parts of Africa, and 'the most heavily affected African countries are the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Madagascar, Mozambique, Uganda and Tanzania.'\n\n The bubonic plague season arrived in Madagascar earlier than usual in 2013, and with it an apparently greater prevalence of a more deadly manifestation of the disease. Between 2 and 8 days after exposure, the patient develops fever and chills, as well as the [painful] swelling of lymph nodes -- the buboes -- to which the bacteria move and where they multiply. As a result of vaccination campaigns, improved housing and public hygiene, and the discovery of streptomycin and the use of insecticides, plague was brought under control in the 1950s. \n\n--\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The numbers in this UN IRIN report differ slightly from previous reports of the current _Yersinia pestis_ infection situation on the island nation of Madagascar. PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (04)\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1612-03-25 00:00:00", "1898-03-25 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00", "1989-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tanzania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Manjakandriana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of the", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2114475", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Madagascar (03): pneumonic, more cases and fatalities", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2114475", "date": "2013-12-13 17:21:43", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (03): PNEUMONIC, MORE CASES AND FATALITIES\n**************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 13 Dec 2013\nSource: New Straits Times, Agence France-Presse (AFP) report [edited]\nhttp://www.nst.com.my/latest/39-dead-from-plague-in-madagascar-government-1.430852\n\n\nA plague spread by rats [via their fleas] has killed 39 people in recent weeks in Madagascar, the health ministry said Thursday, 12 Dec 2013. 'There is an epidemic in Madagascar which is currently affecting 5 districts (out of 112). 86 people have been afflicted by the illness, of which 39 have died,' said the ministry in a statement read to AFP.\n\nA doctor in the ministry in Antananarivo said 90 percent of the cases were diagnosed as pneumonic plague, a lethal form, which can kill within 3 days, leaving little time for antimicrobials to work.\n\nThe 1st person died before November 2013 but government only officially declared the existence of a plague on 23 Nov 2013. According to the doctor, who cannot be named because he does not have clearance to speak to the media, the 1st case was registered in a village in the remote [district] of Mandritsara [Sofia region].\n\nAffected districts are in the north, northeast, southeast and the center of the island nation.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most cases of plague are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. The swollen gland is called a 'bubo.' Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2 to 6 days after being bitten.\n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may produce bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antibiotic therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. At this stage, as appears to have happened in this outbreak, person-to-person spread can occur, causing other cases of 'primary' plague pneumonia. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1kSe.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most cases of plague are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. \n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. It is a 17-year-old, according to the regional manager of health, Jose Evangelista. Therefore, a health brigade came to the area to conduct a campaign to prevent the plague bacteria from spreading.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[_Yersinia pestis_ is endemic in parts of Peru, especially the La Libertad region in the provinces of Trujillo and Ascope. In 2010, the Pan American Health Organization (PAHO) reported at least 27 cases in an outbreak and 4 deaths.\n\nMost cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. The swollen gland is called a 'bubo.' Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2 to 6 days after being bitten.\n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness.
