'We are waiting for the laboratory tests of 6 other people that were evaluated for some symptoms of infection with the plague bacillus, _Yersinia pestis_. One of the new infected is a worker in a funeral home.'\n\nOf the confirmed cases, unfortunately one died: a 17 year old girl who lived in a sector of the town of Visnea Mocanera, in the district of Casa Grande, in the province of Ascope. The Health Authority explained that due to ignorance, the deceased with plague was taken from the morgue of the Regional Teaching Hospital in Trujillo (HRDT) and subsequently transferred to a funeral home, where a worker of the funeral home who manipulated the corpse was infected with the bacterium.\n\nA 68 year old woman and her husband are thought to have pneumonic plague in addition to a doctor who became infected when providing medical care to some of those cases.\n\nOf the 6 confirmed cases, 4 were in the province of Ascope, while a person contracted the plague in the Regional Hospital and the other is of an unclear source.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Clusters of pneumonic plague are now occurring in northern Peru as well as in Madagascar [Plague - Madagascar (03): pneumonic, more cases and fatalities 20131213.2114475]. Secondary spread of plague appears to have occurred in the community as well as nosocomially to a physician. Hopefully, by prompt isolation, identification, and treatment of new cases, the outbreak can be quickly contained. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/1z-z.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Clusters of pneumonic plague are now occurring in northern Peru as well as in Madagascar [Plague - Madagascar (03): pneumonic, more cases and fatalities 20131213.2114475]. PLAGUE - PERU (02): (LA LIBERTAD) PNEUMONIC\n*******************************************\n The Health Authority explained that due to ignorance, the deceased with plague was taken from the morgue of the Regional Teaching Hospital in Trujillo (HRDT) and subsequently transferred to a funeral home, where a worker of the funeral home who manipulated the corpse was infected with the bacterium.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "La Libertad", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Visnea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Peru", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2104065", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Madagascar (02): (SF) fatalities", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2104065", "date": "2013-12-10 19:44:15", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (02): (SOFIA), FATALITIES\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 10 Dec 2013\nSource: BBC [edited]\nhttp://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-25324011\n\n\nA village in Madagascar has been hit by a deadly outbreak of the bubonic plague, medical experts on the island have confirmed. Tests were carried out after at least 20 people in the village, near the northwestern town of Mandritsara, were reported to have died last week.\n\nThe International Committee of the Red Cross warned in October 2013 that Madagascar was at risk of a plague epidemic.\n\nThe disease is transmitted to humans via fleas, usually from rats, and is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_. Essentially a disease of wild rodents spread by fleas, plague spreads to humans either by the bite of infected fleas or rats and does not spread from person to person. Patients develop swollen, tender lymph glands (called buboes) and fever, headache, chills, and weakness. It is treatable if caught early but can be lethal.\n\nIn 2012, Madagascar had 60 deaths from the plague, the world's highest recorded number. The Pasteur Institute of Madagascar confirmed on Tue 10 Dec 2013 that tests taken from bodies in the village last week showed that they had died of the bubonic plague.\n\nThe BBC's Tim Healy in the capital, Antananarivo, says health officials have now gone to the remote area to investigate.\n\nThe Pasteur Institute said there were concerns that the disease could spread to towns and cities where living standards have declined since a coup in 2009 and the ensuing political crisis.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is caused by the _Yersinia pestis_ bacillus, carried by rat fleas. At the start of the rainy season, currently, rats flee the sewers of Madagascar in massive numbers and take refuge in people's cottages. [The following paragraph of this posting is from 1998 (Chanteau S, Ratsifasoamanana L, Rasoamanana B, et al: Plague, a Reemerging Disease in Madagascar. Emerg Infect Dis 1998; 4: 101-4:; http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/4/1/98-0114_article.htm]:\n\n'Between 1930 and 1990, bubonic plague had 'virtually disappeared' on the island due to efficient pest-control and good health management. However, since 1990, an annual 200 cases are being reported, and bubonic plague takes on epidemic form, especially in the port of Mahajanga each year. In the capital city of Antananarivo, more cases are also being notified each year since 1990. Madagascar (pop. 13 million) has accounted for 45 percent of all the cases of plague in Africa.'\n\nFatalities related to plague usually are caused by spread of the organism from the bubo (the very painful infected lymph node which drains the area where the flea bite occurred) to the bloodstream. The bacteremia [presence of bacteria in the blood] can cause a coagulopathy [clotting disorder, an impairment of the blood's ability to clot] producing the purpura [red or purple discolorations on the skin] seen in the 'Black Plague' and can also spread to the lungs, causing a hemorrhagic pneumonia. It is the pneumonia that can facilitate person-to-person transmission.\n\nMadagascar was the location of the isolation of multi-antimicrobial resistant _Y. pestis_ in 1995 (Galimand M, Guiyoule A, Gerbaud G, et al: Multidrug resistance in _Yersinia pestis_ mediated by a transferable plasmid. N Engl J Med 1997; 337(10): 677-80; http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJM199709043371004). The strain was resistant to chloramphenicol, streptomycin, and tetracycline but sensitive to fluoroquinolones and trimethoprim as well as other aminoglycosides. This was an ominous observation; however, it is not clear whether this naturally occurring strain has persisted or spread. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1kSe.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is caused by the _Yersinia pestis_ bacillus, carried by rat fleas. Essentially a disease of wild rodents spread by fleas, plague spreads to humans either by the bite of infected fleas or rats and does not spread from person to person. Emerg Infect Dis 1998; 4: 101-4:; http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/4/1/98-0114_article.htm]:\n\n'Between 1930 and 1990, bubonic plague had 'virtually disappeared' on the island due to efficient pest-control and good health management. The bacteremia [presence of bacteria in the blood] can cause a coagulopathy [clotting disorder, an impairment of the blood's ability to clot] producing the purpura [red or purple discolorations on the skin] seen in the 'Black Plague' and can also spread to the lungs, causing a hemorrhagic pneumonia. Fatalities related to plague usually are caused by spread of the organism from the bubo (the very painful infected lymph node which drains the area where the flea bite occurred) to the bloodstream. \n\nThe disease is transmitted to humans via fleas, usually from rats, and is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_. \n\nMadagascar was the location of the isolation of multi-antimicrobial resistant _Y. pestis_ in 1995 (Galimand M, Guiyoule A, Gerbaud G, et al: Multidrug resistance in _Yersinia pestis_ mediated by a transferable plasmid. PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (02): (SOFIA), FATALITIES\n*********************************************\n \n\nThe Pasteur Institute said there were concerns that the disease could spread to towns and cities where living standards have declined since a coup in 2009 and the ensuing political crisis. The Pasteur Institute of Madagascar confirmed on Tue 10 Dec 2013 that tests taken from bodies in the village last week showed that they had died of the bubonic plague.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "1990-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1995-03-25 00:00:00", "1998-03-25 00:00:00", "2013-10-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Rasoamanana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mahajanga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mandritsara", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2118609", "headline": "PRO/AH> Crayfish plague - Israel: (HM) OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2118609", "date": "2013-12-16 16:39:19", "main_text": "CRAYFISH PLAGUE - ISRAEL: (HAMERKAZ), OIE\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 15 Dec 2013\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2013; 26(51) [summ., edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=14532\n\n\nCrayfish plague (_Aphanomyces astaci_), Israel\n---------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 15 Dec 2013 from Dr Nadav Galon, director, Veterinary Services and Animal Health, Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development, Bet Dagan, Israel\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 1 Apr 2013\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 29 Nov 2013\nReason for notification: 1st occurrence of a listed disease\nManifestation of disease: sub-clinical disease\nCausal agent: _Aphanomyces astaci_\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to the whole country\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nOutbreak 1: Bet Yizhaq Sh. Hefer, HaSharon, HaMerkaz\nDate of start of the outbreak: 1 Apr 2013\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nWater type: fresh water\nPopulation type: farmed\nProduction system: closed\nAffected population: the population is reared in a closed system. No clinical signs have been seen.\nTotal animals affected:\nOf 50 000 susceptible crayfish (_Procambarus alleni_) the number of cases has not been calculated because of missing information. Ther have been no deaths, none hve been destroyed or slaughtered.\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: quarantine, movement control inside the country, no vaccination, no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nPolymerase chain reaction (PCR) and real-time PCR carried out on crayfish (_Procambarus alleni_) on 29 Nov 2013 at the Experimental Zooprophylactic Institute (Venezie), Fish Pathology Department (foreign laboratory) yielded positive results.\n\nFuture reporting: the event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\nThe location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The aetiological agent of crayfish plague is _Aphanomyces astaci_. _A. astaci_ is a member of a group of organisms commonly known as the water moulds. Although long regarded as fungi, this group, the Oomycetida, are now considered protists and are classified with diatoms and brown algae in a group called the Stramenopiles or Chromista.\n\nThe 1st reports of large crayfish mortalities go back to 1860 in Italy. These were followed by further reports of crayfish mortalities, where no other aquatic species were affected, in the Franco-German border region in the 3rd quarter of the 19th century. From there a steady spread of infection occurred, principally in 2 directions: down the Danube into the Balkans and towards the Black Sea, and across the North German plain into Russia and from there south to the Black Sea and north west to Finland and, in 1907, to Sweden. In the 1960s, the 1st outbreaks in Spain were reported, and in the 1980s further extensions of infection to the British Isles, Turkey, Greece and Norway followed. The reservoir of the original infections in the 19th century was never established; _Orconectes_ spp. were not known to have been introduced until the 1890s, but the post-1960s extensions are largely linked to movements of North American crayfish introduced more recently for purposes of crayfish farming. Escapes of such introduced species were almost impossible to prevent, and _Pacifastacus leniusculus_ and _Procambarus clarkii_ are now widely naturalised in many parts of Europe.\n\nTo date, all species of freshwater crayfish have to be considered as susceptible to infection with _Aphanomyces astaci_.\n\nThe target tissue that becomes initially infected is the exoskeleton cuticle. Soft cuticle, as is found on the ventral abdomen and around joints, is preferentially affected. In the highly susceptible European crayfish species, the pathogen often manages to penetrate the basal lamina located underneath the epidermis cell layer. From there, _A. astaci_ spreads throughout the body primarily by invading connective tissue and haemal sinuses; however, all tissues may be affected.\n\nFor the above and additional background information, including diagnostic methods, and references, please refer to the OIE Aquatic Manual 2013, Chapter 2.2.1, Crayfish plague (_Aphanomyces astaci_), at http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/aahm/current/2.2.01_CRAYFISH_PLAGUE.pdf.\n\nSee also commentary in ProMED-mail post 20131022.2013248.\n\nInfected animals may show clinical signs; however, infection may be present in the absence of any signs. Pictures of lesions of crayfish plague can be seen at http://library.enaca.org/Health/FieldGuide/html/cp001cra.htm. - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/9wPl.]", "summary": "Reason for notification: 1st occurrence of a listed disease\nManifestation of disease: sub-clinical disease\nCausal agent: _Aphanomyces astaci_\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (advanced)\n A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< 15 Dec 2013 from Dr Nadav Galon, director, Veterinary Services and Animal Health, Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development, Bet Dagan, Israel\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\n Dec 2013\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2013; 26(51) [summ., edited]\n Epidemiological unit: farm\nWater type: fresh water\n Population type: farmed\nProduction system: closed\n Total animals affected:\nOf 50 000 susceptible crayfish (_Procambarus alleni_) the number of cases has not been calculated because of missing information. Although long regarded to be fungi, this group, the Oomycetida, are now considered protists and are classified with diatoms and brown algae in a group called the Stramenopiles or Chromista.\n\nFor the above and additional background information including diagnostic methods and references, please refer to the OIE Aquatic Manual 2013, Chapter 2.2.1 Crayfish plague (_Aphanomyces astaci_), at http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/aahm/current/2.2.01_CRAYFISH_PLAGUE.pdf.\n\nOIE's internationally agreed upon requirements pertaining to crayfish plague (_Aphanomyces astaci_) are spelled out in chapter 9.1 of OIE's Aquatic Animal Health Code, available at http://www.oie.int/index.php?id=171&L=0&htmfile=chapitre_1.9.1.htm. According to the information found in the WAHID database under the section 'List of countries by sanitary situation' http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statuslist, 102 of 178 OIE Member Countries have provided some information related to crayfish plague (this information is based on the most recent 6-monthly report sent by the countries). Of these 102 countries, the disease was reported as 'never occurred' in 77, 'absent' in 22, 'suspected' in one (Denmark), and as 'demonstrated clinical disease' in 2 (Finland and Czech Republic).\n\nA map showing the distribution of disease in domestic and/or wild species can be obtained at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/Diseasedistributionmap. 26(43) [edited]\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "1977-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Norway", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chromista", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WAHID", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denmark", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lierne", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Czech Republic", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Finland", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2035269", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (04): (NM) fatality", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2035269", "date": "2013-11-02 20:10:27", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (04): (NEW MEXICO) FATALITY\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 1 Nov 2013\nSource: KRWG [edited]\nhttp://krwg.org/post/department-health-reports-fatal-plague-case-bernalillo-county-man\n\n\nThe New Mexico Department of Health announced today, 1 Nov 2013, a fatal case of plague in an 80-year-old man from Bernalillo County. Confirmatory testing was performed at the Department's Scientific Laboratory Division. This is the 4th human case of plague in New Mexico and in the USA in 2013. An environmental investigation by the Urban Biology Division of the City of Albuquerque Environmental Health Department will take place at the man's home to look for ongoing risk to others in the surrounding area.\n\n'The Department of Health will work with health care providers and others close to the patient to determine if they have been exposed to plague and require preventive treatment,' said Department of Health Secretary Retta Ward, MPH. 'As winter approaches, it's important for families to keep wood piles -- where rodents can live -- as far away from your home as possible.'\n\n'People living in areas known to have plague should ensure that their dogs and cats are treated year-round with flea control. This will help prevent domestic animals from bringing plague-infected fleas into the home,' said Dr. Paul Smith with the City of Albuquerque Environmental Health Department.\n\n'Though the peak of plague activity is during the summer months from May to August, we have had human plague cases in New Mexico every month of the year,' said Dr. Paul Ettestad, public health veterinarian at the Department of Health. 'Taking precautions year-round should be a routine that everyone takes seriously.'\n\nWith prompt diagnosis and appropriate antibiotic treatment, the fatality rate in people and pets can be greatly reduced. Physicians who suspect plague should promptly report to the New Mexico Department of Health.\n\nThe 1st 3 human plague cases in New Mexico in 2013 were in a 15-year-old boy and an 11-year-old girl, both from Torrance County; and a 52-year-old man from Santa Fe County. All 3 have recovered. There was one human plague case in New Mexico in 2012, 2 human cases of plague in 2011, no cases in 2010, and 6 human cases of plague in 2009, one of them fatal.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most cases of _Yersinia pestis_ infections in the USA are reported from the Four Corners area of the USA where the states of Colorado, Utah, Arizona, and New Mexico come together.\n\nAs outlined by the CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) and quoted in ProMED-mail post 20120601.1153277: 'Death from bubonic plague occurs after the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_ escapes from the infected bubo into the bloodstream (septicemic plague) causing the manifestations of the sepsis syndrome. Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) with subsequent cutaneous hemorrhage may well have been what was called the 'Black Death' in the Middle Ages. The bacterium can spread to the lungs, causing a secondary plague pneumonia (secondary to the bacteremia), or to the meninges, causing a plague meningitis. Both of these events have a high case fatality rate and the secondary plague pneumonia is the way the infection spreads (by aerosol) from person to person.\n\n'The typical sign of the most common form of human plague is a swollen and very tender lymph gland, accompanied by pain. The swollen gland is called a 'bubo.' Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2 to 6 days after being infected.\n\n'When bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antibiotic therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. About 14 per cent (1 in 7) of all plague cases in the United States are fatal.' - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/90Xf.]", "summary": "There was one human plague case in New Mexico in 2012, 2 human cases of plague in 2011, no cases in 2010, and 6 human cases of plague in 2009, one of them fatal. As outlined by the CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) and quoted in ProMED-mail post 20120601.1153277: 'Death from bubonic plague occurs after the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_ escapes from the infected bubo into the bloodstream (septicemic plague) causing the manifestations of the sepsis syndrome. The 1st 3 human plague cases in New Mexico in 2013 were in a 15-year-old boy and an 11-year-old girl, both from Torrance County; and a 52-year-old man from Santa Fe County. Though the peak of plague activity is during the summer months from May to August, we have had human plague cases in New Mexico every month of the year,' said Dr. Paul Ettestad, public health veterinarian at the Department of Health. ' The bacterium can spread to the lungs, causing a secondary plague pneumonia (secondary to the bacteremia), or to the meninges, causing a plague meningitis. \n\n'When bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. \n\n'The typical sign of the most common form of human plague is a swollen and very tender lymph gland, accompanied by pain. The New Mexico Department of Health announced today, 1 Nov 2013, a fatal case of plague in an 80-year-old man from Bernalillo County. \n\n'The Department of Health will work with health care providers and others close to the patient to determine if they have been exposed to plague and require preventive treatment,' said Department of Health Secretary Retta Ward, MPH. '", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bernalillo County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the City of Albuquerque Environmental Health Department", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Torrance County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santa Fe County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1972093", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (03): (NM) bubonic", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1972093", "date": "2013-09-27 17:15:45", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (03): (NEW MEXICO), BUBONIC\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 26 Sep 2013\nFrom: Dr. Paul Ettestad\nNew Mexico Department of Health [edited]\nhttp://www.health.state.nm.us/CommunicationsOffice/2013%20News%20Releases/NMDOH-PressRelease-20130926-Plague-EN.pdf\n\n\nThe New Mexico Department of Health announced today, 26 Sep 2013, a confirmed case of plague in a 52-year-old man from Santa Fe County. Confirmatory testing was performed at the Department's Scientific Laboratory Division. This is the 3rd human case of plague in New Mexico and in the USA in 2013. An environmental investigation will take place at the man's home to look for ongoing risk to others in the surrounding area.\n\n'Whenever there is a human case of plague the Department takes several steps to ensure the safety of the immediate family, neighbors, and health care providers,' said Department of Health Secretary Retta Ward, MPH. 'We inform neighbors door-to-door about plague found in the area and educate them on reducing their risk. We determine whether individuals close to the patient may also have been exposed to the plague and recommend preventative treatment when necessary.'\n\nPlague is a bacterial disease of rodents and is generally transmitted to humans through the bites of infected fleas, but can also be transmitted by direct contact with infected animals, including rodents, wildlife and pets.\n\n'We are seeing plague activity in several different locations of north-central New Mexico,' said Dr. Paul Ettestad, public health veterinarian at the Department of Health. 'Everyone needs to be aware of the situation and take precautions to avoid rodents and their fleas.'\n\nSymptoms of plague in humans include sudden onset of fever, chills, headache, and weakness. In most cases there is a painful swelling of the lymph node in the groin, armpit or neck areas. Plague symptoms in cats and dogs are fever, lethargy and loss of appetite. There may be a swelling in the lymph node under the jaw. With prompt diagnosis and appropriate antibiotic treatment, the fatality rate in people and pets can be greatly reduced. Physicians who suspect plague should promptly report to the New Mexico Department of Health.\n\nThe 1st 2 human plague cases in New Mexico this year [2013] were in a 15-year-old boy and an 11-year-old girl, both from Torrance County. Both have recovered. There was one human plague case in New Mexico in 2012, 2 human cases of plague in 2011, no cases in 2010, and 6 human cases of plague in 2009, one of them fatal.\n\nFor more information, including fact sheets in English and Spanish, go to the Department of Health's website at: http://nmhealth.org/ERD/HealthData/plague.shtml.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDr. Paul Ettestad\nNew Mexico Department of Health\n<Paul.Ettestad@state.nm.us>\n\n[ProMED once again thanks Dr Paul Ettestad, New Mexico State Veterinarian, for this posting. Dr. Ettestad added:\n\n'All 3 of the human cases in New Mexico this year presented with inguinal buboes [enlargements of the lymph nodes in the groin area]. All 3 have recovered. The peak of cases in New Mexico is usually in the summer months of June and July, but with all of the recent rains in the area, fleas are able to survive longer outside of rodent burrows while questing for a blood meal.' - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/2o_v.]", "summary": "There was one human plague case in New Mexico in 2012, 2 human cases of plague in 2011, no cases in 2010, and 6 human cases of plague in 2009, one of them fatal. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The 1st 2 human plague cases in New Mexico this year [2013] were in a 15-year-old boy and an 11-year-old girl, both from Torrance County. \n\nPlague is a bacterial disease of rodents and is generally transmitted to humans through the bites of infected fleas, but can also be transmitted by direct contact with infected animals, including rodents, wildlife and pets. \n\n'Whenever there is a human case of plague the Department takes several steps to ensure the safety of the immediate family, neighbors, and health care providers,' said Department of Health Secretary Retta Ward, MPH. Dr. Ettestad added:\n\n'All 3 of the human cases in New Mexico this year presented with inguinal buboes [enlargements of the lymph nodes in the groin area]. For more information, including fact sheets in English and Spanish, go to the Department of Health's website at: http://nmhealth.org/ERD/HealthData/plague.shtml.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\n Everyone needs to be aware of the situation and take precautions to avoid rodents and their fleas.'\n\nSymptoms of plague in humans include sudden onset of fever, chills, headache, and weakness. http://www.health.state.nm.us/CommunicationsOffice/2013%20News%20Releases/NMDOH-PressRelease-20130926-Plague-EN.pdf\n\n\nThe New Mexico Department of Health announced today, 26 Sep 2013, a confirmed case of plague in a 52-year-old man from Santa Fe County. \n\n'We are seeing plague activity in several different locations of north-central New Mexico,' said Dr. Paul Ettestad, public health veterinarian at the Department of Health. '", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-01-02 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santa Fe County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico State Veterinarian", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Torrance County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1958625", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Coral reef kill - Caribbean: virus associated with white plague", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1958625", "date": "2013-09-21 23:48:00", "main_text": "CORAL REEF KILL - CARIBBEAN: VIRUS ASSOCIATED WITH WHITE PLAGUE\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 14 Sep 2013\nSource: KVAL.com, Oregon State News & Research Communications report [edited]\nhttp://www.kval.com/news/local/OSU-White-plague-coral-deaths-caused-by-viruses-223510711.html\n\n\nThey call it the 'white plague,' and like its black counterpart from the Middle Ages, it conjures up visions of catastrophic death, with a cause that was at first uncertain even as it led to widespread destruction -- on marine corals in the Caribbean Sea.\n\nNow one of the possible causes of this growing disease epidemic has been identified -- a group of viruses that are known as small, circular, single-strand DNA (or SCSD) viruses. Researchers in the College of Science at Oregon State University [OSU] say these SCSD viruses are associated with a dramatic increase in the white plague that has erupted in recent decades.\n\nPrior to this, it had been believed that the white plague was caused primarily by bacterial pathogens. Researchers are anxious to learn more about this disease and possible ways to prevent it, because its impact on coral reef health has exploded.\n\n'20 years ago you had to look pretty hard to find any occurrences of this disease, and now it's everywhere,' said Nitzan Soffer, a doctoral student in the Department of Microbiology at OSU and lead author on a new study just published in the International Society for Microbial Ecology. 'It moves fast and can wipe out a small coral colony in a few days.\n\n'In recent years the white plague has killed 70-80 percent of some coral reefs,' Soffer said. 'There are 20 or more unknown pathogens that affect corals and in the past we've too-often overlooked the role of viruses, which sometimes can spread very fast.'\n\nThis is one of the 1st studies to show viral association with a severe disease epidemic, scientists said. It was supported by the National Science Foundation.\n\nMarine wildlife diseases are increasing in prevalence, the researchers pointed out. Reports of non-bleaching coral disease have increased more than 50 times since 1965, and are contributing to declines in coral abundance and cover.\n\nWhite plague is one of the worst. It causes rapid tissue loss, affects many species of coral, and can cause partial or total colony mortality. Some, but not all types are associated with bacteria. Now it appears that viruses also play a role. Corals with white plague disease have higher viral diversity than their healthy counterparts, the study concluded.\n\nIncreasing temperatures that stress corals and make them more vulnerable may be part of the equation, because the disease often appears to be at its worst by the end of summer.\n\nOverfishing that allows more algae to grow on corals may help spread pathogens, researchers said, as can pollution caused by sewage outflows in some marine habitats.\n\nViral infection, by itself, does not necessarily cause major problems, the researchers noted. Many healthy corals are infected with herpes-like viruses that are persistent but not fatal, as in many other vertebrate hosts, including humans.\n\n[Byline: David Stauth]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the Caribbean, corals suffer 4 common diseases: Caribbean coral disease, yellow-band disease, dark-spot syndrome and white-plague disease. Recent modelling work suggested that these diseases do not follow a contagious-disease model. Coral diseases may have multiple interacting causes. Coral reefs worldwide are threatened by increasing anthropogenic stressors, particularly overfishing and the problems associated with global climate change. Coral disease is recognized as another problem causing the degradation of reefs, which is demonstrated by a global increase in the numbers of coral diseases, coral species affected and disease outbreaks. The hypothesis that most closely matches the data is that environmental thresholds are exceeded, and then these environmental conditions either weaken the corals, which are then more susceptible to infection, or the conditions increase the virulence or abundance of pathogens. Exceeding such environmental thresholds will most likely become increasingly common in rapidly warming oceans, leading to more frequent coral disease outbreaks, where diverse components of the parasite community will be implicated.\n\nA picture of a coral with white plague can be accessed at http://cdn.c.photoshelter.com/img-get/I0000gsabEkdmNIM/s/750/750/MPOFL294.jpg. - Mod. PMB\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/8vcv.]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the Caribbean, corals suffer 4 common diseases: Caribbean coral disease, yellow-band disease, dark-spot syndrome and white-plague disease. Coral disease is recognized as another problem causing the degradation of reefs, which is demonstrated by a global increase in the numbers of coral diseases, coral species affected and disease outbreaks. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n'In recent years the white plague has killed 70-80 percent of some coral reefs,' Soffer said. ' \n\n'20 years ago you had to look pretty hard to find any occurrences of this disease, and now it's everywhere,' said Nitzan Soffer, a doctoral student in the Department of Microbiology at OSU and lead author on a new study just published in the International Society for Microbial Ecology. ' \n\nIncreasing temperatures that stress corals and make them more vulnerable may be part of the equation, because the disease often appears to be at its worst by the end of summer. \n\nOverfishing that allows more algae to grow on corals may help spread pathogens, researchers said, as can pollution caused by sewage outflows in some marine habitats. Reports of non-bleaching coral disease have increased more than 50 times since 1965, and are contributing to declines in coral abundance and cover. Corals with white plague disease have higher viral diversity than their healthy counterparts, the study concluded. Exceeding such environmental thresholds will most likely become increasingly common in rapidly warming oceans, leading to more frequent coral disease outbreaks, where diverse components of the parasite community will be implicated. Now one of the possible causes of this growing disease epidemic has been identified -- a group of viruses that are known as small, circular, single-strand DNA (or SCSD) viruses. \n\nA picture of a coral with white plague can be accessed at http://cdn.c.photoshelter.com/img-get/I0000gsabEkdmNIM/s/750/750/MPOFL294.jpg. http://www.kval.com/news/local/OSU-White-plague-coral-deaths-caused-by-viruses-223510711.html\n\n\nThey call it the 'white plague,' and like its black counterpart from the Middle Ages, it conjures up visions of catastrophic death, with a cause that was at first uncertain even as it led to widespread destruction -- on marine corals in the Caribbean Sea.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1965-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "2009541", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Madagascar: prison, urban risk, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2009541", "date": "2013-10-19 14:13:47", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR: PRISON, URBAN RISK, ALERT\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 10 Oct 2013\nSource: BBC [edited]\nhttp://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-24461474\n\n\nMadagascar faces a bubonic plague epidemic unless it slows the spread of the disease, experts have warned. The Red Cross and Pasteur Institute say inmates in the island's rat-infested jails are particularly at risk.\n\nThe number of cases rises each October as hot humid weather attracts [promotes breeding of] fleas, which transmit the disease from rats and other animals to humans. Madagascar had 256 plague cases and 60 deaths in 2012, the world's highest recorded number.\n\nBubonic plague, known as the Black Death when it killed an estimated 25 million people in Europe during the Middle Ages, is now rare. Bubonic plague swept through Europe in the 14th Century, killing between one third and one half of the entire population. But the Black Death, as it was called, seemed to disappear some time in the 17th Century, and many people today assume it has died out completely. In fact bubonic plague remains a serious public health problem in many parts of the world. In Madagascar [and Mongolia and the western USA], plague is endemic in the animal population, and cannot be eradicated.\n\nThe prevalence of rats in Madagascar's prisons means the plague can spread easily. Fleas from plague-carrying rats infect prisoners, prison guards and visitors. And rats, unlike the prisoners, can go in and out of jail anytime. The threat to the general population is clear.\n\nOctober is regarded as the start of the plague season in Madagascar. The hot, humid weather means more fleas, and more risk of disease.\n\nThe International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) in Geneva and the Pasteur Institute have worked with local health groups in Madagascar since February 2012 on a campaign to improve prison hygiene. 'If the plague gets into prisons there could be a sort of atomic explosion of plague within the town. The prison walls will never prevent the plague from getting out and invading the rest of the town,' said the institute's Christophe Rogier.\n\nThe ICRC said the 3000 inmates of Antanimora, the main prison in the heart of the capital Antananarivo, live with a huge rat population which spreads infected fleas through food supplies, bedding, and clothing.\n\nThe ICRC's Evaristo Oliviera said this could affect not only inmates and staff, but others they come into contact with. 'A prison is not a sealed place, first of all the staff themselves who work in the prison are at risk, and they go home at the end of the day, already perhaps being a vector of the disease,' he told the BBC. 'Also the rats themselves, they can go in and out of the jail and also propagate the disease. And the prisoners do have visitors who can be also infected, and the prisoners eventually go out as well so we have many, many ins and outs for the disease to spread.'\n\nThe BBC's Imogen Foulkes in Geneva says the eradication project undertaken by the ICRC is tricky because simply killing the rats is not enough. To prevent their infected fleas transferring to another host, possibly a human, the insects must be destroyed as well as the rodents, she says.\n\nExperts say that Africa -- especially Madagascar and the Democratic Republic of Congo -- accounts for more than 90 percent of cases worldwide. During the last 20 years, at least 3 countries experienced outbreaks of human plague after dormant periods of about 30-50 years, experts say. These areas were India in 1994 and 2002, Indonesia in 1997 and Algeria in 2003. According to the WHO, the last significant outbreak of bubonic plague was in Peru in 2010 when 12 people were found to have been infected.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As yet, in 2013, there have been no reported cases of plague infection on the island nation of Madagascar [for 2012, see ProMED archives below].\n\nPlague is caused by the _Yersinia pestis_ bacillus, carried by rat fleas. At the start of the rainy season, currently, rats flee the sewers of Madagascar in massive numbers and take refuge in people's cottages. [The following paragraph of this posting is from 1998 (Chanteau S, Ratsifasoamanana L, Rasoamanana B, et al: Plague, a Reemerging Disease in Madagascar. Emerg Infect Dis 1998; 4(1): 101-4:; http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/4/1/98-0114_article.htm\n\n'Between 1930 and 1990, bubonic plague had 'virtually disappeared' on the island due to efficient pest-control and good health management. However since 1990, an annual 200 cases are being reported and bubonic plague takes on epidemic form especially in the port of Mahajanga each year. In the capital city of Antananarivo more cases are also being notified each year since 1990. Madagascar (pop. 13 million) has accounted for 45 percent of all the cases of plague in Africa.'\n\nFatalities related to plague usually are caused by spread of the organism from the bubo (the very painful infected lymph node which drains the area where the flea bite occurred) to the bloodstream. The bacteremia can cause a coagulopathy producing the purpura seen in the 'Black Plague' and also spread to the lungs causing a hemorrhagic pneumonia. It is the pneumonia that can facilitate person-to-person transmission.\n\nMadagascar was the location of the isolation of multi-antimicrobial resistant _Y. pestis_ in 1995 (Galimand M, Guiyoule A, Gerbaud G, et al: Multidrug resistance in _Yersinia pestis_ mediated by a transferable plasmid. N Engl J Med 1997; 337(10): 677-80; http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJM199709043371004). The strain was resistant to chloramphenicol, streptomycin, and tetracycline but sensitive to fluoroquinolones and trimethoprim as well as other aminoglycosides. This was an ominous observation; however, it is not clear if this naturally occurring strain has persisted or spread. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1kSe.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Emerg Infect Dis 1998; 4(1): 101-4:; http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/4/1/98-0114_article.htm\n\n'Between 1930 and 1990, bubonic plague had 'virtually disappeared' on the island due to efficient pest-control and good health management. \n\nThe ICRC said the 3000 inmates of Antanimora, the main prison in the heart of the capital Antananarivo, live with a huge rat population which spreads infected fleas through food supplies, bedding, and clothing. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As yet, in 2013, there have been no reported cases of plague infection on the island nation of Madagascar [for 2012, see ProMED archives below]. \n\nBubonic plague, known as the Black Death when it killed an estimated 25 million people in Europe during the Middle Ages, is now rare. Madagascar had 256 plague cases and 60 deaths in 2012, the world's highest recorded number.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1998-03-25 00:00:00", "1990-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "1994-03-25 00:00:00", "1997-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-02-25 00:00:00", "2002-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-10-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "1995-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Geneva", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Peru", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "India", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rasoamanana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Algeria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mahajanga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Indonesia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of Congo", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1971423", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, animal - USA (05): (CA) squirrel", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1971423", "date": "2013-09-27 11:24:08", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (05): (CALIFORNIA) SQUIRREL\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[ProMED-mail apologizes for the delay in posting. - Mod.MPP]\n\nDate: Tue 17 Sep 2013 [accessed 24 Sep 2013]\nSource: U-T San Diego [edited]\nhttp://www.utsandiego.com/news/2013/sep/17/plague-squirrel-campground-palomar/\n\n\n[San Diego] County public health officials warned campers Tuesday [17 Sep 2013] to stay away from common California ground squirrels after 3 of the rodents trapped at a Palomar Mountain campground tested positive for plague.\n\nChris Conlan, supervising vector ecologist for the San Diego County Vector Control Program, said the 3 plague squirrels were trapped at the Cedar Grove Campground inside Palomar Mountain State Park.\n\nThe county had already found 3 plague squirrels at Cedar Grove this year [2013] and one at nearby Doane Valley Campground in May, bringing the season total to 7. Though that number is higher than the 4 detected by county officials in 2012, it's less than the 9 squirrels that tested positive in 2008.\n\nConlan said the most common way to get plague is to be bitten by a flea that was living on an infected animal.\n\nTo avoid the disease, health officials caution against feeding, touching or camping near the burrows of wild animals. Touching sick or dead animals is also a risk, and household pets should be protected with flea control medication and kept out of areas where plague has been detected.\n\nThough the county detects a few plague-infected squirrels nearly every year, no human plague cases have been reported in San Diego County since 1926, though there have been cases elsewhere in the state.\n\nIn 2006, for example, a 28-year-old Los Angeles woman tested positive for plague after handling raw rabbit meat hunted in an area where plague fleas were present. She survived after treatment with 2 types of antibiotics.\n\nA study published by the California Department of Public Health states that there have been 62 human plague cases reported in California from 1926 to 2013. Of those, 39 survived and 23 died.\n\nSymptoms of plague infection include the sudden onset of fever and chills and tender, swollen lymph nodes. Those who experience these symptoms one week after visiting an area where plague was recently found should immediately contact their doctor.\n\n[Byline: Paul Sisson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations. Some species are particularly susceptible. For example, _Y. pestis_ caused the extinction of entire colonies of black-tailed prairie dogs. Small rodents such as deer mice and grasshopper mice are suggested to act as the reservoirs. Larger species like squirrels and chipmunks are considered to be more vulnerable to infection.\n\nA map of the affected area can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/8An8. - Mod.PMB]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[ProMED-mail apologizes for the delay in posting. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. Though the county detects a few plague-infected squirrels nearly every year, no human plague cases have been reported in San Diego County since 1926, though there have been cases elsewhere in the state. \n\nThe county had already found 3 plague squirrels at Cedar Grove this year [2013] and one at nearby Doane Valley Campground in May, bringing the season total to 7. \n\nChris Conlan, supervising vector ecologist for the San Diego County Vector Control Program, said the 3 plague squirrels were trapped at the Cedar Grove Campground inside Palomar Mountain State Park. In 2006, for example, a 28-year-old Los Angeles woman tested positive for plague after handling raw rabbit meat hunted in an area where plague fleas were present. USA (02): (NM) bubonic", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1935879", "date": "2013-09-10 23:13:11", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (02): (NEW MEXICO), BUBONIC\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 10 Sep 2013\nFrom: Paul Ettestad <Paul.Ettestad@state.nm.us> [edited]\n\n\nThe New Mexico Department of Health announced today, 10 Sep 2013, a probable case of plague in an 11-year-old girl from Torrance County.\n\nPreliminary test results at the Department's Scientific Laboratory Division were positive. Confirmatory testing is pending. This is the 2nd human case of plague in New Mexico and in the USA in 2013. An environmental investigation will take place at the girl's home to look for ongoing risk to others in the surrounding area.\n\n'Everyone needs to avoid sick or dead rodents and rabbits and their nests and burrows,' said Department of Health Secretary Retta Ward, MPH. 'Families should also talk to their veterinarian about an appropriate flea product for their pets.'\n\nPlague is a bacterial disease of rodents and is generally transmitted to humans through the bites of infected fleas but can also be transmitted by direct contact with infected animals, including rodents, wildlife and pets. 'Unfortunately, it is not possible to eradicate plague from the rodent population or to totally eliminate risk to residents who live in areas where there is plague,' said Dr. Paul Ettestad, public health veterinarian for the Department of Health. 'Education about how plague is transmitted to people and what steps can be taken to reduce your risk are key in preventing future cases of this potentially deadly disease.'\n\nTo prevent plague, the Department of Health also recommends:\n- Keep your pets from roaming and hunting.\n- Clean up areas near the house where rodents could live, such as woodpiles, brush piles, junk and abandoned vehicles.\n- Sick pets should be examined promptly by a veterinarian.\n- See your doctor about any unexplained illness involving a sudden and severe fever.\n- Put hay, wood, and compost piles as far as possible from your home.\n- Don't leave your pet's food and water where mice can get to it.\n\nSymptoms of plague in humans include sudden onset of fever, chills, headache, and weakness. In most cases, there is a painful swelling of the lymph node in the groin, armpit or neck areas. Plague symptoms in cats and dogs are fever, lethargy and loss of appetite. There may be a swelling in the lymph node under the jaw. With prompt diagnosis and appropriate antibiotic treatment, the fatality rate in people and pets can be greatly reduced. Physicians who suspect plague should promptly report to the New Mexico Department of Health.\n\nThe 1st human plague case in New Mexico this year [2013] was reported in August 2013 in a 15-year-old boy from Torrance County. There was one human plague case in New Mexico in 2012, 2 human cases of plague in 2011, no cases in 2010, and 6 human cases of plague in 2009, one of them fatal.\n\nThis case of bubonic plague (left femoral lymphadenopathy) had antibiotics prior to any cultures being done, so there was no growth on culture. The case had a significant titer on acute serology (1:128) and along with clinical findings meets the 'probable' national case definition. A follow up convalescent serology will be done and if there is a 4-fold increase in titer, this will confirm the case.\n\n--\nPaul Ettestad DVM, MS\nState Public Health Veterinarian\nEpidemiology and Response Division\nNew Mexico Department of Health\n<Paul.Ettestad@state.nm.us>\n\n[ProMED thanks Dr. Ettestad for the report and his comment.\n\nBoth USA cases in 2013 have occurred in the same New Mexico county. A county map of the state of New Mexico (http://nmhealth.org/ERD/HealthData/documents/HumanPlagueinNMbyCounty1949-2012.pdf) shows that the concentration of human plague cases in New Mexico (1949-2012) is in the northwestern part of the state. Most USA cases of human plague infection occur in the Four Corner states -- the southwestern states of New Mexico, Arizona, Utah, and Colorado -- although California and Oregon have reported cases in recent years. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/2o_v.]", "summary": "There was one human plague case in New Mexico in 2012, 2 human cases of plague in 2011, no cases in 2010, and 6 human cases of plague in 2009, one of them fatal. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The 1st human plague case in New Mexico this year [2013] was reported in August 2013 in a 15-year-old boy from Torrance County. Most USA cases of human plague infection occur in the Four Corner states -- the southwestern states of New Mexico, Arizona, Utah, and Colorado -- although California and Oregon have reported cases in recent years. \n\nTo prevent plague, the Department of Health also recommends:\n- Keep your pets from roaming and hunting. PLAGUE - USA (02): (NEW MEXICO), BUBONIC\n****************************************\n Unfortunately, it is not possible to eradicate plague from the rodent population or to totally eliminate risk to residents who live in areas where there is plague,' said Dr. Paul Ettestad, public health veterinarian for the Department of Health. ' Plague is a bacterial disease of rodents and is generally transmitted to humans through the bites of infected fleas but can also be transmitted by direct contact with infected animals, including rodents, wildlife and pets. ' \n\n--\nPaul Ettestad DVM, MS\n From: Paul Ettestad <Paul.Ettestad@state.nm.us> [edited]\n\n\nThe New Mexico Department of Health announced today, 10 Sep 2013, a probable case of plague in an 11-year-old girl from Torrance County. A county map of the state of New Mexico (http://nmhealth.org/ERD/HealthData/documents/HumanPlagueinNMbyCounty1949-2012.pdf) shows that the concentration of human plague cases in New Mexico (1949-2012) is in the northwestern part of the state. \n\nThis case of bubonic plague (left femoral lymphadenopathy) had antibiotics prior to any cultures being done, so there was no growth on culture.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2013-08-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2013-09-10 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Torrance County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1909839", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Kyrgyzstan: (YK) fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1909839", "date": "2013-08-29 10:27:11", "main_text": "PLAGUE - KYRGYZSTAN: (ISSYK KUL) FATAL\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 27 Aug 2013\nSource: Agence France-Presse (AFP) [edited]\nhttp://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5j7B5A6puttGZD9B2-Gvn-UcNeqcg?docId=CNG.eb497844a118d291deccabe9966d599a.4a1\n\n\nKyrgyzstan officials on Tuesday, 27 Aug 2013, scrambled to control the spread of bubonic plague that killed a rural boy last week as 3 more people showed possible symptoms of the disease. The easternmost district of Ak-Suu [Issyk Kul province] in the Central Asian country was on lockdown while police guarded the hospitals where 15-year-old was treated and died last Thursday, 22 Aug 2013. The emergency ministry said that 3 more people from the same village as the victim were hospitalized Tuesday, 27 Aug 2013, suspicion of being infected with the deadly disease.\n\n'Residents of Sary-Kamysh [Ak-Suu]... came to the hospital at 12:30 am,' the ministry said in a statement. 'They are now under medical care.'\nThe 3 new patients, a woman with a toddler, and a teenager, exhibited symptoms of bubonic plague, namely a fever and swollen lymph nodes in their armpit and neck areas, an informed Kyrgyzstan government source told AFP on condition of anonymity. 'They had contact with the deceased 15-year-old,' the source said. The health ministry however denied that any new patients have been infected.\n\nA herdboy from the village of Ichke-Zhergez [Ak-Suu], is thought to have become infected after being bitten by a flea carried by a marmot that he reportedly prepared for food. Officials had isolated 131 people as of Tuesday, 27 Aug 2013, to prevent the possible spread of the disease, said Asylbek Sydykanov, the ministry's public health official.\n\nEmergency officials have also gone door to door in the boy's village to look for possible victims of the infection, but did not find signs of the disease, the emergency ministry said.\n\nThe Ak-Suu district, which borders Kazakhstan and China, lies close to the Issyk-Kul Lake and is a popular tourist destination.\n\nKazakhstan said that it is stepping up preventive measures to stop any possible outbreak on its territory, introducing 'special monitoring' of people crossing the border from Kyrgyzstan. Kazakhstan's health ministry also warned its citizens against travelling to Kyrgyzstan 'until the epidemiological situation regarding the plague is stabilized'.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The description of the patients thought to have been infected by exposure to the initial, fatal case is that of classical bubonic plague spread by bites of infected fleas, not pneumonic plague which can be transmitted directly from person-to-person. It is therefore likely to be the case that the other cases were also acquired from flea bites and not from exposure to the teenager who died. The death is likely to have been caused by septicemia from the infection or pneumonia.\n\nDeath from bubonic plague occurs after the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_ escapes from the infected bubo into the bloodstream (septicemic plague) causing the manifestations of the sepsis syndrome. Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) with subsequent cutaneous hemorrhage may well have been what was called the 'Black Death' in the Middle Ages. The bacterium can spread to the lungs, causing a secondary plague pneumonia (secondary to the bacteremia), or to the meninges, causing a plague meningitis. Both of these events have a high case fatality rate and the secondary plague pneumonia is the way the infection spreads (by aerosol) from person to person.\n\nThe typical sign of the most common form of human plague is a swollen and very tender lymph gland, accompanied by pain. The swollen gland is called a 'bubo.' Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2 to 6 days after being infected.\n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antibiotic therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. About 14 per cent (1 in 7) of all plague cases in the United States are fatal.\n\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvbid/plague/resources/plagueFactSheet.pdf.\n\nThe marmot is the most common reservoir for _Yersinia pestis_ in eastern Asia. The etymology of the term 'marmot' is uncertain (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marmot). It may have arisen from the Gallo-Romance prefix marm-, meaning to mumble or murmur (an example of onomatopoeia). Another possible origin is post-classical Latin, mus montanus, meaning 'mountain mouse'. Marmots are hunted for their food and fur, and hunters get bitten by their infected fleas, or infected from their blood when skinning them. For a photo, see http://msnbcmedia.msn.com/j/streams%5C2012/August/120828%5C505846-tdy-120827-CATERS_Marmot_and_Boy_13.blocks_desktop_large.jpg.\n\nMaps of Kyrgyzstan can be seen at http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/commonwealth/kyrgyzstan_pol_05.jpg and http://healthmap.org/r/8azt. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The description of the patients thought to have been infected by exposure to the initial, fatal case is that of classical bubonic plague spread by bites of infected fleas, not pneumonic plague which can be transmitted directly from person-to-person. \n\nDeath from bubonic plague occurs after the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_ escapes from the infected bubo into the bloodstream (septicemic plague) causing the manifestations of the sepsis syndrome. Source: Agence France-Presse (AFP) [edited]\nhttp://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5j7B5A6puttGZD9B2-Gvn-UcNeqcg?docId=CNG.eb497844a118d291deccabe9966d599a.4a1\n\n\nKyrgyzstan officials on Tuesday, 27 Aug 2013, scrambled to control the spread of bubonic plague that killed a rural boy last week as 3 more people showed possible symptoms of the disease. Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The bacterium can spread to the lungs, causing a secondary plague pneumonia (secondary to the bacteremia), or to the meninges, causing a plague meningitis. \n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. The 3 new patients, a woman with a toddler, and a teenager, exhibited symptoms of bubonic plague, namely a fever and swollen lymph nodes in their armpit and neck areas, an informed Kyrgyzstan government source told AFP on condition of anonymity. ' \n\nEmergency officials have also gone door to door in the boy's village to look for possible victims of the infection, but did not find signs of the disease, the emergency ministry said. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. Both of these events have a high case fatality rate and the secondary plague pneumonia is the way the infection spreads (by aerosol) from person to person. The emergency ministry said that 3 more people from the same village as the victim were hospitalized Tuesday, 27 Aug 2013, suspicion of being infected with the deadly disease. \n\nThe typical sign of the most common form of human plague is a swollen and very tender lymph gland, accompanied by pain. Officials had isolated 131 people as of Tuesday, 27 Aug 2013, to prevent the possible spread of the disease, said Asylbek Sydykanov, the ministry's public health official. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2 to 6 days after being infected. \n\nA herdboy from the village of Ichke-Zhergez [Ak-Suu], is thought to have become infected after being bitten by a flea carried by a marmot that he reportedly prepared for food. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. \n\nKazakhstan said that it is stepping up preventive measures to stop any possible outbreak on its territory, introducing 'special monitoring' of people crossing the border from Kyrgyzstan. If plague patients are not given specific antibiotic therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. Kazakhstan's health ministry also warned its citizens against travelling to Kyrgyzstan 'until the epidemiological situation regarding the plague is stabilized'. ' About 14 per cent (1 in 7) of all plague cases in the United States are fatal.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ak - Suu", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kyrgyzstan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1819290", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Russia: (DA) RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1819290", "date": "2013-07-11 20:32:36", "main_text": "PLAGUE - RUSSIA: (DAGESTAN) REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 10 Jul 2013\nSource: Pravda [edited]\nhttp://english.pravda.ru/news/russia/10-07-2013/125087-plague_dagestan-0/\n\n\nAn outbreak of plague was found in the Kulinsky district of the republic [Russian federal subject] of Dagestan. As long as people are highly susceptible to the disease, immunizations will be conducted for the population to avoid mass infection. Restrictive measures will be taken on the territory of nearby villages.\n\nPlague is a deadly infectious disease that is caused by _Yersinia pestis_, named after the French-Swiss bacteriologist Alexandre Yersin. Primarily carried by rodents (most notably rats) and spread to humans via fleas, the disease is notorious throughout history, due to the unrivaled scale of death and devastation it brought. Until June 2007, plague was one of the 3 epidemic diseases specifically reportable to the World Health Organization (the other 2 being cholera and yellow fever).\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of Dagestan is available at http://www.kaukaz.net/cgi-bin/blosxom.cgi/english/dagestan/map_dagestan, and the HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/1A-r. - CopyEd.JE]\n\n[The article does not specifically state that the outbreak involved people; reservoir 'die-offs' can sporadically occur without human cases. - Mod.LL]\n\n[The reservoir of plague in Dagestan is likely to be marmots (_Marmota_ spp., large ground squirrels), as in Mongolia. They are hunted for their fur, and hunters get bitten by their infected fleas, or infected from their blood when skinning them. For a photo, see:\nhttp://msnbcmedia.msn.com/j/streams%5C2012/August/120828%5C505846-tdy-120827-CATERS_Marmot_and_Boy_13.blocks_desktop_large.jpg - Mod.JW]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\n[The article does not specifically state that the outbreak involved people; reservoir 'die-offs' can sporadically occur without human cases. - Mod. \n\n--\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of Dagestan is available at http://www.kaukaz.net/cgi-bin/blosxom.cgi/english/dagestan/map_dagestan, and the HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/1A-r.
