PLAGUE - RUSSIA: (DAGESTAN) REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n**************************************************", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "cholera", "plague", "yellow fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-06-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Dagestan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1848788", "headline": "PRO/AH> Plague, animal - USA (04): (CA) squirrel", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1848788", "date": "2013-07-27 10:27:55", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (04): (CALIFORNIA) SQUIRREL\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 25 Jul 2013\nSource: The Global Dispatch [edited]\nhttp://www.theglobaldispatch.com/plague-infected-squirrel-prompts-closure-of-three-angeles-national-forest-campgrounds-42489/\n\n\nThe Los Angeles County Department of Public Health and US Forestry Service officials have closed the Broken Blade, Twisted Arrow, and Pima Loops of the Table Mountain Campgrounds in the Angeles National Forest, after tests confirmed that one ground squirrel trapped on 16 Jul 2013 during routine surveillance activities tested positive on 23 Jul 2013 for plague, according to a health advisory [notice] issued on Wednesday [24 Jul 2013].\n\nThe campgrounds are expected to be closed for a week while the squirrel burrows in the area will be dusted for fleas and further testing of squirrels is performed.\n\n'Plague is a bacterial infection that can be transmitted to humans through the bites of infected fleas, which is why we close affected campgrounds and recreational areas as a precaution while preventive measures are taken to control the flea population,' said Jonathan E Fielding, director of public health and health officer. 'It is important for the public to know that there have only been 4 cases of human plague in Los Angeles County residents since 1984, none of which were fatal.'\n\nHealth officials advise that individuals visiting recreational areas near the Broken Blade, Twisted Arrow, and Pima Loops of the Table Mountain Campgrounds need to take certain precautions to avoid contact with wild animals that could be carrying plague-positive fleas.\n\nVisitors to recreational areas should not feed wild animals, not leave edible trash out where wild animals can get to it, avoid camping or picnicking in the immediate vicinity of ground squirrel burrows, and should avoid taking pets into areas where they could be exposed to fleas. If you must take your pet into areas with fleas, please ensure that your pet has appropriate flea control and vaccinations, as recommended by a veterinarian.\n\nPlague is an infectious disease caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_. It is found in animals throughout the world, most commonly in rats, but also in other rodents like ground squirrels, prairie dogs, chipmunks, rabbits and voles. Fleas typically serve as the vector of plague. Human cases have been linked to domestic cats and dogs that bring infected fleas into the house.\n\nBubonic plague is the most common form of plague. In this form, the bacteria typically enter the body through the bite of an infected flea or rodent. The bacteria then infect the lymphatic system. After a few days to week, the person will experience fever, chills, weakness, and swollen lymph glands. These are called buboes. Untreated, bubonic plague is fatal about half the time.\n\n_Yersinia pestis_ is treatable with antibiotics if started early enough. Members of the public who see dead ground squirrels in recreational areas, or who want more information about precautions, should contact the LA County Department of Public Health, Vector Management Program at (626) 430-5450.\n\n[byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague, caused by _Yersinia pestis_, is enzootic among rodents in the western USA. Humans can be infected through 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals; 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals.\n\nPlague is a potential bioterrorism agent. Human infections are rare but can be life-threatening. The case fatality rate of plague depends on the clinical presentation (that is, bubonic, septicemic, or pneumonic) and timing of initiation of antibiotic therapy; if untreated, the case fatality rate is over 50 per cent for bubonic plague and approaches 100 per cent for pneumonic plague (1). Rapid laboratory identification can help guide therapy.\n\nDomestic cats and dogs can also contract plague from infective fleas. They may carry infected fleas home to their owners or, especially with cats, serve as a direct source of infection. There are many flea treatments and repellents appropriate for pets available. Some products may be suitable for dogs but not cats or may be suitable for an adult but not a younger animal. Be sure to consult your veterinarian, as some products may be toxic to cats, kittens, and puppies, even resulting in fatalities.\n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under the jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front leg (the armpit, if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever. Please take your pet to a veterinarian if you notice any abnormalities.\n\nVeterinarians should protect themselves by wearing gloves when examining these swellings. A bubo that ruptures may infect the veterinarian or even the pet owner if the pet owner is the one palpating the swelling.\n\nAnother form of the disease is the respiratory form. Cats may acquire this form and can spread it to their owners or the veterinarians through infected expiratory droplets. People are also prone to the respiratory infection.\n\nYou should also be aware that the fleas that hitchhike into your home on a pet can also transmit disease to you, the owner or caretaker of the pet. Sleeping in the same bed with dogs has been associated with plague in enzootic areas (2). Plague patients with no history of exposure to rodents can be infected by _Y. pestis_ if their pets carry infected rodent fleas into the home. Veterinarians always should recommend flea control to dog and cat owners.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. CDC. Human plague -- four states, 2006. MMWR 2006; 55(34): 940-3; available at http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5534a4.htm.\n2. Gould LH, Pape J, Ettestad P, et al. Dog-associated risk factors for human plague. Zoonoses Public Health 2008; 55(8-10): 448-54; abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18489541.\n\nParts of the above comment have been extracted from: CDC. Notes from the field: two cases of human plague - Oregon, 2010. MMWR 2011; 60(7): 214 http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6007a4.htm.\n\nCalifornia may be found on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/3DHP. - Mod.TG]", "summary": "\n\n[byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague, caused by _Yersinia pestis_, is enzootic among rodents in the western USA. \n\n'Plague is a bacterial infection that can be transmitted to humans through the bites of infected fleas, which is why we close affected campgrounds and recreational areas as a precaution while preventive measures are taken to control the flea population,' said Jonathan E Fielding, director of public health and health officer. ' \n\nVisitors to recreational areas should not feed wild animals, not leave edible trash out where wild animals can get to it, avoid camping or picnicking in the immediate vicinity of ground squirrel burrows, and should avoid taking pets into areas where they could be exposed to fleas. Humans can be infected through 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals; 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals. Plague patients with no history of exposure to rodents can be infected by _Y. pestis_ if their pets carry infected rodent fleas into the home. PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (04): (CALIFORNIA) SQUIRREL\n \n\nAnother form of the disease is the respiratory form.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-31 00:00:00", "1984-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Los Angeles County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1781960", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, animal - USA (02): (CA) squirrel, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1781960", "date": "2013-06-19 17:15:47", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (02): (CALIFORNIA) SQUIRREL, ALERT\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 13 Jun 2013\nSource: Ramona Patch [edited]\nhttp://ramona.patch.com/groups/editors-picks/p/3-squirrels-test-positive-for-plague-hikers-warned?utm_\n\n\nThree squirrels with plague have been discovered at Cedar Grove Campground and Doane Valley Campground.\n\nSan Diego County Department of Environmental Health officials urged hikers and campers to take simple precautions Wednesday [12 Jun 2013] to make sure they don't come into contact with squirrels or their fleas, which can spread plague, a disease caused by bacteria that can make people very sick and even kill them without quick treatment.\n\n'It's not unusual for us to find plague in our area, and there really are simple things people can do to protect themselves,' said environmental health director Jack Miller. 'The big thing is to avoid contact with squirrels and the fleas they carry. If you're camping, set your tents up away from squirrel burrows. If you're hiking, don't feed squirrels, and don't let your kids play with them.'\n\nTwo of the squirrels were trapped in routine monitoring at Cedar Grove Campground near Palomar Mountain; the 3rd was trapped at nearby Doane campground.\n\nPlague is mainly a disease of wild rodents, but it can be spread to people by fleas that feed on the blood of a sick animal and then bite humans. San Diego County's environmental health department monitors flea populations at campgrounds and takes measures to control those populations whenever necessary.\n\nPeople who visit or stay in rural mountain areas should look for Plague Warning signs and always follow these easy precautions to make sure they don't come into contact with plague-carrying fleas:\n\n- Avoid contact with ground squirrels, chipmunks and other wild animals.\n- Do not feed, touch or handle wild animals.\n- Do not rest, camp or sleep near animal burrows in the ground.\n- Do not touch sick or dead animals.\n- Protect your pets by keeping them on a leash; use flea control, or, best of all, leave pets at home.\n- Contact your doctor immediately if you become sick within a week of visiting an area known to have plague. (Symptoms include a sudden onset of fever, chills and tender swollen lymph nodes.)\n\n[Byline: Shauntel Lowe]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations. Some species are particularly susceptible. For example, _Y. pestis_ caused the extinction of entire colonies of black-tailed prairie dogs. Small rodents such as deer mice and grasshopper mice are suggested to act as the reservoirs. Larger species like squirrels and chipmunks are considered to be more vulnerable to infection.\n\nA ProMED-mail HealthMap of the affected area can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/7mVg. - Mod.PMB]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nPeople who visit or stay in rural mountain areas should look for Plague Warning signs and always follow these easy precautions to make sure they don't come into contact with plague-carrying fleas:\n\n- Avoid contact with ground squirrels, chipmunks and other wild animals. PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (02): (CALIFORNIA) SQUIRREL, ALERT\n \n- Do not touch sick or dead animals. \n\nSan Diego County Department of Environmental Health officials urged hikers and campers to take simple precautions Wednesday It's not unusual for us to find plague in our area, and there really are simple things people can do to protect themselves,' said environmental health director Jack Miller. Date: Thu 13 Jun 2013\n It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. **\n Larger species like squirrels and chipmunks are considered to be more vulnerable to infection. If you're hiking, don't feed squirrels, and don't let your kids play with them.' For example, _Y. pestis_ caused the extinction of entire colonies of black-tailed prairie dogs.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Diego County 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Diego County Department", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1878261", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA: (NM)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1878261", "date": "2013-08-13 12:05:13", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA: (NEW MEXICO)\n**************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 12 Aug 2013\nFrom: Paul Ettestad <Paul.ettestad@state.nm.us> [edited]\n\n\nThe New Mexico Department of Health confirmed today, 12 Aug 2013, a case of plague in a 15 year old boy from Torrance County who is currently hospitalized in stable condition. This is the 1st human case of plague in New Mexico and in the USA in 2013. An environmental investigation will take place at the boy's home to look for ongoing risk to others in the surrounding area.\n\n'The Department of Health conducts an investigation when a plague case occurs to ensure the safety of the immediate family, neighbors, and health care providers,' said Department of Health secretary Retta Ward, MPH. 'We inform neighbors door-to-door about plague found in the area and educate them on reducing their risk. Health care providers and others close to the patient may also have been exposed, and are assessed to determine if they need preventive treatment.'\n\nPlague is a bacterial disease of rodents and is generally transmitted to humans through the bites of infected fleas, but can also be transmitted by direct contact with infected animals, including rodents, wildlife, and pets. 'Plague activity in New Mexico is usually highest during the summer months, so it is especially important now to take precautions to avoid rodents and their fleas which can expose you to plague,' said Dr Paul Ettestad, public health veterinarian for the Department of Health. 'Pets that are allowed to roam and hunt can bring infected fleas from dead rodents back into the home, putting you and your children at risk.'\n\nTo prevent plague, the Department of Health recommends:\n- avoid sick or dead rodents and rabbits, and their nests and burrows;\n- keep your pets from roaming and hunting;\n- talk to your veterinarian about using an appropriate flea control product on your pets as not all products are safe for cats, dogs, or your children;\n- clean up areas near the house where rodents could live, such as woodpiles, brush piles, junk, and abandoned vehicles;\n- sick pets should be examined promptly by a veterinarian;\n- see your doctor about any unexplained illness involving a sudden and severe fever;\n- put hay, wood, and compost piles as far as possible from your home;\n- don't leave your pet's food and water where mice can get to it.\n\nIn New Mexico, there was 1 human plague case in 2012, 2 human cases of plague in 2011, no cases in 2010, and 6 human cases of plague in 2009, 1 of them fatal.\n\n--\nDr Paul Ettestad\nNew Mexico Department of Health\nUSA\n<Paul.ettestad@state.nm.us>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Ettestad for this report. The form of _Yersinia pestis_ infection -- bubonic, septicemic, or pneumonic -- is not stated in the report but most cases are bubonic. The bubo is an extremely painful lymph node swelling in the area draining from the flea bite that introduced the bacillus.\n\nA county map of the state of New Mexico (http://nmhealth.org/ERD/HealthData/documents/HumanPlagueinNMbyCounty1949-2012.pdf) shows that the concentration of human plague cases in New Mexico (1949-2012) is in the north western part of the state. Most USA cases of human plague infection occur in the Four Corner states -- the south western states of New Mexico, Arizona, Utah, and Colorado -- although California and Oregon have reported cases in recent years. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/2uyq.]", "summary": "\n\nTo prevent plague, the Department of Health recommends:\n- avoid sick or dead rodents and rabbits, and their nests and burrows;\n- keep your pets from roaming and hunting;\n- talk to your veterinarian about using an appropriate flea control product on your pets as not all products are safe for cats, dogs, or your children;\n- clean up areas near the house where rodents could live, such as woodpiles, brush piles, junk, and abandoned vehicles;\n- sick pets should be examined promptly by a veterinarian;\n- see your doctor about any unexplained illness involving a sudden and severe fever;\n- put hay, wood, and compost piles as far as possible from your home;\n- don't leave your pet's food and water where mice can get to it. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n In New Mexico, there was 1 human plague case in 2012, 2 human cases of plague in 2011, no cases in 2010, and 6 human cases of plague in 2009, 1 of them fatal. New Mexico Department of Health\nUSA\n<Paul.ettestad@state.nm.us>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Ettestad for this report. Most USA cases of human plague infection occur in the Four Corner states -- the south western states of New Mexico, Arizona, Utah, and Colorado -- although California and Oregon have reported cases in recent years. Plague activity in New Mexico is usually highest during the summer months, so it is especially important now to take precautions to avoid rodents and their fleas which can expose you to plague,' said Dr Paul Ettestad, public health veterinarian for the Department of Health. ' Plague is a bacterial disease of rodents and is generally transmitted to humans through the bites of infected fleas, but can also be transmitted by direct contact with infected animals, including rodents, wildlife, and pets. ' \n\nA county map of the state of New Mexico (http://nmhealth.org/ERD/HealthData/documents/HumanPlagueinNMbyCounty1949-2012.pdf) shows that the concentration of human plague cases in New Mexico (1949-2012) is in the north western part of the state.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Torrance County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1794260", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, animal - USA (03): (NM) canine, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1794260", "date": "2013-06-27 16:15:04", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (03): (NEW MEXICO) CANINE, ALERT\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 24 Jun 2013\nSource: NewsMax [edited]\nhttp://www.newsmax.com/thewire/bubonic-plague-dogs-black-death-new-mexico/2013/06/24/id/511497\n\n\nNew Mexico officials are warning residents in the East Mountains and El Dorado counties of the bubonic plague, after 2 dogs reportedly came down with the disease.\n\nResidents are advised to keep their dogs away from rodents -- including rabbits, chipmunks, and squirrels -- as they could be carrying plague infected fleas. Officials also recommend removing brush and clutter from around the home, which are hiding places for such animals.\n\n'It is the plague,' Mark Dimenna of the Environmental Health Department [EHD] said. Fortunately, human cases of plague are rare. Humans can be infected from direct contact with infected tissues or fluids while handling an animal that is sick or dead from plague. The disease can be effectively treated with antibiotics.\n\nSymptoms of bubonic plague for humans include fever, headache, chills, and weakness, and swollen, tender and painful lymph nodes, according to the CDC.\n\nSymptoms usually show up within 2 weeks of exposure to an infected animal or flea, county health officials said.\n\nDr Paul Smith, of the EHD, warned dog owners to be on the lookout for clinical signs in their dogs: fever, lethargy, and behavior that is 'not normal.' Cats can also be affected.\n\nMost of the cases plague in the United States have been in the New Mexico, Arizona, and Colorado area and in Nevada, Oregon, and California.\n\n'Plague is naturally present in many parts of California, including higher elevation of El Dorado County, so we all need to be cautious around animals that can carry it,' Dr Alicia Paris-Pombo, the county's public health officer said.\n\nPlague is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_.\n\n[Byline: Megan Anderle]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[New Mexico may be found on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/2o_v.\n\nPlague, caused by _Yersinia pestis_, is enzootic among rodents in the western USA. Humans can be infected through 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals; 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals.\n\nPlague is a potential bioterrorism agent. Human infections are rare but can be life-threatening. The plague case-fatality rate depends on the clinical presentation (that is, bubonic, septicemic, or pneumonic) and timing of initiation of antibiotic therapy; if untreated, the case-fatality rate is over 50 per cent for bubonic plague and approaches 100 per cent for pneumonic plague. Rapid laboratory identification can help guide therapy.\n\nDomestic cats and dogs can also contract plague from infective fleas. They may carry infected fleas home to their owners or, especially cats, serve as a direct source of infection. There are many flea treatments and repellents appropriate for pets and available. Some products may be suitable for dogs but not cats, or may be suitable for an adult but not a younger animal. Be sure to consult your veterinarian, as some products may be toxic to cats, kittens, and puppies, even resulting in fatalities.\n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under the jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front leg (the armpit if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever. Please take your pet to a veterinarian if you notice any abnormalities in your pet.\n\nVeterinarians should protect themselves by wearing gloves when examining these swellings. A bubo that ruptures may infect the veterinarian or even the pet owner if the pet owner is the one palpating the swelling.\n\nAnother form of the disease is the respiratory form. Cats may acquire this form and can spread it to their owners or the veterinarians through infected expiratory droplets. People are also prone to the respiratory infection.\n\nYou should also be aware that the fleas that hitchhike into your home via a pet vehicle can also transmit disease to you, the owner or caretaker of the pet. Sleeping in the same bed with dogs has been associated with plague in enzootic areas. Plague patients with no history of exposure to rodents can be infected by _Y. pestis_ if their pets carry infected rodent fleas into the home. Veterinarians always should recommend flea control to dog and cat owners.\n\nParts of the above explanation have been excerpted from: Notes from the Field: Two Cases of Human Plague --- Oregon, 2010, MMWR, 25 Feb 2011. 60(07);214 http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6007a4.htm - Mod.TG]", "summary": "The plague case-fatality rate depends on the clinical presentation (that is, bubonic, septicemic, or pneumonic) and timing of initiation of antibiotic therapy; if untreated, the case-fatality rate is over 50 per cent for bubonic plague and approaches 100 per cent for pneumonic plague. Plague patients with no history of exposure to rodents can be infected by _Y. pestis_ if their pets carry infected rodent fleas into the home. [Byline: Megan Anderle]\n\n--\n \n\nAnother form of the disease is the respiratory form. A bubo that ruptures may infect the veterinarian or even the pet owner if the pet owner is the one palpating the swelling. \n\nVeterinarians should protect themselves by wearing gloves when examining these swellings. 'Campers should set up tents away from squirrel burrows, never feed squirrels, and warn children not to play with squirrels.' Miller said. A squirrel trapped at Cedar Grove Campground on Palomar Mountain was the 1st reported case of plague in San Diego County this year [2013].\n\nPlague is a bacterial disease of wild rodents that is transmitted to people by fleas that feed on the blood of a sick animal and then bite humans. For more information about plague call the Vector Control Program at 858-694-2888 or visit the website at http://www.sdvector.com.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n['Plague, caused by _Yersinia pestis_, is enzootic among rodents in the western USA. Humans can be infected through 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals; 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals.\n\nPlague is a potential bioterrorism agent. Human infections are rare but can be life-threatening. The plague case-fatality rate depends on the clinical presentation (that is, bubonic, septicemic, or pneumonic) and timing of initiation of antibiotic therapy; if untreated, the case-fatality rate is over 50 per cent for bubonic plague and approaches 100 per cent for pneumonic plague (1). Rapid laboratory identification can help guide therapy.\n\nDomestic cats and dogs can also contract plague from infective fleas. They may carry infected fleas home to their owners or, especially with cats, serve as a direct source of infection. There are many flea treatments and repellents appropriate for pets available. Some products may be suitable for dogs but not cats or may be suitable for an adult but not a younger animal. Be sure to consult your veterinarian, as some products may be toxic to cats, kittens, and puppies, even resulting in fatalities.\n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under the jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front leg (the armpit, if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever. Please take your pet to a veterinarian if you notice any abnormalities in your pet.\n\nVeterinarians should protect themselves by wearing gloves when examining these swellings. A bubo that ruptures may infect the veterinarian or even the pet owner if the pet owner is the one palpating the swelling.\n\nAnother form of the disease is the respiratory form. Cats may acquire this form and can spread it to their owners or the veterinarians through infected expiratory droplets. People are also prone to the respiratory infection.\n\nYou should also be aware that the fleas that hitchhike into your home via a pet can also transmit disease to you, the owner or caretaker of the pet. Sleeping in the same bed with dogs has been associated with plague in enzootic areas (2). Plague patients with no history of exposure to rodents can be infected by _Y. pestis_ if their pets carry infected rodent fleas into the home. Veterinarians always should recommend flea control to dog and cat owners.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. CDC: Human plague -- four states, 2006. Zoonoses Public Health 2008; 55(8-10): 448-54; abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18489541.\n\nParts of the above comment have been extracted from http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6007a4.htm; - Mod.TG\n\nCalifornia may be found on the HealthMap/Promed-mail interactive map at: http://healthmap.org/r/3DHP.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The plague case-fatality rate depends on the clinical presentation (that is, bubonic, septicemic, or pneumonic) and timing of initiation of antibiotic therapy; if untreated, the case-fatality rate is over 50 per cent for bubonic plague and approaches 100 per cent for pneumonic plague (1). Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n['Plague, caused by _Yersinia pestis_, is enzootic among rodents in the western USA. Humans can be infected through 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals; 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals. \n\nPlague is a bacterial disease of wild rodents that is transmitted to people by fleas that feed on the blood of a sick animal and then bite humans. Plague patients with no history of exposure to rodents can be infected by _Y. pestis_ if their pets carry infected rodent fleas into the home. \n\nYou should also be aware that the fleas that hitchhike into your home via a pet can also transmit disease to you, the owner or caretaker of the pet. \n\nDomestic cats and dogs can also contract plague from infective fleas. \n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under the jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front leg (the armpit, if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever. They may carry infected fleas home to their owners or, especially with cats, serve as a direct source of infection. \n\n--\n \n\nReferences\n---------- PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA: (CALIFORNIA) SQUIRREL, ALERT\n A bubo that ruptures may infect the veterinarian or even the pet owner if the pet owner is the one palpating the swelling. \n\nAnother form of the disease is the respiratory form. \n\n\nA ground squirrel that tested positive for plague on Palomar Mountain has led San Diego County health officials to warn campers and hikers to take precautions. For more information about plague call the Vector Control Program at 858-694-2888 or visit the website at http://www.sdvector.com. Some products may be suitable for dogs but not cats or may be suitable for an adult but not a younger animal.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Diego County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6007a4.htm", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1467364", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Madagascar (02): fatalities", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1467364", "date": "2012-12-24 13:23:32", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (02): FATALITIES\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 17 Dec 2012\nSource: RFI (Radio France Internationale) [in French, trans. Mod.JW, edited]\nhttp://www.rfi.fr/afrique/20121217-madagascar-peste-oms-celine-seignon-kandissounon\n\n\nThis is the peak season for the plague in Madagascar. The Big Island remains one of the countries most affected by this disease in the world, the 2nd after the Congo Democratic Republic. With the current heat and rain, cases are increasing in this period. Several foci are being discovered around the capital, Antananarivo.\n\n10 patients have just been newly identified some 80 km from the capital. Other cases have been reported even closer. In total, since the beginning of 2012, the plague has already affected 250 people, 90 since early October 2012, with nearly one out of 5 patients dying. Dr. Celine Seignon-Kandissounon, representative of the WHO in Madagascar, reports an increase in the number of deaths: 'Compared to 2011, there are fewer cases, but these cases were more serious. It was noted that there are more deaths in 2012.'\n\nThe problem with the plague is that too often patients have consulted late, and since the beginning of the crisis 4 years ago, it has worsened. 'The vulnerability of the population has increased,' says Dr. Seignon, 'with the [worsening of the] socio-economic situation. Sometimes, accessibility to the health care centers is difficult, so delay in treatment can explain the increase in the number of deaths.'\n\nInformation campaigns and treatment are underway. The villages affected by the disease are quarantined to contain the outbreak, but it is certain that in Madagascar, plague will never be eradicated.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-FRA\n<promed-fra@promedmail.org>\n\n[There have been few cases but more deaths this year (2012) compared to last year. Delayed treatment may explain this fact, but we must also consider other factors such as the virulence of the infecting strains, resistance to the antibiotics used, counterfeit drugs, and, therefore, under-dosage of those used in the treatment of the disease. In any case, this article is quite pessimistic. If efforts are made to raise the awareness of the people and improve levels of hygiene and sanitation, with a fierce struggle against rats and their [fleas], plague could one day be only a sad memory on the Big Island.\n\nAn interactive ProMED-mail HealthMap of Madagascar is available at: http://healthmap.org/r/018m. - Mod.BM]\n\n[For background see: Chanteau S, Ratsifasoamanana L, Rasoamanana, et al: Plague, a reemerging disease in Madagascar. Emerg Infect Dis 1998;4: 101-104. Available from http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/4/1/98-0114.htm.\n\nAbstract\n------\nHuman cases of plague, which had virtually disappeared in Madagascar after the 1930s, reappeared in 1990 with more than 200 confirmed or presumptive cases reported each year since. In the port of Mahajanga, plague has been reintroduced, and epidemics occur every year. In Antananarivo, the capital, the number of new cases has increased, and many rodents are infected with _Yersinia pestis_. Despite surveillance for the sensitivity of _Y. pestis_ and fleas to drugs and insecticides and control measures to prevent the spread of sporadic cases, the elimination of plague has been difficult because the host and reservoir of the bacillus, _Rattus rattus_, is both a domestic and a sylvatic rat.\n\nIn the last 15 years [through 1998], Madagascar (population 13 million) has accounted for 45 percent of the cases of plague in Africa. - Mod.JW]\n\n[Fatalities related to plague usually are caused by spread of the organism from the bubo (the very painful infected lymph node which drains the area where the flea bite occurred) to the bloodstream. The bacteremia can cause a coagulopathy producing the purpura seen in the 'black plague' and also spread to the lung causing a hemorrhagic pneumonia. It is the pneumonia that can facilitate person-to-person transmission.\n\nMadagascar was the location of the isolation of multi-antimicrobial resistant _Y. pestis_ in 1995 (Galimand M, Guiyoule A, Gerbaud G, et al: Multidrug resistance in _Yersinia pestis_ mediated by a transferable plasmid. N Engl J Med 1997; 337(10): 677-80). The strain was resistant to chloramphenicol, streptomycin, and tetracycline but sensitive to fluoroquinolones and trimethoprim as well as other aminoglycosides. This was an ominous observation; however, it is not clear whether this naturally occurring strain has persisted or spread. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-FRA\n<promed-fra@promedmail.org>\n\n[There have been few cases but more deaths this year (2012) compared to last year. \nHuman cases of plague, which had virtually disappeared in Madagascar after the 1930s, reappeared in 1990 with more than 200 confirmed or presumptive cases reported each year since. Despite surveillance for the sensitivity of _Y. pestis_ and fleas to drugs and insecticides and control measures to prevent the spread of sporadic cases, the elimination of plague has been difficult because the host and reservoir of the bacillus, _Rattus rattus_, is both a domestic and a sylvatic rat. JW]\n\n[Fatalities related to plague usually are caused by spread of the organism from the bubo (the very painful infected lymph node which drains the area where the flea bite occurred) to the bloodstream. PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR (02): FATALITIES\n************************************\n In total, since the beginning of 2012, the plague has already affected 250 people, 90 since early October 2012, with nearly one out of 5 patients dying. \n\nThe problem with the plague is that too often patients have consulted late, and since the beginning of the crisis 4 years ago, it has worsened. ' \n\nMadagascar was the location of the isolation of multi-antimicrobial resistant _Y. pestis_ in 1995 (Galimand M, Guiyoule A, Gerbaud G, et al: Multidrug resistance in _Yersinia pestis_ mediated by a transferable plasmid. Dr. Celine Seignon-Kandissounon, representative of the WHO in Madagascar, reports an increase in the number of deaths: 'Compared to 2011, there are fewer cases, but these cases were more serious. In the last 15 years [through 1998], Madagascar (population 13 million) has accounted for 45 percent of the cases of plague in Africa. If efforts are made to raise the awareness of the people and improve levels of hygiene and sanitation, with a fierce struggle against rats and their [fleas], plague could one day be only a sad memory on the Big Island. Delayed treatment may explain this fact, but we must also consider other factors such as the virulence of the infecting strains, resistance to the antibiotics used, counterfeit drugs, and, therefore, under-dosage of those used in the treatment of the disease. The bacteremia can cause a coagulopathy producing the purpura seen in the 'black plague' and also spread to the lung causing a hemorrhagic pneumonia. \n\n--\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1998-03-25 00:00:00", "1990-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "1995-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Big Island", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Congo Democratic Republic", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mahajanga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rasoamanana", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1415379", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Madagascar: fatalities", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1415379", "date": "2012-11-19 11:43:14", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MADAGASCAR: FATALITIES\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 15 Nov 2012\nSource: L'Express de Madagascar [in French, trans. Mod.MPP, edited]\nhttp://www.lexpressmada.com/epidemie-madagascar/38515-six-personnes-succombent-de-la-peste.html\n\n\nThe arrival of the rain is not always good news, as rats [and their fleas], the plague vectors, take refuge in habitats, wreaking havoc.\n\nIt is the beginning of the plague season on the Big Island and it is time to start worrying. 6 patients have died of the disease in a month. The Bongolava region has paid the highest price. 'Of the 43 cases identified, 2 people died of bubonic plague on [2 Oct 2012], 2 others died on 5 Nov 2012, and another person died on 9 Nov 2012 person,' the statistical management of health monitoring and epidemiological surveillance (DVSSE) within the Ministry of Public Health reported yesterday [14 Nov 2012].\n\nHowever, this epidemic does not affect this region alone. Another victim of the plague was also registered in the District of Mandoto in Vakinankaratra, on 9 Oct 2012. The same day, 3 other non-fatal cases were found in the district of Ambalavao in the Haute-Matsiatra region.\n\nThe cause of this deadly epidemic seems always the same. 'The plague victims sometimes live in remote areas and they self-medicate before going to a health center when the disease worsens. However, all health centers are equipped with rapid diagnostic test and medications to treat this disease immediately,' said Alain Marcel Rahetilahy, head of epidemic and neglected diseases within the Ministry of Health. In contrast, the Regional Director of Public Health for Tsiroanomandidy refused to disclose the circumstances of this deadly epidemic in its domain, without the written permission of the Secretary General of the Ministry of Health.\n\nHowever, Alain Marcel Rahetilahy does not want to dramatize the situation. 'These cases have yet to be confirmed by the Pasteur Institute of Madagascar. And every year, only 30-40 percent of reported cases are confirmed, even if the initial result is positive by a rapid diagnosis test. So the situation is it not very disturbing,' he reassured.\n\nYet other doctors remain cautious. 'The heat, the rain, and the bushfires that devastated several regions in recent months, forced the rats, propagation vectors of the plague, to flee to the villages. This is why people must remain vigilant,' warned a doctor who does not wish to reveal his name. And according to the Secretary General of the Ministry of Health, Philemon Tafangy, the number of suspected cases of plague is between 300 and 500 annually.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is caused by the _Yersinia pestis_ bacillus, carried by rat fleas. At the start of the rainy season, currently, rats flee the sewers of Madagascar in massive numbers and take refuge in people's cottages. [The following paragraph of this posting is from 1998 (Chanteau S, Ratsifasoamanana L, Rasoamanana B, et al: Plague, a Reemerging Disease in Madagascar. Emerg Infect Dis 1998; 4(1): 101-4: 'Between 1930 and 1990, bubonic plague had 'virtually disappeared' on the island due to efficient pest-control and good health-management. However since 1990, an annual 200 cases are being reported and bubonic plague takes on epidemic form especially in the port of Mahajanga each year. In the capital city of Antananarivo more cases are also being notified each year since 1990. Madagascar (pop. 13 million) has accounted for 45 percent of all the cases of plague in Africa.'\n\nFatalities related to plague usually are caused by spread of the organism from the bubo (the very painful infected lymph node which drains the area where the flea bite occurred) to the bloodstream. The bacteremia can cause a coagulopathy producing the purpura seen in the 'Black Plague' and also spread to the lung causing a hemorrhagic pneumonia. It is the pneumonia that can facilitate person-to-person transmission.\n\nMadagascar was the location of the isolation of multi-antimicrobial resistant _Y. pestis_ in 1995 (Galimand M, Guiyoule A, Gerbaud G, et al: Multidrug resistance in _Yersinia pestis_ mediated by a transferable plasmid. N Engl J Med 1997; 337(10): 677-80). The strain was resistant to chloramphenicol, streptomycin and tetracycline but sensitive to fluoroquinolones and trimethoprim as well as other aminoglycosides. This was an ominous observation; however, it is not clear if this naturally occurring strain has persisted or spread. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1kSe.]", "summary": "Of the 43 cases identified, 2 people died of bubonic plague on [2 Oct 2012], 2 others died on 5 Nov 2012, and another person died on 9 Nov 2012 person,' the statistical management of health monitoring and epidemiological surveillance (DVSSE) within the Ministry of Public Health reported yesterday A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n However since 1990, an annual 200 cases are being reported and bubonic plague takes on epidemic form especially in the port of Mahajanga each year. Emerg Infect Dis 1998; 4(1): 101-4: 'Between 1930 and 1990, bubonic plague had 'virtually disappeared' on the island due to efficient pest-control and good health-management. In contrast, the Regional Director of Public Health for Tsiroanomandidy refused to disclose the circumstances of this deadly epidemic in its domain, without the written permission of the Secretary General of the Ministry of Health.\n\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is caused by the _Yersinia pestis_ bacillus, carried by rat fleas. \n\nMadagascar was the location of the isolation of multi-antimicrobial resistant _Y. pestis_ in 1995 (Galimand M, Guiyoule A, Gerbaud G, et al: Multidrug resistance in _Yersinia pestis_ mediated by a transferable plasmid. \n\nIt is the beginning of the plague season on the Big Island and it is time to start worrying. However, all health centers are equipped with rapid diagnostic test and medications to treat this disease immediately,' said Alain Marcel Rahetilahy, head of epidemic and neglected diseases within the Ministry of Health. Fatalities related to plague usually are caused by spread of the organism from the bubo (the very painful infected lymph node which drains the area where the flea bite occurred) to the bloodstream. The heat, the rain, and the bushfires that devastated several regions in recent months, forced the rats, propagation vectors of the plague, to flee to the villages. And according to the Secretary General of the Ministry of Health, Philemon Tafangy, the number of suspected cases of plague is between 300 and 500 annually. The arrival of the rain is not always good news, as rats [and their fleas], the plague vectors, take refuge in habitats, wreaking havoc. And every year, only 30-40 percent of reported cases are confirmed, even if the initial result is positive by a rapid diagnosis test. The plague victims sometimes live in remote areas and they self-medicate before going to a health center when the disease worsens.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1995-03-25 00:00:00", "1998-03-25 00:00:00", "1990-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the District of Mandoto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mahajanga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rasoamanana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1439936", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, animal - USA (05): (SD) prairie dog", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1439936", "date": "2012-12-06 11:22:54", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (05): (SOUTH DAKOTA) PRAIRIE DOG\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 28 Nov 2012\nSource: The Republic, Associated Press (AP) report [edited]\nhttp://www.therepublic.com/view/story/1877615312954586adad946703a1b56e/SD--Prairie-Dog-Plague?\n\n\nA disease that can devastate prairie dog colonies has been confirmed on the Fort Pierre National Grassland in South Dakota. District Ranger Ruben Leal says the bacteria that cause sylvatic plague was found in fleas collected from prairie dog colonies.\n\nSylvatic plague was first detected in South Dakota in 2004. The disease has been migrating north and west. It also has been detected on the Buffalo Gap National Grasslands, in Badlands National Park, and on the Lower Brule Indian Reservation.\n\nThere have not been any confirmed cases of the plague in people in South Dakota.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There are 2 parts to this comment: 1) comments regarding transmission to domestic animals and 2) issues regarding prairie dogs (_Cynomys_) and the black footed ferret (_Mustela nigripes_).\n\nPlague, caused by _Yersinia pestis_, is enzootic among rodents in the western USA. Humans can be infected through 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals; 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals.\n\nPlague is a potential bioterrorism agent. Human infections are rare but can be life-threatening. The plague case-fatality rate depends on the clinical presentation (that is, bubonic, septicemic, or pneumonic) and timing of initiation of antibiotic therapy; if untreated, the case-fatality rate is over 50 per cent for bubonic plague and approaches 100 per cent for pneumonic plague (1). Rapid laboratory identification can help guide therapy.\n\nDomestic cats and dogs can also contract plague from infective fleas. They may carry infected fleas home to their owners or, especially cats, serve as a direct source of infection. There are many flea treatments and repellents appropriate for pets and available. Some products may be suitable for dogs but not cats, or may be suitable for an adult but not a younger animal. Be sure to consult your veterinarian, as some products may be toxic to cats, kittens, and puppies, even resulting in fatalities.\n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under the jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front leg (the armpit if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever. Please take your pet to a veterinarian if you notice any abnormalities in your pet.\n\nVeterinarians should protect themselves by wearing gloves when examining these swellings. A bubo that ruptures may infect the veterinarian or even the pet owner if the pet owner is the one palpating the swelling.\n\nAnother form of the disease is the respiratory form. Cats may acquire this form and can spread it to their owners or the veterinarians through infected expiratory droplets. People are also prone to the respiratory infection.\n\nYou should also be aware that the fleas that hitchhike into your home via a pet vehicle can also transmit disease to you, the owner or caretaker of the pet. Sleeping in the same bed with dogs has been associated with plague in enzootic areas (2). Plague patients with no history of exposure to rodents can be infected by _Y. pestis_ if their pets carry infected rodent fleas into the home. Veterinarians always should recommend flea control to dog and cat owners.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. CDC: Human plague -- four states, 2006. MMWR 2006; 55(34): 940-3; available at http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5534a4.htm.\n2. Gould LH, Pape J, Ettestad P, et al: Dog-associated risk factors for human plague. Zoonoses Public Health 2008; 55(8-10): 448-54; abstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18489541.\n\nSylvatic plague is a bacterial disease of wild rodents that is transmitted by fleas. It can afflict numerous species of mammals, including humans. Prairie dogs are highly susceptible to plague and are the primary food source of the highly endangered black-footed ferret, which is also susceptible to the disease. Sylvatic plague can decimate prairie dog colonies, with mortality rates of 90 percent or more, resulting in local extinctions and population reductions. Because of the susceptibility of prairie dogs to sylvatic plague, coupled with the potentially devastating effect the disease can have on black-footed ferrets, plague control is a vital concern for ferret recovery programs and conservation efforts.\n\nScientists at the USGS National Wildlife Health Center (NWHC), in collaboration with colleagues at the University of Wisconsin, state agencies, and other Federal agencies, have tested the feasibility of vaccinating black-footed ferrets and prairie dogs against sylvatic plague infections. The plague vaccine was developed for humans by the US Army Medical Research Institute for Infectious Disease and is being tested for use on animals at the USGS National Wildlife Health Center. Vaccination of ferrets by injection was shown to be highly successful both in the laboratory and in the field. However, injectable vaccines are not practical for field use in free-ranging animals, such as prairie dogs. Ultimately, management of the disease in ferrets will depend on managing the disease in prairie dogs.\n\nCurrently, efforts to halt the spread of plague rely on dusting individual prairie dog burrows with pesticides that kill plague-infected fleas, but pesticide application is labor intensive, costly and difficult to sustain over time.\n\nSylvatic plague vaccine (SPV)\n-----------------------------\nImmunizing entire populations of free-ranging prairie dogs and other rodents is highly challenging, but preliminary NWHC studies indicate prairie dogs can be successfully immunized by voluntarily eating vaccine-laden baits. These studies suggest that plague in prairie dogs could be managed through oral immunization, which would be especially useful in areas where black-footed ferrets reside and in populations of prairie dogs of conservation concern.\n\nThe Sylvatic Plague Vaccine Subcommittee of the Black-footed Ferret Recovery and Implementation Team is acting to coordinate efforts to complete development and delivery of SPV as a management tool to combat plague in grassland ecosystems. Currently, the NWHC is working with USDA's Center for Veterinary Biologics to register SPV for use in the field. Field safety trials with SPV are scheduled to begin in summer 2012 in Colorado. Field efficacy studies for free-ranging prairie dog populations are planned to begin in 2013. Ultimately, SPV would be used as a plague management tool to reduce the occurrence of plague outbreaks and thus to enhance ferret recovery and prairie dog conservation in targeted areas.\n\nA portion of the discussion above about sylvatic plague has been extracted from http://www.nwhc.usgs.gov/disease_information/sylvatic_plague/\n\nPhotos and more information about the fascinating prairie dog may be found at http://animals.nationalgeographic.com/animals/mammals/prairie-dog/ and http://www.northrup.org/photos/prairie-dogs/.\n\nSouth Dakota may be found on the interactive HealthMap/ProMED- mail map at http://healthmap.org/r/4qmE. - Mod.TG]", "summary": "\n\nA portion of the discussion above about sylvatic plague has been extracted from http://www.nwhc.usgs.gov/disease_information/sylvatic_plague/\n\nPhotos and more information about the fascinating prairie dog may be found at http://animals.nationalgeographic.com/animals/mammals/prairie-dog/ and http://www.northrup.org/photos/prairie-dogs/.\n\nSouth Dakota may be found on the interactive HealthMap/ProMED- mail map at http://healthmap.org/r/4qmE. - Mod. Because of the susceptibility of prairie dogs to sylvatic plague, coupled with the potentially devastating effect the disease can have on black-footed ferrets, plague control is a vital concern for ferret recovery programs and conservation efforts. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There are 2 parts to this comment: 1) comments regarding transmission to domestic animals and 2) issues regarding prairie dogs (_Cynomys_) and the black footed ferret (_Mustela nigripes_). These studies suggest that plague in prairie dogs could be managed through oral immunization, which would be especially useful in areas where black-footed ferrets reside and in populations of prairie dogs of conservation concern. The plague case-fatality rate depends on the clinical presentation (that is, bubonic, septicemic, or pneumonic) and timing of initiation of antibiotic therapy; if untreated, the case-fatality rate is over 50 per cent for bubonic plague and approaches 100 per cent for pneumonic plague (1). Currently, efforts to halt the spread of plague rely on dusting individual prairie dog burrows with pesticides that kill plague-infected fleas, but pesticide application is labor intensive, costly and difficult to sustain over time. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Ultimately, SPV would be used as a plague management tool to reduce the occurrence of plague outbreaks and thus to enhance ferret recovery and prairie dog conservation in targeted areas. Prairie dogs are highly susceptible to plague and are the primary food source of the highly endangered black-footed ferret, which is also susceptible to the disease. Immunizing entire populations of free-ranging prairie dogs and other rodents is highly challenging, but preliminary NWHC studies indicate prairie dogs can be successfully immunized by voluntarily eating vaccine-laden baits. The Sylvatic Plague Vaccine Subcommittee of the Black-footed Ferret Recovery and Implementation Team is acting to coordinate efforts to complete development and delivery of SPV as a management tool to combat plague in grassland ecosystems. Scientists at the USGS National Wildlife Health Center (NWHC), in collaboration with colleagues at the University of Wisconsin, state agencies, and other Federal agencies, have tested the feasibility of vaccinating black-footed ferrets and prairie dogs against sylvatic plague infections. PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (05): (SOUTH DAKOTA) PRAIRIE DOG\n*****************************************************\n \n\nDomestic cats and dogs can also contract plague from infective fleas. \n\nSylvatic plague is a bacterial disease of wild rodents that is transmitted by fleas. Humans can be infected through 1) the bite of an infected flea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals; 2) direct contact with contaminated tissues; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of respiratory secretions from infected people or animals. District Ranger Ruben Leal says the bacteria that cause sylvatic plague was found in fleas collected from prairie dog colonies. \n\nSylvatic plague vaccine (SPV)\n Plague patients with no history of exposure to rodents can be infected by _Y. pestis_ if their pets carry infected rodent fleas into the home. Sylvatic plague can decimate prairie dog colonies, with mortality rates of 90 percent or more, resulting in local extinctions and population reductions. \n\nYou should also be aware that the fleas that hitchhike into your home via a pet vehicle can also transmit disease to you, the owner or caretaker of the pet.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "The Republic , Associated Press", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Badlands National Park", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mustela", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cynomys", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Dakota", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1344859", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, animal - USA (04): (CA) chipmunk, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1344859", "date": "2012-10-15 19:44:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (04): (CALIFORNIA) CHIPMUNK, ALERT\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 12 Oct 2012\nSource: Tahoe Daily Tribune [edited]\nhttp://www.tahoedailytribune.com/article/20121012/ARCHIVES01/121019957/1068\n\n\nLocal, state and federal officials are urging caution after a chipmunk near Taylor Creek Visitor Center was found with plague last week [1st week of Oct 2012].\n\nThe rodent was rolled up in a ball, shaking and struggling to breathe when it was discovered by a U.S. Forest Service employee, Forest Service spokeswoman Cheva Heck said.\n\nVector control officials were contacted and captured the animal, which tested presumptive positive for the bacteria that causes plague, _Yersinia pestis_, Heck said.\n\nThe disease is rare, highly infectious and can be fatal, according to a Wednesday [10 Oct 2012] statement from the El Dorado County Environmental Management Department. But plague is curable in its early stages with diagnosis and treatment. Symptoms include high fever, chills, nausea, weakness and swollen lymph nodes in the neck, armpit or groin.\n\nPeople are typically exposed to plague through an infected flea bite, handling an infected rodent or exposure to an infected pet, especially cats, according to the statement.\n\nResidents and visitors to picnic spots and campgrounds should take precautions to protect themselves against the disease following the discovery, said Bob Hartmann, El Dorado County's interim public health officer, in the statement 'Individuals can greatly reduce their risk of becoming infected with plague by taking simple precautions, including avoiding contact with wild rodents and their fleas,' Hartmann said. 'Do not feed rodents in picnic or campground areas, and never handle sick or dead rodents. Also, leave your pets at home when visiting areas with elevated plague risk.'\n\nPublic health officials urge people to wear long pants tucked into boot tops to reduce exposure to fleas, apply insect repellent containing DEET on socks and trouser cuffs, and avoid walking, hiking or camping near rodent burrows. People should also report any sick or dead animals to forest, campground or local health officials, according to the county.\n\nThe county urges anyone who develops symptoms within 2 weeks of possible exposure to seek immediate medical attention and inform the physician that they have been in an area where plague is known to exist.\n\nPet owners should keep their animals leashed and away from dead rodents and be taken to a veterinarian if they become sick following a visit to the Taylor Creek area, according to the statement.\n\nAdditional rodent surveillance is planned in the area this week [12-19 Oct 2012] to assess public risk. The Forest Service is awaiting further recommendations from the California Department of Public Health based on the results.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations. Some species were particularly susceptible. For example, _Y. pestis_ caused the extinction of entire colonies of black-tailed prairie dogs. Small rodents such as deer mice and grasshopper mice are suggested to act as the reservoirs. Larger species like squirrels and chipmunks are considered to be more vulnerable to infection.\n\nA map of the affected area can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/3Ig5. - Mod.PMB]", "summary": "\n\nResidents and visitors to picnic spots and campgrounds should take precautions to protect themselves against the disease following the discovery, said Bob Hartmann, El Dorado County's interim public health officer, in the statement 'Individuals can greatly reduce their risk of becoming infected with plague by taking simple precautions, including avoiding contact with wild rodents and their fleas,' Hartmann said. ' A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. \n\nPublic health officials urge people to wear long pants tucked into boot tops to reduce exposure to fleas, apply insect repellent containing DEET on socks and trouser cuffs, and avoid walking, hiking or camping near rodent burrows. \n\nPeople are typically exposed to plague through an infected flea bite, handling an infected rodent or exposure to an infected pet, especially cats, according to the statement. \n\nPet owners should keep their animals leashed and away from dead rodents and be taken to a veterinarian if they become sick following a visit to the Taylor Creek area, according to the statement. \n\nThe county urges anyone who develops symptoms within 2 weeks of possible exposure to seek immediate medical attention and inform the physician that they have been in an area where plague is known to exist. \n\nVector control officials were contacted and captured the animal, which tested presumptive positive for the bacteria that causes plague, _Yersinia pestis_, Heck said. \n\nAdditional rodent surveillance is planned in the area this week [12-19 Oct 2012] to assess public risk. \n\nThe disease is rare, highly infectious and can be fatal, according to a Wednesday [10 Oct 2012] statement from the El Dorado County Environmental Management Department. People should also report any sick or dead animals to forest, campground or local health officials, according to the county. Do not feed rodents in picnic or campground areas, and never handle sick or dead rodents. \n\n--\n http://www.tahoedailytribune.com/article/20121012/ARCHIVES01/121019957/1068\n\n\nLocal, state and federal officials are urging caution after a chipmunk near Taylor Creek Visitor Center was found with plague last week PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (04): (CALIFORNIA) CHIPMUNK, ALERT\n \n\nA map of the affected area can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/3Ig5. The rodent was rolled up in a ball, shaking and struggling to breathe when it was discovered by a U.S. Forest Service employee, Forest Service spokeswoman Cheva Heck said. Also, leave your pets at home when visiting areas with elevated plague risk.' Date: Fri 12 Oct 2012\n Small rodents such as deer mice and grasshopper mice are suggested to act as the reservoirs. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. \n\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-12-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "El Dorado County 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taylor Creek", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1328402", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, animal - USA (03): (CA) squirrel", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1328402", "date": "2012-10-07 11:52:44", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (03): (CALIFORNIA) SQUIRREL\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 5 Oct 2012\nSource: Inland News Today [edited]\nhttp://www.inlandnewstoday.com/story.php?s=26023\n\n\nFor the 1st time in nearly a decade, bubonic plague has been confirmed in Riverside County. State health officials said Thursday [4 Oct 2012] that a ground squirrel tested positive.\n\nIt was found during routine testing at the Fern Basin campground in the San Jacinto Mountains north of Idyllwild. It's an area where similar findings were an annual occurrence in the 1990's.\n\nBubonic plague is a bacterial disease that can be transmitted from wild rodents to humans through bites from infected fleas.\n\nCampers are being warned to stay away from squirrels and other wild animals. Further testing of animals is planned to determine if dusting is warranted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The causative bacterium, _Yersinia pestis_, is transmitted to people through fleabites and direct contact with infected animals. Each rodent species is host to one or more species of fleas which, when infected, are carriers. These fleas generally do not infest other animals unless their natural hosts are unavailable.\n\nDomestic cats and dogs can also contract plague from infective fleas. They may carry infected fleas home to their owners or, especially cats, serve as a direct source of infection. There are many flea treatments and repellents appropriate for pets available. Some products may be suitable for dogs but not cats or may be suitable for an adult but not a younger animal. Be sure to consult your veterinarian, as some products may be toxic to cats, kittens, and puppies, even resulting in fatalities.\n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under the jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front leg (the armpit if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever. Please take your pet to a veterinarian if you notice any abnormalities. Veterinarians should protect themselves by wearing gloves when examining these swellings. A bubo that ruptures may infect the veterinarian or even the pet owner if the pet owner is the one palpating the swelling.\n\nAnother form of the disease is the respiratory form. Cats may acquire this form and can spread it to their owners or the veterinarians through infected expiratory droplets. People are also prone to the respiratory infection as well.\n\nYou should also be aware that fleas that hitchhike into your home via a pet vehicle and can also transmit disease to you, the owner, or caretaker of the pet.\n\nCalifornia may be found on the interactive HealthMap at: http://healthmap.org/r/3DHP. - Mod.TG]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The causative bacterium, _Yersinia pestis_, is transmitted to people through fleabites and direct contact with infected animals. \n\nYou should also be aware that fleas that hitchhike into your home via a pet vehicle and can also transmit disease to you, the owner, or caretaker of the pet. \n\nBubonic plague is a bacterial disease that can be transmitted from wild rodents to humans through bites from infected fleas. \n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under the jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front leg (the armpit if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever. \n\nDomestic cats and dogs can also contract plague from infective fleas. They may carry infected fleas home to their owners or, especially cats, serve as a direct source of infection. A bubo that ruptures may infect the veterinarian or even the pet owner if the pet owner is the one palpating the swelling. \n\n--\n \n\nAnother form of the disease is the respiratory form.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1990-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Idyllwild", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Riverside County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1296380", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (05): (OR), 2nd case", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1296380", "date": "2012-09-16 19:53:58", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (05): (OREGON), SECOND CASE\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 14 Sep 2012\nSource: KPTV [edited]\nhttp://www.kptv.com/story/19548445/second-person-in-oregon\n\n\nNew lab results show a 2nd person became infected with the plague in June 2012 after being bitten by a sick cat, health officials in Oregon said Friday, 14 Sep 2012. The woman was bitten around the same time as a Prineville man who became ill\nwith the plague in June 2012. He had tried to take a dead rodent from the cat's mouth in a rural area outside the Central Oregon city. The man became seriously ill, but survived.\n\nBlood tests later conducted on the woman were sent to the CDC and the results, just returned to the Crook County Health Department in Prineville, OR, confirmed she had the plague. Fortunately, antibiotics given to the woman were effective in stopping the plague's symptoms, officials said.\n\nKaren Yeargain, a communicable disease coordinator in Crook County, said she started investigating 10 Jun 2012 after learning of the 1st case of the plague. 'With the help of the sick man's family, a list was put together of all persons who might be at risk,' said Karen Yeargain, of the Crook County Health Department.\n\nHealth workers said the woman happened to be at a hospital out of the area with a family member. When she tried to get treatment for the plague, she was met with disbelief by hospital staff, Yeargain said. She soon began to experience early plague symptoms.\n\n'With my phone call confirming that this was real, the hospital emergency department literally walked her medication to the room where she was located and got her started,' Yeargain said. 'We got to her just in time. If this hadn't happened, we would have had another critically ill person on our hands.'\n\nPlague is a bacterial illness spread through the bite of infected fleas or through direct contact with an animal or person who is ill with the disease. In this case, the illness did not spread from person to person.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Since the woman was an at risk person listed by the family of the initial case, it may well be the case that the same feline was the source of what is presumed to be bubonic plague in this case. The confirmational tests from CDC are not stated but may well be serological and not microbiological. -Mod. PLAGUE - USA (05): (OREGON), SECOND CASE\n*****************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2012-09-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2012-06-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Prineville", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "OREGON", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Crook County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1304269", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, animal - USA (02): (CO) rabbit, bubonic", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1304269", "date": "2012-09-21 19:17:34", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (02): (COLORADO) RABBIT, BUBONIC\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 16 Sep 2012\nSource: Allvoices [edited]\nhttp://www.allvoices.com/contributed-news/12991324-wild-rabbit-tests-positive-for-bubonic-plague-in-colorado-springs-public-health-alert-issued\n\n\nEl Paso County, Colorado, health officials are urging anyone who has recently had contact with wild animals to contact the Public Health Department immediately. On 14 Sep 2012, a wild rabbit was caught near St Francis Medical Center/Hospital, east of Powers Boulevard. Subsequent testing revealed that the animal was infected with bubonic plague.\n\nBubonic plague is, 'a bacterial disease transmitted to humans by the bite of an infected flea. In humans, the symptoms are high fever, chills, headache, extreme fatigue, and tender or swollen lymph glands,' according to the El Paso County Public Health website.\n\nHealth officials believe that all of the people exposed to the animal have been identified and treated to prevent them from developing the disease. There have been no reported cases of bubonic plague in El Paso county since 1991.\n\nRecently, a 7-year-old girl from Pagosa Springs, Colorado, which is about 250 miles [402 km] southwest of Colorado Springs, became infected with the disease. She has since recovered.\n\n[Byline: TJ Larson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As noted in the text, this feral animal case is not geographically linked to the case of septicemic _Yersinia pestis_ infection in late August 2012. - Mod.LL]\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is not native to North America and is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. When it was introduced with the rats, it became established in some native rodent populations. Small rodents such as deer mice and grasshopper mice are suggested to act as the main reservoirs. Larger species like squirrels are considered to be more vulnerable to infection. Lagomorphs are also frequently infected by _Y. pestis_ and can be a source of the disease for humans. - Mod.PMB]\n\n[The state of Colorado can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/3uhp.
