One of them presented with painful swelling of lymph nodes on the right side on 4 Sep 2012 and was admitted to hospital on 7 Sep 2012. His condition deteriorated later and he died on the same day.\n\nAccording to the deceased's clinical characteristics, epidemiological investigation, and laboratory test results, the health authority of Sichuan Province confirmed the case as bubonic plague.\n\nThe health authority has traced 59 close contacts of the deceased (including the other 2 villagers who had consumed the marmot) and carried out medical surveillance. None of them were symptomatic.\n\n'We are maintaining close liaison with the MoH in order to obtain more information on the case,' the spokesman said. The Department of Health's Port Health Office will also alert the travel industry about the report.\n\nThe spokesman reminded travellers to avoid visiting plague-endemic areas. People who need to travel to areas with plague reports have to be vigilant and have to observe precautionary measures including wearing long sleeved shirts and trousers to avoid being bitten by fleas and applying insect repellent. 'They should seek medical attention immediately if they are feeling unwell,' the spokesman said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The death of the case here suggests progression of bubonic plague to septicemic plague and/or pneumonic plague. It is the latter form of infection that can spread via the respiratory route from person-to-person.\n\nThe marmot is the most common reservoir for _Yersinia pestis_ in eastern Asia. The etymology of the term 'marmot' is uncertain (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marmot). It may have arisen from the Gallo-Romance prefix marm-, meaning to mumble or murmur (an example of onomatopoeia). Another possible origin is post-classical Latin, mus montanus, meaning 'mountain mouse'. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/2lQ6.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The death of the case here suggests progression of bubonic plague to septicemic plague and/or pneumonic plague. \n\nA CHP spokesman said that according to the preliminary information from the MoH, 3 villagers in Ganzizhou, Sichuan Province, had consumed a dead marmot on 2 Sep 2012. \n\nThe health authority has traced 59 close contacts of the deceased (including the other 2 villagers who had consumed the marmot) and carried out medical surveillance. ' \n\n'We are maintaining close liaison with the MoH in order to obtain more information on the case,' the spokesman said.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2012-09-02 00:00:00", "2012-09-10 00:00:00", "2012-09-07 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sichuan Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ganzizhou", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1269118", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (04): (CO) septicemic", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1269118", "date": "2012-08-28 21:12:30", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (04): (COLORADO) SEPTICEMIC\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tues 28 Aug 2012\nFrom: Amber Reiss-Holt MD [edited]\n\n\nA 7-year-old girl, a resident of Archuleta County, CO, presented to a small community emergency room (ER) with a fever of 107 F and seizures on the evening of 24 Aug 2012. She was transported to a pediatric ICU in Denver, where she deteriorated into severe septic shock. Further history revealed that she was playing with a dead skunk near her home some days before the onset of fever, and that she received multiple flea bites from fleas on the skunk carcass. Blood cultures have confirmed _Yersinia pestis_ and clinically she has septicemic plague. She remains in critical condition.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nAmber Reiss-Holt MD\nChief of Emergency Services and General Surgeon\nPagosa Springs Medical Center, Pagosa Springs CO\n\n[ProMED thanks Dr. Reiss-Holt for submitting this report. A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1z-L. - Mod.DK\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1z-L.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nAmber Reiss-Holt MD\nChief of Emergency Services and General Surgeon\nPagosa Springs Medical Center, Pagosa Springs CO\n\n From: Amber Reiss-Holt MD [edited]\n\n\nA 7-year-old girl, a resident of Archuleta County, CO, presented to a small community emergency room (ER) with a fever of 107 F and seizures on the evening of 24 Aug 2012. Further history revealed that she was playing with a dead skunk near her home some days before the onset of fever, and that she received multiple flea bites from fleas on the skunk carcass.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Denver", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Archuleta County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1266637", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, animal - USA: (CA) squirrel", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1266637", "date": "2012-08-27 16:58:17", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA: (CALIFORNIA) SQUIRREL\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 22 Aug 2012\nSource: NBC San Diego [edited]\nhttp://www.nbcsandiego.com/news/local/Squirrels-Near-Palomar-Mountain-Test-Positive-for-Plague-167066445.html\n\n\nThree ground squirrels trapped near Palomar Mountain in San Diego's North County tested positive for plague, county officials said Wednesday [22 Aug 2012].\n\nThe squirrels likely were not exposed to the bacterial disease any time recently, but the existence still poses a risk to campers and hikers in the area, according to the San Diego County Department of Environmental Health.\n\nThe squirrels were trapped at the Cedar Grove Campground and the Doane Campground.\n\nIn May [2012], another squirrel trapped at the Cedar Grove Campground also tested positive for plague. A Vector Control spokesperson said it was caught during a separate trapping, and it is not known whether the same squirrel was trapped this time around.\n\nPlague is typically found in rodents and infects humans through the bite of an infected flea. The department has not received any reported cases in humans.\n\nIt is typical for animals to test positive for plague, especially during the summer, said the department's director Jack Miller. Still, park officials have set up signs in rural camping and hiking areas, and visitors should take precautions while in the area.\n\n'Set up your tents away from squirrel burrows; do not feed the squirrels, and warn your children not to play with squirrels,' Miller said. Miller also said to avoid resting or camping near animal burrows in the ground and to keep pets on a leash or leave pets at home.\n\nSymptoms of plague include swollen lymph nodes, chills and a sudden onset of fever.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is primarily a disease of wild rodents. It is caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_, which is mainly spread by the bites of infectious fleas. The bacterium is not native to North America. When it was introduced, it became established in some rodent populations. Some species were particularly susceptible. For example, _Y. pestis_ caused the extinction of entire colonies of black-tailed prairie dogs. Small rodents such as deer mice and grasshopper mice are suggested to act as the reservoirs. Larger species like squirrels are considered to be more vulnerable to infection.\n\nFrom the text, it can be inferred that they found antibodies against _Y. pestis_ in these squirrels, which indicates that the pathogen may be circulating in those populations.\n\nA ProMED HealthMap of the affected area can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/3bnl. - Mod.PMB]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n'Set up your tents away from squirrel burrows; do not feed the squirrels, and warn your children not to play with squirrels,' Miller said. \n\nThe squirrels likely were not exposed to the bacterial disease any time recently, but the existence still poses a risk to campers and hikers in the area, according to the San Diego County Department of Environmental Health. \n\n\nThree ground squirrels trapped near Palomar Mountain in San Diego's North County tested positive for plague, county officials said Wednesday [22 Aug 2012]. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n \n\nIt is typical for animals to test positive for plague, especially during the summer, said the department's director Jack Miller. A Vector Control spokesperson said it was caught during a separate trapping, and it is not known whether the same squirrel was trapped this time around.\n\n \n\n--\n \n\nSymptoms of plague include swollen lymph nodes, chills and a sudden onset of fever. \n\nThe squirrels were trapped at the Cedar Grove Campground and the Doane Campground.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-05-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "San Diego 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1206257", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (03): (OR) septicemic, recovery", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1206257", "date": "2012-07-19 11:39:18", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (03): (OREGON), SEPTICEMIC, RECOVERY\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nTue 18 Jul 2012\nSource: The Guardian [edited]\nhttp://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2012/jul/18/oregon-man-case-plague\n\n\nAn Oregon man who contracted a rare case of the plague trying to take a mouse from the jaws of a choking cat is no longer in a critical condition and has talked about his fears of losing all of his fingers as a result of the disease.\n\nThe family of the man, a welder from Prineville in rural Oregon, released pictures showing his hands withered by the cell-killing infection and darkened to the color of charcoal.\n\n'I don't think I can do my job,' he told the Associated Press in a phone interview from hospital. I'm going to lose all my fingers on both hands. I don't know about my thumbs. The toes, I might lose all them, too.'\n\n'We didn't even know the plague was around anymore,' said his sister. 'We thought that was an ancient, ancient disease.'\n\nThe disease, which rampaged through Europe in the Middle Ages and is thought to have wiped out between 1/4th and 1/3rd of the population, is caused by the _Yersinia pestis_ bacterium. It can develop into 3 kinds of plague, including bubonic plague, which swells lymph nodes across the body. The other 2 are septicemic plague, which affects the bloodstream, and pneumonic plague, which affects the lungs.\n\nThe illness began after he saw a stray cat with a dead mouse jammed in the back of his throat. The cat appeared to be choking, so he and a friend attempted to dislodge the mouse. The distressed cat bit his hand. Unable to remove the mouse, the man shot the cat to end his suffering and buried him in the yard. Two days later, he awoke with a fever and chills.\n\nHe spent nearly a month on life support and only recently left the intensive care unit. At one point, doctors thought he was going to die, said his wife.\n\nThe cat's body was dug up, and tests confirmed it had the plague. Other cats and dogs in the area were tested, and none had the disease.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Septicemic plague can cause peripheral gangrene. A photograph of the patient's hand can be found at:\nhttp://www.komonews.com/news/local/Oregon-man-recovering-from-rare-case-of-plague-162820406.html?tab=gallery&c=y&img=0.\n\nNot necessarily relevant for this posting, in an in-press report (Turdjman M, Ibraheem M, Brett M, et al: Misidentification of _Yersinia pestis_ by automated systems, resulting in delayed diagnoses of human plague infections - Oregon and New Mexico. Clin Infect Dis 2012, in press), the authors underscore the importance of clinical diagnosis of plague because automated systems can misidentify it. In theses cases, the Oregon case was initially identified as _Acinetobacter lwoffii_ by one lab, _Pseudomonas luteola_ by a 2nd and _Yersinia pseudotuberculosis_ by a 3rd. In the 2nd case, the lab 1st identified the isolate as _P. luteola_. Misidentification can delay appropriate treatment as well as isolation if needed for pneumonic plague.\n\nOf note, the same publication reports on unpublished data from CDC regarding the number of confirmed cases of human plague in the USA. From 1990 to 2010, 142 confirmed cases occurred, predominantly in Arizona, California, Colorado and New Mexico. Of the 139 cases with clinical data available, 75 percent were bubonic (with a 7 percent mortality); 21 percent were septicemic (with a 24 percent mortality), and 4 percent were pneumonic (with a 50 percent mortality). - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1fWb.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Of the 139 cases with clinical data available, 75 percent were bubonic (with a 7 percent mortality); 21 percent were septicemic (with a 24 percent mortality), and 4 percent were pneumonic (with a 50 percent mortality). Source: The Guardian [edited]\nhttp://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2012/jul/18/oregon-man-case-plague\n\n\nAn Oregon man who contracted a rare case of the plague trying to take a mouse from the jaws of a choking cat is no longer in a critical condition and has talked about his fears of losing all of his fingers as a result of the disease. \n\nNot necessarily relevant for this posting, in an in-press report (Turdjman M, Ibraheem M, Brett M, et al: Misidentification of _Yersinia pestis_ by automated systems, resulting in delayed diagnoses of human plague infections - Oregon and New Mexico. \n\nOf note, the same publication reports on unpublished data from CDC regarding the number of confirmed cases of human plague in the USA. \n\nThe cat's body was dug up, and tests confirmed it had the plague. The other 2 are septicemic plague, which affects the bloodstream, and pneumonic plague, which affects the lungs. It can develop into 3 kinds of plague, including bubonic plague, which swells lymph nodes across the body. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Septicemic plague can cause peripheral gangrene. \n\n'We didn't even know the plague was around anymore,' said his sister. ' \n\nThe illness began after he saw a stray cat with a dead mouse jammed in the back of his throat. \n\nThe disease, which rampaged through Europe in the Middle Ages and is thought to have wiped out between 1/4th and 1/3rd of the population, is caused by the _Yersinia pestis_ bacterium.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Turdjman M", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "OREGON", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "909748", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, pneumonic - Madagascar (05): (AV)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=909748", "date": "2011-10-14 19:17:52", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PNEUMONIC - MADAGASCAR (05): (ANTANANARIVO)\n***************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 12 Oct 2011\nSource: Afriquinfos [machine transl.] [edited]\nhttp://www.afriquinfos.com/articles/2011/10/11/brevesdafrique-188649.asp\n\n\nA pneumonic plague epidemic has been declared in the district of\nMiarinarivo located in the province of Antananarivo, the Malagasy\ncapital has reported to the local press Tuesday, 11 Oct 2011. One\nperson has died of this disease and 5 other persons are being treated\nat the hospital.\n\nThe district of Miarinarivo and its environs are included among the 12\nregions known as endemic for the disease on the island, but it was\nalso noted that the regions of the central highlands are the most\nfavorable to their development because of a higher altitude to 800\nmeters and a cooler temperature.\n\nPlague reappeared in December 2010 with 5 cases including 1 death in a\nvillage 15 km [9.3 miles] from the capital as well as 16 deaths in\nAmbilobe, in the northern region of Madagascar in February 2011.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Primary pneumonic plague (1 percent of natural plague presentations)\narises as a result of inhalation of plague bacilli in infectious\naerosols, such as would be produced when there are secondary pneumonic\ncomplications in bubonic/septicemic plague.\n\nPrimary plague pneumonia has a short incubation period of 1-3 days,\nafter which there is sudden onset of flu-like symptoms including\nfever, chills, headache, generalized body pains, weakness and chest\ndiscomfort. A cough develops with sputum production, which may be\nbloody, and increasing chest pain and difficulty in breathing. As the\ndisease progresses, hypoxia (low oxygen concentration in the blood)\nand hemoptysis (coughing up blood) are prominent. The disease is\ninvariably fatal unless antimicrobial therapy commences within 24\nhours of exposure.\n\nPatients with primary pneumonic plague generate large quantities of\ninfectious aerosols that pose a significant risk to close contacts.\nCDC guidelines identify contacts within 2 meters [6 feet] as being at\ngreatest risk and do not consider the organism likely to be carried\nthrough air ducts or vents. Persons who have been in contact with\npneumonic plague patients or handling potentially infectious body\nfluids or tissues without appropriate protection should receive\npreventive antimicrobial therapy. The preferred antimicrobial agents\nfor prophylaxis are tetracyclines, quinolones, or chloramphenicol.\n\nMadagascar was the location of the isolation of multi-antimicrobial\nresistant _Y. pestis_ in 1995 (Galimand M, Guiyoule A, Gerbaud G, et\nal: Multidrug resistance in _Yersinia pestis_ mediated by a\ntransferable plasmid. N Engl J Med 1997;337: 677-81). The strain was\nresistant to chloramphenicol, streptomycin and tetracycline but\nsensitive to fluoroquinolones and trimethoprim as well as other\naminoglycosides. This was an ominous observation, however, it is not\nclear if this naturally occurring strain has persisted or spread. -\nMod.LL]\n\n[The interactive HealthMap/ProMED map for Madagascar is available at:\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1kSe - CopyEd.EJP]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Primary pneumonic plague (1 percent of natural plague presentations)\narises as a result of inhalation of plague bacilli in infectious\naerosols, such as would be produced when there are secondary pneumonic\ncomplications in bubonic/septicemic plague. PLAGUE, PNEUMONIC - MADAGASCAR (05): (ANTANANARIVO)\n***************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nThe district of Miarinarivo and its environs are included among the 12\nregions known as endemic for the disease on the island, but it was\nalso noted that the regions of the central highlands are the most\nfavorable to their development because of a higher altitude to 800\nmeters and a cooler temperature.\n\n \n\nPrimary plague pneumonia has a short incubation period of 1-3 days,\nafter which there is sudden onset of flu-like symptoms including\nfever, chills, headache, generalized body pains, weakness and chest\ndiscomfort. Persons who have been in contact with\npneumonic plague patients or handling potentially infectious body\nfluids or tissues without appropriate protection should receive\npreventive antimicrobial therapy. The strain was\nresistant to chloramphenicol, streptomycin and tetracycline but\nsensitive to fluoroquinolones and trimethoprim as well as other\naminoglycosides. A pneumonic plague epidemic has been declared in the district of\nMiarinarivo located in the province of Antananarivo, the Malagasy\ncapital has reported to the local press Tuesday, 11 Oct 2011. Plague reappeared in December 2010 with 5 cases including 1 death in a\nvillage 15 km [9.3 miles] from the capital as well as 16 deaths in\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2010-12-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-02-25 00:00:00", "1995-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1153277", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA: (NM)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1153277", "date": "2012-06-01 14:53:08", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA: (NEW MEXICO)\n**************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 31 May 2012\nSource: Examiner [edited]\nhttp://www.examiner.com/article/new-mexico-man-is-the-first-human-plague-case-the-u-s-this-year\n\n\nA 78-year-old Torrance County, New Mexico man is the 1st human case of plague in New Mexico or the USA in 2012. Health officials report the yet unnamed man is currently hospitalized in stable condition.\n\nAccording to a New Mexico Department of Health press release Thursday (31 May 2012) [http://www.health.state.nm.us/CommunicationsOffice/2012%20News%20Releases/NewsRelease-20120531-PlagueFirstCase-EN.pdf], they confirmed the man as having the plague, or _Yersinia pestis_ [infection]. NM Department of Health Cabinet Secretary, Dr Catherine Torres said, 'The Department of Health takes action when a plague case occurs to ensure the safety of the immediate family, neighbors, and health care providers. We inform neighbors door-to-door about plague found in the area and educate them on reducing their risk. We determine whether individuals close to the patient may also have been exposed to the plague and recommend preventative treatment when necessary.'\n\nPlague is an infectious disease caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_. It is found in animals throughout the world, most commonly rats but other rodents like ground squirrels, prairie dogs, chipmunks, rabbits, and voles. Fleas typically serve as the vector of plague. Human cases have been linked to the domestic cats and dogs that brought infected fleas into the house.\n\nBubonic plague is the most common form of plague. In this form, the bacteria typically enter the body through the bite of an infected flea or rodent. Here the bacteria infect the lymphatic system. After a few days to a week, the person will experience fever, chills, weakness, and swollen lymph glands. These are called buboes.\n\nNM public health veterinarian, Dr Paul Ettestad says plague activity usually begins to increase in the spring and continues into the summer months. Now is the season and people need to take precautions to avoid rodents and their fleas which can expose them to plague. Ettestad says, 'Pets that are allowed to roam and hunt can bring infected fleas from dead rodents back into the home, putting you and your children at risk.'\n\nHealth authorities offer the following recommendations to prevent plague:\n- Avoid sick or dead rodents and rabbits, and their nests and burrows.\n- Keep your pets from roaming and hunting\n- Talk to your veterinarian about using an appropriate flea control product on your pets\n- Clean up areas near the house where rodents could live, such as woodpiles, brush piles, junk, and abandoned vehicles.\n- Sick pets should be examined promptly by a veterinarian.\n- See your doctor about any unexplained illness involving a sudden and severe fever.\n- Put hay, wood, and compost piles as far as possible from your home.\n- Don't leave your pet's food and water where mice can get to it.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[New Mexico can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/r/2uyq. Torrance County can be seen on the map at http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/new-mexico.shtml. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n[Most cases of _Yersinia pestis_ infections in the USA are reported from the Four Corners area of the USA where the states of Colorado, Utah, Arizona, and New Mexico come together.\n\nAs outlined by the CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) at http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvbid/plague/diagnosis.htm: 'Death from bubonic plague occurs after the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_ escapes from the infected bubo into the bloodstream (septicemic plague) causing the manifestations of the sepsis syndrome. Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) with subsequent cutaneous hemorrhage may well have been what was called the 'Black Death' in the Middle Ages. The bacterium can spread to the lungs, causing a secondary plague pneumonia (secondary to the bacteremia), or to the meninges, causing a plague meningitis. Both of these events have a high case fatality rate and the secondary plague pneumonia is the way the infection spreads (by aerosol) from person to person.\n\n'The typical sign of the most common form of human plague is a swollen and very tender lymph gland, accompanied by pain. The swollen gland is called a 'bubo.' Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2 to 6 days after being infected.\n\n'When bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antibiotic therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. About 14 per cent (1 in 7) of all plague cases in the United States are fatal.' - Mod.LL\n\n]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n As outlined by the CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) at http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvbid/plague/diagnosis.htm: 'Death from bubonic plague occurs after the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_ escapes from the infected bubo into the bloodstream (septicemic plague) causing the manifestations of the sepsis syndrome. \n\nHealth authorities offer the following recommendations to prevent plague:\n- Avoid sick or dead rodents and rabbits, and their nests and burrows. \n\n'When bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. The bacterium can spread to the lungs, causing a secondary plague pneumonia (secondary to the bacteremia), or to the meninges, causing a plague meningitis. \n\nBubonic plague is the most common form of plague. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. - Keep your pets from roaming and hunting\n- Talk to your veterinarian about using an appropriate flea control product on your pets\n- Clean up areas near the house where rodents could live, such as woodpiles, brush piles, junk, and abandoned vehicles. \n\n'The typical sign of the most common form of human plague is a swollen and very tender lymph gland, accompanied by pain. These are called buboes.\n\nNM public health veterinarian, Dr Paul Ettestad says plague activity usually begins to increase in the spring and continues into the summer months. Both of these events have a high case fatality rate and the secondary plague pneumonia is the way the infection spreads (by aerosol) from person to person. \n\nPlague is an infectious disease caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2 to 6 days after being infected. NM Department of Health Cabinet Secretary, Dr Catherine Torres said, 'The Department of Health takes action when a plague case occurs to ensure the safety of the immediate family, neighbors, and health care providers. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. PLAGUE - USA: (NEW MEXICO)\n*************************", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2012-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-05-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Torrance County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1041629", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, fatal - Uganda (02): background", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1041629", "date": "2012-02-14 10:19:22", "main_text": "PLAGUE, FATAL - UGANDA (02): BACKGROUND\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 14 Feb 2012\nSource: GideonOnline [edited]\nhttp://www.GideonOnline.com\n\n\nThe following background data on plague in Uganda are abstracted from Gideon (http://www.GideonOnline.com) and the Gideon e-book series (1, 2) (primary references available on request):\n\nThe earliest record of plague in Africa was a report by missionaries in Uganda in 1877, and reporting statistics for much of the continent have been documented for more than 100 years. A series of plague epidemics were recorded in East Africa during the 1920s and 1930s (see graph 3; http://www.gideononline.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/Uganda-Plague.png).\n\n31 305 plague deaths were reported in Uganda during 1910 to 1919; 17 410 during 1920 to 1929; 11 387 during 1930 to 1939.\n\nPresumed local reservoirs include the Nile rat, _Arvicanthus niloticus_. Presumed local flea vectors include _Xenopsylla cheopis_ and _X. brasiliensis_.\n\nNotable outbreaks:\n1982 - an outbreak (152 cases, 3 fatal) was reported.\n1986 - an outbreak (340 cases, 27 fatal) was reported.\n1993 - an outbreak (167 cases, 18 fatal) was reported in Western Region (Nebbi district).\n1998 - an outbreak was reported in Arua district.\n2001 - an outbreak was reported in Nebbi district.\n2004 - an outbreak (4 cases, one confirmed, 3 fatal) of pneumonic plague was reported in Kango subcounty.\n2006 - an outbreak (127 cases, 11 fatal) was reported in Arua and Nebbi districts, including 12 cases of pneumonic plague.\n2007 - outbreaks (179 cases, total) were reported in Masindi district (19 cases, 9 fatal), and in Arua (121 cases, 10 fatal) and Nebbi (39 cases, 9 fatal).\n2008 - an outbreak (68 deaths) was reported in Arua and Nebbi.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Berger SA. Infectious diseases of Uganda, 2012. 398 pp, 61 graphs, 1711 references. Gideon e-books, http://www.gideononline.com/ebooks/country/infectious-diseases-of-uganda/.\n2. Berger SA. Plague: global status, 2012. 98 pp, 102 graphs, 524 references. Gideon e-books, http://www.gideononline.com/ebooks/disease/plague-global-status/.\n3. Gideon graph tool at http://www.gideononline.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/Gideon-Graphs.pps.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nDr Steve Berger\nGeographic Medicine\nTel Aviv Medical Center\n<mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Berger for his continuing contributions. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1wa6.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n2007 - outbreaks (179 cases, total) were reported in Masindi district (19 cases, 9 fatal), and in Arua (121 cases, 10 fatal) and Nebbi (39 cases, 9 fatal). \n\nNotable outbreaks:\n1982 - an outbreak (152 cases, 3 fatal) was reported. References\n----------\n1. The following background data on plague in Uganda are abstracted from Gideon (http://www.GideonOnline.com) and the Gideon e-book series (1, 2) (primary references available on request):\n\nThe earliest record of plague in Africa was a report by missionaries in Uganda in 1877, and reporting statistics for much of the continent have been documented for more than 100 years. 2004 - an outbreak (4 cases, one confirmed, 3 fatal) of pneumonic plague was reported in Kango subcounty.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1982-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1877-03-25 00:00:00", "1998-03-25 00:00:00", "1993-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-02-14 00:00:00", "1986-03-25 00:00:00", "1711-03-25 00:00:00", "2001-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00", "2012-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Uganda", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Masindi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "East Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nebbi district", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kango", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1039922", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, fatal - Uganda: (AW) RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1039922", "date": "2012-02-13 15:10:07", "main_text": "PLAGUE, FATAL - UGANDA: (ARUA) REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 8 Feb 2012\nSource: AllAfrica, The New Monitor (Uganda) report [edited]\nhttp://allafrica.com/stories/201202080058.html\n\n\nA fresh outbreak of plague is suspected after 2 people died of similar symptoms in Vurra County, Arua district, where health officials here have put the community on alert.\n\nOver the years, plague outbreaks have been emerging from the neighboring DR Congo. When contacted, the district health officer, Dr Patrick Anguzu, said he was still consulting for details of the disease. 'I have not yet received a report on the outbreak, but I will try to consult,' he said.\n\nBut the Vurra MP, Dr Sam Okuonzi, told Daily Monitor in a telephone interview that the 2 died in Opia parish. As a drive to fight the annual disease, in 2009, the Ministry of Health launched a sensitization program for the 2 bordering districts of Nebbi and Arua, where previous outbreaks have occurred.\n\n[byline: Felix Warom Okello, Clement Aluma]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-EAFR\n<promed-eafr@promedmail.org>\n\n[No specific details of the cases are included in the posting. Most cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea, causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland. The swollen gland is called a 'bubo'. Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2 to 6 days after being bitten.\n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antibiotic therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. At this stage, person-to-person spread can occur, causing other cases of 'primary' plague pneumonia.\n\nThe districts of Uganda can be seen on the map at http://www.coetzee-uganda.com/index_files/District_Map_of_Uganda.htm. The HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Uganda is available at http://healthmap.org/r/00XI. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "\n\n[byline: Felix Warom Okello, Clement Aluma]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-EAFR\n<promed-eafr@promedmail.org>\n\n[No specific details of the cases are included in the posting. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. \n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. http://allafrica.com/stories/201202080058.html\n\n\nA fresh outbreak of plague is suspected after 2 people died of similar symptoms in Vurra County, Arua district, where health officials here have put the community on alert. PLAGUE, FATAL - UGANDA: (ARUA) REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n******************************************************\n Most cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an infected rodent flea, causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Vurra County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Opia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "774313", "headline": "PRO/AH> Plague, animal - USA (04): (NM) canine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=774313", "date": "2011-07-01 16:42:32", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (04): (NEW MEXICO) CANINE\n**********************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 28 Jun 2011\nSource: Alamogordo Daily News [edited]\nhttp://www.alamogordonews.com/ci_18373276\n\n\nThe New Mexico Department of Health's Scientific Laboratory Division\nconfirmed plague this week in a dog in Rio Rancho. The dog was most\nlikely infected when running in open fields on the north end of the\ncity and encountering sick or dead rabbits and other rodents, health\nofficials said.\n\n'A plague case in a pet serves as a warning that there is plague\nactivity in rabbits, rodents, and their fleas in the area,' said Dr\nCatherine Torres, the Department of Health's cabinet secretary. 'I\nencourage everyone to follow simple prevention recommendations to keep\nthemselves and their families and pets safe.'\n\nPlague, a bacterial disease of rodents, is generally transmitted to\nhumans through the bites of infected fleas, but can also be\ntransmitted by direct contact with infected animals, including\nrodents, rabbits and pets. 'Pets infected with plague are often\nhunters who have eaten an infected rodent or been bitten by a rodent's\nfleas prior to getting ill,' said Dr Paul Ettestad, public health\nveterinarian for the Department of Health. 'Pets can transport the\nfleas back into the home where they can infect people.'\n\nSymptoms of plague in humans include sudden onset of fever, chills,\nheadache, and weakness. In most cases there is a painful swelling of\nthe lymph node in the groin, armpit, or neck areas. Plague symptoms in\ncats and dogs are fever, lethargy, and loss of appetite. There may be\na swelling in the lymph node under the jaw. With prompt diagnosis and\nwith appropriate antibiotic treatment, the fatality rate in people and\npets can be greatly reduced.\n\nTo prevent plague, the Department of Health recommends the\nfollowing:\n- avoid sick or dead rodents and rabbits, and their nests and\nburrows;\n- keep your pets from roaming and hunting, and talk to your\nveterinarian about using an appropriate flea control product;\n- clean up areas near the house where rodents could live, such as\nwoodpiles, brush piles, junk, and abandoned vehicles;\n- sick pets should be examined promptly by a veterinarian;\n- see your doctor about any unexplained illness involving a sudden\nand severe fever;\n- put hay, wood, and compost piles as far as possible from your home;\n- don't leave your pet's food and water where mice can get to it.\n\nIn New Mexico, there have been 2 human cases so far in 2011, both\nfrom Santa Fe County; no human cases in 2010 and 6 human cases of\nplague in 2009: 3 from Santa Fe County, 2 from Bernalillo County and\none from Sandoval County. One of the Santa Fe County cases was a fatal\ncase in an 8-year-old boy. For more information, including fact sheets\nin English and Spanish, go to the Department's website at\nhttp://www.health.state.nm.us/erd/HealthData/plague.shtml\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Rio Rancho in central New Mexico can be located via the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/0*Cr.\n\nPlague, caused by _Yersinia pestis_, is enzootic among rodents in the\nwestern USA. Humans can be infected through 1) the bite of an infected\nflea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals; 2) direct contact\nwith contaminated tissues; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of\nrespiratory secretions from infected people or animals.\n\nPlague is a category A potential bioterrorism agent. Human infections\nare rare but can be life-threatening. The plague case-fatality rate\ndepends on the clinical presentation (that is, bubonic, septicemic, or\npneumonic) and timing of antibiotic therapy initiation; if untreated,\nthe case-fatality rate is over 50 per cent for bubonic plague and\napproaches 100 per cent for pneumonic plague (1). Rapid laboratory\nidentification can help guide therapy.\n\nDomestic cats and dogs can also contract plague from infective fleas.\nThey may carry infected fleas home to their owners or, especially\ncats, serve as a direct source of infection. There are many flea\ntreatments and repellents appropriate for pets and available. Some\nproducts may be suitable for dogs but not cats or may be suitable for\nan adult but not a younger animal. Be sure to consult your\nveterinarian, as some products may be toxic to cats, kittens, and\npuppies, even resulting in fatalities.\n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under\nthe jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front\nleg (the armpit if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever. Please\ntake your pet to a veterinarian if you notice any abnormalities in\nyour pet.\n\nVeterinarians should protect themselves by wearing gloves when\nexamining these swellings. A bubo that ruptures may infect the\nveterinarian or even the pet owner if the pet owner is the one\npalpating the swelling.\n\nAnother form of the disease is the respiratory form. Cats may acquire\nthis form and can spread it to their owners or the veterinarians\nthrough infected expiratory droplets. People are also prone to the\nrespiratory infection as well.\n\nYou should also be aware that the fleas that hitchhike into your home\nvia a pet vehicle can also transmit disease to you, the owner or\ncaretaker of the pet. Sleeping in the same bed with dogs has been\nassociated with plague in enzootic areas (2). Plague patients with no\nhistory of exposure to rodents can be infected by _Y. pestis_ if their\npets carry infected rodent fleas into the home. Veterinarians always\nshould recommend flea control to dog and cat owners.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. CDC. Human plague -- four states, 2006. MMWR 2006; 55(34): 940-3;\navailable at http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5534a4.htm.\n2. Gould LH, Pape J, Ettestad P, et al: Dog-associated risk factors\nfor human plague. Zoonoses Public Health 2008; 55(8-10): 448-54;\nabstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18489541. -\nMod.TG]", "summary": "\n\nTo prevent plague, the Department of Health recommends the\nfollowing:\n- avoid sick or dead rodents and rabbits, and their nests and\nburrows;\n- keep your pets from roaming and hunting, and talk to your\nveterinarian about using an appropriate flea control product;\n- clean up areas near the house where rodents could live, such as\nwoodpiles, brush piles, junk, and abandoned vehicles;\n- sick pets should be examined promptly by a veterinarian;\n- see your doctor about any unexplained illness involving a sudden\nand severe fever;\n- put hay, wood, and compost piles as far as possible from your home;\n- don't leave your pet's food and water where mice can get to it. For more information, including fact sheets\nin English and Spanish, go to the Department's website at\nhttp://www.health.state.nm.us/erd/HealthData/plague.shtml\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n< The plague case-fatality rate\ndepends on the clinical presentation (that is, bubonic, septicemic, or\npneumonic) and timing of antibiotic therapy initiation; if untreated,\nthe case-fatality rate is over 50 per cent for bubonic plague and\napproaches 100 per cent for pneumonic plague (1). *********************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n Humans can be infected through 1) the bite of an infected\nflea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals; 2) direct contact\nwith contaminated tissues; or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of\nrespiratory secretions from infected people or animals. Pets infected with plague are often\nhunters who have eaten an infected rodent or been bitten by a rodent's\nfleas prior to getting ill,' said Dr Paul Ettestad, public health\nveterinarian for the Department of Health. ' is generally transmitted to\nhumans through the bites of infected fleas, but can also be\ntransmitted by direct contact with infected animals, including\nrodents, rabbits and pets. ' In New Mexico, there have been 2 human cases so far in 2011, both\nfrom Santa Fe County; no human cases in 2010 and 6 human cases of\nplague in 2009: 3 from Santa Fe County, 2 from Bernalillo County and\none from Sandoval County. The dog was most\nlikely infected when running in open fields on the north end of the\ncity and encountering sick or dead rabbits and other rodents, health\nofficials said. \n\n'A plague case in a pet serves as a warning that there is plague\nactivity in rabbits, rodents, and their fleas in the area,' said Dr\nCatherine Torres, the Department of Health's cabinet secretary. Plague patients with no\nhistory of exposure to rodents can be infected by _Y. pestis_ if their\npets carry infected rodent fleas into the home. Pets can transport the\nfleas back into the home where they can infect people.'\n\nSymptoms of plague in humans include sudden onset of fever, chills,\nheadache, and weakness. \n\nYou should also be aware that the fleas that hitchhike into your home\nvia a pet vehicle can also transmit disease to you, the owner or\ncaretaker of the pet. \n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under\nthe jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front\nleg (the armpit if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Rio Rancho in central New Mexico can be located via the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/0*Cr.\n\n A bubo that ruptures may infect the\nveterinarian or even the pet owner if the pet owner is the one\npalpating the swelling. Cats may acquire\nthis form and can spread it to their owners or the veterinarians\nthrough infected expiratory droplets. With prompt diagnosis and\nwith appropriate antibiotic treatment, the fatality rate in people and\npets can be greatly reduced.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santa Fe County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sandoval County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rio Rancho", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bernalillo County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "752470", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, animal - USA (03): (CO)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=752470", "date": "2011-06-12 19:53:36", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (03): (COLORADO)\n*************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: 3 Jun 2011\nSource: Boulder County [edited]\nhttp://www.bouldercounty.org/apps/newsroom/templates/bc.aspx?articleid=2659&zoneid=1\n\n\nA domestic cat living in the 2500 block of Sixth Street has tested\npositive for plague. Additionally, a dead squirrel [probably a tree\nsquirrel] found at the intersection of Eighth Street and Maxwell\nAvenue has tested positive for plague. As a result, signs listing\nprecautionary measures to avoid plague have been posted in the\nMapleton Hill neighborhood.\n\nThis is the 1st time plague activity has been confirmed in Boulder\nCounty this season [2011].\n\nFor more information about plague, please visit\nhttp://www.BoulderCountyHealth.org or call the Health Alert Hotline\nat 303-441-1460.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: 9 Jun 2011\nSource: Boulder Weekly [edited]\nhttp://www.boulderweekly.com/article-5757-plague-passes-with-rabies-on-its-heels.html\n\n\nThe plague outbreak in Boulder's Mapleton Hill area reported last\nweek seems to have run its course, according to county officials. But\n2 confirmed cases of rabies in bats rolled in this week to take its\nplace.\n\nOn 3 Jun 2011, Boulder County Public Health (BCPH) announced that a\ndomestic cat and a dead squirrel tested positive for plague. The cat\nlived in the 2500 block of 6th Street, and the squirrel was found at\n8th Street and Maxwell Avenue. Health officials posted signs around\nthe neighborhood advising residents of the danger and listing\nprecautionary measures to take.\n\nJoe Malinowski, manager of the BCPH Environmental Health Division,\nsaid this week that a 2nd dead squirrel tested positive for plague,\nbut the cat was successfully treated for the disease. There have been\nno other confirmed cases, he said, adding that he knows of no humans\nwho have reported contracting symptoms of the plague, which include\nhigh fever, extreme fatigue and painful, swollen lymph nodes. His\noffice has, however, received a few calls from area residents\nreporting additional dead squirrels. But Malinowski said officials\nwon't test another squirrel unless 2 or more are found in the same\nlocation.\n\nThe same area got hit with a similar plague infestation in 2005, he\nsaid, but usually the disease targets prairie dogs, not squirrels.\nMalinowski added that the plague typically runs its course within a\nfew days. 'It goes through the population pretty quickly,' he said.\nUsually, prairie dogs return to the empty burrows of a colony that has\nbeen wiped out, and the squirrel population on Mapleton Hill is\nexpected to bounce back as well, he explained.\n\nThis is the 1st confirmed case of plague identified this season\n[2011], but Malinowski said it is common to have outbreaks each year.\n\nResidents were advised to keep cats indoors, since they seem to be\nmore susceptible to plague than dogs.\n\nOfficials suggest protecting pets with flea powder and keeping them\non a leash and out of wild rodent habitats. People entering wild\nrodent habitats should wear insect repellent and tuck their pants into\nsocks to prevent flea bites. Long-handed shovels should be used to\nremove dead rodents, and they should be sealed in garbage bags and\nplaced in garbage cans. Asked what symptoms sick animals exhibit\noutwardly, Malinowski said plague is not like distemper, which can\nleave animals like raccoons acting lethargic and wobbly. 'Typically,'\nhe said, 'the plague acts so quickly that death comes fast.'\n\n[Byline: Jefferson Dodge]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[With the widespread hot weather we are getting through the western\nstates, we can confidently expect more of these peri-domestic plague\ncases. - Mod.MHJ]", "summary": "\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[With the widespread hot weather we are getting through the western\nstates, we can confidently expect more of these peri-domestic plague\ncases. \n\nJoe Malinowski, manager of the BCPH Environmental Health Division,\nsaid this week that a 2nd dead squirrel tested positive for plague,\n Additionally, a dead squirrel [probably a tree\nsquirrel] found at the intersection of Eighth Street and Maxwell\nAvenue has tested positive for plague. no other confirmed cases, he said, adding that he knows of no humans\nwho have reported contracting symptoms of the plague, which include\nhigh fever, extreme fatigue and painful, swollen lymph nodes. Asked what symptoms sick animals exhibit\noutwardly, Malinowski said plague is not like distemper, which can\nleave animals like raccoons acting lethargic and wobbly. ' PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (03): (COLORADO)\n*************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org As a result, signs listing\nprecautionary measures to avoid plague have been posted in the\nMapleton Hill neighborhood. But Malinowski said officials\nwon't test another squirrel unless 2 or more are found in the same\nlocation. Usually, prairie dogs return to the empty burrows of a colony that has\nbeen wiped out, and the squirrel population on Mapleton Hill is\nexpected to bounce back as well, he explained. For more information about plague, please visit\nhttp://www.BoulderCountyHealth.org or call the Health Alert Hotline\nat 303-441-1460. The cat\nlived in the 2500 block of 6th Street, and the squirrel was found at\n8th Street and Maxwell Avenue. Health officials posted signs around\nthe neighborhood advising residents of the danger and listing\nprecautionary measures to take. But\n2 confirmed cases of rabies in bats rolled in this week to take its\nplace.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "rabies"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2011-06-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Boulder County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Boulder \n County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Boulder", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mapleton Hill", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1165863", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (02): (OR), septicemic", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1165863", "date": "2012-06-12 21:40:57", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (02): (OREGON), SEPTICEMIC\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 11 Jun 2012\nSource: KTVZ [edited]\nhttp://www.ktvz.com/news/31180725/detail.html\n\nCrook County health officials said Mon, 11 Jun 2012, they are investigating a probable case of human plague involving a man in his 50s who is being treated at a local hospital. Contacts with the individual have been notified and are receiving preventive antibiotics, officials said. The man reported contact with a sick stray cat in his neighborhood, they added.\n\nCrook County officials did not identify the man, citing patient confidentiality regulations, but a family member contacted NewsChannel 21, which then learned he's in critical condition at St. Charles Medical Center-Bend. A family member told us he's been only given 30 percent survival odds at present.\n\nThe man was bitten by the cat last week and within 48 hours was taken to a Portland hospital for treatment. He was then moved to Bend, where he is now fighting for his life. Friends say his organs started shutting as they wait to see if antibiotics can get rid of the illness.\n\nPlague is spread to humans or animals through a bite from an infected flea or by contact with an animal sick with the disease. 'People can protect themselves, their family members and their pets,' said Karen Yeargain, communicable disease coordinator with the Crook County Health Department. 'Using flea treatment on your pets will prevent your pets from bringing fleas into your home. Plague is serious but it is treatable with antibiotics if caught early.'\n\nA domestic cat in Crook County tested positive for bubonic plague a year ago. 'For people, it's the cats bringing home the fleas to a household or being in contact with a cat or dog who is actually sick with the plague,' Yeargain told NewsChannel 21. 'Almost exactly a year ago, we did have a cat diagnosed with the plague,' said Yeargain, 'that cat also had septicemic, or bloodstream infection, and that cat did pull through.'\n\nPlague is rare in Oregon. Only 3 human cases have been diagnosed statewide since Crook County's last case of plague in 1995. According to Yeargain, the last Crook County case occurred in a resident who was exposed to plague-infected fleas from household cats that hunted rodents in the fields. 2 of 3 cats in that household also tested positive for plague exposure. In 2010, 2 human cases of plague were diagnosed in Lake County. Further investigation revealed that the family dog had also been exposed to plague. In 2011, an additional case with exposures in Lake County was diagnosed. There were no fatalities in humans or household animals in these cases.\n\nSymptoms of plague typically develop within 1 to 4 days after exposure. 3 clinical syndromes have been described; bubonic (lymph node infection), septicemic (blood infection), and pneumonic (lung infection). Bubonic plague is the most common form and is characterized by high temperatures, lethargy and swollen lymph nodes, most commonly in the neck and under the jaw. Infected lymph nodes may spontaneously abscess and drain.\n\nCollin Gillin, DVM, Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife, reminds people that if anyone observes sick or dead rodents of any kind, to contact the Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife veterinarians. Some additional steps to prevent flea bites are to wear insect repellant, tuck pant cuffs into socks when in areas heavily occupied by rodents, and avoid contact with wildlife including rodents. Pet owners are encouraged to keep cats indoors. Also, do not handle ill-appearing stray or wild animals.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most cases of _Yersinia pestis_ infections in the USA are reported from the Four Corners area of the USA where the states of Colorado, Utah, Arizona and New Mexico come together although as mentioned in the posting, cases occur in Oregon as well as California.\n\nAs outlined by the CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) at http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvbid/plague/diagnosis.htm: 'Death from bubonic plague occurs after the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_ escapes from the infected bubo into the bloodstream (septicemic plague) causing the manifestations of the sepsis syndrome. Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) with subsequent cutaneous hemorrhage may well have been what was called the 'Black Death' in the Middle Ages. The bacterium can spread to the lungs, causing a secondary plague pneumonia (secondary to the bacteremia), or to the meninges, causing a plague meningitis. Both of these events have a high case fatality rate and the secondary plague pneumonia is the way the infection spreads (by aerosol) from person to person.\n\n'The typical sign of the most common form of human plague is a swollen and very tender lymph gland, accompanied by pain. The swollen gland is called a 'bubo.' Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2 to 6 days after being infected.\n\n'When bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they spread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal condition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antibiotic therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. About 14 per cent (1 in 7) of all plague cases in the United States are fatal.'\n\nThe severity of the illness in this man suggests that septicemic plague is occurring here. The need for chemoprophylaxis suggests a concern regarding pneumonic plague which can transmit from person-to-person.\n\n[The interactive HealthMap/ProMED map for the state of Oregon is available at: http://healthmap.org/r/1fWb. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "\n\nAs outlined by the CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) at http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvbid/plague/diagnosis.htm: 'Death from bubonic plague occurs after the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_ escapes from the infected bubo into the bloodstream (septicemic plague) causing the manifestations of the sepsis syndrome. Source: KTVZ [edited]\nhttp://www.ktvz.com/news/31180725/detail.html\n\nCrook County health officials said Mon, 11 Jun 2012, they are investigating a probable case of human plague involving a man in his 50s who is being treated at a local hospital. \n\n'When bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the bloodstream. The bacterium can spread to the lungs, causing a secondary plague pneumonia (secondary to the bacteremia), or to the meninges, causing a plague meningitis. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. Almost exactly a year ago, we did have a cat diagnosed with the plague,' said Yeargain, 'that cat also had septicemic, or bloodstream infection, and that cat did pull through.'
