The\nman is believed to have been infected while hunting in Lake County,\nOregon. He is receiving treatment for the disease.\n\n'Plague is spread to humans through a bite from an infected flea,'\nsaid Genni Lehnert-Beers, Umatilla County public health administrator.\n'Plague is serious but it is treatable with antibiotics if caught\nearly.'\n\nOnly 3 human cases of plague have been diagnosed in Oregon since 1995,\nincluding 2 in Lake County in 2010. All 3 people recovered.\n\nLehnert-Beers recommends that people stay away from flea-infested\nareas and learn to recognize plague symptoms. Plague can be cured with\nantimicrobials, but early treatment is essential. Untreated plague can\nbe fatal. Lehnert-Beers also recommends taking precautions against\nfleas and flea bites, including using flea treatment on pets, wearing\ninsect repellent, tucking pant cuffs into socks when in areas heavily\noccupied by rodents and avoiding contact with wildlife.\n\n[Byline: Michelle Dupler]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most cases of _Yersinia pestis_ infections in the USA are reported\nfrom the Four Corners area of the USA where the states of Colorado,\nUtah, Arizona and New Mexico come together.\n\nAs outlined by the CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) at\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvbid/plague/diagnosis.htm:\n'Death from bubonic plague occurs after the bacterium _Yersinia\npestis_ escapes from the infected bubo into the bloodstream\n(septicemic plague) causing the manifestations of the sepsis syndrome.\nDisseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) with subsequent cutaneous\nhemorrhage may well have been what was called the 'Black Death' in the\nMiddle Ages. The bacterium can spread to the lungs, causing a\nsecondary plague pneumonia (secondary to the bacteremia), or to the\nmeninges, causing a plague meningitis. Both of these events have a\nhigh case fatality rate and the secondary plague pneumonia is the way\nthe infection spreads (by aerosol) from person to person.\n\n'The typical sign of the most common form of human plague is a swollen\nand very tender lymph gland, accompanied by pain. The swollen gland is\ncalled a 'bubo.' Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person\ndevelops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme\nexhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected\nrodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic\nplague 2 to 6 days after being infected.\n\n'When bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the\nbloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they\nspread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal\ncondition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the\npneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected\nperson may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing\ndifficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not\ngiven specific antibiotic therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to\ndeath. About 14 per cent (1 in 7) of all plague cases in the United\nStates are fatal.'\n- Mod.LL]\n\n[The interactive HealthMap/ProMED map for the state of Oregon is\navailable at: http://healthmap.org/r/1fWb - CopyEd.EJP]", "summary": "PLAGUE - USA (04): (OREGON), SEPTICEMIC\n***************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n As outlined by the CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) at\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvbid/plague/diagnosis.htm:\n'Death from bubonic plague occurs after the bacterium _Yersinia\npestis_ escapes from the infected bubo into the bloodstream\n Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person\ndevelops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme\nexhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected\nrodents, rabbits, or fleas. Lehnert-Beers also recommends taking precautions against\nfleas and flea bites, including using flea treatment on pets, wearing\ninsect repellent, tucking pant cuffs into socks when in areas heavily\noccupied by rodents and avoiding contact with wildlife. The bacterium can spread to the lungs, causing a\nsecondary plague pneumonia (secondary to the bacteremia), or to the\nmeninges, causing a plague meningitis. Both of these events have a\nhigh case fatality rate and the secondary plague pneumonia is the way\nthe infection spreads (by aerosol) from person to person. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they\nspread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal\ncondition. If plague patients are not\ngiven specific antibiotic therapy, the disease can progress rapidly to\ndeath. The infected\nperson may experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing\ndifficulty and may expel bloody sputum. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most cases of _Yersinia pestis_ infections in the USA are reported\nfrom the Four Corners area of the USA where the states of Colorado,\nUtah, Arizona and New Mexico come together. The\nman is believed to have been infected while hunting in Lake County,\nOregon.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "1995-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "OREGON", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United \n States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lake County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Umatilla County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "750921", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, animal - USA (02): (OR) feline", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=750921", "date": "2011-06-10 20:55:34", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA (02): (OREGON) FELINE\n******************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 9 Jun 2011\nSource: The Oregonian [edited]\nhttp://www.oregonlive.com/pacific-northwest-news/index.ssf/2011/06/barn_cat_in_prineville_infected_by_the_plague.html\n\n\nBarn cat in Prineville infected by the plague\n---------------------------------------------\nA barn cat in Prineville, Oregon, is being treated for an infectious\ndisease associated with the Middle Ages: bubonic plague. Emilio\nDeBess, Oregon's public health veterinarian, said the 6-year-old cat,\nnamed Meow, was brought into a veterinarian in Prineville at the end\nof May with an abscessed lymph node on its neck and an elevated fever.\nThe vet, worried about the symptoms, alerted DeBess and sent a sample\nof the cat's lymph node to the Veterinary Diagnostic Laboratory at\nOregon State University. Sure enough, Meow had the plague, a disease\nthat has infected wild animals such as squirrels and rats in New\nMexico, Arizona, California and Colorado but is rarely seen in Oregon\nor Washington. The only recent case of a wild animal in Oregon\ninvolved mule deer in Grant County in 2005.\n\nThe plague is carried by fleas, which often infect mice and rats but\ncan bite people and pets as well. DeBess said that since 1995, only 3\npeople in Oregon have been infected. 2 of those cases -- a mother and\ndaughter in Lakeview -- got sick last year [2010]. Their dog was\ninfected as well but the husband was not sick.\n\nStill, those 2 cases grabbed DeBess' attention. 'That's a change from\nwhat we've seen in the past,' he said. 'We're keeping an eye on what's\ngoing on.'\n\nThe other case involved a woman in Bend in 1995 and her 2 cats. All 3\npeople recovered. So did the cats and the dog and Meow is also on his\nway to a full recovery. Meow's owners did not get sick, DeBess said.\n\nEarly detection of the infection and treatment with antibiotics is\ncritical. Untreated, the plague can be fatal. Cats are especially\nsusceptible, DeBess said. Although dogs can become infected, they're\nwhat's known as sentinel animals in that they don't show any symptoms.\nPlague symptoms usually appear one to 4 days after exposure and\ninclude fever, chills, headache, swollen lymph nodes, abdominal pain\nand pneumonia.\n\nDeBess said this latest case should not cause panic but push people\ntowards prevention. 'This is a reminder to use flea treatment and to\nwatch for illnesses that we might not normally think of,' he said.\nCheck with your vet on the best flea treatments for your pets. People\ncan guard against flea bites with insect repellent. Additional\nmeasures may be necessary in areas rife with rodents, including\ntucking pant cuffs into socks. Obviously, avoid contact with mice and\nrats. And if you -- or your pets -- get sick, seek medical help.\n\n[Byline: Lynne Terry]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It's that time of year. _Y. pestis_ infections are not uncommon in\ndomestic cats and dogs up and down the foothills of the Rockies. The\nincidence depends on the ability of the animal owners to recognize\nthat something worth a visit to the veterinarian is worthwhile. And\nflea preventative treatments are easy and omni-available. No one wants\na pet to wander into the home and deposit a flea or 2 on the carpet\nand bite the kids.\n\n[To find Prineville, go to:\nhttp://www.fallingrain.com/world/US/OR/Prineville.html\nHealthmap at http://healthmap.org/en/ - Mod.MHJ]", "summary": "*****************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n Emilio\nDeBess, Oregon's public health veterinarian, said the 6-year-old cat,\nnamed Meow, was brought into a veterinarian in Prineville at the end\nof May with an abscessed lymph node on its neck and an elevated fever. Sure enough, Meow had the plague, a disease\nthat has infected wild animals such as squirrels and rats in New\nMexico, Arizona, California and Colorado but is rarely seen in Oregon\nor Washington. Plague symptoms usually appear one to 4 days after exposure and\ninclude fever, chills, headache, swollen lymph nodes, abdominal pain\nand pneumonia. The vet, worried about the symptoms, alerted DeBess and sent a sample\nof the cat's lymph node to the Veterinary Diagnostic Laboratory at\nOregon State University. No one wants\na pet to wander into the home and deposit a flea or 2 on the carpet\nand bite the kids. Although dogs can become infected, they're\nwhat's known as sentinel animals in that they don't show any symptoms.\n The\nincidence depends on the ability of the animal owners to recognize\nthat something worth a visit to the veterinarian is worthwhile. Additional\nmeasures may be necessary in areas rife with rodents, including\ntucking pant cuffs into socks. Communicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n< \n\nThe plague is carried by fleas, which often infect mice and rats but\ncan bite people and pets as well. \n\nDeBess said this latest case should not cause panic but push people\ntowards prevention. ' 2 of those cases -- a mother and\ndaughter in Lakeview -- got sick last year [2010]. DeBess said that since 1995, only 3\npeople in Oregon have been infected. This is a reminder to use flea treatment and to\nwatch for illnesses that we might not normally think of,' he said.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "1995-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "OREGON", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Prineville", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Grant County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lakeview", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "689110", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, pneumonic - Madagascar (04)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=689110", "date": "2011-04-01 10:14:08", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PNEUMONIC - MADAGASCAR (04)\n***********************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 31 Mar 2011\nSource: tagesschau.de [in German, machine trans., edited]\nhttp://www.tagesschau.de/ausland/pest100.html\n\n\nIn Madagascar, the death toll from plague is rising. According to\nofficial figures as 60 people died of the infectious disease. About\n200 people were also infected with the plague, the health authority\nsaid in Antananarivo. 'We are very concerned,' said Bruno Maes from\nthe UN children's agency UNICEF in the capital of Madagascar over the\nrapid spread of the plague.\n\nMeanwhile, almost all regions of the island nation in southeast\nAfrica are affected by the disease. Plague is transmitted primarily\nthrough the bite of rat fleas to humans. Many rats flee in the rainy\nseason and periodic flooding from November to April in the villages\nand towns.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Pneumonic plague has been occurring in the region with spread from\nperson to person via the respiratory route. It is not clear how many\nof these cases are due to plague pneumonia or if many are bubonic\nplague cases, that in the absence of pneumonia, does not transmit from\nperson to person.\n\nPrimary pneumonic plague (one percent of natural plague\npresentations) arises as a result of inhalation of plague bacilli in\ninfectious aerosols, such as would be produced when there are\nsecondary pneumonic complications in bubonic/septicemic plague.\n\nPrimary plague pneumonia has a short incubation period of 1-3 days,\nafter which there is sudden onset of flu-like symptoms including\nfever, chills, headache, generalized body pains, weakness and chest\ndiscomfort. A cough develops with sputum production, which may be\nbloody, and increasing chest pain and difficulty in breathing. As the\ndisease progresses, hypoxia (low oxygen concentration in the blood)\nand hemoptysis (coughing up blood) are prominent. The disease is\ninvariably fatal unless antimicrobial therapy commences within 24\nhours of exposure.\n\nPatients with primary pneumonic plague generate large quantities of\ninfectious aerosols that pose a significant risk to close contacts.\nCDC guidelines identify contacts within 2 meters as being at greatest\nrisk and do not consider the organism likely to be carried through air\nducts or vents. Persons who have been in contact with pneumonic plague\npatients or handling potentially infectious body fluids or tissues\nwithout appropriate protection should receive preventive antimicrobial\ntherapy. The preferred antimicrobial agents for prophylaxis are\ntetracyclines, quinolones, or chloramphenicol. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "PLAGUE, PNEUMONIC - MADAGASCAR (04)\n***********************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nPrimary pneumonic plague (one percent of natural plague\npresentations) arises as a result of inhalation of plague bacilli in\ninfectious aerosols, such as would be produced when there are\nsecondary pneumonic complications in bubonic/septicemic plague. It is not clear how many\nof these cases are due to plague pneumonia or if many are bubonic\nplague cases, that in the absence of pneumonia, does not transmit from\nperson to person. \n\nPrimary plague pneumonia has a short incubation period of 1-3 days,\nafter which there is sudden onset of flu-like symptoms including\nfever, chills, headache, generalized body pains, weakness and chest\ndiscomfort. Persons who have been in contact with pneumonic plague\npatients or handling potentially infectious body fluids or tissues\nwithout appropriate protection should receive preventive antimicrobial\ntherapy. We are very concerned,' said Bruno Maes from\nthe UN children's agency UNICEF in the capital of Madagascar over the\nrapid spread of the plague. As the\ndisease progresses, hypoxia (low oxygen concentration in the blood)\nand hemoptysis (coughing up blood) are prominent. CDC guidelines identify contacts within 2 meters as being at greatest\nrisk and do not consider the organism likely to be carried through air\nducts or vents.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "704026", "headline": "PRO/AH> Plague, animal - USA: (NM) canine, feline", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=704026", "date": "2011-04-21 02:49:37", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMAL - USA: (NEW MEXICO) CANINE, FELINE\n*************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 13 Apr 2011\nSource: Albuquerque Journal [edited]\nhttp://www.abqjournal.com/abqnews/abqnewseeker-mainmenu-39/28642-pet-plague-cases-confirmed-in-new-mexico.html\n[subscription required. A similar report can be found at: KRQE, New\nMexico Department of Health (NMDOH) report [edited]\nhttp://www.kasa.com/dpps/news/news_health/nmdoh-confirms-plague-in-three-animals_3773229\n\n]\n\n\nThe New Mexico Department of Health's Scientific Laboratory Division\nthis week confirmed a case of plague in a dog in Santa Fe County just\neast of the Santa Fe city limits and has confirmed animal plague cases\nin another dog from Santa Fe County just west of the Santa Fe city\nlimits and in a cat from Rio Arriba County near Abiuqui, according to\na health department news release.\n\nThe cases are the 1st to be reported in 2011, the release said. All\nthe animal cases have recovered, and no human plague cases have been\nconfirmed, according to the health department.\n\n'Plague cases in pets serve as a warning that there is plague\nactivity in rodents and their fleas and human cases can follow, so I\nencourage all New Mexicans to follow the prevention recommendations to\nkeep themselves and their families safe,' health secretary Dr\nCatherine Torres said in the release.\n\nTo prevent plague, the Department of Health recommends:\n- avoid sick or dead rodents and rabbits, and their nests and\nburrows;\n- keep your pets from roaming and hunting and talk to your\nveterinarian about using an appropriate flea control product;\n- clean up areas near the house where rodents could live, such as\nwoodpiles, brush piles, junk and abandoned vehicles;\n- sick pets should be examined promptly by a veterinarian;\n- see your doctor about any unexplained illness involving a sudden\nand severe fever;\n- put hay, wood, and compost piles as far as possible from your\nhome;\n- don't leave your pet's food and water where mice can get to it;\n- veterinarians and their staff are at higher risk and should take\nprecautions when seeing suspect animal plague cases.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[New Mexico can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive\nmap at http://healthmap.org/r/00bF. Santa Fe and Rio Arriba counties\nin northern New Mexico can be seen on the map at\nhttp://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/new-mexico.shtml. -\nSr.Tech.Ed.MJ\n\nPlague, caused by _Yersinia pestis_, is enzootic among rodents in the\nwestern USA. Humans can be infected through 1) the bite of an infected\nflea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals, 2) direct contact\nwith contaminated tissues, or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of\nrespiratory secretions from infected people or animals.\n\nPlague is a category A potential bioterrorism agent. Human infections\nare rare but can be life-threatening. The plague case-fatality rate\ndepends on the clinical presentation (that is, bubonic, septicemic, or\npneumonic) and timing of antibiotic therapy initiation; if untreated,\nthe case-fatality rate is over 50 per cent for bubonic plague and\napproaches 100 per cent for pneumonic plague (1). Rapid laboratory\nidentification can help guide therapy.\n\nDomestic cats and dogs can also contract plague from infective fleas.\nThey may carry infected fleas home to their owners or, especially\ncats, serve as a direct source of infection. There are many flea\ntreatments and repellents appropriate for pets and available. Some\nproducts may be suitable for dogs but not cats or may be suitable for\nan adult but not a younger animal. Be sure to consult your\nveterinarian, as some products may be toxic to cats, kittens, and\npuppies, even resulting in fatalities.\n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under\nthe jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front\nleg (the armpit if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever. Please\ntake your pet to a veterinarian if you notice any abnormalities in\nyour pet.\n\nVeterinarians should protect themselves by wearing gloves when\nexamining these swellings. A bubo that ruptures may infect the\nveterinarian or even the pet owner if the pet owner is the one\npalpating the swelling.\n\nAnother form of the disease is the respiratory form. Cats may acquire\nthis form and can spread it to their owners or the veterinarians\nthrough infected expiratory droplets. People are also prone to the\nrespiratory infection as well.\n\nYou should also be aware that the fleas that hitchhike into your home\nvia a pet vehicle can also transmit disease to you, the owner or\ncaretaker of the pet. Sleeping in the same bed with dogs has been\nassociated with plague in enzootic areas (2). Plague patients with no\nhistory of exposure to rodents can be infected by _Y. pestis_ if their\npets carry infected rodent fleas into the home. Veterinarians always\nshould recommend flea control to dog and cat owners.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. CDC. Human plague -- four states, 2006. MMWR 2006; 55(34): 940-3;\navailable at http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5534a4.htm.\n2. Gould LH, Pape J, Ettestad P, et al. Dog-associated risk factors\nfor human plague. Zoonoses Public Health 2008; 55(8-10): 448-54;\nabstract available at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18489541. -\nMod.TG]", "summary": "\n\nTo prevent plague, the Department of Health recommends:\n- avoid sick or dead rodents and rabbits, and their nests and\nburrows;\n- keep your pets from roaming and hunting and talk to your\nveterinarian about using an appropriate flea control product;\n- clean up areas near the house where rodents could live, such as\nwoodpiles, brush piles, junk and abandoned vehicles;\n- sick pets should be examined promptly by a veterinarian;\n- see your doctor about any unexplained illness involving a sudden\nand severe fever;\n- put hay, wood, and compost piles as far as possible from your\nhome;\n- don't leave your pet's food and water where mice can get to it;\n- veterinarians and their staff are at higher risk and should take\nprecautions when seeing suspect animal plague cases. A similar report can be found at: KRQE, New\nMexico Department of Health (NMDOH) report [edited]\nhttp://www.kasa.com/dpps/news/news_health/nmdoh-confirms-plague-in-three-animals_3773229\n\n]\n\n\nThe New Mexico Department of Health's Scientific Laboratory Division\nthis week confirmed a case of plague in a dog in Santa Fe County just\neast of the Santa Fe city limits and has confirmed animal plague cases\nin another dog from Santa Fe County just west of the Santa Fe city\nlimits and in a cat from Rio Arriba County near Abiuqui, according to\na health department news release. CANINE, FELINE\n*************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Plague cases in pets serve as a warning that there is plague\nactivity in rodents and their fleas and human cases can follow, so I\nencourage all New Mexicans to follow the prevention recommendations to\nkeep themselves and their families safe,' health secretary Dr\nCatherine Torres said in the release. Please\ntake your pet to a veterinarian if you notice any abnormalities in\nyour pet.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Rio Arriba County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Abiuqui", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santa Fe", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santa Fe County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "734814", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (03): (NM) bubonic", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=734814", "date": "2011-05-30 23:36:23", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (03): (NEW MEXICO) BUBONIC\n***************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 27 May 2011\nSource: Examiner.com [edited]\nhttp://www.examiner.com/infectious-disease-in-national/new-mexico-second-case-of-bubonic-plague-2011\n\n\nRodent-related diseases are making themselves known in 2011 in the\n'Land of Enchantment' with cases of hantavirus and plague finding\ntheir way into the human population.\n\nThe latest is the 2nd case of bubonic plague reported by the New\nMexico Department of Health on Fri 27 May 2011. The patient is a\n78-year-old man from Santa Fe County [also where the 1st case of 2011\nwas from. - Mod.LL] who is recovering in the hospital.\n\nNew Mexico Health Secretary Dr Catherine Torres warns that health\nofficials are seeing plague activity in both humans and animals in\nparts of north-central New Mexico and precautions need to be taken to\navoid rodents and their fleas.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most cases of _Yersinia pestis_ infection in the USA occur in the\n'Four Corners' states of Arizona, New Mexico, Colorado, and Utah and\nno cases have ever been acquired along the east coast of the country.\n\nIn New Mexico, 262 cases have been reported from 1949 to 2010\n(http://www.health.state.nm.us/erd/HealthData/documents/HumanPlagueinNMbyCounty1949-2010.pdf),\nthe cases are concentrated in the counties in the north western part\nof the state as can be seen in the URL above. Santa Fe county, where\nthis case arose, reported the most cases, which may in part be related\nto a higher population. - Mod.LL]\n\n[The Four Corners region of the US (Arizona, New Mexico, Colorado,\nand Utah) can be seen on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/00bF. Santa Fe County can be located on the\nmap at http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/new-mexico.shtml.\n- Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "PLAGUE - USA (03): (NEW MEXICO) BUBONIC\n***************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n New Mexico Health Secretary Dr Catherine Torres warns that health\nofficials are seeing plague activity in both humans and animals in\nparts of north-central New Mexico and precautions need to be taken to\navoid rodents and their fleas. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most cases of _Yersinia pestis_ infection in the USA occur in the\n'Four Corners' states of Arizona, New Mexico, Colorado, and Utah and\nno cases have ever been acquired along the east coast of the country. \n\n\nRodent-related diseases are making themselves known in 2011 in the\n'Land of Enchantment' with cases of hantavirus and plague finding\ntheir way into the human population. The patient is a\n78-year-old man from Santa Fe County [also where the 1st case of 2011\nwas from. - Mod.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["hantavirus", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-05-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santa Fe", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santa Fe County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "677787", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, pneumonic - Madagascar (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=677787", "date": "2011-03-18 14:00:09", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PNEUMONIC - MADAGASCAR (03)\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nIn this posting:\n[1] Antananarivo\n[2] Diana, Atsinanana\n\n******\n[1] Antananarivo\nDate: Tue 15 Mar 2011\nSource: L'Express de Madagascar [in French, trans. Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ,\nsumm. & edited]\n<http://www.lexpressmada.com/ambohimangakely-madagascar/21762-une-fillette-meurt-de-la-peste.html>\n\n\nAs of today [15 Mar 2011], 3 people have been killed by plague in\nAmbohimangakely [Antananarivo]. Yesterday [14 Mar 2011], at about 5 in\nthe morning, an 8-year-old girl died from pneumonic plague. Her family\nrefuses to admit [the diagnosis] but the medical inspector of\nAntananarivo-Avaradrano, Minoso Saholy Razafindravao, stated that the\n2 tests performed confirmed it.\n\n'My daughter told me she had a stomach ache. But she was able to play\nas usual. In our home, when we are sick, the doctors quickly conclude\nthat every case is the plague,' comments the mother of the victim. On\nthe other hand, the medical inspector reaffirms his case. 'We sent the\nresults to the Institut Pasteur of Madagascar. We will know in 10 days\nif it is indeed the plague,' she said.\n\nChemoprophylaxis (preventive treatment) was given to all persons who\nhad direct contact with the victim. Area family homes have been\nsanitized and disinfected.\n\n[Byline: Michella Raharisoa]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-FRA\n<promed-fra@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Diana, Atsinanana\nDate: Wed 23 Feb 2011\nSource: Madagascar-Tribune [in French, trans. Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ, summ. &\nedited]\n<http://www.madagascar-tribune.com/La-peste-fait-23-morts,15525.html>\n\n\nPlague has hit where it was least expected. 15 people have died from\nthis disease in parts of the enclave district of Ambilobe [Diana\nregion]. Other deaths occurred in the area of Brickaville [Atsinanana\nregion]. The populations of the villages concerned, hardly familiar\nwith the symptoms of the disease, have been slow to reach out to\nmedical centers and the appropriate means to fight against this\nepidemic have been slow to reach them.\n\nIn total, 45 cases of plague have been detected in Madagascar since\nthe beginning of the year [2011], and 23 people have died.\n\nPlague occurs in Madagascar almost every year, with outbreaks taking\nplace between October and April, when the combined effects of the\nrainy season and drought period affect the food: hygienic conditions\ndeteriorate and rats begin to enter the villages.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-FRA\n<promed-fra@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is not clear from this report whether the cases are pneumonic or\nbubonic plague. A high mortality rate suggests many are pneumonic\nplague, which is the form that can transmit from person-to-person. -\nMod.LL]\n\n[An article from L'Express de Madagascar\n(<http://www.lexpressmada.com/epidemie-madagascar/21168-dix-neuf-victimes-de-la-peste-en-une-semaine.html>\nin French), dated 22 Feb 2011, reports 14 deaths from pneumonic plague\nin a village located 65 km [40 mi] from the district of Ambilobe\n(Diana region) and 3 deaths also from pneumonic plague in the district\nof Brickaville (Atsinanana region). It further reports the death from\nbubonic plague of a 10-year-old girl in Ambohimangakely, near the\nCapital city (Antananarivo).\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Madagascar can be seen\nat <http://healthmap.org/r/0BeG>. The regions mentioned in the\narticles above can be seen on the map at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regions_of_Madagascar>.- Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "LL]\n\n[An article from L'Express de Madagascar\n(<http://www.lexpressmada.com/epidemie-madagascar/21168-dix-neuf-victimes-de-la-peste-en-une-semaine.html>\nin French), dated 22 Feb 2011, reports 14 deaths from pneumonic plague\nin a village located 65 km [40 mi] from the district of Ambilobe\n(Diana region) and 3 deaths also from pneumonic plague in the district\nof Brickaville (Atsinanana region). A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nIn this posting:\n Plague occurs in Madagascar almost every year, with outbreaks taking\nplace between October and April, when the combined effects of the\nrainy season and drought period affect the food: hygienic conditions\ndeteriorate and rats begin to enter the villages. The populations of the villages concerned, hardly familiar\nwith the symptoms of the disease, have been slow to reach out to\nmedical centers and the appropriate means to fight against this\nepidemic have been slow to reach them. Her family\nrefuses to admit [the diagnosis] but the medical inspector of\nAntananarivo-Avaradrano, Minoso Saholy Razafindravao, stated that the\n2 tests performed confirmed it. Communicated by:\nProMED-FRA\n<promed-fra@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n It further reports the death from\nbubonic plague of a 10-year-old girl in Ambohimangakely, near the\nCapital city (Antananarivo). 15 people have died from\nthis disease in parts of the enclave district of Ambilobe [Diana\nregion]. PLAGUE, PNEUMONIC - MADAGASCAR (03)\n***********************************\n Communicated by:\nProMED-FRA\n<promed-fra@promedmail.org>\n\n MJ,\nsumm. & edited]\n<http://www.lexpressmada.com/ambohimangakely-madagascar/21762-une-fillette-meurt-de-la-peste.html>\n\n\n The regions mentioned in the\narticles above can be seen on the map at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regions_of_Madagascar>.- Sr. MJ, summ. &\nedited]\n<http://www.madagascar-tribune.com/La-peste-fait-23-morts,15525.html>\n\n\n In total, 45 cases of plague have been detected in Madagascar since\nthe beginning of the year [2011], and 23 people have died.\n\n Yesterday [14 Mar 2011], at about 5 in\nthe morning, an 8-year-old girl died from pneumonic plague.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-02-22 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Brickaville", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ambohimangakely", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "717936", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (02): (NM) bubonic", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=717936", "date": "2011-05-10 14:03:12", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (02): (NEW MEXICO) BUBONIC\n***************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 8 May 2011\nSource: NY Daily News [edited]\nhttp://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/2011/05/08/2011-05-08_man_in_new_mexico_diagnosed_with_bubonic_plague_first_case_of_black_death_in_201.html\n\n\nA 58 year old man in New Mexico was recently treated for bubonic\nplague, the 1st case of the disease to surface in 2011.\n\nHealth officials in Santa Fe said the unidentified man spent a week\nin the hospital after suffering high fever, intense pain in his\nstomach and groin, and swollen lymph nodes. He was treated and\nreleased, but officials would not say when. The results of blood tests\nreleased Thu 5 May 2011, confirmed the man had bubonic plague,\nofficials said.\n\nDoctors said the man was most likely bitten by a flea carrying the\nplague bacteria, the most common method of transmission to humans.\nRatborne fleas can carry the bacterium, and humans can also catch the\ndisease from contact with infected rodents or animals.\n\n'He was probably bitten by a flea somewhere on his left leg,'\nDepartment of Health veterinarian Paul Ettestad told the Santa Fe New\nMexican. Officials wouldn't say where the man lived, but said they\nwould check his home for rats and rodent burrows and alert his\nneighbors, the paper said.\n\nOnly about 10 to 15 people in the USA catch the illness each year,\ntypically in western states. It is particularly prevalent in New\nMexico because the state has a high population of both rodents and\nfleas.\n\nIt can be treated with antibiotics, but 1 in 7 cases is fatal. The\nlast reported outbreaks of plague in New Mexico were in 2009, when 3\npeople, including an 8 year old in Santa Fe, died.\n\n[byline: Philip Caulfield]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most cases of _Yersinia pestis_ infection in the USA occur in the\n'Four Corners' states of Arizona, New Mexico, Colorado, and Utah and\nno cases have ever been acquired along the east coast of the country.\n\nIn New Mexico, 262 cases have been reported from 1949 to 2010\n(http://www.health.state.nm.us/erd/HealthData/documents/HumanPlagueinNMbyCounty1949-2010.pdf),\nthe cases are concentrated in the counties in the north western part\nof the state as can be seen in the URL above. Santa Fe county, where\nthis case arose, reported the most cases, which may in part be related\nto a higher population. - Mod.LL\n\nThe Four Corners region of the US (Arizona, New Mexico, Colorado, and\nUtah) can be seen on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/00bF. Santa Fe County can be located on the\nmap at http://www.digital-topo-maps.com/county-map/new-mexico.shtml.\n- Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "PLAGUE - USA (02): (NEW MEXICO) BUBONIC\n***************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n[byline: Philip Caulfield]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n< \n\nHealth officials in Santa Fe said the unidentified man spent a week\nin the hospital after suffering high fever, intense pain in his\nstomach and groin, and swollen lymph nodes. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most cases of _Yersinia pestis_ infection in the USA occur in the\n'Four Corners' states of Arizona, New Mexico, Colorado, and Utah and\nno cases have ever been acquired along the east coast of the country. The results of blood tests\nreleased Thu 5 May 2011, confirmed the man had bubonic plague,\nofficials said. Officials wouldn't say where the man lived, but said they\nwould check his home for rats and rodent burrows and alert his\nneighbors, the paper said. The\nlast reported outbreaks of plague in New Mexico were in 2009, when 3\npeople, including an 8 year old in Santa Fe, died. Santa Fe county, where\nthis case arose, reported the most cases, which may in part be related\nto a higher population. (http://www.health.state.nm.us/erd/HealthData/documents/HumanPlagueinNMbyCounty1949-2010.pdf),\nthe cases are concentrated in the counties in the north western part\nof the state as can be seen in the URL above.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-05-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santa Fe", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santa Fe County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "736097", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, bubonic - Libya: (BN)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=736097", "date": "2011-05-31 19:43:19", "main_text": "PLAGUE, BUBONIC - LIBYA: (AL BUTNAN)\n************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 29 May 2011\nSource: Youm7.com [in Arabic, trans. Corr.SB, edited]\nhttp://www.youm7.com/News.asp?NewsID=423226&SecID=97&IssueID=0\n\n\nThe emergence of several infectious diseases, including plague, has\nbeen reported in the Libyan city of Tobruk. A medical source at the\ncity's central hospital, said that at least 4 cases [of plague] have\nbeen isolated at the medical hospital.\n\nHe pointed out that there are 17 other cases which are undergoing\nmedical tests on suspicion of being infected with the disease, said\nthe medical source, who preferred anonymity. There is a state of panic\nand fear, which has hit the city, and it is not the 1st time this has\noccurred, as, in mid-June 2009, there was an outbreak of bubonic\nplague on the outskirts of Tobruk, which resulted in deaths.\n\nThe source added that the Egyptian authorities are taking necessary\naction on the Egyptian-Libyan border to prevent the transmission of\nthe disease into Egypt.\n\nAn official quarantine [has been imposed] at the alternate port of\nSalloum. The fear of the spread of the disease in Egypt will be the\nbiggest focus with the re-emergence of the disease plague, and this\nhas contributed to the lawlessness taking place on the Libyan-Egyptian\nborder at the moment.\n\nThe border city of Tobruk is experiencing many difficulties in the\nfield of health services because it has lost contact with the capital,\nTripoli, since the outbreak of the revolution on 17 Feb 2011.\n\n[Byline: Mahmoud Nasr]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The manifestations of plague in these cases are not stated but are\nlikely to be bubonic in nature causing exquisitely painful\nlymphadenopathy (the bubo). In the absence of pneumonia spread from\nthe local node, person-to-person transmission in bubonic plague does\nnot occur.\n\nTobruk or Tubruq is a town, seaport, and peninsula in northeastern\nLibya, near the border with Egypt, in North Africa. It is the capital\nof Al Butnan District (formerly Tobruk District). Its location can be\nfound on a map at: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tobruk. The last\ncluster of _Yersinia pestis_ infection occurred in 2009 in the same\narea of northeastern Libya. The following contains a description of\nprevious outbreaks in the Saharan Africa area.\n\nConsumption of the meat of an infected camel has been reported to\ncause plague in Libya in 1976 (1). The abstract of the paper is: 'In\n1976, in a small, remote Libyan village, an apparently sick camel was\nslaughtered and skinned, and the camel meat was distributed for human\nconsumption. A few days later, 15 villagers suffered a severe febrile\nillness. Of the 5 individuals who had participated in the killing and\ndispensation of the camel, all were dead within 4 days. When samples\nof serum from 9 of the remaining patients were examined, 7 were found\nto be positive for plague as determined by the passive\nhemagglutination test. Another 6 persons became ill after killing 2\ngoats, and the serum of one goat contained antibodies to _Yersinia\npestis_. Because all of the remaining patients except one were treated\nearly enough, they recovered. These incidents confirm previous reports\nthat the camel and the goat are susceptible to naturally occurring\nplague infection and have a significant role in the dissemination of\nhuman plague.'\n\nTwo more recent outbreaks in the Arab world have been reported in\n2005. In Saudi Arabia (2), a cluster of 5 plague cases were reported\nincluding 4 with severe pharyngitis and submandibular lymphadenitis.\nThese 4 case-patients had eaten raw camel liver. _Yersinia pestis_ was\nisolated from bone marrow of the camel and from jirds [rodents]\n(_Meriones libycus_) and fleas (_Xenopsylla cheopis_) captured at the\ncamel corral. In Jordon (3), a 1997 outbreak of plague was reported\nassociated with cervical lymphadenopathy and fever that occurred in\nthe Jordanian village of Azraq ad-Druze, 50 km [31 miles] west of the\nborder with Saudi Arabia. The 12 cases who presented at hospital were\ninitially assumed to have tularaemia, and all were successfully\ntreated with gentamicin. But all 12 were found to have anti-_Y.\npestis_ IgM. 11 of the 12 patients reported that, 2-4 days before\ntheir symptoms appeared, they had eaten the meat cut from the carcass\nof the same camel, either raw (10 cases) or cooked (one case). All 12\npatients were diagnosed as cases of pharyngeal plague (the 1st cases\nof plague reported in Jordan for more than 80 years) caused by _Y.\npestis_ that most had acquired when they ate raw meat from a camel\nthat was infected with the pathogen.\n\nThe source of the cases of bubonic plague in northeastern Libya is\nnot reported in this posting but may be related to camels and camel\nfleas. ProMED awaits further documentation of this outbreak.\n\nPlague outbreaks in North Africa may bring to mind the novel written\nby Nobel Prize-winning novelist Albert Camus, 'The Plague,' which\nchronicled a 1940s plague outbreak in Oran, Algeria, which began with\na rat die-off in and around the apartment building of the protagonist\nDr. Bernard Rieux.\n\n1. Christie AB, Chen TH, Elberg SS. Plague in camels and goats: their\nrole in human epidemics. J Infect Dis 1980;141: 724-726.\n2. Bin Saeed AA, Al-Hamdan NA, Fontaine RE: Plague from eating raw\ncamel liver. Emerg Infect Dis. 2005;11: 1456-1457.\n3. Arbaji A, Kharabsheh S, Al-Azab S, et al: A 12-case outbreak of\npharyngeal plague following the consumption of camel meat, in\nnorth-eastern Jordan. Ann Trop Med Parasitol. 2005;99: 789-793. -\nMod.LL]\n\n[The interactive ProMED/HealthMap map showing Tobruk (Tubruq) is at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/0VFe\nZoom in step by step to see city names. - Mod.JW]", "summary": "All 12\npatients were diagnosed as cases of pharyngeal plague (the 1st cases\nof plague reported in Jordan for more than 80 years) caused by _Y.\npestis_ that most had acquired when they ate raw meat from a camel\n Plague outbreaks in North Africa may bring to mind the novel written\nby Nobel Prize-winning novelist Albert Camus, 'The Plague,' which\nchronicled a 1940s plague outbreak in Oran, Algeria, which began with\na rat die-off in and around the apartment building of the protagonist\nDr. Bernard Rieux. *****\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n But all 12 were found to have anti-_Y.\npestis_ IgM. 11 of the 12 patients reported that, 2-4 days before\ntheir symptoms appeared, they had eaten the meat cut from the carcass\nof the same camel, either raw (10 cases) or cooked (one case). These incidents confirm previous reports\nthat the camel and the goat are susceptible to naturally occurring\nplague infection and have a significant role in the dissemination of\nhuman plague.' In Jordon (3), a 1997 outbreak of plague was reported\nassociated with cervical lymphadenopathy and fever that occurred in\nthe Jordanian village of Azraq ad-Druze, 50 km [31 miles] west of the\nborder with Saudi Arabia. There is a state of panic\nand fear, which has hit the city, and it is not the 1st time this has\noccurred, as, in mid-June 2009, there was an outbreak of bubonic\nplague on the outskirts of Tobruk, which resulted in deaths. The abstract of the paper is: 'In\n1976, in a small, remote Libyan village, an apparently sick camel was\nslaughtered and skinned, and the camel meat was distributed for human\nconsumption. The fear of the spread of the disease in Egypt will be the\nbiggest focus with the re-emergence of the disease plague, and this\nhas contributed to the lawlessness taking place on the Libyan-Egyptian\nborder at the moment. _Yersinia pestis_ was\nisolated from bone marrow of the camel and from jirds [rodents]\n(_Meriones libycus_) and fleas (_Xenopsylla cheopis_) captured at the\ncamel corral. When samples\nof serum from 9 of the remaining patients were examined, 7 were found\nto be positive for plague as determined by the passive\nhemagglutination test. \n\nThe source of the cases of bubonic plague in northeastern Libya is\nnot reported in this posting but may be related to camels and camel\nfleas. Arbaji A, Kharabsheh S, Al-Azab S, et al: A 12-case outbreak of\npharyngeal plague following the consumption of camel meat, in\nnorth-eastern Jordan. A medical source at the\ncity's central hospital, said that at least 4 cases [of plague] have\nbeen isolated at the medical hospital. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The manifestations of plague in these cases are not stated but are\nlikely to be bubonic in nature causing exquisitely painful\nlymphadenopathy (the bubo). In Saudi Arabia (2), a cluster of 5 plague cases were reported\nincluding 4 with severe pharyngitis and submandibular lymphadenitis.\n He pointed out that there are 17 other cases which are undergoing\nmedical tests on suspicion of being infected with the disease, said\nthe medical source, who preferred anonymity. In the absence of pneumonia spread from\nthe local node, person-to-person transmission in bubonic plague does\nnot occur.
