Of the 5 individuals who had participated in the killing and\ndispensation of the camel, all were dead within 4 days.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1976-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "1997-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-02-17 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Oran", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Libya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tobruk", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jordon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jordan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tobruk District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Azraq", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tripoli", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saharan Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Algeria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SB", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "658689", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, pneumonic - Madagascar (02): (AS) Institut Pasteur report", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=658689", "date": "2011-02-21 12:00:12", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PNEUMONIC - MADAGASCAR (02): (ANTSIRANANA) INSTITUT PASTEUR REPORT\n**************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 14 Feb 2011\nFrom: Jean-Michel Heraud <jmheraud@pasteur.mg> [edited]\n\n[We apologize for the one week delay in posting this communication.\nThere were technical difficulties and a number of emails were\nmisdirected. - Mod. DK]\n\n[Re: Plague, pneumonic - Madagascar: (Antsiranana) RFI 20110220.0555]\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nOn Thu 10 Feb 2011, it was reported to Institut Pasteur from\nMadagascar that 14 people had died from a very contagious disease.\nAccording local health staff, syndromes of patients were likely to be\npneumonic plague. To our knowledge, only 2 out of 7 sputum samples\nhave given positive results on rapid test strips.\n\nThe initial cases appeared in a remote village located 45 km [28 mi]\nfrom Ambilobe (administrative region of Sava [Antsiranana province],\nin the north of Madagascar). Other suspected cases have been reported\nin other villages closer to Ambilobe. On Fri 11 Feb 2011, bubonic\nplague suspected cases have been reported in Ambaja, another city\nlocated in the south of villages where the 1st cases were reported.\n\nMadagascar is an endemic region for plague but cases are generally\nlocated in the Central Highlands. The current outbreak is occurring\nin a region were plague is not endemic. It is not clear for now if\nthe index cases was a patient who came from an endemic area\nincubating the disease or in its earlier stages and developed\npneumonic symptoms on arrival. Over the last year the regions of\nAmbaja and Ambilobe experienced increasing numbers of gem seekers.\nIndeed, sapphires have been recently found between Ambaja and Ambilobe.\n\nInstitut Pasteur from Madagascar (IPM) sent on Sunday morning, 13 Feb\n2011, staffs by plane in order to collect specimens. A joint team\nincluding MoH (Division of Emergency and Response against Disease,\nDULMN) is going on site for investigation.\n\n--\nDr. Jean-Michel Heraud\nChief, Virology Unit\nInstitut Pasteur de Madagascar\nAntananarivo, Madagascar\n<jmheraud@pasteur.mg>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr. Heraud for this report. It may never be\nclearly determined how _Yersinia pestis_ was introduced into this\narea of northern Madagascar where plague has not been endemic. - Mod. LL]\n\n[A map showing the regions of Madagascar can be seen at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/africa/madagascar_pol_2003.jpg>. -\nSr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 14 Feb 2011\n It is not clear for now if\nthe index cases was a patient who came from an endemic area\nincubating the disease or in its earlier stages and developed\npneumonic symptoms on arrival. On Fri 11 Feb 2011, bubonic\nplague suspected cases have been reported in Ambaja, another city\nlocated in the south of villages where the 1st cases were reported. \nDr. Jean-Michel Heraud\nChief, Virology Unit\n \n\nThe initial cases appeared in a remote village located 45 km [28 mi]\nfrom Ambilobe (administrative region of Sava [Antsiranana province],\nin the north of Madagascar). On Thu 10 Feb 2011, it was reported to Institut Pasteur from\nMadagascar that 14 people had died from a very contagious disease.\n It may never be\nclearly determined how _Yersinia pestis_ was introduced into this\narea of northern Madagascar where plague has not been endemic. A joint team\nincluding MoH (Division of Emergency and Response against Disease,\nDULMN) is going on site for investigation. Over the last year the regions of\nAmbaja and Ambilobe experienced increasing numbers of gem seekers.\n \n\nMadagascar is an endemic region for plague but cases are generally\nlocated in the Central Highlands. \n\nInstitut Pasteur from Madagascar (IPM) sent on Sunday morning, 13 Feb\n2011, staffs by plane in order to collect specimens.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-02-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2011-02-11 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ambilobe", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ambaja", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "658019", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, pneumonic - Madagascar: (Antsiranana) RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=658019", "date": "2011-02-20 15:00:04", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PNEUMONIC - MADAGASCAR :(ANTSIRANANA) REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sun 20 Feb 2011\nSource: La Tribune online, Diego Suarez, Madagascar\n[In French, trans. JW, edited]\n<http://latribune.cyber-diego.com/actualites/299-epidemie-de-peste-dans-le-nord-de-madagascar.html>\n\n\nAn epidemic of pneumonic plague has been raging for weeks in the\nnorthern region of Madagascar, mainly around Ambilobe. There are\nalready 16 deaths attributed to this epidemic.\n\nThis statement of the 'Chancellery detached from France' in Diego\nSuarez is based on information from the referring doctor's office,\nDr. Anant Govinjee:\n'An epidemic of pneumonic plague occurred in the region between Diana\nand Ambilobe Ambanja, specifically east of Beramanja (65 km). The\nfirst suspected case appeared 27 Jan 2011, followed by a first death\non 29 Jan 2011. The death toll stands at 16.\n\nA team of the Ministry of Health of Diego Suarez and a team from the\nPasteur Institute are on site. Preventive measures have been taken and\nmass chemoprophylaxis is being carried out.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Primary pneumonic plague (one percent of natural plague\npresentations) arises as a result of inhalation of plague bacilli in\ninfectious aerosols, such as would be produced when there are\nsecondary pneumonic complications in bubonic/septicemic plague.\n\nPrimary plague pneumonia has a short incubation period of 1-3 days,\nafter which there is sudden onset of flu-like symptoms including\nfever, chills, headache, generalized body pains, weakness and chest\ndiscomfort. A cough develops with sputum production, which may be\nbloody, and increasing chest pain and difficulty in breathing. As the\ndisease progresses, hypoxia (low oxygen concentration in the blood)\nand hemoptysis (coughing up blood) are prominent. The disease is\ninvariably fatal unless antimicrobial therapy commences within 24\nhours of exposure.\n\nPatients with primary pneumonic plague generate large quantities of\ninfectious aerosols that pose a significant risk to close contacts.\nCDC guidelines identify contacts within 2 meters as being at greatest\nrisk and do not consider the organism likely to be carried through\nair ducts or vents. Persons who have been in contact with pneumonic\nplague patients or handling potentially infectious body fluids or\ntissues without appropriate protection should receive preventive\nantimicrobial therapy. The preferred antimicrobial agents for\nprophylaxis are tetracyclines, quinolones, or chloramphenicol.\n\nMadagascar was the location of the isolation of multi-antimicrobial\nresistant _Y. pestis_ in 1995 (Galimand M, Guiyoule A, Gerbaud G, et\nal: Multidrug resistance in _Yersinia pestis_ mediated by a\ntransferable plasmid. N Engl J Med 1997;337: 677-81). The strain was\nresistant to chloramphenicol, streptomycin and tetracycline but\nsensitive to fluoroquinolones and trimethoprim as well as other\naminoglycosides. This was an ominous observation, however, it is not\nclear if this naturally occurring strain has persisted or spread. -\nMod. LL]\n\n[The authorities are implementing rat control in the area, but unless\nthey carry out flea control first, that will just make matters worse,\nbecause infectious fleas will jump from dying rats to humans. The\nepidemic seems to be spreading remarkably slowly for an airborne\ndisease, with just 16 deaths in 3 weeks for a disease that is\n'invariably fatal unless antimicrobial therapy commences within 24\nhours of exposure' (actually within 48hrs).\n\nMap showing Ambilobe at the northern tip of Madagascar:\n<http://www.chameleoncompany.com/madagascar_map.jpg> - Mod.JW]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sun 20 Feb 2011\n The\nepidemic seems to be spreading remarkably slowly for an airborne\ndisease, with just 16 deaths in 3 weeks for a disease that is\n'invariably fatal unless antimicrobial therapy commences within 24\nhours of exposure' (actually within 48hrs). \n\nThis statement of the 'Chancellery detached from France' in Diego\nSuarez is based on information from the referring doctor's office,\nDr. Anant Govinjee:\n'An epidemic of pneumonic plague occurred in the region between Diana\nand Ambilobe Ambanja, specifically east of Beramanja (65 km). promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Primary pneumonic plague (one percent of natural plague\npresentations) arises as a result of inhalation of plague bacilli in\ninfectious aerosols, such as would be produced when there are\nsecondary pneumonic complications in bubonic/septicemic plague. \n\nPrimary plague pneumonia has a short incubation period of 1-3 days,\nafter which there is sudden onset of flu-like symptoms including\nfever, chills, headache, generalized body pains, weakness and chest\ndiscomfort. Persons who have been in contact with pneumonic\nplague patients or handling potentially infectious body fluids or\ntissues without appropriate protection should receive preventive\nantimicrobial therapy. The strain was\nresistant to chloramphenicol, streptomycin and tetracycline but\nsensitive to fluoroquinolones and trimethoprim as well as other\naminoglycosides. LL]\n\n[The authorities are implementing rat control in the area, but unless\nthey carry out flea control first, that will just make matters worse,\nbecause infectious fleas will jump from dying rats to humans. The disease is\ninvariably fatal unless antimicrobial therapy commences within 24\nhours of exposure. \n\nMadagascar was the location of the isolation of multi-antimicrobial\nresistant _Y. pestis_ in 1995 (Galimand M, Guiyoule A, Gerbaud G, et\n CDC guidelines identify contacts within 2 meters as being at greatest\nrisk and do not consider the organism likely to be carried through\nair ducts or vents.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-01-27 00:00:00", "2011-02-20 00:00:00", "1995-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-01-29 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beramanja", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "661812", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA: (OR), 2010, bubonic, CDC", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=661812", "date": "2011-02-24 20:00:04", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA: (OREGON), 2010, BUBONIC, CDC\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 24 Feb 2011\nSource: Morbidity Mortality Weekly Report 2011;60:214 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6007a4.htm?s_cid=mm6007a4_e&source=govdelivery>\n\n\nPlague, caused by _Yersinia pestis_, is enzootic among rodents in the\nwestern USA. Humans can be infected through 1) the bite of an infected\nflea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals, 2) direct contact\nwith contaminated tissues, or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of\nrespiratory secretions from infected persons or animals. In September\n2010, the Oregon Health Authority reported the 1st 2 cases of human\nplague in Oregon since 1995 and the only 2 USA cases in 2010.\n\nBoth illnesses began on 21 Aug 2010. The patients, aged 17 and 42\nyears, lived in the same household and might have been exposed to\nplague by infected fleas from a dog; that dog was found to be\nseropositive for _Y. pestis_ by the passive\nhemagglutination-inhibition assay (dilution of 1:64). One patient\nacknowledged sleeping in the same bed with the dog during the 2 weeks\nbefore illness onset. Both patients had high fever and multiple\nbilateral inguinal buboes; one patient had hypotension, tachycardia,\nand acute renal failure and was hospitalized. A gram-negative rod with\nbipolar staining was isolated from a specimen of that patient's\nblood.\n\nFour different clinical laboratories attempted to identify the\nisolate. Three different commercial automated systems identified the\norganism as _Acinetobacter lwoffii_, _Pseudomonas luteola_, and\n_Yersinia pseudotuberculosis_, respectively. However, 25 days after\nspecimen collection, the isolate was identified as _Y. pestis_ by\ndirect fluorescent antibody to F1 antigen, polymerase chain reaction,\nand bacteriophage lysis at the Spokane (Washington) Regional Health\nDistrict Laboratory, prompting notification of the Oregon Health\nAuthority. The 2nd patient was identified retrospectively on the basis\nof a single positive serology (passive hemagglutination-inhibition\n[dilution of 1:32]). Plague was not suspected initially. Both patients\nrecovered uneventfully after empiric therapy with doxycycline and\namoxicillin clavulanate potassium, respectively, although the latter\nis not considered effective in treating plague.\n\nAutomated bacterial identification systems can misidentify _Y.\npestis_ (1,2). Automated identification of _Yersinia_ spp. in blood\nshould prompt further clinical evaluation of the patient to determine\nwhether symptoms are compatible with plague. When plague is suspected,\ntreatment should be started immediately, and both the state public\nhealth laboratory and public health authorities should be notified\npromptly.\n\nPlague is a Category A potential bioterrorism agent. Human infections\nare rare but can be life-threatening. The plague case-fatality rate\ndepends on the clinical presentation (i.e., bubonic, septicemic, or\npneumonic) and timing of antibiotic therapy initiation; if untreated,\nthe case-fatality rate is over 50 percent for bubonic plague and\napproaches 100 percent for pneumonic plague (3). Rapid laboratory\nidentification can help guide therapy.\n\nSleeping in the same bed with dogs has been associated with plague in\nenzootic areas (4). Plague patients with no history of exposure to\nrodents can be infected by _Y. pestis_ if their pets carry infected\nrodent fleas into the home. Veterinarians always should recommend flea\ncontrol to dog and cat owners.\n\nReferences\n--------\n1. American Society for Microbiology: Sentinel laboratory guidelines\nfor suspected agent of bioterrorism: Yersinia pestis. Washington, DC:\nAmerican Society for Microbiology; 2009. Available at\n<http://www.asm.org/images/pdf/Clinical/ypestis12-11-09.pdf>. Accessed\n17 Feb 2011.\n2. CDC: Fatal human plague---Arizona and Colorado, 1996. MMWR\n1997;46:617-620.\n3. CDC: Human plague---four states, 2006. MMWR 2006;55:940-943.\n4. Gould LH, Pape J, Ettestad P, Griffith KS, Mead PS: Dog-associated\nrisk factors for human plague. Zoonoses Public Health\n2008;55:448-454.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This CDC report adds additional information regarding the 2 cases of\nbubonic plague in Oregon that occurred in August 2010. Most cases of\n_Y. pestis_ infections in the USA occur in the area of the 'Four\nCorner' states: Colorado, Arizona, New Mexico and Utah. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "However, 25 days after\nspecimen collection, the isolate was identified as _Y. pestis_ by\ndirect fluorescent antibody to F1 antigen, polymerase chain reaction,\nand bacteriophage lysis at the Spokane (Washington) Regional Health\nDistrict Laboratory, prompting notification of the Oregon Health\nAuthority. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 24 Feb 2011\n The plague case-fatality rate\ndepends on the clinical presentation (i.e., bubonic, septicemic, or\npneumonic) and timing of antibiotic therapy initiation; if untreated,\nthe case-fatality rate is over 50 percent for bubonic plague and\napproaches 100 percent for pneumonic plague (3). The patients, aged 17 and 42\nyears, lived in the same household and might have been exposed to\nplague by infected fleas from a dog; that dog was found to be\nseropositive for _Y. pestis_ by the passive\nhemagglutination-inhibition assay (dilution of 1:64). Humans can be infected through 1) the bite of an infected\nflea carried by a rodent or, rarely, other animals, 2) direct contact\nwith contaminated tissues, or 3) in rare cases, inhalation of\nrespiratory secretions from infected persons or animals. When plague is suspected,\ntreatment should be started immediately, and both the state public\nhealth laboratory and public health authorities should be notified\npromptly. Both patients\nrecovered uneventfully after empiric therapy with doxycycline and\namoxicillin clavulanate potassium, respectively, although the latter\nis not considered effective in treating plague. In September\n2010, the Oregon Health Authority reported the 1st 2 cases of human\nplague in Oregon since 1995 and the only 2 USA cases in 2010. Plague patients with no history of exposure to\nrodents can be infected by _Y. pestis_ if their pets carry infected\nrodent fleas into the home. [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6007a4.htm?s_cid=mm6007a4_e&source=govdelivery>\n\n\nPlague, caused by _Yersinia pestis_, is enzootic among rodents in the\nwestern USA. in blood\nshould prompt further clinical evaluation of the patient to determine\nwhether symptoms are compatible with plague. One patient\nacknowledged sleeping in the same bed with the dog during the 2 weeks\nbefore illness onset. Both patients had high fever and multiple\nbilateral inguinal buboes; one patient had hypotension, tachycardia,\nand acute renal failure and was hospitalized. The 2nd patient was identified retrospectively on the basis\nof a single positive serology (passive hemagglutination-inhibition\n Most cases of\n_Y. pestis_ infections in the USA occur in the area of the 'Four\nCorner' states: Colorado, Arizona, New Mexico and Utah. Zoonoses Public Health\n2008;55:448-454.\n\n--\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-02-17 00:00:00", "2010-08-25 00:00:00", "2010-09-25 00:00:00", "1996-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "1995-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-02-24 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-08-21 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "DC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "OREGON", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "661759", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Plague, fatal - USA: (IL), 2009, lab strain, CDC", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=661759", "date": "2011-02-24 19:00:05", "main_text": "PLAGUE, FATAL - USA: (ILLINOIS), 2009, LAB STRAIN, CDC\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 24 Feb 2011\nSource: CDC. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 2011; 60(07): 201-5 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6007a1.htm?s_cid=mm6007a1_w>\n\n\nFatal laboratory-acquired infection with an attenuated _Yersinia\npestis_ strain -- Chicago, Illinois, 2009\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nOn 18 Sep 2009, the Chicago Department of Public Health (CDPH) was\nnotified by a local hospital of a suspected case of fatal\nlaboratory-acquired infection with _Yersinia pestis_, the causative\nagent of plague. The patient, a researcher in a university laboratory,\nhad been working along with other members of the laboratory group with\na pigmentation-negative (pgm-) attenuated _Y. pestis_ strain (KIM\nD27). The strain had not been known to have caused laboratory-acquired\ninfections or human fatalities. Other researchers in a separate\nuniversity laboratory facility in the same building had contact with a\nvirulent _Y. pestis_ strain (CO92) that is considered a select\nbiologic agent; however, the pgm- attenuated KIM D27 is excluded from\nthe National Select Agent Registry (1). The university, CDPH, the\nIllinois Department of Public Health (IDPH), and CDC conducted an\ninvestigation to ascertain the cause of death.\n\nThis report summarizes the results of that investigation, which\ndetermined that the cause of death likely was an unrecognized\noccupational exposure (route unknown) to _Y. pestis_, leading to\nseptic shock. _Y. pestis_ was isolated from premortem blood cultures.\nPolymerase chain reaction (PCR) identified the clinical isolate as a\npgm- strain of _Y. pestis_. Postmortem examination revealed no\nevidence of pneumonic plague. A postmortem diagnosis of hereditary\nhemochromatosis was made on the basis of histopathologic, laboratory,\nand genetic testing. One possible explanation for the unexpected fatal\noutcome in this patient is that hemochromatosis-induced iron overload\nmight have provided the infecting KIM D27 strain, which is attenuated\nas a result of defects in its ability to acquire iron, with sufficient\niron to overcome its iron-acquisition defects and become virulent (2).\nResearchers should adhere to recommended biosafety practices when\nhandling any live bacterial cultures, even attenuated strains, and\ninstitutional biosafety committees should implement and maintain\neffective surveillance systems to detect and monitor unexpected acute\nillness in laboratory workers.\n\nCase report\n-----------\nOn 10 Sep 2009, the researcher, a man aged 60 years with\ninsulin-dependent diabetes mellitus, was evaluated at an outpatient\nclinic for fever, body aches, and cough of approximately 3 days\nduration. A clinic physician suspected influenza or other acute\nrespiratory infection and referred the patient to an emergency\ndepartment (ED) for further evaluation; however, the patient did not\nseek further care at that time. On 13 Sep 2011, the patient was\nbrought by ambulance to a Chicago hospital ED because of fever, cough,\nand worsening shortness of breath. Paramedics recorded an oxygen\nsaturation level of 92 percent, and oxygen was administered via mask.\n\nUpon arrival at the ED, the patient was noted to be alert and able to\nconverse, with a temperature of 100.9 deg F (38.3 deg C), pulse of 106\nbeats per minute, respiratory rate of 42 breaths per minute, and blood\npressure of 106/75 mm/Hg. Examination revealed distant breath sounds,\nabdominal distention, peripheral cyanosis, and trace pedal edema; no\nlymphadenopathy, rash, or jaundice was noted. A chest radiograph\nrevealed normal lung fields; however, the patient continued to have\nlabored breathing and required supplemental oxygen. Blood chemistries\nshowed renal failure (creatinine: 6.5 mg/dL; blood urea nitrogen: 73\nmg/dL), incipient acidosis (bicarbonate: 17 mEq/L; PaCO2: 31mmHg; pH:\n7.36), and elevated liver function enzymes (aspartate\naminotransaminase: 794 IU/L; alanine aminotransaminase: 160 IU/L).\nComplete blood count showed severe leukocytosis (white blood cells: 79\n200/mL) with a left shift (22 percent band forms) and hemoglobin level\nand platelet count within normal limits. Extracellular bacteria were\nnoted on a peripheral blood smear.\n\nThe patient initially was treated with diuretics for suspected\ncongestive heart failure and later with intravenous antibiotics\n(vancomycin and piperacillin/tazobactam) once infection was suspected.\nAt approximately 12 hours after presentation, the patient had\nworsening respiratory distress and was intubated. He died 1 hour later\nof cardiac arrest, despite resuscitation attempts.\n\nThe patient had last worked in the laboratory on 4 Sep 2009. On 10\nSep 2009, he notified his supervisor about his illness to explain his\nabsence from work. Whether the patient himself suspected his symptoms\nwere consistent with plague is not known; however, existing laboratory\npolicy called for laboratory workers with illness consistent with\nplague to report to the university's occupational health clinic (or to\nthe ED). The patient's occupation was not documented in the records of\neither the outpatient clinic he visited or the hospital ED.\n\nOn 14 Sep 2009, blood cultures drawn the previous day yielded\ngram-negative bacilli (4 of 4 bottles), gram-positive cocci (3 of 4\nbottles), and yeast (1 of 4 bottles and presumed to be a contaminant).\nOn 15 Sep 2009, the clinical laboratory identified the gram-positive\ncocci as nutritionally variant streptococci (NVS). An autopsy\nperformed the same day identified no signs of pneumonia, bowel\nperforation, or endocarditis, which is often associated with NVS\ninfection. Efforts to identify the slow-growing, gram-negative\norganism were under way when, on 16 Sep 2009, an ED physician learned\nthat the patient had worked in a laboratory that conducted research on\nselect biologic agents and notified the hospital clinical laboratory.\nOn the morning of 18 Sep 2009, 16S ribosomal DNA sequencing performed\nby the hospital clinical laboratory narrowed the identity of the\ngram-negative bacilli to either _Y. pestis_ or _Y.\npseudotuberculosis_. That same day, hospital infection control staff\nmembers notified CDPH of the suspected _Y. pestis_ case.\n\nEpidemiologic and environmental investigation\n---------------------------------------------\nOn 18 Sep 2009, CDPH, IDPH, CDC, and the university initiated a joint\ninvestigation to determine the source of _Y. pestis_ infection,\nidentify any potential additional infections, and implement prevention\nand control measures. Because inhalation exposure could not be\nexcluded, antimicrobial prophylaxis was offered to all staff members\nat the research laboratory in which the patient worked and to his\nclose contacts. A close contact was defined as a person who had been\nwithin 6 feet [2 m] of the patient or who had handled his blood or\ntissue samples during 7-18 Sep 2009. Unless contraindications existed,\na 7-day course of doxycycline was prescribed for prophylaxis. All 30\ncoworkers were prescribed prophylaxis during 19-20 Sep 2009. 1\nhousehold contact and 64 other close contacts, including medical,\nlaboratory, and pathology personnel, were identified, and 61 (94\npercent) accepted prophylaxis during 18-20 Sep 2009. No additional _Y.\npestis_ infections have been identified.\n\nAn assessment of the laboratory environment identified no major\ndeficiencies in laboratory engineering controls. A review of\nOccupational Safety and Health Administration Form 300 logs identified\nno recent work-related injuries or illnesses among workers in this\nlaboratory. A review of attendance records for university biosafety\ntraining identified deficiencies in staff attendance (including the\npatient) at a number of required biosafety courses. The patient's\nfamily members and coworkers were asked about knowledge of any\npossible exposure events, such as a needle puncture or splash of\nliquid to the face, and none were reported. Interviews with laboratory\ncoworkers revealed that the patient inconsistently complied with the\nlaboratory policy to wear gloves while handling _Y. pestis_ KIM D27\nbacterial cultures.\n\nLaboratory and pathologic testing\n----------------------------------\nPreliminary PCR and microbiologic analyses conducted by the\nuniversity research laboratory identified the organism isolated from\nthe patient as a pgm- attenuated strain of _Y. pestis_ (3), consistent\nwith the KIM D27 strain with which the patient worked, and not the\nvirulent _Y. pestis_ strain CO92, which was used in a separate\nlaboratory facility on another floor. The IDPH Division of\nLaboratories confirmed the infecting organism as _Y. pestis_. CDC\nindependently isolated _Y. pestis_ from an aliquot of 1 of the\noriginal blood culture bottles and confirmed the absence of the pgm\nlocus. CDC also identified a chloramphenicol resistance gene (a\ncommon, laboratory-based resistance marker) that was not in the\noriginal laboratory stock strain, suggesting that the infecting strain\nhad been modified as part of routine laboratory research.\n\nTo determine whether new virulence mechanisms had been acquired or\ngenetically inserted into the infecting strain, CDC compared the\nvirulence of the infecting strain with that of CO92 from CDC culture\narchives and the original, attenuated KIM D27 stock strain from the\npatient's laboratory. Male Swiss Webster mice were inoculated\nsubcutaneously with varying doses of bacteria ranging from 3 to 8 logs\nof colony-forming units (CFUs) for the infecting strain and the\nparental KIM D27 strain, and from 2 to 3 logs for CO92. Virulence was\nmeasured by determining the median lethal dose (LD). The LD of CO92\nwas equal to or less than 100 CFUs. In contrast, an LD was not\nachieved for either the infecting strain or KIM D27; less than 3% of\nthe mice died after injection with doses as high as 8 logs of CFUs.\nSuch findings suggest that the strain with which the patient was\ninfected was attenuated and that no new virulence mechanisms were\nacquired by or engineered into the infecting strain.\n\nHistopathologic examination of the patient's lung tissue at CDC\nrevealed preserved alveolar structure without inflammatory infiltrates\nthat would have indicated pneumonic processes consistent with plague\n[for figures, see original URL - Mod.LL]). Immunohistochemical tests\nusing an anti-_Y. pestis_ mouse monoclonal antibody revealed abundant\nstaining of _Y. pestis_ in blood vessels of multiple organs,\nconsistent with septicemic plague. Histologic staining revealed\nabnormal iron deposits in the liver, but not in pancreatic or cardiac\ntissues. Postmortem testing of blood samples revealed a total serum\niron of 541 microg/dL (reference range: 40-160 microg/dL), iron\nsaturation of 83.5 percent (reference range: 14-50 percent), and total\niron binding capacity of 648 microg/dL (reference range: 230-430\nmicrog/dL). Genetic testing revealed that the patient was homozygous\nfor the C282Y mutation of the HFE gene, confirming a postmortem\ndiagnosis of hereditary hemochromatosis (4). Investigators found no\nevidence that the researcher knew he had hemochromatosis or that he\nexhibited any symptoms of this condition.\n\n[Reported by: Ritger K, Black S, Weaver K, et al]\n\nEditorial note\n--------------\nThis report describes the 1st known fatality from a\nlaboratory-acquired infection with attenuated _Y. pestis_. The last\nknown laboratory-acquired infection with _Y. pestis_ in the USA\noccurred in 1959 and was caused by inhalation of a virulent strain\n(5). Pathology findings for the case described in this report are\nconsistent with septicemic plague and inconsistent with pneumonic\nplague, suggesting a transdermal or mucosal route of infection.\nHowever, a recent study (6) demonstrated that intranasal infection of\nmice with KIM D27 can result in persistent colonization of the lung\nvasculature, subsequent dissemination of infection, and eventual death\nwithout classic pathologic signs of pneumonic plague. Consequently, a\nrespiratory route of infection cannot be ruled out definitively.\nAlthough the route of transmission for the infection remains unclear,\ndeficiencies in biosafety practices, including inconsistent use of\ngloves, could have resulted in inadvertent transdermal exposure. The\nsevere outcome experienced by the patient was unexpected, given that\nhe had worked with an attenuated _Y. pestis_ strain that 1) is widely\nused by laboratory researchers, 2) has not been associated with\nprevious laboratory-acquired infections or fatalities, and 3) is\nexcluded from select biologic agent requirements (1). Although NVS\nbacteremia cannot be excluded as a contributing factor in the\npatient's death, the clinical course, lack of endocarditis, and the\nvisualization of _Y. pestis_ in blood vessels throughout the body\nstrongly support gram-negative sepsis as the cause of death.\n\nHemochromatosis, an iron-overload disease (7), is characterized by\nincreased iron absorption and progressive iron storage in multiple\norgans. Persons with hemochromatosis are especially susceptible to\ninfection with _Vibrio vulnificus_, _Listeria monocytogenes_,\n_Yersinia enterocolitica_, and _Yersinia pseudotuberculosis_ (7).\nAnimal studies have shown that the virulence of pgm- _Y. pestis_\nstrains can be enhanced by the simultaneous injection of iron into\nexperimental animals (2). Conceivably, hemochromatosis-induced iron\noverload might have a similar effect, enhancing the virulence of the\ninfecting KIM D27 strain by compensating for its iron-acquisition\ndefects (2). Although iron deposition in pancreatic tissue is known to\ncause bronze diabetes, pathologic examination ruled out iron\ndeposition as the cause of this patient's diabetes. Nonetheless,\ndiabetes is a known risk factor for increased severity and\ncomplications from bacterial infections (8).\n\nResearch using animal models of hemochromatosis (9) is under way to\nbetter understand susceptibility to infection with bacteria attenuated\nas a result of defects in iron acquisition. Researchers working with\nattenuated _Y. pestis_ and other potentially infectious material\nshould always use at least biosafety level 2 practices (10), and\nlaboratory managers should ensure that staff adheres to recommended\nbiosafety practices. Institutional safety committees should implement\nand maintain effective surveillance programs to identify and monitor\nacute illness among laboratory workers, and health-care providers\nshould routinely inquire about occupational exposures when evaluating\npatients.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. US Department of Health and Human Services, US Department of\nAgriculture. National Select Agent Registry: select agents exclusions.\nWashington, DC: US Department of Health and Human Services, US\nDepartment of Agriculture; 2010. Available at\n<http://www.selectagents.gov/select%20agents%20and%20toxins%20exclusions.html>.\nAccessed 18 Feb 2011.\n2. Jackson S, Burrows TW: The virulence-enhancing effect of iron on\nnonpigmented mutants of virulent strains of _Pasteurella pestis_. Br J\nExp Pathol 1956; 37(6): 577-83.\n3. Perry RD, Fetherston JD: _Yersinia pestis_-etiologic agent of\nplague. Clin Microbiol Rev. 1997; 10(1): 35-66 [available at\n<http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sites/ppmc/articles/PMC172914/>].\n4. Andrews NC: Disorders of iron metabolism. N Engl J Med 1999;\n341(26): 1986-95 [available at\n<http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJM199912233412607>].\n5. Burmeister RW, Tigertt WD, Overholt EL: Laboratory-acquired\npneumonic plague: report of a case and review of previous cases. Ann\nIntern Med 1962;56: 789-800.\n6. Lee-Lewis H, Anderson DM: Absence of inflammation and pneumonia\nduring infection with nonpigmented _Yersinia pestis_ reveals a new\nrole for the pgm locus in pathogenesis. Infect Immun 2010; 78(10):\n220-30 [available at\n<http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2798233/>].\n7. Khan FA, Fisher MA, Khakoo RA: Association of hemochromatosis with\ninfectious diseases: expanding spectrum. Int J Infect Dis 2007; 11(6):\n482-7 [available at\n<http://www.ijidonline.com/article/PIIS1201971207000811/fulltext>].\n8. Joshi N, Caputo GM, Weitekamp MR, Karchmer AW: Infections in\npatients with diabetes mellitus. N Engl J Med 1999; 341(25): 1906-12.\n9. Huang FW, Pinkus JL, Pinkus GS, Fleming MD, Andrews NC: A mouse\nmodel of juvenile hemochromatosis. J Clin Invest 2005; 115(8): 2187-91\n[available at <http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1180543>].\n10. US Department of Health and Human Services, CDC, National\nInstitutes of Health. Biosafety in microbiological and biomedical\nlaboratories. 5th ed. Atlanta, GA: US Department of Health and Human\nServices, CDC, National Institutes of Health; 2009. Available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/biosafety/publications/bmbl5>. Accessed 18 Feb\n2011.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As seen in the 'see alsos' below, ProMED-mail had posted regarding\nthis case when it occurred. In the 2nd posting Ken Alexander, head of\npediatric infectious disease was quoted that the autopsy did not imply\nthat the strain of the plague was a public health threat. He told the\nChicago Tribune that 'the more likely possibility, I'd say 999 to 1,\nis that there was something unusual about him.' It appears that Dr\nAlexander was correct. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "----------------------------------\nPreliminary PCR and microbiologic analyses conducted by the\nuniversity research laboratory identified the organism isolated from\nthe patient as a pgm- attenuated strain of _Y. pestis_ (3), consistent\nwith the KIM D27 strain with which the patient worked, and not the\nvirulent _Y. pestis_ strain CO92, which was used in a separate\nlaboratory facility on another floor. The\nsevere outcome experienced by the patient was unexpected, given that\nhe had worked with an attenuated _Y. pestis_ strain that 1) is widely\nused by laboratory researchers, 2) has not been associated with\nprevious laboratory-acquired infections or fatalities, and 3) is\nexcluded from select biologic agent requirements (1). A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 24 Feb 2011\n One possible explanation for the unexpected fatal\noutcome in this patient is that hemochromatosis-induced iron overload\nmight have provided the infecting KIM D27 strain, which is attenuated\nas a result of defects in its ability to acquire iron, with sufficient\niron to overcome its iron-acquisition defects and become virulent (2). To determine whether new virulence mechanisms had been acquired or\ngenetically inserted into the infecting strain, CDC compared the\nvirulence of the infecting strain with that of CO92 from CDC culture\narchives and the original, attenuated KIM D27 stock strain from the\npatient's laboratory. Whether the patient himself suspected his symptoms\nwere consistent with plague is not known; however, existing laboratory\npolicy called for laboratory workers with illness consistent with\nplague to report to the university's occupational health clinic (or to\nthe ED). Other researchers in a separate\nuniversity laboratory facility in the same building had contact with a\nvirulent _Y. pestis_ strain (CO92) that is considered a select\nbiologic agent; however, the pgm- attenuated KIM D27 is excluded from\nthe National Select Agent Registry (1). Postmortem testing of blood samples revealed a total serum\niron of 541 microg/dL (reference range: 40-160 microg/dL), iron\nsaturation of 83.5 percent (reference range: 14-50 percent), and total\niron binding capacity of 648 microg/dL (reference range: 230-430\nmicrog/dL). Researchers working with\nattenuated _Y. pestis_ and other potentially infectious material\nshould always use at least biosafety level 2 practices (10), and\nlaboratory managers should ensure that staff adheres to recommended\nbiosafety practices. Although NVS\nbacteremia cannot be excluded as a contributing factor in the\npatient's death, the clinical course, lack of endocarditis, and the\nvisualization of _Y. pestis_ in blood vessels throughout the body\nstrongly support gram-negative sepsis as the cause of death. Researchers should adhere to recommended biosafety practices when\nhandling any live bacterial cultures, even attenuated strains, and\ninstitutional biosafety committees should implement and maintain\neffective surveillance systems to detect and monitor unexpected acute\nillness in laboratory workers. Institutional safety committees should implement\nand maintain effective surveillance programs to identify and monitor\nacute illness among laboratory workers, and health-care providers\nshould routinely inquire about occupational exposures when evaluating\npatients. Blood chemistries\nshowed renal failure (creatinine: 6.5 mg/dL; blood urea nitrogen: 73\nmg/dL), incipient acidosis (bicarbonate: 17 mEq/L; PaCO2: 31mmHg; pH:\n7.36), and elevated liver function enzymes (aspartate\naminotransaminase: 794 IU/L; alanine aminotransaminase: 160 IU/L). CDC also identified a chloramphenicol resistance gene (a\ncommon, laboratory-based resistance marker) that was not in the\noriginal laboratory stock strain, suggesting that the infecting strain\nhad been modified as part of routine laboratory research. The patient, a researcher in a university laboratory,\nhad been working along with other members of the laboratory group with\na pigmentation-negative (pgm-) attenuated _Y. pestis_ strain (KIM\nD27). Efforts to identify the slow-growing, gram-negative\norganism were under way when, on 16 Sep 2009, an ED physician learned\nthat the patient had worked in a laboratory that conducted research on\nselect biologic agents and notified the hospital clinical laboratory. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 2011; 60(07): 201-5 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6007a1.htm?s_cid=mm6007a1_w>\n\n\nFatal laboratory-acquired infection with an attenuated _Yersinia\npestis_ strain -- Chicago, Illinois, 2009\n On 18 Sep 2009, the Chicago Department of Public Health (CDPH) was\nnotified by a local hospital of a suspected case of fatal\nlaboratory-acquired infection with _Yersinia pestis_, the causative\nagent of plague. Interviews with laboratory\ncoworkers revealed that the patient inconsistently complied with the\nlaboratory policy to wear gloves while handling _Y. pestis_ KIM D27\nbacterial cultures. The last\nknown laboratory-acquired infection with _Y. pestis_ in the USA\noccurred in 1959 and was caused by inhalation of a virulent strain\n(5). On the morning of 18 Sep 2009, 16S ribosomal DNA sequencing performed\nby the hospital clinical laboratory narrowed the identity of the\ngram-negative bacilli to either _Y. pestis_ or _Y.\npseudotuberculosis_. Conceivably, hemochromatosis-induced iron\noverload might have a similar effect, enhancing the virulence of the\ninfecting KIM D27 strain by compensating for its iron-acquisition\ndefects (2). Male Swiss Webster mice were inoculated\nsubcutaneously with varying doses of bacteria ranging from 3 to 8 logs\nof colony-forming units (CFUs) for the infecting strain and the\nparental KIM D27 strain, and from 2 to 3 logs for CO92. 1\nhousehold contact and 64 other close contacts, including medical,\nlaboratory, and pathology personnel, were identified, and 61 (94\npercent) accepted prophylaxis during 18-20 Sep 2009. A clinic physician suspected influenza or other acute\nrespiratory infection and referred the patient to an emergency\ndepartment (ED) for further evaluation; however, the patient did not\nseek further care at that time. On 18 Sep 2009, CDPH, IDPH, CDC, and the university initiated a joint\ninvestigation to determine the source of _Y. pestis_ infection,\nidentify any potential additional infections, and implement prevention\nand control measures. Because inhalation exposure could not be\nexcluded, antimicrobial prophylaxis was offered to all staff members\nat the research laboratory in which the patient worked and to his\nclose contacts. \n\nHistopathologic examination of the patient's lung tissue at CDC\nrevealed preserved alveolar structure without inflammatory infiltrates\nthat would have indicated pneumonic processes consistent with plague\n \n\nThis report summarizes the results of that investigation, which\ndetermined that the cause of death likely was an unrecognized\noccupational exposure (route unknown) to _Y. pestis_, leading to\nseptic shock. However, a recent study (6) demonstrated that intranasal infection of\nmice with KIM D27 can result in persistent colonization of the lung\nvasculature, subsequent dissemination of infection, and eventual death\nwithout classic pathologic signs of pneumonic plague. Pathology findings for the case described in this report are\nconsistent with septicemic plague and inconsistent with pneumonic\nplague, suggesting a transdermal or mucosal route of infection.\n Upon arrival at the ED, the patient was noted to be alert and able to\nconverse, with a temperature of 100.9 deg F (38.3 deg C), pulse of 106\nbeats per minute, respiratory rate of 42 breaths per minute, and blood\npressure of 106/75 mm/Hg. CDC\nindependently isolated _Y. pestis_ from an aliquot of 1 of the\noriginal blood culture bottles and confirmed the absence of the pgm\nlocus. On 10 Sep 2009, the researcher, a man aged 60 years with\ninsulin-dependent diabetes mellitus, was evaluated at an outpatient\nclinic for fever, body aches, and cough of approximately 3 days\nduration. The patient's\nfamily members and coworkers were asked about knowledge of any\npossible exposure events, such as a needle puncture or splash of\nliquid to the face, and none were reported. An autopsy\nperformed the same day identified no signs of pneumonia, bowel\nperforation, or endocarditis, which is often associated with NVS\ninfection. On 14 Sep 2009, blood cultures drawn the previous day yielded\ngram-negative bacilli (4 of 4 bottles), gram-positive cocci (3 of 4\nbottles), and yeast (1 of 4 bottles and presumed to be a contaminant). Such findings suggest that the strain with which the patient was\ninfected was attenuated and that no new virulence mechanisms were\nacquired by or engineered into the infecting strain. Although iron deposition in pancreatic tissue is known to\ncause bronze diabetes, pathologic examination ruled out iron\ndeposition as the cause of this patient's diabetes. \n\nHemochromatosis, an iron-overload disease (7), is characterized by\nincreased iron absorption and progressive iron storage in multiple\norgans. A close contact was defined as a person who had been\nwithin 6 feet [2 m] of the patient or who had handled his blood or\ntissue samples during 7-18 Sep 2009. Research using animal models of hemochromatosis (9) is under way to\nbetter understand susceptibility to infection with bacteria attenuated\nas a result of defects in iron acquisition. A review of attendance records for university biosafety\ntraining identified deficiencies in staff attendance (including the\npatient) at a number of required biosafety courses. Animal studies have shown that the virulence of pgm- _Y. pestis_\nstrains can be enhanced by the simultaneous injection of iron into\nexperimental animals (2). Genetic testing revealed that the patient was homozygous\nfor the C282Y mutation of the HFE gene, confirming a postmortem\ndiagnosis of hereditary hemochromatosis (4). \n\nThe patient initially was treated with diuretics for suspected\ncongestive heart failure and later with intravenous antibiotics\n Lee-Lewis H, Anderson DM: Absence of inflammation and pneumonia\nduring infection with nonpigmented _Yersinia pestis_ reveals a new\nrole for the pgm locus in pathogenesis. In contrast, an LD was not\nachieved for either the infecting strain or KIM D27; less than 3% of\nthe mice died after injection with doses as high as 8 logs of CFUs. A postmortem diagnosis of hereditary\nhemochromatosis was made on the basis of histopathologic, laboratory,\nand genetic testing. Although the route of transmission for the infection remains unclear,\ndeficiencies in biosafety practices, including inconsistent use of\ngloves, could have resulted in inadvertent transdermal exposure.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "plague", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1956-03-25 00:00:00", "1997-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-09-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:16", "2009-09-16 00:00:00", "2009-09-15 00:00:00", "1959-03-25 00:00:00", "1999-03-25 00:00:00", "1906-12-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-09-04 00:00:00", "2007-09-18 20:09:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-02-24 00:00:00", "2009-09-14 00:00:00", "2009-09-18 00:00:00", "2011-09-13 00:00:00", "2011-02-18 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Black S", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "DC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Illinois", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chicago", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "pH", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "623557", "headline": "PRO/AH> Plague, pneumonic, 2009 - China: (QH) follow up", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=623557", "date": "2011-01-09 14:00:04", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PNEUMONIC, 2009 - CHINA: (QINGHAI), FOLLOW UP\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 6 Jan 2011\nFrom: Jack Woodall <woodall@promedmail.org>\n\n\nThe report from China of this unusual outbreak has just been\npublished: Hu Wang et al: A Dog-Associated Primary Pneumonic Plague\nin Qinghai Province, China. Clin Infect Dis. 2011;52: 185-190.\n\nThis was reported by ProMED in 2009 in a thread (see ProMED archives\nbelow) that ended with the report from WHO and a comment by ProMED\nthat no further information regarding the patient, who was in\ncritical condition, was available. This paper reports that the\npatient survived and that the index patient contracted pneumonic\nplague after carrying his dead dog on his shoulders around his neck\nfor 400 meters to bury it.\n\nIt also clarifies statements in the WHO report that could have been\nmisunderstood to mean that plague had been transmitted from the index\ncase's corpse. To quote WHO:\n\n'The 1st case was a 32-year-old male herdsman who developed fever and\nhemoptysis on 26 Jul 2009. He was referred to a hospital but died en\nroute and was buried the following day. On 30 Jul 2009, 11 people who\nhad close contact with the case (mainly relatives who attended the\nfuneral) developed fever and cough and were all hospitalized. On 1\nAug 2009, specimens taken from all these 12 people, including the 1st\ncase, tested positive for plague. On 2 Aug 2009, both the 64-year-old\nfather-in-law of the index case and a 37-year-old male neighbor of\nthe 1st case (who helped to bury the corpse) also died.'\n\nThe Chinese authors defined a close contact as 'a person who lived\nwith or had face-to-face contact (within one meter) with the patient,\nand a direct contact as a person who once was together with a patient\nin the same room or in the same car with closed windows.'\n\nOnly the 11 close contacts became infected; none of 61 direct\ncontacts became infected, and nobody who attended the funeral but had\nnot previously been a close contact became infected. They also\nreported that most of the patients (6 of 11, excluding the index\ncase) in this outbreak developed septicemic plague complicated with\nshock; 2 of 11 developed multiple organ failure, and one of 11\ndeveloped meningitis in addition to the plague pneumonia.\n\n[ProMED thanks David Morens <DMORENS@niaid.nih.gov> for drawing\nattention to this paper, and the One Health Initiative\n<http://www.onehealthinitiative.org> for providing a link to the\nabstract at <http://www.onehealthinitiative.com/publications.php>,\nfrom which the full paper can be accessed. - Mod.JW]\n\n[What is also noteworthy regarding this cluster of pneumonic plague\nis the source, a dog, that was likely infected from a marmot, the\nmost common reservoir in China. - Mod.LL]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "They also\nreported that most of the patients (6 of 11, excluding the index\ncase) in this outbreak developed septicemic plague complicated with\nshock; 2 of 11 developed multiple organ failure, and one of 11\ndeveloped meningitis in addition to the plague pneumonia. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 6 Jan 2011\n \n\n[ProMED thanks David Morens <DMORENS@niaid.nih.gov> for drawing\nattention to this paper, and the One Health Initiative\n<http://www.onehealthinitiative.org> for providing a link to the\nabstract at <http://www.onehealthinitiative.com/publications.php>,\nfrom which the full paper can be accessed. \n\nThe Chinese authors defined a close contact as 'a person who lived\nwith or had face-to-face contact (within one meter) with the patient,\nand a direct contact as a person who once was together with a patient\nin the same room or in the same car with closed windows.' This paper reports that the\npatient survived and that the index patient contracted pneumonic\nplague after carrying his dead dog on his shoulders around his neck\nfor 400 meters to bury it. This was reported by ProMED in 2009 in a thread (see ProMED archives\nbelow) that ended with the report from WHO and a comment by ProMED\nthat no further information regarding the patient, who was in\ncritical condition, was available. On 2 Aug 2009, both the 64-year-old\nfather-in-law of the index case and a 37-year-old male neighbor of\nthe 1st case (who helped to bury the corpse) also died.' \n\nOnly the 11 close contacts became infected; none of 61 direct\ncontacts became infected, and nobody who attended the funeral but had\nnot previously been a close contact became infected.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2011-01-06 00:00:00", "2009-08-02 00:00:00", "2009-08-01 00:00:00", "2021-06-11 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Qinghai Province", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "573415", "headline": "PRO/AH> Crayfish plague - UK: England", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=573415", "date": "2010-11-08 18:00:04", "main_text": "CRAYFISH PLAGUE - UK: ENGLAND\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 8 Nov 2010\nSource: BristolZooUK [accessed 8 Nov 2010, summarised, edited]\n<http://www.bristolzoo.org.uk/conservationists-highlight-worsening-plight-of-uk-crayfish?theme=orange>\n\n\nBristol conservationists are highlighting the worsening plight of native\ncrayfish as the species is officially upgraded to 'endangered'.\nWhite-clawed crayfish are the UK's only native freshwater crayfish, but\ntheir numbers have suffered extensive decline in recent years. Experts warn\nthe species could become extinct from the UK within the next 30 years; it\nis currently a protected species.\n\nToday, white-clawed crayfish have been upgraded from 'vulnerable' to\n'endangered' on the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN)\nRed List of Threatened Species, following a Sampled Red List Index (SRLI)\nassessment by the Zoological Society of London (ZSL). The ranking gives an\nindication of how likely a species is to become extinct.\n\nEve Leegwater, technical biodiversity officer at the Environment Agency,\nsaid: 'It is important to base conservation efforts on scientific research,\nand the IUCN Red List has become an increasingly important tool to guide\ngovernment and scientific institutes towards the conservation and\nlegislation of species and habitats at risk of extinction.' She added: 'The\nchange in status of white-clawed crayfish will help stress the need for\nconservation strategies to be implemented to aid this valuable species.'\n\nUp to 70 per cent of white-clawed crayfish have been lost from the south\nwest, and some parts of the UK have lost their entire populations. This is\npredominantly due to the crayfish plague, a fungus-like disease which is\nharmless to people and most animals but lethal to white-clawed crayfish.\nThe crayfish plague is spread by the invasive American signal crayfish, a\nnon-native species which is taking over UK waterways and wiping out our\nsmaller native species.\n\nThe South West Crayfish Project is currently running the largest strategic\ntranslocation in the UK to date, re-homing at-risk populations of\nwhite-clawed crayfish to new safe sites. In addition, a breeding programme\nfor the crayfish is being developed at Bristol Zoo Gardens, the sister\norganisation to the Bristol Conservation and Science Foundation (BCSF).\n\nMaddy Rees, UK conservation officer for the Bristol Conservation and\nScience Foundation, said: 'The plague can be carried on anything that gets\nwet in infected water, so we are urging people to wash, dry and, if\npossible, disinfect footwear, fishing tackle, nets and other equipment that\ngets damp in our rivers and lakes. Never trap for any species of crayfish\nwithout a trapping licence, as it is illegal, and finally, never move wild\nfish between waterways; always use a reputable stockist.'\n\nThe survival of white-clawed crayfish will be the focus of a conference\nheld at Bristol Zoo Gardens later this year [2010]. The event, called\n'Species survival: Securing white-clawed crayfish in a changing\nenvironment' will take place on 16 and 17 Nov 2010. It will include a range\nof lectures from speakers from across Europe and presentations from experts\nin the field of UK crayfish conservation.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The aetiological agent of crayfish plague is _Aphanomyces astaci_, a\nmember of a group of organisms commonly known as the water moulds. Although\nlong regarded to be fungi, this group, the Oomycetida, are now considered\nprotists and are classified with diatoms and brown algae in a group called\nthe Stramenopiles or Chromista.\n\nThere is evidence that established older _A. astaci_ strains that have been\npresent in Europe for many years are less aggressive than newer strains\nintroduced with crayfish imports from North America since the 1960s. Some\nisolates from warmer waters in Spain have temperature/growth curves with\nhigher optimum temperatures compared with those from northern Europe.\n\nAlthough _A. astaci_ is not an obligate parasite and will grow well under\nlaboratory conditions on artificial media, in the natural environment it\ndoes not survive well for long periods in the absence of a suitable host.\nIt has been shown that _A. astaci_ cysts survive for 2 weeks in distilled\nwater, and that zoospores remained motile for up to 3 days. As _A. astaci_\ncan go through 3 cycles of zoospore emergence, the maximum life span\noutside of a host could be several weeks.\n\n_A. astaci_, both in culture and in infected crayfish, is killed by a short\nexposure to temperatures of 60 C (140 F) or to temperatures of -20 C (-4 F)\nor less for 48 hours or more. Sodium hypochlorite and iodophores are\neffective for disinfection of contaminated equipment. Thorough drying of\nequipment (more than 24 hours) is also effective, as _Aphanomyces_ is not\nresistant to desiccation.\n\nThere is good field and experimental evidence that movements of fish from\nareas in which crayfish plague is active can transmit infection from one\nwatershed to another. _A. astaci_ can also be spread by contaminated\nequipment (nets, boots, clothing, etc).\n\nThe information above is derived from chapter 2.3.7. 'Crayfish Plague\n(_Aphanomyces astaci_)' in OIE's (World Organisation for Animal Health)\nManual of Diagnostic Tests for Aquatic animals. The chapter includes\nadditional comprehensive information on the agent factors, host factors,\ndisease pattern, diagnosis, control and prevention, etc; see\n<http://oie.int/eng/normes/fmanual/2.2.01_CRAYFISH.pdf>. - Mod.AS\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the United Kingdom can be\naccessed at <http://healthmap.org/promed?v=54.5,-2,5>. - Mod.SH]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 8 Nov 2010\n \n\nMaddy Rees, UK conservation officer for the Bristol Conservation and\nScience Foundation, said: 'The plague can be carried on anything that gets\nwet in infected water, so we are urging people to wash, dry and, if\npossible, disinfect footwear, fishing tackle, nets and other equipment that\ngets damp in our rivers and lakes. \n\nEve Leegwater, technical biodiversity officer at the Environment Agency,\nsaid: 'It is important to base conservation efforts on scientific research,\nand the IUCN Red List has become an increasingly important tool to guide\ngovernment and scientific institutes towards the conservation and\nlegislation of species and habitats at risk of extinction.' She added: 'The\nchange in status of white-clawed crayfish will help stress the need for\nconservation strategies to be implemented to aid this valuable species.'\n\nUp to 70 per cent of white-clawed crayfish have been lost from the south\nwest, and some parts of the UK have lost their entire populations. The chapter includes\nadditional comprehensive information on the agent factors, host factors,\ndisease pattern, diagnosis, control and prevention, etc; see\n<http://oie.int/eng/normes/fmanual/2.2.01_CRAYFISH.pdf>. Although\nlong regarded to be fungi, this group, the Oomycetida, are now considered\nprotists and are classified with diatoms and brown algae in a group called\nthe Stramenopiles or Chromista. \n\nThe South West Crayfish Project is currently running the largest strategic\ntranslocation in the UK to date, re-homing at-risk populations of\nwhite-clawed crayfish to new safe sites. The crayfish plague is spread by the invasive American signal crayfish, a\nnon-native species which is taking over UK waterways and wiping out our\nsmaller native species. This is\npredominantly due to the crayfish plague, a fungus-like disease which is\nharmless to people and most animals but lethal to white-clawed crayfish. \n\n_A. astaci_, both in culture and in infected crayfish, is killed by a short\nexposure to temperatures of 60 C (140 F) or to temperatures of -20 C (-4 F)\nor less for 48 hours or more. \n\nThere is evidence that established older _A. astaci_ strains that have been\npresent in Europe for many years are less aggressive than newer strains\nintroduced with crayfish imports from North America since the 1960s. \n\nToday, white-clawed crayfish have been upgraded from 'vulnerable' to\n'endangered' on the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN)\n The event, called\n'Species survival: Securing white-clawed crayfish in a changing\nenvironment' will take place on 16 and 17 Nov 2010. \n\nThere is good field and experimental evidence that movements of fish from\nareas in which crayfish plague is active can transmit infection from one\nwatershed to another.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "the United Kingdom", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chromista", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "590449", "headline": "PRO/AH> Crayfish plague - Italy: (VN) OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=590449", "date": "2010-11-26 16:00:04", "main_text": "CRAYFISH PLAGUE - ITALY: (VENETO) OIE\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 26 Nov 2010\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly\ndisease information 2010; 23(48) [edited]\n<http://www.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=9980>\n\n\nCrayfish plague (_Aphanomyces astaci_), Italy\n---------------------------------------------\nInformation received on (and dated) 26 Nov 2010 from Prof Dr Romano\nMarabelli, chief veterinary officer, Department for Veterinary Public\nHealth, Nutrition and Food Safety, Ministry of Health, Rome, Italy\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nStart date: 18 Oct 2010\nDate of 1st confirmation of the event: 15 Nov 2010\nDate submitted to OIE: 26 Nov 2010\nReason for notification: 1st occurrence of a listed disease\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: _Aphanomyces astaci_\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Rio di Ron, Treviso, Voldobbiadene, Veneto\nDate of start of the outbreak: 18 Oct 2010\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: river system\nWater type: fresh water\nPopulation type: wild\nProduction system: open\nAffected animals\nSpecies / Morbidity / Mortality / Susceptible /Cases / Deaths / Destroyed /\nSlaughtered\nEuropean freshwater crayfish (_Austropotamobius_) / 100 per cent / 100 per\ncent / - / 1 / 1 / 0 / 0\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: no vaccination; no treatment of affected animals.\n\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Experimental Zooprophylactic Institute (IZS),\nPadova (local laboratory)\nTests and results\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nAustropotamobius / gene sequencing / 15 Nov 2010 / Positive (_Aphanomyces\nastaci_ )\nAustropotamobius / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 15 Nov 2010 / Positive\n(_Aphanomyces astaci_)\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The aetiological agent of crayfish plague is _Aphanomyces astaci_, a\nmember of a group of organisms commonly known as the water moulds. Although\nlong regarded to be fungi, this group, the Oomycetida, are now considered\nprotists and are classified with diatoms and brown algae in a group called\nthe Stramenopiles or Chromista.\n\nThere is evidence that established older _A. astaci_ strains that have been\npresent in Europe for many years are less aggressive than newer strains\nintroduced with crayfish imports from North America since the 1960s. Some\nisolates from warmer waters in Spain have temperature/growth curves with\nhigher optimum temperatures compared with those from northern Europe.\n\nAlthough _A. astaci_ is not an obligate parasite and will grow well under\nlaboratory conditions on artificial media, in the natural environment it\ndoes not survive well for long periods in the absence of a suitable host.\nIt has been shown that _A. astaci_ cysts survive for 2 weeks in distilled\nwater, and that zoospores remained motile for up to 3 days. As _A. astaci_\ncan go through 3 cycles of zoospore emergence, the maximum life span\noutside of a host could be several weeks.\n\n_A. astaci_, both in culture and in infected crayfish, is killed by a short\nexposure to temperatures of 60 deg C (140 deg F) or to temperatures of -20\ndeg C (-4 deg F) or less for 48 hours or more. Sodium hypochlorite and\niodophores are effective for disinfection of contaminated equipment.\nThorough drying of equipment (more than 24 hours) is also effective, as\n_Aphanomyces_ is not resistant to desiccation.\n\nThere is good field and experimental evidence that movements of fish from\nareas in which crayfish plague is active can transmit infection from one\nwatershed to another. _A. astaci_ can also be spread by contaminated\nequipment (nets, boots, clothing, etc).\n\nThe information above is derived from chapter 2.3.7. 'Crayfish Plague\n(_Aphanomyces astaci_)' in OIE's (World Organisation for Animal Health)\nManual of Diagnostic Tests for Aquatic animals. The chapter includes\nadditional comprehensive information on the agent factors, host factors,\ndisease pattern, diagnosis, control and prevention, etc; see\n<http://oie.int/eng/normes/fmanual/2.2.01_CRAYFISH.pdf>. - Mod.AS\n\nThe location of the outbreak can be seen on the map included in the OIE\nreport at the source URL above. The HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map\nof Italy is available at <http://healthmap.org/r/0heO>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 26 Nov 2010\n Information received on (and dated) 26 Nov 2010 from Prof Dr Romano\nMarabelli, chief veterinary officer, Department for Veterinary Public\nHealth, Nutrition and Food Safety, Ministry of Health, Rome, Italy\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\n Reason for notification: 1st occurrence of a listed disease\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: _Aphanomyces astaci_\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (advanced)\n Population type: wild\nProduction system: open\nAffected animals\nSpecies / Morbidity / Mortality / Susceptible /Cases / Deaths / Destroyed /\n \n\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Experimental Zooprophylactic Institute (IZS),\nPadova (local laboratory)\n Source: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly\ndisease information 2010; Reports say at least 7 people have been admitted to a\nspecial center set up specifically to treat people who have\ncontracted the disease. No deaths has been reported so far.\n\nThe district commissioner, Mr Anatory Choya, said that the outbreak\nhad so far only been reported in areas bordering the government\nforest reserve at the edge of the Rift Valley, and that it should be\ncontained before spreading to other areas in the district. However,\nMr Choya hinted that the situation was worrying because he had been\nnotified that the disaster management unit in the PMO was short of funds.\n\n'The outbreak could worsen with the coming of the rainy season,' he\nsaid, adding that areas where the disease outbreak has been reported\nincluded Tumati in Dong'obesh Division, Murai (Mandisi) and Nandes\nWard near the district headquarters.\n\nThe acting district medical officer, Dr Elirehema Lakey, said plague\nhad been breaking out frequently in the district, adding that this\nwas a matter of 'grave concern'. He said experts from the Sokoine\nUniversity of Agriculture (SUA) had been involved in research on\nrodents in the area where vermin numbers swell before the onset of rains.\n\nSeveral people died in the last 2 plague outbreaks in the district\nlast year and 2007 (see prior ProMED-mail post Plague, bubonic, fatal\n- Tanzania (Manyara) 20070328.1064).\n\n[Byline: Joseph Lyimo]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nThomas James Allen\n<tjallen@pipeline.com>\n\n[Although not specifically stated, it is likely that all the cases\nare bubonic in nature, the most common form of _Yersinia pestis_\ninfection with the lowest mortality rates. - Mod. To date, no new cases were reported.\n\nRegarding the plague outbreak in Peru, from EW 32 to date, the\nMinistry of Health registered 27 cases of plague, of which 11 were\nlaboratory confirmed. Of these 27 registered cases, 21 were bubonic\nplague (including one death), 4 pneumonic plague and 2 deaths from\nsepticemic plague. 25 of them acquired the infection in the province\nof Ascope and 2 in Trujillo. The last case of pneumonic plague\nsymptoms began on 11 Aug 2010, and there were no new cases thereafter.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n\n[This PAHO report does not mention the total number of cases of _Y.\npestis_ infection in Bolivia and reports 27 total cases in Peru. However, the La Libertad area\nwhere the Peruvian cases occurred (see ProMED-mail Plague - Peru\n(04): (LL) 20100814.2808) is on the north western side of the\ncountry. - Mod.LL]\n\n[Maps of Bolivia are available at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/americas/bolivia_admin_2006.jpg> and\nthe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/03Bi>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 25 Aug 2010\n \n\nSo far, 8 cases of bubonic plague, including the death of the\nteenager, have been reported in Apolo, a town with 5000 inhabitants\nbordering Peru, where 3 people have died after an outbreak of plague\nin the past 2 months.
