[24 Aug 2010] in northern La\nPaz department after a 14-year-old boy died from bubonic plague, the\nHealth Ministry said.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "1100-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "1994-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Peru", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Apolo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bolivia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "543965", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (03): (OR) bubonic", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=543965", "date": "2010-10-04 17:00:04", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (03): (OREGON), BUBONIC\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 1 Oct 2010\nSource: Oregon Public Broadcasting [edited]\n<http://news.opb.org/article/14656-rare-case-bubonic-plague-shows-lake-county/>\n\n\nState health officials say a woman in Lake County has been diagnosed\nwith bubonic plague. It is the 1st diagnosis of plague in Oregon in\n15 years. The disease terrorized Europe's population more than 600\nyears ago, but the plague is treatable when caught early.\n\nDr. Emilio DeBess is the public health veterinarian and an\nepidemiologist with the Oregon Department of Human Services. He says\nthe disease, once known as the Black Death, got somewhat of a bad rap\nafter killing off 1/3rd of Europe's population in the 1300s.\n\nBut he says that thanks to scientific advances, 'it's a very\ntreatable condition with antibiotics, and so that's usually not a\nconcern; back then, they didn't have antibiotics. We do have very\ngood antibiotics that treat the infection.'\n\nHealth officials have not released the name of the Lake County woman\nwho fell ill at the end of August 2010. DeBess says authorities are\nnow trying to determine the source of the infection.\n\n[Byline: David Nogueras]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\nAs outlined by the CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention)\nat <http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvbid/plague/diagnosis.htm>: The\ntypical sign of the most common form of human plague is a swollen and\nvery tender lymph gland, accompanied by pain. The swollen gland is\ncalled a 'bubo.' Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person\ndevelops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme\nexhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected\nrodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic\nplague 2 to 6 days after being infected.\n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the\nbloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they\nspread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal\ncondition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes\nthe pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The\ninfected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and\nbreathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients\nare not given specific antibiotic therapy, the disease can progress\nrapidly to death. About 14 per cent (one in 7) of all plague cases in\nthe United States are fatal.'\n\nMost cases of _Y. pestis_ infections in the USA occur in the area of\nthe 'Four Corner' states: Colorado, Arizona, New Mexico and Utah,\nalthough California and to a lesser extent Oregon also may have\ncases. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 1 Oct 2010\n Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person\ndevelops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme\nexhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected\nrodents, rabbits, or fleas. \n\nMost cases of _Y. pestis_ infections in the USA occur in the area of\nthe 'Four Corner' states: Colorado, Arizona, New Mexico and Utah,\nalthough California and to a lesser extent Oregon also may have\ncases. - Mod. The\ntypical sign of the most common form of human plague is a swollen and\nvery tender lymph gland, accompanied by pain. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they\nspread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal\ncondition. Source: Oregon Public Broadcasting [edited]\n<http://news.opb.org/article/14656-rare-case-bubonic-plague-shows-lake-county/>\n\n\nState health officials say a woman in Lake County has been diagnosed\nwith bubonic plague. If plague patients\nare not given specific antibiotic therapy, the disease can progress\nrapidly to death. But he says that thanks to scientific advances, 'it's a very\ntreatable condition with antibiotics, and so that's usually not a\nconcern; back then, they didn't have antibiotics.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lake County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "OREGON", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "538786", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, pneumonic - China: (Tibet Autonomous Region)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=538786", "date": "2010-09-26 19:00:04", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PNEUMONIC - CHINA (TIBETAN AUTONOMOUS REGION), REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: 26 Sep 2010\nSource: Sydney Morning Herald / AFP\n<http://news.smh.com.au/breaking-news-world/plague-breaks-out-in-chinas-tibet-20100926-15s6z.html>\n\n\nPlague breaks out in China's Tibet\n---------------------\nChina issued a health alert in its southwestern region of Tibet after\n5 people were diagnosed with the plague, an often fatal infectious disease.\n\nOne of the 5 has already died from a severe lung infection attributed\nto the pneumonic plague, while one other patient was in a critical\ncondition, the Tibet health department said in a statement on its\nwebsite on Sunday [23 Sep 2010].\n\nThe outbreak was 1st detected on Thursday [23 Sep 2010] last week in\nLatok village in Tibet's Nyingchi Prefecture, the department said.\n\nThe four patients, all of whom had contact with the deceased, have\nbeen quarantined, it said.\n\nDisease control experts have been dispatched to the area in an effort\nto control the further spread of the disease, it said.\n\nThe department also issued a warning to anyone who has visited the\nregion near the outbreak to seek immediate medical attention should\nthey develop fever, cough or other flu-like symptoms common to the plague.\n\nPneumonic plague is spread by rodents like marmots, which are\nnumerous in Tibet.\n\nAn outbreak of the disease last year killed 3 people in Ziketan, a\ntown in a Tibetan area in neighbouring Qinghai province.\n\nThe World Health Organisation says pneumonic plague is the most\nvirulent but least common form of plague. The mortality rate can be\nhigh, but prompt antibiotic treatment is effective.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Dan Silver\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: 26 Sep 2010\nSource: Google News\n<http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5gNB9Xgm6lYfNj0MNcHGtToMb2xPAD9IFE5000>\n\n\n5 infected with deadly pneumonic plague in Tibet\n--------------------------\nChinese authorities say 5 people have been sickened with pneumonic\nplague in Tibet and that the deadly disease has killed one of them.\n\nThe Tibetan regional health department says the cases were reported\nin Laduo, a village in Lang county in the remote region.\n\nThe department said in a statement Sunday [26 Sep 2010] that the 1st\ncase was found [23 Sep 2010] and that the patient died of a severe\nlung infection. The remaining 4 people have been quarantined.\n\nThe disease can kill in as few as 24 hours if left untreated.\n\nLast year, an outbreak of the disease in a farming town in Qinghai\nprovince killed three people and sickened nine, prompting authorities\nto seal off the community of 10,000 people for more than a week.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[Borrowing from Mod.LL's comment associated with the prior outbreak\nof plague in Qinghai China in 2009 (see Plague, pneumonic - China:\n(QH), RFI 20090801.2702), 'Primary pneumonic plague (one percent of\nnatural plague presentations) arises as a result of inhalation of\nplague bacilli in infectious aerosols, such as would be produced when\nthere are secondary pneumonic complications in bubonic/septicemic plague.\n\nPrimary plague pneumonia has a short incubation period of 1-3 days,\nafter which there is sudden onset of flu-like symptoms including\nfever, chills, headache, generalized body pains, weakness, and chest\ndiscomfort. A cough develops with sputum production, which may be\nbloody, and increasing chest pain and difficulty in breathing. As the\ndisease progresses, hypoxia (low oxygen concentration in the blood)\nand hemoptysis (coughing up blood) are prominent. The disease is\ninvariably fatal unless antimicrobial therapy commences within 24\nhours of exposure.\n\nPatients with primary pneumonic plague generate large quantities of\ninfectious aerosols that pose a significant risk to close contacts.\nCDC (US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) guidelines\nidentify contacts within 2 meters (6.5 ft) as being at greatest risk\nand do not consider the organism likely to be carried through air\nducts or vents. Persons who have been in contact with pneumonic\nplague patients or handling potentially infectious body fluids or\ntissues without appropriate protection should receive preventive\nantimicrobial therapy. The preferred antimicrobial agents for\nprophylaxis are tetracyclines, quinolones, or chloramphenicol.\n\nOf note, in June 2005 there was an outbreak of plague in the Tibetan\nAutonomous Region involving 5 individuals. An association with\nhandling marmots for consumption was attributed as the vehicle for\ntransmission. At that time the reports did not specify the form of\nplague (bubonic vs pneumonic) but with the implementation of\nquarantine measures, it was hypothesized that there were pneumonic\nmanifestations. (see Plague - China (Tibet) 20050626.1798).\n\nMore information on this outbreak from knowledgeable sources in the\nregion would be greatly appreciated.\n\nFor a map of the Tibetan Autonomous Region showing Nyingchi\nPrefecture, see\n<http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/09/Nyinchi_map.svg>.\nFor the interactive HealthMap/ProMED map of Nyingchi Prefecture of\nthe Tibetan Autonomous Region, see <http://healthmap.org/r/09zz>. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "LL's comment associated with the prior outbreak\nof plague in Qinghai China in 2009 (see Plague, pneumonic - China:\n(QH), RFI 20090801.2702), 'Primary pneumonic plague (one percent of\nnatural plague presentations) arises as a result of inhalation of\nplague bacilli in infectious aerosols, such as would be produced when\nthere are secondary pneumonic complications in bubonic/septicemic plague. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\n \n\nOne of the 5 has already died from a severe lung infection attributed\nto the pneumonic plague, while one other patient was in a critical\ncondition, the Tibet health department said in a statement on its\nwebsite on Sunday [23 Sep 2010]. \n\nPrimary plague pneumonia has a short incubation period of 1-3 days,\nafter which there is sudden onset of flu-like symptoms including\nfever, chills, headache, generalized body pains, weakness, and chest\ndiscomfort. Persons who have been in contact with pneumonic\nplague patients or handling potentially infectious body fluids or\ntissues without appropriate protection should receive preventive\nantimicrobial therapy. At that time the reports did not specify the form of\nplague (bubonic vs pneumonic) but with the implementation of\nquarantine measures, it was hypothesized that there were pneumonic\nmanifestations. CDC (US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) guidelines\nidentify contacts within 2 meters (6.5 ft) as being at greatest risk\nand do not consider the organism likely to be carried through air\nducts or vents. \n\nThe department also issued a warning to anyone who has visited the\nregion near the outbreak to seek immediate medical attention should\nthey develop fever, cough or other flu-like symptoms common to the plague. \n\nLast year, an outbreak of the disease in a farming town in Qinghai\nprovince killed three people and sickened nine, prompting authorities\nto seal off the community of 10,000 people for more than a week. \nChinese authorities say 5 people have been sickened with pneumonic\nplague in Tibet and that the deadly disease has killed one of them. Source: Google News\n<http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5gNB9Xgm6lYfNj0MNcHGtToMb2xPAD9IFE5000>\n\n\n5 infected with deadly pneumonic plague in Tibet\n [26 Sep 2010] that the 1st\ncase was found [23 Sep 2010] and that the patient died of a severe\nlung infection. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Dan Silver\n\n******\n The disease is\ninvariably fatal unless antimicrobial therapy commences within 24\nhours of exposure. As the\ndisease progresses, hypoxia (low oxygen concentration in the blood)\nand hemoptysis (coughing up blood) are prominent. An association with\nhandling marmots for consumption was attributed as the vehicle for\ntransmission. \n\nThe World Health Organisation says pneumonic plague is the most\nvirulent but least common form of plague.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-09-26 00:00:00", "2010-09-23 00:00:00", "2005-06-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Nyingchi Prefecture of", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nyingchi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mod", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lang county", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ziketan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tibet", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Qinghai", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "498260", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (02): (CA) rodent", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=498260", "date": "2010-08-19 11:00:32", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (02): (CALIFORNIA) RODENT\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sat 14 Aug 2010\nSource: KOLO TV [edited]\n<http://www.kolotv.com/home/headlines/100655624.html>\n\n\nPlague detected at Plumas Eureka State Park. No human cases detected so far\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nPlumas County Environmental Health reports that a rodent found in the\nPlumas Eureka State Park area has tested positive for plague. This\nreport is the 1st sign of plague activity in Plumas County in many years.\n\nPlumas County Environmental Health is working with the State\nVector-Borne Disease program and will be monitoring this situation.\nPlague warnings will be posted in the Plumas Eureka State Park Area\nand surrounding campgrounds. Additional surveillance activities will\nalso begin in these areas.\n\nPlague is a highly infectious bacterial disease which primarily\naffects rodents. Humans and their pets (dogs, and especially cats)\ncan get plague if they visit areas where wild rodents are infected.\n\n'At the present time, there have been no cases of human plague in\nPlumas County. However, it is vital that the disease be diagnosed and\ntreated in its early stages,' states Dr Valeska Armisen, health\nofficer for Plumas County.\n\nIn humans, the initial symptoms of plague include fever, chills,\nmuscle aches, a feeling of weakness and, commonly, swollen and tender\nlymph nodes. The usual incubation period is 2 to 6 days, but contact\na physician immediately if you become ill within 7 days of being in a\nplague-affected area. Plague is curable when diagnosed early. You can\nhelp with diagnosis by telling your doctor where you have been and\nthat you may have been exposed to plague.\n\nPeople can get the disease from animals in several ways. The most\nimportant route of transmission is through bites of fleas from\ninfected rodents, but direct contact with sick or dead animals should\nalso be avoided.\n\nThe most important wild rodents that can carry plague are squirrels\n(especially ground squirrels), chipmunks, wood rats, mice, and\nmarmots. Plague is lethal to many rodents. Therefore, a sick or dead\nrodent is a possible warning that plague may be in the area.\n\nIt is important to note that while it is not uncommon to find plague\nin wild animals in Plumas County, no human cases have been confirmed\nin several years. Nonetheless, Plumas County residents and guests are\nurged to take the following general precautions to help prevent the\nspread of plague:\n- avoid all contact with rodents and their fleas. Do not touch sick\nor dead rodents, but report them to campground hosts or park rangers\n- do not camp, sleep or rest near animal burrows\n- do not feed rodents in campgrounds and picnic areas. Store food and\nrefuse in rodent-proof containers\n- wearing long pants tucked into boot tops can reduce your exposure\nto fleas. Insect repellent sprayed on socks and trouser cuffs also may help\n- leave pets at home if possible. If not, keep pet confined or on a\nleash. Do not allow pet to approach sick or dead rodents or to\nexplore rodent burrows\n- if you have any questions, visit the state Department of Public\nHealth website at\n<http://www.cdph.ca.gov/HealthInfo/discond/Pages/Plague.aspx>.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[For more information of plague, readers are directed to the\nModerator's comments in ProMED-mail post 20100817.2849 - Mod.TG]\n\n[The state of California can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/037r>.\nPlumas County can be located on the map at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plumas_County,_California>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sat 14 Aug 2010\n Do not allow pet to approach sick or dead rodents or to\nexplore rodent burrows\n- if you have any questions, visit the state Department of Public\nHealth website at\n<http://www.cdph.ca.gov/HealthInfo/discond/Pages/Plague.aspx>. Do not touch sick\nor dead rodents, but report them to campground hosts or park rangers\n- do not camp, sleep or rest near animal burrows\n- do not feed rodents in campgrounds and picnic areas. Nonetheless, Plumas County residents and guests are\nurged to take the following general precautions to help prevent the\nspread of plague:\n- avoid all contact with rodents and their fleas. The most\nimportant route of transmission is through bites of fleas from\ninfected rodents, but direct contact with sick or dead animals should\nalso be avoided. Store food and\nrefuse in rodent-proof containers\n- wearing long pants tucked into boot tops can reduce your exposure\nto fleas. \n\nThe most important wild rodents that can carry plague are squirrels\n(especially ground squirrels), chipmunks, wood rats, mice, and\nmarmots. \n\nIt is important to note that while it is not uncommon to find plague\nin wild animals in Plumas County, no human cases have been confirmed\nin several years. The usual incubation period is 2 to 6 days, but contact\na physician immediately if you become ill within 7 days of being in a\nplague-affected area. ----------------------------------------------------------------------\nPlumas County Environmental Health reports that a rodent found in the\nPlumas Eureka State Park area has tested positive for plague. In humans, the initial symptoms of plague include fever, chills,\nmuscle aches, a feeling of weakness and, commonly, swollen and tender\nlymph nodes. TG]\n\n[The state of California can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/037r>. You can\nhelp with diagnosis by telling your doctor where you have been and\nthat you may have been exposed to plague.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Plumas County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "495670", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, wildlife - Canada: (SK) prairie dog", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=495670", "date": "2010-08-17 14:00:08", "main_text": "PLAGUE, WILDLIFE - CANADA: (SASKATCHEWAN) PRAIRIE DOG\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 13 Aug 2010\nSource: CBC (Canadian Broadcasting Corporation) News [edited]\n<http://www.cbc.ca/canada/saskatchewan/story/2010/08/13/sk-praire-dog-plague-1008.html?>\n\n\nParks Canada officials are alerting the public after a Saskatchewan\nprairie dog was found dead of plague. The carcass of the black-tailed\nprairie dog was found on the edge of the Larson prairie dog colony in\nGrasslands National Park in the southern part of the province.\n\nTests confirmed the rodent had been infected with the _Yersinia\npestis_ bacterium, the same type of organism that causes bubonic and\npneumonic plague in humans. With rodents, the disease is called\nsylvatic plague. Park officials said it's a rare but naturally\noccurring disease that affects squirrels and mice throughout the\nsouthern Prairies.\n\nTransmission to humans occurs through infected flea bites, but it's\nextremely rare for people to contract the disease, Parks Canada said\nin a news release.\n\nGrasslands National Park will remain open, but Parks Canada is\nrecommending that visitors not walk through prairie dog colonies.\nPets are now banned from the park's prairie dog colonies. Officials\nare also advising visitors to the park to use insect repellent on\ntheir pants and shoes.\n\nHealth agencies, including the Public Health Agency of Canada and the\nCypress Health Region, have been notified, Parks Canada said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The causative bacterium, _Yersinia pestis_, is transmitted to people\nthrough fleabites and direct contact with infected animals. Each\nrodent species is host to one or more species of fleas which, when\ninfected, are carriers. These fleas generally do not infest other\nanimals unless their natural hosts are unavailable.\n\nDomestic cats and dogs can also contract plague from infective fleas.\nThey may carry infected fleas home to their owners or, especially\ncats, serve as a direct source of infection. There are many flea\ntreatments and repellents appropriate for pets and available. Some\nproducts may be suitable for dogs but not cats or may be suitable for\nan adult but not a younger animal. Be sure to consult your\nveterinarian, as some products may be toxic to cats, kittens, and\npuppies, even resulting in fatalities.\n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under\nthe jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front\nleg (the armpit if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever. Please\ntake your pet to a veterinarian if you notice any abnormalities in\nyour pet. Veterinarians should protect themselves by wearing gloves\nwhen examining these swellings. A bubo that ruptures may infect the\nveterinarian or even the pet owner if the pet owner is the one\npalpating the swelling.\n\nAnother form of the disease is the respiratory form. Cats may acquire\nthis form and can spread it to their owners or the veterinarians\nthrough infected expiratory droplets. People are also prone to the\nrespiratory infection as well.\n\nYou should also be aware that the fleas that hitchhike into your home\nvia a pet vehicle and can also transmit disease to you, the owner or\ncaretaker of the pet.\n\nThe park seems to be operating out of caution to contain the disease\nand protect human and pet health. - Mod.TG]\n\n[The province of Saskatchewan can be seen on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Canada at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/02SU>. Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 13 Aug 2010\n \n\nYou should also be aware that the fleas that hitchhike into your home\nvia a pet vehicle and can also transmit disease to you, the owner or\ncaretaker of the pet. \n\nTransmission to humans occurs through infected flea bites, but it's\nextremely rare for people to contract the disease, Parks Canada said\nin a news release. \n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under\nthe jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front\nleg (the armpit if you will), lethargy, anorexia, and fever. A bubo that ruptures may infect the\nveterinarian or even the pet owner if the pet owner is the one\npalpating the swelling. The carcass of the black-tailed\nprairie dog was found on the edge of the Larson prairie dog colony in\n Park officials said it's a rare but naturally\noccurring disease that affects squirrels and mice throughout the\nsouthern Prairies. Some\nproducts may be suitable for dogs but not cats or may be suitable for\nan adult but not a younger animal.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saskatchewan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "600707", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Undiagnosed disease - Uganda (07): plague suspected", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=600707", "date": "2010-12-08 23:50:00", "main_text": "UNDIAGNOSED DISEASE - UGANDA (07): PLAGUE SUSPECTED\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: Tue 7 Dec 2010\nSource: Reuters Africa [edited]\n<http://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFJOE6B60HX20101207>\n\n\nPneumonic plague has broken out in northern Uganda, killing 38 people\nand putting dozens in hospital, a senior health official said on\nTuesday, 7 Dec 2010.\n\nIssa Makumbi, assistant commissioner in charge of disease\nsurveillance, said investigations into a disease that struck the\nregion in November [2010] were continuing but that tentative tests\nhad confirmed it was pneumonic plague.\n\nHealth services in the impoverished east African nation are patchy\nand it can take weeks before diseases are identified and response\nteams and medical supplies are sent to affected areas.\n\n'So far (pneumonic plague) has been detected in 5 districts in\nnorthern Uganda where a total of about 38 people have died,' Makumbi\nsaid.\n\nMedical personnel had been sent from the capital Kampala and were\nbattling to contain the outbreak. Northern Uganda is recovering from\n2 decades of civil war waged by the Lord's Resistance Army. Poverty\nand poor sanitary conditions makes the region vulnerable to diseases.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[But read further below in [3] and [4] Mod.LM]\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Mon 6 Dec 2010\nSource: AllAfrica, The New Vision (Uganda) report [edited]\n<http://allafrica.com/stories/201012070114.html>\n\n\nPlague, a disease that affects rodents but can be spread to humans\nand other animals usually by infected fleas, has hit the northern\nUgandan district of Kitgum, the health ministry has confirmed. The\nministry said they had confirmed that the strange sickness was\nplague, not a hemorrhagic fever as earlier thought.\n\nThe disease surveillance officer in Kitgum district, Sr Grace Agwang,\nsaid preliminary results from the Centre for Disease Control in\nAtlanta showed that it was plague.\n\nThe disease, according to the WHO report, hit Acholi sub-region on 3\nDec 2010. One person has been admitted in Kitgum at St Joseph\nHospital, 2 others at Kalongo Hospital in Pader. The report adds that\nKitgum district has so far had 18 cases, while one of the infected\npeople died at St Joseph Hospital on 3 Dec 2010. According to the\nreport, 9 other people have so far died.\n\nMedical personnel in Kitgum have set up an isolation unit at Kitgum\nHospital. Health workers are also being trained by Medecins Sans\nFrontieres from Holland to handle the disease. At Kalongo Hospital,\n24 people had been admitted by 3 Dec 2010. The WHO suggested that a\ncommunity-based surveillance system needs to be reactivated in the\naffected districts.\n\n[Byline: Conan Businge, Chris Ocowun]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nThomas James Allen\n<tjallen@pipeline.com>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: 8 Dec 2010\nSource: AFP [edited]\n<http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hgmieXl3QCUDRkdH0Z12UD704bFg?docId=CNG.6a0a014a69f4ce1afd31a8eefff9f2b8.441>\n\n\nUganda scrambling to identify new deadly disease\n----------------------------------------------------------\nUganda is working 'around the clock' with international health\nexperts to identify an unprecedented illness that has killed 38\npeople in the north of the country, an official told AFP on Wednesday.\n\nThe unknown illness was first detected on November 10 in several\ndistricts in the central part of northern Uganda, according to a\nstatement from the health ministry.\n\nLocal and foreign media reports had identified the illness as bubonic\nplague, which has previously struck Uganda, most recently in 2008.\n\nBut an official from the ministry's Epidemiology and Surveillance\nDivision working closely on the outbreak said Wednesday that the\ndisease remained mysterious and evidence collected so far pointed\naway from bubonic plague.\n\n'The results we have received from Fort Collins are negative for\nbubonic plague,' the official, who requested anonymity, told AFP,\nreferring to a specialized laboratory in the US state of Colorado.\n\n'If this was typical plague, we would have found that out by now. We\njust haven't seen a disease like this before,' he added.\n\nThe doctor explained that all previous incidents of plague in Uganda\nwere contained in the West Nile region, much further west than the\ncurrent outbreak.\n\nThe source added that plague victims suffer from inflammation in\nspecific body parts, including the armpits, which has not happened in\nthis case.\n\n'The plague we've seen in the past also tends to cause fatalities\namong women and children, but all the dead here are adult men,' the\nofficial also said.\n\nThe doctor said that while Uganda-based staff from the US Centers for\nDisease Control (CDC) were already working on the case, specialists\nfrom CDC headquarters in Atlanta were on their way to help identify\nthe illness.\n\nStaff from the World's Health Organization's Africa regional office\nin Brazzaville, Republic of Congo have also been sent to Uganda.\n\n'We simply don't have the information to conclude what this disease\nis yet, but we are working around the clock, literally 24 hours,' the\nofficial said.\n\nUgandan staff have developed a treatment that has so far halted the\ndeath toll at 38, according to the source.\n\nThe 91 confirmed patients reported severe headaches, dizziness,\nfever, diarrhoea and vomiting, according to the health ministry.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nThomas James Allen\n<tjallen@pipeline.com>\n\n******\n[4]\nDate: 8 Dec 2010\nSource: NewVision [edited]\n<http://www.newvision.co.ug/D/8/13/740598>\n\n\nNorthern disease still a mystery\n--------------------------------------\nA new team of health experts from the US Centers for Disease Control\n(CDC) is expected in Uganda tomorrow to intensify the fight against a\nmysterious illness that has hit at least six districts in northern\nand north-eastern Uganda.\n\nThe team is to carry out more tests to determine the cause of the\noutbreak, which has claimed about 38 lives since it was first\nreported in November.\n\nCDC team leader, Jeffrey Miller yesterday said tests done at the CDC\nand Uganda Virus Research Institute joint laboratory in Arua district\nruled out plague.\n\nHe said a series of preliminary tests done at the CDC laboratories in\nEntebbe and Atlanta in the USA also proved negative for on Ebola,\nMarburg and Congo Crimean haemorrhagic fever.\n\nPatients complain of severe headache, dizziness, fever, diarrhoea and vomiting.\n\nEarlier this week, the health ministry said the outbreak was plague.\nBut specialists from the World Health Organisation, ministry of\nhealth, CDC and several non-governmental organisations, have now\nrevealed that there are no conclusive results proving this.\n\n[Byline: Jimmy Wokorach-Oboiand Taddeo Bwambale]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nThomas James Allen\n<tjallen@pipeline.com>\n\n\n[Primary pneumonic plague (one percent of natural plague\npresentations) arises as a result of inhalation of plague bacilli in\ninfectious aerosols, such as would be produced when there are\nsecondary pneumonic complications in bubonic/septicemic plague.\n\nPrimary plague pneumonia has a short incubation period of 1-3 days,\nafter which there is sudden onset of flu-like symptoms including\nfever, chills, headache, generalized body pains, weakness, and chest\ndiscomfort. A cough develops with sputum production, which may be\nbloody, and increasing chest pain and difficulty in breathing. As the\ndisease progresses, hypoxia (low oxygen concentration in the blood),\nand hemoptysis (coughing up blood) are prominent. The disease is\ninvariably fatal unless antimicrobial therapy commences within 24\nhours of exposure.\n\nPatients with primary pneumonic plague generate large quantities of\ninfectious aerosols that pose a significant risk to close contacts.\nCDC guidelines identify contacts within 2 meters (6.5 ft) as being at\ngreatest risk and do not consider the organism likely to be carried\nthrough air ducts or vents. Persons who have been in contact with\npneumonic plague patients or handling potentially infectious body\nfluids, or tissues without appropriate protection should receive\npreventive antimicrobial therapy. The preferred antimicrobial agents\nfor prophylaxis include tetracyclines and fluoroquinolones.\n\nIt appears however, that the plague diagnosis may be less than\ndefinitive, as indicated in the most recent news stories. The\nclinical picture described in the outbreak is quite atypical for\npneumonic plague and the absence of any apparent accompanying bubonic\nplague would be unusual, and may mean that another pathogen is\nresponsible or that multiple pathogens are causing disease in the\nsame region. The involvement of teams including Ugandan public health\nauthorities, US CDC, WHO and NGOs indicate extensive international\nattention has been given to this outbreak and that adequate\nlaboratory diagnostic testing should lead to identification of the\npathogen or pathogens responsible for this outbreak. We await\nfurther results with interest.\n\nThe districts in the Northern Region of Uganda affected by the\noutbreak can be located using the map at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Districts_of_Uganda>.\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Uganda can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/0089>. - Mod.LL/LM]", "summary": "The\nclinical picture described in the outbreak is quite atypical for\npneumonic plague and the absence of any apparent accompanying bubonic\nplague would be unusual, and may mean that another pathogen is\nresponsible or that multiple pathogens are causing disease in the\nsame region. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\n The involvement of teams including Ugandan public health\nauthorities, US CDC, WHO and NGOs indicate extensive international\nattention has been given to this outbreak and that adequate\nlaboratory diagnostic testing should lead to identification of the\npathogen or pathogens responsible for this outbreak. \nCommunicated by:\nThomas James Allen\n<tjallen@pipeline.com>\n\n******\n \n\nIssa Makumbi, assistant commissioner in charge of disease\nsurveillance, said investigations into a disease that struck the\nregion in November [2010] were continuing but that tentative tests\nhad confirmed it was pneumonic plague. [Primary pneumonic plague (one percent of natural plague\npresentations) arises as a result of inhalation of plague bacilli in\ninfectious aerosols, such as would be produced when there are\nsecondary pneumonic complications in bubonic/septicemic plague. \n\nPrimary plague pneumonia has a short incubation period of 1-3 days,\nafter which there is sudden onset of flu-like symptoms including\nfever, chills, headache, generalized body pains, weakness, and chest\ndiscomfort. Source: Reuters Africa [edited]\n<http://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFJOE6B60HX20101207>\n\n\nPneumonic plague has broken out in northern Uganda, killing 38 people\nand putting dozens in hospital, a senior health official said on\nTuesday, 7 Dec 2010. Source: AllAfrica, The New Vision (Uganda) report [edited]\n<http://allafrica.com/stories/201012070114.html>\n\n\nPlague, a disease that affects rodents but can be spread to humans\nand other animals usually by infected fleas, has hit the northern\nUgandan district of Kitgum, the health ministry has confirmed. But an official from the ministry's Epidemiology and Surveillance\nDivision working closely on the outbreak said Wednesday that the\ndisease remained mysterious and evidence collected so far pointed\naway from bubonic plague. \n\nThe doctor said that while Uganda-based staff from the US Centers for\nDisease Control (CDC) were already working on the case, specialists\nfrom CDC headquarters in Atlanta were on their way to help identify\nthe illness. ----------------------------------------------------------\nUganda is working 'around the clock' with international health\nexperts to identify an unprecedented illness that has killed 38\npeople in the north of the country, an official told AFP on Wednesday. Persons who have been in contact with\npneumonic plague patients or handling potentially infectious body\nfluids, or tissues without appropriate protection should receive\npreventive antimicrobial therapy. Communicated by:\nThomas James Allen\n<tjallen@pipeline.com>\n\n******\n \n\n'So far (pneumonic plague) has been detected in 5 districts in\nnorthern Uganda where a total of about 38 people have died,' Makumbi\nsaid. \n\n'The plague we've seen in the past also tends to cause fatalities\namong women and children, but all the dead here are adult men,' the\nofficial also said. \n\nCDC team leader, Jeffrey Miller yesterday said tests done at the CDC\nand Uganda Virus Research Institute joint laboratory in Arua district\nruled out plague. \n\n'The results we have received from Fort Collins are negative for\nbubonic plague,' the official, who requested anonymity, told AFP,\nreferring to a specialized laboratory in the US state of Colorado. \n\nThe doctor explained that all previous incidents of plague in Uganda\nwere contained in the West Nile region, much further west than the\ncurrent outbreak. \n\nThe unknown illness was first detected on November 10 in several\ndistricts in the central part of northern Uganda, according to a\nstatement from the health ministry. The disease surveillance officer in Kitgum district, Sr Grace Agwang,\nsaid preliminary results from the Centre for Disease Control in\nAtlanta showed that it was plague. \n\nHealth services in the impoverished east African nation are patchy\nand it can take weeks before diseases are identified and response\nteams and medical supplies are sent to affected areas. \n\nThe districts in the Northern Region of Uganda affected by the\noutbreak can be located using the map at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Districts_of_Uganda>. \n\nThe team is to carry out more tests to determine the cause of the\noutbreak, which has claimed about 38 lives since it was first\nreported in November. The\nministry said they had confirmed that the strange sickness was\nplague, not a hemorrhagic fever as earlier thought. We simply don't have the information to conclude what this disease\nis yet, but we are working around the clock, literally 24 hours,' the\nofficial said. The source added that plague victims suffer from inflammation in\nspecific body parts, including the armpits, which has not happened in\nthis case. The report adds that\nKitgum district has so far had 18 cases, while one of the infected\npeople died at St Joseph Hospital on 3 Dec 2010. UNDIAGNOSED DISEASE - UGANDA (07): PLAGUE SUSPECTED\n***************************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "plague"], "syndromes": ["haemorrhagic fever"], "event_date": ["2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2010-12-25 00:00:00", "2021-11-25 00:00:00", "2008-03-25 00:00:00", "2038-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-12-03 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-12-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-11-10 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brazzaville", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fort Collins", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kitgum", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Holland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pader", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kampala", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "492823", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Peru (04): (LL)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=492823", "date": "2010-08-14 19:00:06", "main_text": "PLAGUE - PERU (04): (LA LIBERTAD)\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 13 Aug 2010\nSource: Agence France-Presse [edited]\n<http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jveEG2qqSLps-8qQRoK1sQE4umiA>\n\n\nThe death of a 29 year old woman from pneumonic plague has brought the\nnumber of plague victims in Peru to 3 in 2 months, the health ministry\nsaid. The woman, who had been seriously ill for 36 days before succumbing\nto the plague in the coastal province of Ascope, some 325 miles (520\nkilometres) north west of Lima, died in hospital on Thursday [12 Aug 2010].\n\nSince late June 2010 another 2 deaths were from bubonic plague, officials\nsaid; and 31 more people have been infected. Health minister Oscar Ugarte\nblamed the situation on the expansion of farming in the region that ha\nprompted rodent infestations in nearby towns.\n\nThe last outbreak of bubonic plague in northern Peru was in 1994, which\nkilled 35 people and infected more than 1100 others.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMed-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There have been discrepancies in the reports of the number of total cases,\n21 or 31 and the number of fatalities. This posting reports 31 total cases\nand a now 3rd fatality, a previously reported case. - Mod.LL\n\nMaps of Peru are available at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/americas/peru_pol91.jpg> and the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at <http://healthmap.org/r/01PJ>. -\nMod.SH]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 13 Aug 2010\n \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMed-mail\n< The death of a 29 year old woman from pneumonic plague has brought the\nnumber of plague victims in Peru to 3 in 2 months, the health ministry\nsaid. Over the years, veterinarians there have\ndiagnosed numerous cases of plague and tularemia, all in domestic\ncats and in the summer months.\n\nCases have ranged from as far north as Norris to this most recent\ncase in the south, residing at Raynold's Pass.\n\nA diagnosis of plague is confirmed either by growing the culprit\nbacteria from a fine needle aspirate or by demonstrating an increase\nin antibodies in the cat from the onset of the disease, compared to a\nconvalescent blood sample taken 3 to 4 weeks later. An independent\nlab in Colorado confirmed the Raynold's Pass cat did have plague. The\ncat has since made a full recovery.\n\nIndoor/outdoor cats in rural areas that hunt rodents are the most\nlikely to encounter the 2 diseases.\n\nSigns [in animals] include swollen lymph nodes, lethargy, anorexia\nand a high fever.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The causative bacterium, _Yersinia pestis_, is transmitted to people\nthrough fleabites and direct contact with infected animals. Each\nrodent species is host to one or more species of fleas which, when\ninfected, are carriers. These fleas generally do not infest other\nanimals unless their natural hosts are unavailable.\n\nDomestic cats and dogs can also contract plague from infective fleas.\nThey may carry infected fleas home to their owners or, especially\ncats, serve as a direct source of infection. There are many flea\ntreatments and repellents appropriate for pets and available. Some\nproducts may be suitable for dogs but not cats or may be suitable for\nan adult but not a younger animal. Be sure to consult your\nveterinarian, as some products may be toxic to cats, kittens, and\npuppies, even resulting in fatalities.\n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under\nthe jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front\nleg (the armpit if you will), lethargy, anorexia and fever. Please\ntake your pet to a veterinarian if you notice any abnormalities in\nyour pet. Veterinarians should protect themselves by wearing gloves\nwhen examining these swellings. A bubo that ruptures may infect the\nveterinarian or even the pet owner if the pet owner is the one\npalpating the swelling.\n\nYou should also be aware that the fleas that hitchhike into your home\nvia a pet vehicle and can also transmit disease to you, the owner or\ncaretaker of the pet. - Mod.TG]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 7 Aug 2010\n \n\nA diagnosis of plague is confirmed either by growing the culprit\nbacteria from a fine needle aspirate or by demonstrating an increase\nin antibodies in the cat from the onset of the disease, compared to a\nconvalescent blood sample taken 3 to 4 weeks later. \nVeterinarians at White and White Veterinary Hospital in Ennis,\nMontana, have diagnosed the 1st case of plague this summer in an\nindoor/outdoor pet cat. \n\nYou should also be aware that the fleas that hitchhike into your home\nvia a pet vehicle and can also transmit disease to you, the owner or\ncaretaker of the pet. \n\nClinical signs in pets involve a localized swelling, such as under\nthe jaw in cats, but also in the inguinal region or under the front\nleg (the armpit if you will), lethargy, anorexia and fever. A bubo that ruptures may infect the\nveterinarian or even the pet owner if the pet owner is the one\npalpating the swelling. Over the years, veterinarians there have\ndiagnosed numerous cases of plague and tularemia, all in domestic\ncats and in the summer months. Be sure to consult your\nveterinarian, as some products may be toxic to cats, kittens, and\npuppies, even resulting in fatalities. Please\ntake your pet to a veterinarian if you notice any abnormalities in\nyour pet.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Montana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "White", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "482788", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, bubonic - Peru (02): (LL), bubonic, pneumonic", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=482788", "date": "2010-08-03 16:00:05", "main_text": "PLAGUE - PERU (02): (LA LIBERTAD), BUBONIC, PNEUMONIC\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 2 Aug 2010\nSource: Associated Press (AP) [edited]\n<http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/38529059/ns/health-infectious_diseases>\n\n\nPeru's health minister says an outbreak of plague has killed a\n14-year-old boy and infected at least 31 people in a northern coastal\nprovince. Health Minister Oscar Ugarte says authorities are screening\nsugar and fish meal exports from Ascope province [La Libertad\nregion], located about 325 miles (520 km) northwest of Lima. Popular\nChicama beach isn't far away.\n\nUgarte says the boy, who had Down syndrome, died of bubonic plague 26\nJul 2010. He said Monday, 2 Aug 2010, that most of the infections are\nbubonic plague, with 4 cases of pneumonic plague. The former is\ntransmitted by flea bites, the latter by airborne contagion. The\ndisease is curable if treated early with antibiotics.\n\nThe 1st recorded plague outbreak in Peru was in 1903. The last, in\n1994, killed 35 people.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Ascope province is located in the region of La Libertad, in\nnorthwestern Peru. It shares a border with Trujillo province where\nthe disease has also been recently reported. It is not clearly stated\nin the posting whether the pneumonic cases were directly acquired\nfrom person-to-person spread or were a complication of bubonic\nplague. Of note, there was an outbreak of bubonic plague reported in\nChicama district of Ascope province in April 2010, suggestive that\nthese current cases may be part of this previously reported outbreak\nas proximity to Chicama beach is mentioned in the above newswire (see\nprior ProMED-mail posting Plague, bubonic - Peru: (LL) RFI\n20100428.1373). - Mods.LL/MPP]\n\n[Maps of Peru are available at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/americas/peru_pol91.jpg> and the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01PJ>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "Of note, there was an outbreak of bubonic plague reported in\nChicama district of Ascope province in April 2010, suggestive that\nthese current cases may be part of this previously reported outbreak\nas proximity to Chicama beach is mentioned in the above newswire (see\nprior ProMED-mail posting Plague, bubonic - Peru: (LL) RFI\n20100428.1373). - A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 2 Aug 2010\n Source: Associated Press (AP) [edited]\n<http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/38529059/ns/health-infectious_diseases>\n\n\nPeru's health minister says an outbreak of plague has killed a\n14-year-old boy and infected at least 31 people in a northern coastal\nprovince. PLAGUE - PERU (02): (LA LIBERTAD), BUBONIC, PNEUMONIC\n******************************************\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1994-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-04-25 00:00:00", "2010-08-02 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "1903-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Trujillo province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Peru", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lima", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chicama", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "484811", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Peru (03): (LL), PAHO", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=484811", "date": "2010-08-05 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE - PERU (03): (LA LIBERTAD), PAHO\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org\n\n\nDate: Mon 2 Aug 2010\nSource: PAHO [edited]\n<http://new.paho.org/hq/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=3311&Itemid=2206>\n\n\nDuring Epidemiological Week (EW) 28 of 2010, the Ministry of Health\nof Peru confirmed the 1st case of pneumonic plague in a 29 year old\npatient from the district of Chocope, province of Ascope, department\nLa Libertad. The presence of buboes had not been identified in the\npatient. Subsequently 3 more cases were registered. They were\nconfirmed by rapid test.\n\nAs of EW 30, 17 cases of plague have been reported; of these 4 are\npneumonic plague, 12 are bubonic plague and 1 was septicemic plague\nwhich resulted in death. The onset of symptoms for the last pneumonic\ncase was 11 Jul 2010. During the investigations, 10 isolates of _Y.\npestis_ were isolated from humans, rodents and domestic cats.\n\nThe last plague outbreak reported in the province of Ascope occurred\nin the locality of Santa Clara, in the district of Casa Grande\nbetween August and September 2009. During the outbreak, 15 cases were\nreported, of which 9 cases were confirmed by laboratory.\n\nAmong the current outbreak control measures carried out by the\nnational and local authorities of Peru are:\n- Active search for contacts and secondary cases; beginning of\nchemoprophylaxis use on the contacts;\n- Strict monitoring of the implementation of biosafety measures by\nthe health workers;\n- Strengthening of the laboratory network for collecting and\nprocessing samples;\n- Implementation of an environmental management program.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is a PAHO confirmation report of the outbreak. ProMED waits to\nsee exactly how many cases will be reported and how many of the\npneumonic cases represent person-to-person spread. - Mod. Squirrel\nburrows in the area will be dusted for fleas, and further testing\nwill be conducted before the campground is reopened.\n\n[Byline: Ruben Vives]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The causative bacterium _Yersinia pestis_ is transmitted to people\nthrough fleabite and direct contact with infected animals. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-27 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Los Angeles County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "459849", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Syria (02): military, denied", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=459849", "date": "2010-07-06 10:00:03", "main_text": "PLAGUE - SYRIA (02): MILITARY, DENIED\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 5 Jul 2010\nSource: Source identity withheld by request [edited]\n\n\n[Re: ProMED-mail Plague - Syria: military, susp. RFI 20100704.2222]\n-------------------------------------------------------------------\nAccording to a reliable source that prefers to remain anonymous,\nSyrian sources have dismissed reports (from a single press report) of\nthe occurrence of plague affecting the Syrian army. According to\nthese sources, no plague cases have been recorded in the past 40\nyears. The Syrian source has been in direct contact with the army\nhospital and confirms that no reports have been issued to WHO or\nhealth institutions regarding plague in Syria.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 5 Jul 2010\n According to a reliable source that prefers to remain anonymous,\nSyrian sources have dismissed reports (from a single press report) of\nthe occurrence of plague affecting the Syrian army. The Syrian source has been in direct contact with the army\nhospital and confirms that no reports have been issued to WHO or\nhealth institutions regarding plague in Syria.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "MILITARY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Syria", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "469160", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, pneumonic - Peru: (TJ)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=469160", "date": "2010-07-18 13:00:04", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PNEUMONIC - PERU: (TRUJILLO)\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 16 Jul 2010\nSource: La Industria [edited]\n<http://www.laindustria.pe/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=17008&Itemid=18>\n\n\nAn outbreak of pneumonic plague, a virulent disease with a high\nmortality rate, was detected in Trujillo. Doctors are striving to\nsave the lives of 3 patients, including a resident doctor and a\nmedical student whose health conditions are serious.\n\nAccording to the regional manager of Health, Victor Peralta Chavez,\nthis is the 1st time this disease has been recorded in the country.\n\nA woman aged 29, from Mariposa Leyva sector, district Chocope\n(Ascope), 40 minutes north of Trijillo, contracted the disease. The\n1st symptoms occurred 5 days prior to her family taking her to\nTrujillo, where she was admitted at the Regional Teaching Hospital.\n\nWith a picture of severe pneumonia (high fever, abdominal pain,\nshortness of breath and other symptoms), the patient was treated for\nboth pneumonia and for potential influenza A (H1N1) (with antibiotics\nand antivirals), but there was no improvement. The results of a quick\ntest [direct fluorescent antibody stain of sputum? - Mod.LL] to\ndetect possible pneumonic plague were negative.\n\nA 32-year-old resident doctor, who treated and intubated the patient\nduring her critical condition, developed the same symptoms as the\ninfected woman. He was immediately hospitalized and treated, but his\nhealth is critical. In this regard, Peralta Chavez said that the\npatient's progress is not good. 'This has caused multiple organ\nfailure, i.e. many of [his] vital organs do not work or [have]\nstopped working properly. The patient is in hospital intensive care\nat Victor Lazarte Echegaray,' he said.\n\nAlso, last Tuesday [13 Jul 2010], a 4th-year student of Human\nMedicine at the Universidad Nacional de Trujillo (UNT), who also had\ncontact with the infected woman, was hospitalized at the Regional\nTeaching Hospital. This patient took a rapid test and tested positive\nfor pneumonic plague. His condition is also very delicate, Chavez said.\n\nWith these results, Peralta Chavez summoned the press and warned of a\npossible outbreak of pneumonic plague at the hospital or in the\nTrujillo Regional Teaching Hospital, although he clarified that this\nis an imported case from Chocope, an area where plague spreads\nsilently and is very dangerous.\n\n[Byline: Hernan Rodriguez Flores]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nFluTrackers\n<http://www.flutrackers.com/forum/showthread.php?t=149334>\n\n[_Yersinia pestis_ is endemic in parts of Peru, as can be seen on a\nCDC map at <http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvbid/plague/world98.htm>.\n\nMost cases are due to bubonic plague following the bite of an\ninfected rodent flea causing a swollen and very tender lymph gland.\nThe swollen gland is called a 'bubo.' Bubonic plague should be\nsuspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills,\nheadache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible\nexposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually\nbecomes ill with bubonic plague 2 to 6 days after being bitten.\n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the\nbloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they\nspread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal\ncondition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes\nthe pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The\ninfected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and\nbreathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients\nare not given specific antibiotic therapy, the disease can progress\nrapidly to death. At this stage, as appears to have happened in this\nposting, person-to-person spread can occur, causing other cases of\n'primary' plague pneumonia. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 16 Jul 2010\n \n\nWith these results, Peralta Chavez summoned the press and warned of a\npossible outbreak of pneumonic plague at the hospital or in the\nTrujillo Regional Teaching Hospital, although he clarified that this\nis an imported case from Chocope, an area where plague spreads\nsilently and is very dangerous. Bubonic plague should be\nsuspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever, chills,\nheadache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of possible\nexposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. With a picture of severe pneumonia (high fever, abdominal pain,\nshortness of breath and other symptoms), the patient was treated for\nboth pneumonia and for potential influenza A (H1N1) (with antibiotics\nand antivirals), but there was no improvement. \n\nAlso, last Tuesday [13 Jul 2010], a 4th-year student of Human\nMedicine at the Universidad Nacional de Trujillo (UNT), who also had\ncontact with the infected woman, was hospitalized at the Regional\nTeaching Hospital. \n\nA 32-year-old resident doctor, who treated and intubated the patient\nduring her critical condition, developed the same symptoms as the\ninfected woman. At this stage, as appears to have happened in this\nposting, person-to-person spread can occur, causing other cases of\n'primary' plague pneumonia. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they\nspread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal\ncondition. If plague patients\nare not given specific antibiotic therapy, the disease can progress\nrapidly to death. The\ninfected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and\nbreathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. PLAGUE, PNEUMONIC - PERU: (TRUJILLO)\n************************************\n FluTrackers\n<http://www.flutrackers.com/forum/showthread.php?t=149334>\n\n[_Yersinia pestis_ is endemic in parts of Peru, as can be seen on a\nCDC map at <http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvbid/plague/world98.htm>.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Peru", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "460188", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Myanmar: (YA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=460188", "date": "2010-07-06 21:00:03", "main_text": "PLAGUE - MYANMAR: (YANGON)\n**************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 5 Jul 2010\nSource: The Irrawaddy [edited]\n<http://www.irrawaddy.org/article.php?art_id=18879>\n\n\nAn unspecified number of Yangon (previously called Rangoon) residents\nhave been diagnosed with plague, a contagious disease primarily\ntransmitted by rodents (mostly rats), according to the Burmese\nMinistry of Health (MOH) in Naypyidaw.\n\nAn epidemiologist at the MOH who asked to remain anonymous told The\nIrrawaddy that some people infected with plague were found in Yangon\nin June 2010 but all survived after treatment by the MOH. 'It was the\n1st time in decades that we found plague in Yangon,' said the MOH\nofficial.\n\nThe MOH has yet to make a public statement regarding the diagnosis of plague.\n\nThe MOH and other ministries have developed and implemented a project\nto eradicate rats for the prevention of plague, according to a MOH\nofficial in Naypyidaw. 'Rat eradication is secretly going on in\ndifferent departments,' he said. An official from the Yangon\nMunicipal Committee said it had formed special task forces for rat\neradication and has killed tens of thousands of rats on a daily basis.\n\nThe MOH reportedly has determined through laboratory experiments that\nrats migrating to the south from Naypyidaw are carrying bacteria for\ncontagious disease such as the plague, and it was developing a\ntreatment program should the disease spread.\n\nA plague awareness program has started among government staff in\nNaypyidaw, according to a source.\n\nState-run newspapers recently warned that the plague can be\ntransmitted to humans by fleas, but it failed to mention that the\ndisease had already infected people in Yangon. An official with the\nLivestock Breeding and Veterinary Department (LBVD) said people who\nfind rat corpses should take them to the nearest LBVD department for\nexamination.\n\n[Byline: Aung Thet Wine]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The manifestations of _Yersinia pestis_ infection in these reported\ncases is not stated. Most cases are due to bubonic plague following\nthe bite of an infected rodent flea causing a swollen and very tender\nlymph gland. The swollen gland is called a 'bubo.' Bubonic plague\nshould be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever,\nchills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of\npossible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person\nusually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2 to 6 days after being\nbitten.\n\nWhen bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the\nbloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they\nspread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal\ncondition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes\nthe pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The\ninfected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and\nbreathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients\nare not given specific antibiotic therapy, the disease can progress\nrapidly to death.\n\nThere were 2 issues of rodent control mentioned in the posting that\ncould cause many more cases of human plague. If rodent eradication\nprograms are introduced without a parallel program to spray for\nfleas, the fleas will flee the dead rodent and increase the risk of\nfeeding on humans. Picking up a dead rat for examination can even\nmore so put the 'picker-upper' at risk. - Mod.LL]\n\n[The interactive HealthMap/ProMED map for Yangon is available at:\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01D3> - CopyEd.EJP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 5 Jul 2010\n \n\nThe MOH reportedly has determined through laboratory experiments that\nrats migrating to the south from Naypyidaw are carrying bacteria for\ncontagious disease such as the plague, and it was developing a\ntreatment program should the disease spread. Bubonic plague\nshould be suspected when a person develops a swollen gland, fever,\nchills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history of\npossible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. An unspecified number of Yangon (previously called Rangoon) residents\nhave been diagnosed with plague, a contagious disease primarily\ntransmitted by rodents (mostly rats), according to the Burmese\nMinistry of Health (MOH) in Naypyidaw. If rodent eradication\nprograms are introduced without a parallel program to spray for\nfleas, the fleas will flee the dead rodent and increase the risk of\nfeeding on humans. An official with the\nLivestock Breeding and Veterinary Department (LBVD) said people who\nfind rat corpses should take them to the nearest LBVD department for\nexamination. \n\nState-run newspapers recently warned that the plague can be\ntransmitted to humans by fleas, but it failed to mention that the\ndisease had already infected people in Yangon. Most cases are due to bubonic plague following\nthe bite of an infected rodent flea causing a swollen and very tender\nlymph gland. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they\nspread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal\ncondition. The MOH and other ministries have developed and implemented a project\nto eradicate rats for the prevention of plague, according to a MOH\nofficial in Naypyidaw.
