He was also\nshivering and suffered from fatigue after he ate the animal on Saturday\nmorning, 13 Jun 2010. He was rushed to the People's Hospital in the Aksai\nKazakh autonomous county and died a few hours later. He was diagnosed with\nbubonic plague.\n\nThe man was one of the workers building a road from Dunhuang to\nDangjinshan. He hunted a marmot for food near the construction site. A\nworker with the project's administrative office confirmed the case to the\nGlobal Times but declined to give details.\n\nThe local health authority launched emergency response measures after the\nincident by sending experts to disinfect the construction site. 'As of\nright now, none of those who had close contact with the man shows any\nabnormal symptoms,' the health authority said in a statement. Health\nofficials have urged herdsmen, tourists, and workers to stay away from\nmarmots and their resting place. They also urged residents to inform\nauthorities if they spot any dead marmots.\n\n[byline: Huang Jingjing]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The usual mode of transmission for bubonic plague is via a flea bite.\nBubonic plague is named for the typical 'bubo', a very tender _Yersinia\npestis_ infected lymph node. A secondary bacteremia may occur which can\nlead to lethal side effects. If pneumonic plague develops, spread from\nhuman-to-human can occur, which can lead to an outbreak of pneumonic plague.\n\nMarmots such as the tarvaga, the tarbagan, or Mongolian marmot, _Marmota\nsibirica_, a large rodent related to the American woodchuck (_M. monax_),\nare thought to be significant zoonotic reservoirs for _Y. pestis_ in\nEastern Asia. The name marmot (<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marmot>) comes\nfrom French marmotte, from Latin _mures monti_ (or _mus montanus_)\n'mountain mouse'. - Mod.LL\n\nA map showing the provinces of China is available at\n<http://travel.nationalgeographic.com/travel/countries/china-map/> and the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of China can be seen at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01x9>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 17 Jun 2010\n \n\nMarmots such as the tarvaga, the tarbagan, or Mongolian marmot, _Marmota\nsibirica_, a large rodent related to the American woodchuck (_M. monax_),\nare thought to be significant zoonotic reservoirs for _Y. pestis_ in\nEastern Asia. \n\n[byline: Huang Jingjing]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< LL\n\nA map showing the provinces of China is available at\n<http://travel.nationalgeographic.com/travel/countries/china-map/> and the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of China can be seen at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01x9>. As of\nright now, none of those who had close contact with the man shows any\nabnormal symptoms,' the health authority said in a statement. Health\nofficials have urged herdsmen, tourists, and workers to stay away from\nmarmots and their resting place. The name marmot (<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marmot>) comes\nfrom French marmotte, from Latin _mures monti_ (or _mus montanus_)\n'mountain mouse'. He was also\nshivering and suffered from fatigue after he ate the animal on Saturday\nmorning, 13 Jun 2010. A\nworker with the project's administrative office confirmed the case to the\nGlobal Times but declined to give details.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-06-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Aksai", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gansu Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dangjinshan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Marmota", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "458779", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Syria: military, susp. RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=458779", "date": "2010-07-04 17:00:04", "main_text": "PLAGUE - SYRIA: MILITARY, SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sat 2 Jul 2010\nSource: JSS News [machine trans., edited]\n<http://jssnews.com/2010/07/02/une-epidemie-de-peste-dans-larmee-syrienne/>\n\n\nAccording to the Syrian opposition in exile, the Syrian president, who\nis visiting Latin America, has ordered the shutdown of all Syrian\nmilitary exercises due to a plague that currently affects a large\nnumber of military, especially conscripts doing their training.\nDrinking water and food in the bases and the current heat wave are the\ncause of the epidemic.\n\nTouched by a terrible drought, this epidemic (which reminds us of the\nMiddle Ages) could cause extensive damage to elements of the Syrian\narmy in the coming weeks. Military sources have completely rejected\nthe possibility of outside intervention that could be causing the\nepidemic.\n\nSyria is currently facing the worst drought in 40 years. Hundreds of\nthousands of people are experiencing food shortages; peasants have\nbeen decimated, and many people are fleeing the country. Already,\nnearly 60 000 small livestock owners have lost all their animals, and\n50 000 others have lost 50-60 percent of their cattle.\n\nIf the early symptoms of plague have occurred in the military (the\nSyrian army has 215 000 men, plus 300 000 reservists), it is probable\nthat the soldiers will spread the disease, especially with the\napproach of Ramadan [11 Aug-9 Sep 2010] when a great number of\nsoldiers return to their villages.\n\nThe last plague epidemic in Europe was in 1910.\n\n[Byline: Ftouh Souhail]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is a bacterial infection of humans and other animals, caused\nby the Gram-negative bacillus _Yersinia pestis_. Three major plague\npandemics have been recorded in human history: the 1st in the 6th\ncentury; the 2nd in the 14th century, which killed up to 1/3rd of the\nEuropean population; and the 3rd at the end of the 19th century\nfollowed the spread of infection from China. Sporadic cases and\nlimited outbreaks of plague continue occur currently in various\ncountries throughout the world. However, during the winter of 1910 to\n1911, an explosive epidemic of primary pneumonic plague raged in\nManchuria and northern China and killed more than 50 000 people\n[Levison ME. Lessons learned from history on mode of transmission for\ncontrol of pneumonic plague. Curr Infect Dis Reports. 2000; 2 (4):\n269-271].\n\nIn the United States, the last urban plague epidemic occurred in Los\nAngeles in 1924-25. Since then, human plague in the United States has\noccurred as mostly scattered cases in rural areas (an average of 10 to\n15 persons each year); more than 90 percent of human plague occurs in\nthe Southwest, especially New Mexico, Arizona, California, and\nColorado. Plague bacillus has also been listed among possible\nbioterrorism agents.\n\nWild rodents in certain areas around the world are infected with the\nplague bacillus. The organism is transmitted among these animals by\nthe bite of infected fleas. Plague may spill over from wild rodents\ninto the peridomestic rodent populations and their fleas, which bring\nplague into human contact. The usual mode of transmission for bubonic\nplague is the bite of an infected rat flea. Direct contacts with\ntissue or bodily fluids of an infected animal or inhaling infectious\nairborne droplets of respiratory secretions are other modes of\ntransmission.\n\nOutbreaks of plague are most likely to occur when rats live closely\nwith humans, usually in poverty-stricken areas with poor sanitation,\nand when humans share habitat with wild rodents infected with plague\nbacteria.\n\nPlague occurs mainly in 3 clinical forms: Bubonic plague, with\nenlarged, tender lymph nodes (buboes), fever, chills and prostration;\nsepticemic plague, with fever, chills, prostration, shock and bleeding\ninto skin and other organs; and pneumonic plague, with fever, chills,\ncough, and difficulty breathing. Septicemic plague may occur with or\nwithout bubonic plague. Pneumonic plague may either be due to a\nsecondary spread through the bloodstream of advanced bubonic plague\n(secondary pneumonic plague), or due to inhalation of aerosolized\ninfectious droplets (primary pneumonic plague). Pharyngeal plague and\nplague meningitis are less common forms. Rapid diagnosis and treatment\nis essential to reduce complications and fatality.\n\nAs noted by ProMED moderator JW, plague has occurred in this region\nhistorically\n(<http://entomology.montana.edu/historybug/napoleon/plague_syria.htm>).\nHowever, the news release above fails to detail microbiologic\nconfirmation, clinical manifestations and epidemiology of this current\noutbreak among the Syrian military. Curiously, the news release above\nsays that drinking water, food, and a heat wave are causes of the\nepidemic, but if this outbreak were plague due to _Y. pestis_, these\nwould be unlikely 'causes,' unless in some way they increased contact\nbetween humans, infected rodents and rat fleas.\n\nPictures related to plague can be found at\n<http://www.wrongdiagnosis.com/phil/html/plague/2045.html>.\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Syria can be seen at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?name=Syria,%20Syria&g=163843&v=35,38,6>\n- Mod.ML]", "summary": "Plague occurs mainly in 3 clinical forms: Bubonic plague, with\nenlarged, tender lymph nodes (buboes), fever, chills and prostration;\nsepticemic plague, with fever, chills, prostration, shock and bleeding\ninto skin and other organs; and pneumonic plague, with fever, chills,\ncough, and difficulty breathing. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sat 2 Jul 2010\n Since then, human plague in the United States has\noccurred as mostly scattered cases in rural areas (an average of 10 to\n15 persons each year); more than 90 percent of human plague occurs in\nthe Southwest, especially New Mexico, Arizona, California, and\nColorado. Curiously, the news release above\nsays that drinking water, food, and a heat wave are causes of the\nepidemic, but if this outbreak were plague due to _Y. pestis_, these\nwould be unlikely 'causes,' unless in some way they increased contact\nbetween humans, infected rodents and rat fleas. Three major plague\npandemics have been recorded in human history: the 1st in the 6th\ncentury; the 2nd in the 14th century, which killed up to 1/3rd of the\nEuropean population; and the 3rd at the end of the 19th century\nfollowed the spread of infection from China. \n\nOutbreaks of plague are most likely to occur when rats live closely\nwith humans, usually in poverty-stricken areas with poor sanitation,\nand when humans share habitat with wild rodents infected with plague\nbacteria. \n\nIf the early symptoms of plague have occurred in the military (the\nSyrian army has 215 000 men, plus 300 000 reservists), it is probable\nthat the soldiers will spread the disease, especially with the\napproach of Ramadan However, during the winter of 1910 to\n1911, an explosive epidemic of primary pneumonic plague raged in\nManchuria and northern China and killed more than 50 000 people\n According to the Syrian opposition in exile, the Syrian president, who\nis visiting Latin America, has ordered the shutdown of all Syrian\nmilitary exercises due to a plague that currently affects a large\nnumber of military, especially conscripts doing their training. Direct contacts with\ntissue or bodily fluids of an infected animal or inhaling infectious\nairborne droplets of respiratory secretions are other modes of\ntransmission. Plague may spill over from wild rodents\ninto the peridomestic rodent populations and their fleas, which bring\nplague into human contact. Pneumonic plague may either be due to a\nsecondary spread through the bloodstream of advanced bubonic plague\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is a bacterial infection of humans and other animals, caused\nby the Gram-negative bacillus _ Sporadic cases and\nlimited outbreaks of plague continue occur currently in various\ncountries throughout the world. As noted by ProMED moderator JW, plague has occurred in this region\nhistorically\n(<http://entomology.montana.edu/historybug/napoleon/plague_syria.htm>). Already,\nnearly 60 000 small livestock owners have lost all their animals, and\n50 000 others have lost 50-60 percent of their cattle.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2000-03-25 00:00:00", "1911-03-25 00:00:00", "1910-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Los", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MILITARY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Syria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Manchuria", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "417411", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, bubonic - Peru: (LL) RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=417411", "date": "2010-04-28 15:00:03", "main_text": "PLAGUE, BUBONIC - PERU: (LA LIBERTAD) REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 26 Apr 2010\nSource: Correo Peru [in Spanish, trans. Corr.SB, edited]\n<http://www.correoperu.com.pe/correo/nota.php?txtEdi_id=21&txtSecci_id=64&txtSecci_parent=0&txtNota_id=338096>\n\n\nThe outbreak of bubonic plague in the Chicama district of La\nLibertad, Peru has been increasing rapidly, specifically in the\nLibertad settlement, where 3 new cases of infection have been confirmed.\n\nThis was revealed by the chief epidemiologist of the Belen Hospital,\nPedro Diaz Camacho, who came to that area to assess the critical\ncondition of those affected, aged 8, 9, and 14.\n\n'The presence of rats has increased in the settlement, and we ask the\nintervention of local and regional authorities,' emphasizes the epidemiologist.\n\nDiaz Camacho also said that the 9-year-old patient is in serious\ncondition and the prognosis is guarded.\n\n[Byline: Lucia Ortecho]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most cases of _Yersinia pestis_ infection in the Western Hemisphere\nare reported from the southwestern part of the USA. Cases from South\nAmerica do occur and have been previously reported in ProMED-mail\nfrom Brazil and Ecuador. ProMED would appreciate more clinical\ninformation about the cases as well as the total number of identified\ncases. - Mod.LL]\n\nMaps of Peru are available at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/americas/peru_pol91.jpg> and the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01eP>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 26 Apr 2010\n LL]\n\nMaps of Peru are available at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/americas/peru_pol91.jpg> and the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01eP>. \n\nThis was revealed by the chief epidemiologist of the Belen Hospital,\nPedro Diaz Camacho, who came to that area to assess the critical\ncondition of those affected, aged 8, 9, and 14. The outbreak of bubonic plague in the Chicama district of La\nLibertad, Peru has been increasing rapidly, specifically in the\nLibertad settlement, where 3 new cases of infection have been confirmed. ProMED would appreciate more clinical\ninformation about the cases as well as the total number of identified\ncases. The 6-year-old cat found by biologists\nhad been tagged with a global positioning system collar.\n\nThe plague is naturally occurring in the area.\n\nPlague is an infectious disease caused by the bacterium _Yersinia\npestis_. It is found in animals throughout the world, most commonly\nin rats but also in other rodents like ground squirrels, prairie\ndogs, chipmunks, rabbits and voles. Fleas typically serve as the\nvector of plague.\n\nPeople can also get infected through direct contact with an infected\nanimal, through inhalation, and, in the case of pneumonic plague,\nperson to person.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Felines, domestic and wild, pick up this infection in Wyoming from\nsick ground squirrels and prairie dogs, which burns through these\nunderground communities. PLAGUE, COUGAR - USA (WYOMING)\n Source: Examiner.com [edited]\n<http://www.examiner.com/x-7707-Infectious-Disease-Examiner~y2010m1d13-Another-cougar-dies-of-plague-in-Yellowstone-area>\n\n\n To find Jackson, WY, go to:\n<http://www.fallingrain.com/world/US/WY/Jackson.html>. **\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-01-13 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Jackson", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WY", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "295336", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, fatal - USA (04): (IL) lab strain susp. RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=295336", "date": "2009-09-20 18:00:03", "main_text": "PLAGUE, FATAL - USA (04): (ILLINOIS) LABORATORY STRAIN SUSPECTED,\nREQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n***************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sun 20 Sep 2009\nSource: Chicago Sun-Times [summ. & edited]\n<http://www.suntimes.com/news/metro/1780803,CST-NWS-plague20.article>\n\n\nA University of Chicago [U of C] researcher studying the genetics of\nthe plague bacteria died last week from an infection he may have\ngotten in the laboratory, officials said Saturday [19 Sep 2009]. The\nresearcher, a 60-year-old molecular genetics professor died 13 Sep\n2009 at the University of Chicago Medical Center's Bernard Mitchell\nHospital.\n\nAn initial autopsy showed that the researcher 'showed no obvious cause\nof death' except for the presence of the weakened strain of the plague\nbacteria _Yersinia pestis_ in his blood, the U of C Medical Center\nsaid in a statement. It is not known to cause illness and has been\nused in some countries as a vaccine to protect against the plague. It\nhas been approved by CDC for lab studies.\n\nUniversity officials said there does not appear to be a public health\nthreat related to the death. There have been no illnesses reported by\nthose who came into contact with him. As a precaution, U of C notified\nthe researcher's close contacts once the bacteria had been identified\nin his blood. The medical center's infection control team is also\nworking with the city and state health departments and the CDC to\ninvestigate the death.\n\nThe researcher had been studying the genetics of harmful bacteria,\nincluding a strain of _Yersinia pestis_ that lacked most of the\nbacteria's harmful components, the university said. Because this form\nof the bacteria is not known to cause problems in healthy people,\nspecial safety procedures are not required to handle it, said Dr\nKenneth Alexander, a virologist and chief of pediatric infections at\nthe U of C Medical Center.\n\nLab researchers who work with the bacteria would typically wear\ngloves, a lab coat and protective goggles, and the bacteria would be\ndisposed of in a biohazard bag and heated for about 2 hours, Alexander\nsaid. 2 key questions in the death will be whether there was anything\ndifferent about the strain he was handling and whether the man had any\nunderlying conditions that may have made him more susceptible to\ninfection, Alexander said.\n\n'There's no indication thus far that this is anything different from\nthe laboratory strain that we know it to be,' he said. 'I can't find\nany reports of anything like this happening before.'\n\n[Byline: Monifa Thomas]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDan Lucey\n\n[ProMED-mail and its readers would appreciate information regarding\nthe clinical aspects of this case, especially whether the patient's\nsigns and symptoms were compatible with a sepsis syndrome, also which\nattenuated _Y. pestis_ strain was isolated.\n\nThe USP, formalin-inactivated plague vaccine was in use in the USA\nuntil 1999 (1). A number of live, attenuated plague strains have been\nstudied as potential vaccines. One strain, designated EV76, was\nproduced in Madagascar by passage in guinea pigs treated with nontoxic\ndoses of iron salts. Severe side effects have been observed (2,3), as\nhave variable virulence levels in different host species. A more\nrecently derived strain, CO92deltayopH, has a protein tyrosine\nphosphatase type III secretion system effector protein deletion, and\nappears to be a potent immunogen (4).\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Williamson ED: Plague vaccine research and development. J Appl\nMicrobiol. 2001; 91(4): 606-8; available at\n<http://www3.interscience.wiley.com/cgi-bin/fulltext/120718161/PDFSTART>.\n2. Meyer KF: Effectiveness of live or killed plague vaccines in man.\nBull WHO. 1970; 42(5): 653-66; available at\n<http://www.pubmedcentral.nih.gov/articlerender.fcgi?artid=2427500>.\n3. Russell P, Eley SM, Hibbs SE, et al: A comparison of plague\nvaccine, USP and EV76 vaccine induced protection against _Yersinia\npestis_ in a murine model. Vaccine. 1995; 13(16): 1551-6; abstract\navailable at\n<http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/8578841>.\n4. Bubeck SS, Dube PH: _Yersinia pestis_ CO92deltayopH is a potent\nlive, attenuated plague vaccine. Clin Vaccine Immunol 2007; 14(9):\n1235-8. Epub 2007 Jul 25; available at\n<http://cvi.asm.org/cgi/reprint/14/9/1235>. - Mod.LL]\n\n[The University of Chicago can be located via the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00Qb>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n[ProMED thanks Powell Gammill who sent a similar report.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sun 20 Sep 2009\n Communicated by:\nDan Lucey\n\n[ProMED-mail and its readers would appreciate information regarding\nthe clinical aspects of this case, especially whether the patient's\nsigns and symptoms were compatible with a sepsis syndrome, also which\nattenuated _Y. pestis_ strain was isolated. A more\nrecently derived strain, CO92deltayopH, has a protein tyrosine\nphosphatase type III secretion system effector protein deletion, and\nappears to be a potent immunogen (4). The 1st case was a 32 year old male herdsman, who developed fever\nand hemoptysis on 26 Jul 2009. He was referred to a hospital but died en\nroute, and was buried the following day. On 30 Jul 2009, 11 people who had\nclose contact with the case (mainly relatives who attended the funeral)\ndeveloped fever and cough, and were all hospitalized. On 1 Aug 2009,\nspecimens taken from all these 12 people, including the 1st case, tested\npositive for plague.\n\nOn 2 Aug 2009 both the 64 year old father-in-law of the index case and a 37\nyear old male neighbor of the 1st case (who helped to bury the corpse) also\ndied. Of the remaining 9 cases, one is in critical condition, one had acute\nsymptoms of fever and cough, and 7 are in stable condition.\n\nAs of 6 Aug 2009, the local health authority has isolated 332 close\ncontacts for further medical observation, and implemented traffic control\naround the affected area. Experts on both disease prevention and control\nand clinical management have been dispatched to Qinghai province.\nProtective clothes, X-ray machines and other medical equipment have been\nsent to the affected area. Prevention guidance pamphlets have also been\ndisseminated.\n\nAccording to the epidemiological investigation, the source of this outbreak\nwas a wild marmot, which had contact with the dog of the index case.\nZiketan is in an area of natural plague bacteria circulation amongst\nanimals and at the present time it is the active season for plague\ntransmission amongst animals. No drug resistance of the bacterium has been\nfound so far and the 3 death cases have been attributed largely to delayed\ntreatment.\n\nChina has established a national surveillance network for plague, and has\nprepared necessary supplies in high-risk areas. After this outbreak,\nspecial funds, supplies and experts were quickly dispatched to the affected\narea.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is the formal WHO outbreak report regarding the recent cluster of\npneumonic plague in north western China. No further information regarding\nthe patient who was in critical condition in ProMED's 6 Aug 2009 posting is\navailable. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 11 Aug 2009\n \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n< On 2 Aug 2009 both the 64 year old father-in-law of the index case and a 37\nyear old male neighbor of the 1st case (who helped to bury the corpse) also\ndied. RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=296145", "date": "2009-09-21 16:00:02", "main_text": "PLAGUE, FATAL - USA (05): (ILLINOIS) LABORATORY STRAIN SUSPECTED,\nREQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n***************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 21 Sep 2009\nSource: Nature.com blog [edited]\n<http://blogs.nature.com/news/thegreatbeyond/2009/09/plague_vaccine_found_in_dead_r.html>\n\n\nInvestigators have found a strain of the plague bacteria _Yersinia\npestis_ in the body of a University of Chicago geneticist who died last\nweek [13 Sep 2009] within 12 hours of his arrival at Bernard Mitchell\nHospital with 'intense flu-like symptoms.' The autopsy did not identify\na cause of death, according to the Chicago Tribune.\n\nNo other cases have been reported in Chicago, and none of the other\nresearchers exposed to the strain, used as a vaccine since the 1960s,\nhas fallen ill, but officials gave antibiotics to his family, friends,\nand co-workers. Ken Alexander, head of pediatric infectious disease\nsaid that the autopsy did not imply that the strain of the plague was a\npublic health threat. He told the Chicago Tribune that 'the more likely\npossibility, I'd say 999 to 1, is that there was something unusual\nabout him.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\nIn this posting, it is stated that severe influenza-like symptoms\n(presumably myalgias, fever, and rigors) occurred with death occurring\nwithin 12 hours of admission. These symptoms can be found in many acute\nillnesses but certainly suggest strongly that the bacterial isolate\n(presumably grown from a blood culture) was a pathogen here.\n\nThe statement that the strain has been 'used as a vaccine' suggests\nthat the strain may be the EV76 mutant. This prototypic live,\nattenuated vaccine strain has lost its pigment phenotype, absorbs\npigments from agar, produces a sideraphore called yersiniabactin and\ncauses a lethal disease after subcutaneous inoculation of laboratory\nanimals (1). The strain was originally reported by Girard and Robic in\n1936 (2).\n\nProMED-mail and its readers await more definitive information regarding\nthe clinical illness and characteristics of the isolated strain.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Podladchikova ON, Rykova VA, Ivanova VS, et al: [Study of PGM\nmutation mechanism in _Yersinia pestis_ (plague pathogen) vaccine\nstrain EV76] Mol Gen Mikrobiol Virusol 2002; 2: 14-9 (in Russian);\nabstract available at\n<http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12180018>.\n2. Girard G, Robic J: La vaccination de l'homme contre la peste au\nmoyen de bacilles vivants (virus vaccin E.V.). Son application a\nMadagascar. Bull Mensu Office Internat Hyg Pub. 1936; 28: 1078-87. -\nMod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 21 Sep 2009\n Source: Nature.com blog [edited]\n<http://blogs.nature.com/news/thegreatbeyond/2009/09/plague_vaccine_found_in_dead_r.html>\n\n\nInvestigators have found a strain of the plague bacteria _Yersinia\npestis_ in the body of a University of Chicago geneticist who died last\nweek [13 Sep 2009] within 12 hours of his arrival at Bernard Mitchell\nHospital with 'intense flu-like symptoms.' This prototypic live,\nattenuated vaccine strain has lost its pigment phenotype, absorbs\npigments from agar, produces a sideraphore called yersiniabactin and\ncauses a lethal disease after subcutaneous inoculation of laboratory\nanimals (1). \n\nNo other cases have been reported in Chicago, and none of the other\nresearchers exposed to the strain, used as a vaccine since the 1960s,\nhas fallen ill, but officials gave antibiotics to his family, friends,\nand co-workers. He told the Chicago Tribune that 'the more likely\npossibility, I'd say 999 to 1, is that there was something unusual\nabout him.'\n\n--\n PLAGUE, FATAL - USA (05): (ILLINOIS) LABORATORY STRAIN SUSPECTED,\nREQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n***************************************************************************\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\nIn this posting, it is stated that severe influenza-like symptoms\n(presumably myalgias, fever, and rigors) occurred with death occurring\nwithin 12 hours of admission.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1936-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2009-09-25 00:00:00", "2002-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Rykova VA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chicago", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ILLINOIS", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ON", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "300312", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Congo DR: (OR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=300312", "date": "2009-09-27 19:00:03", "main_text": "PLAGUE - CONGO DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC: (ORIENTALE)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 23 Sep 2009\nSource: The Monitor [edited]\n<http://www.monitor.co.ug/artman/publish/regional-special/West_Nile_under_fresh_threat_of_Bubonic_Plague_91728.shtml>\n\n\nThe Ministry of Health [of Uganda] has launched a plague control\nprogram in Nebbi and Arua districts as a result of a renewed threat\nof the bubonic plague in the Democratic Republic of Congo. The\nbubonic plague has been reported in Congo's Orientale province, which\nborders the West Nile region. The plague control program is targeting\nVurra and Logiri in Arua district and Kango, Zeu and Jangokoro sub\ncounties in Nebbi district.\n\nUnder the new plague control program ministry of health together with\nthe 2 district health directorates will engage in massive\nsensitization campaigns and spraying of homesteads in 5 subcounties\nto prevent a possible outbreak of the disease.\n\nIn the West Nile area, the disease outbreaks have been commonly\nreported in Logiri and Kango subcounties. In 2008, an outbreak of the\nplague in the 2 subcounties left 17 people dead and 90 others\ninfected.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED Rapporteur Susan Baekeland\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Infections due to _Yersinia pestis_ are endemic in these areas of\nthe Congo DR. - Mod.LL]\n\n[The Democratic Republic of the Congo can be located using the\nHealthMap/ProMEDmail interactive map at:\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00S2>.\n- CopyEd.EJP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 23 Sep 2009\n Under the new plague control program ministry of health together with\nthe 2 district health directorates will engage in massive\nsensitization campaigns and spraying of homesteads in 5 subcounties\nto prevent a possible outbreak of the disease. The Ministry of Health [of Uganda] has launched a plague control\nprogram in Nebbi and Arua districts as a result of a renewed threat\nof the bubonic plague in the Democratic Republic of Congo. The plague control program is targeting\nVurra and Logiri in Arua district and Kango, Zeu and Jangokoro sub\ncounties in Nebbi district. In 2008, an outbreak of the\nplague in the 2 subcounties left 17 people dead and 90 others\ninfected.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2008-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Logiri", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nebbi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nebbi district", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kango", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of the", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of Congo", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "411655", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, canine - USA: (NM)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=411655", "date": "2010-04-18 12:00:04", "main_text": "PLAGUE, CANINE - USA: (NEW MEXICO)\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sat 17 Apr 2010\nSource: NewsChannel 10 KFDA [edited]\n<http://www.newschannel10.com/Global/story.asp?S=12326932>\n\n\nA case of animal plague has been confirmed in eastern New Mexico and\nofficials say human cases could soon follow.\n\nThe New Mexico Department of Health says lab reports confirmed a case\nof plague in a dog near San Jon in Quay County this week [week of 12\nApr 2010]. They say the virus is transmitted to humans through the\nfleas on rodents, rabbits, and pets.\n\nThis is the 3rd case this year [2010] involving animals in New\nMexico. In all cases, the animals have recovered.\n\nFor more information on the plague go to\n<http://www.health.state.nm.us/erd/HealthData/plague.shtml>\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The causative bacterium, _Yersinia pestis_, is transmitted to people\nthrough fleabite and direct contact with infected animals. Each\nrodent species is host to one or more species of flea, which, when\ninfected, is a carrier. These fleas generally do not infest other\nanimals unless their natural hosts are unavailable.\n\nDomestic cats and dogs can also contract plague from infected fleas.\nThey may carry infected fleas home to their owners or, especially in\nthe case of cats, serve as a direct source of infection.\n\nAlthough prairie dogs are more sensitive indicators of plague than\ncats, these are quite sensitive. Often, plague lesions in cats,\nparticularly domestic cats, may initially be confused with a cat\nfight (or cat bite) abscess, as there are often swellings in the\nmandibular region. Plague swellings are buboes, abscesses from\ninfection. Consequently, veterinarians, technicians, animal shelter\nworkers and animal caretakers may become victims when buboes rupture.\n\nPlague, caused by _Y. pestis_, is an acute and sometimes fatal\nbacterial zoonosis that is transmitted primarily by the fleas of rats\nand other rodents. Enzootic foci of sylvatic plague exist in the\nwestern USA and throughout the world, including Eurasia, Africa, and\nNorth and South America. In addition to rodents, other mammalian\nspecies that have been naturally infected with _Y. pestis_ include\nlagomorphs, felids, canids, mustelids, and some ungulates. Domestic\ncats and dogs have also developed plague from oral mucous membrane\nexposure to infected rodent tissues, typically when they are allowed\nto roam and hunt in enzootic areas. Birds and other non-mammalian\nvertebrates appear to be resistant to plague. On average, 10 human\nplague cases are reported each year in the USA; the majority are from\nNew Mexico, California, Colorado, and Arizona. Most human cases\nresult from the bite of an infected flea, although direct contact\nwith infected wild rabbits, rodents, and occasionally other wildlife\nand exposure to infected domestic cats are also risk factors.\n\n_Y. pestis_ is a gram-negative, nonmotile, coccobacillus belonging to\nthe Enterobacteriaceae family. It exhibits a bipolar staining,\n'safety pin' appearance when stained with Wright, Giemsa, or Wayson\nstains. _Y. pestis_ grows slowly even at optimal temperatures (28 deg\nC [82.4 deg F]) and can require greater than 48 hours to produce\ncolonies. Several types of media can be used to grow _Y. pestis_,\nincluding blood agar, nutrient broth, and un-enriched agar. Colonies\nare small (1-2 mm), gray, non-mucoid, and have a characteristic\n'hammered copper' appearance. Different virulence factors are\nexpressed by the organism at different temperatures and environments,\nallowing the organism to survive in flea vectors and then be\ntransmitted to and multiply in mammalian hosts. The organism does not\nsurvive for long at high temperatures or in dry environments.\n\n_Y. pestis_ is easily destroyed by sunlight and drying. Even so, when\nreleased into the air, the bacteria will survive for up to one hour,\nalthough this could vary depending on conditions.\n\nPneumonic plague is one of several forms of plague. Depending on\ncircumstances, these forms may occur separately or in combination.\nPneumonic plague occurs when _Y. pestis_ infects the lungs. This type\nof plague can spread from person to person through the air.\nTransmission can take place if someone breathes in aerosolized\nbacteria, which could happen in a bioterrorist attack. Pneumonic\nplague is also spread by breathing in _Y. pestis_ suspended in\nrespiratory droplets from a person (or animal) with pneumonic plague.\nBecoming infected in this way usually requires direct and close\ncontact with the ill person or animal. Pneumonic plague may also\noccur if a person with bubonic or septicemic plague is untreated and\nthe bacteria spread to the lungs.\n\nBubonic plague is the most common form of plague. This occurs when an\ninfected flea bites a person or when materials contaminated with _Y.\npestis_ enter through a break in a person's skin. Patients develop\nswollen, tender lymph glands (called buboes) and fever, headache,\nchills, and weakness. Bubonic plague does not spread from person to\nperson.\n\nSepticemic plague occurs when plague bacteria multiply in the blood.\nIt can be a complication of pneumonic or bubonic plague or it can\noccur by itself. When it occurs alone, it is caused in the same ways\nas bubonic plague; however, buboes do not develop. Patients have\nfever, chills, prostration, abdominal pain, shock, and bleeding into\nskin and other organs. Septicemic plague does not spread from person\nto person.\n\nWith pneumonic plague, the 1st signs of illness are fever, headache,\nweakness, and rapidly developing pneumonia with shortness of breath,\nchest pain, cough, and sometimes bloody or watery sputum. The\npneumonia progresses for 2 to 4 days and may cause respiratory\nfailure and shock. Without early treatment, patients may die.\n\nEarly treatment of pneumonic plague is essential. To reduce the\nchance of death, antibiotics must be given within 24 hours of 1st\nsymptoms. Streptomycin, gentamicin, the tetracyclines, and\nchloramphenicol are all effective against pneumonic plague.\n\nAntibiotic treatment for 7 days will protect people who have had\ndirect, close contact with infected patients. Wearing a close-fitting\nsurgical mask also protects against infection. A plague vaccine is\nnot currently available for use in the United States.\n\nPortions of this comment were extracted from:\n<http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/51900.htm&word=plague>\n\nand\n<http://www.bt.cdc.gov/agent/plague/factsheet.asp>. - Mod.TG]\n\n[The state of New Mexico in the southwestern US can be located on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01d4>.\nQuay County can be located on the map at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quay_County,_New_Mexico>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sat 17 Apr 2010\n For more information on the plague go to\n<http://www.health.state.nm.us/erd/HealthData/plague.shtml>\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Most human cases\nresult from the bite of an infected flea, although direct contact\nwith infected wild rabbits, rodents, and occasionally other wildlife\nand exposure to infected domestic cats are also risk factors. Domestic\ncats and dogs have also developed plague from oral mucous membrane\nexposure to infected rodent tissues, typically when they are allowed\nto roam and hunt in enzootic areas. Often, plague lesions in cats,\nparticularly domestic cats, may initially be confused with a cat\nfight (or cat bite) abscess, as there are often swellings in the\nmandibular region. Different virulence factors are\nexpressed by the organism at different temperatures and environments,\nallowing the organism to survive in flea vectors and then be\ntransmitted to and multiply in mammalian hosts. Pneumonic\nplague is also spread by breathing in _Y. pestis_ suspended in\nrespiratory droplets from a person (or animal) with pneumonic plague. Pneumonic plague may also\noccur if a person with bubonic or septicemic plague is untreated and\nthe bacteria spread to the lungs. Plague, caused by _Y. pestis_, is an acute and sometimes fatal\nbacterial zoonosis that is transmitted primarily by the fleas of rats\nand other rodents. This occurs when an\ninfected flea bites a person or when materials contaminated with _Y.\npestis_ enter through a break in a person's skin. With pneumonic plague, the 1st signs of illness are fever, headache,\nweakness, and rapidly developing pneumonia with shortness of breath,\nchest pain, cough, and sometimes bloody or watery sputum. On average, 10 human\nplague cases are reported each year in the USA; the majority are from\nNew Mexico, California, Colorado, and Arizona. \n\nPortions of this comment were extracted from:\n<http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/51900.htm&word=plague>\n\nand\n<http://www.bt.cdc.gov/agent/plague/factsheet.asp>. In addition to rodents, other mammalian\nspecies that have been naturally infected with _Y. pestis_ include\nlagomorphs, felids, canids, mustelids, and some ungulates. Enzootic foci of sylvatic plague exist in the\nwestern USA and throughout the world, including Eurasia, Africa, and\nNorth and South America. TG]\n\n[The state of New Mexico in the southwestern US can be located on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01d4>. PLAGUE, CANINE - USA: (NEW MEXICO)\n**********************************\n _Y. pestis_ grows slowly even at optimal temperatures (28 deg\nC [82.4 deg F]) and can require greater than 48 hours to produce\ncolonies. Each\nrodent species is host to one or more species of flea, which, when\ninfected, is a carrier. Patients develop\nswollen, tender lymph glands (called buboes) and fever, headache,\nchills, and weakness. Patients have\nfever, chills, prostration, abdominal pain, shock, and bleeding into\nskin and other organs. Colonies\nare small (1-2 mm), gray, non-mucoid, and have a characteristic\n'hammered copper' appearance. Even so, when\nreleased into the air, the bacteria will survive for up to one hour,\nalthough this could vary depending on conditions. The\npneumonia progresses for 2 to 4 days and may cause respiratory\nfailure and shock.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "San Jon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North and South America", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Quay County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eurasia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "346916", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, feline - USA (CA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=346916", "date": "2009-12-05 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, FELINE - USA (CALIFORNIA)\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.isid.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 4 Dec 2009\nSource: Turn to 23.com [edited]\n<http://www.turnto23.com/news/21868157/detail.html>\n\n\nPlague Found In Cat From Hart Flat\n----------------------------------\nThe Kern County Department of Public Health has confirmed a test\nresult positive for _Yersenia pestis_, the bacterium that causes\nplague, conducted on a domestic cat from Hart Flat, California. A test\non another cat in the same household is pending. The Vector Control\nSection of the California Department of Health Services and the Kern\nCounty Environmental Health, which is now part of Public Health, are\ncollaborating to investigate these cases.\n\nThere is no evidence of human infection at this time, Kim Rodriguez\nwith the KCDPH said. Appropriate preventive steps including\nantibiotics have been recommended to protect those who may have been\nexposed to these cats. One of the symptomatic cats is responding well\nto antibiotics, but one of the cats has died, Rodriguez said.\n\n'(The) plague is still very much present in our county, although we\nmay want to believe that it is an obsolete disease of the past,' says\nMatt Constantine, Director of Public Health. 'The most effective\nweapons in fighting this disease are public awareness, education, and\npreventative measures to reduce the risk for exposure.'\n\nPlague, infection with the bacterium _Y. pestis_, is endemic\nthroughout the southwest United States, including much of Kern County.\nEach year numerous mammals, including domestic cats, are identified\nwith evidence of infection with _Y. pestis_, Rodriguez said. Cats are\nbelieved to be the domestic species most susceptible to plague.\n\nAs in humans, 3 clinical syndromes have been described: bubonic,\nsepticemic, and pneumonic. Bubonic is the most common manifestation\nand is characterized by high fever (105-106 degrees F), lethargy, and\nswollen lymph glands, most commonly of the glands of the neck and\nunder the jaw in cats but in the inguinal area in humans. Infected\nlymph nodes may spontaneously abscess and drain, Rodriguez said.\n\nCats can pose a risk of plague transmission to humans. Because of the\npotential for transmission to humans, cats suspected of having plague\nshould be hospitalized and placed in isolation. Persons having\nsignificant contact with a plague-infected cat, particularly cats with\nrespiratory signs or draining abscesses, should consult with their\nhealth care provider regarding the need for a prophylactic course of\nantibiotics. Local and state public health officials should be\nnotified immediately of cases of plague diagnosed in domestic cats,\nRodriguez said.\n\nPlague is known to be related to fluctuations in rodent population at\nelevations greater than 2500 feet. Residents and visitors in these\nregions are advised to take the following precautions:\n\n-- Do not feed or handle wild animals, particularly ground squirrels\nand chipmunks\n-- Eliminate trash near living areas, which attract and can harbor rodents.\n-- Report any animals acting strangely (i.e., sluggishly) to Kern\nCounty Environmental Health.\n-- Do not touch sick or dead animals. Report their location to Kern\nCounty Environmental Health.\n-- If odors or flies are noticed around rodent burrows, report this to\nKern County Environmental Health.\n-- Do not camp or sit near rodent burrows, where infected animals may\nlive. When possible, sleep off the ground, such as on cots.\n-- Domestic animals visiting plague-suspected areas should be observed\nfor 7 days. If they become ill, they should be examined by a\nveterinarian.\n-- Use insect repellent in plague-endemic areas.\n-- Wear protective clothing including long-sleeved shirts and long\npants with cuffs tucked into the socks.\n-- Use flea-repellent products on your pets regularly; ie: collars,\nbath, ointments, and powders, especially after returning from a\nwilderness area.\n-- If pets appear sick after returning from a wilderness area, handle\nthem carefully and take them to a veterinarian immediately.\n-- See a physician if within 7 days of a visit to an endemic area you\nbecome ill with fever, chills, muscle aches, nausea, sore throat,\nheadaches, physical exhaustion and/or painful swollen lymph nodes as\nthe initial symptoms may be nonspecific.\n\nIt is prudent for all residents and visitors in known endemic areas of\nthe county adhere to measures that would minimize their exposure to\npotentially infected animals. For more information, contact Public\nHealth, Environmental Health Services at 661-862-8700.\n\nInformation provided by the Department of Public Health\n\n--\nMerritt Clifton\nEditor, Animal People\nP.O. Box 960\nClinton, WA 98236\n<anmlpepl@whidbey.com>\n\nThe causative bacterium, _Yersinia pestis_, is transmitted to people\nthrough fleabite and direct contact with infected animals. Each rodent\nspecies is host to one or more species of flea, which, when infected,\nis a carrier. These fleas generally do not infest other animals unless\ntheir natural hosts are unavailable.\n\nDomestic cats and dogs can also contract plague from infected fleas.\nThey may carry infected fleas home to their owners or, especially in\nthe case of cats, serve as a direct source of infection.\n\nCats are sensitive indicators of plague. Prairie dogs [which are\nactually ground squirrels] are more sensitive than cats, but\nnevertheless, cats are quite sensitive. However, this is somewhat late\nin the year to see plague cases. They are more often seen in the\nspring and summer to early autumn.\n\nOften, plague lesions in cats, particularly domestic cats, may\ninitially be confused with a cat fight (or cat bite) abscess, as there\nare often swellings in the mandibular region. Plague swellings are\nbuboes, abscesses from infection. Consequently, veterinarians,\ntechnicians, animal shelter workers and animal caretakers may become\nvictims when buboes rupture.\n\nPlague, caused by _Yersinia pestis_, is an acute and sometimes fatal\nbacterial zoonosis that is transmitted primarily by the fleas of rats\nand other rodents. Enzootic foci of sylvatic plague exist in the\nwestern USA and throughout the world, including Eurasia, Africa, and\nNorth and South America. In addition to rodents, other mammalian\nspecies that have been naturally infected with _Y. pestis_ include\nlagomorphs, felids, canids, mustelids, and some ungulates. Domestic\ncats and dogs have also developed plague from oral mucous membrane\nexposure to infected rodent tissues, typically when they are allowed\nto roam and hunt in enzootic areas. Birds and other non-mammalian\nvertebrates appear to be resistant to plague. On average, 10 human\nplague cases are reported each year in the USA; the majority are from\nNew Mexico, California, Colorado, and Arizona. Most human cases result\nfrom the bite of an infected flea, although direct contact with\ninfected wild rabbits, rodents, and occasion!\nally other wildlife and exposure to infected domestic cats are also\nrisk factors.\n\n_Y. pestis_ is a gram-negative, nonmotile, coccobacillus belonging to\nthe _Enterobacteriacae_ family. It exhibits a bipolar staining,\n'safety pin' appearance when stained with Wright, Giemsa, or Wayson\nstains. _Y. pestis_ grows slowly even at optimal temperatures (28 deg\nC [82.4 deg F]) and can require greater than 48 hours to produce\ncolonies. Several types of media can be used to grow _Y. pestis_,\nincluding blood agar, nutrient broth, and un-enriched agar. Colonies\nare small (1-2 mm), gray, nonmucoid, and have a characteristic\n'hammered copper' appearance. Different virulence factors are\nexpressed by the organism at different temperatures and environments,\nallowing the organism to survive in flea vectors and then be\ntransmitted to and multiply in mammalian hosts. The organism does not\nsurvive for long at high temperatures or in dry environments.\n\n_Y. pestis_ is easily destroyed by sunlight and drying. Even so, when\nreleased into the air, the bacteria will survive for up to one hour,\nalthough this could vary depending on conditions.\n\nPneumonic plague is one of several forms of plague. Depending on\ncircumstances, these forms may occur separately or in combination.\n\nPneumonic plague occurs when _Y. pestis_ infects the lungs. This type\nof plague can spread from person to person through the air.\nTransmission can take place if someone breathes in aerosolized\nbacteria, which could happen in a bioterrorist attack. Pneumonic\nplague is also spread by breathing in _Y. pestis_ suspended in\nrespiratory droplets from a person (or animal) with pneumonic plague.\nBecoming infected in this way usually requires direct and close\ncontact with the ill person or animal. Pneumonic plague may also occur\nif a person with bubonic or septicemic plague is untreated and the\nbacteria spread to the lungs.\n\nBubonic plague is the most common form of plague. This occurs when an\ninfected flea bites a person or when materials contaminated with _Y.\npestis_ enter through a break in a person's skin. Patients develop\nswollen, tender lymph glands (called buboes) and fever, headache,\nchills, and weakness. Bubonic plague does not spread from person to\nperson.\n\nSepticemic plague occurs when plague bacteria multiply in the blood.\nIt can be a complication of pneumonic or bubonic plague or it can\noccur by itself. When it occurs alone, it is caused in the same ways\nas bubonic plague; however, buboes do not develop. Patients have\nfever, chills, prostration, abdominal pain, shock, and bleeding into\nskin and other organs. Septicemic plague does not spread from person\nto person.\n\nWith pneumonic plague, the 1st signs of illness are fever, headache,\nweakness, and rapidly developing pneumonia with shortness of breath,\nchest pain, cough, and sometimes bloody or watery sputum. The\npneumonia progresses for 2 to 4 days and may cause respiratory failure\nand shock. Without early treatment, patients may die.\n\nEarly treatment of pneumonic plague is essential. To reduce the chance\nof death, antibiotics must be given within 24 hours of 1st symptoms.\nStreptomycin, gentamicin, the tetracyclines, and chloramphenicol are\nall effective against pneumonic plague.\n\nAntibiotic treatment for 7 days will protect people who have had\ndirect, close contact with infected patients. Wearing a close-fitting\nsurgical mask also protects against infection. A plague vaccine is not\ncurrently available for use in the United States.\n\nPortions of this comment were extracted from:\n<http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/51900.htm&word=plague>\nand\n<http://www.bt.cdc.gov/agent/plague/factsheet.asp>. - Mod.TG]\n\n[The interactive HealthMap/ProMED map of California is available at:\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00aj> - CopyEd.EJP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.isid.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 4 Dec 2009\n Persons having\nsignificant contact with a plague-infected cat, particularly cats with\nrespiratory signs or draining abscesses, should consult with their\nhealth care provider regarding the need for a prophylactic course of\nantibiotics. Information provided by the Department of Public Health\n\n--\nMerritt Clifton\nEditor, Animal People\nP.O. Box 960\n Domestic\ncats and dogs have also developed plague from oral mucous membrane\nexposure to infected rodent tissues, typically when they are allowed\nto roam and hunt in enzootic areas. Plague, caused by _Yersinia pestis_, is an acute and sometimes fatal\nbacterial zoonosis that is transmitted primarily by the fleas of rats\nand other rodents. Because of the\npotential for transmission to humans, cats suspected of having plague\nshould be hospitalized and placed in isolation. This occurs when an\ninfected flea bites a person or when materials contaminated with _Y.\npestis_ enter through a break in a person's skin. Most human cases result\nfrom the bite of an infected flea, although direct contact with\ninfected wild rabbits, rodents, and occasion! On average, 10 human\nplague cases are reported each year in the USA; the majority are from\nNew Mexico, California, Colorado, and Arizona. Enzootic foci of sylvatic plague exist in the\nwestern USA and throughout the world, including Eurasia, Africa, and\nNorth and South America. \nally other wildlife and exposure to infected domestic cats are also\nrisk factors. Prairie dogs [which are\nactually ground squirrels] are more sensitive than cats, but\nnevertheless, cats are quite sensitive. In addition to rodents, other mammalian\nspecies that have been naturally infected with _Y. pestis_ include\nlagomorphs, felids, canids, mustelids, and some ungulates. -- Use flea-repellent products on your pets regularly; ie: collars,\nbath, ointments, and powders, especially after returning from a\nwilderness area. Each rodent\nspecies is host to one or more species of flea, which, when infected,\nis a carrier. _Y. pestis_ grows slowly even at optimal temperatures (28 deg\nC [82.4 deg F]) and can require greater than 48 hours to produce\ncolonies. Patients develop\nswollen, tender lymph glands (called buboes) and fever, headache,\nchills, and weakness. The most effective\nweapons in fighting this disease are public awareness, education, and\npreventative measures to reduce the risk for exposure.' Patients have\nfever, chills, prostration, abdominal pain, shock, and bleeding into\nskin and other organs. Consequently, veterinarians,\ntechnicians, animal shelter workers and animal caretakers may become\nvictims when buboes rupture. The\npneumonia progresses for 2 to 4 days and may cause respiratory failure\nand shock. Even so, when\nreleased into the air, the bacteria will survive for up to one hour,\nalthough this could vary depending on conditions.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eurasia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North and South America", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kern County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersenia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "262465", "headline": "PRO/AH> Plague, pneumonic - China (05): (QH) Comment", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=262465", "date": "2009-08-07 21:00:06", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PNEUMONIC - CHINA (05): (QINGHAI) COMMENT\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 6 Aug 2009\nFrom: Wendy Orent\n<orentw@bellsouth.net>\n\n\nI've been following this plague in China business with the greatest\ninterest. No one has pointed out in ProMed that all the research done\nby ex-Soviet scientists on marmot plague indicates that it has a\npneumotropism (though I do not know if anyone has demonstrated it on\na molecular level.)\n\nThere were 3 huge outbreaks of pneumonic plague in the 20th Century:\n60 000 dead in 1910, 16 000 in 1916 in Shanxi, China, in 1915-16, and\n10 000 in 1920, with Wu Lien-teh literally sitting right on top of it\n(he treated the index case) but the thing exploded anyway, because\npeople fled. Of the 3 outbreaks there were 3 survivors, acording to\nWu. I was surprised that this time the index case got the plague from\na dog, but I knew marmots had to be involved somehow. They are the\nonly creatures besides humans who can pass pneumonic plague from one\nto another under normal (not laboratory) circumstances. Of course\nthey live in big colonies and they just keep passing it around; the\ngerm survives in their burrows either inside protozoa or in a biofilm\nso it's impossible to eradicate, as the Soviets found when they tried\nkilling off the marmots.\n\nIt is such a shame the people keep fleeing, as the disease can be\ntreated now. I hope we don't have a major outbreak, since that's\nexactly what happened in 1920 at the very least; people just escaped\nfrom quarantine and spread the disease all over Manchuria via the\nrailroad tracks. I think a lot of the common wisdom about\ntransmissibility doesn't apply to marmot plague -- the disease really\ncan't be compared to what we see in this country, where it almost\nnever goes pneumonic except if someone skins a coyote or gets it from\ntheir pet cat (and then, since 1924, it has never spread.) Prairie\ndog plague seems to lack the pneumotropism; prairie dogs spread it\nthrough their fleas, according to prairie dog expert John Hoogland.\nBut no one ever saw a flea on any human being during the Manchurian\nplagues, and those scientists looked! Rats also were never involved.\nAfter the 1st person was infected by exposure to a marmot, it was all\nspread via direct contagion. So it's hard to believe that rats and\nfleas were involved this time, and I wonder why the government is\napparently killing them.\n\n--\nWendy Orent\nAtlanta, Georgia\n<orentw@bellsouth.net>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 6 Aug 2009\n I think a lot of the common wisdom about\ntransmissibility doesn't apply to marmot plague -- the disease really\ncan't be compared to what we see in this country, where it almost\nnever goes pneumonic except if someone skins a coyote or gets it from\ntheir pet cat (and then, since 1924, it has never spread.) \n\nThere were 3 huge outbreaks of pneumonic plague in the 20th Century:\n60 000 dead in 1910, 16 000 in 1916 in Shanxi, China, in 1915-16, and\n10 000 in 1920, with Wu Lien-teh literally sitting right on top of it\n Prairie\ndog plague seems to lack the pneumotropism; prairie dogs spread it\nthrough their fleas, according to prairie dog expert John Hoogland.\n No one has pointed out in ProMed that all the research done\nby ex-Soviet scientists on marmot plague indicates that it has a\npneumotropism (though I do not know if anyone has demonstrated it on\na molecular level.) Of course\nthey live in big colonies and they just keep passing it around; the\ngerm survives in their burrows either inside protozoa or in a biofilm\n \n\n--\nWendy Orent\nAtlanta, Georgia\n<orentw@bellsouth.net>", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1920-03-25 00:00:00", "1910-03-25 00:00:00", "1924-03-25 00:00:00", "1916-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Manchuria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Shanxi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "260819", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, pneumonic - China (03): (QH)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=260819", "date": "2009-08-05 18:00:09", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PNEUMONIC - CHINA (03): (QINGHAI)\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: Wed 5 Aug 2009\nSource: Xinhua News Agency [edited]\n<http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-08/05/content_11831481.htm>\n\n\nAs of late Tuesday [4 Aug 2009], 12 cases of pneumonic plague have\nbeen confirmed in Xinghai County in the Hainan Tibetan Autonomous\nPrefecture of northwest China's Qinghai Province. The cases include 3\ndeaths, 1 near death, and 1 in serious condition. The others are stable.\n\nLocal government has sealed off and quarantined the town of Ziketan,\nthe source of the outbreak and provincial health authorities have\ndeployed a team of experts to the area. There has been no report of\nnew infections.\n\nAt present, 218 people are quarantined in hospital, and 115 of them\nhad been in close contact with those infected. Local authorities have\nhanded out more than 40 000 leaflets and disks on plague prevention.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue 4 Aug 2009\nSource: The Associated Press (AP) [edited]\n<http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5iLFGFVYaEEFibpJ7MThpiQsgInWQD99S75901>\n\n\nResidents of a remote farming town in western China said Tuesday [4\nAug 2009] people were seeking to flee in defiance a lockdown by\nauthorities to prevent the spread of highly infectious pneumonic\nplague, which has claimed 3 lives in the area.\n\nPolice have set up checkpoints around Ziketan in Qinghai province, a\ntown of 10 000 people, which has been put under quarantine after at\nleast a dozen people caught the lung infection, which can kill within\n24 hours if untreated.\n\nSome people tried to leave the quarantined area Monday evening [3 Aug\n2009], mostly by foot, after the 3rd death was reported, 2 residents\nreached by The Associated Press said. Most of the town's residents\nare Tibetan herders of yaks, sheep, and pigs.\n\n'A lot of people ran off last night when they heard that another\nperson died of this plague. They are mostly from other provinces,'\nsaid a food seller who runs a stall at the Crystal Alley Market.\n'They headed back home with food, water, and their donkeys.'\n\nMedical workers in Ziketan were disinfecting and killing rodents and\nfleas that can be carriers for the bacteria that cause the plague,\naccording to a notice on the provincial health department website.\n\nA Tibetan woman, a migrant construction worker from another village\nin Qinghai, said there were very few people on the streets. 'I've\nheard the migrant workers who build projects went home last night [3\nAug 2009],' she said by telephone. 'My boss told me that more than 50\nof the 100 construction workers on our project left homes already.'\n\nIt was unclear if the people who headed out of the town made it past\nthe police checkpoints, which residents say have been set up in\n17-mile (28-kilometer) radius around Ziketan, which lies more than\n300 miles (480 kilometers) west of Beijing.\n\nThe outbreak in Ziketan was first detected Thursday [30 Jul 2009],\nalthough it isn't clear when the 1st victim died. The official Xinhua\nNews Agency said the latest victim was a 64-year-old man, a neighbor\nof the first 2 fatalities, described in reports as a 32-year-old\nherdsman and a 37-year-old man. The herdsman fell sick after burying\nhis dog, which had died suddenly, according to a report by the\nofficial China National Radio, citing a hospital official. He died 4\ndays after the dog's burial and the relatives who handled his funeral\nwere showing symptoms within days, the report said.\n\nThose relatives were among a further 9 people who are infected and in\na hospital, according to the local health bureau. One is in extremely\nserious condition and another has developed symptoms of coughing and\nchest pain, but the rest are in stable condition, Xinhua and the\nhealth department said.\n\nChina has had cases of plague before. WHO said in a 2006 report that\nmost cases in China's northwest occur when hunters are contaminated\nwhile skinning infected animals. In 2004, 8 villagers in Qinghai\nprovince died of plague, most infected after killing or eating wild\nmarmots, creatures related to gophers and prairie dogs.\n\n[Byline: Henry Sanderson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[It is now clearly stated that pneumonic plague has occurred in all\n12 individuals, 11 of whom were exposed to the index case. It is not\nstated how soon antimicrobial therapy was begun in the affected\npersons. It is generally said (1) that treatment of primary plague\npneumonia (primary here means acquired via the respiratory route)\nshould be begun once of the diagnosis is suspected since a delay of\nmore than 18 hours produces a very high mortality rate. It is also\nnot stated whether antimicrobial prophylaxis is being used in the 115\nindividuals who had been in close contact with the cases.\n\nReference\n---------\n1. Oyston PCF, Titball RW: Plague. In, Beyond Anthrax. The\nWeaponization of Infectious Diseases. (Lutwick LI, Lutwick SM, eds),\nHumana Press, New York, 2009, 55-76. - Mod.LL]\n\n[Ziketan town can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00E4>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\n \n\nPolice have set up checkpoints around Ziketan in Qinghai province, a\ntown of 10 000 people, which has been put under quarantine after at\nleast a dozen people caught the lung infection, which can kill within\n24 hours if untreated.\n\n Residents of a remote farming town in western China said Tuesday [4\nAug 2009] people were seeking to flee in defiance a lockdown by\nauthorities to prevent the spread of highly infectious pneumonic\nplague, which has claimed 3 lives in the area. \n\nIt was unclear if the people who headed out of the town made it past\nthe police checkpoints, which residents say have been set up in\n17-mile (28-kilometer) radius around Ziketan, which lies more than\n300 miles (480 kilometers) west of Beijing. The official Xinhua\nNews Agency said the latest victim was a 64-year-old man, a neighbor\nof the first 2 fatalities, described in reports as a 32-year-old\nherdsman and a 37-year-old man. It is generally said (1) that treatment of primary plague\npneumonia (primary here means acquired via the respiratory route)\nshould be begun once of the diagnosis is suspected since a delay of\nmore than 18 hours produces a very high mortality rate. One is in extremely\nserious condition and another has developed symptoms of coughing and\nchest pain, but the rest are in stable condition, Xinhua and the\nhealth department said. Some people tried to leave the quarantined area Monday evening [3 Aug\n2009], mostly by foot, after the 3rd death was reported, 2 residents\nreached by The Associated Press said. \n\nMedical workers in Ziketan were disinfecting and killing rodents and\nfleas that can be carriers for the bacteria that cause the plague,\naccording to a notice on the provincial health department website. \n\nLocal government has sealed off and quarantined the town of Ziketan,\nthe source of the outbreak and provincial health authorities have\ndeployed a team of experts to the area. I've\nheard the migrant workers who build projects went home last night [3\nAug 2009],' she said by telephone. ' He died 4\ndays after the dog's burial and the relatives who handled his funeral\nwere showing symptoms within days, the report said. As of late Tuesday [4 Aug 2009], 12 cases of pneumonic plague have\nbeen confirmed in Xinghai County in the Hainan Tibetan Autonomous\nPrefecture of northwest China's Qinghai Province. In 2004, 8 villagers in Qinghai\nprovince died of plague, most infected after killing or eating wild\nmarmots, creatures related to gophers and prairie dogs. WHO said in a 2006 report that\nmost cases in China's northwest occur when hunters are contaminated\nwhile skinning infected animals.
