It is also\nnot stated whether antimicrobial prophylaxis is being used in the 115\nindividuals who had been in close contact with the cases.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Xinghai County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Qinghai", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ziketan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Qinghai Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "261570", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, pneumonic - China (04): (QH)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=261570", "date": "2009-08-06 12:00:09", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PNEUMONIC - CHINA (04): (QINGHAI)\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 6 Aug 2009\nSource: Agence France-Presse (AFP) [edited]\n<http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hS5A-DJTVP-woDOUuOi7NJIyYfcQ>\n\n\nA dog is suspected to be the origin of an outbreak of pneumonic\nplague in northwest China that has killed 3 people and left 10 000\nunder strict quarantine, state media reported. Ziketan, a remote town\nin a Tibetan area of Qinghai province, has been locked down since\nSaturday [1 Aug 2009] in an effort to contain the spread of the\nhighly virulent disease.\n\nOne patient was in critical condition and 8 others were infected,\nmost of them relatives of the 1st fatality, a 32-year-old herdsman,\nor local doctors, Xinhua news agency said.\n\nInitial tests had shown that the herdsman's dead dog was the likely\norigin of the outbreak, Xinhua reported late Wednesday [5 Aug 2009],\nquoting professor Wang Hu, director of the Qinghai disease control\nbureau. Wang said it was likely that the dog died after eating a\nplague-infected marmot and that the man became infected when he was\nbitten by fleas while burying the dead dog. He died 3 days later.\n\n'The 1st victim buried the dead dog without any protection. After he\nbecame infected, his relatives and neighbours were in close contact\nwith him without taking any protective measures, leading to their\ninfection,' Wang was quoted as saying.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Regarding dogs and plague, an American Veterinary Medical\nAssociation reference\n(<http://www.avma.org/reference/zoonosis/znbuboni.asp>), with the\ncitation numbers changed to begin at 1, states:\n\n'Generally, the canine family is believed to be more resistant to\nplague than the feline family and if they develop the disease at all,\nthe disease usually is subclinical, that is, not easily recognizable.\nWild carnivores in the dog family, such as coyotes and foxes, can\ndevelop blood titers against _Yersinia pestis_ (1,2) Experimentally,\ndogs inoculated with _Y. pestis_ develop bacteremia and have had _Y.\npestis_ isolated for 10 days from the oropharynx (1). Subclinically\nand clinically affected dogs can develop antibodies against _Y.\npestis_ (1), and people have contracted plague after skinning\ninfected coyotes and foxes (1,3).\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Poland J, Barnes A. Plague. In: Steele JH, ed CRC handbook series\nin zoonoses Boca Raton, Fla: CRC Press, 1979.\n2. Rust JH jr, Cavanaugh DC, O'Shita R, et al: The role of domestic\nanimals in the epidemiology of plague. I. Experimental infection of\ndogs and cats. J Infect Dis 1971; 124: 522-6 [although a different\nreference in the same journal actually discusses the serologies: The\nrole of domestic animals in the epidemiology of plague. II. Antibody\nto _Yersinia pestis_ in sera of dogs and cats. Rust JH jr, Miller BE,\nBahmanyar M, et al. J Infect Dis 1971; 124(5): 527-31. - Mod.LL]\n3. Barnes AM: Surveillance and control of bubonic plague in the\nUnited States. Symp Zool Soc London 1982.\n\nMarmots are large rodents related to the American woodchuck (_Marmota\nmonax_), are thought to be significant zoonotic reservoirs for _Y.\npestis_ in Eastern Asia. The name marmot\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marmot>) comes from French marmotte,\nfrom Latin mures monti, 'mountain mouse.' - Mod.LL]", "summary": "promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Regarding dogs and plague, an American Veterinary Medical\nAssociation reference\n(<http://www.avma.org/reference/zoonosis/znbuboni.asp>), with the\ncitation numbers changed to begin at 1, states:\n\n'Generally, the canine family is believed to be more resistant to\nplague than the feline family and if they develop the disease at all,\nthe disease usually is subclinical, that is, not easily recognizable. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 6 Aug 2009\n Wild carnivores in the dog family, such as coyotes and foxes, can\ndevelop blood titers against _Yersinia pestis_ (1,2) Experimentally,\ndogs inoculated with _Y. pestis_ develop bacteremia and have had _Y.\npestis_ isolated for 10 days from the oropharynx (1). Subclinically\nand clinically affected dogs can develop antibodies against _Y.\npestis_ (1), and people have contracted plague after skinning\ninfected coyotes and foxes (1,3). \n\nInitial tests had shown that the herdsman's dead dog was the likely\norigin of the outbreak, Xinhua reported late Wednesday [5 Aug 2009],\nquoting professor Wang Hu, director of the Qinghai disease control\nbureau. After he\nbecame infected, his relatives and neighbours were in close contact\nwith him without taking any protective measures, leading to their\ninfection,' Wang was quoted as saying. Wang said it was likely that the dog died after eating a\nplague-infected marmot and that the man became infected when he was\nbitten by fleas while burying the dead dog. A dog is suspected to be the origin of an outbreak of pneumonic\nplague in northwest China that has killed 3 people and left 10 000\nunder strict quarantine, state media reported. \n\nOne patient was in critical condition and 8 others were infected,\nmost of them relatives of the 1st fatality, a 32-year-old herdsman,\nor local doctors, Xinhua news agency said. \n\nMarmots are large rodents related to the American woodchuck (_Marmota\nmonax_), are thought to be significant zoonotic reservoirs for _Y.\npestis_ in Eastern Asia. [although a different\nreference in the same journal actually discusses the serologies: The\nrole of domestic animals in the epidemiology of plague.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-27 00:00:00", "1979-03-25 00:00:00", "1971-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "1982-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "London", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Poland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cavanaugh DC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Marmota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Qinghai", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Boca Raton", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ziketan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "257328", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, pneumonic - China: (QH), RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=257328", "date": "2009-08-01 21:00:06", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PNEUMONIC - CHINA: (QINGHAI), REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sat 1 Aug 2009\nSource: XinHuaNet [edited]\n<http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-08/02/content_11811126.htm>\n\n\nOne dies of pneumonic plague in NW China\n-----------------------------------------\nOne person has died of pneumonic plague which infected 11 others in\nthe Hainan Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture, northwest China's Qinghai\nProvince, said the province's health bureau. The 11 infected\npatients, hospitalized in quarantined wards, are in stable\nconditions. Most of them are relatives of the dead person, a\n32-year-old herdsman, said a press release from Health Bureau of\nQinghai Province.\n\nThe province sent a team of experts to the area and had the plague\nunder control, said the release. The local government quarantined the\nsource of the plague, Ziketan town, and its vicinity. The area has\nsufficient supplies and the quarantine has not disrupted the basic\nneeds of the locals, according to the release.\n\nThe health bureau demanded those who have fever and cough and have\nbeen to Ziketan town and its vicinity after 16 Jul 2009 to go to\nhospital. Ziketan town, in Xinghai county of Hainan Tibetan\nAutonomous Prefecture, covers 3000 square kilometers and has a\npopulation of 10 000.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Primary pneumonic plague (one percent of natural plague\npresentations) arises as a result of inhalation of plague bacilli in\ninfectious aerosols, such as would be produced when there are\nsecondary pneumonic complications in bubonic/septicemic plague.\n\nPrimary plague pneumonia has a short incubation period of 1-3 days,\nafter which there is sudden onset of flu-like symptoms including\nfever, chills, headache, generalized body pains, weakness, and chest\ndiscomfort. A cough develops with sputum production, which may be\nbloody, and increasing chest pain and difficulty in breathing. As the\ndisease progresses, hypoxia (low oxygen concentration in the blood)\nand hemoptysis (coughing up blood) are prominent. The disease is\ninvariably fatal unless antimicrobial therapy commences within 24\nhours of exposure.\n\nPatients with primary pneumonic plague generate large quantities of\ninfectious aerosols that pose a significant risk to close contacts.\nCDC (US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) guidelines\nidentify contacts within 2 meters (6.5 ft) as being at greatest risk\nand do not consider the organism likely to be carried through air\nducts or vents. Persons who have been in contact with pneumonic\nplague patients or handling potentially infectious body fluids or\ntissues without appropriate protection should receive preventive\nantimicrobial therapy. The preferred antimicrobial agents for\nprophylaxis are tetracyclines, quinolones, or chloramphenicol.\n\nThe area involved is an autonomous prefecture of Qinghai province in\nChina. The prefecture's capital is Gonghe county. The placename\nliterally means 'south of the Qinghai Lake.' It can be found on a map\nat: <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hainan_Tibetan_Autonomous_Prefecture>.\n- Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sat 1 Aug 2009\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Primary pneumonic plague (one percent of natural plague\npresentations) arises as a result of inhalation of plague bacilli in\ninfectious aerosols, such as would be produced when there are\nsecondary pneumonic complications in bubonic/septicemic plague. \n\nPrimary plague pneumonia has a short incubation period of 1-3 days,\nafter which there is sudden onset of flu-like symptoms including\nfever, chills, headache, generalized body pains, weakness, and chest\ndiscomfort. \nOne person has died of pneumonic plague which infected 11 others in\nthe Hainan Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture, northwest China's Qinghai\nProvince, said the province's health bureau. Persons who have been in contact with pneumonic\nplague patients or handling potentially infectious body fluids or\ntissues without appropriate protection should receive preventive\nantimicrobial therapy. CDC (US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) guidelines\nidentify contacts within 2 meters (6.5 ft) as being at greatest risk\nand do not consider the organism likely to be carried through air\nducts or vents. Most of them are relatives of the dead person, a\n32-year-old herdsman, said a press release from Health Bureau of\nQinghai Province. The area has\nsufficient supplies and the quarantine has not disrupted the basic\nneeds of the locals, according to the release.\n\n The health bureau demanded those who have fever and cough and have\nbeen to Ziketan town and its vicinity after 16 Jul 2009 to go to\nhospital. Ziketan town, in Xinghai county of Hainan Tibetan\nAutonomous Prefecture, covers 3000 square kilometers and has a\npopulation of 10 000.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Xinghai county", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ziketan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Qinghai", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gonghe county", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "242974", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, fatal - USA (03): (NM) recovery", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=242974", "date": "2009-07-15 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, FATAL - USA (03): (NEW MEXICO) RECOVERY\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 9 Jul 2009\nSource: KRQE.com [edited]\n<http://www.krqe.com/dpp/news/health/health_krqe_albuquerque_bernalillo_county_girl_recovering_from_plague_200907091454>\n\n\nA 16-month-old Bernalillo County girl is recovering from plague, the\ncounty's 1st human case this year [2009] and the state's 5th,\naccording to the Albuquerque Vector-Borne and Zoonotic Disease\nDivision. The city [officials] said the girl was likely exposed to the\nplague in the East Mountains, and investigators are gathering more\ninformation on how she was exposed.\n\nOfficials also believe the girl's great-grandfather was also infected\nwith plague, but they're still awaiting final test results.\n\nFamily pets are also prone to the plague and could carry infected\nfleas home to their owners. Dogs may not show symptoms, the city said,\nbut cats may develop swollen lymph nodes in the neck, become\nlethargic, suffer a fever or lose their appetite. Officials suggest\nthat pet owners use flea control on their pets, keep them away from\ndead rodents or rodent burrows, and prevent them from roaming or\nhunting. They should also take sick pets to a veterinarian.\n\nPeople should also avoid sick or dead rodents, keep their distance\nfrom wildlife and prevent rodents from living near their homes by\nremoving trash and weeds and getting wood piles off the ground.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although not stated, it is likely that the child had the bubonic form\nof _Yersinia pestis_ infection, the most common manifestation of\nplague in humans.\n\nThe southwestern state of New Mexico can be located on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the US at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00Bg>.\nA map of the state of New Mexico showing the location of Bernalillo\nCounty mentioned in the posting can be found at\n<http://quickfacts.census.gov/qfd/maps/new_mexico_map.html>. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 9 Jul 2009\n A 16-month-old Bernalillo County girl is recovering from plague, the\ncounty's 1st human case this year [2009] and the state's 5th,\naccording to the Albuquerque Vector-Borne and Zoonotic Disease\nDivision. Officials suggest\nthat pet owners use flea control on their pets, keep them away from\ndead rodents or rodent burrows, and prevent them from roaming or\nhunting. \n\nPeople should also avoid sick or dead rodents, keep their distance\nfrom wildlife and prevent rodents from living near their homes by\nremoving trash and weeds and getting wood piles off the ground. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although not stated, it is likely that the child had the bubonic form\nof _Yersinia pestis_ infection, the most common manifestation of\nplague in humans. The city [officials] said the girl was likely exposed to the\nplague in the East Mountains, and investigators are gathering more\ninformation on how she was exposed.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bernalillo County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bernalillo \n County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "258753", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, pneumonic - China (02): (QH)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=258753", "date": "2009-08-03 16:15:07", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PNEUMONIC - CHINA (02): (QINGHAI)\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 3 Aug 2009\nSource: The New York Times [edited]\n<http://www.nytimes.com/2009/08/04/world/asia/04china.html>\n\n\nOfficials have sealed off an isolated town of 10 000 people in rural\nwest-central China after an outbreak of pneumonic plague killed 2\nresidents, the state-run Xinhua news service reported on Monday [3 Aug 2009].\n\nAn official who answered the emergency line at Renmin Hospital in\nZiketan, where the outbreak is centered, said that all roads into and\nout of the area had been closed off, but that residents remained free\nto move about within the town. The official, who refused to give his\nname, said it was unclear when the blockade would be lifted. Repeated\ncalls to a plague emergency phone line produced only busy signals.\n\nZiketan is a remote, ethnically Tibetan town in eastern Qinghai\nProvince, one of the largest and least populated regions of China.\nOfficials said the 1st victim, a 32-year-old herdsman, died last\nThursday [30 Jul 2009], and the 2nd, a neighbor who also was a\nherdsman, died on Sunday [2 Aug 209], more than a day after being\nadmitted to a hospital.\n\nLocal health officials told Xinhua that they had quarantined 10 other\npeople, mostly relatives of the dead men, but that none had developed\ncoughs or fever, signs of the deadly disease.\n\nWhile bubonic plague is spread by bites from infected rodent fleas,\nthe deadlier pneumonic plague bacteria are spread through the air by\ncoughing, and it kills about 6 in 10 sufferers, sometimes within a\nday, if it is not treated.\n\nThe World Health Organization said that the mortality rate could be\nreduced to about 15 percent through treatment with common\nantibiotics. A spokeswoman for the agency told Bloomberg News that\nexperts were monitoring the outbreak but were not especially concerned by it.\n\n[Byline: Michael Wines]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[In the initial posting (Plague, pneumonic - China: (QH), RFI\n20090801.2702), it was stated that besides the initial death, 11\nothers were infected. Here, that it not stated but 1 of those appears\nto have also succumbed to pneumonic plague.\n\nThe following is adapted from reference 1 with the internal citations\nchanged to begin with 2:\n\nCDC guidelines identify contacts within 2 meters (6.6 ft) as being at\ngreatest risk and do not consider the organism likely to be carried\nthrough air ducts or vents (2). Isolation precautions, such as hand\nwashing, wearing latex gloves and gowns, and protection of mucous\nmembranes, should be undertaken for all bubonic plague patients for\n48 hours. If no pneumonia is found or there are no draining lesions,\nisolation can be discontinued.\n\nPneumonic plague patients should also be managed under respiratory\ndroplet precautions, including\n- accommodation in an individual room,\n- restriction of patient movement outside the room and access to the room, and\n- masking of both patient and health-care deliverers.\n\nIt is thought that the risk of transmission is ended after the\ncompletion of at least 4 days of therapy (3). The Working Group on\nCivilian Biodefense recommended isolation during the 1st 48 hours and\nuntil clinical improvement occurs (4).\n\nLaboratory-acquired plague has been reported and can result in\nprimary pneumonic plague. Probably initially reported in Wu's 1926\nclassic monograph on plague (5), the laboratory transmission of\n_Yersinia pestis_ appears to be rare. A case report with a review of\n4 other cases was published in the USA in 1962 (6). _Y. pestis_ has\nbeen found to maintain some viability for some periods of times (at\nleast 5 days) on environmental surfaces under controlled conditions\n(7). Such an environmental risk for humans is likely to be minimal,\nand environmental decontamination is not recommended (4).\n\nA cluster of pneumonic plague in the USA occurred in the early part\nof the 20th century in northern California (Fall of 1919) (8).\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Oyston PCF, Titball RW: Plague. In, Beyond Anthrax. The\nWeaponization of Infectious Diseases. (Lutwick LI, Lutwick SM, eds)\nHumana Press, New York, 2009, 55-76.\n2. Dennis DT, Gage KL, Grantz N, et al: Plague manual: epidemiology,\ndistribution, surveillance and control. World Health Organization,\nGeneva, 1999 [available from\n<http://www.who.int/csr/resources/publications/plague/WHO_CDS_CSR_EDC_99_2_EN/en/>].\n3. McGovern TW, Friedlander AM: Plague. In, Textbook of Military\nMedicine: Medical Aspects of Chemical and Biological Warfare.\n(Zajtchuk R, Bellamy RF, eds), Office of the Surgeon General, Borden\nInstitute, Washington, DC, 1997, pp 479-502 [available from\n<http://www.bordeninstitute.army.mil/published_volumes/chemBio/Ch23.pdf>].\n4. Inglesby TV, Dennis DT, Henderson DA, et al: Plague as a\nbiological weapon -- medical and public health management, JAMA 2000;\n283: 2281-90 [available from\n<http://jama.ama-assn.org/cgi/content/full/283/17/2281>].\n5. Wu L-T: A Treatise on Pneumonic Plague. League of Nations, Geneva,\n1926 [abstract available from\n<http://www.ajtmh.org/cgi/content/abstract/s1-7/4/269>].\n6. Burmeister RW, Tigertt WD, Overholt EL: Laboratory-acquired\npneumonic plague. Report of a case and review of previous cases. Ann\nIntern Med 1962; 56: 789-800 [abstract available from\n<http://www.annals.org/cgi/content/abstract/56/5_Part_1/789?ck=nck>].\n7. Rose LJ, Donlan R, Banerjee SN, Arduino MJ: Survival of _Yersinia\npestis_ on environmental surfaces. Appl Environ Microbiol 2003; 69:\n2166-71 [available from\n<http://aem.asm.org/cgi/content/full/69/4/2166>].\n8. Kellogg WH: An epidemic of pneumonic plague. Am J Public Health\n1920; 10: 599-605 [available from\n<http://www.ajph.org/cgi/reprint/10/7/599>]. - Mod.LL]\n\n[Ziketan town can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00E4>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 3 Aug 2009\n \n\nPneumonic plague patients should also be managed under respiratory\ndroplet precautions, including\n- accommodation in an individual room,\n- restriction of patient movement outside the room and access to the room, and\n- masking of both patient and health-care deliverers. \n\nWhile bubonic plague is spread by bites from infected rodent fleas,\nthe deadlier pneumonic plague bacteria are spread through the air by\ncoughing, and it kills about 6 in 10 sufferers, sometimes within a\nday, if it is not treated.
