The city [officials] said the girl was likely exposed to the\nplague in the East Mountains, and investigators are gathering more\ninformation on how she was exposed.\n\nOfficials also believe the girl's great-grandfather was also infected\nwith plague, but they're still awaiting final test results.\n\nFamily pets are also prone to the plague and could carry infected\nfleas home to their owners. Dogs may not show symptoms, the city said,\nbut cats may develop swollen lymph nodes in the neck, become\nlethargic, suffer a fever or lose their appetite. Officials suggest\nthat pet owners use flea control on their pets, keep them away from\ndead rodents or rodent burrows, and prevent them from roaming or\nhunting. They should also take sick pets to a veterinarian.\n\nPeople should also avoid sick or dead rodents, keep their distance\nfrom wildlife and prevent rodents from living near their homes by\nremoving trash and weeds and getting wood piles off the ground.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although not stated, it is likely that the child had the bubonic form\nof _Yersinia pestis_ infection, the most common manifestation of\nplague in humans.\n\nThe southwestern state of New Mexico can be located on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the US at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00Bg>.\nA map of the state of New Mexico showing the location of Bernalillo\nCounty mentioned in the posting can be found at\n<http://quickfacts.census.gov/qfd/maps/new_mexico_map.html>. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 9 Jul 2009\n A 16-month-old Bernalillo County girl is recovering from plague, the\ncounty's 1st human case this year [2009] and the state's 5th,\naccording to the Albuquerque Vector-Borne and Zoonotic Disease\nDivision. Officials suggest\nthat pet owners use flea control on their pets, keep them away from\ndead rodents or rodent burrows, and prevent them from roaming or\nhunting. \n\nPeople should also avoid sick or dead rodents, keep their distance\nfrom wildlife and prevent rodents from living near their homes by\nremoving trash and weeds and getting wood piles off the ground. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although not stated, it is likely that the child had the bubonic form\nof _Yersinia pestis_ infection, the most common manifestation of\nplague in humans. The city [officials] said the girl was likely exposed to the\nplague in the East Mountains, and investigators are gathering more\ninformation on how she was exposed.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bernalillo County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bernalillo \n County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "241217", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Uganda: (AW, NE), 2008: RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=241217", "date": "2009-07-14 12:00:08", "main_text": "PLAGUE - UGANDA: (ARUA, NEBBI), 2008: REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 13 Jul 2009\nSource: The Monitor & AllAfrica [edited]\n<http://allafrica.com/stories/200907131172.html>\n\n\nThe community in Arua District has been put on high alert over an\noutbreak of the deadly bubonic plague disease that killed 17 people in\n2008. In this regard, the Ministry of Health in collaboration with the\nArua health team has launched a campaign to educate the community on\ncauses, signs and symptoms and prevention of the deadly disease.\n\nThe District Health Officer, Dr Patrick Anguzu, said the campaign is a\nprecautionary measure in case of any outbreak. 'Our community must\nkeep their environment clean especially the houses, because the rats\nthat transmit the disease thrive in unclean environment.'\n\nDr Anguzu told the Daily Monitor that no new case of the disease has\nyet been reported in the district in 2009. The 2008 statistics from\nArua health office indicate that 73 cases of human infections and 17\ndeaths were reported, the highest figure in 2 years. Dr Anguzu added\nthat 29 [of those] cases have since been confirmed to be of the\nbubonic variety.\n\nThe community sensitisation campaign is being carried out in the\ndisease-prone areas of Vurra and Logiri. But even then, the\nsurrounding area of Kango Sub-county in Nebbi, which borders Logiri,\nmust not be left out. Historically, the bubonic plague is reported to\nhave originated from the Democratic Republic of Congo, especially from\nAru and Ariwara.\n\nThe campaign, Dr Anguzu said, is aimed at educating residents who keep\npets like cats, which are also susceptible to plague. In this case,\ninfected cats become sick and may directly transmit plague to people\nwho handle or care for them.\n\n[Byline: Warrom Felix Okello]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The figures given here do not agree with '68 people have died since\nFebruary 2008' in the 1st ProMED ref. below. Clarification would be\nappreciated. - Mod.JW]\n\n[Arua and Nebbi are endemic for plague and are located in northwestern\nUganda as can be seen on a map at:\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/uganda.pdf>.\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Uganda is available at:\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?g=443328&g=443360&v=2,31.167,5>. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 13 Jul 2009\n Our community must\nkeep their environment clean especially the houses, because the rats\nthat transmit the disease thrive in unclean environment.'\n\nDr Anguzu told the Daily Monitor that no new case of the disease has\nyet been reported in the district in 2009. The community in Arua District has been put on high alert over an\noutbreak of the deadly bubonic plague disease that killed 17 people in\n2008. In this regard, the Ministry of Health in collaboration with the\nArua health team has launched a campaign to educate the community on\ncauses, signs and symptoms and prevention of the deadly disease. The 2008 statistics from\nArua health office indicate that 73 cases of human infections and 17\ndeaths were reported, the highest figure in 2 years. In this case,\ninfected cats become sick and may directly transmit plague to people\nwho handle or care for them. JW]\n\n[Arua and Nebbi are endemic for plague and are located in northwestern\nUganda as can be seen on a map at:\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/uganda.pdf>. Historically, the bubonic plague is reported to\nhave originated from the Democratic Republic of Congo, especially from\nAru and Ariwara.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2008-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Arua District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ariwara", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nebbi", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "250457", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, bubonic, pneumonic - Uganda, 2006: (AW, NE)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=250457", "date": "2009-07-24 16:00:07", "main_text": "PLAGUE, BUBONIC AND PNEUMONIC - UGANDA, 2006: (ARUA, NEBBI)\n***********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 23 Jul 2009\nSource: CDC. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 2009; 58: 778-81 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5828a3.htm?s_cid=mm5828a3_e>\n\n\nBubonic and pneumonic plague - Uganda, 2006\n-------------------------------------------\nPlague is a life-threatening fleaborne disease caused by the\nbacterium _Yersinia pestis_. The most common clinical form is bubonic\nplague, which is characterized by high fever and regional\nlymphadenitis. Without treatment, infection can spread from lymph\nnodes [through the bloodstream - Mod.LL] to the lungs, resulting in\npneumonic plague and the potential for person-to-person transmission\nthrough respiratory droplets (1,2).\n\nIn November 2006, the Uganda Ministry of Health received reports of\nan increase in bubonic plague cases and a possible outbreak of\npneumonic plague among residents in the Arua and Nebbi districts. In\nresponse, the Uganda Ministry of Health and CDC conducted a joint\ninvestigation in the 2 districts during 28 Nov 2006-30 Dec 2006. The\nresults of this investigation underscore the need to 1) continue\nefforts to educate residents of rural Uganda regarding the source,\nsigns, and symptoms of plague and the life-saving importance of\nseeking treatment; 2) strengthen plague surveillance and diagnostic\ncapabilities; and 3) improve emergency response and vector-control\ncapacity, especially in remote regions of the country.\n\nIn rural Uganda, where laboratory capacity is limited, clinicians\ngenerally rely on clinical criteria for the diagnosis of plague.\nThese criteria, as established by the Uganda Ministry of Health, are\nas follows: sudden onset of fever, chills, malaise, headache, or\nprostration accompanied by either painful regional lymphadenitis\n(bubonic plague) or cough with hemoptysis (pneumonic plague). For\nthis investigation, a plague case was defined as clinically diagnosed\nplague with onset during 1 Jul 2006-30 Dec 2006, in a resident of\nArua or Nebbi districts. Beginning 28 Nov 2006, cases were\nascertained through retrospective review of patient logs in 8 clinics\nand 2 hospitals that historically have accounted for 85 percent of\nreported plague cases in the region (Uganda Virus Research Institute,\nunpublished data, 1999-2005).\n\nInformation was collected on patient age, sex, village of residence,\nclinical presentation, and outcome. In addition, clinicians at these\nfacilities and all other health clinics in Arua and Nebbi districts\nwere asked to report immediately by cellular telephone or messenger\nany new cases identified. When possible, diagnostic samples (that is,\nserum and bubo aspirates) were collected from patients with acute or\nrecent illness diagnosed as plague. Laboratory-confirmed plague was\ndefined as isolation of _Y. pestis_ or a 4-fold change in antibody\ntiter to F1 antigen between paired acute and convalescent serum\nsamples with a least one sample having a titer equal to or grater\nthan 1:16.\n\nA total of 127 plague cases with onset dates during 19 Jul 2006-30\nDec 2006 (Figure 1 [for figures and tables, see original URL -\nMod.LL]), were identified in Arua and Nebbi districts in northwestern\nUganda (Figure 2). Among the 102 patients with documented symptoms,\n90 (88 percent) had bubonic plague, and 12 (12 percent) had pneumonic\nplague. 2 or more plague cases were reported from 9 different\nvillages, including 4 villages that reported 10 or more cases (Nave,\n18; Kestro, 18; Andosi, 17; and Yiapi, 10). The median patient age\nwas 14 years (range: 2 weeks-65 years); 65 patients (51 percent) were\nfemale (Table).\n\nOf 11 pneumonic plague deaths, 6 (55 percent) occurred in a single\nvillage, in which 4 members of a single family died. Interviews with\nvillage residents indicated that the index case in that family was in\na boy aged 10 years who developed fever and a cervical bubo, followed\nby hemoptysis; he died on 3 Nov 2006. Within 7 days, the child's\nmother, grandmother, and aunt, all of whom had cared for the child,\nalso developed hemoptysis and died. Initially, ill village residents\ndid not seek health care because they believed the illness was of\nsupernatural origin stemming from a local feud. However, when 2\nadditional village members not involved in the feud died of similar\nsymptoms on 8 Nov 2006, ill villagers began seeking care at the\nhealth clinic, where they were treated with appropriate antibiotics\nand recovered.\n\nBubo aspirates were obtained from 11 (12 percent) of 90 patients with\nbubonic manifestations. None of the cases met the criteria for\nlaboratory confirmation. _Y. pestis_ was not recovered from any of\nthe 11 aspirates; however, 8 of the 11 patients had been treated with\nantibiotics before sample collection. Paired acute and convalescent\nblood samples were obtained from 7 (6 percent) of the 127 patients\nand convalescent blood samples alone from another 31 (24 percent). No\npaired serum samples had a 4-fold change in antibody titer. However,\nconvalescent sera from 5 (13 percent) of the 38 total patients with\nconvalescent samples had single titers that ranged from 1:16 to 1:256\n(median: 1:64), which is suggestive of recent or previous _Y. pestis_\ninfection. Samples were not available from any of the 12 patients who\nreceived a diagnosis of pneumonic plague; 11 of these patients died\nbefore the investigation began.\n\nTo evaluate access to care, patient behaviors, and potential plague\nexposures, structured interviews were conducted during 1-16 Dec 2006\nwith a convenience sample of 39 plague patients in 6 Arua and Nebbi\nvillages. Dates of illness onset for interviewed patients were from\n13 Oct 2006 to 14 Dec 2006. 27 patients (69 percent) reported that\nthey walked to the local health clinic for treatment of plague\nsymptoms, and 12 (31 percent) rode a bicycle. 15 patients (38\npercent) said travel to the nearest health clinic took more than 2\nhours, and 24 patients (62 percent) said travel took 2 hours or less.\n17 (44 percent) of the interviewed patients reported taking\nmedications, including acetaminophen, chloroquine, or traditional\nherbs, obtained in the village before visiting the clinic. 23\npatients (59 percent) reported seeing dead rats in their homes during\nthe 2 weeks preceding their illness; some villagers reported recently\nfinding and burying dead rats near their homes.\n\nWhile visiting villages, investigators in the 2 districts recovered 8\ndead rats (_Rattus rattus_), of which 4 tested positive for _Y.\npestis_ by direct fluorescent antibody staining and 2 tested positive\nby culture isolation. Live _R. rattus_ species trapped in 2 affected\nvillages were found to have an average of 2 fleas per rat; recovery\nof more than 1 flea per rat has been associated with increased risk\nfor plague transmission (3). On 8 Dec 2006, vector-control teams\ncomprised of local villagers began applying dichlorvos, a residual\ninsecticide, to households in affected villages in an effort to\ninterrupt plague transmission. By 14 Dec 2006, the teams had treated\n935 houses in 10 Arua District villages that had reported 2 or more\nplague cases since 1 Sep 2006. The death of the vector-control team\nleader from causes unrelated to plague prevented expansion of the\nspraying operation to affected villages in Nebbi District.\n\n[Reported by: Ogen-Odoi A, Katangole Mbidde E, Lutwama J, et al]\n\nEditorial note\n--------------\nAfrican countries accounted for nearly 90 percent of the 28 530\nplague cases reported to the World Health Organization during the\nmost recent 10-year reporting period (1994-2003) (4). In Uganda,\n200-400 clinically diagnosed plague cases are reported annually, with\nan estimated case-fatality rate of 30 percent (4). Although human\ncases typically occur sporadically or in small clusters, the\npotential for pneumonic outbreaks with spread to other areas is a\ngreat concern (5,6). Approximately 6 weeks after this investigation,\nan outbreak of pneumonic plague with 7 deaths was reported from\nMasindi District, a neighboring but ecologically distinct region\nwhere plague is not endemic. The index patient was an adolescent girl\naged 15 years who had become ill while visiting relatives in a\nplague-affected area of Nebbi District.\n\nThe investigation described in this report highlights some of the\nchallenges associated with identifying and controlling plague in\nrural Africa. Because of limited laboratory capacity, clinicians\nusually rely on clinical criteria alone when diagnosing illnesses.\nConsequently, patients with other causes of acute lymphadenitis (such\nas, staphylococcal) can be misdiagnosed as having plague, and\npatients with plague can be misdiagnosed as having other illnesses.\nWhen laboratory services are available, impassible roads and other\nlogistic barriers can prevent timely specimen collection. Patients\nwith less serious conditions might survive long enough to be tested;\nhowever, patients with more severe _Y. pestis_ infection are likely\nto die before specimens can be collected. Such differential testing\nmight have contributed to the low rate of seropositivity observed in\nthis investigation among those patients whose specimens were tested.\nGreater regional laboratory capacity and point-of-care diagnostic\nassays would help clinicians and health officials identify plague\ncases more quickly, distinguish these cases from other causes of\nsimilar illness, and facilitate more effective control of plague in\nAfrica.\n\nAlso highlighted by this investigation is the effect of local beliefs\non care-seeking behavior. Anthropologic studies have indicated that\ntribes living in Arua District hold diverse beliefs about disease\ncausation and the role of the supernatural in human illness (7).\nInvestigators observed that villagers initially ascribed an outbreak\nof pneumonic plague to feuding rather than to a disease that can be\ntreated with antibiotics. Because prompt antimicrobial treatment can\nbe life-saving for patients with plague, further studies are needed\nto 1) define local beliefs as they relate to plague, 2) determine how\nthey influence care-seeking, and 3) identify effective messages that\nwill result in plague patients seeking care at their local health\ncenter more quickly.\n\nTo enhance recognition, treatment, and control of plague in Uganda,\nCDC has entered into a cooperative agreement with the Uganda Ministry\nof Health and the Uganda Viral Research Institute. Studies are under\nway to 1) evaluate rapid, point-of-care diagnostic assays for plague,\n2) describe belief systems that influence health-care-seeking\nbehavior, 3) define the relative importance of various rodent and\nfleas species in plague transmission, and 4) assess opportunities for\nintegrating flea control into existing vector-control programs (such\nas, indoor residual spraying for malaria prevention). The overarching\ngoal of this multidisciplinary effort is to create effective\nprevention programs and develop and exercise local contingency plans\nfor plague outbreak response.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Perry RD, Fetherston JD: _Yersinia pestis_ -- etiologic agent of\nplague. Clin Microbiol Rev 1997; 10: 35-66 [available at\n<http://cmr.asm.org/cgi/reprint/10/1/35.pdf>].\n2. CDC: Prevention of plague: recommendations of the Advisory\nCommittee on Immunization Practices (ACIP). MMWR 1996; 45 (No. RR-14)\n[available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00044836.htm>].\n3. Politzer R: Plague. World Health Organization monograph series.\nNo. 22. Geneva, Switzerland: World Health Organization; 1954.\n4. World Health Organization: Human plague in 2002 and 2003. Wkly\nEpidemiol Rec 2004; 79: 301-6 [available at\n<http://www.who.int/wer/2004/en/wer7933.pdf>].\n5. Outbreak news. Plague, Democratic Republic of the Congo. Wkly\nEpidemiol Rec 2006; 81: 241-2.\n6. Ratsitorahina M, Chanteau S, Rahalison L, Ratsifasoamanana L,\nBoisier P: Epidemiological and diagnostic aspects of the outbreak of\npneumonic plague in Madagascar. Lancet 2000; 355: 111-3 [abstract\navailable at\n<http://www.lancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(99)05163-6/abstract>].\n7. Barnes-Dean V: Lugbara illness beliefs and social change. Africa:\nJournal of International African Institute 1986;56: 334-351 [abstract\navailable at\n<http://www.jstor.org/pss/1160688>].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[It is not common to get more detailed information regarding this\nsignificant 2006 outbreak of plague, which was posted on in ProMED\nwhen it was occurring.\n\nArua and Nebbi are endemic for plague and are located in northwestern\nUganda as can be seen on the maps at\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/uganda.pdf>\nand the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?g=443328&g=443360&v=2,31.167,5>. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "Studies are under\nway to 1) evaluate rapid, point-of-care diagnostic assays for plague,\n2) describe belief systems that influence health-care-seeking\nbehavior, 3) define the relative importance of various rodent and\nfleas species in plague transmission, and 4) assess opportunities for\nintegrating flea control into existing vector-control programs (such\nas, indoor residual spraying for malaria prevention). The\nresults of this investigation underscore the need to 1) continue\nefforts to educate residents of rural Uganda regarding the source,\nsigns, and symptoms of plague and the life-saving importance of\nseeking treatment; 2) strengthen plague surveillance and diagnostic\ncapabilities; and 3) improve emergency response and vector-control\ncapacity, especially in remote regions of the country. Because prompt antimicrobial treatment can\nbe life-saving for patients with plague, further studies are needed\nto 1) define local beliefs as they relate to plague, 2) determine how\nthey influence care-seeking, and 3) identify effective messages that\nwill result in plague patients seeking care at their local health\ncenter more quickly. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 23 Jul 2009\n Greater regional laboratory capacity and point-of-care diagnostic\nassays would help clinicians and health officials identify plague\ncases more quickly, distinguish these cases from other causes of\nsimilar illness, and facilitate more effective control of plague in\nAfrica. Beginning 28 Nov 2006, cases were\nascertained through retrospective review of patient logs in 8 clinics\nand 2 hospitals that historically have accounted for 85 percent of\nreported plague cases in the region (Uganda Virus Research Institute,\nunpublished data, 1999-2005). Laboratory-confirmed plague was\ndefined as isolation of _Y. pestis_ or a 4-fold change in antibody\ntiter to F1 antigen between paired acute and convalescent serum\nsamples with a least one sample having a titer equal to or grater\nthan 1:16. However, when 2\nadditional village members not involved in the feud died of similar\nsymptoms on 8 Nov 2006, ill villagers began seeking care at the\nhealth clinic, where they were treated with appropriate antibiotics\nand recovered. \n\nTo evaluate access to care, patient behaviors, and potential plague\nexposures, structured interviews were conducted during 1-16 Dec 2006\nwith a convenience sample of 39 plague patients in 6 Arua and Nebbi\nvillages. Consequently, patients with other causes of acute lymphadenitis (such\nas, staphylococcal) can be misdiagnosed as having plague, and\npatients with plague can be misdiagnosed as having other illnesses.\n Approximately 6 weeks after this investigation,\nan outbreak of pneumonic plague with 7 deaths was reported from\nMasindi District, a neighboring but ecologically distinct region\nwhere plague is not endemic. These criteria, as established by the Uganda Ministry of Health, are\nas follows: sudden onset of fever, chills, malaise, headache, or\nprostration accompanied by either painful regional lymphadenitis\n(bubonic plague) or cough with hemoptysis (pneumonic plague). Live _R. rattus_ species trapped in 2 affected\nvillages were found to have an average of 2 fleas per rat; recovery\nof more than 1 flea per rat has been associated with increased risk\nfor plague transmission (3). --------------\nAfrican countries accounted for nearly 90 percent of the 28 530\nplague cases reported to the World Health Organization during the\nmost recent 10-year reporting period (1994-2003) (4). On 8 Dec 2006, vector-control teams\ncomprised of local villagers began applying dichlorvos, a residual\ninsecticide, to households in affected villages in an effort to\ninterrupt plague transmission. \n\nWhile visiting villages, investigators in the 2 districts recovered 8\ndead rats (_Rattus rattus_), of which 4 tested positive for _Y.\npestis_ by direct fluorescent antibody staining and 2 tested positive\nby culture isolation. 23\npatients (59 percent) reported seeing dead rats in their homes during\nthe 2 weeks preceding their illness; some villagers reported recently\nfinding and burying dead rats near their homes. The overarching\ngoal of this multidisciplinary effort is to create effective\nprevention programs and develop and exercise local contingency plans\nfor plague outbreak response. Interviews with\nvillage residents indicated that the index case in that family was in\na boy aged 10 years who developed fever and a cervical bubo, followed\nby hemoptysis; he died on 3 Nov 2006. However,\nconvalescent sera from 5 (13 percent) of the 38 total patients with\nconvalescent samples had single titers that ranged from 1:16 to 1:256\n Patients\nwith less serious conditions might survive long enough to be tested;\nhowever, patients with more severe _Y. pestis_ infection are likely\nto die before specimens can be collected. In addition, clinicians at these\nfacilities and all other health clinics in Arua and Nebbi districts\nwere asked to report immediately by cellular telephone or messenger\nany new cases identified. Although human\ncases typically occur sporadically or in small clusters, the\npotential for pneumonic outbreaks with spread to other areas is a\ngreat concern (5,6). \n\nIn November 2006, the Uganda Ministry of Health received reports of\nan increase in bubonic plague cases and a possible outbreak of\npneumonic plague among residents in the Arua and Nebbi districts. Among the 102 patients with documented symptoms,\n90 (88 percent) had bubonic plague, and 12 (12 percent) had pneumonic\nplague. this investigation, a plague case was defined as clinically diagnosed\nplague with onset during 1 Jul 2006-30 Dec 2006, in a resident of\nArua or Nebbi districts. By 14 Dec 2006, the teams had treated\n935 houses in 10 Arua District villages that had reported 2 or more\nplague cases since 1 Sep 2006. 2 or more plague cases were reported from 9 different\nvillages, including 4 villages that reported 10 or more cases (Nave,\n18; Kestro, 18; Andosi, 17; and Yiapi, 10). 27 patients (69 percent) reported that\nthey walked to the local health clinic for treatment of plague\nsymptoms, and 12 (31 percent) rode a bicycle. 15 patients (38\npercent) said travel to the nearest health clinic took more than 2\nhours, and 24 patients (62 percent) said travel took 2 hours or less. Samples were not available from any of the 12 patients who\nreceived a diagnosis of pneumonic plague; 11 of these patients died\nbefore the investigation began. In Uganda,\n200-400 clinically diagnosed plague cases are reported annually, with\nan estimated case-fatality rate of 30 percent (4). When possible, diagnostic samples (that is,\nserum and bubo aspirates) were collected from patients with acute or\nrecent illness diagnosed as plague. Paired acute and convalescent\nblood samples were obtained from 7 (6 percent) of the 127 patients\nand convalescent blood samples alone from another 31 (24 percent). MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 2009; 58: 778-81 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5828a3.htm?s_cid=mm5828a3_e>\n\n\nBubonic and pneumonic plague - Uganda, 2006\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "malaria", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-03-25 00:00:00", "1954-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-11-25 00:00:00", "2045-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-12-08 00:00:00", "2006-09-01 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00", "1997-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-12-14 00:00:00", "2006-12-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Democratic Republic of the Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nebbi District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Geneva", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yiapi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lugbara", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "239524", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, tularemia, prairie dogs - USA (SD)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=239524", "date": "2009-07-12 11:00:05", "main_text": "PLAGUE, TULAREMIA, PRAIRIE DOGS - USA (SOUTH DAKOTA)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 11 Jul 20099\nSource: National Park Traverl.com [edited]\n<http://www.nationalparkstraveler.com/2009/07/update-sylvatic-plague-and-tularemia-afflict-prairie-dogs-badlands-national-park>\n\n\nOfficials have confirmed the presence of sylvatic plague and\ntularemia in Badlands National Park. That's bad news for the park's\nprairie dogs and black-footed ferrets, but visitors should be OK if\nthey use common sense safety precautions.\n\nSylvatic plague, which was 1st detected in South Dakota in 2004,\nturned up last year [2008] in the prairie dog population of the\nConata Basin just south of Badlands National Park. Since fleas spread\nplague from infected animals to healthy ones (and occasionally to\nhumans as well), officials ordered a flea suppression campaign that\nentailed applying insecticides to prairie dog colonies over an area\nof about 11 000 acres. In addition, black-footed ferrets were\ncaptured and given plague vaccinations. It was fervently hoped that\nthese measures would keep the disease from spreading to Badlands\nNational Park, which not only harbors many thousands of prairie dogs\nbut also a small and struggling population of endangered black-footed\nferrets that mainly feed on prairie dogs.\n\nAlas, about a week ago, wildlife biologists confirmed that the\nprairie dog population in the Sage Creek Wilderness Area of the park\nis being assaulted by sylvatic plague. Tularemia (rabbit fever) has\nalso been detected in one of the park's prairie dog colonies. Both\ndiseases sicken and kill prairie dogs, so this disease outbreak has\nthe potential to decimate the park's prairie dog population and\nperhaps undo much of the effort that's been invested in\nreestablishing black-footed ferrets there.\n\nAlthough few people in the U.S. have ever been infected by plague or\ntularemia, both diseases can be transmitted to humans and should be\nconsidered potentially dangerous. Park officials are advising\nvisitors to take these common sense safety precautions to minimize\nthe likelihood of infection:\n\n- Be aware that potentially dangerous diseases can be transmitted to\nhumans by way of ticks or bites and scratches, urine-contaminated\nwater, and the inhaling of infectious aerosols.\n- Apply DEET insect repellant to clothing and skin to avoid bites\nfrom fleas and ticks.\n- Avoid handling sick or dead animals in the park.\n- Do not allow pets to wander into prairie dog colonies where they\nmay come into contact with disease-carrying fleas.\n- See a doctor if you think that you may have been exposed to plague\nor tularemia.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[These are diseases spread by ground squirrels and other wild\nrodents, frequently in the western portion of the United States.\n'Sylvatic' means pertaining to the woods (sylvan). These are diseases\nspread by wild rodents, which serve as a reservoir for humans. In the\nwestern part of the US, they are often spread by prairie dogs, ground\nsquirrels and other small ground rodents. These diseases can happen\nalmost anywhere, but we frequently see the problems in the western\nregion of the US.\n\nPlague results from infection by _Yersinia pestis_, a non-motile,\nfacultatively intracellular, Gram negative rod (family _Enterobacteriaceae_).\n\nPlague is usually spread between rodents or humans by the bites of\ninfected fleas. Vectors include a variety of rodent fleas,\nparticularly the oriental rat flea (_Xenopsylla Cheopis_). In the\nU.S., the most common vector is _Oropsylla Montana_, a flea often\nfound on California ground squirrels, rock squirrels, and sometimes\nother rodents including prairie dogs. Human fleas (_Pulex irritans)_\nmay also carry _Y. pestis_. _Y. pestis_ is also present in the\ntissues and body fluids of infected animals; these bacteria can be\ntransmitted directly through mucous membranes and broken skin.\nAerosols from people or animals with the pneumonic form are\ninfectious, and animals may transmit bacteria in bites. Carnivores\noften become infected when they eat diseased rodents.\n\nPrairie dogs are considered to be sensitive indicators of plague and tularemia.\n\nTularemia results from infection by _Francisella tularensis_\n(formerly known as _Pasteurella tularensis_), a Gram negative,\nnon-motile coccobacillus. Two subspecies exist: _F. tularensis\ntularensis_ (also known as Jellison type A) and _F. tularensis\nholarctica_ (Jellison type B). _F. tularensis tularensis_ is found in\nlagomorphs in North America and is highly virulent for humans and\ndomestic rabbits; _F. tularensis holarctica_ is less virulent and\noccurs in beavers, muskrats and voles in North America and in hares\nand small rodents in Eurasia.\n\n_F. tularensis_ can be transmitted by ingestion, inhalation,\narthropod-borne transfer or direct contact through the skin and\nmucous membranes. Organisms are found in the blood and tissues of\ninfected animals and can survive for long periods on fomites\nincluding food and water. Aquatic animals may develop tularemia after\nbeing immersed in contaminated water. Carnivores sometimes become\ninfected after ingesting a contaminated carcass. Vectors for _F.\ntularensis tularensis_ include ticks (including _Dermacentor\nandersoni_, _D. variabilis_ and _Amblyomma americanum_) and biting\nflies (particularly deerflies). _F. tularensis holarctica_ is also\ntransmitted by mosquitoes in Russia. Rarely, the organism is spread\nby animal bites.\n\n_F. tularensis_ can survive for long periods in arthropod vectors and\nin the environment. Individual flies may carry the organism for 2\nweeks and ticks throughout their lifetimes. Viable bacteria can also\nbe found for weeks to months in the carcasses and hides of infected\nanimals and in fomites including grain dust, straw, water, soil and\nbedbugs. This organism is highly resistant to freezing; live\norganisms have been found after 3 years in rabbit meat stored at -15 C.\n\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from:\n<http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/Factsheets/pdfs/Tularemia.pdf> and\n<http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/factsheets/pdfs/plague.pdf>. - Mod.TG]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 11 Jul 20099\n Park officials are advising\nvisitors to take these common sense safety precautions to minimize\nthe likelihood of infection:\n\n- Be aware that potentially dangerous diseases can be transmitted to\nhumans by way of ticks or bites and scratches, urine-contaminated\nwater, and the inhaling of infectious aerosols. Since fleas spread\nplague from infected animals to healthy ones (and occasionally to\nhumans as well), officials ordered a flea suppression campaign that\nentailed applying insecticides to prairie dog colonies over an area\nof about 11 000 acres. (Jellison type B). _F. tularensis tularensis_ is found in\nlagomorphs in North America and is highly virulent for humans and\ndomestic rabbits; _F. tularensis holarctica_ is less virulent and\noccurs in beavers, muskrats and voles in North America and in hares\nand small rodents in Eurasia. Both\ndiseases sicken and kill prairie dogs, so this disease outbreak has\nthe potential to decimate the park's prairie dog population and\nperhaps undo much of the effort that's been invested in\nreestablishing black-footed ferrets there. It was fervently hoped that\nthese measures would keep the disease from spreading to Badlands\nNational Park, which not only harbors many thousands of prairie dogs\nbut also a small and struggling population of endangered black-footed\nferrets that mainly feed on prairie dogs. In the\nU.S., the most common vector is _Oropsylla Montana_, a flea often\nfound on California ground squirrels, rock squirrels, and sometimes\nother rodents including prairie dogs. Vectors for _F.\ntularensis tularensis_ include ticks (including _Dermacentor\nandersoni_, _D. variabilis_ and _Amblyomma americanum_) and biting\nflies (particularly deerflies). Viable bacteria can also\nbe found for weeks to months in the carcasses and hides of infected\nanimals and in fomites including grain dust, straw, water, soil and\nbedbugs. This organism is highly resistant to freezing; live\norganisms have been found after 3 years in rabbit meat stored at -15 C.\n\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from:\n<http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/Factsheets/pdfs/Tularemia.pdf> and\n<http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/factsheets/pdfs/plague.pdf>. \n\nSylvatic plague, which was 1st detected in South Dakota in 2004,\nturned up last year [2008] in the prairie dog population of the\nConata Basin just south of Badlands National Park. \n\nAlas, about a week ago, wildlife biologists confirmed that the\nprairie dog population in the Sage Creek Wilderness Area of the park\nis being assaulted by sylvatic plague. That's bad news for the park's\nprairie dogs and black-footed ferrets, but visitors should be OK if\nthey use common sense safety precautions. In the\nwestern part of the US, they are often spread by prairie dogs, ground\nsquirrels and other small ground rodents. Two subspecies exist: _F. tularensis\ntularensis_ (also known as Jellison type A) and _F. tularensis\nholarctica_ \n\n_F. tularensis_ can be transmitted by ingestion, inhalation,\narthropod-borne transfer or direct contact through the skin and\nmucous membranes.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eurasia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Dakota", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "218293", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, human - Mongolia: (BO), RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=218293", "date": "2009-06-12 19:00:06", "main_text": "PLAGUE, HUMAN - MONGOLIA: (BAYAN-OLGII), REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 11 Jun 2009\nFrom: Dan Silver\n<dgsilver@yahoo.com>\n\n\nPeople's Daily (<http://society.people.com.cn/GB/41158/9459758.html>)\nreports that a 14-year-old in Mongolia's Bayan-Olgii Province\ncontracted plague after eating marmot on 29 May 2009. Symptoms\nappeared on 2 Jun 2009.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Dan Silver\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED would appreciate more information regarding this case,\nconfirming the diagnosis and clinical presentation.\n\nPlague is endemic in Mongolia. Marmots such as the Tarvaga, the\nTarbagan or Mongolian Marmot, _Marmota sibirica_, a large rodent\nrelated to the American woodchuck (_M. monax_), are thought to be\nsignificant zoonotic reservoirs for _Y. pestis_ in Eastern Asia. The\nname marmot (<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marmot>) comes from French\nmarmotte, from Latin _mures monti_ 'mountain mouse.'\n\nA map of the country of Mongolia can be found at\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/mongolia.pdf>. The\nprovince of Bayan-Olgii is in the extreme western part of the country.\n- Mod.LL]\n\n[Roast marmot ('boodog' in Mongolian) is a popular dish there, some\nunlucky hunters catch plague every year. Recipes can be found at:\n<http://www.e-mongol.com/mongolia_culture_cooking-recipes.htm>\n- Mod.JW]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 11 Jun 2009\n Marmots such as the Tarvaga, the\nTarbagan or Mongolian Marmot, _Marmota sibirica_, a large rodent\nrelated to the American woodchuck (_M. monax_), are thought to be\nsignificant zoonotic reservoirs for _Y. pestis_ in Eastern Asia. People's Daily (<http://society.people.com.cn/GB/41158/9459758.html>)\nreports that a 14-year-old in Mongolia's Bayan-Olgii Province\ncontracted plague after eating marmot on 29 May 2009. The\nname marmot (<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marmot>) comes from French\nmarmotte, from Latin _mures monti_ 'mountain mouse.' Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Dan Silver\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-05-29 00:00:00", "2009-06-02 00:00:00"], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "154155", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, fatal - Algeria (04): NOT", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=154155", "date": "2009-02-06 18:00:45", "main_text": "PLAGUE, FATAL - ALGERIA (04): NOT\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 5 Feb 2009\nSource: The Mercury, South African Press Association (SAPA)/Agence\nFrance-Presse (AFP) report [edited]\n<http://www.themercury.co.za/index.php?fArticleId=4826359>\n\n\nPlague outbreak denied\n----------------------\nAlgeria has dismissed reports that about 40 Al-Qaeda militants were\nkilled by an outbreak of bubonic plague at a secret training camp in\nthe country.\n\n'No case of plague of any type has been recorded in any region of\nAlgeria since 2003,' the health ministry said.\n\nReports had suggested that an Al-Qaeda offshoot had been\nexperimenting with the plague to create a biological weapon.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Without confirmation, this thread is cut. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 5 Feb 2009\n ----------------------\nAlgeria has dismissed reports that about 40 Al-Qaeda militants were\nkilled by an outbreak of bubonic plague at a secret training camp in\nthe country. PLAGUE, FATAL - ALGERIA (04): NOT\n*********************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-02-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Algeria", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "231064", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, bubonic - Algeria: RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=231064", "date": "2009-07-01 16:00:09", "main_text": "PLAGUE, BUBONIC - ALGERIA: REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 29 Jun 2009\nSource: Free Republic, The Media Line report [edited]\n<http://www.freerepublic.com/focus/f-chat/2281642/posts>\n\n\nCountries in North Africa are boosting precautionary measures in heightened\nefforts to prevent bubonic plague from spreading to their territories.\nAccording to the London-based Al-Quds Al-'Arabi, Algeria has documented 50\ncases of the plague, some within 15 kilometres (9 miles) of the border with\nLibya, where 2 people have died of the disease. As a result, Algiers has\ntightened medical surveillance on its borders with Libya.\n\nOfficials there fear that Bedouin are crossing the borders from the Illizi\nprovince into Libya and passing the disease back into Algeria, according to\nlocal Algeria and Moroccan press.\n\nRodents in the area have been seen [found? - Mod.LL] bearing the disease,\nAphaluck Bhatiasevi, a spokeswoman for the World Health Organization (WHO),\ntold The Media Line. 'But it hasn't infected people for 25 years,' she\nsaid. 'They're still investigating the cause. It's likely exposure to\nfleas. It's not pneumonic plague, which can be transmitted from one person\nto the other. It stops at the person who gets infected.'\n\nHealth authorities in Egypt, Tunisia, Algeria, and Morocco are also taking\nextra measures to contain the disease, Al-Quds Al-'Arabi reported. Earlier\nin June 2009, Egypt closed its border with Libya following confirmed\nreports that around 13 people were infected with the bubonic plague in the\nLibyan coastal city Tubruq, 93 miles (150 km) from the Egyptian border.\n\nThe Libyan media reported between one and 3 fatalities from the disease,\nand Bhatiasevi said the Libyan authorities were being extremely supportive,\ncooperative and open with the investigation. She added that they have also\nlaunched awareness campaigns in the area.\n\nAlgeria and Libya share a border 982 kilometres (610 miles) long, and a\nlarge, unsupervised passage of people and goods flow through the border daily.\n\nSome believe the outbreak could be connected to the consumption of camel\nmeat or caused by camel fly bites. Outbreaks connected to the consumption\nof contaminated camel meat were reported in the past in Libya, Jordan, and\nmore recently in Saudi Arabia in 2005.\n\n[byline: Rachelle Kliger]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Susan Baekeland\n\n[Earlier this year (2009), ProMED-mail followed a possible outbreak of\nplague in Algeria that apparently was not. We would appreciate more\ninformation documenting this bacterial infection in Algeria and if the\ndisease has spread from eastern to western Libya. - Mod.LL\n\nAn administrative map of Algeria is available at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/africa/algeria_admin01.jpg> and the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at <http://healthmap.org/r/009O>. -\nSr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 29 Jun 2009\n Earlier\nin June 2009, Egypt closed its border with Libya following confirmed\nreports that around 13 people were infected with the bubonic plague in the\nLibyan coastal city Tubruq, 93 miles (150 km) from the Egyptian border. \n\n[byline: Rachelle Kliger]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Susan Baekeland\n\n According to the London-based Al-Quds Al-'Arabi, Algeria has documented 50\ncases of the plague, some within 15 kilometres (9 miles) of the border with\nLibya, where 2 people have died of the disease. \n\nThe Libyan media reported between one and 3 fatalities from the disease,\nand Bhatiasevi said the Libyan authorities were being extremely supportive,\ncooperative and open with the investigation. \n\nOfficials there fear that Bedouin are crossing the borders from the Illizi\nprovince into Libya and passing the disease back into Algeria, according to\nlocal Algeria and Moroccan press. LL\n\nAn administrative map of Algeria is available at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/africa/algeria_admin01.jpg> and the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at <http://healthmap.org/r/009O>. Source: Free Republic, The Media Line report [edited]\n<http://www.freerepublic.com/focus/f-chat/2281642/posts>\n\n\nCountries in North Africa are boosting precautionary measures in heightened\nefforts to prevent bubonic plague from spreading to their territories. Outbreaks connected to the consumption\nof contaminated camel meat were reported in the past in Libya, Jordan, and\nmore recently in Saudi Arabia in 2005.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-06-25 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "London", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jordan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Morocco", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Algeria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Libya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Algiers", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tunisia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "174637", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, rabbit - USA (NM)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=174637", "date": "2009-04-15 22:00:51", "main_text": "PLAGUE, RABBIT - USA (NEW MEXICO)\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 3 Apr 2009\nSource: Office of the Secretary, NM Dept. of Health [edited]\n\n\nThe New Mexico Department of Health's Scientific Laboratory confirmed\nplague in a rabbit from Santa Fe this week. The rabbit was found dead\non a private residence about 1/2 mile north of the Santa Fe National\nCemetery. This is the 1st indication of plague activity in Santa Fe\nCounty this year [2009]. The Department has also investigated a case\nof plague in a dog near Ojo Caliente in Rio Arriba County in February\n2009.\n\nIn New Mexico, there was one human case of plague in 2008 in an Eddy\nCounty man who got the disease from hunting rabbits. There were 5\nhuman plague cases with one fatality in 2007.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nPaul Ettestad <Paul.Ettestad@state.nm.us>\n\n[More information on plague in New Mexico can be found on the New\nMexico Department of Health's website:\n<http://www.health.state.nm.us/epi/plague.html>.\n\nOur thanks to Paul Ettestad. - Mod.MHJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 3 Apr 2009\n Communicated by:\nPaul Ettestad <Paul.Ettestad@state.nm.us>\n\n[More information on plague in New Mexico can be found on the New\nMexico Department of Health's website:\n<http://www.health.state.nm.us/epi/plague.html>. The Department has also investigated a case\nof plague in a dog near Ojo Caliente in Rio Arriba County in February\n2009. The rabbit was found dead\non a private residence about 1/2 mile north of the Santa Fe National\nCemetery.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-02-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2008-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Rio Arriba County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "232949", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, bubonic - Libya (02): (BN)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=232949", "date": "2009-07-03 15:00:06", "main_text": "PLAGUE, BUBONIC - LIBYA (02): (AL BUTNAN)\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 2 Jul 2009\nSource: Eurosurveillance edition 2009; 14(26) [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19258>\n\n\nPlague outbreak in the Libyan Arab Jamahiriya\n---------------------------------------------\n[Authors: A Tarantola, T Mollet, J Gueguen, P Barboza, E Bertherat]\n\nPlague is circulating regularly in localised areas worldwide, causing\nsporadic cases outside Africa and remains endemic or causes limited\noutbreaks in some African countries. Furthermore, some notable outbreaks\nhave been reported in Asia in the last 20 years. A limited outbreak with 5\ncases has recently been notified by the health authorities of the Libyan\nArab Jamahiriya.\n\nIntroduction\n------------\nPlague is a zoonosis caused by the bacillus _Yersinia pestis_. This disease\nmay have caused over 200 million deaths in the history of humanity (1). The\ndisease is principally transmitted from animal to animal by fleas. Humans\nusually become infected through the bite of an infected flea (mainly)\n_Xenopsylla cheopis_). The occurrence of bubonic plague cases is therefore\nthe result of the presence of fleas, rodents, and humans in a given place\nat a given time.\n\nSince the 1st description of what may have been a plague outbreak in 430 BC\nin Ancient Greece (2), the plague has spread worldwide during the course of\nseveral pandemic waves. Between 1998 and 2008, more than 23 278 cases were\nreported including 2116 fatalities (case fatality ratio, CFR, of\napproximately 9 per cent) in 11 countries (3). Over 95 per cent of the 23\n278 cases, however, were reported in Africa with well-identified endemic\nplague foci (mainly in 3 countries: Madagascar, the Democratic Republic of\nCongo [DRC], and Tanzania).\n\nThe bubonic plague is the most common form of the disease (93 per cent of\nplague cases in Madagascar (4) and 81 per cent of plague cases in the\nUnited States (US) (5). Without adequate treatment, the case-fatality rate\nof bubonic plague ranges from 50 to 90 per cent. Bubonic plague does not\ngive rise to direct human-to-human transmission.\n\nPulmonary plague is not the most frequent form of the disease (3 per cent\nof the plague cases in the US, 8 per cent in DRC, sometimes more frequent\nin outbreaks with sustained human-to-human transmission), but is deadly in\nalmost all cases in absence of adequate and timely treatment. This clinical\npresentation may give rise to human-to-human transmission through droplet\ntransmission. Available evidence points to effective prevention of\nhuman-to-human transmission of pneumonic plague through isolation and\ntreatment of cases and the observance of standard precautions completed by\ndroplet and contact precautions during healthcare (6,7). There is no\navailable vaccine for large-scale use.\n\nOutbreak report\n---------------\nOn 14 Jun 2009, the health authorities of the Libyan Arab Jamahiriya\nreported suspected cases of bubonic plague (including one death) to the\nWorld Health Organization in compliance with the Revised International\nHealth Regulations (IHR) [see ProMED-mail post Plague, bubonic - Libya:\n(BN) 20090616.2227].\n\nThe case definition proposed by the World Health Organization was used (8).\nThe outbreak occurred in a semi-nomadic setting. Subsequent epidemiological\ninvestigations by an international team ascertained a total of 5 cases. 3\nof these occurred in a family cluster in the Tobruk rural area (near the\nborder with Egypt). The 1st identified case was a child who presented with\npneumonic plague and died. 2 siblings were subsequently identified as\nhaving bubonic plague. 2 other epidemiologically unlinked cases occurred in\nyoung women living in the same district. Confirmatory testing is ongoing.\nRodent control measures have been implemented locally.\n\nThe last outbreak reported in the Maghreb to date occurred in Algeria in\nJuly 2008. At that time, the Algerian health authorities reported 4 cases\nincluding 3 fatalities in Laghouat [WHO, unpublished data]. All identified\ncases presented with bubonic plague. The last outbreak reported by the\nLibyan Ministry of Health occurred in 1984 with 8 cases of bubonic plague\n(no deaths) (1). The last deaths due to plague reported in that country\noccurred during a 1977 outbreak that affected 11 people (6 deaths).\n\nDiscussion and conclusion\n-------------------------\nThe implementation in 2007 of the revised IHR and improved surveillance in\nmany countries has strengthened communication between countries and WHO.\nRegional networks have also emerged which facilitate cross-border and\nregional exchange of public health alerts. The Libyan health authorities\nhave been prompt in describing and reporting the outbreak described here,\nthereby enabling speedy confirmation and the implementation of control\nmeasures.\n\nThe Maghreb is no longer considered an endemic area for plague (9). The\nrecent human plague clusters, however, raise the issue of the persistence\nof a large focus or of several limited natural foci, which have been\nquiescent for decades and remain capable of 're-emergence' at various dates\nand locations (Table, Figure [available at the source URL above]). These\nclusters of human cases are generally sporadic and limited, but they may\ncontinue to occur despite the necessary extensive rodent control measures,\nwhich will probably be insufficient to eradicate the plague reservoir in\nwild animals. Health care workers require training to better recognise\nsigns of a disease, which is no longer endemic. Informing and increasing\nawareness of populations living in and around plague foci, strengthening of\nlocal health systems and targeted public health measures around the cases\nremain the key control strategies in plague-prone areas. Improved knowledge\nof the natural foci is also a pre-requisite for any rational vector and\nrodent control.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. WHO. Plague Manual: Epidemiology, Distribution, Surveillance and Control\n(WHO/CDS/CSR/EDC/99/2/EN). Geneva: WHO; 1999. Available from\n<http://www.who.int/csr/resources/publications/plague/WHO_CDS_CSR_EDC_99_2_EN/en/index.html>.\n\n2. Thucydides. The History of the Peloponnesian War. Book II. 431 BC,\nChapter 47 to 54.\n3. Institut de Veille Sanitaire (InVS). Departement International et\nTropical. Peste. Situation mondiale. 8 Jan 2008. [Plague. World situation.\n8 Jan 2008]. Paris: InVS; 2008 [in French]. Available from\n<http://www.invs.sante.fr/international/notes/peste_final_2007.pdf>\n4. Institut Pasteur de Madagascar. Groupe d'Etudes sur la Peste. Atlas de\nla peste a Madagascar. [Atlas of the plague in Madagascar]. Montpellier:\nEditions IRD; 2006. [In French, available from\n<http://www.pasteur.mg/IMG/pdf/Atlas-Peste.pdf>.]\n5. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Human plague - four\nstates, 2006. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 2006; 55(34): 940-3. [Available\nfrom <http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5534a4.htm>.]\n6. Ratsitorahina M, Chanteau S, Rahalison L, Ratsifasoamanana L, Boisier P.\nEpidemiological and diagnostic aspects of the outbreak of pneumonic plague\nin Madagascar. Lancet 2000; 355 (9198): 111-3. [Abstract available from\n<http://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(99)05163-6/fulltext>.]\n\n7. Kool JL. Risk of person-to-person transmission of pneumonic plague. Clin\nInfect Dis 2005; 40(8): 1166-72. [Available from\n<http://www.nycosh.org/workplace_hazards/Biosafety/PlagueArticle4-05.pdf>.]\n8. WHO. International meeting on preventing and controlling plague: the old\ncalamity still has a future. Wkly Epidemiol Rec 2006; 81(28): 278-84.\n[Available from <http://www.who.int/wer/2006/wer8128.pdf>.]\n9. Mafart B, Brisou P, Bertherat E. Epidemiologie et prise en charge des\nepidemies de peste en Mediterranee au cours de la seconde guerre mondiale.\n[Epidemiology and management of plague outbreaks in the Mediterranean\nduring the Second World War]. Bull Soc Pathol Exot 2004; 97(4): 306-10.\n[Article in French, available from\n<http://www.vitaminedz.com/articlesfiche/0/308.pdf>].\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The title of the Eurosurveillance article above refers to the plague\noutbreak in Libyan Arab Jamahiriya, which is in part the official name for\nLibya (officially known as the Great Socialist People's Libyan Arab\nJamahiriya (<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Libya>). Table 1 in the\nEurosurveillance article above lists the occurrence of reported cases of\nconfirmed or probable plague in Algeria, Egypt, Libya, Morocco, and Tunisia\nsince January 1945, and the article's figure shows a map of this region of\nNorth Africa (see\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19258>).\n\nPortions of Algeria, Libya, Morocco, and Tunisia between the high ranges of\nthe Atlas Mountains and the Mediterranean Sea are collectively known as the\nMediterranean Maghreb and share an ecosystem of forests, woodlands, and\nscrub with many species of plants and animals in common\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maghreb#Mediterranean_Maghreb>). The region\nalso shares a culinary tradition; as mentioned in the prior ProMED-mail\npost on the current Libyan outbreak (Plague, bubonic - Libya: (BN)\n20090616.2227), several of the plague outbreaks in North Africa and the\nMiddle East have involved pharyngeal plague accompanied by cervical\nlymphadenopathy that followed consumption of raw or inadequately cooked\nmeat from infected animals, such as camels.\n\nThe authors of the Eurosurveillance article point out that the recent human\nplague cases in this region raise the issue of persistence of unknown\nnatural reservoirs of plague in wild animals, which may remain quiescent\nfor decades, but nevertheless are capable of 're-emergence' at various\ntimes and locations when spill-over into the human sphere occurs. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "Table 1 in the\nEurosurveillance article above lists the occurrence of reported cases of\nconfirmed or probable plague in Algeria, Egypt, Libya, Morocco, and Tunisia\nsince January 1945, and the article's figure shows a map of this region of\nNorth Africa (see\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19258>). A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 2 Jul 2009\n The authors of the Eurosurveillance article point out that the recent human\nplague cases in this region raise the issue of persistence of unknown\nnatural reservoirs of plague in wild animals, which may remain quiescent\nfor decades, but nevertheless are capable of 're-emergence' at various\ntimes and locations when spill-over into the human sphere occurs. These\nclusters of human cases are generally sporadic and limited, but they may\ncontinue to occur despite the necessary extensive rodent control measures,\nwhich will probably be insufficient to eradicate the plague reservoir in\nwild animals. The\nrecent human plague clusters, however, raise the issue of the persistence\nof a large focus or of several limited natural foci, which have been\nquiescent for decades and remain capable of 're-emergence' at various dates\nand locations (Table, Figure [available at the source URL above]). \n\nPulmonary plague is not the most frequent form of the disease (3 per cent\nof the plague cases in the US, 8 per cent in DRC, sometimes more frequent\nin outbreaks with sustained human-to-human transmission), but is deadly in\nalmost all cases in absence of adequate and timely treatment. \n\nPortions of Algeria, Libya, Morocco, and Tunisia between the high ranges of\nthe Atlas Mountains and the Mediterranean Sea are collectively known as the\nMediterranean Maghreb and share an ecosystem of forests, woodlands, and\nscrub with many species of plants and animals in common\n( Informing and increasing\nawareness of populations living in and around plague foci, strengthening of\nlocal health systems and targeted public health measures around the cases\nremain the key control strategies in plague-prone areas.
