[see ProMED-mail post Plague, bubonic - Libya:\n(BN) 20090616.2227]. The 1st identified case was a child who presented with\npneumonic plague and died.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1945-01-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "9198-03-25 00:00:00", "1977-03-25 00:00:00", "1984-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-06-14 00:00:00", "1999-03-25 00:00:00", "2008-01-08 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2008-07-25 00:00:00", "2008-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2116-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tanzania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Laghouat", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Portions", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brisou P", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Libya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Morocco", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tunisia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Algeria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "eurosurveillance", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tobruk", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the \n United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Paris", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "150045", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, fatal - Algeria (03): unconfirmed", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=150045", "date": "2009-01-26 14:00:46", "main_text": "PLAGUE, FATAL - ALGERIA (03): UNCONFIRMED\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sun 25 Jan 2009\nFrom: Martin Dirksen-Fischer <MartinDirksenFischer@gmx.de>\n\n\nAn article [<http://www.echoroukonline.com/eng/algeria/4667.html>]\nfrom Echorouk News (the paper that published the article about the\nplague outbreak a couple of days ago) quotes the leader of the\nSalafist Group of Preaching and Combat (GSPC) named Droudkel. He\ndenies the plague rumor.\n\n--\nDr Martin Dirksen-Fischer\nPublic Health Officer\nGrindelberg\nGermany\n<MartinDirksenFischer@gmx.de>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Dirksen-Fischer for his contribution. There\nmay have been political motivation behind the original newswire and\nthe information may well have been false. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sun 25 Jan 2009\n Dr Martin Dirksen-Fischer\nPublic Health Officer\nGrindelberg\nGermany\n<MartinDirksenFischer@gmx.de>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Dirksen-Fischer for his contribution.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2009-01-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Grindelberg", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "216957", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, fatal - USA (02): (NM) risk, prevention", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=216957", "date": "2009-06-11 13:00:08", "main_text": "PLAGUE, FATAL - USA (02): (NEW MEXICO) RISK, PREVENTION\n****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 10 Jun 2009\nFrom: Paul Ettestad <Paul.Ettestad@state.nm.us>\n\n\nThe 3rd human case of plague (_Yersinia pestis_) from New Mexico in\n2009 has been confirmed and only 1 week after the 1st 2 cases. All 3\ncases were most likely exposed via fleabite due to their clinical\npresentations of bubonic plague. Though we will never know the exact\nexposure, one of the risk factors in the 1st 2 cases was that the\nfamily dog was allowed to roam and hunt and then sleep in bed with\nthe children. No flea control products were used on the dog.\n\nThis type of risk has been seen in other human cases in past years\nand serves as a reminder to emphasize flea control product use on\npets, even in dry areas. These are not the typical dog and cat fleas,\nbut plague-infected rodent fleas from various animal species (prairie\ndogs, rock squirrels, wood rats, etc) that may be involved in a\nplague outbreak. The rodent fleas will transiently move to other\nanimals (dogs, cats, etc) from their preferred rodent host when it\ndies, and can be brought into the home by pets that are allowed to\nroam and hunt.\n\nNorth-central New Mexico is having a cooler and wetter late spring\nwhich allows infected fleas to survive longer and to move to the\nburrow entrances after their host rodent has died from plague without\nbeing prone to desiccation in the usual hot and dry environment. This\nincreases the risk that people and pets walking near the burrow\nentrances may have infected fleas jump onto them to try and take a blood meal.\n\n--\nPaul Ettestad DVM, MS\nState Public Health Veterinarian\nEpidemiology and Response Division\nNew Mexico Department of Health\nUSA\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Ettestad for his first-hand information and\nthe inclusion of the news release from the State Department of\nHealth, dated 10 Jun 2009:\n\nState confirms 3rd human plague case from Santa Fe County\nAnimal cases also confirmed in Taos and Santa Fe Counties\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe New Mexico Department of Health confirmed today [10 Jun 2009] a\n3rd case of bubonic plague in Santa Fe County so far in 2009. A\n56-year-old man was hospitalized and is back home recovering. The\nDepartment of Health is conducting an environmental investigation at\nthe man's residence to determine if there is any ongoing risk to people.\n\nThe Department also confirmed a plague case in a dog from north of\nthe city of Taos and a cat case from the Arroyo Hondo area southeast\nof the city of Santa Fe. Earlier this month [June 2009] the\nDepartment reported a fatal case in an 8-year-old Santa Fe County boy\nand a case in his 10-year-old sister who recovered. There have been a\ntotal of 3 human cases in New Mexico, all in Santa Fe County, so far in 2009.\n\nTo prevent cases of plague, the Department of Health recommends\n- Avoid sick or dead rodents.\n- Teach children not to play near rodent nests or burrows.\n- Treat pets regularly with an effective flea control product.\n- Clean up areas near the house where rodents could live.\n- Keep pets from roaming and hunting.\n- Sick pets should be examined promptly by a veterinarian.\n\nSymptoms in cats and dogs are similar to humans. Fever, lethargy, not\neating, and swollen lymph nodes (usually in the neck area) are the\nmost common signs.\n\nThere was one human case of plague in 2008 in an Eddy County man.\nThere were 5 human cases of plague in Bernalillo, San Juan, Santa Fe,\nand Torrance counties in 2007 with a fatality. 8 human plague cases\noccurred in New Mexico in 2006 with 3 fatalities.'\n\nThe southwestern state of New Mexico can be located on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the US at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00bF>.\nA map of the state of New Mexico showing the location of Santa Fe and\nthe other counties mentioned in the posting can be found at\n<http://quickfacts.census.gov/qfd/maps/new_mexico_map.html>. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 10 Jun 2009\n New Mexico Department of Health\nUSA\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Ettestad for his first-hand information and\nthe inclusion of the news release from the State Department of\nHealth, dated 10 Jun 2009:\n\nState confirms 3rd human plague case from Santa Fe County\n These are not the typical dog and cat fleas,\nbut plague-infected rodent fleas from various animal species (prairie\ndogs, rock squirrels, wood rats, etc) that may be involved in a\nplague outbreak. \n\nNorth-central New Mexico is having a cooler and wetter late spring\nwhich allows infected fleas to survive longer and to move to the\nburrow entrances after their host rodent has died from plague without\nbeing prone to desiccation in the usual hot and dry environment. The rodent fleas will transiently move to other\nanimals (dogs, cats, etc) from their preferred rodent host when it\ndies, and can be brought into the home by pets that are allowed to\nroam and hunt. Though we will never know the exact\nexposure, one of the risk factors in the 1st 2 cases was that the\nfamily dog was allowed to roam and hunt and then sleep in bed with\nthe children. \n\nThis type of risk has been seen in other human cases in past years\nand serves as a reminder to emphasize flea control product use on\npets, even in dry areas. \nThe New Mexico Department of Health confirmed today [10 Jun 2009] a\n3rd case of bubonic plague in Santa Fe County so far in 2009. Earlier this month [June 2009] the\nDepartment reported a fatal case in an 8-year-old Santa Fe County boy\nand a case in his 10-year-old sister who recovered. The Department also confirmed a plague case in a dog from north of\nthe city of Taos and a cat case from the Arroyo Hondo area southeast\nof the city of Santa Fe. This\nincreases the risk that people and pets walking near the burrow\nentrances may have infected fleas jump onto them to try and take a blood meal. All 3\ncases were most likely exposed via fleabite due to their clinical\npresentations of bubonic plague.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2008-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-06-25 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Santa Fe County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arroyo Hondo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santa Fe", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bernalillo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eddy County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Juan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "213091", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, fatal - USA: (NM) bubonic", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=213091", "date": "2009-06-05 14:00:08", "main_text": "PLAGUE, FATAL - USA: (NEW MEXICO) BUBONIC\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 4 Jun 2009\nSource: C-Health, Associated Press (AP) report [edited]\n<http://chealth.canoe.ca/channel_health_news_details.asp?news_id=28186&news_channel_id=131&channel_id=131>\n\n\nNew Mexico boy dies of plague, sister recovering\n------------------------------------------------\nAn 8-year-old New Mexico boy has died and his 10-year-old sister was\nhospitalized after both contracted bubonic plague, the 1st recorded\nhuman plague cases in the USA so far in 2009. New Mexico health\nofficials did not immediately say Thursday [4 Jun 2009] how the\nbrother and sister contracted the infectious disease, but they are\nconducting an investigation at the family's residence to determine if\nthere is any risk to other people.\n\nPlague is generally transmitted to humans through the bites of\ninfected fleas, but also can be transmitted by direct contact with\ninfected animals, including rodents, rabbits, and pets.\n\nThe Health Department, citing privacy concerns, would not release the\nname of the siblings or give a location for their home, other than\nsaying it was in Santa Fe County. Spokeswoman Deborah Busemeyer said\nthe boy died in the last couple of days but she declined to be more\nspecific.\n\nFleas collected from the area are being sent to the CDC for testing.\nHealth workers also canvassed the neighborhood to tell other\nresidents that plague had been confirmed in the area.\n\nThe CDC says an average of 10 to 15 persons contract the plague each\nyear in the USA. Modern antibiotics are an effective treatment.\n\n[Byline: Susan Montoya Bryan]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nEdward McSweegan, PhD\nNational Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases\nBethesda, MD\nUSA\n<McSweegan@nih.gov>\n\n[Photo of inguinal buboes at\n<http://www.bt.cdc.gov/agent/plague/trainingmodule/images/lesson_graphics/2.2_Inguinal_Bubo_Large.JPG> -\nMod.JW]\n\n[It is probable, but not clearly stated that the siblings were\nco-primary cases; that is, they both acquired the infection from flea\nbites.\n\nAs outlined by the CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvbid/plague/diagnosis.htm>:\n'Death from bubonic plague occurs after the bacterium _Yersinia\npestis_ escapes from the infected bubo into the bloodstream\n(septicemic plague) causing the manifestations of the sepsis\nsyndrome. Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) with\nsubsequent cutaneous hemorrhage may well have been what was called\nthe 'Black Death' in the Middle Ages. The bacterium can spread to the\nlungs, causing a secondary plague pneumonia (secondary to the\nbacteremia), or to the meninges, causing a plague meningitis. Both of\nthese events have a high case fatality rate and the secondary plague\npneumonia is the way the infection spreads (by aerosol) from person\nto person.\n\n'The typical sign of the most common form of human plague is a\nswollen and very tender lymph gland, accompanied by pain. The swollen\ngland is called a 'bubo.' Bubonic plague should be suspected when a\nperson develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme\nexhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected\nrodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person usually becomes ill with bubonic\nplague 2 to 6 days after being infected.\n\n'When bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the\nbloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they\nspread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal\ncondition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes\nthe pneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The\ninfected person may experience high fever, chills, cough, and\nbreathing difficulty and may expel bloody sputum. If plague patients\nare not given specific antibiotic therapy, the disease can progress\nrapidly to death. About 14 per cent (1 in 7) of all plague cases in\nthe United States are fatal.'\n\nCases of plague in feral animals and therefore in humans are unusual\nin a calendar year, although the disease may occur at any time.\nProMED-mail has posted a case of human plague from New Mexico in\nJanuary 2000 (Plague, bubonic, human - USA (New Mexico)\n20000127.0138). However, in the past 4 years, 1st cases posted in the\nUSA were May 2004, May 2005, February 2006, April 2007, and January\n2008.\n\nThe southwestern state of New Mexico can be located on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the US at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00bF>.\nA map of the state of New Mexico showing the location of Santa Fe\ncounty mentioned in the posting can be found at\n<http://quickfacts.census.gov/qfd/maps/new_mexico_map.html>. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "As outlined by the CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvbid/plague/diagnosis.htm>:\n'Death from bubonic plague occurs after the bacterium _Yersinia\npestis_ escapes from the infected bubo into the bloodstream\n(septicemic plague) causing the manifestations of the sepsis\nsyndrome. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 4 Jun 2009\n New Mexico health\nofficials did not immediately say Thursday [4 Jun 2009] how the\nbrother and sister contracted the infectious disease, but they are\nconducting an investigation at the family's residence to determine if\nthere is any risk to other people.\n\n \nProMED-mail has posted a case of human plague from New Mexico in\nJanuary 2000 (Plague, bubonic, human - USA (New Mexico)\n20000127.0138). Bubonic plague should be suspected when a\nperson develops a swollen gland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme\nexhaustion, and has a history of possible exposure to infected\nrodents, rabbits, or fleas. Both of\nthese events have a high case fatality rate and the secondary plague\npneumonia is the way the infection spreads (by aerosol) from person\nto person. An 8-year-old New Mexico boy has died and his 10-year-old sister was\nhospitalized after both contracted bubonic plague, the 1st recorded\nhuman plague cases in the USA so far in 2009. Communicated by:\nEdward McSweegan, PhD\nNational Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases\n The bacterium can spread to the\nlungs, causing a secondary plague pneumonia (secondary to the\nbacteremia), or to the meninges, causing a plague meningitis. Plague is generally transmitted to humans through the bites of\ninfected fleas, but also can be transmitted by direct contact with\ninfected animals, including rodents, rabbits, and pets. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they\nspread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal\ncondition. If plague patients\nare not given specific antibiotic therapy, the disease can progress\nrapidly to death. JW]\n\n[It is probable, but not clearly stated that the siblings were\nco-primary cases; that is, they both acquired the infection from flea\nbites. New Mexico boy dies of plague, sister recovering\n------------------------------------------------\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2005-05-25 00:00:00", "2008-01-25 00:00:00", "2004-05-25 00:00:00", "2007-04-25 00:00:00", "2006-02-25 00:00:00", "2000-01-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santa Fe County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "221049", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, bubonic - Libya: (BN)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=221049", "date": "2009-06-16 20:00:10", "main_text": "PLAGUE, BUBONIC - LIBYA: (AL BUTNAN)\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 16 Jun 2009\nSource: Reuters [edited]\n<http://www.reuters.com/article/healthNews/idUSTRE55F42820090616>\n\n\nLibyan authorities have reported an outbreak of bubonic plague in the\nMediterranean coastal town of Tubruq, and the World Health\nOrganization (WHO) was sending a team to investigate, a WHO official\nsaid on Tuesday [16 Jun 2009].\n\nThe cases, approximately 16 to 18 have been reported, would be the\n1st in more than 2 decades in Libya of the disease known in medieval\ntimes as the Black Death, according to John Jabbour, a Cairo-based\nemerging diseases specialist at WHO.\n\n'It is reported as bubonic plague,' Jabbour said, adding WHO still\ndidn't have 'a full picture' of the situation. 'It is officially\nreported by Libya... Tomorrow [17 Jun 2009], the WHO is deploying a\nmission to Libya to investigate the whole situation, to see how many\nof the cases are confirmed, or not confirmed.'\n\nHe said preliminary information from Libyan authorities showed 16 to\n18 reported cases including one death, and that Tripoli had asked for\nassistance from the global health body.\n\nTubruq, where the new cases were reported, is approximately 125 km\n[78 miles] from the Egyptian border and was the scene of previous\nplague cases decades ago, Jabbour said. Egypt, already fighting to\ncontain an outbreak of the H1N1 flu virus, said it had no reported\ncases of plague.\n\nGlobally the WHO reports about 1000 to 3000 plague cases each year,\nwith most in the last 5 years occurring in Madagascar, Tanzania,\nMozambique, Malawi, Uganda and the Democratic Republic of Congo. The\nUSA sees about 10 to 20 cases each year.\n\n[Byline: Cynthia Johnston]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Tobruk or Tubruq is a town, seaport, and peninsula in northeastern\nLibya, near the border with Egypt, in North Africa. It is the capital\nof Al Butnan District (formerly Tobruk District). Its location can be\nfound on a map at:\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tobruk>\n\nConsumption of the meat of an infected camel has been reported to\ncause plague in Libya in 1976 (1). The abstract of the paper is:\n'In 1976, in a small, remote Libyan village, an apparently sick camel\nwas slaughtered and skinned, and the camel meat was distributed for\nhuman comsumption. A few days later, 15 villagers suffered a severe\nfebrile illness. Of the 5 individuals who had participated in the\nkilling and dispensation of the camel, all were dead within 4 days.\nWhen samples of serum from 9 of the remaining patients were examined,\n7 were found to be positive for plague as determined by the passive\nhemagglutination test. Another 6 persons became ill after killing 2\ngoats, and the serum of one goat contained antibodies to _Yersinia\npestis_. Because all of the remaining patients except one were\ntreated early enough, they recovered. These incidents confirm\nprevious reports that the camel and the goat are susceptible to\nnaturally occurring plague infection and have a significant role in\nthe dissemination of human plague.'\n\nTwo more recent outbreaks in the Arab world have been reported in\n2005. In Saudi Arabia (2), a cluster of 5 plague cases were reported\nincluding 4 with severe pharyngitis and submandibular lymphadenitis.\nThese 4 case-patients had eaten raw camel liver. _Yersinia pestis_\nwas isolated from bone marrow of the camel and from jirds (_Meriones\nlibycus_) and fleas (_Xenopsylla cheopis_) captured at the camel\ncorral. In Jordon (3), a 1997 outbreak of plague was reported,\nassociated with cervical lymphadenopathy and fever, occurred in the\nJordanian village of Azraq ad-Druze, 50 km [31 miles] west of the\nborder with Saudi Arabia. The 12 cases who presented at hospital were\ninitially assumed to have tularaemia, and all were successfully\ntreated with gentamicin. But all 12 were found to have anti-_Y.\npestis_ IgM. 11 of the 12 patients reported that, 2-4 days before\ntheir symptoms appeared, they had eaten the meat cut from the carcass\nof the same camel, either raw (10 cases) or cooked (one case). All 12\npatients were diagnosed as cases of pharyngeal plague (the 1st cases\nof plague reported in Jordan for more than 80 years), caused by _Y.\npestis_ that most had acquired when they ate raw meat from a camel\nthat was infected with the pathogen.\n\nThe source of the cases of bubonic plague in northeastern Libya is\nnot reported in this posting but may be related to camels and camel\nfleas.\n\n1. Christie AB, Chen TH, Elberg SS. Plague in camels and goats: their\nrole in human epidemics. J Infect Dis 1980;141: 724-726.\n2. Bin Saeed AA, Al-Hamdan NA, Fontaine RE: Plague from eating raw\ncamel liver. Emerg Infect Dis. 2005;11: 1456-1457.\n3. Arbaji A, Kharabsheh S, Al-Azab S, et al: A 12-case outbreak of\npharyngeal plague following the consumption of camel meat, in\nnorth-eastern Jordan. Ann Trop Med Parasitol. 2005;99: 789-793.\n- Mod.LL]", "summary": "All 12\npatients were diagnosed as cases of pharyngeal plague (the 1st cases\nof plague reported in Jordan for more than 80 years), caused by _Y.\npestis_ that most had acquired when they ate raw meat from a camel\nthat was infected with the pathogen. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 16 Jun 2009\n But all 12 were found to have anti-_Y.\npestis_ IgM. 11 of the 12 patients reported that, 2-4 days before\ntheir symptoms appeared, they had eaten the meat cut from the carcass\nof the same camel, either raw (10 cases) or cooked (one case). Its location can be\nfound on a map at:\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tobruk>\n\nConsumption of the meat of an infected camel has been reported to\ncause plague in Libya in 1976 (1). \n\nThe cases, approximately 16 to 18 have been reported, would be the\n1st in more than 2 decades in Libya of the disease known in medieval\ntimes as the Black Death, according to John Jabbour, a Cairo-based\nemerging diseases specialist at WHO. These incidents confirm\nprevious reports that the camel and the goat are susceptible to\nnaturally occurring plague infection and have a significant role in\nthe dissemination of human plague.' In Jordon (3), a 1997 outbreak of plague was reported,\nassociated with cervical lymphadenopathy and fever, occurred in the\nJordanian village of Azraq ad-Druze, 50 km [31 miles] west of the\nborder with Saudi Arabia. _Yersinia pestis_\nwas isolated from bone marrow of the camel and from jirds (_Meriones\nlibycus_) and fleas (_Xenopsylla cheopis_) captured at the camel\ncorral. \n\nThe source of the cases of bubonic plague in northeastern Libya is\nnot reported in this posting but may be related to camels and camel\nfleas. In Saudi Arabia (2), a cluster of 5 plague cases were reported\nincluding 4 with severe pharyngitis and submandibular lymphadenitis.\n Egypt, already fighting to\ncontain an outbreak of the H1N1 flu virus, said it had no reported\ncases of plague. Arbaji A, Kharabsheh S, Al-Azab S, et al: A 12-case outbreak of\npharyngeal plague following the consumption of camel meat, in\nnorth-eastern Jordan. He said preliminary information from Libyan authorities showed 16 to\n18 reported cases including one death, and that Tripoli had asked for\nassistance from the global health body. In 1976, in a small, remote Libyan village, an apparently sick camel\nwas slaughtered and skinned, and the camel meat was distributed for\nhuman comsumption. Globally the WHO reports about 1000 to 3000 plague cases each year,\nwith most in the last 5 years occurring in Madagascar, Tanzania,\nMozambique, Malawi, Uganda and the Democratic Republic of Congo. When samples of serum from 9 of the remaining patients were examined,\n7 were found to be positive for plague as determined by the passive\nhemagglutination test. Tomorrow [17 Jun 2009], the WHO is deploying a\nmission to Libya to investigate the whole situation, to see how many\nof the cases are confirmed, or not confirmed.' The 12 cases who presented at hospital were\ninitially assumed to have tularaemia, and all were successfully\ntreated with gentamicin. Mediterranean coastal town of Tubruq, and the World Health\nOrganization (WHO) was sending a team to investigate, a WHO official\nsaid on Tuesday [16 Jun 2009]. Another 6 persons became ill after killing 2\ngoats, and the serum of one goat contained antibodies to _Yersinia\npestis_. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\n'It is reported as bubonic plague,' Jabbour said, adding WHO still\ndidn't have 'a full picture' of the situation. ' \n\nTubruq, where the new cases were reported, is approximately 125 km\n [78 miles] from the Egyptian border and was the scene of previous\nplague cases decades ago, Jabbour said. Libyan authorities have reported an outbreak of bubonic plague in the\n Bin Saeed AA, Al-Hamdan NA, Fontaine RE: Plague from eating raw\ncamel liver. \n\nTwo more recent outbreaks in the Arab world have been reported in\n2005.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-06-17 00:00:00", "1997-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "1976-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-06-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Malawi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tobruk District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Libya", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jordan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cairo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jordon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Azraq", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tripoli", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tanzania", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "147422", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, fatal - Algeria", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=147422", "date": "2009-01-19 22:00:43", "main_text": "PLAGUE, FATAL - ALGERIA\n************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 19 Jan 2009\nSource: United Press International [edited]\n<http://www.upi.com/Top_News/2009/01/19/Report_Plague_killing_al-Qaida_terrorists/UPI-88691232390982/>\n\n\nA number of al-Qaida militants in training have been killed by\nplague, the disease believed to have ravaged Europe in the Middle\nAges. At least 40 al-Qaida followers have died since the disease\nswept through a training camp in Algeria, as was reported on Monday\n[19 Jan 2009]. The deaths became known when security forces found a\nbody beside a road.\n\nThe victims were associated with 'al-Qaida in the Land of the Islamic\nMaghreb,' the largest and most powerful al-Qaida group outside the\nMiddle East. Al-Qaida leaders said they fear the plague has spread to\nother cells or to Taliban fighters in Afghanistan. The epidemic began\nin the hideouts of AQLIM (al-Qaida in the Land of the Islamic\nMaghreb) in Algiers, sources said. The group fled to Bejaia and Jijel\nprovinces.\n\n--\nCommunicated by\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Whether person-to-person spread of _Y. pestis_ via pneumonic plague,\nthe only form of human plague transmissible between people, has\noccurred is not clear.\n\nThe outbreak has been reported to have occurred in Tizi Ouzou\nprovince, 150 km east of the capital Algiers. In June 2003, an\noutbreak of plague emerged in the Oran area of Algeria. During the\nfollowing weeks, a total of 11 confirmed and 7 suspected cases of\nplague were reported from the same area. All cases were bubonic\nplague; septicemia and coma later developed in 2 patients. According\nto national health records, the last outbreak in Oran was in 1946,\nand the last human cases of plague occurred in Algeria in 1950 (1).\n\nThe 2003 outbreak brought to mind the novel written by Nobel\nPrize-winning novelist Albert Camus, 'The Plague,' which chronicled a\n1940s plague outbreak in Oran, Algeria, which began with a rat\ndie-off in and around the apartment building of the protagonist Dr.\nBernard Rieux.\n\nReference:\n1. Bitam I, Baziz B, Rolain J-M, et al: Zoonotic focus of Plague,\nAlgeria. Emrg Infect Dis 2006; 12: 1975-1977.\n\nG Bennett-Williams, Ch Akula and ProMED Rapporteur Susan Baekeland\ncontributed versions of this ongoing story. - Mod.LL]\n\nFor maps of Algeria, see\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/africa/algeria_pol01.jpg> and\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/africa/algeria_admin01.jpg>.\n\nFor the interactive HealthMap/ProMED map with links to recent ProMED\npostings on events in Algeria and neighboring countries, see\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?v=28.2,2.6,5>. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 19 Jan 2009\n \n\nThe 2003 outbreak brought to mind the novel written by Nobel\nPrize-winning novelist Albert Camus, 'The Plague,' which chronicled a\n1940s plague outbreak in Oran, Algeria, which began with a rat\ndie-off in and around the apartment building of the protagonist Dr.\nBernard Rieux. Communicated by\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Whether person-to-person spread of _Y. pestis_ via pneumonic plague,\nthe only form of human plague transmissible between people, has\noccurred is not clear. Available from\n<http://www.cdc.gov/EID/content/13/10/1459.htm>.\n\n--\nDr Saada Chougrani\nUniversity of Oran, Algeria\n<labsis@gmail.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Chougrani for his comments regarding the\nreport of an outbreak of _Yersinia pestis_. It is certainly possible\nthat this is not a plague outbreak. ProMED would certainly like to\nhave more information regarding the etiology of this reported\ncluster, whether naturally occurring or not. - Mod.LL]\n\n[For maps of Algeria, see:\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/africa/algeria_pol01.jpg> and\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/africa/algeria_admin01.jpg>.\n\nFor the interactive HealthMap/ProMED map with links to recent ProMED\npostings on events in Algeria and neighboring countries, see\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?v=28.2,2.6,5>. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 20 Jan 2009\n No serious\nsource, health professionals, even more the reference laboratory for\nplague in Oran (Laboratory for the Plague of the Institute Pasteur of\nAlgeria in Oran) or that of in Algiers (medical bacteriology) had to\ntake seriously these rumors. For the interactive HealthMap/ProMED map with links to recent ProMED\npostings on events in Algeria and neighboring countries, see\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?v=28.2,2.6,5>.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-01-06 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-01-20 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Algeria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Algiers", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oran", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "134133", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Peru: (LAM), potential for outbreak", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=134133", "date": "2008-12-08 15:00:39", "main_text": "PLAGUE - PERU: (LAMBAYEQUE), POTENTIAL FOR OUTBREAK\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 5 Dec 2008\nSource: Andina, Agencia Peruana de Noticias [in Spanish, trans. Mod.JG]\n[edited]\n<http://www.andina.com.pe/Espanol/Noticia.aspx?Id=hAz1a4CRhtM=>\n\n\nMr Manuel Aguinaga-Perez, mayor of Oyotun, reported today [3 Dec 2008] that\nthe city council of Oyotun, a district located 83 km (52 miles) east from\nChiclayo [capital city of Lambayeque Department on the northern Peruvian\ncoast], is declaring an emergency alert because of the risk for a potential\noutbreak of bubonic plague as a result of the presence of a 'massive'\nnumber of rats that have destroyed 360 hectares (890 acres) of crops in\nthis area.\n\nMr Aguinaga reported that specialists from the Ministry of Health had found\nup to 25 Asiatic rat fleas (_Xenopsylla cheopis_), vectors of bubonic\nplague, per rat. For this reason, he declared that they fear the occurrence\nof an outbreak of plague. A similar situation occurred 14 years ago in\nMorrope District, where more than 100 people died. 'This phenomenon alarmed\nlocal health authorities, and we are working alongside every involved area\nin order to prevent the occurrence of a deadly epidemic,' he declared.\n\nEven though Mr Aguinaga pointed out that to date not a single case of\nplague has been reported in Oyotun, he said 'there is a potential threat\nthat may expand and burst like a flame, and this is an important reason for\nconcern.' He indicated that the communities of Campo Nuevo, Zorronto, Pan\nde Azucar, Macuaco, and Espinal had lost about 360 hectares of crops,\nmainly cornfields, because of the massive presence of rats, and this has\ncaused serious economical problems for local farmers.\n\n'We are requesting from the regional government financial support,\nparticularly seeds for affected farmers,' Mr Aguinaga added; and he\nobserved that the presence of a massive rat invasion had been reported\nsince last June [2008], and now has spread to the higher parts of the district.\n\nMr Aguinaga pointed out that, under the leadership of the Ministry of\nHealth, a coordinated plan was elaborated with the participation of the\nAgricultural sector and the district municipality, since massive rodent\nelimination may lead fleas to feed on other warm-blooded mammals.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-ESP\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[To this point, there has been no identification of the bacterial cause of\nplague, _Yersinia pestis_, in the rodents or the rodent fleas. Given the\nlarge number of rats in the area, however, concern about the possibility of\nan outbreak of plague is not unreasonable.\n\nLambayeque can be found on the maps of Peru at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lambayeque_Region> and the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?g=3694197&v=-6.852,-74.304,5>. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "[3 Dec 2008] that\nthe city council of Oyotun, a district located 83 km (52 miles) east from\nChiclayo [capital city of Lambayeque Department on the northern Peruvian\ncoast], is declaring an emergency alert because of the risk for a potential\noutbreak of bubonic plague as a result of the presence of a 'massive'\nnumber of rats that have destroyed 360 hectares (890 acres) of crops in\nthis area. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 5 Dec 2008\n \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-ESP\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[To this point, there has been no identification of the bacterial cause of\nplague, _Yersinia pestis_, in the rodents or the rodent fleas. \n\n'We are requesting from the regional government financial support,\nparticularly seeds for affected farmers,' Mr Aguinaga added; and he\nobserved that the presence of a massive rat invasion had been reported\nsince last June [2008], and now has spread to the higher parts of the district. \n\nEven though Mr Aguinaga pointed out that to date not a single case of\nplague has been reported in Oyotun, he said 'there is a potential threat\nthat may expand and burst like a flame, and this is an important reason for\nconcern.' He indicated that the communities of Campo Nuevo, Zorronto, Pan\nde Azucar, Macuaco, and Espinal had lost about 360 hectares of crops,\nmainly cornfields, because of the massive presence of rats, and this has\ncaused serious economical problems for local farmers.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Peru", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Zorronto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Macuaco", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "139279", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, fatal - Uganda (02): (AW, NE)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=139279", "date": "2008-12-23 12:00:40", "main_text": "PLAGUE - FATAL - UGANDA (02): (ARUA, NEBBI)\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sat 20 Dec 2008\nSource: The East African [edited]\n<http://www.theeastafrican.co.ke/news/-/2558/504736/-/rm3wy3z/-/>\n\n\nThe death toll from bubonic plague in Uganda continues to rise as the\ngovernment struggles to come up with a clear response even though\nearly signs of the disease were detected at the beginning of 2008. At\nleast 68 people have died since February 2008 when the plague was 1st\nreported, and now health experts warn that it could spread rapidly in\nthe absence of an adequate response from health workers and local\ncommunities. About 32 000 people are at risk of acquiring the disease\nif they do not take precautions.\n\nThe outbreak was initially restricted to one district but has now\nspread to 2 others, where 73 cases have been reported. Arua District\nHealth Officer Dr Patrick Anguzu said the area has been registering a\nfew cases every year, but this year the numbers started rising,\nreaching alarming levels in August 2008.\n\nDr William Mbabazi of the World Health Organization said the rising\nrates are due to poor hygiene and sanitation because people do not\nclean their houses, allowing bacteria-infected wild rats to find a\nconducive environment in dirty homes, spreading the infected fleas.\nDomestic rats then picking the fleas and due to their contact with\nhumans, the fleas pass on the disease.\n\nThe plague, which mainly affects women and children, has spread into\nthe districts of Arua and Nebbi, where residents still live in mud\nhuts. The WHO says the casualties in these districts are victims of a\ncultural belief that women and children must sleep on the floor while\nthe men sleep on beds.\n\n[Byline: Eve Mashoo]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Arua and Nebbi are endemic for plague and are located in\nnorthwestern Uganda as can be seen on a map at:\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/uganda.pdf>. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Uganda is available at:\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?g=443328&g=443360&v=2,31.167,5>. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Sat 20 Dec 2008\n At\nleast 68 people have died since February 2008 when the plague was 1st\nreported, and now health experts warn that it could spread rapidly in\nthe absence of an adequate response from health workers and local\ncommunities. \n\nDr William Mbabazi of the World Health Organization said the rising\nrates are due to poor hygiene and sanitation because people do not\nclean their houses, allowing bacteria-infected wild rats to find a\nconducive environment in dirty homes, spreading the infected fleas. Arua District\nHealth Officer Dr Patrick Anguzu said the area has been registering a\nfew cases every year, but this year the numbers started rising,\nreaching alarming levels in August 2008. The death toll from bubonic plague in Uganda continues to rise as the\ngovernment struggles to come up with a clear response even though\nearly signs of the disease were detected at the beginning of 2008. The plague, which mainly affects women and children, has spread into\nthe districts of Arua and Nebbi, where residents still live in mud\nhuts.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2008-02-25 00:00:00", "2008-08-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Uganda", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "122266", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, pneumonic - Madagascar: (Toamasina)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=122266", "date": "2008-10-26 14:00:35", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PNEUMONIC - MADAGASCAR: (TOAMASINA)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 23 Oct 2008\nSource: L'Express de Madagascar (Antananarivo)\n[in French, trans. & summ. Mod.JW, edited]\n<http://fr.allafrica.com/stories/200810230719.htm>\n\n\nMorarano village, 40 km east of Moramanga, has been hit by the\nplague; 3 persons of the same family have died in recent days and\n4 people died one by one of plague in Ambohidray station, a rural\ncommune of Morarano in the district of Moramanga, according to the\ndeclaration of death made to basic health center (CSB) Level II,\nMorarano.\n\nA 20-year-old was the 1st victim on 6 Oct 2008. He caught the disease\nwhile keeping his parents' cattle in the field at Ampasimbe, a village\nwhich is located 15 km from the town. Field rats, common in this\nregion, are the reservoir of the disease. In ignorance of the cause\nof the death, he was buried in the family vault.\n\nThe alert was triggered by learning of the death of the father 2 days\nlater. The mother also soon died. The test strip to confirm that it was\nthe plague was positive. She presented symptoms of pneumonic plague\n-- cough with bloody sputum -- said Dr Mamitiana Raveloarijaona,\nmedical director of the CSB Morarano.\n\nPeople panicked when another young man of 16 years died on 15 Oct\n2008. He lived in the Ampandrana district near Ambohidray station.\nTwo more fever patients are still under treatment. Approximately 400\npeople have received basic treatment with sulfadoxine because they\nare in contact with the outbreak of plague, said the chief doctor of\nMorarano.\n\nPlague follows an epidemiological cycle in Madagascar. According to\nDr. Rolland Robinson, director of emergencies and the fight against\ndiseases (DULM), we are in the year of its return, which happens\nevery 5 years. In such a context, the population must be sensitized\nto clean the environment. 'We must trap the rats alive and kill them\nby throwing them into fire or water to kill their fleas along with\nthem,' he suggests [if they are killed in the trap, their fleas\ndisperse. - Mod.JW]. In any case, Madagascar is home to several\nplague foci; Moramanga, in the region of Alaotra Mangoro, is one of\nthem.\n\n[Byline: Noro Haingo Rakotoseheno]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is likely that primary pneumonic plague occurred in the parents\nof the family. Primary pneumonic plague (one percent of natural\nplague presentations) arises as a result of inhalation of plague\nbacilli in infectious aerosols, such as would be produced when there\nare secondary pneumonic complications in bubonic/septicemic plague.\n\nPrimary plague pneumonia has a short incubation period of 1-3 days,\nafter which there is sudden onset of flu-like symptoms including\nfever, chills, headache, generalized body pains, weakness and chest\ndiscomfort. A cough develops with sputum production, which may be\nbloody, and increasing chest pain and difficulty in breathing. As the\ndisease progresses, hypoxia (low oxygen concentration in the blood)\nand hemoptysis (coughing up blood) are prominent. The disease is\ninvariably fatal unless antimicrobial therapy commences within 24\nhours of exposure.\n\nPatients with primary pneumonic plague generate large quantities of\ninfectious aerosols that pose a significant risk to close contacts.\nCDC guidelines identify contacts within 2 meters as being at greatest\nrisk and do not consider the organism likely to be carried through\nair ducts or vents. Persons who have been in contact with pneumonic\nplague patients or handling potentially infectious body fluids or\ntissues without appropriate protection should receive preventive\nantimicrobial therapy. The preferred antimicrobial agents for\nprophylaxis are tetracyclines, quinolones, or chloramphenicol.\n\nMoramanga is in the Alaotra-Mangoro region of the eastern Toamasina\nprovince of Madagascar. The province can be seen on a map of the\nisland nation at:\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toamasina_Province>.\n- Mod.LL\n\nA test using dipsticks for the rapid diagnosis of plague, developed\nand evaluated at the Institut Pasteur in Madagascar and Paris, makes\nit possible to detect this disease in 15 minutes at a patient's\nbedside. This research was published in the 18 Jan 2003 edition of\n'The Lancet':\n<http://www.pasteur.fr/actu/presse/press/03bandelett-E.htm>\nRe the approx. 5-year cycles of plague in Madagascar, the only\nprevious reports from there in ProMED's archives below are for\n1995-96. - Mod.JW]", "summary": "JW, edited]\n<http://fr.allafrica.com/stories/200810230719.htm>\n\n\nMorarano village, 40 km east of Moramanga, has been hit by the\nplague; 3 persons of the same family have died in recent days and\n4 people died one by one of plague in Ambohidray station, a rural\ncommune of Morarano in the district of Moramanga, according to the\ndeclaration of death made to basic health center (CSB) A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 23 Oct 2008\n Primary pneumonic plague (one percent of natural\nplague presentations) arises as a result of inhalation of plague\nbacilli in infectious aerosols, such as would be produced when there\nare secondary pneumonic complications in bubonic/septicemic plague. \n\nPrimary plague pneumonia has a short incubation period of 1-3 days,\nafter which there is sudden onset of flu-like symptoms including\nfever, chills, headache, generalized body pains, weakness and chest\ndiscomfort. LL\n\nA test using dipsticks for the rapid diagnosis of plague, developed\nand evaluated at the Institut Pasteur in Madagascar and Paris, makes\nit possible to detect this disease in 15 minutes at a patient's\nbedside. Persons who have been in contact with pneumonic\nplague patients or handling potentially infectious body fluids or\ntissues without appropriate protection should receive preventive\nantimicrobial therapy. Approximately 400\npeople have received basic treatment with sulfadoxine because they\nare in contact with the outbreak of plague, said the chief doctor of\nMorarano.\n\n We must trap the rats alive and kill them\nby throwing them into fire or water to kill their fleas along with\nthem,' he suggests [if they are killed in the trap, their fleas\ndisperse. According to\nDr. Rolland Robinson, director of emergencies and the fight against\ndiseases (DULM), we are in the year of its return, which happens\nevery 5 years. This research was published in the 18 Jan 2003 edition of\n'The Lancet':\n<http://www.pasteur.fr/actu/presse/press/03bandelett-E.htm>\n She presented symptoms of pneumonic plague\n-- cough with bloody sputum -- said Dr Mamitiana Raveloarijaona,\nmedical director of the CSB Morarano. 5-year cycles of plague in Madagascar, the only\nprevious reports from there in ProMED's archives below are for\n1995-96. - Mod. In any case, Madagascar is home to several\nplague foci; Moramanga, in the region of Alaotra Mangoro, is one of\nthem. He caught the disease\nwhile keeping his parents' cattle in the field at Ampasimbe, a village\nwhich is located 15 km from the town. CDC guidelines identify contacts within 2 meters as being at greatest\nrisk and do not consider the organism likely to be carried through\nair ducts or vents. As the\ndisease progresses, hypoxia (low oxygen concentration in the blood)\nand hemoptysis (coughing up blood) are prominent. The disease is\ninvariably fatal unless antimicrobial therapy commences within 24\nhours of exposure. The province can be seen on a map of the\nisland nation at:\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toamasina_Province>. Patients with primary pneumonic plague generate large quantities of\ninfectious aerosols that pose a significant risk to close contacts. [It is likely that primary pneumonic plague occurred in the parents\nof the family. \n\nPeople panicked when another young man of 16 years died on 15 Oct\n2008. \n\nThe alert was triggered by learning of the death of the father 2 days\nlater. PLAGUE, PNEUMONIC - MADAGASCAR: (TOAMASINA)\n The test strip to confirm that it was\nthe plague was positive. \n\nMoramanga is in the Alaotra-Mangoro region of the eastern Toamasina\nprovince of Madagascar. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n [Byline: Noro Haingo Rakotoseheno]\n\n--\n A cough develops with sputum production, which may be\nbloody, and increasing chest pain and difficulty in breathing.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Moramanga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ambohidray", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ampandrana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Paris", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "115927", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, pneumonic, fatal - China: (Tibet)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=115927", "date": "2008-10-01 20:00:32", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PNEUMONIC, FATAL - CHINA: (TIBET)\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: Tue 30 Sep 2008\nSource: XinHuaNet [in Chinese, trans.& summ. DS] [edited]\n<http://news.xinhuanet.com/newscenter/2008-09/30/content_10136019.htm>\n\n\nAn outbreak of human plague recently occurred in Lang County of\nTibet's Linzhi District. 2 people who contracted pneumonic plague\ndied. After the outbreak, relevant authorities in the Tibet\nAutonomous Region undertook comprehensive plague prevention work.\nThis district does not have any new cases and the outbreak has been\nbrought under control.\n\n[Byline: Hu Xing]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Dan Silver\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Linzhi district is in Nyinchi prefecture in southeastern Tibet and\ncan be found on a map of the area at:\n<http://www.coolscooters.info/tibetmaps/district_map.jpg>. - Mod. LL]\n*****\n[2]\nDate: Wed 1 Oct 2008\nSource: Independent Online [edited]\n<http://www.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=31&art_id=nw20081001122540961C441551>\n\n2 people in eastern Tibet have died of the deadliest and least common\nform of plague, Chinese state media said on Wednesday [1 Oct 2008].\nThe health department of the Himalayan region was notified on Friday\n[26 Sep 2008] that 2 people had died of an unidentified illness in a\nvillage in the Linzhi area, more than 200 km (125 m) southeast of the\ncapital Lhasa, the Beijing Times reported.\n\nHealth authorities examined the victims and determined they were cases\nof pneumonic plague. The report did not identify the 2, but health\nauthorities in Hong Kong said they were a couple who developed\nsymptoms of plague on 14 and 23 Sep 2008.\n\nA spokesperson for the Centre for Health Protection of Hong Kong's\nhealth department said the man, 35, passed away on 20 Sep 2008 and his\n38 year old wife died 5 days later.\n\nPneumonic plague, which is transmitted to humans from infected animals\n-- mainly rodents [by their fleas] -- is highly contagious, the centre\nsaid. It can spread between humans by breathing in respiratory\ndroplets from an infected person and the incubation period of the\ndisease is between 1 & 4 days.\n\nPubu Zhuoma, head of the Tibet health department, said cases of human\nplague had emerged in Tibet in the past. 'Tibet's disease prevention\nworkers have long carried out plague prevention and control work in\ndisease areas. They have had good results in controlling epidemics\namong animals and there have been no epidemics among humans,' he said,\naccording to the Beijing Times.\n\nAuthorities immediately put in preventative and control measures in\nthe village, no new cases of the disease had emerged in the area, and\nthe disease had been contained, the report said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The 9 day interval between the 2 cases strongly suggests that the man\ntransmitted the infection to his wife. Primary pneumonic plague (one\npercent of natural plague presentations) arises as a result of\ninhalation of plague bacilli in infectious aerosols, such as would be\nproduced when there are secondary pneumonic complications in\nbubonic/septicemic plague.\n\nPrimary plague pneumonia has a short incubation period of 1-3 days,\nafter which there is sudden onset of flu-like symptoms including\nfever, chills, headache, generalized body pains, weakness, and chest\ndiscomfort. A cough develops with sputum production, which may be\nbloody, and increasing chest pain and difficulty in breathing. As the\ndisease progresses, hypoxia (low oxygen concentration in the blood)\nand hemoptysis (coughing up blood) are prominent. The disease is\ninvariably fatal unless antimicrobial therapy commences within 24\nhours of exposure.\n\nPatients with primary pneumonic plague generate large quantities of\ninfectious aerosols that pose a significant risk to close contacts.\nCDC (US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) guidelines\nidentify contacts within 2 meters (6.5 ft) as being at greatest risk\nand do not consider the organism likely to be carried through air\nducts or vents. Persons who have been in contact with pneumonic\nplague patients or handling potentially infectious body fluids or\ntissues without appropriate protection should receive preventive\nantimicrobial therapy. The preferred antimicrobial agents for\nprophylaxis are tetracyclines, quinolones, or chloramphenicol. - Mod. LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\n Primary pneumonic plague (one\npercent of natural plague presentations) arises as a result of\ninhalation of plague bacilli in infectious aerosols, such as would be\nproduced when there are secondary pneumonic complications in\nbubonic/septicemic plague. Persons who have been in contact with pneumonic\nplague patients or handling potentially infectious body fluids or\ntissues without appropriate protection should receive preventive\nantimicrobial therapy. CDC (US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) guidelines\nidentify contacts within 2 meters (6.5 ft) as being at greatest risk\nand do not consider the organism likely to be carried through air\nducts or vents. The disease, common in north western Uganda and neighboring\nDemocratic Republic of Congo, causes fever, headaches, and fatigue, the\nnewspaper said.\n\n[byline: Fred Ojambo]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Fatalities in plague, infections due to _Yersinia pestis_ are often due to\nspread of the organism outside of the painful bubo into the bloodstream\ncausing septicemic plague and/or spread to the lung causing pneumonic\ndisease. It is this latter form that facilitates person-to-person spread\nvia the respiratory route.\n\nArua and Nebbi are endemic for plague and are located in north western\nUganda as can be seen on a map at\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/uganda.pdf>. - Mod.LL\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Uganda is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?g=443328&g=443360&v=2,31.167,5>. USA: (AZ)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=118781", "date": "2008-10-12 11:00:34", "main_text": "PLAGUE, BUBONIC, PRAIRIE DOGS - USA: (ARIZONA)\n**************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 10 Oct 2008\nSource: The Salt Lake Tribune [edited]\n<http://www.sltrib.com/ci_10656129>\n\nBubonic plague: Four Corners health alert as man sickened, prairie dogs dying\n\nA northeast Arizona man has contracted bubonic plague and health\nagencies are urging Four Corners residents to help prevent the spread\nof the disease. The Apache County, Ariz., man who contracted the\ndisease began showing symptoms in late September, the Navajo Nation\nsaid, including a 103-degree fever, chills, diarrhea and groin\ntenderness. The man was responding to treatment and doing well Monday\nafternoon,said Jenny Notah, a spokeswoman for Navajo Area Indian\nHealth Service.\n\nThe Navajo Nation also said plague likely killed a number of prairie\ndogs east of Flagstaff, Ariz. There have been no recent reports of\nplague cases on the Utah side of the Four Corners.\n\nHumans can contract plague by touching bodily fluids of infected\nanimals or after being bitten by fleas that have contracted it from\ninfected rodents, according to the U.S. Department of Health and\nHuman Services.\n\nIn 2006, the disease was found in rodents in Mesa Verde National Park\nand Natural Bridges National Monument. No humans were infected, but\nNatural Bridges closed a campground until it determined there was no\nthreat. Both venues were fully open Monday.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[From data collected by the Arizona Department of Health\nServices <http://www.azdhs.gov/phs/oids/vector/plague/stats.htm>,\na total of 61 cases of _Yersinia pestis_ infection have been\nacquired in the state from 1950 to 2000. About one third of these\ncases occurred in Apache County.\n\nFour corners is the only place in the United States where four states\ncome together at one place. The states are Arizona, New Mexico, Utah\nand Colorado. The states are Arizona, New Mexico, Utah\nand Colorado. **\n \n\nApache county is in the north east corner of Arizona. \n\n \n\n Both venues were fully open Monday.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ariz.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Flagstaff", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Apache County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Utah", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Apache county", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "106081", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, bubonic - USA: (CT ex WY)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=106081", "date": "2008-08-27 03:00:38", "main_text": "PLAGUE, BUBONIC - USA: (CONNECTICUT ex WYOMING)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: Tue 26 Aug 2008\nSource: NBC30.com [edited]\n<http://www.nbc30.com/health/17299018/detail.html>\n\n\nAn 18 year old boy scout from Connecticut is recovering at home after\nbecoming infected with bubonic plague, possibly in Wyoming. The teenager\nwas among hundreds of scouts who built trails and did other service work\nlate in July 2008. The Wyoming Department of Health is trying to determine\nhow he became infected.\n\nThe teenager traveled to multiple sites in the area, including Yellowstone\nNational Park. Where the teen contracted the disease is not known.\nInfection usually comes after being bitten by a rodent flea that is\ncarrying the plague bacterium or handling an infected animal.\n\nEach year, 10 to 20 cases occur in the United States according to the US\nCenters for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). About one in 7 cases in\nthe USA is fatal.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Mon 25 Aug 2008\nSource: Wyoming Department of Health [edited]\n<http://wdh.state.wy.us/news.aspx?NewsID=212>\n\n\nWyoming Department of Health officials said today [25 Aug 2008] they are\ninvestigating a case of bubonic plague in an out-of-state resident who\nrecently visited Teton County and Yellowstone National Park.\n\nThe individual traveled to multiple sites in the area with a group of boy\nscouts from 26 Jul 2008 to 3 Aug 2008, said Dr Tracy Murphy, state\nepidemiologist with the Wyoming Department of Health.\n\n'The young adult traveled to Yellowstone National Park, Bridger-Teton\nNational Forest and other sites within Teton County. He was involved in a\ncombination of activities during his visit that included working on a\nservice project, camping, sightseeing, and participating in sports.'\n\nWyoming Department of Health staff will participate in an environmental\ninvestigation with other agencies this week to look for fleas and animal\ncarcasses in areas where the individual visited. 'At this time the exact\nlocation where the exposure to the disease occurred is not known and it is\nlikely we will never determine that level of detail,' Murphy said.\n\nDr Karl Musgrave, state public health veterinarian with the Wyoming\nDepartment of Health, said that while the risk for humans to contract\nplague is relatively low in Wyoming, the disease has been documented in\nanimals in 22 of Wyoming's 23 counties since records were kept.\n\nThis is the 6th human case of plague thought to have been acquired in\nWyoming since 1978. The most recent human case of plague in Wyoming was\nacquired in Goshen County in the fall of 2004. Other recorded cases\ninvolving residents include a 1978 Washakie County case, a 1982 Laramie\nCounty case, a 1992 Sheridan County case that resulted in death and a 2000\nWashakie County case.\n\n'It's safe to assume that the risk for plague exists all around Wyoming,'\nMusgrave said. 'And while the disease is rare in humans, it is important\nthat people take precautions to keep exposure to the disease to a minimum.'\n\nWays to avoid the plague include\n- avoiding unnecessary contact with rodents and their nests and burrows;\n- avoiding unnecessary contact with sick or dead animals, especially\nrodents and rabbits, and wearing protective gloves when handling sick or\ndead animals;\n- having ill pets, such as cats and dogs, examined by a veterinarian;\n- avoiding areas where a large number of unexplained rodent deaths have\nbeen observed;\n- keeping pets away from rodent nests and burrows by keeping them leashed;\n- treating pets with flea preventatives (see your local veterinarian for\nmore information).\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[_Yersinia pestis_, the plague bacillus, is not endemic in the eastern USA.\nAny cases in the residents of this area must have been acquired elsewhere,\nbe related to contact with an infected reservoir inadvertently brought into\nthe area or be due to a deliberate man-related introduction. - Mod.LL\n\nConnecticut (north eastern US) and Wyoming (western US) can be located on\nthe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=40,-97.6,4>. Teton County and Yellowstone\nNational Park can be located on the map at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/united_states/wyoming_90.jpg>. - CopyEd.MJ]", "summary": "\n\nWays to avoid the plague include\n- avoiding unnecessary contact with rodents and their nests and burrows;\n- avoiding unnecessary contact with sick or dead animals, especially\nrodents and rabbits, and wearing protective gloves when handling sick or\ndead animals;\n- having ill pets, such as cats and dogs, examined by a veterinarian;\n- avoiding areas where a large number of unexplained rodent deaths have\nbeen observed;\n- keeping pets away from rodent nests and burrows by keeping them leashed;\n- treating pets with flea preventatives (see your local veterinarian for\nmore information). A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\n \n\nDr Karl Musgrave, state public health veterinarian with the Wyoming\nDepartment of Health, said that while the risk for humans to contract\nplague is relatively low in Wyoming, the disease has been documented in\nanimals in 22 of Wyoming's 23 counties since records were kept. Source: Wyoming Department of Health [edited]\n<http://wdh.state.wy.us/news.aspx?NewsID=212>\n\n\nWyoming Department of Health officials said today [25 Aug 2008] they are\ninvestigating a case of bubonic plague in an out-of-state resident who\nrecently visited Teton County and Yellowstone National Park. Other recorded cases\ninvolving residents include a 1978 Washakie County case, a 1982 Laramie\nCounty case, a 1992 Sheridan County case that resulted in death and a 2000\nWashakie County case. \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nThe individual traveled to multiple sites in the area with a group of boy\nscouts from 26 Jul 2008 to 3 Aug 2008, said Dr Tracy Murphy, state\nepidemiologist with the Wyoming Department of Health. Any cases in the residents of this area must have been acquired elsewhere,\nbe related to contact with an infected reservoir inadvertently brought into\nthe area or be due to a deliberate man-related introduction. LL\n\nConnecticut (north eastern US) and Wyoming (western US) can be located on\nthe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=40,-97.6,4>. At this time the exact\nlocation where the exposure to the disease occurred is not known and it is\nlikely we will never determine that level of detail,' Murphy said. Wyoming Department of Health staff will participate in an environmental\ninvestigation with other agencies this week to look for fleas and animal\ncarcasses in areas where the individual visited. '", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2000-03-25 00:00:00", "2008-08-03 00:00:00", "1992-03-25 00:00:00", "1978-03-25 00:00:00", "1982-03-25 00:00:00", "2008-07-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Connecticut", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sheridan County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Teton County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washakie County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "National Park", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Goshen County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "101727", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Crayfish plague - UK: (England)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=101727", "date": "2008-08-08 22:00:28", "main_text": "CRAYFISH PLAGUE - UNITED KINGDOM: (ENGLAND)\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 7 Aug 2008\nSource: The Telegraph [edited]\n<http://www.telegraph.co.uk/earth/main.jhtml?xml=/earth/2008/08/07/eacrayfish107.xml>\n\n\nA deadly plague is thought to have wiped out hundreds of crayfish in\na river system.\n\nAll the creatures killed so far have been from an invasive species --\nthe Turkish crayfish [_Astacus leptodactylus_; see picture at\n<http://forum.garten-pur.de/attachments/10050009_eAstacus_leptodactylus.JPG>]\n-- but there are fears the disease could spread to the native\nwhite-clawed crayfish [_Austropotamobius pallipes_,\n<http://ecoevol.labo.univ-poitiers.fr/IMG/gif/App-2.gif>].\n\nThe dead crayfish were found by a ranger in the lower River Colne in\nColchester, Essex and samples have now been sent for analysis to the\nCentre for Environment, Fisheries & Aquaculture Science (CEFAS) in Weymouth.\n\nThe crustaceans are thought to have been killed by the\nhighly-virulent fungal disease _Aphanomyces astaci_, commonly known\nas crayfish plague. A similar outbreak on the River Waveney in nearby\nSuffolk last October [2007] killed thousands of crayfish.\n\nThe risk of the disease spreading piles further pressure on the\nnative crayfish which has already been driven to local extinction on\nmany of the waterways in southern England by the relentless advance\nof another invasive species, the American signal crayfish\n[_Pacifastacus leniusculus_,\n<http://www.environment-agency.gov.uk/subjects/fish/246986/342184/1205879/?lang=_e>].\n\nLarger than the native crayfish, [the American signal crayfish] was\nintroduced to be farmed for the restaurant trade but many escaped and\nquickly became established in rivers and lakes. The voracious signal\neats almost anything in its path including plants, snails, and fish\nand has quickly displaced the native crayfish. It also carries a\nvariation of the plague which is harmless to it, but which is fatal\nto its English cousin.\n\nThe Turkish crayfish was also brought into the UK as a food source\nbut has not spread as quickly as the signal.\n\nThe population in the Colchester area has not been big enough to\ncause problems and the loss of significant numbers to the plague may\neven help native river wildlife.\n\n'It is usually found at the bottom of the river and tends only to\nappear when other species of crayfish have moved on,' said\nEnvironment Agency Fisheries, Recreation and Biodiversity officer\nJulia Stansfield.\n\n'Although only Turkish crayfish have been affected so far we think it\nwill be only a matter of time before it spreads to the native species\nand that would be a disaster. There are no native crayfish left in\nthe Colne but there are still some remnants in the River Stour and\nthe River Chelmer.'\n\nThe Environment Agency is asking anglers and other river users to be\naware of the dangers of spreading the disease and is urging them to\nclean and disinfect equipment such as keep-nets.\n\nIronically it may be people who are trapping bigger invasive crayfish\nfor food -- at the same time helping cut numbers in the river -- who\nare spreading the disease.\n\nJulia Stansfield explained: 'One possible route for the spread of\nthis disease is use of unlicenced crayfish traps. The idea of this\n'wild food' is much in vogue.\n\n'While this is safe to do in parts of the country where native\ncrayfish have already been wiped out, in the east of England we are\ntrying to protect one of the last strongholds.\n\n'If members of the public notice dead crayfish in any other rivers,\nplease let the Environment Agency know as soon as possible.'\n\n[Byline: Paul Eccleston]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Crayfish plague is considered to be infection of crayfish with\n_Aphanomyces astaci_, which is a member of a group of organisms\ncommonly known as the water moulds. Although long regarded to be\nfungi, this group, the Oomycetida, are not members of the Eumycota\nand are now classified with diatoms and brown algae in a group called\nthe Stramenopiles or Chromista.\n\nThere is evidence that established older _A. astaci_ strains that\nhave been present in Europe for many years are less aggressive than\nare newer strains introduced with crayfish imports from North America\nsince the 1960s. Some isolates from warmer waters in Spain have\ntemperature/growth curves with higher optimum temperatures compared\nwith those from northern Europe.\n\n_A. astaci_, both in culture and in infected crayfish, is killed by a\nshort exposure to temperatures of 60 deg C (140 deg F) or to\ntemperatures of -20 deg C (-4 deg F) or less for 48 hours or more.\nSodium hypochlorite and iodophores are effective for disinfection of\ncontaminated equipment. Thorough drying of equipment (more than 24\nhours) is also effective as _Aphanomyces_ is not resistant to desiccation.\n\nThe life cycle is simple with vegetative hyphae invading and\nramifying through host tissues, eventually producing extramatrical\nsporangia that release amoeboid primary spores, each of which then\ngerminates as a biflagellate zoospore. Biflagellate zoospores swim in\nthe water column and, on encountering a susceptible host, attach and\ngerminate to produce invasive vegetative hyphae. Zoospores are\ncapable of repeated encystment and re-emergence, extending the period\nof their infective viability.\n\nThere is good field and experimental evidence that movements of fish\nfrom areas in which crayfish plague is active can transmit infection\nfrom one watershed to another . _A. astaci_ can also be spread by\ncontaminated equipment (nets, boots, clothing, etc).\n\nThe information above is derived from chapter 2.3.7. 'Crayfish Plague\n(_Aphanomyces astaci_)' in OIE's (World Organisation for Animal\nHealth) Manual of Diagnostic Tests for Aquatic animals. The chapter\nincludes additional comprehensive information on the agent factors,\nhost factors, disease pattern, diagnosis, control and prevention,\netc; see <http://oie.int/eng/normes/fmanual/A_00054.htm>. - Mod.AS\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of England can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=54.5,-2,5>.\nThe River Colne in Essex can be located on the interactive map at\n<http://www.panoramio.com/photo/6096118>. - CopyEd.MJ]", "summary": "\n\nAll the creatures killed so far have been from an invasive species --\nthe Turkish crayfish [_Astacus leptodactylus_; see picture at\n<http://forum.garten-pur.de/attachments/10050009_eAstacus_leptodactylus.JPG>]\n-- but there are fears the disease could spread to the native\nwhite-clawed crayfish [_Austropotamobius pallipes_,\n<http://ecoevol.labo.univ-poitiers.fr/IMG/gif/App-2.gif>]. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 7 Aug 2008\n The risk of the disease spreading piles further pressure on the\nnative crayfish which has already been driven to local extinction on\nmany of the waterways in southern England by the relentless advance\nof another invasive species, the American signal crayfish\n \n\nThere is evidence that established older _A. astaci_ strains that\nhave been present in Europe for many years are less aggressive than\nare newer strains introduced with crayfish imports from North America\nsince the 1960s. \n\n'It is usually found at the bottom of the river and tends only to\nappear when other species of crayfish have moved on,' said\nEnvironment Agency Fisheries, Recreation and Biodiversity officer\nJulia Stansfield. \n\nThe life cycle is simple with vegetative hyphae invading and\nramifying through host tissues, eventually producing extramatrical\nsporangia that release amoeboid primary spores, each of which then\ngerminates as a biflagellate zoospore. The chapter\nincludes additional comprehensive information on the agent factors,\nhost factors, disease pattern, diagnosis, control and prevention,\netc; see <http://oie.int/eng/normes/fmanual/A_00054.htm>. Although long regarded to be\nfungi, this group, the Oomycetida, are not members of the Eumycota\nand are now classified with diatoms and brown algae in a group called\nthe Stramenopiles or Chromista. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Crayfish plague is considered to be infection of crayfish with\n_Aphanomyces astaci_, which is a member of a group of organisms\ncommonly known as the water moulds. \n\nLarger than the native crayfish, [the American signal crayfish] was\nintroduced to be farmed for the restaurant trade but many escaped and\nquickly became established in rivers and lakes. \n\n_A. astaci_, both in culture and in infected crayfish, is killed by a\nshort exposure to temperatures of 60 deg C (140 deg F) or to\ntemperatures of -20 deg C (-4 deg F) or less for 48 hours or more. \n\nThere is good field and experimental evidence that movements of fish\nfrom areas in which crayfish plague is active can transmit infection\nfrom one watershed to another .
