Ironically it may be people who are trapping bigger invasive crayfish\nfor food -- at the same time helping cut numbers in the river -- who\nare spreading the disease. \n\n'While this is safe to do in parts of the country where native\ncrayfish have already been wiped out, in the east of England we are\ntrying to protect one of the last strongholds. \n\nThe dead crayfish were found by a ranger in the lower River Colne in\nColchester, Essex and samples have now been sent for analysis to the\nCentre for Environment, Fisheries & Aquaculture Science (CEFAS) in Weymouth. The crustaceans are thought to have been killed by the\nhighly-virulent fungal disease _Aphanomyces astaci_, commonly known\nas crayfish plague. \n\nThe Environment Agency is asking anglers and other river users to be\naware of the dangers of spreading the disease and is urging them to\nclean and disinfect equipment such as keep-nets.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Suffolk", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chromista", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "98925", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, wildlife, human exposure -  Russia (Siberia)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=98925", "date": "2008-07-30 10:00:27", "main_text": "PLAGUE, WILDLIFE, HUMAN EXPOSURE - RUSSIA (SIBERIA)\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 17 Jul 2008\nSource: RIA Novosti [edited]\n<http://en.rian.ru/russia/20080717/114225438.html>\n\n\nA 13-year-old Siberian boy has been hospitalized after catching a\nplague-infected ground squirrel and bringing it home, Russia's top\nsanitary official said on Thursday.\n\nThe boy, living in a remote shepherds' community in south Siberia's\nTuva Republic, brought the rodent home in his hat. His grandfather\nimmediately killed the animal, and called a doctor.\n\nThe teenager 'came into immediate contact with a long-tailed ground\nsquirrel [Spermophilus undulatus_] infected with the plague. His\nstate of health is satisfactory. He is undergoing prophylactic\ntreatment,' Gennady Onishchenko told RIA Novosti.\n\nThe area has been thoroughly disinfected, and medics from the\nregional plague prevention center are carrying out anti-epidemic\nmeasures in the area.\n\nPlague, caused by the _Yersinia pestis_ bacterium, can be transmitted\nfrom rodents to humans via fleas. Bubonic plague is now extremely\nrare in industrialized countries, and can be treated with antibiotics.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n\n[More than 200 species of mammals can be infected with _Y. pestis_.\nRodents are the reservoir hosts. Many rodents, including ground\nsquirrels, suffer occasional epidemics or maintain the bacterium in\nnatural cycles. In many cases, rodents may show mild illness or are\nasymptomatic. Probably, the squirrel in the above described case was\nkilled by the boy's grandfather because of demonstrating suspect\nchanges or was sick. - Mod.AS\n\nPlague is endemic, not emerging, in the region, but is reported here\nbecause it is listed as a Schedule A potential bioterror agent.\n\nPhoto of Tuvan shepherd in hat:\n<http://www.spectrasonics.net/artists/htuturvanskaigaloolkhovalyg.jpg>\n\nImage of fluorecent-stained _Yersinia pestis_ bacteria:\n<http://library.thinkquest.org/05aug/00639/en/images/yersinia_pestis.jpeg>\n\nPhoto of a realted species of long-tailed ground squirrel\n(_Spermophilus parryii_, the Arctic ground squirrel:\n<http://animalpicturesarchive.com/WebImg/471/1208917268-t.jpg>\n\nLocator map of the Tuva Republic, on the southern border of Russia\nwith Mongolia, where marmots carry plague and infect hunters:\n<http://worldheritage.heindorffhus.dk/russia-tuva-map.jpg>\n- Mod.JW]", "summary": "<http://www.spectrasonics.net/artists/htuturvanskaigaloolkhovalyg.jpg>\n\nImage of fluorecent-stained _Yersinia pestis_ bacteria:\n<http://library.thinkquest.org/05aug/00639/en/images/yersinia_pestis.jpeg>\n\nPhoto of a realted species of long-tailed ground squirrel\n(_Spermophilus parryii_, the Arctic ground squirrel:\n<http://animalpicturesarchive.com/WebImg/471/1208917268-t.jpg>\n\nLocator map of the Tuva Republic, on the southern border of Russia\nwith Mongolia, where marmots carry plague and infect hunters:\n<http://worldheritage.heindorffhus.dk/russia-tuva-map.jpg>\n- Mod. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 17 Jul 2008\n Source: RIA Novosti [edited]\n<http://en.rian.ru/russia/20080717/114225438.html>\n\n\nA 13-year-old Siberian boy has been hospitalized after catching a\nplague-infected ground squirrel and bringing it home, Russia's top\nsanitary official said on Thursday. \n\nThe area has been thoroughly disinfected, and medics from the\nregional plague prevention center are carrying out anti-epidemic\nmeasures in the area. Probably, the squirrel in the above described case was\nkilled by the boy's grandfather because of demonstrating suspect\nchanges or was sick. - Many rodents, including ground\nsquirrels, suffer occasional epidemics or maintain the bacterium in\nnatural cycles. PLAGUE, WILDLIFE, HUMAN EXPOSURE - RUSSIA (SIBERIA)\n***************************************************\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Tuva Republic", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "96991", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, prairie dogs, ferrets - USA: (SD)(02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=96991", "date": "2008-07-22 09:00:29", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PRAIRIE DOGS, FERRETS - USA: (SOUTH DAKOTA) (02)\n********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.isid.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 15 Jul 2008\nSource: New York Times [edited]\n<http://www.nytimes.com/2008/07/15/science/15ferrets.html?_r=2&ref=science&oref=slogin&oref=slogin>\n\n\nA colony that contains nearly half of the black-footed ferrets in the\ncountry and which biologists say is critical to the long-term health\nof the species has been struck by plague, which may have killed a\nthird of the 300 animals.\n\nA much-publicized endangered species in the 1970s that had dwindled\nto 18 animals, the black-footed ferret had struggled to make a\ncomeback and had been doing relatively well for decades. But plague,\nalways a threat to the ferrets and their main prey, prairie dogs, has\nstruck with a vengeance this year [2008], partly because of the wet spring.\n\nThe ferrets are an easy target for the bacteria. 'They are\nexquisitely sensitive to the plague,' said Travis Livieri, a wildlife\nbiologist here who is trying to save the colony. 'They don't just get\nsick, they die. No ifs, ands or buts.' Humans can catch plague, but\nit is easily treated with antibiotics.\n\nMr. Livieri is working with the federal Fish and Wildlife Service's\nblack-footed ferret recovery team, the Forest Service and some\nvolunteers to try to save the colony at Conata Basin by dusting\nprairie dog burrows with flea powder that kills the plague-carrying\ninsects. Mr. Livieri is also working on a vaccination program,\nprowling the prairie all night to capture ferrets for injections.\n\nPlague thrives in wet years, and this has been one of the wettest in\nthe region in years. A combination of insecticide and vaccines can be\nvery effective, said Dr. Dean Biggins, a research biologist with the\nUnited States Geological Survey, who has studied plague and ferrets.\nHe said he had seen a plague outbreak hit a line of dusted burrows\nand stop cold. 'There's no question they can be protected,' he said.\n'It's not whether we can do it, but are we willing because of cost\nand labor? It might have to be done every year or 2.'\n\nFor now, the race is on to protect the heart of the ferret\npopulation. Mr. Livieri, often working by himself, drives from his\nhome in Wellington, CO, 6 hours away, and spends a week or 2 at a\ntime scouring the prairie all night in hopes of injecting all of the ferrets.\n\nTreating ferrets, though, is only half of the equation. Enough\nprairie dogs need to survive the plague to keep the ferrets from\nstarving to death. One ferret eats 125 to 150 prairie dogs a year.\n\nThe landscape is pockmarked with burrows. Some have been marked with\na streak of white dust to kill fleas, and then pinned with a small\norange flag. Ferrets dwell in the prairie dog burrows among their\nprey, kill the prairie dogs at night and devour them underground.\n\nOn a recent night, glowing eyes were common, but not the right kind.\nAt around 2 a.m., Mr. Livieri and others see their 1st shining ferret\neyes. Mr. Livieri turns his truck and rumbles quickly to the burrow,\nand a tiny masked ferret peers up at him. He places a long slender\ntrap in the hole and drives away. The ferret, which turns out to be a\nyoung female, crawls into it.\n\nMr. Livieri returns, and the trap is removed. Briskly, to minimize\nhandling, plague vaccine is injected into the animal's rump, hair dye\nis swabbed on her neck to indicate she has received her 1st\ninjection, she is sprayed with flea spray and released into her hole.\nShe turns and looks back up at her captor.\n\nThis is the 30th ferret of the estimated 150 that remain here that\nneed to be captured and treated. Each animal must be caught a 2nd\ntime for a booster.\n\n'You feel helpless when a disease like this comes in and threatens\neverything you worked for,' Mr. Livieri said. 'That's why I am going\nto be out here spotlighting, doing what I can.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A photo of the black-footed ferret may be found at:\n<http://animals.nationalgeographic.com/animals/mammals/black-footed-ferret.html>\n\nThe vaccine sounds a little labor intensive but if it saves the\nferrets it will be worth it. It also appears that Mr. Livieri has\nworked some 13 years with this colony so the loss of the ferrets\nwould be a personal loss as well. - Mod.TG]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.isid.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 15 Jul 2008\n \n\nMr. Livieri is working with the federal Fish and Wildlife Service's\nblack-footed ferret recovery team, the Forest Service and some\nvolunteers to try to save the colony at Conata Basin by dusting\nprairie dog burrows with flea powder that kills the plague-carrying\ninsects. That's why I am going\nto be out here spotlighting, doing what I can.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< A colony that contains nearly half of the black-footed ferrets in the\ncountry and which biologists say is critical to the long-term health\nof the species has been struck by plague, which may have killed a\nthird of the 300 animals. Briskly, to minimize\nhandling, plague vaccine is injected into the animal's rump, hair dye\nis swabbed on her neck to indicate she has received her 1st\ninjection, she is sprayed with flea spray and released into her hole. But plague,\nalways a threat to the ferrets and their main prey, prairie dogs, has\nstruck with a vengeance this year [2008], partly because of the wet spring. \n\nA much-publicized endangered species in the 1970s that had dwindled\nto 18 animals, the black-footed ferret had struggled to make a\ncomeback and had been doing relatively well for decades. Mr. Livieri, often working by himself, drives from his\nhome in Wellington, CO, 6 hours away, and spends a week or 2 at a\ntime scouring the prairie all night in hopes of injecting all of the ferrets. Enough\nprairie dogs need to survive the plague to keep the ferrets from\nstarving to death. A combination of insecticide and vaccines can be\nvery effective, said Dr. Dean Biggins, a research biologist with the\nUnited States Geological Survey, who has studied plague and ferrets. They are\nexquisitely sensitive to the plague,' said Travis Livieri, a wildlife\nbiologist here who is trying to save the colony. It also appears that Mr. Livieri has\nworked some 13 years with this colony so the loss of the ferrets\nwould be a personal loss as well. - Mod. Some have been marked with\na streak of white dust to kill fleas, and then pinned with a small\norange flag. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A photo of the black-footed ferret may be found at:\n<http://animals.nationalgeographic.com/animals/mammals/black-footed-ferret.html>\n\n Ferrets dwell in the prairie dog burrows among their\nprey, kill the prairie dogs at night and devour them underground. PLAGUE, PRAIRIE DOGS, FERRETS - USA: (SOUTH DAKOTA) (02)\n Mr. Livieri is also working on a vaccination program,\nprowling the prairie all night to capture ferrets for injections. \n\nFor now, the race is on to protect the heart of the ferret\npopulation. \n\n'You feel helpless when a disease like this comes in and threatens\neverything you worked for,' Mr. Livieri said. ' He said he had seen a plague outbreak hit a line of dusted burrows\nand stop cold. ' Plague thrives in wet years, and this has been one of the wettest in\nthe region in years. The vaccine sounds a little labor intensive but if it saves the\nferrets it will be worth it. Mr. Livieri turns his truck and rumbles quickly to the burrow,\nand a tiny masked ferret peers up at him. This is the 30th ferret of the estimated 150 that remain here that\nneed to be captured and treated. At around 2 a.m., Mr. Livieri and others see their 1st shining ferret\neyes. The ferret, which turns out to be a\nyoung female, crawls into it. Humans can catch plague, but\nit is easily treated with antibiotics. He places a long slender\ntrap in the hole and drives away. On a recent night, glowing eyes were common, but not the right kind.\n Each animal must be caught a 2nd\ntime for a booster. It's not whether we can do it, but are we willing because of cost\nand labor? Source: New York Times [edited]\n<http://www.nytimes.com/2008/07/15/science/15ferrets.html?_r=2&ref=science&oref=slogin&oref=slogin>\n\n\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Wellington", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "98137", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, wildlife - USA: (CO) rabbit", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=98137", "date": "2008-07-27 09:00:28", "main_text": "PLAGUE, WILDLIFE - USA: (COLORADO) RABBIT\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n\nDate: 26 Jul 2008\nSource: The Pueblo Chieftain [edited]\n<http://www.chieftain.com/articles/2008/07/26/news/local/doc488acef1ac429841871677.txt>\n\n\nCrews spray for plague-carrying fleas\n-------------------------------------\nA dead rabbit that tested positive for plague was found near Paradise\nDrive and Platteville Boulevard in Pueblo West, Colorado. Pueblo\nCity-County Health Department crews on Friday [25 Jul 2008] dusted\nprairie dog holes in north Pueblo West to kill fleas that can carry plague.\n\nPlague was confirmed following tests on a dead rabbit found by a\nresident recently in the area of Paradise Drive and Platteville\nBoulevard, according to health department spokeswoman Mary Davis.\n'All residents in the area have been alerted to that and employees\nare dusting prairie dog holes in that area right now,' Davis said Friday.\n\nPlague is relatively common in rabbits and rodents. It can infect\nhumans and domestic animals if they are bitten by a flea that has had\ncontact with an infected mouse, rabbit, prairie dog or other wild animal.\n\nThat's why 'everyone should be aware of the risk, no matter where\nthey live,' Davis said. 'Everyone should always be aware of the\nguidelines for protecting themselves and their pets.' Pets that spend\ntime outdoors, especially in rural areas, should be treated regularly\nfor fleas and should be kept on a leash in areas where rodents and\nother potential plague carriers are known to live.\n\nHomeowners should clear their properties of plant materials, lumber\nor debris that provide attractive cover for rabbits, mice and rats.\nKnown rodent habitats should be treated with flea powder or other\ninsecticides. When spending time in rural areas likely to harbor\nrabbits, prairie dogs and rodents, wearing insect repellent and long\npants, tucked into socks, can prevent flea bites. Humans should avoid\nall contact with wild animals and rodents that are known to be\npotential carriers of plague, and should never handle a sick or dead animal.\n\nSigns of plague infection include a sudden fever, fatigue and general\nmalaise. The disease is treatable in humans and animals but is more\neasily treated if caught early. For more information, or to report a\ndead or sick animal, call the Environmental Health Division of the\nPueblo City-County Health Department at 583-4323.\n\n[Byline: Loretta Sword]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The causative bacterium, _Yersinia pestis_, is transmitted to people\nthrough fleabite and direct contact with infected animals. Each\nrodent species is host to one or more species of flea, which, when\ninfected, is a carrier. These fleas generally do not infest other\nanimals unless their natural hosts are unavailable.\n\nRock squirrels (_Spermophilus variegatus_) are closely related to\nCalifornia ground squirrels and are the most significant plague host\nin Colorado. Their principal flea (_Diamanus montanus_) is an\naggressive parasite and will readily bite other animals and people.\nDomestic cats and dogs can also contract plague by infective fleas.\nThey may carry infected fleas home to their owners or, especially\nwith cats, serve as a direct source of infection.\n\nOften prairie dogs are considered sentinel animals. Cats are also\nvery sensitive. Owners should be alert to any swelling on their\nanimals and if found the pet should be examined by a veterinarian. - Mod.TG\n\nProMED has only ever reported one other rabbit with plague, which was\nlast year, also in Colorado -- see ProMED 2007 archive below. - Mod.JW\n\n[A map of Colorado is available at:\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/united_states/colorado_90.jpg> - CopyEd.EJP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n\nDate: 26 Jul 2008\n Pets that spend\ntime outdoors, especially in rural areas, should be treated regularly\nfor fleas and should be kept on a leash in areas where rodents and\nother potential plague carriers are known to live. Humans should avoid\nall contact with wild animals and rodents that are known to be\npotential carriers of plague, and should never handle a sick or dead animal. It can infect\nhumans and domestic animals if they are bitten by a flea that has had\ncontact with an infected mouse, rabbit, prairie dog or other wild animal. When spending time in rural areas likely to harbor\nrabbits, prairie dogs and rodents, wearing insect repellent and long\npants, tucked into socks, can prevent flea bites. Pueblo\nCity-County Health Department crews on Friday [25 Jul 2008] dusted\nprairie dog holes in north Pueblo West to kill fleas that can carry plague. Plague was confirmed following tests on a dead rabbit found by a\nresident recently in the area of Paradise Drive and Platteville\nBoulevard, according to health department spokeswoman Mary Davis. \n'All residents in the area have been alerted to that and employees\nare dusting prairie dog holes in that area right now,' Davis said Friday. Rock squirrels (_Spermophilus variegatus_) are closely related to\nCalifornia ground squirrels and are the most significant plague host\nin Colorado. Each\nrodent species is host to one or more species of flea, which, when\ninfected, is a carrier. For more information, or to report a\ndead or sick animal, call the Environmental Health Division of the\nPueblo City-County Health Department at 583-4323. PLAGUE, WILDLIFE - USA: (COLORADO) RABBIT\n*****************************************\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The causative bacterium, _Yersinia pestis_, is transmitted to people\nthrough fleabite and direct contact with infected animals.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "77900", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, prairie dogs - USA: (CO), susp., RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=77900", "date": "2008-05-06 15:00:20", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PRAIRIE DOGS - USA: (COLORADO), SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 2 May 2008\nSource: Daily Camera.com [edited]\n<http://www.dailycamera.com/news/2008/may/02/plague-suspected-valmont-butte-prairie-dogs/>\n\n\nPlague suspected in Valmont Butte prairie dogs\n----------------------------------------------\nA population of prairie dogs inhabiting the Valmont Butte site could\nhave the plague, according to Boulder County Public Health officials.\n\nSigns were posted today [2 May 2008] at the site, warning people to\nstay away from the critters as the county investigates.\n\nOfficials say the population of the rodents has declined sharply in\nrecent months -- a sign of possible disease.\n\nFlea samples being collected this weekend [3-4 May 2008] will be\ntested for plague. Results are expected within 2 weeks.\n\nThe city was preparing to relocate the prairie dogs after discovering\nthe animals have dug through soil caps meant to protect wildlife and\npeople from 2 toxic tailing ponds on the butte.\n\nThe city had anticipated that the population would have increased by\nas much as 60 percent since last year [2007], however their numbers\nhave dropped by about 75 percent.\n\nUntil the test results are announced, the city will postpone any\nplans to relocate prairie dogs or continue with any remediation work.\n\nPlague is an infectious disease that can be transmitted to humans by\nthe bites of infected fleas or by direct contact with infected animals.\n\nFor general information about plague, call the Boulder County Public\nHealth Alert Line at 303-441-1460 or visit\n<http://www.BoulderCountyVector.org>.\n\n[Byline: Heath Urie]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Praire dogs are sentinel animals for plague. They are often the 1st\nindication that plague is moving through an area. Plague has often\nbeen found in the western portions of the United States and this year\n(2008) may be no exception.\n\nIt is possible the toxic trailing ponds have a legal substance to the\nprairie dogs. Hopefully in addition to testing the fleas, the\nauthorities will be testing the trailing ponds and conducting full\nnecropsies on some of the prairie dogs.\n\nWe are looking forward to the results and any other information that\nan authoritative source can share. - Mod.TG]\n\n[Valmont Butte is a 5389 ft (1643 m) summit in Boulder County,\nColorado. The County can be located on the map at\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boulder_County,_Colorado>. - CopyEd.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 2 May 2008\n \n\nThe city was preparing to relocate the prairie dogs after discovering\nthe animals have dug through soil caps meant to protect wildlife and\npeople from 2 toxic tailing ponds on the butte. Hopefully in addition to testing the fleas, the\nauthorities will be testing the trailing ponds and conducting full\nnecropsies on some of the prairie dogs. The city had anticipated that the population would have increased by\nas much as 60 percent since last year [2007], however their numbers\nhave dropped by about 75 percent. Plague has often\nbeen found in the western portions of the United States and this year\n(2008) may be no exception. For general information about plague, call the Boulder County Public\nHealth Alert Line at 303-441-1460 or visit\n<http://www.BoulderCountyVector.org>. \n\nUntil the test results are announced, the city will postpone any\nplans to relocate prairie dogs or continue with any remediation work. \n\nIt is possible the toxic trailing ponds have a legal substance to the\nprairie dogs. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nSigns were posted today [2 May 2008] at the site, warning people to\nstay away from the critters as the county investigates. A population of prairie dogs inhabiting the Valmont Butte site could\nhave the plague, according to Boulder County Public Health officials.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2008-05-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Boulder County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Valmont Butte", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "53089", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, human, feline - USA (NM): early season cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=53089", "date": "2008-01-27 12:00:14", "main_text": "PLAGUE, HUMAN, FELINE - USA (NEW MEXICO): EARLY SEASON CASES\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri 25 Jan 2008\nSource: Carlsbad (NM) Current-Argus [edited]\n<http://www.currentargus.com/ci_8080908>\n\nA 50-year-old Eddy County man has been confirmed with New Mexico's\n1st plague case of 2008. The man was hospitalized but now is\nrecovering at home, the state Department of Health said Friday [25\nJan 2008]. It was the 1st case of plague ever reported in an Eddy\nCounty resident, the department said.\nThe man most likely was exposed to plague while hunting and skinning\nrabbits a few days before falling ill, authorities said. The\ndepartment plans an investigation in the area to look for plague in\nother rabbits.\nThe department also reported that 8 people were potentially exposed\nto pneumonic plague, a dangerous form of the disease, when a cat in\nSanta Fe County developed pneumonic plague before it died. All 8\npeople are receiving antibiotics to prevent pneumonic plague.\nPlague is a bacterial disease of rodents generally transmitted to\nhumans through the bites of infected fleas. It also can be\ntransmitted by direct contact with infected animals. Most people\nbecome ill 2-7 days after being infected. Symptoms of bubonic plague\nin humans include fever; chills; painful swollen lymph nodes in the\ngroin, armpit or neck; and sometimes headache, vomiting and diarrhea.\nSepticemic plague, which occurs when the bacteria spread to the\nblood, also can bring a high fever, abdominal pain and diarrhea.\nPneumonic plague involves the lungs and is the form that can spread\ndirectly from person to person.\nNew Mexico reported 5 human cases of plague in 2007 with one\nfatality. Eight human plague cases were reported in the state in\n2006, and 3 were fatal. Four cases were confirmed in 2005.\nPaul Ettestad, the Health Department's public health veterinarian,\nsaid hunters can get plague when bacteria from an infected animal's\nblood or tissues enter the bloodstream through breaks in the skin\nwhen hunters handle or skin a carcass. The animal also might have\ninfected fleas, which can transmit plague through bites.\nThe department recommends hunters wear disposable gloves while\nhandling wildlife carcasses, then discard the gloves; make sure their\nskin does not come into contact with blood or tissues; wash hands\nthoroughly after handling wildlife; and use an aerosol insecticide to\nkill fleas in the animal's fur. The agency recommends hunters\nconsider discarding a carcass if fleas are visible, and dispose of it\nby burying or double bagging and placing in a sanitary landfill.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n[Cases of plague in feral animals and therefore in humans are unusual\nthis early in a calendar year, although the disease may occur at\nanytime. ProMED has posted a case of human plague from New Mexico in\nJanuary 2000 (Plague, bubonic, human - USA (New Mexico)\n20000127.0138). However, in the past 4 years, 1st cases posted in the\nUSA were May 2004, May 2005, February 2006, and April 2007.\nA map of the state of New Mexico showing the locations of the\ncounties mentioned in the posting can be found at:\n<http://quickfacts.census.gov/qfd/maps/new_mexico_map.html>. - Mod.LL]\n[ProMED-mail would like to thank ProMED-mail Rapporteur Joseph Dudley\nfor submitting similar articles. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n \nPaul Ettestad, the Health Department's public health veterinarian,\nsaid hunters can get plague when bacteria from an infected animal's\nblood or tissues enter the bloodstream through breaks in the skin\nwhen hunters handle or skin a carcass. The department recommends hunters wear disposable gloves while\nhandling wildlife carcasses, then discard the gloves; make sure their\nskin does not come into contact with blood or tissues; wash hands\nthoroughly after handling wildlife; and use an aerosol insecticide to\nkill fleas in the animal's fur. The agency recommends hunters\nconsider discarding a carcass if fleas are visible, and dispose of it\nby burying or double bagging and placing in a sanitary landfill.\n \nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n The department also reported that 8 people were potentially exposed\nto pneumonic plague, a dangerous form of the disease, when a cat in\nSanta Fe County developed pneumonic plague before it died. ProMED has posted a case of human plague from New Mexico in\nJanuary 2000 (Plague, bubonic, human - USA (New Mexico)\n20000127.0138). Source: Carlsbad (NM) Current-Argus [edited]\n<http://www.currentargus.com/ci_8080908>\n\nA 50-year-old Eddy County man has been confirmed with New Mexico's\n1st plague case of 2008. Symptoms of bubonic plague\nin humans include fever; chills; painful swollen lymph nodes in the\ngroin, armpit or neck; and sometimes headache, vomiting and diarrhea. [Cases of plague in feral animals and therefore in humans are unusual\nthis early in a calendar year, although the disease may occur at\nanytime. PLAGUE, HUMAN, FELINE - USA (NEW MEXICO): EARLY SEASON CASES\n***********************************************\n The\ndepartment plans an investigation in the area to look for plague in\nother rabbits.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2008-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-02-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2000-01-25 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2008-01-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2004-05-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-05-25 00:00:00", "2007-04-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Santa Fe County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico 's", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eddy County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "93501", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, prairie dog, ferrets - USA: (SD)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=93501", "date": "2008-07-08 23:57:30", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PRAIRIE DOG, FERRETS - USA: (SOUTH DAKOTA)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\n\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org\n\n\nDate: 7 Jul 2008\nSource: Argus Leader.com [edited]\n<http://www.argusleader.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20080707/NEWS/807070317/1001>\n\n\nRodent plague threatens ferrets\n-------------------------------\nThe area of plague-infected black-tailed prairie dogs has more than\ndoubled in western South Dakota since mid-May [2008], and the disease\ncould begin to seriously hurt the state's population of endangered\nblack-footed ferrets. Plague is almost always fatal to infected\nprairie dogs and has killed a large number of the rodents, wildlife\nexperts said. Black-footed ferrets hunt and dine almost exclusively\non prairie dogs.\n\n'When ferrets eat an infected prairie dog, they'll get a massive\ndose' of plague, said Kevin Atchley, Wall District ranger for the\nU.S. Forest Service. 'It's likely that some ferrets have perished.'\n\nThe infected area has bloomed from 4000 acres to 9100 acres as of\nlast week [1 - 4 Jul 2008], Atchley said. The infected area is within\nthe 300 000-acre Conata Basin south of Wall, SD.\n\nPlague is an infectious disease caused by the bacterium _Yersinia\npestis_. The disease, also known as bubonic plague, spread through\nthe West after it appeared in San Francisco in 1902. It was 1st\ndetected in South Dakota wildlife in western Custer County in 2004.\n\nThe disease is mainly spread through wildlife populations -- coyotes\nbeing a favored traveling host -- by infected fleas that transmit the\ndisease through their bite.\n\nIn late May [2008], workers with the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service,\nthe U.S. Forest Service, the National Park Service and the U.S.\nDepartment of Agriculture's Animal and Plant Health Inspection\nService began dusting prairie dog towns with insecticide to kill the\nfleas but keep the ferret's preferred food source alive.\n\nThe insecticide, similar to what is given to dogs and cats to control\nfleas, is released via a wand sprayer from a tank mounted on an\nall-terrain vehicle. Workers stick the wand down each burrow entrance\nto release the dust. As the prairie dogs enter and exit, the dust is\nrubbed into the fur and kills the fleas. As of last week, workers\ndusted 2440 acres of prairie dog towns, including 700 acres within\nBadlands National Park.\n\n'We've dusted specific areas to hold onto our good, productive ferret\nareas,' said Scott Larson, spokesman for the U.S. Fish and Wildlife\nService in Pierre, SD. 'We think it's taken out a lot of the prairie\ndog population, and a lot of that (area) is occupied by ferrets.'\n\n'We'll spray one-third of the colonies to protect two-thirds of the\nferret population,' Atchley said.\n\nThe plague is headed toward Badlands National Park.\n\n'We're anticipating that it'll be in our prairie dog towns,' said\nBrian Kenner, chief of resource management for the park. 'I don't\nthink there's any way to stop it. We don't have a strategy to stop\nit. It can jump pretty far.'\n\nDusting also will be done along Highway 44 and Conata Basin Road as a\nprecaution against a transfer to people. Transmission between\nwildlife and humans is rare, but it is possible. There has never been\na case of human plague reported in South Dakota, said state\nepidemiologist Dr. Lon Kightlinger.\n\nStill, signs have been posted along Highway 44 in the Conata Basin\nand Badlands National Park, warning visitors of the threat. The\nbright yellow signs advise people to stay in their vehicle -- and\nkeep their pets inside the vehicle as well -- around prairie dog villages.\n\nVisitors don't seem to be worried.\n\n'Very few people have expressed a concern about it,' said Judy Olson,\nchief of interpretation for the park.\n\nYet the threat remains for the black-footed ferret, once thought to\nbe extinct but now representing one of the most successful\nreintroduction efforts of wild animals back into a species'\nhistorical range. For the black-footed ferret, that range included\ngrassland habitats in 12 U.S. states, two Canadian provinces and\npossibly northern Mexico.\n\nThe last wild ferrets -- Fish and Wildlife Service officials called\nthem the rarest 18 mammals on Earth -- were captured in Wyoming in\n1987 to begin the breeding and reintroduction program. There are an\nestimated 600 to 800 ferrets now living at 15 reintroduction sites.\n\nAbout 300 ferrets live within the Conata Basin -- considered by\nwildlife advocates to be the most successful of all the sites.\n\nBut the outbreak could hamper future release efforts in western South Dakota.\n\n'We're very concerned,' Larson said. 'That's why we're out there with\nthe other agencies to put down that dust.'\n\n[Byline: Thom Gabrukiewicz\n<tgabrukiew@argusleader.com>]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A photo of the black-footed ferret may be found at:\n<http://animals.nationalgeographic.com/animals/mammals/black-footed-ferret.html>\n\nIt has taken a little less than a year for this disease to reach the\nConata Basin. Prairie dogs are often sentinel animals for this\ndisease. A photo of a prairie dog may be seen at:\n<http://www.northrup.org/photos/Animals/nl-41.htm>.\n\nThe causative bacterium, _Yersinia pestis_, is transmitted to people\nthrough fleabite and direct contact with infected animals. Each\nrodent species is host to one or more species of flea, which, when\ninfected, is a carrier. These fleas generally do not infest other\nanimals unless their natural hosts are unavailable. Rock squirrels\n(_Spermophilus variegatus_) are closely related to California ground\nsquirrels and are the most significant plague host in Colorado. Their\nprincipal flea (_Diamanus montanus_) is an aggressive parasite and\nwill readily bite other animals and people. Domestic cats and dogs\ncan also contract plague by infective fleas. They may carry infected\nfleas home to their owners or, especially with cats, serve as a\ndirect source of infection.", "summary": "In late May [2008], workers with the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service,\nthe U.S. Forest Service, the National Park Service and the U.S.\nDepartment of Agriculture's Animal and Plant Health Inspection\nService began dusting prairie dog towns with insecticide to kill the\nfleas but keep the ferret's preferred food source alive. A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\n\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org\n\n\nDate: 7 Jul 2008\n The area of plague-infected black-tailed prairie dogs has more than\ndoubled in western South Dakota since mid-May [2008], and the disease\ncould begin to seriously hurt the state's population of endangered\nblack-footed ferrets. Yet the threat remains for the black-footed ferret, once thought to\nbe extinct but now representing one of the most successful\nreintroduction efforts of wild animals back into a species'\nhistorical range. \n\nThe disease is mainly spread through wildlife populations -- coyotes\nbeing a favored traveling host -- by infected fleas that transmit the\ndisease through their bite. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A photo of the black-footed ferret may be found at:\n<http://animals.nationalgeographic.com/animals/mammals/black-footed-ferret.html>\n\nIt has taken a little less than a year for this disease to reach the\nConata Basin. \n\n'When ferrets eat an infected prairie dog, they'll get a massive\ndose' of plague, said Kevin Atchley, Wall District ranger for the\nU.S. Forest Service. ' \n\n[Byline: Thom Gabrukiewicz\n<tgabrukiew@argusleader.com>]\n\n--\n \n\nThe insecticide, similar to what is given to dogs and cats to control\nfleas, is released via a wand sprayer from a tank mounted on an\nall-terrain vehicle. \n\n'We've dusted specific areas to hold onto our good, productive ferret\nareas,' said Scott Larson, spokesman for the U.S. Fish and Wildlife\nService in Pierre, SD. ' Plague is almost always fatal to infected\nprairie dogs and has killed a large number of the rodents, wildlife\nexperts said. The\nbright yellow signs advise people to stay in their vehicle -- and\nkeep their pets inside the vehicle as well -- around prairie dog villages. The last wild ferrets -- Fish and Wildlife Service officials called\nthem the rarest 18 mammals on Earth -- were captured in Wyoming in\n1987 to begin the breeding and reintroduction program. As of last week, workers\ndusted 2440 acres of prairie dog towns, including 700 acres within\nBadlands National Park. PLAGUE, PRAIRIE DOG, FERRETS - USA: (SOUTH DAKOTA)\n**************************************************\n They may carry infected\nfleas home to their owners or, especially with cats, serve as a\ndirect source of infection. For the black-footed ferret, that range included\ngrassland habitats in 12 U.S. states, two Canadian provinces and\npossibly northern Mexico. Source: Argus Leader.com [edited]\n<http://www.argusleader.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20080707/NEWS/807070317/1001>\n\n\nRodent plague threatens ferrets\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1902-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00", "1987-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Pierre", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Francisco", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Dakota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Custer County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "57741", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Plague, pneumonic, fatal - Congo DR: (Orientale), susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=57741", "date": "2008-02-13 11:00:16", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PNEUMONIC, FATAL - CONGO DR: (ORIENTALE), SUSPECTED\n***********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 12 Feb 2008\nSource: AllAfrica, Le Potentiel (Kinshasa) report [in French, trans.\nMod.MPP, edited]\n<http://fr.allafrica.com/stories/200802120247.html>\n\n\nAn unknown disease similar to pneumonic plague has killed 5 persons\namong the 20 cases reported since January [2008] in a locality of the\nNortheast of the Democratic Republic of the Congo [DRC], according to\nthe Ministry of Health. 'There is the suspicion of pulmonary plague\nsince the beginning of the month of January [2008] in Bolelole,'\nOrientale province, located approximately 500 km (311 mi) to the\nnortheast of Kisangani, declared Dr Vital Mondonge, director of the\nDepartment of Epidemics in the Ministry of Health.\n\nAccording to the source, patient care has been provided by the local\nstructure of the Ministry of Health, assisted by a team from Medecins\nSans Frontieres (MSF) [Doctors Without Borders], said Dr Mondonge.\n\n'The situation seems to be under control because, we have not\nreported new cases in the past 2 weeks' he said, saying that disease\nsurveillance and public awareness were strengthened.\n\nSamples taken from the cases in order to detect the responsible\n[bacteria] have been sent to a laboratory in Bunia, approximately 200\nkm (125 mi) to the east.\n\n'We are awaiting the results of the [laboratory] analyses, which can\ntake several weeks' said Dr Mondonge. In October 2006, the World\nHealth Organization [WHO] had reported a probable 'outbreak.'\nConsidered by the WHO to be a re-emerging disease, plague can be\nextremely contagious, when transmitted by the respiratory route\n[through inhalation] or through contact with secretions.\n\n[Byline: Regine Kiala]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Primary pneumonic plague (one percent of natural plague\npresentations) arises as a result of inhalation of plague bacilli in\ninfectious aerosols, such as would be produced when there are\nsecondary pneumonic complications in bubonic/septicemic plague.\n\nPrimary plague pneumonia has a short incubation period of 1-3 days,\nafter which there is sudden onset of flu-like symptoms including\nfever, chills, headache, generalized body pains, weakness, and chest\ndiscomfort. A cough develops with sputum production, which may be\nbloody, and increasing chest pain and difficulty in breathing. As the\ndisease progresses, hypoxia (low oxygen concentration in the blood)\nand hemoptysis (coughing up blood) are prominent. The disease is\ninvariably fatal unless antimicrobial therapy commences within 24\nhours of exposure.\n\nPatients with primary pneumonic plague generate large quantities of\ninfectious aerosols that pose a significant risk to close contacts.\nCDC (US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) guidelines\nidentify contacts within 2 meters (6.5 ft) as being at greatest risk\nand do not consider the organism likely to be carried through air\nducts or vents. Persons who have been in contact with pneumonic\nplague patients or handling potentially infectious body fluids or\ntissues without appropriate protection should receive preventive\nantimicrobial therapy. The preferred antimicrobial agents for\nprophylaxis are tetracyclines, quinolones, or chloramphenicol.\n\nA map of Congo DR showing the northeast Orientale (also written\nOriental or Eastern) province can be found at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/africa/congo_demrep_pol98.jpg>. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 12 Feb 2008\n promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Primary pneumonic plague (one percent of natural plague\npresentations) arises as a result of inhalation of plague bacilli in\ninfectious aerosols, such as would be produced when there are\nsecondary pneumonic complications in bubonic/septicemic plague. \n\nPrimary plague pneumonia has a short incubation period of 1-3 days,\nafter which there is sudden onset of flu-like symptoms including\nfever, chills, headache, generalized body pains, weakness, and chest\ndiscomfort. An unknown disease similar to pneumonic plague has killed 5 persons\namong the 20 cases reported since January [2008] in a locality of the\nNortheast of the Democratic Republic of the Congo [DRC], according to\nthe Ministry of Health. ' Persons who have been in contact with pneumonic\nplague patients or handling potentially infectious body fluids or\ntissues without appropriate protection should receive preventive\nantimicrobial therapy. CDC (US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) guidelines\nidentify contacts within 2 meters (6.5 ft) as being at greatest risk\nand do not consider the organism likely to be carried through air\nducts or vents. The situation seems to be under control because, we have not\nreported new cases in the past 2 weeks' he said, saying that disease\nsurveillance and public awareness were strengthened. Considered by the WHO to be a re-emerging disease, plague can be\nextremely contagious, when transmitted by the respiratory route\n \n\nA map of Congo DR showing the northeast Orientale (also written\nOriental or Eastern) province can be found at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/africa/congo_demrep_pol98.jpg>. There is the suspicion of pulmonary plague\nsince the beginning of the month of January [2008] in Bolelole,'\n As the\ndisease progresses, hypoxia (low oxygen concentration in the blood)\nand hemoptysis (coughing up blood) are prominent.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-10-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bunia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of the", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kinshasa", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "42441", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, fatal - China: (Gansu)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=42441", "date": "2007-12-12 23:00:48", "main_text": "PLAGUE, FATAL - CHINA: (GANSU)\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 10 Dec 2007\nSource: XinHuaNet [edited]\n<http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2007-12/10/content_7226599.htm>\n\n\nChina's northwest Gansu Province reported its 2nd plague case in 2007\nin November, China's Ministry of Health said here on Monday [10 Dec\n2007]. The patient died, the ministry said in its monthly report on\ninfectious diseases. No further details were provided.\n\nGansu also reported China's 1st plague case of 2007 in September.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[No information is given regarding either case. Deaths in _Y. pestis_\ninfection usually relate to bacteremia and/or pneumonia. A map of\nChina showing the north-central Gansu province can be found at:\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gansu>.\n- Mod.LL]\n\n[Plague cases in north China near the Mongolian border are usually in\nmarmot hunters who get it from bites from their infected fleas or from\ncontact with infected blood while skinning the marmots. - Mod.JW]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 10 Dec 2007\n LL]\n\n[Plague cases in north China near the Mongolian border are usually in\nmarmot hunters who get it from bites from their infected fleas or from\ncontact with infected blood while skinning the marmots. China's northwest Gansu Province reported its 2nd plague case in 2007\nin November, China's Ministry of Health said here on Monday [10 Dec\n2007]. A map of\nChina showing the north-central Gansu province can be found at:\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gansu>.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-11-25 00:00:00", "2021-09-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gansu Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gansu", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "81720", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, feline - USA (WY): mountain lion", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=81720", "date": "2008-05-22 22:00:22", "main_text": "PLAGUE, FELINE - USA (WYOMING): MOUNTAIN LION\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 21 May 2008\nSource: University of Wyoming News [edited]\n<http://www.uwyo.edu/news/showrelease.asp?id=23719>\n\n\nMountain lion hunters, domestic cat owners and others who may come in\ncontact with mountain lions in Wyoming and other western states are\nurged to protect themselves and their animals against plague.\n\n'Plague was confirmed in a mountain lion found dead in mid-April 2008\nby a landowner in rural Johnson County,' said Todd Cornish, an\nassociate professor in the University of Wyoming College of\nAgriculture's Department of Veterinary Sciences.\n\nCornish said this is the 5th case of plague confirmed in mountain\nlions in Wyoming in the past 3 years. The other 4 cases were in Teton\nCounty and the Greater Yellowstone Area of northwestern Wyoming.\n\n'Plague is an important consideration when mountain lions are found\nsick or dead in Wyoming and elsewhere in the western United States,'\nCornish said.\n\nThose who find sick or dead mountain lions or similar species,\nincluding bobcats, should avoid contact with the animals and are\nasked to contact the Wyoming Game and Fish Department (WGFD), Cornish\nsaid. Contact information for regional offices can be found on the\nWGFD website at\n<http://gf.state.wy.us/admin/regional/index.asp>.\n\n'Appropriate personal safety precautions should be taken by wildlife\nprofessionals working in the field and diagnosticians working in\nlaboratories when handling these animals or their tissues,' he added.\nInformation on how people can protect themselves is available on the\nWyoming State Veterinary Laboratory (WSVL) website at\n<http://wyovet.uwyo.edu/Disease_Updates.asp>.\n\n'Plague is a serious zoonotic disease capable of causing significant\nillness and even death in humans, as exemplified by a recent fatal\ncase of plague in a wildlife biologist working at Grand Canyon\nNational Park (in Arizona),' Cornish said. A zoonotic disease is one\nthat can be transmitted from animals to humans.\n\nThe National Park Service biologist, Eric York, 37, performed a\nnecropsy of a mountain lion carcass last October [2007], and\napproximately 5 days later, he developed a high temperature, mild\nnausea, muscle aches, chills, a cough and streaks of blood in his\nsaliva, according to an article in the April 2008 edition of the\nNewsletter of the Wildlife Disease Association (WDA).\n\nYork died several days later, and specimens from the biologist and\nthe mountain lion both tested positive for the bacterium that causes\nplague, _Yersinia pestis_, according to the WDA article.\n\nWildlife biologists, wildlife veterinarians, public health officials,\nhunters skinning an animal with plague and the owners of domestic\ncats stricken with the disease are among those susceptible to plague.\nCats can contract plague by eating an infected rodent or by being\nbitten by fleas from an infected host.\n\nCornish said: 'What's becoming more of a common recommendation is to\navoid allowing your cats to hunt wildlife. Concerned cat owners\nshould also consider visiting with their veterinarian about a\nflea-control program.'\n\nThere have been one fatal and 4 non-fatal cases of humans contracting\nplague in Wyoming since 1978, said Karl Musgrave, state public health\nveterinarian with the Wyoming Department of Health. There were 2\ncases in Washakie County and one each in Goshen, Laramie and Sheridan counties.\n\nThe 1992 Sheridan County case resulted in the death of a man after he\ncontracted the disease when skinning an infected bobcat. The Goshen\nCounty case involved a resident of Colorado.\n\nWGFD assistant veterinarian Cynthia Tate said: 'Finding plague in\nanimals such as mountain lions and bobcats -- and occasionally\ndomestic cats -- is not surprising because they eat rodents, and\nrodents are the typical carriers.'\n\nTate added: 'Those who hunt or trap predators should protect\nthemselves while skinning animals or handling traps by wearing long\nrubber or latex gloves. They should avoid contact with an animal that\nappears sick (rough hair, coat and/or drainage out of the eyes) and\nimmediately contact the WGFD.'\n\nTate cautions that animals having plague may not appear sick because\nthe disease can kill rapidly. The incubation period of plague is\nbetween 2 and 6 days after exposure, she noted. If hunters or others\ndevelop flu-like symptoms within that period, they should call their doctor.\n\nKen Mills, a professor in the UW Department of Veterinary Sciences,\nsaid: 'Plague could be a risk to mountain lion hunters, but I see it\nas more of a risk to the owners of domestic cats allowed to go\noutside and hunt rodents.'\n\nThere have been at least 7 unrelated cases of plague in domestic cats\nin Wyoming since 2005, Mills said. They included 4 in Laramie County\nand one each in Albany, Natrona and Teton counties.\n\n'If your cat develops a fever and has swollen lymph nodes, it is\ndefinitely time to call a veterinarian,' he said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Cats are sensitive indicators of plague. The size of the cat is\nimmaterial, and these cases demonstrate the sensitivity. Prairie dogs\nare more sensitive than cats, but nevertheless, cats are quite sensitive.\n\nOften, plague in cats, particularly domestic cats, may initially be\nconfused with a cat fight or cat bite abscess, as there are often\nswellings in the mandibular region. These swellings are buboes,\nabscesses from a fight. Consequently, veterinarians, technicians,\nanimal shelter workers and animal caretakers may be come victims when\nbuboes rupture.\n\nPlague, caused by _Yersinia pestis_, is an acute and sometimes fatal\nbacterial zoonosis that is transmitted primarily by the fleas of rats\nand other rodents. Enzootic foci of sylvatic plague exist in the\nwestern USA and throughout the world, including Eurasia, Africa, and\nNorth and South America. In addition to rodents, other mammalian\nspecies that have been naturally infected with _Y. pestis_ include\nlagomorphs, felids, canids, mustelids, and some ungulates. Domestic\ncats and dogs have also developed plague from oral mucous membrane\nexposure to infected rodent tissues, typically when they are allowed\nto roam and hunt in enzootic areas. Birds and other non-mammalian\nvertebrates appear to be resistant to plague. On average, 10 human\nplague cases are reported each year in the USA; the majority are from\nNew Mexico, California, Colorado, and Arizona. Most human cases\nresult from the bite of an infected flea, although direct contact\nwith infected wild rabbits, rodents, and occasionally other wildlife\nand exposure to infected domestic cats are also risk factors.\n\n_Y. pestis_ is a gram-negative, nonmotile, coccobacillus belonging to\nthe _Enterobacteriacae_ family. It exhibits a bipolar staining,\n'safety pin' appearance when stained with Wright, Giemsa, or Wayson\nstains. _Y. pestis_ grows slowly even at optimal temperatures (28 C)\nand can require greater than 48 hours to produce colonies. Several\ntypes of media can be used to grow _Y. pestis_, including blood agar,\nnutrient broth, and un-enriched agar. Colonies are small (1-2 mm),\ngray, nonmucoid, and have a characteristic 'hammered copper'\nappearance. Different virulence factors are expressed by the organism\nat different temperatures and environments, allowing the organism to\nsurvive in flea vectors and then be transmitted to and multiply in\nmammalian hosts. The organism does not survive for long at high\ntemperatures or in dry environments.\n\n_Y. pestis_ is easily destroyed by sunlight and drying. Even so, when\nreleased into air, the bacterium will survive for up to one hour,\nalthough this could vary depending on conditions.\n\nPneumonic plague is one of several forms of plague. Depending on\ncircumstances, these forms may occur separately or in combination.\n\nPneumonic plague occurs when _Y. pestis_ infects the lungs. This type\nof plague can spread from person to person through the air.\nTransmission can take place if someone breathes in aerosolized\nbacteria, which could happen in a bioterrorist attack. Pneumonic\nplague is also spread by breathing in _Y. pestis_ suspended in\nrespiratory droplets from a person (or animal) with pneumonic plague.\nBecoming infected in this way usually requires direct and close\ncontact with the ill person or animal. Pneumonic plague may also\noccur if a person with bubonic or septicemic plague is untreated and\nthe bacteria spread to the lungs.\n\nBubonic plague is the most common form of plague. This occurs when an\ninfected flea bites a person or when materials contaminated with _Y.\npestis_ enter through a break in a person's skin. Patients develop\nswollen, tender lymph glands (called buboes) and fever, headache,\nchills, and weakness. Bubonic plague does not spread from person to person.\n\nSepticemic plague occurs when plague bacteria multiply in the blood.\nIt can be a complication of pneumonic or bubonic plague or it can\noccur by itself. When it occurs alone, it is caused in the same ways\nas bubonic plague; however, buboes do not develop. Patients have\nfever, chills, prostration, abdominal pain, shock, and bleeding into\nskin and other organs. Septicemic plague does not spread from person to person.\n\nSymptoms and Treatment:\nWith pneumonic plague, the 1st signs of illness are fever, headache,\nweakness, and rapidly developing pneumonia with shortness of breath,\nchest pain, cough, and sometimes bloody or watery sputum. The\npneumonia progresses for 2 to 4 days and may cause respiratory\nfailure and shock. Without early treatment, patients may die.\n\nEarly treatment of pneumonic plague is essential. To reduce the\nchance of death, antibiotics must be given within 24 hours of 1st\nsymptoms. Streptomycin, gentamicin, the tetracyclines, and\nchloramphenicol are all effective against pneumonic plague.\n\nAntibiotic treatment for 7 days will protect people who have had\ndirect, close contact with infected patients. Wearing a close-fitting\nsurgical mask also protects against infection.\n\nA plague vaccine is not currently available for use in the United States.\n\nPortions of this comment were extracted from:\n<http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/51900.htm&word=plague>\nand\n<http://www.bt.cdc.gov/agent/plague/factsheet.asp>.\n- Mod.TG]", "summary": "\n\nThe National Park Service biologist, Eric York, 37, performed a\nnecropsy of a mountain lion carcass last October [2007], and\napproximately 5 days later, he developed a high temperature, mild\nnausea, muscle aches, chills, a cough and streaks of blood in his\nsaliva, according to an article in the April 2008 edition of the\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 21 May 2008\n \n\nWGFD assistant veterinarian Cynthia Tate said: 'Finding plague in\nanimals such as mountain lions and bobcats -- and occasionally\ndomestic cats -- is not surprising because they eat rodents, and\nrodents are the typical carriers.'\n\n Plague is a serious zoonotic disease capable of causing significant\nillness and even death in humans, as exemplified by a recent fatal\ncase of plague in a wildlife biologist working at Grand Canyon\nNational Park (in Arizona),' Cornish said. Source: University of Wyoming News [edited]\n<http://www.uwyo.edu/news/showrelease.asp?id=23719>\n\n\nMountain lion hunters, domestic cat owners and others who may come in\ncontact with mountain lions in Wyoming and other western states are\nurged to protect themselves and their animals against plague. \n\n'Plague was confirmed in a mountain lion found dead in mid-April 2008\nby a landowner in rural Johnson County,' said Todd Cornish, an\nassociate professor in the University of Wyoming College of\n ,\nsaid: 'Plague could be a risk to mountain lion hunters, but I see it\nas more of a risk to the owners of domestic cats allowed to go\noutside and hunt rodents.' \n\nThose who find sick or dead mountain lions or similar species,\nincluding bobcats, should avoid contact with the animals and are\nasked to contact the Wyoming Game and Fish Department (WGFD), Cornish\nsaid. Most human cases\nresult from the bite of an infected flea, although direct contact\nwith infected wild rabbits, rodents, and occasionally other wildlife\nand exposure to infected domestic cats are also risk factors. Domestic\ncats and dogs have also developed plague from oral mucous membrane\nexposure to infected rodent tissues, typically when they are allowed\nto roam and hunt in enzootic areas. \n\nPortions of this comment were extracted from:\n<http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/51900.htm&word=plague>\nand\n<http://www.bt.cdc.gov/agent/plague/factsheet.asp>. Different virulence factors are expressed by the organism\nat different temperatures and environments, allowing the organism to\nsurvive in flea vectors and then be transmitted to and multiply in\nmammalian hosts. \n\nWildlife biologists, wildlife veterinarians, public health officials,\nhunters skinning an animal with plague and the owners of domestic\ncats stricken with the disease are among those susceptible to plague. Pneumonic\nplague is also spread by breathing in _Y. pestis_ suspended in\nrespiratory droplets from a person (or animal) with pneumonic plague. \n\nThere have been one fatal and 4 non-fatal cases of humans contracting\nplague in Wyoming since 1978, said Karl Musgrave, state public health\nveterinarian with the Wyoming Department of Health. \n\nYork died several days later, and specimens from the biologist and\nthe mountain lion both tested positive for the bacterium that causes\nplague, _Yersinia pestis_, according to the WDA article. Pneumonic plague may also\noccur if a person with bubonic or septicemic plague is untreated and\nthe bacteria spread to the lungs. Often, plague in cats, particularly domestic cats, may initially be\nconfused with a cat fight or cat bite abscess, as there are often\nswellings in the mandibular region. With pneumonic plague, the 1st signs of illness are fever, headache,\nweakness, and rapidly developing pneumonia with shortness of breath,\nchest pain, cough, and sometimes bloody or watery sputum. Plague, caused by _Yersinia pestis_, is an acute and sometimes fatal\nbacterial zoonosis that is transmitted primarily by the fleas of rats\nand other rodents. Plague is an important consideration when mountain lions are found\nsick or dead in Wyoming and elsewhere in the western United States,'\n \n\n'Appropriate personal safety precautions should be taken by wildlife\nprofessionals working in the field and diagnosticians working in\nlaboratories when handling these animals or their tissues,' he added. This occurs when an\ninfected flea bites a person or when materials contaminated with _Y.\npestis_ enter through a break in a person's skin. PLAGUE, FELINE - USA (WYOMING): MOUNTAIN LION\n***********************************************\n On average, 10 human\nplague cases are reported each year in the USA; the majority are from\nNew Mexico, California, Colorado, and Arizona. Enzootic foci of sylvatic plague exist in the\nwestern USA and throughout the world, including Eurasia, Africa, and\nNorth and South America. In addition to rodents, other mammalian\nspecies that have been naturally infected with _Y. pestis_ include\nlagomorphs, felids, canids, mustelids, and some ungulates. They should avoid contact with an animal that\nappears sick (rough hair, coat and/or drainage out of the eyes) and\nimmediately contact the WGFD.' Tate added: 'Those who hunt or trap predators should protect\nthemselves while skinning animals or handling traps by wearing long\nrubber or latex gloves. Several\ntypes of media can be used to grow _Y. pestis_, including blood agar,\nnutrient broth, and un-enriched agar.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1978-03-25 00:00:00", "2008-04-25 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2037-03-25 00:00:00", "1992-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Eurasia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North and South America", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Johnson County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sheridan County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washakie County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Goshen", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Albany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Laramie County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "49104", "headline": "PRO/AH> Plague, fatal - Madagascar (02): (Antananarivo)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=49104", "date": "2008-01-14 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, FATAL - MADAGASCAR (02): (ANTANANARIVO)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Sun 13 Jan 2008\nSource: GIDEON (Global Infectious Disease & Epidemiology Network) [edited]\n<http://www.GideonOnline.com>\n\nRecent events in Antananarivo highlight the fact that Africa, and\nparticularly Madagascar, have accounted for most of the world's\nplague deaths since the 1980s.\nSee graphs at\n<http://exhibit.gideononline.com/world-plague.jpg> and\n<http://exhibit.gideononline.com/madagascar-plague.jpg>.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDr Steve Berger\nGeographic Medicine\nTel Aviv Medical Center\nIsrael\n<mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\n[Readers should link to the URLs above to observe the reported deaths\ndue to _Yersinia pestis_ from Gideon.\nThe 1st graph compares worldwide statistics as compared to Africa and\nas compared to Madagascar. It illustrates that over the years 1994 to\n2003, the African continent is the source of most of the world's\nreported cases of plague deaths, and since the increased incidence of\nplague in Madagascar in 1996, a significant percentage of the plague\ndeaths were reported from Madagascar.\nThe 2nd graph reports plague deaths from 5 African nations, Uganda,\nTanzania, Namibia, Congo DR, and Madagascar. In the years 1996-2003,\nMadagascar reported more deaths than any of the other 4 nations with\nCongo DR 2nd. In 1996 and 1997, Tanzania reported the 3rd most plague\ndeaths among the 5 nations, but from 1998-2003, Uganda has taken that\nrole. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "It illustrates that over the years 1994 to\n2003, the African continent is the source of most of the world's\nreported cases of plague deaths, and since the increased incidence of\nplague in Madagascar in 1996, a significant percentage of the plague\ndeaths were reported from Madagascar.\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Source: GIDEON (Global Infectious Disease & Epidemiology Network) [edited]\n<http://www.GideonOnline.com>\n\nRecent events in Antananarivo highlight the fact that Africa, and\nparticularly Madagascar, have accounted for most of the world's\nplague deaths since the 1980s. Tel Aviv Medical Center\nIsrael\n<mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\n \nCommunicated by:\nDr Steve Berger\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1996-03-25 00:00:00", "2008-01-13 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Namibia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Congo DR", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tanzania", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "41231", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, fatal - Uganda: (Arua, Nebbi), RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=41231", "date": "2007-12-06 19:00:21", "main_text": "PLAGUE, FATAL - UGANDA: (ARUA, NEBBI), REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 6 Dec 2007\nSource: AllAfrica, New Vision (Kampala) [edited]\n<http://allafrica.com/stories/200712060049.html>\n\n\nPlague is occurring in Uganda, killing 10 out of 121 infected people\nin Arua, and 9 out of 39 in Nebbi, according to the Ministry of Health.\n\nThe disease broke out in Logiri and Vurra sub-counties of Arua. In\nNebbi, the affected area was Nyapea. No new cases have been reported\nin either area in the past week, partly because of massive indoor\nresidual spraying against fleas.\n\nThe Minister of Primary Health, Dr Emmanuel Otaala, said women were\nmost affected due to the local custom that women sleep on the ground.\nThey are only allowed in bed when the husband invites them for sex,\nhe explained.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Arua and Nebbi are located in northwestern Uganda as can be seen on\na map at <http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/uganda.pdf>.\n\nAs can also be seen below, this area is not uncommonly affected by\n_Yersinia pestis_. - Mod.LL]\n\n[Information on the type of plague (bubonic, pneumonic) involved in\nthis present outbreak would be appreciated. For the interactive\nHealthMap/ProMED map of the region with links to other recent\nProMED-mail postings on events in Uganda and neighboring countries,\nsee <http://healthmap.org/promed?v=1.3,32.4,6>. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 6 Dec 2007\n For the interactive\nHealthMap/ProMED map of the region with links to other recent\nProMED-mail postings on events in Uganda and neighboring countries,\nsee <http://healthmap.org/promed?v=1.3,32.4,6>. No new cases have been reported\nin either area in the past week, partly because of massive indoor\nresidual spraying against fleas. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< \n\nThe Minister of Primary Health, Dr Emmanuel Otaala, said women were\nmost affected due to the local custom that women sleep on the ground. \n\nAs can also be seen below, this area is not uncommonly affected by\n_Yersinia pestis_.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Logiri", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nebbi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kampala", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "40111", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Undiagnosed deaths - Zambia (02): pneumonic plague susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=40111", "date": "2007-11-30 13:00:21", "main_text": "UNDIAGNOSED DEATHS - ZAMBIA (02): PNEUMONIC PLAGUE SUSPECTED\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 30 Nov 2007\nSource: Agence France-Presse (AFP) [edited]\n<http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5gZ9MuVrthZ_q9Ng1raaI2bWSiyIA>\n\n\nA mysterious disease, which broke out in the south of Zambia, killing\n4 people, is now suspected to be pneumonic plague, the health\nministry said Friday [30 Nov 2007].\n\nMinistry of Health spokesman, Canicius Banda, said preliminary\nfindings indicate that the disease that has killed 4 people and\naffected over 60 patients could be pneumonic plague but the findings\nwere not yet conclusive. 'Our preliminary findings point to pneumonic\nplague,' Banda said.\n\nA total of 4 people died and 64 others were put under quarantine last\nweek following the outbreak of the disease in Namwala, a small town\nin the Southern Province of Zambia. Banda said the movement of people\nin the area had been banned with immediate effect in order to contain\nthe disease, which had symptoms of vomiting and backache.\n\nMedical experts had also begun spraying all the houses in the area to\nget rid of fleas and rodents suspected to be spreading the disease.\nThe government has also urged people in Namwala to be calm after word\nwent round that the disease could be the deadly Ebola virus,\nprompting panic.\n\n'We have carried out the tests and it is not Ebola. People should not\npanic, the situation is under control,' Health minister Brian Chituwo\nsaid.\n\nPneumonic plague, which is fatal if left untreated, develops when\nplague bacteria infect the lungs, and can cause a public health\nemergency due to its high degree of contagion.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Primary pneumonic plague (one percent of natural plague\npresentations) arises as a result of inhalation of plague bacilli in\ninfectious aerosols, such as would be produced when there are\npneumonic complications (secondary plague pneumonia) in bubonic or\nsepticemic plague. It is, importantly, the form of the disease that\nwould be most likely if _Yersinia pestis_ were to be used in an\naerosol as a biological weapon. Such an aerosol would likely be used\nin an indoor setting to avoid the outdoor UV radiation inactivation\nof the organism.\n\nPrimary plague pneumonia has a short incubation period of 1-3 days,\nafter which there is sudden onset of flu-like symptoms including\nfever, chills, headache, generalized body pains, weakness, and chest\ndiscomfort. A cough develops with sputum production, which may be\nbloody, and increasing chest pain and difficulty in breathing. As the\ndisease progresses, hypoxia (low oxygen concentration in the blood)\nand hemoptysis (coughing up blood) are prominent. The disease is\ninvariably fatal unless antimicrobial therapy commences within 24\nhours of exposure.\n\nPatients with primary pneumonic plague generate large quantities of\ninfectious aerosols that pose a significant risk to close contacts.\nCDC (US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) guidelines\nidentify contacts within 2 meters (6.5 feet) as being at greatest\nrisk and do not consider the organism likely to be carried through\nair ducts or vents. Persons who have been in contact with pneumonic\nplague patients or handling potentially infectious body fluids or\ntissues without appropriate protection should receive preventive\nantimicrobial therapy.\n\nNamwala is located in the Southern Province of Zambia and can be\nfound on a map at:\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/zambia.pdf>. -\nMod.LL\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Zambia can be accessed at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=-14,27.8,5>. - CopyEd.MJ]", "summary": "promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Primary pneumonic plague (one percent of natural plague\npresentations) arises as a result of inhalation of plague bacilli in\ninfectious aerosols, such as would be produced when there are\npneumonic complications (secondary plague pneumonia) in bubonic or\nsepticemic plague. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 30 Nov 2007\n \n\nMinistry of Health spokesman, Canicius Banda, said preliminary\nfindings indicate that the disease that has killed 4 people and\naffected over 60 patients could be pneumonic plague but the findings\nwere not yet conclusive.
