' Source: Agence France-Presse (AFP) [edited]\n<http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5gZ9MuVrthZ_q9Ng1raaI2bWSiyIA>\n\n\nA mysterious disease, which broke out in the south of Zambia, killing\n4 people, is now suspected to be pneumonic plague, the health\nministry said Friday [30 Nov 2007]. \n\nPrimary plague pneumonia has a short incubation period of 1-3 days,\nafter which there is sudden onset of flu-like symptoms including\nfever, chills, headache, generalized body pains, weakness, and chest\ndiscomfort. Persons who have been in contact with pneumonic\nplague patients or handling potentially infectious body fluids or\ntissues without appropriate protection should receive preventive\nantimicrobial therapy. CDC (US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) guidelines\nidentify contacts within 2 meters (6.5 feet) as being at greatest\nrisk and do not consider the organism likely to be carried through\nair ducts or vents. \n\nPneumonic plague, which is fatal if left untreated, develops when\nplague bacteria infect the lungs, and can cause a public health\nemergency due to its high degree of contagion. \n\nA total of 4 people died and 64 others were put under quarantine last\nweek following the outbreak of the disease in Namwala, a small town\nin the Southern Province of Zambia. Banda said the movement of people\nin the area had been banned with immediate effect in order to contain\nthe disease, which had symptoms of vomiting and backache.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Southern Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Zambia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Namwala", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "48346", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, fatal - Madagascar: (Antananarivo), RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=48346", "date": "2008-01-11 14:00:13", "main_text": "PLAGUE, FATAL - MADAGASCAR: (ANTANANARIVO), REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Fri 11 Jan 2008\nSource: L'Express de Madagascar (transl. - Mod.LM) [edited]\n<http://www.lexpressmada.com/display.php>\n\nThe district of Manjakandriana has been confronted with the bubonic\nplague. With the last information communicated by the service of the\ntransmissible disease, the disease has killed, up to now, 3 people.\nIn addition to a 38-year-old man, an inhabitant of Manankasikely and\ndead on 5 Jan 2008, a 12-year-old is also dead in Ambohitseheno. The 3rd\nvictim lived in the rural district of Ambatolaona, and his death\noccurred in December 2007.\nMoreover, as of 10 Jan 2008, 4 men and a woman are under treatment in\nthe hospital complex of the district.\n'The rats haven't been beaten down. We have rushed a medical team to\nManjakandriana to address the situation,' said Dr. Rolland Robinson,\nchief of the service of the Emergenies and Transmissible Diseases within\nthe Ministry of Health, Family Planning and Social Protection.\nIn all the cases, the killing of rats are not done, because 'that\nsupports the profusion of the fleas and, so the recrudescence of the\nmalady,' said Dr. Robinson. He encourages the cleansing of the places\nand the insecticide use.\n[Byline: Fanja Saholiarisoa]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED Rapporteur Dan Silver\n[3 deaths are reported in this press posting but 18 deaths are noted in\nthe web posting below. ProMED would appreciate learning more\ninformation regarding this outbreak.\nMadagascar was the location of the isolation of multi-antimicrobial\nresistant _Y. pestis_ in 1995 (Galimand M, Guiyoule A, Gerbaud G, et al:\nMultidrug resistance in _Yersinia pestis_ mediated by a transferable\nplasmid. N Engl J Med 1997;337: 677-81). The strain was resistant to\nchloramphenicol, streptomycin and tetracycline but sensitive to\nfluoroquinolones and trimethoprim as well as other aminoglycosides. This\nwas an ominous observation, however, it is not clear if this naturally\noccurring strain has persisted or spread.\nManjakandriana is an administrative region in the central Madagascar\nprovince of Antananarivo. The area can be found on a map of the island\nat:\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antananarivo_Province>. - Mod.LL]\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed 9 Jan 2008\nSource: Les dessous d'information mondiale [edited]\n<http://eldib.wordpress.com/2008/01/10/2175/>\n\nAt least 18 people have died of bubonic plague on the East African\nisland of Madagascar in the past 10 days, and at least 5 patients are\nstill in hospital. Bubonic plague is caused by the _Yersinia pestis_\nbacillus carried by rat fleas.\nAt the start of the rainy season, currently, rats flee the sewers of\nMadagascar in massive numbers and take refuge in people's cottages.\n[The following paragraph of this posting is from 1998 (Chanteau S,\nRatsifasoamanana L, Rasoamanana B, et al: Plague, a Reemerging Disease\nin Madagascar. Emerg Infect Dis 1998;4: 101-104:\n'Between 1930 and 1990, bubonic plague had 'virtually disappeared' on\nthe island due to efficient pest-control and good health-management.\nHowever since 1990, an annual 200 cases are being reported and bubonic\nplague takes on epidemic form especially in the port of Mahajanga each\nyear. In the capital city of Antananarivo more cases are also being\nnotified each year since 1990. Madagascar (pop. 13 million) has\naccounted for 45 percent of all the cases of plague in Africa.'\n- Mod.LL]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Source: Les dessous d'information mondiale [edited]\n<http://eldib.wordpress.com/2008/01/10/2175/>\n\nAt least 18 people have died of bubonic plague on the East African\nisland of Madagascar in the past 10 days, and at least 5 patients are\nstill in hospital. Emerg Infect Dis 1998;4: 101-104:\n'Between 1930 and 1990, bubonic plague had 'virtually disappeared' on\nthe island due to efficient pest-control and good health-management.\n Madagascar was the location of the isolation of multi-antimicrobial\nresistant _Y. pestis_ in 1995 (Galimand M, Guiyoule A, Gerbaud G, et al:\nMultidrug resistance in _Yersinia pestis_ mediated by a transferable\nplasmid. We have rushed a medical team to\nManjakandriana to address the situation,' said Dr. Rolland Robinson,\nchief of the service of the Emergenies and Transmissible Diseases within\nthe Ministry of Health, Family Planning and Social Protection. However since 1990, an annual 200 cases are being reported and bubonic\nplague takes on epidemic form especially in the port of Mahajanga each\nyear. [edited]\n<http://www.lexpressmada.com/display.php>\n\nThe district of Manjakandriana has been confronted with the bubonic\nplague. With the last information communicated by the service of the\ntransmissible disease, the disease has killed, up to now, 3 people.\n In all the cases, the killing of rats are not done, because 'that\nsupports the profusion of the fleas and, so the recrudescence of the\nmalady,' said Dr. Robinson. The strain was resistant to\nchloramphenicol, streptomycin and tetracycline but sensitive to\nfluoroquinolones and trimethoprim as well as other aminoglycosides. The 3rd\nvictim lived in the rural district of Ambatolaona, and his death\noccurred in December 2007. This\nwas an ominous observation, however, it is not clear if this naturally\noccurring strain has persisted or spread. The area can be found on a map of the island\nat:\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antananarivo_Province>. He encourages the cleansing of the places\nand the insecticide use.\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2008-01-09 00:00:00", "2008-01-05 00:00:00", "1990-03-25 00:00:00", "2008-01-10 00:00:00", "1995-03-25 00:00:00", "1998-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-12-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Rasoamanana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Manjakandriana", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "FATAL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ambatolaona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ambohitseheno", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mahajanga", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "36210", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, pneumonic - USA: (AZ)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=36210", "date": "2007-11-10 18:00:12", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PNEUMONIC - USA: (ARIZONA)\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: Sat 10 Nov 2007\nSource: Associated Press [edited]\n<http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5iu07orBOP9KjjRoKB4MOB2cZrkEgD8SQI8PG0>\n\n\nA wildlife biologist at Grand Canyon National Park most likely died\nfrom the plague contracted while performing a necropsy on a mountain\nlion that later tested positive for the disease, officials said Fri 9 Nov 2007.\n\nThe 37 year old, who worked in the park's cougar collaring program,\nbecame ill on 30 Oct 2007 and called out sick from for a couple of\ndays before being found dead in his home 2 Nov 2007. Tests were\npositive for pneumonic plague. Officials said 49 people who came in\ncontact with York were given antibiotics as a precaution. None have\nshown symptoms of the disease.\n\nThe biologist, whose family lives in Massachusetts, had skinned the\ncougar and was exposed to its internal organs during the necropsy he\nperformed 3 days before developing symptoms, said David Wong, an\nepidemiologist for the USA Public Health Service.\n\nThe cougar, which had died from the plague, was believed to have\nremained in back-country areas where park visitors wouldn't normally\ngo, officials said.\n\nThe National Park Service is planning to review its safety guidelines\nfor wildlife biologists and make possible recommendations for\nimprovements. Park Superintendent Steve Martin said authorities were\nexamining whether the guidelines were followed in this case.\n\nAn average of 13 plague cases are reported in the USA each year. A\ntotal of 14 percent of cases are fatal, according to the CDC. While\nArizona health officials say the disease appears to be on the rise in\nthe state, CDC spokeswoman Lola Russell said plague cases weren't on\nthe rise nationally.\n\nPlague is transmitted primarily by fleas and direct contact with\ninfected animals. When the disease causes pneumonia, it can be\ntransmitted from an infected person to a non-infected person by\nairborne cough droplets. Cases are treatable with antibiotics.\n\n[Byline: Jacques Billeaud]\n\n--\nContributed by:\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n*****\n[2]\nDate: Fri 9 Nov 2007\nSource: Los Angeles Times [edited]\n<http://travel.latimes.com/articles/la-trw-plague9nov09>\n\n\nGrand Canyon National Park issued new precautions for visitors after\nlab tests indicated that a wildlife biologist had died from pneumonic\nplague. The biologist was found dead 2 Nov 2007 in his home on the\ncanyon's South Rim, and the preliminary lab results were reported\ntoday [9 Nov 2007].\n\nPamela Walls, parks spokeswoman, emphasized that the victim had\nlimited contact with visitors and that, in any event,\nperson-to-person transmission of the potentially fatal disease was\nhighly unlikely. According to the CDC, she said, such transmission\nhas not been observed in the USA since 1924.\n\nHowever, because the disease, carried by fleas that feed off infected\nrodents, can infect humans through flea bites or by direct contact\nwith infected animals, Walls said, officials are adding new\nprecautions to their usual advice to avoid feeding or approaching\nwild animals. Among the recommendations:\n- use insect repellent when visiting or working in areas where\nplague might be active or rodents might be present;\n- control fleas on pets by using flea collars or flea sprays;\n- prevent pets from roaming loose;\n- avoid exposure to rodent burrows and fleas and wild animals; and\n- do not handle sick or dead animals.\n\nWalls said 49 people, including co-workers and roommates but no park\nvisitors, are known to have had contact with the biologist, and they\nhave been put on antibiotics. So far none has shown symptoms, she\nadded. Walls also said she wasn't aware of any prior infections or\ndeaths involving the disease at the park.\n\n[Byline: Jane Engle]\n\n--\nContributed by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Primary pneumonic plague (1 percent of natural plague presentations)\narises as a result of inhalation of plague bacilli in infectious\naerosols, such as would be produced when there are pneumonic\ncomplications in bubonic plague. It is, importantly, the form of the\ndisease that would be most likely if _Yersinia pestis_ were to be\nused in an aerosol as a biological weapon. Such an aerosol would\nlikely be used in an indoor setting to avoid the outdoor UV radiation\ninactivation of the organism.\n\nPrimary plague pneumonia has a short incubation period of 1-3 days,\nafter which there is sudden onset of flu-like symptoms including\nfever, chills, headache, generalized body pains, weakness and chest\ndiscomfort. A cough develops with sputum production, which may be\nbloody, and increasing chest pain and difficulty in breathing. As the\ndisease progresses, hypoxia (low oxygen concentration in the blood)\nand hemoptysis (coughing up blood) are prominent. The disease is\ninvariably fatal unless antimicrobial therapy commences within 24\nhours of exposure.\n\nPatients with primary pneumonic plague generate large quantities of\ninfectious aerosols that pose a significant risk to close contacts.\nCDC guidelines identify contacts within 2 meters [6.5 feet] as being\nat greatest risk and do not consider the organism likely to be\ncarried through air ducts or vents. Persons who have been in contact\nwith pneumonic plague patients or handling potentially infectious\nbody fluids or tissues without appropriate protection should receive\npreventive antimicrobial therapy.\n\nThe location of Grand Canyon National Park in northwestern Arizona\ncan be found at:\n<http://www.cnn.com/EARTH/9705/27/grand.canyon/az.grand.canyon.lg.jpg>\n- Mod.LL]", "summary": "Among the recommendations:\n- use insect repellent when visiting or working in areas where\nplague might be active or rodents might be present;\n- control fleas on pets by using flea collars or flea sprays;\n- prevent pets from roaming loose;\n- avoid exposure to rodent burrows and fleas and wild animals; and\n- do not handle sick or dead animals. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\n However, because the disease, carried by fleas that feed off infected\nrodents, can infect humans through flea bites or by direct contact\nwith infected animals, Walls said, officials are adding new\nprecautions to their usual advice to avoid feeding or approaching\nwild animals. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Primary pneumonic plague (1 percent of natural plague presentations)\narises as a result of inhalation of plague bacilli in infectious\naerosols, such as would be produced when there are pneumonic\ncomplications in bubonic plague. \n\nPrimary plague pneumonia has a short incubation period of 1-3 days,\nafter which there is sudden onset of flu-like symptoms including\nfever, chills, headache, generalized body pains, weakness and chest\ndiscomfort. \n\nPamela Walls, parks spokeswoman, emphasized that the victim had\nlimited contact with visitors and that, in any event,\nperson-to-person transmission of the potentially fatal disease was\nhighly unlikely. Source: Los Angeles Times [edited]\n<http://travel.latimes.com/articles/la-trw-plague9nov09>\n\n\nGrand Canyon National Park issued new precautions for visitors after\nlab tests indicated that a wildlife biologist had died from pneumonic\nplague. While\nArizona health officials say the disease appears to be on the rise in\nthe state, CDC spokeswoman Lola Russell said plague cases weren't on\nthe rise nationally. Persons who have been in contact\nwith pneumonic plague patients or handling potentially infectious\nbody fluids or tissues without appropriate protection should receive\npreventive antimicrobial therapy. The biologist, whose family lives in Massachusetts, had skinned the\ncougar and was exposed to its internal organs during the necropsy he\nperformed 3 days before developing symptoms, said David Wong, an\nepidemiologist for the USA Public Health Service. The location of Grand Canyon National Park in northwestern Arizona\ncan be found at:\n<http://www.cnn.com/EARTH/9705/27/grand.canyon/az.grand.canyon.lg.jpg>\n- Mod. A wildlife biologist at Grand Canyon National Park most likely died\nfrom the plague contracted while performing a necropsy on a mountain\nlion that later tested positive for the disease, officials said Fri 9 Nov 2007. \n\nWalls said 49 people, including co-workers and roommates but no park\nvisitors, are known to have had contact with the biologist, and they\nhave been put on antibiotics. The 37 year old, who worked in the park's cougar collaring program,\nbecame ill on 30 Oct 2007 and called out sick from for a couple of\ndays before being found dead in his home 2 Nov 2007. The cougar, which had died from the plague, was believed to have\nremained in back-country areas where park visitors wouldn't normally\ngo, officials said. When the disease causes pneumonia, it can be\ntransmitted from an infected person to a non-infected person by\nairborne cough droplets. \n\nThe National Park Service is planning to review its safety guidelines\nfor wildlife biologists and make possible recommendations for\nimprovements. The biologist was found dead 2 Nov 2007 in his home on the\ncanyon's South Rim, and the preliminary lab results were reported\ntoday CDC guidelines identify contacts within 2 meters [6.5 feet] as being\nat greatest risk and do not consider the organism likely to be\ncarried through air ducts or vents. The disease is\ninvariably fatal unless antimicrobial therapy commences within 24\nhours of exposure. As the\ndisease progresses, hypoxia (low oxygen concentration in the blood)\nand hemoptysis (coughing up blood) are prominent. It is, importantly, the form of the\ndisease that would be most likely if _Yersinia pestis_ were to be\nused in an aerosol as a biological weapon. Such an aerosol would\nlikely be used in an indoor setting to avoid the outdoor UV radiation\ninactivation of the organism. Contributed by:\nProMED-mail\n< Plague is transmitted primarily by fleas and direct contact with\ninfected animals. Patients with primary pneumonic plague generate large quantities of\ninfectious aerosols that pose a significant risk to close contacts. Officials said 49 people who came in\ncontact with York were given antibiotics as a precaution.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-25 00:00:00", "1924-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "33247", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Crayfish plague - UK (England)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=33247", "date": "2007-10-23 10:00:08", "main_text": "CRAYFISH PLAGUE - UNITED KINGDOM (ENGLAND)\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 22 Oct 2007\nSource: East Anglian Daily Times (EADT24), Suffolk & Essex online [edited]\n<http://www.eadt.co.uk/content/eadt/news/story.aspx?brand=EADOnline&category=News&tBrand=EADOnline&tCategory=news&itemid=IPED22%20Oct%202007%2016%3A09%3A11%3A567>\n\n\nA highly contagious disease threatening the future of Britain's\nendangered white-clawed crayfish has broken out, the Environment\nAgency (EA) said today [22 Oct 2007].\n\nHundreds of dead crayfish have been found in the River Waveney, near\nBeccles, over recent weeks.\n\nAmanda Elliott, spokeswoman for the EA, said tests today confirmed an\noutbreak of _Aphanomyces astaci_, commonly known as crayfish plague.\nMeasures are now being put in place to try to prevent any spread,\nparticularly to rivers populated by the British white-clawed\ncrayfish. Ms Elliott said: 'The affected animals are Turkish crayfish\n[_Astacus leptodactylus_, also known as the narrow-clawed crayfish,\nan introduced species, which has become established in the UK. -\nMod.AS]. What we [are] most concerned about is preventing the disease\nspreading to another river system. 'Luckily, there are no British\nwhite-clawed crayfish recorded in the River Waveney.'\n\nRiver users are being urged to thoroughly clean equipment before\nusing it in other waterways, she added.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[The causative agent of crayfish plague, _Aphanomyces astaci_, is a\nmember of a group of organisms commonly known as the water moulds.\nAlthough long regarded to be fungi, this group -- the Oomycetida --\nare not members of the Eumycota and are now classified with diatoms\nand brown algae in a group called the Stramenopiles or Chromista. For\nfurther information on crayfish plague please refer to chapter 2.3.7.\nof OIE's (World Organization for Animal Health) Manual of Diagnostic\nTests for Aquatic animals, available on-line at\n<http://oie.int/eng/normes/fmanual/A_00054.htm>.\n\nBeccles is on the Norfolk-Suffolk border and can be seen on the map at\n<http://www.multimap.com/maps/?&t=l&map=52.4461938361858,1.59004034116591|14|4&loc=GB:52.4461938361858:1.59004034116591:14&dp=841#t=l&map=52.44619,1.59004|10|4&dp=841&loc=GB:52.4461938361858:1.59004034116591:14>.\n\nWhite-clawed crayfish (_Austropotamobius pallipes_) is an endangered\nEuropean freshwater crayfish, and the only species of crayfish native\nto the British Isles. - Mod. AS\nPhotos of the white-clawed crayfish and the narrow-clawed crayfish\ncan be seen at\n<http://www.shrimpcrabsandcrayfish.co.uk/Shrimp.htm?crayfishEuAs.html~mainFrame>.\n- CopyEd.MJ]\n...................................arn/mj/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. She is currently hospitalized and recovering, according to the\ndepartment. The 4 other cases of plague confirmed in the state in\n2007 occurred in Santa Fe, Torrance, San Juan, and Bernalillo\ncounties. A Bernalillo County boy died of the disease in June 2007.\nHealth Department officials are currently working with the\nAlbuquerque Environmental health department to determine where the\nEast Mountain woman may have contracted the disease. 'We are\ndetermining whether others are at risk, alerting physicians that\nplague is in the area, and providing information to neighbors in a\ndoor-to-door educational campaign,' state epidemiologist Mack Sewell\nsaid in a news release.\nPrevious plague cases in 2007 have been associated with flea bites,\naccording to the health department. Sewell suggests that people use a\nflea control product on their pets to minimize the likelihood off\nintroducing fleas to their environments.\nNew Mexico experienced 8 human plague cases in 2006, 2 of them fatal;\n4 cases were reported in 2005. There [were] no reported cases of\nhuman plague in 2004.\n[Byline: Reed Upton]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[There have been 255 cases of human plague in New Mexico since 1949\nwith 33 deaths. Most New Mexico human plague cases have occurred in\nthe 7 northern counties of Bernalillo, McKinley, Rio Arriba, San\nMiguel, Sandoval, Santa Fe, and Taos (see\n<http://www.health.state.nm.us/epi/documents/HumanPlagueinNMbyCountythrough2006_000.pdf>.)\nOf these cases, most occur between the months of May through September (see\n<http://www.health.state.nm.us/epi/documents/HumanPlagueinNMbymonthyeardecadethrough2006.pdf>.)\nThe formal press release from the New Mexico State Health Department\ncan be found at\n<http://www.health.state.nm.us/epi/documents/plaguefifthcase9-28-07_000.pdf>\nA map of New Mexico showing Bernalillo County and Albuquerque, in the\ncentral part of the state, can be found at\n<http://quickfacts.census.gov/qfd/maps/new_mexico_map.html>.\nThe counties where 2007's previous cases occurred can also be found\non the map. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n [Byline: Reed Upton]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n We are\ndetermining whether others are at risk, alerting physicians that\nplague is in the area, and providing information to neighbors in a\ndoor-to-door educational campaign,' state epidemiologist Mack Sewell\nsaid in a news release. Most New Mexico human plague cases have occurred in\nthe 7 northern counties of Bernalillo, McKinley, Rio Arriba, San\nMiguel, Sandoval, Santa Fe, and Taos (see\n<http://www.health.state.nm.us/epi/documents/HumanPlagueinNMbyCountythrough2006_000.pdf>.) Health Department officials are currently working with the\nAlbuquerque Environmental health department to determine where the\nEast Mountain woman may have contracted the disease. ' PLAGUE, BUBONIC, HUMAN - USA (NEW MEXICO)\n*****************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-06-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "1949-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "San Juan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bernalillo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santa Fe", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "McKinley", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bernalillo County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "28748", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, bubonic - Mongolia (Gobisumber)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=28748", "date": "2007-09-24 21:00:10", "main_text": "PLAGUE, BUBONIC - MONGOLIA (GOBISUMBER)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 20 Sep 2007\nSource: The UB Post [edited]\n<http://ubpost.mongolnews.mn/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=661>\n\nA case of glandular bubonic plague in Gobisumber aimag was confirmed\nthis week. [In Mongolia, an aimag is the 1st level administrative\nsubdivision or province. Each aimag is again subdivided into sums. - Mod.LL]\nA 16-year-old boy in Choir, the capital city of the aimag, showed\nsymptoms of the plague, some days after he had cut his finger while\nskinning a marmot hunted by his father. The marmot is a primary\ncarrier of the plague bacillus in Mongolia.\nThe preliminary diagnosis was confirmed by tests at the National\nCenter for Infectious Disease with Natural Foci (NCIDNF). The boy's\ncondition is now stable, according to local authorities.\n[The Center has sent] 5 veterinary surgeons to Choir to assess the\nsituation. Detailed investigations identified 57 persons with whom\nthe boy came into direct contact during the incubation period. Of\nthem, 54 found in the area were isolated and given preventive medical\ntreatment. [Of these,] 40 have been since released, as they showed no\nsymptoms during the incubation period.\n[Byline: Ch. Sumiyabazar]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Uncomplicated bubonic (glandular) plague is not transmissible from\nperson-to-person. It is only when _Yersinia pestis_ bacilli spread to\nthe lungs through a bacteremia or is initially acquired from aerosol\nspread that contacts would be at risk.\nChoir (which is often spelled Tsoir or Chojr) is the capital of the\nprovince of Gobisumber (also spelled Govisumber) and the province in\nMongolia can be found on a map at\n<http://fi.wikipedia.org/wiki/Govisumber>. - Mod.LL]\n[Plague is endemic in Mongolian marmots and their fleas, but as roast\nmarmot ('boodog' in Mongolian) is a popular dish there, some unlucky\nhunters catch it every year. See marmot photo at\n<http://www.bobak.ru/pics/view/Marmota%20sibirica.jpg>\nand recipes at\n<http://www.e-mongol.com/mongolia_culture_cooking-recipes.htm>\n- Mod.JW]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n See marmot photo at\n<http://www.bobak.ru/pics/view/Marmota%20sibirica.jpg>\nand recipes at\n<http://www.e-mongol.com/mongolia_culture_cooking-recipes.htm>\n- Mod. A 16-year-old boy in Choir, the capital city of the aimag, showed\nsymptoms of the plague, some days after he had cut his finger while\nskinning a marmot hunted by his father. Source: The UB Post [edited]\n<http://ubpost.mongolnews.mn/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=661>\n\nA case of glandular bubonic plague in Gobisumber aimag was confirmed\nthis week. [Plague is endemic in Mongolian marmots and their fleas, but as roast\nmarmot ('boodog' in Mongolian) is a popular dish there, some unlucky\nhunters catch it every year. It is only when _Yersinia pestis_ bacilli spread to\nthe lungs through a bacteremia or is initially acquired from aerosol\nspread that contacts would be at risk. Choir (which is often spelled Tsoir or Chojr) is the capital of the\nprovince of Gobisumber (also spelled Govisumber) and the province in\n [Of these,] 40 have been since released, as they showed no\nsymptoms during the incubation period.\n Of\nthem, 54 found in the area were isolated and given preventive medical\ntreatment.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2054-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Choir", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mongolia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "27421", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, feline - USA (NM)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=27421", "date": "2007-09-14 23:57:08", "main_text": "PLAGUE, FELINE - USA (NEW MEXICO)\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 13 Sep 2007\nSource: Ruidoso News [edited]\n<http://www.ruidosonews.com/news/ci_6888677>\n\nA local [Ruidoso, NM] case of feline plague was reported this week\n[10-14 Sep 2007] by Dr. Amanda Favis, a veterinarian with the Ruidoso\nAnimal Clinic.\nOn 6 Sep [2007], a cat was admitted to the clinic on Sudderth Drive\nwith a 1-week history of depression and a decreased appetite, she\nsaid. Examination revealed that the animal was running a high fever\nand showed an enlarged lymph node in the neck.\nThe attending veterinarian obtained fluid from the [enlarged] lymph\nnode and sent a sample to the New Mexico State Veterinary Diagnostic\nLaboratory, Favis said. Test results were positive for plague. The\ncat was started on the appropriate antibiotics and is recovering well\nfrom her illness.\n'It is important for all animal owners in New Mexico to be aware of\nthe risk of plague in our environment and the possibility of\ninfection in household pets,' Favis said. 'Plague is a bacterium most\ncommonly infecting rodents and rabbits, and is spread primarily by\ninfected fleas. Cats can be infected with plague by eating an\ninfected animal, being bitten by an infected flea, or by inhaling the\nbacteria. Infection in dogs is very rare, because of an inherent\nresistance to the bacteria.'\nCats bitten by an infected flea or who eat an infected animal\ntypically will develop signs of illness within one to 6 days, Favis said.\nSigns of plague in a cat include lack of appetite, fever, depression,\nswelling in the neck region, draining abscesses, difficulty\nbreathing, and coughing.\nPlague may develop in cats in 3 forms, she said. The most common and\nmost treatable form is bubonic plague, which results in swelling of\nlymph nodes in the neck. Less common but more dangerous forms include\npneumonic plague, which involves respiratory infection, and\nsepticemic plague, which is an infection of the blood, Favis said.\nPlague season in New Mexico includes spring, summer, and early\nautumn, when above-freezing temperatures allow the flea population to\nthrive, she said.\n'The best way to protect your cat during this period is to utilize\nflea control,' the veterinarian said. 'Plague can be transmitted to\nhumans by infected pets and the bite of an infected flea.\n'Pets can transmit the bacteria to humans through human contact with\ninfected fluids or tissue, such as ruptured abscess and bite wounds,\nhandling of sick or dead infected animals, and, in pneumonic plague,\nvia respiratory secretions, although this is very rare and has never\nhappened in New Mexico.'\nIf plague is suspected in any animal, immediate veterinary care\nshould be sought to achieve a diagnosis and receive treatment, Favis said.\n[Byline: Dianne Stallings]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[A Map of New Mexico may be seen at:\n<http://www.newmexico.org/explore/index.php>\nThe causative bacterium _Yersinia pestis_ is transmitted to people\nthrough fleabite and direct contact with infected animals. Each\nrodent species is host to one or more species of fleas which, when\ninfected, are carriers. These fleas generally do not infest other\nanimals unless their natural hosts are unavailable.\nDomestic cats and dogs can also contract plague from infective fleas.\nThey may carry infected fleas home to their owners or, especially\ncats, serve as a direct source of infection. There are many flea\ntreatments and repellents appropriate for pets and available. Some\nproducts may be suitable for dogs but not cats or may be suitable for\nan adult but not a younger animal. Be sure to consult your\nveterinarian, as some products may be toxic to cats, kittens, and\npuppies, even resulting in fatalities. - Mod.TG]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Pets can transmit the bacteria to humans through human contact with\ninfected fluids or tissue, such as ruptured abscess and bite wounds,\nhandling of sick or dead infected animals, and, in pneumonic plague,\nvia respiratory secretions, although this is very rare and has never\nhappened in New Mexico.' Cats can be infected with plague by eating an\ninfected animal, being bitten by an infected flea, or by inhaling the\nbacteria. Less common but more dangerous forms include\npneumonic plague, which involves respiratory infection, and\nsepticemic plague, which is an infection of the blood, Favis said. It is important for all animal owners in New Mexico to be aware of\nthe risk of plague in our environment and the possibility of\ninfection in household pets,' Favis said. ' Plague is a bacterium most\ncommonly infecting rodents and rabbits, and is spread primarily by\ninfected fleas. Plague season in New Mexico includes spring, summer, and early\nautumn, when above-freezing temperatures allow the flea population to\nthrive, she said. Signs of plague in a cat include lack of appetite, fever, depression,\nswelling in the neck region, draining abscesses, difficulty\nbreathing, and coughing. On 6 Sep [2007], a cat was admitted to the clinic on Sudderth Drive\nwith a 1-week history of depression and a decreased appetite, she\nsaid. The most common and\nmost treatable form is bubonic plague, which results in swelling of\nlymph nodes in the neck. The attending veterinarian obtained fluid from the [enlarged] lymph\nnode and sent a sample to the New Mexico State Veterinary Diagnostic\nLaboratory, Favis said. Each\nrodent species is host to one or more species of fleas which, when\ninfected, are carriers. Some\nproducts may be suitable for dogs but not cats or may be suitable for\nan adult but not a younger animal. Be sure to consult your\nveterinarian, as some products may be toxic to cats, kittens, and\npuppies, even resulting in fatalities. PLAGUE, FELINE - USA (NEW MEXICO)\n********************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "22357", "headline": "PRO/AH> Plague, ground squirrels - USA (CA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=22357", "date": "2007-08-11 05:00:10", "main_text": "'>http://www.flickr.com/photos/rainriver/1021065784/in/pool-17366380@N00>\n<http://www.etc-etc.com/sqrlpic.htm>\nAn interactive map for the location of Palomar Mountain may be found at:\n<http://www.parks.ca.gov/lat_long_map/default.asp?lvl_id=276>\n- Mod.TG]", "summary": "", "reports": [{"diseases": [], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "29308", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, prairie dogs - USA (SD)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=29308", "date": "2007-09-27 21:00:10", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PRAIRIE DOGS - USA (SOUTH DAKOTA)\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 25 Sep 2007\nSource: Rapid City Journal [edited]\n<http://www.rapidcityjournal.com/articles/2007/09/25/news/top/doc46f862c77a74d207022577.txt>\n\nPlague has apparently now spread to eastern Fall River County where\nit has decimated prairie dog populations and made that area much less\nattractive for the reintroduction of endangered black-footed ferrets,\nwildlife officials say.\nHowever, plague still has not been found in Conata Basin near\nBadlands National Park, site of the most successful black-footed\nferret reintroduction in the country so far.\nPlague 1st was confirmed in western South Dakota almost 3 years ago,\nwhen a rancher found a sick prairie dog in extreme southwestern\nCuster County and took it in for testing. Before that case, plague\nhad not been confirmed in South Dakota for decades, although plague\nhad wiped out prairie dog towns in eastern Wyoming.\nPlague in prairie dogs and other animals (known as sylvatic plague)\ngenerally does not pose a widespread threat to humans, although\npeople can get the disease.\nHowever, the appearance of plague has wildlife officials worried\nabout the already established ferret population in Conata Basin.\nAfter the Custer County case, plague killed thousands of prairie dogs\nin a huge complex north of Oglala on the Pine Ridge Indian\nReservation 2 years ago.\nSince then, plague has spread on the reservation, with smaller\noutbreaks east of Oglala to the Wolf Creek community northeast of\nPine Ridge, west near the Prairie Wind Casino, and about 15 miles\nnorth just below Cuny Table and Red Shirt Table, according to Trudy\nEcoffey, senior biologist with the Oglala Sioux Tribe Parks and\nRecreation Department.\nEcoffey said she thought last fall that the plague would spread\nfaster. But it hasn't moved far this summer [2007], she said.\nAlthough plague showed up northeast of Pine Ridge, it skipped other\nprairie dog towns between Oglala and Pine Ridge, she said.\nEcoffey said she estimates plague has affected 30 000 acres of\nprairie dogs. She said pockets of prairie dogs have begun showing up\nagain at the huge complex just north of Oglala.\nNow, plague is suspected of spreading west, where it has killed\nsizeable numbers of prairie dogs in eastern Fall River County on the\nBuffalo Gap National Grassland, east of Smithwick, according to Fall\nRiver District Ranger Mike McNeill.\nThe die-offs are in the heart of an area targeted for a ferret\nreintroduction, he said.\nAlthough no prairie dogs have been tested and confirmed with plague,\nthey have disappeared from large colonies in the area. McNeill said\nplague is the most reasonable explanation.\nOf 900-1200 acres in the area occupied by prairie dogs a year or 2\nago east of Smithwick, only about 450-500 acres have prairie dogs\nnow, according to U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service biologist Scott\nLarson of Pierre.\nThe die-off makes the area much less attractive as a site to\nreintroduce black-footed ferrets, Larson said. 'It becomes a lower\npriority at this time.'\nBut Larson wouldn't rule out the Smithwick area for a future ferret\nreintroduction. 'We probably have better sites now than Smithwick. It\nmight look entirely different in 5 years.'\nFerrets can get plague by eating prairie dogs that have died of the\ndisease or may get it from fleas that carry the organism, as prairie\ndogs do. Prairie dogs make up about 90 percent of the ferrets' diet.\nFerrets reintroduced elsewhere in the country have died from eating\nplague-infected prairie dogs, Larson said.\nFWS officials have said plague in prairie dog towns has hampered\nblack-footed ferret reintroductions in Wyoming, Montana, Colorado and Utah.\nOfficials also said ferrets can get plague from one flea bite.\nWildlife officials continue to worry about plague harming the\nestimated 250 black-footed ferrets now roaming Conata Basin just\nsouth of Badlands National Park's North Unit.\nConata Basin is about 40 miles northeast of the big Oglala complex\nhit hard by plague in 2005. With plague now approaching Cuny Table,\nit is about 25 miles from Conata Basin.\nAt Conata Basin, the government has spent years and millions of\ndollars to establish a population of black-footed ferrets, which were\nonce thought to be extinct.\nTo protect the project, FWS crews have been dusting prairie dog\nburrows in Conata Basin with an insecticide that kills fleas, the\nprimary carriers of plague.\nThis year [2007], they will dust about 1600 acres of at least 26 000\nacres occupied by prairie dogs, Larson said. But the dusting is being\ndone in an area known to be occupied by ferrets.\nThe dusting by itself won't keep the plague out of Conata Basin,\nLarson said. 'We're hoping to hang on to a few ferret-occupied areas\nin case it comes in.'\nNow in its 3rd year, the dusting appears to be reducing the number of\nfleas, according to David Jachowski, an FWS biologist with the\nnational Black-footed Ferret Conservation Center in Colorado who is\nhelping with the dusting. 'We see fewer fleas on prairie dogs,' Jachowski said.\nCrews dusted 7000 acres 2 years ago. They spray an insecticide powder\ninto the prairie dog burrows, where it gets onto the prairie dogs'\nhides and kills fleas.\nCrews sprayed more than 300 000 burrows in 2005, according to Micah\nReuber, a biologist with FWS, based in Wall.\nIronically, the FWS crews dusting for plague to prevent prairie dogs\nand ferrets from getting plague are working in areas not far from\nplaces where state crews have poisoned prairie dogs in recent years\nto keep them from spreading onto nearby private rangeland.\nRanchers have complained prairie dogs damaged vegetation on their\nprivate ground and on parts of the national grassland they lease for grazing.\nThe Nebraska National Forest, which administers the Buffalo Gap\nNational Grassland, is considering expanding the poisoning to kill\nprairie dogs in the interior of Conata Basin beyond the\npublic-private boundaries.\nMost of the poisoning alternatives being considered are aimed at\ncapping prairie dog acres on the national grasslands.\nEnvironmental groups say the poisoning, particularly if expanded into\nthe grasslands interior, poses a threat to the ferrets and other\nspecies, such as the burrowing owl, that depend on prairie dogs.\nThey argue that ferrets, one of the rarest mammals in the world,\noccupy just 6 10ths of one percent of the national grasslands and\nthat some of the poisoning alternatives would reduce that percentage\neven lower. Livestock are allowed to graze on approximately 99\npercent of the national grasslands.\nArt Smith, wildlife-damage-management program administrator for the\nSouth Dakota Game, Fish & Parks Department, said none of the areas\nbeing dusted for fleas in order to protect prairie dogs are areas\nbeing poisoned to kill prairie dogs.\n'In some areas, (the prairie dog) needs to be controlled,' Smith\nsaid. 'In other areas, it needs to be protected.'\nMeanwhile, Larson said, the annual ferret population survey in Conata\nBasin has just begun.\n'They're finding decent numbers,' he said. Last year's [2006] survey\ncounted about 245 ferrets, he said.\nBut if plague gets into Conata Basin and threatens the ferrets,\nfederal officials might move the ferrets elsewhere.\nSo far, it appears the plague has been confined to the Pine Ridge\nReservation and a little way into Fall River County.\nEcoffey, who is monitoring the plague's spread on the Pine Ridge\nReservation, said the disease eventually may reach Conata Basin, home\nof the endangered ferrets. 'If it's here to stay, there's no reason\nto say it won't,' she said.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n[Fall River county is in the southwest corner of the state of North Dakota.\n<http://www.mapsofworld.com/usa/states/south-dakota/maps/south-dakota-county-map.jpg>.\nPrairie dogs are often sensitive sentinels for plague. A photo of a\nprairie dog may be seen at\n<http://www.northrup.org/photos/Animals/nl-41.htm>.\nBlack-tailed prairie dogs (_Cynomys ludovicianus_) are numerous in\nthe Western and areas of the Southwestern United States.\nThe causative bacterium, _Yersinia pestis_, is transmitted to people\nthrough fleabite and direct contact with infected animals. Each\nrodent species is host to one or more species of flea, which, when\ninfected, is a carrier. These fleas generally do not infest other\nanimals unless their natural hosts are unavailable. Rock squirrels\n(_Spermophilus variegatus_) are closely related to California ground\nsquirrels and are the most significant plague host in Colorado. Their\nprincipal flea (_Diamanus montanus_) is an aggressive parasite and\nwill readily bite other animals and people. Domestic cats and dogs\ncan also contract plague by infective fleas. They may carry infected\nfleas home to their owners or, especially with cats, serve as a\ndirect source of infection.\nA photo of a black-footed ferret and other interesting facts may be found at:\n<http://animals.nationalgeographic.com/animals/mammals/black-footed-ferret.html>.\n- Mod.TG]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Source: Rapid City Journal [edited]\n<http://www.rapidcityjournal.com/articles/2007/09/25/news/top/doc46f862c77a74d207022577.txt>\n\nPlague has apparently now spread to eastern Fall River County where\nit has decimated prairie dog populations and made that area much less\nattractive for the reintroduction of endangered black-footed ferrets,\nwildlife officials say. Since then, plague has spread on the reservation, with smaller\noutbreaks east of Oglala to the Wolf Creek community northeast of\nPine Ridge, west near the Prairie Wind Casino, and about 15 miles\nnorth just below Cuny Table and Red Shirt Table, according to Trudy\n Ironically, the FWS crews dusting for plague to prevent prairie dogs\nand ferrets from getting plague are working in areas not far from\nplaces where state crews have poisoned prairie dogs in recent years\nto keep them from spreading onto nearby private rangeland. Art Smith, wildlife-damage-management program administrator for the\nSouth Dakota Game, Fish & Parks Department, said none of the areas\nbeing dusted for fleas in order to protect prairie dogs are areas\nbeing poisoned to kill prairie dogs. Of 900-1200 acres in the area occupied by prairie dogs a year or 2\nago east of Smithwick, only about 450-500 acres have prairie dogs\nnow, according to U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service biologist Scott\nLarson of Pierre. Plague in prairie dogs and other animals (known as sylvatic plague)\ngenerally does not pose a widespread threat to humans, although\npeople can get the disease.\n Now, plague is suspected of spreading west, where it has killed\nsizeable numbers of prairie dogs in eastern Fall River County on the\nBuffalo Gap National Grassland, east of Smithwick, according to Fall\nRiver District Ranger Mike McNeill. The Nebraska National Forest, which administers the Buffalo Gap\nNational Grassland, is considering expanding the poisoning to kill\nprairie dogs in the interior of Conata Basin beyond the\npublic-private boundaries. However, plague still has not been found in Conata Basin near\nBadlands National Park, site of the most successful black-footed\nferret reintroduction in the country so far.\n Now in its 3rd year, the dusting appears to be reducing the number of\nfleas, according to David Jachowski, an FWS biologist with the\nnational Black-footed Ferret Conservation Center in Colorado who is\nhelping with the dusting. ' They argue that ferrets, one of the rarest mammals in the world,\noccupy just 6 10ths of one percent of the national grasslands and\nthat some of the poisoning alternatives would reduce that percentage\neven lower. Ferrets can get plague by eating prairie dogs that have died of the\ndisease or may get it from fleas that carry the organism, as prairie\ndogs do. They spray an insecticide powder\ninto the prairie dog burrows, where it gets onto the prairie dogs'\nhides and kills fleas. Before that case, plague\nhad not been confirmed in South Dakota for decades, although plague\nhad wiped out prairie dog towns in eastern Wyoming. To protect the project, FWS crews have been dusting prairie dog\nburrows in Conata Basin with an insecticide that kills fleas, the\nprimary carriers of plague. After the Custer County case, plague killed thousands of prairie dogs\nin a huge complex north of Oglala on the Pine Ridge Indian\n Plague 1st was confirmed in western South Dakota almost 3 years ago,\nwhen a rancher found a sick prairie dog in extreme southwestern\nCuster County and took it in for testing. Environmental groups say the poisoning, particularly if expanded into\nthe grasslands interior, poses a threat to the ferrets and other\nspecies, such as the burrowing owl, that depend on prairie dogs. PLAGUE, PRAIRIE DOGS - USA (SOUTH DAKOTA)\n*************************************\n Wildlife officials continue to worry about plague harming the\nestimated 250 black-footed ferrets now roaming Conata Basin just\nsouth of Badlands National Park's North Unit. ' However, the appearance of plague has wildlife officials worried\nabout the already established ferret population in Conata Basin.\n At Conata Basin, the government has spent years and millions of\ndollars to establish a population of black-footed ferrets, which were\nonce thought to be extinct. Medical reports from\nAruu health centers indicate that at least 20 people have been\ninfected by suspected plague. The report says 5 people have been\nkilled as a result of the outbreak.\nThe commissioner for Community Health, Dr Sam Okware said, 'It\n[plague] is endemic [in the region]. It happens at this time of the\nyear, especially when the rains start falling in June. It is caused\nby rats that cross from DR Congo,' he said.\nArua DDHS (Divisional Director of Health Services) Patrick Anguzu\ntold Daily Monitor yesterday, 12 Sep 2007, that a health team from\nArua has set up emergency plans to deal with suspected cases. The\ninfected area, 'Kampala', is a popular market that attracts traders\nfrom West Nile and Congo for cross-border trade.\n'Yes, there is that scare because it can spread faster in our places.\nSo our medical personnel have to be ready for any suspected cases\nthat may spill off to our area. That area (Kampala) is not far from\nus in Arua,' Dr Anguzu said.\n[Byline: Warom Felix Okello]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Formal documentation that these illnesses are plague is still\npending. But, as can be seen on a map, the Arua district of Uganda\nand across the border from the Orientale (Eastern) province of Congo\nDR are both areas where plague occurs\n(<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/uganda.pdf>).\nThe manifestations of _Yersinia pestis_ infection in the cases are\nunstated but, with a substantial fatality rate, more invasive forms\nof the disease such as septicemic and pneumonic plague may be\npresent. It is the pneumonic form that can spread from\nperson-to-person. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The manifestations of _Yersinia pestis_ infection in the cases are\nunstated but, with a substantial fatality rate, more invasive forms\nof the disease such as septicemic and pneumonic plague may be\npresent. But, as can be seen on a map, the Arua district of Uganda\nand across the border from the Orientale (Eastern) province of Congo\nDR are both areas where plague occurs\n(<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/uganda.pdf>). They're warning people to avoid\ncontact with wild animals and to treat their pets for fleas.\nA pair of prairie dogs were found dead last month [Jul 2007] in Doney Park,\nnorth east of the city. A lab at Northern Arizona University confirmed the\npresence of the disease after testing fleas found in the animals' borrows.\nPlague is transmitted by fleas from infected animals.\nCounty environmental specialist Hugh Murray says plague is ever-present in\nthe Flagstaff area. No human cases of the disease have been reported in the\ncounty since 1996.\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Joseph P Dudley\n[The commonest animals in the west [found to suffer plague] are prairie\ndogs, squirrels, or one of the varieties of ground squirrel. This article\nmentions prairie dogs, but suggested to me that perhaps other wildlife had\nbeen affected.\nThe causative bacterium _Yersinia pestis_ is transmitted to people through\nfleabite and direct contact with infected animals. Each rodent species is\nhost to one or more species of fleas which, when infected, are carriers.\nThese fleas generally do not infest other animals unless their natural\nhosts are unavailable.\nDomestic cats and dogs can also contract plague from infective fleas. They\nmay carry infected fleas home to their owners or, especially cats, serve as\na direct source of infection. There are many flea treatments and repellants\nappropriate for pets and available. Some products may be suitable for dogs\nbut not cats or may be suitable for an adult but not a younger animal. Be\nsure to consult your veterinarian, as some products may be toxic to cats,\nkittens, and puppies, even resulting in fatalities.\nA map of Arizona may be found at\n<http://www.thepepper.com/map_arizona2.gif>. - Mod.TG]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society of Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n --\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Joseph P Dudley\n They\nmay carry infected fleas home to their owners or, especially cats, serve as\na direct source of infection. This article\nmentions prairie dogs, but suggested to me that perhaps other wildlife had\nbeen affected. Be\nsure to consult your veterinarian, as some products may be toxic to cats,\nkittens, and puppies, even resulting in fatalities. Souce: KOLD.com [edited]\n<http://www.kold.com/Global/story.asp?S=6918766>\n\nBubonic plaque found in Flagstaff wildlife\n [The commonest animals in the west [found to suffer plague] are prairie\ndogs, squirrels, or one of the varieties of ground squirrel. A lab at Northern Arizona University confirmed the\npresence of the disease after testing fleas found in the animals' borrows. They're warning people to avoid\ncontact with wild animals and to treat their pets for fleas. Health officials in Coconino County, AZ, say they've found bubonic plague\nin wild animals in a Flagstaff suburb. The causative bacterium _Yersinia pestis_ is transmitted to people through\nfleabite and direct contact with infected animals. A pair of prairie dogs were found dead last month [Jul 2007] in Doney Park,\nnorth east of the city. These fleas generally do not infest other animals unless their natural\nhosts are unavailable. Each rodent species is\nhost to one or more species of fleas which, when infected, are carriers. Some products may be suitable for dogs\nbut not cats or may be suitable for an adult but not a younger animal. County environmental specialist Hugh Murray says plague is ever-present in\nthe Flagstaff area. A map of Arizona may be found at\n<http://www.thepepper.com/map_arizona2.gif>. No human cases of the disease have been reported in the\ncounty since 1996. There are many flea treatments and repellants\nappropriate for pets and available.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Coconino County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ARIZONA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Doney Park", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "27343", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, human - USA (AZ)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=27343", "date": "2007-09-14 13:00:10", "main_text": "PLAGUE, HUMAN - USA (ARIZONA)\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 13 Sep 2007\nSource: Arizona Department of Health Services news release [edited]\n<http://www.azdhs.gov/news/2007-all/firstplague-2007>\n\nArizona's 1st case of plague [human? - Mod.MPP] since 2000 has been\nreported in an adult female in Apache County. The woman became ill\nearly September 2007 from a flea bite at her home in northern\nArizona. She is now recovering after receiving the appropriate\nantimicrobial treatment.\nIn a community northeast of Flagstaff in Coconino County, an outbreak\nof plague involving prairie dogs is occurring. Many rodents are dying\nfrom the disease and are leaving behind infected fleas. County health\nand Northern Arizona University officials are closely monitoring and\nresponding to this situation. Response has included flea collecting\nand testing, and extensive prevention education and outreach to\npeople in affected areas.\nDuring the last 30 years (1977-2006), 48 cases of plague have been\nreported in Arizona, 8 of which were fatal. The plague risk has been\nrelatively low during the last 6 years due to drought conditions and\nhigh summer temperatures.\n'The recent appearance of plague activity in 2 northern counties has\nus concerned that we may see plague in other areas as well,' said\nCraig Levy, head of the state Vector Borne and Zoonotic Disease Program.\nPlague can be transmitted to humans by flea bites or by direct\ncontact with infected animal tissues during skinning or handling of\ngame animals. In very rare cases, plague can be spread from\nperson-to-person, or cat-to-person, by airborne transmission. People\nor animals, particularly cats, infected with plague pneumonia can\ntransmit the bacteria by coughing or sneezing in the face of another\nperson or animal.\nIn Arizona, plague activity mostly occurs in areas above 4500 feet\n(1372 m) in elevation. For this reason, campers, hunters, hikers, and\nothers who live in or visit areas above 4500 feet should take the\nfollowing precautions to avoid plague exposures:\n- Do not handle sick or dead animals.\n- Avoid close exposures to rodent burrows and fleas.\n- Prevent cats and dogs from roaming. Wandering animals can pick up\nplague-infected fleas and bring them home.\n- Use appropriate flea control products on cats and dogs. Consult\nyour veterinarian for guidance.\n- Wear protective gloves when skinning rabbits or rodents and when\npreparing them for cooking. Also, game meat should be cooked to 180\ndeg [F] (82 deg C) or until the juices run clear.\n- In the event a plague-like illness develops within 6 days of a\npotential exposure, see a physician immediately.\nFor more information on plague, please visit:\n<http://www.azdhs.gov/phs/oids/vector/plague/index.htm>\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The outbreak of plague in Coconino County has previously been posted\non ProMED-mail. Although not stated, the case is probably one of\nbubonic plague (lymph node infection), the most common form with the\nlowest mortality rate.\nFrom data collected by the Arizona Department of Health Services\n<http://www.azdhs.gov/phs/oids/vector/plague/stats.htm>, a total of\n61 cases of _Yersinia pestis_ infection have been acquired in the\nstate from 1950 to 2000. Adding in the case above from Apache County,\nnumber of cases reported from the following counties:\nCounty / Number of Cases\nApache / 21\nNavajo / 18\nCoconino / 17\nYavapai / 4\nGila / 1\nMohave / 1\nApache, Navajo, and Coconino counties occupy the northeast and north\ncentral parts of the southwestern USA state of Arizona and accounted\nfor 56 of the 62 cases (85 percent).\nA map of the counties of Arizona can be found at:\n<http://www.mapwatch.com/multi-maps/full/arizona-county-map.gif>- Mod.LL]\n[Arizona can be located on the map of the USA at\n<http://geology.com/world/the-united-states-of-america-satellite-image.shtml>.\n- CopyEd.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n People\nor animals, particularly cats, infected with plague pneumonia can\ntransmit the bacteria by coughing or sneezing in the face of another\nperson or animal.\n Adding in the case above from Apache County,\nnumber of cases reported from the following counties:\nCounty / Number of Cases\nApache / 21\n Navajo / 18\nCoconino / 17\nYavapai / 4\nGila / 1\n For this reason, campers, hunters, hikers, and\nothers who live in or visit areas above 4500 feet should take the\nfollowing precautions to avoid plague exposures:\n- Do not handle sick or dead animals. Mohave / 1\nApache, Navajo, and Coconino counties occupy the northeast and north\ncentral parts of the southwestern USA state of Arizona and accounted\nfor 56 of the 62 cases (85 percent). From data collected by the Arizona Department of Health Services\n<http://www.azdhs.gov/phs/oids/vector/plague/stats.htm>, a total of\n61 cases of _Yersinia pestis_ infection have been acquired in the\nstate from 1950 to 2000. For more information on plague, please visit:\n<http://www.azdhs.gov/phs/oids/vector/plague/index.htm>\n--\n The recent appearance of plague activity in 2 northern counties has\nus concerned that we may see plague in other areas as well,' said\nCraig Levy, head of the state Vector Borne and Zoonotic Disease Program. Plague can be transmitted to humans by flea bites or by direct\ncontact with infected animal tissues during skinning or handling of\ngame animals. Although not stated, the case is probably one of\nbubonic plague (lymph node infection), the most common form with the\nlowest mortality rate. The plague risk has been\nrelatively low during the last 6 years due to drought conditions and\nhigh summer temperatures. Response has included flea collecting\nand testing, and extensive prevention education and outreach to\npeople in affected areas. The woman became ill\nearly September 2007 from a flea bite at her home in northern\nArizona. \n- Wear protective gloves when skinning rabbits or rodents and when\npreparing them for cooking. County health\nand Northern Arizona University officials are closely monitoring and\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< In very rare cases, plague can be spread from\nperson-to-person, or cat-to-person, by airborne transmission. During the last 30 years (1977-2006), 48 cases of plague have been\nreported in Arizona, 8 of which were fatal. Wandering animals can pick up\nplague-infected fleas and bring them home. Source: Arizona Department of Health Services news release [edited]\n<http://www.azdhs.gov/news/2007-all/firstplague-2007>\n\nArizona's 1st case of plague [human? - Mod. In the event a plague-like illness develops within 6 days of a\npotential exposure, see a physician immediately. In a community northeast of Flagstaff in Coconino County, an outbreak\nof plague involving prairie dogs is occurring.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2000-03-25 00:00:00", "1372-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "ARIZONA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Apache County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Coconino County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "22087", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, human, fatal - Mongolia (Hovsgol) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=22087", "date": "2007-08-09 16:00:13", "main_text": "PLAGUE, HUMAN, FATAL - MONGOLIA (HOVSGOL) (02)\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Tue 7 Aug 2007 23:20:27 -0700\nFrom: Nyles Bauer <nyles@email.arizona.edu>\n\nI am currently conducting research in Mongolia and wanted to offer a\ncultural response to the posting about the human fatality due to plague.\nThe Mongolians consider hunting marmots ('tarvaga') to almost be a right\nand it occurs every summer and autumn when the animals are at their fattest\nafter the rains. They are considered a treat by most and considered\nmedicinal by many. The older generations may even eat, and offer others,\ninternal organ meat raw as a part of Mongolian traditional medicine.\nWhen intended for food, the animal is generally roasted, often without\nskinning. This offers ample opportunity for human contact with fleas and\nthe animal itself.\nAny government restrictions on hunting this animal would have little\neffect, especially in the countryside.\nI sincerely doubt that the dog played a part in acquiring plague in this\ncase. Mongols consider dogs to be very dirty and disease-ridden animals.\nThis would certainly bias any reporting on transmission of the disease in\nthis case.\n--\nNyles Bauer\nDepartment of Microbiology and Immunology\nCollege of Medicine\nUniversity of Arizona\nUSA\n<nyles@email.arizona.edu>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue 7 Aug 2007\nFrom: Merritt Clifton <anmlpepl@whidbey.com>\n\nThis may involve translation errors at some point, as many Asian dialects\nreputedly call marmots 'dogs', just as we call ground squirrels 'prairie dogs'.\n--\nMerritt Clifton\nEditor\nAnimal People Magazine\n<anmlpepl@whidbey.com>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n University of Arizona\nUSA\n<nyles@email.arizona.edu>\n******\n \nNyles Bauer\nDepartment of Microbiology and Immunology\nCollege of Medicine\n \nMerritt Clifton\nEditor\n This offers ample opportunity for human contact with fleas and\nthe animal itself.\n From: Nyles Bauer <nyles@email.arizona.edu>\n\nI am currently conducting research in Mongolia and wanted to offer a\ncultural response to the posting about the human fatality due to plague. This may involve translation errors at some point, as many Asian dialects\nreputedly call marmots 'dogs', just as we call ground squirrels 'prairie dogs'. The older generations may even eat, and offer others,\ninternal organ meat raw as a part of Mongolian traditional medicine. Any government restrictions on hunting this animal would have little\neffect, especially in the countryside. I sincerely doubt that the dog played a part in acquiring plague in this\ncase. This would certainly bias any reporting on transmission of the disease in\nthis case. The Mongolians consider hunting marmots ('tarvaga') to almost be a right\n When intended for food, the animal is generally roasted, often without\nskinning. and it occurs every summer and autumn when the animals are at their fattest\nafter the rains. They are considered a treat by most and considered\nmedicinal by many. Date: Tue 7 Aug 2007 23:20:27 -0700\n PLAGUE, HUMAN, FATAL - MONGOLIA (HOVSGOL) (02)\n Animal People Magazine\n<anmlpepl@whidbey.com> Date: Tue 7 Aug 2007\n [1]\n [2]\n **\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-08-07 00:00:00"], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "22245", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, human, fatal - Mongolia (Hovsgol) (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=22245", "date": "2007-08-10 11:00:10", "main_text": "PLAGUE, HUMAN, FATAL - MONGOLIA (HOVSGOL) (03)\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[3]\nDate: Thu 9 Aug 2007\nSource: UB Post (Mongolia) [edited]\n<http://ubpost.mongolnews.mn/content/view/508/>\n\nAfter the death on 2 Aug 2007 of a 14 year old boy, later confirmed to have\ncontracted bubonic plague, authorities in Tsetserleg put 79 people who had\nhad contact with the boy under quarantine. The _Yersinia pestis_ is\nbelieved to have come from a marmot that the boy had hunted, according to\nthe TV5 news agency.\nHe was taken to hospital with high fever and bubonic plague-like symptoms.\nHe had earlier nicked his finger while removing the marmot's skin. He died\nafter 4 hours in the hospital. A dead marmot was found with some flesh\nstill on it and this was taken away for tests. The police also found the\nskins of 3 marmots at the boy's house and these were also sent to a\nlaboratory. Experts from the National Research Center for Infectious\nDiseases (NRCID) later confirmed the presence of the bubonic plague\nbacteria in the marmots.\nMarmots are known to be carriers of bubonic plague but this has never\ndeterred people in Mongolia from hunting them for food. Some experts say\nthe Black Death 1st spread to humans through contact with marmots, which\nare still commonly hunted for food in north western China and Mongolia.\nSmaller outbreaks of bubonic plague are frequently reported in remote areas\nof north western China.\n[byline: Sh. Batmonkh]\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[ProMED-mail posting 'Plague, human, fatal - Mongolia (Hovsgol) (02)\n20070809.2589' included doubts about whether what was called a 'marmot' was\nindeed a marmot. This report uses the term with some confidence. - Mod.SH]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Batmonkh]\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< Source: UB Post (Mongolia) [edited]\n<http://ubpost.mongolnews.mn/content/view/508/>\n\nAfter the death on 2 Aug 2007 of a 14 year old boy, later confirmed to have\ncontracted bubonic plague, authorities in Tsetserleg put 79 people who had\nhad contact with the boy under quarantine. Experts from the National Research Center for Infectious\nDiseases (NRCID) later confirmed the presence of the bubonic plague\nbacteria in the marmots. Smaller outbreaks of bubonic plague are frequently reported in remote areas\nof north western China.\n Some experts say\nthe Black Death 1st spread to humans through contact with marmots, which\nare still commonly hunted for food in north western China and Mongolia. The _Yersinia pestis_ is\nbelieved to have come from a marmot that the boy had hunted, according to\nthe TV5 news agency. The police also found the\nskins of 3 marmots at the boy's house and these were also sent to a\nlaboratory.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tsetserleg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mongolia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "19658", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, prairie dogs - USA (CO)(02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=19658", "date": "2007-07-29 16:00:09", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PRAIRIE DOGS - USA (COLORADO) (02)\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 25 Jul 2007\nSource: The Denver Post [edited]\n<http://www.denverpost.com/headlines/ci_6465163>\n\nAt least 2 and possibly 3 prairie dog colonies have been wiped out by\nbubonic plague on Schriever Air Force Base, about 10 miles east of\nColorado Springs. No human cases have been reported.\nAir Force personnel along with officials from the El Paso County\nHealth Department confirmed Tuesday [24 Jul 2007] that 2 of 5\ncolonies are infected.\nBase spokesman Ed Parsons said Wednesday [25 Jul 2007] that a 3rd\ncolony is suspected to contain the plague. A 4th colony was cleared,\nand a 5th colony was not tested because of its remote location, Parsons said.\n'We've not had a die-off like this before,' Parsons said, noting that\nmost of the prairie dogs in the 2 infected colonies have died.\nParsons said the base suspected a problem when the prairie dog\npopulation started to decline. 'It was pretty obvious that we had\nlost a lot of prairie dogs.'\nHealth officials tested the colonies last week and confirmed that\nplague had been found.\n'It's a large die-off of critters, but we have no human cases yet,\nand we want to keep it that way,' said Rick Miklich, director of\nenvironmental health for the El Paso County Health Department.\n'We went out there and harvested a large amount of fleas that are\nlooking for someplace to go. We found the plague in them. It's the\nfleas we're worried about, not the prairie dogs, which are just a\nhost. The infected fleas can move to other hosts, like dogs, cats and people.'\nMiklich said bubonic-plague germs are endemic to the West. 'The\nplague is here all the time. It can remain dormant or flare up into\nan outbreak. What causes that we don't know. What we worry about are\nthe fleas moving. This is a large outbreak. But it's not the 1st time\nit's happened. Off the top of my head, the last outbreak this large\nwas several years ago,' he said.\nParsons said the Air Force has closed the infected areas, advising\npersonnel to avoid dead prairie dogs and on what to do if they\ndevelop flu-like symptoms. The colonies are somewhat remote from base\npersonnel, but one is near a path frequented by joggers, he said. The\ncolonies are being dusted with insecticide to kill the fleas.\nMiklich cautioned residents to avoid prairie dog colonies, at least\nfor the rest of the summer, and not to let their pets run loose near\nthe colonies.\n[Byline: Mike McPhee <mmcphee@denverpost.com>]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Joseph P. Dudley\n[This article wisely points out that the prairie dog is the\nhost-victim, while the fleas are the real problem. Prairie dogs are\nconsidered sentinels for plague.\nIt is good to see them dusting the area for fleas and providing flea\nrelief to the prairie dogs. Prairie dog colonies are fascinating and\nentertaining to watch. Certainly, it is that interaction that prompts\nthe concern.\nFor a further discussion on plague, including maps and photos, please\nsee ProMED-mail post 20070725.2386. - Mod.TG]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Source: The Denver Post [edited]\n<http://www.denverpost.com/headlines/ci_6465163>\n\nAt least 2 and possibly 3 prairie dog colonies have been wiped out by\nbubonic plague on Schriever Air Force Base, about 10 miles east of\nColorado Springs. \nParsons said the Air Force has closed the infected areas, advising\npersonnel to avoid dead prairie dogs and on what to do if they\ndevelop flu-like symptoms. Miklich cautioned residents to avoid prairie dog colonies, at least\nfor the rest of the summer, and not to let their pets run loose near\nthe colonies.\n It's the\nfleas we're worried about, not the prairie dogs, which are just a\nhost. It's a large die-off of critters, but we have no human cases yet,\nand we want to keep it that way,' said Rick Miklich, director of\nenvironmental health for the El Paso County Health Department. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Joseph P. Base spokesman Ed Parsons said Wednesday [25 Jul 2007] that a 3rd\ncolony is suspected to contain the plague. Parsons said the base suspected a problem when the prairie dog\npopulation started to decline. Prairie dogs are\nconsidered sentinels for plague. Prairie dog colonies are fascinating and\nentertaining to watch.
