Air Force personnel along with officials from the El Paso County\nHealth Department confirmed Tuesday", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Colorado Springs", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "El Paso County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "colony", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "21574", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, human, fatal - Mongolia (Hovsgol)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=21574", "date": "2007-08-07 16:00:09", "main_text": "PLAGUE, HUMAN, FATAL - MONGOLIA (HOVSGOL)\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Mon 6 Aug 2007\nSource: Peoples Daily [in Chinese, trans. Rappt.DS, edited]\n<http://world.dayoo.com/gb/content/2007-08/06/content_2889915.htm>\n\nAccording to local media, a 14 year old has died of plague in Tsetserleg\nCounty of Mongolia's Hovsgol Province. On 2 Aug 2007, the child went for\ntreatment at the county hospital due to fever and died that night. Sources\nsay that the deceased contracted plague through contact with a dog on 31\nJul 2007.\nThe Hovsgol Province Infection Prevention and Control Center sent a work\nteam to the area. The area has been closed and 27 individuals with primary\ncontact and 52 with secondary contact have been isolated for observation.\nUp to now none has developed fever.\nMongolia is a high plague incidence region and plague has occurred in\nalmost all provinces. To prevent plague, the Mongolian Government has\nissued prohibitions on marmot hunting. But illicit hunting incidents still\noccur despite repeated prohibitions.\n[byline: Wen Huo]\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Dan Silver\n[The clinical manifestations of plague in the adolescent are not stated,\nespecially if pneumonic plague was present. It is also not clear what\nrelationship the dog had in the transmission of _Yersinia pestis_ in this case.\nAn American Veterinary Medical Association reference\n(<http://www.avma.org/reference/zoonosis/znbuboni.asp>), with the citation\nnumbers changed to begin at 1, states:\n'Generally, the canine family is believed to be more resistant to plague\nthan the feline family and if they develop the disease at all, the disease\nusually is subclinical, that is, not easily recognizable. Wild carnivores\nin the dog family, such as coyotes and foxes, can develop blood titers\nagainst _Y. pestis_ (1,2) Experimentally, dogs inoculated with _Y. pestis_\ndevelop bacteremia and have had _Y. pestis_ isolated for 10 days from the\noropharynx (1). Subclinically and clinically affected dogs can develop\nantibodies against _Y. pestis_ (1), and people have contracted plague after\nskinning infected coyotes and foxes (1,3).\n'References:\n1. Poland J, Barnes A. Plague. In: Steele JH, ed. CRC handbook series in\nzoonoses Boca Raton, Fla: CRC Press, 1979.\n2. Rust JH jr, Cavanaugh DC, O'Shita R, et al. The role of domestic animals\nin the epidemiology of plague. I. Experimental infection of dogs and cats.\nJ Infect Dis 1971; 124: 522-6 [although a different reference in the same\njournal actually discusses the serologies: The role of domestic animals in\nthe epidemiology of plague. II. Antibody to _Yersinia pestis_ in sera of\ndogs and cats. Rust JH jr, Miller BE, Bahmanyar M, et al. J Infect Dis\n1971; 124: 527-31. - Mod.LL]\n3. Barnes AM. Surveillance and control of bubonic plague in the United\nStates. Symp Zool Soc London 1982.'\nPlague is endemic in Mongolia. Marmots such as the Tarvaga, the Tarbagan or\nMongolian Marmot _Marmota sibirica_, a large rodent related to the American\nwoodchuck (_M. monax_), are thought to be significant zoonotic reservoirs\nfor _Y. pestis_ in Eastern Asia. The name marmot\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marmot>) comes from French marmotte, from\nLatin mures monti 'mountain mouse.'\nA map of the country of Mongolia can be found at\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/mongolia.pdf>. The\nprovince of Hovsgol is in the north-central part of the country. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n [byline: Wen Huo]\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Dan Silver\n Marmots such as the Tarvaga, the Tarbagan or\nMongolian Marmot _Marmota sibirica_, a large rodent related to the American\nwoodchuck (_M. monax_), are thought to be significant zoonotic reservoirs\nfor _Y. pestis_ in Eastern Asia. An American Veterinary Medical Association reference\n(<http://www.avma.org/reference/zoonosis/znbuboni.asp>), with the citation\nnumbers changed to begin at 1, states:\n' Subclinically and clinically affected dogs can develop\nantibodies against _Y. pestis_ (1), and people have contracted plague after\nskinning infected coyotes and foxes (1,3). J Infect Dis 1971; 124: 522-6 [although a different reference in the same\njournal actually discusses the serologies: The role of domestic animals in\nthe epidemiology of plague. Generally, the canine family is believed to be more resistant to plague\nthan the feline family and if they develop the disease at all, the disease\nusually is subclinical, that is, not easily recognizable. Experimentally, dogs inoculated with _Y. pestis_\ndevelop bacteremia and have had _Y. pestis_ isolated for 10 days from the\noropharynx (1). Wild carnivores\nin the dog family, such as coyotes and foxes, can develop blood titers\nagainst _Y. pestis_ (1,2) Sources\nsay that the deceased contracted plague through contact with a dog on 31\n It is also not clear what\nrelationship the dog had in the transmission of _Yersinia pestis_ in this case.\n PLAGUE, HUMAN, FATAL - MONGOLIA (HOVSGOL)\n*****************************************\n But illicit hunting incidents still\noccur despite repeated prohibitions.\n The name marmot\n(<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marmot>) comes from French marmotte, from\nLatin mures monti 'mountain mouse.' \n'References:\n1. [The clinical manifestations of plague in the adolescent are not stated,\nespecially if pneumonic plague was present. Mongolia is a high plague incidence region and plague has occurred in\nalmost all provinces.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-08-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "1979-03-25 00:00:00", "1982-03-25 00:00:00", "1971-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Cavanaugh DC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Poland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tarbagan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hovsgol Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "London", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tsetserleg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Boca Raton", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United \n States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "19030", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, prairie dogs - USA (CO)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=19030", "date": "2007-07-25 14:00:08", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PRAIRIE DOGS - USA (COLORADO)\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 24 Jul 2007\nSource: KKTV (Colorado) [edited]\n<http://www.kktv.com/news/headlines/8684382.html>\n\nThe El Paso County Health Department has confirmed several prairie\ndog sites are infected with plague. The sites are at Schriever Air\nForce Base and on neighboring property, in eastern El Paso County.\nPlague is commonly found in the Western US in small ground animals\nthat have been bitten by fleas.\nHuman cases aren't common, but plague can be transmitted to people\nfrom infected animals. Since 1941, there have been 55 cases statewide\nof human plague.\nAccording to the Health Department, take the following precautions to\nprevent infection:\n* Avoid contact with sick or dead prairie dogs and rabbits.\n* Keep a close eye on pets, and make sure they are treated for fleas\nand properly secured when outdoors.\n* Do not linger in areas populated by prairie dogs, rabbits, or\nsimilar animals. Also do not attempt to catch, feed, or play with them.\n* Treat pants, socks, shoe tops, arms, and legs with insect repellent\nwhen engaged in outdoor activities, such as hiking or jogging.\n* Be aware of dead animal smells or heavy fly populations indicating\nanimal 'die-offs,' which are a key sign of plague. Report such areas\nto the Health Department.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Joseph P. Dudley, Ph.D\n[Prairie dogs are often sensitive sentinels for plague. A photo of a\nprairie dog may be seen at\n<http://www.northrup.org/photos/Animals/nl-41.htm>.\nBlack-tailed prairie dogs (_Cynomys ludovicianus_) are numerous in Colorado.\nThe causative bacterium _Yersinia pestis_ is transmitted to people\nthrough fleabite and direct contact with infected animals. Each\nrodent species is host to one or more species of fleas which, when\ninfected, are carriers. These fleas generally do not infest other\nanimals unless their natural hosts are unavailable. Rock squirrels\n(_Spermophilus variegates_) are closely related to California ground\nsquirrels and are the most significant plague host in Colorado. Their\nprincipal flea _Diamanus montanus_ is an aggressive parasite and will\nreadily bite other animals and people. Domestic cats and dogs can\nalso contract plague by infective fleas. They may carry infected\nfleas home to their owners or, especially with cats, serve as a\ndirect source of infection.\nIn humans, the incubation period (interval between exposure and\nappearance of symptoms) is usually 2-6 days. Typical symptoms include\nsudden onset of fever and chills, severe headache, muscle aches,\nnausea, vomiting, and a general feeling of systemic illness. Extreme\npain and swelling in a lymph node draining the infection site is a\nsuggestive symptom of bubonic plague. (The swollen, painful node is\ncalled a 'bubo'). Other forms of the disease include septicemic\nillness with no bubo developing, and pneumonic plague in which the\nlungs are involved. The septicemic and pneumonic forms are the most\nserious. In addition, pneumonic plague can be spread by inhalation of\ninfective droplets expelled by another human or animal with plague pneumonia.\nTreatment with antibiotics is effective during the early stages of\ndisease. If diagnosis and appropriate treatment are delayed,\nlife-threatening complications may follow. A doctor or hospital\nemergency room should be consulted as soon as symptoms appear and a\nhistory of exposure to potentially infected animals is very important\nin evaluating the risk from plague. Anti-plague vaccine is not\nreadily available. It may be advantageous for researchers or people\nworking with plague-infected animals to be vaccinated but it is not\nindicated for the general public.\nIt is an opportune time to remember to treat your pets, cats, and\ndogs with appropriate flea control. There are many excellent choices\nof products to rid your pet of fleas. Be sure to consult your\nveterinarian as some products may be toxic to cats, kittens, and\npuppies, even resulting in fatalities.\nAccording to\n<http://digitalcommons.unl.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1009&context=vpcfour>:\nOne human case was reported in conjunction with a previous outbreak\nof plague among urban populations of fox squirrels (_Scirus niger_)\nin Denver during 1968.\nEl Paso County is south of Denver and can be located on the map of Colorado at\n<http://quickfacts.census.gov/qfd/maps/colorado_map.html>\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from:\n<http://www.cdphe.state.co.us/dc/Zoonosis/plague/plaguefacts.html>. - Mod.TG]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 24 Jul 2007\n A doctor or hospital\nemergency room should be consulted as soon as symptoms appear and a\nhistory of exposure to potentially infected animals is very important\nin evaluating the risk from plague. Be sure to consult your\nveterinarian as some products may be toxic to cats, kittens, and\npuppies, even resulting in fatalities.\n It may be advantageous for researchers or people\nworking with plague-infected animals to be vaccinated but it is not\nindicated for the general public. Source: KKTV (Colorado) [edited]\n<http://www.kktv.com/news/headlines/8684382.html>\n\nThe El Paso County Health Department has confirmed several prairie\ndog sites are infected with plague. Other forms of the disease include septicemic\nillness with no bubo developing, and pneumonic plague in which the\nlungs are involved. One human case was reported in conjunction with a previous outbreak\nof plague among urban populations of fox squirrels (_Scirus niger_)\nin Denver during 1968. Rock squirrels\n(_Spermophilus variegates_) are closely related to California ground\nsquirrels and are the most significant plague host in Colorado. They may carry infected\nfleas home to their owners or, especially with cats, serve as a\ndirect source of infection. Extreme\npain and swelling in a lymph node draining the infection site is a\nsuggestive symptom of bubonic plague. PLAGUE, PRAIRIE DOGS - USA (COLORADO)\n*************************************\n Since 1941, there have been 55 cases statewide\nof human plague.\n Each\nrodent species is host to one or more species of fleas which, when\ninfected, are carriers. Typical symptoms include\nsudden onset of fever and chills, severe headache, muscle aches,\nnausea, vomiting, and a general feeling of systemic illness. Their\nprincipal flea _Diamanus montanus_ is an aggressive parasite and will\nreadily bite other animals and people. A photo of a\nprairie dog may be seen at\n<http://www.northrup.org/photos/Animals/nl-41.htm>. According to the Health Department, take the following precautions to\nprevent infection:\n* El Paso County is south of Denver and can be located on the map of Colorado at\n<http://quickfacts.census.gov/qfd/maps/colorado_map.html>\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-25 00:00:00", "1968-03-25 00:00:00", "1941-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denver", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "El Paso County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Cynomys", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "10620", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, feline - USA (CO)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=10620", "date": "2007-05-27 01:00:01", "main_text": "PLAGUE, FELINE - USA (COLORADO)\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 26 May 2007\nSource: 9NEWS [edited]\n<http://www.9news.com/news/article.aspx?storyid=70803>\n\nOfficials confirm plague caused death in domestic cat\n--------------------------------------\nState health officials in Colorado confirmed on\nFriday [25 May 2007] that the death of a domestic cat was caused by plague.\n'While a case of cat plague is a public health\nconcern, this is not an uncommon finding in areas\nwhere plague is circulating,' said John Pape, an\nepidemiologist who specializes in animal-related\ndiseases for the Disease Control and\nEnvironmental Epidemiology Division at the\nColorado Department of Public Health and Environment.\nSo far this year [2007], at least 15 squirrels\nhave tested positive for plague in the [Denver]\nmetro area. Additionally, a rabbit at City Park\nin Denver also tested positive for plague, and a\nmonkey from the Denver Zoo was confirmed to have\ndied from the bacteria. Pape says plague was\nfound in wild animals in 25 different Colorado counties last year [2006].\nState health officials say cats are very\nsusceptible to contracting plague because they\nwill commonly eat rodents which were infected.\nPape says last year, 23 cats were diagnosed with\nplague. Officials say cats infected with plague\nbecome extremely ill and have many of the same\nsymptoms humans do: high fever, severe lethargy and swollen lymph nodes.\nIf you think your cat has been infected, you are\nadvised to contact a veterinarian. Dogs are\ngenerally resistant to plague, but can bring\ninfected fleas into the home, according to state\nhealth officials. Officials say most human plague\ncases occur from infected fleabites, but can also\nresult from direct contact with blood of an infected animal.\n[Byline: Dan Boniface]\n--\nCommunicated by: ProMD-mail Rapporteur Joseph Dudley\n[There are many maps listed in the previous\npostings of this plague outbreak in Colorado.\nCats are generally regarded as one of the more\nsensitive domestic animal sentinels for plagues. \ufffd Mod.TG]", "summary": "While a case of cat plague is a public health\nconcern, this is not an uncommon finding in areas\nwhere plague is circulating,' said John Pape, an\nepidemiologist who specializes in animal-related\ndiseases for the Disease Control and\nEnvironmental Epidemiology Division at the\nColorado Department of Public Health and Environment. PLAGUE, FELINE - USA (COLORADO)\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2007-05-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denver", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "18510", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, squirrel - USA (CA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=18510", "date": "2007-07-20 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, SQUIRREL - USA (CALIFORNIA)\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 19 Jul 2007\nSource: KNBC.com (Los Angeles) [edited]\n<http://www.knbc.com/health/13715171/detail.html>\n\nA ground squirrel in the Stoneyvale Picnic Area of the Angeles\nNational Forest tested positive for plague, Los Angeles County health\nand US Forestry Service officials said Thursday [19 Jul 2007].\nThe squirrel was one of a dozen captured in traps on 10 Jul 2007. The\npicnic area, located 5 miles (8 km) north of La Canada-Flintridge, is\nexpected to remain closed for at least 10 days as crews dust for\nfleas and monitor other squirrels.\n'Plague is a bacterial infection that could be transmitted to humans\nthrough the bites of infected fleas. However, it is very important\nfor the public to know that there have only been 4 cases of human\nplague in Los Angeles County residents since 1984, none of which were\nfatal,' said Dr. Jonathan Fielding, the county's public health\ndirector.\nIn 1996, 2 ground squirrels found in the same picnic area tested\npositive for plague, as did a squirrel found in an adjacent\ncampground in 1995.\nA ground squirrel found at the Doan Valley Campground on Palomar\nMountain in San Diego County tested positive for plague earlier this\nmonth [July 2007].\nBubonic plague is transmitted through fleabites. Symptoms may include\nthe enlargement of lymph glands near the fleabite and rapid onset of\nfever and chills.\nIf left untreated, plague can result in an infection of the blood or\nlungs, causing pneumonic plague. All forms of the disease are fatal\nif left untreated.\nVisitors in the San Gabriel Mountains can protect themselves from\nplague-carrying fleas by avoiding camp and picnic areas in the\nimmediate vicinity of ground squirrel burrows. They should also\nrefrain from feeding wild animals and avoid taking their pets into\nareas where they could be exposed to fleas.\n'Protection with an insect repellant containing DEET is also\nrecommended for persons visiting the Angeles National Forest and\nengaging in outside recreational activities in other areas of L.A.\nCounty,' Fielding said.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteurs Joseph P. Dudley, Ph.D & Brent Barrett)\n[The article does not tell us specifically what type of ground squirrel was\naffected, and there are many different squirrels. The common\nCalifornia ground squirrel is _Spermophilus beecheyi_ (link to image\nbelow).\nThe causative bacterium _Yersinia pestis_ is transmitted to people\nthrough fleabite and direct contact with infected animals. Each rodent\nspecies is host to one or more species of fleas which, when infected,\nare carriers. These fleas generally do not infest other animals unless\ntheir natural hosts are unavailable.\nDomestic cats and dogs can also contract plague from infective fleas.\nThey may carry infected fleas home to their owners or, especially\ncats, serve as a direct source of infection. There are many flea\ntreatments and repellants appropriate for pets and available. Some\nproducts may be suitable for dogs but not cats or may be suitable for\nan adult but not a younger animal. Be sure to consult your\nveterinarian, as some products may be toxic to cats, kittens, and\npuppies, even resulting in fatalities. - Mod.TG\nA photo of the California ground squirrel _Spermophilus beecheyi_ can\nbe seen at:\n<http://www.doubledogmusic.com/images/2006/california_ground_squirrel.jpg>\n- Mod.JW\nA map of California may be seen at\n<http://www.infoplease.com/atlas/state/california.html>.\nAngeles National Forest is located in the San Gabriel Mountains of\nLos Angeles County, just north of the metropolitan area of Los\nAngeles. - CopyEd.MJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n However, it is very important\nfor the public to know that there have only been 4 cases of human\nplague in Los Angeles County residents since 1984, none of which were\nfatal,' said Dr. Jonathan Fielding, the county's public health\ndirector. Source: KNBC.com (Los Angeles) [edited]\n<http://www.knbc.com/health/13715171/detail.html>\n\nA ground squirrel in the Stoneyvale Picnic Area of the Angeles\nNational Forest tested positive for plague, Los Angeles County health\nand US Forestry Service officials said Thursday [19 Jul 2007]. The\npicnic area, located 5 miles (8 km) north of La Canada-Flintridge, is\nexpected to remain closed for at least 10 days as crews dust for\nfleas and monitor other squirrels. A photo of the California ground squirrel _Spermophilus beecheyi_ can\nbe seen at:\n<http://www.doubledogmusic.com/images/2006/california_ground_squirrel.jpg>\n- Mod. Protection with an insect repellant containing DEET is also\nrecommended for persons visiting the Angeles National Forest and\nengaging in outside recreational activities in other areas of L.A.\nCounty,' Fielding said. \nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteurs Joseph P. Dudley, Ph.D & Brent Barrett)\n In 1996, 2 ground squirrels found in the same picnic area tested\npositive for plague, as did a squirrel found in an adjacent\ncampground in 1995. PLAGUE, SQUIRREL - USA (CALIFORNIA)\n***********************************\n Some\nproducts may be suitable for dogs but not cats or may be suitable for\nan adult but not a younger animal.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-07-25 00:00:00", "1984-03-25 00:00:00", "1995-03-25 00:00:00", "1996-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Los \n Angeles", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Los Angeles County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Diego County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "L.A. \n County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Los Angeles", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "12914", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, human, septicemic - USA (NM)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=12914", "date": "2007-06-12 14:00:01", "main_text": "PLAGUE, HUMAN, SEPTICEMIC - USA (NEW MEXICO)\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Mon 11 Jun 2007\nSource: Santa Fe New Mexican [edited]\n<http://www.santafenewmexican.com/news/62967.html>\n\nState health investigators plan to trap rodents in a rural area south\nof Santa Fe today [11 Jun 2007], in hopes of discovering how a\n50-year-old woman got plague. They will also knock on doors to warn\nresidents and distribute brochures explaining how to avoid\ncontracting the severe infection, which is commonly spread to humans\nfrom fleas that have feasted on infected rodents.\nThe woman has recovered after being hospitalized and already has been\nspreading the word in her neighborhood, according to the New Mexico\nDepartment of Health. The woman had septicemic plague, a blood\ninfection that can cause death. Symptoms can include fever, vomiting,\ndiarrhea, abdominal pain, low blood pressure, blood-clotting\nproblems, and organ failure.\nDr. Paul Ettestad, a public health veterinarian for the Health\nDepartment, said it's not a good sign that the state has confirmed 4\ncases of plague since April [2007]. 'It could be a significant year\nfor a lot of plague activity,' he said.\nPrairie dogs and rock squirrels, common carriers of the plague, may\nhave swelled in number over the past couple of years because of\nwetter than usual seasons, Ettestad said. Combine a lot of rodents\nwith a cool, wet spring, in which fleas multiply, and you have got a\nmixture that could produce more plague cases in humans in 2007, he\nsaid.\nRecent cases seem to have other factors in common: plague-infected\nrodents scurrying near but not inside the house, cats or dogs that\nlike to hunt rodents, cats or dogs that have not been treated for\nfleas, and cats or dogs that flop on beds or couches inside the\nhouse. Ettestad admits it is hard to prove that this is exactly how\nthe fleas got from the rodents to the humans, but he thinks it is\nplausible.\n'There are ways to protect you and your pets from plague: Prevent\nyour pets from roaming and hunting rodents, use a flea control\nproduct on all your pets, and do not allow them to sleep in bed with\nyou,' Ettestad said.\nLast year [2006], 8 people in New Mexico had confirmed cases of\nplague, and 2 of them died. According to the Health Department,\npeople who are promptly treated with the proper kind of antibiotics\nare much less likely to die.\nThe cases in New Mexico in 2007:\nThe 1st case occurred in late April in a San Juan County man who recovered.\nThe 2nd was reported 5 Jun 2007 in a Torrance County woman who\nremains hospitalized.\nThe 3rd was a 3-year-old Bernalillo County boy who was reported dead\non 7 Jun 2007.\nThe most recent is a 50-year-old woman who has recovered after hospitalization.\n[Byline: Diana Del Mauro]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Joseph P. Dudley, Ph.D\n[As the posting states, following preventive strategies, early\nrecognition, and treatment of presumptive cases of plague are the\nmost important modalities in decreasing morbidity and mortality of\n_Yersinia pestis_ infection.\nA map of New Mexico showing Santa Fe, Torrance, and Bernalillo\ncounties in central New Mexico and San Juan County in the extreme\nnorthwestern part of the state can be found at\n<http://county-map.digital-topo-maps.com/new-mexico-county-map.gif> - Mod.LL]", "summary": "Recent cases seem to have other factors in common: plague-infected\nrodents scurrying near but not inside the house, cats or dogs that\nlike to hunt rodents, cats or dogs that have not been treated for\nfleas, and cats or dogs that flop on beds or couches inside the\nhouse. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Source: Santa Fe New Mexican [edited]\n<http://www.santafenewmexican.com/news/62967.html>\n\nState health investigators plan to trap rodents in a rural area south\nof Santa Fe today [11 Jun 2007], in hopes of discovering how a\n50-year-old woman got plague. They will also knock on doors to warn\nresidents and distribute brochures explaining how to avoid\ncontracting the severe infection, which is commonly spread to humans\nfrom fleas that have feasted on infected rodents. [As the posting states, following preventive strategies, early\nrecognition, and treatment of presumptive cases of plague are the\nmost important modalities in decreasing morbidity and mortality of\n_ Prevent\nyour pets from roaming and hunting rodents, use a flea control\nproduct on all your pets, and do not allow them to sleep in bed with\nyou,' Ettestad said. ' Prairie dogs and rock squirrels, common carriers of the plague, may\nhave swelled in number over the past couple of years because of\nwetter than usual seasons, Ettestad said. Ettestad admits it is hard to prove that this is exactly how\nthe fleas got from the rodents to the humans, but he thinks it is\nplausible. Symptoms can include fever, vomiting,\ndiarrhea, abdominal pain, low blood pressure, blood-clotting\nproblems, and organ failure.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Bernalillo County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Torrance County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santa Fe", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Juan County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "12280", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, human, secondary pneumonic - USA (NM)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=12280", "date": "2007-06-07 16:00:02", "main_text": "PLAGUE, HUMAN, SECONDARY PNEUMONIC - USA (NEW MEXICO)\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Tue 5 Jun 2007\nSource: Las Cruces Sun-News, Associated Press report [edited]\n<http://www.lcsun-news.com/latest/ci_6066751>\n\nA Torrance County [New Mexico] woman was listed in critical condition Tue 5\nJun 2007, with plague. The state Department of Health said the 58 year old\nwoman developed bubonic plague, which progressed to plague pneumonia. The\ndepartment did not say where the woman was hospitalized. Officials are\ninvestigating her home to determine if there is a risk to other people.\nIt was the 2nd case of plague confirmed in New Mexico in 2007. A San Juan\nCounty man recovered after being infected in April 2007. [That case was\nsepticemic. - Mod.LL]\nPlague, a bacterial disease of rodents, usually is transmitted to humans\nthrough the bites of infected fleas. However, it can be transmitted by\ndirect contact with infected animals, including rodents, wildlife, and\npets. Prompt treatment with antibiotics can greatly reduce the fatality rate.\nPlague takes 3 forms -- bubonic, septicemic, and pneumonic. Symptoms of\nbubonic plague in humans include fever; painful swollen lymph nodes in the\ngroin, armpit or neck areas; chills; and sometimes headache, vomiting, and\ndiarrhea. Pneumonic plague [affects] the lungs.\nSepticemic plague, which occurs when the bacteria multiply in the blood,\nalso can have symptoms of high fever, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. Most\npeople become ill 2 to 7 days after being infected.\n'With the warmer weather there will likely be an increase in plague\nactivity in wild rodents, especially in the north central and north western\nparts of the state, where we have traditionally found most of the plague\nactivity in New Mexico,' said Dr Paul Ettestad, the Health Department's\npublic health veterinarian.\nNew Mexico had 8 cases of human plague, 2 of them fatal, in 2006. Of these,\n5 came from Bernalillo County. Santa Fe, San Miguel, and Torrance counties\nhad a single case each. The state reported 4 human plague cases in 2005,\nand none in 2004.\nThe department recommends prevention measures, including avoiding sick or\ndead rodents; teaching children not to play near rodent nests or burrows,\ntreating pets regularly with flea control products, cleaning up areas near\nhouses where rodents could live; and keeping pets from roaming.\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[Plague pneumonia (pneumonic plague) can be acquired secondarily from\nbacteremic spread from the bubonic form (as reported here) or as a primary\nform from another human or animal (especially a cat) with plague pneumonia\nor from an intentional bioterrorism event.\nThe following is a capsule summary of the management of plague pneumonia\nobtained from the New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene\n<http://www.nyc.gov/html/doh/html/cd/plaguemd.shtml>\n'Epidemiology:\n-highly infectious after aerosolization\n-person-to-person and animal-to-person transmission occurs with pneumonic\nplague.\nClinical:\n-incubation period is 1-3 days (ranges up to 7 days)\n-aerosolization would most likely result in pneumonic plague\n-pneumonic plague presents with the acute onset of high fevers, chills,\nheadache, malaise, and a productive cough, that is initially watery before\nbecoming bloody.\nDiagnosis:\n-characteristic staining features include gram negative coccobacilli with\nbipolar 'safety-pin' appearance\n-organism grows slowly on standard blood and MacConkey agar\n-immunofluorescent staining for capsule (F1 antigen) is diagnostic\n-bacterial cultures should be handled in BSL 2 (Biological Safety Level 2)\nfacilities\nTreatment:\n-streptomycin or gentamicin are the preferred antibiotics\n-tetracyclines or fluoroquinolones are alternative choices\n-co-trimoxazole (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole) is recommended for pregnant\nwomen and children between the ages of 2 months and 8 years\n-chloramphenicol should be used for plague meningitis\nProphylaxis:\n-antibiotic prophylaxis is recommended for all persons exposed to the\naerosol or persons in close physical contact with a confirmed case\n-tetracyclines or fluoroquinolones are recommended for 7 days\nPatient Isolation:\nStrict respiratory isolation until the patient has received at least 48\nhours of antibiotic therapy.'\nA map of New Mexico showing Torrance County in the central part of the\nstate can be found at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/united_states/newmexico_90.jpg>. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "The following is a capsule summary of the management of plague pneumonia\nobtained from the New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene\n<http://www.nyc.gov/html/doh/html/cd/plaguemd.shtml>\n'Epidemiology:\n-highly infectious after aerosolization\n-person-to-person and animal-to-person transmission occurs with pneumonic\nplague. Treatment:\n-streptomycin or gentamicin are the preferred antibiotics\n-tetracyclines or fluoroquinolones are alternative choices\n-co-trimoxazole (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole) is recommended for pregnant\nwomen and children between the ages of 2 months and 8 years\n-chloramphenicol should be used for plague meningitis\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n With the warmer weather there will likely be an increase in plague\nactivity in wild rodents, especially in the north central and north western\nparts of the state, where we have traditionally found most of the plague\nactivity in New Mexico,' said Dr Paul Ettestad, the Health Department's\npublic health veterinarian. The department recommends prevention measures, including avoiding sick or\ndead rodents; teaching children not to play near rodent nests or burrows,\ntreating pets regularly with flea control products, cleaning up areas near\nhouses where rodents could live; and keeping pets from roaming.\n Prophylaxis:\n-antibiotic prophylaxis is recommended for all persons exposed to the\naerosol or persons in close physical contact with a confirmed case\n-tetracyclines or fluoroquinolones are recommended for 7 days\n Diagnosis:\n-characteristic staining features include gram negative coccobacilli with\nbipolar 'safety-pin' appearance\n-organism grows slowly on standard blood and MacConkey agar\n [Plague pneumonia (pneumonic plague) can be acquired secondarily from\nbacteremic spread from the bubonic form (as reported here) or as a primary\nform from another human or animal (especially a cat) with plague pneumonia\nor from an intentional bioterrorism event. -aerosolization would most likely result in pneumonic plague\n-pneumonic plague presents with the acute onset of high fevers, chills,\nheadache, malaise, and a productive cough, that is initially watery before\nbecoming bloody. Symptoms of\nbubonic plague in humans include fever; painful swollen lymph nodes in the\ngroin, armpit or neck areas; chills; and sometimes headache, vomiting, and\ndiarrhea. -immunofluorescent staining for capsule (F1 antigen) is diagnostic\n-bacterial cultures should be handled in BSL 2 (Biological Safety Level 2)\nfacilities\n --\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Brent Barrett\n PLAGUE, HUMAN, SECONDARY PNEUMONIC - USA (NEW MEXICO)\n*****************************************************\n However, it can be transmitted by\ndirect contact with infected animals, including rodents, wildlife, and\npets. Clinical:\n-incubation period is 1-3 days (ranges up to 7 days)\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-04-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Torrance County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santa Fe", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bernalillo County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Miguel", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Juan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "12478", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, human, fatal - USA (NM)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=12478", "date": "2007-06-08 18:00:02", "main_text": "PLAGUE, HUMAN, FATAL - USA (NEW MEXICO)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri 8 Jun 2007\nSource: KOB TV, New Mexico [edited]\n<http://kob.com/article/stories/S107035.shtml?cat=517>\n\nA 3 year old Bernalillo County boy has died of bubonic plague, marking the\n1st fatal case of the disease in New Mexico in 2007. The state Health\nDepartment made the announcement on 7 Jun 2007.\nThe city of Albuquerque's Environmental Health Department and the state\nHealth Department are conducting an investigation at the boy's home in the\nEast Mountain area to determine if there is any risk to [other] people.\nThe boy was the 3rd plague case in New Mexico in 2007. The 1st, in late\nApril 2007, was a man from San Juan County who recovered, and the 2nd was a\nwoman from Torrance County who is still hospitalized.\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[As outlined by the CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvbid/plague/diagnosis.htm>:\n'Death from bubonic plague occurs after the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_\nescapes from the infected bubo into the bloodstream (septicemic plague)\ncausing the manifestations of the sepsis syndrome. Disseminated\nintravascular coagulation (DIC) with subsequent cutaneous hemorrhage may\nwell have been what was called the 'Black Death' in the Middle Ages. The\nbacterium can spread to the lungs, causing a secondary plague pneumonia\n(secondary to the bacteremia), or to the meninges, causing a plague\nmeningitis. Both of these events have a high case fatality rate and the\nsecondary plague pneumonia is the way the infection spreads (by aerosol)\nfrom person to person.\n'The typical sign of the most common form of human plague is a swollen and\nvery tender lymph gland, accompanied by pain. The swollen gland is called a\n'bubo'. Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen\ngland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history\nof possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. A person\nusually becomes ill with bubonic plague 2 to 6 days after being infected.\n'When bubonic plague is left untreated, plague bacteria invade the\nbloodstream. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they\nspread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal\ncondition. Infection of the lungs with the plague bacterium causes the\npneumonic form of plague, a severe respiratory illness. The infected person\nmay experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may\nexpel bloody sputum. If plague patients are not given specific antibiotic\ntherapy, the disease can progress rapidly to death. About 14 per cent (1 in\n7) of all plague cases in the United States are fatal.'\nA map of New Mexico showing Bernalillo County and Albuquerque, in the\ncentral part of the state, can be found at\n<http://quickfacts.census.gov/qfd/maps/new_mexico_map.html> - Mod.LL]", "summary": "[As outlined by the CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvbid/plague/diagnosis.htm>:\n'Death from bubonic plague occurs after the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_\nescapes from the infected bubo into the bloodstream (septicemic plague)\ncausing the manifestations of the sepsis syndrome. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n --\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org Bubonic plague should be suspected when a person develops a swollen\ngland, fever, chills, headache, and extreme exhaustion, and has a history\nof possible exposure to infected rodents, rabbits, or fleas. Source: KOB TV, New Mexico [edited]\n<http://kob.com/article/stories/S107035.shtml?cat=517>\n\nA 3 year old Bernalillo County boy has died of bubonic plague, marking the\n1st fatal case of the disease in New Mexico in 2007. Both of these events have a high case fatality rate and the\nsecondary plague pneumonia is the way the infection spreads (by aerosol)\nfrom person to person. As the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream, they\nspread rapidly throughout the body and cause a severe and often fatal\ncondition. The\nbacterium can spread to the lungs, causing a secondary plague pneumonia\n The infected person\nmay experience high fever, chills, cough, and breathing difficulty and may\nexpel bloody sputum.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2007-04-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bernalillo County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Torrance County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Juan County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "10150", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, squirrels, rabbit - USA (CO)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=10150", "date": "2007-05-05 10:00:02", "main_text": "PLAGUE, SQUIRRELS, RABBIT - USA (CO)\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://wwww.isid.org>\nDate: Fri 4 May 2007\nSource: CBS4 Denver [edited]\n<http://cbs4denver.com/health/local_story_124093516.html>\n\nPlague Killed Squirrel In Jefferson County: Health Experts Say\nThere's Little Threat To Humans\n------------------------------------------------\nHealth officials reports that 14 squirrels have died from the plague\nin the Denver [CO] metro area in recent weeks [Apr - May 2007]. The\nlatest case was discovered in Jefferson County near Chatfield and\nWadsworth. Surveillance has increased in Denver's City Park after 3\nsquirrels and a rabbit were found dead from the plague there. Experts\nsaid there are no major concerns for people, although fleas can\ntransmit the potentially deadly disease to people.\n'We see very few spillovers into humans,' said John Pape of the State\nHealth Department. 'We don't see a lot of human cases. We've never\nhad a situation where we've had hundreds of human cases like we had\nwith West Nile Virus.'\nImages of advanced plague in humans can be gruesome. But experts said\nthose cases are rare and happen only when individuals fail to seek\ntreatment in a timely fashion.\n[Byline: Paul Day]\n--\nContributed by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Joseph Dudley\n[The moderator comments in ProMED-mail post 20070504.1447 provides an\nexcellent update of plague in humans. - Mod.TG]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://wwww.isid.org>\n But experts said\nthose cases are rare and happen only when individuals fail to seek\ntreatment in a timely fashion.\n Experts\nsaid there are no major concerns for people, although fleas can\ntransmit the potentially deadly disease to people. The zoo learned late Friday [18 May 2007] from the Colorado\nDepartment of Public Health and Environment (CDPHE) that the hooded\ncapuchin monkey had the plague.\nThe monkey seemed lethargic last Tuesday [15 May 2007] and was found\ndead Wednesday morning [16 May 2007] by a zookeeper, zoo officials\nsaid. It's unclear if the monkey contracted the disease from infected\nfleas, or if the monkey ingested the remains of an infected squirrel.\nThe zoo suspects it's from ingestion. None of the other monkeys in\nthe troop have displayed signs of illness, but antibiotics have been\nadministered as a precaution.\n'Denver Zoo remains in regular contact with CDPHE,' Senior\nVeterinarian Dave Kenny said in a prepared statement. 'And although\nthe risk of contracting plague to people and animals in the area is\nextremely low, we are continuing to emphasize communication with\nvisitors to prevent exposure to squirrels and rabbits.'\nJohn Pape, an epidemiologist with CDPHE, said the death was\nunfortunate, but not unexpected. 'There are some animal species in\nthe zoo collection, including monkeys, that could be susceptible to\nplague,' Pape said. 'Infected squirrels and a rabbit have been\nreported in the area and can have contact with the zoo animals.'\nHooded capuchin monkeys are a small primate native to South America.\n[Byline: Matthew J. A\nsquirrel in Aurora is now the 18th animal to have [a confirmed diagnosis of\nthe disease]. Most of the squirrels have been found around City Park, where\nparents, and pet owners have plenty of questions.\nHealth officials say fleas that jump from animal to animal spread the\ndisease. [Humans can become ill if infected fleas get on them, as is the\ncase of 4 people in Colorado who contracted plague last year [2006]. One\nperson died from the disease in 2004. Vets say cats are very susceptible to\nplague. Dogs are usually immune, but can carry infected fleas inside the house.\nThe best advice is to not touch dead animals, and to keep a close eye out\nfor fleas on pets. Early signs among pets include swollen lymph nodes and\nbreathing problems.\n[byline: John Romero]\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Joseph P Dudley, PhD\n******\n[2] Colorado - fleas\nDate: Wed 15 May 2007\nSource: The Daily Times-Call [edited]\n<http://www.longmontfyi.com/Local-Story.asp?id=16368>\n\nBoulder (Colorado) officials announced Monday [14 May 2007], that fleas\ncollected on May 8 [2007] near 63rd Street and the Diagonal Highway have\ntested positive for plague.\nEmployees posted signs at the area, near the base of the Boulder Reservoir\ndam, and next to the city of Boulder Water Treatment Plant, and the city\nplans to dust some prairie dog burrows with a pesticide to reduce the\nchance of plague exposure from fleas.\nThe announcement came one week after Boulder Parks officials closed Tom\nWatson Park near IBM because they were concerned that a prairie dog colony\nthere was infected with plague. The park reopened the next day.\n'While the current location of affected prairie dog colonies does not\nwarrant the closure of city property at this time, we urge all visitors to\nCoot Lake, Tom Watson Park, and the Boulder Reservoir dam to keep pets on\nleashes and out of prairie dog areas,' said Jan Geden, city director of\nParks and Recreation. 'Our city staff will continue monitoring adjacent\nprairie dog colonies and take necessary steps to inform and protect the\npublic should the disease spread to other areas.'\nPlague is a bloodborne disease most commonly transmitted by fleas. Public\nhealth officials urge residents to protect pets with flea powder and keep\nthem away from areas where wild rodents live. Residents also should prevent\nrodent infestations around houses and treat rodent sites with flea powder.\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Joseph P Dudley, PhD\n******\n[3] California - domestic cat\nDate: Fri 11 May 2007\nSource: Eye Out for You.com, Eyewitness News [edited]\n<http://www.eyeoutforyou.com/news/local/7471377.html>\n\nThe Kern County Department of Public Health learned on Thursday [10 May\n2007] that a domestic cat from Hart Flat, California, had tested positive\nfor _Yersinia pestis_, a bacterium that causes plague. The case is under\ninvestigation by the Department of Public Health as well as the Vector\nControl Section of the California Department of Health Services.\nSo far, there is no evidence of human infection, but those that may have\n[been exposed to] the infected cat and that cat itself have been given\nantibiotics. The Department of Public Health says cats are believed to be\nthe domestic species most susceptible to plague.\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Joseph P Dudley, PhD\n[Dr Dudley also provided the reference 'Vector-Borne Diseases in\nCalifornia, 2005 Annual Report'\n<http://www.dhs.ca.gov/ps/dcdc/disb/pdf/Vector-Borne%20Diseases%20in%20California,%20Annual%20Report%202005.pdf>,\nwhich indicates that during 2005, plague was confirmed from 3 cats in Kern\nCounty. Kern County is the large county located directly above Los Angeles\nCounty and may be viewed at\n<http://quickfacts.census.gov/qfd/maps/california_map.html>.\nPrairie dogs are generally considered one of the sentinel animals with\nregard to plague. The collection and testing of the fleas is an early\nsurveillance for the disease. There are many flea treatments and repellants\nappropriate for pets and available from veterinarians. It is advisable to\nvisit the veterinarian, as some products may be suitable for dogs but not\ncats or may be suitable for an adult but not a younger animal. To avoid\ntoxic problems with flea protection products, please consult your veterinarian.\nA map of the Boulder area may be found at\n<http://maps.yahoo.com/py/maps.py?Pyt=Tmap&addr=&csz=Boulder%2C+CO&Get%A0Map=Get+Map>.\nCoot Lake, Tom Watson Park, and the Boulder Reservoir dam appear to be\nnorth of the airport and just to the west of diagonal highway 119.\nA broader discussion of plague may be found in the moderator's comment in\nProMED-mail posting 20070427.1381. - Mod.TG]", "summary": "\n'While the current location of affected prairie dog colonies does not\nwarrant the closure of city property at this time, we urge all visitors to\nCoot Lake, Tom Watson Park, and the Boulder Reservoir dam to keep pets on\nleashes and out of prairie dog areas,' said Jan Geden, city director of\nParks and Recreation. To avoid\ntoxic problems with flea protection products, please consult your veterinarian.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-05-14 00:00:00", "2007-05-15 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2007-05-10 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Los Angeles", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Boulder", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Watson Park", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kern County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denver", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "around City Park", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "10115", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, squirrel - USA (CO)(02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=10115", "date": "2007-05-03 23:00:03", "main_text": "PLAGUE, SQUIRREL - USA (COLORADO) (02)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 2 May 2007\nSource: 9 news.com [edited]\n<http://www.9news.com/news/article.aspx?storyid=69222>\n\nThe county's Department of Health and Environment learned on\nWednesday [2 May 2007] that a dead squirrel found in the Littleton\narea has tested positive for bubonic plague.\nThe squirrel came from a greenbelt bordered by Wadsworth Boulevard\nand Chatfield Avenue. Warnings will be posted in the area, and\ncitizens will be urged to take simple precautions to prevent\nexposure. Last week, plague was confirmed in squirrels found near\nCity Park in Denver.\nPlague is a highly infectious bacterial disease transmitted mainly by\nflea bites. 'Squirrels, rodents, prairie dogs and other mammals, such\nas rabbits and cats, are susceptible to plague because they get\nfleas, and this is the beginning of the 2007 plague season,' says Dr.\nJim Dale, DVM, MPH, Director of Environmental Health Services.\nThe best way to prevent exposure to plague is to control rodents in\nand around your home, avoid wild rodents, confine house pets so they\ncannot prey on rodents and bring the plague home, and use flea\ncontrol products on your pets and around your home. Although\nextremely rare, humans may be infected with plague through bites from\ninfected fleas, by the cough from an infected animal, or by direct\ncontact (i.e. through a bite) with blood or tissues of infected animals.\nPlague is easily treated in humans with antibiotics when recognized early.\nTwo to 6 days after being infected with plague, people become ill\nwith the following symptoms: sudden onset of high fever; muscle pain;\nmalaise, or a general feeling of being ill; nausea and vomiting.\nIf a dead rabbit, squirrel, prairie dog or other rodent is found, do\nnot directly handle the animal. Use gloves and place in a plastic bag.\nCitizens or visitors are urged to report dead squirrels, prairie\ndogs, other rodents and rabbits by calling the CO-HELP hotline at\n1-877-462-2911.\n[Byline: Mark Peterson]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Joseph Dudley\n[For a discussion on plague, see ProMED-mail post 20070427.1381. For\na map of Colorado, see\n<http://worldatlas.com/webimage/countrys/namerica/usstates/co.htm>.\nLittleton is slightly south of Denver. - Mod.TG]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The best way to prevent exposure to plague is to control rodents in\nand around your home, avoid wild rodents, confine house pets so they\ncannot prey on rodents and bring the plague home, and use flea\ncontrol products on your pets and around your home. Although\nextremely rare, humans may be infected with plague through bites from\ninfected fleas, by the cough from an infected animal, or by direct\ncontact (i.e. through a bite) with blood or tissues of infected animals. Squirrels, rodents, prairie dogs and other mammals, such\nas rabbits and cats, are susceptible to plague because they get\nfleas, and this is the beginning of the 2007 plague season,' says Dr.\nJim Dale, DVM, MPH, Director of Environmental Health Services. Two to 6 days after being infected with plague, people become ill\nwith the following symptoms: sudden onset of high fever; muscle pain;\nmalaise, or a general feeling of being ill; nausea and vomiting. Citizens or visitors are urged to report dead squirrels, prairie\ndogs, other rodents and rabbits by calling the CO-HELP hotline at\n1-877-462-2911. Warnings will be posted in the area, and\ncitizens will be urged to take simple precautions to prevent\nexposure. Plague is a highly infectious bacterial disease transmitted mainly by\nflea bites. ' If a dead rabbit, squirrel, prairie dog or other rodent is found, do\nnot directly handle the animal. Last week, plague was confirmed in squirrels found near\nCity Park in Denver. PLAGUE, SQUIRREL - USA (COLORADO) (02)\n The squirrel came from a greenbelt bordered by Wadsworth Boulevard\nand Chatfield Avenue. Date: 2 May 2007\n **\n \n \n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-05-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Denver", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "City Park", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Littleton", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "10125", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, septicemic - USA (NM)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=10125", "date": "2007-05-04 12:00:01", "main_text": "PLAGUE, SEPTICEMIC - USA (NEW MEXICO)\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 3 May 2007\nSource: KOB.com [edited]\n<http://kob.com/article/stories/S76614.shtml?cat=520>\nThe New Mexico State Department of Health on Thursday confirmed a\ncase of septicemic plague in a 49 year old San Juan County man. It\nis the first case of 2007 in New Mexico and the first in a San Juan\nCounty resident since 1999. The department will conduct an\nenvironmental investigation at the victim's home to determine if\nthere is any continuing risk.\nPlague is generally transmitted to humans through bites of\ninfected fleas. It can also be transmitted by direct contact with\ninfected animals, including rodents, wildlife and pets.\nSepticemic plague occurs when the bacteria multiply in the\nblood. Health Department public health veterinarian Paul Ettestad\nsaid winter and spring precipitation has allowed rodents and their\nfleas to survive and multiply.\n--\nContributed by:\nProMED Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[Bubonic plague is the classical form of _Yersinia pestis_\ninfection,representing 85-90 percent of clinical presentations. The\nprocess arises as a result of a bite from an infected flea or by\ncontamination of an open skin lesion. Local bacterial proliferation\nis sometimes evident (4-10 percent of cases) in the form of an\nabscess or ulcer at the site of infection (1).\nSepticemic plague may occur as a consequence of more common\nbubonic form or may occur after exposure without the development of\na bubo. The absence of a bubo may delay considering the appropriate\ndiagnosis and treatment, increasing morbidity and mortality.\nThe mechanism of transmission of plague from flea to mammalian host\nis as follows:\nFleas become infected upon feeding on the blood of a rodent suffering\nfrom bacteremic infection. The bacteria are restricted to the\nalimentary tract of the flea, where they multiply in the midgut. The\nbacteria may form large brown clumps that extend throughout the\nmidgut, esophagus and proventriculus, a valve-like chamber situated\nbetween the esophagus and the midgut. The clumps increase in mass\nover a few days until the proventriculus is blocked.\nThe 'blocked' flea then feeds on blood, but the meal is unable to\npass into the stomach. The flea continues to attempt to feed, but as\nit futilely sucks blood from the host, the blood meal, mixed with\nbacteria from the foregut, is regurgitated into the mammal. As many\nas 24 000 bacilli may be transmitted in a single attempted feeding (2).\n1. McGovern, T. W. and Friedlander A. M. Plague. In Zajtchuk R. and\nBellamy R.F. (eds.) Textbook of Military Medicine: Medical Aspects of\nChemical and Biological Warfare. Office of the Surgeon General,\nBorden Institute, Washington, D.C., pp 479-502.\n2. Burroughs, AL: Sylvatic plague studies. The vector efficiency of\nnine species of plague compared with _Xenopsylla cheopis_. J Hyg\n1947;45:371-96.\nA map of New Mexico showing San Juan county in the northwestern\npart of the state can be found at:\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/united_states/newmexico_90.jpg>. - Mod. LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The\nbacteria may form large brown clumps that extend throughout the\nmidgut, esophagus and proventriculus, a valve-like chamber situated\nbetween the esophagus and the midgut. Health Department public health veterinarian Paul Ettestad\nsaid winter and spring precipitation has allowed rodents and their\nfleas to survive and multiply.\n The flea continues to attempt to feed, but as\nit futilely sucks blood from the host, the blood meal, mixed with\nbacteria from the foregut, is regurgitated into the mammal. Septicemic plague may occur as a consequence of more common\nbubonic form or may occur after exposure without the development of\na bubo. Local bacterial proliferation\nis sometimes evident (4-10 percent of cases) in the form of an\nabscess or ulcer at the site of infection (1). The mechanism of transmission of plague from flea to mammalian host\nis as follows:\n The\nprocess arises as a result of a bite from an infected flea or by\ncontamination of an open skin lesion. The department will conduct an\nenvironmental investigation at the victim's home to determine if\nthere is any continuing risk. PLAGUE, SEPTICEMIC - USA (NEW MEXICO)\n*******************************************\n It\nis the first case of 2007 in New Mexico and the first in a San Juan\nCounty resident since 1999. A map of New Mexico showing San Juan county in the northwestern\npart of the state can be found at:\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/united_states/newmexico_90.jpg>. - Mod. Source: KOB.com [edited]\n<http://kob.com/article/stories/S76614.shtml?cat=520>\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1999-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Washington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "D.C.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Juan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Juan County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "8752", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Uganda (Masindi) (03): pneumonic", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=8752", "date": "2007-03-09 11:00:02", "main_text": "PLAGUE - UGANDA (MASINDI) (03): PNEUMONIC\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 8 Mar 2007\nFrom: Joseph Dudley <fnjpd@uaf.edu>\nSource: New Vision [edited]\n<http://www.newvision.co.ug/D/8/13/553076>\n\nThe pneumonic plague that hit Masindi district killing at least 9\nresidents in Mutunda sub-county has been contained, the Ministry of\nHealth has announced. Out of 19 cases, 11 have been discharged in the\nlast 2 weeks. No new cases have been reported in the same period.\nThe ministry, however, advised the public to put up flea control\nmeasures and kill rats to contain the outbreak. Yesterday [7 Mar\n2007], the health minister, Dr. Stephen Malinga, advised residents to\nensure an environment free of rodents even though the disease had\nbeen successfully controlled. 'We cannot therefore, sit back and say\nall is done. We have to get rid of rats which carry fleas.'\n[Byline: Fred Ouma]\n--\nJoseph P. Dudley, PhD\nResearch Associate\nInstitute of Arctic Biology\nUniversity of Alaska, Fairbanks\nUSA\n<fnjpd@uaf.edu>\n[Although one of the previous postings described the cases as\nbubonic, it appears that the disease was pneumonic plague as\npreviously stated. It is important to reemphasize that bubonic plague\nis spread to man from the bite of an infected (usually rodent) flea,\nnot from another person. Pneumonic plague can develop related to\nbacteremic spread of _Yersinia pestis_ from a bubo (secondary plague\npneumonia) or, as primary plague pneumonia, aerolized directly from\nanother person with the respiratory form of _Y. pestis_. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Pneumonic plague can develop related to\nbacteremic spread of _Yersinia pestis_ from a bubo (secondary plague\npneumonia) or, as primary plague pneumonia, aerolized directly from\nanother person with the respiratory form of _Y. pestis_. Institute of Arctic Biology\nUniversity of Alaska, Fairbanks\nUSA\n<fnjpd@uaf.edu>\n [Byline: Fred Ouma]\n--\nJoseph P. Dudley, PhD\nResearch Associate\n Source: New Vision [edited]\n<http://www.newvision.co.ug/D/8/13/553076>\n\nThe pneumonic plague that hit Masindi district killing at least 9\nresidents in Mutunda sub-county has been contained, the Ministry of\nHealth has announced.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Mutunda", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "10006", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, squirrel - USA (CO)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=10006", "date": "2007-04-27 23:56:02", "main_text": "PLAGUE, SQUIRREL - USA (COLORADO)\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 26 Apr 2007\nSource: Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment news\nrelease [edited]\n<http://www.cdphe.state.co.us/release/2007/042507b.html>\n\nPlague Found in Dead Denver Squirrel\n-----------------------------------------\nState health officials Thursday confirmed that plague has been found\nin a dead tree squirrel in the vicinity of City Park. A citizen had\nnoticed a die-off of squirrels in the neighborhood and reported it to\nDenver Animal Control. A carcass was collected Wednesday and tested\nat the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment\nlaboratory where preliminary tests were positive for plague.\nJohn Pape, an epidemiologist who specializes in animal-related\ndiseases for the department's Disease Control and Environmental\nEpidemiology Division, said, 'Plague is a disease seen every year\namong rodent populations in rural areas of Colorado, including the\nFront Range. It is unusual to find plague in the center of an urban\narea although it has happened before.' In Colorado, plague-infected\nanimals are most likely found in the foothills and mountains, he\nadded.\nAccording to Pape, 'Plague [bacteria are] maintained in various\nspecies of rodents and rabbits and transmitted by fleas. When an\ninfected rodent becomes sick and dies, its fleas can carry the\ninfection to other warm-blooded animals, including humans. People\nalso can be exposed through direct contact with infected rodents,\nrabbits and cats.'\n'The risk of Denver residents contracting plague is extremely low,'\nsaid Denver Public Health Director Dr. Chris Urbina. 'We want people\nto be aware of what to look for and take a few simple precautions to\nfurther reduce that risk.' He indicated that Denver Health, the\nColorado Department of Public Health and Environment and Denver\nEnvironmental Health are working together to investigate the case and\nto determine the extent of the die-off in the area.\nWhen plague appears in an area, there is usually a die-off of the\nrodents and rabbits. When the animal dies, the fleas leave the\ncarcass to find another host thus spreading the disease. Most human\nplague cases result from infected fleabites. Less commonly, people\nare infected by direct contact with blood from an infected animal or\nfrom cats which can become infected and transmit the disease.\nPeople should not directly handle any dead rodents they find and\nshould keep their pets away from them. If a dead rodent is found, do\nnot handle the animal directly. Use gloves and place in a plastic\nbag. Contact CO-HELP (Colorado Health Education Line for the Public)\nat 1-877-462-2911 to report a dead rodent or rabbit. Although the\nillness is severe and potentially life threatening, human cases occur\ninfrequently and plague is easily treated with common antibiotics\nwhen recognized early.\nDr. Urbina said that after 2-6 days after being infected, people\nbecome very ill with the following symptoms:\nA sudden onset of high fever;\nMuscle pain;\nMalaise; or a general feeling of being ill;\nNausea and vomiting.\n'With bubonic plague, individuals develop a large, swollen, painful\nlymph node called a bubo in the area of the flea bite, usually in the\ngroin or armpit,' he explained. 'If untreated, the disease can enter\nthe bloodstream (septicemic plague) or lungs (pneumonic plague) which\nare severe, life-threatening complications.'\nAccording to Pape, since 1957, 58 cases of human plague, 9 (15.5\npercent) of which were fatal, have been confirmed in Colorado. In\n2004, 3 human cases of plague were reported, including one fatality.\nHunters infected while cleaning rabbits comprised 2 of these cases,\nand another person was infected by a fleabite while camping. A total\nof 4 cases was reported in both 2005 and 2006; none of these 8 cases\nwas fatal. Most were infected by fleabites from around their home.\nPlague was identified last year in wild animals from 25 Colorado\ncounties, according to Pape. Veterinarians' diagnosed 23\nplague-infected cats, which are highly susceptible to plague and are\nusually infected from eating rodents. Cats with plague become\nextremely ill and develop an illness very similar to people with high\nfever and swollen lymph nodes.\nOwners are advised to contact their veterinarian if they see these\nsigns in a cat, especially cats known to hunt rodents. Dogs are\ngenerally resistant to plague but can bring infected fleas into the\nhome.\nPape and Urbina offered the following precautions for Denver citizens to take:\nDo not feed squirrels or other rodents. This brings them onto your\nproperty and in close contact with each other increasing the risk of\ndisease transmission;\nRodent-proof houses and outbuildings;\nDon't let dogs or cats catch or eat squirrels;\nDo not allow pets to roam freely, and keep them treated for fleas\naccording to a veterinarian's advice;\nBe aware of rodent and rabbit populations in your area and report\nsudden die-offs or multiple dead animals;\nContact your physician if you develop a high fever and other plague\nsymptoms following a fleabite or direct contact with dead rodents or\nrabbits.\nAdditional information on plague can be found on the CDPHE website:\n<http://www.cdphe.state.co.us/dc/Zoonosis/plague/index.html>\nContact CO-HELP (Colorado Health Education Line for the Public) at\n1-877-462-2911 to report a dead rodent or rabbit.\n--\nCommunicated by:\nSuzanne Kelley, M.Ed, MT (ASCP)\nPublic Information Officer/Client Relations Manager/State Training Coordinator\nColorado Department of Public Health and Environment\nLaboratory Services Division\n8100 Lowry Boulevard\nDenver, CO 80230\nUSA\nSimilar information communicated by ProMED-mail Rapporteur Joseph Dudley, Ph.D.\n[The causative bacterium _Yersinia pestis_ is transmitted to people\nthrough flea bite and direct contact with infected animals. Each\nrodent species is host to one or more species of fleas which, when\ninfected, are carriers. These fleas generally do not infest other\nanimals unless their natural hosts are unavailable. Rock squirrels\n(_Spermophilus variegates_) are closely related to California ground\nsquirrels and are the most significant plague host in Colorado. Their\nprincipal flea _Diamanus montanus_ is an aggressive parasite and will\nreadily bite other animals and people. Domestic cats and dogs can\nalso contract plague by infective fleas. They may carry infected\nfleas home to their owners or, especially with cats, serve as a\ndirect source of infection.\nIn humans, the incubation period (interval between exposure and\nappearance of symptoms) is usually 2-6 days. Typical symptoms include\nsudden onset of fever and chills, severe headache, muscle aches,\nnausea, vomiting and a general feeling of systemic illness. Extreme\npain and swelling in a lymph node draining the infection site is a\nsuggestive symptom of bubonic plague. (The swollen, painful node is\ncalled a 'bubo'). Other forms of the disease include septicemic\nillness with no bubo developing, and pneumonic plague in which the\nlungs are involved. The septicemic and pneumonic forms are the most\nserious. In addition, pneumonic plague can be spread by inhalation of\ninfective droplets expelled by another human or animal with plague\npneumonia.\nTreatment with antibiotics is effective during the early stages of\ndisease. If diagnosis and appropriate treatment are delayed,\nlife-threatening complications may follow. A doctor or hospital\nemergency room should be consulted as soon as symptoms appear and a\nhistory of exposure to potentially infected animals is very important\nin evaluating the risk from plague. Anti-plague vaccine is not\nreadily available. It may be advantageous for researchers or people\nworking with plague-infected animals to be vaccinated but it is not\nindicated for the general public.\nIt is an opportune time to remember to treat your pets, cats and dogs\nwith appropriate flea control. There are many excellent choices of\nproducts to rid your pet of fleas. Be sure to consult your\nveterinarian as some products may be toxic to cats, kittens and\npuppies, even resulting in fatalities.\nAccording to:\n<http://digitalcommons.unl.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1009&context=vpcfour\n>\nOne human case was reported in conjunction with a previous outbreak of plague\namong urban populations of fox squirrels (_Scirus niger_) in Denver\nduring 1968.\nFor a map of Colorado and the location of Denver, please see:\n<http://touristguide.com/maps/colorado-map.jpg>\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from:\n<http://www.cdphe.state.co.us/dc/Zoonosis/plague/plaguefacts.html>\n- Mod.TG]", "summary": "This brings them onto your\nproperty and in close contact with each other increasing the risk of\ndisease transmission;\nRodent-proof houses and outbuildings;\nDon't let dogs or cats catch or eat squirrels;\nDo not allow pets to roam freely, and keep them treated for fleas\naccording to a veterinarian's advice;\n \nDr. Urbina said that after 2-6 days after being infected, people\nbecome very ill with the following symptoms:\nA sudden onset of high fever;\nMuscle pain;\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Be aware of rodent and rabbit populations in your area and report\nsudden die-offs or multiple dead animals;\nContact your physician if you develop a high fever and other plague\nsymptoms following a fleabite or direct contact with dead rodents or\nrabbits. John Pape, an epidemiologist who specializes in animal-related\ndiseases for the department's Disease Control and Environmental\nEpidemiology Division, said, 'Plague is a disease seen every year\namong rodent populations in rural areas of Colorado, including the\nFront Range. Less commonly, people\nare infected by direct contact with blood from an infected animal or\nfrom cats which can become infected and transmit the disease. If untreated, the disease can enter\nthe bloodstream (septicemic plague) or lungs (pneumonic plague) which\nare severe, life-threatening complications.' In addition, pneumonic plague can be spread by inhalation of\ninfective droplets expelled by another human or animal with plague\npneumonia. It may be advantageous for researchers or people\nworking with plague-infected animals to be vaccinated but it is not\nindicated for the general public. Cats with plague become\nextremely ill and develop an illness very similar to people with high\nfever and swollen lymph nodes. People\nalso can be exposed through direct contact with infected rodents,\nrabbits and cats.'
