Rock squirrels\n(_Spermophilus variegates_) are closely related to California ground\nsquirrels and are the most significant plague host in Colorado.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00", "1957-03-25 00:00:00", "1968-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denver", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Urbina", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "9285", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, bubonic, fatal - Tanzania (Manyara)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=9285", "date": "2007-03-28 19:00:03", "main_text": "PLAGUE, BUBONIC, FATAL - TANZANIA (MANYARA)\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 28 Mar 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: IPP Media, Guardian report [edited]\n<http://www.ippmedia.com/ipp/guardian/2007/03/28/87237.html>\n\nAt least 8 people have died of plague in Endoji Village, Mbulu\nDistrict, in Manyara Region. The deadly disease is spread by rodents,\nwhich have multiplied in large numbers in the area. The Mbulu\nDistrict Medical Officer, Dr John Gulisha, confirmed that 8 people\nhad died of the disease since 28 Feb 2007, when the 1st case was reported.\nDespite the fact that medical reports indicate that only 8 people,\nmainly children, had died of the disease, impeccable sources in the\nvillage maintained that the death toll stood at 15 people.\nDr. Gulisha said symptoms of the ailment include swellings under the\narmpits, high fever, and body fatigue.\nSince the beginning of January 2007, rodents have invaded some\nvillages in Mbulu District. The situation deteriorated when villagers\nstarted killing the rats. As more rats got killed and were discarded\nat random, the bacterium [_Yersinia pestis_] that causes the disease\nspread out quickly [through its flea vector - Mod.LL], causing more\ninfection to people, especially among children.\nDr. Gulisha said efforts had been made to control the spread of the\ndisease, including communicating with the Sokoine University of\nAgriculture in Morogoro and the Ministry of Health and Social\nWelfare. He called on villagers to cooperate with medical experts by\nkeeping their surroundings clean and avoiding arbitrary killing of\nrats, because the practice [produced] a breeding ground of the epidemic.\n[Byline: Charles Masayanyika]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The description of symptoms suggests that the illness is bubonic\nplague spread from rodent fleas. It may appear paradoxical that\nkilling of the rodents would cause more human cases, but the death of\nrodents (either an epizooic or man-related extermination) will\nproduce infected and hungry fleas looking for a blood meal. If no\nrodents are available, humans will do. The number of deaths is\nreported (either 8 or 15) but no denominator of the total number of\ncases of plague is given. Untreated bubonic plague has a case\nfatality rate of 50-60 percent.\nMost of the _Yersinia pestis_ reports that ProMED-mail has posted\nfrom Africa have been from Congo DR and Uganda, although Tanzania\nhad one of the world's highest incidence rates in the 1980s. The\nManyara region of northeastern Tanzania can be found on a map at:\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manyara_Region>. It is bordered on the\neast by Tanga region, which includes Lushoto district where 64\nsuspected cases were reported in 1999 up to 22 Sep, with 2 deaths --\nsee 1999 ProMED archive below - Mod.LL/JW]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n It may appear paradoxical that\nkilling of the rodents would cause more human cases, but the death of\nrodents (either an epizooic or man-related extermination) will\nproduce infected and hungry fleas looking for a blood meal. It is bordered on the\neast by Tanga region, which includes Lushoto district where 64\nsuspected cases were reported in 1999 up to 22 Sep, with 2 deaths --\nsee 1999 ProMED archive below - Mod. >\nSource: IPP Media, Guardian report [edited]\n<http://www.ippmedia.com/ipp/guardian/2007/03/28/87237.html>\n\nAt least 8 people have died of plague in Endoji Village, Mbulu\nDistrict, in Manyara Region. He called on villagers to cooperate with medical experts by\nkeeping their surroundings clean and avoiding arbitrary killing of\nrats, because the practice [produced] a breeding ground of the epidemic.\n Dr. Gulisha said efforts had been made to control the spread of the\ndisease, including communicating with the Sokoine University of\nAgriculture in Morogoro and the Ministry of Health and Social\nWelfare. [Byline: Charles Masayanyika]\n--\nProMED-mail\n< Despite the fact that medical reports indicate that only 8 people,\nmainly children, had died of the disease, impeccable sources in the\nvillage maintained that the death toll stood at 15 people. The Mbulu\nDistrict Medical Officer, Dr John Gulisha, confirmed that 8 people\nhad died of the disease since 28 Feb 2007, when the 1st case was reported.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1999-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-02-28 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Manyara Region", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mbulu \n District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lushoto", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Endoji Village", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mbulu District", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tanzania", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Morogoro", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tanga", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "8520", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, pneumonic - Uganda (Masindi): conf", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=8520", "date": "2007-03-01 19:00:01", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PNEUMONIC - UGANDA (MASINDI): CONFIRMED\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 28 Feb 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Relief Web [edited]\n<http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/RWB.NSF/db900SID/EKOI-6YV4AJ?OpenDocument>\n\nAn emergency team has started a campaign to kill fleas and rats in a bid to\ncontrol the outbreak of the infectious pneumonic plague that has hit\nMasindi district, killing 10 people.\nThe group is made up of officials from the health ministry, the Uganda\nVirus Research Institute, the Centres for Disease Control (USA), the World\nHealth Organization, district health officials, and the epidemic control\ntask force.\nThe commissioner of health services, Dr Sam Okware, said they were\ndestroying the rats that carry the fleas, through spraying. He revealed\nthat the disease had been confirmed as pneumonic plague after tests in\nlaboratories in Kenya and Egypt. 'We are sensitising the communities that\nthis disease is related to poor hygiene. We are teaching them to keep their\nenvironment clean.'\nOkware pointed out that West Nile and Masindi were the focal areas but\nadded that the possible source of plague was the DR Congo. He also stressed\nthat they had enough drugs to deal with the situation. 'In fact we don't\nexpect more than a few hundred cases. We reacted fast enough to the\ndisease,' Okware noted.\nThe Masindi district director of health services, Dr John Turyagaruka, said\nno new cases had been reported while those admitted were improving.\nHowever, he complained that there was a shortage of gloves, masks, and\nboots needed for the exercise.\n[byline: Alfred Wasike, Steven Candia]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Plague is endemic in Uganda and annual outbreaks have been reported over\nthe past several years (see prior ProMED-mail postings listed below).\nMasindi is located in the north west of Uganda near Lake Albert. (Lake\nAlbert is situated on the border between Uganda and the Democratic Republic\nof the Congo (DRC)). The prior outbreaks of plague in Uganda reported on\nProMED-mail were also located in the north west of the country near the\nborder with the DRC (see\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/africa/uganda_pol_2005.jpg> and\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/uganda.pdf> for maps of\nUganda).\nAs both the DRC and Uganda are endemic for plague, in the absence of\ninformation on the index case in the outbreak, it is hard to point a\ndefinite finger as to whether the outbreak began in Uganda or was imported\nfrom the DRC.\nFor background information on plague, see the WHO fact sheet at:\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs267/en/> (excerpted below).\n'Plague is a zoonotic disease circulating mainly among small animals and\ntheir fleas. The bacterium _Yersinia pestis_ can also infect humans. It is\ntransmitted between animals and humans by the bite of infected fleas,\ndirect contact, inhalation, and rarely, ingestion of infective materials.\nPlague can be a very severe disease in people, with a case-fatality ratio\nof 30-60 per cent if left untreated.\n'Infected persons usually start with 'flu-like' symptoms after an\nincubation period of 3-7 days. Patients typically experience the sudden\nonset of fever, chills, head and body-aches, and weakness, vomiting and\nnausea. Clinical plague infection manifests itself in 3 forms depending on\nthe route of infection: bubonic, septicaemic and pneumonic.\n'* Bubonic form is the most common form of plague resulting from the bite\nof an infective flea. Plague bacillus enters the skin from the site of the\nbite and travels through the lymphatic system to the nearest lymph node.\nThe lymph node then becomes inflamed because the plague bacteria, _Y.\npestis_, will replicate here in high numbers. The swollen lymph node is\ncalled a 'bubo' which is very painful and can become suppurated as an open\nsore in advanced stage of infection;\n'* Septicaemic form of plague occurs when infection spreads directly\nthrough the bloodstream without evidence of a 'bubo'. More commonly\nadvanced stages of bubonic plague will result in the presence of _Y.\npestis_ in the blood. Septicaemic plague may result from flea bites and\nfrom direct contact with infective materials through cracks in the skin.\n'* Pneumonic form of plague is the most virulent and least common form of\nplague. Typically, pneumonic form is due to a secondary spread from\nadvanced infection of an initial bubonic form. Primary pneumonic plague\nresults from inhalation of aerosolized infective droplets and can be\ntransmitted from human to human without involvement of fleas or animals.\nUntreated pneumonic plague has a very high case fatality ratio.'\nPlague is endemic in many countries in Africa, in the former Soviet Union,\nthe Americas, and Asia. In 2003, 9 countries reported 2118 cases and 182\ndeaths. Of [the total number of] cases and deaths, 98.7 per cent and 98.9\nper cent, respectively, were reported from Africa. Today the distribution\nof plague coincides with the geographical distribution of its natural foci.\n- Mod.MPP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The swollen lymph node is\ncalled a 'bubo' which is very painful and can become suppurated as an open\nsore in advanced stage of infection;\n'* Septicaemic form of plague occurs when infection spreads directly\nthrough the bloodstream without evidence of a 'bubo'. The prior outbreaks of plague in Uganda reported on\nProMED-mail were also located in the north west of the country near the\nborder with the DRC (see\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/africa/uganda_pol_2005.jpg> and\n Source: Relief Web [edited]\n<http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/RWB.NSF/db900SID/EKOI-6YV4AJ?OpenDocument>\n\nAn emergency team has started a campaign to kill fleas and rats in a bid to\ncontrol the outbreak of the infectious pneumonic plague that has hit\n As both the DRC and Uganda are endemic for plague, in the absence of\ninformation on the index case in the outbreak, it is hard to point a\ndefinite finger as to whether the outbreak began in Uganda or was imported\nfrom the DRC. The group is made up of officials from the health ministry, the Uganda\nVirus Research Institute, the Centres for Disease Control (USA), the World\nHealth Organization, district health officials, and the epidemic control\ntask force. [byline: Alfred Wasike, Steven Candia]\n--\nProMED-mail\n< Primary pneumonic plague\nresults from inhalation of aerosolized infective droplets and can be\ntransmitted from human to human without involvement of fleas or animals. Clinical plague infection manifests itself in 3 forms depending on\nthe route of infection: bubonic, septicaemic and pneumonic.\n' More commonly\nadvanced stages of bubonic plague will result in the presence of _Y.\npestis_ in the blood. He revealed\nthat the disease had been confirmed as pneumonic plague after tests in\nlaboratories in Kenya and Egypt. ' It is\ntransmitted between animals and humans by the bite of infected fleas,\ndirect contact, inhalation, and rarely, ingestion of infective materials. The Masindi district director of health services, Dr John Turyagaruka, said\nno new cases had been reported while those admitted were improving.\n \n'Infected persons usually start with 'flu-like' symptoms after an\nincubation period of 3-7 days. Patients typically experience the sudden\nonset of fever, chills, head and body-aches, and weakness, vomiting and\nnausea. However, he complained that there was a shortage of gloves, masks, and\nboots needed for the exercise.\n (Lake\nAlbert is situated on the border between Uganda and the Democratic Republic\nof the Congo (DRC)). * Pneumonic form of plague is the most virulent and least common form of\nplague. * Bubonic form is the most common form of plague resulting from the bite\nof an infective flea.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2118-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Soviet Union", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Egypt", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kenya", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "8563", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Uganda (Masindi) (02): RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=8563", "date": "2007-03-02 11:00:02", "main_text": "PLAGUE - UGANDA (MASINDI) (O2): REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 1 Mar 2007\nFrom: Joseph Dudley <jdudley@eaicorp.com>\nSource: All Africa [edited]\n<http://allafrica.com/stories/200702280906.html>\n\nAccording to a ministry of health official, the plague that has infected 15\npeople and killed 9 in Masindi (in the north west of Uganda) is in fact, a\nmodified strain of the bubonic plague that killed an estimated 25 million\npeople in just 5 years (1347-1352.)\nThe director general of health services, Sam Zaramba, said the 1st case was\nreported 3 weeks ago but the spread has been contained. There has not been\na new infection reported in the last week. When the 1st deaths occurred in\nMasindi, initial suspicions were that either meningitis or Ebola were the\ncause.\nBlood samples from the deceased were quickly tested [and the results\nconfirmed] that it was bubonic plague that caused the deaths. [The results\nof additional tests performed] in South Africa and in Denmark, further\nconfirmed the suspicions.\nThis is not the 1st time bubonic plague has occurred in Uganda in the\nrecent past. Dr Zaramba said it has occurred on and off in Nebbi [also in\nnorth western Uganda] a number of times over the past 30 years. He further\nsaid that after discovering the occurrence of plague, the 1st priority is\nto contain the spread. Plague originates in rats and spreads to humans\nthrough fleas.\nThe 1st measure taken in Masindi was to stop people from sleeping on the\nfloor. Dr Zaramba said this reduced the prevalence of rats. Smearing floors\nwith cow dung also helps contain the spread of plague as it discourages\nrats from entering domestic environments.\n[byline: Ben Simon]\n--\nJoseph P Dudley, PhD\nEAI Corporation\n4301 North Fairfax Drive, Suite 200\nArlington, VA 22203\nUSA\n<jdudley@eaicorp.com>\n[In yesterday's ProMED-mail posting (Plague - Uganda (Masindi): pneumonic\n20070301.0725), the newswire mentioned that the form of plague in this\ncurrent outbreak was the pneumonic form. In the above newswire describes\nthe plague as bubonic (see yesterday's [1 Mar 2007] moderator comment for a\ndescription of the different forms of plague). In the pneumonic form of\nplague person-to-person transmission occurs at a higher frequency than in\nthe bubonic form as there is respiratory spread from aerosolized droplets.\nThe mortality rate with pneumonic plague is much higher than seen with the\nbubonic form. In the above newswire, the 'observed' case fatality rate is\n60 per cent, within the range expected with untreated disease. ProMED-mail\nwould appreciate clarification of the epidemiologic picture in this current\noutbreak from knowledgeable sources. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Source: All Africa [edited]\n<http://allafrica.com/stories/200702280906.html>\n\nAccording to a ministry of health official, the plague that has infected 15\npeople and killed 9 in Masindi (in the north west of Uganda) is in fact, a\nmodified strain of the bubonic plague that killed an estimated 25 million\npeople in just 5 years (1347-1352.) [byline: Ben Simon]\n--\nJoseph P Dudley, PhD\nEAI Corporation\n4301 Smearing floors\nwith cow dung also helps contain the spread of plague as it discourages\nrats from entering domestic environments.\n [In yesterday's ProMED-mail posting (Plague - Uganda (Masindi): pneumonic\n20070301.0725), the newswire mentioned that the form of plague in this\ncurrent outbreak was the pneumonic form. [The results\nof additional tests performed] in South Africa and in Denmark, further\nconfirmed the suspicions.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2007-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Arlington", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Fairfax Drive", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nebbi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Denmark", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "8809", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Uganda (Masindi): pneumonic", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=8809", "date": "2007-03-01 00:00:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE - UGANDA (MASINDI): PNEUMONIC\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 28 Feb 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Relief Web [edited]\n<http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/RWB.NSF/db900SID/EKOI-6YV4AJ?OpenDocument>\n\n\nAn emergency team has started a campaign to kill fleas and rats in a bid to\ncontrol the outbreak of the infectious pneumonic plague that has hit\nMasindi district, killing 10 people.\n\nThe group is made up of officials from the health ministry, the Uganda\nVirus Research Institute, the Centres for Disease Control (USA), the World\nHealth Organization, district health officials, and the epidemic control\ntask force.\n\nThe commissioner of health services, Dr Sam Okware, said they were\ndestroying the rats that carry the fleas, through spraying. He revealed\nthat the disease had been confirmed as pneumonic plague after tests in\nlaboratories in Kenya and Egypt. 'We are sensitising the communities that\nthis disease is related to poor hygiene. We are teaching them to keep their\nenvironment clean.'\n\nOkware pointed out that West Nile and Masindi were the focal areas but\nadded that the possible source of plague was the DR Congo. He also stressed\nthat they had enough drugs to deal with the situation. 'In fact we don't\nexpect more than a few hundred cases. We reacted fast enough to the\ndisease,' Okware noted.\n\nThe Masindi district director of health services, Dr John Turyagaruka, said\nno new cases had been reported while those admitted were improving.\nHowever, he complained that there was a shortage of gloves, masks, and\nboots needed for the exercise.\n\n[byline: Alfred Wasike, Steven Candia]\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is endemic in Uganda and annual outbreaks have been reported over\nthe past several years (see prior ProMED-mail postings listed below).\n\nMasindi is located in the north west of Uganda near Lake Albert. (Lake\nAlbert is situated on the border between Uganda and the Democratic Republic\nof the Congo (DRC)). The prior outbreaks of plague in Uganda reported on\nProMED-mail were also located in the north west of the country near the\nborder with the DRC (see\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/africa/uganda_pol_2005.jpg> and\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/uganda.pdf> for maps of\nUganda).\n\nAs both the DRC and Uganda are endemic for plague, in the absence of\ninformation on the index case in the outbreak, it is hard to point a\ndefinite finger as to whether the outbreak began in Uganda or was imported\nfrom the DRC.\n\nFor background information on plague, see the WHO fact sheet at:\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs267/en/> (excerpted below).\n\n'Plague is a zoonotic disease circulating mainly among small animals and\ntheir fleas. The bacterium _Yersinia pestis_ can also infect humans. It is\ntransmitted between animals and humans by the bite of infected fleas,\ndirect contact, inhalation, and rarely, ingestion of infective materials.\nPlague can be a very severe disease in people, with a case-fatality ratio\nof 30-60 per cent if left untreated.\n\n'Infected persons usually start with 'flu-like' symptoms after an\nincubation period of 3-7 days. Patients typically experience the sudden\nonset of fever, chills, head and body-aches, and weakness, vomiting and\nnausea. Clinical plague infection manifests itself in 3 forms depending on\nthe route of infection: bubonic, septicaemic and pneumonic.\n\n'* Bubonic form is the most common form of plague resulting from the bite\nof an infective flea. Plague bacillus enters the skin from the site of the\nbite and travels through the lymphatic system to the nearest lymph node.\nThe lymph node then becomes inflamed because the plague bacteria, _Y.\npestis_, will replicate here in high numbers. The swollen lymph node is\ncalled a 'bubo' which is very painful and can become suppurated as an open\nsore in advanced stage of infection;\n\n'* Septicaemic form of plague occurs when infection spreads directly\nthrough the bloodstream without evidence of a 'bubo'. More commonly\nadvanced stages of bubonic plague will result in the presence of _Y.\npestis_ in the blood. Septicaemic plague may result from flea bites and\nfrom direct contact with infective materials through cracks in the skin.\n\n'* Pneumonic form of plague is the most virulent and least common form of\nplague. Typically, pneumonic form is due to a secondary spread from\nadvanced infection of an initial bubonic form. Primary pneumonic plague\nresults from inhalation of aerosolized infective droplets and can be\ntransmitted from human to human without involvement of fleas or animals.\nUntreated pneumonic plague has a very high case fatality ratio.'\n\nPlague is endemic in many countries in Africa, in the former Soviet Union,\nthe Americas, and Asia. In 2003, 9 countries reported 2118 cases and 182\ndeaths. Of [the total number of] cases and deaths, 98.7 per cent and 98.9\nper cent, respectively, were reported from Africa. Today the distribution\nof plague coincides with the geographical distribution of its natural foci.\n- Mod.MPP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 28 Feb 2007\n The prior outbreaks of plague in Uganda reported on\nProMED-mail were also located in the north west of the country near the\nborder with the DRC (see\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/africa/uganda_pol_2005.jpg> and\n The swollen lymph node is\ncalled a 'bubo' which is very painful and can become suppurated as an open\nsore in advanced stage of infection;\n\n'* Septicaemic form of plague occurs when infection spreads directly\nthrough the bloodstream without evidence of a 'bubo'. \n\nAs both the DRC and Uganda are endemic for plague, in the absence of\ninformation on the index case in the outbreak, it is hard to point a\ndefinite finger as to whether the outbreak began in Uganda or was imported\nfrom the DRC. \n\nThe group is made up of officials from the health ministry, the Uganda\nVirus Research Institute, the Centres for Disease Control (USA), the World\nHealth Organization, district health officials, and the epidemic control\ntask force. Primary pneumonic plague\nresults from inhalation of aerosolized infective droplets and can be\ntransmitted from human to human without involvement of fleas or animals. We are teaching them to keep their\nenvironment clean.'\n\nOkware pointed out that West Nile and Masindi were the focal areas but\nadded that the possible source of plague was the DR Congo. It is\ntransmitted between animals and humans by the bite of infected fleas,\ndirect contact, inhalation, and rarely, ingestion of infective materials. The mountain lions were all\ncollared and part of a research project.\nKen Mills, a professor in the University of Wyoming College of\nAgriculture's Department of Veterinary Sciences, said researchers aren't\nsounding alarm bells just yet, but want people to be aware the disease is\nout there if they or cats exhibit symptoms. The disease is treatable by\nantibiotics. 'Is this an indication we have a more active plague at this\ntime? It could be,' Mills said.\nPeople and cats get the bubonic plague mainly through flea bites, where the\nflea has been infected by biting an infected rodent, such as a prairie dog,\ngopher, or squirrel. Infected people and cats have swollen lymph nodes and\na fever. The disease can also be pneumonic, which tends to be much more\nserious, and is exhibited by respiratory infection. People catch that\nplague by directly breathing in the bacteria from infected cats that are\ncoughing and sneezing, Mills said.\n[byline: Whitney Royster]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[A photo of a cougar may be seen at\n<http://animals.timduru.org/dirlist/puma%20cougar/cougar%2082.jpg>. Cougars\nare also called pumas, or mountain lions, but all are _Puma concolor_. The\nbacterial agent responsible for plague is _Yersinia pestis_. If these\nanimals are dying of this disease, then the disease is out there and owners\nshould keep an eye on their pets, especially cats, for any swellings. Most\noften the swellings will be around the jaw line or neck. - Mod.TG]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Source: Star-Tribune [edited]\n<http://www.jacksonholestartrib.com/articles/2006/12/14/news/wyoming/8dd01802e7095178872572440008bcd5.txt>\n\nFour mountain lions in north west Wyoming have died of bubonic plague,\nprompting specialists to warn people of the risks to hunters and domestic\ncat owners. [byline: Whitney Royster]\n--\nProMED-mail\n< People and cats get the bubonic plague mainly through flea bites, where the\nflea has been infected by biting an infected rodent, such as a prairie dog,\ngopher, or squirrel. People catch that\nplague by directly breathing in the bacteria from infected cats that are\ncoughing and sneezing, Mills said. If these\nanimals are dying of this disease, then the disease is out there and owners\nshould keep an eye on their pets, especially cats, for any swellings. Agriculture's Department of Veterinary Sciences, said researchers aren't\nsounding alarm bells just yet, but want people to be aware the disease is\nout there if they or cats exhibit symptoms. Most\noften the swellings will be around the jaw line or neck.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Wyoming", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7058", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, rodents - Russia (Volgograd, Astrakhan): susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7058", "date": "2007-01-28 21:00:02", "main_text": "PLAGUE, RODENTS - RUSSIA (VOLGOGRAD, ATRAKHAN): SUSPECTED\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 23 Jan 2007\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Kuban.info [trans. Mod.NP, edited]\n<http://smi.kuban.info/article/55838/1016>\n\nPlague has been recorded in the Volgograd and Astrakhan regions of\nthe Southern Federal District of Russia. Sick rodents were found in\nseveral [parts] of these regions.\nAccording to experts, rats and mice have been infected by plague;\nhumans are at risk of being infected by pets [which have killed\ninfected rodents]. The experts expect a hazardous situation to\ndevelop. Vaccination of the population at risk is being applied.\nIt has been postulated that unusually warm winter weather has\ncontributed to the development of the outbreak.\nThe control activities undertaken include poisoning of rats and mice.\nThe effect of these measures is not yet clear, since there is\nmovement of mice to open areas where food, namely winter wheat, is\navailable. It is practically impossible to carry out effective\ncontrol in outdoor conditions.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[According to\n<http://www.5-tv.ru/news/print.php?newsId=2116>,\nsick rodents have been found in the Limanskiy district of the\nAstrakhan region, which borders Kalmykia. Cases of plague are\nregistered in the Volgograd region, close to the regional centre\n[Volgograd] Kalachaebskiy and Svetlojarskiy districts.\nIn the Russian Federation, natural foci of plague in rodents have\nbeen recorded [historically] in several regions, namely the republics\nof Chechnya, Kabardino-Balkaria, Karachaevo-Cherkessia, Kalmykia and\nDagestan, and the regions Stavropol and Astrakhan, all located in the\nSouth Federal District of Russia. Cases have also been observed in\nthe republics of Tyva and Gorniy Altay.\nSince 1984, no plague cases have been recorded in humans in Russia. See\n<http://biology.krc.karelia.ru/misc/atl/ra56g.htm>.\nHowever, abnormally warm weather and a sharp increase in the rodent\npopulation enhance the danger of an epidemic in pets and humans in\nmany regions of the country. - Mod.NP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n In the Russian Federation, natural foci of plague in rodents have\nbeen recorded [historically] in several regions, namely the republics\nof Chechnya, Kabardino-Balkaria, Karachaevo-Cherkessia, Kalmykia and\nDagestan, and the regions Stavropol and Astrakhan, all located in the\nSouth Federal District of Russia. [According to\n<http://www.5-tv.ru/news/print.php?newsId=2116>,\nsick rodents have been found in the Limanskiy district of the\nAstrakhan region, which borders Kalmykia. According to experts, rats and mice have been infected by plague;\nhumans are at risk of being infected by pets [which have killed\ninfected rodents]. However, abnormally warm weather and a sharp increase in the rodent\npopulation enhance the danger of an epidemic in pets and humans in\nmany regions of the country. The effect of these measures is not yet clear, since there is\nmovement of mice to open areas where food, namely winter wheat, is\navailable. The local authorities\nhave now [11 Nov 2006] reported 1174 suspected cases, including 50\ndeaths. More than 50 samples have been collected and analyzed;\nhowever, the diagnosis of plague has not been finally laboratory confirmed.\nA 5-person team from WHO and the Ministry of Health will return to\nthe field to re-assess the situation with the local medical staff and\ninternational non-governmental organizations working in the affected areas.\nFor more information, see the WHO plague fact sheet at\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs267/en/index.html>.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[In the previous post on 15 Oct 2006 -- see belwo -- some of the\ncases had been apparently been confirmed as plague, but it was noted\nthat the case fatality rate seemed to be too low for all cases to be\ndue to pneumonic plague, a disease with a much higher mortality rate.\nA map of Congo DR showing the northeast Orientale (also written\nOriental or Eastern) province, where Haut-Uele district is located,\ncan be found at:\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/africa/congo_demrep_pol98.jpg>.\n- Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n [In the previous post on 15 Oct 2006 -- see belwo -- some of the\ncases had been apparently been confirmed as plague, but it was noted\nthat the case fatality rate seemed to be too low for all cases to be\ndue to pneumonic plague, a disease with a much higher mortality rate. From 31 Jul to 8 Oct 2006, 626 suspected\ncases including 42 deaths have been reported. However, the low case\nfatality ratio is unusual for pneumonic plague which suggests that the\nnumber of suspected cases may be an overestimation.\nPreliminary results from a rapid diagnosis test in the field found 3\nsamples positive, out of 8. Additional laboratory confirmation is under way.\nA team from the Provincial Health Authority, WHO and Medecins sans\nFrontieres (MSF Switzerland) carried out an initial investigation. Disease\nsurveillance is being strengthened and case management, contact tracing,\nand sensitization of the affected population are being implemented.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[A map of Congo DR showing the north east Orientale (also written Oriental\nor Eastern) province, where Haut-Uele district is located, can be found at:\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/africa/congo_demrep_pol98.jpg>.\nProMED-mail also thanks Joseph Dudley for contributing information about\nthis WHO report. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Source: WHO Outbreak Reports [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2006_10_13/en/index.html>\n\nThe World Health Organization (WHO) has received reports of a suspected\npneumonic plague outbreak in 2 health zones in Haut-Uele district, the\nmajority reported from Wamba health zone in Oriental province in the\nnorthern part of the country. \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n However, the low case\nfatality ratio is unusual for pneumonic plague which suggests that the\nnumber of suspected cases may be an overestimation. Akusa said they had flu-like symptoms, vomiting and\ndiarrhea, which are associated with the plague.\nHe said preliminary results from the tests confirmed pneumonic plague, the\nleast common but most lethal form of the a typical disease. Akusa said the\ndisease was suspected to have originated from areas bordering the DR Congo,\nwhere WHO reported an outbreak of the plague 3 months ago.\n[Byline: Frank Mugabi]\n--\nJoseph P. Dudley, Ph.D.\nChief Scientist, Biosecurity and Biosurveillance\nEAI Corporation\nArlington, VA\n<jdudley@eaicorp.com>\n[As can be seen on a map, the Arua district of Uganda is across the border\nfrom the Orientale (Eastern) province of Congo DR where reports of\npneumonic plague have been occurring.\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/uganda.pdf> - Mod. Congo DR (Orientale): susp., RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3157", "date": "2006-10-04 00:00:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PNEUMONIC - CONGO DR (ORIENTALE): SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Tue 3 Oct 2006\nFrom: Joseph Dudley <jdudley@eaicorp.com>\nSource: UN Integrated Regional Information Networks (IRIN) [edited]\n<http://www.irinnews.org/report.asp?ReportID=55811&SelectRegion=Great_Lakes&SelectCountry=DRC>\n\n[Suspected - Mod.LL] pneumonic plague has, since 16 Aug 2006, claimed 29\nlives and infected another 500 people in the Pawa and Wemba areas of Isiro\nDistrict in northeastern Democratic Republic of Congo, according to the WHO.\nDr. Florent Ekwanzala, an epidemiologist with the WHO, said on Mon 2 Oct\n2006 that a WHO-backed health team comprising a supervisor, laboratory\nnurse and members of an international NGO had collected samples that were\nsent to the National Institute of Bio-Medical Research in Kinshasa to\nconfirm the diagnosis.\nThe WHO team has been informing the local population on how to avoid the\ndisease by taking precautions against flea bites, avoiding the handling of\ncarcasses in plague-endemic areas and contact with infective tissues, or\nbeing exposed to patients with pneumonic plague.\n'The samples are expected to be compared with those of other lung diseases,\nas it could also turn out to be leptospirosis,' Ekwanzala said.\nEkwanzala said the same area recently experienced a similar epidemic on a\nsmaller scale, which could have spread from the neighboring region. A few\ncases were recorded in the Reti, Ringa and Zobia zones of the Bas-Uele\nDistrict.\nThere were 19 deaths and 100 suspected cases in June 2006 in the\nneighboring district of Ituri, which, according to the WHO, is the most\nactive breeding ground for human plague in the world, with an average of\n1000 cases per year.\nPlague is endemic in many countries in Africa, in the former Soviet Union,\nthe Americas and Asia. In 2003, 9 countries reported 2118 cases and 182\ndeaths, almost all in Africa.\n--\nJoseph P. Dudley, Ph.D.\n<jdudley@eaicorp.com>\n[The relatively low mortality rate reported in the posting suggests\nalternative diagnoses; at least not all the cases are the pneumonic form.\nProMED would like more information about these clusters of possible\npneumonic plague.\nA map of Congo DR showing the northeast Orientale (also written Oriental or\nEastern) province, where Isiro, Ituri and Bas-Uele districts are located,\ncan be found at:\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/africa/congo_demrep_pol98.jpg>.\nProMED thanks Dr. Joe Dudley for this submission. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "Dr. Florent Ekwanzala, an epidemiologist with the WHO, said on Mon 2 Oct\n2006 that a WHO-backed health team comprising a supervisor, laboratory\nnurse and members of an international NGO had collected samples that were\nsent to the National Institute of Bio-Medical Research in Kinshasa to\nconfirm the diagnosis.\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The WHO team has been informing the local population on how to avoid the\ndisease by taking precautions against flea bites, avoiding the handling of\ncarcasses in plague-endemic areas and contact with infective tissues, or\nbeing exposed to patients with pneumonic plague. Plague is currently or recently endemic to Haut Zaire Province and\nIturi Sub-region (Managi Administrative Zone)\nA graph of plague incidence and rates per 100 000 population in DRC is\ndisplayed at: <http://exhibit.gideononline.com/Plague-DRC.jpg>\nNote that DRC has accounted for an increasing proportion of plague cases in\nAfrica in recent years:\n<http://exhibit.gideononline.com/Plague-Africa-DRC.jpg>\nNotable outbreaks:\n2004 - An outbreak (1042 suspect cases, 58 fatal) was reported in Ituri.\n2005 - An outbreak (134 cases, 61 fatal) of pneumonic plague was reported\nin a diamond mining area of Zobia, Kisingani.\n--\nDr. Steve Berger\nGeographic Medicine\nTel Aviv Medical Center\n<mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\n[ProMED thanks Dr. Berger for this Gideon information. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Source: GideonOnline [edited]\n<http://www.GideonOnline.com>\n\nThe first cases of plague in this country were reported in Ituri (632 cases\nduring 1928 to 1959) and North Kivu (190 cases during 1938 to\n1961). Note that DRC has accounted for an increasing proportion of plague cases in\nAfrica in recent years:\n<http://exhibit.gideononline.com/Plague-Africa-DRC.jpg>\n \nDr. Steve Berger\nGeographic Medicine\n A graph of plague incidence and rates per 100 000 population in DRC is\ndisplayed at: <http://exhibit.gideononline.com/Plague-DRC.jpg>\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "1938-03-25 00:00:00", "1961-03-25 00:00:00", "1042-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "North Kivu", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Managi Administrative Zone", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Zobia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ituri", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3072", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, pneumonic - Congo DR (Ituri) (05) :susp., RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3072", "date": "2006-09-29 00:00:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PNEUMONIC - CONGO DR (ITURI) (05): SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri, 29 Sep 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Mail & Guardian [edited]\n<http://www.mg.co.za/articlepage.aspx?area=/breaking_news/breaking_news__africa/&articleid=285398>\n\nA deadly epidemic feared to be pneumonic plague has broken out in\neastern Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), WHO said on Fri, 29 Sep 2006.\nThere are dozens of suspect cases and up to 20 deaths in the\noutbreak, which a WHO team is investigating along with health\nministry officials, WHO plague expert Eric Bertherat said. 'There is\nan epidemic which we are trying to confirm is the plague in the\nnortheast Ituri region,' Bertherat told Reuters.\nPreliminary indications point to pneumonic plague, the most deadly\nand least common form of the disease, which can be spread by humans\nwithout involvement of fleas, he said. 'It seems it could be the\npneumonic form, which is extremely contagious with a high mortality\nrate of about 50 percent ... At least several dozen cases are\nreported and up to 20 fatalities,' Bertherat said.\nThe outbreak is around Isiro, north-east of the eastern city of\nKisangani in the remote, mineral-rich Ituri region.\nIn early 2005, 150 cases of plague were confirmed in Zobia, north of\nKisangani, half of them fatal, according to the WHO. Many of the\nminers working at the diamond mine in Zobia fled the outbreak and\nspread the highly contagious disease.\nRapid diagnosis and treatment with antibiotics is essential to reduce\ncomplications and fatality, according to the WHO.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Primary pneumonic plague (1 percent of natural plague presentations)\narises as a result of inhalation of plague bacilli in infectious\naerosols, such as would be produced when there are secondary\npneumonic complications in bubonic/septicemic plague.\nPrimary plague pneumonia has a short incubation period of 1-3 days,\nafter which there is sudden onset of flu-like symptoms including\nfever, chills, headache, generalized body pains, weakness and chest\ndiscomfort. A cough develops with sputum production, which may be\nbloody, and increasing chest pain and difficulty in breathing. As the\ndisease progresses, hypoxia (low oxygen concentration in the blood)\nand hemoptysis (coughing up blood) are prominent. The disease is\ninvariably fatal unless antimicrobial therapy commences within 24\nhours of exposure.\nPatients with primary pneumonic plague generate large quantities of\ninfectious aerosols that pose a significant risk to close contacts.\nCDC guidelines identify contacts within 2 meters as being at greatest\nrisk and do not consider the organism likely to be carried through\nair ducts or vents. Persons who have been in contact with pneumonic\nplague patients or handling potentially infectious body fluids or\ntissues without appropriate protection should receive preventive\nantimicrobial therapy. The preferred antimicrobial agents for\nprophylaxis are tetracyclines, quinolones, or chloramphenicol.\nA map of Congo DR showing Oriental province, where Ituri is located,\ncan be found at:\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/africa/congo_demrep_pol98.jpg>. This\narea as can be seen below has been troubled by this disease earlier\nthis year as well as in 2004 and 2005. - Mod.LL]\n[More information from knowledgeable sources on the etiology of this\noutbreak would be appreciated. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n \nPrimary plague pneumonia has a short incubation period of 1-3 days,\nafter which there is sudden onset of flu-like symptoms including\nfever, chills, headache, generalized body pains, weakness and chest\ndiscomfort. [Primary pneumonic plague (1 percent of natural plague presentations)\narises as a result of inhalation of plague bacilli in infectious\naerosols, such as would be produced when there are secondary\npneumonic complications in bubonic/septicemic plague. Persons who have been in contact with pneumonic\nplague patients or handling potentially infectious body fluids or\ntissues without appropriate protection should receive preventive\nantimicrobial therapy. Source: Mail & Guardian [edited]\n<http://www.mg.co.za/articlepage.aspx?area=/breaking_news/breaking_news__africa/&articleid=285398>\n\nA deadly epidemic feared to be pneumonic plague has broken out in\neastern Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), WHO said on Fri, 29 Sep 2006. As the\ndisease progresses, hypoxia (low oxygen concentration in the blood)\nand hemoptysis (coughing up blood) are prominent.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-09-29 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "eastern Democratic Republic of Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Isiro", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Zobia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Congo", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3004", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - USA (CO)(03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3004", "date": "2006-09-28 00:00:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (COLORADO)(03)\n***************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Tue, 26 Sep 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Durango Herald (CO) [edited]\n<http://durangoherald.com/asp-bin/article_generation.asp?article_type=news&article_path=/news/06/news060926_3.htm>\n\nA 49-year-old woman has been diagnosed with plague, the 4th case in\nLa Plata County in 2006, health officials announced Mon, 25 Sep 2006.\nThe 4 cases -- all caused by fleas brought in by family pets, health\nofficials suspect -- equal an annual record for the entire state.\nNationally, 10 to 15 cases of plague occur in humans every year. New\nMexico has already seen 7 this year, resulting in 2 deaths. The most\nrecent case struck in the Grandview area, said Joe Fowler, regional\nepidemiologist for Southwest Colorado.\nSo far in 2006, 13 rodents and cats in southwest Colorado have tested\npositive for plague. Cats become infected from flea bites or by\ndirect contact with infected rodents. Plague-infected cats generally\nhave a history of roaming freely in rural areas, the San Juan Basin\nHealth Department said in a news release.\nPlague reappeared in Colorado residents in 2004 after a 3-year\nabsence. 3 cases were reported in 2004, none in La Plata County. In\n2005, 2 of the 3 cases in the state were found in La Plata County.\nPlague season in southwest Colorado extends through October. Health\nofficials recommend taking steps against fleas to reduce the chances\nof contracting the disease.\n'People need to realize it really does happen to normal people around\nsouthwest Colorado,' Fowler said.\n[Byline: Chuck Slothower]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[_Yersinia pestis_ infection in humans continue to be reported in the\nsouthern USA with more cases recognized this year. Although not\nstated, the case was probably one of the bubonic variety. The\nfinding of cases in animals in Colorado as early as Feb 2006 was an\nindicator that more human cases might be diagnosed in 2006. La Plata\ncounty is found in the southwestern part of the state on the\nfollowing map:\n<http://www.mapsofworld.com/usa/states/colorado/colorado-county-map.html>\n- Mod. LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n La Plata\ncounty is found in the southwestern part of the state on the\nfollowing map:\n<http://www.mapsofworld.com/usa/states/colorado/colorado-county-map.html>\n- Mod. [Byline: Chuck Slothower]\n--\nProMED-mail\n< Source: Durango Herald (CO) [edited]\n<http://durangoherald.com/asp-bin/article_generation.asp?article_type=news&article_path=/news/06/news060926_3.htm>\n\nA 49-year-old woman has been diagnosed with plague, the 4th case in\nLa Plata County in 2006, health officials announced Mon, 25 Sep 2006. The\nfinding of cases in animals in Colorado as early as Feb 2006 was an\nindicator that more human cases might be diagnosed in 2006. Plague-infected cats generally\nhave a history of roaming freely in rural areas, the San Juan Basin\nHealth Department said in a news release. Health\nofficials recommend taking steps against fleas to reduce the chances\nof contracting the disease. The most\nrecent case struck in the Grandview area, said Joe Fowler, regional\nepidemiologist for Southwest Colorado. PLAGUE - USA (COLORADO)(03)\n***************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-10-25 00:00:00", "2006-02-25 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-09-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "La Plata County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New \n Mexico", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2453", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, pneumonic - Congo DR (Ituri) (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2453", "date": "2006-08-25 00:00:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PNEUMONIC - CONGO DR (ITURI) (03)\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu, 24 Aug 2006\nFrom: Joe Dudley <jdudley@eaicorp.com>\nSource: Alertnet.org [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thefacts/reliefresources/11564322273.htm>\n\nA massive plague epidemic could hit eastern Congo DR after an alarming\nspike in infections in recent weeks, a German medical charity warned on\nThu, 24 Aug 2006.\nThere have been 1400 cases so far in 2006, 600 of them in June and July,\nsaid Alfred Kinzelbach, regional coordinator for aid agency Malteser\nInternational. That compares with 800 cases for the whole of 2005.\nHealth workers are particularly concerned about a sudden increase in\nextremely contagious pneumonic plague. Most of the cases are bubonic\nplague, which is spread by infected rat fleas, but pneumonic plague, an\nairborne disease, can transmit between humans.\n'If you have 2 cases of pneumonic plague then perhaps the whole village\nwill get it, so it spreads much quicker than the bubonic plague,'\nKinzelbach told AlertNet in an interview. 'People can die within 24 hours\nso you have to treat it quickly.'\nAround 10 percent of people who catch the plague are dying -- double the\nrate in 2005, he said.\nThe outbreak is near Lake Albert in northeast Ituri district, where\nmilitias are still fighting 3 years after the end of Congo's 6-year war,\nthe world's deadliest conflict since World War Two.\n--\nJoseph P. Dudley, PhD\nBiosecurity and Biosurveillance\nEAI Corporation Arlington, VA <jdudley@eaicorp.com>\n[This area has had a problem with plague, bubonic and pneumonic, for a\nnumber of years. As noted, it is the pneumonic form that fans an epidemic\nsince it relatively easily spreads from person (or animal) to person,\nwhereas the bubonic form itself does not. Plague pneumonia occurs in a\nsecondary form related to bacteremic spread for the bubonic form or in its\nprimary form due to person-to-person spread.\nThe first signs of pneumonic plague are fever, headache, weakness, and\nrapidly developing pneumonia with shortness of breath, chest pain, cough,\nand sometimes bloody or watery sputum. The pneumonia progresses for 2 to 4\ndays and may cause respiratory failure and shock. Without early treatment,\npatients may die. To reduce the chance of death, antibiotics must be given\nwithin 24 hours of first symptoms. Streptomycin, gentamicin, the\ntetracyclines, and chloramphenicol are all effective against pneumonic\nplague. Antibiotic treatment for 7 days will protect people who have had\ndirect, close contact with infected patients. Wearing a close-fitting\nsurgical mask also protects against infection.\nA map of the Democratic Republic of the Congo showing the location of Ituri\nin Oriental Province in the northeast part of the country can be found at:\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/drcongo.pdf>.\n- Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Source: Alertnet.org [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thefacts/reliefresources/11564322273.htm>\n\nA massive plague epidemic could hit eastern Congo DR after an alarming\nspike in infections in recent weeks, a German medical charity warned on\n Plague pneumonia occurs in a\nsecondary form related to bacteremic spread for the bubonic form or in its\nprimary form due to person-to-person spread. Most of the cases are bubonic\nplague, which is spread by infected rat fleas, but pneumonic plague, an\nairborne disease, can transmit between humans. If you have 2 cases of pneumonic plague then perhaps the whole village\nwill get it, so it spreads much quicker than the bubonic plague,'\n As noted, it is the pneumonic form that fans an epidemic\nsince it relatively easily spreads from person (or animal) to person,\nwhereas the bubonic form itself does not. The first signs of pneumonic plague are fever, headache, weakness, and\nrapidly developing pneumonia with shortness of breath, chest pain, cough,\nand sometimes bloody or watery sputum. Streptomycin, gentamicin, the\ntetracyclines, and chloramphenicol are all effective against pneumonic\nplague. The outbreak is near Lake Albert in northeast Ituri district, where\nmilitias are still fighting 3 years after the end of Congo's 6-year war,\nthe world's deadliest conflict since World War Two. There have been 1400 cases so far in 2006, 600 of them in June and July,\nsaid Alfred Kinzelbach, regional coordinator for aid agency Malteser\nInternational. A map of the Democratic Republic of the Congo showing the location of Ituri\nin Oriental Province in the northeast part of the country can be found at:\n<http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/drcongo.pdf>. --\nJoseph P. While it is the 3rd case of the plague in\nthe county in 2006, there have been 5 human cases in the last 12 months.\n'I am quite concerned by the situation in La Plata County right now,'\nsaid Joe Fowler, regional epidemiologist for the Health Department.\n'The entire state of Colorado has never had more than 4 cases in a\nsingle year, but in 2006, if our residents do not take precautions to\nprotect themselves, La Plata County could single-handedly surpass that number.'\nIn New Mexico in 2006, 2 of the 6 people who have contracted the\ndisease died. Historically, in Colorado, about 1 in 5 cases results\nin death, the health department said in a news release.\n'The plague is so widespread,' Fowler said, 'that the health\ndepartment hesitates to say what regions these individual cases are\npopping up in because people don't think it is in their area. But\nit's all over Southwest Colorado.' Westberg said that no other human\ncases have been reported in the state, but animals have tested\npositive in both Archuleta and Montezuma counties as well.\nAt least 8 animals in Southwest Colorado, including squirrels,\nhousehold cats and prairie dogs, have tested positive for plague this\nsummer, according to the news release. Cats become infected from\nflea bites or by direct contact with infected rodents.\nPlague-infected cats generally will have a history of roaming freely\nin rural or semi-rural areas, and their owners often report that they\nare known hunters.\nThe plague season generally begins in mid-August and continues for\nabout 2 months, Westberg said. If it gets really hot, it will knock\nit out, she said.\n'Everyone in Southwest Colorado should be on high alert,' Fowler said.\n[Byline: Ann Butler]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[_Yersinia pestis_ infection in humans continue to be reported in the\nsouthern USA with more cases recognized this year. Source: Durango Herald [edited]\n<http://durangoherald.com/asp-bin/printable_article_generation.asp?article_path=/news/06/news060808_4.htm>\n\nThe 3rd human case of plague in the last 5 weeks has been reported in\nLa Plata County, according to the San Juan Basin Health Department. Archuleta and Montezuma counties border La Plata on the east and\nwest, respectively, and all of them border on the state of New\nMexico, which has reported cases since May this year -- see below. At least 8 animals in Southwest Colorado, including squirrels,\nhousehold cats and prairie dogs, have tested positive for plague this\nsummer, according to the news release. Plague-infected cats generally will have a history of roaming freely\nin rural or semi-rural areas, and their owners often report that they\nare known hunters. The male patient was released from the hospital after several days\nand is recovering at home, said Lynn Westberg, the executive director\nof the Health Department. Cats become infected from\nflea bites or by direct contact with infected rodents.\n While it is the 3rd case of the plague in\nthe county in 2006, there have been 5 human cases in the last 12 months. Historically, in Colorado, about 1 in 5 cases results\nin death, the health department said in a news release. The plague season generally begins in mid-August and continues for\nabout 2 months, Westberg said. The bubonic plague\ncase was confirmed by the state Health Department, which said it was\nthe 1st case from the central New Mexico county in 2006.\nNew Mexico has had one plague death so far in 2006. A woman from\nBernalillo County died of the septicemic form of the plague in May\n2006. The other 3 victims, a Bernalillo County teenager, a Santa Fe\nCounty man and a San Miguel County child, all recovered.\nThe Department of Health was investigating the Torrance County\nwoman's home to determine whether the area poses a continued risk for plague.\n'Plague infection continues to be prevalent in rodents, especially in\nnorth-central counties in New Mexico,' state Epidemiologist C. Mack\nSewell said.\n--\nJoseph P. Dudley, PhD\n<jdudley@eaicorp.com>\n[ProMED thanks Dr. Dudley for this submission. Human c s in the USA occurs mostly in rural\nareas, with an average of 10 to 15 cases each year nationwide.\nIn Southwest Colorado, 7 animals -- including squirrels, household\ncats, and prairie dogs -- have tested positive for plague this\nsummer, according to a news release from the health department. 'This\nyear particularly, there seems to be a lot of plague, and it is\nwidespread throughout the county and region,' Westberg said.\nCats become infected from flea bites or by direct contact with\ninfected rodents. Plague-infected cats will generally have a history\nof roaming freely in rural or semi-rural areas, and their owners\noften report that the felines are known hunters. Infected cats\nfrequently exhibit swelling and sores around the mouth, head and neck\nand appear ill. Pet owners should seek veterinary care for such\nanimals. Because domestic cats can carry infected fleas into the\nhome, it is important to consult a veterinarian for information about\nflea control for pets, health experts say.\n--\nMark Liao\nProgram in Human Biology\nStanford University\nStanford, CA\n<markliaohk@gmail.com>\n[The manifestations of plague in this man were not stated, but it is\nmost likely that this was bubonic plague.
