PLAGUE, BUBONIC, HUMAN - USA (NEW MEXICO)\n*****************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Bernalillo \n County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Santa Fe County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Bernalillo County", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1849", "headline": "PRO/AH> Plague, cats - USA (AZ)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1849", "date": "2006-06-30 00:00:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, CATS - USA (ARIZONA)\n****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 29 Jun 2006\nFrom: Joe Dudley <jdudley@eaicorp.com>\nSource: AZ Central [edited]\n<http://www.azcentral.com/news/articles/0628PlagueCat28-ON.html>\n\nA cat in the northern Arizona community of Winona has tested positive for\nbubonic plague. The Coconino County Health Department said fleas collected\nfrom prairie dog burrows about 2 miles away from the home where the cat\nlives also tested positive for plague. Winona is about 12 miles east of\nFlagstaff, along Interstate Highway 40.\nThe area is the only location in Coconino County where plague has been\nconfirmed this year, although officials believe the disease may be more\nwidespread. There have been no human plague cases reported in Arizona in\n2006. Plague is curable with antibiotics if diagnosed and treated early.\n--\nJoseph P Dudley, PhD\n<jdudley@eaicorp.com>\n[It would be interesting to get more details about the clinical presentation\nof the cat. No human case is mentioned, so I assume that the owner and\nveterinarian involved recognised the zoonotic potential associated with\nplague in cats and took appropriate hygiene measures to keep safe. There\nhave been documented cases of pneumonic plague transmission to veterinarians\nand other humans.\nPlague monitoring programs in the western United States have a long history\nof surveillance in wild animal population such as prairie dogs. Calvin\nSchwabe, in his classic text, Veterinary Medicine and Human Health (Williams\nand Wilkins, 1984), provides a detailed description of these surveillance\nprograms and their public health significance. Although the text is very\nhard to get hold of now as it out of print, it is well worth the effort, as\nthere are numerous descriptions of the potential areas by which\nveterinarians contribute to public health. Like other public health programs\nwhich require significant infrastructure, plague surveillance in wild\nanimals has suffered from time to time. In the case referenced above,\nhowever, we certainly see the value to people in Arizona of testing these\nwild animal populations. - Mod.PC]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Although the text is very\nhard to get hold of now as it out of print, it is well worth the effort, as\nthere are numerous descriptions of the potential areas by which\nveterinarians contribute to public health. There\nhave been documented cases of pneumonic plague transmission to veterinarians\nand other humans.\n Like other public health programs\nwhich require significant infrastructure, plague surveillance in wild\nanimals has suffered from time to time. The Coconino County Health Department said fleas collected\nfrom prairie dog burrows about 2 miles away from the home where the cat\nlives also tested positive for plague. No human case is mentioned, so I assume that the owner and\nveterinarian involved recognised the zoonotic potential associated with\nplague in cats and took appropriate hygiene measures to keep safe. Schwabe, in his classic text, Veterinary Medicine and Human Health (Williams\nand Wilkins, 1984), provides a detailed description of these surveillance\nprograms and their public health significance. Source: AZ Central [edited]\n<http://www.azcentral.com/news/articles/0628PlagueCat28-ON.html>\n\nA cat in the northern Arizona community of Winona has tested positive for\nbubonic plague. The area is the only location in Coconino County where plague has been\nconfirmed this year, although officials believe the disease may be more\nwidespread. In the case referenced above,\nhowever, we certainly see the value to people in Arizona of testing these\nwild animal populations. --\nJoseph P Dudley, PhD\n<jdudley@eaicorp.com Plague monitoring programs in the western United States have a long history\nof surveillance in wild animal population such as prairie dogs. There have been no human plague cases reported in Arizona in\n2006. PLAGUE, CATS - USA (ARIZONA)\n [It would be interesting to get more details about the clinical presentation\nof the cat.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-03-25 00:00:00", "1984-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Coconino County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "ARIZONA", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1835", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, pneumonic - Congo DR (Ituri) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1835", "date": "2006-06-27 00:00:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PNEUMONIC - CONGO DR (ITURI)(02)\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Tue, 27 Jun 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Medical News Today [edited]\n<http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/medicalnews.php?newsid=45974>\n\nSince 2 Jun 2006, Medecins sans Frontieres (MSF; doctors without borders)\nmedical teams have been monitoring and treating victims of a pneumonic\nplague outbreak in north eastern Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC).\nAs of 19 Jun 2006, 22 deaths had been confirmed out of 144 identified cases\nso far in the Ituri region of the DRC. There are now 12 zones in Ituri --\nwith total population of almost 100 000 -- affected by the plague outbreak.\nPneumonic plague is an extremely contagious airborne disease. Bubonic\nplague, a less contagious form of the disease, is endemic to Ituri.\nFaced with a constant increase in the number of patients affected by the\ndisease, MSF has deployed teams of medical volunteers to the area. They have\nset up 2 isolation centers for the treatment of patients in Kwandroma (Rethy\nmedical district) and in Vedza (Linga medical district).\nMSF is concerned that if rapid control measures are not put in place, the\noutbreak could soon spread to some populations where access is restricted\ndue to some security constraints, particularly around Budza, Djubate, Lailo\nand Zali, all located in the Rethy medical district.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[A map of DRC showing Oriental province, where Ituri is located, can be\nfound at: <http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/africa/congo_demrep_pol98.jpg>.\nThis is the same general area where there was a major outbreak of pneumonic\nand bubonic plague in 2005 (see prior ProMED-mail postings listed below). -\nMod.LL]", "summary": "\nMSF is concerned that if rapid control measures are not put in place, the\noutbreak could soon spread to some populations where access is restricted\ndue to some security constraints, particularly around Budza, Djubate, Lailo\nand Zali, all located in the Rethy medical district.\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n They have\nset up 2 isolation centers for the treatment of patients in Kwandroma (Rethy\nmedical district) and in Vedza (Linga medical district). --\nProMED-mail\n< PLAGUE, PNEUMONIC - CONGO DR (ITURI)(02)\n**************************************\n This is the same general area where there was a major outbreak of pneumonic\nand bubonic plague in 2005 (see prior ProMED-mail postings listed below). medical teams have been monitoring and treating victims of a pneumonic\nplague outbreak in north eastern Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC).", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-06-02 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-06-19 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "eastern Democratic Republic of Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Vedza", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kwandroma", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "Budza", "country": "Montenegro"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1868", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, septicemic - USA (CA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1868", "date": "2006-07-01 00:00:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, SEPTICEMIC - USA (CALIFORNIA)\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri, 30 Jun 2006\nFrom: Joseph Vinetz <jvinetz@ucsd.edu>\n\nA 79 year old woman presented to a community hospital with an abrupt decline\nin mental status over 2 days without fever. Without a microbiological\ndiagnosis she was transferred to a tertiary care hospital in San Diego. She\nwas obtunded, had necrotic skin lesions suggestive of ecthyma gangrenosum\n[Ecthyma gangrenosum (EG) is a well-recognized cutaneous infection most\ncommonly associated with a _Pseudomonas aeruginosa_ bacteremia. EG usually\noccurs in patients who are critically ill and immunocompromised. - Mod.LL],\npulmonary infiltrates (but not bloody sputum) and renal failure.\nRetrospective examination of the Wright-Giemsa-stained peripheral blood\nsmear from the initial admission showed few bipolar staining rods. A\nperipheral smear from the day of transfer to the tertiary care hospital\nshowed 6-10 schistocytes per high-powered field and the patient was\nthrombocytopenic (approx 30K platelets/microL) [these findings are\nsuggestive of disseminated intravascular coagulation - Mod.LL].\nBlood cultures from the time of admission were initially misidentified, then\nfound to grow a non-motile, non-lactose fermenting Gram negative rod that\ngrew slowly on all media. API biochemical testing suggested _Yersinia\npestis_; an anti-F1 antigen monoclonal antibody test performed by the San\nDiego County Public Health Laboratory presumptively confirmed the\nbiochemical analysis; a PCR test confirmed the identification. The patient\nis recovering from the illness with persistent anuria, having been\ndefinitely treated with gentamicin, doxycycline (for a question of\nmeningitis) among other empiric broad-spectrum antibiotics.\nThe patient lives between Mammoth and Bishop in Mono County, where numerous\nsmall rodents (including ground squirrels) were observed on her property.\nRodent droppings were found in the house. The California State Health\ndepartment is currently carrying out epizootic investigation activities.\nPost-exposure prophylaxis was offered to hospital personnel, family and\nother close contacts.\n--\nJoseph M Vinetz, MD\nUniversity of California San Diego School of Medicine\n<jvinetz@ucsd.edu>\nSharon L Reed, MD\nUniversity of California San Diego School of Medicine\nMichele Ginsberg, MD\nSan Diego County Health & Human Services Agency\n[At this hour, no media report of this case appears to have been released.\nProMED-mail thanks Dr Vinetz and his colleagues for this first-hand report.\nSepticemic (bacteremic) plague can be a complication of the more common\nbubonic variety or, as in this case, it may occur without a bubo. It does\nnot appear that the infection spread to the lungs causing a secondary\npneumonic plague. Plague pneumonia is the form capable of person-to-person\nspread.\nA link showing a map of California with Mono County highlighted can be found\nat: <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mono_County,_California> - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n --\nJoseph M Vinetz, MD\nUniversity of California San Diego School of Medicine\n<jvinetz@ucsd.edu>\n Sharon L Reed, MD\nUniversity of California San Diego School of Medicine\nMichele Ginsberg, MD\nSan Diego County Health & Human Services Agency\n A\nperipheral smear from the day of transfer to the tertiary care hospital\nshowed 6-10 schistocytes per high-powered field and the patient was\nthrombocytopenic (approx 30K platelets/microL) API biochemical testing suggested _Yersinia\npestis_; an anti-F1 antigen monoclonal antibody test performed by the San\nDiego County Public Health Laboratory presumptively confirmed the\nbiochemical analysis; a PCR test confirmed the identification. The patient\nis recovering from the illness with persistent anuria, having been\ndefinitely treated with gentamicin, doxycycline (for a question of\nmeningitis) among other empiric broad-spectrum antibiotics. Blood cultures from the time of admission were initially misidentified, then\nfound to grow a non-motile, non-lactose fermenting Gram negative rod that\ngrew slowly on all media. Post-exposure prophylaxis was offered to hospital personnel, family and\nother close contacts.\n It does\nnot appear that the infection spread to the lungs causing a secondary\npneumonic plague. She\nwas obtunded, had necrotic skin lesions suggestive of ecthyma gangrenosum\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2006-06-30 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Mono County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "San Diego", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2436", "headline": "PRO/AH> Plague - USA (Southwest): MMWR Dispatch 55", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2436", "date": "2006-08-26 00:00:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE - USA (SOUTHWEST): MMWR DISPATCH 55\n************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri, 25 Aug 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report 2006;55 (Dispatch):1-3 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm55d825a1.htm>\n\nPlague is a zoonotic disease caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_. [So\nfar] in 2006, a total of 13 human plague cases have been reported among\nresidents of 4 states: New Mexico (7 cases), Colorado (3), California (2),\nand Texas (1).\nThis is the largest number of cases reported in a single year in the USA\nsince 1994. Dates of illness onset ranged from 16 Feb to 14 Aug 2006; 2 (15\npercent) cases were fatal. The median age of patients was 43 years (range:\n13-79 years); 8 (62 percent) patients were female. Five (38 percent)\npatients had primary septicemic plague, and the remaining 8 (62 percent)\nhad bubonic plague. Two (15 percent) patients developed secondary plague\npneumonia, leading to administration of antibiotic prophylaxis to their\nhealth-care providers.\nThis report summarizes 6 of the 13 cases, highlighting the severity and\ndiverse clinical presentations of plague and underscoring the need for\nprompt diagnosis and treatment when plague is suspected.\nCase 1. On 17 Feb 2006, a man aged 39 years from Travis County, Texas, was\nhospitalized with a 1-day history of high fever, delirium, nausea, and\nvomiting. Although lymphadenopathy was not detected on the initial\nexamination, a prominent axillary bubo was noted later. Blood cultures\nyielded _Y. pestis_. The patient recovered after treatment with multiple\nantibiotics, including gentamicin, doxycycline, ciprofloxacin, and\nlevofloxacin. Before his illness, the patient had hunted rabbits in Lea\nCounty, New Mexico, and skinned the rabbit carcasses. Cultures from one of\nthe carcasses yielded _Y. pestis_ that was indistinguishable from the\nclinical isolates when subtyped by pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE).\nCase 2. On 17 Apr 2006, a woman aged 28 years received the 1st diagnosis of\nplague in Los Angeles County, California, since 1984. The woman was\nhospitalized with fever, septic shock, and a painful right axillary\nswelling;blood cultures grew _Y. pestis_. She responded to treatment with\ngentamicin and levofloxacin. Although symptoms were compatible with bubonic\nplague, the diagnosis had not been suspected because the patient did not\nreport traveling outside her urban Los Angeles neighborhood. Later,\nhealth-care providers learned that the patient had handled raw meat from a\nrabbit that had been killed in Kern County, California, and transported to\nher home. An environmental investigation in Kern County revealed evidence\nof die-off among jackrabbits and cottontails; rabbit carcasses collected in\nthe area yielded _Y. pestis_. PFGE patterns of isolates from the patient\nand rabbits were indistinguishable. A total of 16 medical contacts and\nfamily members and friends who had visited the patient's residence received\nantibiotic prophylaxis.\nCase 3. On 17 May 2006, a woman aged 54 years from Bernalillo County, New\nMexico, went to a local urgent care center with a 4-day history of fever,\nsevere abdominal pain, and bloody stools. No lymphadenopathy was noted.\nWhile being evaluated, the patient began vomiting blood and experienced\nacute respiratory distress. She was transferred to a regional hospital but\ndied within a few hours of arrival. Blood and lung cultures obtained at\nautopsy yielded _Y. pestis_; however, no histologic evidence of plague\npneumonia was discovered. One of the patient's dogs and a rock squirrel\n(_Spermophilus variegatus_) that had been trapped by investigators on her\nproperty had serologic evidence of past infection with _Y. pestis_.\nCase 4. On 25 May 2006, a man aged 45 years from Santa Fe County, New\nMexico, went to a hospital emergency department with a 3-day history of\nnausea, vomiting, and fever to 104 degrees F (40 degrees C). Initial chest\nradiographs revealed right lower lobe infiltrates; he was admitted with a\ndiagnosis of pneumonia. The patient was treated with gentamicin but was not\nplaced in respiratory isolation. On hospital day 1, the patient required\nintubation for respiratory distress. On hospital day 2, blood cultures\ndrawn at admission yielded _Y. pestis_. The patient remained on mechanical\nventilation for 4 weeks and eventually recovered. At least 37 hospital\nworkers who had contact with the patient before he was intubated received\npostexposure prophylaxis with doxycycline. Both of the patient's dogs had\nserologic evidence of past _Y. pestis_ infection. _Y. pestis_ was isolated\nfrom fleas (_Anomiopsyllus nudatus_) combed from a woodrat (_Neotoma\nmicropus_) that was trapped by investigators on the patient's property.\nCase 5. On 9 Jul 2006, a man aged 30 years from La Plata County, Colorado,\nwent to a hospital emergency department with a 3-day history of fever,\nnausea, vomiting, and right inguinal lymphadenopathy. He was discharged\nhome without treatment. Three days later, the man returned and was\nhospitalized with sepsis and bilateral pulmonary infiltrates. Plague was\nconsidered immediately, and the patient was placed in respiratory\nisolation. He was treated with gentamicinand recovered. Five hospital\nworkers were administered doxycycline prophylaxis because of exposures\nbefore respiratory isolation had been initiated. Cultures of blood and a\nlymph node aspirate grew _Y. pestis_. One of the patient's dogs had\nserologic evidence of past _Y. pestis_ infection. _Y. pestis_ was recovered\nfrom fleas of 2 species (_Aetheca wagneri_ and _Pulex simulans_) collected\nnear the patient's home. A plague epizootic had been noted in the area, and\n4 other human plague cases have been reported from La Plata County since\nJul 2005.\nCase 6. On 18 Jul 2006, a woman aged 43 years from Torrance County, New\nMexico, went to a local clinic with a 1-day history of vomiting, diarrhea,\nabdominal pain, and fever. The patient reported a recent dog bite and was\ntreated for presumed cellulitis. The next day, the woman returned to the\nclinic because of worsening symptoms and pain in the left side of her\ngroin. She was transported by ambulance to the emergency department, where\ninguinal lymphadenopathy was noted and plague was suspected. She was\nadmitted to the hospital, placed in the intensive care unit, and\nadministered gentamicin and doxycycline. _Y. pestis_ was isolated from\nblood cultures. Despite treatment, she died on 22 Jul 2006. Animals trapped\non the patient's property, including 4 mice (_Peromyscus spp._) and 5 rock\nsquirrels, did not have laboratory evidence of infection with _Y. pestis_.\n[Reported by: Bertram-Sosa L, Jaso C, A Valadez A, et al]\nEditorial Note:\nThe natural reservoir of plague is wild rodents. Human infection usually is\nacquired through the bites of infected rodent fleas and has an incubation\nperiod of 1-6 days (1). Plague also can be contracted from handling\ninfected animals, especially rodents, lagomorphs (e.g., rabbits or hares),\nand domestic cats, or through close contact with patients with pneumonic\nplague. However, person-to-person transmission is extremely rare; the last\nsuch transmission in the USA was reported in 1925. During 1990-2005, a\ntotal of 107 cases of plague were reported in the USA (CDC, unpublished\ndata, 2006), a median of 7 cases per year. The increased plague activity in\n2006 is consistent with the predicted relationship between climate and the\nfrequency of human plague in the southwestern USA. 2 consecutive Feb-Mar\nperiods with high precipitation and an intervening cool summer predicts\nincreased cases of plague the next summer; this effect is thought to lead\nto increased reproduction and survival rates among rodents and fleas (2).\nThe principal forms of plague are bubonic, septicemic, and pneumonic (3).\nAll of these forms can be accompanied by fever and systemic manifestations\nof gram-negative sepsis. Bubonic plague is distinguished by the presence of\na bubo (i.e., one or more enlarged, tender, regional lymph node). Patients\nwith septicemic plague often have prominent gastrointestinal symptoms,\nincluding nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain (4), and patients\nwith pneumonic plague have dyspnea, chest pain, and a cough that can\nproduce bloody sputum. During 1990-2005, a total of 81 (76 percent) of 107\nplague cases in the USA were classified as primary bubonic plague, 19 (18\npercent) as primary septicemic plague, and 5 (5 percent) as primary\npneumonic plague; 2 (2 percent) were not classified (CDC, unpublished data,\n2006). Eleven (10 percent) cases were fatal. In 2006, 5 (38 percent) of the\n13 patients had primary septicemic plague, underscoring the need for\nclinicians to consider this diagnosis !\nin patients who do not have an obvious bubo. Septicemic and pneumonic\nplague progress rapidly and are usually fatal without prompt treatment;\nbubonic plague has a mortality rate of 50-60 percent if untreated.\nIn the USA, nearly all fatal plague cases are associated with delays in\ndiagnosis and treatment. In its early stages, plague is treatable with\nappropriate antibiotics. Health-care providers should consider a diagnosis\nof plague in persons who 1) have unexplained fever, suspected sepsis, or\npneumonia with or without lymphadenopathy or a classic bubo, and 2) live in\nor have traveled to a plague-endemic region (e.g., the western United\nStates) (3). When plague is suspected, appropriate antibiotic treatment\nshould be initiated immediately and not delayed for laboratory\nconfirmation. Drugs effective against plague include streptomycin and the\ntetracyclines. Although not approved by FDA for treatment of plague,\ngentamicin is more readily available than streptomycin and has been used\nsuccessfully (5). Fluoroquinolones are used empirically to treat critically\nill patients and have demonstrated activity against _Y. pestis_ but are not\nFDA-approved for this indication (6).\nThe majority of exposures to plague occur in the peridomestic environment\n(3); free-roaming pets that bring infected rodent fleas into the home have\nbeen suspected as a potential source of human infections. Persons residing\nin areas where plague is endemic should keep their dogs and cats free of\nfleas through regular use of flea treatments and by keeping them indoors.\nYear-round rodent control should be conducted, including rodent-proofing of\nstructures and eliminating food sources (e.g., pet food or garbage) and\nharborage (e.g., piles of wood or debris) in the peridomestic environment.\nPersons who participate in outdoor recreational activities, particularly\nrabbit hunting (7), in areas of epizootic plague activity also are at risk\nfor plague.\nPersonal protective measures include using insect repellents, wearing\nprotective clothing, and avoiding sick or dead animals. In areas of\nepizootic plague activity, public health officials should treat rodent\nhabitats with insecticides and should educate the public regarding plague\nprevention and control. Health-care providers and veterinarians should be\neducated regarding the manifestations and diagnosis of plague. Antibiotic\nprophylaxis might be indicated for close contacts (who come within 2 m) of\npatients with plague pneumonia (5). Appropriate respiratory droplet\nprecautions should be taken when treating patients with suspected plague\nwho have evidence of respiratory involvement (8).\n1. CDC: Prevention of plague: recommendations of the Advisory Committee on\nImmunization Practices (ACIP). MMWR 1996;45(No. RR-14).\n2. Enscore RE, Biggerstaff BJ, Brown TL, et al: Modeling relationships\nbetween climate and the frequency of human plague cases in the southwestern\nUnited States, 1960--1997. Am J Trop Med Hyg 2002;66: 186-96.\n3. Dennis DT, Campbell GL: Plague and other Yersinia infections. In: Kasper\nDL, Braunwald E, Fauci AS, et al, eds. Harrison's principles of internal\nmedicine. 16th edition. New York, NY: McGraw-Hill; 2004.\n4. Hull HF, Montes JM, Mann JM: Plague masquerading as gastrointestinal\nillness. West J Med 1986;145: 485-87.\n5. Dennis DT: Plague, method of. In: Rakel RE, ed. Conn's current therapy.\nPhiladelphia, PA: WB Saunders Co.; 2001: 115-17.\n6. Inglesby TV, Dennis DT, Henderson DA, et al: Plague as a biological\nweapon: medical and public health management. Working Group on Civilian\nBiodefense. JAMA 2000;283: 2281-90.\n7. von Reyn CF, Barnes AM, Weber NS, Hodgin UG: Bubonic plague from\nexposure to a rabbit: a documented case, and a review of rabbit-associated\nplague cases in the United States. Am J Epidemiol 1976;104:81-87.\n8. CDC, Association for Professionals in Infection Control and\nEpidemiology: Bioterrorism readiness plan: a template for healthcare\nfacilities. Atlanta, GA: CDC, Association for Professionals in Infection\nControl and Epidemiology; 1999:19--20. Available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dhqp/pdf/bt/13apr99apic-cdcbioterrorism.pdf>.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[An overview of the increased number of plague cases in the American\nsouthwest with more clinical information than what has been posted on\nindividual cases. Two of the cases did have secondary plague pneumonia\nwith potential for human-to-human spread. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "During 1990-2005, a total of 81 (76 percent) of 107\nplague cases in the USA were classified as primary bubonic plague, 19 (18\npercent) as primary septicemic plague, and 5 (5 percent) as primary\npneumonic plague; 2 (2 percent) were not classified (CDC, unpublished data,\n2006). A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Health-care providers should consider a diagnosis\nof plague in persons who 1) have unexplained fever, suspected sepsis, or\npneumonia with or without lymphadenopathy or a classic bubo, and 2) live in\nor have traveled to a plague-endemic region (e.g., the western United\nStates) (3). Patients\nwith septicemic plague often have prominent gastrointestinal symptoms,\nincluding nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain (4), and patients\nwith pneumonic plague have dyspnea, chest pain, and a cough that can\nproduce bloody sputum. [So\nfar] in 2006, a total of 13 human plague cases have been reported among\nresidents of 4 states: New Mexico (7 cases), Colorado (3), California (2),\nand Texas (1). Plague also can be contracted from handling\ninfected animals, especially rodents, lagomorphs (e.g., rabbits or hares),\nand domestic cats, or through close contact with patients with pneumonic\nplague. In areas of\nepizootic plague activity, public health officials should treat rodent\nhabitats with insecticides and should educate the public regarding plague\nprevention and control. 2 consecutive Feb-Mar\nperiods with high precipitation and an intervening cool summer predicts\nincreased cases of plague the next summer; this effect is thought to lead\nto increased reproduction and survival rates among rodents and fleas (2). In 2006, 5 (38 percent) of the\n13 patients had primary septicemic plague, underscoring the need for\nclinicians to consider this diagnosis !\n Animals trapped\non the patient's property, including 4 mice (_Peromyscus spp._) and 5 rock\nsquirrels, did not have laboratory evidence of infection with _Y. pestis_.\n Later,\nhealth-care providers learned that the patient had handled raw meat from a\nrabbit that had been killed in Kern County, California, and transported to\nher home. This report summarizes 6 of the 13 cases, highlighting the severity and\ndiverse clinical presentations of plague and underscoring the need for\nprompt diagnosis and treatment when plague is suspected. Septicemic and pneumonic\nplague progress rapidly and are usually fatal without prompt treatment;\nbubonic plague has a mortality rate of 50-60 percent if untreated. A plague epizootic had been noted in the area, and\n4 other human plague cases have been reported from La Plata County since\n von Reyn CF, Barnes AM, Weber NS, Hodgin UG: Bubonic plague from\nexposure to a rabbit: a documented case, and a review of rabbit-associated\nplague cases in the United States. The increased plague activity in\n2006 is consistent with the predicted relationship between climate and the\nfrequency of human plague in the southwestern USA. Persons who participate in outdoor recreational activities, particularly\nrabbit hunting (7), in areas of epizootic plague activity also are at risk\nfor plague. During 1990-2005, a\ntotal of 107 cases of plague were reported in the USA (CDC, unpublished\ndata, 2006), a median of 7 cases per year. The majority of exposures to plague occur in the peridomestic environment\n(3); free-roaming pets that bring infected rodent fleas into the home have\nbeen suspected as a potential source of human infections. Two (15 percent) patients developed secondary plague\npneumonia, leading to administration of antibiotic prophylaxis to their\nhealth-care providers. Antibiotic\nprophylaxis might be indicated for close contacts (who come within 2 m) of\npatients with plague pneumonia (5). On 9 Jul 2006, a man aged 30 years from La Plata County, Colorado,\nwent to a hospital emergency department with a 3-day history of fever,\nnausea, vomiting, and right inguinal lymphadenopathy. Although symptoms were compatible with bubonic\nplague, the diagnosis had not been suspected because the patient did not\nreport traveling outside her urban Los Angeles neighborhood. Blood and lung cultures obtained at\nautopsy yielded _Y. pestis_; however, no histologic evidence of plague\npneumonia was discovered. On 25 May 2006, a man aged 45 years from Santa Fe County, New\nMexico, went to a hospital emergency department with a 3-day history of\nnausea, vomiting, and fever to 104 degrees F (40 degrees C). [An overview of the increased number of plague cases in the American\nsouthwest with more clinical information than what has been posted on\nindividual cases. Appropriate respiratory droplet\nprecautions should be taken when treating patients with suspected plague\nwho have evidence of respiratory involvement (8). On 17 May 2006, a woman aged 54 years from Bernalillo County, New\nMexico, went to a local urgent care center with a 4-day history of fever,\nsevere abdominal pain, and bloody stools. On 18 Jul 2006, a woman aged 43 years from Torrance County, New\nMexico, went to a local clinic with a 1-day history of vomiting, diarrhea,\nabdominal pain, and fever. Plague was\nconsidered immediately, and the patient was placed in respiratory\nisolation. Modeling relationships\nbetween climate and the frequency of human plague cases in the southwestern\nUnited States, 1960--1997. On 17 Feb 2006, a man aged 39 years from Travis County, Texas, was\nhospitalized with a 1-day history of high fever, delirium, nausea, and\nvomiting. When plague is suspected, appropriate antibiotic treatment\nshould be initiated immediately and not delayed for laboratory\nconfirmation. Although not approved by FDA for treatment of plague,\ngentamicin is more readily available than streptomycin and has been used\nsuccessfully (5). Persons residing\nin areas where plague is endemic should keep their dogs and cats free of\nfleas through regular use of flea treatments and by keeping them indoors. One of the patient's dogs and a rock squirrel\n(_Spermophilus variegatus_) that had been trapped by investigators on her\nproperty had serologic evidence of past infection with _Y. pestis_. _Y. pestis_ was recovered\nfrom fleas of 2 species (_Aetheca wagneri_ and _Pulex simulans_) collected\nnear the patient's home. Human infection usually is\nacquired through the bites of infected rodent fleas and has an incubation\nperiod of 1-6 days (1). _Y. pestis_ was isolated\nfrom fleas (_Anomiopsyllus nudatus_) combed from a woodrat (_Neotoma\nmicropus_) that was trapped by investigators on the patient's property. The patient recovered after treatment with multiple\nantibiotics, including gentamicin, doxycycline, ciprofloxacin, and\nlevofloxacin. The woman was\nhospitalized with fever, septic shock, and a painful right axillary\nswelling;blood cultures grew _Y. pestis_. An environmental investigation in Kern County revealed evidence\nof die-off among jackrabbits and cottontails; rabbit carcasses collected in\nthe area yielded _Y. pestis_. At least 37 hospital\nworkers who had contact with the patient before he was intubated received\npostexposure prophylaxis with doxycycline. Year-round rodent control should be conducted, including rodent-proofing of\nstructures and eliminating food sources (e.g., pet food or garbage) and\nharborage (e.g., piles of wood or debris) in the peridomestic environment. A total of 16 medical contacts and\nfamily members and friends who had visited the patient's residence received\nantibiotic prophylaxis. Fluoroquinolones are used empirically to treat critically\nill patients and have demonstrated activity against _Y. pestis_ but are not\nFDA-approved for this indication (6). Cultures from one of\nthe carcasses yielded _Y. pestis_ that was indistinguishable from the\nclinical isolates when subtyped by pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE). Five hospital\nworkers were administered doxycycline prophylaxis because of exposures\nbefore respiratory isolation had been initiated. She was\nadmitted to the hospital, placed in the intensive care unit, and\nadministered gentamicin and doxycycline. The next day, the woman returned to the\nclinic because of worsening symptoms and pain in the left side of her\ngroin.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-07-18 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "1994-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-04-17 00:00:00", "2006-08-14 00:00:00", "2006-02-17 00:00:00", "2006-05-17 00:00:00", "1925-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-05-25 00:00:00", "1960-03-25 00:00:00", "2001-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00", "1984-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Los Angeles", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New \n Mexico", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Los Angeles County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Neotoma", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "United", "country": "Cameroon"}, {"location": "Torrance County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bernalillo County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kern County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Travis County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Lea \n County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Philadelphia", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santa Fe County", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1837", "headline": "PRO/AH> Plague, animals - USA (Colorado) (02): prairie dogs", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1837", "date": "2006-06-27 00:00:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMALS - USA (COLORADO) (02): PRAIRIE DOGS\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 27 Jun 2006\nFrom: Joe Dudley<jdudley@eaicorp.com>\nSource: Greeley Tribune, 24 Jun 2006 [edited]\n<http://www.greeleytrib.com/article/20060624/NEWS/106240089>\n\nFour prairie dogs found dead on the Pawnee National Grasslands north east of\nGreeley have tested positive for plague, according to the Weld County\nDepartment of Public Health and Environment.\nTo date, 43 positive cases of plague in animals have been documented in\nColorado. No human cases have been reported in 2006 in Colorado.\n'Plague is most commonly found in the prairie dog populations in the\ngrassland areas of Weld County. People need to take precautions from being\nbitten by fleas when walking out in the grasslands,' said Sara Evans,\nenvironmental health manager at the Weld County Department of Public Health\nand Environment.\nEvans suggests that people:\n- use insect repellent particularly on the lower legs and ankles\n- treat pets for fleas\n- avoid any contact with rodents\nCats are of particular concern because they can become severely ill and\ntransmit the disease directly to humans. Cats infected with plague will look\nextremely ill, run a high fever, become lethargic, and may have swelling\naround the face and neck or abscesses draining blood and pus. Any cat with\nthese signs should be isolated from other animals and people and examined by\na veterinarian immediately, Evans said. [see moderator's comment below]\nPlague is a highly infectious bacterial disease maintained by various types\nof wild rodents and is transmitted primarily by flea bite. Although human\ncases don't occur often, the illness can be severe and even\nlife-threatening. Plague is easily treated with antibiotics when recognized\nearly.\nThree Coloradans contracted plague in 2004 and one person died. In 2005\nthere were also 3 human cases of plague.\nSymptoms of plague in humans can begin 2 to 6 days after infection and\ninclude sudden onset of high fever, muscle pain, malaise, nausea and\nvomiting. With bubonic plague, individuals may develop a large swollen,\npainful lymph node called a bubo in the area of the flea bite, usually the\ngroin or the armpit.\nFor more information, call Environment Health Division at the Weld County\nDepartment of Public Health and Environment at 304-6415 or the Colorado\nEmergency Line for the Public (CoHelp) at (877) 462-2911.\n--\nJoseph P Dudley, PhD\nChief Scientist, EAI Corporation\n4301 North Fairfax Drive, Suite 200\nArlington, VA 22203\n<jdudley@eaicorp.com>\n[Cats are not always apparently ill. This is especially true early in the\ncourse of the disease. Since cats naturally spend considerable time\nsleeping, some owners may not be aware that their cat is more lethargic than\nnormal. The buboes or abscesses may be swollen and sensitive to the touch.\nThey may be found prior to rupturing and draining, but one should be careful\nwhen examining these swellings. They may easily rupture, thus releasing the\nplague organism, _Yersinia pestis_. Any swelling on your pet is reason for\nconcern, and a veterinarian should be consulted. - Mod.TG]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Evans suggests that people:\n- use insect repellent particularly on the lower legs and ankles\n- treat pets for fleas\n- avoid any contact with rodents\n >\n\nFour prairie dogs found dead on the Pawnee National Grasslands north east of\nGreeley have tested positive for plague, according to the Weld County\nDepartment of Public Health and Environment.\n People need to take precautions from being\nbitten by fleas when walking out in the grasslands,' said Sara Evans,\nenvironmental health manager at the Weld County Department of Public Health\nand Environment. \nJoseph P Dudley, PhD\nChief Scientist, EAI Corporation\n4301 Cats infected with plague will look\nextremely ill, run a high fever, become lethargic, and may have swelling\naround the face and neck or abscesses draining blood and pus. Symptoms of plague in humans can begin 2 to 6 days after infection and\ninclude sudden onset of high fever, muscle pain, malaise, nausea and\nvomiting. With bubonic plague, individuals may develop a large swollen,\npainful lymph node called a bubo in the area of the flea bite, usually the\ngroin or the armpit. (see\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2006_06_14/en/index.html> for full report).\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed, 21 Jun 2006\n As of 13 Jun 2006, WHO has received reports of 100 cases of\nsuspected pneumonic plague, including 19 deaths in Ituri district,\nOriental province.' \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org> The revised report states that there were only\n19 deaths and 100 cases.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "2209563", "headline": "PRO/ERR> Plague, pneumonic - Congo DR (Ituri): correction", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2209563", "date": "2006-06-22 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PNEUMONIC - CONGO DR (ITURI): CORRECTION\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed, 21 Jun 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n[There was an apparent error in the initial WHO outbreak report which\nreported 100 deaths. The revised report states that there were only\n19 deaths and 100 cases. ProMED thanks J. (see\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2006_06_14/en/index.html> for full report).\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed, 21 Jun 2006\n As of 13 Jun 2006, WHO has received reports of 100 cases of\nsuspected pneumonic plague, including 19 deaths in Ituri district,\nOriental province.' \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org> The revised report states that there were only\n19 deaths and 100 cases.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "1735", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, pneumonic - Congo DR (Ituri)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1735", "date": "2006-06-14 00:00:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PNEUMONIC - CONGO DR (ITURI)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 14 Jun 2006\nFrom: Marianne Hopp <mjhopp12@yahoo.com>\nSource: WHO Outbreak Reports [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2006_06_14/en/index.html>\n\nAs of 13 Jun 2006, WHO has received reports of 100 deaths of\nsuspected pneumonic plague, including 19 deaths in Ituri district,\nOriental province. Suspected cases of bubonic plague have also been\nreported, but the total number is not known at this time. Preliminary\nresults from rapid diagnostic tests in the area confirm pneumonic\nplague. Additional laboratory analysis, including tests by culture,\nis ongoing on 18 samples.\nIturi is known to be the most active focus of human plague worldwide,\nreporting around 1000 cases a year. The 1st cases in this outbreak\noccurred in a rural area, in the Zone de Sante of Linga, in mid-May 2006.\nA team from Medecins sans Frontieres (Switzerland), WHO and Ministry\nof Health has been in the area to assess the situation and provide\nsupport to the local health authorities. Isolation wards have been\nestablished to treat patients; close contacts are being traced and\nreceiving chemoprophylaxis. However, control measures have been\ndifficult to implement because of security concerns in the area.\nFor more information, see the fact sheet on plague at\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs267/en/>.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Primary pneumonic plague (one percent of natural plague\npresentations) arises as a result of inhalation of plague bacilli in\ninfectious aerosols, such as would be produced when there are\nsecondary pneumonic complications in bubonic/septicemic plague.\nPrimary plague pneumonia has a short incubation period of 1-3 days,\nafter which there is sudden onset of flu-like symptoms including\nfever, chills, headache, generalized body pains, weakness and chest\ndiscomfort. A cough develops with sputum production, which may be\nbloody, and increasing chest pain and difficulty in breathing. As the\ndisease progresses, hypoxia (low oxygen concentration in the blood)\nand hemoptysis (coughing up blood) are prominent. The disease is\ninvariably fatal unless antimicrobial therapy commences within 24\nhours of exposure.\nPatients with primary pneumonic plague generate large quantities of\ninfectious aerosols that pose a significant risk to close contacts.\nCDC guidelines identify contacts within 2 meters as being at greatest\nrisk and do not consider the organism likely to be carried through\nair ducts or vents. Persons who have been in contact with pneumonic\nplague patients or handling potentially infectious body fluids or\ntissues without appropriate protection should receive preventive\nantimicrobial therapy. The preferred antimicrobial agents for\nprophylaxis are tetracyclines, quinolones, or chloramphenicol.\nA map of Congo DR showing Oriental province, where Ituri is located,\ncan be found at:\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/africa/congo_demrep_pol98.jpg>. - Mod.LL]\n[Of note, this is the same general area where there was a major\noutbreak of pneumonic and bubonic plague in 2005 (see prior\nProMED-mail postings listed below. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n \nPrimary plague pneumonia has a short incubation period of 1-3 days,\nafter which there is sudden onset of flu-like symptoms including\nfever, chills, headache, generalized body pains, weakness and chest\ndiscomfort. [Primary pneumonic plague (one percent of natural plague\npresentations) arises as a result of inhalation of plague bacilli in\ninfectious aerosols, such as would be produced when there are\nsecondary pneumonic complications in bubonic/septicemic plague. Source: WHO Outbreak Reports [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2006_06_14/en/index.html>\n\nAs of 13 Jun 2006, WHO has received reports of 100 deaths of\nsuspected pneumonic plague, including 19 deaths in Ituri district,\nOriental province. Persons who have been in contact with pneumonic\nplague patients or handling potentially infectious body fluids or\ntissues without appropriate protection should receive preventive\nantimicrobial therapy. [Of note, this is the same general area where there was a major\noutbreak of pneumonic and bubonic plague in 2005 (see prior\nProMED-mail postings listed below. Preliminary\nresults from rapid diagnostic tests in the area confirm pneumonic\nplague. PLAGUE, PNEUMONIC - CONGO DR (ITURI)\n***************************************\n For more information, see the fact sheet on plague at\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs267/en/>.\n CDC guidelines identify contacts within 2 meters as being at greatest\nrisk and do not consider the organism likely to be carried through\nair ducts or vents. A team from Medecins sans Frontieres (Switzerland), WHO and Ministry\nof Health has been in the area to assess the situation and provide\nsupport to the local health authorities.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the Zone de Sante of Linga", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Congo", "country": "Congo Republic"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "Switzerland"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1601", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, human - USA (NM)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1601", "date": "2006-06-01 00:00:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, HUMAN - USA (NEW MEXICO)\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed, 31 May 2006\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource New Mexican [edited]\n<http://www.freenewmexican.com/news/44388.html>\n\nA Santa Fe County man is the 2nd person to contract the plague in New\nMexico in 2006, the state Department of Health said.\nThe unidentified man was hospitalized Wed, 30 May 2006, in critical\nbut stable condition, said Deborah Busemeyer, department spokeswoman.\nThe man was suffering from the septicemic form of the disease in\nwhich the plague bacteria multiply in the bloodstream.\nThe department confirmed last Fri, 26 May 2006, that a Bernalillo\nCounty woman died the previous week of the septicemic form of the\nplague. She was the 1st person to die from plague in New Mexico in a\ndozen years.\nPlague generally is transmitted to people by the bites of infected\nfleas, but also can be transmitted by direct contact with infected\nanimals -- rodents, wildlife and pets.\n'This is the time of year when we see the most plague activity, so\nit's especially important to avoid rodents and fleas by getting wood\nand compost piles away from your home and making sure your pet has an\neffective flea control product,' said C. Mack Sewell, state\nepidemiologist for the department.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[As discussed in an earlier ProMED post -- Plague, animals - USA\n(CO): early season cases 20060220.0563 -- a mild winter seems to have\ncontributed to an increase in cases of feral animal and human plague\nin 2006.\nA map of New Mexico showing the counties can be found at:\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/united_states/newmexico_90.jpg>. It\nshould be noted that Santa Fe county borders on Bernalillo county.\nBoth are in the central part of the state.\nThe following children's' rhyme (of unclear origin) has elements that\ncan be interpreted as being related to plague, epidemic in the Middle\nAges.\nRing around the rosies,\nA pocket full of posies,\nAshes, ashes!\nWe all fall down\nRosies represent rosary beads, used to (hopefully) provide divine\nintervention against the disease. Plague victims may emit a rather\nstrong and objectionable odor; flowers (posies) could be carried to\nmask the smell. Ashes are all that was left of a burnt corpse (in\nthe Middle Ages).\n'All fall down' reflects the profound death rate. Around 1348, the\npopulation of England was estimated to be about 4 million, and within\n2.5 years about 1/3 had died from plague, sometimes called The Great\nDying. One third of the residents of Florence died in the first 6\nmonths of the epidemic and as much as 75 percent died in a single\nyear. Venice lost 60 percent of its population over 18 months that\nthe epidemic raged.\nAlternatively, for the last 2 lines of the rhyme:\nThe 3rd line can be replaced with 'A Tishoo, a tishoo,' which\nrepresents the sneezes of the victims of pneumonic plague which are\ninfectious to others.\nTo be sneezed on by them was a sure death sentence for all. The\ndeath rate for those who acquire pneumonic plague directly is almost\n100 percent. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n [As discussed in an earlier ProMED post -- Plague, animals - USA\n(CO): early season cases 20060220.0563 -- a mild winter seems to have\ncontributed to an increase in cases of feral animal and human plague\nin 2006. it's especially important to avoid rodents and fleas by getting wood\nand compost piles away from your home and making sure your pet has an\neffective flea control product,' said C. Mack Sewell, state\nepidemiologist for the department. Around 1348, the\npopulation of England was estimated to be about 4 million, and within\n2.5 years about 1/3 had died from plague, sometimes called The Great\n The following children's' rhyme (of unclear origin) has elements that\ncan be interpreted as being related to plague, epidemic in the Middle\nAges.\n \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n Source New Mexican [edited]\n<http://www.freenewmexican.com/news/44388.html>\n\nA Santa Fe County man is the 2nd person to contract the plague in New\nMexico in 2006, the state Department of Health said. Plague generally is transmitted to people by the bites of infected\nfleas, but also can be transmitted by direct contact with infected\nanimals -- rodents, wildlife and pets. The department confirmed last Fri, 26 May 2006, that a Bernalillo\nCounty woman died the previous week of the septicemic form of the\nplague. The\ndeath rate for those who acquire pneumonic plague directly is almost\n100 percent. Plague victims may emit a rather\nstrong and objectionable odor; flowers (posies) could be carried to\nmask the smell. One third of the residents of Florence died in the first 6\nmonths of the epidemic and as much as 75 percent died in a single\nyear. The 3rd line can be replaced with 'A Tishoo, a tishoo,' which\nrepresents the sneezes of the victims of pneumonic plague which are\ninfectious to others. Venice lost 60 percent of its population over 18 months that\nthe epidemic raged.\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-05-26 00:00:00", "2006-05-31 00:00:00", "2006-03-25 00:00:00", "2006-05-30 00:00:00", "1348-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Santa Fe County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Venice", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Santa Fe", "country": "Argentina"}, {"location": "Bernalillo county", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1443", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, human, fatal - USA (NM)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1443", "date": "2006-05-28 00:00:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, HUMAN, FATAL - USA (NEW MEXICO)\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri 26 May 2006\nFrom: Pablo Nart <pablo.nart@terra.es>\nSource: KOBTV [edited]\n<http://www.kobtv.com/index.cfm?viewer=storyviewer&id=25982&cat=ABQMETRO>\n\nA Bernalillo County, New Mexico woman's death is the state's 1st death from\nthe plague in more than a decade. The woman died early last week of bubonic\nplague, the bacterium of which many historians blame for the Black Death\nthat killed more than a million people in Europe during the mid-14th century.\nBubonic plague is usually transmitted to humans through the bites of\ninfected fleas but also can be transmitted through infected pets or other\nanimals. Symptoms of the plague include fever; painful, swollen lymph nodes\nin the groin, armpit and neck [these very painful lymph gland swellings are\ncalled buboes - Mod.LL]; and chills.\nDr. Paul Ettestad, the state's public health veterinarian, says Bernalillo\nCounty and other north-central New Mexico counties had increased plague\nactivity this year [2006]. Plague peaks during the warmer months, so\nEttestad says it's very important to avoid rodents and fleas now.\nFour people in New Mexico were infected with the plague in 2005. The last\ndeath from plague was 12 years ago, when a child in Rio Arriba County died\nof the disease.\n[Byline: Todd Dukart]\n--\nPablo Nart\n<pablo.nart@terra.es>\n[Bubonic plague is the classical form of _Yersinia pestis_ infection,\nrepresenting 85-90 percent of clinical presentations. Individuals present\nwith fever, chills, headache and the painful bubo. The process arises as a\nresult of a bite from an infected flea or by contamination of an open skin\nlesion. Local bacterial proliferation is sometimes evident (4-10 percent of\ncases) in the form of an abscess or ulcer at the site of infection (1).\nSymptoms of fever and malaise develop 2-6 days after exposure. The bubo\ngenerally occurs in the groin lymph nodes (90 percent), more commonly in\nthe femoral than inguinal nodes. Axillary and cervical lymph nodes may be\ninvolved reflective of the location of the fleabite. Usually heralded by\nvery severe pain within 6-8 hours after the onset of constitutional\nsymptoms, the bubo becomes evident within 24 hours. It has been said (1)\nthat the bubo may be so tender that semicomatose patients will posture in a\nway to attempt to decrease pressure on the swelling. The bubo may not be\nevident in the 1st few days of symptoms. Furthermore, involvement of deeper\nlymph nodes may not be visible. In these cases, abdominal pain suggestive\nof appendicitis, colitis, enteritis or cholecystitis may be described. In\nsuch cases, tenderness upon abdominal palpitation will be misleading and\nmay result in hazardous exploratory surgery and a potentially lethal delay\nin specific antimicrobial therapy.\nThe mechanism of transmission of plague from flea to mammalian host is as\nfollows:\nFleas become infected upon feeding on the blood of a rodent suffering from\nbacteremic infection. The bacteria are restricted to the alimentary tract\nof the flea, where they multiply in the midgut. The bacteria may form large\nbrown clumps that extend throughout the midgut, esophagus and\nproventriculus, a valve-like chamber situated between the esophagus and the\nmidgut. The clumps increase in mass over a few days until the\nproventriculus is blocked.\nThe 'blocked' flea then feeds on blood, but the meal is unable to pass into\nthe stomach. The flea continues to attempt to feed, but as it futilely\nsucks blood from the host, the blood meal, mixed with bacteria from the\nforegut, is regurgitated into the mammal. As many as 24 000 bacilli may be\ntransmitted in a single attempted feeding (2).\nDeaths from plague are generally related to spread of the bacilli from the\ninfected bubo into the blood stream with septicemia and dropping blood\npressure. The septicemia can spread to the lungs causing a secondary plague\npneumonia. It is this form that can spread from person-to-person. The\nmanifestations of _Y. pestis_ infection in this case is not stated.\n1. McGovern, T. W. and Friedlander A. M. Plague. In Zajtchuk R. and Bellamy\nR.F. (eds.) Textbook of Military Medicine: Medical Aspects of Chemical and\nBiological Warfare. Office of the Surgeon General, Borden Institute,\nWashington, D.C., pp 479-502.\n2. Burroughs, AL: Sylvatic plague studies. The vector efficiency of nine\nspecies of plague compared with _Xenopsylla cheopis_. J Hyg 1947;45:371-96.\n- Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n [Byline: Todd Dukart]\n--\nPablo Nart\n<pablo.nart@terra.es>\n The bacteria may form large\nbrown clumps that extend throughout the midgut, esophagus and\nproventriculus, a valve-like chamber situated between the esophagus and the\nmidgut. The last\ndeath from plague was 12 years ago, when a child in Rio Arriba County died\nof the disease.\n In\nsuch cases, tenderness upon abdominal palpitation will be misleading and\nmay result in hazardous exploratory surgery and a potentially lethal delay\nin specific antimicrobial therapy. Deaths from plague are generally related to spread of the bacilli from the\ninfected bubo into the blood stream with septicemia and dropping blood\npressure. Bubonic plague is usually transmitted to humans through the bites of\ninfected fleas but also can be transmitted through infected pets or other\nanimals. The bubo\ngenerally occurs in the groin lymph nodes (90 percent), more commonly in\nthe femoral than inguinal nodes. The flea continues to attempt to feed, but as it futilely\nsucks blood from the host, the blood meal, mixed with bacteria from the\nforegut, is regurgitated into the mammal. The woman died early last week of bubonic\nplague, the bacterium of which many historians blame for the Black Death\nthat killed more than a million people in Europe during the mid-14th century. Source: KOBTV [edited]\n<http://www.kobtv.com/index.cfm?viewer=storyviewer&id=25982&cat=ABQMETRO>\n\nA Bernalillo County, New Mexico woman's death is the state's 1st death from\nthe plague in more than a decade. Usually heralded by\nvery severe pain within 6-8 hours after the onset of constitutional\nsymptoms, the bubo becomes evident within 24 hours. The mechanism of transmission of plague from flea to mammalian host is as\nfollows:\n It has been said (1)\nthat the bubo may be so tender that semicomatose patients will posture in a\nway to attempt to decrease pressure on the swelling. The process arises as a\nresult of a bite from an infected flea or by contamination of an open skin\nlesion. PLAGUE, HUMAN, FATAL - USA (NEW MEXICO)\n*******************************************\n Symptoms of the plague include fever; painful, swollen lymph nodes\nin the groin, armpit and neck [Bubonic plague is the classical form of _Yersinia pestis_ infection,\nrepresenting 85-90 percent of clinical presentations.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Washington", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "D.C.", "country": "Colombia"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Bernalillo \n County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rio Arriba County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Bernalillo County", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1444", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, squirrel - USA (CA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1444", "date": "2006-05-28 00:00:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, SQUIRREL - USA (CALIFORNIA)\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 28 May 2006\nFrom: Mark Liao <markliaohk@gmail.com>\nSource: KSBY.com, 27 May 2006 [edited]\n<http://www.ksby.com/home/headlines/2886871.html>\n\nDead squirrel in park tests positive for plague\n-----------------------------------------------\nThere's a serious health warning for those heading outdoors this weekend.\nSan Luis Obispo County Public Health confirmed that a dead squirrel tested\npositive for plague. It's likely others are infected with the potentially\ndeadly disease.\nA plea today to people heading to parks, beaches, or anywhere wild rodents\nroam: don't feed the animals. 'Just about everybody who comes here, they\nfeed them peanuts, cat food,' says a Morro Bay resident. He's seen people\nfeeding squirrels here all the time, but San Luis Obispo County health\nofficers hope that will change now that it could be life threatening.\n'That dead rodent could've passed it on via the flea to another rodent,'\nsays Dr. Frank Mazzoni, a family practitioner. The plague is an infectious\nbacterial disease spread by rodents and their fleas. Humans can contract\nthe disease if exposed to infected fleas or if they handle infected\nanimals, which includes feeding them.\nOther residents know all too well how dangerously close these rodents get.\n'I know the bravery of these things; it would be nothing for someone to get\nbit,' says a resident. 'They walk right up to you, no fear of man whatsoever.'\nHealth officers are not releasing the name of the Morro Bay park where the\ninfected squirrel was found, but they're warning everyone to avoid contact\nwith wild rodents and walking near their burrows. They also advise leaving\nyour pets at home during outings and warn that cats are highly susceptible\nto plague and can spread the disease to humans.\nDr. Mazzoni adds the discovery is reason for concern, but not panic. 'It\ncan be a relatively serious infection, but the risk of developing it is\nrelatively low.'\nSymptoms of plague include high fever, chills, headaches, and swollen\nglands. Individuals who develop these symptoms should seek immediate\nmedical attention. If caught early, plague is treatable with antibiotics;\nif untreated, it can be deadly. In the last 36 years, 39 human cases of the\nplague have been confirmed in California.\n[Byline: Carina Corral]\n--\nMark Liao\n<markliaohk@gmail.com>\n[An excellent review of plague and its transmission can be found in the\nmoderator's comments of ProMED-mail post 20060419.1148. - Mod.TG]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n [Byline: Carina Corral]\n--\nMark Liao\n<markliaohk@gmail.com>\n Health officers are not releasing the name of the Morro Bay park where the\ninfected squirrel was found, but they're warning everyone to avoid contact\nwith wild rodents and walking near their burrows. Source: KSBY.com, 27 May 2006 [edited]\n<http://www.ksby.com/home/headlines/2886871.html>\n\nDead squirrel in park tests positive for plague\n They also advise leaving\nyour pets at home during outings and warn that cats are highly susceptible\nto plague and can spread the disease to humans. The plague is an infectious\nbacterial disease spread by rodents and their fleas.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-05-27 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "CALIFORNIA", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "San Luis Obispo County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "San Luis Obispo County Public Health", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2209320", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, animals - USA (CO): early season cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2209320", "date": "2006-02-20 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, ANIMALS - USA (COLORADO): EARLY SEASON CASES\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 16 Feb 2006\nFrom: Tony Schountz <tony.schountz@unco.edu>\nSource: Grand Junction Daily Sentinel [edited]\n<http://www.gjsentinel.com/news/content/news/stories/=202006/02/16/2_17_more_Re\ndlands_plague.html>\n\n2 more cases of plague reported\n-------------------------------\nA cat that made a meal out of a squirrel likely contracted the plague\nfrom its prey, health officials said on Thu 16 Feb 2006. The domestic\ncat and the white-tailed antelope squirrel both tested positive for\nplague this week, said Steve DeFeyter, director of environmental\nhealth for the Mesa County Health Department.\nThis new plague report comes a week after the plague was found in 2\nchipmunks on Colorado National Monument, resulting in the closing of\nthe Saddlehorn Campground. 'It is odd and puzzling to have plague\nactivity this early in the year,' DeFeyter said.\nApril is the earliest DeFeyter said he expected to see plague\nactivity. Rodents are usually in hibernation this time of year, he\nsaid. From what he has seen on the monument and in the Redlands area,\n'as far as I can tell, there's a lot of rodent activity going on,' he\nsaid.\n'I'm confident that the unseasonably warm weather, spring weather,\nthat we've had ... is a factor in us seeing activity this early,'\nDeFeyter said.\nIn 2005, the 1st case of plague was reported in May in a woman from\nGateway. It was later found in rodents and several cats.\nWith the recent plague-positive tests, 'I would consider the entire\nRedlands from Kingsview (Road) clear to the Gunnison River an area of\nconcern,' DeFeyter said.\nSaddlehorn Campground remains closed, and the National Park Service\nis in the process of assessing the plague risk in the area and doing\nfollow-up studies, DeFeyter said. 'They're concerned about it. We're\nconcerned about it,' DeFeyter said. 'It could be that there has been\nan outbreak of plague in the animals up there.'\nThe domestic cat that most recently tested positive for the plague is\nalive and being treated, he said. The cat apparently brought home the\nplague-infected squirrel after catching it, said Dr. Michael\nAduddell, director of the Health Department.\nIt is one of 2 cats in this particular Redlands household, and the\nother cat is also being tested for the plague. Those results are\npending. DeFeyter said, 'It wouldn't surprise me if it came out\npositive too.'\nPlague is transmitted through the bite of a flea infected with the\nplague bacteria. Ground squirrels, prairie dogs and rabbits are\ncommon hosts for infected fleas, the Health Department said. Plague\nmay be transmitted to people by bites from infected fleas, by\nhandling the carcasses of infected animals, or by scratches or bites\nfrom infected domestic cats, the Health Department continued.\n[Byline: Ann Winterholter]\n--\nTony Schountz, PhD\nUniversity of Northern Colorado\nGreeley, CO 80639\n<tony.schountz@unco.edu>\n[ProMED thanks Dr. Schountz for the contribution. It is disconcerting\nthat feral animal plague is occurring this early in the year. The\nmild winter presumably resulted in less winter die-off of the rodents\nand shorter hibernation cycles of those that hibernate. - Mod.LL]\n[See photos:\nColorado National Monument\n<http://www.nps.gov/applications/parks/colm/ppphotos/monument_canyon.jpg>\nWhite-tailed Antelope Ground Squirrel\n<http://animals.timduru.org/dirlist/squirrel/White-\ntailedAntelopeGroundSquirrel_01.jpg>\nChipmunk\n<http://www.crimsonmyst.com/photos/chipmunk.jpg>\n- Mod.JW]", "summary": "[Byline: Ann Winterholter]\n--\nTony Schountz, PhD\nUniversity of Northern Colorado\nGreeley, CO 80639\n<tony.schountz@unco.edu>\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The domestic\ncat and the white-tailed antelope squirrel both tested positive for\nplague this week, said Steve DeFeyter, director of environmental\nhealth for the Mesa County Health Department. The patient had flea bites on the left\nankle and a left inguinal bubo. Rock squirrels collected in the vicinity of\nthe patient's home were heavily infested with fleas, and fleas were\ncollected from burrows in the area. Rodent blood and tissue and fleas are\nen route to CDC-Division of Vector Borne Infectious Diseases in Fort\nCollins, CO for testing.\n--\nPamela J. University\nof Colorado researchers have been studying the new outbreak for clues about\nhow plague spreads and how human development affects its movement.\nSharon Collinge said evidence she and her research assistants have compiled\nappears to support the theory that deer mice are a reservoir for the\ndisease because it does not seem to affect them.\nIn both the infected colony and a healthy colony nearby, the deer mice\npopulation is about the same, suggesting the mice haven't been hurt by the\ndisease, she said.\nThe plague outbreak comes as Boulder city officials are struggling to\ndevelop a policy for dealing with prairie dogs. Attempts to kill the\nanimals often provoke protests in the city.\nAlice Guthrie, who is heading the city's effort to draw up a policy, said a\nplague die-off would buy some time but would not eliminate the need for a\npolicy because the animals' population will recover.\n'We know that we can't really depend on plague coming through really often\nto control populations, so we have to have other tools and accepted\nmethods,' she said.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Because Prairie dogs are very sensitive indicators of the presence of the\nplague organism, _Yersinia pestis_, they are often considered sentinel\nanimals. Domestic cats are also sensitive to the plague agent.\nA review of the transmission of the plague agent can be found in\nProMED-mail post 20050709.1954 - Mod.TG]\n[Elsevier reference:\nPhalen DN. Prairie dogs: vectors and victims. Seminars in Avian and Exotic\nPet Medicine. The rodents have\nbeen missing for 2 weeks.\nSources say FBI agents and bioterrorism experts are interviewing and\npolygraphing employees at the University of Medicine and Dentistry in\nNewark, N.J., the location of the lab run by the Public Health\nResearch Institute, a leading center for research on infectious\ndiseases.\nThere are no indications of terrorism.\n'The FBI responded to the matter, and we dedicated a great number of\nagents as well as a large number of resources to the investigation,\nwhich is still ongoing,' said Special Agent Steve Siegel, a spokesman\nfor the FBI's Newark field office. 'We're satisfied that there is no\npublic safety risk and there doesn't seem to be any nexus to criminal\nactivity or terrorism.'\nNew Jersey officials also are downplaying the health risk. They\nbelieve the infected mice probably died quickly.\nHowever, some government officials are deeply concerned about what\nthe case says about security of some of the most deadly infectious\ndisease projects and research labs.\nOne source admitted that while officials are saying there is minimal\nhealth risk, no one can be entirely certain.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[There is minimal information provided, but '3 mice' possibly\nrepresents only a single box of such animals in a BSL-3 facility.\nOccam's razor would indicate a stupid mistake, but as the loss was\nnoted 2 weeks ago, all probable explanations will have been\ninvestigated and the answer is still being sought. If the mice had\ndied, been incinerated, and the box emptied, cleaned, and sterilized,\nall traces will have been lost, along with any memories of what had\nhappened. But the card for the box should have been kept along with\nany comments.\nIf this were a break-in by Friends of the Earth, there would have\nbeen ancillary damage unless this has been suppressed. They have the\nexperience to carry out such a 'raid' -- if raid it was.\nClearly those involved are assuming that the mice have died, if they\nwere removed.\nOdd, but those with experience of such facilities probably have\nplenty of pre-Homeland Security war stories. - Mod.MHJ]\n.................tg/mhj/pg/lm\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
