Occam's razor would indicate a stupid mistake, but as the loss was\nnoted 2 weeks ago, all probable explanations will have been\ninvestigated and the answer is still being sought. One source admitted that while officials are saying there is minimal\nhealth risk, no one can be entirely certain.\n They\nbelieve the infected mice probably died quickly.\n We're satisfied that there is no\npublic safety risk and there doesn't seem to be any nexus to criminal\nactivity or terrorism.' --\nProMED-mail\n< Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: [There is minimal information provided, but '3 mice' possibly\nrepresents only a single box of such animals in a BSL-3 facility.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "NEW JERSEY", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "N.J.", "country": "Argentina"}, {"location": "New Jersey", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Newark", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2208608", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Undiagnosed deaths - Congo DR (Maniema) (08): pneumonic plague susp", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2208608", "date": "2005-09-05 23:50:00", "main_text": "UNDIAGNOSED DEATHS - CONGO DR (MANIEMA) (08): PNEUMONIC PLAGUE SUSPECTED\n************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nJournal of Clinical Virology\n<http://intl.elsevierhealth.com/journals/jocv>\nDate: Mon 5 Sep 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: IRIN [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/IRIN/274ed4a3686af8958a66a87dc8a8fa1e.htm>\n\nDRC: epidemic in diamond area identified as pneumonic plague\n------------------------------------------------------------\nAt least 38 people have died, and at least 1300 others are diagnosed with a\ndisease that the UK-based medical NGO Merlin calls a highly contagious form\nof pneumonic plague, which broke out in July 2005 in the remote diamond\nmining area of Libaku ya Suka in the Democratic Republic of Congo's eastern\nManiema Province.\nThe disease has a high fatality rate, Merlin said in a statement released\non Fri 2 Sep 2005. Those infected suffer from high fever and acute\nshortness of breath as well as chest pains, headaches and swollen lymph glands.\nPneumonic plague is a bacterial infection of the lungs and can be easily\ntransmitted from human to human through infected air droplets, infected\nclothing or other contaminated articles, Merlin said.\nThe disease can be treated with antibiotics if identified early enough, but\nMerlin's head nurse, Prosper Tunda, at Libaku ya Suka, said that hospitals\nand health centers in the area were not equipped to deal with this kind of\nemergency. Patients are lying on the floor, as there are not enough beds or\nmattresses, and all the health facilities lack basic equipment and\nessentials drugs,' Tunda said.\nThe Merlin team is working with other organizations in the area and local\nhealth staff to identify and treat new cases in the Punia, Lubutu and\nObokote districts of the province. Efforts to quarantine infected people is\ndifficult, Merlin said, because many of them are working at an open diamond\nmine in poor sanitary conditions in close proximity to some 8000 other miners.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Some cases may well be pneumonic plague, but it would seem extremely\nunlikely that the large outbreak involving more than 1300 individuals is\ndue to _Y. pestis_ pneumonia, primary or secondary, unless the strain is\nmuch less virulent than usual. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n At least 38 people have died, and at least 1300 others are diagnosed with a\ndisease that the UK-based medical NGO Merlin calls a highly contagious form\nof pneumonic plague, which broke out in July 2005 in the remote diamond\nmining area of Libaku ya Suka in the Democratic Republic of Congo's eastern\nManiema Province. The disease can be treated with antibiotics if identified early enough, but\nMerlin's head nurse, Prosper Tunda, at Libaku ya Suka, said that hospitals\nand health centers in the area were not equipped to deal with this kind of\nemergency. Efforts to quarantine infected people is\ndifficult, Merlin said, because many of them are working at an open diamond\nmine in poor sanitary conditions in close proximity to some 8000 other miners.\n [Some cases may well be pneumonic plague, but it would seem extremely\nunlikely that the large outbreak involving more than 1300 individuals is\ndue to _Y. pestis_ pneumonia, primary or secondary, unless the strain is\nmuch less virulent than usual. Sponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nJournal of Clinical Virology\n<http://intl.elsevierhealth.com/journals/jocv>\n Pneumonic plague is a bacterial infection of the lungs and can be easily\ntransmitted from human to human through infected air droplets, infected\nclothing or other contaminated articles, Merlin said.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-07-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Libaku", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of Congo", "country": "DR Congo"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1363", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, bubonic, human - USA (CA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1363", "date": "2006-04-19 00:00:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, BUBONIC, HUMAN - USA (CALIFORNIA)\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 19 Apr 2006\nFrom: Alfonso Rodriguez <ajrm_msds@yahoo.es>\nSource: Los Angeles Times, CA [edited]\n<http://www.latimes.com/news/printedition/california/la-me-bubonic19apr19,1,6380349.story?coll=la-headlines-pe-california>\n\nWoman is treated for the plague\n-----------------------------------\nA Los Angeles woman is being treated for bubonic plague, the 1st case\nof the age-old pestilence in the county since 1984, health officials\nannounced Tue 18 Apr 2006.\nThe infected patient, whose identity was withheld, came down with\nsymptoms last week and continues to be treated in a hospital for the\ndisease, which is characterized by swollen lymph nodes, officials\nsaid. She may have contracted the disease from fleas in the area\naround her Country Club Park neighborhood.\nAlthough the disease is 'rare, it is important to remember that this\nstill can happen,' said Dr. Jonathan Fielding, director of public\nhealth for the Los Angeles County Department of Health Services.\nTraps have been set out for squirrels and other wild animals in the\narea to determine the extent of exposure, officials said. Neighbors\nare being warned to avoid contact with dead animals and fleas from\nrodents and pets.\nAlthough human cases of the plague are uncommon, it is endemic to\nground squirrels and some rodents in parts of the Angeles National\nForest, Tehachapi, Lake Isabella and Frazier Park.\nThe last major urban epidemic in the USA occurred in Los Angeles in\n1924, resulting in dozens of deaths. On average, about 5 to 15 people\nget the plague annually around the country, mostly in rural areas,\naccording to the CDC. [Most of the cases are in the southwestern part\nof the USA in the states of Arizona, Colorado, New Mexico and Utah. - Mod.LL]\nBubonic plague is primarily transmitted through flea bites or direct\ncontact with infected open wounds or sores.\n[Byline: Michelle Keller]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Bubonic plague is the classical form of _Yersinia pestis_ infection,\nrepresenting 85-90 percent of clinical presentations. Individuals\npresent with fever, chills, headache and the painful bubo. The\nprocess arises as a result of a bite from an infected flea or by\ncontamination of an open skin lesion. Local bacterial proliferation\nis sometimes evident (4-10 percent of cases) in the form of an\nabscess or ulcer at the site of infection (1).\nSymptoms of fever and malaise develop 2-6 days after exposure. The\nbubo generally occurs in the groin lymph nodes (90 percent), more\ncommonly in the femoral than inguinal nodes. Axillary and cervical\nlymph nodes may be involved reflective of the location of the\nfleabite. Usually heralded by very severe pain within 6-8 hours after\nthe onset of constitutional symptoms, the bubo becomes evident within\n24 hours. It has been said (1) that the bubo may be so tender that\nsemicomatose patients will posture in a way to attempt to decrease\npressure on the swelling. The bubo may not be evident in the 1st few\ndays of symptoms. Furthermore, involvement of deeper lymph nodes may\nnot be visible. In these cases, abdominal pain suggestive of\nappendicitis, colitis, enteritis or cholecystitis may be described.\nIn such cases, tenderness upon abdominal palpitation will be\nmisleading and may result in hazardous exploratory surgery and a\npotentially lethal delay in specific antimicrobial therapy.\nThe mechanism of transmission of plague from flea to mammalian host\nis as follows:\nFleas become infected upon feeding on the blood of a rodent suffering\nfrom bacteremic infection. The bacteria are restricted to the\nalimentary tract of the flea, where they multiply in the midgut. The\nbacteria may form large brown clumps that extend throughout the\nmidgut, esophagus and proventriculus, a valve-like chamber situated\nbetween the esophagus and the midgut. The clumps increase in mass\nover a few days until the proventriculus is blocked.\nThe 'blocked' flea then feeds on blood, but the meal is unable to\npass into the stomach. The flea continues to attempt to feed, but as\nit futilely sucks blood from the host, the blood meal, mixed with\nbacteria from the foregut, is regurgitated into the mammal. As many\nas 24 000 bacilli may be transmitted in a single attempted feeding (2).\n1. McGovern, T. W. and Friedlander A. M. Plague. In Zajtchuk R. and\nBellamy R.F. (eds.) Textbook of Military Medicine: Medical Aspects of\nChemical and Biological Warfare. Office of the Surgeon General,\nBorden Institute, Washington, D.C., pp 479-502.\n2. Burroughs, AL: Sylvatic plague studies. The vector efficiency of\nnine species of plague compared with _Xenopsylla cheopis_. J Hyg\n1947;45:371-96.\n- Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The infected patient, whose identity was withheld, came down with\nsymptoms last week and continues to be treated in a hospital for the\ndisease, which is characterized by swollen lymph nodes, officials\nsaid. LL]\nBubonic plague is primarily transmitted through flea bites or direct\ncontact with infected open wounds or sores.\n The\nbacteria may form large brown clumps that extend throughout the\nmidgut, esophagus and proventriculus, a valve-like chamber situated\nbetween the esophagus and the midgut. Neighbors\nare being warned to avoid contact with dead animals and fleas from\nrodents and pets.\n [Byline: Michelle Keller]\n--\nProMED-mail\n< The flea continues to attempt to feed, but as\nit futilely sucks blood from the host, the blood meal, mixed with\nbacteria from the foregut, is regurgitated into the mammal. Usually heralded by very severe pain within 6-8 hours after\nthe onset of constitutional symptoms, the bubo becomes evident within\n24 hours. The New Mexico Department of Health\nreports that the patient has been hospitalized and is recovering. The\ndepartment is conducting an environmental assessment of the youth's home to\ndetermine whether there is any ongoing risk to the public.\n'We have been seeing plague cases in cats, dogs and rodents in many of the\nnorth central counties of New Mexico,' says Dr. Paul Ettestad, the\ndepartment's public health veterinarian.\nPlague is a bacterial disease that is usually contracted from bites from\ninfected fleas but can also be transmitted by direct contact with infected\nanimals. The symptoms of plague include fever, swollen lymph nodes, chills\nand sometimes headache, vomiting and diarrhea. The symptoms in cats are\nsimilar.\nThe department reports that plague can be successfully treated with\nantibiotics if it is promptly diagnosed.\nThere have been cases of plague in animals reported in 2005 in Rio Arriba,\nSanta Fe, Taos, Los Alamos, Colfax and Bernalillo Counties.\nThere were no reported cases of human plague in the state in 2004. 1 case\nwas reported in Torrance County in 2003 and 2 cases were reported in 2002\nin Santa Fe County. The last plague fatality occurred in 1994 in a Rio\nArriba County child.\n[Byline: Reed Upton]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The specific aspects of this case are not included. That the adolescent\nis recovering suggests strongly that this is a case of bubonic plague and\nwas diagnosed and treated promptly.\n_Y. pestis_ infection is endemic in the southwestern USA. Introduction of\ninfection into wildlife occurred following the introduction of plague in\nSan Francisco in the early 20th century (1).\n1. Lipson LG: Plague in San Francisco in 1900. The United States Marine\nHospital Service Commission to study the existence of plague in San\nFrancisco. Ann Intern Med 1972; 77:303-10.\n- Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n [Byline: Reed Upton]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n Sponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nPrinciples and Practice of Infectious Diseases Online, 6th edition\n<http://tinyurl.com/7sfzw>\n We have been seeing plague cases in cats, dogs and rodents in many of the\nnorth central counties of New Mexico,' says Dr. Paul Ettestad, the\ndepartment's public health veterinarian. USA (NEW MEXICO)\n********************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-03-25 00:00:00", "1972-03-25 00:00:00", "1994-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2002-03-25 00:00:00", "1900-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-07-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Taos", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Torrance County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Los Alamos", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Santa Fe", "country": "Argentina"}, {"location": "Santa Fe County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "San \n Francisco", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "the United States Marine \n Hospital Service Commission", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Francisco", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2208237", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, feline - USA (WY): Alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2208237", "date": "2005-07-09 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, FELINE - USA (WYOMING): ALERT\n**************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nThe International Journal of Infectious Diseases\n<http://tinyurl.com/bj3md>\nDate: 9 Jul 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Associated Press Writer [edited]\n<http://www.palmbeachpost.com/health/content/shared-gen/ap/Health_Medical/Cat_Plague.html>\n\nPlague-Infected Cats Cause Worry in Wyoming\n--------------------\nA local cat was diagnosed with plague Friday -- the 4th in southern Wyoming\nthis year -- and public health officials warned that people should take\nprecautions to protect their pets and themselves.\nGus Lopez, director of the Cheyenne-Laramie County Health Department, said\nthe latest case occurred west of the city, in the same general area where 2\nother cats contracted the disease. A 4th cat, in neighboring Albany County,\nalso was diagnosed with plague.\n'Getting 4 of them in southern Wyoming in a short period of time is\nunusual,' said Ken Gage of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention\n(CDC) in Fort Collins, Colorado. 'It's not cause for panic, or anything,\nbut it is cause for some concern.'\nIn many parts of the West, plague is endemic in the fleas infesting rodent\npopulations. The disease can jump to other animals, including humans, if\nthey come into contact with infected fleas. Researchers speculate that the\ninfected cats probably caught or ate infected rodents.\nHuman cases remain extremely rare. A southwest Colorado woman who caught\nplague from infected fleas is the region's only human case this year.\nWyoming has had just 5 human cases since 1978.\nBut state health officials also point out that they hadn't recorded any\nfeline cases in more than 20 years.\n'I think this is just going to be the tip of the iceberg,' Lopez said. 'And\nwhat really concerns me is these cases with cats right now really increase\nthe risk of human exposure.'\nThat's because handling infected animals is much riskier than simply being\nexposed to infected fleas. In the 5 recorded human cases since 1978 in\nWyoming, each had handled an infected animal, Gage said.\nAn infected cat might bring infected fleas into a home; it might also\ninfect people by biting, scratching or coughing. 'That's very, very\ndangerous, because the disease progresses very rapidly in that situation,'\nGage said.\nDr. Tracy Murphy, Wyoming's state epidemiologist, said rodent populations\nappeared to be up in Wyoming and much of the West this year, in part\nbecause of increased rain and snow during winter and spring. As rodent\npopulations increase, so does the chance that rodents will infect each\nother, spreading plague.\nHealth officials are warning people to avoid contact with rodents or with\nany sick or dead animals. If such contact is unavoidable, people should\nwear gloves and insect repellant. Pets or people showing plague symptoms --\nswollen glands, fever, chills, pain and extreme exhaustion -- should get\nimmediate medical attention.\n[Byline: Dan Lewerenz]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Plague is caused by _Yersinia pestis_ and transmitted most often by flea\nbites.\nWhen sylvatic outbreaks occur in rodent populations, domestic cats can be\ninfected by fleas on the rodents or by direct contact with infected rodent\ntissues -- as they chomp on squirrels or other rodents. The incubation\nperiod in cats may be short, a day or 2, and marked by a fever of up to\n41.5 C and lymphadenopathy. Typical buboes often occur in the head and\nneck, and can be mistaken for cat fight abscesses. Dogs are considered to\nbe less susceptible.\nBubonic plague, one form of the disease, is of zoonotic concern, as\nindividuals may contract disease from either infected fleas or contact with\npurulent discharges or blood from the cat. An even greater threat occurs\nwhen the disease in cats progresses to pneumonic plague. This has been\ndocumented in cats, including transmission to veterinarians and owners.\nAntibiotic treatment is effective in cats, but the threat of plague is only\none of many reasons that people should keep their pets free of fleas.\nThere are many good flea control products and methods of eliminating fleas\nfrom the animal as well as the yard. If an animal owner is having trouble\nwith fleas, a visit to the veterinarian may be in order. If an animal has a\nswelling, extra caution should be taken by the animal owner as well as the\nveterinarian. The swellings may rupture and expose the owner and/or the\nveterinarian to the plague agent. The disease is treatable with\nantibiotics, so a trip to the veterinarian may be in order. - Mod.TG]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n [Byline: Dan Lewerenz]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n A local cat was diagnosed with plague Friday -- the 4th in southern Wyoming\nthis year -- and public health officials warned that people should take\nprecautions to protect their pets and themselves.\n Pets or people showing plague symptoms --\nswollen glands, fever, chills, pain and extreme exhaustion -- should get\nimmediate medical attention.\n \nDr. Tracy Murphy, Wyoming's state epidemiologist, said rodent populations\nappeared to be up in Wyoming and much of the West this year, in part\nbecause of increased rain and snow during winter and spring. When sylvatic outbreaks occur in rodent populations, domestic cats can be\ninfected by fleas on the rodents or by direct contact with infected rodent\ntissues -- as they chomp on squirrels or other rodents. Bubonic plague, one form of the disease, is of zoonotic concern, as\nindividuals may contract disease from either infected fleas or contact with\npurulent discharges or blood from the cat. \nAntibiotic treatment is effective in cats, but the threat of plague is only\none of many reasons that people should keep their pets free of fleas. Gus Lopez, director of the Cheyenne-Laramie County Health Department, said\nthe latest case occurred west of the city, in the same general area where 2\nother cats contracted the disease. Source: Associated Press Writer [edited]\n<http://www.palmbeachpost.com/health/content/shared-gen/ap/Health_Medical/Cat_Plague.html>\n\nPlague-Infected Cats Cause Worry in Wyoming\n As rodent\npopulations increase, so does the chance that rodents will infect each\nother, spreading plague. And\nwhat really concerns me is these cases with cats right now really increase\nthe risk of human exposure.' Getting 4 of them in southern Wyoming in a short period of time is\nunusual,' said Ken Gage of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention\n The incubation\nperiod in cats may be short, a day or 2, and marked by a fever of up to\n41.5 C and lymphadenopathy. If an animal has a\nswelling, extra caution should be taken by the animal owner as well as the\nveterinarian. That's very, very\ndangerous, because the disease progresses very rapidly in that situation,'\n PLAGUE, FELINE - USA (WYOMING): ALERT\n**************************\n The International Journal of Infectious Diseases\n<http://tinyurl.com/bj3md>\n An infected cat might bring infected fleas into a home; it might also\ninfect people by biting, scratching or coughing. '", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1978-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Fort Collins", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Albany County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2208153", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - China (Tibet)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2208153", "date": "2005-06-26 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE - CHINA (TIBET)\n**********************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: Sat 25 Jun 2005\nFrom: Dan Silver <dsilver@reedpointgroup.com>\nSource: XinHuaNet.com [edited]\n<http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2005-06/25/content_3136079.htm>\n\n\nMinistry: plague in Tibet brought under control\n-----------------------------------------------\nThe plague in Zhongba, a county in Xigaze Prefecture of south west China's\nTibet Autonomous Region, has been brought under control, the Chinese\nMinistry of Health cited a report of the Tibet Department of Health as\nsaying. The epidemic has so far affected 5 people, an official with the\nministry said here on Sat 25 Jun 2005. The disease came over them during\nthe period 13 to 18 Jun 2005, and 2 of them died.\n\nThe official stated that, after the epidemic occurred, health organizations\nin the Tibet autonomous region immediately launched an epidemiology probe\nin an effort to track down and quarantine the people who had had direct\ncontact with the patients, to oblige them to take preventive medicines, as\nwell as taking other disease prevention and control measures, including\nsterilization and quarantine.\n\nAfter receiving report of the epidemic, the ministry also immediately sent\nexperts to the epidemic area to help cope with it. The ministry reported\nthe epidemic to the WHO early Saturday morning, 25 Jun 2005. Meanwhile, the\nministry asked the epidemic areas to beef up publicity about prevention and\nto urge local people to report suspect cases to health departments as soon\nas possible.\n\n--\nDan Silver\n<dsilver@reedpointgroup.com>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sun 26 Jun 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Monsters and Critics [edited]\n<http://news.monstersandcritics.com/health/article_1022537.php/Two_die_of_plague_after_eating_marmot_in_Chinas_Tibet_region_>\n\n\n2 die of plague after eating marmot in China's Tibet region\n-----------------------------------------------------------\n2 people died of plague, and 3 others were hospitalized, after they ate\nmarmot meat in a remote area of China's Tibet region, state media said on\nSun 26 Jun 2005.\n\nThe 5 migrant road workers became ill after eating marmot on 11 Jun 2005 in\nTibet's Zhongba county, close to China's border with Nepal, the official\nXinhua news agency said. Doctors treated the 5 workers for an unspecified\nform of plague, but 2 of them died in the hospital, the agency said.\n\nHealth officials quarantined 75 people who had contact with the infected\nworkers, but none showed plague-like symptoms. Police were also trying to\ntrace a woman who had contact with the infected people but crossed the\nborder into Nepal on 21 Jun 2005.\n\nThe health ministry reported the infections to the WHO and the Nepalese\ngovernment on Sat 25 Jun 2005, the agency said. The most common form is the\nbubonic plague, which became known as the 'black death' after a major\noutbreak spread to Europe from Central Asia in the 14th century. Some\nexperts believe the Black Death 1st spread to humans through contact with\nmarmots, which are still commonly hunted for food by Mongolians.\n\nSmaller outbreaks of bubonic plague are frequently reported in remote areas\nof north western China and Mongolia. In 2004, plague outbreaks linked to\nmarmot hunting killed 8 and infected at least 11 others in a remote area of\nQinghai province, which occupies the northern half of the Tibetan plateau.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dan Silver for contributing the 1st posting. We would\nappreciate more information regarding the manifestations of plague in these\nindividuals. The form of _Yersinia pestis_ infection is not stated here,\nbut the institution of quarantine in contacts suggests that a plague\npneumonia may have been present as a primary or secondary manifestation. -\nMod.LL]", "summary": "Meanwhile, the\nministry asked the epidemic areas to beef up publicity about prevention and\nto urge local people to report suspect cases to health departments as soon\nas possible.\n\n--\nDan Silver\n<dsilver@reedpointgroup.com>\n\n******\n The official stated that, after the epidemic occurred, health organizations\nin the Tibet autonomous region immediately launched an epidemiology probe\nin an effort to track down and quarantine the people who had had direct\ncontact with the patients, to oblige them to take preventive medicines, as\nwell as taking other disease prevention and control measures, including\nsterilization and quarantine. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\n -----------------------------------------------------------\n2 people died of plague, and 3 others were hospitalized, after they ate\nmarmot meat in a remote area of China's Tibet region, state media said on\nSun 26 Jun 2005. China's\nTibet Autonomous Region, has been brought under control, the Chinese\nMinistry of Health cited a report of the Tibet Department of Health as\nsaying. edited]\n<http://diariodonordeste.globo.com/materia.asp?codigo=243909>\n\nHuman plague diagnosed in Pedra Branca\n------------------------------------\nAlmost 10 years after the last case of human plague was reported in the\nNortheast [of Brazil], the alert signal was raised in the region following\na positive diagnosis. The existence of antibodies against the _Yersinia\npestis_ bacterium were confirmed in a male resident of Pedra Branca, a\nmunicipality in the interior of Ceara, 261 kilometers from Fortaleza [the\ncapital of Ceara State].\nThe disease, which claimed millions of victims during the middle ages, is\ncontagious in a form that attacks the lungs and can thereby be transmitted\nperson to person.\nThe case was detected in February [2005], during a strengthened\nepidemiologic surveillance operation that for more than a year had\nidentified cases in cats with positive serology against plague in areas of\nCeara (Baturite and Ipu) and Pernambuco (Exu and Triunfo).\nAccording to the biologist Marise Sobreira of the Microbiology Department\nof Aggeu Magalhaes, national reference laboratory in the area, the disease,\nwhich is endemic among the wild rodents, becomes more worrisome when it\nappears in sentinel animals.\n'Dogs and cats with antibodies against plague are a signal that the\nbacterium is circulating in the region', she explained, adding that in\ngeneral they are infected by the bite of fleas from sick rodents.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[While this is a delayed report, plague is on the list of internationally\nreportable diseases in the current IHR and its reappearance\n(quasi-reappearance) in an area after 10 years of no cases is of\ninterest. One suspects that this is not unrelated to the implementation of\nactive surveillance -- seek and ye shall find. More information from\nknowledgeable sources would be appreciated. - Mod.MPP]\n[No clinical manifestations of plague in the patient are stated. These\nfigures are based on the current situation and a retrospective analysis of\ncases since 15 Dec 2004. No cases of bubonic plague have been detected.\nLaboratory analysis of specimens and contact tracing is continuing. To date,\na total of 363 contacts have been followed up. Suspect cases are being\ntreated in isolation treatment centers.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The last WHO update reported 114 suspect cases. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n These\nfigures are based on the current situation and a retrospective analysis of\ncases since 15 Dec 2004. Source: WHO Outbreak Reports [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2005_03_15/en/>\n\nPlague in the Democratic Republic of the Congo - update 4\n--------------------------------------------------------- PLAGUE, PNEUMONIC - CONGO DR (07): (NORTH EAST)\n***********************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2004-12-15 00:00:00", "2005-03-14 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Congo", "country": "Congo Republic"}, {"location": "Zobia", "country": "Ivory Coast"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of the", "country": "DR Congo"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2207880", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, human - USA (CO)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2207880", "date": "2005-05-18 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, HUMAN - USA (COLORADO)\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 17 May 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Rocky Mountain News [edited]\n<http://rockymountainnews.com/drmn/local/article/0,1299,DRMN_15_3783189,00.html>\n\nPlague cases may rise; wetter weather in state aiding increase in rodents\nand fleas\n-----------------------------------------------\nBubonic plague has sickened one Colorado woman this month [May 2005], and\nthe wetter weather means more cases may be on the way, especially in rural\nareas.\nThe woman, who lives in La Plata County in southwestern Colorado, is\nrecovering after spending time in a hospital, said the Colorado Department\nof Public Health and Environment. She probably got it from a flea that\njumped off her cat and bit her, say epidemiologists.\nPeople visiting rural campgrounds, picnic spots and wilderness areas also\nshould be cautious.\nBubonic plague is a highly infectious bacterial disease of rodents that is\nspread by their fleas. Human cases are infrequent and can be treated easily\nwith common antibiotics when recognized early. Otherwise, they can be\nlife-threatening.\nThe wetter weather, combined with the 5- to 10-year cycle of plague in the\nwestern United States, means Colorado could see more plague this year\n[2005], said John Pape, an epidemiologist who specializes in animal-related\ndiseases for the health department. The damper weather gave rise to more\nplants for rodents to eat, so their numbers grew. Lower temperatures also\nallow fleas to survive longer on their rodent hosts, Pape said.\nEarlier this year [2005], a plague-positive cat was reported in Douglas\nCounty. A positive squirrel was found in El Paso County and, most recently,\na positive rabbit was found in Jefferson County. Rapid die-offs of rodents\nand rabbits, a telltale sign of plague, have been reported from several\nareas of the state, Pape said.\nBubonic plague:\nSymptoms emerge 2 to 6 days after infection:\n* A sudden onset of high fever\n* Muscle pain\n* Malaise or a general feeling of being ill\n* Nausea and vomiting\n* A large swollen, painful lymph node, usually in the groin or armpit\n[Byline: Bill Scanlon]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Sporadic cases of bubonic plague, caused by _Yersinia pestis_, continue to\noccur in the rural areas of the Western US. The CDC web site states: 'In\nthe United States, the last urban plague epidemic occurred in Los Angeles\nin 1924-25. Since then, human plague in the United States has occurred as\nmostly scattered cases in rural areas (an average of 10 to 15 persons each\nyear). Globally, the World Health Organization reports 1000 to 3000 cases\nof plague every year.' Plague bacillus is considered a Category A\nbioterrorist agent by CDC.\nAn excellent description of the pathogenesis of bubonic plague and further\nreferences can be found in the ProMED-mail archived report: Plague, human,\nfatal - USA (CO) 20041214.3311. - Mod.LM]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n -----------------------------------------------\nBubonic plague has sickened one Colorado woman this month [May 2005], and\nthe wetter weather means more cases may be on the way, especially in rural\nareas. Congo DR (04): (North East)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2207457", "date": "2005-03-02 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PNEUMONIC - CONGO DR (04): (NORTH EAST)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Tue, 1 Mar 2005\nFrom: Marianne Hopp <mjhopp12@yahoo.com>\nSource: WHO Outbreak Reports 1 Mar 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2005_03_01/en/>\n\nPlague in the Democratic Republic of the Congo\n----------------------------------------------\nThe multidisciplinary team arrived in Zobia, Bas-Uele district, Oriental\nprovince on 25 Feb 2005 where the suspected cases of pneumonic plague have\noccurred (see previous report <http://www.who.int/csr/don/2005_02_18/en/>).\nThe team now consists of epidemiologists, a clinician, data manager,\nlogistician and experts in social mobilization from the Congolese Ministry of\nHealth and WHO (Country and African Regional Offices and headquarters),\nlaboratory experts from the WHO Collaborating Center, Institut Pasteur,\nMadagascar and a logistician and clinical management team from Medecins sans\nFrontieres (MSF-Belgium).\nThe team is carrying out intensive surveillance activities. Since 25 Feb\n2005, 4 probable cases (including 1 death) and 4 suspect cases have been\nreported. A retrospective study of cases is ongoing and an additional 34\nsamples have been collected for testing at the Institut de la Recherche\nBiomedicale, Kinshasa. The team is actively following up 113 contacts in\nsurrounding areas. MSF have established an isolation center for treatment of\ncases.\nA committee for the Control of Epidemics has been created with the local\nauthorities. WHO has provided equipment, including drugs and materials for\ncase management and for laboratory sampling and diagnosis.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The team now consists of epidemiologists, a clinician, data manager,\nlogistician and experts in social mobilization from the Congolese Ministry of\nHealth and WHO (Country and African Regional Offices and headquarters),\nlaboratory experts from the WHO Collaborating Center, Institut Pasteur,\n Since 25 Feb\n2005, 4 probable cases (including 1 death) and 4 suspect cases have been\nreported. The multidisciplinary team arrived in Zobia, Bas-Uele district, Oriental\nprovince on 25 Feb 2005 where the suspected cases of pneumonic plague have\noccurred (see previous report <http://www.who.int/csr/don/2005_02_18/en/>). A retrospective study of cases is ongoing and an additional 34\nsamples have been collected for testing at the Institut de la Recherche\nBiomedicale, Kinshasa. WHO has provided equipment, including drugs and materials for\ncase management and for laboratory sampling and diagnosis.\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2005-02-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Congo", "country": "Congo Republic"}, {"location": "Zobia", "country": "Ivory Coast"}, {"location": "Kinshasa", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of the", "country": "DR Congo"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2207451", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, pneumonic - Congo DR (03): (North East)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2207451", "date": "2005-02-28 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PNEUMONIC - CONGO DR 03): (NORTH EAST)\n*********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Mon, 28 Feb 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Reuters [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/LEW828191.htm>\n\nNew cases of Congo plague but appears contained\n-----------------------------------------------\nDoctors have found at least 60 new cases of plague in eastern Congo, but the\ndisease does not appear to be spreading beyond the mining town where it broke\nout, aid workers said on Mon, 28 Feb 2005.\nPneumonic plague, which is highly contagious, broke out 2 months ago in\nZobia, a town that was home to at least 7000 diamond miners, some 300 km (186\nmiles) north of the provincial capital Kisangani.\n'There are still cases coming into Zobia, but these are restricted to the\nmining area. It does not seem to have spread any further,' Eric Bertherat,\nhead of a WHO team, told Reuters by phone from Zobia.\nAid agency Medecins sans Frontieres (MSF) said it had registered new cases in\nthe town, which is in Congo's lawless Ituri district, where fighting over\nminerals has raged for years.\n'We have registered 61 fresh cases, including a death,' Philippe Havet, MSF's\nemergency coordinator said on Mon, 28 Feb 2005. 'There were 15 new cases\nyesterday, but these people are limited to the mine, no further.'\nDoctors had feared the disease might have spread when 4000 of the miners left\nZobia and disappeared into the bush 2 weeks ago, fleeing the disease and\nclashes involving various factions of the security forces guarding the mining\narea.\nPneumonic plague infects victims' lungs, can be easily transmitted between\npeople, and kills within 48 hours if not treated immediately, doctors say.\nAid agencies and government health officials have scoured the bush for\ninfected miners who may have fled Zobia but say they have found none so far.\nInitial reports suggested that 61 people had died in the outbreak. Bertherat\nsaid all the recorded deaths are being re-examined by the teams on the ground\nnow to reconfirm the causes of those deaths. 'Although we are finding more\ncases in Zobia, it seems that, overall, there are fewer cases than the 400 we\noriginally thought there were,' he said. 'We are also trying to change the\nway that people deal with their dead. The local custom here is for the body\nto be washed and dressed, but this is very dangerous as the plague is so\ncontagious,' he said.\nCongo is struggling to recover from a 5-year war and decades of chaos which\nleft its health system in tatters. The conflict in the former Zaire was\nofficially declared over in 2003 but clashes still erupt, especially in the\neast.\n[Byline: David Lewis]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[In our previous post it was reported that MSF had discovered a new case in\nthe town of Buta after sending an emergency team of doctors to the area.\nThis town is substantially separated from Zobia. Now it seems possible that\nthe case was either unrelated to the Zobia cases or was not plague at all.\nEven if the infection is confined to the area, the continuing number of cases\nis of significant concern and demonstrates ongoing person-to-person\ntransmission. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n \nDoctors have found at least 60 new cases of plague in eastern Congo, but the\ndisease does not appear to be spreading beyond the mining town where it broke\nout, aid workers said on Mon, 28 Feb 2005. The conflict in the former Zaire was\nofficially declared over in 2003 but clashes still erupt, especially in the\neast.\n [Byline: David Lewis]\n--\nProMED-mail\n< Aid agency Medecins sans Frontieres (MSF) said it had registered new cases in\nthe town, which is in Congo's lawless Ituri district, where fighting over\nminerals has raged for years. Pneumonic plague, which is highly contagious, broke out 2 months ago in\nZobia, a town that was home to at least 7000 diamond miners, some 300 km (186\nmiles) north of the provincial capital Kisangani. Although we are finding more\ncases in Zobia, it seems that, overall, there are fewer cases than the 400 we\noriginally thought there were,' he said. Even if the infection is confined to the area, the continuing number of cases\nis of significant concern and demonstrates ongoing person-to-person\ntransmission. and disappeared into the bush 2 weeks ago, fleeing the disease and\nclashes involving various factions of the security forces guarding the mining\narea. Source: Reuters [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/LEW828191.htm>\n\nNew cases of Congo plague but appears contained\n The local custom here is for the body\nto be washed and dressed, but this is very dangerous as the plague is so\ncontagious,' he said. Bertherat\nsaid all the recorded deaths are being re-examined by the teams on the ground\nnow to reconfirm the causes of those deaths. ' We have registered 61 fresh cases, including a death,' Philippe Havet, MSF's\nemergency coordinator said on Mon, 28 Feb 2005. ' [In our previous post it was reported that MSF had discovered a new case in\nthe town of Buta after sending an emergency team of doctors to the area. Pneumonic plague infects victims' lungs, can be easily transmitted between\npeople, and kills within 48 hours if not treated immediately, doctors say. There were 15 new cases\nyesterday, but these people are limited to the mine, no further.' Now it seems possible that\nthe case was either unrelated to the Zobia cases or was not plague at all. There are still cases coming into Zobia, but these are restricted to the\nmining area. Aid agencies and government health officials have scoured the bush for\ninfected miners who may have fled Zobia but say they have found none so far. Doctors had feared the disease might have spread when 4000 of the miners left\n Congo is struggling to recover from a 5-year war and decades of chaos which\nleft its health system in tatters. It does not seem to have spread any further,' Eric Bertherat,\nhead of a WHO team, told Reuters by phone from Zobia. These figures are based on the\ncurrent situation and a retrospective analysis of cases. With the\nexception of 2 cases of the septicemic form of plague, all recorded\ncases are pneumonic plague.\n(see previous report\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2005_03_01/en/>)\nOut of 18 specimens tested, preliminary laboratory results from\nKisangani Provincial Laboratory confirm 10 positive specimens by\ndirect examination (sputum).\nContact tracing and follow-up of 125 contacts is continuing. The team is\nproviding support to the clinical management of cases in Zobia and Medecins\nsans Frontieres-Belgium are constructing 2 isolation centers. Social\nmobilization activities are taking place in surrounding areas.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The multidisciplinary team has reported a total of 57 cases (54\nsuspect cases, 3 probable cases), including 16 deaths in Zobia,\nBas-Uele district, Oriental province. With the\nexception of 2 cases of the septicemic form of plague, all recorded\ncases are pneumonic plague. The team is\nproviding support to the clinical management of cases in Zobia and Medecins\nsans Frontieres-Belgium are constructing 2 isolation centers. Out of 18 specimens tested, preliminary laboratory results from\nKisangani Provincial Laboratory confirm 10 positive specimens by\ndirect examination (sputum). Source: WHO Outbreak Reports [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2005_03_04/en/>\n\nPlague in the Democratic Republic of the Congo - update 2\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "Congo", "country": "Congo Republic"}, {"location": "Zobia", "country": "Ivory Coast"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of the", "country": "DR Congo"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2207405", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, pneumonic - Congo DR (Ituri)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2207405", "date": "2005-02-18 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PNEUMONIC - CONGO DR (ITURI)\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1] Date: Fri, 18 Feb 2005\nFrom: Marianne Hopp <mjhopp12@yahoo.com>\nSource: WHO Outbreak Reports 18 Feb 2005 [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2005_02_18/en/>\n\nPlague in the Democratic Republic of the Congo\n----------------------------------------------\nAs of Tue, 15 Feb 2005, WHO has received reports of 61 deaths from pneumonic\nplague in the district of Ituri, Oriental province, in the northern part of\nthe country. The total number of cases is still not known. [Note this was\nposted to the WHO website on 18 Feb 2005. - Mod.JW]\nPreliminary results from rapid diagnostic tests in the area confirm\npneumonic plague, and the cases had clinical features compatible with\nthis disease. 40 samples have been taken and will be tested by\nculture and serology at the Institut de la Recherche Biomedicale,\nKinshasa [Congo Rep.]. No cases of bubonic plague have been reported to date.\nThe cases have occurred in workers in a diamond mine in Zobia where\nabout 7000 people work. The mine was re-opened on 16 Dec 2004 and the\n1st case occurred on 20 Dec 2004.\nA team from Medecins sans Frontieres (Belgium and Switzerland),\nMedair, WHO and Ministry of Health have been in the area to assess\nthe situation. An additional multi-disciplinary team will be leaving\nfor the Democratic Republic of the Congo on 19 Feb 2005.\nIf humanitarian access is possible given the security concerns in the\narea, the team will go to the affected area to provide technical\nsupport in case management and treatment of cases, intensive\nsurveillance and tracing of possible contacts and further\nepidemiological investigations.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n*****\n[2]Date: Fri, 18 Feb 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Reuters Health 18 Feb2005\n\n\nWHO: Thousands flee as plague kills 61 in Congo\n-----------------------------------------------\nAn outbreak of plague in northeastern Democratic Republic of Congo has killed\n61 diamond miners and infected hundreds more, the World Health Organization\n(WHO) said Friday [18 Feb 2005].\nMany of the 7000 miners working in Zobia, north of the city of Kisangani,\nhave fled since the outbreak began 2 months ago, and could have spread the\nhighly contagious disease, the United Nations agency said. 'The\nepidemiological data is still incomplete but we are sure there are at least\n61 deaths. The main problem is that due to panic, maybe two thirds of the\npopulation, ran away from the mine,' Eric Bertherat, head of the WHO team,\ntold reporters. 'There is a risk that some patients in [the] incubation\n[period] run away and maybe arrive in Kisangani. So it is very important to\ninform health care workers to alert them of the risk of admission of highly\ncontagious patients,' he said.\nKisangani is Congo's 3rd biggest city and a major trading center on the Congo\nRiver.\nPlague, which is spread between rodents by fleas, can also be transmitted to\npeople through infected rodent flea bites. It has a case-fatality rate of 50%\nto 60% in humans if not treated with antibiotics, WHO says. There are 3 main\nforms of plague in humans and the one suspected in the former Zaire is\npneumonic plague, WHO said. 'It is very important to quarantine, isolate\nthese people who are sick with pneumonic plague so that the transmission is\nbrought under control. If we can find the cases and treat them effectively,\nthis can be stopped,' said May Chu, a WHO expert.\nA 10-member WHO emergency team was leaving at the weekend with supplies of\nantibiotics to try to stem the outbreak and ensure that health workers in the\nregion isolate suspect cases. But the remote mine in mineral-rich Ituri,\nreportedly controlled by rebels, is difficult to reach and the team will\nrequire U.N. security clearances, officials said.\nCases are still occurring in the mine, where conditions are crowded and\nunsanitary, and 20 workers were admitted to health facilities in Zobia with\nsymptoms Wednesday [16 Feb 2005], he added. The diagnosis of plague had been\nverified through testing, WHO spokesman Dick Thompson said.\n[By Stephanie Nebehay]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[As implied in the posting, the epidemic curve and analysis are\nneeded to discover the potential cause of the outbreak. Cases have\napparently been reported over almost 2 months, so it is likely that\nseveral generations of primary pulmonary plague have occurred,\nassuming the diagnosis is correct.\nPrimary pneumonic plague (1 percent of natural plague presentations)\narises as a result of inhalation of plague bacilli in infectious\naerosols, such as would be produced when there are pneumonic\ncomplications in bubonic plague. It is also the form of disease\ncontracted from infected cats. This is, importantly, the form of the\ndisease that would be most likely if _Yersinia pestis_ were to be\nused in an aerosol as a biological weapon. Such an aerosol would\nlikely be used in an indoor setting to avoid the outdoor UV radiation\ninactivation of the organism.\nPrimary plague pneumonia has a short incubation period of 1-3 days,\nafter which there is sudden onset of flu-like symptoms including\nfever, chills, headache, generalized body pains, weakness and chest\ndiscomfort. A cough develops with sputum production, which may be\nbloody, and increasing chest pain and difficulty in breathing. As the\ndisease progresses, hypoxia (low oxygen concentration in the blood)\nand hemoptysis (coughing up blood) are prominent. The disease is\ninvariably fatal unless antimicrobial therapy commences within 24\nhours of exposure.\nPatients with primary pneumonic plague generate large quantities of\ninfectious aerosols that pose a significant risk to close contacts.\nCDC guidelines identify contacts within 2 meters as being at greatest\nrisk and do not consider the organism likely to be carried through\nair ducts or vents. Persons who have been in contact with pneumonic\nplague patients or handling potentially infectious body fluids or\ntissues without appropriate protection should receive preventive\nantimicrobial therapy. The preferred antimicrobial agents for\nprophylaxis are tetracyclines, quinolones, or chloramphenicol. -\nMod.LL]", "summary": "If humanitarian access is possible given the security concerns in the\narea, the team will go to the affected area to provide technical\nsupport in case management and treatment of cases, intensive\nsurveillance and tracing of possible contacts and further\nepidemiological investigations.\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Primary pneumonic plague (1 percent of natural plague presentations)\narises as a result of inhalation of plague bacilli in infectious\naerosols, such as would be produced when there are pneumonic\ncomplications in bubonic plague. JW]\nPreliminary results from rapid diagnostic tests in the area confirm\npneumonic plague, and the cases had clinical features compatible with\nthis disease. Primary plague pneumonia has a short incubation period of 1-3 days,\nafter which there is sudden onset of flu-like symptoms including\nfever, chills, headache, generalized body pains, weakness and chest\ndiscomfort. Cases have\napparently been reported over almost 2 months, so it is likely that\nseveral generations of primary pulmonary plague have occurred,\nassuming the diagnosis is correct. Persons who have been in contact with pneumonic\nplague patients or handling potentially infectious body fluids or\ntissues without appropriate protection should receive preventive\nantimicrobial therapy. ' This is, importantly, the form of the\ndisease that would be most likely if _Yersinia pestis_ were to be\nused in an aerosol as a biological weapon.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2004-12-25 00:00:00", "2005-02-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2005-02-16 00:00:00", "2004-12-16 00:00:00", "2005-02-15 00:00:00", "2005-02-18 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kisangani", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of the", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Congo", "country": "Congo Republic"}, {"location": "Democratic Republic of Congo", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "Zobia", "country": "Ivory Coast"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "Switzerland"}, {"location": "Zaire", "country": "Angola"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2206848", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, tularemia, rodents, human - USA (CO)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2206848", "date": "2004-11-10 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, TULAREMIA, RODENTS, HUMANS - USA (COLORADO)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 9 Nov 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: The Rocky Mountain Collegian 9 Nov 2004 [edited]\n<http://www.collegian.com/vnews/display.v/ART/2004/11/09/419067c0089df>\n\nHealth officials find dead animals infected with the plague\n-------------------------------------\nLocal health officials have found evidence that the plague and tularemia\nhave been found in dead animals and pets and are alerting the public to use\npreventative measures to avoid the diseases.\n2 pet cats have been diagnosed with the plague [caused by the\nbacterium _Yersinia pestis_] in the past 2 weeks, and a woman died from\nthe plague while visiting the Red Feather Lakes area in August 2004.\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention have jointly been working\nwith the Larimer County Department of Health and Environment in monitoring\nthe plague and other infectious diseases.\n'Plague has always been endemic to this area,' said LeeAnn Kempton, an\nenvironmental specialist at the health and environment department.\nSo far, 4 feline plague cases have been reported this year. In 1999, a\nwoman died from the plague in the same area that this year's human case\noccurred.\nAnn Watson, public information specialist with the health and environment\ndepartment, said it is rare to find humans infected with the plague and\nsaid those people that are infected come from contact with their pets.\n'Most of our human cases come from cats. We have had so few cases it is\nhard to make generalizations,' Watson said.\nCats and other animals can be infected with the plague when they kill and\neat infected rodents that are riddled with infected fleas. From that point,\npets can transmit the disease to humans through bites, scratches or\ndroplets from their coughs. The bacteria can also be transmitted via the\ninfected fleas themselves, which pets can also bring into domesticated areas.\nBubonic plague, the more common form of the plague, occurs when extreme\npain and swelling of the lymph nodes strikes a victim. The groin and armpit\nregion are the most common fleabite locations in humans, according to a\npress release from the health and environment department. The bubonic\nplague is not transmitted person-to-person, but it can spread to the lungs\nto form pneumonic plague, and the victim's close contacts can be infected.\nThough the plague may be rare in humans, rodent populations carry it often,\nsuch as in mice or rats, Kempton said.\nRecently, another bacterium, [_Francisella tularensis, the cause of ]\ntularemia, has been traced in Larimer County in a dead beaver and mouse. A\nman from Loveland was struck with pneumonia caused by tularemia in August.\nTularemia is another rare occurrence in Larimer County and infects humans\nwho handle infected animals such as rodents or rabbits or humans who are\nbit by infected insects, especially ticks and deer flies. Tularemia is a\nbacterial disease that can affect humans or animals from insects that have\nthe disease.\nHealth officials say to take precautions to prevent infections from these\ndiseases. Using insect repellents, avoiding sick or dead rodents, keeping\npets leashed while camping or hiking, and keeping close attention to a\npet's health are all preventative measures.\nAdrienne LeBaily, the county's heath department director, said, 'Although\nthese bacteria are potential bioterror agents, we are convinced that these\nhuman cases were naturally occurring.'\n[Byline: James Baetke]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org\n[Prairie dogs are often considered the most sensitive sentinel to plague.\nGenerally monitoring prairie dog activity can give one a clue as to when\nthe rodent cycle of plague may be spilling over into other\npopulations. Cats may be one of our most sensitive domestic sentinels.\nPlague generally has 2 forms: pneumonic and bubonic. Pneumonic form can\nspread between people if the contact is relatively close.\nWhile fleas carry plague, ticks carry tularemia.\nTularemia may be acquired from ticks, or from handling an infected carcass,\nfrom inhalation of the bacteria, and from consumption of contaminated food\nor water. Tularemia is not known to spread from person to person.\nBoth of these bacterial diseases can be treated, in pets as well as in\nhuman beings. - Mod.TG]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The bubonic\nplague is not transmitted person-to-person, but it can spread to the lungs\nto form pneumonic plague, and the victim's close contacts can be infected.\n \n2 pet cats have been diagnosed with the plague [caused by the\nbacterium _Yersinia pestis_] in the past 2 weeks, and a woman died from\nthe plague while visiting the Red Feather Lakes area in August 2004. \nLocal health officials have found evidence that the plague and tularemia\nhave been found in dead animals and pets and are alerting the public to use\npreventative measures to avoid the diseases. Adrienne LeBaily, the county's heath department director, said, 'Although\nthese bacteria are potential bioterror agents, we are convinced that these\nhuman cases were naturally occurring.'\n Ann Watson, public information specialist with the health and environment\ndepartment, said it is rare to find humans infected with the plague and\nsaid those people that are infected come from contact with their pets. [Byline: James Baetke]\n--\nProMED-mail\n< Tularemia is another rare occurrence in Larimer County and infects humans\nwho handle infected animals such as rodents or rabbits or humans who are\nbit by infected insects, especially ticks and deer flies. Source: The Rocky Mountain Collegian 9 Nov 2004 [edited]\n<http://www.collegian.com/vnews/display.v/ART/2004/11/09/419067c0089df>\n\nHealth officials find dead animals infected with the plague\n The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention have jointly been working\nwith the Larimer County Department of Health and Environment in monitoring\nthe plague and other infectious diseases. Using insect repellents, avoiding sick or dead rodents, keeping\npets leashed while camping or hiking, and keeping close attention to a\npet's health are all preventative measures. In 1999, a\nwoman died from the plague in the same area that this year's human case\noccurred. Generally monitoring prairie dog activity can give one a clue as to when\nthe rodent cycle of plague may be spilling over into other\npopulations. Tularemia may be acquired from ticks, or from handling an infected carcass,\nfrom inhalation of the bacteria, and from consumption of contaminated food\nor water. The groin and armpit\nregion are the most common fleabite locations in humans, according to a\npress release from the health and environment department. Tularemia is a\nbacterial disease that can affect humans or animals from insects that have\nthe disease. From that point,\npets can transmit the disease to humans through bites, scratches or\ndroplets from their coughs. Cats and other animals can be infected with the plague when they kill and\neat infected rodents that are riddled with infected fleas. Bubonic plague, the more common form of the plague, occurs when extreme\npain and swelling of the lymph nodes strikes a victim. Though the plague may be rare in humans, rodent populations carry it often,\nsuch as in mice or rats, Kempton said. Plague has always been endemic to this area,' said LeeAnn Kempton, an\nenvironmental specialist at the health and environment department. PLAGUE, TULAREMIA, RODENTS, HUMANS - USA (COLORADO)\n The bacteria can also be transmitted via the\ninfected fleas themselves, which pets can also bring into domesticated areas. Both of these bacterial diseases can be treated, in pets as well as in\nhuman beings. Recently, another bacterium, [_Francisella tularensis, the cause of ]\ntularemia, has been traced in Larimer County in a dead beaver and mouse. Pneumonic form can\nspread between people if the contact is relatively close. Health officials say to take precautions to prevent infections from these\ndiseases. We have had so few cases it is\nhard to make generalizations,' Watson said. A\nman from Loveland was struck with pneumonia caused by tularemia in August. Date: 9 Nov 2004\n promed@promedmail.org\n **\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague", "tularemia"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1999-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-08-25 00:00:00", "2004-08-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Larimer County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Loveland", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2207423", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, pneumonic - Congo DR (02): (North East)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2207423", "date": "2005-02-23 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PNEUMONIC - CONGO DR (02): (NORTH EAST)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Tue, 22 Feb 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: IRIN News [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/IRIN/75e240563dbff9b075ec88a00f310b47.htm>\n\nDRC: pneumonic plague kills 43\n------------------------------\nSome 43 people have died and 13 others [been] infected following an\noutbreak of pneumonic plague in the mining area of Zobia, in the region of\nBas-Uele in Oriental Province, eastern Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC),\nan official in the Ministry of Health told IRIN on Mon 21 Feb 2005.\nThe ministry's director of epidemiology, Dr Benoit Kebele Ilunga, said the\nepidemic showed up 3 weeks ago in one of the mines in the diamond rich\narea. He said the 13 infected survivors had responded well to antibiotics.\nSamples from the infected people analysed at the Bio Medical Research\nInstitute in the capital, Kinshasa, confirmed the plague.\nA medical team comprised of representatives from the NGO Doctors Without\nBorders [presumably Medecins sans Frontieres! - Mod.SH], Medair, the World\nHealth Organization, and the Ministry of Health had assessed the situation\nin the area, Ilunga said. Another team of experts, made up of specialists\nfrom the WHO in Geneva and its African offices, and from the Pasteur\nInstitute in Madagascar, also conducted further studies at the site of the\nepidemic.\n'The epidemic of pneumonic plague is well confirmed in this area,' Dr\nJean-Marie Yanehogo, in charge of epidemics at WHO, said. 'The WHO sent a\nresearch team to gather all available evidence.'\nA major challenge for health officials in DRC that remains is how to\ncontain the epidemic. Kebele said the major difficulty was to find all the\npeople who may have contracted the infection and who may have left the\nZobia mine while the disease was still in its incubation period. 'They\n[people] may develop the disease in another mine, and so, propagate the\nepidemic,' Kebele said.\nSome 7000 miners live in Zobia. Medical officials are now looking for 2000\nof them who worked in Zobia when the epidemic broke out. The mine was\nclosed in 2004 when several cases of plague were detected. However, the\nmine was reopened on 14 Dec 2004, but only a week later, new cases of the\nplague reappeared.\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed, 23 Feb 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: BBC News [edited]\n<http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/4290783.stm>\n\nDR Congo plague outbreak spreads\n--------------------------------\nAn outbreak of what tests suggest is pneumonic plague has spread to a 2nd\ntown in the Democratic Republic of Congo, according to a medical charity.\nMedecins Sans Frontieres (MSF) says it believes it has found a case in a\n2nd area in the north east.\nThousands have fled the remote diamond mining town of Zobia since the\ndisease first emerged at the end of 2004. At least 60 people have died so\nfar. The plague affects victims lungs and is fatal if left untreated.\n'People have been leaving Zobia. They were starting to panic - its\ncontagious,' MSF's Meike Steensens told BBC News from the city of\nKisangani. The outbreak began just 4 days after the diamond mine reopened\nnear Zobia, in Oriental province, north of the country's biggest city,\nKisangani, a major trading center on the Congo River. Those who have died\nare all diamond miners. Another 350 miners have been infected.\nMSF discovered the new case in the town of Buta after sending an emergency\nteam of doctors to the area. Final confirmation of the plague is expected\nnext week, MSF say, but initial tests indicate that they are dealing with\nan outbreak of pneumonic plague. An advance team of medical experts from\nthe WHO has already visited the area to confirm that people are infected\nwith the plague.\nAround 7 000 people worked at the mine. The WHO team will focus on trying\nto trace the 2 000 who have left since the start of the outbreak. Bubonic\nplague is endemic in parts of Africa, including the DR Congo, but pneumonic\nplague, which occurs when bacteria infect the lung, has a very high\nfatality rate and is 'invariably' deadly when left untreated, WHO said.\nHumans are generally infected with plague by rodents and fleas, but the\npneumonic form of the disease can also be transmitted from person to person\nthrough respiratory droplets.\n******\n[3]\nDate: Wed, 23 Feb 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: IRIN news [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/IRIN/e228350e00ccd9a2f1d376d5a80e99dc.htm>\n\nMSF has sent 2 teams to an area in northeastern Democratic Republic of\nCongo (DRC) where an outbreak of pneumonic plague had been reported. In a\nstatement issued in Nairobi on Tue 22 Feb 2005, MSF said an exploratory\nmission from 14-16 Feb 2005 found 93 cases of the disease in the Dingila\nhealth zone, which includes Zonia, Kana and Mambenge, all in north eastern\nOrientale Province.\nReports indicated that the epicentre of the outbreak was in the town of\nZobia, around 190 km from the town of Buta, MSF said. 'One MSF team will\nfocus on Zobia, while the 2nd will follow the main routes,' it said. 'This\n2nd team will identify and treat those that have recently fled Zobia due to\nviolence and fear of contracting plague.'\nMSF said the disease was a form of plague, which primarily attacks the\nlungs. 'While it is endemic to this region of the DRC, the current outbreak\nis unusual in the number of people affected,' MSF reported.\nPlague is caused by the _Yersinia pestis_ bacterium and primarily affects\nwild animals such as rats, Alain Decoux, the head of mission for MSF in the\nDRC, was quoted as saying. He added: 'Since transmission to humans often\noccurs due to bites from infected fleas, a commonly held belief is that the\nway to stop the spread is to exterminate the rat population. In fact, this\nworsens the situation as it deprives the fleas of their blood supply, which\nmeans that they are more likely to seek out alternatives such as humans.'\nMSF said plague could easily be cured through a course of antibiotics,\nprovided that the patient was found in time. However, the organization\nsaid, breaking the chain of transmission is difficult as sufferers of\npneumonic plague need to be strictly isolated during the period of their\nillness. 'Doing so in severely underdeveloped areas, such as around Buta,\nis a major challenge,' Decoux said. He said the nature of the region\naffected made the work of MSF much more difficult. 'The fact that Zobia is\na diamond producing area results in a high level of insecurity,' he said.\n'Clashes between forces in the area coming as recently as 14 Feb 2005\naffect the MSF teams, as well as causing the population to scatter widely.\nThe result is that plague sufferers are hard to identify in time.'\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The exact number of deaths from pneumonic plague, which in its primary\nform is spread from person to person without the need for infected rodents\nor fleas, in the outbreak is either 43 or 60 based on these reports. It is\ndisconcerting that at least 1 case has arisen (or carried) to another town.\nProMED awaits further word on the scope of the outbreak and new areas of\ninvolvement. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Some 43 people have died and 13 others [been] infected following an\noutbreak of pneumonic plague in the mining area of Zobia, in the region of\nBas-Uele in Oriental Province, eastern Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC),\nan official in the Ministry of Health told IRIN on Mon 21 Feb 2005. Bubonic\nplague is endemic in parts of Africa, including the DR Congo, but pneumonic\nplague, which occurs when bacteria infect the lung, has a very high\nfatality rate and is 'invariably' deadly when left untreated, WHO said. Humans are generally infected with plague by rodents and fleas, but the\npneumonic form of the disease can also be transmitted from person to person\nthrough respiratory droplets.\n However, the organization\nsaid, breaking the chain of transmission is difficult as sufferers of\npneumonic plague need to be strictly isolated during the period of their\nillness. ' In a\nstatement issued in Nairobi on Tue 22 Feb 2005, MSF said an exploratory\nmission from 14-16 Feb 2005 found 93 cases of the disease in the Dingila\nhealth zone, which includes Zonia, Kana and Mambenge, all in north eastern Another team of experts, made up of specialists\nfrom the WHO in Geneva and its African offices, and from the Pasteur\nInstitute in Madagascar, also conducted further studies at the site of the\nepidemic. \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n [The exact number of deaths from pneumonic plague, which in its primary\nform is spread from person to person without the need for infected rodents\nor fleas, in the outbreak is either 43 or 60 based on these reports. Final confirmation of the plague is expected\nnext week, MSF say, but initial tests indicate that they are dealing with\nan outbreak of pneumonic plague. An advance team of medical experts from\nthe WHO has already visited the area to confirm that people are infected\nwith the plague. \nAn outbreak of what tests suggest is pneumonic plague has spread to a 2nd\ntown in the Democratic Republic of Congo, according to a medical charity. \nMSF said the disease was a form of plague, which primarily attacks the\nlungs. ' \nMSF said plague could easily be cured through a course of antibiotics,\nprovided that the patient was found in time. The ministry's director of epidemiology, Dr Benoit Kebele Ilunga, said the\nepidemic showed up 3 weeks ago in one of the mines in the diamond rich\narea. Kebele said the major difficulty was to find all the\npeople who may have contracted the infection and who may have left the\nZobia mine while the disease was still in its incubation period. ' This\n2nd team will identify and treat those that have recently fled Zobia due to\nviolence and fear of contracting plague.' PLAGUE, PNEUMONIC - CONGO DR (02): (NORTH EAST)\n***********************************************\n Plague is caused by the _Yersinia pestis_ bacterium and primarily affects\nwild animals such as rats, Alain Decoux, the head of mission for MSF in the\nDRC, was quoted as saying.
