'", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2005-02-22 00:00:00", "2005-02-23 00:00:00", "2014-02-16 20:05:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-12-14 00:00:00", "2005-02-14 00:00:00", "2005-02-21 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "eastern Democratic Republic of Congo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oriental Province", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "Kinshasa", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of Congo", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "Nairobi", "country": "Kenya"}, {"location": "Madagascar", "country": "Madagascar"}, {"location": "Zonia", "country": "Mali"}, {"location": "Democratic Republic of", "country": "Yemen"}, {"location": "Geneva", "country": "Switzerland"}, {"location": "Zobia", "country": "Ivory Coast"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2207380", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, camels - Uzbekistan, Kazakhstan, Turkmenistan:susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2207380", "date": "2005-02-12 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, CAMELS - UZBEKISTAN, KAZAKHSTAN, TURKMENISTAN: SUSPECTED\n****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Sat,12 Feb 2005\nFrom: ProMED-mail Corresp. Natalia Pchenitchnaia <crane@aaanet.ru>\nSource: Iran News agency, Russian page, 11 Feb 2005 [translated & edited]\n<http://iran.ru/rus/print_news.php?news_id=27585>\n\nCases of a camel plague: Uzbekistan, Kazakhstan, Turkmenistan\n---------------------------------------------------\nCases of camel plague have been recorded in Uzbekistan, Kazakhstan\nand Turkmenistan, says Dr Zahtab, Chief of the Central Veterinary\nDirectorate in the Iranian province Gulistan. Gulistan shares a\nborder with Turkmenistan, hence the decision to apply preventive\nmeasures against the introduction of camel plague. This includes\npatrols of veterinary teams along the province's frontiers and\nsurveillance activities.\nSo far, no symptoms of camel plague have been detected. Up to now,\n5000 camels have been registered in the frontier areas of Gulistan.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The use of the term Camel plague, as a specific camel-related\ndisease entity, might be misleading and confused with Cattle plague\n(rinderpest). The issue is the potential spread of plague, caused by\n_Yersinia pestis_, to humans.\nOf the domestic animals, cattle, horses, sheep and pigs are not known\nto develop plague. Goats and camels have reportedly developed\nclinical illness, and there have been several human outbreaks of\nplague attributable to ingestion of camel meat infected with\n_Yersinia pestis_ in Middle Eastern and Central Asian countries (see\nreferences).\nFurther reading:\nOrlovsky K.A. & Lathropp S.L.(2003). Zoonoses update - Plague: a\nveterinary perspective. JAVMA 222,4, 444 - 448.\nAikimbajev A, Meka-Mechenko T, Temiralieva G, Bekenov J, Sagiyev Z,\nKaljan K, Mukhambetova AK (2003). Plague in Kazakhstan at the present\ntime. Przegl Epidemiol. 57(4):593-598.\n- Mod.AS]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Goats and camels have reportedly developed\nclinical illness, and there have been several human outbreaks of\nplague attributable to ingestion of camel meat infected with\n_ This includes\npatrols of veterinary teams along the province's frontiers and\nsurveillance activities.\n [The use of the term Camel plague, as a specific camel-related\ndisease entity, might be misleading and confused with Cattle plague\n(rinderpest). Gulistan shares a\nborder with Turkmenistan, hence the decision to apply preventive\nmeasures against the introduction of camel plague. Cases of camel plague have been recorded in Uzbekistan, Kazakhstan\nand Turkmenistan, says Dr Zahtab, Chief of the Central Veterinary\nDirectorate in the Iranian province Gulistan. PLAGUE, CAMELS - UZBEKISTAN, KAZAKHSTAN, TURKMENISTAN: SUSPECTED\n****************************************************************\n Up to now,\n5000 camels have been registered in the frontier areas of Gulistan.\n --\nProMED-mail\n<", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2005-02-11 00:00:00", "2005-02-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "Kazakhstan"}, {"location": "Camel", "country": "Antarctica"}, {"location": "Turkmenistan", "country": "Turkmenistan"}, {"location": "Uzbekistan", "country": "Uzbekistan"}, {"location": "Gulistan", "country": "Uzbekistan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2207021", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, human, fatal - USA (CO)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2207021", "date": "2004-12-14 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, HUMAN, FATAL - USA (COLORADO)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Sat 11 Dec 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Pueblo Chieftain (CO) [edited]\n<http://www.chieftain.com/metro/1102799203/2>\n\nPueblo man reportedly dies of plague\n-------------------------------------\nA 66-year-old Pueblo man died this week from bubonic plague, the Pueblo\nCity/County Health Department announced on Fri 10 Dec 2004.\nThe man reportedly died Wed 8 Dec 2004 in a local hospital after being\ninfected while rabbit hunting recently in Park County. According to the\nvictim's son, his father was hunting near Breckenridge. He was hospitalized\non Mon 6 Dec 2004.\nLocal health department Director Chris Nevin-Woods said the man had an open\nwound on one of his hands and probably was exposed while skinning an\ninfected rabbit that he had shot. She said more testing will be done on the\nrabbit for plague.\nThe case was the 1st plague-related death in Colorado since 1999 and the\nstate's 3rd case in 2004. Since the 1st human case was reported in 1957,\nColorado has reported 50 cases with 8 fatalities. The state averages 2\ncases per year.\nIn Colorado, plague-infected animals are most likely to be found in the\nfoothills and mountains. Most human cases occur in the summer and early\nfall months.\nJohn Pape, an epidemiologist who specializes in animal-related diseases\nwith the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment's Disease\nControl and Environmental Epidemiology Division, explained: 'When a rodent\nbecomes infected, the bacteria circulates in the blood. Fleas are infected\nwhile feeding on the animal and can transmit the infection to other\nwarm-blooded animals, including humans. People also can be exposed through\ncontact with blood from infected animals.\n'Plague is found throughout Colorado and cycles from year to year,' Pape\nsaid. 'This summer, we saw an increase in plague activity around the state,\nincluding 20 cats, which are highly susceptible to the disease.'\nAlthough plague is a serious illness, it can be readily treated with common\nantibiotics if recognized early. People will have a very sudden onset of\nhigh fever, fatigue and weakness, and a painful, swollen lymph node. The\nswollen lymph node is usually under the armpit, in the groin area, or in\nthe neck.\nPape said that people can greatly reduce their risk of becoming infected\nwith plague by taking a few simple precautions, including avoiding contact\nwith sick rodents and rabbits. Hunters should use gloves when cleaning and\ndressing rabbits and other game to avoid blood exposure. 'Do not feed\nrodents in picnic or campground areas, and never handle sick or dead\nrodents. Leave your pets at home when visiting rural areas,' Pape advised.\nState and local health officials regularly monitor plague-prone areas. If\nsick and dying rodents or other evidence of plague are observed, and a high\nrisk of transmission to humans is determined, affected areas may be\ntemporarily closed to protect the public and to implement control measures.\nIn recent years, Pueblo County bubonic plague outbreaks occurred in 2001\nnear Lake Pueblo and the southern edge of Pueblo West and, in 1998, near\nSouth Park Elementary School, according to Chieftain reports. Officials\nwere alerted when prairie dog colony die-offs were reported.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Fleas become infected upon feeding on the blood of a rodent suffering from\nbacteremic infection. The bacteria are restricted to the alimentary tract\nof the flea, where they multiply in the midgut. The bacteria form large\nbrown clumps that extend throughout the midgut, esophagus and\nproventriculus, a valve-like chamber situated between the esophagus and the\nmidgut. The clumps increase in mass over a few days until the\nproventriculus is blocked.\nThe 'blocked' flea then feeds on blood, but the meal is unable to pass into\nthe stomach. The flea continues to attempt to feed, but as it futilely\nsucks blood from the host, the blood meal, mixed with bacteria from the\nforegut, is regurgitated into the mammal. As many as 24 000 bacilli may be\ntransmitted in a single attempted feeding (1).\nBlockage of the flea, and thus efficient transmission of bacteria, has been\nshown to be dependent on the _Y. pestis_ hemin storage locus (hms) (2).\nAlthough originally identified as being responsible for binding and storage\nof hemin (and Congo Red) in the outer membrane, the hms (+) phenotype\nappears to be required for the hydrophobic surface properties of the\nbacteria. _Y. pestis_ hms mutants are hydrophilic, not autoaggregating in\naqueous environments. The mutants are unable to colonize the proventriculus\nand produce blockage, although they do colonize the midgut and produce the\nlarge pigmented masses. Proventriculus blockage is temperature dependent\nwith temperature more than 30 C preventing the obstruction. The effect is\nnot due to differences in hms protein expression but rather\nposttranslational stability (3). Since one hms protein possesses enzyme\nactivity similar to enzymes vital to the production of polysaccharides for\nbiofilms, it is possible that biofilm, rather than the hms proteins\ndirectly, is responsible for the blockage (3).\n1. Burroughs, AL: Sylvatic plague studies. The vector efficiency of nine\nspecies of plague compared with _Xenopsylla cheopis_. J Hyg 1947;45:371-96.\n2. Cavanaugh, DC: Specific effect of temperature upon transmission of the\nplague bacillus by the oriental rat flea _Xenopsylla cheopis_. Am J Trop\nMed Hyg 1971;20:264-72.\n3. Perry, RD, Bobrov, AG, Kirillina, O, et al Temperature regulation of the\nhemin storage (hms+) phenotype of _Yersinia pestis_ is postranscriptional.\nJ Bacteriol 2004;186:1638-47. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n If\nsick and dying rodents or other evidence of plague are observed, and a high\nrisk of transmission to humans is determined, affected areas may be\ntemporarily closed to protect the public and to implement control measures.\n John Pape, an epidemiologist who specializes in animal-related diseases\nwith the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment's Disease\nControl and Environmental Epidemiology Division, explained: 'When a rodent\nbecomes infected, the bacteria circulates in the blood. Since one hms protein possesses enzyme\nactivity similar to enzymes vital to the production of polysaccharides for\nbiofilms, it is possible that biofilm, rather than the hms proteins\ndirectly, is responsible for the blockage (3). The bacteria form large\nbrown clumps that extend throughout the midgut, esophagus and\nproventriculus, a valve-like chamber situated between the esophagus and the\nmidgut. Although originally identified as being responsible for binding and storage\nof hemin (and Congo Red) in the outer membrane, the hms (+) phenotype\nappears to be required for the hydrophobic surface properties of the\nbacteria. \nLocal health department Director Chris Nevin-Woods said the man had an open\nwound on one of his hands and probably was exposed while skinning an\ninfected rabbit that he had shot. >\nSource: Pueblo Chieftain (CO) [edited]\n<http://www.chieftain.com/metro/1102799203/2>\n\nPueblo man reportedly dies of plague\n \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n Pape said that people can greatly reduce their risk of becoming infected\nwith plague by taking a few simple precautions, including avoiding contact\nwith sick rodents and rabbits. The flea continues to attempt to feed, but as it futilely\nsucks blood from the host, the blood meal, mixed with bacteria from the\nforegut, is regurgitated into the mammal. In recent years, Pueblo County bubonic plague outbreaks occurred in 2001\nnear Lake Pueblo and the southern edge of Pueblo West and, in 1998, near\nSouth Park Elementary School, according to Chieftain reports. Fleas are infected\nwhile feeding on the animal and can transmit the infection to other\nwarm-blooded animals, including humans. The mutants are unable to colonize the proventriculus\nand produce blockage, although they do colonize the midgut and produce the\nlarge pigmented masses. Do not feed\nrodents in picnic or campground areas, and never handle sick or dead\nrodents. The effect is\nnot due to differences in hms protein expression but rather\nposttranslational stability (3). PLAGUE, HUMAN, FATAL - USA (COLORADO)\n***************************************\n The\nswollen lymph node is usually under the armpit, in the groin area, or in\nthe neck. Blockage of the flea, and thus efficient transmission of bacteria, has been\nshown to be dependent on the _Y. pestis_ hemin storage locus (hms) (2). A 66-year-old Pueblo man died this week from bubonic plague, the Pueblo\nCity/County Health Department announced on Fri 10 Dec 2004. The case was the 1st plague-related death in Colorado since 1999 and the\nstate's 3rd case in 2004. The man reportedly died Wed 8 Dec 2004 in a local hospital after being\ninfected while rabbit hunting recently in Park County.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1999-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00", "1957-03-25 00:00:00", "1998-03-25 00:00:00", "2001-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-12-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kirillina", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Pueblo County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Breckenridge", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Cavanaugh", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Park County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "dc", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2206755", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, squirrels - USA (CO) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2206755", "date": "2004-10-22 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, SQUIRRELS - USA (COLORADO) (02)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu, 21 Oct 2004 18:13:07 -0600\nFrom: Jim Thurman <jimthurman@att.net>\n\n\nIn the above referenced post (20041021.2851), the only city mentioned is\nDenver. Although the television station from which the article originated\nis in Denver, the actual incident occurred in Colorado Springs, El Paso\nCounty, Colorado about 60 miles South of Denver.\n\n--\nJim Thurman\nCentennial, Colorado USA\n<jimthurman@att.net>\n\n[Our thanks to Jim for this correction. Jim Thurman\nCentennial, Colorado USA\n<jimthurman@att.net>\n\n[Our thanks to Jim for this correction. PLAGUE, SQUIRRELS - USA (COLORADO) (02)\n **\n From: Jim Thurman <jimthurman@att.net>\n\n\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2004-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "El Paso", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Colorado Springs", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Denver", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2206757", "headline": "PRO/AH> Plague, squirrels - USA (CO)(03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2206757", "date": "2004-10-22 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, SQUIRRELS - USA (COLORADO) (03)\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 21 Oct 2004 5:00 PM\nFrom: Joseph Dudley jdudley@intellibridge.com\nSource: KKTV 11 News [edited]\n<http://www.kktv.com/home/headlines/1115316.html>\n\nPlague Detected in Colorado Springs\n--------------------------------\nThe El Paso County Department of Health and Environment has determined that\na tree squirrel has tested positive for plague in the Colorado Springs area.\nThe Health Department staff has been monitoring the situation for the past\n2 weeks in the western side of the city. The area affected is the South and\nWest border of Garden of the Gods, including the Northeast part of Manitou\nSprings.\nNow, Health Department staff are informing and educating residents within\nthe affected area. They are going door to door and handing out pamphlets\nthat contain information that cautions residents about plague. Health\nDepartment staff has also set up insecticide tubes that will aid in the\ncontrol of infected fleas on the local tree squirrel population.\nPlague is a bacterial disease of rodents transmitted to humans by the bite\nof an infected flea. In humans the symptoms are high fever, chills,\nheadache, severe prostration, and tender or swollen lymph glands. Health\nDepartment advises residents who experience these symptoms to contact their\nphysician.\nIn Colorado, the last reported human case was in a woman from Weld County,\nwho is fully recovered. In El Paso County, the last reported human case\noccurred in 1991.\nDon Mydlowski, the Health Department's program manger for animal diseases\nthat can be transmitted to humans, says 'Do not attempt to catch, kill,\nfeed or handle any type of squirrel, chipmunk or other wild rodent.. Keep\nyour dogs and cats under control and do not allow them to chase wild\nanimals. If you live in the affected area, keep cats indoors. Residents\nwithin the affected area should also clear property from trash, lumber\npiles, and other areas where animals my live or hide.'\nIf you find a dead squirrel in the affected area please contact the Health\nDepartment at 578-3199.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Joe, many thanks.\nIf you must pick up a dead squirrel, use an inverted plastic bag.\nFor those concerned, the clinical signs in cats include lethargy, anorexia,\nand high fever. All 3 forms -- bubonic, septicemic, and pneumonic --\nusually have all 3 of these signs, and the bubonic form has enlarged lymph\nnodes as well (buboes; lymphadenopathy; lymphadenitis), especially in the\nsubmandibular lymph nodes. Some of these may abscess. Both the bubonic and\nsepticemic forms may also become pneumonic in cats, and this increases the\nrisk of spread to humans. There may occasionally be oral lesions or\ncoughing. The following samples should be taken and forwarded to the\nrelevant diagnostic laboratory: Lymph node aspirate in sterile tube with\nsaline Whole blood (red top tube); if necropsy: liver, spleen, LN biopsy,\nlung (fresh and formalin). - Mod.MHJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n All 3 forms -- bubonic, septicemic, and pneumonic --\nusually have all 3 of these signs, and the bubonic form has enlarged lymph\nnodes as well (buboes; lymphadenopathy; lymphadenitis), especially in the\nsubmandibular lymph nodes. \nDon Mydlowski, the Health Department's program manger for animal diseases\nthat can be transmitted to humans, says 'Do not attempt to catch, kill,\nfeed or handle any type of squirrel, chipmunk or other wild rodent.. The following samples should be taken and forwarded to the\nrelevant diagnostic laboratory: Lymph node aspirate in sterile tube with\nsaline Whole blood (red top tube); if necropsy: liver, spleen, LN biopsy,\nlung (fresh and formalin). The area affected is the South and\nWest border of Garden of the Gods, including the Northeast part of Manitou\nSprings.\n Health\nDepartment advises residents who experience these symptoms to contact their\nphysician.\n \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n Residents\nwithin the affected area should also clear property from trash, lumber\npiles, and other areas where animals my live or hide.' Health\nDepartment staff has also set up insecticide tubes that will aid in the\ncontrol of infected fleas on the local tree squirrel population. Both the bubonic and\nsepticemic forms may also become pneumonic in cats, and this increases the\nrisk of spread to humans. \nThe El Paso County Department of Health and Environment has determined that\na tree squirrel has tested positive for plague in the Colorado Springs area. Keep\nyour dogs and cats under control and do not allow them to chase wild\nanimals.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1991-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "El Paso County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "LN", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Weld County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Colorado Springs", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2206749", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, squirrels - USA (CO)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2206749", "date": "2004-10-21 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, SQUIRRELS - USA (COLORADO)\n******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 21 Oct 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: CBS 4 Denver / AP [edited]\n<http://news4colorado.com/health/local_story_295114712.html>\n\nPlague has been confirmed in a squirrel on the city's west side, and health\nofficials launched a campaign to eradicate fleas that might transmit the\ndisease to humans.\nEl Paso County Health Department workers also distributed pamphlets on the\ndisease Tuesday to about 750 homes within a half-mile of the spot where the\ninfected squirrel was found.\nResidents began reporting dead squirrels in the area about 2 weeks ago,\nsaid Don Mydlowski, environmental quality manager for the health department.\nAfter tests confirmed plague, workers set out tubes that coat squirrels'\nfur with insecticide when they crawl through to get to a peanut butter bait.\nMydlowski suggested area residents keep cats indoors and check with\nveterinarians about flea control for dogs and cats.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[It's a bad year for plague. The archival reports listed below are merely a\nselection. There are a total of 59 US plague reports in the ProMED-mail\narchives. Wandering domestic cats are at measurable risk of acquiring this\ndisease in the affected states. - Mod.MHJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Source: CBS 4 Denver / AP [edited]\n<http://news4colorado.com/health/local_story_295114712.html>\n\nPlague has been confirmed in a squirrel on the city's west side, and health\nofficials launched a campaign to eradicate fleas that might transmit the\ndisease to humans. PLAGUE, SQUIRRELS - USA (COLORADO)\n Date: 21 Oct 2004\n promed@promedmail.org>\n **\n From: ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-30 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "US", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "El Paso County Health Department", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2206787", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, fatal - China (Qinghai)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2206787", "date": "2004-11-01 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, FATAL - CHINA (QINGHAI)\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 30 Oct 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: China Daily, 29 Oct 2004 [edited]\n<http://www.chinadaily.com.cn>\n\nFatal plague in Qinghai brought under control\n-------------------------------------------\nAn outbreak of plague in Northwest China that killed 8 villagers is\nreportedly under control. A total of 19 plague cases were reported across 4\ncounties in the central and eastern parts of Qinghai Province between 4-9\nOct 2004, said a Ministry of Health spokesman yesterday [28 Oct 2004]. No\noutbreaks have been detected in other areas, said the spokesman.\n8 people died, while the 11 who survived have all recovered, said a\ncircular issued by the provincial health bureau on Wednesday [27 Oct 2004].\nThe majority of the infected were farmers and herdsmen who caught the\ndisease after killing or eating wild marmots, said the circular. However,\nthe cause of several cases in Nangqen County is still under investigation.\nThe counties of Ulan, Huangyuan, and Madoi have lifted medical quarantine,\nand Nangqen is expected to come out of isolation soon, said the circular.\nAfter the outbreak, the Ministry of Health sent a work team to the affected\nareas to offer medical guidance, said the spokesman.\nThe Qinghai Provincial Health Bureau also took a series of measures to\ndistribute medicine, curb the spread of the disease, and strengthen\nsupervision on the marmot market. Marmots are related to gophers and\nprairie dogs. They usually live in the grasslands of China's northwestern\nregions and Mongolia, where villagers often hunt them for meat.\nLate in August 2004, the Ministry of Health reported 2 plague cases in\nQinghai and its neighboring Gansu Province. One person died.\nPlague is a somewhat general term that applies to a number of contagious,\noften fatal, bacterial diseases transmitted by fleas from infected rats and\nby contact with infected blood or tissue. The most common form, bubonic\nplague, can cause high fever, delirium, and swollen lymph nodes.\nThe ministry spokesman said some grass-roots medical workers do not have a\nfull awareness of the importance of plague prevention and control. He said\nthe ministry has ordered local health authorities to improve their plague\nmonitoring system and to draw up an emergency plan against plague outbreaks.\nCases of rats and marmots dying of plague, suspected plague patients, and\ncases of high-fever without a known reason must all be reported to the\nministry in time, said the spokesman.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Infection caused by _Yersinia pestis_ occurs when humans become accidental\nhosts in the normal cycle of transmission between rodents from the bite of\na flea. Humans may be infected by a flea bite or directly by contact with\nbody fluids of a rodent. The usual result is bubonic plague, which may\nprogress to bacteremia, occasionally with localization in the lungs and\npneumonia. Rarely, humans may directly infect each other, usually when one\nhas pneumonic plague. The mode of transmission in most of the cases in this\nreport was by direct contact with an infected rodent (marmot) - Mod.DK].", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Cases of rats and marmots dying of plague, suspected plague patients, and\ncases of high-fever without a known reason must all be reported to the\nministry in time, said the spokesman. A total of 19 plague cases were reported across 4\ncounties in the central and eastern parts of Qinghai Province between 4-9\nOct 2004, said a Ministry of Health spokesman yesterday [28 Oct 2004]. He said\nthe ministry has ordered local health authorities to improve their plague\nmonitoring system and to draw up an emergency plan against plague outbreaks. Plague is a somewhat general term that applies to a number of contagious,\noften fatal, bacterial diseases transmitted by fleas from infected rats and\nby contact with infected blood or tissue. \n8 people died, while the 11 who survived have all recovered, said a\ncircular issued by the provincial health bureau on Wednesday [27 Oct 2004]. Last week, a 54-year-old Weld\nCounty woman was hospitalized with the plague.\n'Plague activity, after a 4- to 5-year absence, is starting to make a\ncomeback,' said John Pape, a state health department epidemiologist.\nCats can transmit plague to people by scratching, biting or coughing. While\nthe plague has killed millions of people throughout history, it can be\ntreated with antibiotics if it is caught in time.\nIn Jefferson County, the cats diagnosed with the plague are free-roaming\noutdoor cats, said David Volkel, a Jefferson County environmental health\nspecialist.\nThe county health department issued an advisory on the finds last week.\nThe cats suddenly became lethargic, were taken to the veterinarian and were\ndiagnosed within the past several weeks, Volkel said. Although health\nofficials aren't sure how the cats caught the disease, typically cats will\ncontract it after being bitten by infected fleas, Volkel said.\nHe cautioned people to watch their outdoor cats for signs of illness, which\ninclude lethargy, a swollen neck, coughing and trouble breathing.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Plague is caused by _Yersenia pestis_ and transmitted most often by flea\nbites.\nWhen sylvatic outbreaks occur in rodent populations, domestic cats can be\ninfected by fleas on the rodents or by direct contact with infected rodent\ntissues -- as they chomp on squirrels or other rodents. The incubation\nperiod in cats may be short, a day or 2, and marked by a fever of up to\n41.5 C and lymphadenopathy. Typical buboes often occur in the head and\nneck, and can be mistaken for cat fight abscesses. Dogs are considered to\nbe less susceptible.\nThe report above mentions bubonic plague, which is of zoonotic concern, as\nindividuals may contract disease from either infected fleas or contact with\npurulent discharges or blood from the cat. An even greater threat occurs\nwhen the disease in cats progresses to pneumonic plague. This has been\ndocumented in cats, including transmission to veterinarians and owners.\nAntibiotic treatment is effective in cats, but the threat of plague is only\none of many reasons that people should keep their pets free of fleas. - Mod.TG]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Source: The Denver Post [edited]\n<http://www.denverpost.com/Stories/0,1413,36~53~2369770,00.html#>\n2 cats in Jefferson County were diagnosed recently with bubonic plague, a\ndiscovery that in addition to previous finds has epidemiologists wondering\nwhether a plague cycle is beginning anew in Colorado. Although health\nofficials aren't sure how the cats caught the disease, typically cats will\ncontract it after being bitten by infected fleas, Volkel said. In Jefferson County, the cats diagnosed with the plague are free-roaming\noutdoor cats, said David Volkel, a Jefferson County environmental health\nspecialist. When sylvatic outbreaks occur in rodent populations, domestic cats can be\ninfected by fleas on the rodents or by direct contact with infected rodent\ntissues -- as they chomp on squirrels or other rodents. \nAntibiotic treatment is effective in cats, but the threat of plague is only\none of many reasons that people should keep their pets free of fleas. The report above mentions bubonic plague, which is of zoonotic concern, as\nindividuals may contract disease from either infected fleas or contact with\npurulent discharges or blood from the cat. He cautioned people to watch their outdoor cats for signs of illness, which\ninclude lethargy, a swollen neck, coughing and trouble breathing.\n The incubation\nperiod in cats may be short, a day or 2, and marked by a fever of up to\n41.5 C and lymphadenopathy. While\nthe plague has killed millions of people throughout history, it can be\ntreated with antibiotics if it is caught in time. --\nProMED-mail\n< An even greater threat occurs\nwhen the disease in cats progresses to pneumonic plague. The cats, which live about 12 miles apart, are among 8 felines statewide\nthat have caught the disease so far in 2004. The cats suddenly became lethargic, were taken to the veterinarian and were\ndiagnosed within the past several weeks, Volkel said. Last week, a 54-year-old Weld\nCounty woman was hospitalized with the plague. This has been\ndocumented in cats, including transmission to veterinarians and owners. Typical buboes often occur in the head and\nneck, and can be mistaken for cat fight abscesses.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2004-09-01 00:00:00", "2004-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Jefferson County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Yersenia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2206461", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, fatal - China (Gansu, Qinghai)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2206461", "date": "2004-09-01 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, FATAL - CHINA (GANSU, QINGHAI)\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 1 Sep 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: The Age / AP [edited]\n<http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2004/09/01/1093938978439.html?oneclick=true>\n\nPlague in western China kills one person\n------------------------------\nOne person in China has died of the plague and another has been infected,\nthe health ministry and state media said Wednesday.\nThe cases were found in the western regions of Gansu and Qinghai, the\nministry said on its Web site. It did not provide any other details or say\nin which area the death occurred. Telephones were not answered at health\nbureaus in either region.\nThe Beijing News said local health officials and governments have 'taken\nmeasures to put things under control,' but did not elaborate.\nOne case occurred in Sunan Yugu in Gansu, the newspaper said, while the\nother was found in Qinghai's Qilian county.\nNeither the health ministry nor the newspaper identified the type of\nplague. The term 'plague' applies to a number of contagious, likely fatal\nbacterial diseases transmitted by fleas from infected rats and by contact\nwith infected blood or tissue. The most common form, the bubonic plague,\nresults in high fever, delirium and swollen lymph nodes.\nOutbreaks have killed about 200 million people in the past 1500 years. The\nmost infamous epidemic, Europe's Black Death, started in 1347, killing 25\nmillion people in Europe and 13 million in the Middle East and China within\n5 years.\nAn outbreak in China's southwest in 1997 infected 19 people. The victims\nwere hospitalised, and disease prevention teams and villagers were\nmobilized to kill mice and fleas, according to the official Xinhua News\nAgency. Local officials denied there were any cases.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[It is unknown whether these cases were related in any way. More\ninformation would be welcome. We would like to thank Yang Li\n<yangli@flu.org.cn> for submitting a different article on these cases which\nindicated that the death was due to bubonic plague. - Mod.DK]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The\nmost infamous epidemic, Europe's Black Death, started in 1347, killing 25\nmillion people in Europe and 13 million in the Middle East and China within\n5 years. The victims\nwere hospitalised, and disease prevention teams and villagers were\nmobilized to kill mice and fleas, according to the official Xinhua News\nAgency. The term 'plague' applies to a number of contagious, likely fatal\nbacterial diseases transmitted by fleas from infected rats and by contact\nwith infected blood or tissue. \nOne person in China has died of the plague and another has been infected,\nthe health ministry and state media said Wednesday. We would like to thank Yang Li\n<yangli@flu.org.cn> for submitting a different article on these cases which\nindicated that the death was due to bubonic plague. Source: The Age / AP [edited]\n<http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2004/09/01/1093938978439.html?oneclick=true>\n\nPlague in western China kills one person\n One case occurred in Sunan Yugu in Gansu, the newspaper said, while the\nother was found in Qinghai's Qilian county.\n PLAGUE, FATAL - CHINA (GANSU, QINGHAI)\n**************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1347-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-09-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "1997-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Qinghai", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Gansu", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Sunan Yugu", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2205767", "headline": "PRO/AH> Plague, prairie dogs - USA (TX)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2205767", "date": "2004-05-20 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PRAIRIE DOGS - USA (TEXAS)\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 20 May 2004\nFrom: James Alexander <James.Alexander@tdh.state.tx.us> [edited]\n\nThe Rita Blanca National Grasslands (RBNG), located in Dallam County in the\nnorth west corner of Texas, is currently the site of a plague outbreak in\nprairie dogs. So far plague has been confirmed in fleas from sites 9, 19,\n23, and 35. Other sites are suspected to have experienced plague based on a\nvisual inspection of the towns where no, or minimal prairie dog activity\nwas observed. These sites are 7, 11, 14, 21, 22, 40, 46, and 89.\nWarning posters have been placed throughout the area, but all areas with\nprairie dog towns have not been inspected, and posters may not be at the\nentrance to every site with a prairie dog town. All prairie dog towns in\nthe RBNG should be considered as potential sites of plague infection. While\ninfection has not been confirmed outside the RBNG, spread is possible to\nadjacent areas.\nNormally, the area is sparsely populated. In the past 2 weeks, however,\nprairie dog hunting enthusiasts from multiple states have been frequenting\nthe RBNG to pursue their avocation. If a person presents with symptoms that\ncould be due to infection with _Yersinia pestis_, a history should be\nobtained to determine whether the individual has recently been to the RBNG.\nIf affirmative, appropriate diagnostics and prophylaxis should be pursued\nimmediately.\nHunters are advised not to enter a prairie dog town. If a prairie dog town\nis visited, however, prairie dogs, dead or alive, should not be handled,\nand precautions should be taken to prevent being bitten by fleas.\n--\nJames L Alexander, DVM, MPVM, Dipl. ACVPM\nRegional Zoonosis Control Veterinarian\nTexas Department of Health\nPublic Health Region 1\nWTAMU Box 60968\nCanyon, TX 79016-0968\n<james.alexander@tdh.state.tx.us>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Warning posters have been placed throughout the area, but all areas with\nprairie dog towns have not been inspected, and posters may not be at the\nentrance to every site with a prairie dog town. If a prairie dog town\nis visited, however, prairie dogs, dead or alive, should not be handled,\nand precautions should be taken to prevent being bitten by fleas. Texas Department of Health\nPublic Health Region 1\nWTAMU Box 60968\n Other sites are suspected to have experienced plague based on a\nvisual inspection of the towns where no, or minimal prairie dog activity\nwas observed. From: James Alexander <James.Alexander@tdh.state.tx.us> [edited]\n\nThe Rita Blanca National Grasslands (RBNG), located in Dallam County in the\nnorth west corner of Texas, is currently the site of a plague outbreak in\nprairie dogs. In the past 2 weeks, however,\nprairie dog hunting enthusiasts from multiple states have been frequenting\nthe RBNG to pursue their avocation.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2046-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-05-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2040-03-25 00:00:00", "2035-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-22 00:00:00", "1989-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "TEXAS", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Dallam County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2206235", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Congo DR (Ituri): susp.", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2206235", "date": "2004-07-30 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE - CONGO, DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC (ITURI): SUSPECTED\n******************************************************\nProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu, 29 Jul 2004\nFrom: Dr. Felicia B. Nutter <felicia_nutter@hotmail.com>\nSource: AllAfrica.com and UN Integrated Regional Information Networks [edited]\n<http://allafrica.com/stories/printable/200407290860.html>\n\nDRC: Suspected Plague Kills 58 in Ituri\n-----------------------------------------\nHealth officials in the Democratic Republic of the Congo said on Thu,\n29 Jul 2004, 58 people, suspected to have caught the plague, had died\nso far this year in the northeastern district of Ituri.\nThey were among the 1042 suspected plague cases recorded since Jan\n2004, according to a joint Ministry of Health and WHO mission sent to\nthe area from 18-26 Jul 2004.\n'Ituri remains the area in the DRC most affected by plague because of\nincessant population displacements caused by the continued fighting\nbetween rebel groups,' Dr Vital Mondonge Makuma, deputy director of\nthe Epidemiological Surveillance Unit at the Ministry of Health, said.\nThe mission reported that most of the cases occurred in Mahagi\nTerritory, 140 km north east of Bunia, within Ituri District.\nWith 517 suspected cases of the disease recorded, the health zone of\nRethy is the hardest hit: 31 deaths were registered there from Jan to\nMay 2004. During the same period, the Logo zone registered 340\nsuspected cases and 15 deaths; Rimba 183 suspected cases and 10\ndeaths; and Nyarambe 2 deaths.\n'Even if we can no longer call this a severe outbreak, cases continue\nto be reported with a 5.5 percent mortality rate,' Mondonge said.\nDr Jean-Marie Yameogo of WHO Kinshasa told IRIN on Thu, 29 Jul 2004:\n'Even though the region has been a hot spot for the plague since\n1928, the absence of proper laboratory facilities in Ituri has made\nit impossible to confirm scientifically that those infected are\nindeed suffering from plague.'\nThe mission's report shows that 90 percent of the cases are suspected\nto be bubonic plague, 7 percent pulmonary plague, while 3 percent are\nsuspected to be septicemic.\nDr Tarcis Elongo of WHO Bunia told IRIN that one of the factors\nencouraging the epidemic was the climate. 'The high humidity during\nthe rainy season forces [people] to store their food indoors, and\nthis attracts rats and [their] fleas that are carriers of the\ndisease,' He said. 'The fact that people are forced to live in the\nbush during fighting has also contributed to its spread.'\n---\nFelicia B. Nutter, DVM\nField Veterinarian\nMountain Gorilla Veterinary Project\nBP 105\nRuhengeri, RWANDA\n<felicia_nutter@hotmail.com>\n[Infection with _Yersinia pestis_ is endemic in this area of central\nAfrica. ProMED has posted outbreaks or suspected outbreaks in Uganda\nand the Democratic Republic of the Congo previously, as listed below.\nAs stated in the report, the laboratory confirmation of the infection\nis so far lacking. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "PLAGUE - CONGO, DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC (ITURI): SUSPECTED\n******************************************************\nProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Dr Jean-Marie Yameogo of WHO Kinshasa told IRIN on Thu, 29 Jul 2004:\n'Even though the region has been a hot spot for the plague since\n1928, the absence of proper laboratory facilities in Ituri has made\nit impossible to confirm scientifically that those infected are\nindeed suffering from plague.' Mountain Gorilla Veterinary Project\nBP 105\nRuhengeri, RWANDA\n<felicia_nutter@hotmail.com>\n \n---\nFelicia B. Nutter, DVM\nField Veterinarian\n Ituri remains the area in the DRC most affected by plague because of\nincessant population displacements caused by the continued fighting\nbetween rebel groups,' Dr Vital Mondonge Makuma, deputy director of\nthe Epidemiological Surveillance Unit at the Ministry of Health, said. The mission's report shows that 90 percent of the cases are suspected\nto be bubonic plague, 7 percent pulmonary plague, while 3 percent are\nsuspected to be septicemic. During the same period, the Logo zone registered 340\nsuspected cases and 15 deaths; Rimba 183 suspected cases and 10\ndeaths; and Nyarambe 2 deaths. They were among the 1042 suspected plague cases recorded since Jan\n2004, according to a joint Ministry of Health and WHO mission sent to\nthe area from 18-26 Jul 2004. '", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2004-03-25 00:00:00", "1928-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-05-25 00:00:00", "2004-01-25 00:00:00", "1042-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Congo", "country": "Congo Republic"}, {"location": "Ituri", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "Bunia", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "the Democratic Republic of the", "country": "DR Congo"}, {"location": "RWANDA", "country": "Rwanda"}, {"location": "Uganda", "country": "Uganda"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC", "country": "Yemen"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2205922", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, prairie dogs - USA (CO): alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2205922", "date": "2004-06-14 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PRAIRIE DOGS - USA (COLORADO): ALERT\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Sat 12 Jun 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Greeley Tribune [edited]\n<http://www.greeleytrib.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20040612/NEWS/106120035>\n\nPrairie dogs die of plague\n------------------------------\nWeld County health officials are asking people who visit or live\naround Pawnee National Grasslands to look out for signs of plague after\nfinding the disease in 6 dead prairie dogs. A researcher observing prairie\ndogs in the park found the infected colony at the northwest intersection\nof Weld County roads 96 and 67, northwest of Briggsdale.\n6 of the 8 dead prairie dogs handed over to the Center for Disease\nControl and Prevention tested positive for bubonic plague. Officials think\nthe other 2 also have the disease, but more tests are needed, said Sara\nEvans, consumer protection supervisor for the Weld County Department of\nPublic Health and Environment.\nOn average, 13 cases of plague in humans are reported in the USA each\nyear. Most occur in the southwestern states. Humans, and their pets, can\nbe infected when a prairie dog with the plague dies and the fleas look\nfor another host. 'If a dog, cat, or human happens to be nearby, they\nwill hitch a ride and feed on them,' Evans said.\nThe last known case of the plague infecting a person in Weld\nCounty occurred a little more than 10 years ago, Evans said. Investigators\nbelieve that a student at the University of Northern Colorado caught the\ndisease while playing baseball in a Fort Collins field where rodents were\npresent, she said.\nOver the past few years, Weld county officials have suspected plague\nwhen they have seen populations of prairie dogs die off in areas near\nFort Lupton, Hudson, and Pierce Evans said. However, without animals to\ntest, officials could not confirm that plague was responsible, she said.\nResidents should watch rodent populations near their homes and report\nany sudden die-offs to the health department, Evans said.\n[Byline: Julio Ochoa]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Prairie dogs are very sensitive indicators of when the plague organism,\n_Yersenia pestis_, is in an area. Prairie dogs are often considered\nsentinel animals. Domestic cats are also sensitive to the plague agent. -\nMod.TG]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n ------------------------------\nWeld County health officials are asking people who visit or live\naround Pawnee National Grasslands to look out for signs of plague after\nfinding the disease in 6 dead prairie dogs. These foci are located in the\nsouthwestern USA, northern Peru, the Department of La Paz in Bolivia,\nseveral areas in northeastern Brazil, and in the Chimborazo Province of\nEcuador (1).\n\nEcuador reported an estimated 160 cases from an outbreak in 1998 including\npneumonic cases (1, 2). In the 1960s, however, 200-350 cases per year were\nreported from 1961 to 1966 (3).\n\n1. Ruiz A. Plagues in the Americas. Emerg Infect Dis 2001;7(Suppl):539-40.\n\n2. Gabastou JM, Proano J, Vimos A, et al. An outbreak of plague including\ncases with probable pneumonic infection, Ecuador, 1998. Trans R Soc Trop\nMed Hyg 2000;94:387-91.\n\n3. WHO. WHO/CDS/CSR/ISR/2000.1 - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri, 7 May 2004\nFrom: Marianne Hopp <mjhopp12@yahoo.com Source: WHO Epidemiological Record 7 May 2004 [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/wer/2004/wer7919/en/>\n\n2 cases of plague, both fatal, have been reported from Ecuador since 28 Apr\n2004. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[ProMED-mail would appreciate more information about these plague cases in\nEcuador, especially their exact location(s) and whether they were bubonic\nor pneumonic. Most of the world's cases of _Y. pestis_ infection occur in Africa and\nAsia; the foci of plague in the Americas account for no more than 1.4\npercent of world cases annually. These foci are located in the\nsouthwestern USA, northern Peru, the Department of La Paz in Bolivia,\nseveral areas in northeastern Brazil, and in the Chimborazo Province of\nEcuador (1). \n\nEcuador reported an estimated 160 cases from an outbreak in 1998 including\npneumonic cases (1, 2).", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2004-05-07 00:00:00", "1998-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Peru", "country": "Peru"}, {"location": "the Chimborazo Province", "country": "Argentina"}, {"location": "Bolivia", "country": "Bolivia"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "Ecuador", "country": "Ecuador"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2205676", "headline": "PRO/AH> Plague, cats - USA (NM)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2205676", "date": "2004-05-02 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, CATS - USA (NEW MEXICO)\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 30 Apr 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Associated Press [edited]\n<http://kobtv.com/index.cfm?viewer=storyviewer&id=10501&cat=4HEALTH>\n\nThe New Mexico State Department of Health has confirmed plague infections\nin 2 Santa Fe County cats, and the agency says several people exposed to\nthe sick cats will be given antibiotics to prevent them from contracting\nthe plague.\nPlague is generally transmitted to people through the bites of infected\nfleas from rodents. The disease also can be transmitted by direct contact\nwith infected animals -- including rodents, wildlife, and pets. Symptoms of\nbubonic plague in humans include fever, swollen lymph nodes, chills and\nsometimes headache, vomiting and diarrhea. Health officials urge people to\nregularly use flea control products on their pets.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Although endemic in rodent populations the western United States, Plague\nis most commonly seen in 2 regions: firstly, northern New Mexico, northern\nArizona, and southern Colorado and, secondly, California, southern Oregon,\nand western Nevada (see\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvbid/plague/plagwest.htm>) for a map.\nWhen sylvatic outbreaks occur in rodent populations, domestic cats can be\ninfected by fleas on the rodents or by direct contact with infected rodent\ntissues as they chomp on squirrels or other rodents. The incubation period\nin cats may be short, a day or 2, and marked by a fever of up to 41.5 C and\nlymphadenopathy. Typical buboes often occur in the head and neck, which can\nbe mistaken for cat fight abscesses. Dogs are considered to be less\nsusceptible.\nThe report above mentions bubonic plague, which is of zoonotic concern, as\nindividuals may contract disease from either infected fleas or contact with\npurulent discharges or blood from the cat. An even greater threat occurs\nwhen the disease in cats progresses to pneumonic plague. This has been\ndocumented in cats, including transmission to veterinarians and owners.\nAntibiotic treatment is effective in cats, but the threat of plague is only\none of many reasons that people should keep their pets free of fleas. - Mod.PC]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Source: Associated Press [edited]\n<http://kobtv.com/index.cfm?viewer=storyviewer&id=10501&cat=4HEALTH>\n\nThe New Mexico State Department of Health has confirmed plague infections\nin 2 Santa Fe County cats, and the agency says several people exposed to\nthe sick cats will be given antibiotics to prevent them from contracting\nthe plague. [Although endemic in rodent populations the western United States, Plague\nis most commonly seen in 2 regions: firstly, northern New Mexico, northern\nArizona, and southern Colorado and, secondly, California, southern Oregon,\nand western Nevada (see\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvbid/plague/plagwest.htm>) for a map. When sylvatic outbreaks occur in rodent populations, domestic cats can be\ninfected by fleas on the rodents or by direct contact with infected rodent\ntissues as they chomp on squirrels or other rodents. The report above mentions bubonic plague, which is of zoonotic concern, as\nindividuals may contract disease from either infected fleas or contact with\npurulent discharges or blood from the cat. \nAntibiotic treatment is effective in cats, but the threat of plague is only\none of many reasons that people should keep their pets free of fleas. Symptoms of\nbubonic plague in humans include fever, swollen lymph nodes, chills and\nsometimes headache, vomiting and diarrhea. The incubation period\nin cats may be short, a day or 2, and marked by a fever of up to 41.5 C and\nlymphadenopathy.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Santa Fe County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Nevada", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Oregon", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Plague", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2206056", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Turkmenistan (Dashoguz): susp", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2206056", "date": "2004-07-06 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE - TURKMENISTAN (DASHOGUZ): SUSPECTED\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Mon, 5 Jul 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: IRIN News [edited]\n<http://www.irinnews.org/report.asp?ReportID=42013&SelectRegion=Central_Asia&SelectCountry=UZBEKISTAN>\n\nTashkent is tightening border controls and migration in a bid to prevent\nthe possible spread of plague from neighboring Turkmenistan, according to a\nhealth official. 'We recently held a session of the national anti-epidemic\ncommission, where we adopted a number of measures to prevent the spread of\nplague from Turkmenistan to Uzbekistan,' Nurmat Atabekov, head of the\nsanitary and epidemiological control department, told IRIN from the\ncapital, Tashkent, on Mon 5 Jul 2004.\nHis comments followed recent media reports claiming that there had been\nreported cases of plague in the northern Turkmen province of Dashoguz,\nbordering Uzbekistan. 'We got information from mass media reports that the\nsituation in border regions of Turkmenistan [with regard to plague] is\ncomplicated, but we haven't been able to get official confirmation from\nTurkmenistan,' Atabekov added.\n'Normally in such cases, quarantine and restrictive measures are taken. We\nare trying to minimize the migration of the population [in border regions],\npreventing [trade in] cattle and livestock products, and strengthening\nhealth control of the people crossing the border,' the Uzbek health\nofficial maintained.\nAccording to the Uzbek Health Ministry, some staff members of its\nquarantine and contagious infections service and 28 epidemiological teams\nwere now working in the steppe areas of Khorezm, Navo'i and Surkhandarya\nprovinces, Karakalpakstan and Ustyurt plateau, bordering Turkmenistan.\nMoreover, in Khorezm province and Karakalpakstan, 7 anti-epidemic mobile\nteams have been sent, who were taking necessary preventive measures on the\nground.\nAlso in an effort to avert plague, cattle breeders, geologists, and oil\nworkers have been vaccinated against plague along with some 15 000 camels\nin the region. 'We conduct continuous monitoring of the rodent population\nfor vermin. In these regions, plague bacteria is being detected in both\nfleas and rodents,' Atabekov said.\nAccording to him, in the former Soviet Union there were 16 areas that were\nnatural foci for plague and 1 of them was in Central Asia. 'The whole\nterritory of Turkmenistan is an endemic foci of plague. Therefore, they\nshould not ignore that,' he said.\n'If there are cases of the infection, they should immediately let us know,'\nhe noted, adding that the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS)\ncountries earlier agreed on sharing epidemiological information. 'We agreed\nthat we would regularly provide information on the situation with regard to\ninfectious diseases. In cases of quarantine and extremely dangerous\ninfectious diseases, we are to inform each other immediately. But\nunfortunately Turkmenistan doesn't provide that information.'\n'We don't know what the overall situation in terms of infectious diseases\nand of extremely dangerous infectious diseases, particularly plague, is\n[there],' he stressed. 'During Soviet times, there wasn't an anti-plague\nservice in Turkmenistan. An anti-plague station in Astrakhan [Russia] was\ncarrying out those activities for them. But now, in the post-Soviet era, we\ndon't know the pace of the anti-plague work there, the scope of it and\nwhether it is really being carried out.'\n******\n[2]\nDate: Mon, 5 Jul 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Associated Press [edited]\n<http://www.phillyburbs.com/pb-dyn/news/94-07052004-327017.html>\n\nTurkmenistan says no infectious diseases\n----------------------------------------\nAuthorities said Mon, 5 Jul 2004, that no dangerous diseases have been\ndetected in Turkmenistan recently, in an apparent response to recent media\nreports of a plague outbreak in the country's north.\n'The epidemiological situation on Turkmen territory is favorable,' the\nExtraordinary Anti-Epidemics Commission said in a statement. 'No cases of\nany dangerous diseases have been reported.'\nAn opposition Turkmen website, Gundogar, reported in Jun 2004, citing\nunspecified sources, that Turkmenistan's northern Tashauz province was hit\nby a plague outbreak. It did not say how many cases had been reported\nthere, but said 2 were fatal.\nRumors of the plague in the north have been circulating in the Turkmen\ncapital, Ashgabat, for weeks and some residents have stopped buying meat\nand dairy products that came from outside the city. On Fri, 2 Jul 2004,\nfearing the plague may spread to its territory, neighboring Uzbek\nauthorities announced restrictions on the movement of people and livestock\nalong the Turkmen border.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[ProMED-mail would appreciate more information regarding whether plague --\nin any form -- has been diagnosed in Turkmenistan. According to the WHO\nCommunicable Disease Surveillance and Response Plague Manual, Kazakhstan\nwas the only former Soviet republic reporting plague. The first reports\nwere from 1989. In the 1989-1997 period, 11 cases with 4 deaths were\nreported from the Guriev and Kzyl-Orda regions\n<http://www.who.int/emc-documents/plague/docs/whocdscsredc992c.pdf>. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n We recently held a session of the national anti-epidemic\ncommission, where we adopted a number of measures to prevent the spread of\nplague from Turkmenistan to Uzbekistan,' Nurmat Atabekov, head of the\nsanitary and epidemiological control department, told IRIN from the\ncapital, Tashkent, on Mon 5 Jul 2004. On Fri, 2 Jul 2004,\nfearing the plague may spread to its territory, neighboring Uzbek\nauthorities announced restrictions on the movement of people and livestock\nalong the Turkmen border.\n We\nare trying to minimize the migration of the population [in border regions],\npreventing [trade in] cattle and livestock products, and strengthening\nhealth control of the people crossing the border,' the Uzbek health\nofficial maintained. We got information from mass media reports that the\nsituation in border regions of Turkmenistan [with regard to plague] is\ncomplicated, but we haven't been able to get official confirmation from\nTurkmenistan,' Atabekov added. Source: IRIN News [edited]\n<http://www.irinnews.org/report.asp?ReportID=42013&SelectRegion=Central_Asia&SelectCountry=UZBEKISTAN>\n\nTashkent is tightening border controls and migration in a bid to prevent\nthe possible spread of plague from neighboring Turkmenistan, according to a\nhealth official. ' But now, in the post-Soviet era, we\ndon't know the pace of the anti-plague work there, the scope of it and\nwhether it is really being carried out.'\n According to the Uzbek Health Ministry, some staff members of its\nquarantine and contagious infections service and 28 epidemiological teams\nwere now working in the steppe areas of Khorezm, Navo'i and Surkhandarya\nprovinces, Karakalpakstan and Ustyurt plateau, bordering Turkmenistan.
