' An opposition Turkmen website, Gundogar, reported in Jun 2004, citing\nunspecified sources, that Turkmenistan's northern Tashauz province was hit\nby a plague outbreak. According to the WHO\nCommunicable Disease Surveillance and Response Plague Manual, Kazakhstan\nwas the only former Soviet republic reporting plague. Rumors of the plague in the north have been circulating in the Turkmen\ncapital, Ashgabat, for weeks and some residents have stopped buying meat\nand dairy products that came from outside the city. We agreed\nthat we would regularly provide information on the situation with regard to\ninfectious diseases. In the 1989-1997 period, 11 cases with 4 deaths were\nreported from the Guriev and Kzyl-Orda regions\n<http://www.who.int/emc-documents/plague/docs/whocdscsredc992c.pdf>. Moreover, in Khorezm province and Karakalpakstan, 7 anti-epidemic mobile\nteams have been sent, who were taking necessary preventive measures on the\nground.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2004-07-05 00:00:00", "2004-06-25 00:00:00", "1989-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-07-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Soviet Union", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Karakalpakstan", "country": "Uzbekistan"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Khorezm province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Astrakhan", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Tashauz province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "Kazakhstan"}, {"location": "Tashkent", "country": "Uzbekistan"}, {"location": "Turkmenistan", "country": "Turkmenistan"}, {"location": "Uzbekistan", "country": "Uzbekistan"}, {"location": "Nurmat Atabekov", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Khorezm", "country": "Uzbekistan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2206064", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Turkmenistan (Dashoguz): susp (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2206064", "date": "2004-07-07 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE - TURKMENISTAN (DASHOGUZ): SUSPECTED (02)\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Sun 6 Jun 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Gundogar, Turkmenistan forum, 6 Jun 2004 [translated by Mod.NR, edited]\n<http://www.gundogar.org/?topic_id=8&id=556>\n\n1st cases of bubonic plague in 20 years have been reported in Turkmenistan\n-----------------------------------------------\nAn epidemic of plague began in May 2004. There have already been more\nthan 20 deaths in Turkmenistan. News about the plague was delivered\nby a German humanitarian aid company that works at the Uzbek-Turkmen\nborder in the north Karakums in the Tashhovuz region. According to a\nspecialist, this is the most serious outbreak in the last 20-30 years.\nAccording to radio 'German wave' (Nemezkaya volna), during a recent\nweek, 7 people died, in the Turkmen city Mari, from plague. There\nhave been fatal cases in Ashgabad (capital of Turkmenistan) as well.\nUnfortunately, there is no reliable information from Turkmenistan,\nfrom the Russia epidemiological surveillance center, or from WHO.\nAccording to the chief sanitary physician of Russia, Gennadiy\nOnishenko, everything associated with acute diseases in Turkmenistan\nis kept secret.\nTurkmenistan officials have made some efforts to prevent the spread\nof the epidemic. Quarantine was introduced in several of the\nhospitals of Ashgabad, and public pools are closed.\nAccording to Gennadiy Onishenko, carriers of plague in Central Asia\nare camels. If a camel dies, people usually eat the meat. However,\npeople will not be infected with plague if they cook the meat\nthoroughly [and avoid contamination with the uncooked meat - Mod. LL].\nUzbekistan has taken serious measures to prevent the spread of this\ndangerous infection. Transportation of domestic animals across the\nborder, including camels, is prohibited, and people living near the\nborders have been assessed. So far, according to official data, there\nhave been no human cases of plague registered in Uzbekistan.\nThere are no quarantine measures established in Russia. According to\nOnishenko, all elements of the transportation system of Central Asia,\nincluding airports and trains, have been notified.\nThe last case of plague in Turkmenistan was reported 25 years ago.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue 6 Jul 2004\nFrom: Wendy Orent <orentw@mindspring.com> [edited]\n\nAccording to the moderator (LL), Kazakhstan is the only former Soviet\nrepublic reporting plague. This is, in part, because the Soviet Union\nactively suppressed all reports of plague outbreaks. In fact, in\n1949-50, there was a sizeable outbreak of pneumonic plague, which may\nhave killed upwards of 100 people, according to Dr. Lev A. Melnikov,\nwho was an eyewitness. Melnikov attributed the outbreak to the\ndangerous plague reservoir _Rhombomys optimus_ (the great gerbil.). I\nreported this in my recent book, Plague: The Mysterious Past and\nTerrifying Future of the World's Most Dangerous Disease, pp. 27-29.\n[The Free Press, New York, USA, 2004]\nPlague, and its reservoirs, are no respecters of borders, and the\nconditions prevailing in Kazhakstan (the presence of ancient\nreservoirs of gerbils and marmots) are also found in Turkmenistan.\nAtabekov is certainly correct that the territory of Turkmenistan is\nan endemic focus of plague, and there is no reason to discount\nreports of plague in Turkmenistan out of hand.\n--\nWendy Orent\n<orentw@mindspring.com>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Atabekov is certainly correct that the territory of Turkmenistan is\nan endemic focus of plague, and there is no reason to discount\nreports of plague in Turkmenistan out of hand.\n In fact, in\n1949-50, there was a sizeable outbreak of pneumonic plague, which may\nhave killed upwards of 100 people, according to Dr. Lev A. Melnikov,\nwho was an eyewitness. NR, edited]\n<http://www.gundogar.org/?topic_id=8&id=556>\n\n1st cases of bubonic plague in 20 years have been reported in Turkmenistan\n However,\npeople will not be infected with plague if they cook the meat\nthoroughly [and avoid contamination with the uncooked meat - Mod. Plague, and its reservoirs, are no respecters of borders, and the\nconditions prevailing in Kazhakstan (the presence of ancient\nreservoirs of gerbils and marmots) are also found in Turkmenistan. News about the plague was delivered\nby a German humanitarian aid company that works at the Uzbek-Turkmen\nborder in the north Karakums in the Tashhovuz region. I\nreported this in my recent book, Plague: The Mysterious Past and\nTerrifying Future of the World's Most Dangerous Disease, pp. Transportation of domestic animals across the\nborder, including camels, is prohibited, and people living near the\nborders have been assessed. PLAGUE - TURKMENISTAN (DASHOGUZ): SUSPECTED (02)\n************************************************\n According to a\nspecialist, this is the most serious outbreak in the last 20-30 years.\n Quarantine was introduced in several of the\nhospitals of Ashgabad, and public pools are closed.\n There\nhave been fatal cases in Ashgabad (capital of Turkmenistan) as well.\n Unfortunately, there is no reliable information from Turkmenistan,\nfrom the Russia epidemiological surveillance center, or from WHO.\n Onishenko, everything associated with acute diseases in Turkmenistan\nis kept secret.\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2004-06-06 00:00:00", "2004-05-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Ashgabad", "country": "Turkmenistan"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Uzbekistan", "country": "Uzbekistan"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "Kazakhstan"}, {"location": "the Soviet Union", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Gennadiy", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Turkmenistan", "country": "Turkmenistan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2205720", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, fatal - Ecuador (Chimborazo) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2205720", "date": "2004-05-13 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, FATAL - ECUADOR (CHIMBORAZO) (02)\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n\n[1]\nDate: Tue, 11 May 2004\nFrom: Renato Leon <renatol@mail.usfq.edu.ec>\nSource:This information is derived from 2 articles published in El Universo\nnewspaper, 11 May 2004.\n<http://www.eluniverso.com/core/12/eluniverso.asp?page=noticia&id=12&tab=1&contid=42873F9E44A34017B29E58A990A5ED0E&EUID=>\n\n\nAccording to an Ecuadorian newspaper, the health department in Chimborazo\nProvince (located in the Andean mountains) advised local medical personnel\nthat patients admitted from the town of Guamote presenting fever, cough,\nenlargement of the lymph nodes, weakness and malaise, should be considered\nas suspected cases of bubonic plague. This decision was taken after\nconfirming 3 fatal cases due to the disease in the last 2 months.\n\nThe death of several guinea pigs (cuyes) has been reported in the\ncommunity of San Pedro de Yaucupamba, where 2 human fatalities have already\noccurred. Unfortunately, the information was suppressed, said Dr. Adela\nVimos, Director of Epidemiology, Chimborazo Province. It also mentioned\nthat personnel from the Malaria Control Program are currently spraying in\nthe community of San Pedro de Yaucupamba, the urban area of Guamote and\nother vicinity communities including Santa Teresita, Cochaloma and\nJatumpamba. Teachers from local schools started an educational campaign to\nprevent the occurrence of new cases.\n\nAccording to Vimos, the disease is endemic in the region, reason why the\nnew re-emergence of human cases is a dangerous threat to the community\nhealth. The health authorities of the Province of Chimborazo have also\nprohibited the consumption of guinea pigs and rabbits in the region until\nthe transmission of the disease is controlled. The manipulation of flesh,\nconsumption of poorly cooked guinea pigs, or the direct contact with the\nhost or the infected fleas could potentially lead to human infection -- all\nreasons that the health authorities urge the elimination of guinea pigs,\nrabbits, and rats, especially in the areas from where the cases were\nreported.\n\n--\nRenato Leon Ph.D.\nUniversidad San Francisco de Quito\nQuito, Ecuador\n<renatol@mail.usfq.edu.ec>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Mon, 10 May 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: El Universo.com, Ecuador, 10 (05/2004) [translated by Maria Jacobs,\nProMED-ESP; edited]\n<http://www.eluniverso.com/core/eluniverso.asp?edicion=1&page=noticia&id=12&tab=1&contid=7AD620E20FAD4796924EEE07F93EACC5>\n\n\nThe health authorities of Chimborazo confirmed that over the past 2 months,\nin the canton of Guamote, a mother and her daughter died with symptoms\ncompatible with bubonic plague. A 3rd person presenting similar symptoms is\nhospitalized in the isolation unit of a teaching hospital in the city of\nRiobamba.\n\nThe health authorities issued a ban on the consumption of cavies or guinea\npigs (_Cavia porcellus_), and rabbits due to a reappearance of bubonic plague.\n\nAdela Vimos, head of Epidemiology of the Health Department of Chimborazo,\nreported that in the canton of Guamote, and particularly in the community\nof San Pedro de Yacupamba, the disease has been present for several years,\nand that over the past few months a dangerous resurgence of the disease has\nbeen observed.\n\nThe epidemiology department is carrying out control measures that include\nthe fumigation of high-risk areas. Vimos placed special emphasis on the\nneed to abstain from the commerce and consumption of cavies and rabbits.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Wed, 12 May 2004 20:33:41 -0400\nTo: promed@promedmail.org\n\nFrom: Abramo Ottolenghi <ottolenghi.1@osu.edu>\nSource: Summarized from El Comercio on line Quito 11 and 12 May 2004\n<http://www.elcomercio.com/noticias.asp?noid=93313>\n<http://www.elcomercio.com/noticias.asp?noid=93338>\n\n\nA 55 year old woman and her 22 year old daughter died of bubonic plague in\nthe locality of Guamote in the province of Chimborazo. The mother and\ndaughter raised guinea pigs for sale. These animals are a common food in\nthe Andean region. 500 persons were treated to prevent spread of the\ndisease. The epidemiological focus was identified and according to\nauthorities an epidemiological containment circle has been\nestablished. High risk areas will be fumigated to eradicate the fleas.\n\nAuthorities indicated that plague is endemic in that area (grasslands over\n2000 mts. above sea level). When it rains rats that live in those\ngrasslands seek refuge in inhabited areas. In this case a rat bit a guinea\npig that was then consumed by the deceased. On April 29th an alert was\nissued for the provinces of Cotopaxi, Tungurahua, Bol\u00edvar, Azuay and\nChimborazo. No new cases have been detected.\n\n--\nAbramo Ottolenghi, Ph.D.\nProfessor Emeritus\nDepartment Molecular Virology Immunology and Human Genetics\nThe Ohio State University College of Medicine\nColumbus, Ohio\n<ottolenghi.1@osu.edu>\n\n[ProMED thanks Dr. Leon and Dr. Ottolenghi for information regarding this\ncluster of plague cases in the Andean area of Ecuador where plague has\noccurred in the past. - Mod.LL]\n\n[The outbreak of pneumonic plague reported by ProMED-mail in 1998\n(Pneumonic plague - Ecuador 19980501.0852) also occurred in Guamote\ncounty/canton but in a different locality. Plague has been reported in\nthis general region since first reports of cases in Chimborazo in 1977.\nThere was a major outbreak in 1998 (approximately 160 cases) and 14 cases\nreported in 1999 (<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/eid/vol7no3_supp/ruiz.htm>) -\nMod.MPP]", "summary": "The manipulation of flesh,\nconsumption of poorly cooked guinea pigs, or the direct contact with the\nhost or the infected fleas could potentially lead to human infection -- all\nreasons that the health authorities urge the elimination of guinea pigs,\nrabbits, and rats, especially in the areas from where the cases were\nreported. \n\nAdela Vimos, head of Epidemiology of the Health Department of Chimborazo,\nreported that in the canton of Guamote, and particularly in the community\nof San Pedro de Yacupamba, the disease has been present for several years,\nand that over the past few months a dangerous resurgence of the disease has\nbeen observed. According to an Ecuadorian newspaper, the health department in Chimborazo\nProvince (located in the Andean mountains) advised local medical personnel\nthat patients admitted from the town of Guamote presenting fever, cough,\nenlargement of the lymph nodes, weakness and malaise, should be considered\nas suspected cases of bubonic plague. \n\n--\nAbramo Ottolenghi, Ph.D.\nProfessor Emeritus\nDepartment Molecular Virology Immunology and Human Genetics\n It also mentioned\nthat personnel from the Malaria Control Program are currently spraying in\nthe community of San Pedro de Yaucupamba, the urban area of Guamote and\nother vicinity communities including Santa Teresita, Cochaloma and\nJatumpamba. (Pneumonic plague - Ecuador 19980501.0852) also occurred in Guamote\ncounty/canton but in a different locality.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "malaria", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2004-05-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "1998-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-04-29 00:00:00", "2004-05-25 00:00:00", "1977-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-05-10 00:00:00", "1999-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-05-12 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Quito", "country": "Ecuador"}, {"location": "Chimborazo Province", "country": "Argentina"}, {"location": "Azuay", "country": "Ecuador"}, {"location": "San Francisco de", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Columbus", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Ecuador", "country": "Ecuador"}, {"location": "the Province of Chimborazo", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "El Comercio", "country": "Honduras"}, {"location": "Ohio", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2205690", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, rodents - USA (TX)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2205690", "date": "2004-05-06 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, RODENTS - USA (TEXAS)\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 6 May 2004\nFrom: Carla Everett <ceverett@tahc.state.tx.us>\nSource: Texas Department of Health press release [edited]\n\nPlague Identified in Rodents in West Texas, Panhandle\n----------------------------------------------\nThe Texas Department of Health (TDH) confirmed today that _Yersinia\npestis_, the bacterium that causes plague, has been detected in wood\nrats found dead in a rural location near the Midland-Glasscock\ncounties border in West Texas and in fleas from wild prairie dogs in\nDallam County in the Texas Panhandle.\nTDH zoonosis control officials said it is not unusual to have plague\nin wild rodents in the western United States, including the western\npart of Texas.\n'Plague occasionally cycles through the wild rodent population,\nsometimes causing large die-offs of rats, prairie dogs and other\nrodents,' said Tom Sidwa, acting director of TDH's zoonosis control\nprogram, in Austin.\nPlague is usually spread by fleas that have bitten an infected\nrodent. The illness can be transmitted to dogs, cats and humans.\nPlague in humans can be effectively treated with antibiotics if\ndetected early, Sidwa said. Infection also can occur by breathing in\nrespiratory droplets from a live animal that has the pneumonic form\nof the illness.\nThe last recorded human case of plague in Texas was in 1993 in a Kent\nCounty resident. An average of 13 human cases a year occur in the\nUnited States.\nTDH is issuing a plague advisory to veterinarians and physicians in\nthe West Texas, Panhandle and South Plains areas of the state and\nreminding the public to take routine precautions to reduce the\nchances of being bitten by an infected flea. The public is asked to\nreport large die-offs of rodents to public health officials.\nPersonal precautions include: removing food and shelter sources for\nrodents around homes, work sites and recreational areas; using safe\ninsecticides to kill fleas around property; applying a\nDEET-containing repellent to exposed skin and clothing when in\nflea-inhabited areas, especially when camping or in other\nrodent-inhabited areas; and treating pets with long-acting flea\ncontrol products.\nTDH also advises wearing gloves if it's necessary to handle an animal\nthat could have plague. Because some rodents also carry hantavirus,\nrodent nests in closed-in areas should be aired out before removal,\nand any rodent nests and droppings should be wetted down with a 10\npercent bleach - 90 percent water solution before removing.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The Texas Panhandle is the column of land that juts out in a\nnortherly direction from the rest of Texas. It borders New Mexico.\nHowever, the western portion of New Mexico, on the other side of\nstate from the Texas Panhandle, has the highest prevalence of human\ncases. - Mod.PC]", "summary": "Personal precautions include: removing food and shelter sources for\nrodents around homes, work sites and recreational areas; using safe\ninsecticides to kill fleas around property; applying a\nDEET-containing repellent to exposed skin and clothing when in\nflea-inhabited areas, especially when camping or in other\nrodent-inhabited areas; and treating pets with long-acting flea\ncontrol products.\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The Texas Department of Health (TDH) confirmed today that _Yersinia\npestis_, the bacterium that causes plague, has been detected in wood\nrats found dead in a rural location near the Midland-Glasscock\ncounties border in West Texas and in fleas from wild prairie dogs in\n Plague occasionally cycles through the wild rodent population,\nsometimes causing large die-offs of rats, prairie dogs and other\nrodents,' said Tom Sidwa, acting director of TDH's zoonosis control\nprogram, in Austin. Because some rodents also carry hantavirus,\nrodent nests in closed-in areas should be aired out before removal,\nand any rodent nests and droppings should be wetted down with a 10\npercent bleach - 90 percent water solution before removing. TDH is issuing a plague advisory to veterinarians and physicians in\nthe West Texas, Panhandle and South Plains areas of the state and\nreminding the public to take routine precautions to reduce the\nchances of being bitten by an infected flea. \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n TDH zoonosis control officials said it is not unusual to have plague\nin wild rodents in the western United States, including the western\npart of Texas. However, the western portion of New Mexico, on the other side of\nstate from the Texas Panhandle, has the highest prevalence of human\ncases. Infection also can occur by breathing in\nrespiratory droplets from a live animal that has the pneumonic form\nof the illness. The public is asked to\nreport large die-offs of rodents to public health officials.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hantavirus", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1993-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-05-06 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Texas", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dallam County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Austin", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the West Texas", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Panhandle", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "TEXAS", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2205657", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Plague warning - Russia: RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2205657", "date": "2004-04-27 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE WARNING - RUSSIA: REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri, 23 Apr 2004 20:29:54 -0300\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Mosnews.com [edited]\n<http://www.mosnews.com/news/2004/04/23/plague.shtml>\n\nChief sanitary inspector warns of plague threat\n-----------------------------------------------\nRussia's chief sanitary inspector, Gennadiy Onischenko, has called upon his\ncolleagues to be prepared for an outbreak of plague, the Rosbalt news\nagency reported, citing the press service of the State Sanitary and\nEpidemiology Monitoring Service.\nIn order to provide epidemiological security and to prevent the spread of\nthe dangerous disease among the population, the chief sanitary inspector\ntold the directors of anti-plague institutions located in the Russian\nregions bordering Kazakhstan, Mongolia, and China, to prepare for possible\ncases of plague, especially at border checkpoints. He also called for a\njoint effort of the State Sanitary and Epidemiology Monitoring Service and\ndepartments of the Health Ministry to carry out preventive measures within\nthe country.\nThe last case of plague was registered in Russia in 1979.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Given the absence of plague in Russia, it is important to know the reason\nfor this warning. ACHS(ESD)\nKampala\nUganda\n<esd@afsat.com>\n[Arua & Nebbi are neighboring remote districts on the Western border of\nUganda with the Congo DR. It is an area endemic for plague -- there was a\ncase in Arua district in March 2003 -- see refs. below. These cases are\nprobably bubonic, easily treated with antibiotics.\nThere are no implications for international travel (other than for local\nborder-crossing residents, militia or humanitarian relief staff). - Mod.JW]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n \nDr. A. Talisuna\nESD Ministry of Health\nAg. ACHS(ESD) From: ESD Ministry of Health <esd@afsat.com>\nWeekly Epidemiological Newsletter for the 37th week of 2003 (week ending 14\n You can contact the following key persons in the production of this\nnewsletter on the following telephone numbers.\n Plague:\nArua district: 6 cases (no deaths)\n Uganda\n<esd@afsat.com>\n PLAGUE - UGANDA (ARUA, NEBBI)\n*************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-09-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the Congo DR", "country": "DR Congo"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204580", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (Kzyl-Orda) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204580", "date": "2003-09-18 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, BUBONIC - KAZAKHSTAN (KZYL-ORDA)(02)\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Tue, 16 Sep 2003 13:09:51 -0700 (PDT)\nFrom: Nilufar Rakhmanova <rakhmanovan@yahoo.com>\nSource: Kazakhstan today [edited]\n<http://www.gazeta.kz/art.asp?aid=32724>\n\nMedical personnel in the city of Aralsk in the Kzyl-Orda region, where\nthere has been a focus of plague infection, have decided to release the\nAralsk infectious diseases hospital from quarantine.\nAccording to earlier reports, a 4 year old girl from the village of Shomish\ndied from plague in Aralsk district hospital, infected after a flea bite\n[see: Plague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (Kzyl-Orda) 20030822.2119]. The\ndiagnosis was proven microbiologically.\nNo other symptoms of the disease have been found in local residents.\nDisinfection and measures against rats and insects have been taken. 7000\nsquare metres of land were treated by required means. Anti-infection\nmeasures have also been taken in a neighboring district, and 6000\nhouseholds have been inspected.\nObservation of 7 people contacts of the girl who died from plague is\ncontinuing, though no symptoms of disease have yet been detected.\n--\nNilufar Rakhmanova MD\nMaster of Public Health\nBoston University School of Public Health\nBoston, MA, USA\n<rakhmanovan@yahoo.com>\n[No other cases of bubonic plague have yet been reported from this endemic\narea despite the epidemiologic studies around the fatal case. \u00ad Mod.LL]", "summary": "--\nNilufar Rakhmanova MD\nMaster of Public Health\nBoston University School of Public Health\nBoston, MA, USA\n<rakhmanovan@yahoo.com>\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Source: Kazakhstan today [edited]\n<http://www.gazeta.kz/art.asp?aid=32724>\n\nMedical personnel in the city of Aralsk in the Kzyl-Orda region, where\nthere has been a focus of plague infection, have decided to release the\nAralsk infectious diseases hospital from quarantine.\n According to earlier reports, a 4 year old girl from the village of Shomish\ndied from plague in Aralsk district hospital, infected after a flea bite\n Anti-infection\nmeasures have also been taken in a neighboring district, and 6000\nhouseholds have been inspected. Observation of 7 people contacts of the girl who died from plague is\ncontinuing, though no symptoms of disease have yet been detected.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-09-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "MA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "Kazakhstan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204869", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, foxes, rodents - USA (NV)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204869", "date": "2003-11-12 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, FOXES, RODENTS - USA (NEVADA)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 12 Nov 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: KLAS-TV website, accessed 10 Nov 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.klastv.com/Global/story.asp?s=1519436>\n\nIf you intend to visit Mount Charleston, NV you'll need to take some\nprecautions. A plague warning is in effect there.\n4 gray foxes that were trapped in Mount Charleston tested positive for\nplague. The disease is transmitted to people through a fleabite or direct\ncontact with an infected animal. Health officials say if you're visiting\nMount Charleston you should wear long-sleeved shirts and pants and stay\naway from wild animals.\nResidents who live in the area are already taking precautions. Christopher\nOlson, who lives on Mount Charleston, said, 'I have heard that the rodents\nhere do have some type of infection, so we told the kids to stay away from\nthe mice and whether they're dead or alive.'\nPlague can be transmitted to humans through a fleabite or direct contact\nwith an infected animal. The symptoms are swollen glands, fever, chills,\nheadache, and extreme exhaustion. The Clark County Health District advises\nanyone who visits the Mount Charleston area to avoid contact with rodents\nand wild animals.\nHealth officials say if you take your pet up to Mount Charleston, don't let\nthem wander and keep a flea collar on them. If a human were to contract it,\nif it's detected early, plague responds well to antibiotics.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The introduction of plague into the US via California about a century ago\nled to the spread of the infection eastward across about halfway across the\ncountry. It did not reach the east coast. The infection continues to be\nendemic in rodents in the southwestern parts of the US including Colorado,\nNew Mexico, Arizona, and California.\n_Yersinia pestis_ is the agent responsible for bubonic plague. Endemic foci\nof sylvatic plague exist in the western USA and several other areas of the\nworld. Fleas are the vectors primarily responsible for spreading _Y.\npestis_ from these reservoirs, although contact with infected rabbit\ncarcasses has been a significant source of infection for man during the\nwinter. Throughout history, outbreaks of human plague involving rats in\ndensely populated agricultural or urban areas have occurred when rats\ncommingled with infected sylvatic rodents.\nPrairie dogs are often considered sentinel animals because of their\nsusceptibility to the organism. However, cats are extremely sensitive as\nwell and may be the source that exposes humans. The swollen lymph glands\nmay be mistaken for normal abscesses where a cat has been bitten. If one of\nthese buboes (swollen lymph glands) ruptures, it may be the source of\nbacteria to people associated with the cat.\nIn humans, the bubo in the groin or under the arm is most common. However,\nthere may also be a systemic infection involving the lungs and,\nconsequently, transmission between people is possible. Pneumonic plague can\nbe recognized by the bloody sputum coughed up by patients that are TB-negative.\nThe flea vector of _Y. pestis_ would rather feed on its usual host, but in\nthe absence of a warm-blooded prairie dog, it may attempt to feed on a\nhuman. Infection in the flea causes obstruction in the gastrointestinal\ntract of the flea, which regurgitates the bacilli while attempting to\nfeed. In addition to warnings, other possible measures to curb outbreaks\ninclude treating die-off areas with insecticides to kill the fleas.\nPet owners should be encouraged to keep their pets free of fleas. There are\na number of excellent products to combat fleas on your pets available from\nyour veterinarian; however, some such products may be toxic to cats. Pet\nowners should consult their veterinarian about anti-flea products and\nshould thoroughly read the label of the product. - Mod.TG]", "summary": "Christopher\nOlson, who lives on Mount Charleston, said, 'I have heard that the rodents\nhere do have some type of infection, so we told the kids to stay away from\nthe mice and whether they're dead or alive.'\n A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Fleas are the vectors primarily responsible for spreading _Y.\npestis_ from these reservoirs, although contact with infected rabbit\ncarcasses has been a significant source of infection for man during the\nwinter. Throughout history, outbreaks of human plague involving rats in\ndensely populated agricultural or urban areas have occurred when rats\ncommingled with infected sylvatic rodents. The flea vector of _Y. pestis_ would rather feed on its usual host, but in\nthe absence of a warm-blooded prairie dog, it may attempt to feed on a\nhuman. Infection in the flea causes obstruction in the gastrointestinal\ntract of the flea, which regurgitates the bacilli while attempting to\nfeed. [The introduction of plague into the US via California about a century ago\nled to the spread of the infection eastward across about halfway across the\ncountry. If one of\nthese buboes (swollen lymph glands) ruptures, it may be the source of\nbacteria to people associated with the cat. There are\na number of excellent products to combat fleas on your pets available from\nyour veterinarian; however, some such products may be toxic to cats. Pet\nowners should consult their veterinarian about anti-flea products and\nshould thoroughly read the label of the product. The Clark County Health District advises\nanyone who visits the Mount Charleston area to avoid contact with rodents\nand wild animals. Endemic foci\nof sylvatic plague exist in the western USA and several other areas of the\nworld. However,\nthere may also be a systemic infection involving the lungs and,\nconsequently, transmission between people is possible. \n4 gray foxes that were trapped in Mount Charleston tested positive for\nplague. The infection continues to be\nendemic in rodents in the southwestern parts of the US including Colorado,\nNew Mexico, Arizona, and California.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-11-10 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Arizona", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "NEVADA", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204558", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, prairie dogs - USA (MT): alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204558", "date": "2003-09-14 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PRAIRIE DOGS - USA (MONTANA): ALERT\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nFrom: David Rudolph <bowmq1@netzero.net>\nDate: Sun, 14 Sep 2003 02:45:44 GMT\nSubject: Bubonic - Plague\n\nI just returned from southeast Montana near the town of Broadus. The Praire\nDog Towns are empty due to the bubonic plague.\n---\nDavid Rudolph\n<bowmq1@netzero.net>\n[Further information has been requested from Montana. - Mod.MHJ]\n[Broadus is located in the southeast of Montana, whereas the deer mule\nfound positive for plague (see: Plague, mule deer - USA (MT) 20030911.2286)\nwas located in the southwest of Montana. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nFrom: David Rudolph <bowmq1@netzero.net>\n [Broadus is located in the southeast of Montana, whereas the deer mule\nfound positive for plague (see: Plague, mule deer - USA (MT) 20030911.2286)\nwas located in the southwest of Montana. ---\nDavid Rudolph\n<bowmq1@netzero.net>\n PLAGUE, PRAIRIE DOGS - USA (MONTANA): ALERT\n********************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-09-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Broadus", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Montana", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204603", "headline": "PRO/AH> Plague, prairie dogs - USA (MT) (02): suspected", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204603", "date": "2003-09-23 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PRAIRIE DOGS - USA (MT) (02): SUSPECTED\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nDate: Mon, 21 Sep 2003\n\nWe have sought confirmation from the Montana Fish, Wildlife, and\nParks (Keith Aune), the Montana Veterinary Diagnostic Laboratory\n(Bill Layton), and the Acting State Veterinarian (Tom Linfield). JW in the last ProMED-mail posting on plague in\nMongolia (Plague - Mongolia 20020919.5361), these cases have no\nimplications for international travel; they are reported by ProMED-mail as\na reminder that plague foci are still present in the world. Plague is\nendemic in Mongolia, and human cases of bubonic plague are reported every\nyear, mainly in country dwellers who have been hunting marmots for\ntheir fur. Marmots are large, burrowing rodents similar to groundhogs\n(woodchucks) in the USA. Most of the world's plague cases are reported\nfrom Africa - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 5 Sep 2003\n Plague is\nendemic in Mongolia, and human cases of bubonic plague are reported every\nyear, mainly in country dwellers who have been hunting marmots for\ntheir fur. Mongolia (Plague - Mongolia 20020919.5361), these cases have no\nimplications for international travel; they are reported by ProMED-mail as\na reminder that plague foci are still present in the world. Source: WHO Notifications 29 Aug - 4 Sep 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/wer/2003/wer7836/en/>\n\nMongolia reports 3 cases of plague (none fatal) from a report dated 26 Aug\n2003.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-09-25 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mongolia", "country": "Mongolia"}, {"location": "Plague - Mongolia 20020919.5361", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204540", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, mule deer - USA (MT)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204540", "date": "2003-09-11 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, MULE DEER - USA (MONTANA)\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 11 Sep 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Arizona Central 10 Sep 2003 5:05 PM [edited]\n<http://www.azcentral.com/news/articles/0910plaguefound-ON.html>\n\nPlague found in deer, precautions advised for hunters\n--------------------------------------------------\nA deer found near the Big Hole River in southwestern Montana was diagnosed\nwith plague, state officials said Wednesday. The infected mule deer was\nfound by 2 veterinarians 31 Jul 2003. The animal was congested, breathing\nrapidly, and in very poor condition. It was killed and tissue samples were\nsent for testing.\nWhile the discovery means hunters should take precautions, it should not\nalter their hunting plans this fall, officials said. The state's big game\narchery season opened Saturday, and the general rifle season starts 26 Oct\n2003. 'This is not some new disease that has befallen us and is spreading,'\nsaid Dr. Todd Damrow, state epidemiologist. 'This is something we've been\nliving with for years.'\nPlague[, caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_,] long has been\nwidespread in wildlife, particularly in rodents and animals that eat\nrodents, Damrow said. The bacterial disease can be passed from animals to\nhumans through direct contact with infected blood or tissue.\nHuman-to-human spread of the disease is extremely uncommon.\nThe plague usually infects 10 to 15 people each year in the United States\nand can be fatal if not treated, according to the Centers for Disease\nControl and Prevention. A Montana hunter contracted the disease in 1987\nfrom an infected antelope killed in Wheatland County. The hunter eventually\nrecovered. In 1992, a Wyoming man died after skinning a bobcat in\nsouth-central Montana.\nHealth officials said hunters can protect themselves by wearing gloves when\nbutchering their game, making sure the meat is cooked thoroughly to kill\nany bacteria, and washing hands after handling wild game. Symptoms of the\nplague are similar to the flu -- fever, nausea, muscle aches, and swollen\nlymph glands -- and usually appear about a week after contact with an\ninfected animal.\n[Byline: Bob Anez]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[As you will see from the previous postings referenced below, _Y. pestis_\nis most usually recovered from ground rodents and cats. With the fall\nhunting season upon us, it is hopefully not too late to remind hunters not\nto shoot non-alert game; such animals may well be ill, if not from plague,\nthen from a wide variety of other equally unpleasant conditions, all\ncapable of qualifying the hunter for a Darwin Award. - Mod.MHJ]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 11 Sep 2003\n With the fall\nhunting season upon us, it is hopefully not too late to remind hunters not\nto shoot non-alert game; such animals may well be ill, if not from plague,\nthen from a wide variety of other equally unpleasant conditions, all\ncapable of qualifying the hunter for a Darwin Award. Symptoms of the\nplague are similar to the flu -- fever, nausea, muscle aches, and swollen\nlymph glands -- and usually appear about a week after contact with an\ninfected animal.\n [Byline: Bob Anez]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n Health officials said hunters can protect themselves by wearing gloves when\nbutchering their game, making sure the meat is cooked thoroughly to kill\nany bacteria, and washing hands after handling wild game. Plague[, caused by the bacterium _Yersinia pestis_,] long has been\nwidespread in wildlife, particularly in rodents and animals that eat\nrodents, Damrow said. The state's big game\narchery season opened Saturday, and the general rifle season starts 26 Oct\n2003. ' The plague usually infects 10 to 15 people each year in the United States\nand can be fatal if not treated, according to the Centers for Disease\nControl and Prevention. A deer found near the Big Hole River in southwestern Montana was diagnosed\nwith plague, state officials said Wednesday. While the discovery means hunters should take precautions, it should not\nalter their hunting plans this fall, officials said. Source: Arizona Central 10 Sep 2003 5:05 PM [edited]\n<http://www.azcentral.com/news/articles/0910plaguefound-ON.html>\n\nPlague found in deer,", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-09-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "1987-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "1992-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": States"}, {"location": "Montana", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204434", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, bubonic - Kazakhstan (Kzyl-Orda)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204434", "date": "2003-08-22 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, BUBONIC - KAZAKHSTAN (KZYL-ORDA)\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Tue, 19 Aug 2003 11:29:02 -0700 (PDT)\nFrom: Rakhmanova Nilufar <rakhmanovan@yahoo.com>\nSource: IRIN Big News Network 18 Aug 2003\n<http://feeds.bignewsnetwork.com/redir.php?jid=3ac2f5d75d22fed8>\n\nUN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs\n4-year-old girl dies of bubonic plague\n------------------------------\nA 4-year-old girl died of bubonic plague on Saturday in the south-central\nKazakh province of Kzyl-Orda, while another 27 people who had been in contact\nwith her were now under treatment.\n'We have a confirmed the diagnosis [of plague] regarding the dead child -- a\ngirl born in 1999, who had lived in the Aral District of the Kzyl-Orda\nProvince and passed away on 16 Aug 2003,' Baurzhan Bayserkin, the deputy\nhead of the epidemiological inspection agency of the Kazakh health ministry,\ntold IRIN from the capital, Astana, on Monday.\nBayserkin explained that the disease had been caused by the bite of a flea\ncarrying the plague bacterium, noting that the child had lived in the village\nof Shomysh in Kzyl-Orda Province, which was located in a natural reservoir of\nthe disease.\n'27 people have been in contact with her, including people where she resided,\nas well as those who were in contact with her before she reached the medical\nunit, and medical staff involved in examining her,' the health official said,\nadding that no quarantine (in the region) would be announced, because the\ncase had been one of bubonic plague, which was not as dangerous as the\npneumonic form of the disease.\nAccording to Bayserkin, efforts were being made to tackle the issue, with\nresources from local budgets being allocated in an effort to ensure preventive\ntreatment of those with whom the child had been in contact, adding that steps\nwould also be taken to disinfect the village and kill all its rats, which\nnormally host fleas. Additionally, the local population, mainly cattle\nbreeders and small-scale farmers, would be inoculated against plague, he\nadded.\nThe health official maintained that the situation on the ground was under\ncontrol, while comprehensive epidemiological and preventive measures were\nbeing taken, adding that there had been no other cases of plague.\n3 people contracted bubonic plague in the western Kazakh province of\nMangistau at the end of July [2003] by way of contact with the meat of an\ninfected camel [see ref. below).\nRecent outbreaks have shown that plague may reoccur in areas that have long\nremained free of the disease. Untreated, mortality -- particularly from\npneumonic plague -- may reach high levels. When rapidly diagnosed and\npromptly treated, plague may be successfully managed with antibiotics such as\nstreptomycin and tetracycline, reducing mortality from 60 percent to less\nthan 15 percent.\n--\nNilufar Rakhmanova M.D.\nMaster of Public Health\nBoston University\nSchool of Public Health\nBoston, MA, USA\n<rakhmanovan@yahoo.com>\n[Plague is endenic in this area of Kazakhstan (see refs. below), however,\ngiven the increased amount of tourism & trade to & from remote areas, it is\nimportant that travelers realise the risk. - Mod.JW]", "summary": "27 people have been in contact with her, including people where she resided,\nas well as those who were in contact with her before she reached the medical\nunit, and medical staff involved in examining her,' the health official said,\nadding that no quarantine (in the region) would be announced, because the\ncase had been one of bubonic plague, which was not as dangerous as the\npneumonic form of the disease.\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Master of Public Health\nBoston University\nSchool of Public Health\nBoston, MA, USA\n<rakhmanovan@yahoo.com>\n We have a confirmed the diagnosis [of plague] regarding the dead child -- a\ngirl born in 1999, who had lived in the Aral District of the Kzyl-Orda\nProvince and passed away on 16 Aug 2003,' Baurzhan Bayserkin, the deputy\nhead of the epidemiological inspection agency of the Kazakh health ministry,\ntold IRIN from the capital, Astana, on Monday. According to Bayserkin, efforts were being made to tackle the issue, with\nresources from local budgets being allocated in an effort to ensure preventive\ntreatment of those with whom the child had been in contact, adding that steps\nwould also be taken to disinfect the village and kill all its rats, which\nnormally host fleas. \nA 4-year-old girl died of bubonic plague on Saturday in the south-central\nKazakh province of Kzyl-Orda, while another 27 people who had been in contact\nwith her were now under treatment. Bayserkin explained that the disease had been caused by the bite of a flea\ncarrying the plague bacterium, noting that the child had lived in the village\nof Shomysh in Kzyl-Orda Province, which was located in a natural reservoir of\nthe disease. Source: IRIN Big News Network 18 Aug 2003\n<http://feeds.bignewsnetwork.com/redir.php?jid=3ac2f5d75d22fed8>\n\nUN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs\n4-year-old girl dies of bubonic plague\n When rapidly diagnosed and\npromptly treated, plague may be successfully managed with antibiotics such as\nstreptomycin and tetracycline, reducing mortality from 60 percent to less\nthan 15 percent.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-27 00:00:00", "1999-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-08-16 00:00:00", "2003-08-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Kzyl - Orda Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "KZYL - ORDA", "country": "Kazakhstan"}, {"location": "Astana", "country": "Kazakhstan"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "Kazakhstan"}, {"location": "Kazakh province", "country": "China"}, {"location": "MA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204345", "headline": "PRO/AH> Plague, prairie dogs - USA (CO) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204345", "date": "2003-08-13 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PRAIRIE DOGS - USA (CO) (02)\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: 11 Aug 2003\nFrom: Pamela J. Reynolds <pamr@DOH.STATE.NM.US>\n\nIn response to the moderator's comment (Plague, prairie dogs - USA (CO):\nalert 20030809.1973): 'Cats and other mammals occasionally become infected\nvia the same mechanism as humans', while it is true cats can become\ninfected through flea bite, most cats acquire plague through ingesting\nplague-infected rodents. Flea control on pets is recommended to prevent\nthose pets from bringing plague-infected fleas into the home, but cats that\nhunt can still become infected with plague and serve as a source of human\ninfection.\nReferences:\nEidson, et al. 1988. Feline plague in New Mexico: risk factors and\ntransmission to humans. Am J Public Health 1988; 78(10): 1333-5.\nGage, et al. 2000. Cases of cat-associated human plague in the Western US,\n1977-1998. Clin Infect Dis 2000; 30: 893-900.\n--\nPamela J Reynolds\nVector Control Specialist\nNM Department of Health\nOffice of Epidemiology\nSanta Fe, NM 87505\nemail: <pamr@doh.state.nm.us>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 11 Aug 2003\nFrom: Staci_Myers@occhd.org\n\nSome flea control products just prevent the fleas from reproducing, they\ndon't kill the fleas that are on the animal. In areas where plague is a\nconcern, owners should be sure to use a product that kills fleas.\nStaci L Myers, DVM\nBioterrorism Epidemiologist\nOklahoma City-County Health Department\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[If you are uncertain if the active ingredient in your flea control product\nkills fleas, check with your veterinarian. Also, make sure the product you\nselect is safe for cats if you intend to use the product on your cats. \u00ad\nMod.TG]", "summary": "--\nPamela J Reynolds\nVector Control Specialist\nNM Department of Health\nOffice of Epidemiology\nSanta Fe, NM 87505\nemail: <pamr@doh.state.nm.us>\n******\n \nStaci L Myers, DVM\nBioterrorism Epidemiologist\nOklahoma City-County Health Department\n--\nProMED-mail\n< From: Pamela J. Further\ninvestigations will be needed to identify and describe a possible natural\nfocus (unknown so far in Algeria) as well as to identify the mechanism of\nthe spread of the causative organism, _Yersinia pestis_, in this area.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Source: WHO Outbreak Reports [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_07_10/en/>\n\nAs of 9 Jul 2003, the Ministry of Health, Algeria has reported a total of\n10 laboratory-confirmed cases and 1 probable case of Plague in Oran\ndistrict (see previous report:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_07_03b/en/>). Rakhmanova] [edited]\n\n\n3 cases of plague reported in west Kazakhstan in Mangistausk region\n---------------------------------------------------------\nAccording to the chief sanitary physician of the Republic, first deputy\nminister of Health Care, Anatoliy Belonog, the diagnosis was confirmed\nby serology. He said that they are waiting for the results of bacteriologic\nanalysis.\n\nHe also reported that the number of people found who had contact with\nthe plague patients had increased to 130. They are all now hospitalized to\nprevent spread of infection. The inhabitants of Jangildi & Tauchik\nvillages took part in camel slaughter last week, which is the possible\nsource of the disease. Slaughter and further sale of 180 kg of meat was\ndone without the required veterinary confirmation.\n\nMeanwhile, according to Dr. Belonog, 50 kg of meat has already been\ndiscovered and withdrawn. Preventive measures are being taken to stop\nthe spread of plague among the population. There are about 320 000\npeople in the Mangistausk region. An epizootic of plague has been\ndiscovered among rodents this year [2003].\n\n****\n[2]\nDate: 30 July 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Pravda Central Asia News 30 July 2003\n[in Russian, translated by N. Rakhmanova] [edited]\n<http://pravda.ru>\n\n\n5 men were hospitalized in the Mangistausk region of Kazakhstan with\nsuspected plague. They had eaten camel meat. 3 of them felt ill on the\nthird day and were admitted to hospital with a preliminary diagnosis of\nplague. For confirmation of the diagnosis, Kazakhstan Ministry of Health\nCare staff arrived in the Mangistausk region.\n\nAccording to 'RIA' News, Albert Askarov, chief of the Sanitary\nEpidemiology Surveillance Department of Kazakhstan, said 91 people\nwere hospitalized for preventive investigation. All those hospitalized had\nhad contact with the 5 ill patients. At present the hospital and Tauchik\nvillage are under the control of regional police.\n\nAccording to the Kazakhstan Ministry of Health, the last confirmed cases\nof plague were registered in Kazakhstan in 2001[see ref. below].\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Plague is enzootic in wild rodents in central & southeast Asia, and\ncamels coming into contact with them become infected. Plague is easily\ntreated with tetracycline or chloramphenicol; contacts, including medical\npersonnel, should be given the antibiotic in 4 daily doses for one week\nafter contact ceases. The hospitalization of contacts is presumably\ndesigned to ensure adherence to that regime, & prevent further spread.\nThe use of the police to control epidemics is a common practice in the\ncountries of the NIS/CIS (former USSR). - Mod.JW]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\n Plague is easily\ntreated with tetracycline or chloramphenicol; contacts, including medical\npersonnel, should be given the antibiotic in 4 daily doses for one week\nafter contact ceases. USA (CO): alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204324", "date": "2003-08-09 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PRAIRIE DOGS - USA (COLORADO): ALERT\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 9 Aug 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: KRDO TV 7 Aug 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.krdotv.com/DisplayStory.asp?id=6192>\n\nBubonic plague outbreak hits southern Colorado\nInfected Fleas Are Spreading The Plague Through Prairie Dog Colonies\n------------------------------\nResidents in southern El Paso county are being warned to take immediate\nprecautions as an outbreak of bubonic plague is spreading through prairie\ndog colonies.\nThe plague has been detected in various parts of the county for years now,\nbut this outbreak has the El Paso county health department worried and\nthey're warning people to protect their pets.\nDr. Tom Wood of the El Paso county health department says, 'The thing you\nworry about with dogs is [when the dog] brings in a sick or dying prairie\ndog, and then the fleas are on the owner, who is then exposed to the fleas.\nThe thing we worry about with cats is they actually contract the infection\nand transmit it to people.'\nHealth officials say infected fleas spread the disease, which results in\nflu-like symptoms, and that if you have aches and a fever, see your doctor\nright away.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Plague (_Yersinia pestis_) is enzootic in the south and western parts of\nthe US, including Colorado, New Mexico, Arizona, and California. The usual\ninfected rodent in the USA is the prairie dog, and less often, squirrels.\nThere are about 10 cases each year in humans in the USA, who usually become\ninfected when bitten by the flea vector or, less commonly, by direct\ncontact with the infected rodent. The flea vector of _Y. pestis_\npreferentially feeds on its rodent host but will occasionally feed on a\nhuman. Infection in the flea leads to obstruction of its gastrointestinal\ntract, causing it to regurgitate the bacilli while attempting to feed. Cats\nand other mammals occasionally become infected via the same mechanism as\nhumans.\nAnimal owners should be reminded of a number of new and excellent flea\ncontrol products available through your veterinarian for cats or dogs. -\nMod.TG]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 9 Aug 2003\n Source: KRDO TV 7 Aug 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.krdotv.com/DisplayStory.asp?id=6192>\n\nBubonic plague outbreak hits southern Colorado\nInfected Fleas Are Spreading The Plague Through Prairie Dog Colonies\n------------------------------ The plague has been detected in various parts of the county for years now,\nbut this outbreak has the El Paso county health department worried and\nthey're warning people to protect their pets.\n \nResidents in southern El Paso county are being warned to take immediate\nprecautions as an outbreak of bubonic plague is spreading through prairie\ndog colonies. Dr. Tom Wood of the El Paso county health department says, 'The thing you\nworry about with dogs is [when the dog] brings in a sick or dying prairie\ndog, and then the fleas are on the owner, who is then exposed to the fleas. There are about 10 cases each year in humans in the USA, who usually become\ninfected when bitten by the flea vector or, less commonly, by direct\ncontact with the infected rodent. Health officials say infected fleas spread the disease, which results in\nflu-like symptoms, and that if you have aches and a fever, see your doctor\nright away.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "Arizona", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "El Paso", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204097", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - Algeria (Oran) (04)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204097", "date": "2003-07-04 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE - ALGERIA (ORAN) (04)\n****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu, 3 Jul 2003\nFrom: Marianne Hopp <mjhopp12@yahoo.com>\nSource: WHO Outbreak Reports [edieted]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_07_03b/en/>\n\nPlague in Algeria - Update\n---------------------------\nAs of 2 Jul 2003, the Ministry of Health, Algeria has reported a\ntotal of 10 cases, of which 8 have been laboratory-confirmed (see\nprevious report <http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_06_24a/en/>). These\ninclude 8 cases of bubonic plague and 2 of septicemic plague, of\nwhich one was fatal. 8 additional cases are under investigation.\nA team from WHO and the Institut Pasteur, Paris, France, a partner in\nthe Global Outbreak Alert and Response Network\n(<http://www.who.int/csr/outbreaknetwork/en/>) is working with the\nMinistry of Health to carry out epidemiological investigations and\nassist with vector control measures.\n----\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "A team from WHO and the Institut Pasteur, Paris, France, a partner in\nthe Global Outbreak Alert and Response Network\n(<http://www.who.int/csr/outbreaknetwork/en/>) is working with the\nMinistry of Health to carry out epidemiological investigations and\nassist with vector control measures.\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n As of 2 Jul 2003, the Ministry of Health, Algeria has reported a\ntotal of 10 cases, of which 8 have been laboratory-confirmed (see\nprevious report <http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_06_24a/en/>). A 12th\ncase of the plague was reported today near Oran, Algeria's second-largest city.\n11 cases have been confirmed over the past weeks near Oran, most in the\ntown of Kehailia, 400 km west of Algiers. One child has died.\n'A WHO technical assistance team, including plague experts, arrives on 29\nJun 2003. They'll study the plague,' said the official.\nBubonic plague killed an estimated 25 million people during the Middle Ages\nbut is now treatable with antibiotics. The disease is [usually - Mod.LL]\nspread to humans through bites from fleas infected by rats.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[ProMED awaits the findings of the WHO investigation, since this disease\nhas not been endemic in Algeria in the recent past. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 29 Jun 2003\n \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n Source: South African Broadcasting Corporation 29 Jun 2003 19:35 [edited]\n<http://www.sabcnews.com/africa/north_africa/0,1009,61331,00.html>\n\nWHO to visit Algeria as new plague cases reported\n \n11 cases have been confirmed over the past weeks near Oran, most in the\ntown of Kehailia, 400 km west of Algiers. PLAGUE, BUBONIC - ALGERIA (ORAN) (03)\n**************************\n A World Health Organization (WHO) team is due to visit Algeria 29 Jun 2003\namid an outbreak of bubonic plague, a Health Ministry official said. To date, no new cases have been officially reported.\n\nWHO is working with the Ministry of Health to provide rapid diagnostic tests\nand technical support in liaison with WHO Collaborating Centers: Institut\nPasteur, Paris, France, also a partner in the Global Outbreak Alert and\nResponse Network <http://www.who.int/csr/outbreaknetwork/en/>, and Kazakh\nScientific Center for Quarantine and Zoonotic Diseases, Almaty, Kazakhstan.\n\nFor More Information\n\n- WHO Fact Sheet on Plague\n<http://www.who.int/inf-fs/en/fact267.html>\n- Plague Manual: Epidemiology, Distribution, Surveillance and Control\n<http://www.who.int/emc-documents/plague/whocdscsredc992c.html>\n---\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue, 24 Jun 2003\n <http://www.who.int/inf-fs/en/fact267.html>\n- Plague Manual: Epidemiology, Distribution, Surveillance and Control\n<http://www.who.int/emc-documents/plague/whocdscsredc992c.html>\n---\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org> \n\nWHO is working with the Ministry of Health to provide rapid diagnostic tests\nand technical support in liaison with WHO Collaborating Centers: Institut\nPasteur, Paris, France, also a partner in the Global Outbreak Alert and\nResponse Network <http://www.who.int/csr/outbreaknetwork/en/>, and Kazakh\nScientific Center for Quarantine and Zoonotic Diseases, Almaty, Kazakhstan.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2003-06-23 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "Kazakhstan"}, {"location": "Tafraoui", "country": "Algeria"}, {"location": "Algeria", "country": "Algeria"}, {"location": "Paris", "country": "France"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2203557", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - The fatal case arrived late in\nthe course of the illness at hospital mid-week, and could not be saved. The\nothers are being treated and their condition is improving.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Plague is not commonly reported from North Africa, and ProMED-mail has not\nreported a case from Algiers in its 10 years of existence, but consumption\nof the meat of an infected camel has been reported to cause plague in\nneighboring Libya (Christie AB, Chen TH, Elberg SS. Plague in camels and\ngoats: their role in human epidemics. J Infect Dis 1980; 141: 724-6). I\nalso heard of a similar case in Saudi Arabia years ago. The remoteness of\nthis location in Algeria means that these cases are very unlikely to have\nimplications for international trade or travel. - Mod.JW/DS]\n.......................jw/sh\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The GIDEON database indicates that plague is\nendemic to Uganda's western region, Nebbi District, and northern region,\nArua District. A total of 18 cases were reported in 1954; 153 cases (3\nfatal) were reported in 1982; 340 (27 fatal) in 1986; 167 (18 fatal) in\n1993 (the latter from the western, Nebbi District). From the Arua District,\n49 (16 fatal) cases were reported in 1998. In the intervening years, few\ncases were reported. Rodent control is undoubtedly the key to altering the\npattern. - Mod. Plague is endemic in Mongolia, and human cases\nof bubonic plague are reported every year, mainly in country dwellers\nwho have been hunting marmots for their fur. Marmots are large,\nburrowing rodents similar to groundhogs (woodchucks) in the USA. -\nMod.JW]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n Plague is endemic in Mongolia, and human cases\nof bubonic plague are reported every year, mainly in country dwellers\nwho have been hunting marmots for their fur. The first victim this year was a 9 year\nold girl from Zavedo village. Outbreaks of bubonic plague have occurred in\nNsanje district at the southern tip of the country since 1994, with the\nnumber of cases peaking at 304 in 1999. There were no reported cases for\nthe 2 years before April 2002.\nThe plague, which has a case fatality ratio of up to 60 per cent if left\nuntreated, has also been reported in Mozambique, leading to cross-border\ncollaboration between Mozambican and Malawian health teams. 'WHO is\nconcerned due to the fact that the current epidemic is combined with\nmalnutrition because of the food shortage in the country. It is a\nwell-known fact that prevalence and severity of all infectious diseases\nincrease where malnutrition is rampant,' a statement said.\nA World Food Program (WFP) assessment released this week estimated that 3.2\nmillion Malawians face food shortages due to anticipated food shortages\nthis year. The country is only just recovering from a cholera epidemic that\nkilled over 900 people. Malawi's overstretched health services now share\nthe added burden of acquiring adequate medical staff and finding chemicals\nto spray against fleas and rodents. The UN children's agency, UNICEF, and\nWHO response includes providing cash to districts to buy insecticides for\nhousehold spraying and sending a consultant to give front-line health\nworkers refresher training.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The Nsanje district of Malawi has been the subject of ProMED-mail postings\nin the past (see below). The role of population disruption due to war,\nfamine, floods and other calamities cannot be overemphasized in the\nepidemiology of a variety of infectious diseases including plague. In such\nsituations involving plague, one must be concerned about the possibility of\npneumonic plague with the possibility of person to person spread and a very\nhigh mortality even with treatment. The bubonic form of _Yersinia pestis_\ninfection itself is spread to man from infected rodent fleas and without\nsecondary pneumonia is not infectious to others. - Mod.LL]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n In such\nsituations involving plague, one must be concerned about the possibility of\npneumonic plague with the possibility of person to person spread and a very\nhigh mortality even with treatment. ---------------------------\nLilongwe (UN Integrated Regional Information Networks/All Africa Global\nMedia): Malawi's existing health challenges of cholera, malnutrition,\nmalaria, and HIV/AIDS have been joined by another -- the bubonic plague. The UN children's agency, UNICEF, and\nWHO response includes providing cash to districts to buy insecticides for\nhousehold spraying and sending a consultant to give front-line health\nworkers refresher training. \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n Since April 2002, 71 cases of the disease carried by fleas and rodents have\nbeen reported in the far south of the country, the World Health\nOrganization said on 30 May 2002. Outbreaks of bubonic plague have occurred in\nNsanje district at the southern tip of the country since 1994, with the\nnumber of cases peaking at 304 in 1999. The plague, which has a case fatality ratio of up to 60 per cent if left\nuntreated, has also been reported in Mozambique, leading to cross-border\ncollaboration between Mozambican and Malawian health teams. Malawi, Mozambique", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2201772", "date": "2002-05-10 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, BUBONIC - MALAWI, MOZAMBIQUE\n****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 8 May 2002 17:24:42 -0400 [the delay in posting is regretted]\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: African Eye News Service/All Africa Global Media, AllAfrica.com\n\nBubonic Plague Breaks Out in Lilongwe\n------------------------------\nMalawi health officials are battling to contain a bubonic plague outbreak in\nthe southern border district of Nsanje.\nThe first cases were reported in April [2002] and officials suspect it\nspread from the neighbouring Mozambican district of Mutarara where an\noutbreak was reported in March [2002].\nThe bacterium responsible for the disease is carried by fleas and was most\nlikely brought into Malawi by rats, said Nsanje environmental officer\nGeorge Chitimbe.\nA total of 10 people are already being treated for the disease, he said.\n'We are working hard to contain the disease and have contacted Mozambique\nhealth officials to formulate a joint strategy to contain it,' he said.\nSymptoms include shivering, vomiting, headaches, giddiness, intolerance to\nlight, pain in the back and limbs and a white coating on the tongue.\nAlthough it causes extreme discomfort the disease is easily treated with\nmodern medicine [antibiotics] and once a person has recovered, they will\nhave acquired an immunity to the disease, Chitimbe said. If untreated, the\nmortality rate can be as high as 75 percent.\n[by Brian Ligomeka]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Plague is endemic in this area. - Mod.JW]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n [by Brian Ligomeka]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org Although it causes extreme discomfort the disease is easily treated with\nmodern medicine [antibiotics] and once a person has recovered, they will\nhave acquired an immunity to the disease, Chitimbe said. The first cases were reported in April [2002] and officials suspect it\nspread from the neighbouring Mozambican district of Mutarara where an\noutbreak was reported in March [2002]. The bacterium responsible for the disease is carried by fleas and was most\nlikely brought into Malawi by rats, said Nsanje environmental officer\nGeorge Chitimbe. \nMalawi health officials are battling to contain a bubonic plague outbreak in\nthe southern border district of Nsanje. If untreated, the\nmortality rate can be as high as 75 percent.\n PLAGUE, BUBONIC - MALAWI, MOZAMBIQUE\n****************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-05-08 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Malawi", "country": "Malawi"}, {"location": "Mutarara", "country": "Mozambique"}, {"location": "Nsanje", "country": "Malawi"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2201747", "headline": "PRO/AH> Plague, prairie dogs, suspected - USA (CO) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2201747", "date": "2002-05-07 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, PRAIRIE DOGS, SUSPECTED - USA (COLORADO) (02)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 6 May 2002\nFrom: Julia N Allen, PhD, DVM <DrJNA@att.net>\n\n\n[From a previous post: Plague Suspected In Jefferson County Prairie\nDog Die-Off Leads To Health Warning . . . Pet owners who live close\nto rodent populations should dust their pets with flea powder,\nfollowing the instructions on the label.]\n\nThe use of 'flea powder' is considerably outdated in our 'war on fleas.'\n\nNot only is it hazardous to the person applying it (inhalation of the\npowder as it is dusted on, and contact with the skin), the pet also\ninhales and ingests the toxic insecticide. The powder does not absorb\nor dissipate with time, so anyone who touches or handles the pet later\nmay contact and potentially ingest the product (especially children).\n\nFlea control on pets has been revolutionized with the use of topical\ndrops which are applied monthly, absorbed into the skin, and continue\nto repel and kill fleas for 30 days. Sprays have also been revolutionized\nin their safety and effectiveness. In many places flea powder is no\nlonger marketed.\n\nHopefully, public health officials will take note of this in their future\npublic recommendations - and consult a local veterinarian if they have\nany questions. I'm concerned about pet owners rushing to purchase\n'powder' when it is not the product of choice.\n\n\u00ad\u00ad\nJulia N Allen, PhD, DVM\nEmergency Management Animal Services\nSeattle, WA 98199 USA\n<DrJNA@att.net>\n\n[Dr. Allen is correct. Powder is not the flea prevention of choice. There\nare number of excellent products on the market. Please consult your\nveterinarian for the best choice for your pet. - Mod.TG]\n\n[A reader has sent the following comments on the original post on this\nsubject -- see first ref. below.\n\n'Plague is enzootic, not endemic, since it involves other animals\nbesides man. Colorado is not in the southwestern USA. Ground\nsquirrels are the natural hosts, but not the golden-mantled species.\nConcerning 'a warm-blooded prairie dog', there are no cold-blooded\nones.'\n\nProMED is grateful for these corrections. - Mod.JW]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 6 May 2002\n \n\n\u00ad\u00ad\nJulia N Allen, PhD, DVM\nEmergency Management Animal Services\n \n\nFlea control on pets has been revolutionized with the use of topical\ndrops which are applied monthly, absorbed into the skin, and continue\nto repel and kill fleas for 30 days. \n\nNot only is it hazardous to the person applying it (inhalation of the\npowder as it is dusted on, and contact with the skin), the pet also\ninhales and ingests the toxic insecticide. Pet owners who live close\nto rodent populations should dust their pets with flea powder,\nfollowing the instructions on the label.] The powder does not absorb\nor dissipate with time, so anyone who touches or handles the pet later\nmay contact and potentially ingest the product (especially children). Hopefully, public health officials will take note of this in their future\npublic recommendations - and consult a local veterinarian if they have\nany questions. TG]\n\n[A reader has sent the following comments on the original post on this\nsubject -- see first ref. below.
