PLAGUE, PRAIRIE DOGS, SUSPECTED - USA (COLORADO) (02)\n **\n Ground\n \n \n\nThe use of 'flea powder' is considerably outdated in our 'war on fleas.'", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-05-06 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Jefferson County Prairie", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Seattle", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2202828", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, bubonic - USA (New York City ex New Mexico)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2202828", "date": "2002-11-06 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, BUBONIC - USA (NEW YORK CITY ex NEW MEXICO)\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 6 Oct 2002\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: NY1.com [edited]\n<http://www.ny1.com/ny/TopStories/SubTopic/index.html?topicintid=1&subtopicintid=1&contentintid=25664>\n[Our thanks to George Robertson for submitting an article on this as well.\n- Mod.MPP]\n\nMan Tests Positive For Bubonic Plague In Manhattan\n------------------------------------------------------------------------\nA 53-year-old man tested positive in preliminary tests for bubonic plague\nat the Beth Israel Hospital in Manhattan Wednesday, 6 Nov 2002. Tests on\nhis 47-year-old wife, who had complained of the same symptoms, have not\ncome in yet.\nThe couple, who are from New Mexico, showed up at the hospital Tuesday [5\nNov 2002] night with flu-like symptoms, according to the Associated Press.\nHospital spokesman Mike Quane told the AP that the couple was placed in\nisolation. Health officials had tested for a number of different\nrespiratory illnesses, including plague. At about 7 PM Wednesday [6 Nov\n2002], the husband was said to be in very critical condition; his wife was\nin stable condition. It appears that the couple contracted the illness in\ntheir home town in New Mexico. Officials said animals in that area - fleas\nand rodents - have been tested and tested positive for the [organism that\ncauses] bubonic plague. Health officials say there is no cause for concern,\nsince it looks like the couple did not contract the illness in New York.\nThe plague is not uncommon in the southwestern USA.\nBubonic plague is caused by the bacteria _Yersinia pestis_and it is\ntypically spread from wild rodents like ground squirrels and prairie dogs\nvia infected flea bites. It can be contracted from infected animals or\ntheir infected fleas. The plague, which was called the 'Black Plague,' is\nnotorious for its spread through Europe during the 14th century, when it\nkilled millions of people. Nowadays, it can be treated effectively with\nantibiotics.\nAccording to the Centers for Disease Control, initial symptoms of bubonic\nplague include a swollen and very tender lymph gland, fever, chills,\nheadaches, extreme exhaustion. People who develop the plague also tend to\nhave a history of exposure to infected rodents or fleas. Symptoms appear\nabout 2 to 7 days after infection. Bubonic plague can be fatal if left\nuntreated.\n---\nProMED-mail\npromed@promedmail.org\n[Assuming that there has been a microbiological confirmation, it is highly\nlikely that the couple acquired plague while at home in New Mexico in the\nAmerican Southwest where the disease has been identified in animals as well\nas humans (see prior ProMED-mail postings listed below). It is bothersome\nthat the clinical description available at this time does not specifically\nmention the presence of a bubo - the characteristic swollen lymph\ngland. If it was truly absent and one or both of the couple had a\npneumonia-like presentation, the diagnosis of pneumonic plague should be\nconsidered. _Yersinia pestis_ (the organism responsible for plague) is a\nclass A biologic agent. Concern of a possible intentional infection would\nbe raised if these cases had occurred in a couple that had not had exposure\nin a known endemic area.\nAlthough the bubonic form of plague does not spread from person-to-person,\nboth primary pneumonic plague (spread directly from an aerosol) and\nsecondary pneumonic plague (spread to the lung via the bloodstream from the\ninfected lymph node) can be transmitted from person-to-person.\nMore information on these cases would be appreciated. - Mods.LL/MPP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 6 Oct 2002\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org Although the bubonic form of plague does not spread from person-to-person,\nboth primary pneumonic plague (spread directly from an aerosol) and\nsecondary pneumonic plague (spread to the lung via the bloodstream from the\ninfected lymph node) can be transmitted from person-to-person. [Assuming that there has been a microbiological confirmation, it is highly\nlikely that the couple acquired plague while at home in New Mexico in the\nAmerican Southwest where the disease has been identified in animals as well\nas humans (see prior ProMED-mail postings listed below). It is bothersome\nthat the clinical description available at this time does not specifically\nmention the presence of a bubo - the characteristic swollen lymph\ngland. >\nSource: NY1.com [edited]\n<http://www.ny1.com/ny/TopStories/SubTopic/index.html?topicintid=1&subtopicintid=1&contentintid=25664>\n Officials said animals in that area - fleas\nand rodents - have been tested and tested positive for the [organism that\ncauses] bubonic plague. The plague, which was called the 'Black Plague,' is\nnotorious for its spread through Europe during the 14th century, when it\nkilled millions of people. According to the Centers for Disease Control, initial symptoms of bubonic\nplague include a swollen and very tender lymph gland, fever, chills,\nheadaches, extreme exhaustion. If it was truly absent and one or both of the couple had a\npneumonia-like presentation, the diagnosis of pneumonic plague should be\nconsidered. Yersinia pestis_and it is\ntypically spread from wild rodents like ground squirrels and prairie dogs\nvia infected flea bites. Concern of a possible intentional infection would\nbe raised if these cases had occurred in a couple that had not had exposure\nin a known endemic area. At about 7 PM Wednesday [6 Nov\n2002], the husband was said to be in very critical condition; his wife was\nin stable condition. Tests on\nhis 47-year-old wife, who had complained of the same symptoms, have not\ncome in yet. Nowadays, it can be treated effectively with\nantibiotics.\n A 53-year-old man tested positive in preliminary tests for bubonic plague\nat the Beth Israel Hospital in Manhattan Wednesday, 6 Nov 2002.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2002-03-25 00:00:00", "2002-11-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Manhattan", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "NEW YORK CITY", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2201413", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague - India (Chandigarh) (04): WHO confirmation", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2201413", "date": "2002-02-20 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE - INDIA (CHANDIGARH) (04): WHO CONFIRMATION\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>", "summary": "", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "2202829", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Plague, bubonic - New York City ex New Mexico (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2202829", "date": "2002-11-06 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, BUBONIC - NEW YORK CITY ex NEW MEXICO (02)\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: 6 Nov 2002\nFrom: New York City Department of Health & Mental Hygiene\nSource: New York City Department of Health & Mental Hygiene Alert\n<http://www.ci.nyc.ny.us/html/doh/>\n\nTwo cases of travel-associated bubonic plague in New York City\n---------------------------------\nThe New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene (NYC DOHMH) has\npresumptively diagnosed bubonic plague in a 53-year-old male resident of\nNew Mexico who was visiting New York City. In addition, the patient's\n47-year-old wife has symptoms consistent with bubonic plague and laboratory\ntest results are pending.\nBoth patients reside in Santa Fe County, New Mexico - in an area that is\nknown to be an enzootic focus for plague. The source of these patients'\ninfections is suspected to be rodents and rodent fleas near their home, as\na woodrat that was found in the patients' back yard this past July tested\npositive for plague. Fleas taken from this woodrat also tested positive\nfor plague.\nThis couple traveled to New York City on November 1, 2002 and both\ndeveloped a flu-like illness on November 3rd. As symptoms continued to\nworsen, they were admitted to a hospital on November 5th and on examination\nboth had fever and swollen, tender inguinal lymph nodes ('buboes'). A\nblood culture on the male patient tested positive at the NYC DOHMH's Public\nHealth Laboratory this evening for Yersinia pestis by both polymerase chain\nreaction and direct fluorescent antibody testing. Further confirmatory\ntests will be performed by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention\n(CDC). Laboratory tests on the female patient are still pending, but her\nclinical presentation is consistent with bubonic plague. Both patients are\nbeing treated with aminoglycosides and doxycycline. The 53-year-old male,\nwho is also diabetic, is in critical condition with a secondary septicemia\nand multi-system failure; the 47-year-old female is stable.\nAll epidemiologic evidence suggests that these infections were naturally\nacquired in New Mexico. Although the exact source of exposure for these\npatients is not yet known, most human plague cases are due to bites from\nplague-infected fleas around the home. The usual incubation period for\nplague is between 2 to 7 days. As these patients became ill within 48\nhours of their arrival in New York City, their exposure occurred in New\nMexico. Since Y. pestis was isolated recently from fleas on their property,\nthis is the location where they probably were infected. The New Mexico\nDepartment of Health and the CDC are currently conducting an environmental\ninvestigation in the area around these patients' home to assess potential\nsources of exposure.\nAs neither patient had symptoms or radiographic evidence of pneumonia,\nantibiotic prophylaxis has not been recommended for any hospital or social\ncontacts. Laboratory staff handling specimens from these patients have\nbeen instructed to follow Biosafety Level 2 precautions.\nNaturally occurring plague is a disease primarily affecting rodents, and\ntransmission between rodents is via infected fleas. In the United States,\nbubonic plague is transmitted to humans through the bites of infected\nfleas; bubonic plague is not transmitted person to person. Pneumonic\nplague is transmitted after plague bacilli are inhaled following direct\ncontact with infected animals, including rodents, wildlife and pets (cats\nand dogs) or via droplet transmission from a patient with pneumonic plague.\nBubonic plague symptoms in humans include fever; painful swollen lymph\nnodes in the groin, armpit or neck areas; chills; and headache, vomiting,\nand diarrhea. Patients may develop secondary septicemic plague or pneumonic\nplague; pneumonic plague can be spread person-to-person. With prompt\ndiagnosis and appropriate antibiotic treatment and supportive care, most\npatients with bubonic plague survive.\nHuman plague has been reported most often from the four western states of\nArizona, California, Colorado and New Mexico. Wild rodents, especially\nground squirrels and prairie dogs, are the natural reservoir for the plague\nbacterium. Since January 1980, there have been 272 cases of plague\nreported in the United States; the overwhelming majority of cases were\nbubonic plague. Of these, 143 (53%) were acquired in New Mexico. Plague\nis not enzootic in the eastern United States; there has not been a case of\nplague in New York City in at least 100 years.\nUseful websites for additional information on plague include:\nCenters for Disease Control and Prevention\n\nJohns Hopkins Center for Civilian Biodefense Strategies\n\nCenter for Infectious Disease Research and Policy\n\n--\nNew York City Department of Health & Mental Hygiene\n<http://www.ci.nyc.ny.us/html/doh/>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 6 Nov 2002\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: New York City Department of Health & Mental Hygiene Press Release\n<http://www.ci.nyc.ny.us/html/doh/html/public/press02/pr931106.html>\n\nAn Individual who travelled to New York City from Sante Fe, New Mexico is\npreliminarily positive for plague\nThis Form Of Plague Is Not Spread From Person-To-Person\n------------------------------------------------\nThe New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene (DOHMH) has\npresumptively diagnosed bubonic plague in a 53-year-old male resident of\nSanta Fe, New Mexico who was visiting New York City. In addition, the\npatient's 47-year-old wife has similar symptoms and laboratory test results\nare pending. He is currently hospitalized in critical condition; she is in\nstable condition. The couple arrived in New York City from New Mexico on\nNovember 1, 2002 and went to the hospital after two days of flu-like\nsymptoms, high fevers and swollen lymph nodes. The usual incubation period\nfor plague is between two to seven days. As these patients became ill\nwithin 48 hours of their arrival in New York City, their exposure occurred\nin New Mexico. These individuals live in a plague-endemic area and all\nepidemiologic evidence indicates that the source of their infection is\nrodents and rodent fleas in the vicinity of their home in which plague was\nconfirmed earlier this summer. Bubonic plague is not spread from\nperson-to-person. An investigation of the patients' home is being conducted\nby the New Mexico Department of Health (NMDOH) and the U.S. Centers for\nDisease Control and Prevention (CDC).\nBubonic plague is a bacterial disease of rodents transmitted to humans\nthrough the bites of infected fleas. Pneumonic plague, a more serious form\nof the disease occurs when plague bacteria are inhaled after direct contact\nwith infected animals including rodents, wildlife and pets. Most people\nbecome ill two to seven days after being infected with the plague bacteria.\nPlague symptoms in humans include fever; painful swollen lymph nodes in the\ngroin, armpit or neck areas; chills; and sometimes headache, vomiting, and\ndiarrhea. With prompt diagnosis and appropriate antibiotic treatment, the\nfatality rate in people can be greatly reduced.\nCDC reports that there are 10-15 cases of plague per year, mostly rural\nareas in New Mexico, Colorado, Arizona, California, Oregon and Nevada. The\nillness occurs in areas where infection of wild animals is common,\nincluding parts of the American Southwest. Wild rodents, especially ground\nsquirrels and prairie dogs, are the natural reservoir for the plague\nbacterium. Rats, other wild rodents, cats and dogs can become infected with\nplague, and the disease is occasionally transmitted to people by these\nanimals or their infected fleas. Most patients with plague can be\nsuccessfully treated with antibiotics, particularly if treated in the early\nstages of the disease. If detected in its early stages, plague is treatable\nwith antibiotics. Plague is treatable by a 10-day course of antibiotics.\nHowever, approximately 10% of patients who become ill from plague die.\nThe hospital reported the case to the DOHMH on Tuesday, November 5. Within\nhours of this report, specimens were sent to DOHMH's Public Health\nLaboratories and presumptive positive results were received this evening.\nThis case underscores the critical link between hospitals and physicians\nwith the DOHMH to control and prevent diseases in New York City. The DOHMH\nis working closely with CDC, NMDOH and the New York State Department of\nHealth in this investigation.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[In our earlier report we noted the lack of mention of bubos with concern\nfor a possible plague pneumonia picture. Thanks to the excellent summary\nof the clinical syndrome and epidemiologic information provided by the New\nYork City Department of Health & Mental Hygiene, it is clear these are\ncases of classical bubonic plague. -\nWe were reminded by 'Jeff Danska' <jdanska@salud.unm.edu> in the Department\nof Medicine UNM School of Medicine, that there have not been any reports of\nhuman plague cases in New Mexico this year prior to these cases. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "Useful websites for additional information on plague include:\nCenters for Disease Control and Prevention\n\nJohns Hopkins Center for Civilian Biodefense Strategies\n\nCenter for Infectious Disease Research and Policy\n\n--\nNew York City Department of Health & Mental Hygiene\n<http://www.ci.nyc.ny.us/html/doh/>\n******\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\n Pneumonic\nplague is transmitted after plague bacilli are inhaled following direct\ncontact with infected animals, including rodents, wildlife and pets (cats\nand dogs) or via droplet transmission from a patient with pneumonic plague. These individuals live in a plague-endemic area and all\nepidemiologic evidence indicates that the source of their infection is\nrodents and rodent fleas in the vicinity of their home in which plague was\nconfirmed earlier this summer. The source of these patients'\ninfections is suspected to be rodents and rodent fleas near their home, as\na woodrat that was found in the patients' back yard this past July tested\npositive for plague. Thanks to the excellent summary\nof the clinical syndrome and epidemiologic information provided by the New\nYork City Department of Health & Mental Hygiene, it is clear these are\ncases of classical bubonic plague. Although the exact source of exposure for these\npatients is not yet known, most human plague cases are due to bites from\nplague-infected fleas around the home. \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n Pneumonic plague, a more serious form\nof the disease occurs when plague bacteria are inhaled after direct contact\nwith infected animals including rodents, wildlife and pets. Brazil (Bahia)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2199860", "date": "2001-05-06 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, HUMAN - BRAZIL (BAHIA)\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Sat 5 May 2001\nFrom: Marianne Hopp <mhopp@iri.ldgo.columbia.edu>\nSource: WHO/WER Notifications received from 27 Apr to 3 May 2001\n\nBrazil reports one non-fatal case of plague from Serrinha municipality,\nBahia State, with date of 2 Nov 2000.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Bahia State is an endemic focus of plague, & sporadic cases have been\nreported from there for years. WHO often labels reports such as these as\nhaving no implications for international travel.\nPlague is one of the 3 diseases -- the others are cholera & yellow fever --\nwhich countries are obligated to report to WHO within 24 hours of even a\nsuspicion of a case. While a late report is better than none at all --\nnobody wants to see countries suppressing identification of a case because\nthey are late reporting it -- it is of little use to public health. A\ntimely report would have alerted local physicians to consider plague as an\nalternative diagnosis in febrile patients, and travel doctors in other\ncountries to consider plague in febrile tourists returning from travel in\nBahia, Brazil. We may now never know whether absence of reports of\nsubsequent cases from the same focus is due to delays in reporting, or lack\nof recognition because there was no index of suspicion among physicians at\nthe time. - Mod.JW]\n............................................jw/es/ds\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. (Ituri)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2196842", "date": "1999-11-05 23:50:00", "main_text": "CHOLERA, PLAGUE - CONGO, DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC\n(ITURI)\n******************************************\nA ProMED post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>\n\nDate: Thu, 04 Nov 1999 20:50:02 -0500\nFrom: 'Marjorie P. Pollack' <pollackmp@mindspring.com>\nSource: UN Integrated Regional Information Network, 3 Nov 1999\n[edited]\n\nDRC: Ituri situation 'catastrophic'\n-----------------------------------------\nIn a report received by IRIN on Wednesday, OCHA said there\nwere widespread epidemics of cholera, measles and the plague\n[presumably bubonic; in that part of Africa it is endemic - Mod.JW].\nThe humanitarian situation in the northeast district of Ituri, wracked\nby civil strife since June [1999], has been described as\ncatastrophic. An exploratory mission by OCHA last month found\nthat over 7000 people had been killed and over 100 000 people\ndisplaced.\nEmergency humanitarian action was urgently needed to help\nthousands of people at risk, the report stressed. The conflict pits\nthe Hema ethnic group against the Lendu people in a dispute over\nland in the Djugu area. An inter-agency follow-up mission is\ncurrently on the ground.\n--\nThis item is delivered by the UN's IRIN humanitarian information unit\ne-mail: irin@ocha.unon.org\nfax: +254 2 622129\nWeb: http://www.reliefweb.int/IRIN\nbut may not necessarily reflect the views of the United Nations. KAZAKHSTAN (AKTYUBINSK)\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>\n\nDate: Tue 13 Jul 1999\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@usa.healthnet.org>\nSource: Interfax News Agency, Thu 08 Jul 1999\n\nA 7-year-old boy residing in the settlement of Murunkum, Aktyubinsk region\nin western\nKazakhstan has been hospitalized with bubonic plague, Zhumamurat Aldashev,\nhead of the regional Public Health Board, told Interfax-Kazakhstan on\nThursday.\nEighteen residents of the settlement and 78 residents of the southern town\nof Aralsk who had contact with the child have also been sent to the\nhospital, he said. They show no signs of the plague.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@usa.healthnet.org>\n[Kazakhstan has several endemic foci of plague, so on the face of it this is\nnot an abnormal case. Whitham <rwhitha@emory.edu>\n\n'[...Nevertheless, cats that explore rodent burrows, or kill and eat\nflea-infested rodents, could serve as temporary hosts for these\nectoparasites and bring them into human habitations, etc., where they could\njump off and bite people - Mod CHC]'\nJudging from what Dr. Eidson has said, cats aren't very suitable hosts for\nrodent fleas (they apparently don't spend much time on them). The\npossibility would seem to be rather remote that they would wait on a cat's\nbody for it to come home, then to jump on an equally unsuitable host\n(human) to finally transmit the plaque. It is probably possible, but\nevidentially not the center of attention for a control program.\n--\nDr. Raymond G. Whitham\n<rwhitha@emory.edu>\n[Had I known anyone would read my comments, I would have said, 'fed on\npeople', not 'bite people'. Nonetheless -- various workers have recovered\nrodent fleas from pets. There has been a cat-associated human plague case\nin northwestern New Mexico, where fleas were noted on the cat. Cat fleas\n(_Ctenocephalides felis_) are not present in this part of the U.S. (too\ndry) and the fleas almost undoubtedly were associated with the prairie\ndog/rock squirrel die-off that was going on in the same area. Rodent fleas\nmight not stay on pets for long periods of time but the fact that\ninvestigators have found them on these animals suggests that some rodent\nfleas stay on long enough to be carried into homes. While treating cats or\ndogs with flea powders that are insecticidal or repellent might not\ncompletely solve the problem, it is a relatively easy operation to perform\nand could result in some reduction of risks (of course, it would be best if\npeople confined their animals but they rarely do so). The entire\nprevention/control package would include community education, dusting\nrodent burrows, heightened surveillance, implementation of rodent\nsanitation measures, etc., as well as asking people to confine their\nanimals and to treat them for fleas. Treating pets is just a minor part of\nthe public health response and scarcely constitutes the 'center of\nattention' of a control/prevention program. Let's cut this string. - Mod\nCHC]\n...................................................................chc/jw\n\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. PLAGUE, CATS AND DOGS TO HUMANS (02)\n Plague, cats & dogs to humans 990619110831]\n ***********************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2195912", "headline": "PRO/AH> Plague, cats & dogs to humans", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2195912", "date": "1999-06-19 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE, CATS & DOGS TO HUMANS\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>\n[see also\nPlague, human - USA (Colorado) (03) 990609213850\nPlague, cats - USA (New Mexico) 990531221457\nPlague, cats - USA (New Mexico) (02) 990602121020]\nDate: Mon, 7 Jun 1999 10:37:34 -0400\nFrom: Millicent Eidson <mxe04@health.state.ny.us>\n\nThe recent postings about\nplague on ProMED-mail didn't address really well the issue of cats, plague,\nand\nrisk of transmission to humans. As the former State Public Health\nVeterinarian in New Mexico, and author of several papers on cats, plague,\nand transmission to people, I was able to gain a lot of experience in this\narea.\nWhenever the risk of cats acquiring plague is mentioned, flea control is\nalways emphasized. Our studies in New Mexico indicated that cats probably\ndo not primarily acquire plague by the bite of a flea. In some unpublished\nresearch we did, having seen fleas on your cat or lack of use of flea\ncontrol did not increase the probability of a cat getting plague, in\ncomparison to other cats in the household and neighborhood that did not\ncome down with the disease. Evidence in the infected cats of a flea bite,\nsuch as an abscess on the leg or back, or bubo in those areas, was\nrelatively rare. In addition, the type of fleas that spread plague in the\nwestern U.S. are rodent fleas, not cat fleas, and as such don't spend a\nwhole lot of time on cats compared to rodents.\nRather, the primary risk\nfactor was hunting behavior. This fits with the predominant symptom in cat\nplague cases of submandibular lymphadenopathy (with those lymph nodes\ndraining the mouth/head area). Of course, we can't be sure whether the\ncats are becoming infected by direct inoculation of the organism in the\ninfected rodents into the mouth, or by infected fleas from the rodents\nbiting the cat in the face while the cat is eating them. Lesions inside\nthe mouth and tongue, including abscesses, were also reported, perhaps\nsupporting the direct inoculation rather than flea bites to the face.\nThus, although flea control is important and should be recommended, in\nregards to reducing cats getting plague, preventing hunting behavior is\nmore important, and of course, can be difficult to do with outdoor cats. I\nbelieve the educational materials on plague need to emphasize the\nimportance, if you have an outdoor hunting cat, of prompt veterinary\ndiagnosis of any illness, including just the down and draggy febrile cat\n(which could have septicemic plague), but particularly the cat with fever\nand a bubo.\nIt's been decades since we've had person-to-person spread of\nprimary pneumonic plague in the U.S. Thus these days a person's primary\nrisk factor for developing primary pneumonic plague is from an undiagnosed\ncat, whose symptoms have progressed far enough that it's pneumonic. This\nrarely happens any more with people, who usually get hospitalized before\nthey develop plague pneumonia. The case count of people developing\npneumonic plague from cats, or from handling cats with draining plague\nabscesses or buboes, keeps increasing, because of a lack of early diagnosis\nof plague-infected cats.\nPeople also can catch plague directly from their\nclinically ill plague-infected dogs, which few people are aware of.\nFortunately, most dogs infected with plague develop subclinical infections,\nbut some clinical illnesses with the capability of being transmitted to\npeople have occurred .\nI think these particular aspects too often are overlooked.\n--\nMillicent Eidson, MA, DVM, Dipl. ACVPM\nState Public Health Veterinarian\nDirector, Zoonoses Program, NYSDOH\nAssociate Professor, SUNY School of Public Health\n621 Corning Tower, ESP, Albany NY 12237\nTEL: 518-474-3186\nFAX: 473-6590\nE-MAIL: mxe04@health.state.ny.us\n[This is an interesting discussion of a very practical matter and we\nappreciate Dr. Eidson's taking time to send her thoughts and data to us. A\nplague expert, to whom I am grateful, at CDC/Ft. Collins suggested to me\nthat flea control is recommended primarily to reduce the risk that hunting\ncats will bring infectious fleas into their owners' homes, rather than as a\nmeans to keep cats from getting plague. As Dr. Eidson points out, most\ncats appear to acquire plague through ingesting infected rodents (these\nconclusions come largely from studies she published in the Am J Vet Med).\nNevertheless, cats that explore rodent burrows, or kill and eat\nflea-infested rodents, could serve as temporary hosts for these\nectoparasites and bring them into human habitations, etc., where they could\njump off and bite people - Mod CHC]\n.....................................................chc/jw\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "summary": "Nevertheless, cats that explore rodent burrows, or kill and eat\nflea-infested rodents, could serve as temporary hosts for these\nectoparasites and bring them into human habitations, etc., where they could\njump off and bite people - Mod CHC]\n.....................................................chc/jw\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n In some unpublished\nresearch we did, having seen fleas on your cat or lack of use of flea\ncontrol did not increase the probability of a cat getting plague, in\ncomparison to other cats in the household and neighborhood that did not\ncome down with the disease. The case count of people developing\npneumonic plague from cats, or from handling cats with draining plague\nabscesses or buboes, keeps increasing, because of a lack of early diagnosis\nof plague-infected cats. Collins suggested to me\nthat flea control is recommended primarily to reduce the risk that hunting\ncats will bring infectious fleas into their owners' homes, rather than as a\nmeans to keep cats from getting plague. Of course, we can't be sure whether the\ncats are becoming infected by direct inoculation of the organism in the\ninfected rodents into the mouth, or by infected fleas from the rodents\nbiting the cat in the face while the cat is eating them. The recent postings about\nplague on ProMED-mail didn't address really well the issue of cats, plague,\nand\nrisk of transmission to humans. As the former State Public Health\nVeterinarian in New Mexico, and author of several papers on cats, plague,\nand transmission to people, I was able to gain a lot of experience in this\narea. prompt veterinary\ndiagnosis of any illness, including just the down and draggy febrile cat\n(which could have septicemic plague), but particularly the cat with fever\nand a bubo. Lesions inside\nthe mouth and tongue, including abscesses, were also reported, perhaps\nsupporting the direct inoculation rather than flea bites to the face.\n Thus, although flea control is important and should be recommended, in\nregards to reducing cats getting plague, preventing hunting behavior is\nmore important, and of course, can be difficult to do with outdoor cats. In addition, the type of fleas that spread plague in the\nwestern U.S. are rodent fleas, not cat fleas, and as such don't spend a\nwhole lot of time on cats compared to rodents. People also can catch plague directly from their\nclinically ill plague-infected dogs, which few people are aware of.\n As Dr. Eidson points out, most\ncats appear to acquire plague through ingesting infected rodents (these\nconclusions come largely from studies she published in the Am J Vet Med). Thus these days a person's primary\nrisk factor for developing primary pneumonic plague is from an undiagnosed\ncat, whose symptoms have progressed far enough that it's pneumonic. This fits with the predominant symptom in cat\nplague cases of submandibular lymphadenopathy (with those lymph nodes\ndraining the mouth/head area). Fortunately, most dogs infected with plague develop subclinical infections,\nbut some clinical illnesses with the capability of being transmitted to\npeople have occurred . I\nbelieve the educational materials on plague need to emphasize the\nimportance, if you have an outdoor hunting cat, of PLAGUE, CATS & DOGS TO HUMANS\n*******************************\n Evidence in the infected cats of a flea bite,\nsuch as an abscess on the leg or back, or bubo in those areas, was\nrelatively rare.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "New Mexico", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2195848", "headline": "PRO/AH> Plague, human - USA (COLORADO, NEW MEXICO) (02)\n **\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "2193930", "headline": "PRO> Plague facts", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2193930", "date": "1998-08-05 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE FACTS\n************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>\nDate: Wed, 5 Aug 1998 12:17:47 GMT-3\nSource: News media\nFrom: ProMED-mail\n\nPlague Facts by Deborah Baker\n-----------------------------\nWhat it is:\n* A bacterial disease of rodents generally transmitted through flea bites.\n* May be transmitted by direct contact with infected rodents, wildlife,\npets or people.\n* Most people become ill two to seven days after infection.\n* Symptoms may include fever, chills, swollen lymph nodes in groin, [called\n'buboes,' hence the name 'bubonic plague' - Mod.JW] armpit or neck,\nheadache, muscle pain, vomiting, nausea, diarrhea.\n* Can be cured by prompt treatment with appropriate antibiotics.\n* Can be fatal.\nWays to reduce the risk:\n-----------------------------\n* Avoid sick or dead animals.\n* Teach children to avoid dead animals and rodent nests or burrows.\n* Don't use tents or sleeping bags near rodent nests or burrows.\n* Use insect repellent on skin and clothes.\n* Don't allow cats and dogs to roam free.\n* Treat cats and dogs with a product that kills fleas on contact.\n* Have sick outdoor pets examined promptly by a veterinarian.\n* Hunters, trappers should wear gloves when handling dead animals.\n--\nProMED-mail\ne-mail: promed@usa.healthnet.org\n........................................jw/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. This book is dedicated to these scientists\nand to ProMED-mail. ProMED-mail may be our best hope should fact follow\nfiction.'\nThe authors are generously donating a portion of their book advance to\nProMED-mail.\nJohn Marr will be autographing copies of the book at a booth at the\nInternational Conference on Emerging Infectious Diseases in Atlanta next\nmonth.\n'The eleventh Plague' is published by Harper Collins, New York. I suggest Joe Pesci\nfor the Jack Woodall (Jack Bryne) role.\nDo not send purchase orders or requests for copies of this book to either\nProMED-mail or to me. Pitchers and catchers have reported for spring\ntraining and I have far too much to do to answer such requests. Besides, I\nam trying to find out what 'sui generis' means; I thought it was some sort\nof pig.\n--\nCharles H. These deaths are among the five cases reported by the Centers\nfor Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) in 1996.\nAn 18-year-old man from Flagstaff, Arizona was bitten by fleas while walking\nthrough a colony of prairie dogs in the northeast part of the state.\nThe same month, a 16-year-old Colorado girl contracted the plague. It is\nreported that she lived near an area where many prairie dogs had died. The\nCDC believes she got the plague from her cat, who became infected from the\nprairie dogs. Cats can get infected from fleas or rodents and pass it on\nwhen they bite, scratch or lick humans.\nHuman plague can be treated with antibiotics if treatment is begun early\nenough. There have been 390 of human plague in the United States since\n1947, resulting in 60 deaths. Most of the cases are from Arizona,\nCalifornia, Colorado and New Mexico.\n.....................................................mc/jw\n\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. That is, to view an American\nor Canadian programme taped directly to videotape, I think one will need a TV\nmade for that market. I don't remember if that is also true of the videotape\nmachine. I believe that it is possible to convert between formats, but that\nthis in essence requires making a new tape. Subscribers outside the US or\nCanada may wish to verify this before purchasing videotapes intended for sale\nhere. Perhaps someone with more technical expertise can clarify, as my\nexperience is somewhat dated.\n---\nJohn Gawoski, M.D.\nDepartment of Laboratory Medicine\nLahey Hitchcock Clinic\n41 Mall Road\nBurlington, MA 01805 USA\n617.273.8935\ne-mail: <jgawoski@warren.med.harvard.edu>\n[Absolutely correct. -- Mod CHC]\n................................\n[4]\nDate: Wed, 23 Apr 1997 02:35:25 +1000\nFrom: Ken and Meryl dorey <van@mypostbox.com>\nGood idea! For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["8240-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Canton", "country": "Switzerland"}, {"location": "Ohio", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2190632", "headline": "PRO/AH> The Coming Plague: TV documentary, brief reviews", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2190632", "date": "1997-04-22 23:50:00", "main_text": "THE COMING PLAGUE: TV DOCUMENTARY, BRIEF REVIEWS\n================================================\n[1]\nDate: Mon, 21 Apr 1997 16:13:30 -0400\nFrom: rbl@hal.EPBI.CWRU.Edu (Robin B. Lake)\n\nAll-in-all, the program was excellent.\nShortcomings: overdramatization\nof the risks and the exposures of the field investigators. Not to\ndenigrate this in the least -- it's just TV's way of keeping you on\nthe channel. Also, there were a rather select group of expert participants.\nAlso, no mention of the technology (ie. this mailing list) that helps\nprovide support for emerging diseases.\nStrengths: Showing the horrible medical conditions in many (African)\nregions. The pitiful facilities, lack of clean water, drugs, and\ntransportation. Also a very insightful presentation of the cultural\nrole of sex workers in Africa and India -- and the very difficult\ntask of changing these cultural norms.\nWished they would have: Shown more detail of the laboratory work\nrequired to support viral identification. Also a more graphic\nvisualization of the impact of these diseases. Even with the numbers\nquoted, it is difficult to visualize in one's mind the severity of\nthe impacts.\nAgain: Solid facts, excellent presentation of the brave persons involved,\nand no casting of US social standards into the rest of the world.\n--\nRobin Lake\nEnvironmental Modeling Inc.\nrbl@po.cwru.edu\n---------------------------\n[2]\nDate: Mon, 21 Apr 1997 17:09:13 -0400\nFrom: Alexandra Sevilla <alexs@wri.org>\n\nClassically, the movie is not as good as the book....\nThe Coming Plague documentary so far has given viewers glossy and\nsexy profiles of a few of the most eminent doctors/epidemiologists in the\nfield and a noble, but ultimately thin, overview of the AIDS pandemic.\nUnfortunately, the program lacks the pacing of Laurie Garrett's great\nbook. Too often it seems to switch gears from disease to disease, time\nperiod to time period, location to location, without building the case of the\nsociological, political, historical, environmental, and economic factors in\nthe emergence and resurgence of infectious diseases which made\nGarrett's book much more important than a collection of outbreak\nnarratives.\n[I believe that will be covered in Part 2 - Mod.JW]\nIt also is very thin on science in terms of explaining what\nvirus are, how they infect humans, jump species, treatments....\nPositively, it is a fascinating program to those who are not entirely\nfamiliar with the impacts and history of infectious diseases (or the book).\nThe program does do an outstanding job packaging information into\nhighly understandble concepts for people who know nothing of the\nscience and epidemiology of infectious diseases. It would make an\nexcellent introductory education tool and promotes awareness\neffectively.\nI watched the program with several people who are not\nfamiliar with the subject matter at all and each felt it was an excellent\nproduction and really shed light on issues that they were not remotely\naware of.\nI look forward to seeing the next installment.\n--\nAlexandra Sevilla\nWorld Resources Institute\nalexs@wri.org\n-------------------------\n[3]\nFrom: EdRegis@aol.com\nDate: Mon, 21 Apr 1997 21:47:18 -0400 (EDT)\n\nI thought the first two hours were remarkably error-free (other than for\ndating the Kikwit outbreak in 1994), balanced, and objective. Especially\ninstructive was Joe McCormick's comment about hemorrhagic fever viruses such\nas Ebola:\n'These hemorrhagic viruses are scary enough without making them into science\nfiction. Doctors don't need space suits to treat patients or space capsules\nto move them about. Mostly they need compassion and common sense: gloves,\nsurgical masks, barrier nursing, and proper sanitary procedures. Ebola\nwithers in the face of proper hospital procedures. It isn't going to sweep\nthe world killing a billion people. That's just not the way it works.'\n(Joe McCormick, M.D., former chief of the CDC's Special Pathogens Branch,\nnow of the Institut Pasteur.)\n--\nEd Regis, Ph.D.\nCollege Fellow\nWestern Maryland College\nWestminster, Maryland 21157\ne-mail: <edregis@aol.com>\n........................................................jw\n\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "summary": "Too often it seems to switch gears from disease to disease, time\nperiod to time period, location to location, without building the case of the\nsociological, political, historical, environmental, and economic factors in\nthe emergence and resurgence of infectious diseases which made\nGarrett's book much more important than a collection of outbreak\nnarratives. jw\n\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n Especially\ninstructive was Joe McCormick's comment about hemorrhagic fever viruses such\nas Ebola:\n'These hemorrhagic viruses are scary enough without making them into science\nfiction. --\nEd Regis, Ph.D.\nCollege Fellow\nWestern Maryland College\n I watched the program with several people who are not\nfamiliar with the subject matter at all and each felt it was an excellent\nproduction and really shed light on issues that they were not remotely\naware of. Even with the numbers\nquoted, it is difficult to visualize in one's mind the severity of\nthe impacts.\n --\nRobin Lake\nEnvironmental Modeling Inc.\n \nAlexandra Sevilla\nWorld Resources Institute\n The program does do an outstanding job packaging information into\nhighly understandble concepts for people who know nothing of the\nscience and epidemiology of infectious diseases. Also a very insightful presentation of the cultural\nrole of sex workers in Africa and India -- and the very difficult\ntask of changing these cultural norms. The Coming Plague documentary so far has given viewers glossy and\nsexy profiles of a few of the most eminent doctors/epidemiologists in the\nfield and a noble, but ultimately thin, overview of the AIDS pandemic. Again: Solid facts, excellent presentation of the brave persons involved,\nand no casting of US social standards into the rest of the world.\n It also is very thin on science in terms of explaining what\nvirus are, how they infect humans, jump species, treatments....\n this mailing list) that helps\nprovide support for emerging diseases.\n Not to\ndenigrate this in the least -- it's just TV's way of keeping you on\nthe channel. It would make an\nexcellent introductory education tool and promotes awareness\neffectively. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: THE COMING PLAGUE: TV DOCUMENTARY, BRIEF REVIEWS\n================================================\n (Joe McCormick, M.D., former chief of the CDC's Special Pathogens Branch,\nnow of the Institut Pasteur.)\n Positively, it is a fascinating program to those who are not entirely\nfamiliar with the impacts and history of infectious diseases (or the book). Newton, Ph.D.' <Nolan_Newton@deh.ehnr.state.nc.us>\n\nCDC has posted a notice at http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/tbsplague.htm\nregarding the April 20 and April 27 showings of parts 1 and 2 of a\nTBS special based on 'The Coming Plague'.\n[The CDC notice runs as follows - Mod.JW]\n\nOverview of 'The Coming Plague'\nTurner Broadcasting Superstation has put two years of work into a 4 hour\ndocumentary based on the research from Laurie Garrett's book of the same name.\n***Part 1 (two hours long) will show Sunday, April 20, 1997 at 9pm (ET). It\nwill show again Monday, April 21 at 12:05 am (ET).\n***Part II (also two hours long) will show Sunday, April 27 at 9pm (ET).\nPart II will show again Monday, April 28 at 12:05 am (ET).\nHour one: 'Virus Hunters' follows disease cowboys around the world in an\neffort to solve epidemic mysteries and discover ways to prevent future\noutbreaks.\nHour two: 'The Price of Passion' focus on the AIDS epidemic and its global\nimplications.\nHour three: 'Revenge of the Microbes' documents the pathogens' ability to\nfight back against our technology.\nHour four: 'A World Out of Balance' details how many aspects of 'modern'\nlife must change if we are to avoid -- the coming plague.\n.............................................................jw\n\n--\nJack Woodall, Ph.D., Director, FAS ProMED-mail\nNew York State Dept.of Health, Albany NY, USA\ne-mail: woodall@wadsworth.org\nhttp://www.fas.org/promed/\nhttp://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html\nhttp://www.outbreak.org/cgi-outbreak-unreg/credits.html#jack\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. It\nmust, they said, be remembered that the total economic loss to\nIndia due to the plague epidemic in 1994 was of the order of\n$1.7 billion.\nIn all, over 45,000 travellers to India had cancelled their\ntravel plans, leading to 20 to 60 per cent decrease in hotel\noccupancy. While Air India lost $66,000 per day, Indian Airlines\nlost $1 million every week. There was also a 50 per cent\ndecrease in ships docking at Mumbai. The country lost $460\nmillion in exports, of which $23 million was in diamond\nexports alone, they observed.\n[Although diamonds have been responsible for the death of many people during\nrecorded history, they have never been proved to carry plague - Mod.JW]\nThe officials particularly emphasised the importance of\ndeveloping effective mechanisms to ensure prevention and control\nof epidemics, through better disease surveillance systems and by\nmeasures to provide for quick response in case of outbreaks.\n....................................................jw/mhj\n\n\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Amazon region.\nToxin on spines is fibrinolytic, and leads to burning sensation,\nheadache and generalised discomfort. Ecchymoses appear within 8-72\nhr and spread to the rest of the body. Melendy' <amm@vetmed.wsu.edu>\nOrganization: WSU College of Veterinary Medicine\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1996-01-11 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "BRAZIL", "country": "Brazil"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2190297", "headline": "PRO/AH> Plague in wildlife, 1997 - USA (Colorado, Nevada)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2190297", "date": "1997-03-06 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE IN WILDLIFE, 1997 - USA (COLORADO, NEVADA)\n=================================================\nDate: Thurs, Mar 6, 1997\nFrom: Russell E. Enscore <rce0@cidvbi1.em.cdc.gov>\nCenters for Disease Control, National Center for Infectious Diseases,\nDivision of Vector-Borne Infectious Diseases, Bacterial Zoonosis Branch,\nPlague Section, Fort Collins, Colorado, TEL: (970) 221-6452\nVia: VECTOR list\n[Below are listed] the first positive plague surveillance samples for 1997.\nSerological analyses were performed at CDC and fluorescent antibody assay on\nthe fox squirrel [_Sciurus niger_] from Manitou Springs [near Colorado\nSprings, central Colorado] was performed at the Colorado Department of Health.\nFox squirrel (FA positive) - Manitou Springs - collected 1/10/97\n(Note: This squirrel was infected during an epizootic that began in Fall 1996\nin western Colorado Springs and nearby Manitou Springs. During Fall 1996, a\ntotal of 25 fox squirrels were found to be plague-positive in these areas.\nEl Paso County [Colorado Springs] Health Department officials placed\ninsecticidal bait tubes in affected areas and conducted an educational\ncampaign among residents. Special plague surveillance activities, including\na canine serosurveillance program, are still being conducted to assess the\nextent of the epizootic and the likelihood that it will continue during\nSpring 1997.)\nA total of 54 sero-surveillance samples were recently submitted to CDC for\nanalysis by Daniel J. Maxson, R.S., Senior Environmental Health Specialist,\nClark County Health District, Nevada. These samples were collected from four\ncounties in southeast Nevada (Clark, Lincoln, Nye and White Pine). Listed\nbelow are only those samples that tested POSITIVE for antibodies to the F-1\nantigen of _Yersinia pestis_ [the etiologic agent of plague]. All samples\nwere collected between 11/22/96 and 2/4/97. None of the 23 samples submitted\nfrom Clark County (Las Vegas is located in this county) were positive. The\nhigh percentage of positives from the other three counties suggest that a\nwidespread epizootic is occurring in the other three lightly populated\ncounties north and northwest of Las Vegas, NV (Titers greater than 10 are\nconsidered positive in passive hemagglutination assays.)\nCounty Species Titer\n====== ======= =====\nLincoln _Canis latrans_ (2) 128\nLincoln _Urocyon cinereoargenteus_ (2) 512\nLincoln _Felis rufus_ 32\nNye _Felis rufus_ 64\nNye _Canis latrans_ 64\nNye _Urocyon cinereoargenteus_ (2) 128\nNye _Urocyon cinereoargenteus_ 256\nNye _Urocyon cinereoargenteus_ 512\nWhite Pine _Canis latrans_ 64\nWhite Pine _Canis latrans_ 256\nWhite Pine _Canis latrans_ 1024\n---\nProMED-mail\n<promed@usa.healthnet.org>\n[Note: _Canis latrans_ = coyote, _Urocyon cinereoargenteus_ = gray fox,\n_Felis rufus_ = bobcat. -- Mod CHC]\n............................................................................\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1997-03-06 00:00:00", "1024-03-25 00:00:00", "1997-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Manitou Springs", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Fort Collins", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "R.S.", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Clark County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "El Paso County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Colorado Springs", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Las Vegas", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Nevada", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "NEVADA", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Clark", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Clark County Health District", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2187692", "headline": "PROMED-AHEAD: Caterpillar plague - Brazil", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2187692", "date": "1996-01-10 23:50:00", "main_text": "Date: Fri, 5 Jan 1996 14:13:20 -0500 (EST)\nFrom: 'David W. Swim' <dwswim@cais.com>\nvia: Brasil Net <bras-net@psg.com>\nCATERPILLAR PLAGUE - BRAZIL\n===========================\nSubject: 'Killer caterpillars return to southern Brazil'\nSAO PAULO, Jan 5 (ex Reuter) - Apparently, caterpillars are spreading\nfear in southern Brazil, where 20 people have been taken to hospital\nrecently after touching them, authorities said on Friday.\nThe caterpillars, which secrete a potent venom through their skin,\nhave killed nine people over the past two years, Celso Bernardon,\na public health official, informed Reuters. A public awareness\nprogramme has been initiated in Santa Catarina.\nContact with the venom causes a burning sensation and spotting on the\nskin. If left untreated, it can lead to high fever, bleeding from the\nnose and ears, kidney failure and death, said Luis Dalla Costa, a doctor\nin the Santa Catarina city of Chapeco. Since December, 20 people have\nbeen treated in hospital after contact with the caterpillars, Costa said.\nIn most cases, unsuspecting victims grab a tree trunk or another\nobject where the caterpillar rests. But authorities are concerned that\nchildren, attracted by the greenish worm-like creature, might become\ncurious and want to feel it. It grows to a length of two inches (5 cms).\nIt is appears every year from December to March. The pupal and adult\nforms are harmless.\nOnce just a rural phenomenon, the caterpillars this year are migrating\ninto urban centres, turning up on porches and in the fruit trees of\nsuburban gardens. This apparent increase is being blamed on the excessive\nuse of toxic fertiliser killing the caterpillars' normal predators.\nDavid W. SWIM\n<dwswim@cais.com>\nWestgate - McLean - Fairfax - Virginia - United States of America\nhttp://members.aol.com/dwswim/index.html\n---------------------------------------------------------------------\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. From: 'David W. Swim' <dwswim@cais.com>\nvia: Brasil Net <bras-net@psg.com>\nCATERPILLAR PLAGUE - BRAZIL\n===========================\n Apparently, caterpillars are spreading\nfear in southern Brazil, where 20 people have been taken to hospital\nrecently after touching them, authorities said on Friday. The caterpillars, which secrete a potent venom through their skin,\nhave killed nine people over the past two years, Celso Bernardon,\na public health official, informed Reuters. Once just a rural phenomenon, the caterpillars this year are migrating\ninto urban centres, turning up on porches and in the fruit trees of\nsuburban gardens. This apparent increase is being blamed on the excessive\nuse of toxic fertiliser killing the caterpillars' normal predators.\n If left untreated, it can lead to high fever, bleeding from the\nnose and ears, kidney failure and death, said Luis Dalla Costa, a doctor\nin the Santa Catarina city of Chapeco. But authorities are concerned that\nchildren, attracted by the greenish worm-like creature, might become\ncurious and want to feel it. SWIM\n<dwswim@cais.com>\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1996-01-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-12-25 00:00:00", "2021-01-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Brazil", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "Santa Catarina", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "Fairfax", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2188698", "headline": "PROMED-AHEAD: Plague: current world situation", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2188698", "date": "1996-06-08 23:50:00", "main_text": "PLAGUE: CURRENT WORLD SITUATION\n================================\nDate: Tue, 4 Jun 1996 09:36:58 -0400\nFrom: Eodrdton@aol.com\n\nSource: World Health Organization's World Health Report, 1996, p.52-53.\n-------\nPlague is often regarded as a scourge of medieval times, from which the\nworld is now largely free. But the latest evidence suggests that incidence\nof the disease is on the increase...... cases occur in areas that had\napparently been free from the disease for many decades.\n\nSource: Control of Communicable Diseases Manual, 16th ed.,\nAmerican Public Health Association, 1995, pp. 353-354.\n-------\nPlague continues to be a threat because of vast areas of persistent wild\nrodent infection; contact of wild rodents with domestic rats occurs\nfrequently in some enzootic areas.\nWild rodent plague exists in the western half of the USA; large areas of\nSouth America; north-central, eastern and southern Africa; central and\nSoutheast Asia. There are several natural plague foci within the Russian\nFederation and Kazakhstan.\nWhile urban plague has been controlled in most of the world, human plague\nhas occurred recently in:\nAfrica: (Angola, Botswana, Kenya, Madagascar, Namibia, South Africa,\nMalawi, Mozambique, Tanzania, Uganda, Zimbabwe, Zaire and Libya).\nAsia: Plague is endemic in China, Indonesia, Mongolia, Myanmar (Burma),\nIndia and especially in Vietnam, where thousands of cases of bubonic plague,\nboth urban and rural, with scattered outbreaks of pneumonic plague, were\nreported between 1962 and 1972.\nAmericas: foci in northeastern Brazil and the Andean region (Peru and\nBolivia) continue to produce sporadic cases and occasional outbreaks.\n[- Latterly it has appeared in domestic cats in New Mexico, having\nspilled over from the local ground rodent reservoir. MHJ]\n........................................................................JW\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Asia: Plague is endemic in China, Indonesia, Mongolia, Myanmar (Burma),\nIndia and especially in Vietnam, where thousands of cases of bubonic plague,\nboth urban and rural, with scattered outbreaks of pneumonic plague, were\nreported between 1962 and 1972. While urban plague has been controlled in most of the world, human plague\nhas occurred recently in:\nAfrica: (Angola, Botswana, Kenya, Madagascar, Namibia, South Africa,\nMalawi, Mozambique, Tanzania, Uganda, Zimbabwe, Zaire and Libya). Plague continues to be a threat because of vast areas of persistent wild\nrodent infection; contact of wild rodents with domestic rats occurs\nfrequently in some enzootic areas. Wild rodent plague exists in the western half of the USA; large areas of\nSouth America; north-central, eastern and southern Africa; central and\nSoutheast Asia. But the latest evidence suggests that incidence\nof the disease is on the increase...... cases occur in areas that had\napparently been free from the disease for many decades. Americas: foci in northeastern Brazil and the Andean region (Peru and\nBolivia) continue to produce sporadic cases and occasional outbreaks.\n Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: CURRENT WORLD SITUATION\n================================\n The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail.
